column2: Coleman Clark of Chicago won the national amateur championship conducted by the American Ping-Pong Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16. -- The Princeton freshman baseball team won its first victory of the season here this afternoon by swamping the Rutgers freshmen, 22 -- 2, on Brokaw Field. Keller struck out nine men as the Tiger Cubs bunched their hits and took advantage of their opponent's errors to score a total of seventeen runs in two big innings, the second and sixth.

GENEVA April 17 -- During the coming week the disarmament conference must begin to face definite decisions. It must at least decide the principle on which it must seek the result for which it was convened at the demand of hundreds of millions of taxpayers throughout the world.

Leaders in the construction industry here have estimated at 20,000 to 40,000 the number of men in the building trades who would be employed as the result of early adoption of the new building code, according to opinions gathered by Allen E. Beals of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh spent the seventh Sunday since their 21-month-old baby was stolen from their home near Hopewell, N.J., awaiting word yesterday from the criminals who failed to give him up after receiving the $50,000 ransom they demanded.

Observing his twenty-fifth anniversary as rabbi of the Free Synagogue, which he founded, Dr. Stephen S. Wise yesterday morning pledged to a congregation which filled Carnegie Hall that so long as he continued to occupy the pulpit he would never be remiss in denouncing corruption in public life and would always champion the cause of the poor man.

Three copper companies controlled by the Aanaconda Copper Mining Company reported yesterday a sharp reduction in earnings for 1931. compared with the total for 1930. The companies reporting were the Chile Copper Company, Andes Copper Mining Company and Greene-Cananea Copper Company.

Mayor Walker and Borough President Samuel Levy will lead 2,000 marchers this afternoon in a parade up Alien Street Boulevard, the broad highway that was known only a few months ago as the "Street of Perpetual Shadow." The procession will start from East Broad-way at 3 o'clock and move to East Houston Street.

Fewer palatial homes are being built by wealthy Americans and their waning interest may result in the passing of the personal suburban dwelling and the rise of the "model village" or standardized house, according to the first report of President Hoover's survey of social trends, dealing with the nation's architecture, which was made public yesterday by the American Institute of Architects.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A further slight decline in wholesale prices throughout the United States during March was reported today by the Labor Department. The drop was less than half of 1 per cent as compared with the preceding month's level, but a reduction of 13 per cent in comparison with March, 1931.

Egon Petri's farewell recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon was one of the few remaining ornaments of the waning season. The Dutch pianist, who was concluding his first visit to this country, played a program of substantial music in a manner that was not only proficient and scholarly but actually exciting.

BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP). -- Timely hitting enabled the Orioles to take the opening game of the series from the Montreal Royals, 11 to 5, today. Frank McGowan hit two home runs for the Birds and Jordan one.

BERLIN, April 17 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler filed a libel suit today against Theodor Wolff, publisher and editor of the Berliner Tageblatt, for an article in which it was said that Herr Hitler had told foreign correspondents that France had inspired the government's ban on his storm troops.

The West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., through its managing director, James W. Danahy, repeated yesterday its charge that the city was planning to delay operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway line until there was "reasonable" assurance that unification of all rapid-transit lines could be achieved within the next three years.

A program of concert pieces and solos was given by the Lighthouse Music School for the benefit of the Blind Men's Improvement Club of New York last night in the Ambassador Theatre, donated by Lee and J.J. Shubert for the evening.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Corn traders are moderately bullish, believing that with wheat advancing corn should do better. At the same time there are traders who say that corn should be sold on bulges, and they are following out their ideas by selling and at the same time buying wheat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ambassador Mellon has presented his credentials to the King of England and in the same breath stated that he was not instructed to discuss reparations or war debts. Secretary Stimson is now bound for Geneva to attend the disarmament conference.

The Speyer home's annual pet show went on yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Roosevelt and adjacent rooms. Cats and dogs -- all of them more or less recent orphans -- blandly stared back at official judges, and then hopefully tried to reach each other's throats.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- A warning to Pennsylvania drys that the fate of national prohibition depends considerably on the outcome of the Republican Senatorial contest in the primary election of April 26, has been sounded again by F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, in a letter addressed to clergymen of this State.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- About 300 prohibitionists and a few "wets" today laughed and applauded while Bishop James Cannon Jr. and Canon William Sheafe Chase posed for photographers at an old-time saloon bar in the "Prohibition Fair" sponsored by the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement, a preview of which was given by Mrs. Henry W. Peabody, chairman of the committee.

ALBANY, April 17. -- A dust, smoke and gas nuisance from industrial plants in New Jersey along the Arthur Kill and Kill Van Kull, "which creates a menace to the health and safety of a considerable number of persons on Staten Island," has been reported by the Division of Sanitation of the State Department of Health.

BRITONS never shall be slaves, but ball players shall be chattels. Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis frowns on the program, but Samevil Breadon, the sweet singer of St. Louis, goes blithely ahead adding links to his chain-store system. It's a long chain and there is a suspicion that all the links are not on public view. Some of them may be hidden under ground.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- Philadelphia'a batting power drove three Washington pitchers from the box today, while George Earnshaw struck out twelve batters to defeat the Senators. 11 to 3.

To the temporary chairman of a national convention belong the mystic honors of the keynoter. This functionary may be described as First Big Wind. Whether he is accompanied with thunder and lightning, like Mr. CLAUDE BOWERS, or a drizzle of platitudes, like Mr. SIMEON FESS, he is unintelligible to students of ennui.

MOSCOW. April 17 (AP) -- A telegram from Peiping, published in Russian newspapers today, said that 400 Russian "White Guards" besieged the offices of the Chinese Eastern Railway at Harbin recently, closing the exits and shouting threats against Soviet members of the board of directors.

The strike of longshoremen on coastwise ship line piers, which was called on Friday when the men refused to accept a reduction from 75 to 67 cents an hour and $1.10 to $1 for overtime, continued yesterday with victories claimed for both sides and important developments expected today.

The vision and courage of former Governor Smith in proposing his debt modification plan was praised by the Rev. Harold Purcell, Catholic editor, in an address yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Fire Department Holy Name Society at the Hotel Astor.

Members of the League or New York Theatres and other representatives of the legitimate stage will appear before the Senate Finance Committee in Washington today to protest against the 10 per cent admission tax proposal in the Federal tax bill.

With plans for public hearings on the activities of Mayor Walker mapped out at a week-end conference in Easthampton, L.I., Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, returned to New York yesterday prepared to order the subpoenaing of witnesses.

Blaming the indifference of the public for the existence and dissemination of "obscene, indecent and lascivious magazines," the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin delivered a sermon in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, yesterday in which he called for a mobilization of public opinion against what he characterized as "one of the most subtle and indefensible rackets of our day."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 17. -- Letters, diaries and other document of Hessian officers in the American Revolution, probably the most important papers on that war uncovered in recent years, have been acquired by the William L. Clements Library of American History at the University of Michigan.

If George Washington's example had been followed there would be no Eighteenth Amendment today and gambling "would not now be a police problem," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Ninetieth Street and Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday at the annual memorial services of the Sons of the American Revolution held in his church.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 17 (AP) -- Police tonight scanned the multifarious connections of John M. Picco, Italian consular agent, in an effort to uncover a motive for his assassination late yesterday.

New York State will acquire a tract of more than 2,500 acres in the township of Shandaken, Ulster County, that includes a mile of frontage on Esopus Creek, the noted stream in the Catskills, according to plans now being completed by the Conservation Department.

BERLIN, April 17 (AP). -- The fiftieth anniversary of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra was observed today with a gala ceremony during which a gold Goethe medal was presented to Wilhelm Furtwaengler, conductor of the orchestra for a decade, on behalf of President von Hindenburg.

A police car speeding northward in Lexington Avenue at 4:30 A.M. yesterday in answer to a radio alarm was hit by an eastbound sedan at Fifty-ninth Street and hurled against a corner of the Bloomingdale building. One policeman was killed, three were injured, and a woman in the sedan was badly hurt.

HAVANA. April 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Adelaide Lamar, an American described only as "a resident of Indiana." died today in Calixto Garcia Hospital of burns suffered last night, when an incubator toppled over on her at her home in Reparto Batista, near Havana. She was found by neighbors with her clothing aflame.

PITTSBURGH, April 17. -- Demand for steel has not decreased in the last two weeks, but it has shown no increase. Demand from the automobile industry has been rising for three or four weeks, but in so small a way that its influence on steel demand, taken as a whole, has not been noticeable.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 17 -- One youth was fatally injured and an unknown number of other persons were less seriously hurt in a riot in the new Capitol early this morning over the adoption of a flag for Porto Rico bearing the single star of independence.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Wheat prices have advanced 8 3/8 cents in two weeks, with sentiment bullish, based on sensational crop damage reports from the Winter wheat section of the Southwest. Buying sentiment has increased of late, but around the top prices, 62 cents for May and 64 7/8 cents for July, there was profit taking and a sharp reaction.

The reliable and hard-working Will Mahoney is at the Palace this week, making those frantic and for the most part unsuccessful efforts to maintain his equilibrium as he careens wildly across the stage, dancing on the xylophone (an original routine, which he invented) and, in general, disporting himself as he has done on previous occasions at the First Music Hall and more recently in the "Vanities."

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The declaration of Secretary Hyde yesterday in favor of resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment has convinced some drys, as well as the wet leaders, that the Republican party is likely to swing away from its 1928 position and adopt a platform acceptable to the "conservative wets."

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 27. -- In an exhibition soccer match on the Port Chester baseball grounds today the Newark City Football Club defeated the Port Chester Football Club, 5 to 1. Mclntyre netted two goals.
MOSCOW, April 17 -- A big Spring Cleaning is under way in Soviet industry, the purpose being to "shorten the period of infantile maladies," as the Bolsheviki call them, of the new ''giant" factories.

BOSTON, April 17. -- With his Olympic hopes blazing more brightly than they did twenty years ago when he first wore the American shield at Stockholm, Clarence DeMar, the peerless marathoner, today quit his Keene, N.H., home and headed for Hopkington, starting point of the j Boston A.A. thirty-sixth annual marathon race on Tuesday.

The elernffntary school alone may to longer be designated properly as the "common school" in New York City, since virtually the entire growth in the total number of pupils during the past few years is due to increases in the higher grades, according to the annual report of Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, excerpts of which are made public today.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP). -- After trailing on the short end of a 3-1 count from the fourth inning, the Pittsburgh Pirates rallied in the ninth inning to drive in three runs and defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 4 to 3, today.
PARIS, April 17 -- Without entering into particulars. Premier Andre Tardieu in a campaign speech today adopted a much more conciliatory tone when speaking of reparations questions.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 17 (AP). -- The doubles team of E. Hall and B. Peters. Springfield, Ill., totaled 1,280 to create the only upset of the day as the Elks' national bowling tournament came to an end today. The total brought the Illinois team first place.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 17 -- The news of the occupation of Pogranichnaya by General Wan Fulin's insurgent army has had a decidedly disquieting effect in inner circles at Mukden. It is noted that General Wan Fu-lin, in holding a large city on the Manchurian border at the eastern terminus of the Chinese Eastern Railway, would be in an excellent position to receive arms, munitions and supplies from Siberia.

LONDON, April 15 -- The London market is still in marked degree under the influence of what is described here as the "calamity complex." This state of mind continues to drive into British Government issues or other equally safe securities any capital which is available for immediate investment.

The pamphlet report of the Philadelphia Company and subsidiaries for 1931 shows net income of $14,278,285 after taxes, charges and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $2.20 a share on 4,801,028 common shares and scrip outstanding, compared with $15.330,103, or $2.55 a share on the same number of shares in 1930.

HONOLULU, April 17 (AP) -- Prosecutor John C. Kelley declared today that Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie did not shoot Joseph Kahahawai, whose killing he confessed on the witness stand yesterday, and characterized the defense plea of insanity as "the bunk."

PEIPING, April 17 (AP) -- The visit of the League of Nations commission of inquiry to Mancuhria would be delayed, it was understood today, until the new State of Manchoukuo made its attitude clear on the presence there of Dr. Wellington Koo, the commission's Chinese assessor.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 17 -- The ruins of a large and ancient city, similar in style to those of Tiahuanaco, have been found fifty miles from Tarija near the Argentine border in Southeastern Bolivia, according to private reports received here today.

TOKYO, Monday, April 18 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today reports from the Japanese Consulate General at Harbin, Manchuria, Indicated that the wreck of a Japanese troop train near there last Tuesday was the "work of Russian Communists," although positive proof was lacking.

LONDON, April 17 -- Professor John Garstang's theory that the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt took place in 1447 B.C. has received confirmation, according to Sir Charles Marston, from Professor Percy A. Newberry and also is supported by the fact that it clarifies the significance of other archaeological discoveries that are not fully understood and explains several problems of the Old Testament narrative.

ABOARD GOVERNOR ROOSEVELT'S TRAIN IN WISCONSIN, April 17 -- Speeding into the Northwest for an address to St. Paul Democrats tomorrow night. Governor Roosevelt is preparing tonight to renew his insistence on increased consideration for the "forgotten man" in economic rehabilitation plans.

While evangelistic services were being conducted last night in the Glad Tidings Tabernacle, a revival church at 327 West Thirty-third Street, opposite the General Postoffice, two hold-up men, one armed with a pistol, who previously had posed as members of the congregation, bound and gagged a trustee in the basement below.

The private schools known as "progressive" and "experimental," which are undertaking the education of children of the well-to-do in increasing numbers, were praised by Waldo Prank and denounced by McAlister Coleman, two writers who were invited to discuss what such schools have to offer, during the Sunday radio forum hour broadcast yesterday at 3 P.M. from Station WOR.

A $500,000,000 slum clearance investment securities issue, privately floated for popular subscription on the part of the general investing public, was proposed yesterday by Dwight L. Hoopingarner, executive head of the American Construction Council, as a means of providing low-priced housing and at the same time serve as a spur to business recovery.
The New York Americans won an intercity soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday, defeating Philadelphia by 4 to 2 before a crowd of about 1,000.

DUBLIN, April 17 -- President Eamon de Valera of the Free State Council has had a troubled week-end. His decision to abolish the oath of allegiance to the Crown has antagonized big employers of labor, who are threatening to close part of their works, and his position is further complicated by the extremists in the Sinn Fein movement.

Andre Citroen, the noted French automobile manufacturer, believes that the chief obstacle which confronts the American business man today "is the fact that he is not trained to fight against difficulties of all sorts," he said in a talk broadcast from Paris yesterday and heard in the United States over a National Broadcasting Company network.

COLBY, Kan., Monday, April 18 (AP) -- A telephone message was received here from Saint Francis that the men who took Richard Read from the jail were believed to he from Selden, the home town of both the slayer and his victim, Dorothy Hunter.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- When "moderate leaders" obtain control in Japan and China a compromise solution of the Manchurian question may be possible looking to cooperative development of the Chinese and Japanese railway systems in that area, the Foreign Policy Association said today in a special report prepared by T.A. Bisson.

The proposed government tax on Wall Street stock transfers was critcized as being entirely un-American in spirit yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood in his sermon at the St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

SAINT FRANCIS, Kan., Monday, April 18 (AP) -- Sheriff A.A. Bacon of Cheyenne County announced early today that he had been notified by telephone that Richard Read, confessed slayer, had been hanged by a mob southwest of Atwood.

Radio listeners hearing a new tune "plugged" for a month or two by the advertisers of a dozen different products probably never give the composer of the persistent ditty a thought. It may occur to some of them that he must be making a lot of money from the oft-repeated melody.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., April 17 (AP). -- Frank L. Spangler, 32, a magazine salesman of Fifty-seventh Street and Eighth Avenue, New York City, died in a hospital here tonight from a fractured skull suffered in the collision of his automobile with a truck.

HONOLULU, April 17 -- When the Fortescue-Massie trial for the killing of Joseph Kahahawai opens again tomorrow, Prosecutor John C. Kelley will resume his cross-examination of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and probably will keep him on the stand most of the day.

BERLIN, April 15 -- The ordinary budget of the Reich, covering the eleven completed months of the financial year, show a deficit of 96,000,000 marks in the ordinary budget and of 127,000,000 in the extraordinary budget. If deficits acquired from the preceding years are included, the total deficiency is 1,130,00,000.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The British Ambassador and Lady Lindsay were the ranking guests at a luncheon given today in honor of the British High Commissioner for Canada and Lady Ciark by William Duncan Herridge. Minister of Canada, who entertained at the Canadian Legation in Massachusetts Avenue.

Twenty-seven gunners went to the firing line at Travers Island yesterday for the final regular shoot of the season for the New York Athletic Club, C.J. Winninger winning the High Scratch Cup with 96 out of 100 targets. The High Handicap Cup went to G.N. Hersey, who had a card of 87, 5-92.

A survey among 3,442 privately supported institutions and agencies for neglected children and homes for dependent aged throughout the United States, conducted by the Golden Rule Foundation, 60 East Forty-second Street, discloses financial difficulties so serious as to constitute an "alarming situation," according to preliminary reports made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP). -- Willie Kamm and George Connally, both former White Sox players, returned to Comiskey Park today to help defeat Chicago by a score of 6 to 1. It was the first victory of the series for Cleveland, and the triumph was almost entirely due to the feats of these two ex-Sox.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, speaking last night at a forum meeting in the Theresa Kaufman Auditorium at the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at Ninety-second Street, declared it was the duty of all good citizens to take an active Interest in governmental affairs and in politics.

MONTE CARLO, April 17 -- The Italian racing driver Nuvolari set a new record for a Grand Prix automobile when he accomplished that break-neck race of 318 kilometers (199 miles) through the narrow streets of Monte Carlo and Monaco in 3 hours 32 minutes and 25 1-5 seconds.

Eino Pentti, unattached, remained undefeated in the series of six runs being conducted by the long-distance running committeee of the Metropolitan Association, A.A.U., by winning the second run, a 10,000-meter race around Central Park, yesterday. The event started and finished at the Paulist A.C., 30 West Sixtieth Street.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Prospects are for fewer finished cattle in the near future as supplies of feed in cornbelt States have been greatly reduced. Prospects of lighter supplies, however, have not affected the market, for although choice to fancy steers have sold at $4.75 to $8.25. the trade was not at all brisk.

HANKOW, China, April 17 -- Chinese reports slowly trickling in from the northeastern part of Hupeh Province today said that an earthquake April 6 took a terrible toll, "several tens of thousands of persons perishing."
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Wray Cleveland and Miss Marjorie Cleveland have returned to 995 Fifth Avenue from Hot Springs, Va.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An innovation in platform making will be attempted at Chicago by the Democrats. Jouett Shouse, chairman of the committee on arrangements for the convention, today requested members of the National Committee to designate their selections for the resolutions committee so that they may attend a meeting in Chicago on June 23, four days in advance of the convention.

Members of the Merchants Association of New York have voted 2,372 to 40 in favor of some form of modification of the prohibition law, in a referendum just completed, according to an announcement yesterday by the association's board of directors.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America announced yesterday the personnel of its newly created committee on worship, the purpose of which is "the securing of a deeper awareness of the presence of God in public worship."

BOSTON, April 17. -- A snow flurry this morning prevented the scheduled baseball game between the Yankees and the Boston. Red Sox and, with the continuance of frigid weather, Babe Ruth went on the sick list, remaining in bed in his hotel room all day because of a heavy cold in his throat and chest.

Light Rates Unchanged. The decision of the Public Service Commission not to take any steps to reduce the electric light rates charged by the New York Edison system until the expiration of a "fair trial period" supports the orderly processes of regulation.

Reporting for 1931, the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries show net earnings of $63.106.000 after operating expenses, maintenance and taxes, compared with $84.862,000 in 1930 and $69,734,000 in 1929. Chaotic conditions in the oil industry were almost entirely responsible for the decrease. it is stated.

A call for immediate action by the city to provide additional funds for the unemployment relief work of official and private agencies, whose resources are nearly used up, was made yesterday by the Welfare Council's coordinating committee, representing 1,200 relief agencies and official organizations, in a letter to Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- Investigation of the feasibility of establishing a free port on the Delaware River is recommended by the Regional Planning Federation of the Philadelphia Tri-State District in its studies of projects designed to improve port and rail facilities in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The international cartel has failed as a stabilizing factor in the present crisis and its influence remains insignificant, according to a study of cartel developments during 1931 by Louis Domeratsky, chief of the Division of Regional Information of the Commerce Department.

At his farewell concert which took place yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, Sir Thomas Beecham conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra in a program consisting of Mendelssohn's "Fingal's Cave" overture, Saint-Saens third concerto in B minor for violin, Delius's "Summer Night on the River," the prelude to "Die Meistersinger," and Brahms' second symphony-a full symphonic dinner of admirably chosen courses.

ST. PAUL, April 17. -- Blaring bands. marching soldiers and waving flags will greet Governor Roosevelt when he arrives here Monday to speak at the largest dinner gathering planned in the history of the Northwest.

After having scored ten consecutive victories each in the annual inter-club competition of the Metropolitan Chess League, the Marshall and Manhattan Chess Club teams met yesterday in the eleventh and final round for the championship at the new clubiiouse of the former.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17. -- Chances of the Far West providing the winner of the 1932 Kentucky Derby have been increasing daily as Liberty Limited improves in training at Churchill Downs. "The Limited" is considered the most advanced of any of the Derby eligibles engaging in workouts at the track.

RICHMOND, Va., April 17 (AP). -- Police tonight arrested three men on bribery charges growing out of an alleged attempt to bribe a private detective investigating the theft of $20.000 in Federal Reserve notes from a Philadelphia bank.

MEXICO CITY, April 17. -- In discovering the famous treasure tomb of Monte Alban, Mexican archaeologists may have come upon the burial place of "the Fallen Eagle," regarded by the Indians as the last of the Aztec Kings. This is the suggestion brought to the attention of archaeologists by Mrs. Zelia Nuttall, American archaeologist who resides here.
The schedules for Spring sports teams at the Clioate School, Wallingford, Conn., have been announced by Rowland C. Massie, athletic director at the school.
Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the dance recital tonight by Mary Wigman at Carnegie Hall in aid of the Child Study Association of America.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 17. -- With Mayor Walker among the gallery of hardy fans who turned out in heavy robes and blankets, William Tilden, world's professional champion, defeated Hans Nusslein of Germany, professional champion of Europe, at Briarcliff Lodge today, to open the outdoor tennis season in the metropolitan area.

CHALKHILL, one learns from a life of WALTON, "is no other than our old piscatory friend incognito." How full of pleasure the fisher's life is depends sometimes on the weather. The opening day for trout in Massachusetts, Connecticut and New Jersey on Friday was chilly.

The grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria was packed last night at a benefit performance held to equip Irvington House, a convalescent home for cardiac children being erected at Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. The building will replace the former home, which was destroyed by a fire in 1930.

Details of the plan for meeting on June 1 bank loans and a $20,727,750 bond maturity of the St. Louis South-eastern Railway (Cotton elt) are announced in a letter to holders of the bonds by Daniel Upthegrove, president. Mr. Upthegrove said that one bank holding the notes has agreed to the plan and that the prompt acceptance of the other bank was confidently expected.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 17 -- Search in Mexico for swordtails and platyfish, with cancerous growth has been successful, according to word received here from Dr. Myron Gordon, Cornell University scientist in charge of an expedition there.

Admiral MAHAN made the world familiar with the danger in naval warfare of "a fleet in being." The enemy never knew where or when it would strike. Even superior strength might be surprised and defeated by a sudden raid. The theory is also true in politics.
READING, Pa., April 17 (AP). -- Ray Schalk's Buffalo Bisons took the opening game of the series with Reading on a wind-swept field today, 9 to 4.

Congratulatory messages were received yesterday from President Hoover, the Pope, Premier Mussolini, Cardinal Hayes and many other prominent persons by the officials, trustees and staff of the Columbus Hospital, 227 East Nineteenth Street, who celebrated the first anniversary of the new structure with a reception given in the auditorium of the building.

The economic depression as yet had had little effect on mental diseases of institutional severity, according to a survey of mental hospitals conducted by the National Committee for Mental Hygiene at 450 Seventh Avenue, the results of which were made public yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17 -- The cotton contract market was far from active last week, but prices improved moderately. Investment buying was email but trade buying was fair, while price fixing by mills enabled cotton prices to resist depressing outside influences.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 17. -- Nine racing yachts en route to Havana in the third anual international race from St. Petersburg to the Cuban capital, were experiencing difficulty tonight in making progress toward their destination.

Some 5,000 intrepid souls who apparently had sworn a solemn vow on opening day to stick by the Giants until they had won a game, come what may, risked chilblains, pneumonia and frostbite at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but in the end were well rewarded for their rare disney of loyalty and hardihood.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 17 -- Negotiations of a Philadelphia priest and a coroner's physician delivered Hilda Brodsky, 8 years old, from the hands of kidnappers in this city today and restored her to her parents. Mr. and Mrs. Harry Brodsky of Wilmington, Del., fifty-four hours after she had been abducted while walking toward a public school in her home city.

Athletic insignia have been awarded to 115 Columbia athletes and sports managers for participation in Winter sports and cross country, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager. The list includes participants in intercollegiate and interclass contests.

TOKYO, Monday, April 18 -- The situation in North Manchuria is growing worse. General Wang Fu-lin and other disaffected Kirin Generals have taken up headquarters at Pogranichnaya, apparently reckoning on the proximity of Russian territory to shelter them.

WASHINGTON, AprM 17. -- Senator Wagner, by his sponsorship of the labor exchange bill, of Federal aid In unemployment insurance and particularly by his construction bill, has made himself "the keyman on unemployment in the present Congress," according to the People's Lobby, of which Professor John Dewey of Columbia University is president.

It is an old belief that prolonged economic distress will express itself in social unrest. Yet in this third year of a severe depression the chief industrial nations have been scarcely troubled by threats against established institutions. People used to think of "Labor" as an enemy of our economic system.

PARIS, April 15 -- The opinion of this market, in the light of the week's experiences, is that the American talk of French "attacks on the dollar" is not only exaggerated, but amounts to complete misrepresentation. There have been speculative sales, but those on record reached comparatively trifling figures and were not long continued.

Opening the annual appeal of the Catholic Charities, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle urged the worshipers at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to share their means generously with "the needy, who have more to bear this year than in any other period within the memory of the oldest among us."

An invitation that America join in the centenary celebration of the Oxford movement next year was extended by the Rev. Cecil E. Russell, organizing secretary of the Anglo-Catholic Congress in England, guest preacher at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 17. -- Rowing critics will have their first opportunity to weigh Yale's chances as an Olympic possibility on Saturday when Head Coach Ed Leader's crews will compete against three crews from Massachusetts Institute of Technology on the Housatonic.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The action of the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections in voting fully to investigate charges made by George M. Pritchard, Republican, of North Carolina, that the election of Senator Josiah W. Bailey, whom Mr. Pritchard opposed, was marked by fraud were received here today with much satisfaction by friends of the unsuccessful candidate.

Recent developments in the contest between Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic nomination for President have so widened the breach between them that reconciliation of these two former political friends and associates has become virtually impossible.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., April 17. -- Barnegat Bay's most active racing season in over thirty years of yachting will get under way on May 8, nearly a month earlier than the earliest start on record, because of the necessity of selecting a local representative for the Olympic semifinals in the Star Class at Narragansett Bay early in June.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- With three Republicans and one Democrat insisting tonight that the House Economy Committee's 11 per cent pay cut proposal go into the President's omnibus bill to reduce Federal expenditures, and another group fighting for inclusion of the army and navy consolidation plan, a stormy session of the committee looms for tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I appreciate the constant endeavor of your paper to maintain its present high standard of journalism in clarity and accuracy of news. In spite of this endeavor, inaccurate statements may inevitably creep into the multifarious news coming from distant parts of the world.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 17. -- Iodine Pep. a six-year-old orange and white pointer, today scored a notable triumph when he captured the amateur subscription all-age stake, which brought to a close the three-day meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club.
"Marry-Go-Round." a play by Albert Maltz and George Sklar, will open tonight at the Provincetown Theatre. Ian Maclaren, Elisha Cook Jr., Viola Frayne, Ruth Thomas and Gregory Robins are in the cast.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 17. -- Rough water combined with a high wind again forced the postponement of the Frostbite Yacht Club's dinghy sailing races, scheduled to he held today by the Knickerbocker Yacht Club on Manhasset Bay.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., April 17 (Canadian Press) -- Unemployed here today abandoned their avowed intention of holding on outlawed public meeting. The situation in the city, disturbed by intermittent rioting and looting since last Thursday, remained tense but quiet.

A central agency to act as an economic general staff to advise government and business on economic and financial problems as a means of avoiding or mitigating depression is urged by Wallace Brett Donham, dean of the graduate school of business administration of Harvard University, in his book "Business Looks at the Unforeseen," published today by Whittlessey House, McGraw-Hill Book Company.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- Pitcher Milburn Shoffner's homer with two out in the ninth Inning gave the Newark Bears a 9-to-8 victory over the Rochester Red Wing's before a chilled crowd of 10,000 today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 17. -- The twelfth annual Mason and Dixon lawn tennis tournament, under the direction of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, will open on the Green Brier courts tomorrow.

BERLIN, April 15. -- After seven months in which official Stock Exchange trading has been interrupted, trading on the Boerse was formally resumed last Tuesday. Business on the day of reopening was very inactive. Prices declined, but on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday the general public entered the market and there were very considerable advances both in stocks and bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Further developments as a result of the activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the policy of the Federal Reserve Banks, following adoption of the Glass-Steagall act, of buying heavily of government securities in the open market in an effort to bring about a "controlled expansion of credit" and rising commodity prices are being awaited anxiously by government officials.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP). -- Making his debut in the major leagues, Tex Carleton, young Cardinal pitcher, held the Chicago Cubs hitless today until the sixth inning. He issued nine bases in balls from then on and the Cubs won, 4 to 1.

This little New England town has come into a world-wide distinction. Not only does it continue to give attractive setting to one of the best and most famous of American colleges; it furnishes a delightful Summer course for the study and discussion of international relationships.

Wholesale apparel markets last week reflected an increasing consumer demand for seasonal goods and retailers placed substantial orders for Summer clothing for both men and women. The vogue for cotton dresses was an outstanding feature of the week's buying, with evening gowns, sportswear and daytime dresses wanted in all price ranges.

LONDON, April 15. -- The foreign trade position of Great Britain assumed the foremost place in this week's discussion in financial quarters. The overseas trade returns for March, published this week, were noteworthy because they are the first to have been issued since the general tariff went into operation on March 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to call the consideration of your readers to a situation which has become very acute and one which it seems has escaped the attention of those persons interested in the extension of hospital facilities in the metropolitan area.

The disintegration of family life today can be attributed to the movies, the stage and current output of fiction in their attempt to "bring back the old Greek interpretation of love and make it synonymous with sex appeal," the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- To their Forty-First Continental Congress, opening tomorrow, Daughters of the American Revolution delegates today made a bicentennial celebration prelude.

Lincoln Ellsworth, veteran of two daring air expeditions to the North Polar regions, is planning to bisect the area known as the Antarctic Continent by airplane. His pilot is to be Bernt Balchen, who, with Bert Acosta, flew Admiral Byrd's transatlantic plane from Roosevelt Field to France and two years later was at the controls of Admiral Byrd's plane on its flight to the South Pole.

There is something very strange about the paintings by Milton Avery, whose one-man, show opened Saturday at Gallery 144 West Thirteenth Street. Mr. Avery was born up-State and has lived most of his life in Connecticut. Furthermore, the gallery assures us that he has never been in Europe.

BERLIN, April 15. -- The possibility of further reduction in the Reichsbank rate is being discussed, probably because reichsmark exchange holds fairly firm and the reserve position has improved. Between the end of the first standstill agreement and the end of 1931, the Reichsbank lost 613,000,000 marks gold and gold exchange; but the loss since the beginning of the present year, covering considerably more than half as much time, has been only 135,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the past you have taken the present administration in Washington to task for what may be termed "ambiguousness" and only recently you inferred it would be better if Al Smith dropped out of the Presidential picture in order to avoid another possible campaign of whispering against the Catholic religion.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- A 435-mile flight over the mountains from Buffalo brought the seaplane XP2Y1, recently purchased by the navy, to the Anacostia Naval Air Station after a trip such as seldom has been undertaken by water-going aircraft.

Charging that the State Chamber of Commerce had adopted a report that was absolutely misleading and deliberately misrepresenting "upon the basis of which It asked Mayor Walker to investigate the Sanitation Department, Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission, retorted to the chamber in a letter yesterday.
Mayor Walker is contemplating a radio appeal on a nation-wide network to crystallize sentiment in the cities of the country for the Jbeer parades" on May 14.

Salary reductions, taken by the entire staff at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, and a general curtailment of expenses have reduced the church's proposed budget for the coming fiscal year $35,000 below that for last year, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, announced to his congregation yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, April 17. -- Eight grades passed in two years and a school teacher at the age of 7 is the unusual record of Joanna Xenos, product of the tenements and daughter of immigrant parents.

More than 18,000 congealed fans saw the Robins and the Phils battle brilliantly for ten innings to a scoreless deadlock at Ebbets Field yesterday and then watched the visitors take the decision in the eleventh 2 to 0.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Since the arrival in this district of Malachi L. Harney, prohibition administrator, raids on speakeasies and the "knocking over" of illicit stills and breweries, have increased at a rapid rate.

Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, announced yesterday that the Metropolitan Opera was the prospective tenant of the new $4,500,000 opera house in Rockefeller Centre for which plans were filed on April 8 with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Two major committees of the Senate will continue inquiries tomorrow into aspects of the business depression and some means of lifting the government out of its fiscal difficulties. One will resume an investigation of shortselling on the stock market; the other will take up again the new tax bill, designed to raise $1 ,000,000,000 toward balancing the Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The assertion by Sir Austen Chamberlain, former Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs of Great Britain, in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning that the burden of the war debts must be considered "at the same time and in the same spirit" as the problem of reparations was read with great interest by State Department officials and members of the Senate.

In Sunday's TIMES our correspondent at Milwaukee explained how it happened that in the April primary the LA FOLLETTES lost control of the Wisconsin delegation to the Republican National Convention for the first time in twenty-eight years. It was always a misnomer to call that delegation "Republican."

EL, PASO, Texas, April 17 (AP). -- An acute water shortage, which sent the poor of Juarez, Mexico, staggering through the streets with heavy buckets of water, ended today, but the municipality still was without street lighting service.
John North Willys, United States Ambassador to Poland, is due to return today on the Europa. Prince Erik of Denmark is also a passenger. Others arriving on that liner include:
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Bodman were hosts at a dinner in the Homestead this evening in honor of Mr. and Mrs. William Sergeant Kendall.

While Vicente Escudero was saying his season's farewell last night in his fifteenth New York performance at Chanin's Forty-sixth Street Theatre, Dhimah was engaged in her first recital of the season at the John Golden. Both events succeeded in attracting large audiences, and in the case of Escudero considerable loudly expressed enthusiasm such as has been customary at his performances when he has been in good form.

A northwest gale lashed the metropolitan area, and much of the north Atlantic coast yesterday. It ripped down signs in the city, injuring two pedestrians, one seriously, blew over fences and dislodged fragments of roofs, keeping police emergency squads busy throughout the afternoon.

President Hoover, in Washington, joined civic and educational leaders here yesterday in paying tribute to Goethe, the centennial of whose death in 1832 is being observed throughout the world, at a dinner of the Goethe Society of America in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Complete Federal regulation of interstate passenger bus operations such as is now imposed on the railroads and Federal licensing of motor trucks engaged in interstate commerce were urged by the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report to Congress.

GENEVA, April 18. -- After two months of speechmaking the disarmament conference today is near to reaching its first decision regarding its program and aims. This accomplishment was the outcome of a full morning's discussion and an hour of labor by the drafting committee.

GLEN COVE, L.I., April 18. -- The body of Sidney Hadlington, 38 years old, a B.M.T. mechanic, of 107-23 139th Street, Jamaica, was found in the water off the New York Yacht Club here this morning by John Weber and Dominick Barbieri, Glen Cove fishermen.

TOKYO, April 18. -- Strong evidence that, despite the apparent menace in the tension between Japan and Russia over Manchuria there is rigid determination on the part of both to avoid situations which might lead to a clash, is seen by observers here in the statement yesterday by a spokesman for the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A revised administration revenue program calling for $1,033,000,000 in additional taxes and $208,000,000 in savings for the fiscal year 1933 was submitted to the Senate Finance Committee today by Secretary Mills.

ATWOOD, Kan., April 18 (AP). -- An investigation started personally by Governor Harry H. Woodrins was under way here tonight in an attempt to learn the identity of members of a mob that lynched Richard Read, slayer of 8-year-old Dorothy Hunter.

Ely Jacques Kahn, one of the foremost exponents of modern architecture in America, is having an exhibition of photographs and drawings of his work at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, until April 30. The show was opened yesterday with a reception at 4 o'clock.

Besides providing his exhibition with a baker's dozen, Leopold Seyffert has made possible, in his portrait of Mrs. Adam Gimbel, one of the most striking vista achievements in the art history of New York. You walk into the first exhibition room at the John Levy Galleries, where Mr. Seyffert's show opened yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has about concluded negotiations for the purchase of the foreign properties of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company. The consideration, it is understood, will be both cash and stock and will amount to approximately $100,000,000.

Answering the charge that he demanded an illegal fee for filing a judgment in the City Court, of which he is chief clerk, Harry C. Perry submitted an affidavit yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Gavegan declaring that he had only followed the "mandatory provision of the statute."

THE runners will be plodding over the Wellesley Hills to Boston town today and the queer thing is that the fellow who started this Patriots' Day celebration in New England was going away from Boston and not on foot. He rode a horse.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 18. -- Citing the United States as an example of what a confederation of adjoining States signifies for their economic and political development, Emilio Tagle, a Chilean lawyer and politician, urges in a statement today the formation of a customs union for the southern section of South America.

The Socialist son of a former Prime Minister of England has been making a survey of conditions in the United States. On his return to London, young Mr. OLIVER BALDWIN reported, with an air of regret, that things are not yet "half bad enough" in America to result in the setting up of a Socialist Government.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 18. -- Optimism pervaded the annual convention of the Westchester County Republican Committee at Grace Church this afternoon when William L. Ward was re-elected chairman for his thirty-seventh consecutive term.

PARIS, April 18. -- American financial circles in Paris showed keen interest in the announcement today that French loans issued by the United States would be quoted on the Bourse, commencing tomorrow. This in itself will not have any great effect, but it is feared it is merely the first step toward the rumored possibility of France permitting quotations by the Bourse of American securities generally.

Prices of bonds were mildly reactionary on the Stock Exchange yesterday in virtually all groups. Trading, however, was comparatively light. Of the eleven active United States Government Issues, eight finished at declines of 1-32 to 11-32 point, while the three others were unchanged to 2-32 point higher.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Although prices of stocks fell yesterday to a new low level, the volume of sales was uncommonly small and Wall Street hoped that this foreshadowed the end of the liquidating movement. Transactions on the Stock Exchange involved a total of 848,000 shares, compared with 1,481,854 shares on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

LONDON, April 18. -- The British budget, which Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will present to the House of Commons tomorrow, was submitted today to his colleagues in the Cabinet, all of whom approved it except, of course, Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw and the other free trade members of the government who object to new tariffs as a means of producing revenue.

Declaring that the welfare agencies were "too polite" in demanding further aid for the needy unemployed, the City Affairs Committee contended in a statement yesterday that $60,000,000, or $10,000,000 a month for the next six months, would be necessary to "save the city from bread riots."

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on April 13 shows decreases for the week of $115,000,000 in loans and investments, $27,000,000 in time deposits and $52,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $101,000,000 in net demand deposits and $71,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
LONDON, April 18. -- A caustic attack on present-day Senators and Representatives from Mississippi is contained in the annual report of the Council of Foreign Bondholders, to be published tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Senator Borah, who was one of the stanch supporters of President Hoover in 1928, is expected to attend the Republican National Convention and fight against his party's adopting a plank favoring a referendum on prohibition unless it offers a concrete substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment that is acceptable to him.

ST. PAUL, April 18. -- Governor Roosevelt of New York enunciated the fundamentals of his political economy in an address here tonight, and took occasion in doing so to strike back at his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, on his recent charge of a "demagogic" attempt to stir up class hatred.
BERLIN, April 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of April 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

While business activity in some lines showed a slight improvement in March in response to seasonal influences, the upturns were but a fraction of what is normal for that period of the year, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation at their annual meeting in Hoboken yesterday overwhelmingly rejected a motion made on behalf of a small minority group to disapprove the action of the directors in reducing dividends on the common stock.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP). -- Charlie Root allowed the St. Louis National League champions only four hits today to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-to-1 victory and a clean sweep of a two-game series.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 18. -- Three Philadelphia gunmen, attempting an escape from the Camden County jail early this evening, started a disturbance in which eight prisoners, two guards and two policemen were injured or overcome by tear gas used in restoring order.

Strikebreakers were enrolled yesterday at two buildings used as branches of the Salvation Army to replace longshoremen who left the piers of three coastwise ship lines on Friday when a 10 per cent wage reduction was enforced, and as the result of protests by the International Longshoremen's Association the adjutants in charge of the buildings were warned by superiors in the organization that the practice must cease.

MONTE CARLO, April 18. -- For the first time in its history the Casino company, which had its annual board meeting this morning, has decided to pass a dividend because of diminished profits. Usually it has declared a dividend varying from 100 to 200 per cent.

Another last season's pitching disappointment returned to form at Ebbets Field yesterday when Babe Phelps gave 8,000 fans a thrill by shutting out the Phillies with six scattered hits, while the Robins hammered four hurlers for twelve hits. The score was 8 to 0.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 (AP). -- Thrown from a horse during the filming of a motion picture, Lina Basquette, dancer and film actress, was injured seriously today when her foot caught in a stirrup and she was dragged fifty feet.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Senator Wheeler today attacked the newspapers that endorsed Alfred E. Smith's criticism of Governor Roosevelt and praised the latter's son, James Roosevelt, for defending his father.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 18 (AP). -- Several thousand steel workers were back at work today in the mills of Birmingham, Pittsburgh and Youngstown, Ohio, as stable prices and an increase in orders gave encouragement to the steel industry.
READING, Pa., April 18 (AP). -- Pounding three Key pitchers for a total of fourteen base hits, the Buffalo club defeated Reading today, 7 to 4.

Alexander Kelberine, pianist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night in a program devoted exclusively to Beethoven and Bach. The Beethoven section consisted of the Thirty-two variations in C minor, the Sonata, Op. 31, No. 2, in D minor; the Bagatelle, Op. 119, and the Rondo a Capriccio, Op. 129.

SHANGHAI, April 18. -- The Shanghai peace parley, which broke down over the question of a definite time limit for the withdrawal of Japanese troops, is expected to be resumed Wednesday following a conference yesterday of Nanking Government leaders, including General Chiang Kai-shek, Foreign Minister Lo Wenkan, Vice Foreign Minister Quo Taichi and Minister of War Ho Ying-ching.

ORBETELLO, Italy, April 18. -- Lieut. Col. Guascone Guasconi, one of Italy's foremost speed pilots, who participated in the Schneider Trophy races at Norfolk, Va., in 1926, was killed with two other men when a seaplane plunged into the water here in a demonstration flight today.

PARIS, April 18. -- Miss Anne Morgan, sister of J.P. Morgan, was elevated to the rank of Commander of the Legion of Honor by nomination of the Foreign Ministry She did much work in France for soldiers during the war and continued active in numerous charities here afterward.
Two American diplomats who returned on the Europa yesterday on leave from their posts were John M. Morehead, Minister to Sweden, and Herman Bernstein, Minister to Albania.
To multitudinous, weary ears Cardinal O'CONNELL'S words bring a little comfort, though it be accompanied with even less hope:

One More Chance for Buses. However long - suffering the public, there is apparently a limit to Buses the patience of the courts. At any rate, there is such a limit in the case of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which has been called upon time after time to protect "emergency" bus operation in Manhattan and Queens against interference by injunction.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Apparently the major criticism of the stock market is due to the professional traders' so-called manipulation either through individual action or through pools.

Several months ago John McDonald got a cat. A friend gave it to him, and he thought it would be company for the quiet little studio apartment at 168 West Eighteenth Street. The cat liked salmon and in the evenings it went out for private engagements.

Writers are not looked upon with favor by the proprietor of Reid's Hotel, the only hotel in Pango Pango and the one which Somerset Maugham used as the setting for "Rain, according to Charles Peden, author of "Newsreel Man," to be published by Doubleday, Doran on Thursday.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding fell $8,101,166 in March to $911,290,714 at the close of the month, according to the American Acceptance Council. Compared with the figures for the end of March, 1331, the current report shows a reduction of $555,445.789, or more than the total volume that was outstanding as recently as 1927.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh issued a statement last night declaring he had been "unable to reestablish a definite contact" with the criminals who kidnapped his baby son and robbed him of $50,000 intended as the infant's ransom.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The United States has informed Haiti of its readiness to negotiate immediately an arrangement for financial control in the island republic sufficient to protect American, bondholders after the expiration in 1936 of the 1915 treaty.

Mary Wigman, fresh from a transcontinental tour, gave her last New York performance but one last night at Carnegie Hall as a benefit for the Child Study Association of America. Though the huge hall is anything but ideal for dancing and the audience were for the most part more interested in the cause they were supporting than in the art they had come to see, Frau Wigman won another of her characteristic victories.
The Labor Bureau's index number of average prices for commodities in March, published yesterday, compares with the average in previous months and years as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Sponsors of cashing the $2,000,000,000 soldier bonus rested their case today with the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, claiming the support of one-third of that group for their currency-expansion plan.

GENEVA, April 18 (AP). -- Secretary of State Stimson, the victim of an annoying cold, remained in his sixteenth-century villa all today while the disarmament conference debated a proposal for reduction in arms to be achieved by successive stages.

Rapid-transit facilities, operating on a fare sufficient to meet all interest and amortization costs of the bonds issued to pay for their construction, should be provided for Staten Island as soon as the city's financial condition warrants action, Controller Berry told members of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce at St. George last night.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- More showers in parts of Kansas and Nebraska and weakness in securities dampened the ardor of the local bullish element today on the Board of Trade. While a rally of about a cent followed an early break, the finish was easy, with final trades at about the lowest figures.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP). -- The fighting Washington Senators today upset the American League champions, the Athletics, 15 to 7.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- The market value of the estate of Richard T. Crane Jr., president of the Crane Company, has shrunk from $19,000,000 on Nov. 7, the day of his death, to $5,500,000, the inventory filed today showed.

Price trend in commodities was lower yesterday. Grains, cotton, sugar, rubber and cocoa in the futures all showed losses, hides and silk being irregular. In the spot trading lard reached a new low for the year.
Edwin R. Harris has been appointed manager of the municipal bond department of Ewart, Adams Bond, and Jackson Cherry will have charge of the municipal trading department.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- With the opening races scheduled for this Saturday against a new rival, the varsity crews of Yale today started their final drive toward a new season.

The third of Lou Holtz's variety revues, staged last night at the Hollywood Theatre, continues in the mood and manner of its predecessors. Like them, it is a decidedly informal variety show, entirely Times Square in conception and execution, and, like them, it presents, for the most part, faces well known to those who seek their pleasure on Broadway, particularly at the larger musical revues and the Palace.

A drive to raise $100,000 as the quota of the New York Women's Division of the Democratic Victory Campaign was started yesterday afternoon at a meeting attended by 300 women at the Hotel Commodore. Miss Elisabeth Marbury, chairman of the division and member of the Democratic National Committee, presided.

In a surprise move as it was nearing the close of its case against Nicholas C. Fartos, former head of the Cornel Drug Stores Corporation, the prosecution assented yesterday to a directed acquittal for Ellis A. Laskey, Partos's co-defendant and formerly chief bookkeeper for the drug chain and other corporations Partos controlled.

DETROIT, April 18. -- Ralph Stone, speaking for New York, Chicago and Detroit bankers, who, through lending large sums at money to the city, are financially interested in Detroit's present condition, today announced that the "compromise ordinance" by which Corporation Counsel Wilcox hoped to restore the city's credit and avoid a 33 1-3 per cent reduction in salaries is not acceptable and that the banks could no longer aid the city.

"Angeline Moves In," the Hale Francisco play, formerly entitled "Whiskey Blanc," will open tonight at the Forrest Theatre. Suzanne Caubaye, Mrs. Jacques Martin, Robert Brister and Katherine Reyner will be among those in the cast.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate is slated to decide today, probably in executive session, whether bus franchises in Queens will be awarded to the North Shore Bus Corporation and the Jamaica Buses, Inc., or given to a number of existing operators as proposed by Borough President George U. Harvey.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell hurled his second victory of the season today as he held the White Sox to seven hits, the Cleveland-Indians winning, 2 to 1.

Controller Charles W. Berry has virtually closed negotiations with Wall Street banking houses to handle $25,000,000 of new short-term municipal securities between now and the midle of June, it was reported yesterday in financial circles. The first instalment of the new city financing, it was said, will consist of $6,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent special corporate stock notes, to be taken tomorrow by a syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank.

TRENTON, N.J., April 18. -- Nominating petitions for Representative Percy H. Stewart, who will oppose United States Senator W. Warren Harbour for election to the Senate as the successor to the late Dwight W. Morrow, were filed here today. Mr. Stewart is now the Democratic Representative from the Fifth District.

LONDON, April 18. -- Sir Thomas Lawrence's famous portrait, "The Red Boy," was withdrawn today from the auction of the art treasures of Lambton Castle, at Durham, when the bidding stopped at u95,000 [about $361,000 at current exchange rates]. It was announced the reserve price had not been reached.

Revenues of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad from the movement of anthracite decreased from $17,386,261 in 1930 to $13,948,016 in 1931, or by 19.7 per cent, according to the annual report of J.M. Davis, president. Mr. Davis said the drop could be attributed in part to an unusual Winter, records of the New York Weather Bureau showing that 1931 had been the warmest since 1868.

VIENNA, April 18. -- The fate of the London Danubian Conference is already threatening the Innsbruck conference of the International Chamber of Commerce. According to Czechoslovak sources, a sharp conflict has broken out between the supporters of the Tardieu plan and adherents of the German proposal for unilateral preference for Austrian industrial products, combined with a general preference for agrarian products of Yugoslavia, Rumania and Hungary.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Thousands of refugees have arrived at Amoy from the interior, and all Americans have been evacuated from the interior points considered unsafe as a result of a threat to the city of Changchow in Fukien Province by a Chinese independent army, Lynn W. Franklin, United States Consul at Amoy, reported to the State Department today.

Since the Veterans' Administration is by far the largest spending agency of the Federal Government, it was inevitable that search for means of reducing expenditures should turn to a scrutiny of its appropriations. The "national economy bill" which the President has submitted to Congress contemplates a saving of about $80,000,000 out of a total of $830,000,000 carried in the budget for veterans' relief next year.

LONDON, April 18. -- The fascination of Napoleon for Premier Mussolini is apparent in every scene of his long, historical play, "Napoleon -- The Hundred Days," which was produced here for the first time in English tonight.
ST. PAUL, April 18. -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's address here tonight:

Mayor Walker assailed anew the critics of his administration in an address at the formal opening of the new Allen Street Boulevard yesterday afternoon. First he singled out the Controller. Then he criticized the Hofstadter Legislative Commission and the State Housing Commission without naming them.

By order of the Board of Governors of the Building Trades Employers Association the executives of thirty trade groups in the association began posting notices yesterday announcing wage reductions of between 20 and 35 per cent for 115,000 building trades workers beginning May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- By a vote lacking only two of being unanimous, the Senate today approved the action of the Appropriations Committee in reducing the House allotment for prohibition enforcement from $11,369,000 to $10,250,000, although the drys defeated two attempts to cut the $10,250,000 fund still further.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The letter of Secretary Mills to Chairman Smoot of the Finance Committee regarding the Treasury's revenue proposals follows:

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Despite the fact that Alfred E. Smith is the grandfather and Executive Chairman Jouett Shouse is the father of the suggestion for an early meeting of members of the Democratic platform committee, no sign of opposition appeared today from the Roosevelt managers or from any other party source.

Holding that the use of misleading signs in picketing may be more harmful than physical violence, Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink in Brooklyn yesterday permanently enjoined a motion picture operators' union from interfering with theatres owned by the Esco Operating Company which, with its affiliates, controls thirty-three theatres in Manhattan, the Bronx and in Brooklyn.

The first intimation of the nature of the secret inquiry into the affairs of Mayor Walker by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, was received yesterday when William H. Woodin, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, was reported to have been one of the witnesses questioned by Mr. Seabury in private.

ALBANY, April 18 (AP). -- Professional budget trimmers started work today where the amateur surgeons of the legislative economy committee left off last week after its first session to find means of reducing New York State's expenses.

Mayor Walker's "Beer for Taxation" parade on May 14 was assured yesterday of an enthusiastic group of marchers as a nucleus when John H. McCooey's Democratic organization in Brooklyn announced its intention to send a unit from each of the twenty-three Assembly Districts in the borough.

There has been a considerable increase in the average daily register of the city day schools taken as a whole -- larger than in any other year since 1923-1924. But, as Superintendent O'SHEA'S report shows, this is due, not to a growing child-population but to the longer period of school attendance by pupils advancing from the lower classes.

A sweeping examination of the thirty-five officers of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, pending trial of a suit for an accounting of $7,500,000 funds, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler to fifteen union members represented by John Holley Clark Jr. of 120 Broadway.

HOLLAND PATENT, N.Y., April 18 (AP). -- F.R. Fuller, 75 years old, architect, died tonight at his home here. He had charge of the architectural work in connection with the erection of the Poughkeepsie State Hospital and of a government building at Ottawa.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 18. -- William Ziegler Jr.'s Spinach, making his first appearance since the Laurel meeting last October, accounted for Havre de Grace's feature race today when he galloped home to an easy victory in the Hampton Roads purse over one mile and seventy yards.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP). -- Babe Herman's first homer of the season and inspired fielding behind Ray Kolp's fine pitching gave the Reds a 5-to-0 shutout victory over the Pittsburg Pirates today. With the score 2 to 0 for the Reds in the eighth, Herman drove the ball to the right-field corner, sending home Manion and Gilbert before him.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 (AP). -- Completely overlooked in the betting, C.W. Moore's Benefit furnished a surprise when he drove home the winner in the Nicholasville Purse, feature attraction today at Lexington. The heavily-played Jane Packard, owned by Edward Haughton, was second and Furst, Bauer and Hukill's Abe Furst third.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Secret files of the War Department, dealing with the final phases of the World War which have never been made public, will feature the memoirs of General Peyton C. March, the wartime chief of staff, which will be published next Fall.

The first of the Broadway producing managers to reveal his plans for next season is Brock Pemberton, who announced yesterday that he had already assembled a group of plays for production at that time and was continuing his search for new material.

Movement of values generally was uncertain yesterday, but with last week's irregularly distributed recovery of domestic bonds continued in numerous securities. Advances of 2 to 5 points occurred in the railway bond list, offset as usual by scattered declines.

Because he started fighting with the opening clang of the gong and did not cease until the final bell, Franta Kekolny of Czechoslovakia carried off the decision over Jay Macedon, South Orange, N.J., welterweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The House Economy Committee, counseled by Speaker Garner and Minority Leader Snell, agreed today to put all the proposed economy plans into a single omnibus bill in deference to the wishes of President Hoover.

LONDON, April 18. -- The stock markets were quiet today, with a marked decrease in business. British Government funds were firm, improving slightly in the afternoon with the exception of the war loan, which was lower.
NEW YORK. Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont gave a farewell luncheon yesterday at the Pierre for Mrs. Cornelius Tiers, who is sailing tonight on the Europa.

State censorship of motion pictures was criticized yesterday by George J. Zehrung, director of the Motion Picture Bureau of the Y.M.C.A., who addressed the motion picture conference of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, at the Astor.

A drop of 1/4 to 2 1/4 per cent in the lenders' rate for time money, all maturities, was the only development of any significance in the day's money market. The bid remained at 2. No trades were reported, the market being on a nominal basis so far as business was concerned.

BREMEN, April 18. -- The International Commodity Clearing Company was formed by 100 merchants here today to promote the exchange of goods between Germany and other countries, eliminating difficulties in the payment of foreign exchange. The company will approach prospective importers and exporters and try to exchange German exports for imports.
MONTREAL, April 18 (AP). -- Reggie McNamara and Harry Horan of Newark held a one-lap lead over the field in Montreal's six-day bicycle race after twenty-one hours of pedaling tonight.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18. -- Isaac Andrews of Spartanburg, S.C., former Grand American champion; Dr. Howard Kinsley, Toledo, Ohio; Samuel H. Sharman, Salt Lake City and R.C. Coffey, Prairie City, Iowa, each scored 96 to tie for first prize in the introductory shoot for Class 1 gunners, the opening event in the North and South target tournament at the Pinehurst Gun Club today.

Being an array of young men who will do such things on the spur of the moment, the Giants went right back into reverse yesterday at the Polo Grounds and by offering little more than a sort of passive resistance succumbed to the Boston Braves, 7 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Ten civilians and six Federal agents were killed in the enforcement of the national prohibition act from July 1, 1931, to Feb. 29, 1932, Colonel Amos W.W. Woodcock, head of the prohibition bureau, said today. The total represents one death for every 4,458 persons arrested, 71,333 having been apprehended for dry law violations in the nine months.

With patrols along State streams, a check made by the Connecticut officials concerning the number of trout caught on the opening day of the season reveals a total of approximately 3,875. Wardens canvassed waters and inspected creels for the purpose of tabulating results last Friday, some points being surveyed in the early part of the day and others in late afternoon.

HAVELBERG, Germany, April 18 (AP) -- The High District Court of Brandenburg has ruled that the heirs to the $100,000,000 fortune left by Ella Wendel, who died in New York last year, are the groups represented by Mrs. Gertrude Ohsann Kay of San Francisco and Adelaide Elizabeth Kroeger of Bremen, Germany.
MOSCOW, April 18. -- There is no doubt of growing Soviet irritation over what is happening in Manchuria, and no doubt either, in the Soviet mind, as to who is responsible.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 18 (AP). -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare today won the medal in the qualifying round of the women's Old Dominion golf championship with a record-breaking 74.

Less than two weeks after agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, began a census of speakeasies in Greater New York the administrator ordered his men to begin what was expected to be one of the widest drives against beer and liquor New York has known in years.
HONOLULU, April 18. -- Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie today came through the ordeal of cross-examination with his story of the slaying of Joseph Kahahawai unchanged in any material aspect.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 18. -- Earl Combs's triple against the centre field fence with two on bases in the eighth inning was the nearest to a bit of Babe Ruth performance the Yankees could offer today in their 8-to-2 victory in an exhibition game with the Springfield Rifles, the local Eastern League team which this year will serve as one of the subsidiary members of Colonel Jacob Ruppert's baseball chain.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Although Samuel Insull's Middle West Utilities Company is in receivership, two local operating companies which he heads, the Commonwealth Edison Company and Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, issued today quarterly reports showing earnings ample to cover dividends.
PALERMO, Italy, April 18 (AP). -- Major Gen. Antonino di Giorgio, who was Italian Minister of War in 1925, died here today at the age of 64. He had retired from the army.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 18. -- A jawbone believed to be that of a specimen of the earliest Homo sapiens (modern man) has been found in early Pleistocene deposits on the shore or Lake Victoria, near the native village of Kanam, by the Third East African Expedition, headed by Dr. Louis S.B. Leakey, which has been working in that district for five months.

The city of Tampa, Fla., which has never failed to meet its debt obligations, has decided to take steps to preserve its record by asking the holders of various issues of its bonds that will mature from July 1, 1932, to Dec. 31, 1935, to exchange their holdings for bonds with longer maturities and bearing higher rates of interest.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18.-- Plans for the Olympic rowing trials were outlined tonight at a meeting of the Schuylkill Navy and the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen held at the Penn A.C.
