PEIPING, April 18. -- The belief is growing that what is described as a Red menace in Fukien Province has no connection with communism but is part of a wider movement involving the rapid revival of the Kuominchun (so-called People's Army, which was led by General Feng Yu-hsiang).

VINELAND, N.J., April 18. -- A long-standing controversy between school authorities here and a man who believes that his wife is a better educator of his three children than the teachers in the public schools remained at a deadlock today when Arthur J. Smart informed H.W. Weidner, superintendent of schools, that he would continue to fight any attempts to force his children to attend public school.

More than $600,000 passes immediately in public bequests from the $1,695,712 net estate of Charles N. Vilas, philanthropist and retired hotel man, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The town of Alstead, Vt., where Mr. Vilas died on Sept. 8, 1931, receives immediately $475,000 in legacies and trust funds.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The New York Central Railroad today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a separate brief on the Eastern railroad consolidation. It had refused to participate in the joint brief of other trunk-line proponents of the four-party plan because of a disagreement over a legal interpretation of the transportation act and was reluctant to enter the controversy over the Pennsylvania Railroad's interests in New England roads.

Executive heads of nineteen of the largest sugar refining companies in the country have joined in an appeal to Congress to restrict the shipments of insular sugar to this country. The protest is being made in conjunction with the recent action of the House on the Philippine independence bill and is directed specifically against imports from those Islands, although Cuba and Porto Rico are also included.

The Rev. Charles L. O'Donnell, president of Notre Dame, last night defended the university from the charge that it is "a place of no particular intellectual pretensions." Speaking at the annual dinner of the Notre Dame Club of New York, at the McAlpin, he based his talk on a statement by a writer in The London Saturday Review, in which this phrase appeared in connection with football.

Fox Film interests were voted out of control of the Roxy Theatres Corporation yesterday, when Class A stockholders, as a result of the omission of their dividend, assumed control of the board of directors. Harley L. Clarke, chairman of the Fox Film Corporation, retired as president and a director and S.R. Burns and W. C. Michel, both associated with Fox, retired from the Roxy board.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 18. -- With Ellsworth Vines, national champion and first seeded player, leading the way all the favorites moved into the second round as the twelfth annual Mason and Dixon tennis tournament got under way today.

JERUSALEM, April 18. -- Decisive evidence has now been obtained that Tell en Nasbeh, near Ramallah, which is twenty-six miles northwest of Jerusalem, is the ancient Biblical Mizpah of Benjamin's time. This definitely rules out the old supposition that Neby Samwil, in the hills west of Jerusalem, was the site of Mizpah.

HONOLULU, April 18 (AP). -- John C. Kelley, the prosecutor, announced, today that he had alienists coming from the United States to attack the insanity plea of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, charged with three others with killing Joseph Kahahawai. Mr. Kelley said he did not plan to ask any delay in the trial.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A Senatorial revelation of the names of "prominent" short-sale operators in the stock market failed to materialize today.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A strong army and navy until all nations agree to disarm was advocated tonight by Vice President Curtis at the opening session of the Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Mr. Curtis invoked the wisdom of George Washington to support his argument.

Henry E. Schnackenberg, former vice president and instructor of the Art Students' League, who was asked by a students' committee to reconsider his acceptance of nomination for president of the league opposing John Sloan, declined yesterday to withdraw.
NEWARK, N.J., April 18 (AP). -- Harry Holsclaw's five-hit pitching today upset the Rochester Red Wings and the Newark Bears won their second successive game of a four-game series. 7 to 0.

"Curb cuts," which figured so sensationally in the Willard-Flynn testimony before the Hofstadter committee, have current significance for Manhattan, where Borough President LEVY has declared war on "slump parking." This is the practice of tearing down a building to save taxes and then renting it out as a parking space.

Norman Armitage of the Fencers Club replaced Leo Nunes of the New York A.C. as metropolitan saber champion last night by winning the final round of the competition at the Salle d'Armes Vince. Armitage ascended to the championship by defeating John R. Huffman of the New York A.C. in a fence-off.
DETROIT, April 18 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers scored a 14-to-7 victory over the St. Louis Browns today in a game featured by twenty-eight hits and nine errors.

A swing away from the individual suburban home is noted in the first report from President HOOVER'S inquiry into social trends, just published by the American Institute of Architects. Fewer elaborate homes are being built by men of large means.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- New Haven's Eastern League baseball team was extended to ten innings today before gaining a 3-to-2 victory over Yale in their annual town and gown game at Yale Field.

Whole families migrating like gypsies in search of work have become one of the most serious problems in relief work today, it was reported yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Travelers Aid Society of New York at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward, 9 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Strengthening of the Kellogg pact by a supplementary agreement providing for specific action by the nations signatory to the pact against any violator of the world's peace was urged in a radio address yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

The Whitney family swept half the card at Jamaica yesterday, each of the three branches now racing winning one race. Mrs. Payne Whitney, owner of the Greentree Stable, took the featured Spinalong Purse when her Curacao won easily by five lengths.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Senator Johnson stirred up the first prohibition battle of the session with his proposal to cut the enforcement to $5,125,000 "in the interest of economy."

Members of the Eastern Ogontz Association held their annual luncheon yesterday at the Central Park Casino, having Miss Amy Sutherland, principal of the Ogontz School in Rydal, Pa., as guest of honor. After the luncheon Queena Mario of the Metropolitan Opera sang.

The defense won a point yesterday in the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, when Judge George L. Donnellan, in General Sessions, ruled that the defense might show what effect the stock market crash of 1929 and the subsequent continued decline in the securities market had upon the duties assigned to the Banking Department.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. is opposed to a resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment "until the people have indicated clearly in Congressional and Senatorial elections that the people themselves, not the wet press, not the associations opposed to prohibition, nor even the wet women want the amendment resubmitted," he told the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement today.

CADIZ, Ohio, April 18 (AP). -- Strike sympathizers again defied National Guardsmen on duty in the Eastern Ohio bituminous coal mine field, and three of their number were shot as they charged a barricade.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 19. -- That the Army and Navy shortly will resume football relations, though there is no assurance that this will be brought about this year, is the opinion of Major Gen. William R. Smith, retiring superintendent of the United States Military Academy, expressed in an interview today.

John Wanamaker will open today additional Au Quatrieme rooms for the exhibition and sale of antiques in the Waldorf-Astoria. The entrance is on the Park Avenue side of the hotel, near Forty-ninth Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 19. -- Officers of the Eastern Society of the Directors of Physical Education for Women in Colleges and Universities were elected at a business meeting this afternoon at the annual convention of the association at New Jersey College for Women.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 19. -- Paavo Nurmi's disqualification affair today entered a new and remarkable stage as the Finnish Athletic Association, in a strongly worded communication to the International Amateur Athletic Association, flatly refused to accept the decision reached in Berlin, which disqualified Finland's champion runner.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Although Earle Combs, acting as double for Babe Ruth, slammed a home run in each game of the Patriots' Day doubleheader, and additional homers were furnished by Dickey, Gehrig and Lazzeri, the Yankees did no better than break even with the Red Sox today.

LONDON, April 19. -- The British budget for 1932-33, which was presented to Parliament today, makes no provision for $171,500,000 which will be due the United States in the next twelve months on the war debt account. Neither does it list among the items of expected revenue the equivalent amount which will be due from German reparations and from European allies on their war debts to Britain.

LONDON, April 19. -- Despite the recurrence of his eye trouble, Prime Minister MacDonald expects to fly to Paris tomorrow afternoon and take a night train to Geneva. Dr. Thomas Horder will go with him and an oculist will follow later in the week.

"Tambor y Cascabel" ("Drum and Bell"), a new comedy by the Quinteros, will be performed for the first time in America tonight by the GuerreroMendoza company, now in the third week of their Spanish repertory engagement at the New Yorker Theatre. Another American premiere, on Friday night, will be that of a new play by Jacinto Benavente, the title of which is translated as "When Eve's Children Are Not Adam's."
Parade, v. i., To exhibit one's self, as by walking in a public place; to walk in public with some circumstance of show.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Senate Finance Committee hastened today toward the end of its hearings on the tax bill. Members believed, after a score of witnesses had testified during a five-hour session today, that testimony would end late tomorrow or early Thursday.

Plans to invite the Clearing House banks of New York that participated in January, in the issue of $100,000,000 of special corporate stock notes to participate in the new $25,000,000 short-term financing planned by the city were discussed yesterday at a meeting in the Chase National Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Senator Borah's address in the Senate today on the foreign debt situation was as follows:

GENEVA, April 19 (AP). -- Secretary of State Stimson wrote a chapter of American history at today's session of the disarmament conference by becoming the first high-ranking United States official to participate in an important international parley held under the auspices of the League of Nations and at the seat of the League.

ABOARD THE ROOSEVELT TRAIN, AURORA, Ill., April 19. -- Heading homeward tonight from an invasion of the farm belt, Governor Roosevelt carries with him the predictions of political leaders that he would be nominated and would wring the Northwest from the Republican column in November.

Indictments charging robbery in the first degree and criminally receiving about $300,000 in jewels obtained by gunmen on Jan. 21 last in the hold-up of the home of Harry C. Glemby, a hair net manufacturer, at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, were handed up yesterday against two women and three men who were arrested in a police trap eight days ago.

Showing a keen reluctance toward leaving their home surroundings, albeit they brought them nothing but misfortune since the present championship campaign began, the Giants struggled through thirteen innings against the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday only to tumble down to another inelegant defeat by a score of 8 to 7.

James A. Farrell retired yesterday as president of the United States Steel Corporation, terminating an active service of more than fifty years in the steel industry. William A. Irvin, his successor, was formally elected president at the organization meeting of the directors.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate, by a vote of 12 to 4 taken yesterday in executive session, recorded its approval of bus franchise awards in Queens to the North Shore Bus Corporation and the Jamaica Buses, Inc., a subsidiary of the Jamaica Central Railways.
Following is comment of newspapers of the country on the speech of Governor Roosevelt Monday evening at St. Paul:

RICHMOND, Va., April 19. -- Another fight between majority and minority stockholders of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company was presaged at the annual meeting here today when the minority group protested against large stock purchases in the Erie, Pere Marquette and the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroads.

DUBLIN, April 19. -- President Eamon de Valera expects an easy victory in the Dail tomorrow when he introduces the bill abolishing the oath of allegiance to the King from the Constitution. It will be the first time in the history of the modern British Empire that a dominion Parliament has attempted to break its tie with the Crown.

Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, with offices at 280 Broadway, was elected president of the National Republican. Club last night at the organization's annual meeting in the clubhouse at 54 West Fortieth Street. He succeeds General James G. Harbord.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- World War veterans with distinguished records, Representatives La Guardia of New York, Johnson of South Dakota and Simmons of Nebraska, who left legislative halls to don the uniform, stoutly opposed the $2,240,000,000 bonus bill today, declaring that such a drain on the government would lead to financial instability.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced last night that seven railroads had agreed to withdraw their lighters from service at the piers of the Clyde-Mallory, Savannah and Morgan steamship lines, where union longshoremen are on strike.

A house party of The Groups will be held at Briarcliff Lodge beginning Friday and lasting through May 2, it was announced yesterday. The organization is called "A First Century Christian Fellowship" and its nickname is "Buchmanism." Its chief exponent is the Rev. Frank N. D. Buchman, formerly of Oxford, England, and Princeton, N.J.

The freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 4 will increase revenues of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad by roughly $750,000 annually, George B. Elliott, president of the company, said yesterday. He estimated the saving in expenses from the 10 per cent wage deduction at about $2,000,000 for 1932.

The colors of John J. Robinson, which were so ably carried in 2-yearold specials last year by Renaissance and Lucky Tom, were borne to victory in the Suffolk Claiming Stakes, feature at Jamaica yesterday, by the Stimulus gelding Eisenberg. Eisenberg earned $3,875 by a strong charge through the stretch, which proved too much for Tinema and eight other juveniles.

John Walter, co-chief proprietor of The Times, of London, arrived last night on the White Star liner Majestic to spend a month in this country after an absence of thirty years. He is accompanied by Mrs. Walter. He expects to visit several cities in the Eastern States before returning to England.

A preliminary sketch of a large mural which will adorn the walls of the main floor of the International Music Hall in Rockefeller Centre has been completed by Ezra Winter, the first of a group of artists being chosen to execute an extensive decorative program for the midtown office and amusement centre.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Payments for the operation and maintenance of general departments of West New York, N.J., amounted to $1,724,978, or $46.25 per capita, in 1930, according to a survey made public by the Census Bureau today. Interest on debt was $302,156 and outlays for permanent improvements were $107,268.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (AP). -- A new Kentucky Derby threat loomed today when Knebelkamp Morris's hitherto lightly regarded Adobe Post made good in his first 1932 appearance to capture the Spring Station Purse, feature at Lexington today.

Max Klein, a restaurant owner of 34 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, testified yesterday as the State's principal witness in the General Sessions trial of the Rev. Samuel Buchler, lawyer and former Jewish chaplain at Sing Sing, on a grand larceny indictment.

The New York Telephone Company has applied to the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $109,000,000 additional common stock. It now has $371,300,000 common stock outstanding, all owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, out of $500,000,000 stock authorized.

Because of the necessity of cutting payrolls from $1,400,000 in April to about $525,000 in May, approximately one-half of those holding emergency jobs under the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau will have to be dropped on May 1, it was announced yesterday by William H. Matthews, director of the bureau, in a letter to non-profit-making institutions that have provided "made jobs."

MONTE CARLO, April 19. -- The charts committee of the International Hydrographic Conference met today to examine the joint proposal of the United States and Germany on the manner of inserting echo soundings on marine maps.
BUENOS AIRES, April 19. -- An excellent impression has been created in commercial and financial circles by Congress's handling of the budget.

IF the Weather Man is agreeable, Colonel Jacob Ruppert will throw open the gates of the Yankee Stadium this afternoon and the fans will have a chance to see the Ruppert Rifles, 1932 model, in combat with the cohorts of Connie Mack.

Edwin R. Tinker was elected yesterday chairman of the board of directors of the Fox Film Corporation, succeeding Harley L. Clarke, president of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., which controls the Fox company. It was said Mr. Clarke had asked to be relieved of the duties of his office.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19 (AP). -- In a contest featured by two home runs the Rochester Red Wings finally overcame the Newark Bears today, winning, 6 to 3. Wetherell held the home club in check. The Bears, however, hold the series edge, two game to one, with one contest remaining.

Three one-act plays, written and directed by young unemployed men of the "white collar" class, will be staged at the Bowling Green Neighborhood Association, 205 Washington Street, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. No admission will be charged and cigarettes and coffee will be served to players and audience after the performance.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19. -- One of the world's most difficult feats has just been performed for the only time in history, within modern knowledge. It is the scaling of Mt. Katmai, famous Alaskan ice mountain, in the dead of Winter.

Organization of Mayor Walker's "beer-for-taxation" parade here on May 14 moved forward yesterday as the Mayor conferred at City Hall on arrangements for the demonstration with Police Commissioner Edward P. Muirooney and Chief Inspector John O'Brien and made plans for whipping the various units into parade order at a meeting today.

The Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution at City Hall yesterday proclaiming Saturday, April 30, as a municipal holiday because it is the anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President.

Fifty-two prisoners taken in forty-eight raids during the last two days in the campaign started by Andrew McCampbell, Prohibition Administrator, to close all drinking places listed in a recently compiled directory of speakeasies were held yesterday in bail of from $500 to $1,000 each when they were arraigned before Garrett.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Approval of loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation aggregating $300,000 were sought in applications filed by three railroads today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A new principle in the absorption of short and unprofitable railroads by major lines was proposed in the petition of the New York Central Railroad filed on Monday with the Interstate Commerce Commission for relief from the obligation of buying the Boyne City, Gaylord Alpena Railroad.

Reports for March by railroads yesterday showed declines from March, 1931. The Union Pacific reported a drop of $100,000 in net operating income for the month. The Nickel Plate for the three months showed a net loss of $1,015,130, against a net income of $510,296 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Public disclosure of the names of "prominent persons, if any," on the list of short-selling traders in securities now under the scrutiny of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee was promised today by Chairman Norbeck.

Nobody would have been disappointed in Governor ROOSEVELT'S address at St. Paul if so many trumpets had not been sounded before him on his way to make it. It was to be a fighting speech, the public was told. The glove thrown down before the Governor by Mr. SMITH was to be picked up and flung back full in the face of the challenger.

The last several years have seen constantly dwindling revenues and continuously mounting expenditures for the Iron Steamboat Company, which since long before the city acquired Coney Island, has been operating passenger boats in Summer between Manhattan, Rockaway Beach and Coney Island.

Nothing happened in the money market to distinguish it from preceding sessions. Easy conditions persisted so far as the supply of lendable funds was concerned, but as demand was light the turnover was at a minimum. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2, while Street trades were made at 1 1/2 @ 2 and Federal funds at 1/8.

Samples of students' work from nine of the principal art schools of New York will be shown at an exhibition which opens tomorrow and continues until April 30 at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. The public exhibition will be preceded by a reception and private view tonight.

The concert given by Sir Thomas Beecham, conductor, Jose Iturbi, pianist, and the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra of 200 players at present without regular employment, last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, was the most brilliant concert of this series of Tuesday night entertainments thus far given.

The General Electric Company reports profits of $4,508,668 available for dividends on the common stock in the first quarter of 1932, equivalent to 16 cents a share earned on 28,845,927 shares of stock, comparing with $10,844,334, or 38 cents a share, earned in the first quarter of 1931.

Playing a brand of baseball in sharp contrast to that displayed in their three previous games with the Phillies, the Robins found themselves on the short end of a 10-to-2 count yesterday. About 12,000 fans saw the game at Ebbets Field.

GLEN COVE, L. I., April 19. -- The first flower show of a season that promises much activity among Long Island horticultural societies and garden clubs will be the two-day narcissus exhibit of the Westbury Horticultural Society which opens on April 27 in Winthrop Hall, Westbury.

GENEVA, April 19. -- Secretary Stimson took his seat at the disarmament conference today just as that body had, in general committee, registered with some mental reservations its first unanimous decision and embarked on the second definition of its aims.
The North German Lloyd liner Europa sailed last night for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremen with 1,415 passengers, the largest number leaving in one ship for Europe this year.

BERLIN, April 19. -- The approaching Prussian elections cast their first shadow on the Boerse today. Trading declined in volume and prices showed a downward tendency. Buying by the public, which was confined to flow price stocks, was retarded by rumors of impending failure of two local retail concerns.
LANDI KOTAL, India, April 19. -- Four hundred Afridi tribal elders gathered to greet the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon, when he halted here on his way through the Khyber Pass this morning.

Charles M. Schwab confided yesterday to the Pennsylvaaia Society, of which he is president, that he had been a very rich man before the depression, but that despite the reverses which have struck all persons of wealth he was still an optimist.

BUFFALO, April 19 (AP). -- An order restraining the Pysol Chemical Company of Niagara Falls and the Sanford Chemical Corporation of Buffalo from further sales of stock in New York State was signed today by Justice Alonzo G. Hinkley of the Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP). -- It took Rube Walberg four innings to find his pitching form today, but it was too late, for the Washington Senators had a good lead and again beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 7 to 4.

Holding that six fire insurance companies had delayed unnecessarily in making an appraisal of losses, Supreme Court Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn awarded yesterday $28,500 to the Crest Furniture Company, Inc., of 138 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Rudolph Spreckels's suggestion that a tax be levied against American investments in manufacturing enterprises abroad, with which I am heartily in accord, Is based largely on the theory that such taxation would bring funds invested abroad back to this country.

It is a common ambition of every vaudeville actor to quit the stage and retire to a chicken, farm. Actors, authors and lecturers come to feel a responsibility to their public, an emotion comparable to the special attachment of Congressmen for their constituents.

Three interesting exhibitions of drawings in ink and water-color have opened this week: work by Walt Kuhn at the Marie Harriman Gallery by John Carroll at the Rehn and by Boardman Robinson at Brownel Lambertson's. In these shows on finds reflected three personalities with apparently nothing in common save a deeply sincere love of art and a measure of success that has brought each of the artists well to the front.

READING, Pa., April 19 (AP). -- Buffalo's biffing Bisons took their sixth victory in a row and the third straight from Reading today, 14 to 10. Nine runs scored by the victors in the second frame after they had started with two tallies in the first put them far in the lead.

PARIS, April 19. -- Opening dull today under the influence of yesterday's weakness in Wall Street, the Bourse became active toward midsession owing to recovery in Rio Tinto Copper and the stocks of several French banks. After having weakened considerably in the early part of the session the whole list improved and at close the majority showed some gains over yesterday's final prices.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the beet names. Monday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Boston College celebrated Father's Day in fitting fashion on University Heights today by winning a thrilling 9 to 8 baseball contest from Fordham University before close to 5,000 spectators.
NEWARK, N.J., April 19. -- Harry G. Hendricks, ousted receiver for the Earl Radio Corporation, surrendered this afternoon to Prosecutor Joseph L. Smith at the court house.

The Board of Justices of the City Court cleared Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the court, yesterday of all charges brought against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee.

HAVANA, April 19. -- All foreigners residing in Cuba must register with the Department of the Interior within sixty days following the opening of the register of foreigners, according to a Presidential decree signed and sent for publication to the Official Gazette today.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Senate Manufactures Committee, by a vote of 7 to 4, reported unfavorably today a bill legalizing 4 per cent beer, opening the way for a vote of the Senate.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 19 (AP). -- The Japanese command rushed reinforcements to the North today to put down new outbursts of irregulars in the districts around Liaoyang, Tungliao and Taonan. [The first two cities named are about 90 and 150 miles, respectively, west of Changchun, capital of Manchoukuo, and are on the Tatung Railway.

HONOLULU, April 19 (AP). -- Alienist testimony that Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie was insane at the moment Joseph Kahahawai was killed put the prosecution in a fighting mood today as the defense effort to clear four persons of the slaying approached its finale.

Official reports of the State Banking Department, filed by examiners less than six months before the Bank of United States was closed, showed that Bernard K. Marcus and Saul Singer, executive heads of the bank, had been "dishonest" in their manipulation of the bank's affiliates, George W. Egbert, First Deputy Superintendent of Banks, testified yesterday at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent.
ST. PAUL, April 19 (AP). -- Hope for the re-establishment of a friendly relationship with Alfred E. Smith was expressed today by Governor Roosevelt as he started homeward.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 19. -- Pounding Pitcher Spanier for ten hits and seven runs in the first four innings, the Princeton baseball team defeated City College today 9 to 5.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- W. Cameron Forbes completed his service as Ambassador to Japan today by reporting to President Hoover and State Department officials upon his arrival from the Orient.

"WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The House Economy Committee today receded from its stand for exclusive consideration of its own salary-cut plan of 11 per cent for all salaries over $1,000 and agreed to allow President Hoover's furlough proposal to be offered as an amendment when the omnibus bill is submitted to the House.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The declaration by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, that no receipts from reparations and no outlay for war debts had been included in the budget for the fiscal year 1932-1933, submitted to Parliament today, brought sharp reactions in official and political circles here.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Prices of hogs dropped 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight today, and the average equaled the inside figures since 1900. The top was off 20 cents at $4.15, while the day's average was 10 cents lower than yesterday's at $3.75.

After having declined 30 points in the last few days, prices on the Cotton Exchange were steady for several hours yesterday. Then the market came under pressure and the final quotations were 4 to 5 points lower on the day.

Expressing regret that the New York statutes do not provide for punishment at the whipping post in cases of this kind, Magistrate William C. Dodge in Essex Market Court yesterday sentenced Jacob Rosen, 23 years old, of 60 Suffolk Street, to fifteen days in the workhouse for his part in the Communist demonstration last Friday in front of the Home Relief Bureau in Public School 79, 38 First Street.
PLYMOUTH, Vt., April 19 (AP). -- The old Plymouth farm where his mother spent her girlhood and where his father and mother were married may come into the possession of Calvin Coolidge.

After receiving a petition charging gross mismanagement against the Roerich Museum, Roerich Museum Inc., and the Roerich Apartments Inc., Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer in the Bronx yesterday ordered all three parties to turn over the records pertaining to the operation of their premises at 310312 1/2 Riverside Drive to Philip J. Curry, the receiver appointed on April 6 when the corporations were reported to have failed.

CARMEL, N.Y., April 19. -- Presenting the bill of Daniel Wolff, former Police Chief of Yonkers, which the Appellate Division has ruled Putnam County must pay in full, along with legal costs, for getting evidence against speakeasies, Maurice Degenstein of Yonkers, attorney for Wolff, was informed today, he said, by E. D. Stannard, County Treasurer, that the county has no funds available to pay the $1,654.

KANKAKEE, Ill., April 19. -- After eleven months of intimate contact with the Farmers' National Grain Corporation of Chicago, Edward E. Kennedy, leader of the Kankakee County revolt against Federal farm relief agencies, today denounced the operations of the grain corporation and its parent, the Federal Farm Board.

DOVER, Del., April 19 (AP). -- The Republican State Convention today elected nine national delegates favoring the renomination of President Hoover and defeated a platform plank providing for a referendum on prohibition.

In an effort to raise funds for the continuation of its activities next season, the New York Opera Comique will give a special concert at Carnegie Hall on May 9. Beniamino Gigli and Claudio Frigerio of the Metropolitan Opera Company and Kathryn Newman, soprano, will contribute their services.

Production of new life insurance in March was 13.5 per cent below that of March, 1931, and the first three months of the year 5.7 per cent under that in the same time last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reports from data given by its forty-four member companies having in force 82 per cent of all insurance outstanding in domestic legal reserve companies.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Of the 9,207,995 native-born Americans living in New York State, 7,833,595 or 85.1 per cent were born in that State according to a compilation made public today by the Census Bureau. The figures also showed natives of other States, now residing in New York as follows:

LONDON, April 19. -- Interest in the stock markets today was almost wholly confined to those sections the likeliest to be affected by the budget. Trading generally was on a small scale and the tendency of prices irregular. British Government funds continued to advance.

HOT SPRINGS,. Va., April 19. -- Mrs. Charles A. Brayton entertained with a dinner in the Homestead this evening for Mrs. Daniel H. Holmes, Mr. and Mrs. Fay Ingalls, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Stimson Ingalls, Mrs. J. W. Clark and Ernest P. Lenihan.

In a review of forty-five operating utility companies under Insull management, Halsey, Stuart Co. report that while aggregate gross earnings and other income were down $5,560,000 in 1931, net earnings before depreciation were $4,640,000 higher and were more than three times the interest requirements on the mortgage debt of the companies.

HONOLULU, April 19. -- Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie was suffering from delirium with ambulatory automatism when he fired the shot which killed Joseph Kahahawai, according to Dr. Thomas J. Orbison, a Los Angeles alienist for the defense in the Fortescue-Massie trial.

Irregularly lower prices characterized dealings yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Trading continued under $9,000,000, or about $1,000,000 below an average day's volume. Domestic corporation bonds, as a group, suffered most, but only a comparatively few issues showed any marked weakness.

LONDON, April 19 (AP). -- A libel action brought by Mrs. Meurig Morris, a spiritualist medium, against The London Daily Mail ended tonight in a judgment for the defendants after some of the strangest scenes eve rwitnessed in an English court of law.

Two 18-year-old boys who had come into possession of a small pistol decided yesterday to become bandits. At the first sign of resistance by their intended victim they began to shoot with the result that three men were wounded and they were caught.

It is the mind and not the eye that is deceived by tricks of magic, and many conjuring tricks are perfect psychological experiments whose effectiveness was proved hundreds of years before the study of psychology as such was thought of, John Mulholland, prominent magician, writes in "Quicker Than the Eye," published today by Bobbs-Merrill.

The theatre is "the sole custodian of the art of motion," an art within itself rather than a combination of all arts, in the opinion of Roy Mitchell, professor in charge of experimental dramatic work in the College of Fine Arts, New York University, who spoke yesterday at the opening of the twenty-third annual convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At a recent dinner party of fourteen presumably Intelligent and wellinformed people almost every one present, both male and female, thought that Samuel Seabury was a Republican and was of the opinion that Governor Roosevelt had been derelict in his duty in that he had not removed Sheriff Farley several months ago, before any formal charges had been preferred against him.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- House leaders and members of the Economy Committee fear that the program of government retrenchment may suffer the fate which befell the Ways and Means Committee's tax bill. If it does, investigation reveals that the reason for the slaughter will be the same the pressure of organized minorities upon a legislative body without a strong party majority.

PRINCETON. N. J., April 19. -- If the American people rally to the defense of their institutions, it would mean the beginning of a new era in this country and a step upward in the progress of its civilization, Dr. John Grier Hibben, retiring president of Princeton University, declared in an interview here today on the seventy-first anniversary of his birth.

KITCHAWAN, N. Y., April 19 (AP). -- Dr. Francis J. Quinlan, 79 years old, New York physician and a former president of the Catholic Club of New York, was married here on Sunday to Mrs. Elizabeth Maurer, 31. It was the second marriage for each.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 19. -- Union College opened its baseball season with a 6-to-0 victory over Northeastern today. Meredith allowed the Boston nine two hits and struck out eleven.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 19. -- The will of William T. Graham of Otter Rocks, Belle Haven, Greenwich, was admitted to probate by Judge William C. Rungee here today. It disposes of real estate estimated at 150,000 and personal property exceeding $100,000.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Senator Cordell Hull of Tennessee, urged by many of his associates in the Roosevelt nomination movement to become a candidate for chairman of the resolutions committee at the Chicago convention, today notified several of them, including ex-Governor Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, that he is not even a receptive candidate for that honor.

With public hearings on the activities of Mayor Walker scheduled to begin next Monday, it was revealed yesterday that further evidence on stock-market transactions had been sought by Hofstadter committee investigators recently in connection with the Walker inquiry.

Liquor flowed, like water on the stage of the Forrest Theatre last night-and, since it was supposed to be whisky blanc they poured so freely out of the bottle, doubtless it was water. The occasion was the first performance of a farcical comedy that 'wasn't farcical enough, "Angelina Moves In," the work of Hale Francisco, who was concerned several years ago in the authorship of a musical comedy, "Paradise Alley."

Damage to the Indian cotton crop and hostilities in the Far East have benefited American cotton substantially and have steadily increased its importance in the world export trade in the staple. Besides, the cotton grown in this country last season is rated as unusually fine in quality.

WORCESTER, April 19. -- Holy Cross won the opening game of its season today from Brown, 3 to 1, as Bucky Mahoney, the Crusaders pitching ace, held the visitors to one hit and fanned nine. Kroeger's sharp single in the sixth scored Harris for Brown's lone run.

One of Governor ROOSEVELT'S hobbies is rural electrification. It hitches up to his plans for the St. Lawrence, but is proceeding apace even while the river remains unharnessed. The latest annual report of the Public Service Commission reviews the situation in New York State with the aid of the statistics made available by the census of 1930.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 19. -- Consolidation of the managerial staffs of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and the Union Switch and Signal Company was announced today following the annual meetings of the stockholders of the two companies. Westingbouse has controlled the other company since 1917.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The offer of the Lykes Brothers-Ripley Steamship Company and the Tampa Interocean Steamship Line to buy four of the Gulf services, operating to the Far East and to European ports, was approved today by the Shipping Board, provided mail contracts were received by the lines from the Postoffice Department.

The Erasmus Hall High School nine triumphed, 5 to 2, over Lincoln in a Class B, Brooklyn P. S. A. L. test yesterday at Erasmus Field. The winners clinched the contest in the second inning when they tallied a trio of runs on singles by Witkin and Braverman, a sacrifice by Hadley and triples by Frank Osnato and Morris Black.
The movement to preserve "roadside beauty" was discussed yesterday by leaders of civic, cultural and industrial groups at a forum under the Federation of Women's Clubs at the Park Central Hotel.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Judges in the essay contest conducted in high and secondary schools by the New York State George Washington Bicentennial Commission have awarded first prize to Miss Kathleen O'Hare of the Convent School, Syracuse. Her essay, "The Many-Sidedness of Washington," will be entered by the State in the contest being conducted by the national George Washington Bicentennial Commission.

ROME, April 19. -- General Italo Balbo, the Air Minister, has sent Captain Mario Recagno on a special mission to Greenland to investigate the possibility of passing that way enroute to North America, with a considerable number of seaplanes.

The celebration of the Feast of Passover, commemorating the release of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, will begin today at sundown and will continue until April 28. Arrangements have been made to enable hundreds of Jewish unemployed to keep the festival according to their ancient faith.

MELBOURNE, April 19. -- The State Premiers' conference as such adjourned for today while the Premiers of Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania discussed with Prime Minister Lyons plans for expending the proposed unemployment relief loan of u3,000,000 ($11,340,000 at current exchange).
With a view toward emphasizing conservation, Governor Olson of Minnesota has proclaimed that next week will be Conservation Week for his State.

No sensational developments in the German financial situation in the near or foreseeable future are expected by Douglas Miller, assistant commercial attache of the United States at Berlin, he told members of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce at a luncheon in his honor at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday.

Led by the individual brilliance of Winston Guest, the Optimists rode over Los Nanduces to the national open indoor polo championship at Squadron A Armory last night, 12 to 6 1/2. The game ended the round robin of the open with the Optimists undefeated and with Yale in second place with one defeat.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 19. -- The continuance of the Newport Casino Theatre this Summer is assured. A Paris cable received from Mrs. Moses Taylor, president of the theatre company, endorsed the decision of the board of directors at a meeting in New York two weeks ago to proceed with plans for the season.

SCHENECTADY, April 19 (AP). -- An echo of the "shot heard round the world" that signaled the beginning of the American Revolution at Concord 157 years ago went riding around the globe again today -- on short-wave radio.

A change in the method of calculating balances subject to interest, which will reduce by one-eighth of 1 per cent the interest paid by clearing banks on demand deposits, was approved by the New York Clearing House Committee on Monday and announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- A beginning of what may prove to be a national movement by the railroads of the country to recapture business lost through truck competition will be made in Chicago within a month, when roads centring in this city will enter the highway trucking business.

A wet third party, with the Liberal party in Pennsylvania as its nucleus and an outright repeal plank as the central feature of its platform, will enter the Presidential campaign if the older parties fail to declare for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and nominate candidates for President who in good faith will live up to such a platform, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Samuel Harden Church of Pittsburgh, president of the Carnegie Institute.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19. -- George S. West's greyhound, Ch. Gamecock Duke of Wales, won the award for best dog in show at the twenty-ninth annual event of the Middlesex County Kennel Club in the Cambridge Armory tonight.

PARIS, April 19 (AP). -- The Swedish Consul, who knew Ivar Kreuger and saw his body after his suicide here on March 12, formally denied today a rumor from Stockholm that the suicide had been simulated and that the Swedish financier really had taken refuge on the Island of Sumatra.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edgar F. Price gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. John M. Morehead, wife of the American Minister to Sweden, who arrived on the Europa.
GENEVA, April 19. -- The League of Nations' nineteen-power committee, meeting privately this afternoon, agreed on the text of a resolution on Japanese evacuation of Shanghai.

Daily average gross crude oil production, in the United States for the week ended last Saturday was 2,181,650 barrels, compared with 2,226,500 for the preceding week, a decrease of 44,850, the American Petroleum Institute reports. Production east of California averaged 1,663,650 barrels, against 1,714,400, a decrease of 50,750.
DETROIT, April 19 (AP). -- The Tigers backed up Earl Whitehill's fine pitching with eleven hits, ten of them off Walter Stewart, and fast fielding to shut out the Browns, 8 to 0, today.

A concentrated Columbia attack in the sixth inning, combined with three errors by Manhattan, cleared the path to a 7-5 triumph for the Lions yesterday at Baker Field. Trailing by 3 -- 2, the Blue and White bombarded Tom Garrison for four hits, which with the errors gave the Morningside nine 5 runs and eventual victory.

For Germans this is a period of intensive training in the science and art of the ballot-box. Since the middle of March they have had two elections for President. Next Sunday they will be electing new Diets in Prussia, Bavaria and lesser States of the German Federal Union.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The President and Mrs. Hoover were the honor guests at dinner tonight of the Attorney General and Mrs. Mitchell, who entertained for twelve in their home on Kalorama Circle.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The machinelike strides of Paul De Bruyn, 24year-old German marathon champion, wore out 220 rivals today and brought him home first in the thirtysixth running of the Boston A.A. marathon from Hopkinton to Boston. De Bruyn finished 200 yards ahead of Jimmy Henigan of Medford, last year's winner.

Declaring that powerful manufacturers' lobbies in Washington and at Albany make it impossible to pass legislation designed to prevent ruinous price cutting, the druggists of the metropolitan area, at a convention of the New York Pharmaceutical Conference at the Hotel Astor yesterday, passed resolutions "declaring open war against the commercially insane and ruinous practice of selling nationally advertised patent medicines and toilet articles at a loss."

Few business ventures in the United States requiring the stimulus of advertising could live without the use of the newspaper, says Kenneth Collins, executive vice president and director of publicity for K. H. Macy Co., in his book, "The Road to Good Advertising," published today by Greenberg.

MONTREAL, Que., April 19. -- A grant of $1,232,652 from the Rockefeller Foundation to McGill University for the establishment of a neurological institute was announced today following a special meeting of the board of governors of McGill.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Leigh Colvin of New York told the Woman's National Committee for Law Enforcement today that the wet Republicans have conceded President Hoover is a prohibition supporter and that his views cannot be changed.

If the general public is losing interest in the Senate investigation of Stock Exchange rules and practice it is because of the somewhat foolish anticlimax that has been reached. There was a great fluttering in the Senate committee over its private tip that the " bear interest " was about to create a Black Saturday in Wall Street, followed by one of the dullest days in the market's history.

Interpreting Flying Weather. Growing use of air lines is making the traveling public weather-conscious in a new way. Operators report a marked difference in the procedure of the man who has flown before and the neophyte.

For the first time since it began to give consideration to the question, the Interstate Commerce Commission has recommended Federal action in regrard to motor trucks engaged in interstate transportation. Hitherto it has limited its findings to passenger-bus operation.

Further weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday seemed to Wall Street to reflect the prevalent discouragement. The market was not acutely unsettled and there was nothing in the day's news to account for the slow but persistent pressure. The selling obviously represented liquidation, brokers said.

Olympic trials for Western Long Island Sound star class yachts will be held on five different days, according to dates announced yesterday by George W. Elder. The trials will be held on May 22 at the Larchmont Yacht Club, May 28 at the American Yacht Club, May 29 at the New Rochelle Yacht Club, May 30 at the Harlem Yacht Club and June 4 at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

CHICAGO. April 19. -- An oversold condition in wheat was disclosed late in today's session of the Board of Trade here when local shorts tried to cover and a rally of about 1 1/2 cents from the inside figure followed. The finish was within a fraction of the top, with net gains of 1/4 to 3/3 cent.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Adolph Dauber, 55, head of the investment brokerage house bearing his name, was killed late tonight in a leap from his office on the twentieth floor of the Continental Illinois Bank Trust Company building.

An estate of $708,067 gross, reduced by debts and expenses to $437,195, was left by Jefferson Livingston, according to the transfer-tax appraisal filed here yesterday. Mr. Livingston, who died on Feb. 9, 1931, was founder and president of the T. A. Snider Preserve Company.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 19. -- Iona School vanquished Fordham Prep of New York City, 11 to 2, today in a Manhattan division C.H. S.A.A. baseball game.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Continuing its sharp reductions of the President's budget estimates, the House Appropriations Committee today reported the 1933 Navy Department bill carrying a total of $326,340,466 for "direct" naval requirements.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities showed an average decline of one-third of 1 per cent in the month ended March 15, compared with the preceding month, and were 17 per cent below the average of the corresponding date last year, the Labor Department announced today.

Cold weather, curtailment of the free list and general scarcity of spending money have served to make a big reduction in American League attendance since President Hoover tossed out the first ball a week ago, but the same factors apparently have bad little effect on fans of the National League.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 19. -- Continuing their parade through the Mason and Dixon tennis tournament, the four members of the United States Davis Cup team advanced to the quarter-final round today without losing a set.

The eighth annual exhibition of the Grand Central School of Art was opened yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Galleries with a reception and tea. Crowds interested in the "futures" in American art gathered to view the five hundredodd canvases and to hear the announcement of awards.
For the second time in two days an Industrial project featured the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday. Proposed construction of an addition to a Bayonne oil plant was reported Monday.

Yesterday's was again a drifting market; it reflected mostly the scattered sales, by holders of both stocks and bonds, which has been the recent deadweight on movement of prices. In this regard the market appears merely to reflect the perplexity and discouragement, doubtless also the less favorable condition of individual balance sheets, which has overhung all financial transactions of the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Majesty of character is often one with reticence of life. And so it was with Anna Sands, who passed quietly out of this world on April 9, bearing in silence a great assault of pain.
TOKYO, April 19. -- Premier Inukai telegraphed yesterday to Count Uchida, president of the South Manchurian Railway, asking him to withdraw his resignation of April 10.

A scar inflicted in a fight more than twelve years ago that ended, with the death of Giuseppi Berelido in Toronto, Canada, led to the holding of Frank Lombardi in Hoboken yesterday to await extradition to Canada on a murder charge. Lombardi had been living in North Bergen for nine years under the name of Frank Collo, according to the police.

Little change in the political situation was caused by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's speech at St. Paul Monday night, according to the opinions expressed yesterday by local Democrats. Governor Roosevelt refrained from giving former Governor Alfred E. Smith any further opportunity for attack such as he afforded his predecessor in his radio speech referring to "the forgotten man," which Mr. Smith criticized as demagogic.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 19. -- Samuel H. Sharman of Salt Lake City won the 16-yard trap shooting championship for Class 1 entrants in the United North and South amateur target tournament today, scoring 196 in the 200-target competition. Andrew J. Smith of Providence, R.I., and R.C. Coffey of Prairie City, Iowa, with 194, finished in a tie for second place in this division.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney is certain that prohibition showed the criminal "the way to big money," but George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, does not quite agree with him. Their views were brought out in their answers last night to questions submitted after they had addressed an open meeting of the Men's Club of Congregation Emanuel, at 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, on "Crime Problems in New York City."

With Mayor Walker taking the leading part in the pre-game ceremonies and Babe Ruth back at his post in right field, the Yankees will inaugurate their 1932 home season this afternoon against the Athletics.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 19. -- Over Time, out of The Porter -- Pretty Peggy, which races for Mrs. John Hay Whitney, scored easily in a strong field of 3-year-olds in the Combat Purse, feature at Havre de Grace today. He returned $6.70 for $2.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Hunger marchers were denounced by Mrs. Lowell Fletcher Hobart, retiring president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, in her final report, which she read to the congress of the organization today. She described their demands as "desecration" and warned of revolutionary plots against which the Daughters should defend themselves.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 20 -- The University of Rochester baseball team opened its season today with an 8-to-2 victory over Syracuse University. Seven runs in the eighth inning clinched the game for the home team.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a Democrat who since attaining his majority has voted consistently except in the two McKinley campaigns for each Democratic candidate for President, I contemplate the immediate prospect with real concern.

This country has long been unhappily notorious for its position near the foot of the list of countries striving to lower the death-rate from childbirth. In the May number of The Forum the statistician LOUIS I. DUBLIN restates the humiliating facts, but also points out certain hopeful signs.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 20 -- Andrew J. Smith of Providence, won the United North and South Handicap, 100 targets at 16 to 25 yards, the feature event of tho week's trapshooting events at the Pinehurst Gun Club today by breaking 95. Smith shot from the 20-yard mark.

NEWMARKET, England, April 20 (Canadian Press) -- One of the greatest races in the long history of the Two Thousand Guineas, first run in 1809, was promised when the final acceptances for the Newmarket classic today revealed that the finest 3-year-olds of the English turf are left in.

A truck driver, passing through the old Herrick Farm at Williston Park, Nassau County, to get a load of topsoil yesterday morning, found the body of a man sprawled on the ground and, a little further on a dying woman.

The cost of living for wage earners declined 20.7 per cent from October, 1929, to February, 1932, but the average reduction in wage rates for the same period was 13 per cent, according to the National Industrial Conference Board, which made public yesterday a comprehensive study of salaries and wages since the depression began.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Before Mayor Walker's "beer parades" fall into line and Wall Street reports in creasing purchases of stocks of companies dealing in the materials and manufacture of beer, at least one high government official hopes that some consideration will be given to the legal aspects of the question.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The possibility of precipitate action by the United States regarding the import quotas applied by France diminished today when the State Department announced that Acting Secretary Castic had begun conversations with Ambassador Claudel looking to a removal of conditions which the United States regards as amounting to discrimination.

READING, Pa., April 20 (AP) -- Manager Clarence Rowland switched his lineup today and the Reading Keys staged a rally in the ninth to win, 4 to 3, and check Buffalo's victorious streak at six straight.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Under pressure of economy, the navy expects to carry out this year its usual custom of bringing its Atlantic fleet eastward through the Panama Canal at the conclusion of the fleet's concentration in the Pacific next month.

Three witnesses, each of whom gave testimony on a specific topic connected with Mayor Walker -- one dealing with the Mayor's missing accountant. Russell T. Sherwood; another with the much-discussed Equitable bus franchise, and the third with the taxicab situation -- were examined in private yesterday at the headquarters of the Hofstadter legislative inquiry.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- A $6,000,000,000 national investment trust to stabilize business and assist relief work was suggested today by W.P. Witherow, former vice president of the Republic Steel Corporation.

Bricks in the hands of an Irishman have traditionally been considered a good weapon in any fight, and Jack Meehan, a typical Irish New Yorker, has been using them to good effect in his personal battle with the depression, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Clarence E. Huff, president of the $20,000,000 Farmers' National Grain Corporation, today denied a charge by Edward E. Kennedy of Kankakee, Ill., secretary of the National Farmers' Union, that Mr. Kennedy had been offered $50,000 of the grain corporation's money to vote for Mr. Huff's re-election as president of the Farmers' Union at the 1930 Union convention in St. Paul.
Controller Berry announced yesterday that he would vote for "any safe and sane program of unemployment relief that the Board of Estimate devises."

Governor Roosevelt's appearance as a defense witness at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superin- tendent of Banks, was set tentatively yesterday by Martin Conboy, defense attorney, for Friday, April 29. The date, however, is subject to change in accordance with the Governor's convenience, Mr. Conboy added.

Former Sheriffs Thomas A. Farley and Charles W. Culkin and James Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, were named as the sources of "political protection" for Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in affidavits filed in Supreme Court yesterday in connection with the suit for an accounting brought against the union's officers by fifteen members.

It has been prophesied by an eminent authority that we shall come to glory in "illocality" -- that instead of looking for our sanctions to the past, we shall increasingly look around the globe and take or encourage the best wherever it rises to view.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange resisted the action of the wheat and stock markets yesterday and an advance of nearly 15 points left the list 10 to 13 points higher than on Tuesday.
Brokers and managing agents of buildings in Manhattan announced a large number of leases yesterday. The renting was well distributed throughout the borough and included contracts for entire floors.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Currency depreciation, in foreign countries has had no material effect on imports into the United States of wood pulp and pulp wood, although larger imports have been shown from some countries, according to a report to the Sonata today by the Tariff Commission.

HONOLULU, April 20. -- In a white heat of anger, Mrs. Thalia Massie today on the witness stand tore to bits a paper handed to her by John C. Kelley, the public prosecutor. The paper, it was intimated by Mr. Kelley, bore the witness's written answers to the questions of a psychiatrist, in which she was alleged to have admitted a rift with her husband, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity shows a decline to a new low of 23.2 from 25.2 for the preceding week and 54.9 for the corresponding week last year. The decline in the index for last week represents a lower rate of operations by United States Steel subsidiaries, independents having shown an increase.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP). -- Within San Quentin's sea-splashed walls Tom Mooney, for perhaps the last time, went about his daily chores today outwardly unconcerned that a decision will be announced in a few hours on his fifteen-year fight for freedom and exoneration.

We are indebted to Leopold Stokowski -- as we are indebted to him for so much which has advanced the cause of music -- for a most valuable and hitherto (in these parts) lacking documentation of a phase of the creative development of Arnold Schonberg.

Like most general impressions about the American people, ideas about the mobility of our population are greatly exaggerated. It is not true that only the exceptional American lives in the State in which he was born. Figures from the Census Bureau show that even in New York three out of every five persons are natives of the State.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 20 -- Playing one of the greatest rounds of her golfing career, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare defeated Miss Grace Amory of the Seminole Club, Palm Beach. 7 and 6, in the final of the Old Bominion championship over the Homestead course today.

TOKYO, April 20 -- Fresh advances by recalcitrant forces, unopposed by Manchoukuo troops, in regions from which Japanese troops recently retired and threats of labor unrest on the Chinese Eastern Railway are causing anxiety regarding the situation in North Manchuria, according to reports received at the War Office here from Mukden headquarters.

Reed Harris, the expelled editor of The Spectator at Columbia, was reinstated into the academic fold yesterday and he immediately resigned from the university. The forces of collegiate liberality claimed a thorough victory, and the bronze Alma Mater of the library steps again became rid of public orators.

TOKYO, April 20 -- The draft resolution of the League of Nation's committee of nineteen powers for the settlement of the Shanghai problem fails to satisfy Japan, and it is intimated that if it is adopted Japan probably will not send representatives to the public session of the Assembly in Geneva.

Albert E. Radert, an expert accountant for the Federal Department of Justice, was called as a surprise witness yesterday by Thomas F. Kane, Assistant District Attorney, in the trial of Nicholas C. Partos, organizer of a drug store chain, now in the hands of a receiver, on an indictment alleging the theft of $625 from a woman investor in stock of the chain.

One gunman was killed and his companion seriously wounded in a pistol battle with two policemen early this morning after they had held up three men in a cordial shop at 600 West 135th Street and robbed them of $33.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A House committee was told today by Representative Blanton that William Wolff Smith, general counsel for the Veterans' Bureau, was a member of a "clique that has been robbing the government for a number off years."

Eddie Pipgras, rookie right hander, held the Toronto Maple Leafs to eight scattered hits at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday and Jersey City scored an easy 11 -- 2 victory to even the series at two games each. Pipgras had a shut-out until the ninth, when Ray Fritz hit a home run with one on base.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- There were 17,628 pilots and 7,476 aircraft holding Department of Commerce licenses on the first of this month, Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said today. This is a light decrease since Jan. 1, when there were 17,739 licensed pilots and 7,553 licensed aircraft.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20 -- Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers provided a decided upset in the quarter-finals of the Mason and Dixon tennis tourney today by turning back John Van Ryn of Philadelphia, Davis Cup star and fourth ranking player in the country, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Subpoenas were served today upon ten of twenty-six brokerage houses whose records are desired by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in connection with its investigation of short selling in the securities market.

It is agreeable to record another successful production by the Spanish players. Their New York engagement has won them deserved appreciation. The Guerrero-Mendoza Company has presented a large repertory, pleasantly varied, from Lope de Vega, through such an old battlepiece as the "Don Juan Tenorio" of Zorilla, down to the most modern writers for the Spanish stage.

One of Connecticut's plans in its six-year program to improve fishing and hunting conditions in the State resulted in the selection of a sports advisory council that will act in conjunction with the State board of fish and game, and tomorrow this group, including some of the State's well known sportsmen, will convene in Hartford for the first time.
SYRACUSE, April 20 (AP) -- Mayor Rolland B. Marvin sat down this morning to a breakfast costing a couple of cents or so. Lunch and dinner ran his grocery bill for the day to exactly 9 cents.

Three nonchalant robber's attired in evening dress sauntered into The Brook, an exclusive club at 111 East Fifty-fourth Street, shortly after 10:30 o'clock last night, held up three employes and a member of the club who walked in while they were there, and escaped with $1,700 after imprisoning their victims in an automatic elevator.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- An appeal from the stage to be spared higher admission taxes was laid before the Senate Finance Committee by old troupers who played Cripple Creek "before the railroad was built," and producers, musicians, stage hands and scenery artists who later shared their success on Broadway.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 20 -- Responsibility for the wrecking of the Canadian National steamship Prince David on a Bermuda coral reef, when the ship was en route from Boston to Bermuda on March 13, was laid to the alleged incompetence of Captain William McKay and her second and third officers, in the judgment of a marine court of inquiry, the full text of which was released here today.

BERLIN, April 20 -- The Boerse opened weak today, responding to the declines in European and American markets yesterday. The upward movement of Farben, however, soon led the way to all around recovery. Prices later were irregular, with the close at about yesterday's levels.
The City College baseball team sent across runs in three different innings and blanked the Stevens Tech nine, 3 to 0, at Castle Point Field in Hoboken yesterday.

Another day, the fiftieth since the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was stolen from his parents' home near Hopewell, N.J., passed yesterday without apparent progress toward the restoration of the baby.

A renewed campaign to have a "clean and moral Forty-second Street before April 30" and to make that thoroughfare "safe for out-of-towners and New Yorkers alike" was announced yesterday by the Forty-second Street Property-Owners and Merchants Association, Inc.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 20 -- Following its away-from-home defeats by Pennsylvania and Columbia, the Harvard nine opened its home season today by defeating the University of Maine, 11 to 2.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 20 (AP) -- Sally, a mere schoolgirl in the elephant world with her 3,000 pounds, died in the city zoo today of somthing akin to an old-fashioned "tummyache."

LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- An Exchange Telegraph dispatch from Amsterdam today said the Bank of the Netherlands had decided to withdraw all the gold that it holds abroad, amounting to 103,000,000 florins ($41,200,000), principally in the United States.

Mayor Walker and Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee were the principal targets yesterday of attacks launched by civic groups and individuals against the bus franchise program approved by the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate in executive session on Tuesday.

Major George Haven Putnam, president of G. P. Putnam's Sons and dean of American publishers, who died on Feb. 27, 1930, left his estate of $776,168 gross and $675,540 net principally to his widow and five children, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

JACKSON, Mich., April 20 (AP) -- Robert O. Lord, president of the Guardian Detroit banking group, said in an address before the Jackson Chamber of Commerce tonight that the true wealth of America is intact, regardless of what ledgers may show.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Ganson Depew of Buffalo are at the Ritz-Carlton.

State of Minnesota. The State of Minnesota plans to market a new issue of $10,000,000 of highway bonds on May 10, according to private advices received here yesterday. Previous reports from Minnesota had indicated that only $7,000,000 would be sold.

PARIS, April 20 (AP) -- The American Aid Society today confirmed reports published in Paris newspapers that Ruth Putnam Mason, American actress and producer, was being held in St. Lazare prison on a charge of issuing worthless checks.

Mayor Walker's committee to organize the "beer for taxation" demonstration on May 14 began its work yesterday in temporary headquarters at the Manhattan Municipal Building under the chairmanship of First Deputy Police Commissioner Philip D. Hoyt, who was chosen for the position because of his knowledge of traffic conditions.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Following is the text of Secretary Mills's letter to Senator Oddie:

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A protest that "ardent drys" have been picked for key positions in the Republican National Convention was sent tonight to Senator Fess, national chairman, by the Chicago branch of the Republican Citizens Committee against National Prohibition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- William D. MacQuesten, former Mayor of Mount Vernon and Edison Pioneer, who died April 9, left his entire estate in trust for a cousin, Charlotte S. Tilton of Garden Avenue, Mount Vernon, according to the will filed for probate here today.
"The Blue Bird." a Russian revue headed by Yascha Yushny, will open tonight at the Cort Theatre.

A total of 112 raids on as many alleged drinking resorts, most of them small basement places, have been made by agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, since last Monday, when a drive was begun to close every place listed in the administrator's recently compiled directory of Manhattan speakeasies.

Condemnation of extravagance in government, mingled with pleas for free industry and extension of the "open shop," were the notes sounded most frequently yesterday by speakers at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the National Metal Trades Association at the Hotel Commodore.

During the last few weeks there has been a great rise in the tide of popular demand that the prohibition law be either repealed or modified. But the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement is as resolved as ever to mop it back. Yesterday these admirably consistent women served notice on President HOOVER that they would not support him as a personal Dry standing upon a Wet platform.

The railroads were represented as overtaxed in a plea for a general reduction of government expenditures made by F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, in a radio broadcast last night. He asserted that government activities had been expanded too much in the last decade.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20 -- Army won its fourth straight baseball game today at the expense of Temple University, defeating the Philadelphia Collegians in a well-played contest, 5 to 1.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Either nullification or repeal of the prohibition laws are two extremes toward which this country is headed, according to several members of the Wickersham Commission who have followed conditions since their report was presented to President Hoover fifteen months ago.

Senator CORDELL HULL was so moved by the Pauline fervor of Governor ROOSEVELT'S St. Paul speech that he telegraphed his felicitations. He was particularly struck by the "fine restraint" that pervaded an address which "rose to the highest "level of statesmanship and humani"tarianism."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The former British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Sir Austen Chamberlain, makes a fervent appeal for cancellation in a statement appearing in THE TIMES. Reparations and war debts, from the European point of view, must be canceled and the slate wiped clean.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Alleged unconstitutionality of the Davis-Kelly coal stabilization bill continued today to hold the attention of the Senate subcommittee on mines which is considering the measure.

Gene Tunney and Mrs. Tunney were the guests of Mayor "Chubby" Klee and his staff of officials yesterday. Mayor Klee -- although he has not passed his fifteenth birthday -- is already a prominent east side official. He heads the recently formed Boys' Brotherhood Republic at 282 East Third Street, a group of "reformed crap-shooters" who no longer steal apples -- not even green ones -- from the fruit vendors.
Babe Ruth, his health apparently restored to par, sounded the keynote in his own favorite fashion for a highly successful opening of the home schedule at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A less spectacular national policy than that which has characterized the last two administrations of the Daughters of the American Revolution was foreshadowed tonight with the nomination of an uncontested slate of officers, headed by Mrs. William Russell Magna of Holyoke, Mass.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will not personally enter the preferential primary contest in Massachusetts, in which he is being opposed by Governor Roosevelt. Announcement was made yesterday at the Smith headquarters in the Empire State Building of the decision, reached after a conference of supporters here and telephone consultation with his campaign managers in Massachusetts.

White Favored in Summer Lines. Buying preparations now under way in the wholesale trades here indicate that an exceptionally good white season in Summer merchandise is in prospect. Orders are gaining steadily for white styles in apparel, handbags, shoes and millinery, and the view prevails that the next two weeks will see a heavy influx of both new business and reorders.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Persistent liquidation in May wheat resulted today in increased pressure on the new-crop months on the Board of Trade here. Reports of crop damage in the West and Southwest decreased, and lacking aggressive support, prices declined 1 3/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish, May leading.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Roosevelt returned to the Executive Mansion early this evening after his trip from St. Paul, the homeward journey having been broken by a stop at Rochester, where he delivered an address at a luncheon of the International Society for Crippled Children, in which he insisted that the social welfare activities of the government must not be reduced too drastically in seeking economies.

LONDON, April 20 -- Princess Betty, who some day may be England's second Queen Elizabeth, will celebrate her sixth birthday tomorrow, and the important thing to keep in mind is that she will be "really grown up."

MELBOURNE, April 20 -- As the Commonwealth Government is unwilling to issue securities on behalf of New South Wales because of that State's internal and external defaults, the Labor Government of Premier J.T. Lang is unable to participate in the unemployment relief scheme applied today elsewhere in Australia.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 20 Williams opened its baseball season today with a victory over Norwich, 8 -- 4. Coane of Norwich and Bartlett of Williams hit home runs.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP) -- Sam Gray pitched his second shut-out game of the year against Chicago today as the Browns defeated the White Sox, 5 to 0.

James M. Fairbanks, 40 years old, former office manager for the brokerage firm of Tucker, Anthony Co., at 120 Broadway, was to have been sentenced yesterday for the theft of $290,000 from his employers. But at the time the court was convening employes of the Dixie Hotel found Fairbanks's pajama-clad body on the roof of a three-story extension.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Announcement that bids would be received on a new issue of ninety-one-day Treasury bills in the amount of about $50,000,000, to be dated April 27, was made today by Secretary Mills. They will mature July 27. The proceeds will be employed to retire an issue of $50,937,000 maturing the same date, and it was anticipated that the allocation would be in about the amount of the old issue.

The second edition of the "Theatre in Art" exhibition, which opened yesterday at the Sidney Ross Gallery, 22 East Fifty-fifth Street, is, if anything, better than the first. Many of the old head-liners are still on the bill and about a score of fresh features have been introduced in addition to a special act devoted exclusively to scenic and costume designs.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, officially confirmed today reports that the company is negotiating for the sale of the foreign properties of its subsidiary company, the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company, to the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
