NEWARK, N.J., April 20 (AP) -- Coming back with two big innings after Rochester had scored five times in the fourth, the Newark Bears decisively defeated the 1931 International League champions, 11 to 7, today.

Several witnesses testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer in the Bronx in the suit brought by John Irwin and fifty other members of Local 125, International Union of Operating Engineers, against John Possehl, international president, and the officers of the local.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 -- Bob Lassiter, who took Albie Booth's place last Fall, scored three touchdowns for the Tale varsity eleven today in a hard scrimmage against other members of the varsity squad. In all, the team led by Captain Wilbur tallied five times in thirty-five minutes, Marting accounting for the two other touchdowns.
Residential deals provided the bulk of realty activity in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

Plans of a six-story hotel for the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street were filed for approval yesterday with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings by the 85 Park Avenue Corporation of 17 East Forty-second Street. A.F. Darrin, the architect, estimates the cost at $100,000.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Employment in New York City remained at a comparatively low level in practically all lines and considerable unemployment prevailed during March, the government's Employment Service reported today in a bulletin, which also said that there was no marked improvement in New York State, and only slight improvement throughout the country.

Edwin Markham's "The Man With the Hoe" was probably the most profitable poem ever written, for it has earned its author $250,000 in the last thirty-three years, Mr. Markham said in an interview yesterday. It has been translated into nearly forty languages, 250,000 copies of it in book form have been sold, and it has provided the basis for about 1,500 lectures by Mr. Markham.

Mild rallies in railroad issues were chiefly responsible for a slight grain in the domestic corporation bond average on the Stock Exchange yesterday, since industrial and utility bonds showed considerable price irregularity. United States Government bonds were again lower, while foreign loans as a group held reasonably steady in slightly more active trading.
DUBLIN, April 20 -- The bill to remove the oath of allegiance from the Irish Free State Constitution was passed on first reading in the Dail Eireann today with only one dissenting voice.

At meeting of Class A and Class B stockholders of the Federal Water Service Corporation yesterday new directors were elected by the stockholders, with the result that all representatives of the Tri-Utilities Corporation were eliminated from the board.

BALBOA, C.Z., April 20 -- Abolition of the Panama Railroad Steamship Line, as proposed in Washington, would bring an average involuntary contribution to the American Merchant Marine from Canal Zone American employes up to $200 to $300 a year, in the opinion of C.F. Wahl, acting head of the labor organizations here.

Yesterday's uncertain movement of financial markets gave what was taken as a picture of greater cheerfulness, because, in parts of both markets, a perceptible trend of recovery was visible. It made perhaps the less impression because the recovery was not general.

Appeal of the Salvation Army. No agency of relief has done more effective work during the recent hard times than the Salvation Army. Under great difficulties its activities have been enlarged, the number of persons who look to it for aid having so greatly increased.

STOCKHOLM, April 20 -- Communism, which has been a negligible factor in Swedish politics, has made great strides in the last five weeks, it is generally agreed here, as a result of the revelations that followed the suicide of Ivar Kreuger.

BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP) -- Reaching Claset, Pomorski and Beam for eleven hits, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Montreal Royals, 9 to 4, in the fourth game of the series today. Jack Hopkins held the visitors to five hits, while Ralph Boyle led the Oriole attack with a triple, double and two singles.

HAVANA, April 20 (AP) -- Making good time under adverse weather conditions, the schooner Windjammer from New Orleans and the thirty-two-foot yawl Marlen II, owned by Kent Curtis of Captiva, Fla., were named the winners in the two divisions of the third annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race tonight.

TOKYO, April 20 (AP) -- General Sadao Araki, Minister of War, told Japanese reporters in a train interview that it might be necessary to send more troops to Manchuria if the threats of rebels against the new government continued to grow.

PARIS April 20 -- Prime Minister MacDonald's visit here today en route to Geneva, instead of being the perfunctory stopping off for a few hours that every one had expected, brought a dramatic turn of events that included a visit by Ambassador Edge to Premier Tardieu, a conversation between the French and British Premiers and finally a sudden announcement that M. Tardieu was going to Geneva.
PARIS, April 20 -- Another import quota materially affecting American exports to France of cotton and artificial silk socks and stockings was announced today in an official government decree.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The administration was in the dark tonight concerning the questions that will be discussed by Premiers and Foreign Ministers of Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy with Secretary Stimson tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The burning question of what is wrong with the Giants went on display today as part of Philadelphia's National League inaugural, but so far as a gathering of 12,000 was able to discern the afternoon's proceedings revealed nothing enlightening.

PARIS, April 20 -- Opening steady today, the Bourse began with fairly animated trading which later subsided and a large proportion of the stocks declined. The rise in wheat made a favorable impression and part of the list was active for a time.

The celebration of Passover began at nightfall yesterday and, as the sun was setting, Orthodox, Conserva- tive and Reform Jews gathered at their homes or community centres, where Sedar services were held. Special arrangements bad been made to provide unleavened bread for Jewish unemployed.

PARIS, April 20 -- The British Government's action in wiping the slate of reparations and war debts by omitting these items from its budget passed today without remonstrance in the Paris press or in official quarters.

By rallying in the closing stages of the battle, New York University's baseball team repulsed Rutgers, 10 to 6, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was a long-drawn-out contest, which required 2 hours and 30 minutes to play. Twelve errors marked the game, seven by N.Y.U.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 -- Fordham battered the offerings of two Yale pitchers, George Parker and Bill Newton, to rout the Elis, 14 to 3, in their annual game today.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Joseph Leiter, sportsman and financier, left the bulk of his fortune, estimated at $10,000,000, in trust to his widow, Mrs. Juliette Leiter, and their children, Thomas, 20, and Nancy, 15.

Four witnesses testified yesterday that they had given money to the Rev. Samuel Buchler, lawyer, former city official and former Jewish chaplain at Sing Sing, in futile efforts to bring allen relatives into this country. The witnesses, a woman and three men, were produced by the prosecution in Buchler's trial before General Sessions Judge Freschi on one of five grand larceny indictments.

LONDON, April 20 -- The portrait of Mahatma Gandhi, painted by Captain Oswald Birley when the Mahatma was in London last year for the round-table conference, has been rejected by the Royal Academy as undesirable for its forthcoming Summer exhibition.

The manufacturer, the merchant and the advertiser have done more to improve standards of art in recent years than have teachers of art in the schools, Dr. Herbert B. Bruner, director of the bureau of curriculum research at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although the iron and steel business remains dull, "constructive features" are present and there are signs of reviving demand, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This publication emphasizes the slow improvement in steel demand resulting from the aggressive sales efforts of automobile manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- With developments in Congress today indicating that any proposal for extension of the Hoover moratorium on international debts will face determined opposition, administration officials took the position that the action of the British Government in omitting reference to war debts and reparations in the budget submitted to Parliament yesterday should not be accepted as conclusive evidence that payments to the United States in the next fiscal year would be withheld.

The Common Council of Detroit has declared formally that the sinking fund and interest charges on its debt are prior liens on all taxes for the current fiscal year, according to word received here yesterday by bankers who have been active in marketing the city's bonds.

The greatest single lesson learned by the American people in the World War was the necessity of mobilizing the entire nation and its resources not only components such as the army and navy, declared Bernard M. Baruch in an address last night befor the Military Intelligence Reserve Society of New York at the Army and Navy Club.
SEATTLE, April 20 -- The possibility that Washington will have two Democratic National Committeemen appointed to fill the vacancy caused by the death of A. Scott Bullitt was seen today.

ROCHESTER, April 20 -- A warning against excessive cuts in governmental, social and welfare activities in seeking general reduction of costs was sounded by Governor Roosevelt at a luncheon of the International Society for Crippled Children, in convention here today.

Ha Ha and Waylayer, which had a duel in the first race of the metropolitan season last Saturday, fought it out again in the Newtown Claiming Stakes at Jamaica yesterday, with Ha Ha winning once more. When they met under level weight on the opening day of the meeting, the W.R. Coe colorbearer won by six lengths.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 20 (AP) -- The colors of Admiral Cary T. Grayson were very much in the limelight at Havre de Grace today, his fast sprinter, Happy Scott, coming back after Gay Party's clever victory in the second race to score over a fast field in the running of the featured Everglades Purse.

A letter from President Hoover expressing interest in the celebration of the Union Square centenary to be held on Saturday was made public yesterday by its recipient, A.M. Plyer, chairman of the Union Square Centennial Committee. The letter said:

A $1,500,000 realty investment deal in the Pennsylvania Station zone was announced yesterday by J. Clarence Davies, who bought the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and West Thirty-third Street in one of the largest all-cash transactions of the year.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- Before an opening-day crowd of 22,995 that filled League Park to overflowing, George Uhle let down his former Cleveland mates with five hits and pitched the Tigers to a 2-to-1 victory.

BALTIMORE, April 20 -- I.A. Hirschmann, director of publicity at Lord Taylor of New York, urged the Baltimore Advertising Club today to "advertise higher priced merchandise" and not to "undersell America" or "trade America down."

Because railway shares were favored above other classes of stocks yesterday, Wall Street concluded that the liquidating movement was narrowing down to limited groups, particularly among the industrial and miscellaneous issues. Brokers again stressed the light volume -- the day's turnover on the Stock Exchange was less than 1,000,000 shares.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Speaking today at the annual meeting of the Illinois Central Railroad, L.A. Downs, president, said the net deficit after taxes and charges for the first quarter of 1932 was estimated at $843,000, against a net deficit of nearly $3,000,000 in the corresponding period last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 -- Lehigh defeated, the Princeton nine today, 4 to 3, a last inning Princeton rally being cut short when Grier, Lehigh shortstop, made a beautiful catch of a line drive from Craig's bat with two Tigers on the bases.

VIENNA, April 20 -- The International Chamber of Commerce, which since Saturday had been discussing at Innsbruck how economic cooperation in Central Europe could best be achieved, broke up today without reaching any agreement except on the broadest principles.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Continuing the hearing on the bonus bill, the House Ways and Means Commit- tee today heard two more veterans assail the proposed $2,400,000,000 payment. They were Colonel Benjamin F. Castle and Captain Knowlton Durham, both of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 20 -- Finding a warm, sunny day with a light wind that veered a bit down the course, the sturdy veteran Bill Haines, who coaches the varsity crews of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, today put his men through their last hard drill before the opening race against Yale at Derby Saturday.

Controller Charles W. Berry challenged Mayor Walker yesterday to prepare real economy program to restore public confidence in the City Administration and improve the standing of its bonds in the investment market. If such a program is not forthcoming within the next three or four weeks, he indicated, he will present one of his own.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although no other spot in the country rests smugly assured in the magnificence and grandeur of New York, and although here imposing structures, contending for elaborate perfection, awe the stranger with a luxury which even reaches the point of extravagant wastefulness, yet no backwoods town would permit, in its meager environs, such an unkept, distasteful blot as New York's City Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Bureau of Aeronautics and the non-flying officers of the Navy Department were reported to be at odds today as the result of the House Appriations Committee's recommendation of a drastic reduction in flight pay allowances to naval aviators.

TRENTON, N.J., April 20 -- Action by the Republican Senate on the governmental reorganization program of Governor A. Harry Moore, which calls for a consolidation of functions into a cabinet of twelve departments, was abandoned indefinitely today with the substitution of a proposal to place full power over all State funds in the hands of the Governor in the interest of economical operation of the government.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 20 (AP) -- Broadway was named in a divorce suit today by Carl L. Shotter, electrical engineer, as the lure which caused his wife to desert him. His wife, Mrs. Laura Josephine Shotter, is a niece of O.O. McIntyres and is now living with the McIntyres in Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A new Cathedral Council of thirty men has been named to constitute a consultative body for all matters of administration in the growing work of the Cathedral Foundation on Mount St. Alban. The board is composed of the fifteen members of the Cathedral Chapter and fifteen other men selected from various callings.

"Limits and Renewals," Rudyard Kipling's first volume of short stories in six years, is published in the American edition today by Double-day, Doran. The book contains fourteen short stories and nineteen short poems. One of the poem's, called "Naaman's Song," was generally accepted when published in England a short time ago as aimed at Hollywood.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 -- Miss Marion McAfee, American soprano, formerly of the Royal Opera in Covent Garden, London, was the soloist at a musicale today at the Present Day Club. Miss McAfee presented a program of songs by Schumann, Brahms, Mozart, Rachmaninoff, Debussy and Cyril Scott.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., April 20 (AP) -- Andrew J. Horvatt, former president of the State Bank of Binghamton who is serving a long term in Auburn prison for the looting of the bank, was brought here today as a witness in the trial of three directors of the bank who are charged with making a false report on its condition.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Arguments connected with freight rates on grain and grain products were resumed here today with the opening of hearings before Arthur R. Mackley and George J. Hall, examiners of the Interstate Commerce Commission. First hearings on the subject were started six years ago as a result of the Hoch-Smith resolution ordering an investigation of railroad rates.

Money market was listless, virtually little business being reported in any section -- demand loans, maturity money, commercial paper or acceptances. Quotations for all classes remained unchanged. On the Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, but street trades were done at 1 1/2 and Federal funds loaned at 1/8.

The American Geographical Society announces that LINCOLN ELLSWORTH, who shared the adventure of flying toward the North Pole and almost reaching it with AMUNDSEN in 1925, and the next year crossed the Arctic Sea with him in the airship Norge, will lead in 1933 an expedition of his own to discover by airplane the character of the vast region lying between the Bay of Whales and Weddell Sea in the Antarctic.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- Major Joshua Fry Bullitt, prominent lawyer and clubman, descendant of a Colonial family, died of an internal hemorrhage today at his home in Chestnut Hill after an illness of several months. He was 75 years old.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- Steve Swetonic allowed only three hits and the Pittsburgh Pirates blanked the world champion St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 0, in the season's opener today at Forbes Field.

About 300 strike-breakers were employed yesterday at Pier 36 North River to unload the Clyde Mallory liner Cherokee, which was docked about 8 A.M. She is scheduled to leave at noon today for Charleston and Jacksonville. Half an hour after the ship arrived the replacements for longshoremen who quit last Friday rather than accept a 10 per cent reduction of wages were at work.
CHICAGO, April 20 -- Sponsors today visualized 100,000 Chicagoans in line May 14 for the "beer for taxes" parade.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Hoover was informed by representatives of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement today that women prohibitionists of the country would not support "a dry candidate on a wet platform" in the coming Presidential campaign.

LONDON, April 20. -- Major C. R. Attlee, opening the budget debate for the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons today, said the government's financial program was singularly insular and wholly unrelated to world conditions. He cited as evidence the fact that Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain had left out of the budget any provision for paying the war debt due to the United States.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- The taxpayers' strike, which has complicated the financial difficulties of the local governments, received a setback today when the Illinois Supreme Court upheld the legality of Cook County's 1928 and 1929 real estate tax levies and reversed County Judge Edmund K. Javecki's ruling in the Ciser case.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 20 -- A $65,000 issue or twenty-year bonds, to pay for street improvements un- dertaken last Fall to provide work for the unemployed, was sold today to the M. T. Trust Company of Buffalo. The interest rate was computed at 5.40 per annum.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The House Economy Committee today rejected two sections of President Hoover's economic program affecting the Veterans' Bureau administration, thus reducing his estimated saving of $58,000,000 to $29,627,000.

MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- Foreign investors in Mexican oil fields must be compelled to revive the industry in order to help the amelioriation of business in other lines and save Mexico from the ignominy of having to import oil after having been the world's greatest producer, in the view of the journal El Economista.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds turned on some of their newly acquired power for a 7-to-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the opening game of the National League campaign here. A crowd of 30,000 saw the game.

BUFFALO, April 20 (AP) -- There were 10,119 persons living in the town that had grown out of a little settlement by an Indian ford on Buffalo Creek when, a century ago. Governor Enos T. Throop signed the bill incorporating Buffalo. The city celebrated its hundredth birthday today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Secretary Hyde tonight lined up with Alfred E. Smith in heaping criticism upon Governor Roosevelt's recent address scoring the administration for alleged neglect of the "little fellow" in extending relief to business.

GENEVA, April 20 -- The Japanese delegation received, instructions tonight regarding the nineteen-power commission's Shanghai evacuation resolution which have made the diplomatic situation here perceptibly more serious.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 20 (Canadian Press.) -- A report of the world wheat situation today, issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, shows a bright spot for Canada in an estimate of a comparatively small carryover and indications of a favorable export trade for the crop year ending on July 31.

Much that Senator BORAH said in his speech on the war debts was sound and statesmanlike. He was justified in pointing out that repayment of these obligations has accounted for only a small part of the recent budgets of our chief debtors.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- Captain Bill Graupner set a terrific batting pace today as Pennsylvania defeated Swarthmore on Franklin Field, 17 to 7.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Virginian Railway Company was directed by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to turn over to the government $4,825,241, representing one-half of its excess net railway operating income from September, 1920, through 1927.

The world premiere showing of R.K.O. Radio Pictures' presentation of John Barrymore in "State's Attorney" will be given at the May- fair Theatre on Thursday, May 5, at 9:15 P.M. for the benefit of the Adopt-a-Family Committee of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday.
MONTE CARLO, April 20 -- The committee on technical documents of the International Hydrographic Conference met today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The cost element involved in carrying out the proposed four-party consolidation of all Eastern railroads, built around the New York Central, Baltimore Ohio, Pennsylvania and Chesapeake Ohio Railroads, was injected into the proceedings today in a brief of opposition filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the State Corporation Commission of Virginia.

NEW HAVEN, April 20 -- Railroad stockholders and patrons were urged to support Federal and State legislation for equality of taxation and regulation between all forms of transportation by J.J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, at the annual meeting here today.
A few new leasehold deals were announced yesterday along with others recorded at the Register's Office.

An interpretation of education as "an all-around opportunity for life" is needed for the youth of today, Dr. Percy G. Kammerer, provost of Avon Old Farms, Avon, Conn., declared yesterday in an address before members of the Parent-Teachers Association of the Dalton School, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street.

Henry E. Schnackenberg was elected president of the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, last night at a stormy meeting in the league building, defeating the rival candidate, John Sloan, by 109 votes. The vote was: Schnackenberg, 420; Sloan, 311.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- (AP) -- A conviction that American officials and business men should change their policy toward commerce with Soviet Russia, was expressed today by Robert P. Lamont Jr., son of the United States Secretary of Commerce, after surveying the country's cattle raising industry at the invitation of the Soviet Government.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The number of motor vehicles registered in the United States in 1931 was 25,814,103. Their owners paid registration and license fees of $344,337,654, according to reports from State agencies collected by the Bureau of Public Roads of the Department of Agriculture.

PRAGUE, April 20 -- Czechoslovakia's film imports are to be greatly restricted under an order issued by the Minister of Commerce today. The ratio between Czechoslovak and foreign films i snow established at one to seven.

Six persons who did not know their grandfather's right name until recently have discovered that it makes them fifth degree relatives of Ella Virginia von Echtzel Wendel, the last of three generations of Wendels who devoted their lives to accumulating New York real estate worth about $60,000,000.

GENEVA, April 20 -- There will be gathered here tomorrow at the home of the League of Nations the Prime Minister of Great Britain, the Premier of France, the Chancellor of Germany, the Foreign Ministers of Britain and Italy and the Secretary of State of the United States.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- The slaying of a pretty 28-year-old divorcee, Mrs. Kathryn Jones, was laid by detectives tonight to her reputed activities as a "tipster" for prohibition agents.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A questionnaire asking what effect the anti-trust laws have had on trade and what changes might be recommended has been sent to many individuals and firms by Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, of Massachusetts.

LONDON, April 20 -- The stock markets were generally quiet today. The budget is regarded in financial circles as an admirable demonstration of sound finance, but there is some disappointment over the absence of immediate bull points likely to tempt the investing public.

Almost 600 athletic stars of the past and present attended the "All-Sports" Olympic dinner of the New York Athletic Club, staged in the club's gymnasium last night. After listening to a number of speakers, they witnessed a series of boxing, wrestling and fencing matches.

CADIZ, Ohio, April 20 (AP) -- A determination to maintain the Ohio National Guard in the Eastern Ohio bituminous coal mine strike region until peace has been restored and there is respect for law and order was announced today by Governor White.

In approving the form of contract for bus operations in Queens the Board of Estimate met the virtual ultimatum of the Appellate Division, which had threatened to forbid further use of the streets by the "emergency" buses unless the board took action this week.

Playing its third game in three consecutive days, and registering its second decisive triumph in that number, the Fordham University baseball team vanquished Columbia, 10 to 2, at Fordham Field yesterday.

LONDON, April 21. -- Forty-eight hours of Parliamentary and public discussion of the British budget has developed two theories relative to the significance of the fact that no provision was made for paying the war debt due to the United States in December.

MIAMI. Fla., April 21. -- Haden Clarke, a writer, was killed by a pistol shot early today in the home of Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller, the Australian aviatrix, who, pending an investigation of Clarke's death, is held at the county jail. With her is held Captain W.N. Lancaster, former British aviator, Mrs. Keith-Miller's flying partner.

The other day a Scots laddie was trying his skill among the lightly jumping glowrin trouts of Loch Lannish. His offers were accepted by a specimen that weighed seven pounds and a half, according to the estimate of the catcher. A slight reduction, reckoned in troy, must be made for the gold wedding ring in the captive's interior department.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 21. -- The Central Bank suspended the sale of foreign drafts today in order to protect its gold reserve.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has extended two mortgages which it holds from the Cinema Building Corporation, S.R. Burns, vice president. One is for $26.100 on 9 Ferry Street, extended to Sept. 29. 1934, at 5 1/2 per cent. $300 being paid off semi-annually; the other is for $19,075 on 1-3 Jacob Street, which will be due May 5. 1934, at 5 1/2 per cent, and reduced $225 every six months.

GENEVA, April 21. -- Secretary of State Stimson is exercising a calming influence on Europe's troubled waters. This is how he conceives his mission here, and it is in that way he has sought to influence his European colleagues. They have all discovered now that he has not brought any panaceas or promises with him.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Demagogues who mix politics with problems involving the national credit; Wall Street, which is "nothing but a peanut stand" in the present emergency, and groups with leaders in Congress which urge enactment of a $2,400,000,000 bonus Jaw were roundly denounced in old-time "Dawes fashion" before the Ways and Means Committee today.

The verbal battle over the Queens bus franchises is scheduled to be renewed today at the meeting of the Boared of Estimat at City Hall. The Board of Estimate at City Hall. The day, took the first step in approving franchise awards to the Jamaica Buses, Inc., subsidiary of the Jamaica Central Railways, and the North, Shore Bus Company, but this must formally be approved today.
MONTE CARLO, April 21. -- Today's plenary sessions of the International Hydrographic Conference were devoted to discussion of several important technical problems.

Cash contributions to Block-Aid for three weeks have now reached a total of $441,367,23, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization. The cash contributions for the third week total $165,782,34.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, April 21. -- Equipped with the undeniable power which the return of six of the veterans from last year's undefeated varsity gives it, Harvard's navy is heading slowly into a new season, which opens on the Charles on April 30 in a regatta, with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Talk of inflation in the currency, as indicated by reports from Washington, and a belief that the proposal to appropriate $100,000,000 of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's funds to facilitate exports of wheat, more than offset everything of a bearish character today on the Board of Trade here, and prices of wheat dropped fractionally early to a new low mark on the present downturn.

LONDON, April 21 -- The tendency was firm in early dealings on the Stock Exchange today. British Government funds rose after the announcement that the bank rate had been reduced to 3 per cent. Industrials generally were steady. A bright feature was partial recovery by the brewery stocks, mainly as a result of hear covering.

General DAWES, after he had read yesterday to the Ways and Means Committee his usual commination service, said one thing which bears on our national state of mind at present. He declared that the "mass-feeling" of the people is better than it was a few months ago.

The United Public Service Company, an Insull interest, that controls utility and ice-making concerns in nine Middle Western States, was placed in receivership yesterday by Vice Chancellor John J. Fallon in Jersey City. Hurst F. Broom of Montclair and John Milton, formerly prosecutor of Hudson County and friend of Mayor Frank Hague, were named to take over the company's affairs.

The Railroad Credit Corporation will have an estimated gross revenue of $60,000,000 this year, compared with the original estimate of $100,000,000 to $125,000,000, E.G. Buckland, president of the organization, said yesterday after a meeting of the board in the Railway Express Agency's offices.

A plan to have the Railway Express Agency undertake highway trucking for the Eastern, railroads will be discussed today at a meeting of the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives in the Hotel Biltmore. The devising of such a plan was delegated to the management of the agency some months ago and a report of progress is expected to be presented.

ALBANY, April 21. -- Changes in the personnel of the State Temporary Relief Administration were disclosed today as the members took luncheon with Governor Roosevelt and conferred on the unemployment program.

TOKYO, Friday, April 22 -- A complete illustration of the independent role which the army plays in Japanese affairs was given last night by General Sadao Araki, Minister of War, when in a public political speech he proclaimed his views over the whole range of delicate international questions now under discussion between Japan and the powers.

A radio studio party for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid will be held on the roof of the New Amsterdam Theatre on the afternoon of Sunday, May 1. Among those who will appear are George Cehanovsky, Aida Doninelli, Beniamino Gigli, Giovanni Martinelli, Grace Moore, Carmela Ponselle, Lily Pons, Gladys Swarthout, Ernestine Schumann-Heink, John Charles Thomas, Theodore Webb, Reinald Werrenrath and Walter Damrosch and the National Symphony Orchestra.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21 (AP). -- A six-race winning streak was broken today when E.R. Bradley's Chicsu finished third behind H. C. Muran's Sister Zoe and Mrs. Payne Whitney's Delicacy in the featured Martha Washington Purse, which was decided over a mile and seventy yards at Havre de Grace.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Prohibitionists defiantly fought back today at the recent drives by wets for rerepeal or modification of the dry laws.

Frederick A. Victor, New York State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, voiced the defiance of the organized drys to the rising tide of wet sentiment when he declared yesterday that any system, of liquor control by governmental agencies was "morally wrong, a crime against humanity, a perversion of government" and a failure according to the record of every nation that has tried it.

The pleasant weather this week has been a chief cause for a good deal of the luck that fishermen have been reporting after many cold, chill days. In Maine those who fish the waters of Bangor's famed salmon pool are having considerable to chat about back home at night, when the sport for the day is over.
BOMBAY, April 21. -- An armed guard was necessary today to carry out the Mohammedan marriage of the 60-year-old Shaukat Ali, an important Moslem leader, and a young attractive English woman.

ATHENS, April 21 -- Premier Venizelos, who yesterday returned here from Geneva, told a conference of directors of big banks, presidents of chambers of commerce and other commercial associations today it had been a mistake for Greece not to leave the gold standard when Britain

Maurice Schwartz last night returned to Second Avenue for an end-of-the-season engagement at the Folks Theatre in a Yiddish adaptation of a play from the Spanish of Francisco Sanchos called "The New Man." It is set in a small town and deals with a theme which has not shown much vitality on the stage of late -- illegitimacy.

The former J.B. Horner residence at 407 West Twenty-first Street, in the Chelsea section, was sold by Mrs. Lillian B. Kuper yesterday to an investing client of the Duross Company, broker in the deal. This is a four-story high-stoop, brownstone house on a lot 22 by 90 feet, opposite the Chelsea Theological Seminary.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 21 (AP) -- An enormous crowd of Japanese and Chinese greeted the members of the League of Nations inquiry commission when they arrived here today on two special trains. The station swarmed with detectives of both nationalities, there to guard Dr. Wellington Koo, Chinese assessor, whose safety has been threatened.

HONOLULU, April 21 (AP) -- The two alienists who arrived today to aid the prosecution in the Fortescue-Massie trial are Dr. Joseph Catton of San Francisco, who contributed to the testimony that brought a conviction and death sentence to Mrs. Winnie Ruth Judd for the murder of two women in Phoenix, Ariz., and Dr. Paul Bowers of Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Fishing rods and guns have resumed direct relationship to the family food supply instead of being merely a means of diversion, makers of guns and tackle, here for the convention of the Izaak Walton League of America, said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH. April 21 (AP). -- Lloyd Waner cracked out a double in the tenth inning today, scoring Grace and giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7-to-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in the second game of the series. It was the sixth consecutive defeat for the world's champions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- A new theory of the source of animal energy, based upon the observations of analogies between cellular protoplasm and nitro-explosives such as nitroglycerin, was presented today by Dr. George W. Crile, director of the Cleveland Clinic, at the 105th annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The House bill introduced by Representative Goldsborough of Maryland, directing the Federal Reserve Board to employ its control over credit and currency to bring the average purchasing power of the dollar in line with wholesale commodity prices from 1921 to 1929, was reported favorably today by the Banking and Currency Committee.

The Rev. H. Dobson Peacock, one of the three Norfolk men who believe they have established contact with the kidnappers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's baby son, landed from a plane at Newark Airport last night and hurried to New York.

MEXICO CITY, April 21. -- Thirty-five men have paid with their lives for the attack last week on Paso del Macho and other outrages in the State of Vera Cruz, it was revealed here today. In addition, several women are under arrest for spreading "fanatical propaganda," presumably stimulating the outbreak.

TRENTON, N.J., April 21 -- Denial that the board of directors of the American Light and Traction Company made purchases and sales of stock in the interest of the United Light and Power Company of Baltimore and the Koppers Company of Delaware is made in an answer filed here today by Merritt Lane, one of the defendants in the chancery suit brought by stockholders of American Light and Traction.

SACRAMENTO, April 21 -- Governor Rolph today declined to grant a pardon to Thomas J. Mooney because, he flatly declared, he was convinced that Mooney was guilty of the bombing in the Preparedness Day parade at San Francisco on July 22, 1916, in which ten persons were killed and forty injured.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 (AP). -- Buck Foreman made a wild pitch with the bases filled in the eleventh inning today and allowed Bob Rolfe to score the run that gave Newark a 6-to-5 victory over the Rochester Red Wings. The Bears won the series, four games to one.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- Comment here on the decision of Governor Rolph of California denying the pardon application of Thomas Mooney included the following:

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Corporation tax collections for March, the first payment on incomes of 1931, amounted to $103,419,000, a reduction of $72,576,900 from the corresponding month last year, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

GENEVA, April 21 -- Secretary of State Stimson and Premier Andre Tardieu succeeded today in reaching a better understanding of each other's attitude on the crucial problems of disarmament and security, but no progress toward reconciling the French and American views was achieved in their discussion.

Arguing that the proposed Federal tax on sales of contracts for future delivery of commodities would defeat its own purpose. H.H. Pike Jr. as president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, has sent a formal protest to the Finance Committee of the Senate.

The annual entertainment and dinner dance in behalf of the Neighborhood Playhouse will be given tonight in the Della Robbia Room of the Vanderbilt. The program will include Latin-American and Negro folk music and dancing. Among the participants will be musicians and dancers who will wear native folk costumes of Argentina, Chile, Panama, Cuba, Mexico and the Bahamas.

LONDON, April, 21 -- Edgar Wallace, one of the world's most prolific and successful writers, who died in Hollywood on Feb. 10, left debts of about u81,000 [more than $300,000], assets of u18,000 [about $67,680] and a personal estate of nil. These figures were quoted by The Daily Mail tonight, and according to a subsequent interview with his widow there seems to be no reason to dispute them.

Lee Higginson Co. head a syndicate which will offer today $30,000,000 Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston gold notes, of which $I0,000,000 are one-year 4 1/2 per cents, priced at 99.76 to yield about 4 per cent, and $20,000,000 are three-year 5 per cents, priced at 98.79 to yield about 5.44 per cent.

HONOLULU, April 21 -- The Fortescue-Massie trial recessed today until Saturday morning to give the alienists for the prosecution an opportunity to read the record and examine Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, who, with his mother-in-law, Mrs. Granville Fortescue, and two navy enlisted men, is charged with the killing of Joseph Kahahawai, accused of having assaulted Lieutenant Massie's wife.

BOSTON, April 21. -- After extended conferences between the trustees of the Boston Metropolitan District and representatives of a syndicate of banking houses in Boston and New York, an agreement was reached today for the flotation of a $24.000.000 bond issue, callable in five years at 102 1/2, in connection with the retirement of the preferred stock of the old Boston elevated system.

Plans to provide additional leverage for its common stock through assumption of the bonded indebtedness and acquisition of the supporting collateral of the Investors' Equity Company were announced yesterday by the Tri-Continental Corporation.

Sam Byrd and Lou Gehrig hit home runs for the Yankees yesterday, augmenting the imposing string of circuit smashes the team is building to eighteen for seven games, but as far as the second game of the Yankees-Athletic series at the Stadium was concerned the homer Mickey Cochrane hit was by far the mightiest.

WASHINOTON, April 21. -- Following is the text of the statement General Charles G. Dawes, president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, read at the bonus hearing before the Ways and Means Committee today:

H.G. Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, held out little hope of an early recovery in the shipbuilding industry in his report yesterday to the annual meeting of the association at the Whitehall Club, 17 Battery Place.

AMSTERDAM, Holland, April 21 (AP). -- No definite reason was advanced today for the drop in prices of Royal Dutch Oil shares. It was suggested in financial circles, however, that rather heavy short offerings, partially from America, with rumors that no dividends would be paid and that bigger exports would come from Russia may have been partly accountable.

PARIS, April 21 -- A sharp decline by Royal Dutch Oil at the opening was followed by repeated attacks by bearish speculators on the Bourse today. Trading became demoralized, and with the exception of some French industrial issues which withstood the offensive the entire list declined. The Bank of France shares, Rio Tinto Copper, Credit Lyonnais and Suez Canal sustained heavy losses as wild rumors were circulated on the Bourse.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Stanley of Alderley have returned from California to the Barclay.

ROME, April 21. -- Rome's 2,685th birthday was celebrated with imposing ceremonies throughout Italy today. As April 21 has been proclaimed by Premier Mussolini as "Labor Day" instead of May 1, the celebration everywhere assumed the character of a glorification of the toil of Italian workers, and important public works were inaugurated.

For the second time within fourteen months Leon Lewin routed hold-up men who tried yesterday afternoon to rob his haberdashery store at 202 Third Avenue, giving two would-be robbers an unexpected greeting in the form of a fusillade of bullets that made them take to their heels.

The high protective tariff was denounced last night by Howard S. Cullman, commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, as a burden on business and labor as well as on the consumer, and a strangling influence on the port itself. He spoke at the annual dinner of the National Council of Importers and Traders at the Hotel Astor.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange rallied briskly yesterday, with comparatively few issues declining. United States Government ans were active and strong, their turnover reaching $6,710,000, a daily total exceeded this year only once before.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (AP). -- Tom Mooney, convicted preparedness parade bomber, self-styled "symbol of the struggle of labor for its rights," peels vegetables in the kitchen of San Quentin Penitentiary.

Yesterday's further reduction of the London bank rate, which was the only outstanding financial incident of the day, had been expected, but not so soon as this. It may possibly have had some effect in encouraging better ideas of financial values, but yesterday's recovery in both stocks and bonds was sufficiently explained by the prolonged spell of pessimism which has lately governed the course of prices.
Residential properties again constituted the bulk of New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Congress is about to adopt a schedule of very high inheritance taxes. Such a policy will accomplish nothing substantial in the direction of raising much-needed revenue, unless steps are taken promptly and effectually to prevent evasion.

The identities of four members of the New York Stock Exchange who made arrangements last week for the sale of their seats at prices ranging from $80,000 to $82,000 were disclosed yesterday by the Exchange. The $80,000, at which the last sale was effected, was the lowest quotation for a membership since 1924.

A distinct novelty in the British budget is connected with the efforts of financial authorities to control the price of sterling. Mr. CHAMBERLAIN asked from Parliament "power to borrow up to u150,000,000" for what he terms "the exchange equalization account."

A shipment of $2,411,200 gold to Holland was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, representing, it was assumed, repatriation by the Bank of the Netherlands of part of its holdings of earmarked gold in accordance with the decision announced on Wednesday.

Pearl S. Buck's best-selling novel, "The Good Earth," has been dramatized by Owen Davis and his son, Donald Davis, and will be presented by the Theatre Guild next Fall as its first or second production of the season. It is probable that Alla Nazimova will have the leading role in the play, which will be directed by Philip Moeller, it was learned yesterday.
BOSTON, April 21. -- Entering unwillingly into the spirit of the occasion, the Robins today helped celebrate the Braves' official opening day by losing, 6 to 3.
LONDON, April 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Hans Lange, assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed the last Thursday night concert of the subscription series of the season 1931-32 yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall. Harold Bauer was soloist. He played the Beethoven "Emperor" Concerto -- a worthy conclusion of this series of concerts.

With lively fighting in prospect at Tuesday's Presidential preference primaries in Massachusetts and Pennsylvania between followers of Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, word came last night to the Roosevelt headquarters that another attempt by Governor Wilbur L. Cross to effect a compromise between the Smith and Roosevelt forces in Connecticut had been thwarted by supporters of Mr. Smith.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- The Washington Senators got ten hits, good for fourteen bases, off the hurling of Jack Russell and Wilcy Moore today, but were unable to hit in the pinches and lost to Boston, 1 to 0.
LONDON, April 21 (AP). -- Princess Betty became "6-going-on-7" today, and, like a grown-up lady, played hostess to the royal family at Buckingham Palace.
PARIS, April 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Controller BERRY, as befits the member of the administration charged with the supervision of city finances, has been increasingly out-spoken in his demands for economy. The Board of Estimate can hardly contemplate the budget for 1933, let alone the more immediate emergency of unemployment, without misgiving.
CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers took the American League lead today as they again defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 3, and Washington fell before Boston.

The Mereworth Stud's smart filly, Swivel, won the Rosedale Stakes, feature at Jamaica yesterday, but considerable interest was centred on the Douglaston Purse, second on the program, in which six Kentucky Derby eligibles went to the post.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. George N. Ostrander entertained in honor of Captain and Mrs. William Talbott this evening in the Homestead, preceding the assembly.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Senater Hastings of Delaware defends proposed increases in taxes in a letter to Lammot du Pont, explaining why he believes the balancing of the budget impossible through reduction of expenditures alone.

PARIS, April 21. -- Premier Andre Tardieu's declaration six years ago that France was much better informed about American social, political and economic conditions than the United States was informed about France was endorsed as still a truism today by William D. Guthrie, president of the France-Amerique Committee of New York, in a speech after a dinner tonight at the House of American Nations.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

Marked improvement in the business situation in England, accompanied by a return of confidence and "a determination to see this thing through." was reported yesterday by H. Gordon Selfridge, London department store owner, now on a visit to this country.

Four youthful gunmen were sentenced to Sing Sing terms in General Sessions yesterday, two for the killing of a confederate soon after they had held up a couple in their Washington Heights apartment Nov. 13, and the others for the hold up of employes in the Gregorian Hotel in West Thirty-fifth Street last month.

James G. Blaine, banker and grandson of the one-time Secretary of State of that name, left the financial district in the nooji hour yesterday and ate his luncheon at Gold Dust Lodge, a Salvation Army shelter for homeless and unemployed men in Corlears Street, at the East River.

After a further improvement prices on the Cotton Exchange fell back in the last hour yesterday and closed 2 to 4 points lower than on Wednesday. For several hours, the market was firm and quotations went up almost $1 a bale from the week's low levels.

Contending that reparations are not in themselves enough to account for the world crisis, which he attributes rather to the burden of interest being paid one way and another on the vast sums sunk unproductively in the World War, Kuno Renatus, a German economist, whose book, "The Twelfth Hour of Capitalism," will be published today by Alfred A. Knopf, suggests a way out for relief of this burden.

The Patriots' Roll-Call to enlist 150,000 citizens in support of the celebration of the Washington Bicentennial through contributions of $1 each got under way at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore yesterday. The signatures of all contributors are to be enrolled in a gigantic book.

Having seen the Federal Farm Board in action and witnessed the result of its attempt to peg the price of wheat, one might think that all factions in Congress would be content for the present to eschew further "stabilization" of prices by governmental action.

Jobbers' Dry Goods Orders Small. The failure of retailers to reorder on Spring dry goods again held down wholesalers' purchases in the local markets during the week, but the expectations were that stores would be in the market shortly and that jobbers would have to replenish their stocks.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 21. -- one hundred and seventeen awards have been, made to members of four Princeton football squads, the varsity and freshman fencing teams and the varsity and freshman wrestling teams, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Amoy, which is now disturbed by the proximity of a Chinese independent army, is one of the four principal cities on the south coast of China and is important as an export and import centre. American interests, however, are relatively slight.

A bank accountant testified for the State yesterday at the trial of Nicholas C. Partos, organizer of the Cornel Drug Stores, Inc., which is in the hands of a receiver, on an indictment accusing him of selling stock to a woman when the corporation was insolvent.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A resolution urging legislation to empower the President to proclaim the existence of an emergency and to order all aliens not gainfully employed to leave the country was adopted today by the Daughters of the Revolution at their national congress here.

The depression has demonstrated that public and private measures to alleviate distress are inadequate and that unemployment insurance is essential, according to Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

The late Mr. FRANK SEVERANCE quoted a Boston school teacher as saying of Buffalo: "But you are new here, you can't have much, history." Yet CHARLES DICKENS, after his visit to the Falls, referred to the Buffalo background as coeval with that described in Genesis when "light came "rushing on Creation at the word "of God."

A radical change in prohibition enforcement in the Southern District of New York, involving substitution of wholesale padlock proceedings for criminal prosecutions in all but the most important cases, has been ordered, effective immediately, it was revealed yesterday at the Federal Building.

Mayor Walker, like the lesser politicians who have preceded him to the witness stand, will be asked to explain his bank accounts before the Hofstadter legislative committee, it became known yesterday as the task of summarizing a mass of evidence on the Mayor's financial affairs went forward at the city inquiry headquarters.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A further increase of $93,000,000 in the Federal Reserve Bank's purchase of government securities in the drive to ease the money market and a reduction of $64,079,000 in member-bank indebtedness were the significant features of the Reserve Board's weekly condition statement issued today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 -- Twelve persons, eight of them students, were arrested tonight during a wild demonstration in which more than 2,000 Harvard undergraduates and others participated.

International control of railroads and submarine cables was suggested yesterday as one measure to enforce world peace, by Professor T. Giannini of the University of Rome. Professor Giannini spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Greater New York Branch of the League of Nations Associations, Inc., at the Hotel Woodstock.

LONDON, April 21 -- Great Britain's tariff will be increased at midnight next Monday from 10 per cent to an average of about 20 per cent. Semi-luxuries and luxuries will be taxed 25 and 30 per cent. A tariff of 33 1-3 per cent will be placed on some iron and steel manufactures for the next three months, pending further study.

Open market discounts on bankers' acceptances were reduced yesterday one-quarter of 1 per cent. The cut, the fifth to be effected this month, restored the rates to the lowest levels on record or those that prevailed last year from the latter part of May until the suspension of the gold standard by England on Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The House Economy Committee completed its draft of the economy omnibus bill tonight, with a saving of $250.000,000 agreed upon and a possibility that another $28,373,00 would be added tomorrow.

The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway lost a substantial amount of traffic to motor vehicles in 1931, C.T. O'Neal, president, says in his annual report. He expresses hope for legislative relief from unregulated competition.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Revelation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today of the names of 350 leading "bears" on the New York Stock Exchange on April 8 provided the first climax in what Chairman Norbeck promised to be a series of "exposures of the stock market."
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP). -- The Cubs made the most of little in the way of offense today to defeat Cincinnati, 3 to 2, and square the series.

Nassau County officials investigating the murders of Edward Blinker Jr. and Miss Rose Welk, who were found early Wednesday morning with their skulls fractured and throats slashed on the old Herrick farm in Williston Park, were hunting yesterday for a dark green sedan seen in the vicinity of the farm by a policeman about 11:30 the previous night.

John Wurtele Lovell of 112 West Ninety-second Street, retired book publisher, former real estate developer and prominent Theosophist, died on Monday of hardening of the arteries at the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled, after a brief illness, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 20, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1.713,000,000, an increase of $84,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $748,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1930.

Robert Edmond Jones, one of the foremost of American scenic designers, has been engaged by S.L. (Roxy) Rothafel as art director for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum theatres in Radio City. The appointment is the first announced by Mr. Rothafel since he assumed direction of the various theatrical enterprises which will be a part of the Rockefeller Centre.

Agnes Yarnall, whose work will be on view at the Ferargil Gallery until April 30, is a young Philadelphia artist who turned about three years ago from poetry (in which she had achieved the early accolade of publication) to sculpture. Her work has vitality, coupled with an admirable technical finish.

The price trend in commodities was irregular yesterday, advances and declines being about evenly distributed. Grains were higher, but cotton closed lower. Coffee and silk were irregnlar, while sugar and rubber advanced, Hides and cocoa declined. Strength in tin was attributed to plans for curtailment in production.

The possibility of a students' strike, organized by the student protest committee which backed John Sloan in vigorous campaign to re-elect the artist to the presidency of the Art Students' League, loomed yesterday before the reverberations of Wednesday night's stormy meeting, at which Mr. Sloan lost his fight to regain control of the organization and Henry E. Schnackenberg was elected president, had time to fade out.

Because the improvement in the stock market yesterday coincided with the disclosure of individuals, firms and corporations having extensive short commitments it was assumed that covering was largely responsible for the higher prices on the Stock Exchange.
Fourteen dogs were decorated for heroism at Wanamaker's yesterday by the New York Anti-Vivisection Society.
STOCKHOLM, April 21 -- The authorities plunged today into the voluminous correspondence and other papers left by Ivar Kreugrer.

LOS ANGELES, April 21. -- With requests for ticket reservations being received from all parts of the world, preparations are being made for a daily attendance of more than 350,000 spectators at the games of the Tenth Olympiad, to be celebrated from July 30 to Aug. 14, inclusive, it was announced today by heads of the local organizing committee.

Rolling up a 3-0 lead at half-time, New York University's lacrosse team defeated City College, 5 -- 1, in their annual game at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The C. C. N. Y. goal was scored in the second half by George Clemens on a foray through the Violet defense.

BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP). -- A home run by James Ripple in the second with the bases loaded enabled the Montreal Royals to defeat Baltimore in the final game of the series, 7 to 2, today. The Orioles captured the series, four games to two.

MEDFORD, Mass., April 21. -- The Tufts baseball team scored its second straight victory of the season today by defeating the University of Vermont, 6 to 4. Vermont held a slight edge until the sixth inning, when the home team scored three runs to Clinch the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read with considerable indignation in THE TIMES of an article written by one Stewart Browne, real estate man, to the effect that free colleges should be banished from the earth for fear of educating morons.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Formal hearings on the billion-dollar tax bill, passed by the House April 1, were ended by the Senate Finance Committee at noon today.

The taking of depositions was begun here yesterday in the equity suit filed Dec. 14 in the United States District Court at Cleveland against the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, Inc., of which Will H. Hays is president, the Cleveland Film Board of Trade and seventeen producing and distributing corporations.

BERLIN, April 21 -- The Boerse displayed remarkable strength today despite the uncertainties in the political situation. The volume of trading was comparatively light, but demands exceeded offers. England's reduction of the discount rate made a favorable impression here and gave rise to the hope that the Reichsbank would follow suit early in May.

Dr. Abraham Flexner, research scientist of the Rockefeller Foundation, will sail on the Italian liner Augustus which leaves this afternoon for Mediterranean ports. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Flexner. Others booked include:

Union Square began donning its holiday attire yesterday, in preparation for the celebration of the centennial of its founding, which will begin tomorrow morning, when the new bandstand will be dedicated.

Probably Yascha Yushny's "The Blue Bird," which alighted at the Cort last evening, should be described as an intimate revue in Russion. Like the "Chauve-Souris," it is an evening of light songs, light turns and elephantine costumes, and, like Balieff, Mr, Yushny comes before the curtain with every number.

A demonstration of the unemployed, in which many Communists participated, proceeded in orderly fashion for an hour in the streets surrounding the City Hall yesterday, with paraders and policemen regarding each other with mutual tolerance, and then suddenly turned into a riot when one of the spokesmen tried to force his way through the police line to see Mayor Walker.
Murray Hoffman, a young artist with a blithe, modern outlook, is holding his first one-man show at the Seligmann Galleries. The pictures will be on view until May 2.

Asked yesterday to comment on the challenge of Controller Charles W. Berry threatening to issue a real city economy program in a few weeks if one was not forthcoming from the Mayor's office, Mayor Walker asked with a smile if it were likely that the Controller would issue another statement.

The principle of economic emancipation as embodied in the social laws of Moses must be applied by the world if it is to emerge from the ills with which it is beset, declared Dr. Jacob Katz, rabbi of the Montefiore Hebrew Congregation. Hewitt and Macy Places, the Bronx, in his Passover sermon yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 21. -- Ellsworth Vines, national singles champion from Pasadena, Cal., and Frank Shields of New York today joined Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers, N.Y., and Warner Allison of Austin, Texas, in the semi-finals of the men's singles in the Mason and Dixon tennis tournament.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 21. -- Back from the Northwest, Governor Roosevelt plunged into his work here today and prepared for a busy cleanup period before leaving for the South. He expects to make several major appointments within the next few days.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Senator Watson, Republican of Indiana, charged in an interview today that international bankers were attempting to depress the market in order to force cancellation of war debts.

MILFORD, Conn., April 21. -- Mrs. Aimee Greele Abbott, widow of Charles G. Abbott, New York business man and Rotary Club official, today announced her marriage to Chan M, Jett, Chinese Harvard graduate and controlling stockholder of a chain of New York restaurants.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Plans for increased building operations throughout the United States brought the estimated cost of new construction, including alterations and repairs, for which permits were issued in March, to $45,390,806, an increase of 10.1 per cent over February, the Labor Department announced today.
LONDON, April 21 -- After the market had awaited it for four weeks, the Bank of England directors today announced a reduction an the bank rate to 3 per cent.

Now It Can Be Paid. If ever a Mayor of an American city had reason to heave a sigh of relief over a court decision it was Mayor CERMAK of Chicago when he learned of the action of the Illinois Supreme Court reversing a ruling of the lower courts outlawing the 1928 and 1929 tax levy.

Although slightly larger last week than in the preceding week, bank clearings continued to run below 1931 for the week ended on Wednesday. The total reported to R.G. Dun Co. from twenty-two principal centres was $4,912,267,000, a decrease of 41.5 per cent from the corresponding period last year.

Now For Daylight Saving. Tonight is the night to think about the clocks. Daylight saving, officially or anti-officially, goes into effect throughout most of the territory which enjoys that warm-weather blessing, at 2 o'clock tomorrow morning, to last until the last Sunday in September.

EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22. -- In the mud flats of Watchemoket Cove the body of Nathanial E. Jones, a student in the Harvard School of Business Administration, who had been missing since Jan. 31, was found at low tide today by Chester Mehaffey, a fisherman, who visited the lonely section in search of bait.

Canadian Bank Stock Trust Shares, Series D, a fixed investment trust, will be liquidated, according to a notice sent by the Empire Trust Company to holders, which says that the agreement and declaration of trust under which the shares were issued has been terminated by the United States Shares Corporation, depositor.

Prices of bonds were inclined to be easier on the Stock Exchange yesterday and, as in recent sessions when the advance was halted, trading slowed down perceptibly. The total sales, $8,554,550, were less than a normal day's business, while on Thursday, when prices rallied, dealings reached $14,681,000.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- Criminals as a group have physical characteristics differing from those of the non-criminal population and criminals vary physically according to the types of crimes they commit, the American Philosophical Society was told today by Professor Earnest A. Hooton, anthopologist of Harvard University.
The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds now offered by dealers:

Price trend in commodities worked lower yesterday. Grains, cotton, rubber, hides, silk and coffee all declined, and in the spot trading rye and zinc established new lows for the year. Steadiness prevailed in sugar, cocoa, dairy products and provisions.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Conditions in Northern Manchuria are chaotic, with the inhabitants suffering severely from depredations by irregular forces, according to authoritative advices received today. The prediction was made that the situation would become worse.
NEW YORK. The German Ambassador and Frau von Prittwitz-Gaffron are at the Ambassador.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- John Ashhurst, librarian of the Free Library of Philadelphia for sixteen years, died at the Graduate Hospital today in his sixty-seventh year. He was operated on several weeks ago.

Governor Roosevelt will return to this city today, arriving early in the afternoon preparatory to his departure tomorrow morning for Richmond, Va., to attend the Governors' conference. He is scheduled to deliver one of the important addresses at the annual gathering of State Chief Executives.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 22. -- Two persons were killed and two others were injured seriously today in an automobile accident on the Hutchinson River Parkway near here, which involved four cars. The victims were Mrs. George Burn, 65 years old, of 40 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, and Asa Yoemans, 31, of Blind Brook Lodge, Rye, said to be an importer.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22. -- Harvard's junior varsity crew handed the varsity a two-length defeat over a mile and three-quarters course on the Charles River basin today.
Influenced by weakness in the stock market and predictions of showers in the Southwest, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined sharply yesterday and ended at losses of 10 to 13 points.

Columbus was seeking a short route for the drug trade at a time when spices were used, not as condiments but as medicaments, when he incidentally discovered America, and it was for the control of the drug trade that the naval battles from which emerged the British Empire were fought, Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor of Physiology at Yale University, writes in "The Lame, the Halt and the Blind."

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the dance recital by children, under the direction of Miss Claire Holcomb Bloss, this afternoon at the Roosevelt for the benefit of the Cardiac Clinic of the Post-Graduate Hospital. The clinic was founded in 1916 to provide treatment for children and adults suffering from heart disease whose parents or families cannot afford private medical care.

A park including innumerable lakes and extensive primeval forests on both sides of the Minnesota-Ontario border, 10,000,000 acres in area, is a sublime conception. In mid-North America this is the only forest and lake region left of wide range.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Back of the sudden Senatorial activity in favor of Soviet recognition is the determination of some Senate leaders, should the Soviet and Japan go to war, that the United States shall be in a position to supply -- or to deny -- military and other supplies to both combatants.

TRENTON, N.J., April 22 (AP). -- The Supreme Court ruled today that New Jersey has a right to levy a franchise tax on the outstanding capital stock of the New York Telephone Company, although the company has confined its operations since 1927 to New York and Connecticut.

STOCKHOLM, April 22. -- It was revealed today by a former councilor of the Soviet Legation here that the Moscow Government had proposed a gigantic scheme to the late Ivar Kreuger in 1926 and again in 1928 whereby Russia would have furnished all the wood for his match monopolies, Sweden adding phosphorus, which was not procurable in Russia.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, former Secretary of War, whose name is expected to go before the Democratic convention as a nominee for President, is one of the members of the Wickersham Commission who contends that the Eighteenth Amendment should be repealed.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Vincent Bendix, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, sent out a letter today to 22,000 stockholders urging them to demand of their members of Congress that expenses of the Federal Government be reduced immediately by at least $1,000,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (AP). -- Recognition of Ben Eastman's world's records in the quarter-mile and half-mile runs by the Pacific Association was announced today by officials of the local branch of the National A.A.U.

In recognition of his flight across the Pacific last October from Tokyo to Wenachee, Was., with Hugh Herndon Jr., Clyde E. Pangborn received yesterday the annual trophy presented by the Ligue Internationale des Aviateurs for the outstanding flight of the year.

It is not quite true, as ROBERT P. LAMONT Jr. is reported to have said at Moscow, that Americans have been cutting off their noses to spite their faces by refusing to take full advantage of the opportunities for trade with Soviet Russia. When you cut off your nose to spite your face it is a complete job.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The effort on American export trade of the drastic upward revision to be made in the British tariff after next Monday cannot be determined until after the receipt and analysis of the full tariff schedule, the Commerce Department said today.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Gossip in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade today credited a leading local professional with going out of a line of long July wheat. This, with an absence of aggressive support, dropped prices about 1 1/2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish to a new low level on the present downturn.
LYNDHURST, England, April 22. -- The original "Alice in Wonderland," Mrs. Alice Hargreaves. will take with her an apology to thousands of American children when she sails on the Berengaria tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A quarter of a dollar with a new design will be placed in circulation by the Treasury in about a month.

LONDON, April 22. -- Another flurry in the oil market, in which shares of the Royal Dutch-Shell companies were a highly nervous centre, was followed tonight by an emphatic statement respecting the liquidity of the huge companies' financial position.

Captain Bob McNamara led the New York University baseball team to an 8-to-7 victory over Georgetown at Ohio Field yesterday. N.Y.U. had to quell a closing drive by the visitors in recording its second triumph in three days and its third victory of the season.

Sixty-three wrestlers set out in quest of the New York State amateur titles in the championship tournament which started at the New York Athletic Club last night. Bouts were held in the preliminary rounds in all classes except the 191-pound division, which drew only four entries.
DUBLIN, April 22. -- Despite President Eamon de Valera's plan to remove the oath of allegiance, the Irish Free State Parliament will remain "the King, the Dail and the Senate."

The New York Water Color Club is holding its first independent exhibition since it ceased to appear jointly with the American Water Color Society. The show opened privately last evening at the American Fine arts Building and the pictures will be on public view beginning today, until May 9.

The need for a national program for waterfowl conservation was the subject of an address yesterday by Paul G. Redington chief of the Biological Survey of the Department of Agriculture, at the Izaak Walton League convention in Chicago.

The University Glee Club, with a resident membership of 200, drawn from many colleges over the country, completed its thirty-eighth season before an invited audience that filled Carnegie Hall last night. Channing Lefebvre chose the popular "Lord Geoffrey Amherst" to close a final group of campus airs, led in turn by graduates of Northwestern University, Cornell, Princeton, Harvard and Columbia.

The centralizing of the work relief and home relief programs under a unified board to avoid duplication was urged yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor in an announcement in which he said that the temporary terms of Cornelius N. Bliss and his associates on the Work Relief Administration would expire June 1.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 22. -- Five judges of the High Court refused the New South "Wales Government today leave to appeal to the Privy Council, the empire's highest tribunal, against a majority High Court decision on April 6 that the financial agreement enforcement act, under which the Commonwealth of Australia is forcing the State to pay its debts is valid.

Mr. and Mrs. William E. Russell of this city and Pelham Manor, N.Y., gave a dinner last night in the Pillement Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the twenty-first birthday of their son, William E. Russell Jr. Their guests were the Misses Marie Johnstone, Carol Dickson, Kathryn Tolbert, Virginia Duryee and Beatrice Guinn, Houston Wilson, Royal S. Copeland Jr., Harmon Strauss, J. Lester Reed and John R. Folger.

Governor Roosevelt will testify in behalf of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, now on trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions, at a date convenient to him, probably Friday, whether or not the prosecution has concluded its case by that time, it was agreed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A plan to solve the prohibition question by placing control of liquor largely in the hands of physicians was urged today by Claudius H. Huston, former chairman of the Republican National Committee.

A suit for foreclosure of a mortgage on the street car lines and other property of the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railload Company, a subsidiary of the Third Avenue Railway Company, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company as trustee for the bondholders under a first mortgage of Dec. 1, 1892.
ALBANY, April 22. -- Addressing a luncheon conference of members of his special health commission at the Executive Mansion today, Governor Roosevelt warned against cuts in public health expenditures.

Calling upon the members of the Old Guard militia "to stand four-square against the self-seeking interests that would undermine and destroy our nation," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, chaplain of that organization, charged the City Administration yesterday with dishonesty and recklessness.

AMBLESIDE, Westmoreland, England, April 22. -- Edward Taylor Scott, who succeeded his father, C.P. Scott, as editor of The Manchester Guardian in 1929, was drowned in Lake Windermere, near here, this afternoon.

LONDON, April 22. -- There was a heated moment in the House of Commons today when Colonel Josiah Wedgwood accused the British officials in Palestine of criticizing, cramping and disappointing the Jews and administering pinpricks.

Three armed robbers whose methods indicated a flair for the dramatic entered the Academy of Music Building, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, Brooklyn, shortly after the doors opened yesterday morning, ascended to the third-floor offices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, tied and gagged four persons and escaped with $500.

The Socony-Vacuum Corporation, which is the combination of the Standard Oil Company of New York and the Vacuum Oil Company, reports for 1931 a consolidated net loss of $4,169,247 after all charges and reserves including the loss applicable to minority interests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The futility of the way in which our Legislature is attempting to meet the war-debt problem was well illustrated in the Senate yesterday.
