While Senator Borah was voicing the popular American sentiment against a cancellationist policy, news arrived from London that the appropriations for war-debt payments during the coming fiscal year had been omitted from the budget.

TOKYO, Friday, April 23. -- The Foreign Office yesterday indicated that Japan's weakened tie with the League of Nations had been further strained by the resolution of the League's committee of nineteen looking to the fixing of a date for Japan to withdraw her troops from Shanghai.

HONOLULU, April 22 (AP). -- Balked in his plan to have his own alienists examine Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, the public prosecutor, John C. Kelley, set himself today for a furious finish in his battle to convict the naval officer and three others of the killing of Joseph Kahahawai.
NEWARK, N.J., April 22 (AP). -- Harry Holsclaw walked Doc Gautreau with the bases loaded in the eleventh inning and Montreal beat Newark, 3 to 2, today. Wally Walters tallied the winning run.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Following is the text of Secretary Mills's speech on the budget situation before the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight:
TOPEKA, Kan., April 22 (AP). -- The Kansas Capitol was sold for taxes today. It was a bargain -- $4,321.80, with the city library thrown in for good measure. No money was actually paid.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- General agreement was evident today among leaders of both parties on the necessity for speed in drafting the Senate's tax bill, work on which will begin at executive meetings of the Finance Committee on Monday.

The order of "wetness" among the members of four professions is lawyers first, physicians second, bankers third, and the clergy, fourth and driest, according to the Literary Digest, which, in today's issue, lists the results of its classified poll on prohibition, taken in conjunction with its nation-wide poll.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Which Democratic candidate for the Presidency the Louisiana delegation will support at Chicago is still an open question, Senator Long of that State said this afternoon.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 22. -- Edward E. Feely, the United States Minister to Bolivia, gave to Foreign Minister Juan Maria Zalles today an explanation of a diplomatic incident that has aroused considerable excitement and criticism of the United States here in the last few days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to official statements, more than $50,000,000,000 has been collected through, the income tax. This has been, gratifying to those who advocate the Robin Hood method of robbing the rich for the benefit of the poor; but the process is fraught with grave danger to the welfare of the country, and particularly so because it is now proposed to add greater burdens of taxation.

ALBANY, April 22. -- Governor Roosevelt announced today the selection of former Mayor Charles D. Osborne of Auburn to fill the vacancy on the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration caused by the resignation of Acting Chairman Philip J. Wickser.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to see the soft-coal industry taken under government control. This is the sorest spot today in our industrial condition. If it could be nationalized, all the better, but today it shows the utter folly of wasteful competition with unemployment following overproduction.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- An appeal for a "treaty navy" was made today before the congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution by Rear Admiral Sumner E. Kittelle, retired. He asserted that the United States now has a "second best" navy, rapidly becoming third best, and denounced the disposition of Congress to "appropriate millions to enforce impossible laws" rather than for the maintenance of our treaty obligations.

Daylight Saving Time. In accordance with resolution adopted by the Board of Aldermen. It is provided that such standard time shall be advanced one hour at 2 A.M. on the last Sunday in April, to wit: April 24.

After spirited bidding, the painting "Venus Consolant I'Amour," by Francois Boucher, dated 1751, was auctioned for $31,000 at the sale of paintings, tapestries and objects of art from the collection of the Marchioness Curzon of Kedleston at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., last night.

St. Peter's High School of Staten Island opened its baseball season by defeating La Salle Academy, 7 to 0, yesterday at Sisco Park. Staten Island. Vinny McCormack, St. Peter's pitcher, struck out fourteen and yielded only one hit, a single by O'Brien, first up in the first inning.

BOSTON, April 22. -- Bob Brown, a 20-year-old rookie, allowed the Robins only five hits and proved a better pitcher than Dazzy Vance in the veteran's second start of the season today, and the Braves took the second straight game of the current series, 4 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A member of the English Parliament, in a recent Interview, said that the best brains of America were in business, those of England in politics, and that the two countries should make an exchange loan of advisory instructors in those respective fields.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- With its racing start a bit further away than some of the other Eastern colleges, the navy of Pennsylvania is fairly well along in its preparations for a new season.

Reds Lead Fa Woolen Hues. Bordeaux and Burgundy tones, forecast as high-fashion favorites for Fall, will feature the Fall woolen card of the Textile Color Card Association, to be issued shortly, it was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 22. -- Captain and Mrs. William Talbott were hosts at a dinner at Broadlawn, honoring Mr. and Mrs. George N. Ostrander.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS. W. Va., April 22. -- Wilmer Allison, originally picked to play only in the doubles on the United States Davis Cup team, today made a strong bid for the No. 2 singles berth when he defeated his team-mate and chief rival for the honor, Frank Shields, in the semi-final round of the Mason and Dixon tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- The tragic fate of a young Chicago scientist seeking data for his Doctor of Philosophy thesis in the almost impenetrable jungles of tropical Ecuador was disclosed today in a letter from his comrade on the expedition. The letter, written from Monzon, Peru, by Harold Foard of West Virginia, gave first news of the death on Jan. 29 of Thomas Walsh Jr. to Walsh's parents here.

BALTIMORE, April 22 (AP). -- Guy Cantrell was too much for the Orioles in the opening game of the series today and the Toronto Leafs took the decision by a 3-to-2 score. Cantrell won his own game with a home run in the eighth after batting R. Smith home with a double in the fifth.

The Port of New York Authority has bought real estate sufficient to obviate much difficulty in acquiring the remainder needed for its proposed Midtown Hudson Tunnel from Thirty-eighth Street, Manhattan, to Weehawken, Julius Henry Cohen, general counsel of the organization, made known at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Workers employed in the sixteen major industrial groups of the United States in March numbered 1.5 per cent fewer than in February and their earnings were reduced 2.4 per cent in the same period, it is announced by the Labor Department.

Despite its incidental crudities of workmanship, "Merry-Go-Round," which was acted at the Provincetown last evening, is an exciting political melodrama, chiefly because of its local resemblances. It is a first play by Albert Maltz and George Sklar, who are, or were, students of the drama at Yale.
WORLAND, Wyo., April 22 (AP). -- The body of Lawrence W. Heye, found under his wrecked automobile here yesterday, will be sent to New York tonight.

MOSCOW, April 22. -- Each day brings fresh signs of the effort which, characterizes the present period of Soviet activity in the drive to remedy the defects of the Communist party, the Communist Youth Organization and labor organizations so that they will cope more rapidly and, successfully with the task of getting the new industrial enterprises running smoothly.

MADISON, Wis., April 22. -- The loss of five veterans by graduation, coupled with a limited training period this Spring, has dampened hopes for a strong crew at the University of Wisconsin. Second-place winners at Poughkeepsie five times in the twenty-three years they have competed and third as many times, the Badgers may pass up the intercollegiate rowing classic this year and take their chances in the Olympic tryouts.

LIMA, Peru, April 22 (AP). -- The Peruvian Government moved today to regain the right to collect taxes on petroleum leases on the "Brea and Parinas" property in the northernment department, one of the richest oil regions in the continent.

HOLLINS COLLEGE, Va., April 22. -- The world's fastest top, spinning at 500,000 revolutions a minute and producing the terrific centrifugal force of 1,000,000 times that of gravity, was explained to the Virginia Academy of Science today by University of Virginia research workers in physics.

Gold in the amount of $14,363,900, most of which was earmarked metal being repatriated by the Bank of the Netherlands, was withdrawn yesterday from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and shipped to Europe. The shipments to Holland amounted to $13,544,900, against which there was a release from earmarking of $13,344,900.

Frederick S. Ruth, 48 years old, of 383 Park Avenue, senior partner of F.S. Ruth Co., realty brokers at 120 Broadway, killed himself with a shotgun yesterday in a room on the eleventh floor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, according to the report of the police and the medical examiner.

BOMBAY, April 22 (AP). -- Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, 53-year-old patriot, poet, orator and philospher, when arrested today on her way to Delhi to preside over a congress of the Nationalist party, scheduled for Sunday. The congress had been forbidden by the government.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs bunched seven of their eight hits in the first three innings today to defeat Cincinnati, 5 to 4, in the third game of the series.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP). -- The world's champion St. Louis Cardinals snapped out of a six-game losing streak today to down the Pittsburgh Pirates in ten innings, 5 to 3. It was the second ten-inning battle between the clubs in two days.

Thirty-nine centuries ninety-nine years and 232 days of sleeping time will be lost in one second tomorrow morning by approximately 35,000,000 residents of fifteen States in the Union when, with the advent of Daylight Saving Time, 2 A.M. becomes 3 A.M..

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on former Governor Smith's recent Jefferson banquet speech leaves nothing to be said in the way of unbiased, purely objective yet generous appreciation.

GENEVA, April 22. -- Marked progress was obtained today in the disarmament conference, due largely to the stimulation of the delegations by the presence at Geneva of Secretary of State Stimson and the heads of the British, French and German Governments and the quiet pressure they exerted.

Assailing the Hofstadter legislative committee for its attempts to depict New York City as other than a place of "sweetness and light," Supreme Court Justice John Ford yesterday ruled in support of William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner who is attacking testimony given at the committee's public hearings.

New municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $10,567,313, compared with this week's aggregate of $18,455,924 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $20,874,854. Next week's light program is expected further to stiffen municipal bond prices, since it will enable dealers to concentrate on unsold blocks of old issues still on their lists.
MESSINA, Sicily, April 22. -- Forty families, mostly of humble means, have found overnight that wealth is theirs for the taking.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net income of $9,689,433 after interest, Federal taxes and equity in undivided profits or losses of controlled companies not consolidated. This was equivalent, after debenture dividends, to 74 cents a share on 10,943,767 shares of common stock.

For the first time in its existence the Association to Promote Proper Housing for Girls is making an appeal for funds for its clubs. The present emergency has cut its income from every source, and many more girls than usual are asking for cheap rooms and other aid.

There was still liquor in Manhattan yesterday though agents of Andrew McCampbell. prohibition administrator, completed the fifth day of their campaign to close all drinking resorts listed in a directory of speakeasies for this borough which the agents, according to Prohibition Director Amos W.W. Woodcock, compiled in as many days.

Recent statements by Controller Charles W. Berry, criticizing Mayor Walker and other members of the city administration, directly or by strong inference, for failure to adopt a real program of economy and retrenchment, were linked in financial circles yesterday with a City Hall conference at which Mayor Walker discussed municipal finances with Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the National City Bank, and Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The House Economy Committee, nearing completion of the omnibus bill recommended by President Hoover, executed an about-face today and agreed to give the President blanket authority to make departmental and bureau changes and consolidations by Executive order.

The dangers and economic problems arising from a declining birth rate and the possibility of future population decreases, the tremendous increase in the number of feeble-minded in the United States and other problems related to population were discussed yesterday by sociologists and economists at the first annual meeting of the Population Association of America, held during the afternoon and evening at the Town Hall in West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP). -- Govenor Rolph was praised and condemned today in the House for his refusal to pardon Mooney.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22 (AP). -- The Calvert Purse, a dash of six furlongs, which was provided as an attraction at Havre de Grace today, furnished an upset when English Knight, a 3-year-old maiden that races for F.J. Hughes, scored a runaway victory.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (AP). -- Colonel Edward Riley Bradley, whose colors enjoy the unique distinction of having finished one-two in two Kentucky Derbies, served notice that repetition of that feat is not beyond the realm of possibility when Brother Joe and Burgoo King, his two candidates for this year's renewal of the classic, led home a small but select hand of 3-year-olds in the featured Dixiana Purse today at Lexington.

James Melton, tenor, who has established in several years a considerable reputation as a radio singer, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. The program began with a Handel aria and Haydn's "Pleasing Pain" and "The Sailor's Song" and continued with four songs by Franz and one by Strauss.

Commercial and Industrial art is far more important for today than the art stored in museums, speakers agreed yesterday at the concluding session of the twenty-third annual convention of the Eastern Arts Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
BOSTON, April 22. -- The Boston University baseball team showed a reversal of form today and conquered Vermont, 12 to 7, on Nickerson Field.
WILD WOMEN OF BORNEO, produced by Television Productions; directed by Charles Dilez. At the Cameo.

While the Senate Banking and Currency Committee was listening yesterday to the entertaining testimony of two well-known market operators, stocks resumed the decline on a broad front but in slow trading. The general list reached new lows, if the averages may be used as an index.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22. -- Yale and Massachusetts Institute of Technology held brief workouts late today to end preparation for tomorrow's races between the varsity, jayvee and 150-pound crews on the Housatonic. Tonight the Engineers rested at the Hotel Clark in Derby.

MIAMI, Fla., April 22. -- Authorities continued to hold Captain W.N. Lancaster and Mrs. J.M. Keith-Miller, aviators, tonight for further investigation of the death of Haden Clarice, son of Ida Clarke, University of Miami professor, fatally wounded by a pistol bullet in the Keith-Miller home here about 2:30 A.M. yesterday.
An alleged attempt to extort $5,000 from C.A. Cowles, banker, of Southington, Conn., under threat of kidnapping one of his children, was frustrated by the Union City (N.J.) police yesterday.

HONOLULU, April 22. -- Clarence Darrow, chief of the defense counsel for Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, who, with his mother-in-law, Mrs. Granville Fortescue, and two navy enlisted men, is charged with the killing of Joseph Kahahawai, refused today to allow alienists for the prosecution to examine the young naval officer, whose plea of insanity at the time of the slaying has stirred the entire Territory.

On the surface yesterday's decline on the Stock Exchange appeared to reflect little more than the vagaries of a bewildered speculative element. The losses were moderate, so, far as the main body of stocks was concerned, but in spots pronounced weakness cropped out.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22. -- A resolution requesting Governor Moore to start an investigation immediately of the Court of Chancery proceedings in receiverships was adopted today at a meeting of the committee of 100 for the correction of State receivership practices here.

R. Hoe Co., Inc., manufacturers of printing presses and newspaper machinery for 113 years, consented yesterday to the appointment of the Irving Trust Company and Henry Swartz as receivers in equity for its affairs under a bond of $50,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 22. -- Eli Cosman Sr. is dead at his home in Hilton, at the age of 94. He had been prominent in farming and real estate, having retired when he was 90 years old. Mr. Cosman was born in Newburgh. N.Y. Until a week ago he had never been ill. Nine sons survive him.

TOWANDA, Pa., April 22. -- Seldom have the queer cross-currents of politics been so much in evidence as in this Fifteenth Pennsylvania Congressional District, where one of the most colorful primary campaigns in the history of the State has ended.

A "service of praise and thanksgiving for the life and work of George Washington," commemorating the 200th anniversary of his birth and the 143d anniversary of his inauguration as first President of the United States will be held Friday at noon in St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway, between Fulton and Vesey Streets.

The market was quiet and steady. Business was light and quotations for every class of accommodation remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, outside trades 1 1/2 and Federal funds 1/8. Time money ranged 2@2 1/2.
Further activity in housing properties was reported in the New Jersey metropolitan area yesterday.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 22. -- The Temple University nine fell before Seton Hall College, 7 to 6, today in twelve innings as a crowd of 2,000 looked on.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- With Bill Terry embellishing the show with his sixth home run in four successive games, the Giants outhit the Phillies today, to record their third straight triumph. The score was 13 to 8, though the Phils had the better total of hits, sixteen to twelve.

Walter J. Salmon's Mad Pursuit, which made his season's debut at Jamaica yesterday in the featured Lynbrook Handicap, finished second to the Oak Ridge Stable's Mountain Elk. beaten three-quarters of a length at the end of the mile and a sixteenth.

PRAGUE, April 22. -- The Communist press has been complaining for a considerable period that Czarist Russians in Czechoslovakia are being recruited under Japanese auspices for anti-Chinese action in Manchuria.

If the refusal of Governor ROLPH of California to pardon MOONEY leaves a certain feeling of disquiet among fair-minded men, this is not because they doubt the Governor's sincerity. Nor can it be supposed that his predecessors in office who successively came to the decision that MOONEY was properly found guilty of an atrocious crime were actuated by anything except what they conceived to be a sense of public duty.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 23. -- Japanese war authorities, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi, hold that Japan should now make it clear in Geneva that she can no longer cooperate with the League of Nations if the committee of nineteen persists in its present attitude.

THE good golfing weather of recent days recalls to mind the fact that, as Paul Revere once said, the Redcoats are coming. Like true Britishers, they are coming at a leisurely pace. Though the Walker Cup matches are months away, the British team has been picked, and presumably Captain Tony Torrance is seeing to it that they do a certain amount of light drilling for the coming clash.

LONDON, April 22 (Canadian Press). -- Keen disappointment was recorded from the Yorkshire wool district today at the reduction from 50 to 20 per cent in the import duty on all manufactured textiles except yarns.
"Angelina Moves In." which opened on Tuesday night at the Forrest Theatre, will be withdrawn after tonight's performance. Another closing tonight will be "Bloodstream," at the Times Square Theatre.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22. -- This city was guarded by seventyfive patrolmen and every inspector tonight lest Harvard College students should attempt to repeat the riotous scenes of Thursday night, described by a professor as "moon madness."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22. -- Lawrenceville won a neighborhood track meet today, compiling the overwhelming score of 73 points. Princeton Prep was second with 23 points. Rutgers Prep had 22, Trenton High 18, Princeton High 15, and Pennington Prep 3.

PARIS, April 22. -- The Bourse was stimulated to some extent today by the improvement yesterday in Wall Street, but because of other influences the recovery was not general. The market opened strong, became irregular and closed with a slight improvement.

LONDON, April 22. -- With the Continent still unsettled, prices weakened in most sections of the Stock Exchange today. Despite a drop in sterling exchange on New York to $3.74, British Government funds were firm, the war loan improving to u103 5-16, the highest point since last July.

Gilbert Miller has resigned as vice president of Charles Frohman, Inc., he announced yesterday. He said the step had been taken because the company desires to suspend temporarily, it producing activities of which, in the past, Mr. Miller has been in charge.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- While withholding an opinion as to the wisdom of government aid in financing exports of wheat and cotton, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in a letter to Senator McNary. which he made public today, opposed the allocation of an additional $100,000,000 from its fund for that purpose.

Business and industry generally maintained an even, pace during the last week, slight recessions in some lines being offset by small gains in others in comparison with the preceding week, according to weekly reviews.

In the face of vigorous protest by Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial and a formal objection by Borough President George U. Harvey, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to advance for public hearing on May 6 only the applications of the North Shore Bus Company and Jamaica Buses, Inc., for franchises in Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The excessive Stock Exchange speculation prior to the crash of 1929 was "an accompaniment or symptom of unsound credit and banking conditions themselves," Senator Glass asserted in a report to the Senate today on the Glass banking bill.

The Rev. Frank N.D. Buchman, chief exponent of the religious movement known as "a First Century Christian Fellowship," which, under its more familiar name of "Buchmanism," has been a subject of controversy in this country and abroad for several years, arrived yesterday from Europe aboard the Aquitania with twenty-two members of the so-called "Oxford group" of the movement to attend a house party of the groups at Briarcliff Lodge, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

BUENOS AIRES, April 22. -- The possibility of the imposition of a meat quota by Great Britain is causing anxiety here, as it is regarded as evidence of Britain's intention to prepare for reciprocal tariff concessions to promote British exportation of agricultural and general machinery to Argentina.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A crowd that jammed a large Senate committee room to the doors today heard a scion of the Rockefeller family describe the effect of the depression on his share of one of America's fabulous fortunes.

Drastic reduction in passenger-train mileage to meet recommendations as to economy recently made by the Interstate Commerce Commission were disclosed in a draft of a letter to the commission drawn up at a meeting of the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

MANAGUA, April 22. -- Three American officers and eight Nicaraguan National Guardsmen were killed and four Nicaraguans wounded near Apali yesterday in three fierce encounters with 200 irregulars. The fighting lasted from 11:30 A.M. until 3:30 P.M. The Americans killed were:

The gentry who produce the nation's radio programs are receiving attention at the Capitol. One may see the automatic clapping machine that produces the back-stage applause for the crooners, together with the man who produces the sound accompaniment for the radio dramatists.

Mrs. Josephine L. Hanna, widow of Robert Milholland Hanna, who died on April 9, left virtually all of her estate of undetermined value to twelve public institutions, to which she grave cash bequests totaling $59,000 and proportionate parts of the residue of her estate, according to her will, which was offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court yesterday.
LONDON, April 22. -- Representatives in London of United States industrial exporting concerns were inclined today to be philosophical over the results of the new British tariff schedule.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The British resolution for qualitative disarmament was unanimously adopted by the general commission of the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva today before it adjourned until Monday, according to a report to the State Department from Ambassador Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation.

Mrs. Josephine L. Hanna, widow of Robert Milholland Hanna, who died on April 9, left virtually all of her estate of undetermined value to twelve public institutions, to which she grave cash bequests totaling $59,000 and proportionate parts of the residue of her estate, according to her will, which was offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Harriet Citron, a 12-year-old slip of a girl with a soft voice, representing Edward B. Shallow Junior High School 227, Brooklyn, won yesterday the city championship for junior public high schools of New York in the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution conducted in this region by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association in a letter to Senator Reed Smoot, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has reaffirmed its opposition to any form of sales tax, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the organization.

New York had a real taste of Summer weather yesterday. A beaming sun sent the mercury up to 75 degrees, making the day the warmest of 1932, divesting the city's residents of topcoats and sending belated suburbanites hurrying into their gardens.

Outlining the functions and limitations of a college newspaper, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in an article published in The Spectator, undergraduate daily, that freedom to express editorial opinion must be allowed to students, provided that responsibility for abuse of this privilege is likewise accepted.
The sale of two apartment houses on Washington Heights featured real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- A proposal which, according to government officials, will cost the Post-office Department and the public millions of dollars annually, if it becomes law, has been inserted in the President's omnibus economy bill.

PARIS, April 22. -- The satisfaction rendered to France at Geneva today has served to put a stop to one of the most furious tirades against the United States that the Paris press has seen for a long time.

DETROIT, Mich., April 22. -- Replying to a question about dividends from a stockholder at the annual meeting of the company today, C. B. VanDusen, president of the S.S. Kresge Company, said the company would do what, in the judgment of the directors, was best for the company.
Mr. WILLIAM MORGAN BUTLER was once described by Mr. COOLIDGE as having something about him that is as appealing as the impression that is made by a strong and substantial edifice.
CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP). -- The soaring Detroit Tigers tightened their grip on first place in the American League today as they battered Cleveland pitchers for twenty-two hits and a 16-to-3 victory.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 22. -- James A. Bausch, national pentathlon champion, gave notice of his Olympic qualifications today by scoring an impressive point total in the first half of the Missouri Valley A.A.U. decathlon competition.

Samuel Untermyer and Siegfried F. Hartman are counsel for and Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, is chairman of a new independent protective committee of security holders of the Kreuger Toll Company and the International Match Corporation.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns made it two straight from the Chicago White Sox today, winning by 4 to 1 to maintain a perfect record this season on the home field.
The New York University track team, intercollegiate indoor champions, defeated Columbia, 83 -- 52, yesterday at Baker Field in the opening outdoor meet of the year for the two teams.

ALBANY, April 22. -- Fresh from his encouraging trip to St. Paul, Governor Roosevelt stated in an interview that he is a wet, is against bonus payments at present, favors a balanced budget for State and nation, has a tariff plan and believes the government can do for the farmer a lot it isn't doing.

BELGRADE, April 22. -- Two new Cabinet members were sworn in today, M. Srulja becoming Minister of Forests and Mines in place of Dr. Stanko Sibenik, and M. Pogatschnik succeeding Dr. Nikola Praka as Minister of Public Works.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Indicating a substantial improvement in the banking situation, bank failures were reduced to forty-five in March, the Federal Reserve Board said today, compared to failures in February numbering 122 and 342 in January.

For their latest excursion into the American drama of another day, the band of antiquarians who operate on Morningside Heights as the Columbia Laboratory Players have dug up "Marion, or the Hero of Lake George," a play by Mordecai Manuel Noah, which was first produced on Evacuation Day, 1821.

BALTIMORE, April 23 -- Yeoman carried the colors of Miss Frances Lynch of Baltimore to victory in the thirty-third annual running of the Grand National Point to Point Steeplechase at Brookland Wood today.

LONDON. WHAT is the effect of broadcasting on speech? An old question has arisen in a new form in connection with British broadcasting. Hitherto it has been urged by some people that radio is tending to eliminate dialect and those local idioms of English speech in Britain which charm the Englishman and American, but baffle the foreigner.

ONE of our old-timers, a fourth offender doing a natural life sentence, said to me recently: "Things are sure different now. All you see here is a bunch of kids. And believe me, they don't know what it's all about. This place looks more like a kindergarden than a prison."

MINEOLA, L.I., April 23 -- Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey, who was assigned by Governor Roosevelt, early in 1931 to hear testimony in the suit brought by the State for a declaratory judgment awarding title to Seaman's Gore, near Jones Beach, to the State, signed the final judgment and notice of settlement in the case here today.

DETROIT CONFIDENT that they finally have carried their point that the automobile industry is of first importance in the huge task of relieving unemployment, motor executives who returned from Washington this week are optimistic that they will escape the burden of a special excise tax at this time.

HAVANA, April 18 -- The next President of Cuba, to take office in 1935, will be from the Liberal party, according to a prediction made by President Machado recently before Liberal party representatives of forty-three districts of Havana who visited the palace for an exchange of impressions with the Chief Executive.

BY signing the League's convention for the regulation of whaling, the United States recently joined a number of other nations in an effort to conserve the whale supply. The convention prohibits the killing of right whales (a species formerly so extensively hunted that it is now threatened with extinction) and also of calves or suckling whales, immature whales and female whales accompanied by calves.

SHANGHAI, March 27 -- The belated arrival in Shanghai of copies of the Constitution of the new Manchurian State -- Manchoukuo -- reveals that all the preliminary talk about founding a republic has been misleading. The new State is a dictatorship of the most pronounced type, and the people will have nothing to say about the manner in which they are to be ruled.

A plea for realty construction funds to permit the erection of new dwellings, "soon to be a necessity," in the Scarsdale section of Westchester County, was voiced by the Scarsdale Realty Board in making public yeslying sections of Greenburgh, East ing fewer vacant homes than was the case two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Turning from its consideration of the mysteries of the universe, of archaeological discoveries and matters of pure science, the American Philosophical Society studied today the factors of the economic depressions.

The sound of starlight was broadcast for the first time, it was believed, over a WABC-Columbia network from the general science laboratory of the School of Commerce of New York University at Washington Square last night. The beam of Venus was picked up from the eyepiece of a telescope by a photoelectric cell and amplified into a microphone as a sustained high note resembling one from a violin.

With substantial relief from dry conditions in the cotton-growing sections of the Southwest, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined yesterday , to low levels of the week. Owing to heavy switching operations as holders reduced the long interest in May before the issuance of notices on Tuesday, a larger quantity of cotton changed hands than the narrow fluctuations would indicate.

The fate of security affiliates of banks, which now hold about 50 per cent of the security-distributing power of the country, hangs in the balance, awaiting action this week by the Senate on the Glass bill, as amended, which would throw the burden of new financing on the shoulders of independent banking houses.

A GAY round of diversions is forecast for the annual Toe H dinner dance and entertainment to be held on the night of May 2 aboard the liner Berengaria. The event has been in preparation for several weeks and has enlisted the aid of many in society.

FOR several years the Great White Way, which symbolizes gayety, has been degenerating into a flamboyant midway, which symbolizes hocus-pocus. By day or night it is flashy. The signs are monstrous; the billboards and placards swoon with distorted faces and formalized passion, and their lettering is in a style that every civilized printer flung out of his cases thirty years ago.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- During the gilded decade which ended so abruptly within the memory of all, the prohibition laws were lauded by an enthusiastic group of their supporters as the fundamental cause for the era of national prosperity.

HANOVER, N.H., April 22 -- In an "open letter" printed in The Daily Dartmouth, the student newspaper. Dr. Gordon Ferry Hull, Professor of Physics who has been on the faculty since 1899, takes issue with President Ernest Martin Hopkins on the latter's recently published letter to Senator Bingham of Connecticut criticizing the Eighteenth Amendment as having "provided a subsidy for the underworld."

Every real home teaches a child, with but the slightest conscious effort on his part, the one fundamental quality which every good citizen must have -- a sense of responsibility. This sense of responsibility is what shapes his thought and his action and eventually makes him take his share of the common burden in the community in which he lives.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- John B. Chapple, editor of The Ashland (Wis.) Daily Press and an anti-La Follette leader in Wisconsin announced himself today a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Senate to succeed John J. Blaine of the La Follette faction, whose term expires next March.

Prices of bonds drifted lower again yesterday during the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange. In the domestic corporation list the chief setbacks occurred in the railroad group, with industrial bonds irregularly lower, while utility issues held their ground well, with a few issues rallying slightly.

BOMBAY, April 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Sarojini Naidu. India's most noted woman and the most prominent personage in the civil disobedience movement other than Mahatma Gandhi, was sentenced today to serve a year in prison.

MUSIC is called the backbone of broadcasting. The composers want more money for their music; in fact they have devised a new "yardstick" to measure radio's relation to melody. They want 5 per cent royalty on the gross income of each station, which means that an independent station now taxed $10,000 for the music rights, but making $1,500,000 gross, must pay $75,000.

Fred Cauchois one of the leading gunners in the metropolitan district, won the distance championship of the New York Athletic Club over the Travers Island traps of the organisation yesterday. He look the title in a field of thirty-seven gunners, breaking 96 out of 100 targets at twenty-three yards.

LONDON, April 5 WE hear from all sides that the theatres are playing to very poor business. We have heard this before, the plan' of the theatrical manager like that of the farmer being always with us, but this time there appears to be grave truth in it.

PARIS FRANCE is preparing for a general election. Most observers concedes that it will be the Left parties, that is to say. the Radicals and Socialists, who will this time win a success over the Nationalists and Right Centre who have formed the majority behind the Poincare, Tardieu and Laval Governments in the last four years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a listener to the radio reproduction of Tannhauser at the Metropolitan Opera House, I am moved to submit a few suggestions which I hope may be developed in the future into a national benefit.

GENEVA, April 23 -- Speaking for France, Joseph Paul-Boncour, at a luncheon of the League of Nations Journalists Association, declared this morning, "This disarmament conference will not fail." and Prime Minister MacDonald of Britain warned his audience:

New Yorkers will have an opportunity from Tuesday to Saturday this week to view the best of the artistic accomplishments of about 2,000 children of twenty-two member-houses of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc., which will be on exhibition at the Russell Sage Galleries, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Senators bit opportunely behind Carl Fischer's left-handed speed ball today and defeated Boston, 5 to 0. The victory gave the Senators a one-game edge in the three-game series.

The future of American industry hinges to a great extent on the intelligent reorganization of administrative personnel in business concerns through the elimination of unnecessary officials, who are a byproduct of the unorganized growth of companies since the war, Dr. Stuart C. McLeod, secretary of the National Association of Cost Accountants, told THE TIMES yesterday.
The New York University freshman baseball team staged a seven-run rally in the seventh inning to defeat George Washington High School, 15 to 9, at the Washington Stadium yesterday.

THE title of this story might lead one to suspect that it is about a deadly feud between rival candidates for the Pulitzer Prize. But it is not so simple as all that. Nevertheless, the murders with which this book deals do arise, indirectly, from the award of this coveted prize to a novel published ten years before the story opens.

Joseph M. Proskauer president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, announced yesterday that for the first time in its history, the federation will undertake, a Spring campaign this year. The drive will he for 5,000 new members and will have no specific financial goal.

Holding the excellent form that made him the favorite, Edwin Lake 15 year-old Jamaica High School star easily captured the P.S.A.L. individual rifle championship by leading eighteen rivals at the General Wingate Athletic Field range yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The grand offensive power of the Giants was strangely missing today with the result that the Phillies, after being floored three days hand running, were able to pick themselves up and capture the final of the series. 7 to 2.

SILVER stones beneath the patient, plodding feet of Indians. Pink towers cutting the pure blue of the Mexican sky. Altars crusted thick with gold, in tall white walls, and a blue majolica dome opening like a gigantic flower.

MAYOR WALKER'S plan for a beer parade, the interest it has stirred in many cities throughout the nation, the pending bill in the Senate to declare 2.75 per cent beer legal and the nation-wide agitation for and against prohibition have all focused the country's attention on the revenue which might be derived by the Treasury from a tax on beer.

ALTHOUGH some may think it still too early in the season for trips to the seashore, this objection hardly applies to lakes and hills. There is a great deal of pleasure in early Spring motoring into the country, especially for those who love flowers, which are to be found in profusion in Northern New Jersey and Rockland County.
HEIDELBERG, April 23 -- On my desk lies an article by Sir Austen Chamberlain, which appeared a week ago.

How large reptiles of all kinds have been used during the past seventeen years to shed light on the workings of human physiology is described in a report by Dr. Francis G. Benedict, director of the nutrition laboratory, Carnegie Institution of Washington, which yesterday made public an abstract of the report.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 23 -- An unexpected turn in Georgia politics came today when it was disclosed that Governor Richard B. Russell Jr. would announce on Monday the appointment of Major John S. Cohen, publisher of The Atlanta Journal and Democratic National Committeeman, to fill temporarily the place of the late Senator William J. Harris.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Immediate recall of the marines from Nicaragua was urged upon the Senate today by Senator James Hamilton Lewis to "reaffirm our former friendships in South and Central America, bring back the Monroe Doctrine and return to American principles, to American laws, and to an American Government for American citizens."

Union Square celebrated the centenary of its founding yesterday with a maximum of pomp and pageantry and a minimum of oratory. The ceremonies began at 10 A.M. and lasted until late in the afternoon, and never, from noon on, were there fewer than 10,000 spectators.

PARIS, April 12. -- Into the vindictive atmosphere of economic recriminations and of a bitter political campaign the French Academy has injected a most helpful element for healthy controversy by its unexpected act in issuing its official grammar.

A effervescent entertainment with a foreign flavor has been made from the late Avery Hopwood's adroit farce, "Naughty Cinderella." This picture, which was at the Paramount, has the enviable distinction of having among its players Roland Young, Charles Ruggles and Lily Damita, who contribute to the general gayety of the production, which is further enhanced by agreeable melodies.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Frederick Mitchell Gould has left the St. Regis for her Summer home in Newport.

LONDON IT is pleasant to record that after a spell of very bad luck (worse names have been used for it!) the film gamble appears to be entering upon a lucky streak. Hollywood has emerged from its Slough of despond, and even Elstree, thanks in some measure to American cooperation, would seem to be taking heart again.

THE recently announced plans of a British expedition under J.M. Stagg of the Meteorological Office to make observations of the aurora borealis at Fort Rae, on Great Slave Lake, Canada, are part of a comprehensive program of similar investigations to be carried out at many places during the forthcoming international polar year, beginning next August.

MEXICO CITY, April 23 -- A decree increasing the duty on Enslish-language motion-picture films from about $3 a kilogram (2.2 pounds) to $12 a kilogram and that on disks from $1.75 to about $7 a kilogram has been promulgated by President Ortiz Rubio.

BOSTON, April 22. -- On Tuesday the Presidential primaries will be held in this State. There is no special interest in the Republican voting, because there is no general contest. President Hoover is the only candidate. The few local ructions are of minor importance.

Spring piped another dulcet tune yesterday for New York and vicinity, luring thousands to the parks, seashore and countryside. The weather seemed to suit New Yorkers perfectly, but in Atlantic City it was so hot -- 78 degrees, a new record there -- that one man was prostrated.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs scored a run in a wild twelfth inning today to defeat Cincinnati, 2 to 1, and make it three out of four for the series.
BOSTON, April 23 -- Checking out of Boston tonight after having lost their third straight frame to the Braves, the homeward-bound Robins were chilled both in body and spirit.

IT has been remarked in these columns before that signs were not wanting of air travel's corning of age. This is particularly apparent in the sloughing off by the air-transport lines of a degree of recklessness that goes with youth. The spirit of "get through at any cost" has been replaced all over the wide network of the commercial airways with the spirit of "safety first."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 23. -- Dr. James Hrvey Stebbns, 74 years old. died at night at his home in Clayton. He was a noted analytical and consulting chemist. Born in Brooklyn, he was educated in Paris. Harvard, Rutgers and the University of Omaha conferred honorary degrees on him.

Inspector Howard E. Cudney of Hackettstown, N.J., who surveys a good many trout streams in the course of a season, calls conditions "splendid" along the Musconetcong following the warm weather of the last few days.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- One wise and disinterested observer of California politics has remarked that the issue in the Democratic primary here is whether Franklin D. Roosevelt shall have the Presidential delegates or William G. McAdoo shall control the State organization in the interest of the dry cause.

Out of Sight and Out of Mind. Just who is this Forgotten Man of whom we have been hearing so much recently? Below we give a few specimens of this submerged American type as rediscovered with characteristic enterprise and energy by the special representatives of By-Products.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- The Harvard Athletic Association today announced the awards of 192 letters and numerals to Harvard athletes for participation in Winter sports.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The House Economy Committee tonight had completed the general outline of a program designed to make savings of about $263,277,000 in Federal expenditures during the fiscal year 1933.

Colonel Stimson reports from Geneva that although there is a chaos as to method there is a real will to accomplish something at the arms conference. It is upon the existence of that will to do that the Secretary of State bases his optimism that there will be accomplishments worthy of the history of the period.

ATLANTA, April 22. -- Southern editors and political leaders who fought valiantly four years ago for Al Smith are becoming aggressively antagonistic to his method of leadership, which he claims is his as titular head of the Democratic Party.

IN this new collection from the a pen of Rudyard Kipling there are fourteen short stories and nineteen short poems. Following a Kipling custom of long standing, each poem bears some relation to the story with which it is tied up.

IT was announced recently that in the laboratory of a New York physician a fish was sleeping for the benefit of science. The aquatic marathon slumberer rounding out its fourth year's snooze is the survivor of twenty-eight lungfish brought back from Africa several years ago by a medical man who calls them the "strangest creatures in the world."

Recovery from the world crisis is as much a challenge to the sociologist as it is to the economist, since the present difficulties are primarily social rather than economic, according to educators who spoke yesterday at the third annual meeting of the Eastern Sociological Conference in Town Hall.

CAPE TOWN, March 23 -- Outside of the vendetta between General Hertzog and General Smuts, one of the matters most interesting to the public here at present is the grapejuice craze. South Africa has suddenly awakened to a realization of the fact that this drink tickles the palate more than wine, beer, whisky or any other beverage sanctioned by British tradition.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 23. -- A survey of the religious beliefs of 2,503 prisoners in Sing Sing prison discloses that all but twenty of them professed adherence to some form of worship. The question of the standing of religion in the prison was raised with the recent statement of Walter Bannigan, escaped prisoner, who returned to the prison after he had been missing twenty-one years, that he had surrendered because he had "got religion."

HALF a dozen years have passed since the publication of Mrs. Deland's latest novel, and many more since the book by which she is perhaps best known. "The Awakening of Helena Ritchie," made its very successful appearance.
That LINCOLN ELLSWORTH has long been looking forward to an expedition of his own is indicated by a letter that he wrote his father back in 1925:
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 23 (AP) -- John B. Chapple's announcement of his Senate candidacy was received without comment by conservative Republicans here.

WHEN Emerson died of pneumonia fifty years ago, on April 27, 1882, Concord was brokenhearted. Shortly after 9 o'clock that evening the bell on the Unitarian Church tolled seventy-nine strokes, which counted his age, to announce the doleful news throughout the village.

The Twenty-third Street Association has approved a resolution presented by John J. Cavanagh endorsing the bill offered by Alderman Murray W. Stand calling for a toll charge of 5 cents for pleasure cars and 10 cents for trucks on the Brooklyn, Manhattan, Williamsburg and Queensboro Bridges.

EXETER, N.H., April 23 -- The Harvard freshman nine defeated Exeter, 9 to 6, today in a slow game, errors aiding both teams in scoring. Harvard took the lead in the third inning, bunching four singles to register three runs.

TOKYO, April 23 -- The newspaper Asahi reports today that the Japanese Government has been advised by its delegates at Geneva to accept with amendments the resolution last Monday of the League of Nations committee of nineteen for the solution of the Shanghai problem.

Elementary Business Policy. How many of us see the true significance behind the statement of Alfred E. Smith's Jefferson Day address when he said "If the United States doesn't win, what difference does it make which party wins"? By many it will be taken as waving the American flag for votes.

A building to house the industrial arts exhibit at the Chicago Exposition next year has been designed by Ely Jacque Kahn. The design is included in the exhibition of Mr. Kahn's works now being shown at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.

LINCOLN, Neb IN April this year occurs the centennial of the birth of J. Sterling Morton, first United States Secretary of Agriculture, and the sixtieth anniversary of the first Arbor Day, the creation of which brought Mr. Morton enduring fame.

I BELIEVE the chief trouble which confronts the American business man today is the fact that he is not trained to fight against difficulties of all sorts. The automobile manufacturer may say to himself that a product such as the automobile is indispensable and necessary.
READING, Pa., April 23 (AP) -- Combing twelve hits, two of them home runs by Pucoinelli, from three pitchers, Rochester took the second game of the series with Reading today, 7 to 5.

CAMHRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Charley Devens of Harvard, in his first appearance on Soldiers Field this season, today pitched one of the most brilliant games he has turned in since he became one of the outstending college boxmen of the East.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 22. -- Politics in Arizona, suffering from Spring languor, took a sudden jump in interest with the recent statement that George W.P. Hunt, seven times Governor of Arizona and the most colorful figure in Southwestern politics, would again be a candidate for the Democratic nomination.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- One of the most remarkable things about the Soviet Five-Year Plan is that only now, in the fourth month of its concluding year, is the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics beginning to learn what it is all about and why. The Kremlin doubtless knew this from the outset, but abroad and here, too, a multitude of programs and figures obscured the real issues.

VIENNA, April 22 -- Sunday will be a fateful day for Germans in Central Europe. In Austria and Germany the greater part of the electors will go to the polls to choose respectively new State and provincial Legislatures, and incidentally to register their views on general issues which divide the politics of their countries.

WHILE waiting for the boys to make a start for the ball park yesterday. Bob Grove lighted a long cigar, settled himself in an easy chair, and began talking about baseball. In his early years with the Athletics the lean left-hander was one of those tall, silent men, but last season it was discovered that he had been wired for sound. Now he can rattle along and hold up his end in any debate.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that the Allephany Corporation, principal unit in the Van Sweringen railroad holding company structure, added substantially on April 13 to the collateral pledged under its collateral trust indenture.

NICE, April 10 -- The Riviera has had the worst season in the memory of veteran hotel managers and shopkeepers, with the exception of the four World War years. Cannes alone has been patronized by only about 50 per cent of its regular Winter visitors.

Fires on Long Island and in New Jersey swept thousands of acres of fields and woodlands yesterday, and were still raging last night while large forces of fire wardens and citizens strove to check them. One of the Jersey fires was said to be of incendiary origin.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 23 -- In a ten-minute extra period the lacrosse team of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn vanquished New York University, 4 to 2, today.

The editorial committee of the American Library Association made public yesterday a list of "fifty notable books of 1931" chosen in advance of the New Orleans conference of the association which starts tomorrow and will continue through Saturday.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 23 -- A pilot was killed instantly and his passenger seriously injured here today when an airplane in which they were heading for Floyd Bennett Field stalled 200 feet in the air after leaving the Curtiss Airport and fell when the pilot vainly attempted to turn back to a safe landing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- About 20,000 volumes, comprising the jurisprudence section of the Stolberg-Wernigerode Library, which has been one of the most important privately owned collections in Germany, has been bought by the Harvard University Library and will be distributed in the College Library, the Law Library and the Business Library.

Superstition has been defined as belief without evidence. We have had from Washington recently many samples of it. One of the most glaring came from Senator WATSON of Indiana on Thursday when he declared: " I have a solemn " conviction that international bankers " through their brokers have tried to " smash the market and hold up the re" covery of American business in order " to force cancellation of war debts."

PROVIDENCE, April 23 -- Holy Cross defeated Brown today for the second time this week, winning by 6 to 2. The Crusaders landed on Humphries in the seventh inning for five hits, including Mahoney's triple and a double, for four runs, which clinched the game.

THE cost of government in the United States, a dull subject in prosperous years, has become a challenging issue in the third year of the depression. For two months Congress and the President have been moving heaven and earth in an effort to cut $250,000,000 from the Federal budget.

SYRACUSE, April 23 -- Sending proposal after proposal into the diplomatic scrap-heap, the "major powers" of Europe succeeded in blocking all attempts at negotiation brought up and supported by the smaller countries in the final plenary session of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations at Syracuse University today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 23 -- Harness ponies held the centre of the stage today at the first annual horse show of the Parkway Riding Club in its new but uncompleted arena on Mill Road. Though there were only five entries, the competition was so keen that the judges, Mrs. James A. Hewlett and Arthur Eustace, were compelled to send the class over the course three times before picking a winner.

Britain's amazing strides toward recovery have been widely discussed from the economic viewpoint. Just as vital is the psychological aspect of the effort to put her house in order. This phase of the situation is dealt with in the following article.

SPIRITUAL guides, teachers, swamis and so-called yogis from India are not unusual phenomena in America, but seldom does the cable announce their coming in advance. Yet a recent dispatch told of the sailing from Bombay of Shri Meher Baba, a spiritual leader whom his many disciples and devotees style by such transcendent appellations as "the Messiah," "the Avatar," "Sadguru" and "the Perfect Master."
BATON ROUGE, La., April 23 (AP) -- The State of Louisiana was run by a woman today for the first time in its history -- a young woman at that -- and never knew the difference.
LONDON, April 22 -- Britain still refuses to become excited over the Anglo - Irish controversy although Eamon de Valera appears to be winning a clear road toward abolition of the oath of allegiance.

GIBRALTAR FOR a century, beginning on April 30, 1832, three generations of the Sprague family -- father, son and grandson -- have represented the United States at Gibraltar. Horatio, first of the consular line, belonged to a Massachusetts sailing family of Devon extraction which set out in three ships of its own about 1800 and boldly decided that Gibraltar, as the crossroads of the world, was a good place for traders to make their centre.

GENEVA, April 22 -- Even those who are the most prejudiced either way about the League of Nations and the failure of the United States to enter it admit that there is something very dignified and very courageous about the Washington Administration's bow to that institution this week in the person of Secretary Stimson.
CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians ended their three-game losing streak today with rallies in the eighth and ninth that enabled them to defeat Detroit, 8 to 7.

THE completion of the reproduction of Federal Hall in Bryant Park by the City of New York Washington Bicentennial Commission will reveal to New Yorkers an artistic structure that was the pride of the metropolis in 1789. It will duplicate the facade and copperdomed cupola of the original building, as well as the famous balcony on which George Washington was inaugurated as the first President.

Teaching standards as well as teachers' salaries should be raised in order to get a more satisfactory adjustment in the educational field, Dr. Lester Dix, research worker at Teachers College, Columbia University, and teacher in the Lincoln School, declared yesterday in a survey on ''The Economic Basis for the Teacher's Wage."

IT IS impossible to sever this volume from the personality of its author. His theme is the part which German reparations and the war debts are playing in disarranging the whole financial structure of the world today and prolonging the depression.

THE late April weddings include an international one, that of Miss Katharine Kelso Stewart to Vicomte Eric de Spoelbrech of Belgium, which, although not taking place in New York, is of interest to a large circle of friends and relatives here.

DR. LAURENCE E. DODD and W.W. Harper, physicists of the University of California, have devised a method of timing runners and automobile racers so accurately that thousandths of a second may now be considered. To prove how fallible is a human being holding a stop-watch when compared with automatic timing, Dr. Dodd made a series of striking comparisons.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Newspapers of the United States are a natural forum for discussion of present economic problems, the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today in urging that the people look to the press for leadership.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The State Department intends, if possible, to avoid being drawn into the agitation in Congress for recognition of Russia by the United States.

DISTINGUISHING features of American sculpture in mass are difficult to find and still more difficult to trace along a continuing course. The art, in comparison with that of painting, is young with us -- many doubtless would be surprised to know how young.

PARIS, April 22 -- France is right in the midst of an electoral campaign whose results are bound to have world-wide repercussions, yet one has to keep reminding one's self of that fact for there is an amazing lack of interest in it among the French people.

FLORENZ ZIEGFELD, who leads a troupe to the microphone on Sunday nights, has brought a real live performance to radio. Too often, when a new broadcast is introduced, it starts with a flourish of trumpets and then slips back into what the critics in the audience term "just another program."

The first big sale of property at Journal Square, Jersey City, to be made for some time took place yesterday when Ella D. Romig, 370 West End Avenue, New York, purchased the vacant plot at 2.835-37 Boulevard from Sarah E. Dutcher. The plot, which is near the Elks Club, has a Boulevard frontage of 50 feet and a depth of 100 feet.

The Associated Press will hold Its thirty-third annual meeting tomorrow, and the American Newspaper Publishers Association will hold its forty-sixth annual convention from Tuesday to Friday inclusive at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 600 publishers of the country or their representatives are expected to attend the sessions.

NOWADAYS when a visitor passes through the whirling doors of a modern hotel he finds himself in a world complete in itself. The foyer and corridors of the establishment are a miniature Rue de la Paix, in whose glittering show windows the fashions of the day, from golden cigarette cases to beach pajamas, are displayed.

Eight thousand of the 20,000 emergency workers on the payrolls of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau will be released at the end of this week, it was announced yesterday by William H. Matthew, director, who said that as far as he knew not one of the 8,000 had any work in sight.

THE Philharmonic - Symphony season of 1931-32 has come to an end. The extra concert to be given this week by Mr. Toscanini for the benefit of unemployed musicians is not a part of this season, of which the results can now be retailed.

NOTWITHSTANDING its slenderness, Clarence Day's little book makes a sizable addition to the understanding and the amusement of the world. It relates his conception, as a lad, of his father's religion and character, and in the relations in the matter of that religion between his father and mother, all of it told simply and objectively, but with a rich and mellow sense of humor.

Plans for the celebration or Parents' Day were disclospd yesterday by Uncle Robert, sponsor of radio programs, who predicted that, this year 50,000 persons would gather on the Mall in Central Park to take part, in the observance. In accordance with the custom of marking Parents Day on the second Sunday in May the exercises will be held this year on May 8.

PARIS, April 22 -- A brilliant social affair of the last week was a dinner for 150 persons, followed by a dance, given by Lady Rothermere, wife of the British publisher, whose principal guest was Sir Malcolm Campbell, holder of the world's automobile speed record.

TORONTO, Ont., April 23 -- Ontario's history of mineral production to the end of 1931 shows that since the beginning of mining in the Province the output of ores has had a total value of $1,110,754,349, of which $361,708,376 has been paid as dividends to shareholders of the companies concerned.

THE last two concerts of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra presented for the first time a new work by its conductor. Frederick Stock. This is "A Musical Self-Portrait." begun last July in Austria and finished only last month.

PARIS, April 12 -- First experiments conducted in Paris with New York's system of synchronized traffic regulation resulted in a complete traffic jam in exactly twenty minutes. But Prefect of Police Jean Chiappe, who superintended the test is not convinced that the system is impractical.

DERBY, Conn., April 23 -- Yale's rowing flotilla successfully weathered its first test of the season today when the 150-pound varsity, the Junior varsity and then the varsity came pounding down the Henley distance on the Housatonic course in front of the eights of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

THERE are many instances recorded of unusual incidents at bull-fights in Spain and Latin America. Rarely does the bull escape in his encounters with the sharp thrust of the picador's lance, the sizzling stab of the fire darts and, finally, the swift lunge of the matador's sword, but frequently the animal does much damage to the pride and person of his tormentors.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 23 -- A new banking decree was issued by President Olaya Thursday, apparently to relieve the credit situation and retire some of the government high rate foreign and internal loans. Foreign banks are said by a reliable informant to have received the plan unfavorably.

THE problem of the artist in a machine age is probably the last thing that is at the present moment worrying anybody except the artist himself and his relatives and dependents. The greater problem of anybody at all in a machine age has taken its place.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- General rains, which fell from the Gulf of Mexico to the Canadian Northwest and embraced the greater part of the crop-producing area of the country, combined with a pessimistic feeling among traders, led to liquidation in all grains at the opening of trading today on the Board of Trade.

ONE of the interesting results already of our departure from the free trade policy has been a certain influx of foreign manufacturing business. That tendency has been rather exaggerated in the press, but it is a real movement, and I would remind you that we in England have owed a good deal in the past to some of those importations of new manufactures.

PEARL S. BUCK, author of "The Good Earth," is engaged upon a translation of a thirteenth-century Chinese classic, the novel "Shui Hu," by Shih Nai-an. This book has for 700 years been highly regarded in the Orient for its graphic and picturesque style, its humor and its insight into Chinese manners and customs.

Supreme Court Justice John Ford's criticism of the Hofstadter committee and its counsel as maligners of New York City, which he called a centre of "sweetness and light." will not go unanswered, Samuel Seabury revealed yesterday.

The cost of government is too high and government itself needs to be greatly simplified. Governor Roosevelt told the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the organization's headquarters. 331 East Seventieth Street.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 23 -- Four scholarships and the university poetry prize in the College of Arts and Sciences at Cornell University were awarded today as follows:

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody is expected in New York tomorrow. In past years when the American tennis champion has visited here prior to sailing for tournaments abroad she has been the centre of much attention. As a dominating figure in women's sports she has had her share of the spotlight of publicity which every celebrity receives.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 23 -- The Boston College freshman nine overwhelmed Andover. 20 -- 6, today, batting Reiter and Meade hard. Concannon and Curran walloped home runs and the former also connected for a triple. The sixth was a bad inning for Andover, the visitors counting ten tallies.

PARIS, April 23 (AP) -- Edouard Herriot, leader of the powerful Radical Socialists of the Opposition group in the Chamber of Deputies, delivered an attack against Premier Tardieu's government in an election campaign speech tonight before a crowd of 5,000 persons at Livron.

BERLIN, April 12. -- Students in German universities and the other "hochschulen" ranking with them -- engineering and other professional colleges -- have practically doubled since the war. Counting only students of German nationality, there were 69,295 in 1914 and 130,886 in 1931.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 23 (Canadian Press) -- The High Court of Australia today refused the application of Premier J.T. Lang of New South Wales for permission to appeal to the judicial committee of the Privy Council regarding the validity of the Commonwealth act which empowers the Commonwealth Government to seize the revenues of a defaulting State, the act being aimed principally at New South Wales.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, April 23 -- The Prince of Wales today, on William Shakespeare's birthday, opened the fine new Shakespeare Memorial Theatre, the world's tribute to the poet to which the United States largely contributed.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 20 -- Porto Rico is making a strenuous effort to come within, the scope of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in order to make some of its frozen assets available for further credit. Washington authorities have explained that it was a mere oversight that the island was not included within the provisions of the measure.

ALBERT King of the Belgians, traveling in the ordinary craft of river, lake and air. has been inspecting the Eastern Belgian Congo. For a month he has been visiting the vast land which was owned and governed by King Leopold as the Congo Free State and later presented by him to Belgium.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary Doak today announced the failure of his second attempt to get Ohio coal operators to attend a conference here with representatives of miners to settle the strike in that area.

Governor Rolph's statement in denying a pardon to Tom Mooney, in so far as it was reported in the press, was "the weakest justification of an act of cruelty that I have ever heard." Norman Thomas asserted at a mass meeting in Columbus Circle yesterday noon.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 23 -- The men's Old Dominion golf championship beginning on Monday at the Cascades course is bringing more visitors to the Homestead colony.

Reminiscent of old-time realty conditions was the investment purchase last week by J. Clarence Davies of the fifteen story building at the north-east corner of Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street, a plot fronting about 35 feet on the avenue by 100 on the street, a two-story annex being on the latter thoroughfare.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Moving steadily upward, the Treasury's deficit reached $2,213,948,164 April 21 as a result of an increase of more than $26,000,000 on that date. The excess of expenditures over receipts in the last few days has been somewhat abnormal owing to large interest payments.

THE League of Composers is making elaborate plans for the celebration of its tenth anniversary in the 1932-33 season. It will take part in the Chicago World's Fair in 1933 in connection with the New York and Chicago International Society for Contemporary Music, by presenting a week of orchestral and chamber works, as well as one of the stage programs which have been a feature of its work in recent years.

HAVANA, April 18 -- The necessity for reforming the present organic laws, particularly in the Judicial Department, was emphasized in a recent message of President Machado to Congress, in which he urged that the recommendations soon to be presented to that body by the commission appointed to study the entire legal procedure of the republic, be followed.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Hoover was called on in the House today by Representative Britten, Republican, of Illinois, to arrange an Army-Navy football game in Washington this year.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 23 -- An unofficial elimination process expected to discover timber for the United States Olympic team turned up two likely contenders at the tenth annual Kansas relays today. They are James A. Bausch of the Kansas City Athletic Club, National pentathlon champion and decathlon star, and Captain George Saling, hurdler and sprinter of the University of Iowa.

The Belgian Ambassador and Mme. Paul May, members of the Embassy staff and many prominent members of the Belgian colony here attended the annual ball of the Belgian Benevolent Society last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The ball was preceded by a reception at which the guests were received by the Ambassador and members of his party.

TODAY. 12:15 P.M. -- Works of contemporary Argentine composers short waved from Buenos Aires by an orchestra drawn from the ranks of the Buenos Aires Symphony, under the direction of Juan Jose Castro, reaches listeners attuned to WABC's network.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 23 -- "The Torch Bearers," by George Kelly, was presented tonight by the players of the Bronxville Women's Club under the auspices of the art department. A dance followed the performance. The proceeds will be used to aid the craft work of the department and the relief measures of the architects' emergency committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Bonavia's comment from London on Sibelius -- dated March 21, published by you April 10 -- contains a misleading statement. Comparing the Finnish composer with Grieg, Mr. Bonavia states that the latter's "originality was blunted by his German training.

The Maritime Association of the Port or New York declared yesterday in opposition to the leasing of upper floors of the city-owned Staten Island piers for storage of cargoes received from ships or held for shipment from the piers. An amendment to the city charter was recently sponsored by Alderman Gardella.

Babe Ruth's fifth home run in the six American League games in which he has played this year was the signal for the Yankees to rally yesterday against the 5-to-0 lead held by the Philadelphia Athletics at the moment.

PARIS THE daytime costumes noted at the smart events of the Paris Spring season are distinguished because of their discretion. One does not look too well-dressed in these days of financial crisis, though sometimes the present brand of simplicity is more difficult to achieve -- if not more expensive -- than many more ornate modes.

IN the music room of Adolph Lewlsohn's house, 881 Fifth Avenue, on Saturday night, a program, of chamber music will be given by four prominent musicians in the interest of the United Parents' Associations of New York. A distinguished group of patrons and patronesses has subscribed to the event, the proceeds from which will be devoted to the work of the association in fostering parent education throughout the city.

WHAT is the appeal to us, the English-speaking, of a poet whose verse is actually a translation from Bengali? How was it that the Nobel Prize for Literature was given to Tagore when the judges had before them only a thin volume in which that poet had rendered into English a few of his poams originally in Bengali?

Al Jochim of the Swiss Turn Verei, of Hudson County, New Jersey, won the all-around senior gymnastic championship of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. for the seventh time last night at Sokol Hall. Starting with 160.45 points, which he compiled Friday evening, the defending champion increased his total to 205.85 points to take the championship.
PEIPING, April 23 (AP). -- China's women are ready for monogamy, but her men are still polygamously inclined. Pearl S. Black author of "The Good Earth." declared in a lecture here.

LIMA, April 23. The staff of business houses, workshops, industrial establishments and also commercial houses must have 80 per cent of workers of Peruvian nationality under a federal law which was published today. The law applies to technical and administrative staffs and laborers.

THE search for new radio detectors is unending despite the magic of the vacuum tube. The coherer invented by Edouard Branly of France, as the first detector, guided Marconi and others along the pathway to success in detecting wireless signal.

Peripatetic Martyrs. MOTORISTS are indicted on many counts by those who walk about cities and in rural districts. Many of the indictments stand up. There's no denying that numerous operators of automobiles habitually commit crimes against the rights of individuals on foot.

GOOD taste achieves wonders in interior decoration and is especially important today when a slender budget often must cover twice as much ground as formerly. A careful selection of the pieces of furniture is one of the first requisites for a successful room.

If no bids are received on Tuesday on the Board of Transportation's proposed contract for independent operation of the new city subway system, beginning with the Eighth Avenue line, Chairman Delaney will transmit at once to the Board of Estimate a request for an appropriation of about $2,000,000 to provide for municipal operation of the first link of the new system, It was ascertained yesterday.
The circus went to Bellevue yosterday. It wen according to tradition in make sick persons laugh. Dextor Fellows saw that it went and the clowns provided the laughs.
