SEATTLE, Wash., April 23 -- St. Paul's University (Rikkio) of Tokyo, Japan, gained an even break with the University of Washington in the first international collegiate baseball series for the visitors by winning from the Huskies, 6 to 4, today.

HANOVER, N.H., April 23 -- Dartmouth opened its home baseball season in frigid weather today and won an 8-to-2 decision over Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game before a crowd of 2,500. President Ernest Martin Hopkins threw out the first ball.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Hoover in a statement today urged nation-wide observance of National Better Homes Week, beginning tomorrow and ending May 1. Anything that can be done to better the homes of the nation, said the President, will serve to promote finer values of home, community and nation.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 23 -- Two irregulars were killed on Thursday by the National Guard garrison at Kisalaya on the east coast of Nicaragua and Lieutenant Francisco Gaitan and a private of the Guard were wounded in an attack by a band of irregulars which the garrison repulsed.

IT is slowly beginning to dawn on men and women in many walks of life that the airplane even to day is an indispensable element in industrial and economic life. That statement has been repeated almost as frequently and loudly as the goat old slogan, "aviation is still in its infancy"; yet both truisms are true.

The shortest-priced favorite thus far this season in the East ran and won at Jamaica yesterday when James Butler's Questionnaire, backed from 1 to 5 down to 1 to 8, captured the Kings County Handicap before 10,000 persons. Under 130 pounds, the son of Sting which won the Paumonok under the same impost, easily scored over three rivals and earned $4,650, making him the largest money winner so far during the metropolitan season.

PRINCETON, April 23. -- A second Summer conference course in industrial relations, during which those problems which have arisen during the economic depression will be studied in particular, will be held under the auspices of Princeton University in September.

Properly organized chain groups of retail grocery stores are thriving in the present depression, while corporate chains and independents not affiliated with voluntary groups are experiencing declining sales volume and profits, Thomas W. Balfe, vice president of R.C. Williams Co., Inc., wholesale grocery house sponsoring the Royal Scarlet stores, said here yesterday.

The emergency relief work for unemployed seamen during the last year is termed the outstanding achievement of the Rev. Dr. Archibald R. Mansfield, superintendent of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, in a statement by the report committee of the institute, issued yesterday.

Striking examples of the spirit of optimism and fortitude which characterizes the people of the city of New York in the present emergency are to be found in the classes for the retraining of unemployed adults located in the continuation schools. Many men and women, some of them out of work one and two years, have returned to school to prepare themselves for re-employment.

The Illinois Athletic Club defeated the New York Athletic Club in the final game of the national A.A.U. championship water polo tournament in the losers' pool last night, 6 to 2. The victory gave the title to the Illinois swimmers, who were runners-up to the New York A.C. last year.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- There have been a few encouraging developments in the business trend in some of our foreign markets, but general conditions have not changed materially, according to the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Two years should be the limit for the increased taxes proposed in the revenue bill now in the hands of the Senate Finance Committee, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said this afternoon in an open letter written to the committee by President Silas H. Strawn.

POMFRET, Conn., April 23 -- In a very stiff head wind, the strong Pomfret first crew defeated the Columbia freshman four-oared crew today by one length. The time for the half-mile was 3 minutes 15 seconds, good time considering the weather conditions.

If the depression lasts long enough, the level of adult education in Europe will have risen to a new high mark, according to Dr. Douglas Waples of the University of Chicago, who has just returned from a seven months' study of popular reading habits in England and seven countries of the Continent.

MR. DENNIS'S earlier books, imaginative and mystical, acclaimed by a few people and neglected by most, have not -- beyond the pronounced individuality of Mr. Dennis's self-expression -- very much in common with "The Red Room."

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- Plans to sail a fifty-four foot boat across the Atlantic Ocean this Summer have been made by six Princeton undergraduates. C.A. Hardy Jr., '32, of New York City is to be skipper of the craft which is now being conditioned at New Brunswick N.J.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23 -- Princeton defeated Yale at rugby today, 3 to 0, on a 25-yard penalty kick late in the opening half when Bill Halton booted the ball over the goal from a difficult angle. It was the first defeat for Yale in two games. Princeton had previously lost to Harvard.

FAIR HAVEN, Vt., April 22. -- Vermont is restless. Nestled picturesquely between historic Lake Ghanaplain on the west and the Connecticut River on the east, the lives of the 359,611 people that populate the geographic area of this 9,565 square miles are as a rule quiet and tranquil, their nerve tempo continually soothed by the musical splash of 600,000,000 quarts of milk yielded annually by some 294,000 milch cows; for Vermont is a dairy State.

ROME, April 23 -- Premier Mussolini gave Italy's disarmament proposals at Geneva his moral support today by ordering the Navy Department to present no construction program to Parliament for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Reluctant testimony given before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by two witnesses reputed to be among the leading bear operators on the New York Stock Exchange linked the names of prominent politicians and business men with one of the largest bull pool operations in market history, a $32,000,000 deal involving Anaconda Copper in 1929.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Vs., April 23 -- Ellsworth Vines Jr., slim youngster who bulks large in the United States Davis Cup plans, set at rest fears that he might not regain his national championship form by trouncing Wilmer Allison in straight sets.

Several special services will be held in the churches today for young people. Today is Palm Sunday in the Orthodox Greek and Russian churches, as they use the Julian, calendar rather than the Gregorian calendar, followed by the churches of the Western world.

THE town clock skipped an hour last night, and daylight-saving time sets in once more. On the happy Sunday morning last Fall when daylight time was laid away in camphor for the Winter, a statistician on this newspaper calculated that the 7,000,000 inhabitants of Greater New York had gained a total of eight centuries of sleep.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. BRITISH and other foreign made pictures will never seriously jeopardize the American product. This news, naturally cheering to Hollywood, was brought this week by Millard Debb, director of "Gentlemen of the Press," "The Sea Beast" and a dozen or so other films, after a year of direction with British -- Gaumont at their Shepherd's Bush studios.
AMHERST, Mass., April 23 -- A second inning rally netting seven runs enabled the Amherst nine to defeat Clark University, 12 -- 7, today. The box score:

PARIS, April 23 (Canadian Press) -- All through the 615 constituencies of France the nominations for the first ballot to be held May 1 closed today. Until after the first ballot in her double-ballot general elections no new candidates may be nominated.

Owing to the rapid decline in the market price of common stocks, which has proceeded much more swiftly than the reduction in the net assets of leading corporations, more than half of the representative industrial equities listed on the New York Stock Exchange are selling now for less than their bock values, and in many instances for less than the amount of the net working capital available for each share of common stock.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 24 -- With Waybright, Navy sprint star, finishing first in both the 100 and 220 by big margins, tying the academy record of 0:09.8 in the former event, the Naval Academy track and field team defeated the University of Virginia today, 73 to 53.

The week ended with the markets in a state resembling suspended animation. Stocks hardly moved; the business done in them was the smallest of any Saturday but one this year. Bonds, where they moved at all, were irregularly changed; United States Government securities weakened 1/8 to 3/8 point.

A spotless pitching record which Ernie Vavra maintained through four years of high school baseball continued unbroken as he twirled New York University to an 8-to-3 victory over Temple at Ohio Field yesterday. It was Vavra's third consecutive triumph on the mound for the Violet this season.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 21 -- Manoeuvring of wet and dry forces rather clearly indicates that Oregon will be made the theatre of the principal battle of the year in the prohibition issue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- A decisive victory for Governor Roosevelt is indicated in Pennsylvania's primary election next Tuesday. His leaders predict he will win from sixty to seventy of the seventy-six delegates and that these, added to his present lead, will make certain his nomination for President on an early oallot.
FINE ARTS BUILDING -- Forty-third annual exhibition of the New York Water Color Club. Opened privately last Friday evening and to the public yesterday, when it was also reviewed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From various newspaper reviews, letters, conversations and questions asked of me when speaking on music and musicians in the Soviet Union, I gather that the impression is prevalent that the authorities inspire, and the Russian people rejoice in, music which represents and idealizes the noises of factories, locomotives, tractors and so on.

FAVORABLE weather brought improved retail trade during the weak and demand for Spring apparel and accessories was about the beat so far experienced. Men's wear business picked up a little, also. Home furnishing lines were rather quiet except on special low-price offerings.

An athletic contract bridge tournament and a burlesque of "Mourning Becomes Electra" were highlights of "Horrors of 1932," the varsity show of the New York University Washington Square College, which was presented last night at Mecca Temple, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Creative thinking, imagination and elimination of "softness" are three major requisites in attacking current business problems, according to H. Gordon Selfridge, London department store owner, now in this country for a short visit. Routine management has gone by the board, he said in an interview yesterday, and a revival of "pioneer spirit" should be a major factor in establishing healthy business conditions.

For the first time in history the United States will be represented in the world's amateur three-cushion billiard championship tournament when Edward N. Lee of the New York A.C., twice a winner of the American title, competes at Vichy, France, on June 1.

MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) -- The government has announced that 1931 incomes of collective farms, now composing more than 60 per cent of the entire cultivated area in the Soviet Union, nearly doubled those of 1930 and greatly exceeded the earnings of individual peasants, or those who have not yet been attracted to the communal form of agriculture.

SAO PAULO BRAZIL claims to he the first South American country to take up gliding. Several glider clubs have been formed, and a corporation has been organized to manufacture gliders. The first club is composed of students of MacKenzie College, the American educational Institution at Sao Paulo, and several other clubs have been organized in the State.

THE NAMELESS BEGGAR," a new opera by Robert Heger, was given its premiere recently in Munich. Heger has written his own text for this three-act work. The anonymous hero is Odysseus. According to the reviewer, Heger's attribution of Christ-like characteristics to his hero, and the imposition of the Messianic upon the Homeric world, are sometimes developed to an extent that mar the noble simplicity of his general plan.

Upon, the outcome of today's election in Prussia it depends whether political and economic tension on the Continent is to be eased or made worse. Ever since his amazing victories in the Reichstag election of September, 1930, HITLER has been a threat to European peace and economic recovery.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 23 -- Lighting Bolt, owned by Mrs. John Hay Whitney, today won the Philadelphia Handicap, $10,000 added, mile and sixteenth feature of the Havre De Grace card. Aegis was second and Happy Scot third.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The dwindling number of Democrats who hope that they can "stop Roosevelt" were looking forward this week to the Pennsylvania and Massachusetts primaries instead of backward upon a crowded calendar of important events.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the contribution of Waldemar Kaempffert in THE TIMES in his Illuminating review of the mighty explorers of space from Aristotle to Einstein, I fail to see in the parade of these colossi a giant whose work entitles him to occupy third place.

WITH the passage by the House of a bill providing for Philippine independence in eight years, the attention of the American people is again drawn to their colonial empire. In increasing its area from 892,000 square miles in 1789 to 3,738,000 square miles at the present time, the United States has made a record for territorial expansion equaled by few other powers in a similar period of time.

The Survey, organ of social workers, has recently published the results of an inquiry into the unemployment relief situation in thirty-seven of the largest American cities. The replies to its questions are the more significant because they come not from politicians but from the executives of charitable organizations, community chests and other similar agencies.

ONE of the bicentennial's results of positive and permanent value is that it is collecting and putting into accessible and interesting form so much information about Washington that otherwise would be available only for research students.
HONOLULU, April 23 (AP) -- The killing of Joseph Kahahawai was "part of a well-laid plan'' premeditated by the four persons on trial as his slayers, in the opinion of Dr. Paul Bowers of Los Angeles.

Requisitions for dresses and accessories showed a marked increase in the wholesale markets here last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Activity was marked on chiffon dresses and triple sheers in daytime colors and stylings.
In an altercation with the telephone operator at Herben Hall, 621 West 171st Street. where he lived. William Cackett, 35 years old, was tatally stabbed under the right arm last night.

THE theatre is full of actors, playwrights and directors who were virtually born in the wings of some playhouse or other, and Dan Jarrett is all three of them. There are few traditions more purple. The actor Jarrett, for instance, was born in Little Rock, Ark., during a performance of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

Two pitched engagements between the forces representing the striking pier longshoremen and the strike-breakers who offered to take their jobs resulted yesterday in at least two men being rushed to hospitals with serious wounds and scores of others requiring treatment.
WARSAW, April 23 -- Marshal Josef Pilsudski's return from his six weeks' vacation tour to Egypt and Rumania has given rise to fresh rumors of impending changes in the Polish Government.

ATER one month, during which the company issued nothing in the gold-labeled "Hall of Fame" series, followed by an unusually meager list, the unheralded appearance of Brunswick Album No. 35 occasioned considerable relief.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- Northwestern University's latest contribution to science is the teletactor, an instrument which greatly widens the field of instruction and entertainment for the deaf and for persons who are both deaf and blind.

The New York A.C. made a clean, sweep of all seven championships in the New York State wrestling tournament which was concluded at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night. In addition to this, N.Y.A.C. stars also took three second places.

ONE of the annual Spring events for charity which always attracts a wide interest is the performance of one of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas given by members of the Bluehill Troupe, a group of amateur players devoted to the productions of the Savoy operas.

CHICAGO A last the Tree Studio and other groups of Chicago's conservative artists are on public exhibition. And, of all places, at the Arts Club, nationally and even internationally famous as one of America's most radical art organizations.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 23 -- The Harvard freshman track team repeated its indoor victory by downing Andover, 79 to 47, today in the first meet of the season. The Crimson yearlings took ten first places. Calvin scoring in the 220-yard dash and broad jump.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- John Paul Powhida hurled Penn's baseball team to an 8-to-0 victory over Yale on Franklin Field today, the triumph giving the Red and Blue undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. The defeat was Yale's first in league competition this year.

FROM 1793 until 1803 the flourishing French colony on the Island of Haiti went through harrowing experiences, until in December of the latter year the French were finally expelled. Toussaint L'Ouverture rose to power and was captured by the French, after having defeated the British during this period.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The tentative roster of officials for the Democratic National Convention at Chicago was announced today by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee. The selections are subject to the approval of the convention.

A plan to organize industrial buyers in an effort to halt commodity price declines, advanced last week by the national affairs commitee of the Purchasing Agents' Association of Rochester, was regarded as unworkable by representative purchasing executives who commented on the proposal yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The Horace Howard Furness Memorial, a library of 12,000 volumes of Shakespeareana and Elizabethan dramatic literature, was formally dedicated at the University of Pennsylvania tovost of the university; President day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The seeking of public office to do good is certainly commendable. An intention could hardly be higher. But democracy is not run simply on high intentions. It must necessarily be run, if run at all, on the principles of open debate and party commitments.
AN UNUSUAL, entertainment will take place on the night of May 12 on board the Majestic for the benefit of the Flower Hospital Auxiliary. The occasion will mark National Hospital Day.

The Women's National A.A.U. indoor swimming and diving championships will be decided in four consecutive days of competition at Los Angeles, starting Thursday, and local interest will centre upon the battle for team laurels, as the Women's Swimming Association of New York, never beaten in the indoor title tests, was able to send only five girls to the meet.

PIES are cut Into slices, cities Into blocks, and frequently there is no deeper logic in the one than in the other. Indeed, one sometimes suspects that the city has rather the worst of It. The size of a slice of pie is determined with more or less logic at home by the appetite of the eater and in the restaurant by the economics of the holding corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission issued its first formal order today denying an application for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. On the ground of inadequate security and prospective earnings, it rejected a request of the Cairo, Truman Southern Railroad Company for a three-year loan of $75,000.

THIS is real folklore, making up the sort of book that, as Sir Walter Scott said, "a child will understand, yet a man will feel the temptation to peruse should he take it up." These tales have the vigor and fine directness of stories collected at first hand, for the author listened to them and wrote them down on his expedition across Arctic America in 1921-24.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Piano beats as well as heart beats must ring true to hold the love of Frances Williams.

Although unable to take a single first, New Utrecht High School's representatives accumulated many minor places to register twenty-two points and win the team trophy in the annual Columbia College interscholastic track and field meet, opening event of the scholastic outdoor track season, at Baker Field yesterday.

IN the final days of preparation for the Charity Carnival of 1932, finishing touches are being applied to the many features of entertainment which are expected to make the carnival the most brilliant in the series given for several years in the interests of the Judson Health Centre.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 22. -- With the State's general fund steadily accumulating a deficit despite drastic economies, which have included salary cuts ranging from 10 to 30 per cent, the 1933 Legislature will face the same revenue problems which deadlocked the 1931 session for five months and which are now engaging the attention of Congress.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- For the first time since the revolution the former imperial palace in the Kremlin will be the scene of a brilliant diplomatic reception next Thursday, when Premier Molotoff will honor the visiting Turkish Premier, Ismet Pasha, Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdi Bey and thirty-three leading Turkish representatives of government departments, Parliament, literature and the press.

STOCKHOLM, April 23 -- Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish industrialist who committed suicide in Paris recently, still remains "a fine and noble personality" to Mme. Ingeborg Eberth, whom he had known over a period of twenty years and to whom he willed $125,000 just before his death.

PARIS, April 23 -- The Bourse closed the week with a large portion of the list showing substantial losses from last week's prices. Today's session was irregular, with the closing, in most cases, on the day's lows. Renewed weakness in Wall Street yesterday together with uncertainty concerning the Prussian elections afforded a basis of operations by bearish speculators who took full advantage of the situation.

LONDON. WHEN the Duke of York, during his recent tour of the industrial North of England, made a meal off Lancashire hot-pot, wonder was expressed in some quarters that he should have par-taken of, and obviously enjoyed, such a humble dish.

BOSTON, April 23 -- Alfred E. Smith will win a victory over Governor Roosevelt of New Tork in next Tuesday's primary election and obtain a majority of the thirty-six votes of Massachusetts in the Democratic National Convention.
NEWARK, April 23 -- Two home runs and a single by Billy Zitzmann drove in all Newark runs in a 5-to-4 victory over Montreal before a crowd of 7,000 today.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of New York's Governor, is stroking the "stern four" boat in the Groton School's rowing practice on the Nashua River, a half mile from the campus. Raymond Clark, Groton's crew captain, is No. 3 in Roosevelt's shell and George Eyer, another experienced oarsman, is stroking the "bow four" in the drills.

LONDON, April 12 -- A nation of happy marriages and cheerful home is the picture of England just revealed by a "family life questionnaire" prepared by Sir William Beveridge, of the London School of Economics, on behalf of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 23 -- Yale was no match for Army at lacrosse today, the Cadets winning handily by a score of 10 to 2. The Elis tallied twice before the game was two minutes old, Beggs counting both goals. Glick ran into Army's defends with the ball and on a quick fling Beggs shot it home.

THE well-known one-piece "Monkey" Winter flying suit, long familiar to the Air Corps, is due for the shelf. Complaints from the service concerning its various faults led to the design and development at the materiel division of a new two-piece suit which was tested and accepted as standard.

BOGOTA, April 19 -- The Chamber of Commerce has petitioned the Secretary of the Treasury to rescind the decree effective May 1, prohibiting the importation by parcel post of articles on which customs duty is collected. The United States has a parcel post convention with Colombia and the effect of this decree is practically that of abrogation.

The text of the speech of the Prince of Wales yesterday at Stratford-on-Aron, in opening the Shakespcare Memorial Theatre, as heard in the United States over a National Broadcasting Company network, follows:

Behind the growing tendency of New York City public school students to stay on into the higher years of study, noted by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in his annual report now being made public in instalments, there appear to be changes of attitude on the part of both the students themselves and of employers of the city.

MARMET, W. Va., April 23 (AP) -- Five men wreocrushed to death, at least three others are buried beneath tons of earth and seven men were injured in a cave-in at a government dam project here tonight.

WHEN all is said and done, there is nothing like a formal tailored suit: it serves so many purposes. Silks, plain and printed, may come and go, but cloth suits are always popular; no well-balanced wardrobe is complete without one of these standbys.

BERLIN, April 14 -- In considering Hungary's possibilities in the Olympic Games at Los Angeles one finds that it scored four victories in the 1928 meet and finished eleventh. It has every chance to do better this year. Hungary is in the first rank in three branches of sport -- swimming, fencing and wrestling.

PALESTINE is no longer merely a land with a past. Its future has become an important factor in the consideration of many present problems. The growth of the country within recent years has been so steady and so consistent that predictions as to further development need not be purely speculative.

LEWIS STONE, the bibulous Roger Chilcote in "The Wet Parade," has had a long and distinguished career in pictures. His silver hair and kindly, intelligent demeanor have graced dozens of films from year to year. Never a star in his own right, his work in many silent films, including that worthy picture, "Scaramouche," attracted wide attention.
John (Bud) Hassett lost his initial starting effort on the mound for Manhattan yesterday, Providence College winning by 9 -- 6 at Jasper Field.

WASHINGTON IN the late afternoon or early evening, usually about half past 6, a man emerges from the White House offices and passes through the gardens to the secluded rear doors of that distinguished old mansion.

Wall Street gave scant attention to the stock market yesterday, being engrossed in the Senate Banking Committee's continued effort in Washington to learn the inside story of various speculative operations. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was 470,970 shares, the slowest Saturday business since Feb. 27.

Although the sixty days within which it was designated to report expired late in January, the committee appointed by Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, to work out a practical plan for unit operation of oil pools has not yet finished its work and indications are that it will require more time to solve its problems.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 -- Driving two Navy pitchers to the dugout and hitting another at will, a hard-slugging Washington and Lee nine today, for the second consecutive year, defeated the midshipmen. The score was 13 to 6.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 23 -- A double, two singles, a walk and two errors in the third inning resulted in five runs for C.C.N.Y. and gave it a 5-0 victory over the Union College nine today. The runs were scored after two outs.

BERLIN, April 23 -- Trading on the Boerse was light today, confined mainly to week-end realizations. A new slump in Burbach Potash by 5 per cent caused a general downward tendency. In view, however, of the all-round stagnation the decline failed to gain momentum.

Paintings, furniture, Chinese porcelains, and bronzes from the collection of the late Sir William H. Bennett, K.C.V.O., F.R.C.S., noted surgeon and art connoisseur, are to be auctioned at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., Friday and Saturday.

AS the world divides into conflicting groups that more or less checkmate each other, all jealous of power, all struggling for a share of apparently limited means of support. Everett Dean Martin keeps up a forlorn rearguard struggle to preserve the spirit of Erasmus and Voltaire, to keep alive the sane skepticism that puts a check upon the compulsive dogmatisms of the hungry body.

LONDON. WE have in this country no institution that attempts to fill the role of a centre of literary taste and authority corresponding to the Frenrh Academy. More than sixty years ago Matthew Arnold, in the preface to his "Culture and Anarchy,'' gave the quietus to proposals for establishing in England an analogue of that famous body.

PARIS, April 23 (AP) -- La Journee Industrielle, the newspaper organ of French business interests, said today that France would seriously study the possibility of revising the import quotas so American business interests would receive "that importance in France's international commerce to which they are entitled."

A desire by the New York Central Railroad to learn as soon as possible the status of its position in respect to control of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad caused the former road to file with the Interstate Commerce Commission last week its own brief relative to railway consolidations in the East, an examination of the orief reveals.

The resignation Friday night of Richard W. O'Neill, one of this State's war heroes, as Commander of the Greater New York Chapter of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War when members of the chapter voted three to one for payment of the bonus, was followed yesterday by the resignation of Adjutant George Clark.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 23 (AP) -- Many of the depositors subpoenaed as witnesses in the trial of the directors of the State Bank of Binghamton are in the breadline and lack funds for carfare to Cooperstown, where the trial is being held, Sheriff Charles W. Kress has informed the Attorney General's office.

A BIOGRAPHY of Robert Burns straight out of the blue being an impossibility, for there have been few men in English letters to receive more biographical attention than the Scotch plowman-poet, this new "Life" by Franklyn Bliss Snyder must be examined primarily on its claim to definitive position among the scores of volumes from Maria Ridell's' ''Memoir'' of 1796 down to Catherine Carswell's biography of last year.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 22 -- Political minded men in Indiana who danced to the tune of the Anti-Saloon League in the heydey of its power here have suddenly become articulate on the prohibition question. The dam of repressed expression was broken by the Congressional vote on the Beck-Linthicum resolution, for no sooner had the count; been taken than wet candidates for the primary preference vote on May 3, sprang up like mushrooms.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns out-hit the White Sox to win, 11 to 6, today and make a clean sweep of a three-grame series with Chicago.

Calls issued last week for bonds to be redeemed before their maturity dates affected parts of several foreign issues and some small lots of municipal bonds and warrants. The total for April is now $15,427,250, compared with $11,110,000 last month and $61,117,000 in April, 1931, at corresponding dates.

A momentous struggle for control between the bourgeois-liberal elements in Japan and the military-fascist faction now in power, a struggle involving a possible armed clash between Japan and the United States, is depicted by Kurato Hirosa, leader of the Japanese Anti-War Federation, in an article in the current issue of The Christian Century.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- In an address under the auspices of the Columbia Broadcasting System Public Affairs Institute tonight Dr. John Grier Hibben, president of Princeton University, urged the American people to action "in defense of our own institutions" against a growing criminal class, which he declared to be "systematically and powerfully organized," with "enormous capital to finance its operations."

HONOLULU, April 23 -- Two physicians called by the prosecution today assailed the contention of the defense that Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie was insane when he fired the shot that killed Joseph Kahahawai.

GEORGETTE LEBLANC, who was known for many years as Maeterlinck's wife, but who was never technically married to him, relates in her memoirs the story of a love In which the protagonists did not live happily ever after.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of April 8 appeared a report by Dr. Frederick Hoffman on the homicidal rate per 100,000 population, taking in 164 of the leading cities of the United States.

REPUBLICANS' KEYNOTER. ONCE upon a time the keynote speech at a national political convention was a shrill call to arms, an artful assembly of fighting words. Now it is more of a lullaby, a soothing coo bringing peace to warring members of the same political household.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Adolf Meyer of Johns Hopkins University was recently quoted by THE NEW YORK TIMES as having declared in a lecture at the Academy of Medicine that psychiatry finds psycho-analysis useful, but not the sole "way to salvation."

THERE once was an American doctor," we read, "who, after making a most careful and painstaking investigation of London's milk, water and sanitation, was able to prove beyond the shadow of a doubt that no child could possibly live to the age of 5."

The lease of the four-story garage at 225-231 West Forty-ninth Street held by Jacob J. Shubert from Roberta Field Frank since Sept. 24, 1919, has been modified so that the net rental for two and a half years beginning April 1 last is reduced 25 per cent and the amount of such reduction added to and spread over the following five years.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 23 -- Army's baseball team, hitherto undefeated, fell before the hard-hitting Penn State batsmen today, 17 to 4.

CAPE TOWN OLD mysteries of the deserts of South Africa are being solved today by men in motor cars. Those who penetrate those almost unknown territories -- the Kalahari, the Koakoveld and the coastal deserts of Southwest Africa -- have strange tales to tell when they return to civilization.

OSLO. "IN connection with the recent flood of "psychological" novels in Norway, a pertinent question has been raised: Is an intimate knowledge of psychoanalysis an asset or a liability for a creative worker?

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 23 -- With Joyce winning his eleventh consecutive victory in two seasons, Seton Hall College defeated Georgetown University today, 9 to 6. A triple by Kearney, a double by Keller and a single by Joyce put Seton Hall ahead in the fourth.

THE publication of Mrs. Piozzi's "Thraliana," in 1778, made it quite clear that Hester Thrale, her eldest daughter, had letters from Samuel Johnson which she would not allow her mother to use. And now, some one hundred and fifty years later, these letters are for the first time made public.

A NEW YORK Stage Society, patterned upon the similarly named London, group, intends to swing into action next season. (Talk of next season, and not too much of that, is the chief thing to be heard on Broadway these days.

BOSTON, April 22 IT is all over but the censoring, and that is likely to be slight. Which is to say that "Mourning Becomes Electra" has been acted for the first time in Boston and for the first time outside New York by the original cast.

A group of Eli Nadelman's sculpture from Helena Rubinstein's collection is being shown by Marie Sterner in her International Gallery, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will stay until May 6. Those long familiar with Nadelman's work will know what to expect; those now making its acquaintance are likely to acknowledge as the initial impact a sense of paraphrased Greek.

MIAMI, Fla., April 23 (AP) Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller and Captain W.N. Lancaster, her flying partner, were free tonight after being held since Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of her fiance, Haden Clarke, 26-year-old author.

ONCE again through the gray Hollywood dawn, caravans of trucks loaded with sound equipment, lights and cameras, bound for location, are heard rumbling on their way. The ban on work outside studio walls that came in with talking pictures has been lifted, and the various production companies have issued orders requiring even more unusual "atmospheric" scenes than were used in silent picture days.

Dr. F.A. Vening Meinesz, Professor of Geophysics at the University of Utrecht, Holland, sailed for home yesterday on the Holland-America liner Statendam, having completed several months of research on an American submarine equipped with his multiple pendulum gravity apparatus, which has allowed science for the first time to take exact observations on the magnitude and direction of gravity pull in the earth crust.
BALTIMORE, Md., April 23 -- Johns Hopkins defeated the Princeton lacrosse team, 11 to 0, at Homewood today.

NOW that he has completed "Two Seconds," Edward G. Robinson will spend the next few weeks making "Tiger Shark," formerly known as "Tuna," which Howard Hawks wrote and which he will also direct. It is a story of the ins and outs of the fishing industry along the coast of California and Mexico.

THE second annual festival of American music will be given by the Eastman School of Music of Rochester the evenings of May 3,4,5 and 6 in the Eastman Theatre and in Kilbourn Hall. All performances are open to the public without charge.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (AP) -- Tannery, E.F. Prichard's crack handicap performer, registered his second success of the current meeting when he romped to an easy victory in the featured Camden Handicap, which had its twenty-second renewal today at Lexington.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- "Simply patriotic education" was declared today a leading factor in the national defense plans of the Daughters of the American Revolution by Mrs. Russell William Magna of Holyoke, Mass., new president-general of the organization.

THE fifth anniversary of the great transatlantic season of 1927 is close at hand. Five years ago last week Clarence D. Chamberlin and Bert Acosta brought the world's duration record back to the United States in G.M. Bellanca's Whirlwind-powered Columbia, flying overland.

One coach of rowing at an Eastern university, who prefers to remain anonymous for the time being, is considering making a formal effort to have the distance of the races for 150-pound crews changed from the present Henley length of a mile and five sixteenths to two miles.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP). --The House will decide next week whether to spend $327,353,457 on the navy in 1933, or to reduce that sum by 10 per cent.

RICHMOND, Va., April 23. -- Virginia has a full schedule for next week, including its Conference of Governors, the Washington Bicentennial Celebration, a celebration in honor of the landing of the first permanent Colonists, a State music festival, dedication of the first monument, to James Monroe in the State, and the opening to the public for the full week of 100 Colonial homes and gardens.

THIS remarkable study will be an eye-opener to all who, in thinking of the race problem in politics, dispose of what they call "the South" by a formula. "The South" cannot be pigeonholed, ticketed, classified or catalogued. Not only its history but its present is diverse; different conditions govern different localities, but so do different mental slants.

British discussion of the gold standard, of England's departure from it and of the real significance of that action, has been so inextricably confused since last September by a multitude of incidental considerations that it has encouraged elsewhere the revival of crude ideas on the whole subject.

Eighty-five Fordham men were honored at the fourth annual Block F dinner held under the auspices of the Fordham University Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. More than 400 undergraduates and alumni attended.

ONCE more the bleak continent of Antarctica is to be invaded. Men and dogs, airplanes and motor sledges will figure in two scientific expeditions that may be under way simultaneously in the southern Summer of 1934. One will be an all-air expedition; the other will he primarily a ground party, though it will use airplanes for reconnoissance work in depot-laying.

Six high school orators, winners at county and district finals held last week, have entered the regional semi-finals round of the National Oratorical Contest held in the New York-New Jersey area under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26, 1932 FOLLOWING a recent decree of our new Lord Mayor, Dr. Romulo Naon, that the Teatro Colon would be closed to productions of international opera during the Winter season of 1932, debate and discussion arose to a high degree in both musical and governments circles.

Victory came the way of the Columbia nine yesterday in its Eastern Intercollegiate League game with Princeton at Baker Field, the Lions getting off to an early and highpressure start to gain a 12-3 triumph. It was the first conquest of the campaign In league competition for the Blue and White, and it aided to revive the championship hopes of the Morningside Heights institution.

SINCE we were so successful in repaying credits abroad last year and in balancing the national account a tide of liquid capital has set in toward these shores. That is flattering to our vanity, but sometimes is a serious embarrassment to our trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest in THE TIMES the opinion of Dr. Herbert J. Spender, curator of ethnology of the Brooklyn Museum, that "since there is no relationship between the ancient Central American languages and any languages of the Old World, it is extremely unlikely that there is any relationship between the writings."

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The kidnapping of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's son is ascribed by many directly to the friends of Al Capone and indirectly to the effect of prohibition, Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut said in the Senate today.

PARIS, April 12 -- A venerable little stone farmhouse at La Deviniere, a few miles from Chinon on the route to Fontevrault, has just been acquired by the French Government. Recent researches have come to the support of local tradition in identifying the house as the birthplace of Francois Rabelais.

PARIS, April 12 -- A venerable little stone farmhouse at La Deviniere, a few miles from Chinon on the route to Fontevrault, has just been acquired by the French Government. Recent researches have come to the support of local tradition in identifying the house as the birthplace of Francois Rabelais.
Textile High School's baseball team the defense of its city P.S. A.L. championship by defeating High 3 to 2 yesterday Lereto Field. Staten lower Manhattan-Rich P.S.A.L. game. Joe the winning run

SINCE we were so successful in repaying credits abroad last year and in balancing the national account a tide of liquid capital has set in toward these shores. That is flattering to our vanity, but sometimes is a serious embarrassment to our trade.
BUFFALO, April 21. -- Boy rumrunners on the Niagara frontier bring into the problem of prohibition enforcement a phase of human interest that is, in some measure, peculiar to the locality.

PERSONS Interested in the welfare of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre have taken over the performance of "Too True to Be Good" on the night of May 9 at the Guild Theatre in aid of the organization. After the performance a unique entertainment will be held on board the Minas Princess at the foot of West Seventy-ninth Street, Hudson River, to which Miss Lillie and Miss Williams with other members of the cast have been invited.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 -- Acting Provisional President Aranha arrived here today, having obtained an agreement from the State of Rio Grande do Sul not to obstruct Provisional President Vargas's plans. It is rumored that the terms of the entente indicate the calling of a constitutional assembly next February.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Interest rates for loans to veterans on their adjusted service certificates would be cut from 4 1/2 to 2 per cent under a bill just introduced by Senator Connally. He said it was presented at the request of national representatives of the American Legion.
ANNA STEN, the slender Russian blond peasant girl who has finished two screen careers and is now Hollywood-bound for a third, smiled sweetly and said:

Trends of prices in the local commodity markets were mixed last week, the movements being largely results of internal conditions in each group. Coffee and rubber advanced, while sugar, cocoa and hides lost ground.

HAPPILY for themselves, the American people have not in recent months hoarded small change as they did during some crises of the past. Nickels, dimes, quarters, half-dollars and dollars have circulated freely. Cigars have been purchased, nickels dropped in the subway turnstiles, papers bought, and all the other necessary petty business transactions carried on every day just as if there were no financial stress.

LIKE a medieval armored knight contending against modern weapons is the eighteenth-century Franco-Spanish town struggling to survive to the heart of a modern American city, especially when that city is the second largest port in the United States.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Thirteen ringleaders of the gang of alleged interstate bank robbers and kidnappers, arrested last night in raids by the authorities of Indiana, Wisconsin and Illinois at Chicago Heights, were paraded before victims of recent kidnappings and bank robberies today at Criminal Court Building.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) -- Gus Suhr was the hero of Pittsburgh's 10-to-9 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today, the Pirates' third victory in the four-game series.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 -- A forlorn hope for President Hoover in Missouri has changed almost overnight into Republican confidence that the party will carry the State for President, Senator and Governor. The wet plank adopted by the Republican State Convention, held here a few days ago, explains the optimism.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The importance of the elections tomorrow in Prussia and four other German States was stressed by the Foreign Policy Association tonight in a report on "The Political Outlook in Germany and France."

AMONUMENT to Robert Edwin Peary, discoverer of the North Pole, will rise this year at Cape York in North Greenland. Above the cold cliffs of that promontory, which is the furthest bourne of civilization in the North, and by the Danes is called Thule, a tower of brown-gray stone sixty feet in height will look out across the Ice-laden tides of Baffin Bay, unique among the earth's memorials to great men.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a special concert Thursday evening for the benefit of New York's unemployed musicians. The program will include excerpts from "Parsifal" and Beethoven's Ninth symphony, with soloists.

A total of $245,775 was realized yesterday at the sale of rare rugs and carpets of V. and L. Benguait at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The highest price, $62,000, was paid for a royal Persian carpet of the sixteenth century by Starbuck Hunt.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 23 -- The "house party" of the First Century Christian Fellowship began actively this morning. It is being held at the Briarcliff Lodge and will last ten days. Over the week-end nearly 500 are present-individuals and groups from all parts of the country.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., April 18 -- Fewer than 500 Democrats of the Canal Zone will meet at Ancon on Sunday to elect six delegates to the national convention at Chicago. The registration, just completed, totaled 470 out of a total voting population of possibly 4,000 Zone residents.
BERLIN, April 23 -- For the third time in six weeks the question of supporting or repudiating Hitlerism will be up for decision by German voters tomorrow.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 23 -- After piling up a big lead in the track events. Boston College saw the Army more than even the score in the field events and ultimately win the opening track meet of the season today on the Plains, 66 to 60.

Dr. Lillien Jane Martin, consulting psychologist of San Francisco, who has spent more than half a century as an educator and will celebrate her eighty-second birthday in July, arrived here yesterday fresh and active after driving her own car across the continent and lecturing in the large cities along the way.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23 -- The Mercersburg Academy track team defeated the Navy Academy plebes today. 65 1/2 to 51 1/2.

For some years before 1929 much was heard of international cartels. Their primary purpose was to fix prices and to apportion markets through voluntary association of independent producers or distributers, who would thereby be deprived of the incentive to enter into competition with other members of the group.

An outbreak of the Riker's Island fire. which has smouldered into an institution for almost two decades beneath the mountains of rubbish and refuse with which the penal colony at Hell Gate is dotted, attracted wide attention last night in upppr Yorkville.
E.G. Petherick of San Francisco will serve as a member of the National Outboard Racing Commission, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles F. Chapman, who is chairman of the commission.

A TWO-DOOR sedan, priced at $575, has been announced as an addition to the 1932 Plymouth line. The sedan brings the number of Plymouth body styles up to ten. The rear compartment is entered through wide doors opening from the front.

STATE'S ATTORNEY," the picture which John Barrymore has been making for RKO, was completed at the studios last week. It will be presented at the Mayfair Thursday evening, May 5. Merlin H. Aylesworth, new president of RKO, has placed the theatre for this first showing at the disposal of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt is chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ending April 16 declined from the previous week to a point 35 per cent below a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions by the Department of Commerce.

Developments at the ninth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx Senior High School swimming championship of the Public School Athletic League in the 75-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday completely changed the outlook for the title tournament.

THE key to the European situation good or bad is the reparations problem. If Europe cannot solve the reparations problem, if they are unable to adjust that problem, it is useless to talk to the American taxpayer about aiding Europe by canceling debts, and equally useless to talk to the American hanker about lending more money in Europe.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The burden of unemployment is weighing heavier and more perilously upon Germany than upon other industrial countries. She has relatively the most unemployed, her fiscal resources are the least able to support them and her productive system is the most hampered by lack of operating capital.

NEXT Thursday the court house green in the little old town of Edenton, N.C., will take on an animation it has not known for a hundred years. On that day Charles Francis Adams, Secretary of the Navy, will unveil there a monument erected by Congress to the memory of Joseph Hewes, who can be accurately described as at least a godfather of the American Navy.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 23 -- L.D. Ward and J.C. MacEvitt each scored a leg on the Board of Governors and President. Cup over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today, both finishing with a full score of 50 targets. The special shoot went to M. Berdick.

WHERE are the snacks of yesterday? A spirited discussion over popcorn in the correspondence columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES raises the question: and -- though there seems to be a popcorn revival in New York -- it must be conceded that many of the between-meals foods and drinks of a generation, or even a decade, ago have vanished almost as completely as the snows.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Confused in spots as the Spanish scene evidently is, it is no cause of wonder to see conflicting and sometimes alarming reports that seem to indicate that not all goes well with the present republican regime. The task of a foreign correspondent is not a happy one at this time.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Wet Republican Senators believe, said one of them today, that, as a result of recent conferences, they have solved the question how President Hoover can agree to run on a platform which contains a party pledge to resubmit prohibition to the States.

THE Twelfth Hour of Capitalism," by Kuno Renatus, is a readable and stimulating book. It attempts to analyze the causes of the existing disturbance in the economic world and it seeks to find a way for dealing with them in a fundamental and comprehensive manner.

MADRID, April 22 -- A couple of centuries ago the English helped Spain to find out that the "Invincible Armada" was just a theory. This week the armada -- which, by the way, is just a Spanish name for navy -- found out again what the country had learned long ago, that it was not invincible.

ENGLISH poetry would have been robbed of what is probably its most frequently quoted verse had it not been for William the Conqueror. For had there been no William the Conqueror there might have been no curfew, and without the curfew, Gray's "Elegy" could not have evoked the same picture of calm serene in its opening stanza.

FEODOR CHALIAPIN, who appeared about twenty-five years ago in a film called "Ivan the Terrible," has agreed to act in a number of British talking pictures to be produced by the newly formed company. Nelson Films, Ltd., according to the London press.

Fresh testimony continues to come out of the earth in support of the Scriptural narrative. The discoveries in the Sinaitic peninsula are of particular interest in throwing light upon certain passages relating to the Israelitish sojourn in Egypt and the wandering in the wilderness.

The City of New York Commission for the Celebration of the 200th Anniversary of the Birth of George Washington made, public. yesterday plans for the exercises next Saturday at the 143d anniversary of Washington's first inauguration as President and for the dedication next Sunday of the reproduction of Mount Vernon, the Washington home.

THE studios of ithe Fox Film Corporation are occupied with twelve pictures and are rapidly Hearing completion of the forty-eight pictures which will be seen between now and August. Four of the twelve pictures are ready to be placed in production, three are being filmed and five have been completed and are in the cutting room.

The State Insurance Department has sent to all Insurance companies under its jurisdiction a letter urging the taking of all possible steps to improve their condition. In accordance with its suggestion, it assumes that companies will not pay dividends out of surpluses arising from the department's beneficial ruling regarding the evaluation of securities.

THE last year in naval aviation has been chiefly remarkable because of three achievements: the development of a powerful coordinated attack by all types of planes and materially increased accuracy in bombing and in gunnery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial, "Medical Costs," THE TIMES summarized the essence of what may be called "the medical evil." The lay public complains of being exploited by physicians; physicians complain, just as bitterly, of being exploited by the public.

Opposition to the nomination of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President was announced yesterday by Thomas L. Chadbourne in a letter to Homer S. Cummings, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a supporter of the Governor.

Greenwich Village does not support its churches any more, and most of them would have been "out of business twenty years ago" had it not been for aid from congregations throughout New York City and the country, according to the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis, pastor of the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

The present group of paintings by contemporary American painters at the Milch Gallery, 108 West Fifty-seventh Street, contains some admirable landscapes and figure subjects. It is one of the best shows held at the Milch this season.

LONDON, April 22. -- While sterling exchange was hardly influenced by Thursday's reduction in the bank rate, this week's moderate decline was entirely occasioned by Tuesday's announcement of the government's plans for securing adequate control of the exchange market.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Frederic C. Ebinger, banker, of Oak Park, was found dead in his garage today. His head was near the exhaust pipe at the rear of his automobile, the motor of which was running, and the doors to the garage were closed.

DETROIT, April 24. -- The tenth convention of the National League of Women Voters, a nonpartisan organization, will open here tomorrow Members throughout the nation and male politicians as well are expected to lend an attentive ear for possible hints on the trend of feminine choice of platform planks and voting next November.

Opposing views on the amendments to the present immigration law which would permit the entrance into this country, as exceptions to the quota, of near relatives of aliens legally present here and of alien relatives of American citizens were expressed yesterday in a debate broadcast over WOR by former Representative Nathan Perlman of New York and Representative Albert Johnson of Washington, chairman of the House Committee on Immigration.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The major items contained in the omnibus bill as finally framed by the House Economy Committee are:

Applicants for taxicab licenses, or for the transfer of licenses previously issued, will be required to "present a history of business dealings in accordance with acceptable standards," Maurice Hotchner, chairman of the Board of Taxicab Control, announced in the board's first opinion, made public yesterday, denying the petition of an operator of fifty taxicabs to transfer his licenses to new vehicles after repossession of the original fleet for failure to meet instalment payments.

PITTSBURGH, April 24. -- Julius Spindler, recognized as one of the greatest flute players of his day, who two weeks ago thought the world had forgotten him and remarked, "My life is finished, I am ready to die," now wants to live and again be a musician.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP). -- A counterattack against assaults upon the Democratic party leadership of Alfred E. Smith was launched here today by Representative Mary T. Norton of New Jersey on the eve of the Massachusetts primary election Tuesday.

BERLIN, April 24 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler's National Socialists became the strongest political party in four of the five States where Diet elections were held today, but nowhere did they prove strong enough to take over the government alone.

MIAMI, Fla., April 24 (AP). -- Captain W.N. Lancaster, in custody three times since Thursday as a result of the fatal shooting of his roommate, Haden Clarke, 26 years old, and a Federal agents' inquiry into an alleged smuggling project, was released again tonight.

RICHMOND, Va., April 24. -- With national politics officially barred, the twenty-fourth annual Governors' conference will open here tomorrow with the 1932 Presidential race shadowing the gathering despite efforts to keep the assemblage of State Executives non-partisan.

BALTIMORE, April 24. -- Bradley K. Purdum, 57, Baltimore banker and real estate operator, was killed instantly last night and Joseph L. Koller, who recently moved to New York from Baltimore, died of injuries sustained in an automobile crash on a road near Trenton, N.J.

The rights of property owners in this city and the methods open to them for the protection of those rights are set forth in a statement on the subject of assessed valuations issued yesterday by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

ATTICA, N.Y., April 24 (AP). -- Three brothers and their wives, all of whom have been married more than half a century, today joined in a golden wedding celebration. They are Mr. and Mrs. William Killian, married fifty-six years; Mr. and Mrs. George Killian, fifty-four years, and Mr. and Mrs. John Killian, fifty years.

AUGUSTA, Me., April 24 (AP). -- Fire of undetermined origin destroyed the Summer home of Henry I. Ottman, wealthy New York packer, on the cast shore of Lake Cobbosseccontee today. The loss was estimated at $40,000. Mr. Ottman and his guest, Sergeant George O'Donnell of the State highway police, were awakened by smoke and barely escaped from the building.

HONOLULU, April 24 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Catton, a San Francisco alienist, who is expected to be the final prosecution rebuttal witness in the trial of four persons charged with the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, submitted a report on his findings in the case today.

While illuminating gas seeped through her small top-floor apartment in Brooklyn yesterday, Mrs. Mary Quinn picked up some hospital bills and wrote on the back of them, "I love him too much to see him suffer like this. Pray for me that I may be forgiven."

Continuing their retarded climb toward the top of the league ladder, the Giants yesterday trampled on the Robins at Ebbets Field, almost obscuring the Carey athletes beneath a barrage of sixteen hits that gave the McGrawmen the game, 7 to 2.
Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, will begin his attack on Mayor Walker today with a study of the Administration's handling of the transit problem.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP). -- A wild finish in which the Tigers scored four runs in each of the eighth and ninth innings enabled them to overcome a six-run deficit and win the first game of the series from the Chicago White Sox, 10 to 9, today.

Voluntary complaints of citizens about the condition of the city parks and parkways deserve prompt attention from officials. The Park Association is receiving many letters reporting specific abuses, but it can only recommend changes. At this time of year crowds want to make use of every open space and every green spot available, and they should be encouraged to do so.
PARIS, April 24 (Canadian Press). -- Premier Andre Tardieu, speaking today in his own constituency of Belfort
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- Monte Weaver, Washington's rookie right-hander, today pitched the Senators to an 8-to-2 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics, for his third consecutive triumph.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 24 -- A romance of many years' standing with the late Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish "match king," was hinted at today by Mrs. Ingeborg Eberth, Stockholm society woman, to whom $125,000 was bequeathed in Kreuger's will.

Militant support by its adherents is one of the greatest needs of the Christian Church today, the Rev. Theodore Fiske Savage, executive secretary of the Presbytery of New York, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Presbyterian Church of the Puritans, Fifth Avenue and 130th Street.

The week's line-up at the Palace, where a change of program every seven days is again the policy, is about as reliable an exhibit as has held the boards there in some time. The headliners -- Ethel Merman, Jack Haley and Benny Rubin, Eddie Leonard and his son, Patsy Kelly and Dave Apollon -- all know their business and have something to contribute.

Agreement in principle upon a plan for the reorganization of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., which went into receivership on March 1, has been reached by the two protective committees recently formed in the interests of the company's security holders.

Harald Kreutzberg, assisted by his group of four dancers, made his farewell appearance of the season last night at the Craig Theatre. Though the costumes and something of the dancers' spontaneity showed signs of the long tour that they have just completed, the performance was a better one than those given earlier in the season.

The thirty-first delegated Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will open a week from today for a month's session at the Municipal Auditorium, Atlantic City, with 840 delegates from all parts of the world attending.

Mild weather in most sections of the country aided retail trade and resulted in increased buying of Summer merchandise during the week, particularly sheer dresses and white and swagger coats. Cotton dresses are in steadily growing demand and are conceded an excellent season.

The revised Glass bill to amend the Federal Reserve act and the national bank act retains the essentially wrong point of view of the original measure in that it is aimed at symptoms rather than at the causes of the defects in the national banking system, according to Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, who discusses the bill at length in the current issue of the Chase Economic Bulletin.

BAYSIDE, L.I., April 24. -- Yachting enthusiasts who had been buffeting wintry weather for the past few months in the regattas of the Frostbite Yacht Club took advantage of the ideal conditions today and held eight races on Little Neck Bay off the Bayside Yacht Club.

VIENNA, April 24. -- Hitlerism spread from Germany to Austria in today's orderly elections for the Vienna Diet and two other provincial Diets. The Hitlerite National Socialist successes were achieved in the provinces and in Vienna chiefly at the expense of the Pan-German and Farmers' parties, which were wiped out.

A field of ninety-three gunners competed in the annual shoot of the Atlantic Indians at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. L.R. Slocum, a Class A gunner, and E.H. Locatelli, who shot in Class B. tied for the High Over All Cup.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- A surplus of supplies and an unsatisfactory call for dressed beef, pork and lamb carried prices of all live stock lower, with the close around the bottom of the week. Cattle prices were within 10 cents of the lowest since July, 1911, $6.30 average price, compared with $6.50 the previous week and $7.75 a year ago.

A plea in behalf of the unemployment relief fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church was made yesterday by District Attorney Thomas C. T. Crain at the morning service at St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Ninety-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

There is no dissension in the Greater New York Chapter of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War, Walter W. Breheny, vice commander of the chapter and chairman of the hospitalization committee, said yesterday in a statement supporting the proposed bonus legislation, which he said represented not only his own official and personal views but the opinions of disabled veterans throughout New York.

On the basis of the Board of Estimate's action last Friday, virtually committing the city to bus franchise awards in Queens to the North Shore Bus Corporation and Jamaica Buses, Inc., the city will ask the Appellate Division in Brooklyn today to extend until July 1 the stay which holds up operation of the taxpaypayer's injunction barring "emergency" buses from Manhattan and Queens.

Asserting that the situation of the Federal Government with regard to its budget "has reached a point where neither more borrowing nor more taxation can be resorted to without a threat of disastrous results," the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of its Guaranty Survey, warns against the mounting burden of government expenditure.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 24. -- Luncheons and dinner parties featured a large social program in the Homestead colony this week-end.
BERLIN, April 24. -- President von Hindenburg, who did not vote in the recent Presidential election, voted early today as a Prussian citizen. Accompanied by Dr. Meissner, Execu...

Sixteen players progressed yesterday to the second round of the senior national four-wall soft ball handball singles championship tournament, play in which, got under way at the New York Athletic Club.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- Future hopes and past glories of science were shown today in an exhibition of scientific apparatus arranged for the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

Until after supper-time tomorrow the Mayor of Syracuse, N.Y., with a devotion to duty more Roman than Syracusan, will be trying out on himself the 9-cent-a-day dietary recommended by the municipal health authorities as a basis for distributing home relief.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 23. -- The registration of women voters, who will cast their first ballots in the November elections, has been ended in twenty-eight of the seventy-seven municipalities of the island, and all indications point to 150,000 women qualifying to vote.

Fires which had burned through thousands of acres of fields and woodland in New Jersey and on Long Island were nearly all under control last night, although a few still raged in scattered districts. With rain promised for late today, fire wardens felt that the menace would be short-lived.

WILMER ALLISON is a popular figure on the tennis courts, but tennis fans around the country must have breathed a bit easier when Ellsworth Vines defeated him at White Sulphur Springs on Saturday. Not that any one wanted to hear that Allison was humbled, but that there is a Davis Cup campaign up ahead and our chances of getting back the trophy would be slim unless Vines came back to top form.

"The trouble with America is not its Congress, millionaires and ministers "but that its Christianity is too anemic to be a leavening power for love," the Right Rev. Dr. Irving Peake Johnson, Bishop of Colorado, said in his sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

The Lambs, maintaining an honorable April tradition, gamboled publicly last night at the Imperial Theatre before a capacity house. Officials of the theatrical club estimated that the receipts of the performance would be about $18,000, of which $8,000 was derived from the souvenir program.

In the late Speaker KEIFER'S career fame showed more than once her inconstancy and irony. He was chosen Speaker of the House in the Forty-seventh Congress, largely because of his lack of salience and enemies. He was an Ohio politician of the Bloody Shirt school.

BERLIN, April 22. -- The loss of 33,000,000 marks in the Reichsbank's reserve of gold and foreign exchange, as reported on Tuesday for the second week of April, caused no anxiety here. The reduction was mainly due to interest and amortization payments abroad, but it was also partly caused by the import movement, which is always largest in the first half of any month.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Slack will give a dinner tomorrow night at the St. Regis for Miss Happy Shannon and Eugene G. Hodenpyl, whose marriage will take place Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Little is heard these days of the old-time battle cry of the Democrats that under President Hoover the United States had become a government by commission.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- When the curtain rises at the Majestic Theatre in the Loop tomorrow night for the "Breadline Frolics" there will be former actors, college graduates and even an erstwhile professor in the cast.

aFour hundred persons assembled yesterday afternoon on the east side of Grant's Tomb at Riverside Drive and 121st Street to pay homage to the memory of the Civil War General whose birthday falls on Wednesday. The exercises were arranged by the local branches of the auxiliaries and Sons of the Union Veterans of the Civil War.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Good rains over a large part of the American Winter and Spring wheat sections as well as throughout Western Canada are expected to improve crop prospects in Winter wheat and give the Spring wheat on both sides of the international line a good start.

NEW HAVEN, April 23 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.8, which compares with 62.4 a week ago, 62.5 two weeks ago, 62.9 three weeks ago and 63.1 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3 in the first week of January; this week's average is the lowest.

Delegates to a meeting of the American Jewish Congress in the Jewish Club, 23 West Seventy-third Street, voted yesterday afternoon to call a world conference of Jews in Geneva next July. The delegates represented ten national and more than 100 local Jewish organizations.

GENEVA, April 24. -- During this week the disarmament conference should, if it follows its program, get down to a discussion of and make a first decision on the principles involved in the French and German proposals. But somehow every one is unwilling to face these issues yet.

Provisions of the Glass bill now before the Senate, which would force national banks and trust companies to dispense with their affiliated security companies, were praised yesterday by Samuel Untermyer.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP). -- The heavy hitting of Earl Averill of the Cleveland Indians, who drove in seven runs with two homers and a double, enabled his team to run away with the St. Louis Browns today, 14 to 3. Yesterday the teams were tied for fourth place in the American League standing, but the Indians pushed the Browns into fifth with today's game.

Romain Rolland, who, like Bernard Shaw, has lately expressed much interest in communism, has been unanimously elected an honorary member of the Soviet Union Academy of Science. The proposal was made by Academicians Anatole Lunatcharsky and Nikolai Bukharin, the Moscow News reports, and was adopted in Leningrad on March 28.

NEW DELHI, April 24 (AP). -- Armored cars patrolled Delhi tonight, following the arrest of 369 members of the All-India National Congress who came here for the forty-ninth session of the Congress, in defiance of the government ban. There were no disorders, however.

A dinner will be given on May 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the metropolitan group of Boys' Clubs of America to celebrate Boys' Week in New York, which will begin next Saturday. Many prominent men and women, as well as representatives of the forty-two boys' clubs of the metropolitan group, are expected to attend.

The age-long ideas of morality's dependence on religion have collapsed and the union of morals and religion is swiftly being broken up, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, minister of the new Riverside Church and radio preacher for the National Vesper Service, writes in "As I See Religion," published by Harper.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York yesterday filed a protest with the United States Shipping Board against the proposed transfer of the government-owned piers in Hoboken to the city of Hoboken at an "unreasonably low" price.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP). -- Josef von Sternberg, motion picture director, left last night for New York, bringing to a crisis his dispute with the Paramount studio over Marlene Dietrich's next picture.

PITTSBURGH, April 24. -- Demand for steel has been approximately stationary in the last three weeks, following the marked decrease that began early in March. A new low volume has been reached, and producers are disposed to regard it as the possible minimum.
"Another Language," a play by Rose Franken, will open tonight at the Booth Theatre, with Glenn Anders, Dorothy Stickney and Margaret Wycherly in the leading roles.

Myra Hess's farewell concert of the season, given yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, was imbued from beginning to end with the qualities which have made this distinguished pianist unique -- a tone of great sensuous beauty combined with penetrating logic and intellectual clarity.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 24. -- Foreign banks operating in Colombia are severely criticized by the newspaper El Tiempo for their alleged failure to cooperate with the government in preparing its recent decree creating a new bank to fund Colombia's debts.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., April 24. -- International outlook, sympathy and understanding were the main themes of Dr. George N. Shuster, managing editor of The Commonweal, a Catholic weekly review, and Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, in addresses at the Spring meeting of the Secondary Schools Society held here today at Canterbury School.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Senate Banking and Currency Committee's investigation of short selling becomes more ludicrous every day. Senator Watson provides the crowning absurdity. He is quoted in this morning's papers as declaring. "I have a solemn conviction that international bankers through their brokers have tried to smash the market and hold up American business recovery to force us to cancel their war debts.

The New York A.C. baseball team came from behind to defeat Fort Slocum, 12 to 2, yesterday on the New York A.C. diamond at Travers Island. The victors staged six-run and five-run rallies, respectively, in the fifth and sixth innings to win the seven-inning contest.

The goal of too many churches is a great congregation, whereas Jesus Christ worked with individuals, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, declared in a sermon yesterday morning in the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, Bennett Avenue and West 189th Street.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24. -- Scoring eight runs in the first inning, Newark scored a 16-to-8 victory over the Montreal Royals to enable the Bears to continue in a first-place tie with the Buffalo Bisons.

A bulletin from Southold, L.I., carries the news that several threepound weakfish were caught in a trap off Founders Landing along with black fish and sea bass, which is a welcome sign to salt water fishermen in and around New York. The same source of information states that several three and one-half-pound weak fish have been caught on hook and line off Jessups Point.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 24. -- Return to the tenets of early Christianity as "the answer in a day of crisis" was stressed today in the conferences being held at the "house party" of the First Century Christian Fellowship at Briarcliff Lodge.
