The annual report of the Fire Department Pension Fund, filed yesterday with Mayor Walker by Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, discloses a net increase in payments of $171,412, of which $160,080 is attributed to the mandatory increase from $300 to $600 annually of pensions to the widows of firemen.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24. -- An attempt by the All-India National Congress to meet here today, despite the government's ban, led to several clashes with the police. More than 450 persons were arrested. Two hundred persons were arrested yesterday, including Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, who became president of the Congress when Mrs. Sarojini Naidu was arrested in Bombay Friday.

Published today by the Carnegie Foundation is its "Annual Review of Legal Education." Like preceding reports of the kind, it contains both a record and recommendations. The public as well as the legal profession should value the information given concerning law schools and the conditions of admission to the bar throughout the United States and in Canada.
READING, Pa., April 24 (AP). -- Rochester got to three Reading hurlers today for seventeen hits, to win the third straight game of the series from the Keys, 8 to 5.

A new Institute of Family Relations, modeled on the one at Los Angeles and on 200 similar organizations in Europe has been formed here and is now seeking financial support to begin functioning, Dr. Victor Cox Pederson, consulting urologist and sociologist who is general secretary and director of the organization, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- As Tuesday's primary approaches, the belief of observers here is that Pennsylvania Republicans will renominate Senator Davis for the Senate, with the selection of seventy-five delegates to the national convention who will support President Hoover and a wet plank in the party platform.

BERLIN, April 24. -- Liberalism lost Parliamentary control of Prussia today through the defeat at the polls of the Weimar three-party coalition, which had governed the State since 1919. Its slender majority was wiped out by the Hitlerites winning 162 mandates in the new Diet, against six held in the expiring Legislature.

SHANGHAI, April 24. -- The largest crowd ever seen in Shanghai thronged the streets this afternoon to pay honor to Robert Short, American aviator, who was killed in February during an air fight with Japanese planes over Soochow.

A chill north-west wind brought a drop in temperature of more than ten degrees yesterday, but the weather continued moderate and the bright sunshine sent large crowds to Long Island and New Jersey seashore resorts. Boardwalks were thronged with promenaders arrayed in Spring finery, and concessions, many of which opened for the first time this year, did a brisk business throughout the afternoon.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- No rush of buyers was apparent in any line of trade or industry last week, although there was a fair distribution of merchandise among wholesalers and retailers, compared with the aggregate a year ago.

Edwin Markham, 80 years young, stepped from the wings at Carnegie Hall shortly after 10 o'clock last night and received the applause of more than 2,000 persons who had assembled to honor him on the day after his eightieth birthday.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Finance Committee will launch a "hurry-up" program tomorrow to have the billion-dollar tax bill ready for action in the Senate by early next week.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Avowing that increase in the State highway building program would mean a 1-cent boost in the gasoline tax, Republican Senate Leader George R. Fearon in a statement here today assailed what he termed propaganda by road contractors for a special session to augment the current program.

Yachtsmen affiliated with the Western Long Island Sound fleet of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association will have a full program of competition this season, the schedule announced yesterday reveals.

TUEBINGEN, Germany, April 24 (AP). -- Germany's thanks for the Hoover moratorium will find a measure of expression tomorrow and Tuesday at the ancient University of Tuebingen when Frederic M. Sackett, the American Ambassador, will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Political Science.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 24. -- Miss Helen Hicks and Johnny Farrell defeated Miss Maureen Orcutt and George McLean in an exhibition foursome at the Grassy Sprain Golf Club today, 5 and 3. The event, conducted for the benefit of the unemployed in Yonkers, was well attended, a crowd of 2,500 persons following the players.

Arturo Toscanini, composer and orchestral conductor, will arrive today from Rome on the French liner Ile de France to conduct one concert at Carnegie Hall next Thursday night, April 28, for the benefit of unemployed musicians. He will leave again for Europe on the same ship the following night.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP). -- The Braves won their sixth straight game by taking a pitchers' battle from the Phililes, 2 to 1, today before 12,000 fans. The game was a gripping duel between Ed Brandt and Ray Benge, the latter allowing two runs in the sixth to clinch the game for the league leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Working from early morning until last midnight, the House Economy Committee, created on Feb. 19 to study the methods to reduce Federal expenditures in the fiscal year 1933, completed drafting the huge omni-bus bill expected to save the government more than $263,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the article by Louis I. Dublin on the immigration situation in America which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently. As a student of population problems, I must disagree with at least two of Mr. Dublin's conclusions.

BALBOA, April 24. -- Canal Zone Democrats elected six uninstructed delegates to the national convention today at a mass meeting in which harmony prevailed, in contrast to the last convention, when a split resulted in a rump convention and two delegations were sent to Houston, Texas.

PARIS, April 22. -- While the foreign balances as reported by the Bank of France increased 131,000,000 francs last week, despite the simultaneous increase of 156,000,000 in the bank's gold holdings, this does not prove that the bank had bought exchange on the market.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 24. -- The retirement of Dr. William G. Anderson as director of the gymnasium, a post he has held since 1903, was announced today by Yale University in connection with plans for the operation of the new $4,000,000 Payne Whitney Gymnasium.

Increased unemployment relief campaign activity in all districts of the city was reported yesterday by the Block Community Organization at its headquarters, 29 Broadway. The number of blocks now reporting "stamp-out-want" stamp sales increased 43 per cent during the third week of the drive.

The Prince of WALES handsomely acknowledged the "very generous help" which had been forthcoming from America in the building of the new Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford. Whatever has been given by Americans is not beyond our debt to the memory of the "myriad-minded" one whose "priceless heritage" we share.

NORFOLK, Va., April 24. -- Rear Admiral W.D. MacDougall, commandant of the Norfolk Naval District, has been selected by Secretary of the Navy Adams to represent the navy at the unveiling of a monument to Joseph Hewes at Edenton, N.C., next Thursday.

Georgetown University fell a victim to a ten-run rally in the sixth inning by the Staten Island Baseball Club yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., and lost to the clubmen, 11 to 7. Heaney had held the victors well in hand for five innings to lead, 5 to 1, at the start of the sixth.

In a transatlantic broadcast from London yesterday over the Columbia network in the United States, Ralph D. Blumenfeld, American-born editor of The London Daily Express, declared that his forty years of journalism in England had proved to him that there was no fundamental difference between that country and this, that American influence was increasing in England and that to the British those of all nationalities except Americans were regarded as foreigners.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad added to its holdings of stock of the Reading Company in 1931 by purchasing 1,600 first preferred. 1,800 second preferred and 6,500 common shares for $775,069, the annual report reveals. In addition, the New York Transit and Terminal Company, a subsidiary, bought 800 first preferred, 6,500 second preferred and 41.600 common Reading shares for $2.549,319.

A crowd of 2,000 fans at Commercial Field in Brooklyn yesterday saw the Hakoah All-Stars subdue Boston, 3 -- 0, in an American Soccer League match. All the tallies were registered in the second period.

LONDON, April 22. -- Plantation grades were steady but quiet in the rubber market. Smoked sheet spot April-May sold at 1 15/16 d. a pound buyers, June at 2d. sellers, July-September at 2 1/16 d. sellers, October-December 2 1/8 d. sellers, January-March 2 1/4 d. sellers, April-June 2 3/5 d sellers, crepe spot quoted at 2 1/2 d. value.

New York State will enter the market in a few days with a new issue of short-term notes, probably $75,000,000. Controller Tremaine marketed on March 31 an issue of $50,000,000 3 3/4 per cent notes, due on Jan. 15, 1933, at par, in anticipation of taxes and revenues.

VIENNA, April 22 -- All banks at Vienna and Prague have decided against distributing dividends this year; consequently the previous stagnation on the Stock Exchanges has been aggravated. As compared with July, 1931, the index number of Stock Exchange prices at Prague has fallen from 70 to 46 and at Vienna from 46 to 36.

Real charity is the sinner's key to Heaven, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral in what was announced as the last appeal for Catholic Charities this year from the Cathedral pulpit. "Show me the man or woman filled with real charity and I don't care what sins he has committed, he will be enthroned in the heart of God," Father Hammer said.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 24 (AP) -- Two women and four children were killed instantly late today when their automobile was demolished by a Pennsylvania passenger train two miles east of Monroeville.

A glowing tribute was paid the late Lieut. Commander John Philip Sousa as composer and conductor by Joseph N. Weber, president of the American Federation of Musicians, at the unveiling of a life-size portrait of the band master yesterday afternoon at Musical Union headquarters, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Seniors of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and the College of Engineering are less optimistic about the salaries they expect to earn than previous seniors have been, the annual questionnaire at University Heights reveals.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs slugged their way to a one-sided victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

It is an interesting and somewhat amusing account which our Washington correspondent gives of the appeal of the Wet dialecticians of the Republican party to Mr. HOOVER. They are getting to be very numerous, including as they do several members of the Cabinet.
Light in Dark Places. An old lawyer once said that whenever a judge indulged in an "obiter" from the bench, it meant that he wanted to say something silly.

Optimistic reports of slowly reviving business in many sections of the country were brought here yesterday by the vanguard of more than 500 publishers or their representatives, who are arriving for the thirty-third annual meeting of The Associated Press, opening today, and the forty-sixth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, beginning tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Opposition to the proposed new building code developed from three sources during the past week, according to Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The opposition is based to some extent on rivalry and comes on the eve of the final submission of the ordinance to the Board of Aldermen for adoption, the Dow Service writer declares.

In letters addressed yesterday to the Employing Electrotypers and Stereotypers of New York and the Photo-Engravers' Board of Trade, the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association, representing the closed shop group of the book and job printing industry, urged the two organizations to seek a temporary reduction in wages for their unions.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- In sharp contrast to the jammed docket of past years, the Supreme Court will listen this week to its last oral arguments of the term with the probability that there will not be enough cases to occupy its time.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Association Against the Prohibition Amendment today denounced suggestions offered to effect a change in the prohibtion law and declared that it would ask the two major political parties for a plank favoring repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Persons interested in the activities of the Soldiers and Sailors' Club of New York have arranged for a benefit bridge tournament on the afternoon of May 9 in the ballroom of the Plaza. The organization maintains a clubhouse at 283 Lexington Avenue.

GENEVA, April 24. -- Although several important conversations were held last week by Chancellor Bruening with Premier Tardieu and Prime Minister MacDonald and by each of these statesmen with Secretary Stimson, it is believed little progress was made toward preparations for the Lausanne conference on interallied debts, which more than any other issue accounts for the presence here at least of the European Premiers.

KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP). -- Police authorities anxiously awaited verification or denial tonight of their hope that Marshall Deputy, alias Martin Depew, alleged kidnapper of Mrs. Nell Donnelly, was under arrest at Johannesburg, South Africa.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24. -- World from Seattle said today the crew of the Dimon Line freighter Pacific Pine had been ordered off the ship and would have to be content with pay up to Feb. 23 instead of to date. The crew had hoped that by remaining abroad their ship they could protect a wage lien on the company, which is now in the hands of a recover.

VIENNA, April 24 (AP). -- Widespread large gains by the National Socialists (Fascists) and the virtual extinction of the Pan-German party (supporters of former Chancellor Shober's foreign policy) were the chief results of balloting in three Austrian Provinces which elected new Diets today.

BARCELONA, Spain, April 24. -- More than 100,000 Catalonians, dressed in short breeches, black broadcloth coats and red caps, paraded here today and cheered for the passage without change of the Catalan autonomy statute by the Cortes in Madrid.
MARMET, W.Va., April 24 (AP). -- Tons of earth, torn from the banks of the Kanawha River, brought death last night to at least six workmen on the new Federal Government dam under construction here.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Stock Exchange "bear hunt" by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today awaited the formulation of new tactics which the committee expects to develop at an executive session tomorrow morning.

Another day of wide-flung effort yesterday brought the search for the infant son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh no nearer a successful conclusion, as far as was disclosed, than when he was first missed on the night of March 1.

TOKYO, Monday. April 25. -- The Japanese Government has ended an unlucky experiment in State control of the price of basic products by selling 107,380 bales of raw silk to Paolino Gerli, president of the Silk Association of America.

LONDON, April 16. -- The surprising thing about the situation in Europe just now, and the one that should cause anxiety, is that nothing is being done to prepare for the coming conference at Lausanne on German reparations.

The outdoor bicycle racing season was officially opened yesterday when 8,000 fans attended the Coney Island Velodrome's inaugural meet. Most of the spectators were present to witness the debut of the recently arrived Giovanni Manera, motorpaced champion of Italy for the past two years.

All periods of severe financial depression present a series of successive phases, differing in outward semblance from one another yet perfectly logical in their sequence. The characteristic circumstance in the aftermath of 1893 was the desperate struggle of the Treasury to maintain its credit, pay its bills and prevent default on the national currency; in the two or three years after both 1893 and 1873 it was the virtual insurrection of labor.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Immediate cash requirements of the Treasury impelled Secretary Mills to announce today two new issues of government securities totaling $450,000,000.

Encouraged by favorable reports from Massachusetts, supporters of former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic nomination for President expressed confidence yesterday that Mr. Smith would have the delegates from Rhode Island and Connecticut.
All six teams in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League took part in title games on Saturday and as a result the standing of the contestants showed several changes.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three four months' paper.

Employing a series of body slams and an airplane spin, Jim Londos, Greek grappler, successfully defended his world's heavyweight wrestling championship last night by throwing Joe da Vito, Italian challenger, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The bout lasted 21 minutes and 42 seconds. Londos weighed 204 pounds and de Vito 210.

DALLAS, Texas, April 25 (AP) -- John L. Merrill of New York told the annual Southwest Foreign Trade Conference tonipht that mutual suspicion must be reduced as a preliminary to increased foreign trade among nations of the Western Hemisphere.

Mrs. Ida M. Wigand, widow of Albert A. Wigand, who died Feb. 12, left the residue of her estate to the Renaselaer Polytechnic Institute of Troy and a $10,000 trust fund to the Lawrence and Memorial Associated Hospital of New London, Conn., according to her will, filed for probate in Surrogates court yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past few years I have been a regular reader of your paper and have learned to appreciate its clear-cut and conservative presentation of the news from day to day.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday involved only 640,596 shares, the smallest turnover since Sept. 1, 1931. It was the fourth slowest day in this respect since Oct. 29, 1924. Only 473 separate issues figured in the trading, so that the market was the narrowest in about six years.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 25 -- Qualifying rounds for the men's Old Dominion golf tournament, played at the Cascades course today, were followed by large galleries. Interest was centred on Billy Howell, captain of the Washington and Lee University golf team, and R.A. Stranahan of Toledo, three times winner of the Mason and Dixon championship.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Charles M. Hay of St. Louis, one of the leading prohibitionists in the country and former counsel for the Missouri Anti-Saloon League, declared himself today in favor of submission of a liquor control plan as a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment.

Lew Feldman, Brownsville featherweight, stepped out of his class last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, and, before a slim crowd, administered a severe drubbing to Jackie Pilkington, Yorkville lightweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

LONDON, April 25 -- The intricacies of the new exchange equalization account were explained to the House of Commons today by Major Walter Elliot, Financial Secretary to the Treasury, in the absence of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who is suffering from acute gout.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The text of Dr. Millikan's paper read at the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences today follows:

WASHINGTON, April 25.-While news cameras click and leaders of American and Canadian tennis stand by, President Hoover tomorrow will make the draw for the opening round of the North American zone Davis Cup matches, to be played at the Chevy Chase Club Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

Nicholas C. Partos, who was president of the defunct Cornell drug store chain, took the stand in General Sessions yesterday at his trial on a charge that he defrauded Mrs. Helen Tar, 65 years old, of Bridgeport, Conn., of about $625 in 1929 through sale of stock in the chain.

TUEBINGEN, Germany, April 25 (AP) -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Science was conferred with solemn ceremony today upon United States Ambassador Frederic M. Sackett by the ancient University of Tuebingen as an expression of Germany's thanks for the Hoover moratorium on reparations payments.

Frank L. Dame, president of the North American Company since 1921, was elected chairman of the board at the meeting of directors, after yesterday's annual session of stockholders, and Edwin Gruhl was chosen president. Four retiring directors were re-elected for three years by the stockholders, and the directors re-elected all other officers.

Rapid progress is being made in excavation work for the first buildings on the Fifth Avenue side of Rockefeller Centre. More than 28,000 cubic yards of dirt and rock already have been removed in the central block front, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, in preparation for the erection of the British Empire Building, La Maison Franchise, the central forum and promenade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read your editorial on the Mooney case with no little satisfaction. It is timely, it is just, notably contrasting with the vociferous outpourings from other quarters of the New York press.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- Representatives of 9,000 grape growers of California unanimously adopted a program today advocating revision of the Eighteenth Amendment to permit the sale of naturally fermented beverages.

James R. Page, prosecutor of Jackson County, Mo., went aboard the American South African liner City of New York when she docked from South Africa yesterday, carrying photographs of the man who is believed to have kidnapped Mrs. Nell Donnelly, wealthy garment manufacturer, in Kansas City last December.

MADRID, April 25 (AP) -- Stringent penalties, designed to bring out of hiding millions of dollars' worth of art and antique objects now concealed by the owners, are being considered by the Republican Government.

BERLIN, April 25 -- Parliamentary chaos threatens to follow yesterday's elections for the Prussian Diet, which, despite the spectacular gains of the Hitlerites, failed to give the National Socialists (Nazis) a working majority.

The General Motors Corporation's preliminary report for the quarter ended on March 31, which was issued yesterday, showed a net income of $9,693,027, including the corporation's equity in the undivided profits or losses of subsidiary companies not consolidated.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, made public yesterday a letter he had addressed to Albert C. Benninger, Queens Park Commissioner, requesting information about the policies to be followed in the operation of the $530,000 bathing pavilion in Jacob Riis Park, which is to be opened about July 1.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith expressed his thanks yesterday to the assurance received from Thomas J. Spellacy of Hartford that Connecticut's sixteen votes in the Democratic National Convention would be for him. Most of the caucuses in Connecticut will be held this week and the State convention will be on May 16.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If further proof were needed that the drys are at last convinced that public opinion has turned against national prohibition it is furnished by the flock of proposals emanating from dry headquarters, all having for their purpose the drawing of a "referendum" herring across the path of immediate repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

ATHENS, April 25 -- A bill was introduced in the Chamber tonight providing for abandonment of the gold standard. Sponsored by the government, the bill grants a monopoly in foreign exchange transactions to the Bank of Greece and to other leading Greek banks for its account.
The Government as Publisher. Of the many changes proposed in the "omnibus" economy bill, two concern the activities of the Government as publisher.
ST.LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians used up three of the Browns' pitchers today in winning their second game of the series, 10 to 5, and St. Louis was pushed back to sixth place.

GENEVA, April 25 -- During the next two weeks the principal effort of the disarmament conference will be to "select those weapons whose character is most specifically offensive and most threatening to civilians." While that is being done all other activities except such as can be classified as private exchanges of views will be suspended.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government has been requested by Willys R. Peck, United States Consul General at Nanking, "to take all possible measures to protec't American life and property" at Amoy and in the International Settlement at Kulangsu.

Earl Sande, America's best-known jockey, at Jamaica yesterday rode his first winner since he wound up the victorious career of Gallant Fox in the Fall of 1930 at Belmont. Sande, now making a come-back, had hunch players and others backing his mount, which was the Howe Stable's Old Master, a Kentucky Derby eligible.

Samuel Seabury began the presentation of evidence yesterday to show the Hofstadter committee that a bus company in which a friend of Mayor Walker was interested had an easier time in getting a franchise for use of the city's streets than any of its competitors.

HONOLULU, April 25 -- Testimony in the Fortescue-Massie murder trial ended today when an alienist for the prosecution, Dr. Joseph Catton, said Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, on trial for murder with his mother-in-law, Mrs. Granville Fortescue, and two navy enlisted men, was sane at the time of the shooting of Joseph Kahahawai.

The outcome of the Prussian election was not wholly unexpected, but all the same reveals an unpleasant possibility. HITLER and his Nationalist allies are now apparently in a position to control the Prussian Diet. Such comfort as the democratic elements in Germany may glean out of the Prussian returns amounts to little more than saying that it might have been worse.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Stock Exchange investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee assumed a new course today with the appointment of five members, headed by Chairman Norbeck, to act as a steering committee, with full authority to choose "counsel accountants and investigators."

Dr. Samuel A. Brown has resigned as dean of the New York University and Bellevue Hospital Medical College, and has been made a member of the university council, Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday, following a meeting of the council.

BOSTON, April 25 -- Boston College won its fourth straight baseball game at University Heights today by defeating Syracuse, 2 to 1, in a well-played game. Ed Gallagher, B.C. hurler, yielded four scattered singles. The Eagles made seven hits.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A quick and heavy oversubscription of the Treasury's offering of $225,000,000 in two-year 3 per cent notes and $225,000,000 in one-year 2 per cent certificates of indebtedness was indicated when Acting Secretary Ballantine announced that the subscription books had been closed at the end of business today.

More than 2,500 unemployed exservice men will start work Saturday selling a thirty-page booklet, describing George Washington's activities in New York and its environs, at 25 cents a copy, according to plans outlined yesterday at a meeting under the auspices of the New York Bicentennial Commission at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Cochran bill to punish the sending of threatening letters through the mails was referred back to the Judiciary Committee today by the Senate.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Senate today passed and sent to the House a bill to facilitate rediscounting of intermediate credit bank debentures through the Federal Reserve System.

A huge tank, containing 210,000 gallons of oil and naphtha, solution exploded and started a fire on the Standard Oil Company's property at the foot of Caven Point Avenue, Jersey City, just before midnight last night. For a time, the flames menaced several hundred other tanks on the mile-square property.

Representatives of the drama, clergy, Police Department, civic associations, banks and real estate owners joined forces yesterday in a drive against the continuance of burlesque shows on Forty-second Street. They charged these shows injured real estate, lowered the general tone of the district and gave rise to conditions that were a degradation to the city.

Entry of the United States into the World Court on the basis of the Root protocol now awaiting ratification by the Senate is indorsed in a survey conducted for the past nine months by the National World Court Committee, It was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

In connection, with a study of the new Glass bill contained in the current bulletin of the Chase National Bank, Benjamin M. Andersen, economist of the Chase, attacks the proposal of the Federal Reserve Board to base reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve upon the velocity with which deposits are turned over.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Representative Rainey of Illinois, Democratic House leader, urged recognition of Soviet Russia today as a means of stimulating business. He expressed his views in commenting on the recognition resolution of Representative Sabath, introduced in the House last week.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 25 -- Members of the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church gathered here this evening from all parts of the country for the emergency meeting of that body and a joint conference with the National Council of the Communion, which will be held tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday.
Harms Hasting, composer-pianist, presented a number of his compositions for the modern dance last night in Steinway Hall, with what the program called "percussive assistance" by Gretl Curth.

AMOY, April 25 (AP) -- Advices from Changchow, thirty miles west of this city, today said the Chinese Communist Army had occupied the city and the soldiers were enjoying a carnival of looting, which included raids upon the homes of American missionaries, schools, churches and other foreign property.

It may be objected that the address on our public finances which Secretary MILLS made at the luncheon of The Associated Press yesterday contained nothing new. But this is really one of its high merits. It is no time for novelties or daring experiments in the handling of our great public deficit.

Separate classes and schools for the segregation of girls with behavior problems were recommended by a special committee of district superintendents and principals in a report made public yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools.

PARIS, April 25 -- Judging from the press today, the more the French think about the German elections the worse they feel, but it is significant that the Bourse had no reaction, while much of the alarm expressed must be discounted, as political propaganda on the part of Right sympathizers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- The value of the five feature stakes in the thoroughbred racing at the New York State Fair next September will be $10,000 under last year's figure, but with an advance from $600 to $800 in the overnight races the total purses of $35,000 for the meet will be about the same.

Rollin C. Bastress, 59 years old, former chief inspector of the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings, and John I. Cahalan, 55, a former construction superintendent, were sentenced to four months each in the penitentiary yesterday by Judge Koenig in General Session on their conviction about three weeks ago of accepting a $1,500 bribe for Bastress's approval of revised building plans in July, 1927.

Reports of stamp sales are now being made from 3,144 blocks out of the 9,767 blocks organized in the Block-Aid campaign, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the effort, who said it was expected that total cash subscriptions of $500,000 would be reported in a few days.

Dead hands drifting in thick gloom, a wraithlike shroud floating in the dark and a "ghost" yielded by a bellboy held some 600 men, women and children more or less spellbound last night at the Hotel McAlpin.

It is stated that the American Institute of Architects at its sixty-fifth convention in Washington this week will take steps to develop a program of cooperative action in the building industry. Organization of the Construction League of the United States, following the establishment during the last decade of building congresses in many parts of the country, will provide the starting point.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Closing its primary campaign with the customary predictions of victory on all sides, Pennsylvania sat back tonight to await tomorrow's balloting, in which is at stake the make-up of the delegation of seventy-six members to the Democratic National Convention.

The remaining assets of the Tri-Utilities Corporation, which is in receivership, will undergo a further sharp contraction on May 9, when seven parcels of its securities will be offered at public auction to the highest bidder for all or for the separate parcels of securities by the Equitable Trust Company of New York, as successor-trustee.

LONDON, April 25 -- A new search for Colonel P.H. Fawcett, the English explorer; his son, Jack, and his companion, Raleigh Rimell, reported as lost in the jungle in 1925 while seeking the cradle of Brazilian civilization and now thought by some to be alive, will be undertaken by a British expedition leaving England in June.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- AI Capone's last desperate attempt to find a legal escape from his elevenyear prison sentence was vigorously opposed today by the government.

Harry Lazarian, High School of Commerce student, captured the hardest fought of the long list of matches staged last night in the second round of the national senior four-wall soft-ball handball championship tournament in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club.

An upward swing in values placed on the lunch and fruit-stand concessions of the Dock Department was noted yesterday at an auction of five waterfront stands at the offices of the department at Pier 2, North River. The high bidders for four of the stands offered prices ranging from 40 to 100 per cent above those now in effect, and a slight reduction was made in the fifth.

STOCKHOLM, April 25 -- During a few days of inquiries in Stockholm I had occasion to speak to the leading personalities in the government, beginning with King Gustaf, who honored me with a long conversation, and later talking with various Ministers.

Approximately 1,600 barbers, chiefly in Manhattan, went on strike yesterday and will be joined in a few days by 500 to 1,000 additional men, it was announced by Anthony Merlino, vice president of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, after two meetings of the union members.

According to his legend, HAWTHORNE was something shy, apart, impenetrable, shadowy, cut off from reality, as his imaginative works are in the estimation of the late W.C. BROWNELL. Spectator HUTTON painted this withdrawing and metaphysical entity as " the ghost of New England."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your mental conflict in the editorial which characterized Governor Roosevelt's St. Paul speech as a "catch-all," and then commended its discretion, reflects a widespread impression throughout the country.

GENEVA, April 25 -- A secret meeting of the Nineteen-Power Commission of the League Assembly was called for tomorrow after its small-power members showed in a rump gathering this afternoon their impatience at the Shanghai armistice delay.

The circus had its most appreciative audience yesterday, when 14,768 youngsters from orphanages and charity institutions gathered in the Garden to pay their respects to the Messrs, Ringling, Bafnum and Bailey.

Butter. Receipts. 5,520 package. The market held full steady yesterday on all grades. Early call buying was limited, but before the close ample support developed to sustain prices in pood shape. Trading was quite broad up to noontime and we seem to have a good balance of supply and demand.

Dr. Matthew W. Sterling of the Bureau of American Anthropology at the Smithsonian Institution returned from South America yesterday on the liner Santa Rita and told of the sojourn of a party of nine scientists in the land of the Jivaros, head-hunters who live near the headwaters of the Amazon.
MADISON, Wis., April 25 (AP) -- A ten-dollar piano from a junk shop has been converted into an instrument that plays "color notes" at the University of Wisconsin.

Following the actual consummation of its purchase of the foreign properties of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is expected to form a holding company for all of its foreign properties with the possible exception of the Imperial Oil Company, Ltd., and the latter's South American subsidiary, the International Petroleum Company, Ltd.

The new week in money failed to develop any important change either in business volume or quotations. Demand for all classes of accommodation remained upon a small scale at levels unchanged from last Friday. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, outside trades 1 1/2, and Federal funds 1/8.

A proposal to speed up justice in the municipal courts by means of the arbitration plan that has been tried out by Justice Nathan Sweedler in Brooklyn was discussed yesterday at a closed meeting of sixteen justices of the court in the First District Court, 102 Court Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- New methods have been devised by which it its hoped that definite immunity from infantile paralysis may be given to human beings. Dr. Simon Flexner of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research told members of the National Academy of Sciences at their annual meeting here today.

Jose Henrique Miro, a South American by birth, called "the policy king of Harlem," was found guilty at 10:15 o'clock last night by a Federal Jury on three counts of willful evasion of payment of Federal income tax and three additional counts of failure to file income tax returns.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Farm Board has rejected offers for private sale of its surplus wheat.
BABYLON, L.I., April 25 -- Mayor Robert N. Overton of Babylon died here tonight at the age of 47 in the Brunswick General Hospital, where he underwent an appendicitis operation last Tuesday.

BOSTON, April 25 -- The Massachusetts Presidential primary election fight between the opposing factions of former Governor Smith and Governor Roosevelt wound up with a barrage of sensational charges and counter-charges delivered over the radio tonight as the two sections of the Bay State Democracy made their final pleas for the State's thirty-six votes at the Chicago national convention in June.

LONDON, April 25 -- Sterling continued to weaken today, the leading foreign exchanges moving further against London. The New York rate was $3.71 1/2. The announcement of a new u10,000,000 Indian loan checked the recent advance in Indian securities, and British Government funds were easier.

Union longshoremen maintained yesterday their refusal to load freight to and from railroad lighters at the piers of the deep-sea ship lines as long as the railroads serve the piers of coastwise lines at which fellow-members of the International Longshoremen's Association are on strike because of wage reductions.
The search for the 22-month-old son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who was kidnapped on the night of March 1 from the Lindbergh home near Hopewell, N.J., brought only negative results yesterday.

PARIS, April 25 -- The French press showed great interest today in reports from Geneva of conversations among Premier Tardieu, Chancellor Bruening and Secretary Stlmson over reparations and war debts. Inquiries made here at authoritative American and French sources, however, elicited emphatic denials of any new developments or any particular accomplishments.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 25 -- With Winter still lingering in these parts, and making itself very much felt today in a cold, gray rain that threatened to become hail, the rowing squad of Cornell is heading toward a new season which does not open for almost another month.

Emphasizing that the average citizen has been the administration's major concern in its economic relief measures, Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills outlined yesterday at the thirty-third annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria the steps the government has already taken and the policies it intends to pursue to combat the depression.

Young rebels against all that is established, accepted or perhaps merely tolerated in the world are always with us, but are never so conscious of their mission as in the Spring. Then the sap starts running, and the annual assault on the conservatives is begun.

Mrs. Edward F. Hutton gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 2 East Ninety-second Street, for persons actively interested in preparations for the Charity Carnival of 1932 to be held the night of May 3 in Madison Square Garden. Mrs. Hutton followed a custom of several years' standing in entertaining the patrons and patronesses, committee workers and members of the cast for the carnival pageant.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Disregarding arguments that he is merely "an outsider," the Senate decided, 33 to 31, late today, to permit former Senator J. Thomas Heflin of Alabama to speak two hours on the floor tomorrow and state his position in the contest he is bringing for the seat of Senator John H. Bankhead.

BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP) -- Governors Roosevelt and Ritchie, aspirants for the Democratic Presidential nomination, were attacked before the United Democratic Law Enforcement Clubs of Maryland here today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25 (AP) -- Heavy rains yesterday and this morning converted the track into a veritable quagmire and today's card at Lexington was riddled by withdrawals. The original fifth and seventh events were canceled and it was necessary to split the second and third to furnish substitutes.

So many former "realities" have come to be translated into states of mind that it is not very surprising now to find New England put up as a candidate for this distinguished honor. "Pictures of New England by a New Englander" -- Marsden Hartley -- opens today at the Downtown Gallery, to remain until May 15.

The International Film Foundation, formed independently of the motion-picture industry as a central producing and distributing organization for educational films, made its initial announcement yesterday from its headquarters at 151 East Fiftieth Street.

PARIS, April 25 -- Despite the unfavorable light in which the Prussian elections are viewed here, the Bourse remained steady today. Apparently financial circles had been expecting the Prussian results and already had taken positions. While trading in no sense was active, there was steady improvement, and the closing came in most instances on the day's highs.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 25 -- Governor Russell today announced the appointment of Major John S. Cohen, president and editor of The Atlanta Journal and Democratic National Committeeman, to fill until the November elections the place of the late Senator William J. Harris, and at the same time the Governor revealed that he would be a candidate in November for the unexpired term of Senator Harris' which runs to March 3, 1937.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on April 20 shows increases for the week of $61,000,000 in loans and investments, $77,000,000 in net demand deposits and $26,000,000 in time deposits and decreases of $117,000,000 in government deposits. $59,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks and $34,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

TRENTON, N. J., April 25 UP).A petition containing; the names, of 2,200 women voters was presented to State leaders today in protest against a recommended cut in the annual appropriation to the New Jersey College for Women.

CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals and the Cincinnati Reds changed places on the National League cellar steps today, the Cardinals mounting one by virtue of a 4-to-2 victory and the Reds slipping further down.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius K.G. Billings will return to the Pierre Friday from Santa Barbara, where they passed the Winter.

CO01 RSTOWN, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- State Troopers and local officers were on the alert when Andrew J. Horvatt, former president of the State Bank of Binghamton, wrecked through his theft of deposits, entered the court room today to face the hostile stares of fifty laborers brought to destitution by the closing of the bank.
Two $1,000 mortgage certificates changed hands yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange. The asked prices on various bond issues were revised upward.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The whole American tax problem, Federal, State and municipal, as well as all aspects of the national and State economy situation, will be discussed by President Hoover Wednesday afternoon before the conference of Governors in Richmond.

A consignment of five grams of radium worth $350,000, packed in platinum tubes worth $50,000, was received yesterday at Bellevue Hospital and turned over to Dr. Ira Kaplan, director of the cancer division of the Department of Hospitals. Bellevue now has a total of ten grams of radium on hand, twice as much, it is asserted, as any other medical institution in the world.

Active final liquidation of the May position prior to notices today carried prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange to within 2 points of the low levels of the month, but the market strengthened in the last hour and closed with gains of 5 to 7 points.

If FARADAY is generally regarded as the discoverer of induced electricity, it is because he was the first to publish his results. There can be no doubt that JOSEPH HENRY anticipated him by a year. It was therefore fitting that last night the National Academy of Sciences should have commemorated the hundredth anniversary of HENRY'S electrical discoveries.

Definite progress on the part of many debtor nations of the world toward establishing favorable trade balances is revealed in a survey of the foreign trade of twenty-two countries for 1931 prepared by the National Industrial Conference Board.

THE HAGUE, April 25 -- Five fossil skulls of the age of the Neanderthal man, more recent that the Pithecanthropus Erectus skull discovered in East Java, have been found on the banks of the Solo River in Java. The finders, Engineers Terhaar and Oppenoorth of the geological charting service, called the type "Homo Javanthropus Soloensis" and estimated its age at 100,000 years.

Newspapers of America have caried on admirably in spite of the depression and they have been aided to some extent in doing so "through increasing reliance upon The Associated Press," Kent Cooper asserted in his report as general manager, submitted to the board of directors of The Associated Press at its thirty-third annual meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The State of California has decided to sell at auction its issue of $3,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds on May 19 instead of on May 10 as private advices had indicated. The bonds will bear interest at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent and will mature serially on Feb. 1, 1937 to 1953.

RIGHT out of the library comes a tip that might lead to interesting developments in pugilism, baseball or some other field of sports. This very evening and in this very city, certain amateurs of printing, binding, first editions, original manuscripts, old folios and quaint quartos will be attending the Colophon dinner.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 25 -- Secretary Hurley, making the keynote address today before the Republican State Convention, praised President Hoover's steps to lead the way out of the depression.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 25 (AP) -- An extensive search of the Providence and Seekonk Rivers and Narragansett Bay as far as Bristol for the body of Floyd F. Stewart, missing Harvard Business School student, with airplanes and divers to aid in the hunt if necessary, was authorized this afternoon by Joseph Stewart of Garden City, Kan., the youth's father, after a conference with the East Providence police.

CHARLOTTESVTLLE, Va., April 25 -- Governors of thirty States came from their Richmond conference today to witness the unveiling of a statue of James Monroe, the work of the Italian sculptor Artillio Piccirilli.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Demands by counsel for the New England Governors' Committee that Federal approval of the proposed four-party plan of Eastern railroad consolidation be made conditional on divestment by Pennsylvania Railroad interests of their stock holdings in New England roads marked the opening today of final argument on the plan before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ALGIERS, April 2 (by mail) -- Thousands of men have been thrown out of work here by the shutting down of the iron ore, zinc and phosphate mines because the freight to ship the minerals out of the country costs more than the market price of the products in Europe at present.

PARIS, April 25 -- Cooperation and rapprochement -- the policies of Aristide Briand -- were invoked almost for the first time in the present political campaign by Joseph Caillaux, former Premier, speaking at Nantes tonight in the district in which the dead former Foreign Minister would have been a candidate.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -- Harry G. Hendricks, who was deposed last week as a receiver for the Earl Radio Corporation, was sentenced today to three years in the State prison for contempt of court by Vice Chancellor John H. Backes. Hcndricks, who had been a receiver for sixteen concerns under appointment by Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church until his removal in the Earl rase, was found guilty of the contempt charge on Thursday.

John Walter, co-chief proprietor o The London Times, in an address at the thirty-third annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, asserted that the day of the "self-sufficient newspaper," like that of the self-sufficient individual, had passed.

DETROIT, April 25 -- The National League of Women Voters assembled here today for a five-day convention, in which 600 elected or appointed delegates will decide the participation in government which will be attempted during the next two years by their constituent State or local leagues in forty-two States, the District of Columbia and Hawaii.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 25 (CanadianPress) -- Dornier-X, largest flying boat in the world, will hop off from Newfoundland and head out over the Atlantic about May 20, according to Captain Wilhelm Neimann, navigation officer, who is selecting a suitable base for the giant plane on this coast.

Anne Schmidt made her debut as a solo dance recitalist last night in the Town Hall in a program of "sketches and dances." The performance was a benefit for the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College and was well attended.

On the strength of an affidavit signed by Mayor Walker, reciting the most recent effort of the Board of Estimate to provide franchised bus service in Manhattan and Queens. Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division in.

VIENNA, April 25 -- Austrian Hitlerites, who gained about 18 per cent of the votes cast yesterday by three-fourths of the Austrian electors, said today they would introduce to Austrian Parliamentary politics the emphatic methods pursued in the election campaign.

The possibilities of basic changes in the Democratic and Republican parties which the coming election may involve is at least as important as the election itself, according to Jay Franklin, whose book, "What We Are About to Receive," is published today by Covici, Friede.

The addresses of twenty-eight places raided as speakeasies or liquor stores in a continuation of the drive started recently by Federal agents were made public yesterday by the local prohibition enforcement authorities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Legal action to break the will of Arthur Peterson, former naval officer and editor who died on Feb. 17, leaving an estate estimated at nearly $1.000,000, was begun in Orphans Court here today by his brother, Walter Peterson, who was not mentioned in the will.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 25 (AP) -- Tornadoes willed at least six persons in farming communities of this vicinity today, injured a score or more, and also did extensive damage in other sections of the State and in Arkansas and Kentucky. Several communities In Northern Alabama were damaged by hard winds last night.

Several Manhattan residential properties, including a tall apartment house on Riverside Drive, will be offered in auction sales to be held today. Tomorrow's list will include a sixteen-story house on West End Avenue.

The names of two Governors may appear at the head of the Democratic national ticket, if Governor Roosevelt receives the nomination for President. With an active boom in progress for Governor George H. Dern of Utah for second place, many prominent Roosevelt supporters are already predicting that if the New Yorker is nominated, Governor Dern will be his running mate.

A large German shepherd dog that already had killed a Boston terrier and bitten three persons, in West New York, N.J., boarded the Manhattan-bound ferry Utica at the Weehawken slip of West Shore Ferries yesterday and bit three passengers and tore the clothing of six others before he was finally trapped , in the men's cabin and shot.

MONTREAL, April 25 -- Canadian International Paper Company becomes the world's largest producer of newsprint paper, controlling a daily capacity of 2,800 tons of newsprint through its acquisition, announced today, of the New Brunswick International Paper Compnny and the International Power and Paper Company of Newfoundland, Ltd.

The Master School of Music, a new conservatory for teachers and advanced students, will open this Summer in Siena, Italy, under the direction of Claude Gonvierre, American pianist living in Italy, through the generosity of Count Guido Chigi-Saracini, Mr. Gonvierre announced yesterday at the Hotel Wellington.

Just as most of us were beginning to suspect that the season was virtually over, one of the finest plays of the year came quietly into the Booth last evening. It is entitled "Another Language," and it is the work of Rose Franken, one-time author of a psychoanalytical novel entitled "Pattern."

Xavier Resigno of the Manhattan freshmen hurled his team to a 9-to-3 victory yesterday at Jasper Field, defeating the Samuel Johnson Academy nine of Stratford, Conn. He allowed only six hits, the losers combining these safeties in the third inning for their only tallies.

MARION, Ohio, April 25 (AP) -- Reputed to have been the only editor ever to direct the operation of a newspaper for a President of the United States, George H. Van Fleet of The Marion Star retired today after an editorial career of nearly four decades.
Several business properties were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday, in addition to scattered residential deals.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Secretary Hyde and the office of Attorney General Mitchell denied today the accusation by Donald D. Conn in California, that Fruit Industries, Ltd., "had its genesis as a result of conferences between the Department of Justice, the Treasury an the Department of Agriculture in Washington."

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, April 25 -- Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, who, more than twenty years ago, in a little Pennsylvania town, started the movement that has become the First Century Christian Fellowship, told today of its present sweep and magnitude and offered it as the salvation of the world.
BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Exchange Trust Company failed to open this morning. A notice posted on the doors stated the bank's affairs had been taken over by the State Commissioner of Banks.

A whirring automaton of shining steel that can turn out 50,000 news papers an hour has just been in stalled in the pressroom, of THE NEW YORK TIMES and will be on exhibition this week to the visiting delegates of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association.

Every year the forest fire season reaches two peaks, one in the early Spring and the other in the late Fall. April is always a bad month, often the worst month. Two years ago conditions became so bad early in May that Governor ROOSEVELT, for the second time in the history of the State, had to close the forests.
Starting tonight, Tuesday evening performances of "The Laugh Parade," Ed Wynn's revue at the Imperial Theatre, will be eliminated. Mr. Wynn will begin a aeries of weekly radio broadcasts tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Payment of $5,000 to Senelma Wirkkula of Big Falls, Minn., whose husband, Henry Wirkkula, was shot to death by Emmett J. White, United States border patrolman, was approved today by the Senate.

DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- One man was killed and thirty persons were injured in an explosion of gas that ripped a one-story plumbing shop out of a row of buildings this afternoon in Hamilton Avenue, Highland Park, and wrecked several other stores nearby.

Connecticut's advisory council, which acts in conjunction with the State Board of Fisheries and Game, has recommended that the State bureau be empowered by the Legislature to set the open season for fishing and hunting. This would expand the duties of the board which now can only arbitrarily advance the opening date for shad fishing.

ST. JOHN, N.B., April 25 (Canadian Press) -- The newsprint mill at Dalhousie reflects the most modern development in newsprint mill construction. Two of its machines began operation early in 1930 and the other two in November, 1930, and January, 1931.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua April 25 -- A Nicaraguan National Guard patrol of forty soldiers, under Gunnery Sergeant John Hamas of Philadelphia, Sergeant John A. Burns of Burgaw, N.C., Corporal David H. Wallace of Caddo, La., and Luis Emilio Gutierrez of Ocotal pursuing a band which had attacked and killed three United States Marine Corps non-commissioned officers near Apali serving with the Guard, battled with a group of 100 outlaws yesterday near the Guambuco mountains.

E. Gerli Co. will pay $16,320,000 to the Japanese governmental agency which has just sold to them 14,144,000 pounds of silk and terminated its efforts to stabilize the market. This is at the rate of $150 a bale of 130 pounds each, and substantially below the price quoted here for crack double extra, the highest grade.

RICHMOND, April 25 -- With President Hoover revealed as a prospective speaker on Wednesday, the twenty-fourth annual Governors' conference opened here today and spread itself over a large portion of the State.
PARIS, April 25 (Canadian Press) France entered calmly today into the final week of the struggle before election day, next Sunday.

Synchronizing his offering of $75,000,000 of New York State 2 3/4 per cent notes, due in one year, with the announcement of the United States Treasury's financing plans for May 2, State Controller Tremaine formally opened yesterday the subscription books on the State's issue and before the close of business he had in hand orders aggregating more than $200,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- New money plans for cashing the soldiers' bonus were assailed by organized manufacturers as "economic bunk" today in a House hearing broken by the hissed resentment of veterans against former war comrade who opposed the $2,400,000,000 payment.
The text of the address by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, before The Associated Press at its annual luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday fallows:

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate Finance Committee made quick work of the tariff items proposed for the billion-dollar tax bill today, and moved on to remodeling the measure with such speed that a report to the floor for action by early next week was deemed assured.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25 (AP) -- Walter M. Jeffords's Boatswain, a recent winner at this track and an entrant for the Preakness, accounted for the featured Mayfield Purse, an allowance affair at a mile and seventy yards, today at Havre de Grace.

In addition to Governor Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Lehman and a number of prominent bankers will appear as witnesses in behalf of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, it was learned yesterday. Among the bankers will be P.A. Rowley, president of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company, and Mortimer N. Buckner. chairman of the board of the New York Trust Company and recently named member of the New York State Banking Board.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, national women's tennis champion, arrived in New York from San Francisco yes terday, en route to Europe, where she will captain the United States Wightman Cup team and seek to re gain the French and English championships which she allowed to go undefended last year.

The Finance Committee of the Senate began yesterday to rewrite the House version of the new revenue bill. Hearings which were concluded last week furnished few surprises. Plenty of witnesses appeared, but no volunteers for higher taxes. Representatives of the automobile industry, the retail druggists, the manufacturers of electrical refrigerators, the security brokers and many others testified in opposition to the special excise taxes on products which they make or sell.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Controller General McCarl was accused today by T.V. O'Connor, chairman of the Shipping Board, of exceeding his authority and of "an inability to comprehend or a refusal to recognize" Congressional acts applicable to the board.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Fairly general rains over the greater part of the Winter and Spring grain areas caused selling today on the Board of Trade that sent prices fractionally under Saturday's finish. Material pressure was absent, and even sharp breaks in corn and oats had only a temporary effect.

Mayor Walker's committee charged with the arrangements for the "beer for taxation" parade on May 14 estimated yesterday that forty-eight divisions of the demonstration would be necessary to accommodate those who have already asked for places in the line of march.

Freight revenue of the Missouri Pacific Railroad decreased from $99,779,356 in 1930 to $79,709,811 in 1931, or by 20 per cent, according to the report for last year of L.W. Baldwin, president. Revenue tonnage declined 19.3 per cent and ton-miles 20.7 per cent.

Lieutenant George Calnan of the United States Navy, a member of the Fencers Club of New York, just managed to qualify for the national foils championship finals last night in the semi-finals of the competition at the New York Athletic Club. Calnan, defending champion, was extended considerably in the second round of the semi-finals.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- The largest number of entries in the history of the University of Pennsylvania's annual relay carnival has been received for the program of twelve special events, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Four members of the National Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement, George W. Wickersham, Judge William I. Grubb, Judge William S. Kenyon and Judge Paul J. McCormick, urged a further trial of the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead act when their report was presented to President Hoover fifteen months ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- After several weeks of discussion the Pacific Coast-Europe Conference, consisting of the nine foreign lines carrying passengers and cargo between the Pacific Coast and ports of Europe, today decided on a general reduction of approximately 10 per cent.

Frederick Starr, Manhattan contractor, announced yesterday that he had purchased the four-mile Whitestone spur of the Long Island Railroad. Mr. Starr, who has been negotiating the purchase of the branch since shortly after the railroad abandoned it on Feb. 15, declined to discuss either the terms of the sale or the exact use to which the line would be put.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 25 -- About 300 alumni, students and friends of Upsala College attended a reception in honor of Wollmar Bostrom, Minister from Sweden to the United States given tonight by the women's auxiliary of the college. The reception, in the music rooms of the college, followed a dinner given for Mr. Bostrom by Mrs. August Merz.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was dull and generally lower yesterday. The United States Government list ran counter to the market trend, rallying mildly. Transactions in bonds on the Exchange aggregated $6.324,000, the lightest since Aug. 3. 1931, when dealings totaled $6.016,000.

With only four days of preparation remaining before their first regatta of the season with Navy on the Severn at Annapolis, Columbia University's oarsmen went through a spirited seven-mile drill on the Harlem yesterday. The authorities plan lengthy workouts for today and tomorrow with a slight let-down coming on Thursday.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa, April 25 -- Countless billions of locusts, moving inexorably forward at the rate of 100 miles a day, are laying waste great areas of West Africa and adjoining parts of the Union of South Africa.

Belief that the application of the Prudence Company for a loan of about $20,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation may be granted soon was expressed by officials of the company yesterday after a meeting of holders of stock of New York Investors, the parent company, at which the posting of other subsidiary stocks as collateral for the proposed loan was approved.

A tentative program for the development of new sources of city revenue will be submitted to the Board of Estimate within the next few weeks, it was indicated yesterday at City Hall. The program, which is being mapped out under the direction of Mayor Walker and his executive aides, will be the subject of a detailed report to be considered soon at an executive session of members of the Board of Estimate.

MIAMI, Fla., April 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Jessie Keith-Miller and her flying partner, Captain W.N. Lancaster, apparently were released today from possibility of a grand jury investigation of the mysterious death of Haden Clarke, 26 years old, author and fiance of the Australian aviatrix, at her home here.

Louis Zeltner wiped the inkstains off his fingers yesterday in his office at 25 West Forty-second Street, tipped his chair back till it creaked and proudly glanced at the formal charges he had drawn against the Hon. Stitch McCarthy, chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors.

A summary of the results of clinical and experimental research on the causes of the common cold and its relation to rheumatic fever, the heart and blood vessels, allergic manifestations, and to the involvement of the paranasal sinuses and the ears was presented last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by six specialists in their respective fields at a symposium under the auspices of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Losing his control after two were out in the twelfth inning, relief pitcher Ben Cantwell walked pinch-hitter Douglass Taitt to force in the winning run and give the Phillies a hard-earned 4-to-3 victory over the Braves today. It broke a six-game winning streak for the McKechnie men.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Right of way for the omnibus economy bill for curtailing Federal expenditures more than $266,000,000 was granted today by the House Rules Committee.

Stocks marked time yesterday as Wall Street continued to debate the dividend uncertainties of some of the largest industrial companies. Business was at low ebb on the Stock Exchange and the net changes in prices were inconsequential. The bond market also was dull; aside from a modest advance in some of the United States Government issues, the trend was irregularly downward.

BERLIN, April 25 -- The Boerse's reaction to the Prussian elections was favorable. There was no nervousness, but on the contrary, there was a certain feeling of relief that the elections are over Bankers pointed out that a large number of stocks are still considerably undervalued.

Sandwiched between the steady parade of witnesses called by those opposing renewals of licenses to the burlesque shows at the Eltinge and Minsky's Republic Theatres on West Forty-second Street at the continued hearing before License Commissioner James F. Geraghty yesterday were two who testified for the applicants and voiced their hearty approval of the performances.

LONDON, April 26. -- Dominions Secretary J.H. Thomas served another warning today on Eamon de Valera. President of the Irish Free State Council, that the British Government regarded his bill to abolish the oath a repudiation of the 1921 treaty.

The business giants of thirty years ago would be dwarfed in business today, Ida M. Tarbell, who has been writing biographies of business men for forty years, said in an interview yesterday. The elder Rockefeller, Carnegie, Hill and Harriman would today find themselves blocked in most of their major dealing's by the general acceptance of more complex social and economic codes, she declared.

As it came from the House, the tax bill imposed tariff duties on fifteen products, of which fuel oil, coal and gasoline were the most important. The Senate Finance Committee has added a tariff on copper. It refused to place a duty on logs and lumber; but Senator JONES announced that he will insist on a vote on this proposal in the Senate.

Net income of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, as shown in the annual report mailed yesterday to stockholders, was $1,246,594 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, subsidiary preferred stocks and minority interests.

LONDON, April 26. -- Continued liquidation resulted in a further sharp fall in sterling in the foreign exchange market today, the New York rate dropping to $3.64 1/4, a deline of 3 3/4 cents on balance. Continental currencies moved with the dollar.

State Senator John A. Hastings demanded a contribution to Mayor Walker's campaign fund in 1925 as a step toward obtaining a bus franchise for the Equitable Coach Company, according to evidence presented yesterday to the Hofstadter committee.
WARSAW, April 26. -- A semi-official communique says that a private conference of the President's advisers was held yesterday, but announces no official decisions.

When the terms of the contract for the operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway were first announced, fear was expressed that they were so harsh that no responsible company would be willing to accept them. The annual compensation to be paid the lessee was to be taken out of net revenues; no net revenues, no compensation.

An "electric ear" that intercepts, analyzes and records graphically all sounds "within its range will be in operation tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House during the special performance of "Rigoletto."

STOCKHOLM, April 26. -- The mystery of the forged Italian Treasury bills found in Ivar Kreuger's safe is now explained by Professor Martin Fehr, one of the official investigators. It appears that Kreuger forged the bills to exchange them with the International Match Corporation for a holding of $50,000,000 worth of German bonds.

PARIS, April 26. -- A divorce has been granted to Mrs. John Munroe, the former Misa Adelaide Sedgewick, by a Paris court, it was learned today. The Munroes were married at Port Chester, N.Y., in September, 1929.

GARDEN CITY., L.I., April 26. -- A call for the appointment of a committee to investigate departments of the national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church because of what was asserted to be gross extravagances in administration was made this afternoon at the opening session of an "emergency meeting" of the House of Bishops of that communion at the Garden City Hotel.

The outlook for the petroleum Industry is better, on the whole, than a year ago, R.C. Holmes, president of the Texas Corporation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. He explained that efforts were being made continuously to control the production of crude oil, but he added that progress was slow.

The forty-eight-story Continental Bank Building at 30 Broad Street, newest addition to the office skyscrapers of the downtown financial district, will be officially opened today to receive its first tenants.

A "floating university," which will have a student body of approximately 600 and will travel more than 35,000 miles around the world in eight months, is being planned for next Fall, it was announced yesterday. The movement is supported by a large group of men and women prominent in social, educational and business circles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Robert Henderson, in his letter to THE TIMES, advocates Rudolph Spreckels's plan to tax American investments in manufacturing enterprises abroad. He and Mr. Spreckels have evidently been disturbed by the great number of American, concerns which have established branch factories in Canada and several European countries in order to overcome the situation created by the Hawley-Smoot tariff.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 26. -- The Chamber of Deputies voted today to eliminate from the budget an item inserted as in compliance with the Stifel-Nicolaus loan contract of 1922.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- A speeding up of loans to companies and institutions eligible to borrow from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has resulted in the issuance by the corporation of $250,000,000 of six months' notes, all of which will be purchased tomorrow by the Secretary of the Treasury.

John Dunwoody Jr. of the Pastime A.C. furnished an upset last night in the national senior four-wall soft-ball handball championship tournament at the New York Athletic Club when he defeated Herman Dworman of Detroit, a favorite for the title, in a thrilling three-game match, 7-21, 21-11, 21-9.

In a report prepared by the committee on Federal trade commission and anti-trust laws of the Merchants' Association and made public yesterday the Davis-Kelly bill, which has been introduced in Congress for the avowed purpose of relieving the coal industry, is described as "one of the most perfect examples of legislative gold brick that has ever been offered to any group of American business men."
Miguel A. de Capriles, defending champion, was eliminated in the semi-final round of the national epee-Championship tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

HONOLULU, April 26 (AP). -- Although attorneys on both sides in the Massie-Fortescue trial expressed the desire to get the case to the jury tomorrow, the arguments of Clarence Darrow, chief of defense counsel, and of the public prosecutor, John C. Kelley, and Judge Charles Davis's instructions to the jury remained to be delivered.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP). -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines told the House Ways and Means Committee today that government expenditures on World War veterans would aggregate by 1945 the cost of that war.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26. -- Final decision was reached today by Governor Moore and legislative leaders of both parties to enact laws imposing an additional tax of two cents per gallon on gasoline in order temporarily to finance relief work in the State and to provide for a referendum vote at the general election in November on a $20,000,000 bond issue to carry on the program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- Animals have been immunized against infantile paralysis for more than two years at the Harvard Medical School, but experiments are too premature to permit the application to children, it was learned from the Harvard Infantile Paralysis Commission today.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26. -- Six exceptions were taken to provisions in the Glass banking bill here today by the executive council of the American Bankers' Association.

The long examination at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, of Hyman Lipschutz, once bookkeeper for the principal affiliates of the defunct Bank of United States, drew toward its close yesterday when, after nearly three weeks of intermittent questioning, Max D. Steuer ended his direct examination.

As far back as 1785 the French physicist COULOMB noted that the air is electrically conductive. Why? Not until our own time could an answer be given. The atmosphere becomes conductive -- "ionized" in our more precise language -- when electrons have been torn from atoms. X-rays, the gamma rays of radium, electrons can thus ionize air.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Studebaker Corporation, held yesterday in Jersey City, A.R. Erskine, president, said the directors of the company probably would suspend today the dividend on the company's common stock, and that its subsidiary, the Pierce-Arrow Company, probably would omit its preferred dividend today.

ALBANY, April 26. -- More gasoline was sold in the State in February than in any corresponding month, the Department of Taxation and Finance reported today. The total was 10 per cent above January and 27 per cent over the figure for a year ago.

Edward Kuhn, 78 years old, of the Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street, was fatally injured shortly before 9 o'clock last night when he was run down by a newspaper delivery truck as he was crossing Sixty-second Street at Madison Avenue.

The listed bond market showed a small degree of improvement yesterday in virtually all departments. Trading, which increased somewhat, was still considerably below what is generally considered an average day. United States Government bonds improved more as a group, with nine of the eleven active issues moving up 2-32 to 15.32 point and the Treasury 4 1/4 s and 4s declining 1-32 and 3-32 respectively.

Civic and shipping interests urged the War Department yesterday to dredge the Hackensack River to a depth of fifteen feet between the seaboard and Hackensack at a hearing before Colonel R.T. Ward of the Second District engineers at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

Nicholas C. Partos, organizer and president of the Cornel. Drug Stores, Inc., which went into the hands of a receiver in March, 1930, after a stock-selling campaign, continued his testimony under cross-examination yesterday at his trial in General Sessions on a charge of defrauding a woman investor by misrepresentation.

For the third time in its history, and the first time since January, 1915, directors of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday omitted the dividend on the common stock, which was placed on a $2 annual basis three months ago. The regular quarterly dividend of 1 3/4 per cent on the preferred stock was declared.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP). -- A challenge to make Russian recognition a clean-cut party issue came today from Representative Fish, New York Republicaln.
