In a statement he referred to assertions by Senator Robinson of Arkansas and Representative Rainey of Illinois, Democratic leaders in the Senate and House, favoring rcognition of Moscow and added:

A group of persons affiliated with the American Civil Liberties Union and headed by Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the organization, plans to leave New York tomorrow afternoon for Kentucky, where they hope to be able to help the striking coal miners in Harlan and Bell Counties.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- The Harvard Athletic Association today announced the schedules for four of Harvard's Winter sport teams for next season. The dates are for basketball, swimming, wrestling and boxing.

BOSTON, April 26. -- Massachusetts will cast its full complement of thirty-six delegate votes for Alfred E. Smith for the Presidential nomination at the Democratic National Convention at Chicago two months hence.

PARIS, April 26. -- James H. DunCan, American veteran of the World War and for many years superintendent of the American Military Cemeetery at Suresnes, is in a serious condition in the hospital at Boulognesur-Seine tonight as a result of self-inflicted bullet wounds.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 26. -- Surgery will cure 40 per cent of the tuberculosis cases that can be reached by it, Dr. William Francis Honan, director of thoracic surgery at the Metropolitan and Seaview Hospitals in New York, said today at a meeting of the Homeopathic Medical Society of the State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As president of our local Chamber of Commerce, I had a telegram from Frank Knox, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, asking me to accept the local chairmanship of an organization for the sale of a new issue of government certificates for the purpose of getting out hoarded money.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The Court of Appeals today cleared John C. Flinn and Henry F. Lalley, Pathe studio officials, of manslaughter indictments in the deaths of Catherine Porter and Edna Burford, who lost their lives in the fire in December, 1929. at the Pathe motion picture studio, 1,990 Park Avenue, New York City.

The name "The National "Urban League" does not convey to many the purpose of this organization. But when it is known that KINCKLE JONES is its administrative secretary, its identity is better recognized. The league is concerned with spreading the knowledge of conditions under which Negroes live and work in the cities to which they have migrated in such vast numbers in the last three decades.

Financial aid aggregating about $25,000,000 was made available by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to numerous small banking institutions throughout the country which were in danger of having to close their, doors. This was revealed yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, president of the company, at the annual convention of its field managers.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Senator Watson, Republican leader, who is seeking re-election, said today that he believed there should be a referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment and that the States should set up machinery for it.

The fourth of the Tuesday night concerts of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of 200 unemployed players last evening in the Metropolitan Opera House was devoted to Wagner and was conducted by Walter Damrosch, with Ernestine Schumann-Heink as soloist.
HAVRE DE GRACE, April 26 (AP). -- The Glyndon Purse, for 4-year-olds and upward under allowance conditions, featured today's program at Havre de Grace and it went to Her Grace.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, April 26 (AP). -- Alien Carp of New York and E.P. Beck, members of the expedition which will make a study of cosmic dust, were landed yesterday on Muldrow Glacier, at an altitude of 6,200 to 6,500 feet, by Joe Crosson, pilot of a large cabin plane.

A small boy with very red hair ran up to Patrolman Arthur Engh at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at Second Avenue and Eighth Street in Brooklyn. His eyes were wide with fright and his red hair stood on end.

LONDON, April 26 (Canadian Press). -- Husband and wife, each a politician of some celebrity, are supporting opposite sides in the byelection in St. Marylebone, where polling takes place on Thursday. Captain Hilton Philipson, Liberal member of the House of Commons for Berwick-on-Tweed for a brief period from November, 1922, is actively campaigning on behalf of Captain Alec Cunningham-Reid.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- Yale's baseball team hit the offerings of Stefanelli hard and in timely fashion to defeat Syracuse, 7 to 2, today. Ned Wheeler of Yale was steady in the pinches and allowed the visitors only five hits, his delivery puzzling the Orangemen.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Only a single seat will separate the leading Republican and Democratic Presidential contenders when they break bread together at the White House next Thursday night.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26 (AP). -- William (Gorilla) Jones of Akron, Ohio, recognized by the National Boxing Association as the world's middleweight champion, successfully defended his title tonight by taking a twelve-round decision from Young Terry of Trenton.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26. -- The political issues on which women voters should take a position in the coming campaign were examined here today by the National League of Women Voters, which is now assembled in biennial convention to determine what government operations the State leagues and affiliated societies in forty-two States shall study during the next two years and what they shall support as a result of the past two years of study.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter are giving a dinner tonight in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. William Beverley Rogers.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Charges of the California grape industry that it had been betrayed by the government through the prosecution of the concentrate business were met by a statement at the Department of Justice today that no change in policy had been adopted as to the distribution of grape products.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Reports from leading investigators on climatic cycles and their value in longdistance forecasting featured the closing sessions of the National Academy of Sciences today.

HONOLULU, April 26. -- An instant's insanity at the moment of a criminal act will not excuse that act, Barry S. Ulrich, the assistant prosecutor, today told the jury which tomorrow will take in its hands the fate of the four defendants in the Fortescue-Massie murder trial.

Indictments charging grand larceny in connection with their management of the defunct Equitable Casualty and Insurance Company were returned yesterday by the grand jury against Harold Spielbergr, 53 years old, a lawyer, of 21 West Eighty-sixth Street, and his brother, Bernard, 29 years old, of the same address.

MUKDEN, Manchuria,. April 26. -- Despite feverish preparation for an attempt to impress the League of Nations' investigators the "independent" Manchoukuo Government presents an unconvincing and sometimes an astonishing and amusing spectacle.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Opposition from various New England interests to the proposed four-party consolidation of Eastern railroads encountered support of the plan by business and commercial organizations from the same section, during final arguments before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

Prohibition has been both a boon and a bane to California. Its first effect was to double the vineyard area of the State. Prices rose nobly. There was the usual boom, followed by the usual slump. The Government stepped in. How could money be better spent than on relief of a once mighty and always deserving California industry?

Daily average gross crude oil prodiction in the United States for the week ended on last Saturday was 2,267,900 barrels, compared with 2,181,650 for the preceding week, an increase of 86,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,747,600 barrels daily, against 1,663,850, a rise of 83,750 barrels.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Contending that he was defrauded of his seat in the Senate by widespread corruption in the Alabama election last year, former Senator J. Thomas Heflin occupied the Senate floor for five hours and twelve minutes today. He consumed all but seventeen minutes of the Senate's session.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 26 (AP). -- Marlene Dietrich, German screen, star, and James Cagney, two of the leading money-making performers in motion pictures, "were suspended by their studios today because of disputes over their work and salary, respectively.

The steady improvement in the demand for high-grade municipal bonds, which is expected eventually to lead the general bond market out of its present low estate, is at present most pronounced in the short, maturities, those of a year or two. Municipal bankers reported yesterday that it was next to impossible to obtain a sufficient volume of firstgrade short-term municipals to satisfy the demand.

Controller Morris S. Tremaine consummated yesterday the largest deal in the history of New York State financing when he allotted the issue of $75,000,000 one-year 2 3/4 per cent notes to seventy-five New York State banks and banking houses in amounts ranging from $2,000,000 to $100,000.

The quick turnover of an apartment house on Washington Heights was announced yesterday, when Ennis Sinnott resold the five-and-one-half-story building at 565 West 188th Street. The house occupies a plot 62.6 by 100 feet, between Audubon and St. Nicholas Avenues.

RICHMOND, April 26. -- Prohibition came to the forefront of the Governors' conference here tonight as Governor Ritchie of Maryland demanded a return to State liquor control and pointed to the large revenue loss under present conditions.

Representatives of the smaller daily newspapers of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at a special meeting yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria, laid down the principle that they must balance their budgets without impairing their service, which during the economic stringency should do perhaps more than any other agency to restore public confidence.

Net income of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31 was $23,163,141 after taxes, charges and depreciation. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.16 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding.

Railroad statements issued yesterday showed for the most part operating or net deficits in March or else reduced net returns, although the Illinois Central more than doubled its net operating income in the month. This resulted in part from drastic economies and from a reduction in depreciation charges, which formerly were figured at about 5 per cent.
The Yankees climbed into second place in the league standing yesterday by defeating Washington, 6 to 5, at the Yankee Stadium in the first meeting of the year between the two teams.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26. -- Chancellor Edwin Robert Walker revealed today that he had asked twice for the resignation of Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church of Newark as a result of the disclosures in receivership cases that led yesterday to the sentencing of Harry G. Hendricks to three years in prison on a charge of contempt of court.

CAMP MULDROW GLACIER, April 14 (By Dog Team to McKinley Park Station). -- So far everything is progressing satisfactorily. We made the trip to our base camp on the Clear Water River in four days. The climbing party on skis, with an outfit hauled by three dog teams, arrived in just a week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: David L. Saunders closes his letter to THE TIMES with the following observation:

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- An assertion that corruption of newspaper financial writers was a routine part of "bull pool" operations was made before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia.

TOKYO, April 26. -- The government is ready to give favorable consideration to a new formula for Japanese evacuation of Shanghai offered by Sir Miles W. Lampson, British Minister to China, who is a member of the League of Nations Mixed Commission on Shanghai.

The Brooklyn office of the Laundry Board of Trade of Greater New York, Inc., will be closed next Saturday and the services of the official there discontinued, it was disclosed yesterday at the resumption of the public hearing into the activities and practices of the laundry industry in New York City before Referee Nathan Friedman, in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.
There was no official indication yesterday of any definite trace of the 22-month-old son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who was kidnapped March 1.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP).-- To date, the two parties have selected 966 delegates to their national conventions in June. Of these, the Republicans have chosen 470 and the Democrats 496.

Salons of America, Inc., is ten years old this year. "Founded in 1922 by Hamilton Easter Field," a catalogue note observes, "its purpose, a democratic one, is to afford equal opportunity for all -- no jury exhibitions'." The anniversary celebration began last evening, with the opening of the Spring Salon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, an exhibition containing nearly 400 paintings, water-colors, prints, drawings and pieces of sculpture.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- The Yale freshman nine defeated Colby Academy today, 8 to 1. Davis Harrington, who has started all the freshman games this season, allowed only three hits.

Ha Ha, the 3-year-old son of Polymelian and Many Smiles, became the first triple winner of the meeting when he won the Highland Claiming Stakes, feature at Jamaica yesterday. The colt won the first race of the metropolitan season, repeated for W.R. Coe on the fourth day, and scored yesterday in the silks of F. Costello, who claimed Ha Ha after his last race.

Some improvement in the stock market appeared yesterday, but the volume of trading was so small that little importance could be attached to the negligible swing of prices. The day's transactions on the Stock Exchange were only slightly larger than on the day before.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody will sail tonight for England on the Cunarder Aquitania to captain the American team that will play abroad. Others sailing on the Aquitania include Mme. Lucrezia Bori, opera singer; Mrs. Somerset Maugham, Arthur S. Vernay, Mrs. David Dows, Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell Iselin, Marques de Faronda, Mrs. E.S. Canning, J.A. Crabtree, Mrs. H.M. Gaudet, Miss E. Markell, Mr. and Mrs. W.D. Miller, Mrs. W. Smith and Miss J. White.

St. Ann's Academy, defending city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion, scored its third straight Manhattan Division C.H.S. A.A. victory yesterday at Macomb's Dam Park, vanquishing Fordham Prep, 10 to 0.

A Plan With Details. The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce is out with a program of municipal economy which has the merit of being explicit. A 10 per cent reduction in the city budget for 1933 is the Chamber's goal.
LONDON, April 26 (AP). -- Board of Trade figures for 1930 show British exports to Russia of u6,000,000 and imports of u34,000,000. In 1929 exports were u3,000,000 against imports of u26,000,000.
After the circulation of notices for about 38,000 bales, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday and closed 4 to 7 points lower than on Monday.

Yascha Yushny and his "Blue Bird" company will end their limited engagement on Sunday night at the Cort Theatre, to which they came last Thursday right after a six months' transcontinental tour. Mr. Yushny and his troupe are scheduled to sail immediately for Berlin to begin a Summer season.

Plans for refunding nearly half the $11,000,000 of the 5 per cent gold bonds of the United Light Railways Company of Maine maturing on June 1 and for the payment of principal and accrued interest on the old bonds at their maturity were announced last night by William Chamberlain, president of the parent company, the United Light Power Company.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Industrial unemployment is increasing at the peak of the usual Spring busy season," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, stated today. Last year at this time 280,000 men were taken back to work, Mr. Green said.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 26. -- Mrs. George Adams Ellis of Bay Shore, L.I., and Hot Springs has arrived to open Stepping Stones and will remain in residence here for the season. Since her departure from Charleston, S.C., last month, Mrs. Ellis has been at her Long Island estate.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 27. -- The Presidential preferential contest between Governor Roosevelt of New York and former Governor Smith in Pennsylvania yesterday is much closer than the Roosevelt men or political observera had expected.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP). -- United States Steel common, after selling down on the Curb Exchange here today to a new low at 28, rallied to close at 28 1/4, with sales of nearly 1,000 shares. Steel common closed in New York at 28 7/8.

QUETTA, British Baluchistan, April 26. -- Mir Azam Jang Khan, who succeeded his brother last year, was installed as Khan of Kalat by the Viceroy this morning in a ceremony unique in the annals of Baluchistan.

Miss Anne Morgan, president of the American Woman's Association, received the Anna W. Porter Memorial Medal in recognition of her successful leadership during the last year at the annual meeting of the association last night at its clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox, making their first appearance of the season here, displayed total disregard of the pitching prowess of Lefty Grove today and pounded the Athletics' southpaw ace and his successor, Ed Rommell, for a 10-to-2 victory.

The National Orchestral Association gave the last of eight concerts played this season, by its student orchestra under Leon Barzin in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Efrem Zimbalist was guest artist. The program consisted of Bach's overture No. 2 in B minor, with flute solo by Frances Blaisdell; Beethoven's concerto for violin in D major, and Richard Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel."

A distinguished group of bibliophiles, defying talk of a depression in the book world, unbent so far last night at a frolicsome supper as to dispose at auction of a list of $2 books for prices ranging as high as $250.

The tremendous interest excited by the appearance of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody on the tennis courts was vividly demonstrated yesterday when the balcony of the east court at the River Club was jammed to capacity for the national champion's second practice session there preparatory to her departure for Europe tonight on the Aquitania.

The nomination of Wilmer Allison to play in the Davis Cup singles against Canada means undoubtedly that Frank Shields, the second ranking player of the country and one of the singles aces of the 1931 combination in both the American and European zone play, will be shut out of the matches at the Chevy Chase Club.

Final figures for many areas in The Literary Digest's nation-wide poll on prohibition, showing that most of the large cities so far reported are predominantly wet and that anti-prohibition sentiment has invaded even such places as the religious colony at Zion, Ill., were made public yesterday.
Paul Miller sold the four-story, sixteen-family apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 42-44 Prospect Street, near Palisade Avenue, Jersey City, assessed at $56,000, to Faye Baumgarten.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 26. -- Miss Catherine Singer of the home links and Mrs. Leo Federman and Miss Beatrice Gottlieb of Glen Oaks shared the low-gross honors for the first eighteen holes of the three-day tournament which formally opened the Women's Metropolitan Association season, today at the Seaview Golf Club.

HAVANA, April 26. -- Ruben de Leon, Rafael Escalona and Ramiro Valdez Daussa, three Cuban students whose case was brought up in the United States Senate by Senator Borah on April 11, have been sentenced to serve eight years in prison, it was announced this morning.

The People's Chorus of New York presented its seventh annual Spring song festival last night at Carnegie Hall, observing at the same time the sixteenth anniversary of its existence as well as the Washington bicentennial celebration. Lorenzo Camllieri, conductor of the chorus, directed the program and Rachel Morton, soprano, was the assisting soloist.
BERLIN, April 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The Samuel J. Tilden High School nine continued its undefeated pace in Section B of the Brooklyn P.S. A.L. tourney when it vanquished Abraham Lincoln, 6 to 3, yesterday on the latter's diamond for its third straight league victory.

A general state of pessimism regarding the immediate future characterizes business sentiment throughout the country this month, according to the current report prepared for the National Association of Purchasing Agents by their business survey committee.

JODHPUR CITY, India, April 26 (AP). -- Gorgesus scenes of Oriental splendor marked the alliance by marriage of two of the most aristocratic and oldest ruling houses of Rajputana, the ceremonies of which ended today. The marriage was that of the 21-year-old Maharajah Sawai Man Singh Bahadur, ruler of Jaipur to the daughter of the Maharajah of Jodhpur.

The development of outstanding importance in the day's money market was the decline in time money to 2 per cent for all dates up to and including four months, with a little four months' funds done at that figure. This is the lowest rate since last Fall.

TO avoid confusion, it should be stated at the outset that the lecturer was not the Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the German financial expert, but Dr. AI Schacht of the Washington Senators. He was just plain Al Schacht until he became an authority on dieting and gave Waite Hoyt the diet on which Waite lost thirty pounds in thirty minutes or something like that.

HAVANA, April 26. -- The Supreme Court decided today that the closing of Havana University and suspension of faculty salaries by Presidential decree on July 1, 1931, was unconstitutional. It is now expected that the university will reopen as soon as may be convenient.

LONDON, April 26. -- At the moment when some leaders in the United States Congress are agitating for recognition of the Soviet Government so that American trade may be helped Great Britain is so disappointed with her own commerce with Russia that she is considering whether it would not help her interests to "break off or cancel the existing trade agreement between the two countries."

The loss of three American officers of the Nicaraguan National Guard in an encounter with Sandinistas or bandits may raise the question of the sufficiency of the Guard's training as a native constabulary, but it should have no bearing upon the policy of the United States to return the marine contingent to the United States by Jan. 1.

At the annual meeting of stock-holders of the Paramount-Publix Corporation yesterday Adolph Zukor, president, said the company would show a small loss for the first quarter of the year after depreciation. Fixed charges were covered by a slight margin before depreciation, he said.

Dr. Samuel Buchler, lawyer and former rabbi in Sing Sing prison and various synagogues in this city, testified in his own defense yesterday before Judge Freschi and a jury at his General Sessions trial on a charge he defrauded Max J. Klein of 34 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, of $200 in 1929, under pretense he would use "influence" in Washington to have Klein's father-in-law, a rabbi, admitted into this country from Austria.
Buffalo triumphed over Jersey City, 6 to 2, at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, giving the Bisons their third victory in the four-game series.

The Brooklyn-Queens Transit Corporation, a subsidiary of the B.M. T., filed with the State Transit Commission yesterday new tariff schedules, indicating that it would increase the fare on the Williamsburg Bridge trolley cars from 2 to 3 cents on May 19.

The Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street, opens today an exhibition of paintings by members. Prizes will be awarded by an outside jury composed of Hilda Belcher, Emma Fordyce McRae and Harriet Lord. The exhibition will be open to the public daily, except Thursdays, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., until May 23.

PATERSON, N.J., April 26. -- Three boys were injured seriously this afternoon when they fell down a slanting cliff on the Passaic County Park Reservation at Garret Mountain near here. One of the boys was found late tonight after his father had reported to the police that he had not been home for supper.

DUBLIN, April 26 (AP). -- The Free State Government has imposed a high emergency tariff on all imported ready-made clothing. It will become effective tonight with the issuance of the official order. The amount of the tariff was not made public.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- An agreement covering the transportation of passengers between New Orleans and Cristobal in connection with Peru and Chile cruises and other South American cruises of the Grace Line between that line and the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company was approved by the Shipping Board today.

More adequate educational facilities for physically handicapped children and additional sight-conservation classes are recommended in the annual report of Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, another section of which was made public yesterday.

GENEVA, April 26. -- In an effort to help create an atmosphere of political peace in Europe which he and others believe to be the essential prelude to any armaments reduction and any hope of stability. Secretary of State Stimson took today the second important step he has taken since he came to Geneva.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The House tonight was prepared for one of the most bitter debates of the session in anticipation of the introduction tomorrow of a special rule which, if adopted by a majority vote, will automatically attach the Economy Committee omnibus bill to the legislative appropriation bill.

College students and representatives of the financial district joined yesterday in asking permission to march in Mayor Walker's "Beer for Taxation" parade on May 14, which has already rained the support of many labor and fraternal groups.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- A reversal of the Treasury policy against so-called "double taxation" of American residents abroad was voted today by the Senate Finance Committee, considering the billion-dollar revenue bill.

Two clumps of boxwood which George Washington himself set out when he built his Hayfield, Va., home in 1761 were planted yesterday beside the reproduction of Mount Vernon being erected in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, by the New York Bicentennial Commission.

PARIS, April 26. -- The Paris Bourse today was firm and the session was marked by a general recovery, particularly of those shares that were mo severely attacked at the end of last week. It is believed that speculators anticipating a bis drop to follow the Prussian elctions were forced to make covering purchases owing to the market's strength.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Bullish crop and weather news today was sufficient to advance wheat prices sharply on the Board of Trade here, but the market flattened out after an upturn of about a cent from a fractional dip early, and net grains were only 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

Mayor Walker yesterday announced his willingness to act as mediator in the strike of longshoremen of the Morgan, Savannah and Clyde-Mallory steamship lines who left the piers on April 15 rather than accept a wage reduction of 10 per cent. Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, visited City Hall and after receiving the Mayor's assurance of cooperation decided to wait until today before formally inviting him to act.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 26. -- With the opening of the fifth national High School Art Exhibition at Carnegie Institute today, Scholastic, national magazine for the high school classroom, named those who received honors in Annual Awards for creative work in art and literature.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 26. -- With the old veteran of the rivers, Jim Ten Eyck, back in the launch this week for the first time since the illness which put him in bed early last month, Syracuse crews are working under wintry conditions toward the opening of their season at Annapolis against Navy crews a week from Saturday.

Not a single bid was received by the Board of Transportation yesterday on its proposed Contract No. 5 for private operation of the new city subway system. The board immediately sent to the Board of Estimate a request for a $700,000 appropriation to cover the cost of starting municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway, the first link of the new system, about July 1.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26. -- President Getulio Vargas and leaders in the State of Minas Geraes held a confidential conference today which the newspapers here believe was concerned with speeding ,up plans for the registration of voters in preparation for the return to constitutionalism demanded by critics of the provisional regime.

Before the eyes of their mother and an older brother, two youths, Edward and Charles Forrest, were killed yesterday afternoon in the cave-in of an excavation they were digging in the rear yard of their home at 221-37 114th Road, St. Albans, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- An overture that proposed the introduction of a new type of minister in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to meet the claims of some small congregations that they could not support clergymen having the educational background required by the denomination has been defeated by a vote of the country's presbyteries.

From New Suffolk, L.I., comes an expression of "watchful waiting," as far as the weakfish season is concerned. During the first ten days of May, when the fish generally are in Peconic Bay, the section becomes a great rendezvous not only for New York anglers out for those who come from near-by States for several days of salt-water fishing each Spring.

Trading was extremely slow on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the turnover amounting to 780,000 shares, compared with 640,596 shares on the day before. Fluctuations were within a narrow range; they showed a negligible net gain for the day. The average net advance for fifty selected stocks was $1.01.

LONDON, April 27 -- While the Dail Eireann in Dublin debated critical issues today, the House of Commons overwhelmingly defeated introduction of a bill for abolishing the oath of allegiance to the Crown for members of the British Parliament.

The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday that its net income in 1931 was $26,057,312, or $9.93 a share on common stock, against $38,- 736,005, or $15.63 a share in 1930. There was a deficit of $153,512 after dividends in 1931. Profit and loss surplus was reduced from $276,249,135 on Dec. 31, 1930, to $266,041,344 on Dec. 31 last.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Hoover today vetoed, with sharp criticism, an omnibus pension bill passed virtually without debate, and without a roll-call, and containing many "undeserving cases * * * previously rejected by the Pension Bureau."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A protest was filed today by the National Association of Broadcasters with the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee against passage of the Davis omnibus radio bill, favorably reported and now awaiting action on the calendar.

A further slight improvement in the rate of operations in steel mills in the last week is noted by The Iron Age in its weekly review. The rate now is placed at about 23 per cent of theoretical capacity, against 22 1/2 per cent a week ago and 21 per cent two weeks ago.

With the exception of the Virginian railway, which showed an increase in net operating income for March, railroads reporting yesterday showed declines in returns if not actually operating deficits for the month. Among the roads to report a deficit was the Northern Pacific, while the Santa Fe, Baltimore Ohio, Burlington, North Western, New York Central and Southern reported declines in net operating returns.

MULDROW GLACIER, April 18 (via Fairbanks, Alaska, April 27) -- We made our final glacier camp at an elevation of 11,000 feet here last night, and today our dog teams moved up our entire outfit. We were fortunate enough to complete our freighting exactly on schedule, without any serious mishaps.

At Monday's session of the Hofstadter committee Assemblyman CUVILLIER objected to some of the questions which Judge SEABURY put to Chairman DELANEY of the Board of Transportation, on the ground that political campaigns had nothing to do with bus franchises.

The defeat suffered by Governor Roosevelt at Tuesday's preferential primaries in Massachusetts will revive and lend new force to the "StopRoosevelt" movement, brought to temporary halt after an unbroken line of Roosevelt victories in other States, according to statements made in the camp of Alfred E. Smith, who was the victor in the Bay State primary.

Executives of many of the principal steamship lines, railroads and hotels were guests of the Cosulich Line and the American Steamship and Tourist Agents' Association last night at dinner aboard the Cosulich liner Saturnia at Pier 84, foot of West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- After allowing a home run, triple, double and single in the first inning today, Pat Malone held Pittsburgh to one hit thereafter, and the Cubs won the final game of the series, 8 to 4, to go into first place in the National League.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 27 -- Universal regret was expressed in Brazilian newspapers today at the deaths of three officials and injuries to Jose Americo, Minister of Public Works, in a seaplane accident at Bahia last night. Senhor Americo was returning to Rio de Janeiro from an inspection of the drought area to meet President Getulio Vargas and sail back with him to North Brazil.

In his address to the Governors yesterday Mr. HOOVER used a graphic method of measuring the rapidly increasing cost of government in the United States. Before the war, he said, theoretically every man worked twenty-five days a year to support Federal, State and local institutions.

The New England Power Association reports for the first quarter of 1932 a net income of $3,086,911 before depreciation, compared with $3,000,999 in the same period last year, and a balance of $2,086,110 after preferred dividends, against $2,006,790, a gain of $79.320.

A young married couple who, according to the police, held up chain grocery stores and then went home and changed their clothes and went to other grocery stores in the same neighborhood to buy provisions with their loot were arrested last night and locked up in the West 100th Street police station.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Efforts of financial interests to obtain a sharp of the $225,000,000 3 per cent loans to be sold next week by the Treasury brought an over-subcription of ten times the total sought.

HONOLULU, April 27 (AP) -- The inquiry into the death of Mrs. Granville Sevier, Irvington, N.Y., heiress and wife of Colonel Granville Sevier, U.S.A., may be reopened as a result of a decision today by the Territorial Supreme Court permitting a second autopsy on her body.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 27 -- Unanimous approval of the preaching mission movement proposed by Bishop A.W. Leonard of Buffalo to take the "blight off evangelism caused in other years by the claptrap of mountebanks working on overwrought emotionalism" was expressed today by the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Methods of popularizing scientific research, and at the same time keeping the information distributed within the range of strict accuracy, were discussed today at a meeting of Science Service, an institution organized under the sponsorship of leading scientific organizations.

The bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, in its annual report submitted yesterday at the forty-sixth annual convention of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria, estimated that a total of $442,000,000 was invested in national advertising in 1931.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 27 (AP) -- An attack on Governor Roosevelt's St. Paul speech was made here tonight by Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, during a plea for the re-election of President Hoover.

Extra precautions will be taken by the New York police to guard against May Day disturbances this year on account of recent Communist and unemployment demonstrations, it was said yesterday at Police Headquarters. The entire police force of the five boroughs will be held in readiness from 4 P.M. Saturday until 8 A.M. Monday, with special guards posted at strategic points around the city all day Sunday.

Some idea of the developments of Federal work toward wild life conservation is contained in the material distributed by the Department of Agriculture which reviews not only some of the recent activities of the Bureau of Biological Survey but also includes additional comment on the waterfowl situation.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church of Newark refused today for the second time to resign from his post in answer to a demand for his resignation from Chancellor Edwin Robert Walker. The Vice Chancellor repeated his request for an investigation of his appointments of receiverships.

DUBLIN, April 27 -- The government of Eamon de Valera met an unexpected defeat in the Dail Eireann today when it started its move to obtain second reading of its bill to abolish the oath of allegiance to the British Crown.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 (AP) -- Walter B. Smith, Bell County attorney, who has barred various investigating delegations from the Southeastern Kentucky coal fields, said today his actions toward the proposed visit of the American Civil Liberties Union delegates would depend upon what they did on arrival.

TORONTO, April 27 -- Solution of India's problem lies in an all-India federation within the British Commonwealth on a footing of equal partnership. Lord Irwin declared tonight in the first of the Massey lectures at the University of Toronto, which are to bring to Canada each year a man of prominence from Britain.

The directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad voted yesterday to defer action on the quarterly dividend usually announced at this time, but the Delaware Hudson Company declared the regular quarterly disbursement of $2.25 a share. Pennsylvania stock closed a point lower at 12 3/8 on the Stock Exchange, while D. H. rallied to 64 and closed at 61 for a net gain of 2 1/4 points.

Results of a poll of 106 college newspaper editors, conducted by The Columbia Spectator, were printed in The Spectator yesterday. The four questions asked on the ballot were: Did the signer favor the renomination of President Hoover? What man was best fitted for the Democratic nomination?

The Columbia rowing squad was quarantined at its headquarters at Baker Field yesterday and the edict will be in effect today, but present plans call for the Blue and White oarsmen to leave for Annapolis tomorrow to meet the Naval Academy on Saturday in the opening regatta of the season for the Morningside Heights institution.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., April 27 -- The trade agreement with Canada, presented to Parliament today, provides for mutual British preferential tariff rates except on certain items.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 27 -- Army's nine came from behind to defeat Wesleyan today, 8 to 5. Wesleyan was leading, 5 to 3, at the end of the third inning. Pitcher Coughlin of the Army settled down thereafter and held his opponents scoreless.

There are three shows at the Midtown Galleries, 559 Fifth Avenue. Two one-man shows contain work by Homer Boss and Hans O. Hofman respectively, and in addition there is a group exhibition-oils, water-colors, drawings and sculpture by members of this new cooperative organization.

Herman Dworman and Joseph Bathe of the Cadillac A.C., Detroit, the defending champions, were extended to triumph over Leo O'Brien and Vincent Borrelli of the Nassau Boat Club, New York, in the first round of the National A.A.U. senior four-wall soft-ball handball doubles championship tournament, which got under way at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Mr. NORMAN THOMAS in the role of apologist for American municipal government is something of a surprise. As a Socialist he is committed to the party view of what capitalism does to the conduct of government in general and the administration of our cities in particular.

NEWMARKET, England, April 27 -- Orwell, champion 2-year-old of the English, turf last year, sped on his way to the 3-year-old title today, winning the 2,000 Guineas for Washington M.G. Singer, retired New York business man.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- No bill ever drafted in any American Congress was "better calculated to destroy confidence" in the national credit than the $2,400,000,000 soldiers' bonus proposal now pending before the House Ways and Means Committee, Secretary Mills told the committee today.

Because the court hearing they desire cannot be obtained earlier, delegates the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that their contemplated visit to the coal-strike areas of Harlan and Bell Counties, Ky., would be postponed until about May 12.

A group of electrical contractors met yesterday at the office of the Building Trades Employers' Association and rehabilitated the Electrical Contractors' Association, which was split three years ago because of disagreement concerning its policy toward the demands made by Local 3 of the Electrical Workers' Union.

Sounds that the average man considers art were analyzed last night at the Metropolitan Opera House by dispassionate science with a technique used for ordinary, everyday noises. The results proved that art, in this case Verdi's "Rigoletto," attained intensities that even the street car could not equal.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The formulation of "secret plans" for pursuing the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's investigation of the stock market caused temporary postponement of further hearings today.

At its annual meeting yesterday the National Academy of Design, one of the oldest art organizations in the country, elected seven members from the ranks of its associate membership. Artists are not eligible to election as full academicians until after they have served as associate members.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Delving further into the financial status of railroads subject to its jurisdiction, the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered all Class I roads today to report on the number of their employes paid $10,000 or more a year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent editorial in THE TIMES entitled "As a People Thinketh" occurs this statement: "If, in fact, capitalism is to survive, it will be through the efforts of capitalists to prove to the world that it is fittest to survive.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 27 -- The second annual Westchester County Home Show opened tonight at the County Centre with fifty exhibitors. It will continue for one week.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A coalition in the House of Representatives began tonight the shattering of the Economy Committee's program for large savings in Federal expenses.

Five men, all unemployed, who had built themselves a shack in a vacant lot at 134th Street and Twelfth Avenue, awoke last night to find the shack in flames. Two of them man- aged to get out. But before the other three could extricate themselves, the flimsy structure collapsed and they were smothered in a mass of blazing debris.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) -- Donald D. Conn, managing director of the California Vineyardists' Association, disclosed today that President Hoover, while Secretary of Commerce, tentatively approved the grape industry rehabilitation plan, including the marketing of grape by-products.

At the annual meetings in Boston yesterday of the International Paper and Power Company and its subsidiary, the International HydroElectric System, A.R. Graustein, president of both companies, issued preliminary figures of earnings for 1931 and discussed the dividend outlook.

Canada has weathered the economic disorganization as well as any other country and better than most, Major Stuart Morgan declared yesterday at the "Canadian Day" celebration of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin. Major Morgan is an official of the Near East Development Corporation, which is cooperating with the British in developing the Mosul oil fields in Iraq.
Babe Ruth has given up his alternate love -- golf -- in order to concentrate on and conserve his energies for the business of helping to wallop the New York Yankees to the top of the American League.

The Spanish training ship, Juan Sebastian Elcano, a graceful four-masted barkentine with an auxiliary screw, painted white and carrying at her bow an artistically decorated figurehead of a young woman, arrived here yesterday from her cruise to South America, on which, she started a year ago from this port.

HANOVER, N.H., April 27 -- Dartmouth's baseball team defeated St. Michael's, 4 to 0, today in a game that was started in a blinding snow-storm, necessitating a twenty-minute intermission in the first inning when the outfielders could not see the ball. The delay caused the game to be called after seven innings by agreement.

As a final practice preparatory to her departure late last night on the Aquitania for France, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody of San Francisco, the national women's tennis champion, engaged in a doubles match yesterday at the River Club.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (AP) -- Although India is under a forced peace, the government believes that, with Mahatma Gandhi and other Nationalist leaders in prison, it will be possible to institute some of the constitutional reforms promised by the round-table conference in London.
Further activity in housing properties was reported yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 27 -- Hitting safely in every inning except the third, the University of West Virginia nine defeated the Naval Academy today, 16 to 3. The visiting batters found the offerings of three Navy twirlers for a total of twenty hits.

John R. Huffman of the New York Athletic Club retained his national saber championship by defeating Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club of New York in a fence-off in the final round-robin tournament of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Hotel Astor last night.

Politics and the Airplane. In the Presidential campaign four years ago the radio came into its own as a political instrument of the first rank. It will doubtless be pressed into service to an even greater extent this year.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 27 -- The delay of international athletic authorities in restoring Paavo Nurmi to good standing, following the rejection of charges against the great runner by the Finnish Athletic League, has prompted another storm of protest here.

HONOLULU, April 27 (AP) -- The Golden Rule was invoked by Clarence Darrow today in his plea to a racially mixed jury for vindication of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and three others accused of avenging an alleged attack on Mrs. Thalia Massie by slaying Joseph Kahahawai.

Union longshoremen offered yesterday to compromise with, the coast-wise ship lines on their wage demands and to accept a reduction of five cents an hour as a means of ending the strike which has been effective at the piers of the Morgan, Savannah and Clyde-Mallory lines since April 15.

VIENNA, April 27 -- Joseph Kuderna, Austrian, who is accused of an attempt to obtain the vast Wendel fortune by representing himself in New York through a forged death certificate as a relative of Miss Ella Wendel, went on trial in the Provincial Court here today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 27 -- The Cascades Club was a centre of activities today with the playing of the first tournament matches in the Old Dominion golf championship, and at midday many informal luncheon groups gathered on the terrace.

LONDON, April 27 -- The stock market again was dull today. The only firm group was British Government funds, renewed investment demand causing rises. The textiles were particularly depressed, but rayons held fairly steady. Cables and Wireless recovered slightly.

Mediators of the Federal and State Labor Departments will confer today with officials of the Barbers Union in an endeavor to settle the strike which began on Monday and which continued to spread until it included yesterday more than 2,000 journey-men barbers on the upper east and west sides.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 27 -- With players and spectators shivering in frigid weather, Lehigh won its third straight game today defeating Ursinus, 16 to 12, in seven innings.
THE witness being duly sworn, the examination then proceeded as follows:

The $5,000.000 bond issue which the Board of Estimate is expected to authorize for relief purposes tomorrow will provide the barest necessities of life for 100,000 families for two months, but thousands of other families will be face to face with hunger and eviction unless a much larger sum is provided by the city, according to reports made yesterday at a meeting of the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee on Unemployment.

A virtual guarantee that the operator's fee would be paid ahead of all other charges against the railroad is the principal feature of a revised form of contract for independent operation of the new city subway system, made public yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

ABSECON, N.J., April 27 -- Miss Catherine Singer of the home links went into the lead at the conclusion of thirty-six holes of play in the season's opening tournament being staged at the Seaview Golf Club by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 27 -- Tick On, one of the two favorites for the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, lost his first start as a 3-year-old today, when he was outraced by S.W. Labrot's Springsteel, another Derby hopeful, in the Shenandoah Purse at Havre de Grace.

BOSTON, April 27 -- The Democratic voters of Massachusetts gave Alfred E. Smith all of the thirty-six Bay State votes in the national convention in a landslide primary victory yesterday over Governor Roosevelt.

Truth in the guise of Governor PINCHOT was crushed to earth on Tuesday. His singular want of success with the Legislature had but spurred him to efforts of a larger scope. He set out to get control of the State Committee, nominate certified Pinchotians to the Legislature, send anti-Hooverites to the National Convention, beat Senator DAVIS, reformed prohibitionist, with General SMEDLEY BUTLER, dryest of the Drys.

The George Washington High School baseball team turned back De Witt Clinton, 3 to 2, yesterday at George Washington High School Stadium in the opening Upper Manhattan-Bronx division P.S.A.L. game for both. Leo Schoppmeyer's single scored Thompson with the deciding run in the fifth inning.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Moses Taylor will arrive from Morocco May 10 on the Majestic and will be at the Pierre.

HONOLULU, April 27 -- The jury in the Fortescue-Massie murder case went out at 4:25 this afternoon to begin its deliberations, after Judge Charles S. Davis had instructed the jurors. At 10 P.M. the jury was locked up for the night.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 27 -- Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann, exhibiting blooms grown on her estate, Sunken Orchard, at Oyster Bay, won the sweepstakes award with twentythree points this afternoon at the second annual narcissus show of the Westbury Horticultural Society being held today and tomorrow in Winthrop Hall, the parish house of the Church of the Advent.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Democrats in Washington who are opposed to the nomination of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York drew the first hope they have known in weeks from the results of the Massachusetts and Pennsylvania Presidential preference primaries yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 -- The final accounting in the estate of James W. Brice of Old Greenwich, filed by the New York Trust Company and G. Buddington of Old Greenwich and New York, as executors and trustees, was accepted by Probate Judge William C. Rungee in the Greenwich Probate Court today.
CANTON, Ohio, April 27 (AP) -- Harry Bouklias, former underworld "informer" and reporter for The Ohio Examiner, a weekly newspaper fighting crime conditions, was shot from ambush early today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27 -- Harried for twenty-one hours that he might not fall into a fatal sleep, Howard Edwards, 30 years old, of 15 Warren Street was allowed this afternoon at City Hospital to lapse into normal slumber and is expected to awake fully recovered from an overdose of a sleeping potion.
Formation of a National Action Committee sheaded by former Ambassador Richard Washburn Child, to obtain support for a national welfare program it has worked out, was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Opposition to the proposed four-party plan of Eastern railroad consolidation gathered force today near the close of final arguments before the Interstate Commerce Commission, when representatives of commercial organizations of Baltimore and Philaphia, the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Southern and Louisville Nashville Railroads, present owners of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville, were heard.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 -- Clara Bow, red-headed girl of the screen, is about to return to motion pictures. She has signed a contract to make one picture for Fox studios, Richard Rowland, executive vice president, has announced, and Fox has obtained an option from her for a series of pictures.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 27 (AP) -- President Juan Esteban Montero's standing abroad is firmer than ever, foreign trade and official circles believe, as a result of his veto of an anti-foreign section of the new peso devalorization law under which Chile recently went off the gold standard.

The Dudensing Gallery, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, very precisely sets forth the biography of its present exhibitor, Arnold Wiltz: "Born: Berlin, 1889; migrated to United States June, 1914. Studied: self-taught. Member: Brooklyn Society of Modern Artists. Woodstock Art Association, Salons of America.

A system of landscaped express parkways, having no grade crossings, with bridle paths along much of their length and with picnic grounds and recreation areas where parks or other city land adjoin them, extending from the heart of the city far out on Long Island, is favored by Robert Moses, chairman of the Long Island Park Commission, to end the traffic bottle neck in Queens, he disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Andre Tardieu, French Premier, and Ambassador Edge signed in Paris today a convention designed to settle certain questions relative to double taxation.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 27 -- The Republican State Convention declared today in favor of a referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment and cheered a statement by Secretary Hurley that President Hoover was the only President who, in a time of financial crisis, had offered a nation-wide non-partisan program of reconstruction.

Scattered advances on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated that sentiment in Wall Street was somewhat more cheerful, but there was no evidence of any fundamental change in the market position. There were some net gains of consequence, mainly in the railway division, and this improvement reflected, of course, the steadily advancing course of transportation earnings, resulting from the more economical administration of the railway properties.

Fifteen members of a bankruptcy ring which is said to have defrauded the public of more than $1,000,000 by obtaining credit on false financial statements are under Federal investigation, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, who is conducting a campaign against bankruptcy racketeers, announced yesterday.

Dr. Samuel Buchler, lawyer, former Sing Sing Jewish chaplain and for about eleven years, as he said, "on the city payroll," testified under cross-examination yesterday before Judge Freschi and a jury in General Sessions at his trial on a grand larceny charge.

HARBIN, Manchuria, April 27 (AP) -- The Japanese Army, whose conquest of Manchuria brought about the establishment of the Manchoukuo Government March 9, opened a major offensive today in an effort to save that government from being consumed by the revolt that is flaming through the northern and eastern districts.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Members of the Power Authority of New York sought a first-hand report this afternoon on the progress made by James G. Rogers, Assistant Secretary of State, and his aides in the negotiation of a treaty with Canada to govern the development of the St. Lawrence Deeper Waterway.

A strong plea for the rehabilitation of the men's clothing industry in Kew York City, through greater cooperation between manufacturers and retailers, was made yesterday by several speakers at a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker tendered by the New York State Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers to Arthur D. O'Shea, president of the National Association of Retail Cloth- iers and Furnishers.

For weeks before the Massachusetts primary it was evident that Governor ROOSEVELT was very badly advised to go into it at all. He might have gracefully conceded the State to SMITH and no great harm to his own candidacy would have been done.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The Boerse today experienced the first boom in many months, with the average advance in stocks 4 per cent and that of bonds 1 to 2 per cent. Brisk trading continued throughout the day. The public entered the market more boldly, but there was also buying by large industrial concerns in Rhineland.
MULDROW GLACIER (by airplane to Nenana), April 27 -- The first stage of our expedition for cosmic ray observations on Mount McKinley is behind us.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Representative John J. Boylan of New York was taken to Garfield Hospital from the floor of the House early this evening. He was in serious condition from a bladder ailment.

RICHMOND, Va., April 27 -- With Governor Rolph of California among the State Executives gathered for the conference here, a group of labor representatives attempted to stage a Tom Mooney demonstration here today and \vas scattered by the police.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Improvement of social conditions through large-scale housing operations and eradication of slumps received the attention of the American Institute of Architects at the opening today of the institute's sixty-fifth convention, marking its seventy-fifth anniversary.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Placing upon the large commercial banks a large share of responsibility for recent depression of security values. Chairman Norbeck of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee threatened tonight to bring their activities under the spotlight of the Stock Exchange investigation.

A successive drop of 1/4 in time money to 1 3/4 @ 2 per cent for maturities up to 90 days, on top of a like decline on Tuesday, furnished the really interesting development of the day in money. Longer dates were unchanged. Market remains upon a purely nominal basis, and notwithstanding the lower offerings bidding is not active and turnover light.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27 -- The Yale Athletic Association today announced the award of major letters to eleven members of the varsity swimming team. Major Ys were also given to John F. Potter and Rockwood Quock Ping Chin in fencing.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/4 Per cent tor the best names. Tuesday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The United States under the Presidency of Calvin Coolidge was a "gambler's civilization," Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, said yesterday in an address to the student body of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken.

Testimony intended to show that undesirables loitered in the vicinity of at least one of the burlesque shows on West Forty-second Street was presented yesterday at the third day of the hearings before License Commissioner James F. Geraghty to help him decide whether or not the licenses for the shows at the Republic and Eltinge Theatres should be renewed.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27 -- Governor Moore of New Jersey was among the interested spectators at the opening session, tonight of the twelfth annual Newark Horse Show in the Roseville Avenue Armory under the auspices of Essex Troop.

After holding within a narrow range for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced in the last hour to the top levels of the week and closed 8 to 10 points higher than on Tuesday. The best figures were reached in the final dealings.

The cold weather prevented the Yankees and Washington from continuing their second-place fight at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The two teams, after having played only one of the three games scheduled for their first series here this year, parted company until Sunday, when Manager McCarthy and his sluggers will begin a three-day invasion of Washington.

Six elementary schools in Manhattan will be discontinued at the close of the present term, the Board of Education decided yesterday, in line with its policy of consolidating classes where registration has decreased as a result of shifting population.

Charitable and religious organizations receive a large share of the estate of Mrs. Mary B. Caswell, widow of John Henry Caswell, which was appraised yesterday for transfer purposes at $572,216 gross and $519,019 net. Mrs. Caswell died Aug. 27, 1931.
DETROIT, April 27 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox perpetrated six errors today but in spite of them defeated the Tigers, 4 to 3, dropping Detroit to second place in the American League standing.

The little-favored Halcyon, a son of Broomstick from Prudery, which has raced without great success for Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney for two seasons, surprised spectators at Jamaica yesterday when he defeated three of the best sprinters in train ing in the Jamaica Handicap.
RICHMOND, Va., April 27 (AP) -- Following is the full text of the President's address delivered here today to the conference of Governors:

The New York opening of Jane Cowl's play, "A Thousand Summers," scheduled for May 10 at the Selwyn Theatre, has been postponed until the latter part of next month. The play, now in the midst of a Philadelphia engagement, will be revised before it comes to Broadway.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The major changes in the revenue bill made today by the Senate Finance Committee follow:
PRINCETON, N.J., April 27 -- The Princeton varsity golf team defeated Lafayette today, 8 to 1, over the Springdale links.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 27 -- An audience of more than 700 persons from all parts of the North Shore of Long Island heard Verdi's opera "Il Trovatore" sung by stars of various opera companies in the auditorium of the Great Neck High School tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- An active newspaper man stood on the floor of the Senate today, looked self-consciously at the press gallery and then was sworn in as the new Senator from Georgia.

Pearl S. Buck turned from fiction to propaganda in defense of the role that foreigners have played in making the new China when she wrote "The Young Revolutionists," published today by Friendship Press and distributed by John Day. She advances her views through the character, and story of a Chinese boy, Ko-sen, who during a severe illness has been promised to the gods in exchange for his life.

Declaring that the Board of Estimate had failed to avail itself of "full opportunity" to act on Manhattan bus franchise awards, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, by unanimous decision, denied yesterday the city's plea for a further stay of the taxpayer's injunction which for two years has been, hanging over "emergency" bus operation on seven crosstown lines.

PARIS, April 27 -- The Bourse today did not maintain its recent strength despite advices indicative of improvement in Wall Street yesterday. Premier Tardieu's illness, the postponement of dividends by the Mexican Eagle and Canadian Eagle Oil Companies and a decline in Suez Canal sufficed to check trading and the session was unusually dull.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A willful, deliberate, malicious lie, by a man I never heard of," was the way Vice President Curtis answered today an alleged statement by a man named Specker that he "came direct from Charlie Curtis" when he endeavored to obtain advertising for the Republican National Convention program.

RICHMOND, Va., April 27 -- President Hoover voiced an appeal today for national cooperation among all governmental units to insure drastic economies and tax reductions as vital factors in speeding economic recovery throughout the country.

The city's staff of nurses was praised last night as the greatest "humanizing" force in New York health work by Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, at a dinner of the Division of Nursing of the Department of Hospitals at the Hotel Commodore.

The American Newspaper Publishers' Association, by a resolution adopted yesterday, formally characterized as "an encroachment upon freedom of the press" the decision of Judge J.H. Bottum of the South Dakota Circuit Court in the contempt proceedings against The Aberdeen (S.D.) American-News and commended the fight of that newspaper against the decision.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was slightly more active yesterday than on the day before. The turnover was 1,120,000 shares, as compared with 790,000 shares in the preceding session. The trend of prices was irregularly upward; fifty stocks showed an average net gain of $1.06.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was marked generally by narrow fluctuations. Most domestic corporation Issues and foreign loans were a shade lower, while United States Government bonds averaged higher. Trading continued quiet, aggregating only $8,255,500, compared with $8,363,500 on the previous day.

SAN JOSE, C.R., April 27 -- With a clash threatening due to the tense political situation, many prominent families are leaving the city and schools are closing from April 30 to May 9, covering the period of the expected trouble.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 27 -- Members of the Harrison Town Board reserved decision tonight on the application for a change of zoning in the Purchase section of this township, after hearing arguments against the change by William Mulnoon, veteran member of the New York State Athletic Commission, who spoke in behalf of the Purchase Civic Association.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The unseating of John H. Bankhead as Senator from Alabama was advocated in the Senate today by Senator Norris of Nebraska.

Louis H. Willard, who testified against William J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, at a recent hearing of the Hofstadter committee, was indicted yesterday for perjury in connection with a minor detail of his testimony.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reports for 1931 a net loss of $27,008,310 after charges and deductions for depreciation, depletion, intangible drilling costs and surrendered leases. This contrasts with a net loss of $5,095,574 in 1930. J.C. Van Eck, president, in his remarks to stockholders says the deficit for last year consumed all of the company's surplus account.

The price trend in commodities was irregular. In the grains wheat was lower, but corn turned up. Cotton also showed improvement, as did rubber and hides. Silk, sugar and cocoa were heavy. Spot positions developed the same degree of irregularity.

PARIS, April 27 -- Ambassador Edge and Premier Tardieu today signed a treaty definitely abolishing the French double taxation system. thereby saving American business hundreds of millions of dollars and eliminating a cause of friction between the two countries stretching over six years.

Dr. Paul Leverkuehn, former German Alien Property Commissioner, will sail tonight for Bremen on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus. He is accompanied by Mrs. Lever- kuehn. Others sailing on the ship are Armand Tokatyan, opera singer, Mr. and Mrs. W.S. Grossbeck-Fowler, E.W. Pierce, Mr. and Mrs. A. Vanderwerp, Mr. and Mrs. B. Lewis, Dr. K. Mirow, W.H. Seibert, Mr. and Mrs. J.W. Schaeffer, Mr. and Mrs. H. Horning, F. Pearson and Dr. M. Wallerstein.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27 -- A squeeze play in the twelfth inning in which Pitcher Ray's bunt scored Eno from third base gave the Princeton varsity baseball team an 8-to-7 victory over Penn State today.

Previous analyses of our present economic chaos have failed to point a real way out. This is because they have almost invariably placed the blame on one or a few cogs in the great social and economic system.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was slightly more active yesterday than on the day before. The turnover was 1,120,000 shares, as compared with 790,000 shares in the preceding session. The trend of prices was irregularly upward; fifty stocks showed an average net gain of $1.06.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was marked generally by narrow fluctuations. Most domestic corporation Issues and foreign loans were a shade lower, while United States Government bonds averaged higher. Trading continued quiet, aggregating only $8,255,500, compared with $8,363,500 on the previous day.

SAN JOSE, C.R., April 27 -- With a clash threatening due to the tense political situation, many prominent families are leaving the city and schools are closing from April 30 to May 9, covering the period of the expected trouble.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 27 -- Members of the Harrison Town Board reserved decision tonight on the application for a change of zoning in the Purchase section of this township, after hearing arguments against the change by William Mulnoon, veteran member of the New York State Athletic Commission, who spoke in behalf of the Purchase Civic Association.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The opening of the United States-Canada Davis Cup play tomorrow at the Chevy Chase Club is expected to show whether Ellsworth Vines has regained the form which brought him the national tennis championship last year.

Mary Wigman brought her second American season to a close at Carnegie Hall last night with a recital which was announced as her last sole appearance in this country. When she returns next season, she will be accompanied by a group of fifteen dancers.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 27 (Canadian Press) -- Based largely on the British preferential tariff rates, the trade agreement between Canada and New Zealand was tabled in the House of Commons here today by Harry H. Stevens, Minister of Trade and Commerce.
LOUISVILLE, April 27 (AP) -- Kentucky's twenty-five votes in the Republican National Convention were pledged late today to President Hoover and Vice President Curtis.
The kidnapped son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was still missing yesterday, and official information was that no progress had been made toward his recovery.

Boston, Mass. Indicative of the demand for highgrade short-term municipal loans, the city of Boston (Mass) awarded yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of notes, dated April 28 And due on Oct. 5, on a 2.23 per cent basis. The award went to the First National Bank of Boston in the face of keen competition from six other bidders.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 to 4, today by timely hitting. Grantham led the Reds' attack with four hits. Babe Herman contributed three safeties.

Spring fled before returning Winter in up-State New York yesterday as snow fell in many sections and temperatures dropped to freezing or below. The Weather Bureau promised that the cold spell would be short, however, and that rising temperatures would be general throughout the State today.

Facing facts and making the best of them must be fundamental to any program of mental hygiene. Dr. STANLEY P. DAVIES, who has an article on the subject in the April number of Mental Hygiene, has had experience in public education through his work with the State Charities Aid Association of this city, and is convinced that in order to be healthy-minded we must not avoid reality.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The statement of Secretary Mills to the Ways and Means Committee on the soldiers' bonus today was as follows:
Letters and numerals have been awarded to fifty-nine members of the varsity basketball, indoor track, boxing and rifle teams at New York University, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, April 27 -- Search for a solution for the Parliamentary impasse resulting from Sunday's stalemate in the election in Prussia is making small headway, and if the followers of Adolf Hitler assume that the Centrists are in a hurry to coalesce with them, no such inclination is shown by Chancellor Bruening's party.

NEW ORLEANS, April 27 -- Mrs. Laura Adams Armer of Berkeley, Cal., author of "Waterless Mountain," is announced winner of the John Newbery Medal, awarded annually for "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A three-year loan of $1,500,000 to the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The funds are to be used by the road in meeting interest charges of $1,558,462 due May 1 on its general consolidated mortgage bonds.

DETROIT, April 27 -- The problem of preventing the recurrence of depression was put today in a position of importance heretofore reserved for that of preventing the recurrence of war in plans for the education of women now being formulated here by the National League of Women Voters to govern the participation of forty-two State leagues in the affairs of government during the next two years.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A decision to ask taxpayers of the country to pay more than $40,000,000 in new income taxes, in addition to those already voted in the House bill, was made by the Senate Finance Committee today as part of the budget-balancing program.

NEW ORLEANS, April 27 -- Mrs. Laura Adams Armer of Berkeley, Cal., author of "Waterless Mountain," is announced winner of the John Newbery Medal, awarded annually for "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A three-year loan of $1,500,000 to the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The funds are to be used by the road in meeting interest charges of $1,558,462 due May 1 on its general consolidated mortgage bonds.

For the first time in five months Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hallam will close their little stationery store at 5,021 Broadway at an early hour tonight. In their apartment at 514 West 177th Street they will dress in the finery that befits their age of 70 years and go to a party at the home of their youngest son, Alfred, at 1 Seaman Avenue, marking their golden wedding anniversary.

DETROIT, April 27 -- The problem of preventing the recurrence of depression was put today in a position of importance heretofore reserved for that of preventing the recurrence of war in plans for the education of women now being formulated here by the National League of Women Voters to govern the participation of forty-two State leagues in the affairs of government during the next two years.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A decision to ask taxpayers of the country to pay more than $40,000,000 in new income taxes, in addition to those already voted in the House bill, was made by the Senate Finance Committee today as part of the budget-balancing program.
PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- The Reds made their season's bow in Pittsburgh today by defeating the Pirates, 7 to 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of April 23 F.L. Smith pronounces AI. Smith the one and only outstanding political leader. I cannot agree with him; nor can I agree with your recent editorial praising Smith so highly for his courage in making his Washington speech.

Recent oils by Nan Watson will be shown until May 14 at the Kraushaar Galleries, 680 Fifth. Avenue. Mrs. Watson's painting possesses in marked degree what is perhaps the most precious quality in art: emotional overtone. This is one of those slippery factors, easy enough to tap off on the typewriter, but extremely difficult to explain.

Repression is not the only instrument of British, policy in India today. Though emergency rule has filled the jails with more than 50,000 political prisoners, the Viceroy lets it be known that the work of building a Constitution for India is going on.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 28 -- William Muldoon, 86-year-old member of the New York State Athletic Commission, has adopted his 43-year-old secretary, Miss Margaret V. Farrell of 32 Prospect Street, this city, to make her his heir, it was revealed here today by papers filed in the Surrogate's Court.

In announcing that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had had a record operating loss of $3,685,769 in the first quarter of this year, Eugene G. Grace, president of the company, declared yesterday that European Steel manufacturers were dumping their output in the American market below the cost of production, and were thus "taking work right out of the hands of American wage-earners."

PARIS, April 28 -- Whatever disappointment Geneva is feeling today over the illness of Premier Andre Tardieu and the consequent breaking up of the week-end plans, Paris is distinctly relieved. Although no one denies M. Tardieu is genuinely ill, it is nevertheless true he could not have found a better time to become so if he wanted to so far as French interests are concerned.

Frank E. Brown's Condescend which had won twice previously at the meeting, flashed his most impressive performance of the season at Jamaica yesterday when he defeated J.H. Louchheim's A La Carte in the featured Long Beach Claiming Handicap by six lengths.

Signs of a return to prosperity will be evident after the Presidential election in November, and repeal of the prohibition laws would be a complete solution of present economic difficulties, Morgan J. O'Brien, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, declared yesterday as he viewed conditions on his eightieth birthday.

On the petition of Herbert McNerny, holder of fifty shares of stock, Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman yesterday appointed the Irving Trust Company receiver in equity for the National Bellas Hess Company, Inc., once rated as the third largest mail-order house in the country.

John W. Davis, Democratic nominee for President in 1924, spoke yesterday in support of the Emerald-Hodgson Hospital at Sewanee, Tenn., at a luncheon at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, given by a group of friends of the institution. The hospital, which serves the mountaineers of the district, is the only one within a radius of seventy-five miles.

Tomorrow the 143d anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President of the United States will be observed as a municipal holiday, to be known as "Inauguration Day." In response to the proclamation issued by Mayor Walker plans were being completed yesterday for the pageantry with which New York will celebrate an outstanding day in its history.

John Dunwoody of the Pastime A. C. last night furnished the biggest upset to date in the National A.A.
