U. senior four-wall soft ball handball singles championship tournament at the New York A.C. by defeating George Nelson of Baltimore, runner-up for the last two years and former holder of the title, in a quarter-final round match.

DUBLIN, April 28 -- Members of the Dail Eireann came close to blows tonight toward the close of the second day of debate on President de Valera's bill to abolish the oath of allegiance to Great Britain.

The Contract Already Revised. Failing to obtain a single bid on "Contract No. 5" for the operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway, the Board of Transportation took action with commendable promptness.

Thirteen years of illegal bus operation in Manhattan by the socalled "emergency" buses came to an end yesterday when Police Commissioner Mulrooney ordered them off the streets, in compliance with the Supreme Court injunction that forbade further countenancing of their operation by the city.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will take the witness stand today at the trial of his appointee, Joseph A. Broderick, and may definitely absolve the State Superintendent of Banks of the charge of willful neglect of duty in failing to close the Bank of United States sooner than he did.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 28 -- Jim Londos successfully defended his world's heavyweight wrestling championship by throwing George Calza of Italy in 23 minutes and 28 seconds of the feature wrestling exhibition at the 102d Medical Regiment Armory tonight.

In recent years greater attention has been given by fly fisherman to the artificial nymph. In the study of under-water food for trout it has been discovered that in the pupal stage, the insect, before it ascends to the surface of the water and emerges to fly away, is an especially attractive morsel.

The annual report of the Diamond Match Company of Delaware, mailed to stockholders yesterday, says that "notwithstanding the pronounced period of business depression that has been recently and is now being experienced, with the very low levels of securities now prevailing," the plan of reorganization of January, 1931, has proved to be most advantageous to all stockholders of the predecessor Illinois company.

PARIS, April 28 -- The report by the Shell Union Oil Corporation on its operations in 1931 caused a new decline in Royal Dutch shares on the Paris Bourse today. Suez Canal, whose dividends are impending, also declined sharply. These two developments at the opening of the session were sufficient to restrain trading in general and the session was dull all day.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The question whether a corporation legally can rescind a dividend declaration duly voted by the directors arose today when the Central and Southwest Utilities Company notified the Chicago Stock Exchange that the quarterly dividend recently authorized on its prior-lien and preferred stocks had been canceled.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 29. -- The unrest which Japanese predicted would occur during the visit of the inquiry commission of the League of Nations is appearing all over Northwestern Manchuria.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 28 -- The estate of Charles T. Pierce of Greenwich, said to be worth more than $1,000,000, is divided principally among religious, educational and welfare institutions. The will was filed for probate here today.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., April 28 -- One man was injured and eight planes and several hundred dollars' worth of machinery were wrecked when fire destroyed the hangar of John H. Whitney here this morning. The damage was estimated at $300,000.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- America's 20-year-old tennis champion -- Ellsworth Vines -- rallied from the verge of defeat today to beat the ace of the Canadian team and give the United States Davis Cup forces a clean sweep of their first two matches.

The executive committee of the Kings County Republican organization adopted yesterday a resolution favoring a nation-wide referendum to decide whether "the Eighteenth Amendment be retained, modified or repealed." The action was interpreted to mean that the sixteen Brooklyn delegates to the national convention would support a referendum plank in the party's platform.

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 -- Military competitions for challenge cups were the featured numbers on the program for the second session of the twelfth annual Newark horse show in the Roseville Avenue Armory tonight.

"We are fast drifting from capitalism to communism, and its cessation is imperative if we are to preserve the Constitution and save the nation," William Guggenheim, capitalist, warned last night at the annual dinner of the University of Pennsylvania Club at the clubhouse, 35 East Fiftieth Street.

"Drafting" of capital to provide funds for the relief of unemployment by public works and the holding of a joint Republican and Democratic national convention, to pick the best qualified men for President as methods of ending the economic depression are advocated by Harold G. Aron in a book, ''Respectfully Submitted," which will be published next week.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, prepared yesterday to resume his presentation of evidence against Mayor Walker today despite Democratic opposition and new threats of lawsuits.

A plan for reorganization of the Steneck Trust Company and the Steneck Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Hoboken, which were suspended last June, has been prepared by F. Eberstadt Co. and Irving Rossi and adopted by the reorganization committee for the Steneck institutions, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I sincerely hope every reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES will read the editorial "Park Use and Abuse." Yesterday I visited Central Park for the first time this year, and the evidences of neglect were most starting, and yet there are many possibilities for the restoration of this once beautiful park which thoughtful citizens dearly love.

HONOLULU, April 28 (AP). -- After being out twenty-six hours, the jury in the Massie slaying case went to dinner at 5:30 P. M. today (midnight New York daylight time). It was ordered to return, two hours later and to deliberate until 10 P.M. (4:30 A.M. Friday New York daylight time).

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP). -- Charles H. Ewing, who began his career with the Reading company at the age of 17 years as a rodman, was elected today president of the railroad to succeed the late Agnew T. Dice. Edward W. Scheer, general manager of the eastern lines of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, succeeds Mr. Ewing as vice president in charge of operations.

The State of Kentucky Budget Commission telegraphed yesterday to municipal bond houses here asking for bids on a new issue of $13,500,000 of bonds to refund State warrants of like amount issued in the last five years and now outstanding. The new issue will mature serially up to twenty years and will bear interest at not more than 5 per cent.

The saga of Admiral Peary's adventures in the Far North was retold last night in a lecture at the American Museum of Natural History by Captain Robert A. Bartlett, who, as plain "Captain Bob," has himself become a legendary figure in modern sea lore.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 28 -- The New York University tennis team handed Virginia its first defeat of the season on the home courts, 9 to 0, today.

BERLIN, April 28 -- Trading on the Boerse was again brisk today, with a general upward movement of prices. The market opened irregular, due to realizations in view of the developments at Geneva, but a new flood of orders from the public at large soon restored confidence.

More than the proposed increase of protection for the big brown bears of Alaska will have to be provided if their extermination in the near future is to be prevented. The demand for a change of present regulations has resulted in investigation of conditions on the islands and mainland.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Walter Johnson's flashy Washington Senators pushed the Philadelphia Athletics further downward today with a 10-to-4 victory, scored over one of Connie Mack's aces, Rube Walberg.
PARIS, April 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Pickets returned to duty in the neighborhood of the piers of the Clyde-Mallory, Savannah and Morgan steamship lines yesterday as the union longshoremen, who are on strike in protest against a wage reduction of 10 per cent, prepared to resume their fight.

One of the largest recent realty deals in Hoboken took place yesterday when Hoboken Terminal Properties, Inc., Graham M. Brush, president, sold the property on the east side of Hudson Street, opposite the foot of Twelfth Street, to the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The latest success in science's long quest after the elusive vitamins was described today before the American Biochemical Society, which opened its annual meeting at the University of Pennsylvania in conjunction with other groups comprising the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Mr. BOWERS, in his address at the unveiling of the statue of MONROE at "Ash Lawn" in Virginia, made him a worthy associate of JEFFERSON and MADISON, the "father of the Constitution." Though MONROE is remembered as President in the Era of Good Peeling, he was "essentially a fighter" till there was nothing to fight about.

MOSCOW, April 28 (AP) -- The harmonious relations between Soviet Russia and Turkey were celebrated today by the arrival in Moscow of Ismet Pasha, Turkish Premier, and a party of thirty-four Turkish officials who are here on a visit of state.
The opening of "Broadway Boy," scheduled for tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, has been postponed until next Tuesday evening.

The largest directory of college and university alumni ever printed, giving the names of every person who has completed in good standing one year of residence study in any of the schools of Columbia University since its founding in 1754, has been compiled by the Alumni Federation and is nearing publication, Clarence E. Lovejoy, alumni secretary, announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 28. -- One of the strangest Parliamentary by-elections of recent years was won tonight at St. Marylebone by Captain Alec S. Cunningham-Reid, who in a straight fight defeated another Conservative, Sir Basil Blackett, well-known financier, by a majority of 1,003 in a total vote of 22.331.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the performance of a musical comedy recently I was greatly struck with the slimness, if not the thinness, of the girls in the chorus. I also attended a play last week in which the leading lady was a living skeleton, and the next in line was nearly as fashionable.

Ten five-story flats with stores on the west side of Eighth Avenue, from Twenty-eighth to Twenty-ninth Street, have been bought by the Rayvale Realty Corporation, which has elected not to renew the ground lease, it was reported yesterday by George W. Brown of George W. Mercer Son, appraiser for the landlord.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Hoover will have "a real rest" this week-end for the first time in seven months. Accompanied by Mrs. Hoover and members of his "White House volley ball team," he will leave Washington for his Rapidan camp in Virginia early Saturday morning.

LONDON, April 28 -- After six years of litigation involving costs of u195,000, the House of Lords Judiciary Committee, Britain's highest judicial tribunal, finally settled the so-called Waterlow case today in favor of the Bank of Portugal.

The metropolitan outdoor tournament season in lawn tennis will open tomorrow, when the Westchester County championships for men and women will start on the clay courts of Briarcliff Lodge at Briarcliff Manor.

Threat of further conflict in the Art Students' League developed last night when the students and members' protest committee held a mass meeting at the league's headquarters, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, and adopted a program of action.

Graduation ceremonies were held last night at the Hotel Astor, where thirty-nine young women received diplomas from the School of Nursing of Lenox Hill Hospital. Nine awards were made to the graduating class and the classes of '33 and '34.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,759,000,000, an increase of $46,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $835,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Continuing on an accelerated scale the drive to ease credit conditions and force additional money into business and industry, the Federal Reserve Banks for the week ended on Wednesday, increased their holdings of United States securities by $113,000,000 to a total of $1,191,000,000.

The Appellate Division, having at last taken action against the "emergency" buses in Manhattan, the Commissioner of Plant and Structures promptly ordered his inspectors to have nothing more to do with them, and the Police Commissioner has now ordered them off the streets.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The best thing Congress can do to restore the nation's confidence is to indicate clearly that it has no intention of "tinkering" with the currency, Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House Ways and Means Committee today in opposing the $2,400,000,000 bonus bill.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Continuing its revolt against the Economy Committee's omnibus bill designed to reduce Federal expenditures by more than $250,000,000 in the fiscal year 1933, the House today rejected, 141 to 118, the plan to eliminate half-holidays for government employes.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Twenty-six Governors had dinner tonight at the White House as guests of President and Mrs. Hoover, thus closing their twenty-fourth annual conference, which began Monday in Richmond.

HONOLULU, April 28 -- John C. Kelley, Public Prosecutor, said late this evening that the defense in the Fortescue-Massie slaying trial had called him on the telephone and asked him whether he would accept an 11-to-1 or 10-to-2 verdict, and that he had refused.

TOPEKA, April 28 (AP). -- Stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company, at their annual meeting here today, voted to modify the company's proposed first lien and refunding mortgage or deed of trust to include stocks and bonds of Santa Fe affiliated companies recently formed.

GENEVA, April 28 -- Secretary of State Stimson, who announced yesterday he would leave Geneva tomorrow, has changed his plans, and it was indicated tonight he would remain here while a session of the League of Nations Assembly is held on Saturday to consider the Sino-Japanese conflict.
More leases were closed by Hanford Henderson. Inc., this month than in any month since December, 1926, when the firm began business. George B. Hanford, president of the company, announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, April 28 -- Hart Crane, the American poet, who was reported to have fallen or jumped from the liner Orizaba on the way from Vera Cruz to New York, had been severely affected by the death last year of his father, a candy manufacturer at Chagrin Falls, Ohio, according to friends here.

Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War, told more than 400 members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and their guests at the Bureau of Advertising's annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening that they would never see President Hoover admitting "that the American people can be licked."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 28 -- The prohibition element was grateful to Mayor Walker because his beer parade plan would "vindicate truths" espoused, by the drys years ago, the Rev. Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, declared here today as he arranged for a dry rally at the municipal auditorium to be held two days in advance of the Walker parades.

SHANGHAI, Friday, April 29. -- The two most seriously injured in the bomb explosion were Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese Minister to Chhina and director of the recent peace parleys here, and Consul General Kuramatsu Mural. Their lives were despaired of.

A resolution providing for the election rather than the appointment of members of the budget and planning committee of the State Council of Parks was introduced at the monthly meeting of the council yesterday in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

Bonds of domestic corporations suffered yesterday their severest decline on the Stock Exchange since April 1, the heaviest losses being in the railroad group, where many issues broke 1 to 6 1/2 points. United States Government bonds turned reactionary, but foreign loans held fairly well.

Peeping into the Massachusetts primary election returns, one comes across a name mildly familiar for a few months at Washington and long endeared to Holyoke. Shut now the book, student of history, and tell us who succeeded Mr. HOOVER as Secretary of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The hearing of final arguments on the proposed four-party plan of Eastern rail consolidation took an unexpected turn near its conclusion before the Interstate Commerce Commission today when counsel for the New York Central Railroad, one of the signers of the application, failed to appear in its support, though he had sat through the previous hearing's.

Possibly because it was the most convenient explanation, Wall Street ascribed yesterday's weakness on the Stock Exchange to the declining trend of the commodity markets. Business was slower than on the previous day. There was an irregular opening, followed by a modest rally.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 28 -- Nassau County's financial affairs hereafter would be directed by a committee of bankers headed by William C. Potter president of the Guaranty Trust Company, it was announced today by Supervisor J. Russell Sprague.

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 (AP) -- With Harry Holsclaw pitching a six-hit game, the Newark Bears, idle for two days because of cold weather, defeated the Buffalo Bisons, 5 to 2, today. The victory enabled the Bears to take undisputed possession of first place after the two clubs had been tied for the lead.

The Juilliard School's final program of the season, including Malipiero's "Il Finto Arlecchino" and Wolf-Ferrari's "The Secret of Suzanne," presented these works yesterday afternoon at the school. They will be repeated this afternoon and evening and tomorrow evening.

Ward Summerfield and Elvira Davis were married three weeks ago. Immediately after the wedding he lost his job in a grocery store and she lost her job in the dance hall. Yesterday in West Side court they admitted a series of chain-store holdups that had netted them $300.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Farrell entertained with a luncheon at the Cascades Club today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. McLennan.

The mortgage for $8,325, held by the Jolly Realty Corporation from the Valrose Corporation, Inc., on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, has been extended to July 1. 1938. at 6 per cent, this being subject to a first mortgage for $24,975 and to a second for $10,500.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 28 -- Brown scored a 14-to-2 baseball victory over Lowell Textile today.

Columbia's rowing squad, none the less physically and mentally fit despite the quarantine, leaves this morning for Annapolis, where it will meet the Naval Academy tomorrow on the Severn River in the opening regatta of the campaign for the Blue and White.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The right of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to continue operation of its six steamer lines on Long Island Sound was upheld by the Interstate Commerce Commission today. The finding was on the petition of the New Haven for authority to continue operation.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Like the celebration of the return of a victorious Roman General was the reception to Premier Ismet Pasha, Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdi Bey and other Turkish officials when their train pulled in to Moscow from Odessa at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Adzharistan is the only district in the Union of Soviet Republics which can grow citrus fruits successfully, so an edict has gone forth from Moscow for it to specialize in these products. Tea culture and the production of fruits which can be grown elsewhere in Russia will be abandoned in the district.

In the first report of funds raised by this year's Catholic Charities annual appeal it was announced yesterday that $746,789.92 in cash collections from the parishes had been tabulated to date. The same announcement indicated that the final total for 1932 might fall below the $979,765.24 collected in 1931, but expressed the hope that the present difference would be reduced materially when the sums raised in outlying parishes were fully reported.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -- Two of the nation's leading Olympic hopes. Miss Helene Madison of Seattle and Miss Eleanor Holm of New York, successfully defended their women's national A.A.U. indoor swimming titles today in the opening events of the four-day program.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Senator Blaine charged in a Senate speech today that stock market operators "are very much like racketeers and gangsters."
WASHINOTON, April 28 -- Movements of vessels follow all dates are April 28 unless specified:

DETROIT, April 28 -- The biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters began final consideration today of the "program of work" which will govern the activities of forty-two State leagues and affiliates during the next two years.
CLEVELAND, April 28. -- To a golf ball which bounced off his skull Bernard Haag, 14-year-old caddie, attributes his growth of eight inches in less than two years.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- George Blaeholder allowed the Detroit Tigers eleven hits today, but the visitors were able to make them count in only one inning and the St. Louis Browns won, 5 to 4.

ABSECON, N.J., April 28 -- Mrs. Leo Federman of Glen Oaks today gained the Mortimer M. Singer Trophy as her reward for shooting the low gross of 261 in the fifty-four-hole tournament, which raised the curtain on the 1932 Women's Metropolitan Association season.

Samuel Untermyer, counsel for a committee of holders of debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, said yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange, in requiring immediate notice of substantial changes in collateral securing listed issues, was attempting to "close the stable door after the horse has escaped."

After several years of close association, with George Bernard Shaw, Thornton Wilder and William Lyon Phelps, Gene Tunney, retired heavy-weight champion of the world, is hard at work on an autobiography. He has written with some regularity for magazines and newspapers but has not yet had a book to his credit.

The Literary Digest poll on prohibition, in which 4,668,537 ballots were cast, shows that 73 per cent of those who voted favor repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, while 27 per cent are for continuance of prohibition. Dry majorities were registered by slender margins in two States-Kansas and North Carolina-returns from all other States indicating sentiment against prohibition.

A further decline from last year is recorded in bank clearings throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday night in reports received by R.G. Dun Co. The figures for twenty-two cities show clearances of $4,329,998,000, a decrease of 48.4 per cent from the corresponding period in 1931.

The Public Service Commission, by a 3 to 2 vote, declined yesterday to begin an investigation into the reasonableness of the extra charge of 25 cents a month made by the New York Telephone Company for the use by a subscriber of each hand or French type of combined receiver and transmitter.

Whether or not Twenty Grand ever will race again will be determined today, it was announced at Jamaica yesterday by Major L.A. Beard, manager of the racing interests of Mrs. Payne Whitney, owner of the colt.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 -- The Harvard Athletic Association today announced schedules for the varsity track, hockey and polo teams and the freshman polo, soccer and wrestling teams for the coming campaigns.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.

The Hispanic audience of the New Yorker Theatre witnessed last evening a second local premiere of a play by Don Jacinto Benavente, performed by the players from Madrid. Like "Eve's Children" of last week, "Of Very Good Family" was revolutionary, but in another way.

The two twenty-family tenement houses at 220-222 West Sixty-fourth Street have been purchased for investment by the Maryen Realty Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The Rowley Realty Management Corporation has been appointed agent of the property.

Villanova College of Philadelphia fell from the ranks of undefeated Eastern nines when it lost to Manhattan, 5 to 4, at Jasper Field yesterday. A two-run counter-attack by the Jaspers, after Villanova had scored twice in the ninth inning, brought about the first defeat Villanova has experienced in six games this season.

PARIS, April 28 -- That art perseveres despite every discouragement is demonstrated by the fact that the annual French Spring Salon opening at the Grand Palais tomorrow contains the greatest number of exhibits in history.

Bald-headed and white-haired "schoolboys" of "Old Number Three" raised their voices in the songs of days gone by last night, when members of the B.D.L. Southerland Association gathered at the Hotel Astor for their anual dinner and reunion.

The Federal Farm Board, still holding the bag containing wheat and cotton purchased at prices far above the present level, has been trying for some time to dispose of its surplus stocks in foreign markets. Last year it "traded" some of its wheat for Brazilian coffee and later sold some in China.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- With 3,000 college and high school athletes converging on Philadelphia for the two-day University of Pennsylvania relay carnival, injuries today began taking their toll of the entrants.

Hugo Riesenfeld, for many years managing director and conductor of the Rialto, Rivoli and Criterion Theatres, will come back on May 13 to conduct the return of a Roxy Theatre Symphony Orchestra of eighty musicians, Harry G. Kosch. president of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Lincoln Memorial in Washington, the Empire State Building in New York and the Nebraska State Capitol at Lincoln were the three American architectural monuments selected by a list of fifty leading architects as among the structures "whose architectural design was felt to be most satisfactory and appealing" in a poll taken by The Federal Architect and made public today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 28 (AP). -- The Florida Peninsular Hotel Corporation, formerly the Florida Collier Coast Hotels, Inc., operator of seven large hostelries in this State, was placed in receivership today by order of Federal Judge Alexander Akerman.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Governor Roosevelt drew further ahead of Alfred E. Smith as late returns trickled in today from Tuesday's Presidential preference contest.

CARTERET, N.J., April 28 -- Mrs. Samuel Bishop, a resident here for forty-seven years, died last night at the home of her daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mulvihill of 98 Washington Avenue. She recently returned to her daughter's home after undergoing an operation.

Tentative plans have been made for a new $750,000 three-story building, 250 feat by 250 feet, to replace the present Brower Park building of the Brooklyn Children's Museum at Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. John J. Schoonhoven, chairman of the board of the Auxiliary of the Children's Museum.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 -- Control of the Democratic State Convention by supporters of Alfred E. Smith appeared certain tonight on the basis of incomplete returns from town primaries and caucuses.

HAVANA, April 28. -- Two university students, Florentine and Guillermo Mason, accused of illegal possession of explosives and conspiracy against the government, were tried today by the second court-martial convened under a new law submitting civilians to military jurisdiction in cases of violation of the explosives law.

PARIS, April 28 -- Premier Tardieu, in his final speech of the political campaign, hinted that the government formed after the elections Sunday would face decisions of weighty consequence for France and for the world. Because of his illness the speech was read for a radio broadcast by Pierre Cathala, Under-Secretary of State, at a meeting of the Belfort Chamber of Commerce tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Having found their mislaid batting punch during a three-day vacation, Max Carey's Robins fell upon a quartet of Philly pitchers for fourteen hits today, stopped their losing streak at five games and won, 11 to 5, in the opener of a three-game series.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover, assisted by Secretary Wilbur, celebrated the opening of "Better Homes Week" today by planting a California redwood tree in the Memory Garden of the Girl Scouts' "Little House."
LONDON, April 28. -- The Federation of British Industries issued a report tonight containing suggestions for a new monetary policy for Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Governors of more than half the nation's States -- among them strong political enemies of President Hoover -- joined in praise of the Chief Executive tonight as host at "a very pleasant dinner."

LONDON, April 28 -- Forced end-of-account liquidation had a depressing effect on the stock market today, and the industrial stocks weakened considerably. A feature was provided by dealings in the new Indian loan. Starting at 3/8 premium, the quotation rose 1 7/8 and finished at 7/8.

Geraldine Bernstein, 18 years old, of 201 West 105th Street, a member of the Metropolitan Opera ballet, was shot in the right shoulder early yesterday in a taxicab at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street by Charles Del Rio, 29, an unemployed waiter, who then shot himself in the right temple.
The text of the prepared address by Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War, from which he spoke, deviating from it in phraseology but not in substance, follows:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 28. -- In spite of the widespread financial stringency, the business of the Protestant Episcopal Church will be carried on, the House of Bishops declared in a pastoral letter at the closing session this afternoon of a three days' meeting in the Garden City Hotel.

BRUSSELS, April 28. -- The Belgian Parliament discussed proposed amendments to the blue laws yesterday and today amid scenes unprecedented in the chamber. The Deputies argued until, as Emile van der Velde complained, the debate became quite incoherent.

Prohibition agents, who for the last nine days have been raiding small basement resorts, carrying out orders of Andrew McCampbell, Prohibition Administrator, to close every place listed in their directories of speakeasies, turned their attention early yesterday to an elaborately furnished resort atop a twenty-one-story building at 18 East Forty-first Street.
LENOX DALE, Mass., April 28 (AP) -- A bell weighing 2,390 pounds will toll the praises of Alfred E. Smith as a Presidential candidate from Lenox Dale to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 28 (AP) -- Marmion, a Coldstream Stud nominee for both the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, proved a surprise winner of the featured Elkridge Purse, an allowance affair for 3-year-olds, today at Havre de Grace.

The Yankees' tenure of first place in the American League was never in jeopardy yesterday at Yankee Stadium, with their pitching ace, Vernon Gomez, restricting the Boston Red Sox to three singles and McCarthy's men recording their fourth straight victory, the score being 5 to 1.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 -- George Parker hurled masterly baseball for Yale today, and the Blue scored its second victory of the week, defeating Penn State, 11 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Those political realists, the New York members of the Senate and House, are not hazarding any prophecies on the Presidency just now. They are mildly interested in the tables of delegates, in discussions of the effects of the Massachusetts and Pennsylvania primaries and in speculations as to what choices California, Connecticut and other groups of Democrats will make among the party Presidential candidates in May.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Governor Roosevelt, stopping off here on his return from the Governors' conference, took exception today to President Hoover's advice to the Governors to exert their influence to effect State economies. He declared most States had already reduced their expenditures and balanced their budgets.
Alice will enter the new Wonderland this afternoon; not by the rabbit hole, but down the gangplank of the Berengaria, when the liner docks at 5:30 P.M. at the Cunard pier.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28 -- Several hundred members of the Football Officials' Association of Connecticut gathered at Anthony Thompson Field today to witness a game staged by two Yale elevens in which the new rules, designed to minimize injuries, were used.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A fairly good portion of our seven million New Yorkers travel daily to and from their homes by way of the subway or elevated trains. They walk under great constructions of steel; they permit men to lift massive bulks of iron over their heads and place them in trucks waiting in the street.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 28.In a letter to the Nicaraguan National Guard today President Moncada praised its brilliant action in recent conflicts near Apali and expressed regret at the deaths of Lieutenants Brunton Covington and Whitehead, who were detached non-commissioned officers of the United States Marine Corps.

The charge that the forces of Franklin D. Roosevelt had spent $150,000 in Massachusetts in the primary contest Tuesday without getting a single delegate was made by Frank J. Donahue, State Chairman, yesterday in a telegram to P.M. Abbott of Los Angeles, secretary of the Al Smith Presidential League of California.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 26:

The cause of Arturo Toscanini's return to New York and his conducting of Wagnerian excerpts and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall was the plight of unemployed orchestral musicians of this city. It was for their sake that Mr. Toscanini came quickly overseas, at his own expense and with an arm sufficiently healed to aid them.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee today struck all tariff items from the billion-dollar tax bill and voted to confine it strictly to the purpose of raising the revenue needed to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933. This was a reversal of the committee's action of three days ago.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Rejecting the plea made by former Senator Heflin, the Senate decided this afternoon by a vote of 64 to 18 that Senator John H. Bankhead of Alabama was entitled to his seat.

Abolition of all wasteful and costly rules enforced by printing trades unions, and wage cuts of 20 to 25 per cent, in order to balance budgets in a period of extraordinary stringency, were recommended to the American Newspaper Publishers Association at its forty-sixth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The press dispatch on Pluto gives an incorrect account of the discovery of this object.

When the House voted to raise to S.2,500 the salary exemption of Federal employes, in connection with the economy cut, the galleries and the corridors were said to be filled with applauding Government employes. It could not have been an exhilarating spectacle.

Stitch McCarthy, Chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors, was adjudged technically guilty last night in Aristocrat Hall, 69 St. Mark's Place, of wearing a hat unbecoming a Chief Mayor at the parade on April 20 that marked the formal opening of Allen Street.

Unemployment has brought New York City face to face with an emergency situation of disaster proportions, and as nobody can predict the period for which relief activities will be necessary there must be a coordinated administration of all public and private relief forces in accordance with a central accepted plan to meet the present overwhelming need, declared Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, chairman of the executive group of the Coordinating Committee on Unemployment, in an address yesterday.
NEW YORK. Lord St. Levan and his daughter, Lady Mary St. Aubyn, of London, are at the Plaza.

The first sixty railroads to report their earnings in March showed total net operating incomes of $28,969,000, against $41,128,000 in March, 1931, a decrease of 29.5 per cent, and against $58,850,000 in March, 1930, a drop of 46.2 per cent. In February their net operating incomes were $20,426,000, against $24,630,000 in February, 1931, a decline of 17 per cent.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch, in Brooklyn, denied yesterday an application for a padlock injunction against Henri's Restaurant, on Scranton Avenue, East Rockaway, L. I., one of the best-known dining places in Nassau County.

Nicholas C. Partos, 51 years old, who at one time was credited with having amassed a fortune of several millions through real estate and other investments, was found guilty by a Jury in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions yesterday on the charge that he defrauded a woman of about $613 through misrepresenting the value of stock she bought in the Cornel Drug Stores, Inc., one of the many corporations he founded.

Plans were formuated to combat impure foods and underweight packaged goods and to effect a standardization of the pure-food laws throughout the country, at a round-table conference of the Woman's Chamber of Commerce last night at Allerton House, 130 East Fifty-seventh Street.

VIENNA, April 28 -- France's efforts to bring the Danubian States together are likely to meet as little appreciation from the countries for whose welfare they are designed as from the great powers who consider their interests would be thus prejudically affected, to judge from today's developments in Austria and Rumania.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) -- Knocking Pat Caraway out of the box in the fourth inning and continuing their assault on McKain and Gregory, the Indians today trounced the White Sox, 11 to 2, and ran their winning streak to five straight.

Hitting hard and fielding perfectly behind the effective pitching of Morris Cohen, veteran southpaw, City College's varsity baseball team scored its fifth victory of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday when it conquered the Upsala College nine of East Orange, N.J., 13-6.

LOS ANGELES, Gal., April 28. -- Charging from her bungalow home to escape a barrage of tear gas bombs after a two-hour gun battle with thirty policemen, Mrs. Ella May Thompson Alger, 29 years old, was instantly killed this afternoon in a hail of bullets from the guns of the bosiegringr officers.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 -- Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, Ohio, was nominated on the third ballot for the Presidency of the United States at the model convention staged here tonight by the Woodrow Wilson Democratic Club of Princeton University.

Money market was featureless. Business was small and quotations for all classes showed no change from Wednesday. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent, while street trading went on at 1 1/2, and Federal funds were offered at 1/8, without takers.

The new Earl Carroll Theatre at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street, from which Mr. Carroll moved on March 1 after less than a season of tenancy, has been leased by the 755 Seventh Avenue Corporation to the F.Z. Corporation, on behalf of Florenz Ziegfeld.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (AP) -- A bitter three-cornered fight for control of the Democratic delegation to the national convention and internal dissension over party control embroiled California members of the party today as each faction appealed for support in Tuesday's Presidential primary.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 -- Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, Ohio, was nominated on the third ballot for the Presidency of the United States at the model convention staged here tonight by the Woodrow Wilson Democratic Club of Princeton University.

Money market was featureless. Business was small and quotations for all classes showed no change from Wednesday. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent, while street trading went on at 1 1/2, and Federal funds were offered at 1/8, without takers.

GENEVA, April 29 -- News of the Shanghai bomb outrage perturbed Geneva today on the eve of the meeting of the League of Nations Assembly to act on the resolution of the Commission of Nineteen relative to Japanese evacuation of Shanghai.

New York City will borrow $10,000,000 on May 6 under the $151,000,000 revolving credit arranged in January with a city-wide banking group, according to information at the controller's office yesterday. This borrowing will bring the total used under the credit to $148,000,000, all of which is at the fixed rate of 5 3/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Mickey Walker, a great little fighter, outweighed twenty-three pounds, bounced off the canvas in the first round and then went on to conquer King Levinsky in a viciously fought ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium tonight.
RENO, Nev., April 29 -- A year that saw the rise of the divorce industry in Nevada into the class of "big business" ends tomorrow.

War Among the Literati. Writers of novels and their professional critics are getting excited about a general, all-inclusive, confusing argument started some time ago over THORNTON WILDER'S book "The Bridge of San Luis Rey."

BOSTON, April 29 -- The championship campaign apparently started all over again today for the Giants, who, after four days of idleness, returned to their astounding opening-day form. Embarking on a new series of amazing blunders, they contrived to lose to the Braves today, 8 to 3.

An optional agreement to purchase the Jersey City club of the International League by Nov. 1 was announced yesterday by Frank B. York, president of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club. The purchase price, although not disclosed, was reported as $135,000.

Journalism is in the peculair and difficult position of being an educational influence which at the same time is dependent on its practical success, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared last night at the twentieth anniversary dinner of the Columbia University School of Journalism.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Two home runs that drove in six runs were too great a handicap for the Robins to overcome, and the Phillies won today's game, 13 to 6, before a gathering of 4,000. Ray Benge yielded fourteen hits, but the Phillies made their thirteen go further.

Esthetics and utility have often been at odds in modern times, especially in the domain of Aladdin. The early battle over Niagara ended in a truce which, made possible the great industrial development about the Falls without destroying their beauty or attraction.

The listed bond market showed better resistance to the decline yesterday than on Thursday. Domestic corporation bonds bore the brunt of the selling, with the United States Government and foreign loan groups finishing moderately lower. Quite a number of new lows for the year were touched by domestic utility and industrial issues as well as by railroad obligations.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 -- Miss Helene Madison returned to the role of record-breaker in the women's national A.A.U. indoor swimming championships today by leading the Washington Athletic Club 400-yard free-style relay team to a new American record.

LITTLE VALLEY, N.Y., April 29 (AP) -- Faced with a charge of bigamy, Archie Campbell of Buffalo has told a story of finding buried treasure worth nearly a million dollars. His attorney, Robert P. Galloway of Silver Creek, contends that the desire to wrest the treasure from Mr. Campbell is the real motive behind the bigamy charge and other actions pending against him.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Concern was manifested here today lest the bombing of the high Japanese officials in Shanghai delay a permanent solution of the dispute between China and Japan. Reports recently received by the State Department indicated that both sides were close to an agreement in their negotiations at Shanghai.

Bishop MANNING had an honorable precedent for his discourse in St. Paul's yesterday on political corruption in this city. Another Bishop of New York stood up in the pulpit of the same church in 1889, at the time of the celebration of the first assumption of the Presidency of the United States by GEORGE WASHINGTON, to denounce the demoralization of the civil service of the Federal Government then going on.

Governor Roosevelt, appearing voluntarily yesterday in behalf of his appointee, Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, willingly and emphatically assumed part of the responsibility for the failure of Mr. Broderick to close the Bank of United States sooner than he did.

A law compelling employers desiring to reduce operations to curtail the number of working hours or days rather than to dismiss employes as a method of keeping up the market for consumers' goods was suggested yesterday at the meeting of the New York City Conference of Social Workers at the Hotel Pennsylvania by James F. Little, vice president of the Prudential Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission over loans to railroads from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was used for the first time today to force a reduction in the fixed charges of a Class I road.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, April 30 -- The Sino-Japanese peace negotiations were indefinitely postponed as a result of the bombing in Hongkew Park.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The first major offensive along the Eastern track and field fronts today developed black-haired, stout-hearted Joe McCluskey of Fordham University as the foremost American candidate for 1932 Olympic steeplechase running honors.

More than 100 issues sold yesterday on the Stock Exchange at new lows for the year to date, the market having been under steady pressure most of the day. The net losses among the more active issues ranged from a fraction to 3 points; the average decline for fifty stocks was $1.64.

The consolidated income statement of the United Gas Improvement Company for the year ended on March 31 shows a net income of $37,402,567, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.44 a share earned on the common stock, against $38,642,410, or $1.54 a common share, in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- From the galleries in the Chamber where members of the House of Representatives are steadily excising economy from the government economy bill it can easily be noted that both the Republican and the Democratic parties are, with equal strength, laying the axe to the roots of retrenchment.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Vast stores of radium cached in "Davy Jones's Locker" and landslides crashing down mountain sides at the bottom of the sea were described by scientists today before the American Geophysical Union.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Governor George H. Dern of Utah, speaking before the Woman's National Democratic Club tonight, criticized the Federal Government as not having reduced expenditures and said the States had anticipated the President's plea for economies in State governments.

READING, Pa., April 29 (AP) -- Putting over seven runs in the seventh inning and driving Van Alstyne from the mound. Toronto won the second game of the series from the Reading Keystones today, 11 to 6.

EDDYVILLE, Ky., April 29 (AP) -- The grimmest incident in the history of Western State Penitentiary marked the execution early today of three Negroes In the electric chair. Only after a guard had been stabbed and tear-gas bombs had been used to subdue the third Negro were the executions completed.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A 10 per cent tax on all pari-mutuel tickets by which bets are placed at race tracks was voted by the Senate Finance Committee today in its quest for new levies to make up for what It has deleted from the billion dollar tax bill.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 29 -- Private forest taxation, which often compels land owners to cut trees before they are mature, to escape heavy taxes, was deplored by former State Assemblyman Clarence L. Fisher, president of the New York State Forestry Association, addressing the annual State Reforestation Conference which opened here today with about sixty delegates.

LONDON, April 29 -- The usual brilliant private view of the Royal Academy's annual exhibition inaugurated the new London season today. For the next six weeks there will be a round of important social activities, culminating in four courts at Buckingham Palace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Henry Ford's plan, as outlined to President Hoover, for combining farming with industry whereby a workman could save $500 a year by raising part of the food consumed by his family seems to me possible of wider application.

Emil Lederer, resident director of the Hamburg-American Line, will assume a "czarship" in the transatlantic passenger field similar to that of Will Hays in motion pictures and Judge Landis in baseball if the principals of the Transatlantic Steamship Conference accept a plan sponsored by a majority of the lines.

Two men were killed and another was critically injured shortly after 8 o'clock last night when the coupe in which they were riding crashed into a motor-truck trailer parked on Exterior Street at East Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House insurgent group, composed about equally of Democrats and Republicans, continued today its drive against the omnibus economy bill designed to save more than $250,000,000.

A portrait of a barber-surgeon, generally believed to be the "missing" portrait of Michel Angelo, surgeon to Pope Innocent X, by Diego Rodriguez de. Silva y Valesquez, was sold last night for $4,900 at the first session of the auction of the collection of the late Sir William H. Bennett at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.
More than 600 New York University undergraduates participated in the second annual intramural carnival held on the quarter-mile oval track at University Heights yesterday.

The Appellate Division, by a 3-to-2 vote yesterday, dismissed the $2,000,000 damage suit brought by Lillian Mendal Popielawski agrainst Frederick A. Gimbel, treasurer of Saks Co. and director of Gimbel Brothers. The suit charged that Mr. Gimbel was under agreement to marry the plaintiff, and that to avoid doing so he conspired with Marie de Rivera, a medium, to bring about the plaintiff's marriage last July to Count Stanislaus Popielawski, a Pole.
HONOLULU, April 29 (AP) -- Twelve men of varied racial origin, tonight convicted of manslaughter the four persons accused of killing Joseph Kahahawai for vengeance.

The Roman Catholic population of the United States in 1931 was 20,236,391, a gain of 21,293 over the preceding year, according to statistics compiled for the 1932 Official Catholic Directory, issued yesterday by P.J. Kenedy Sons, publishers. The number of converts to Catholicism during the year was 40,269, a gain of 741 over 1930.
NEW YORK. Baron and Baroness Ashfield of London arrived on the Berengaria and are at the Plaza.

Trapped when the roof of a burning chemical warehouse collapsed beneath them, four firemen were critically burned yesterday afternoon. They were rescued by spectators, three of whom were painfully burned as they assisted the injured men from the blazing structure.

A lone gunman who ignored an armed guard a yard away and obtained $11,000 from a teller in the midtown branch of the Public National Bank and Trust Company, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, successfully eluded pursuit by a ruse shortly after noon yesterday.

Linked improvement in sentiment has been observed in municipal bond circles here this week, as reflected in keen competition for new issues and the general uplift of prices of highgrade municipal bonds, and this is believed to be assurance of a good reception for the slightly enlarged calendar of bond issues which are to come up for award next week.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Rev, Dr. Thomas A. Sparks, for two years rector of the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Rosemont, has accepted a call to become priest in charge of Old Trinity Church at Wall Street and Broadway, New York, beginning Sept. 1.

GENEVA, April 29 -- That the governments most interested in the success of the present disarmament conference do not intend to permit it to become abortive without exerting their utmost efforts to wrest substantial results from it was the interpretation placed tonight upon an interesting gathering this afternoon at the Villa Bessinge on the eve of Secretary of State Stimson's departure for the United States.

PARIS, April 29 -- Although showing a tendency to improve at the opening today, the Bourse was unable to resist the depressing influenres of Wall Street's weakness yesterday, the declines in wheat and oil and the unfavorable situation regarding the arms conference at Geneva.

The case to be presented by counsel for the burlesque shows at the Eltinge and Republic Theatres on West Forty-second Street at the hearings next week before License Commissioner James F. Geraghty to determine whether licenses should be renewed, was partly outlined by them at a brief session yesterday morning.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production has dropped sharply in response to curtailment plans and continued absence of volume demand. The index for the week ended Apr. 23 is 75.4, as against 87.3 for the preceding week and 93.8 for the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON. April 29 -- A headlong attack by the national doubles champions -- Johnny Van Ryn and Wilmer Allison -- carried the United States into the second round of American zone Davis Cup competition today with a decisive victory over Canada.

BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles gained third place in the International League today when they turned back the Rochester Red Wings, 8 to 7, for the second straight time by staging a three-run rally in the ninth. Don Heffner drove in the winning run.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 -- The Princeton varsity baseball team scored a 4-to-3 victory over Williams today, a ninth-inning rally, in which the losers scored twice, falling one run short.

Lucky Tom, winner of the Louisiana Derby by a nose, qualified for the Kentucky Derby yesterday when he led from start to finish of the featured Boulevard Handicap at Jamaica, flashing a smart performance under 126 pounds, his impost in the Churchill Downs test.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 -- The $500 championship stake for saddle horses went to the Boxwood Farm tonight at the third session of the Newark horse show in the Essex Troop Armory when Tom McCray galloped away with the rosette on the bridle of the chestnut mare Milady Mary.

Development of the concept of time throughout the ages, from the Egyptians, through Galileo and Newton, down to Einstein, Planck and Heisenberg, has produced revolutions in scientific thought and the development of new concepts of reality, it was declared last night by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, who delivered the first annual James Arthur lecture on "Time and Its Mysteries," in the Gould Memorial Library, New York University.
Alan Claset pitched in brilliant form yesterday, holding Jersey City to four scattered hits, and the Montreal Royals scored their second victory in a row at West Side Park, Jersey City, 6 to 1.

Records were shattered with marked progression yesterday at Baker Field as the Columbia baseball team defeated Cornell, 27 -- 3, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest. The victory sent the Lions into a tie for third place with Princeton and Dartmouth.

CLEVELAND, April 29 (AP) -- Cleveland staged a three-run rally in the seventh at the expense of the veteran Urban Faber to down the Chicago White Sox, 7 to 5, today and to score its sixth consecutive victory.

Replying to criticisms leveled against the practices of protective committees in the refinancing of defaulted properties, Hamilton C. Rickaby of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, attorneys, with offices at 120 Broadway, yesterday made public a letter he has addressed to Attorney General Bennett defending the interposition of committees and management agents for the protection of bondholders.

An appeal to Governor Roosevelt to lead the fight against civic corruption here and "to condemn it as it would have been condemned by Grover Cleveland or Theodore Roosevelt" was made yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.
OTTAWA, April 29 (AP) -- A 12-year-old Eskimo boy took a high place today in the long roster of heroes of the Far North.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Medical science passed another milestone in its battle against yellow fever with the announcement today before the American Societies for Experimental Biology of the development of a serum for the immunization of human beings against the disease.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 29 (AP) -- Twenty-four letters of John Jacob Astor which disappeared from the Gerrit Smith collection at Syracuse University last Winter and, after changing hands several times, came into the possession of the New York Public Library, are coming back this month, it was announced today by the university.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Backers of Governor Roosevelt, after a conference with him here last night, have decided to oppose the selection of Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, as permanent chairman of the national convention.
MEMPHIS, April 29 (AP) -- W.L. Clayton of Houston, Texas, attacked today what he termed government interference in the cotton industry in an address to the American Cotton Shippers' Association.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Washington Senators again won from the Philadelphia Athletics today, triumphing, 2 to 1, on the five-hit pitching of Monte Weaver, sensational young right-hander.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday presented an uninspiring picture, the most active issues on the list extending their recent declines in response to fresh liquidation. There was no acute unsettlement and business was slow, but Wall Street watched with increasing pessimism the ceaseless pressure against such a great number of stocks that were for years the outstanding leaders of the market.
New York City will turn time back 143 years today and in the streets of a town that was venerable when the Republic was born will be re-enacted the most dramatic day in the life of George Washington.

MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- The capital was buzzing with comment today on the first social function of the Soviet Government in the Hall of St. George in the Kremlin and the tacit permission given to the Soviet women present to wear evening clothes.

Labor organizations in various sections of the city will take part today in mass meetings, parades and demonstrations in their annual observance of May Day, labor's international holiday. The observances are being held today because the police had announced that no permits would be given for parades on Sunday.
MANILA, April 29 -- The Philippines were left today without a functioning Supreme Court.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 29 -- Students from thirty men's colleges are guests of the class of '33 at Mount Holyoke for the junior promenade festivities, which began tonight with a dinner. Then followed the "prom," introduced by the grand march, in which more than 130 couples took part.

Those who live within the shadow of skyscrapers are not cognizant, perhaps, of the yearly damage done by fire to the national forests of the country. The city dweller, for the most part, can only appraise the extent of the damage by documentary evidence, while his rural cousin pales at the thought of first-hand experience of this disturbing menace to the land.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 29 -- The Parrish Memorial Art Museum at Southampton, L.I., ultimately will receive one-half of the residuary estate of its founder, Samuel L. Parrish, retired New York lawyer and art patron, it was disclosed today with the filing of Mr. Parrish's will in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The first Gubernatorial dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight attempt is set for a take-off tomorrow at day-break-weather permitting.

Secretary HURLEY'S speech to the Newspaper publishers was full of force and marrow. There was no rhetoric about it and no nonsense. It was the salient and pithy expression of a strong individuality. If you like, leave aside as special pleading what he said about President HOOVER and his program.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29 -- One intercollegiate record and two meet marks were shattered today in the opening events of the twenty-third annual Drake relays.
COPENHAGEN, April 29 -- Denmark's most important industry was thrown into turmoll tonight when work was suspended in all bacon factories.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Automobile production throughout the United States in March amounted to 118,959 cars, an increase of 1,541 over February, the Department of Commerce announced today. The increase was due to a seasonal increase in sales of passenger cars.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., April 29 (AP) -- Churchill Downs opened its gates today in an emergency relief benefit program and the result was most encouraging. Despite lowering clouds which gave forth an intermittent drizzle throughout the afternoon, a crowd of approximately 10,000 was in attendance and early estimates were that between $25,000 and $30,000 would be realized for the needy of Louisville.

Beniamino Gigli, the Italian tenor, has severed his connections with the Metropolitan Opera Association rather than take a reduction in salary in accordance with the company's retrenchment policy caused by the depression it was revealed yesterday in authoritative quarters.

A national commission to devise means for co-ordinating State and Federal taxation was urged, last night by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, in a speech before the bar of the city of New York at their headquarters, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29 (AP) -- At least six of Connecticut's ten district delegates to the National Democratic Convention were assured today for Alfred E. Smith, whose forces also were confident of instructing the six delegates-at-large in his behalf.
The Pan-Hellenic Association of Hunter College announced yesterday the election of the following ninety-seven students to twenty-two sororities:

BOSTON, April 29 -- Ernest Vavra, crack N.Y.U. pitcher, lost his first game in seven years of his high school and college career when Boston College overcame a 5-0 deficit to administer a 6 -- 5 defeat to the Violet before 5,000 spectators today. Vavra was opposed by Emile Roy, who limited the Violet to four hits and fanned eight.

DUBLIN, Saturday, April 30 -- President de Valera's bill for the abolition of the oath of allegiance to the British Crown passed the second reading in the Dail Eireann early this morning by a vote of 77 to 71.
Leasehold deals, especially in lower Manhattan, featured a mild market yesterday.

Mrs. Reginald G. Hargreaves, who as a child in England inspired Lewis Carroll to write "Alice in "Wonderland" and "Through the Looking Glass" arrived hero last night on the Cunarder Berengaria to be the guest of honor at the celebration on May 4 at Columbia University of the 100th anniversary of the author's birth.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 29 -- James Cagney, motion picture star, who has been suspended by the Warner Brothers studio because of his strike against appearing in more films until his $1,400-a-week salary is raised, today disclosed that he had made an offer to the company to "work in three more pictures without a cent of salary if, in return, the company would cancel the remainder of my five-year contract."

DETROIT, April 29 -- The National League of Women Voters, after twelve years of uncertainty as to opinion in this country, adopted a resolution today favoring the entrancre of the United States into the League of Nations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the long letter of Herbert Wachsman in THE TIMES relative to utilizing improvement and invention as an aid to business recovery. Mr. Wachsman appears to be a keen student of economics and shows a superb analytic mind in locating its faults.

A group of men, women and children, many in night clothes, stood bewildered in West 114th Street yesterday morning in the midst of broken glass, charred debris and fire hose, wondering where they were to find shelter and their next meal.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A one-man mutiny broke out in the Senate this afternoon when Senator Long, Democrat, of Louisiana attacked the party leadership of Senator Robinson of Arkansas and resigned on the spot from all the committee places to which Senator Robinson had assigned him.

Slight Gains in Men's Wear Sales. A scattered improvement in retail turnover of men's clothing and furnishings during the week was reported yesterday by store executives. The recurrence of cool weather, however, held down volume considerably and prevented the better showing which had been expected.

The Yankees' winning streak reached five straight yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, but the Boston Red Sox, by a five-run flare-up in the fifth inning, made the second game of the series much harder to take than the first. The score was 8 to 7.

LONDON, April 29 -- Business was practically at a standstill on the Stock Exchange today. The tone again was dull, although there was less liquidation reported. Few orders were transacted for the new account because the Exchange will be closed until Tuesday and also because of the uncertain state of the market.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 29 -- Mrs. C.A. Meredith and Mrs. R.M. Patterson drove out to Fassifern Farm for luncheon after making a tour of the Hot Springs Gardens. Miss Mary D. Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Cushman and Miss Edna Smith were others visiting estates which are open to the public for garden week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter, "Up to the Capitalists," which appeared in THE TIMES is very timely and deserving of commendation.

Eighteen men and two women stars were named yesterday as members of the United States Olympic fencing team by the 1932 Olympic Fencing Committee. Seven of the men selected are members of the New York Fencers Club, including Lieutenant George C. Calnan, team captain.

Three detectives, testifying for the State yesterday as rebuttal witnesses in the General Sessions trial of Dr. Samuel Buchler, lawyer and former Sing Sing chaplain, on a grand larceny indictment, told of the arrest of a man in the defendant's office at 132 Nassau Street in January, 1931, after the receipt of a typewritten communication at Police Headquarters signed "M.N."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The killing in battle of Florencio Silva was reported to the Navy Department today by Lieut. Col. Calvin D. Matthews of the marines, commanding officer of the Nicaraguan National Guard. The battle, which lasted three hours, was fought last Tuesday at Estancia, an isolated town in the province of Nueva Segovia, five miles from the Honduran border.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Pushing its plans for the stock market inquiry, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today retained George K. Watson Co., accountants of New York, Philadelphia and Chicago, and revealed that four investigators, who will work on "leads" supplied by the committee, will be retained immediately.

The Nitrate Corporation of Chile, the Chilean nitrate monopoly, known as Cosaeh, announced yesterday that interest payable on May 1 on the Anglo-Chilean Consolidated Nitrate Corporation's twenty-year 7 per cent sinking-fund debenture bonds due in 1945 would not be paid.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Eppa Rixey veteran Cincinnati left-hander, turned in his first victory of the season today as the Reds won the second game of the series from the Pirates, 6 to 4. Brame, Swift and Spencer worked on the mound for Pittsburgh.

An effort to end the receivership of the Roerich Museum at 103d Street and Riverside Drive will be made Monday, when Morris L. Ernst, attorney for the museum, will argue a motion in Bronx Supreme Court asking for the vacating of the order of Justice Joseph M. Callahan, granted early this month, appointing Philip J. Curry receiver for the institution.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Further tabulation of primary election results in the anthracite coal region today reflected the popularity of Alfred E. Smith in that part of the State and cut deeply into Governor Roosevelt's lead in the Democratic Presidential preference balloting.
The third exhibition of the Painters and Sculptors' Guild at the New School for Social Research is by far the most interesting and inspiriting show that this society so far has staged.
The Jamaica Teachers Training College defeated Wagner College, 10 to 2, at baseball yesterday on Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

The need for an import duty on copper entering this country as a protection for American miners was stressed yesterday by E.H. Westlake, vice president of the Tennessee Corporation, formerly the Tennessee Copper and Chemical Corporation, it the annual meeting of stockholders.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, April 30 (AP) -- The police identified the bomb thrower as a Korean revolutionary from Manchuria and a member of a Chinese-Korean revolutionary society functioning in various Oriental countries.

Patrick McGovern, head of Patrick McGovern, Inc., the company whose contract with the city to build a $43,000,000 water tunnel from Yonkers to Brooklyn, is under investigation by the Hofstadter legislative committee, was threatened yesterday with contempt of court action when lie refused to answer questions before the Federal grand jury, which is conducting a John Doe investigation under the income tax law.

Encouraged by his primary victory over Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in Massachusetts and the result in Pennsylvania, supporters of former Governor Alfred E. Smith prepared yesterday to put pressure on John F. Curry, leader of Tammany; John H. McCooey of Brooklyn and other Democratic leaders to get Mr. Smith a majority of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention from New York State.

VRYHEID, Natal, April 29 -- Theunis Botha, a cousin of the great Boer leader, and other whites of this neighborhood are greatly puzzled by the unexplained appearance of a manna-like food on Mr. Botha's farm.

Except in a few centres which showed improvement, industry throughout the country continued quiet throughout the last week, according to the review by the mercantile agencies. Retail sales maintained the slight gain recorded earlier in the month.

An old Baluchi proverb has it that when the Almighty created the world "Baluchistan was formed of the waste material." But the report from Quetta of the installation of Mir AZAM JANG as Wali of Kalat and the Khan of the Brahui Confederacy would allow the inference that what was left had some jewels hidden in the clay.

ROME, April 29 -- The United States will be represented by five pilots at the congress of transoceanic fliers who linked continent to continent flying over oceans in heavier-than-air machines, which will be opened in Rome on May 22. Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who at first accepted an invitation to be present, has since informed the organizing committee that the kidnapping of his child will prevent his leaving America at present.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- An economist and a soldier joined today in opposing cash redemption of the soldiers' bonus now.

The Literary Digest published yesterday a final count of its vote on prohibition. Out of a total of 4,668,537 ballots cast, 73.5 per cent favored repeal and only 26.5 per cent preferred continuance of the Eighteenth Amendment. Repeal carried every State with two exceptions.

At the Delphic Studios, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, a group of American prints has been installed. It remains on view until May 8. Among the lithographs by George Bellows one finds the magnificent "Stag at Sharkey's," which posterity may, not without reason, acknowledge to be his ring masterpiece.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Complaints from the Port Henry (N.Y.) Chamber of Commerce, from Boston organizations and other sources that pig iron is being dumped in the United States by English and Dutch companies brought an investigation by the Customs Bureau today.

William W. McLaughlin, 85 years old, former Deputy Police Chief, who was known as "the greatest thieftaker next to Tom Byrnes," caused the arraignment of his son, Edward S. McLaughlin, on a summons yesterday charging the larceny of $400,000 of his fortune.

Arturo Toscanini, who came from Milan this week expressly to conduct the concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday for the benefit of the unemployed musicians, is to sail this afternoon for Italy on the French liner Ile de France. Moshe Menuhin, violinist; Artur Bodanzky, conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Mrs. Bodanzky, and Angelo Bada, operatic tenor, are to be among the other passengers.
Two exchange deals were included in the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

The Consolidated Gas Company of New York has applied to the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $30,000,000 of 5 per cent twenty-five-year gold debenture bonds, the proceeds of not less than $28,200,000 to be applied toward the liquidation of $22,000,000 of notes payable to the National City Bank and of $6,200,000 of advances from the United Electric Light and Power Company, a subsidiary.

MERA, Ecuador, April 20 (By mallvia Guayaquil) -- Cevallos, a station on the Guayaquil Quito Railway, is nowadays the jumping off place for the Province of Oriente, with its dense forests populated by head-hunters and other supposedly dangerous fauna.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- Mark C. Steinberg Co., a stock and bond brokerage firm in the Boatmen's Bank Building here, was suspended today by the New York Stock Exchange following the decision of the nine partners to wind up their affairs under the direction of receivers appointed yesterday on the application of the partners.

With only $7,743,000 of bonds marketed, new financing this week was the lightest since early in February. The total might have been increased to about $10,000,000 had it not been that several small municipal issues were placed privately. In the corresponding week last year the new bond issues placed on the market aggregated $20,870,400.

A further recession in the dollar volume of business in this district during March, compared with March of last year, will be reported in the May 1 review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales by wholesale firms were down 22 per cent, sales by chain-store organizations were off 4 1/2 per cent and sales by reporting department stores averaged 19 per cent under March of last year.

State Senator John A. Hastings, the $12,000-a-year "political contact man" for the Equitable Coach Company, was to yet a third of its common stock without investing a dollar, according to evidence presented yesterday at a public hearing of the Hofstadter committee.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., April 29 -- More than 200 garden lovers from all parts of the North Shore visited Collectors' Corner this afternoon, where the garden department of the North Country Community Association conducted its annual benefit flower and plant exhibit and sale. Mrs. E.B. Ball of Glen Cove is chairman of the committee in charge.

Farmers have little difficulty in securing government aid for any project that can be brought under the wing of the Department of Agriculture. Only the department's accountants know how much of the $247,283,130 appropriated for the year ending June 30, 1932, for example, was spent in teaching farmers how to plow, sow, reap and market more efficiently.

ROME, April 29 -- A new land, probably an island continent similar to Australia, will rise in the South Atlantic as a sequel to the volcanic disturbances in South America, Professor Ugo Mondello, Italian geologist, predicts.

Longshoremen who left the piers of the Clyde-Mallory, Savannah and Morgan steamship lines on April 15 rather than accept a wage reduction of 10 per cent, voted yesterday afternoon to end their strike and return to work at the rate fixed by the lines.

Old memories of scandal surging from 100 years ago were responsible for the fall of King Aifonso XIII of Spain, Robert Sencourt, British historian, writes in "The Spanish Crown," published today by Scribners. The feeling of the country, Mr. Sencourt writes, was not against the King personally so much as against what it believed was a court tradition and a selfish clique.

HONOLULU, April 29 -- Guilty of manslaughter was the verdict late this afternoon for all four defendants in the killing of Joseph Kahahawai -- Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, his mother-in-law, Mrs. Granville Fortescue, and the two navy enlisted men, E.J. Lord and Albert O. Jones.

Tomorrow's parliamentary elections in France can no more than indicate a general trend. Even this may not be apparent if the contest should turn out to be as close as is generally expected. The real decision will be rendered in the second round on May 8.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The athletes from the University of Florida came to the Penn relays in style. They arrived by plane and got to Franklin Field just in time for J.C. Hall to take off his coat and start in the decathlon event.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 -- Representatives of the Democratic, Republican and Socialist parties made appeals today to the 175 delegates of twenty-one colleges and universities now in attendance at a conference on the political issues of 1932 at Princeton University.

The annual report of the General Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1931 shows a net income of $6,666,948 after taxes, charges, depreciation and underlying dividends, compared with $7,575,039 in 1930. The surplus on Dec. 31 was $4,209,500 after $162,840 amortization of debt discount and expense of subsidiary companies, $4,006,521 preferred dividends, $2,272,630 Class A and B common dividends and $63,477 miscellaneous deductions.

The undefeated Juvenile champion of 1931 and the future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Top Flight, will make her 3-year-old debut today, at Jamaica in the $10,000 added Wood Memorial, a mile and seventy-yard test exclusively for 3-year-olds.

Responding to the appeal of the heads of the family welfare societies, the Board of Estimate voted $5,000,000 yesterday for unemployment relief and $1,000,000 for veterans' relief for the period June 1 to Aug. 1.

Breaking of the drought in the Southwest by the heaviest rainfall in several months caused a sharp decline in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.
