General liquidation developed, in which hedging by mill and dry goods interests became a feature, and prices broke more than 30 points, ending with net losses of 25 to 33 points on the day.
The text of the address of Secretary of the Treasury Mills before the City Bar Association last night follows:

A dramatic event in the world of music, not scheduled in the concert announcements nor reviewed by the critics, took place after the performance Thursday evening, led by Arturo Toscanini, of Beethoven's ninth symphony, which hymns the brotherhood of man.

PARIS, April 29 (AP) -- Edouard Herriot, veteran Mayor of Lyons and former Premier, continued today his attacks on Premier, Tardieu and Leon Blum in the election campaign which will end in balloting for the Chamber of Deputies Sunday.

With the aid of a dictograph and a marked $100 bill three detectives, trapped Cornelius D. McNerney, who described himself as chief investigator for the Lord's Day Alliance, yesterday and charged him with extortion.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 (AP) -- Gaining a good lead and closing with another bunch of runs, the Newark Bears again defeated the Buffalo Bisons today, 7 to 3, in a contest featured by long-distance hitting. Cohen clouted his second homer in as many days, while Hill and Barrett slammed triples.

Celebrations are to be held in several towns of Norway to mark on May 20 the fiftieth birthday of Sigrid Undset, Nobel Prize winner in literature, who writes some of the best and almost the longest novels written today. Her trilogy, "Kristin Lavransdatter," is said to be the most popular book the Book-of-the-Month Club ever distributed.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 29 (AP) -- Mrs. J.H. Whitney's brown colt Boundless Deep was a driving winner of the featured Buckingham Purse, an allowance affair at one mile and a sixteenth for 3-year-olds and upward, today at Havre de Grace.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 29 -- A tentative proposal for a reunion of the three divisions of the Methodist Episcopal Church will be submitted here tomorrow at a meeting of the Methodist Episcopal Commission on Inter-Denominational Relations, by Bishop William F. McDowell of Washington, senior Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Three entire floors of the fashionable Hotel Delmonico at 502 Park Avenue leased to the Breakfast Club, Inc., which was raided last November by agents of Andrew MeCampbell, prohibition administrator, were ordered closed for one year when Federal Judge Goddard acted yesterday on a padlock complaint drawn up by the government.

Colorfully costumed and expertly lighted to suggest its Florentine background within a deeply curtained stage, von Suppe's "Boccaccio" was sung to a large and applauding audience last night in the unaccustomed setting of Carnegie Hall. Gatti-Casazza and Charles Wagner both had taken earlier toll of this music of a merry past.

Dividend payments announced in April showed no improvement over previous months, the general tendency to lower disbursements continuing in nearly all industries. Several leading corporations, which have reduced payments several times during the depression, eliminated them entirely in April to conserve working assets.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 30. -- Slamming the ball to every corner of the lot, Lehigh today defeated Rutgers in a loosely played game, 24 to 17.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- The Yale freshman lacrosse team scored a 4-to-2 victory over Peekskill Military Academy today. After playing on even terms in the first half, Allan McQuade and Morton Winer clinched the game for the Blue.

THOSE who read Gustav Eckstein's "Noguchi" will have a curiosity as to whether they will find in this book the same literary charm and distinctive flavor of personality. They can be assured they will find a book alone in its own class, something different from any other they have ever read, a quaint, tender, delightful book that will do something, perhaps, to their attitude toward animals, whatever that may already be.

MR. THOMAS has bad two purposes in putting into book form material considerable parts of which have already appeared in magazine articles or public addresses. The first is to reply to the critics, or rather reviewers, who for one reason or another found his previous book.

On National Child Health Day we may well ask what plans the community child health program should include for the prevention of crime, that disease of society which, the experts tell us, has its roots in childhood and its maturity in youth.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sunday, May 1 (AP). -- The Hudson River and its banks in the neighborhood of the United States Military Academy were being searched early today for two second year cadets, Allan J. Light and Leo A. Skeim.

WITH Masterworks Album No. 171. Columbia resumes its Chopin series. In this Robert Lortat, who has already supplied sets Nos. 110, the Preludes, and 163, the Etudes, plays fourteen of the fifteen waltzes ascribed to the composer, on five twelve-inch records.

BOSTON, Mass., April 30. -- An unofficial convention with State-wide representation under the direction of the Republican Club of Massachusetts, meeting today in Faneuil Hall, voted 304 to 47 in favor of immediate submission of the Eighteenth Amendment to State conventions for "repeal."
Overcoming a two-goal lead amassed by the visitors in the first few minutes of play, the City College lacrosse team defeated Springfield College, 4 to 3, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

PERFORMANCES of "Iolanthe" will be given on Thursday and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre by members of the Bluehill Troupe in aid of the Girls' Service League. The annual productions of this group of young amateurs, for the last seven years devoted to performances of Gilbert and Sullivan operas, usually attract wide interest.
IMAGINE that no reasonable person believes any longer that the cause of temperance has been furthered by national prohibition.

A new child guidance clinic and a course in practice in clinical diagnosis that will be useful in educational guidance work have been introduced at Hunter College by Professor Mary F. Higgins, head of the education department.

HERE, at last, is a view, not of one section of the war but of the whole, humanly presented, motivated by a passion too deep and purposeful for exaggeration, and with a perspective that would have been impossible earlier.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., April 30 (Canadian Press). -- Fifty trade unionists in the pay of the government occupied the New South Wales Tax Office today, prepared to resist any attempt by the Federal Government to seize the files kept there.

Ability in Public Office. It has been a sad state of affairs that the average citizen looked upon politics as unclean and an unworthy following. The tide of national affairs is beginning to turn our thoughts toward the business of politics and government, and is revealing the heretofore many unknown merits and demerits of the persons we elected to represent us.
IN one of T.S. Eliot's poems there is a quatrain that reads: I shall not want Honour in Heaven

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Optimistic predictions that the revenue bill would be reported out of the Senate Finance Committee early next week were discounted today while the committee awaited a treasury estimate of what the measure would produce as it has been amended to date by the Senate body.
EXETER, N.H., April 30. -- The Harvard freshmen decisively defeated Exeter today in track, 88 to 38. The crimson made a clean sweep in the broad jump, mile run and 880.

IT was the mellow tea hour. Spring sunlight, gliding the haze of the campus smoking room, softened the almost standardized sophistication of the girl beside me. She leaned back, the picture of an Ingenuous young houri, speaking with the pleasant sense of authority of one who consciously interprets the elusive younger generation.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Senator Huey Long of Louisiana fired another defiant blast at his party leadership today by proposing that the Democrats nominate Senator George W. Norris, independent Republican, of Nebraska, for President.

With the increasing difficulty in selecting distinctive names for dogs, mainly because of the vast number of pure-bred animals that are registered annually in this country, more and more breeders and owners are turning to kennel names, which are used as prefixes or suffixes to distinguish the product of their kennels.

The department of musical education of New York University last night crowned a century of activity with the presentation of the most ambitious work yet undertaken by the department, Verdi's Requiem Mass, written in commemoration of his friend Allessandre Manzoni and last performed in New York under the direction of Toscanini in January, 1931.

Like the Great Teacher, the American Child Health Association calls the child and sets him in our midst. Its concern extends through the year, but it invites special attention of the public on the first of May to the program it has for all the days of all children in America.

WHEN City Tunnel No. 2 was "holed through" the other day. the shot that fired the charge signaled the approaching completion of another unit in a maze as complex as the labyrinth of Greek legend -- a system which has been evolving for ninety years, which connects the Catskill Mountains with Staten Island, which with all of its multitudinous ramifications is capable of supplying the metropolis with a billion gallons of water a day.
MADRID, April 29. -- The Spanish Republic will now begin definitely to take the form which will bind it for years to come.

Groups of young Communists made several unsuccessful attempts to break up the Socialist party May Day celebration in Union Square yesterday afternoon, at which more than 6,000 members of labor unions and others were present.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- Yale took possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by scoring a ten-inning victory over the University of Pennsylvania, 4 to 3.

LOS ANGELES, April 30. -- That gangling, spectacled speedster of Stanford, Big Ben Eastman, gave further proof of his world's championship calibre today, but the effort failed to save his school from defeat in the annual dual track meet with the University of Southern California.

Department stores are playing an increasingly important part in the retail distribution of household electrical appliances, according to a survey just completed by Kenneth Dameron of the electrical merchandising joint committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The second and final session of the sale of the late Sir William Bennett's art collection, held yesterday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., brought $56,047.50. The grand total was $98,137.50.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Princeton University will pay tribute to President John Grier Hibben on Saturday, May 14, which has been designated as "Hibben Day," when alumni will return to honor Dr. Hibben, who will retire in June after twenty years as president of the university.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- After an unsteady first inning, in which Cornell scored twice on two hits, Pitcher Fred Kammer tightened up and allowed the Ithacans only four more safe blows, the Princeton varsity baseball team winning, 8 to 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today.
Apartment houses and smaller dwellings figured in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday, in addition to scattered business property deals.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., April 30. -- Hotchkiss lost to the Pawling School nine today 7 -- 5. Rallies by Hotchkiss netted three runs in the eighth and one in the ninth, but the Pawling lead was too great.

The mounting cost of government during the depression is decried by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, which points out in the current issue of its publication. The Lamp, that the expenditures of the Federal Government, excluding debt charges, have increased 32 per cent since Dec. 1, 1929, while the indices of industry and finance have shown reductions ranging from 15 to 61 per cent.

Some of the reasons for the extraordinary decline in international trade since 1929 are evident. Business activity has slowed down. Purchasing power in all countries has been reduced. A sharp fall has taken place in the level of prices and accordingly in the value of goods moved across national frontiers.

A late, cold Spring bursts into blossom and song with the coming of May. The magnolia and pear put out their flowers in April, even in a Spring as late as this. The dogwood blooms in Virginia now; it may be another fortnight before it whitens our woods. The bird migration fills the night sky, and bids us good morning, as May opens with a rise in temperature.

LONDON. BEHIND all the grandeur and pageantry of courts at Buckingham Palace -- two at which will be given by the King and Queen in May and two more in June -- there is an immense amount of organization and of hard work.

VIENNA, April 30. -- The revelation of an alleged plan of French financial interests to take over the Central European State railroad systems as security for loans that the Danubian States are seeking caused alarm in Pan-German circles here today.

The French Parliamentary elections, which take place today and next Sunday, form an important factor in current European politics. That is to say that it has been the imminence of the French vote that has hung over many of the deliberations of recent weeks through which the Old World is seeking a better day politically.

TOKYO, April 8. -- Some curiously suggestive information regarding the mysterious assassination of Chang Tso-lin and the course of Japanese policy in Manchuria has been disclosed by Fusanosuke Kuhara in a Tokyo magazine article. Mr. Kuhara, who is now Director General of the Seiyukai, was a Cabinet Minister at the time of the events he describes, and a close friend of Baron Tanaka, the Prime Minister, whose memory he is defending.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Announcements that the naturally occurring chemical group which is responsible for cell division in cancer as well as in normal tissue has been definitely identified and that cancerous growth in rats has been arrested by the application of the X-ray to the pituitary gland instead of direct to the malignant growth itself were made here today before the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

LOS ANGELES, April 28. -- Fanfare of trumpets proclaiming the opening event of the Olympic Games only three months away. Preliminary work well in hand. Beautiful and completely equipped segregated village for the athletes "under construction. Splendid stadium, seating 110,000 spectators in readiness.

ROME, April 29. -- Exactly five years ago in May King Victor Emmanuel inaugurated the new excavations of Herculaneum. Abandoning the ancient method of delving into the bowels of the earth by means of tunnels to seek the treasures hidden in the buried city, he proposed to completely unearth the old Roman seaside pleasure resort.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 25. -- The financial condition of Costa Rica has gradually grown worse during the administration of President Cleto Gonzolez, which ends next month, and the new administration will have many serious problems to face. Yet there is no reason for considering a moratorium, according to Dr. Carlos Merz, an expert, who has made a careful study of the present economic situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one phase of the revenue bill as passed by the House which has not been receiving the attention which its importance demands. I refer to the capital gains provision.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 30 (AP). -- Restless music of modern America rang loudly in the sunlit gardens of Yaddo, the estate of the late Spencer Trask, today, as 150 composers and critics met for the first annual festival of contemporary American music.

Samuel Seabury, it became known yesterday, will try to show at the next public hearing of the Hofstadter committee that a considerable part of the $282,000 trustee fund created by the backers of the Equitable Coach Company found its way into the pocket of State Senator John A. Hastings.

Figures published indicate that the Class 1 railroads had net operating incomes of about $32,300,000 in March, against $45,905,000 in March, 1931, a decline of 29.6 per cent, and against $61,188,000 in March, 1930, a drop of 47.2 per cent. Gross revenues in March were estimated at $290,100,000, against $376,148,000 in March, 1931, a decrease of 22.8 per cent, and against $452,953,000 in March, 1930, a drop of 35.9 per cent.

To Buy or Not to Buy. AUTOMOBILE dealers and salesmen appear to be unanimous in reporting a new form of sales resistance. They say that many people who want to buy cars and can afford them, refrain from doing so because of what their neighbors and business associates might think.
Leroy C. Bellows leased the onefamily house at 6 Hillcourt, Malba, from the Briggs Holding Corporation. Quinlan, Terry Johnson were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The political magicians are setting the Congressional stage so that, after the tatters of the Federal economy bill are swept off the boards, the House can attempt to produce from its silk hat the latest anti-depression rabbit -- the Goldsborough bill.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- In a period of approximately ten months a sum of not less than $30,000,000 will be spent on unemployment relief in Chicago and Cook County. The period will end on Aug. 1, that date being fixed by the fact that estimates of the Illinois Emergency Relief Commission contemplate the exhaustion at that time of the $20,000,000 appropriation made last February by the Legislature.
HAMILTON, N.Y., April 30. -- St. John's of Annapolis defeated the Colgate Lacrosse team today, 15 to 0. Ramsey and Lynch each scored four times.

Say not that honest discussion naught availeth in a democracy. Overwhelming proof that it does has been furnished lay the changing status of the bonus bill still before Congress. When it was first proposed, there was a despairing feeling that nothing could stop it. Its enthusiastic champions declared that it would pass both Houses of Congress by immense majorities and would easily be made law over the President's veto.

BY recent accretion the list of English and Continental plays held for possible production by the soon-to-depart Gilbert Miller has been considerably augmented. Probably the chief of these acquisitions is "Musical Chairs," a first play by Ronald Mackenzie which was tried out at the Arts Theatre in London last November and recently began a series of regular performances at the Criterion with John Gielgud, Carol Goodner, Frank Vosper and Margaret Webster in the leading roles.

AT this season of the year, before the beach resorts have attained their popularity, many who like to tour on Long Island are in search of other places of interest. This year, in particular, there is great interest in Revolutionary and Colonial landmarks because of the widespread activities of the George Washington Bicentennial celebration.

Loose thinking on the part of some commentators on business conditions is responsible for the widespread belief that conscientious purchasing agents are exerting a depressing influence on prices, George A. Renard, secretary of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said here yesterday.

Kenneth Murchison, dressed as George Washington, stood in Bryant Park yesterday, in the canyon formed by skyscrapers lancing at the sun. Around him were other figures in the pageant commemorating the 143d anniversary of the first inauguration of the first President of the United States.

Plans for a world conference of builders in 1933 will be formulated when members of the International Federation of Building and Public Works meet in Paris next Thursday. John W. Harris, American representative sailed yesterday on the Ile de France to represent the construction industry of this country at the Federation discussions.

A PARTICULARLY disturbing form of enterprise is the making of facsimiles of books, letters and manuscripts without appropriate safeguards against the deception that may result. Though the purpose of their manufacture may be innocent enough, the art of facsimile reproduction has reached such a degree of perfection that, to adapt a phrase from the foremost Shavian, the results are often too true to be good.

WASHINGTON. THE numerous accessions of dry to the referendum idea have placed the question of resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment in such a clear light that it is expected to appear in the platform of the Republican as well as of the Democratic party.

The theory that wage reductions in industry will result in a reduction of costs, an increase in production and greater earnings to workers is disproved in a study of wage liquidations since 1929, covering 256 plants and 156,915 workers, made by the National Association of Cost Accountants.

Fewer buyers arrived in the market last week and retailers are gradually reducing their stock of Spring goods and are only reordering numbers suitable for May business, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 30. -- Scoring clean sweeps in six events, Andover swamped the M.I.T. freshman track team, 102 to 24, today. Cahners featured with a hammer throw of 170 feet 11 inches. Horton in the quarter mile and Chalmers in the mile were the only winners for M.I.T.
LONDON, April 30. -- One of the happiest young couples in London society attribute their married bliss largely to the fact that since their marriage in 1930 they have occupied separate homes.

Arturo Toscanini, conductor, who came here on the Ile de France on Monday to conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the cause of the unemployed musicians, sailed yesterday on the French liner to remain in Europe until the Fall.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Harry Washington Smith, chief clerk of the Office of Naval Intelligence, retired today after nearly forty-five years, continuous service in the Navy Department. He was born here in 1864 and appointed to the department in 1888.

In the crisis that has overtaken the famous "Little Red Schoolhouse" -- as the experimental classes conducted by Miss Elisabeth Irwin in Public School 41 are called -- and that is ending in the discontinuance of the experiment as part of the city's public school system, the issue between the time-honored educational system and the methods of the so-called progressive schools is sharply drawn.

WITH Spring comes always a flock of big group exhibitions. The Society of Independent Artists has had its sixteenth annual at Grand Central Palace. The National Academy's 107th annual has duly come and gone. Now to be seen (and ere this reviewed) are the exhibitions of the New York Water Color Club, at the American Fine Arts Building, and the tenth anniversary showing by Salons of America, Inc., at the American-Anderson Galleries.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- As the climax to six record-smashing performances, the University of Pennsylvania's flashy one-mile relay team today shattered its own meet record by whirling through the dust in 3 minutes 15.4 seconds in the outstanding feature of the Penn Relay Carnival.

WHEN a man buys a meal in the Canadian Province of Quebec he is not only appeasing his hunger, but aiding the hospitals. Not that restaurant food has been found to keep the sick lists down. But, under a measure passed by the last legislature and recently put into force, a 5 per cent tax must be paid on an meals costing 35 cents or more that are served in public places.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Twenty years or more ago Dr. W. J. Humphreys of the United States Weather Bureau pointed out the fact that certain cold years followed volcanic eruptions in which great volumes of very fine ash -- which is merely another name for dust -- were ejected.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 30. -- Wesleyan defeated Williams at track today, 72 1-3 to 62 2-3.

FEW mysteries are more potent in their fascination than that of the vanished Maya civilization, whose cities, centuries ago, disappeared beneath the green sea of the jungle. F.A. Mitchell-Hedges has for many years conducted expeditions into Central America for the British Museum and more recently for the Museum of the American Indian (Heye Foundation) of New York.

Production of crude oil throughout the world for the first quarter of 1932 averaged 3,570,800 barrels daily, compared with 3,546,600 barrels daily for the first three months of 1931, according to statistics compiled by World Petroleum. Of the 4,510,000barrel gain in the total output, 3,237,000 barrels were accounted for by increased production in Russia, whose total for the quarter was 39,106,000 barrels.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The question whether the world-wide depression of the last two years is only cyclical or marks an epochal turning away from world trade to self-contained nations or groups of nations, has split economic political writers in Germany into two camps.

Thirty high schools in Westchester and Putnam Counties selected five district champions last week in the National Oratorical Contest, which is sponsored in the metropolitan area by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Contests were held at Yonkers, Katonah, New Rochelle, Tarrytown and Tuckahoe.

TORONTO, Ont., April 30. -- A suggestion made by Lieut. Col. George A. Drew that committees of three men from the Ontario Mining Institute, the Ontario Prospectors Association and stock brokers be appointed to discuss with him troublesome clauses in the securities act, formerly the security frauds prevention act, was approved heartily at a joint meeting of the mining institute and the prospectors' association.

HAND-WROUGHT silver, one of the oldest products of the the craftsman, is also one of the most virile types of workmanship, as may be seen by numerous examples in shops and exhibitions. With silver is associated the exclusiveness of a costly metal, together with a traditional fineness of workmanship, and it is at the same time one of the best of the metals for engraving, chasing and etching.

Calling for a revision of the present monetary system, which is "hopelessly out of Rear and unsuitable for modern requirements," J. M. Kenworthy, former member of the British House of Commons, discusses the way back to prosperity in the May issue of Current History.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 28. -- The lynching of an ex-convict who killed a child threatens to become a campaign issue in Kansas. Donald Muir of Anthony, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, and author of the capital punishment law which was vetoed by Governor Woodring, is calling the attention of the voters to the failure of the statutes to provide capital punishment for first-degree murder and similar crimes.

LONDON, April 30. -- At the request of Ambassador Mellon, Mme. de Fleuriau, the wife of the French Ambassador, who is dean of the Diplomatic Corps here, will present the American women who will make their curtsies before King George and Queen Mary at this year's four courts.

COORDINATION of air transport, with other modes of transport, rather than conflict, is a hopeful sign in many parts of the world. In the United States the air-rail schedules, inaugurated in transcontinental travel and still widely used, set an example.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30. -- Three outstanding performers stole the spotlight at the Drake relays today. They were Henry Brocksmith of Indiana University, distance star; Ralph Metcalfe, speedster of Marquette University, and George Saling, the hurdling marvel from the University of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Assets and liabilities of the banks under the jurisdiction of the Federal Farm Loan Board on March 31 balanced at $2,087,899,044, while net mortgage loans and other loans and discounts outstanding at that time totaled $1,775,935,108, the board announced today.

LOS ANGELES, April 30. -- Miss Helene Madison of Seattle late today won her second title in the women's national indoor swimming championships, taking the 220-yard free style event for the third consecutive year.

BERLIN. IF the path on which German airplane designers are proceeding is the right one, airplanes of the future will differ in two respects from the ones now in use: they will travel at altitudes where they can neither be seen nor heard from the earth, and they will be all-wing planes.

Within the Arctic Circle hangs the curtain of the aurora. There are brewed magnetic storms that affect transcontinental and transoceanic telegraphy and telephoning. And there, too, lies the explanation of radio's vagaries. Whether we shall ever fly to Europe over Greenland, whether crops shall be good or bad, whether next Summer will be hot and dry or cool and wet, are determined by the atmosphere of the Far North.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Vigorously assailing the Republican party for its lack of constructive leadership and the Smoot-Hawley tariff bill in particular as a "gold brick the Republicans handed to the farmers of this country," Senator Alvin W. Barkley of Kentucky, who will be keynote speaker at the Democratic convention, addressed delegates to the conference on national political issues of 1932 in the final session of a two-day convention at Princeton University tonight.

ELKINS, W.Va., April 28. -- Not only has the action of the State Board of Education in making sweeping changes in school textbooks affecting the rural districts of West Virginia reached the courts, but to some extent at least it has been injected into the primary campaign.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal. UNDER the title to which rather strenuous objection was made in 1928 when the picture was made as a silent, shooting of "Rain" will begin during the coming week on Catalina Island.

THE "dramatic poem for music, Merry Mount," by Richard Stokes, is text for the opera of the same name, the score composed by Howard Hanson of Rochester. This work has been announced for future performance by the Metropolitan Opera Company.
AMHERST, Mass., April 30. -- Taking all first places except one, Amherst's track team routed Brooklyn College today by a score of 114 to 21.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 30. -- Beginning with an early morning drag hunt and reaching a climax with the formal assembly in the Crystal Room this evening, the program today comprised an intensive round of social and sport activities.

THE rising voice of protest against the American liquor traffic, setting the politician in vibration between the wet and dry horns of a dilemma, calls attention again to the familiar prohibition controversy. From where we stand under the shadow of Andrew Volstead, a glance at France, the proverbial home of fine wines, reveals by contrast a rather astonishing sight.

WHAT the world really wants to know about China is the history of the origin, development and ultimate triumph of war-lordism. The estimate that there are 2,000,000 men under arms today in China is a conservative one and the calculation that their support consumes more than $400,000,000 yearly is by no means an exaggerated statement of the truth.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- The Bears found Hank Brewer, Buffalo right-hander, difficult to hit with men on the bases after the first inning today and dropped a 6-to-3 decision to the Bisons before a crowd of 8,000. The defeat snapped Newark's fivegame winning streak.

The award to American students of scholarships for study at the Institute of Art and Archaeology of the University of Paris during a sixweek course next Summer were announced yesterday. These scholarships were offered by the Institute of International Education in cooperation with the College Art Association, using a special grant for this purpose made by the Carnegie Corporation.

DETROIT, April 30. -- Complying with the decision of the convention of the National League of Women Voters, which adjourned yesterday, the board of directors and council of the league at a post-convention session today appointed part of a committee to formulate a program "on which the full force of the league may be concentrated to meet the challenge of the present economic emergency."

Bonds called for payment in April before their maturity dates were more numerous than in the previous month, but far below the rails in April, 1931. The redemptions in April aggregated $15,427,000, compared with $11,110,000 in March and $61,117,000 for April a year ago.

LONDON, April 29. -- Eight Labor politicians are seeking their party's nomination, for the seat in Parliament now held by Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald as the member from Seaham. One of them is Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Mines in the Labor Government over which Mr. MacDonald presided before he and the Labor organization parted company.

ONE of the proposals for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, which would permit the people themselves to express their individual opinions, is attracting considerable support throughout the country, and this procedure is known as a referendum.

ESPECIALLY do I take this occasion to pay tribute to the courage shown by our public officials, both executive and legislative. * * * Their task is no light responsibility, * * * offers no rosy path to popularity.

WE think of Carl Van Vechten as a novelist of the '20s who swam with the surface currents of the years that were only yesterday, and whose descent over Niagara as an artist coincided rather patly with the descent of the stocks of the Electric Bond and Share Company and Radio common.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With all the space given the fact that this year the Metropolitan Opera, like so many other concerns, had to use up a goodly portion of its surplus, why has there been no mention of the fact that for twenty-five years Mr. Gatti has accomplished a miracle, unprecedented in the annals of opera-giving in the world?

GENEVA, April 29. -- Alongside the naval, military and budgetary committees, which are the technical staffs trying to work out the practical phases of the various proposals taken up by the disarmament conference, there is another committee charged with the high task of propagating the moral disarmament of the world.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 30 (Canadian Press). -- An improvement in foreign markets for Canadian commodities and a corresponding increase in Canada's purchases of raw products from other countries is revealed in a survey of government statistics issued this week.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Despite a shortage of players the New York Rugby Club battled the Princeton varsity fifteen to a scorelees tie on McCormick Field today.
SHANGHAI, April 30 (AP). -- Eleven Koreans alleged to have been involved in the Hongkew bombing were arrested today.

About 30,000 building trades workers are expected to stop work tomorrow because of an eleventh-hour development yesterday which resulted in failure of employers and employes to reach an agreement to replace the one expiring today.

MILAN, April 6, 1932. GINO MARINUZZI'S three-act "melodrama" on Gioacchino Forzano's libretto "Palla de' Mozzi," premiered at La Scala last night, scored a hit (thirty calls), despite a mediocre cast. The favorable verdict was partly a reaction against Veretti's cerebral effort, "Il Favorito del Re," that preceded, but mainly the recognition of an orthodox book and score.

The Rev. Thomas A. Sparks, who has just resigned as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd, Rosemont, a suburban section of Philadelphia, to accept the invitation of the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, rector of Trinity Parish, to become priest in charge of old Trinity Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street, is expected to take up his duties here with the opening of the church year next Autumn.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 30. -- Trinity won its first ball game in four starts today, defeating Williams. 4 -- 1. Ray Adams allowed Williams only four scattered hits. Sheehan pitched well for the Purple, but his support was poor.

MOSCOW, April 30 (AP). -- The Russian Orthodox Easter was observed tonight by thousands of persons. The churchgoers gathered early in the dimly lit chapels, large and small. The shabby exteriors of the buildings were in striking contrast to the 40,000 churches formerly in Moscow.

WHEN Harry Emerson Fosdick writes about religion the reader is aware that he will have placed before him not creeds but principles, not dogma but honest effort at discovery and interpretation. Dr. Fosdick's book -- his first in five years, we are informed -- is, therefore, an inquiry.

AMONG those men who gave independence to the United States Sir William Howe might well be counted high on the list He had it in his power not once or twice, but in all probability four times, to put a period to the rebellion of the Colonists.

LONDON, April 9. I WROTE last week that the theatre was in difficulties. This week has been suicidal. It began with a production of Maeterlinck's "Pelleas and Melisande" by a group called the Cosmopolitan Theatre, which, under the direction of J.T. Grein, puts on foreign plays in their original language.
VIENNA. CUMBERSOME as was the old Hapsburg monarchy, it served as the whetstone on which Austrian wit and cynicism sharpened its bons mots, directed mostly against the unwieldy monarchy itself.

PARIS, April 11. ACTORS -- and actresses also -- have always enjoyed performing in that very artificial kind of play which enables them to impersonate two characters -- physically exactly resembling each other but morally direct opposites -- for it enables them to show off, in one evening, the most strongly contrasted aspects of the superficial side of their talent.

THE final concert in the series of five for the benefit of unemployed musicians will be given by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. A feature of this concert will be Bach's three-piano concerto played by Harold Bauer, Myra Hess and Ernest Schelling.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your readers will get an extraordinary impression of the British workman from the letter which the Rev. R.H. White contributed to your columns. In it he says: "One has only to look at the dinner table of many a British workman * * * there is a quart of beer costing more than a shilling, surrounded by food that costs less.

PRODUCTION has been started at the Paramount shop on Maurice Chevalier's next film, "Love Me Tonight," a musical romance, with lyrics and music by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart. The screen play represents a collaboration by Samuel Hoffenstein, Waldemar Young and George Marion Jr. from the original Continental play by Leopold Marchand and Paul Armont.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The War Department disclosed today that for fourteen years it has kept secret the existence of a device for converting the Springfield rifle into a miniature machine gun.

Normal operation of "emergency" buses on the seven crosstown routes in Manhattan was resumed yesterday afternoon, on the assurance that the Appellate Division in Brooklyn would grant a sixty-day stay tomorrow of the injunction order under which they were forced to quit last Thursday.

BLUEFIELD, W.Va., April 30 (AP). -- An engine and ten freight cars ran over a 13-month-old baby lying between the rails today, but the only injuries physicians could find were bruises on the child's temple and cheek.
Changes in the operating personnel of the New York Central and the Baltimore Ohio Railroads were announced yesterday. Consolidations of divisions are involved in the B. O.'s changes.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP). -- California's Democratic fight moved today toward the Tuesday Presidential primary with the forces supporting Governor Roosevelt holding the centre rings both here and in Los Angeles.

Paintings from the collection of the late George A. Hearn, sold at auction here in 1918, will come under the hammer again on Thursday evening when works of art will be offered for sale at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries by direction of his legatees.

The selling movement that has been under way on the Cotton Exchange since Thursday reached large proportions yesterday, causing a break of about a quarter cent and leaving the list nineteen to twenty-five points lower than on Friday.

The original Alice of Wonderland is now visiting the United States, and perhaps we might get her to ask the March Hare to ask the Mad Hatter to ask the Carpenter to explain the way the stock market has been behaving.

THE eighth annual Westchester County Music Festival, to take place May 20 and 21 at the County Centre, White Plains, will this year be colored by the worldwide observance of the 200th anniversary of Haydn's birth, and by the George Washington Bicentenary celebration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES editorial entitled "Darwin Fifty Years After" many things which were left unsaid might easily have changed the whole tone and outlook of the piece. Undoubtedly, Charles Darwin has greatly influenced the trend of modern thought, but mere change does not constitute justification.

MANY prominent physicians and individuals throughout New York State, as well as others from near-by States, who have been active in the philanthropic projects of the Maternity Centre Association, are expected to attend a luncheon in behalf of that organization Thursday at the home of Mrs. E. Marshall Field at 4 East Seventieth Street.

THE last of the four distinguished European dancers who have added America to their itineraries has made the customary seasonal adieux, and the time is perhaps ripe for a glance at the contributions they have made to the land of their peregrinations and the recompenses that have accrued to them.

The Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes, rabbi emeritus of the Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, where he went in 1877, preached there yesterday as a part of the observance of his eightieth birthday, which will be continued with a reception in the synagogue assembly room this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Washington Cathedral on Mount St. Albans, the foundation stone of which was laid twenty-five years ago, will be opened for public worship on Thursday, Ascension Day.

ALTHOUGH most New Yorkers know that George Washington visited their State many times, few, perhaps, realize that he lived within its borders more than six years at different stages of his career and that he could well have counted it, next to Virginia, as his second home.
LURAY, Va., April 30. -- President Hoover's first 1932 week-end at his Rapidan camp was a dreary one as far as weather was concerned.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28. -- When the Supreme Court of Alabama, with its chief justice alone dissenting, confirmed last March death sentences for seven of the eight Negroes convicted at Scottsboro of criminal assault on two white girls, there was no such applause from Alabama folk as the public elsewhere may have been led to expect.
MONTREAL, April 30 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal's day shelter for unemployed men has closed, with the committee in charge characterizing its operation as a "most unique and successful experiment."

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Playing brilliant tennis in a drizzling rain, Frank Shields and Ellsworth Vines turned back the Canadians in the last two battles of the Davis Cup series today to give the United States a clean sweep of all five matches.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Portraits of George Washington as a Virginia Colonel, of Nellie Custis, of Light Horse Harry Lee and of Lafayette, copies of originals formerly in the possession of General Washington at Mount Vernon and later of George Washington Parke Custis at Arlington mansion, were presented to the War Department this afternoon by historical societies.

Friends of Mrs. Georgianna Furey, 87-year-old widow of Colonel John V. Furey, one of Brooklyn's most distinguished soldiers, started a movement yesterday to obtain a Colonel's pension for Mrs. Furey who is facing poverty as a result of the depression.

THE Charity Carnival of 1932, sixth in a series of brilliant annual events for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre, will be held Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden. With its glittering pageant, "Adventure," which is expected to surpass its predecessors of other years, "Aztec Gold," "Romance" and "Enchantment," the carnival will mark the culmination of weeks of effort on the part of many committees that have been active in preparations.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 30. -- Evening, George D. Widener's fleet little filly, showed a clean pair of heels to a field of Preakness and Derby candidates today to win the thirteenth running of the $10,000 added Chesapeake Stakes and won $10,850 for her owner.

THIS is autobiography -- and much more. Warden Lawes skillfully uses the story of his extraordinary career to lay before the public hard facts about crime, law enforcement and our present methods of dealing with criminals.

INTERVIEWED by a representative of the Neue Freie Presse of Vienna shortly after his return from his last American engagement, Bruno Walter, the German conductor, expressed his views on present conditions in the world of art as follows:

To judge by the volume of transactions, Wall Street gave the stock market only passing notice yester- day. The turnover on the Stock Ex- change was less than 440,000 shares. The irregularly lower course of prices appeared to reflect again the prevalent uncertainties, if it had any significance at all.

MR. GUY POCOCK of the editorial staff of J.M. Dent Co., London, is credited with the discovery of F.C. Boden, whose novel, "Miner." is to be published here on May 2 by E.P. Dutton Co. Four years ago Mr. Pocock asked Mr. Brailsford of The New Leader and Hamilton Fyfe of The Daily Herald to publish a letter asking working men to send literary work with a view to criticism and possible publication.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., April 30. -- A man who is believed to be one of the leaders of rum-running activities in Long Island was arrested early today after, it is charged, he had walked into a trap set by three agents from the office of Alexander G. Blue, District Attorney of Suffolk County.

A display of fireworks from the tops of the huge towers of the George Washington Bridge, 635 feet above the Hudson River, attracted tens of thousands of persons to the New York and New Jersey shores last night and was watched also from rooftops, windows and streets in both States.

Miss Dorothy Haffner of New York University captured the women's intercollegiate fencing championship yesterday and, with her two teammates, Miss Francis Siegel and Miss Marjorie Lancing, retained for N.Y. U. the intercollegiate team fencing titie.

HAROLD LLOYD'S first picture in nearly two years is nearing the end of its production grind in what, for Mr. Lloyd, is jig time. "Movie Crazy" has been shooting at the United Artists studio for eight weeks, and the spectacled one, who is producer as well as star, expects to be able to start assembling and cutting his comedy this week.

DALLAS, April 28. -- Backers of Speaker John. N. Garner for the Democratic Presidential nomination will find May a merry month in Texas. The surface calm belies the bitterness of the impending struggle. There is no doubt, of course, that the Speaker will get this State's forty-six votes at Chicago, probably as long as he wants them.

General George Washington, simply attired in silver-gray breeches and flowing coat, white cotton stockings and buckled shoes and a black three-cornered hat, landed from a barge on Manhattan Island yesterday and under a shower of ticker tape moved through the ceremonies which made him the first President of the United States 143 years ago.

MANILA. STRONG support has been forthcoming from every part of the Philippines for the suggestion of Governor General Theodore Roosevelt that radio broadcasting be made a public basis for the dissemination of information to remoter towns and villages of the islands.

AMERICAN - AND ERSON -- Tenth annual Spring exhibition of The Salons of America, Inc. Nearly 400 works in oil, water-color, the graphic mediums and sculpture. Opened April 26, closes May 14. Reviewed April 27. See further comment on this page.

Ushering out a month which holds few pleasant memories for the financial community, the stock and bond markets yesterday made a generally unsatisfactory showing. If there were few wide declines in either market, the fact remains that they both were governed by reactionary influences and there was a continuance of slow liquidation.

Failure of trade associations to present organized opposition to appropriation slashes proposed in Congress for the Department of Commerce is traced to three causes: resentment at the department for failing to rally to the support of trade groups during the depression, shortcomings in services offered by the department and alleged bureaucratic development in the one branch of government service which was to be an example of business leadership.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Metropolitan Opera Company has enjoyed big headlines on the front page regarding reduction of prices for next season, one account stating that prices would be reduced 50 per cent.

ZASU PITTS, who has a habit of popping out of unexpected corners in films, is contributing her latest comedy bit to "The Trial of Vivienne Ware," now at the Roxy. Although Miss Pitts is only a meek 32 years of age, she is one of the real veterans among the Hollywood troupers.

With the exception of coffee and hides, prices generally moved down on local commodity exchanges last week and several new low records were established. Some products were subjected to heavy selling yesterday.

PARIS, April 16. -- For a country to be rich, or at any rate to appear rich, is a state which is not without its inconveniences. The United States found this out when they were reproached with cornering the world's gold supply. Later, France came in for her share of the unpopularity which Europe attaches to countries holding a large gold reserve.

Boat owners in many parts of the country have expressed their intention of cooperating in the campaign recently initiated appealing to boat users to put their craft overboard this Spring and some already are purchasing supplies and hiring labor for the annual overhauling.

The Spring moving season in the business world reached its peak yesterday without taxing the facilities of the city's van owners and was set down by real estate interests and moving men as one of the quietest in years.

THOUGH the freshets that strike New York on or after April 15 are alleged to wash up its theatre, thus causing numerous men and women to dust off old passports and fix weary eyes on other vistas, there come occasionally such matters as give pause to those who are quick to call the season over.
PARIS, April 29. -- Judging from the French press, it is an embittered France that is going to the polls Sunday -- a France surrounded by enemies desperately seeking her undoing.

CROOKING is not what it used to be. Radio's so-called crooners are not getting the big bags of mail that they did a few months ago, according to those who compile statistics for the broadcasting stations.

DOUGLAS FAIRBANKS and his South Seas expedition are on the bounding blue Pacific at this minute, one day out from the shores of California. The picture they have been making around Tahiti has been appropriately christened "Robinson Crusoe of the South Seas," and is all finished except for the tie-in shots which must be made in Hollywood.

In a game that was marked by fierce hitting, with four home runs being registered, the Fordham University baseball team scored a decisive triumph over the Temple University nine at Fordham Field yesterday, 17 to 6.

A SOD house, such as the first settlers of the prairies used, is to be built in Topeka, Kan. It will enable tourists to visualize the conditions endured by the pioneers. The project is under the direction of the Kansas State Historical Society, which is already conducting negotiations with sod-house builders of the old days.

Settlement of the coastwise pier strike which caused 1,000 longshoremen to accept a 10 per cent reduction of wages was accepted yesterday in shipping circles as a step toward reduction of wages on the deep-sea piers at the expiration of the working agreement of the ship lines and the International Longshoremen's Association in October.

WHAT are the cosmic rays? Kolhorster in Germany, who, like Millikan, has spent years in studying them, thinks they are high-speed electrons -- a view not acceptable to most physicists, because electrons entering the earth's magnetic field from outer space would spiral around the Poles, whereas the rays are actually as strong at the Equator as they are anywhere else.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Final figures for the Treasury's offering of $450,000,000 in 2 per cent one-year certificates and 3 per cent two-year notes dated May 2, showed total subscriptions of $4,196,796,700 and allocations of $483,431,600.

New public financing in April was slightly less than in March, bond issues accounting for virtually all the offerings. The month's new offerings aggregated $130,299,000, of which $129,549,000 was for thirty-five bond issues and $750,000 for one stock issue.

LONDON, April 30 (AP). -- The Everton football club clinched the championship of the English Soccer League today. The season has another week to run, but Everton has compiled enough points to assure victory.

FOR more than half a century meteorologists have been familiar with evidence indleating that mean annual termperatures in the earth's atmosphere tend to vary slightly in coincidence with the eleven-year sunspot period, being somewhat lower when sunspots are numerous than when they are few.

MODERNISTIC is a word without a country. No definition fits and "modern" is coming to be almost as vague in its implications. This, no doubt, is the reason that most of the public are willing to rest for a long time upon only one or two of the many manifestations of the spirit of research and reaction as it whirled into the twentieth century, stirring up a blinding dust and creating general commotion.

Industry continues to set the National Legislature an example in the problem of balancing budgets. The largest industrial corporation -- United States Steel -- went a step further last week in its effort to get down to bedrock by omitting its quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on its common stock.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30. -- With Charley Devens pitching one of the best games of his career, Harvard's baseball team defeated Penn State today, 5 to 0. Devens allowed only four singles and not a Harvard outfielder had to handle a fly ball.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- The Fordham freshman nine today overwhelmed the Yale Jayyees by hard hitting, 14 to 2, scoring in every inning but two.

Cyrus L. Sulzberger, merchant, philanthropist and leader in civic and Jewish communal affairs, died at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his home, 300 West End Avenue, in his seventy-fourth year. He had been in failing health for several months. In the last few months he had been confined to his home.
NEW YORK. Brigadier General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt have returned to New York from Hot Springs, Va.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Slightly increased business activity in a few American markets abroad was shown in the current weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.

An aged sailor who had lived at Sailors' Snug Harbor for the last fifteen years and who died several weeks ago, left ail his money and personal possessions to the Mariners' Family Asylum, a home on Staten Island for widows, mothers and daughters of seamen, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- On the eve of the biggest Soviet holiday of the year there is more excitement in the air than on the night before Christmas in the United States. Tomorrow the Soviet will demonstrate its military strength and the solidarity of its workers in a gigantic parade in Red Square here and also in celebrations in Leningrad and other large cities.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- In the words of Alfred E. Smith, "They put a chock under the Roosevelt bandwagon" this week in Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Connecticut. The Governor of New York suffered the first defeats after his steady series of victories in Presidential preference primaries ranging from Washington, in the Pacific Northwest, to Maine, jutting her rocky coasts into the North Atlantic.

From Sir John Martin-Harvey. To the Dramatic Editor: I notice that your issue of Sunday, April 17, refers to "The King's Messenger" as one of my "older favorites." This play, by your American author Frederick Jackson, was produced in London just one year ago and is entirely modern.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP). -- The prize of $1,000 for a concerto for string quartet with orchestral accompaniment, offered by the Edward Garrett McCollin Memorial Fund, has been awarded to Josap Valls of Paris, it was announced today.

These are the days when the sports caravans are sailing to Europe. A few days ago the first of the women tennis stars left these shores to carry the American invasion to the courts of England and the Continent.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 30. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lacrosse team defeated the Bronx Lacrosse Club, 9 to 0, today for its third triumph in as many starts.

Further pressure against domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday sent railroad, industrial and utility issues generally lower in the order named. Several active loans of the three groups lost 1 to 6 points, uncovering further new low marks for the year.

LONDON, April 19, 1932. THE Haydn centenary has not passed without recognition. Indeed, it has been, is and will be celebrated for some time to come. But, oddly enough, one concert only has been given with a program devoted wholly and exclusively to his compositions.

The Yankees staged a tempestuous finish, with homers by Dickey, Ruth and Combs in that order, to wrest from the Boston Red Sox the third and final game of the series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday by the score of 6 to 3, stretching their winning streak to six straight and giving a crowd of 18,347 a royal good time.

As the machine becomes more and more dominant in our civilization, the worker's main function, it is often thought, is to make himself a kind of vocational robot adapted to a particular task. The exact opposite seem to be the case. For our machine age is also an age of bewildering change; one process and specialization supplants another with breath-taking rapidity.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- More than half the delegates to the Republican National Convention have been elected, according to a compilation by the national committee, which shows that President Hoover has 641 delegates instructed or favorable to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been recent agitation in favor of repeal of the "foreign credits" clause of the income tax law. The revenue act of 1928, under which income taxes are now collected, allows American citizens and corporations to deduct from their income taxes certain proportionate amounts of any such taxes paid to a foreign State.

AMERICAN girls are following in the footsteps of their English cousins in selecting the month of May for their marriages, for not in many years have there been so many weddings arranged for that month as the present season.

PARIS, April 30. -- After a brief effort at recovery today, the Bourse finished the week in a condition of general weakness and most of the list closed at the day's low prices. Month-end settlements, however, were accomplished easily. The money rate was one-eighth of 1 per cent on the Bourse floor and 4 1/4 on the Curb, and many shares were carried over at a figure much under the official rates.

THE Screen Guild, a boisterous infant of one month, had its first look at New York last week. M.C. Levee, president of the new organization, came in from Hollywood and augmented the newspaper dispatches with additional information about the guild, which has the support of Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks, Cecil B. De Mille and numerous leaders among the screen's executive, acting, directing and writing folk.

Textile's baseball team, defending city P.S.A.L. senior high school champion, rolled up the largest score to date in the current P.S.A.L. tourney, swamping Stuyvesant, 28 to 1, yesterday at Suydam Oval.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., April 30. -- The Peddie School baseball team scored its second successive triumph by shutting out Brooklyn Poly Prep. 7-0, today. Peddie won the game in the first inning with a four-run rally. Dann allowed only three hits.

PARIS, April 17. -- "If France will only get off our neck," a leading German banker said to me in Berlin th,e other day, "we can come back industrially. But in view of her course in the last year I see little hope."
James G. McDonald, chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, announced yesterday that $25,000 was needed to continue the work of the association, which, he said, "is not a luxury but a necessity."

IN the Spring, as soon as may be after the Flower Show, the garden lovers go forth with high hearts to make the perfect garden. Some of them go too soon, and into soil still puddly from thawing they thrust the tender and expensive root or seedling, imbedding it so firmly in mortarlike mud that the plant will debate a long while whether it cares to live or not.

The Amateur Athletic Union's national four-wall soft-ball handball championship titles in singles and doubles were won by New Yorkers yesterday for the first time in the history of the sport under A.A.U. control, and to Angelo Trulio, New York A.C. player, went the distinction of winning one and sharing the other.

PITY of God" is the first present-day novel of Beulah Marie Dix, hitherto known for her historical novels and juveniles. The story deals with the events of a day in the life of an American family, which conceals deeply running emotional conflicts under its apparently serene surface, and over which hangs the menace of an unsuspected catastrophe.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended April 23 increased over those of the preceding week, but continued considerably below the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Three plainclothes patrolmen of Chief Inspector John O'Brien's staff raided an expensively furnished fifteen-room apartment on the ninth floor of 625 Park Avenue, at Sixty-fifth Street, early this morning. They arrested two men on charges of keeping and maintaining a gambling resort and of being common gamblers and dispersed the patrons, all in evening clothes, who had crowded the apartment.

TO the ordinary modern man nothing is simpler than the idea of time. He had a Waterbury watch for a Christmas present by the time he was 6. He timed horse races or hundred-yard dashes or bicycle speeds to a fifth of a second with a stop watch before he was 12.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 30. -- The first trapshooting season of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club over the organization's new traps came to an end today with the first shoot for the Erskine H. Lott Memorial Trophy.

On the heels of the announcement that Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor, had severed his connection with the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was revealed at an authoritative source yesterday that another star, Maria Jeritza, the Austrian soprano, whose career with the Metropolitan has been one of sensational success, also had refused to accept a cut in salary and would not return to the opera house next season.
DETROIT, April 30. -- Expenditure of $986,692 in services to 215,000 juveniles is revealed in the annual report of the Children's Fund of Michigan, endowed by Senator Couzens.

HANOVER, N.H., April 30. -- An unassisted goal by Harry Litzenberger, star Dartmouth football player, was the deciding factor in a keenly contested lacrosse game today and Dartmouth beat Harvard, 1 to 0. for the Green's third straight victory and the Crimson's first defeat of the season.

BOSTON, April 28. -- Everybody is thinking of the overwhelming sweep for Al Smith in the Massachusetts Presidential primaries of yesterday. The expected happened, only a lot more of it. Smith was conceded in advance almost the entire delegation, but most observers supposed that Mayor Curley and Jim Roosevelt would pull through.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30. -- The Harvard rugby team blanked Yale today by the overwhelming score of 17 to 0 on Soldiers Field. The Crimson also took the Jayvee contest, 11 to 0.

The American Bankers Association, representing virtually the entire American banking community, announced yesterday that it approved as a whole the revised Glass bill to amend the Federal Reserve act and the National Bank act, but that it advocated certain important amendments.

RETAIL trade held to its improved level during the week except in sections of the country that suffered from unfavorable weather. The chief activity in this area centred on women's apparel and accessories. Low-priced floor coverings, lamps and other home furnishing lines, except furniture, attracted fairly good response.

Today will mark the beginning of the Summer season in some churches which with last Sunday discontinued until Fall their afternoon or evening service. The Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, will this morning preach his last sermon there until Autumn and from now to October the 4 and 8 P.M. services will be omitted.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 30. -- The junior members of the Larchmont Woman's Club held a dance tonight at the Larchmont Shore Club for the benefit of the local unemployment relief fund. Miss Muriel Gedney was chairman, assisted by:

ITHACA, N.Y., April 30. -- Cornell's lacrosse team won its third straight victory today, overwhelming the Yale twelve, 5 goals to 1. Yale was unable to cope wnth the Red's fast attack in the second half, and the Ithacans scored three goals. Cornell led the Elis 2 to 1 at the half.

GOVERNOR ELY of Massachusetts has signed the bill passed recently by the Massachusetts Legislature requiring all new motor vehicles to be equipped with shatterproof plate glass windshields after Jan. 1, 1934, it is reported. This bill supplements the present State law requiring safety glass in the wind- shields of all buses, taxicabs and vehicles for hire.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 30. -- Governor Roosevelt returned to his "other" State tonight and was enthusiastically greeted by his supporters in this part of the South. The Governor and Mrs. Roosevelt drove at once to their new cottage with their daughter-in-law, Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt, who accompanied them on the trip South.

WHEN the season was nearly finished last year the drama in Greenwich Village suddenly came to life with a play at the Provincetown based on the Mooney cause celebre. Something of the same sort has happened again this year.

Swimmers of George Washington High School clinched for the fifth successive year the ManhattanBronx senior high school team championship of the Public School Athletic League by defeating De Witt Clinton, 38 to 24, at the tenth series of dual meets for the title in the victors 75-foot pool yesterday.

THE Beethoven prize of 10,000 marks ($2,380), established by the Prussian Government in 1927 as an annual recognition by the State of the work of either an unusually talented young composer or an older one of generally acknowledged merit, has been awarded to Professor Max von Schillings this year.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The activities of large stock market operators over a perod of years will be compiled in an intensive investigation "on the ground" in New York City, according to plans completed today by William A. Gray, counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 30 (AP). -- Power lines serving Santiago and Valparaiso were cut tonight, throwing the two cities into darkness for half an hour on the eve of threatened May Day demonstrations here.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30. -- Burning Blaze, one of the favorites for the Kentucky Derby, was eliminated as a starter in the classic by an accident sustained in beating six other Derby eligibles today.

Mouette, champion English 12-meter yacht purchased and brought to this country for racing by Horace Havemeyer, is under sail on Long Island Sound, being put through her tuningup paces. The tall, graceful sloop attracts much attention with her lofty rig.

More than $2,500,000 was paid into the City Collector's office yesterday as part of the first half of this year's real estate taxes, which become due and payable today. Taxes may be paid, however, up to May 31 without penalty.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Jack Quinn, star relief hurler, wild-pitched away a ball game for the Robins today in the thirteenth inning after the Phillies and Brooklyn had battled for three and a half hours before 10,000 fans. The score was 8 to 7.

DROUGHT and famine have blighted the desert of Arabia. Starving Bedouins, once reckoned among the earth's fiercest fighting men, are straggling into the Jordan valley to demand the Oriental equivalent of a nickel for a cup of coffee.

SEATTLE, April 28 -- Voters of Washington are proceeding blithely to the task of repealing its bone-dry law which long has served as a model for other States in fashioning repressive prohibition measures. Years before the Eighteenth Amendment was adopted, the Washington law was regarded by the Anti-Saloon League as the ideal statutory enactment.

THE recent campaign waged by an expeditionary force of French gendarmes against brigands in Corsica, together with other developments in the news, has served to call attention to the state of outlaw gangs in widely separated regions.

Cardinal Hayes will dedicate the new prisoners' chapel on Harts Is- land at ceremonies to be held there at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Among those who will take part are Commissioner of Correction Richard C. Patterson Jr. and the Rev. Deme- trius B. Zema, Catholic chaplain of Harts Island prison.

Nearly 200 boxers from twentyeight Amateur Athletic Union district associations in the United States and Hawaii are scheduled to compete for titles in the A.A.U.'s national championship boxing tournament to be held in Madison Square Garden Wednesday, Thursday and Friday nights.

Besides the unemployed who have obtained "made jobs" from funds raised by Block-Aid, 965 previously unemployed persons have been put to work in connection with the Block Aid organization, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization.

HONOLULU, April 30. -- The verdict in the Fortescue-Massie trial has aroused great bitterness here. Many business men express themselves heatedly, and the women whose sympathy all along has been with Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, Mrs. Granville Fortescue and the two navy enlisted men, E.J. Lord and A.O. Jones, fairly seethe with indignation.
NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- The only comment of Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church on the statement of Chancellor Walker relieving the Vice Chancellor of chancery duties was:

PARIS. FROM the beginning of his career Jules Remains has upheld a doctrine which he calls "unanimisme." This phrase is an attempt to describe a literary method which permits him to escape from the poem or the novel that is centred around an individual.

Plans for small houses and three large projects filed in Queens last month swelled the construction total for that borough, figures announced yesterday show. Plans for 390 new buildings were submitted. These represent a total valuation of $1,454,293, as against 1,899 plans costing $10,615,232 put in by architects during April, 1931.

Although it held intact its two principal investments, those of 499,697 shares of common stock of the Allied Chemical Dye Corporation and 19,517 common shares of the International Corporation, the Solvay American Investment Corporation made extensive sales of bonds from its portfolio in the fiscal year ended on March 31.

WHAT has happened in the scientific realm of radio? True, the jazz bands are playing "Blow Your Blues Away" and every hour of the radio day is vibrant with melody or words. But something seems askew backstage.

ALTHOUGH Upton Sinclair's "book of reminiscences" can hardly be called autobiography in any full-blooded sense, the author having confessedly taken a "casual and lighthearted" tone, "American Outpost" is a necessary document to all who would understand Mr. Sinclair.

IN point of time this is the first of the Ellery Queen stories, although it is the fourth to be published. It tells how young Bllery Queen, not long out of college, undertakes his first major crime investigation, acting as the unofficial assistant of his father.

The eighteenth national convention of the Socialist Labor party opened yesterday at the Cornish Arms Hotel, in West Twenty-third Street, and with a celerity rarely, if ever, observed in a political gathering elected a chairman, heard an address by the national secretary and accredited thirty-three delegates from twenty-six States in less than an hour.

IN aid of the Flower Hospital, a unique entertainment has been arranged by members of the auxiliary of that institution for the night of May 12 on board the Majestic at Pier 59 at the foot of West Eighteenth Street. After dinner, which will be served in the main dining salon of the steamship, there will be a musical program by Pasquale Amato, former baritone of the Metropolitan Opera, and Mme. Gina Pinero.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., April 30. -- Headed by Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, tenth in the national ranking, and Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers, a field of twenty-seven players started in the Westchester County tennis championships today on the clay courts of Briarcliff Lodge.

TODAY. 12:00 M. -- WABC -- Hungary offers a half-hour musical program for listeners in the United States and Canada in exchange for the "Hello, Europe," presentations sent overseas. Erno Dohnanyi, known in this country as well as abroad as a composer and pianist, conducts a symphony orchestra in Budapest, playing the works of Berlioz and Liszt.

The Fossils, that organization of publishers, editors and business men who fifty and sixty years ago were amateur editors and printers, held their annual reunion dinner last night at the Hotel Astor and named, but failed to install a new president.

Large shipments to France and Holland marked the movements of gold through the port of New York in April. France obtained $24,525,200 after having received $37,532,000 in March, while shipments to Holland totaled $22,087,500, against only $14,965,000 in the first three months of the year.

BERLIN. THE League of Nations is one of the most disputed Institutions of our time. Its fundamental idea, and the results brought forth by this huge organization, are viewed favorably or unfavorably, opinions varying with the standpoints, of its constituent parties.
MEMBERS of Congress are frequently asked, "What steps are necessary to accomplish either the repeal or a modification of the Eighteenth Amendment?"
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Some of the busiest public men are among the best customers of capital book stores, but the literary taste of politicians is as unpredictable as a cyclone.

BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings scored three runs in the ninth to take the third game of the series from Baltimore today, 11 to 8. Ten two-base hits featured the afternoon. Home runs were hit by Packard, Arlett, Puccinelli and Windle.

THIS little novel from the pen or Pearl S. Buck can scarcely be regarded as a successor to "The Good Earth," nor does it tempt comparison with that beautifully written and strangely moving chronicle of the Chinese peasant.

LONDON, April 30. -- Winston Churchill, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, addressed the Royal Academy at a pre-opening banquet tonight on another academy -- the "National Academy," or government. After proposing a toast to that "academy" Mr. Churchill said:

DETROIT, April 30. -- The so-called ordinance to reduce the pay of city employes 50 per cent during May and June was passed by the Common Council today by a vote of 6 to 3. It was signed immediately by Mayor Murphy and became effective at once.

IN any efforts we make to extend the trade of the British Empire, we are not going to try to do so on a basis which would make us exclusive, that is to say, which shut us off from the rest of the world.

Most of Poly Prep's baseball players, who, as a team, have turned in an impressive record to date this season, are versatile athletes, having been members of other sports squads at the Brooklyn school earlier in the current school year.

MERLIN H. AYLESWORTH, president of the National Broadcasting Company and chief executive of RKO, is the prophet who foresees the day when all amusement is likely to centre around radio. He visions a vast amusement enterprise the nucleus of which will be television.

There can be no quarreling with ALBERT EDWARD WIGGAM'S contention that the national fiber suffers if our educated classes refuse to raise families of three or four children. It is a loss for the nation if those who are best situated, by education and economic advantage, to give their children a start toward successful manhood, should reject the opportunity.

After three hours of speedy and strenuous checker play in the open air yesterday afternoon, eighteen boys went home with prizes, including baseball gloves, bats and tennis racquets, while 107 others left empty-handed. It was the occasion of the first city-wide checker tournament of the various boys' clubs, held in the playground of the Gramercy Boys' Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street, in the heart of the "gas house" district.

"Dagmar." a new opera by Kurt Striegler, Kapellmeister of the Dresden National Opera, was given its first hearing recently in Dresden with Max Lorenz, just back from his engagement with the Metropolitan, in the leading role. The text is by Robert Bosshart, after a novel by Theodor Storm set in chivalric times and dealing with the troubles of a knight, a demonic countess and the gentle Dagmar.

THIS volume of eighty poems by Edwin Markham is the fifth volume of verse by the author of "The Man With the Hoe." There is no very long piece in the present book, there are perhaps a score of quatrains, and perhaps a score and a half of sonnets.

THE small Kentucky town of Pineville, county seat of troubled Bell County, has challenged outsiders in general, and New York City in particular, against interference in its affairs. For months Pineville has made itself a walled town.

CHICAGO, April 29. A RENAISSANCE of playgoing has accompanied the engagements of Walter Hampden in "Cyrano de Bergerac" and Katharine Cornell in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street." The way the populace has been running around in excited circles trying to buy tickets to these attractions suggests that the happy days may have come again, for a brief visit at any rate.

These are expectant days for the trout fisherman in New York State. He is anxiously waiting for the time to roll by so that he can get away for a few days to his favorite stream and take advantage of the usually good fishing in the Catskill region during the middle of May, then later in the Adirondacks.
