PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- Governor Gifford Pinchot's name was not on the ballot at Tuesday's primary election, yet his defeat was to the Republicans the most striking outcome of the voting.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30. -- Timely hitting behind the steady pitching of Stankus enabled the William and Mary nine to defeat Navy, 7 to 3, today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 30. -- There is no longer any doubt that the Navy has a good crew this year. Late today, rowing into a strong head wind through rough water on the Severn, the Navy varsity capped a three-race regatta with Columbia by a victory by one and one-quarter lengths.

CLINTON, N.Y., April 30. -- Hallock C.Campbell of 359 Stuyvesant Avenue, Brooklyn, a senior at Hamilton College, is the winner this year of the Root Fellowship in Science, established in 1904 by Elihu Root, '64.

THE eighth annual Westchester County Music Festival, to take place May 20 and 21 at the County Centre, White Plains, will this year be colored by the worldwide observance of the 200th anniversary of Haydn's birth, and by the George Washington Bicentenary celebration.

ONE of the outstanding events of the Spring season takes place tomorrow night when the fourth annual entertainment in the interests of Toc H will be given aboard the liner Berengaria at its West Fourteenth Street pier.

WE are confronted with a most extraordinary and baffling paradox. We know that, judged by any economic standards, past or present, the United States is a remarkably rich country, richer than anything ever dreamed of by any nation in the world.

LONDON. DOES Rudyard Kipling retain his hold upon the British reading public? Our newspaper editors evidently think be does. It is significant that "Limits and Renewals," published on a Thursday, was reviewed at length in all our leading journals the same morning.

MY mother does not remember her first meeting with Mr. Dodgson. She was 4 years old when my grandfather became dean of Christ Church and the family moved to Oxford. Mr. Dodgson was then a lecturer in mathematics at Christ Church -- a fine figure who carried himself as stiffly, upright as if he had swallowed a poker -- and at Oxford he remained until after my mother married and moved away.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- A $250,000 Capone distillery, equipped with trapdoors, blind entrances and a sumptuously furnished lookout room, was seized today by prohibition agents, who declared it was the largest raided in the United States since prohibition.

A suggestion that the government give consideration to the English method of administering income taxes, particularly on corporations, was offered here yesterday by A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers.

A NEW policy of enforcement, recently announced, has intensified the war along the New York prohibition front. Wholesale padlock actions, instead of criminal prosecutions, are now being instigated by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, to relieve the burdened judiciary and to close more speakeasies and liquor stores.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- An investigation of the Massie trial in Honolulu should be undertaken by President Hoover, and if he finds the facts identical with those reported in the press he should pardon Lieutenant Massie, Mrs. Fortescue and the two sailors, Albert O. Jones and E.J. Lord, within a week, Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois said today.

Spurred by an unprecedented order of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the St. Louis-San Francisco Rail-way management began yesterday to devise a plan for relieving the company of part of the interest burden imposed by its $292,000,000 of outstanding bonds.

PARIS, April 29. -- The American-born Princesse Edmond de Polignac, who divides her time chiefly between her Paris residence on the Avenue Henri Martin and her Venetian residence, Montecuccoli Palace, is well known for her many benefactions. A few years ago, with former President Poincare as one of her chief advisers, she founded the "Fondation Singer-Polignac," to provide rest homes and better living conditions for the workers of Paris.

FROM the title and the picture on the jacket the reader might think that this book was a life of Mr. Gandhi. In reality it is more like a death of the British Empire. Mr. Gandhi, to be sure, is both intimately and refreshingly treated, being made to appear neither a mountebank nor a god.

Recognizing the need for additional safety zones for children and that more adequate protection for them would ease the strain on parents facing economic difficulties, the committee to open recreation centres of the Community Councils will begin a campaign soon to provide more playgrounds through public subscriptions.

The story of Henry C. Murphy, stockbroker, of 51 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, that he was drugged, taken to a speakeasy in a West Seventy-second Street apartment, robbed and then held captive until his firm sent him a $2,000 check, which was endorsed by him and then cashed by his captors, resulted yesterday in the arrest of three men and two women in a raid on the resort by prohibition agents.
EXETER, N.H., April 30. -- St. John's won from Exeter, 7 to 6, today, winning the game with two runs in the first half of the ninth after Exeter had taken a 6-to-5 lead in the eighth.

MADRID, April 30. -- Police reinforcements were put into action over all Spain today and arrested hundreds of Communists and syndicalist leaders. The government hopes tonight it has smashed plans for a national revolutionary general strike officially announced from Communist headquarters in Barcelona.

A LONDON police sergeant with a record of twenty-five years' service is sweating with agony in the witness box at the Old Bailey Court House in London Charged by his superior officers with complicity in the bribing of a fellow-officer, he is desperately denying his part in the affair.

New rules have been adopted for the 151-cubic-inch class of racing motor boats. They were announced yesterday by Charles F. Chapman, secretary of the Racing Commission of the American Power Boat Association. Superchargers are eliminated and a price limit is set on the cost of the motors.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- By Request won the biggest money event of the final day of the twelfth annual Newark Horse Show, the $500 championship jumping stake, the title and $250 going to the chestnut gelding owned and jumped by Fred Wettach Jr. of the Trillora Farm of Shrewsbury, N.J. A capacity crowd attended the closing session tonight of a most successful exhibition.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 30 (AP). -- Blly Howell of Richmond gained a second leg on the Old Dominion golf trophy and equaled the competitive record for the sporty Cascades course today.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 30. -- Stockholders of the Gray Telephone Pay Station Company received today a request from the directors for proxies "to vote your shares at any and all meetings which may occur until the next annual meeting of stockholders on Feb. 7, 1933."

ORANGE, N.J., April 30. -- The marriage of Miss Helen Huitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Huitt of East Orange, to Wharley L. Parrott of East Orange, son of Mrs. Wharley L. Parrott of Bishopville, S.C., took place tonight at the First Baptist Church, East Orange.

COUNTLESS years ago on what is now the west shore of the Hudson, nature's forces left behind a stone portrait of Washington almost as perfect as any likeness subsequently painted from life. Long before any one heard of the Father of Our Country it was guarding a 500-foot gorge in the cliffs that overhang the Hudson at Alpine, N.J.

The United Light and Power Company, in completing plans to meet in full the maturity of $11,000,000 bonds due on June 1, which is the only important maturity of the system in more than five years, has also consummated plans for a simplification of corporate structure which will result in early elimination of at least one intermediary holding company.

CLARENCE D. CHAMBERLIN, the transatlantic flier and former world's distance record holder, has organized and is operating a unique flying school and ground school in which his faculty is largely made up of transatlantic fliers.

AFTER reading Count von Polzer-Hoditz's book it is difficult not to feel a great affection for the late Emperor Karl. This Hapsburg was a man and did not pose as a hero and a demi-god. Although his story bears comparison with any past royal tragedy the author has judiciously refrained from exploiting the more sensational side of his material.

MR. BROMFIELD'S hero for this is his first book in which a male character takes a central position is one Pierre Radier the illegitimate son of a circus performer, the leopard trainer, Mme. Azais and a Teutonic nobleman.

Beginning with the new Fall term, students attending evening courses in Cooper Union's Engineering School will be able to obtain regular college degrees. Under an arrangement just completed with the State Board of Education at Albany, a six-year evening course will be accepted as the equivalent of the regular four-year day course.

Door delivery of freight is a problem facing the railroads which is nowhere else so important as it is in New York City, it was said yester- day by J.W. Roberts, assistant vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad and chairman of the sub committee of the railroad presidents' committee which devised a plan for putting this service into force here.

WASHINGTON. IN the cities and towns of Massa- chusetts, in Philadelphia and the hard-coal regions of Pennsylvania, the small but determined and distinguished band of Democrats who oppose the nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt as the party's candidate for President have at last thrown up a barricade against his ambition.

HONOLULU, April 30. -- An outwardly quiet but tense city looked on today while opposing sides prepared for further battle over the Fortescue-Massie manslaughter case. Radio patrol cars equipped with machine guns and manned by police rolled through the city.

Lord ERNLE, more familiar once as Mr. ROWLAND PROTHERO, was editor of The Quarterly Review in the '90s. In the April number he writes of his "Early Victorian Childhood." He was born on the then unspoiled Isle of Wight in 1851. He is more ancient than croquet, which seems the typical Victorian recreation.

As a matter of "good business," holders of farm mortgages at this time should make adjustments with financially embarrassed farmers so that the man and the land will not be parted, Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, said yesterday in a radio address from WJZ, sponsored by the Corn Belt Farm Dailies.

MANILA, March 26. -- The arrival of Senator Hawes's book, "Philippine Uncertainty," has caused scarcely a ripple in Manila in spite of his diatribe against Manila Americans. Much of this was expected from the Senator's conduct and comments while he was here.

Sale of a nine-story apartment house in the lower Fifth Avenue district and a five-story dwelling on upper Park Avenue, both transactions being announced yesterday, were the important features last week. With those exceptions, the realty situation was moderately quiet.

BOSTON, April 30. -- The supposedly powerful, pennant contending Giants and the Braves, who in the pre-season forecasts were not expected to do much more than round out the field of eight in the National League race, were still moving in opposite directions to what had been anticipated when the Boston entry, for the second successive afternoon, flattened the McGrawmen today.

THE greatest blow that aviation has received in many years is contained in the naval approtion bill now before Congress." So reads an announcement from the Navy Department discussing both the cuts proposed in funds to purchase necessary equipment next year and the provision placing restrictions on flying pay.

Revival of booms for Owen D. Young and Newton D. Baker as "dark horse" candidates for the Democratic nomination for President has followed the decisive victory of former Governor Alfred E. Smith over Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in Massachusetts, and his good showing in Pennsylvania, it was learned yesterday.
NO material seems too humble to enter into competition as a candidate for marking the beltline. String, clothes line, cord and raffia all lend themselves with surprising effectiveness.

To the Editor of The York Times: Mayor Hidejiro Nagata of Tokyo has just sent me a letter in which he states with singular clarity and deft niteness what I believe to be the position of the great body of Japanese opinion with respect to both Shanghai and Manchuria.

EMPORIA, Kan., April 28. -- The Massachusetts and Pennsylvania primaries seem to indicate that Al Smith and his followers have not stopped Governor Roosevelt, but have definitely winged him. Overnight, the Roosevelt band wagon has been transformed into a vehicle which may be the Democratic water wagon, or only one of those humble fertilizer-spreaders found in the open spaces of the rural West.

Scoring four runs in the eighth inning on as many hits, the Massachusetts State College baseball team defeated City College, 5 to 2, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The game, played for the benefit of the American Olympic Fund, was witnessed by 1,000 spectators.

Rowing, with the coming week-end and the Blackwell Cup races at Philadelphia among Yale, Columbia and Pennsylvania, enters the full swing of its mid-season, with the new feature of the observation train -- Philadelphia's first -- to add interest and background to the race.

A complete survey of the history of American agriculture, a field in which almost no research has been done up to the present, will be made by a group of prominent educators and economists. Dr. Harry J. Carman, Professor of History at Columbia University, announced yesterday.

THE point has been reached in the design of automobiles where speed is no longer the most important item in the purchase of an automobile. The most inexpensive car sold is capable of going 70 to 80 miles per hour, or faster than most of our highways can stand with safety or comfort.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 30. -- Army overwhelmed Haverford in baseball today, 15 to 3. The cadets drove Tripp from the mound in the opening inning. Landry of Army was effective throughout, the Haverford runs resulting from misplays.

DETROIT. MOTOR car prices constitute a subject that refuses to remain composed. At present all automobile executives are said to be giving consideration to the advisability of increases and an affirmative decision within the next thirty days would not be surprising.

In an article entitled "European Sentiment and American Policies," Fernand J.J. Merckx, editor of Le Messager de New York, outlines in today's issue of that publication what he regards as the general state of resentment felt by certain European nations over America's attitude toward Germany.

PANAMA, R.P., April 26. -- Misinformation published in some American newspapers after correspondents, inadequately informed, have paid hasty visits to Latin-American countries, is listed by Professor Stephen P. Duggan as one of the chief obstacles to better understanding between the Americas.

A Spring Folk Festival with more than 400 participants will be given in the Chanin Theatre on May 15, under the auspices of the Folk Fes- tival Council, of which Dr. John H. Finley is chairman, according to an announcement yesterday. Performances will be given in the afternoon and evening by thirty organizations representing the twenty-four ethnic groups belonging to the council.

Until May 7, when the gallery doors are shut for the Summer season, art enthusiasts with a penchant for discovering "unknowns" can indulge this pleasant hobby at the Times Gallery, 773 Madison Avenue, conducted by Richard Cameron Beer. This final show, like those that have preceded it, runs the gamut from mild academism to extreme modernism and, like its predecessors, contains some every fine work interspersed with mediocre.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 1. -- Foreign Minister Yoshizawa, Minister of War Araki and Minister of the Navy Osumi reported to the Emperor yesterday afternoon the government's decision to proceed with the armistice negotiations at Shanghai as previously arranged and to treat as a separate affair the Shanghai bombing incident in which one Japanese official was killed and six injured.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 30. -- Holy Cross suffered its first defeat of the baseball season today before 3,000 persons when it fell before a smart New York University nine by a score of 2 to 0.

The old adage that "dead men tell no tales" was refuted last night when Dr. E.E. Free, science lecturer at New York University, broadcast the sound of radioactivity in the bone of a recent victim of radium poisoning, and allowed the bone "to tell its own story of its murder."

WHILE Wall Street is walling and Main Street is moaning, a Harvard professor in Newton Centre, Mass., is delving into financial reports and trying to fathom the complexity of Juggled figures. Once a week, at least, he leaves the quiet of his study, and with brief case tilled with the results of his investigations dashes off to some city to meet with representatives of labor or capital.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 30. -- T. Bedell Jr. annexed the high-scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today, breaking 48 out of a possible 50 targets. The handicap trophy went to F. Chapman, who finished with a full card.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 30. -- Rogers Caldwell, former president of Caldwell Co., investment banking house which crashed in November, 1930, and who was convicted in Davidson County criminal court and sentenced to serve one to three years on charges of fraudulent breach of trust, will receive a new trial under an opinion by the Tennessee Supreme Court, which reversed the verdict of the lower court and remanded the case today.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30. -- John D. Rockefeller arrived at his estate here late this afternoon after spending the Winter at the Case- ments, his home in Ormond, Fla. He left the train with members of his household at Princeton Junction, N. J., having arrived there shortly after 4 P.M., and immediately motored to his estate at Lakewood.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month continued on a moderate scale. Sales for April, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 31,402,988 shares, compared with 33,060,518 shares in March, and 54,333,243 shares in April, 1931.
ALBANY, April 30 (AP). -- Thirteen men and one woman will walk out of State prisons Monday, freed under commutation orders by Governor Roosevelt. Their crimes ranged from murder to petit larceny.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- A resounding wallop by Moe Berg to deep left field for a two-bagger drove Reynolds home in the eighth with the winning run today to give the Washington Senators their sixth consecutive victory over the Philadelphia Athletics, ending a pitching duel between Lefty Grove and Alvin Crowder, the score being 2 to 1.
GENEVA, April 30. -- With impressive coolness the special assembly of the League of Nations here this morning received another solemn promise from Japan.

AT the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra concert on Tuesday evening, in the Metropolitan Opera House, Harold Bauer, Myra Hess and Ernest Schelling will appear as soloists in a Bach triple concerto. This will be the final concert in the series of five which the orchestra of 200 men, who otherwise are without work, have been giving on consecutive Tuesday evenings.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30. -- The Harvard freshman baseball team won its fourth game in five starts by defeating the Brown freshmen 7 to 2 today. Bill Lincoln limited the visitors to three scattered hits.

READING, Pa., April 30 (AP). -- A four-run rally in the twelfth inning gave the Toronto Leafs a third straight victory over the Reading Keys today, 7 to 3, and marked the latter's seventh successive defeat. Michaels's home run started the winning rally.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's filly Top Flight. Kentucky Derby future book favorite for months, was soundly beaten at Jamaica yesterday for the first time in her career when she finished fourth in the Wood Memorial before a stunned throng of 10,000 persons which included many well known in business, society and politics.
HAVANA, April 23. -- Cuba's present obligations total $193,582,680, according to the official bulletin of the Department of Treasury, which presents a complete list of the nation's debts.
BROADCASTERS plan to defy Summer and the hot sun this year. Tossing radio programs across the Atlantic heretofore has been a Winter pastime. But not so this year.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The House today almost completed the wrecking of the Economy Committee's program by voting, 153 to 135, to reject the plan to consolidate the War and Navy Departments into a Department of National Defense.

JOLIET, Ill., April 30. -- Hopeful of private negotiations for the return of the son kidnapped by gangsters on Thursday night, Max Miller, malt seller and real estate dealer here, withheld details of the kidnapping from the police today.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 28. -- Because the threatened depletion of this State's vast forest acreage strikes at a major resource of tremendous commercial importance, proceedings at the second Florida Commercial Forestry Congress, held recently at Ocala, were timely steps worthy of immediate State-wide emulation.

TOKYO. THE Japanese people are building high hopes upon the new economic era which they believe is opening before them, now that Manchuria has been brought within the Japanese orbit. The atmosphere registered in the press for the past few months has continually reminded this writer of the title of one of John Oliver Hobbes's novels -- "The Dream and the Business."

Much interest was aroused in the United States by the radio farewell message that Jules Jusserand, former French Ambassador to Washington, delivered to this country from his home in Paris April 10 in opening an international radio forum organized by Ira Nelson Morris of Chicago to bring Europe closer to America through transatlantic broadcasting.

More than fifty thousand school children and Boy Scouts will participate in the fifth annual celebration of Parents' Day at Central Park next Sunday, when Mayor Waflser and other officials will speak, it was announced yesterday by Uncle Robert.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's filly Top Flight. Kentucky Derby future book favorite for months, was soundly beaten at Jamaica yesterday for the first time in her career when she finished fourth in the Wood Memorial before a stunned throng of 10,000 persons which included many well known in business, society and politics.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 30. -- Labor unions throughout Bolivia have called for a stoppage of work tomorrow and the workers are preparing for celebrations everywhere of International Labor Day. Street cars, taxicabs and all other public vehicles will not operate.

BERLIN, April 30 (AP). -- Chancellor Heinrich Bruening returned to Berlin from the Geneva disarmament conference today and immediately attacked the problem of what to do about Adolf Hitler's opposition National Socialists, who, by virtue of the April 24 elections, are within striking distance of the mastery of Prussia.

CARBON monoxide, the gas which causes more deaths than the total of all other gases, is not to be allowed to play a lethal role in connection with aircraft such as it has in connection with automobiles; that is, not if the United States Navy can prevent it.

BERLIN, April 30 (AP). -- Chancellor Heinrich Bruening returned to Berlin from the Geneva disarmament conference today and immediately attacked the problem of what to do about Adolf Hitler's opposition National Socialists, who, by virtue of the April 24 elections, are within striking distance of the mastery of Prussia.

CARBON monoxide, the gas which causes more deaths than the total of all other gases, is not to be allowed to play a lethal role in connection with aircraft such as it has in connection with automobiles; that is, not if the United States Navy can prevent it.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Two Army Reserve Corps officers were killed this afternoon when their airplane crashed into the second story of a house at 124 East Seventy-fifth Street, burst into flames and set the dwelling afire.
BROADCASTERS plan to defy Summer and the hot sun this year. Tossing radio programs across the Atlantic heretofore has been a Winter pastime. But not so this year.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The House today almost completed the wrecking of the Economy Committee's program by voting, 153 to 135, to reject the plan to consolidate the War and Navy Departments into a Department of National Defense.

JOLIET, Ill., April 30. -- Hopeful of private negotiations for the return of the son kidnapped by gangsters on Thursday night, Max Miller, malt seller and real estate dealer here, withheld details of the kidnapping from the police today.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 28. -- Because the threatened depletion of this State's vast forest acreage strikes at a major resource of tremendous commercial importance, proceedings at the second Florida Commercial Forestry Congress, held recently at Ocala, were timely steps worthy of immediate State-wide emulation.

TOKYO. THE Japanese people are building high hopes upon the new economic era which they believe is opening before them, now that Manchuria has been brought within the Japanese orbit. The atmosphere registered in the press for the past few months has continually reminded this writer of the title of one of John Oliver Hobbes's novels -- "The Dream and the Business."

Much interest was aroused in the United States by the radio farewell message that Jules Jusserand, former French Ambassador to Washington, delivered to this country from his home in Paris April 10 in opening an international radio forum organized by Ira Nelson Morris of Chicago to bring Europe closer to America through transatlantic broadcasting.

SPRING again brings to the fore the series of garden visits in Long Island and Westchester, which for several years have been fixed events of the countryside, having proved a novel means of furthering the work of philanthropies.
WHAT a season for colors and fabrics! Now it is the sportswoman's turn to indulge her whims, and what a time she is going to have picking out her open-air trousseau.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Facing in unprecedented shortage of funds, the American Olympic Committee, in in all-day session at the Perm A.C., decided today to classify the teams that shall represent this country at Los Angeles next Summer.
The annual check-up on comparative times and distances in the Penn and Drake relays reveals a slight edge for the Eastern classic.
Developments of May Day. Soviet Russia kept International Labor Day with an imposing parade of the Red Army In Moscow, followed by a march of about 1,000,000 civilians.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- The slugging Cleveland Indians continued to burn up the American League base paths today by walloping three Chicago pitchers for thirteen hits to gain an 11-to-1 victory, their eighth in a row.

PARIS, Monday, May 2 -- Premier Andre Tardieu's majority has been shaken if not defeated in the first ballot of the French national elections held yesterday. All over the country the Left, and more especially the moderate Left, has won votes, if not seats, and next Sunday when the second ballot is taken this advantage seems certain to be confirmed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 1 -- Preaching the General Conference sermon here today, Bishop William McDowell of Washington, D.C., senior prelate of the Methodist Episcopal Church, advocated a return to the old ideals of religion and emphasis on the doctrine of Methodism.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- The flying Governors, James Rolph Jr. of California and Fred B. Balzar of Nevada, were like two boys after a particularly exciting lark as they took off for Sacramento today after a transcontinental flight.

The causes of suicide and some maxims for making life worth living were the main themes of the sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. Lon Ray Call at Community Church, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. The advice to those in distress was as follows:

A comprehensive plan for the development of Jacob Riis Park on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, prepared by the Regional Plan Association "on a scale consistent with the park's city-wide and region-wide importance," was made public yesterday by George McAneny, president of the association.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- With, only one event remaining, the Los Angeles Athletic Club today assured itself of the women's national indoor A.A. U. swimming championship by sweeping three positions of the ten-foot springboard diving event.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 1 (AP) -- Professional music critics were informed, in effect, by contemporary composers of chamber music today that the world would be a better place without them.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Net earnings of the Pure Oil Company for its fiscal year ended on March 31, including its proportion of undistributed earnings of affiliated companies amounted to $2,403.795, which was in excess of preferred dividends and surplus adjustments.

CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -- After spotting Pittsburgh a lead of five runs in the first five innings, the Cincinnati Reds batted their way into the lead, drove two Pirate pitchers from the mound and won, 7 to 5, today.

Because of the expiration of the agreement between the Building Trades Employers Association and unions representing thirty-two trade groups in the industry, involving about 30,000 of the 115,000 building trades employes now at work, the members of those unions will not work today, John Halkett, president of the Building Trades Council, said last night.

Thirty-two members of the Metropolitan Opera Company joined in censuring Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor, for his unwillingness to accept a cut in salary, the management of the Metropolitan disclosed yesterday, making public a letter signed by leading singers and conductors and addressed to General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza.
Veterans' organizations will play a large part in Mayor Walker's "Beer for Taxation" parade on May 14, the arrangements committee announced yesterday.

Any project bearing the name of JACOB RIIS should be the best thing of its kind. He once said that a false prophet could do less harm than a careless reporter. It was his endeavor always "to gather facts to build upon." Others might not agree with him, he said, about their application, but he did his part as a conscientious reporter to furnish the basic facts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Senate Finance Committee is reported to have voted favorably on adding an import duty on copper to the revenue act, and has been criticized for including a tariff provision in a revenue bill.

In his address before the Bar Association Secretary MILLS called attention, to a defect in the American system of taxation which, is rapidly becoming a matter of challenging importance. It is the conflict between the Federal Government and the States for profitable sources of revenue.

The annual report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for 1931 shows a net income of $15,272,436 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, equal, after preferred dividends, to $4.02 a share on 2,162,607 common shares outstanding at the end of the year.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and acting head of the National Civic Federation, made public yesterday a letter he has sent to members of the Judiciary committees of the Senate and House of Representatives containing a report of a survey made by the federation of outrages perpetrated throughout the country during the last four months.

A deficit in the mission funds of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church is attributed by Bishop Louis Childs Sanford, of San Joaquin, California, "not to the depression but to the fact that people are forgetting their religious obligations and responsibilities."

The largest fields in the history of the event will struggle for the lightheavyweight and heavyweight titles in the Amateur Athletic Union's national championship boxing tournament to be held in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Unemployment insurance received by a worker is not a dole any more than is life insurance received by a widow on her husband's death, Senator Wagner declared tonight in setting forth his "individual views" as a member of the Senate select committee directed to investigate unemployment insurance.

Federal prohibition agents, for whom Sunday raiding forays admittedly are unusual assignments, took fifteen speakeasies and cordial shops by surprise late yesterday afternoon and early last night, arrested their operators and seized small quantities of alleged liquor.

Unmindful of a rain that persisted during the first fifteen miles of the race, Charles Eschenback of the New York A.C. stamped himself as a possible Olympic competitor yesterday by capturing the Metropolitan A.A.U. twenty-mile walking championship at Silver Lake Park, Staten Island.

"The notion that the New York City charter needs drastic reorganization is much exaggerated," Joseph D. McGoldrick of Columbia Universtiy declared in a discussion of the city manager plan for New York City. Mr. McGoldrick's views, which are against the city manager plan, and an answer by Dr. William J. Schieffelin, are published in the May issue of The National Municipal Review.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Plans of leaders to adjourn Congress on June 11 seem likely to go awry because of the pressure of legislation and the demoralization in the House. Today there is a strong probability that a recess will be taken for the national conventions and the session continued into the Summer.

BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP) -- The Orioles divided the spoils with the Rochester Red Wings in a double-header today, winning the opener, 10 to 3, and dropping the nightcap, 7 to 3. This gave the Flock three victories out of the five-game series.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Notable changes, consisting partly of omissions, have been made in the report of the special commission on marriage, divorce and remarriage of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, adopted by the General Assembly last year, in formulating the revision of the "solemnization of marriage" section in the Directory of Worship to be proposed to the General Assembly, meeting in Denver late this month.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Scarcely any one knew it was Easter Sunday today [the Russian Orthodox Easter], as nearly every one was marching in one of the biggest military and civil parades Moscow had ever seen. Those who were not marching were looking on.

A heavy green van with "Department of Correction" in dull gold letters on its side rumbled up to the handsome new yellow-brick building at Sixth Avenue and Ninth Street at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

BERLIN, April 29 -- That the Reichsbank considers its reserve position none too secure is shown by the fact that the ratio of exchange to importers has again been reduced. The new ration is only 25 per cent of the amount actually required by importers in October, 1930.

Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars of the Bronx Zoo, who seldom goes about without a snake for company, became an ophthalmologist yesterday afternoon. With the assistance of a box made of wire netting, a press made of felt and a head keeper with an iron nerve, he operated on the eye of the Bronx's most famous cobra.

PARIS, May 1 (AP) -- From the bands on smart sailor bats to the striking black and white frocks worn with coats having linings to match, the Paris Summer mode is striped from head to heel. Roman-stripped taffeta scarfs and vestees worn with dark suits, multicolored striped wool jackets to accent wool frocks and awning-striped linen blouses accompanying suspender skirts are further accents to the vogue.

Speaking at the dedication yesterday afternoon of the new parochial school of St. Veronica's parish, 272 West Tenth Street, Cardinal Hayes defended the residents of Greenwich Village as God-fearing men and women. He observed facetiously that he did not fear any harm would come to his reputation from his visit to the neighborhood.

The organization of the Anti-Prohibition Battle Fund, Inc., with head-quarters at 103 Park Avenue, which will make an immediate attempt to raise $5,000,000 to fight for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURG, May 1 -- After three weeks of steel production at a virtually uniform rate, about 21 per cent of plant capacity, steel producers are looking for an upward turn within the next fortnight. They add, however, that if there is no increase there will be a decrease.

MARBLEHBAD, Mass., May 1 -- Sailing handily through, fog banks and rain squalls of a "smoky sou'wester." Miss Lorna Whittelsey, with, her two New York clubmates, Bill Swan and Ted Clark, led an invading fleet of Long Island Sound dinghies to a three-point victory over Boston craft today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- In substantiation of his contention that Judge Albert M. Cristy of the Circuit Court of Hawaii should be impeached, Senator Kenneth McKellar, Tennessee Democrat, cited tonight a letter he received from a member of the Honolulu grand jury which returned second degree murder indictments against Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, Mrs. Granville Fortescue and two navy enlisted men.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Twelve out of thirty-seven Republican and Democratic State conventions which have named Presidential nominating delegates have come out for repeal or resubmission of the prohibition amendment in various ways. Eight of the twelve conventions favoring a change or an opportunity to vote on the question are Democratic with only fourteen conventions held to date.
LONDON, May 1 -- Prime Minister MacDonald, immediately after his arrival in London tonight, announced his intention or returning to Geneva, possibly in about a fortnight.

The exhibition of paintings, graphic art and sculpture by contemporary German artists at the Roerich Museum, which opened on Saturday, contains some excellent examples. Especially rewarding is the work in oil and water-color. Also it is a privilege to be able to make the acquaintance of several modern German artists as yet little known, or known not at all, in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Uncertainty as to the form tax legislation will take and the possibility of enactment of measures calling for virtually un- restricted currency inflation are tend- ing to retard efforts to revive busi- ness, according to bankers who have visited the national capital.

DNIEPROSTROY, Soviet Union, May 1 -- Power began to flow today in what ultimately was to be the world's largest hydroelectric plant -- Dnieprostroy, one of the Soviet's most ambitious projects. It received its first official trial today. [The Boulder Dam plant will be larger than Dnieprostroy.]

Samuel Untermyer, counsel for the independent committee for the $50,000,000 of Kreuger Toll debentures, announced yesterday he would ask the New York Stock Exchange for a list of holders of the securities. He asserted that the Exchange would be asked to refuse to list deposit certificates of the Lee, Higginson Co. committee until his committee had received this information.

CLEVELAND, May 1 -- The Cleveland Shamrocks today brought to this city its first national amateur soccer championship by defeating the powerful Santo Christo eleven of New Bedford, Mass., 2 to 1, in the cup final at Slavia Field. Threatening weather held the crowd to 2,500.

The Mozart Quartet and Boris Voronovsky, Russian baritone, gave a joint concert of chamber works and songs in Chalif Hall yesterday afternoon. The quartet played a Haydn work in D minor, three Idylls by Frank Bridge, two manuscript pieces by Vincent Jones and Bernard Ocko, and short works of Ernest Bloch and Beryl Rubenstein.

Most critics of the Police Department have little respect for law and order themselves and criticize merely to revile the men who prevent them from carrying out their own designs. Commissioner Mulrooney declared yesterday in addressing 4,000 Brooklyn and Queens policemen at the annual communion breakfast of the Police Department Ho!y Name Society of the two boroughs, held at the Brooklyn Elks Club.

While the House of Representatives on Saturday did many erratic things in rejecting measures for economy, it followed a sound instinct in refusing to agree to the consolidation of the army and the navy in a single department. To this proposal it was known that the President strongly objected.

It hardly needed the initials "W. A.W." at the end of the column to identify the writer of the notes on New York in The Emporia Gazette. Besides the opening sentence, which, declares in an unmistakable phrase that "art is on the bum in this busted Babylon," there is a reference to a club which" the White family has been coming to" for many years.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Business interests here are looking for the steel industry to lead in a revival of business. A small increase in activity is reported in the Chicago district owing to automobile interests giving out more orders, mainly for parts.

Such is the nature of things vaudevilllan that Mme. Frances Alda finds her Palace debut surrounded this week on one side by a brash and amusing young newcomer named Wally Vernon and on the other by those returning knights of the burnt cork, the Messrs, Moran and Mack.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 1 -- Mount Holyoke's annual May Day pageant is to be presented here under the auspices of the College Dramatic Club on May 14. The title is "The Pied Piper of Hamelin" and children of the village are wondering whether there will be "real rats" in the cast and what becomes of the children "in the end."

OSSINING, N.Y., May 1 -- Two drill corps of Sing Sing cadets marched across the athletic grounds of the prison here this afternoon in their first public exhibition drill, which was followed by a baseball game. Spectators in the grand stand included a group of writers, editors and publishers who were being entertained at the prison by Warden Lewis E. Lawes.

The War-Against-Depression campaign, begun last February by the American Legion, the American Legion Auxiliary, the American Federation of Labor and the Association of National Advertisers, was officially ended yesterday with an announcement by officers of these organizations that 688,607 jobs had been found for men and women.

In celebrating the Washington Bicentennial, the 30th of April was fittingly marked by special ceremonies. The day in 1789 when WASHINGTON took the oath of office was the natal day of the United States Government under the Constitution.

In the manner of other political figures who have attacked the Hofstadter legislative inquiry, but without naming the committee, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee and manager of Governor Roosevelt's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, condemned yesterday "reprehensible" attacks on public officials.
Four metropolitan major league baseball games were washed out completely yesterday, double-headers at both the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field being called off because of the persistent downpour.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Discovery in the omnibus economy bill of what amounts in a sense to a "joker" section is causing grave concern to high army and naval officials.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Twenty persons, including three women and twelve aliens, were told today by Magistrate Thomas O'Hara that their conduct in yesterday's "May Day" clashes with police put them "on the same level with the majority of the criminals in our penitentiaries," and were held in heavy bail, charged with assault and battery on the police, disorderly conduct, inciting to riot and parading without a license.

LONDON, April 29 -- Along with this week's decline in sterling, much less foreign money is now being offered in London. Recently, indeed, certain withdrawals occurred, owing to the less confident feeling in regard to sterling's price. Investment funds continue to flow strongly in the direction of gilt-edged securities and new offerings of the high-grade class are being eagerly absorbed.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Meat prices are unusually low, with supplies of beef, pork and mutton liberal. Consumption is only fair, making returns to live stock raisers unsatisfactory. There is an abundance of feed in Corn Belt States, with corn at the lowest level in thirty-three years, yet profits of live stock raisers are limited and Representatives in Congress from leading live stock districts are reported to be endeavoring to get relief.

LONDON, May 1 -- The atom has not only been split but an element has been transmuted into another element -- atoms of hydrogen, have been turned into atoms of that rare and commercially valuable gas, helium. At the same the energy of part of an atom has been released in a quantity 60 per cent greater than the amount used to produce this phenomenon, although it occurred only once in each 10,000,000 atoms bombarded.

Life and death, laughter and tears, dreams and crystal-gazing, enzymes, chromosomes and hormones, are a few of the "Riddles of Science" pondered by Sir J. Arthur Thomson, eminent British scientist, in his book of that name, published today by Liveright, Inc.

Consolidation of the Shipping Board services in the Gulf trade by the Lykes Brothers-Ripley Steampship Company will be affected June 1, according to announcement yesterday at the New York offices of the company, 17 Battery Place. The company recently bought the American Gulf Orient, Dixie Mediterranean, Dixie United Kingdom and Southern States lines from the Shipping Board for about $2,500,000 and will combine pier operations and other details without changing the sailings and similar details.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 1 -- An invitation to join a Russian scientific expedition to study isolated groups in that country this Summer has been accepted by Dr. K. Koffka, director of the Smith College research laboratory in experimental and educational psychology.

Miss Betty Gordon, 30 years old, committed suicide by illuminating gas yesterday afternoon in the kitchenette of her two-room, apartment on the eleventh floor of 404 East Fifty-ninth Street. She left a will bequeathing her entire estate to Rex Cole, head of the refrigerator sales concern by which she was employed.

Commenting upon the manslaughter verdict of the jury in the Massie case in Hawaii, the Rev. John Brett Langstaff, rector of St. Edmund's Protestant Episcopal Church, Morris Avenue and East 177th Street, took issue in his sermon yesterday morning with the arguments on which Clarence Darrow, veteran attorney, pleaded unsuccessfully for an acquittal.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- A. B. Crawford, director of the department of personnel study at Yale, and president of the Eastern College Personnel Officers' Association, announced today that the placement and personnel officers of twenty-seven Eastern colleges had determined to exert every effort to curb the practice of door-to-door salesman trading upon their college connections to make sales.

A unique funeral service was held yesterday at the synagogue of Congregation Ahavath Moische, Brooklyn, for the desecrated scroll Or Torah, stolen from the synagogue on April 21. According to Hebraic law, a sacred object such as a scroll must not be destroyed or burned when it has been damaged, but must be buried.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Yankee winning streak of six straight ended today when Walter Johnson's Senators, by a vigorous early attack and sparkling defensive play, registered a 4-to-2 victory in the opening game of the three-day series.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 1 -- The cotton market was nervous and erratic all week, with the general trend of prices slowly downward. All the new crop positions made new lows for the present downward movement and July duplicated the low of several weeks ago.

NEW HAVEN, April 30 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.8, which compares with 61.8 a week ago, 62.4 two weeks ago, 62.5 three weeks ago and 62.9 four weeks ago."The present year's highest average to date was 66.3 in the first week of January; this week's average, also reached a week ago, is the lowest.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Grain traders throughout the world and especially in the United States believe it would he for the best interests of the trade, and principally for the farmers, if the Federal Farm Board would liquidate its holdings as soon as possible, as the impresssion prevails that the longer it stays in business the worse the situation is likely to become and the more money the Farm Board will lose.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 1 (AP) -- The records of the past are cited by Gilbert T. Hodges, president of the Advertising Federation of America, as proof that it pays to advertise even in times of economic distress.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Winter wheat crop prospects, as estimated by a Chicago crop statistician, suggest a yield of around 435,000,000 to 450,000,000 bushels, compared with an average of 500,000,000 bushels on April 1. Reports will be issued tomorrow.

The organization meeting of the American Lacrosse League was held at the Hotel Paramount yesterday with the purpose of laying the foundation for outdoor professional box lacrosse for the coming Summer. Six teams are enrolled in the league, which will commence operation about the first of next month.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 1 -- Virtually untouched by the Presidential pre-convention campaign, this State, approaching a primary Tuesday, finds itself concerned chiefly with efforts of ninety-three candidates to obtain one of the twelve seats allotted to Indiana in the National House of Representatives, and with a Democratic organization fight badly snarled our Gubernatorial issues.

PARIS, Monday, May 2 (AP) -- Returns from 500 of the 615 constituencies in yesterday's election to the Chamber of Deputies gave the political groups of the Left a slight gain, with 283 seats thrown into the run-off election next Sunday, which grew more important in determining the fate of the Tardieu Government.

As the ship was coming up the river, the Duchess -- strictly not Russian Grand -- said, "That's the Smith "Tower, fivescore and two stories "high." "Yes ?" answered Alice, with a slightly contemptuous upward inflection of her voice and nose.

The annual Toe H dinner dance and entertainment will be held tonight on board the liner Berengaria at its West Fourteenth Street pier. Many in society have subscribed to the event, the net proceeds from which will be given to the Boys' Bureau, formed a year ago by the Charity Organization Society and the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

The Museum of Modern Art will open its new home at 11 West Fifty-third Street to invited quests tomorrow and on "Wednesday to the public. With its removal from temporary headquarters at 730 Fifth Avenue to its own five-story building, the "experimental period" of the museum comes to an end, according to A. Conger Goodyear, president.

LONDON, April 28 -- From a purely banking viewpoint, the American situation certainly seems to financial London to be improving. The fact that no important failures have occurrpd for some time, and that smaller difficulties appear to be diminishing, sustains this general view. It is felt that the influence exerted on the hoarding mania by this greater stability must be beneficial and cumulative.

The action of the Senate Finance Committee in eliminating the provision made by the House of Representatives for a special tax penalty on consolidated returns of two or more corporations and in restoring the individual tax exemption on dividends received from corporations was praised yesterday by George H. Coppers, chairman of the taxation committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.
LONGVIEW, Texas, May 1 (AP) -- More than a score of men faced criminal charges tonight in the wholesale theft of crude oil from wells of the East Texas field.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 1 -- With supporters battling for him in two of three States, where seventy-eight national convention delegates will be chosen Tuesday, Governor Roosevelt ignored politics today and asserted that he was far more interested in his new home than in primary elections.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 1 -- The government has reduced national expenditures by L5,940,000 in three years and a further reduction of L4,390,000 is expected in the current year, according to a statement by Minister of Finance William D. Stewart. [The pound was quoted on Saturday at $3.66].

With the approach of National Cotton Week on May 16, retail buyers concentrated the bulk of their orders on cotton dresses and accessories during the week. While general demand for goods was not very heavy, practically all departments shared in the activity, which originated from all sections of the country.

Alice in Wonderland stood before a microphone in her suite in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday and described for the big and little children of America a tiny bit of the immortal topsy-turvy land down a rabbit's hole and behind a looking glass.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Residential consumption of electricity has proved a profitable business for public utility companies which are now recognizing its value and have made reductions in gas and electric rates. The annual report of the Public Service Commission indicates that the companies doing business in the State have reduced their rates about $7,400,000 annually.

Of $662,000,000 of additional funds put into the market by the Federal Reserve Banks between Feb. 24 and April 27, $539,000,000 was absorbed in the repayment of member bank indebtedness and in the piling up of excess reserves, it is shown in a tabulation published in the current review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

One of the largest and most glittering of Broadway's annual Spring events, the National Variety Artists' Fund show, went on last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where stage, screen and radio performers assembled to prove once again the theatre's loyalty and generosity in caring for its own.

A theatrical producing company is being organized by Bert I. De Young and Daniel W. Blumenthal, lawyer, according to announcement yesterday by the latter, to produce a play called "U.S.A. with Music," the work of Walter Lowenfels, a young American poet who last year received half of the Richard Aldington Poetry Prize.

State Senator John A. Hastings issued a statement last night denying that he had "solicited, demanded, received or accepted," any contribution to Mayor Walker's campaign fund from the Equitable Coach Company, which employed him at $12,000 a year.
MOSCOW, May 1 (AP) -- Soviet Russia was described today as "the protector of world peace," and thereafter proletarians marched by Lenin's tomb in a militant May Day demonstration of fidelity.

To the Editor of The News York Times: Like Mr. Larkin, whose letter appears in THE TIMES, I read your editorial on the Mooney case with great interest, but my reaction to it was different. Like him, too, I was within a few hundred feet of the explosion, but I was in the procession, not watching it.
"The Man Who Changed His Name," a play by the late Edgar Wallace, will open tonight at the Broadhurst Theatre, with Fay Bainter and Frank Conroy heading the cast.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am fully in accord with the suggestion in your editorial that "the interval [during the various stages of the bill to remove the oath] should be used to remind sensible Irishmen, whereto the course marked out by President de Valera will, if not checked, lead the Free State."

BERLIN, May 1 -- Under the influence of benign weather, International Labor Day in Germany turned out to be more of a Spring festival than a demonstration of the class struggle. In Berlin the Social Democrats and Communists took turns in the Lustgarten, the usual place for political open-air meetings.

Yale's victory over Pennsylvania at New Haven, which enabled the Elis to take the lead, and Columbia's record-breaking game against Cornell proved the highlights in last week's Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race.

PARIS, April 29 -- With the slackening of the not very important recent speculative sales of the dollar, recovery was not long in occurring. Sterling also is quiet, with few transactions, and the Bank of England does not seem to have intervened much in the market.

The rain yesterday prevented the holding of the Washington Bicentennial parade in Brooklyn and the formal opening of the reproduction of Mount Vernon erected at the foot of Lookout Mountain in Prospect Park. In spite of the bad weather, throngs of men, women and children visited the structure and 2,000 of them were permitted to file through its quaint and charming rooms.

Probably the atmosphere of profound depression, which, appears at present to prevail, is largely created by the fact that the government's, important remedial measures have not yet produced a tangibly improved situation. It is true, the bank failures have virtualiy ceased.
NEW YORK. Lieut. Col. Sir Walrand Sinclair of London arrived on the Berengaria and is at the Ritz-Carlton.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Three Senators, Brookhart, Nye and Blaine, classed with the Progressive faction, face sharp opposition from the Republican regulars in the primaries.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 1 -- The authorities here are convinced that two cadets of the second class of the Military Academy, Alan J. Light of Connecticut Avenue, Washington, D.C., and Cadet Leo A. Skeim of Valley City, N.D., who have been missing since last evening, were drowned after the canoe in which they were crossing the Hudson capsized near the shore of Bannerman's Island, opposite the academy.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Wild Bill Hallahan was very wild today, but he was as hard to hit as he was wild, and the world champion St. Louis Cardinals ended the Chicago Cubs' seven-game winning streak with a 7-to-1 victory in the final game of the series.

BERLIN, May 1 -- Delegates of fifty nations assembled today in the auditorium of the Federal Economic Council for the opening session of World Trade Week. They will discuss ways to stem the tide of economic nationalism.

Union longshoremen who left the piers of the Clyde-Mallory, Savannah and Morgan lines April 15 when their wages were reduced ten per cent, will return to work this morning at the new rate fixed by the lines. The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that the ship lines had given assurance that the men would be accepted on their former status and that their action in striking would not be held against them.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- California voters will go to the polls Tuesday in the State's Presidential primary election with the Republican delegation pledged to President Hoover unopposed. Interest thus centres in the three-cornered contest in the Democratic ranks, with Alfred E. Smith, Governor Roosevelt and Speaker Garner as the aspirants.

LOU LITTLE, Harvey Harman, Chick Meehan and other football coaches were debating the rules and blocking traffic in a corridor of the RitzCarlton hostelry in Philadelphia a few nights ago when a bellboy, coming down the hall at a 10-flat pace, crashed into the group.
In its program for waterfowl conservation the Bureau of Biological Survey has reported additional details relating to the work of establishing an elaborate system of wildfowl sanctuaries.

"The prisons of the world are sanctified by God, for within their walls many men have found their hearts turning toward Him, and He has spoken to them oftener than to the priest in the sanctuary or the monk in the monastery," declared Cardinal Hayes in his dedicatory address yesterday at the new brick and stone Gothic chapel at Harts Island, the Bronx.

A greater manifestation of sympathetic interest in one's fellow-man in these days of distress was urged by the Rev. Dr. Nelson B. Chester, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

Formation of a committee in the interests of holders of Allerton New York Corporation first-mortgage 5 1/2 per cent sinking fund loan certificates, due on Jan. 1, 1947, to press for a reorganization of the properties underlying the certificates, was announced yesterday.

To the strains of "The International" and other revolutionary airs, Communists observed May Day yesterday by marching in the rain. Drenched in the showers, the men, women and children paraded from Union Square through lower east side streets to Rutgers Square.

Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, sent greetings to President Hoover and the American people yesterday in a radio address from Budapest, broadcast in the United States by a Columbia Broadcasting system network.

Why Economists Go Mad. It's an ill wind that blows no one any good -- or isn't it? Snow was so scarce last Winter that the city had to spend only $13,892 of the $1,000,000 it had set aside for snow removal.
TOKYO, Monday, May 2 (AP) -- Wide areas in Northern and Eastern Manchuria were the battleground of Japanese and various guerrilla forces today.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- Making his debut in a uniform of the Browns, Irving Hadley, who came to St. Louis recently in a trade with the White Sox involving Ralph Kress, struck out elevan men, allowed nine hits and twirled his new team to a 4-to-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
Members of the New York Junior League Players will give a revue as their final production this season tomorrow night in the great hall of their clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Marriage is in danger of becoming little more than a form "honored in the breach rather than in the observance," the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise declared yesterday in a sermon on "The Making, Unmaking and Remaking of Marriage" at the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall.

The transference of the regulation and responsibility of court procedure from the Legislature to the courts and the establishment of a judicial council composed of laymen, legislators, lawyers and judges to act as an advisory body in recommending law reforms were urged yesterday by three speakers who discussed court reform in a symposium broadcast from station WOR.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 1 -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, today issued the following statement:

HONOLULU, May 1 -- Honolulu is catching its breath over the weekend and trying to forget the verdict in the Fortescue-Massie case for a day. On Sundays most of the city goes fishing, bathing and motoring, and today it was impossible to find any one in town who had anything to do with the case.

Mayor Walker praised last night the work carried on by Sydenham Hospital and other hospitals which give medical aid to the needy in a city in which the municipal hospitals are crowded to capacity. He spoke at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt to mark the fortieth anniversary of Sydenham Hospital.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1 (AP) -- Rhode Island Democrats will gather here tomorrow in State convention to elect delegates to the national convention and to elect the two Rhode Island members of the Democratic National Committee.

An attack on the rule which requires the vote of two-thirds of the delegates to make the nomination for President may be made at the Democratic National Convention which will convene at Chicago on June 27.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Fears of "severe" effects on the economic situation in Sweden as a result of the death of Ivar Kreuger were cited in a report to the Department of Commerce from Basil D. Dahl, United States Trade Commissioner at Stockholm, made public today.

In sharp contrast with the declining tendency of the general bond market, high-grade and even some of the lower rated State and municipal bond issues have advanced substantially during the last few days. With the prospect of higher income taxes, the position of the municipal market has been strengthened considerably, but on this score municipal bankers point out that the tax-exempt feature on municipals does not dictate the price necessarily.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1 -- A check for $10,000, representing the contributions of Jews throughout New Jersey for the rehabilitation of Palestine as the Jewish homeland, was presented tonight to Dr. Nahum Sokolow of London, president of the World Zionist Organization, at a dinner at the Young Men's Hebrew Association here.

The big problem before education in the United States is that of selecting and diffusing the best accomplishments in the educational experiments being conducted by 150,000 school district boards in the United States, writes Dr. Henry Suzzallo, president of the, Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, in the twenty-sixth annual report of the foundation, made public yesterday.

Columbia's rowing squad, consist ing of varsity, freshman and varsity 150-pound crews, returned from Annapolis late Saturday night, keenly disappointed at not winning the varsity race against the Naval Academy, but nevertheless looking to future races with high hopes.

A plan for forced stimulation of business by means of Federal subsidies to certain types of new construction and to new capital investments is proposed by M.C. Rorty, engineer-economist and former vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a special supplement of The Harvard Business Review published yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- William Draper Harkins, Professor of Physical Chemistry at the University of Chicago and the first man to make calculations of the vast energies that could be released by the transmutation of hydrogen atoms into helium atoms, said tonight that the experiments of Dr. Cockroft and Dr. Walton at Cambridge University were of great importance.

Mrs. Gertrude De Witt, 28 years old, whose marriagre nine years ago in Binghamton, N.Y., was a social event, but who has recently been earning her living as a taxicab driver here, staggered into the Swedish Hospital in Brooklyn early yesterday morning and said she had taken poison.

Memorial ceremonies marking the 110th anniversary of the birth of General Ulysses S. Grant, sponsored by the New York County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, were held yesterday at the tomb of the Civil War leader after a parade up Riverside Drive in the rain.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A review of the work of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace during the past year is set forth in the annual report of its secretary. Dr. James Brown Scott, just presented to the trustees. Increasing sentiment for peace and international cooperation is reported by Dr. Scott.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- A second and last telephone call to the family of Gustav Miller, 22 years old, and son of Max Miller, a Joliet malt dealer, who was kidnapped Thursday night, directed the search for the abductors today to the haunts of the "Forty-two Gang" on Chicago's West Side.

It is curious to observe how some people feel upset or even dejected by the doubt that has come over Governor ROOSEVELT'S Presidential candidacy. They had taken his nomination as a certainty and hate to give it up. They are disquieted by the reports that other names will be considered by the Democratic National Convention at Chicago -- NEWTON BAKER, for example, or OWEN YOUNG.

HONOLULU, May 1. -- Robert Bell of New York gave assurance today that Mrs. Thalla Massie, his niece and the wife of the convicted "honor" slayer of Joseph Kahahawai, will testify at the retrial of four Hawaiians charged with assaulting her last Sept. 12.

Columbia's rowing squad, consist ing of varsity, freshman and varsity 150-pound crews, returned from Annapolis late Saturday night, keenly disappointed at not winning the varsity race against the Naval Academy, but nevertheless looking to future races with high hopes.

Continuous liquidation of stocks throughout April, with the volume of transactions, however, slight smaller than in March, resulted at the end of last month in a new low level of prices for securities on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the second successive month of declining prices, following a moderate upturn in February.

Not long ago a literary tea in honor of James Branch Cabell was broadcast nationally over the radio. Today a tea which will be made remarkable by pink lemonade, sawdust, a mustached barker with a derby hat and checked vest, hot dogs, an Oriental dancer and gaudy posters, will introduce Phil Stong's novel, "State Fair."

NEWARK, N. J., May 2. -- Charges that the proposed increase in the gasoline tax from three to five cents to provide funds for unemployment relief would bring an increase of "gasoline bootlegging" throughout the State were made here today by C.G. Sheffield, vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier, Democratic member of the Hofstadter legislative committee, announced last night that he would apply in Supreme Court today for an order halting the current series of public hearings on matters connected with Mayor Walker.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 2 (AP) Candidates rallied their forces in Alabama tonight for the Democratic primary tomorrow, in which the State's twenty-four votes at the national convention are at stake. One delegate slate pledged to Governor Roosevelt and another uninstructed are in the field.
GENEVA, May 2. -- The League of Nations received today the first report of the Lytton Commission, which is investigating the situation in the Far East.

SHANGHAI, May 2. -- Bishop Jay Rouchouse of the French Catholic Mission has been forced to flee from Chengtu and hide from Inner Szechuan militarists who attempted to force him to grant them a "loan" of $1,500,000.

Only half the people in this country have a sense of humor and clever advertisements seldom sell anything, John Caples, associated with Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., advertising agents, writes in "Tested Advertising Methods," published yesterday by Harpers. He declares the average American is approximately 13 years old mentally, and that words not in a 13-year-old's vocabulary, turns of phrase too complex to be understood easily by a child, are virtually worthless in advertising.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated Boston in the first game of their series today, 7 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Supreme Court, in an opinion of farreaching consequences, ruled today that the great meat packers shall not be permitted to deal in groceries or engage in any business other than the slaughter-house industry.

Efforts of leading sugar refiners on April 5 to increase the buying of sugar by moving their price down to the low record of 3.90 cents a pound appeared yesterday to have been in vain, and they made another cut of 10 points, lowering the price to 3.80 cents.

An English brick and stucco dwelling just completed on the east side of Lynwood Avenue, Cedarhurst, L. I., has been purchased by Mrs. Rose H. Bagedonow from the George Alien Realty Company through. H. Frankfort Son. The house is on a plot 164 by 114 feet.

In the May Current History Mr. THEODORE CHRISTIANSON, a Republican who was six years Governor of Minnesota, tries to show us, disinterestedly and without intrusion of personal opinion, the general feeling of Mid-Westerners in the present discontents.

WITH the national amateur boxing championships coming up this week at the Garden, a glance back over the record brings a curious fact to light. In forty-four years of competition approximately 350 national amateur boxing titles have been distributed. Only four amateur title winners moved ahead to gain world's championships in the professional ring.

The Southern Pacific Company increased the freight it moves by motor truck in California, Oregon and Arizona by 438 per cent in 1931, compared with 1930, Hale Holden, chairman of the executive committee, says in his annual report. These operations are carried on by the Pacific Motor Transport Company, a subsidiary, which provides door-to-door service and also maintains three highway lines as feeders to the railway.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Led by Bryan Grant, former national clay court champion, the University of North Carolina tennis team blanked Pennsylvania on the River Field Courts today, 9 to 0.
DENVER, Col., May 2 (AP). -- Mrs. Frances Kent Lament, wife of Robert P. Lament Jr., made her professional debut here last night as the leading woman of a local stock company.

The Board of Taxicab Control announced yesterday that it would not consider or act upon applications for additional cab licenses until further notice, or until its code of regulations has been formulated and adopted. Maurice Hotchner, chairman of the board, said that the ruling applied to all applications received after May 1.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 2 (AP). -- Juveniles held the premier position in the inaugural program of the Maryland Jockey Club at Pimlico today, nine promising 2-year-olds meeting in the Pimlico Home-Bred and the result was a surprise when Golden Fate, sporting the silks of William du Pont's Foxcatcher Farms and ridden by B. Hanford, accounted for the major honors.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The experiments of Dr. J.D. Cockroft and Dr. E.T.S. Walton at Cambridge, England, are important because they demonstrate that atoms in being artificially smashed can liberate more energy than is put Into the smashing process.

Bankers as a whole are extending to business whatever loans each case may justify. The American Bankers Association Journal says. "The banker individually is still the custodian of private funds," it asserts, "and must employ them with their specific safety as the primary object, rather than for the purpose, however laudable theoretically, of bringing about economic improvement."

The performance of the Bach Bminor Mass, given last night in Carnegie Hall, and now an annual observance of the Oratorio Society, of which Albert Stoessel is conductor, would be under any circumstances an extraordinary event. There is no music that more nearly approaches at certain moments the sublime, and none which contains to a greater degree the pure rapture of religion.

Domestic corporation bonds, notably the rails, were weak on the Stock Exchange yesterday, while foreign loans and United States Government bonds were irregularly lower in moderately active trading. Most of the active railroad issues fell 1 to 10 points for the day, and in certain sections of the industrial and utility groups the losses were almost as great.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 2. -- Dr. and Mrs. Harold E.B. Pardee gave a luncheon today at the Cascades Club for Dr. and Mrs. Henry Thorndyke Chickering, Dr. and Mrs. William St. Lawrence and Alfred Law.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 2. -- The opening matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association team championship witnessed the elimination today of the Class B champions of 1931, Essex County Country Club.

Those who anticipate some of the good fishing that is always associated with thoughts of Moosehead Lake, Me., will be glad to know that word received from the vicinity yesterday states that the lake undoubtedly will be clear of ice by the end of the week.
LONDON, May 2. -- Commenting on the financial difficulties of the United States Government, The Times will say editorially tomorrow:

Protest against the conviction of the defendants in the Massie case, on the ground that it degraded the American flag, was voiced in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Brooklyn Women's Constitutional Hoover-Curtis Committee. Copies of the resolution will be forwarded to Washington in the hope that it "will be a lesson to future governments of the United States."

Walter B. Tobias and B. La Rossa, prohibition agents on the staff of Andrew McCampbell, administrator, are in danger of facing a criminal action as a result of a complaint made against them yesterday by Frank W. Ford, former Assistant United States Attorney, before Federal Judge William Bondy.

George Gallagher has ambled up the steps of the Supreme Court Building in Brooklyn more than 18,000 times during his service as night watchman, but yesterday he entered the court on an unofficial mission -- as the distinguished guest of every one, from the presiding justice to the scrubwoman.

PARIS, May 2. -- The political trend to the Left in France manifested in yesterday's elections was sufficient to alarm the Bourse here almost to the point of hysteria today. Heavy selling of French rentes and shares of the Bank of France and the Suez Canal were attributed only to the success of Left candidates at the polls.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- A charge of attempting to rescue a prisoner was dismissed today when Daniel W. Loesser, 23 years old, one of the Harvard students arrested during the night of rioting on April 21, received a hearing in East Cambridge District Court.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Movement of hogs in the West fell below expectations today and, with a fairly good demand, the market was strong to 15 cents higher than on Friday, the best stock selling up to $3.90 a hundred-weight, or 20 cents above the top of the poor quality offered on Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask why you suggest that Governor Roosevelt should have let the selection of delegates go by default in Massachusetts, yet in the same breath assert that the selection of the nominee of the party in the convention should be arrived at by free deliberation and sound judgment and not by default?

Henry Kaiser, 25-year-old butcher, tried to be a hold-up man yesterday, according to the police, but his attempt ended when he was beaten by two girls and arrested. He was held by the police on charges of robbery and violation of the Sullivan law, and he nursed painful injuries as mementoes of his alleged short career in crime.

PARIS, May 2 (AP). -- The Radical Socialists emerged from yesterday's election with sixty-three seats, the biggest solid bloc elected so far, while the Left Republicans of Premier Tardieu lost heavily, placing only thirty-seven candidates in the victory column.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 2. -- The mechanical forces of the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company will be reduced by 200 men this week, according to an announcement today by J. Raymond Carringer, general manager of the plant. He explained that the lay-off affected chiefly men who were employed three years ago in the construction program which had reached completion.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Federal Farm Board announced today that it would dispose of half its holdings of 1.300.000 bales of stabilization cotton within a year from Aug. 1. Its decision was in response to complaints that its large holdings had led to uncertainty in the market.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The collapse of Vernon Gomez's winning streak spelled defeat for the Yankees today. The slim southpaw ace, after winning his first three games of the season, went down under heavy firing from Senatorial bats and the Yankees lost, 10 to 3, while a crowd of about five thousand supplied jubilant sound effects.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2. -- A mother who surrendered her son for adoption sixteen years ago has brought suit in Supreme Court here to compel the foster parents to tell her the present name and whereabouts of her boy.
