She seeks to become acquainted with her son to make him heir to a fortune of more than $250,000 which she recently inherited.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- Sixty-six athletic awards to members of Princeton's minor Winter sports teams were announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

A recommendation of the Board of Examiners of the public school system that applicants for teaching positions pay fees to take examinations for licenses is thought "worthy of serious consideration" by Dr. Wiliam J. O'Shea. Superintendent of Schools, who discussed this and other suggestions of the examiners in a section of his annual report made public yesterday.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday 3 1/4 Per cent for the best names. Friday 3 1/4 per cent for the best names.

George Abbott and Philip Dunning, playwrights, and Joseph P. Bickerton Jr., theatrical lawyer, will be associated next season as the producing firm of Abbott-Dunning, Inc. Three plays are now on their production list, the first of which will be "Gilded Lilly," by Mr. Abbott and Mr. Dunning, based on a story by Frances Fox Dunning.

The annual report of the Central Public Service Corporation for 1931 shows gross revenue of $39,453,014, against $41,688,130 in 1930, and net earnings of $15,301,683, against $16,564,491. Total income was $16,094,624, against $18,120,102.

AURORA, Ill., May 2 (AP). -- Burning Up, a star of the Mrs. Emil Denemark Stable, captured the Aurora Handicap, feature event of the opening day's card at Aurora Exposition Park today. Burning Up made every post a winning one, staving off a hard drive at the finish by Fortunate Youth.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 2 (AP). -- Displaying a sparkling brand of speed, S.C. McAtee's Billies Orphan defeated a small but select band of juvenile fillies in the Blossom Time Purse, feature attraction today at Churchill Downs. The Three D's Stock Farm supplied the runner-up in its home-bred, Black Squaw with J.F. Patterson's Georgia Lily saving the show.

May Day in Russia was commemorated by a display of the nation's millitary strength in the capital, and by bringing into test operation the great hydroelectric plant on the Dnieper which has been five years in construction under American direction.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Negroes cannot be barred by the Texas State Democratic Executive Committee from participating in the party primary elections, the Supreme Court today decided in a majority opinion written by Justice Cardozo. The decision was 5 to 4.

Taxes for the first half of 1932 became due and payable on Sunday. They may be paid, however, up to May 31 without penalty. Anxious eyes will be focused on the reports emanating from the City Collector's office during that period. Real estate organizations have joined with city officials in deprecating a tax strike, but many owners are so hard pressed they may not have the funds to meet the city's bills promptly.
RENO, Nev., May 2. -- A suit for divorce was filed today by Mrs. Elizabeth Shevlin Smith against Paul Morton Smith of New York. The charge was mental cruelty.

HONOLULU, May 2 (AP). -- A bill containing substantially the same provisions as the Bingham bill passed today by the United States Senate to prevent two "hung" juries from operating as an acquittal in Hawaiian criminal cases, already is before Governor Lawrence M, Judd for his signature.

Charitable organization ultimately will receive $80,000 from the estate of Benjamin Bernard, which was appraised yesterday at $418,785 gross and $386,752 net for transfer tax purposes. The valuations were as of Nov. 3, 1929, the date of Mr. Bernard's death.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Justice constitutes "the safest corner upon which the people may erect their entire social structure," President Hoover said today in a message to the opening meeting of the American Conference on Institutions for the Establishment of International Justice.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Democratic leaders, commenting today on the reported move of the Roosevelt faction to abolish the two-thirds rule in the national convention, generally favored its abolition.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 2. -- Baroness Giacomo Levi, semi-finalist in the national championship at Forest Hills two years ago, started in quest of the women's Westchester County tennis championship at Briarcliff Lodge today by defeating Miss Olga Kallos of New York, 6-1, 6-3, to gain the second round.

Tax collections from the 1932 levy on real and personal property amounted to $10,469,088.54 yesterday, the first day on which they are legally due. The receipts showed a slight decrease this year, compared with the figure of $10,539,830.90 received on the first payable day of 1931.

BUENOS AIRES, May 2 (AP). -- An appeal to patriotic Argentines to support the government's financial program, enabling it to discharge its domestic obligations and continue to pay foreign debts promptly, was made by President Agustin P. Justo in his first message to Congress today.

Benny Leonard, fighting as a middleweight, administered such a drubbing to Willie Garafola of Brooklyn last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, that Referee Jed Gahan in the fourth round interrupted what was to have been a ten-round battle.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 2. -- Rhode Island's delegation to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago was selected at a special State Convention here today and instructed to "make every effort" to obtain the nomination of Alfred E. Smith for President.

Realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday were confined almost exclusively to dwelling deals, the demand for small properties showing no sign of diminishing on the opening day of the week's trading.

VIENNA, May 2. -- W.A. Shepherd of Columbia University, the visiting Carnegie professor in Vienna, made the inaugural address today at the lecture hall of the University of Vienna, where eight years ago he was the first American professor to help restore the intellectual ties of Austria and the United States.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's homer in the eleventh inning today gave the Athletics a 3-to-2 victory over the Red Sox in the opening game of their series. The Athletics used three pitchers and Lefty Grove, who hurled the last two frames, was credited with the victory, his second of the season.

The National Electric Power Company has reduced its notes payable to banks and others by more than $3,000,000 this year, Harry Reid, president, says in a quarterly report to stockholders. By the omission of dividends on the Class A and B common stocks recently, he says, reductions in loans will be accelerated.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Several of your correspondents have indulged in criticism of stockholders' and bondholders' protective committees. The assertion has been made that such committees do not send to security holders copies of protective agreements along with the letters in which the deposit of securities is requested.

Reactionary influences were again at work on the Stock Exchange yesterday, although trading was uncommonly light for a full five-hour day. The turnover was about 775,000 shares, compared with 1,166,820 shares on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

The heads of many important Industries met at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday for the annual Spring convention of the American Management Association, which will continue through Friday. The opening day was devoted to a public relations conference under the direction of C. Alison Scully, vice president of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company.

Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor, who has just severed his connection with the Metropolitan Opera, is considering an offer to appear in the Paramount-Publix chain of theatres, it was learned last night. It is understood that he has been considering the offer for the last six weeks and that he is to receive a salary of about $7,000 a week for twenty weeks.

Columbia's rowing squad resumed its training yesterday on the Harlem River in preparation for its meeting with Yale and Pennsylvania in the Blackwell Cup regatta at Philadelphia on Saturday. Coach Richard J. Glendon had the Morningside fleet go through a seven-mile workout, no part of which was at an idling pace.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway expects to receive its $1,800,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation tomorrow, C.W. Michel, assistant to the chairman, said yesterday. He added that indications were that the Frisco would be in a position formally to accede by that time to the conditions for the loan laid down by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LONDON, May 2. -- Prime Minister MacDonald, who returned from Geneva last night, resumed his duties in the House of Commons for a short time this afternoon after submitting to a two-hour examination by an oculist and after a long conversation with Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, who has been Acting Prime Minister during his absence at the disarmament conference.

Most women take pleasure in shopping. Most shops are eager to sell and to make buying enjoyable. Yet in the May American Mercury an article on "The Dreadful Chore of Buying" describes a losing battle with clerks and floor-walkers. And its author, DOROTHY G. HOLLAND, apparently does not belong to that small group who refuse to look at more than two or three things of a kind because it makes choosing so difficult.

Victorious over Canada in their opening test at the Chevy Chase Club, Maryland, the four members of the United, States Davis Cup team arrived in New York yesterday and began practice for the next match with Mexico to be played in New Orleans, May 13, 14 and 15.

The Museum of Modern Art opens with a private showing today its new permanent quarters at 11 West Fiftythird Street. The exhibition, which will be open to the public beginning tomorrow, consists of murals by American painters and photographers.

A miniature radio sending station, eighteen inches high and weighing only thirty-five pounds, especially to link airplanes, vessels or land vehicles with broadcasting networks, was successfully tried out yesterday afternoon, high above New York. For fifteen minutes WABC's listeners heard the tinkling of two toy pianos played in an airplane above the city by two entertainers.

An ill wind continued to blow the Giants nothing but misfortune yesterday, for among other things, it blew the Robins onto the Polo Grounds, and, as the Robins have not been going so well of late, either, there could, of course, be only one result.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Tuesday, May 3. -- The first round of the annual Westchester County contract bridge championship for the J. Noel Macy Trophy ended early this morning with most of the better-known pairs well up in the first night's totals.
ROME, May 2 (AP). -- The Bank of Italy reduced its discount rate from 6 to 5 per cent today.

An attempt by Max B. Steuer, special prosecutor, to introduce balance sheets of the Bank of United States, to show how the bank's officers gave directors a false impression of the institution's financial status, was forestalled yesterday by Judge George L. Donnelian in General Sessions at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks.

A new schedule of rates for electric current to residents of WestChester County served by the Westchester Lighting Company was filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday. The saving to consumers will be close to $700,000 a year, it was said.

One man was drowned and a second was rescued from the North River by a policeman at 5 A. M. yesterday when an automobile in which they were riding plunged off the ferry slip at the foot of Christopher Street. The owner of the car was arrested on charges of homicide and driving while intoxicated.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May (AP). -- President A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard would "commit suicide" rather than lay down inexorable laws now for Harvard's destiny during the next 100 years, he said tonight at an address before the Cambridge Club.

LONDON, May 2. -- The assertion of two young Cambridge scientists that in breaking up an atom by a new high-voltage process they transmuted one element into another has aroused world-wide interest in scientific and commercial circles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In studying the tax problems of any one State, we inevitably come up against the brick wall that, having done all that any State can do, there can be no improvement in permanent general conditions until the farmer and laborer can get a fair return for their work, and that depends on trade conditions beyond the reach of any State.

Twenty-eight co-ed athletes at New York University who earned varsity letters for their work during the past year as members of either the girls' swimming, field hockey, basketball, tennis or fencing teams were honored at the eighth annual N.Y.U. women's athletic dinner at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

SHANGHAI, May 2 (AP). -- Negotiations seeking a formal armistice between China and Japan in this area would be resumed at 10 A.M. tomorrow, Chinese authorities announced tonight. They said an agreement putting an end to the hostilities might be initialed tomorrow and formally signed on Thursday.

BERLIN, May 2 (AP). -- A woman about 40 years old who was found dead, apparently of poison, in a Berlin rooming house last Friday was identified by police today as Lucille Chalfant, an American singer known professionally here as Annie Lind.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP). -- Two big innings that netted all their runs gave the Indians a 6-to-5 victory over the St. Louis Browns today and moved them into second place in the American League. It was Cleveland's ninth straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The House of Representatives, which for several days has been tearing to pieces the Economy Committee's program to cut Federal expenditures more than $250,000,000, gave an indication today of what may happen to the remaining section of the measure, the Veterans' Bureau legislation, when it passed the $100,000,000 World War widows and orphans bill.

The City Affairs Committee yesterday accused Mayor Walker of planning to use the recent decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, barring "emergency" bus operation in Manhattan, as a lever to jam through franchise awards to the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and its subsidiary, the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Reducing the hours of labor rather than cutting wages is the rational step for employers to take in the present economic situation, Benjamin. Schlesinger of New York, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, declared in an address here today at the opening of the union's twenty-first convention.
U.S. vs. Smith. President HOOVER won a constitutional victory over the Senate yesterday when the Supreme Court handed down a decision putting a limit on that body's right to change its mind.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2. -- Tomorrow afternoon the Harvard oarsmen will try for the second time to open their 1932 season when they are scheduled to oppose M.I.T. on the Charles River in four races.

The general operation of the American Museum of Natural History has been progressing satisfactorily, in the main, despite disturbed financial conditions, it was reported yesterday by Cleveland E. Dodge, chairman of the executive committee, at a meeting of the board of trustees.

AMHERST, Mass., May 2. -- Heritage, a new magazine, made its appearance at Amherst College this week, through the enterprise of Cecil H. Hemley of New York City, a sophomore. As its name implies, the magazine's purpose is to correllate the culture of the past with that of the present and thus provide a basis for future standards of literary criticism.

City College will celebrate the eighty-fifth anniversary of its founding with all-day exercises today. Starting at 10 A.M. and continuing until after midnight, the Charter Day program will include a series of addresses and musical selections in the Great Hall, a military review in the Lewisohn Stadium and a moonlight dance on the St. Nicholas Heights campus.

The unemployed or New York City are as much in need of recreation facilities as of jobs, Mrs. Nathan Straus Jr. declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women at the Temple Emanu-El Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- President Hoover was more than 8,000 votes ahead of former Senator Joseph I. France in today's Republican Presidential primary contest for Maryland's nineteen votes in the national convention as outlying sections started to report their totals tonight in the Senator's home State.

A letter from Cardinal Hayes, condemning the Republic and Eltinge burlesque theatres in West Fortysecond Street as "breeders of vice," was entered in the records of the hearings before License Commissioner James F. Geraghty yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is singular that one never sees in print the main reasons for the vast armament of European nations and, consequently, for the failure of disarmament conferences.
NEW YORK. Rear Admiral and R.S.V. Drax of the British Navy and Mrs. Drax are expected on the Olympic and will be at the New Weston.

The steamer Sandy Hook, which was burned at her Jersey City pier last October, will have her trial trip in about two weeks, having been remodeled and equipped with many modern appurtenances and luxuries of a private yacht, at the Port Richmond plant of the United Drydock Company.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 2. -- Senator Brookhart today selected his home town of Washington to begin his active campaign for re-election. He faces five opponents in the Republican primary in June.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Secretary Mills, in submitting the Farm Loan Board's annual report to Congress today recommended a further strengthening of the law to increase the authority of the Farm Loan Bank System to aid agriculture, after calling attention to the difficulties faced by these institutions during the depression.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The first challenge of the authority of the Senate Republican steering committee occurred today when Republicans and Democrats identified with the "Progressive Bloc" prevented temporarily a vote on a motion to take up the Hale naval bill.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Senate Finance Committee made numerous changes in the billion-dollar tax bill today, among these being several increases over rates proposed by the House.

An international oil conference looking toward balancing production with demand, as well as toward a division of foreign petroleum mark ts will be begun here next week. Representatives of the Soviet oil industry will arrive on the Bremen today, and almost immediately informal discussions are expected to commence.

Between 30,000 and 40,000 building trades mechanics struck yesterday because the Elevator Manufacturers Association and the Elevator Constructors Union had made a verbal agreement for a wage scale of $11.20 a day, or 51-20 above the rate previously arranged between the Building Trades Council and the Building Trades Employers Association.

Favorable weather over Sunday led to a continuation yesterday morning of last week's selling movement on the Cotton Exchange and carried the spot month to 5.32 cents a pound, the low figure of the season which had been reached last October. July, the immediate active future delivery, sold at 5.45 cents, a new low record for that delivery for the season and the lowest since 1898.

MIAMI, Fla., May 2. -- Captain W. N. Lancaster, former British flier, was in jail tonight, charged with the first degree murder of Haden Clarke, 26-year-old author and fiance of Lancaster's flying partner, Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 2. -- A merchants' strike against the 25 per cent sales tax, proposed by the Chamber of Commerce in the Merchants' Federation convention today, led the federation to cable Governor Beverley to call an extra session of the Legislature to provide substitute revenues.

The Block Community Organization will put 5,000 unemployed heads of families to work within a few days, but whether or not they will remain in employment will depend upon the continued raising of money in each block to which a block-aid case is assigned, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Senate today passed unanimously a bill designed specifically to prevent the freeing of the four surviving men accused of a criminal attack on Mrs. Thalia Massie. The measure strikes out that provision of the Hawaiian law which makes two successive jury disagreements equivalent to acquittal in criminal cases.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., May 2 (AP). -- Harry K. Devereaux, 72 years old, wealthy Cleveland sportsman and philanthropist, died at his Winter home last night of heart disease. He had been in failing health for a number of years. For the last thirty-five years Devereaux was the central figure in Grand Circuit racing, having been president of the Grand Circuit Racing Association until failing health forced his resignation six years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- One of the rarest of astronomical spectacles, that of the planet Jupiter without any moons, will be visible to stargazers equipped with small telescopes tomorrow evening. Jupiter, largest of the earth's family of planets, is provided with nine satellites, or moons, of which four are easily visible through even a small telescope.
BERLIN, May 2. -- Apprehensive of an attempted Polish coup at Danzig, the German Government is prepared to resist with all its forces any such move, it was stated today at the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The State Department received today from Huqh R. Wilson, United States Minister to Switzerland, the following official text, of the resolution adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations on Saturday urqing an early adjustment by China and Japan through negotiation of the Shanghai problem, looking to withdrawal of the Japanese forces:

The examination before trial of officers of the Electrical Workers' Union, Local 3, before Referee Robert McC. Marsh at 14 Vesey Street yesterday struck a snag when Frank P. Walsh, attorney for the union, refused to obey the referee's ruling and turn over to John Holley Clark Jr., counsel for the fifteen plaintiffs, a document concerning the union's accounts.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2. -- The thirty-first quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, opening in the municipal auditorium here today, voted timesaving revisions in its rules of procedure which will enable its various committees to accomplish in one week work scheduled for two.

Synthetic opera, in which the voices of the singers will be played on disks, synchronized to the pantomime of actors and actresses whose appearance would not destroy the illusions of the audience, is being planned by Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, he revealed last night in a talk on "New Horizons in Music" during the seventh meeting of the Acoustical Society of America, at the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

GENEVA, May 2. -- The French elections were deemed here to have shown a stronger shift to the Left than had been expected and this result was generally welcomed. The prevailing view seems to be that expressed by a British international official who said:
DOVER, Del., May 2. -- The Demo-, cratic State Committee in session here this afternoon selected May 24 as the date for the State convention to elect delegates to the national convention in June.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Top Flight, future book favorite for the Kentucky Derby until she met the first defeat of her career in the Wood Memorial last Saturday, has been declared out of the Kentucky Derby, and will not run in the Preakness, Trainer Tom Healey said yesterday at Jamaica.

TOKYO, May 2 (AP). -- A new trouble spot appeared in Manchuria over the week-end as various press dispatches told of fighting in Fengtien, the southernmost province and next-door neighbor to Mongolia.

The real Alice of "Wonderland" gazed happily around her yesterday from the steps of the Columbia University Library and learned more about the marvels and pleasures connected with this "topsy-turvy world." In a private ceremony Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made Mrs. Reginald Liddell Hargreaves, for whom Lewis Carroll wrote "Alice in Wonderland" in her childhood, a Doctor of Letters.

SYDNEY, N. S. W., May 2. -- The battle between Premier J. T. Lang of New South Wales and the Commonwealth of Australia, which threatened to stop the flow of taxes in the State, apparently came to an end today with a victory for the Commonwealth.

In addition to his innumerable accomplishments Edgar Wallace had a sense of humor. "The Man Who Changed His Name," which was acted at the Broadhurst last evening with Fay Bainter and Frank Conroy in the leading parts, pieces out the mystery with comedy, which is a pleasant patchwork for evening wear in the Spring.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2. -- California's forty-four votes in the Democratic National Convention and party control in this State are the stakes for which rival Democratic factions will be battling in tomorrow's primary.
Youths from the poorer sections of the city held a dinner at the West Side Boys' Club last night under the auspices of the Children's Aid Society to mark the opening of Boys' Week.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Hoover won and the Senate lost today when the Supreme Court unanimously decided that the Senate could not reconsider the nomination of George Otis Smith as chairman of the Federal Power Commission after the President had been notified of the Senate's original approval of the appointment and Mr. Smith's commission had been issued.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP). -- Sylvester Johnson shut out the rebuilt Cincinnati Reds for eight innings today and the Cardinals took the first of a three-game series, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Goldsborough bill, which directs the Federal Reserve System to employ its control over credit and currency in an effort to restore commodity prices to about the 1926 level, was adopted in the House today by the overwhelming vote of 289 to 60.
No transactions were recorded yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- A convict's number instead of the notorious name Alphonse (Scarface) Capone, blue denim as a daily garb in place of fashionably tailored suits and shirts, rough prison shoes, and the beginning of at least seven and a half years' loss of contact with the world outside prison walls appeared tonight a matter of less than twentyfour hours for the portly Chicago gang leader.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP). -- Withdrawal of four leading Eastern candidates today strengthened the claim of Mrs. L.G. Kaufman's Tick On to the position of pre-post favorite for the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP). -- Withdrawal of four leading Eastern candidates today strengthened the claim of Mrs. L.G. Kaufman's Tick On to the position of pre-post favorite for the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 2. -- Evidence that Theodore M. Edison, youngest son of the late Thomas A. Edison, had taken up the reins relinquished by his father at the Edison research laboratories was seen by his associates here today when he received notification from Washington that his first independent patent had been granted.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Newly developed devices that will improve the recording of earthquakes and may enable seismologists to prognosticate with considerable accuracy the time and place of earth tremors were described today before the eastern section of the Seismological Society of America at its annual meeting at the Franklin Institute here.

A new conception of merchandising which would forcefully and dramatically restore the American business man's faith in himself and his subordinates was urged and predicted yesterday by Charles E. Murphy, president of the Advertising Club of New York, in a talk before the last meeting of the season of the Government Club at the Hotel Astor. Mr. Murphy spoke on "The Responsibility of Advertising to Recovery."

The liner Berengaria, at its West Fourteenth Street pier, was the scene last night of the annual dinner dance and entertainment of Toc H, given for the benefit of the Boys' Bureau. The entire entertaining quarters of the vessel, which returned here last week after several weeks' reconditioning abroad, were given over to the fete.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 2. --The arrangements committee of the Connecticut Democratic Convention on May 16 and 17 selected William C. Fox of New London today to be temporary chairman on the evening of May 16.

BUCHAREST, May 2. -- Princess Helen left Bucharest today after several weeks, receiving honors usual to the departure of a foreign Princess. Her departure disposes of rumors of a reconciliation with King Carol and confirms the statement that she had come only to see her son, Crown Prince Michael, and to arrange her financial affairs.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP). -- Steve Swetonic outpitched Pat Malone in a brilliant duel today and the Pittsburgh Pirates took the first game of the series from the Chicago Cubs, 2 to 0.

Only $220,197,000 of new public financing was done in the United States in the first four months of 1932, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal financing, according to figures announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.

Results in the national A.A.U. indoor swimming and diving championships for women, concluded at Los Angeles on Sunday, provided gratifying evidence that the United States will be able to muster a formidable team of naiads for this Summer's Olympics.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that THE TIMES was a little unfair in the editorial "Privileged Classes."

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP). -- After holding Detroit to four scattered hits in eight innings today, Sam Jones collapsed and the Tigers scored five runs in the ninth and won the series opener from the White Sox, 5 to 3.

Two hundred workers in the emergency Spring drive of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies gathered last night at the home of Felix M. Warburg, 1,109 Fifth Avenue, and heard an appeal for support by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the federation.

The New York State Bankers' Association has addressed to its members a report on the Glass bill to amend the Federal Reserve act and the national bank act, setting forth the points which it believes should be modified or eliminated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democratic skies are clearing. The brighter day seems to be dawning. Roosevelt and Smith have grappled in a struggle for self-extermination, and seem to be doing a perfectly splendid job of it. Let us hope that It is finished to the entire satisfaction of a blah-blah weary nation.
COLUMBIA, S. C.. May 2 UP).Delegates to Democratic county conventions in this State's two largest cities voted today for a popular referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment.

Adelaide B. Fitch, Individually and as executor of the estate of Henry Brown, and others have leased 152-54 West Thirty-fourth Street to Orsons, Inc., of 152 West Thirty-fourth Street from March 15, 1932, to the end of February, 1942. The rentals, as recorded in the Register's office yesterday, will be $20,000 for the first two years, $21,000 for the next three and $23,000 for the last five years.

No change of financial mood greeted the new month. Stocks continued their slow decline in a dull, colorless market, while bonds felt the impact of heavy liquidation in spots. Commodities were under pressure, most of them losing ground. The more important foreign exchanges were firm.

A revision of the contract bridge rules to make them uniform in Great Britain and the United States, which is likely to be marked by a change in the scoring greatly increasing the penalties for non-vulnerable sets, as a means of discouraging "psychic" or bluff bidding, will probably be adopted by early Fall, It became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Governor Roosevelt of New York today was indirectly put on record against the proposal in the tax bill to revalue estates.

Appointments to the ways and means committee of the Greater New York Teachers Economy Committee, were announced yesterday by Augustus Ludwig, president of the Brooklyn Teachers Association, at a meeting at the Unity Club, Brooklyn. Mr. Ludwig also heads the economy committee.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 2. -- On the eve of important primaries, Governor Roosevelt continued today to abjure politics, but a favorable omen was found in his new house.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- Testimony that a $2,400,000,000 issue of new money would upset the national currency and impair Federal Reserve banking control was the opposition's last word today against redemption of veterans' bonus certificates.

The wide range of school objectives in the United States gives an impression of "a confused professional mind," but Dr. SUZZALO, in his report as president of the Carnegie Foundation, does not agree to this. Rather is it to him a clear indication of free choice and free experimentation, and he holds that these are to be preferred to "the simplified orders of a political or educational bureaucracy."

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Rehabilitation work in the Shanghai area still awaits the formal cessation of hostilities and evacuation of Japanese troops, which number about 40,000 in the Shanghai-Woosung section, according to a report received at the Commerce Department today from Acting Commercial Attache Smith at Shanghai.

In the election address made by Premier TARDIEU early in April, he made a strong plea for what might be called political concentration. He deplored the existence of so many parties, or groups, separated from each other by fine-spun and almost unintelligible distinctions.
Jockey Mack Garner, one of the Veterans of the saddle, scored a triple at Jamaica yesterday with the Geneseo Stable's Winning Ways and Joseph E. Wldener's Hastipast and Mr. Sponge.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 (AP). -- Steel production will pick up slightly in Alabama this week with resumption, of operations in two open-hearth furnaces of the Gulf States Steel Company at Gadsden.

Proposals to provide adequate medical care by health insurance and the establishing of community groups were made yesterday by public health leaders at a meeting in the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue.

Sixteen, persons and one newspaper were Included in the 1932 Pulitzer awards for outstanding achievements in letters, journalism and scholarship, which were announced yesterday by Columbia University.

A strong finish that more than off set Columbia's erratic start enabled the Lions to come through to a 10-9 victory over Dartmouth yesterday at Baker Field in the tenth inning. The triumph kept the Morningside nine in the running for the Eastern Inter-collegiate League championship.

PARIS, May 3. -- Although they lost the first round of the electoral battle. Premier Andre Tardieu and his followers are far from having given up the fight. Tomorrow evening the Premier will broadcast a speech from his room, and the whole governmental press unites today in urging his supporters not to abandon hope.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The omnibus economy bill now before Congress contains a provision which I believe has been distressingly miscalculated, not only as to its intended saving but as to the hardships it would impose, to say nothing of the fact that it would constitute a breach of faith on the part of the government on a par with repudiation of a bond issue.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, May 3 (AP). -- The League of Nations commission investigating Sino-Japanese affairs today began assembling material on the organization of Manchoukuo, the Japanese sponsored State that was recently formed with Henry Pu-Yi, former boy Emperor of China, as its head.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3. -- More vigorous enforcement of the Eighteenth Amendment and more equitable reorganization of the entire industrial system as between capital and labor were some of the demands made here today by the Bishops in their episcopal address to the Thirty-first Quadrennial Delegated Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the Municipal Auditorium.

With support in both houses from a few insurgent Republicans, the Democrats adopted a bill to amend the Hawley-Smoot tariff of 1930. It is predicted in Washington that it will he vetoed by the President. But it has a certain interest as showing the position of the Congressional wing of the Democratic party.

A new issue of $5,000,000 Nassau County (N.Y.) hospital, road and land purchase bonds, the larges piece of municipal financing on this week's calendar, was awarded yesterday at a price of 101.69 for the bonds as 4 1/2s, equivalent to about a 4.37 per cent basis.

Shoe retailers were strongly urged to substitute emphasis on quality and style for "destructive price competition" by various speakers at the joint style conference of the shoe and leather industries at the Hotel Astor yesterday. At the same time expressions of confidence were placed in Fall business, when the forecasts of leading shoe fashions and colors for Fall and Winter were offered for the consideration of the industry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3. -- Led by a varsity crew which made up in power what it lacked in rowing finesse, Harvard today opened its 1932 rowing season by sweeping the Charles River in four brushes against M.I.T. crews.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Savings to New York State of $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 may result from the action of the Senate Finance Committee today in striking out the estate revaluation clause of the House tax bill, according to a letter from Lieut. Gov. Lehman and a memorandum by Mark Graves, director of the New York State Budget, appearing in the Congressional Record.

One of the important features of the forthcoming Southampton social season will be the return of the Hampton Players. The organization was founded and is directed by Henry Codman Potter, grandson of the late Right Rev. Henry Codman Potter, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

First testimony here on the collapse of the $1,000,000,000 match empire established by Ivar Kreuger before his recent suicide in Paris revealed yesterday that Lee, Higginson Co., who handled the American financing, did so without ever seeing the foreign, concessions Kreuger claimed as assets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to take decided issue with the contents of the letter of Edwin J. Schlessinger, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the subject of bondholders depositing their bonds with protective committees.

The same four players who constituted the United States Davis Cup team for the opening-round tie with Canada were named again yesterday: by Bernon S. Prentice, chairman of the Davis Cup committee and the selection committee, to oppose Mexico at New Orleans May 13. 14 and 15.

"Adventure," a glittering, fanciful pageant, with 1,000 persons in the cast, among them a group of the most noted American explorers, was unfolded before a socially brilliant audience of 15,000 in Madison Square Garden last night as a feature of the annual charity carnival in aid of the Judson Health Centre.

A heavily bearded man in a faded brown suit, who said he was a graduate of the University of Colorado and had held responsible positions as a civil engineer in this country, China, Panama and the jungles of Venezuela, was arraigned yesterday on a charge of vagrancy in Flatbush Court, where he told such a dramatic and straightforward story of his experiences that he held the attention of the crowded courtroom for nearly an hour.

Three representatives of the Russian oil industry arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to attend an international oil conference here in which the leaders of the world's major companies in the industry are to participate. In scope it will be the largest conference of its kind ever held.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 8. -- Governor Roosevelt planned to retire early tonight although aides made arrangements to receive bulletins on the results in the California, Alabama and South Dakota primaries.

The awards of merit in the art school of the National Academy of Design were announced yesterday. Francisco Roggeri who won honorable mention yesterday in the completion for the Prix de Rome in painting, was listed as the winner of a Pulitzer traveling scholarship, as was made public Tuesday by Columbia University.

KEHL, Baden, Germany, May 3 (AP). -- Paul Schwartz, the man who was forgotten for twelve years while he served as a prisoner of war on Devil's Island, Cayenne, returned to his home town today and was enthusiastically greeted by thousands of persons gathered at the railway station.
A great-great nephew of J.Q.A. Ward, one of America's best known sculptors of the last century, carried on the family tradition yesterday by winning the Prix de Rome in sculpture.

Assuming responsibility for obtaining the funds to keep 5,000 heads of families at work, 10,000 workers in the Block-Aid campaign pushed the sale of stamps vigorously yesterday, it was announced by the Block Community Organization.

Net loss of 164 Class 1 railways, including seventeen switching and terminal companies, was $19,647,355 after taxes and charges in February, against a net loss of $10,054,622 in February, 1931, according to figures filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LONDON, May 3. -- Three adult skeletons and skulls of the Neanderthal type have been discovered in Palestine by the joint expedition of the British School of Archaeology at Jerusalem and the American School of Prehistoric Research.
BERLIN, May 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

PRAGUE, May 3. -- The Czechoslovak crown having been officially tied to the United States dollar, the passing of the Goldsborough bill by the House of Representatives caused much excitement in Prague today. The National Bank stated that even if the bill became a law it could have no influence on Czech currency because the crown was bound by law to gold.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Senator Wagner's "emergency peace loan" proposal was endorsed by Professor Edwin R.A. Seligman of Columbia University in a letter to the Senator which the latter presented to the Senate today. Professor Seligman expressed the opinion that Senator Wagner is "on the right track" in the proposal for an enlarged publicworks program at this time to help solve the unemployment situation.

The need of an emergency fund to continue the work of the Biblical Seminary in New York, an interdenominational graduate school at 235 East Forty-ninth Street, was emphasized yesterday at a meeting called by a group of the board of trustees of the institution at the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 3 (AP). -- Three receivers were appointed in Chancery Court today for the Appalachian Gas Corporation, a holding concern controlling numerous public utilities. The receivership bill was filed by Theodore W. Hauer of Drexel Hill, Pa., owner of 500 shares of the corporation's common stock.

The monthly index number of average prices compiled by Dun's Review, as of May 1, shows decrease during April of 2 1-3 per cent. Since the beginning of the present year the Dun average has declined 3 7/8 per cent. As compared with a year ago, the reduction is 9 1/2 per cent.

Final ceremonies in the Lewis Carroll centennial celebration at Columbia University will be held today, the eightieth birthday of Mrs. Reginald Liddell Hargreaves, the original "Alice," in the University Gymnasium at 4 P.M. Mrs. Hargreaves, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and Professor Harry M. Ayres will speak.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP). -- The league-leading Boston Braves evened the series with the Phils today by winning 9 to 4.

The Columbia freshman track team defeated the New York University yearlings, 58 -- 55, yesterday at Baker Field. The Lions were leading, 53 -- 51, when the javelin throw, the last event on the program, was held, and the victory of Mario Vigezzi assured the Lions the victory in the meet.
CHICAGO, May 3. -- Alphonse (Scarface Al) Capons was whisked from the Cook County jail to the Dear-born Street Station late tonight and started on his way to the Federal penitentiary at Atlanta.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Resolutions sanctioning a group of proposed strikes in the dress and suit industries were introduced at the convention of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union here today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 3. -- Farmers from all parts of Iowa unanimously declared themselves here today in favor of a "farm holiday," during which they plan neither to buy nor to sell in an attempt to raise the level of farm prices.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The question of legalizing beer with a 4 per cent alcoholic content was put before the Senate when a majority of the Manufactures Committee reported the Bingham bill unfavorably, with a minority comprising Senators Metcalf, Barbour, La Follette and Bulkley making a favorable report.

The Bronx Borough contests of the New York Music Week Association's present series will open tomorrow night at P.S. 63 and continue through the week. All these sessions will be devoted to hearings of piano contestants who competed successfully in the recent Bronx district contests.

The first-degree murder trial of three youths for the shooting of a speakeasy owner in his West Fifty-seventh Street establishment in a hold-up on Jan. 7 was in progress in General Sessions yesterday when one of the defendants, William J. Turner, 21 years old, began to play solitaire on the table beside the five defense lawyers.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America yesterday, David Sarnoff, president of the company, issued a report for the first quarter of 1932 showing a net income of $503,224 after depreciation, charges, taxes and amortization of patents, compared with 11,566,519 in the first quarter of 1931.

GENEVA, May 3. -- Revision of the London Naval Treaty, which limits the fleets of the United States, Britain and Japan, was advocated today by France, which, with Italy, has declined to enter into this convention.

BERLIN, May 3. -- The adoption of the Goldsborough bill by the United States House of Representatives yesterday has revived the old fight between the inflationists and deflationists of Germany. While the former see a new hope that the world may be salvaged through determined inflation in the United States, the latter condemn the move as an unfortunate mistake by Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The entrance of the United States into the World Court was advocated tonight by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, in an address before the American Conference on Institutions for the Establishment of International Justice, which is being held under the auspices of the American Peace Society.
Two thoroughbreds, each of which had a perfect record at the meeting, attempted to score a fourth victory in succession at Jamaica yesterday, but only one of them succeeded.

LONDON, May 3 (Canadian Press). -- J.H. Thomas, Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, announced in the House of Commons today that seven business advisers would accompany the United Kingdom's delegation, to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Decision to raise $15,000,000 by floating a municipal bond issue at 5 per cent, the highest interest rate allowed since shortly after the war was reached today at a conference of Mayor J. Hampton Moore and several other city officials.

George W. Wickersham said in a prepared address last night that twelve of the reports of the National Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement, which he handed to President Hoover a year ago, had received little or no attention, due to the overwhelming public interest in the two reports that concerned prohibition.

TRENTON, N.J., May 3. -- Charles L. Carrick of Jersey City, an advisory master, was named as a special master by Chancellor Edwin R. Walker today to Investigate the administration of receiverships and other trust estates in New Jersey. The State Bar Association and the Committee of 100 had requested the inquiry.

DUBLIN, May 3 (AP). -- The de Valera Government of the Irish Free State threw out tonight in the Bail Eireann two Opposition amendments that would have modified its bill to abolish the oath of allegiance to the British crown.

Prohibition in the West. Four years ago, in the Republican, convention at Kansas City, Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER made an eloquent plea for an amendment to the party platform favoring repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A three-year loan of $2,698,630 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the receivers of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The money is to be used to pay $1,748,629 in overdue preferred claims, and a bond maturity of $950,000.

The strike of 30,000 to 40,000 building mechanics which began on Monday tightened yesterday when building contractors decided to dispense with the services of members of three unions who had remained at work.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I note in THE TIMES a very sensible communication headed "Ages of Criminals," signed by Alexander Kadison.

The Firewood Fleet was destroyed by the police yesterday at the foot of East Tenth Street and it was the fault, of Willie Muzuka and John Maine, more or less, although they didn't think their little trip out into East River would have any such result.

Sports insignia were awarded to 118 City College athletes yesterday at the annual Charter Day exercises at the Lewisohn Stadium. Professor Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, presided, and Graduate Manager of Athletics Walter Williamson supervised the awarding of the insignia.

MADRID, May 3 (AP). -- A decree intended to modernize further the Spanish Army and make it more efficient through widespread changes in the method of selecting and promoting officers was submitted to the National Assembly, the Cortes, for its approval today by Premier Manuel Azana.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3. -- Vice Chancellor John H. Backes directed the receivers for the Earl Radio Corporation today to drop the proposed suits against former officers and directors of the company for the losses caused by alleged improper management. Representatives of creditors urged that there was little chance of recovery through the suits and that the money left in the estate should be saved.

Four leading banking institutions here will offer at auction tomorrow, for a minimum sum of $10,325,000, substantial blocks of shaves of the Commonwealth Edison Company, the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.

MONTREAL, May 3 (Canadian Press). -- Eight thousand saw the Royals of Montreal open their home season today and defeat the Reading Keys, 12 -- 6. The Royals got sixteen hits off three Key hurlers, six of which were for extra bases. Walters and Ripple hit homers as Claset held the visitors to seven scattered hits and two earned runs.
BERLIN, May 3 (AP). -- A Cabinet reorganization that would increase the conservative representation in the German Government appeared imminent today.

The last of the Tuesday night concerts of the present season by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of 200 players took place yesterday evening in the Metropolitan Opera House before a packed theatre. The conductor was Eugene Goossens. There were three soloists, the pianists Myra Hess, Harold Bauer and Ernest Sehelling, They played the Bach triple piano concerto and were forced to play the last movement as an encore.

TORONTO, May 3 (Canadian Press). -- Toronto opened its home season today with a 1-0 victory over the International League leaders, the Newark Bears, before a crowd of 9,000. The only run of the game was scored in the third inning when the Leafs bunched a single by Guy Cantrell, Morehart's double and a line single by Fritz.

LONDON, May 3. -- The stock markets opened the new account today confidently and with some bright features. British funds rose sharply on the terms of the new treasury issue. It is believed a period of cheap money is assured.

Helen Kane, describing herself as an actress "who uses in her speech and songs an exaggerated lisp and a childish voice and manner, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday against Max Fleischer, the Fleischer Studios, Inc., and the Paramount Publix Corporation, asking $250,000 damages and an order perpetually enjoining the defendants from exhibiting "Betty Boop" animated cartoons.

WITH the Olympic treasury filling but slowly and Messrs, Nurmi and Ladoumegue under suspension as amateur athletes, this is no time to be casting any further shadow over the coming Olympic Games at Los Angeles. Yet the esteemed John T. McGovern, barrister-at-law and one of the compilers of the famous Carnegie Foundation Bulletin No. 23, is out now with a report that will shake the amateur world to its very Carnegie foundations.

While the passage by the House of Representatives of the Goldsborough bill, with its inflationary portents, may have influenced to some extent yesterday's tracing on the Stock Exchange, the continued weakness was attributed mainly to the intangible anxieties and uncertainties that have acted as a depressant for some time.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Ten months of the fiscal year ended April 30 with a government deficit or $2,334,105,142 and indications of an excess of expenditures over receipts of $2,000,900,000 to $3,231,747,800 or more for the year, according to figures made available today.

In a hundred university laboratories physicists are hammering atoms, hoping to solve the riddle of matter. The latest and most successful of these assaults is that made by Drs. COCKROFT and WALTON of Cambridge, England. Their master, RUTHERFORD, had broken down more than a dozen elements by bombarding their nuclei with high-speed alpha particles given off by radium and driving out hydrogen nuclei from all.

When men at work in the navy yards have been, dropped, members of Congress have waited on Secretary ADAMS to protest. "All Boston," it was said last October, "is "aroused over the proposed abandonment of the Charlestown Navy "Yard."

SHANGHAI, May 3. -- In a coup at Canton tonight General Chen Chiatang, who is opposed to the Nanking regime, seized control of the fleet and air forces stationed there, while Admiral Chan Chak, who had been favorable to Nanking, made his escape to Hongkong.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The House passed the Economy Committee's omnibus economy bill by a vote of 316 to 67 tonight with only $38,124,000 left of the original estimated savings of $206,000,000 in expenditures during the 1933 fiscal year.

Governor Roosevelt sent a message to the Museum of Modern Art, which opened yesterday its new home at 11 West Fifty-third Street. Many members of the museum and invited guests visited the building throughout the day. The museum will be open to the public starting today.

A fresh break in sugar futures, with the May contract selling down to 0.53 cent, with a final bid of 0.52, featured trading in commodity markets yesterday. Other options lost 1 to 2 points. Grains also declined, but elsewhere the market showed evidence of strength by reason of a sharp rally in cocoa, coffee, rubber and hides. In the spot market, corn, rye and printcloths established new lows for the year.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Democratic and Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee joined today in replying to Representative Patman of Texas, who in a plea before the committee for the soldiers' bonus attacked Secretary Mills.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, May 4. -- Returns from 2,308 precincts out of 10,271 in California's Presidential primary last night gave for the Democratic preference: Roosevelt, 37,620; Smith, 37,178; Garner, 33,719.

Governor Roosevelt now has pledged to him or instructed for him 275 delegates of the 1,154 to the national convention, counting 10 from South Dakota and 24 from Alabama elected yesterday. California returns are insufficient to determine the result.

Following the sharp recovery of more than a quarter cent late on Monday, prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously yesterday in a range of $1 a bale and closed 2 to 6 points higher on the day.

ROCHESTER. N.Y., May 3 (AP). -- Rochester lost to Jersey City, 6 to 5, in sixteen innings in the opening day baseball game here, a crowd of more than 15,000 being rewarded with three hours, 15 minutes of sensational play.

Although the Board of Higher Education will cooperate to the utmost in the present city economy program, it will not curtail in any way the scope of the municipal colleges so long as there remains a possibility of effecting savings in other departments of government, Mark Eisner, chairman of the board, said yesterday at the eighty-fifth annual observance of the granting of a charter to City College.

After a two-and-a-half-hour session behind closed doors at the Hotel Governor Clinton yesterday, the Lord's Day Alliance of New York State, for forty-two years an auxiliary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States, announced it had severed its relationship with the national body and planned to reorganize as the Lord's Day League of New York.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 3. -- The second annual festival of American music, sponsored by the Eastman School of Music, was opened tonight in the Eastman Theatre with a concert by the Eastman School Symphony Orchestra of 100 players and the Eastman School chorus of 250 voices.

Officials of the racing associations which conduct meetings in this State were unanimous yesterday in their statements that a tax of 25 per cent on admissions to the race tracks would end racing here.

BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP). -- Danny McAuliffe, veteran jockey, badly injured when he was thrown from Sun. Meadow after the horse had won the feature event at Pimlico today, was weighed in the arms of a track official at the hospital to which he was taken to make the victory stand.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3. -- With Captain Eddie Warren, who last Summer lost his left arm in a motorboat accident, making his season's debut in right field, Yale today scored an easy victory over Wesleyan, 15 to 2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP). -- Knebelkamp and Morris's Adobe Post added to the pre-Derby confusion when he easily defeated ten other eligibles for the classic in the Preparation Purse at Churchill Downs today.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,177,500 barrels, compared with 2,267,900 in the preceding week, a decrease of 90,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production cast of California averaged 1,659,900 barrels daily, against 1,747,600 in the previous week, a decrease of 87,700.

A lower death rate was registered for the first quarter of 1932 among the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's industrial policy holders in the United States and Canada than ever had been recorded for a first quarter before, the company announced yesterday, pointing out that 1931 had been the healthiest entire year on record for the same group.

"Merry-Go-Round," a melodrama of political corruption, was scheduled to open last night at the Avon Theatre. It did not. Instead, five policemen and several plain-clothes men were at the door, sent there to see that no one entered. The official reason given for the failure of the play to go on was that the owners of the house had not asked for a renewal of the license in time.

Only by "some wise and judicious means of limiting the number of births" can the world hope to find a permanent solution for the difficulties arising from overpopulation, overproduction and unemployment, Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, president of the American Museum of Natural History, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Sponsors of the Goldsborough credit and currency expansion bill, adopted in the House yesterday by a vote of almost five to one, predicted today it would get through the Senate, despite administration opposition. They contended the bill had been stripped of radical features while under consideration by the House Banking and Currency Committee and in its present form was neither revolutionary nor super-inflationary.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 3. -- Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, tenth in the national ranking, and Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers gained the semi-final round of the Westchester County tennis championship today on the clay courts of Briarcliff Lodge.

The Giants were all set to extend to the Robins the exclusive rights to the cellar berth in the National League in the concluding clash of their two games at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the Robins, suddenly becoming aware of what was being perpetrated upon them, kicked up a terrific furor In the ninth inning to wipe out a four-run deficit.

The "policies of prudence" followed by bankers and for which they have been criticized are the highest form of public service in the existing conditions, the economic policy commission of the American Bankers Association declares in a statement issued yesterday in reply to charges that a business revival had been held back because bankers were overcautious in extending credit.

Through the cross-examination yesterday of Herman A. Metz, former City Controller, attorneys for Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, were able to bring before the jury, in advance of the opening of the defense's case, one of the merger proposals by which Mr. Broderick had hoped to save the Sank of United States.

The Manual Training High School nine defeated Erasmus Hall High in a ten-inning P.S.A.L. game at Erasmus Field yesterday, 8 to 7. Erasmus scored a run in the tenth, but Manual came back to tally twice.

The burlesque at the Republic Theatre, in West Forty-second street, was defended by comparison with Broadway musical shows yesterday at the hearing before License Commissioner James F. Geraghty on the applications of the Republic and the Eltinge, another burlesque house, for lenewals of their licenses.

After listening to three shrill acts of "Broadway Boy," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening, you are likely to suspect that show business is not one of the elegant occupations. Wallace A. Manheimer and Isaac Paul, who are the authors, have set down in chronological order the various dilemmas of backstage madness on the eve of a Broadway opening.

OTTAWA, May 3 (Canadian Press). -- While the Canadian delegation at the disarmament conference in Geneva has not lost hope that some good may be accomplished by the deliberations there, nothing from it in the form of a report that could be presented to enlighten the House of Commons has been received.

With Grand Master Charles H. Johnson, State Commissioner of Public Welfare, officiating, the Grand Lodge of the Order of Free and Accepted Masons opened its 151st annual communication yesterday in the Hotel Astor and closed the first day's activities at a dinner given for the Grand Master by his staff.

The human ear grows less sensitive, particularly to the higher sound frequencies, from decade to decade between the ages of 26 and 60, according to a report presented before the seventh meeting of the Acoustical Society of America by J.B. Kelly and H.C. Montgomery of the Bell Telephone laboratories.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Although receiving sixteen bases on balls from the "Washington pitchers, the Yankees could muster only six hits today and were beaten, 5 to 4. The "setback sent the Yanks from third into fourth place in the standing, half a game behind the Detroit Tigers, who were idle today.

According to the report of the Bay Shore Boatmen's Association, the fishermen were out in reassuring numbers on Great South Bay despite the cold wind, driving rain, fog and rough water on Sunday. Twenty-one well-crowded boats left Bay Shore. One of the largest catches included 870 flounders, brought back by a party of sixty fishermen.

The depression and the restoration of prosperity will be a vital issue in the coming Presidential campaign, according to Julian Mason, editor of The New York Evening Post, and Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who were interviewed last night on "The Party and the Issues" by Ruth Morgan, vice president of the National League of Women Voters, over the WJZ network of the National Broadcasting Company.

To the Editor at The New York Times: An editorial in THE TIMES which was captioned "Hot and Rebellious Youth" attributes the origin of Rebel Arts to a seasonal effusion, of raw youth. Further, it states that the enthusiasm of the rebels is one breathing revolt against everything.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation offered yesterday to acquire the Nevada Consolidated Copper Company by an exchange of one share of its stock for two of Nevada outstanding. The Utah Copper Company, of which Kennecott owns about 98 per cent of the outstanding stock, has about 45 per cent of the capital stock of Nevada.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Elimination from the House revenue bill of the one-fourth of 1 per cent stock transfer tax was voted today by the Senate Finance Committee. The levy thereupon was set at a flat rate of four cents a share, as recommended by the Treasury.
NEW YORK. Vice Admiral William S. Sims, U. S. N., retired, is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Charles Page Perin at 640 Park Avenue.

Money market was quiet. The little business reported represented routine requirements, all of which was done at quotations which have prevailed for some time. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent, but street trades were arranged at 2, as on Monday.

Their fears of inflation revived by the passage by the House of Representatives of the Goldsborough bill to reduce the purchasing power of the dollar, European markets yesterday sold dollar exchange, driving the United States currency down below the gold export point in terms of French, Dutch, Swiss and Belgian money.

Mr. Caparn Favors Course Which Could Be Used for Other Purposes. To the Editor of The New York Times: In reference to THE TIMES editorial which quotes with approval the view that an eighteen-hole golf course is not included in the newest "layout" for the Jacob Riis Park, because the intensity of land use would be too low," I offer the following comments:

The National Employment Exchange, 30 Church Street, which was organized twenty-one years ago, with the backing of some of the nation's largest financiers, as a charitable enterprise through which the unemployed could find jobs, is about to be put into liquidation.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A bill authorizing a "gigantic public works program," involving a maximum of $5,000,000,000, which the Federal Government would undertake as an unemployment relief measure, was introduced in the House today by Representative Black of New York.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP). -- Connie Mack's prize hurling corps got back into winning ways today and George Earnshaw pitched the Philadelphians to a 6-to-1 victory over the Red Sox. Earnshaw held the Red Sox down to four hits, and the Athletics' triumph gave them the second and final game of their series here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After nine years of bewildering debate there is at last some hope for action which will enable the United States to support the World Court. The resolution introduced in the House of Representatives by Mr. Linthicum, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, calls for an appropriation to enable the United States to pay a fair share of the court's expenses.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- Grain exports last week from the United States amounted to 2,649,000 bushels, against 2,603,000 the previous week and 608,000 during the corresponding week of last year. Commerce Department figures today gave the following comparisons between last week's exports and those of the week before: Wheat, 2,041,000, against 2,365,000 last week and 514,000 last year; Barley, 10,000, against 64,000; corn, 26,000 against 159,000; oats, 6,000, against 15,000; rye, 566,000, against none.

Reductions of steamship passenger rates were extended to the intercoastal field with the announcement yesterday by the Panama Pacific Line, a subsidiary of the International Mercantile Marine Company, that rates from 18 to 45 per cent below those now charged would become effective May 8.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- Three adult skeletons of the Neanderthal race have just been found near Athlit. Palestine, by Theodore D. McCown, according to a cablegram received today by Professor George Grant MacCurdy of Yale University, director of the American School of Prehistoric Research.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 3 (AP). -- A young woman, dressed in black, was shot dead here today as she fled from a drug store holdup.

There was no change yesterday in the trend of the various markets. Stocks went fractionally lower and irregular concessions on the bond market continued, with foreign securities perhaps showing smaller changes than usual. The wheat market moved uncertainly; rising at first on lower private estimates for the Winter crop than had been expected, then losing all the gain.
BUFFALO, May 3 (AP). -- Before approximately 20,000 fans, the largest crowd to witness a baseball opening here in league history, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Bisons today by a score of 7 to 2.

Through the entire history of America booms and depressions have run as regularly as a normal pulse, and the present depression will be ended by a boom Just as all the others have been, James Truslow Adams, historian and former Wall Street broker, said in an interview yesterday.

With amateur boxing champions from all over the country and Hawaii on edge for the competition, the Amateur Athletic Union's national championship tournament will get under way tonight in Madison Square Garden.

Thirteen of the sixteen directors of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., were re-elected at the tenth annual meeting of the bureau yesterday at 280 Broadway. The three new members are Neil Petree, president, James McCreery Co.; Walter Hammitt of Frederick Loeser Co. and Bernard Lichtenberg of Amos Parrish Co.

Mayor Walker's reply to the recent demand of Controller Charles W. Berry for a "real city economy program from the Mayor's office" was expressed yesterday in the Mayor's disclosure that more than $4,000,000 had been saved in the current budget and that work on a program of new sources of revenue had been going on under his direction since last January, when the Board of Estimate passed its economy resolutions.

Glenway Wescott, who at the age of 30 has been for five years a spectacular figure in modern fiction, turned his attention from fictional situations to the world crisis when he wrote "Fear and Trembling," published by Harpers today. The thick new book grew out of an automobile tour through Europe during which the young writer decided that in a world of confusion a new conception of truth is necessary for personal and national salvation.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 3. -- Winnie Wilson allowed Duke only three hits today as the Princeton varsity baseball team defeated the Southerners, 4 to 3, on a first-inning rally which produced four runs.

Dr. Samuel Buchler, lawyer and former Jewish chaplain at Sing Sing prison, was denounced as a "religious racketeer," who had "dragged his rabbinical robes through mud," by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney, in summing up the State's case yesterday at Buchler's General Sessions trial on one of five grand larceny indictments.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- After two Says of determined opposition, principally by Senators from inland States, the Hale bill authorizing building of the Navy up to the limits at the London treaty won preferred status in the Senate late today by a vote of 46 to 25.

Declaring that the Democratic party was a local and not a national party, former Governor Alfred E. Smith appealed last night for contributions to the so-called Democratic victory fund, said that the party should pay the $320,000 it owed to John J. Raskob, National Chairman, and denounced as false reports that the drive was being used for the benefit of any particular candidate for the Presidential nomination.

Suit to foreclose a mortgage covering the Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue at Forty-sixth Street and the adjoining Park-Lexington Building at 247 Park Avenue was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Empire Trust Company as trustee for the bonds issued under the $5,500,000 mortgage.

PELHAM MANOR, N.T., May 3. -- More than 400 men who run the trains, and J.J. Pelrey, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, joined at the Hunter Island Inn tonight in paying tribute to Hubert J. Reynolds of this village, who attained the fifty-year mark today in the service of the railroad.

BERLIN, May 3. -- The Boerse was firm throughout the day, there being gains of 1 to 3 per cent. The weekly statement of the Reichsbank showing a small increase in gold reserves made a favorable impression and the initial nervousness caused by a report of the status of the Federal Railroad Company was overcome soon.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP). -- Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, who won twenty-six games last season for Houston, won his first game for the Cardinals this year when he pitched St. Louis to a 9-to-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. The Cardinals made it two in a row over the Reds.

Withdrawal of the two pending applications for bus franchises in Manhattan, involving extensive motorization of existing surface car lines, loomed yesterday unless the Board of Estimate takes early action on the proposals.
TOKYO, May 3. -- With signature of the armistice at Shanghai in sight, officials here show less concern regarding a round-table conference, and apparently are indifferent as to when it shall meet.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Senator Frazier, one of the dryest of the drys in Congress, unwittingly yielded time on the Senate floor today while verses advocating the legalization of beer were read.
PITTSBURGH, May 3 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs rallied for five runs in the seventh inning today and tripped the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 to 6.

With Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare expected here from Philadelphia this morning, the members of the women's golf team which will represent the United States in the international matches against the British, will assemble today and sail tonight aboard the Berengaria for England.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today reported the Grosser Airship bill, authorizing the Postmaster General to enter into contracts with builders of lighter-than-air craft for transoceanic mail service.

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 3. -- While the United States Airship Akron, largest in the world, cruised through sunny skies today at a speed varying from fifty knots upward, Naval Lieutenants D.W. Harrigan and H.L. Young, flying two of the new little "spider" planes, made fifteen successful take-offs and "hook-ons" from the bar by which they were lowered from the hangar within the body of the airship.

In the old Greek days time was reckoned by Olympiads -- the recurrence at regular intervals of the Olympic Games. In their modern revival the old interval is kept, but they are held in various centres of the Western world. This year the Winter games were an added feature, for Elis had no snow or ice -- Prometheus had to be sent to the snowy Caucasus -- and took place in the Adirondacks.

The Whitney Museum of American Art announces for next November the first of a series of group exhibitions devoted to contemporary American painting, these exhibitions to be held thereafter biennially. It promises to represent a service to the public somewhat similar to that performed every two years at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington.

Park Commissioner Albert C. Benninger of Queens assured Rockaway civic leaders yesterday that no plan for the development of Jacob Riis Park would be adopted that did not provide for a golf course, according to Henry A. Soffer, regional director for Riis Park of the Park Association of New York City.

A request of Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, to increase from $124,000 to $239,000 that part of his department's 1932 budget pertaining to personal service schedules in connection with work on the Triborough Bridge was reported out favorably by the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

Hold-up men and burglars visited two widely separated offices of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in busy sections of the Bronx yesterday. In one place three armed men lined up seven employes and fled with $4,500 just a few minutes before the money was to be deposited in a bank in the same building.

Buyers Showed Increase for Week. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an Increase over the figures for the previous week but remained practically the same as for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 3 (AP). -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt pulled ahead tonight on widely scattered returns from Alabama's Democratic primary and, unless later boxes upset the early trend, he seemed assured of the State's twenty-four votes at the national convention.

The Equitable Coach Company, in which State Senator John A. Hastings was to have received a third interest, aimed at control of the city's entire surface transportation system, it was indicated yesterday at a public hearing of the Hofstadter committee.

It is not easy to take seriously the vote of the House on the Goldsborough bill to mark up prices -- or, as the bill itself declares in its title, "for restoring and maintaining the purchasing power of the dollar." Even the author of the measure appeared to shrink from its possible implications.

PARIS, May 3. -- The trend of prices was higher on the Bourse today. After yesterday's alarm over the election it was concluded today that apparently everything was not going wrong in France. Exterior influences, however, were encouraging. The feature of today's trading was the strength of the metal market.

HONOLULU, May 3. -- The interest of those connected with the Fortescue-Massie case now centres on Washington and public opinion on the mainland. The measure introduced in Congress to pardon Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and also the bill removing the restriction on retrials in cases where the jury has disagreed are being followed closely.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- Two measures resulting from the Massie attack case in Hawaii will be considered by the House Judiciary Committee in executive session Thursday. It reached that decision today after hearing Seth W. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General, who has made a survey of conditions in Hawaii.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns stole a trick or two of the Indians' stuff today and pounded the tribe into submission, 11 to 8, under a barrage of sixteen base hits. The defeat halted a Cleveland winning streak that had run to nine games.

MIAMI, Fla., May 3 (AP). -- While a county grand jury scanned two purported suicide notes which Captain W.N.
