Lancaster admitted forging, the British flier, held in jail on a first degree murder warrant, tonight debated his "tough breaks" and expressed the wish that he could be his own attorney in event he is indicted for the murder of Haden Clarke, 26-year-old author, on April 21.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Democrats of the Senate accepted today the resignation of Senator Huey Long of Louisiana from the various committees of which he has been a member, thus taking up the challenge he issued to his party a few days ago when he tendered the resignation in revolting against the leadership of Senator Robinson.

LONDON, May 3 (AP). -- Tin production in the principal tin countries will be suspended during June and July and resumed in August at the rate of 40 per cent of the present assigned quotas, it was announced today.

That Jersey county of Sussex is a good place to live in, dowered with a rich variety of rural charm. But how about its inhabitants? The revolt of youth against prohibition is but too notorious. Many old persons, feeling the need, of a gentle stimulant, have cried out against Mr. VOLSTEAD and the impertinence so long shown, by Dr. Congress in the matter of medicinal alcohol.

LONDON, May 3. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's hope to return to Geneva soon to take part in the disarmament negotiations vanished today when his doctors gave him the choice between an Immediate operation, on his right eye or several weeks' rest as a preliminary to an operation.

Fanning thirteen batters and allowing only five scattered singles, Ken Auer, brilliant sophomore hurler, pitched Fordham to a 6 -- 2 victory over Manhattan before a crowd of 2,000 at Jasper Field yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Loans made or authorized to railroads by the Railroad Credit Corporation for meeting fixed interest obligations amounted to $18,681,159.50 as of April 30, according to the corporation's monthly report today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Reflecting the enormous liquidation of securities in April, borrowings by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange were reduced last month by $154,086,397, or from $533,103,059 on March 31 to $379,016,662 on April 30. This is the largest percentage decrease of which there is any record and the total of loans at the end of April was the smallest since the Exchange began to compile the records.

Plans to give free performances of plays and musical shows for the unemployed throughout the country, starting in the near future, will be discussed this afternoon at a conference of the National Alliance of the Theatre, which comprises every field of the legitimate stage, it was learned yesterday.
Fluctuations were irregular again in trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and, after moving in a range of 15 points, prices ended the day with losses of 8 to 13 points.

Heavy selling drove prices of bonds sharply lower yesterday in virtually all sections of the list on the Stock Exchange. United States Government issues weakened perceptibly, many domestic corporation bonds lost 1 to 10 points for the day, automatically establishing new record lows, and few foreign loans were able to make any headway in the general selling movement.

Surrogate John Hetherington of Queens dismissed yesterday charges of incompetence and misconduct in office brought by the City Affairs Committee against John Theofel, Democratic county leader of Queens and Chief Clerk of the County Surrogate's Court.

A strange world, almost as fantastic as the stories that Lewis Carroll used to tell her, was revealed yesterday afternoon to the original "Alice," Mrs. Reginald Liddell Hargreaves, on her eightieth birthday, when she was the guest of honor at the closing ceremonies of Columbia University's celebration of the hundredth anniversary of Lewis Carroll's birth, held in the university gymnasium.

The plight of the textile industry and the low price of cotton are due to the industry's being 100 years behind the times, it having failed to utilize modern research methods to find new uses for cotton by developing new textile fabrics.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The exhibition of architectural drawings and book decorations designed by the late Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue, at the Architectural League, should not be allowed to pass without some word of tribute to the outstanding and consummate artist that he was.

A hearing which started yesterday before Surrogate James A. Foley to determine whether the late Ella Wendel was a legal resident of New York County or of Westchester was abruptly adjourned when the first witness, Charles G. Koss, counsel for the Wendels and executor, beneficiary and temporary administrator of the estate, collapsed on the witness stand from a heart attack.

United States Coast Guards made two seizures off the New Jersey coast yesterday. One was the rumrunner Whichone, a speedy craft that has come under the Federal eye before, and the second was a small and swift cruiser marked K25235, which contained Charles (Vannie) Higgins, a well-known lobster fisherman.

Charles W. Berry, City Controller, appeared yesterday as a witness before the Hofstadter committee and delivered a series of resounding blows at Mayor Walker and John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.
Following is another of the signs of the approaching weakfish season at Poconic Bay:

LAKEHURST, N.J., May 4 -- With 100 persons on board, the United States airship Akron made a cruise today over the New Jersey seaboard, Philadelphia and Atlantic City to demonstrate to members of the Naval Affairs Committee of Congress that she was an airworthy unit in the navy's forces.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity shows a further advance, the figure for the week ended April 30 being 25.4, as against 24.2 for the preceding week and 54.1 for the corresponding week last year. The increase is attributed almost exclusively to increased Ford requirements, demand from other consumers continuing sluggish.
CHICAGO, May 4. -- Miriam Hopkins, motion picture actress, adopted a baby boy today from the Evanston Cradle Society in a brief hearing before County Judge Jarecki.

Apparently in an effort to learn what connection, if any, there is between brokerage houses and pool operations, the New York Stock Exchange, in a new questionnaire, has directed that daily reports be submitted to its business conduct committee of all puts and calls on listed securities issued or endorsed by member firms.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Protest against the second-class postal rate increase, which was voted yesterday by the Senate Finance Committee and tentatively made a part of the permanent revenue structure of the country today, was laid before that body today by the organized newspaper publishers.

The estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical producer, which was believed to be worth nearly $75,000,000 at the time of his death on March 7, 1930, is worth $124.20 in cash plus $1,270,252 in debts "uncollected or uncollectable," according to an intermediate accounting filed yesterday by Saul J. Baron, temporary administrator of the estate.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Huck Betts won his third straight victory for the Boston Braves when he shut out the Phils today, 3 to 0, allowing only four hits.

PARIS, May 4. -- The passage of the Goldsborough till and the wreckage the House made of the economy bill at Washington has aroused new fears in Paris regarding the possibility of inflation in the United States.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- Two new directors were elected by the Cotton Belt Railway here today: Henry W. deForest of Oyster Bay, N.Y., chairman of the board of the Southern Pacific, which recently took over the Cotton Belt, and Walter Douglas of New York.

A woman suffered a minor leg injury and nineteen other persons, including home-going high school students, were slightly hurt shortly before 6 o'clock last evening when the Webster Avenue trolley car in which they were riding bumped into a car ahead near the intersection of Webster Avenue and East 179th Street, the Bronx.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Today we have factions in our business and professional life taking decidedly opposite views on important questions without any apparent good reason, and it seems hard to say whether these opinions are the result of sincere convictions or merely made to favor the particular group or political party to which the holders belong or by whom they are employed.

The Kansas City Southern Railway and subsidiaries reported for 1931 a net income of $192,900 after taxes and charges, equal to 92 cents a share on 4 per cent preferred stock, against 51,452,916, or $2.04 a share on common stock, in 1930. Gross was $14,164,311, against 519,206,518.

LONDON, May 4. -- Joining the critics of the National Government who are calling for a clear definition of the official monetary policy, the Midland Bank's monthly review, which is popularly supposed to express the views of Chairman Reginald McKenna, today blames what it considers the Bank of England's deflationary monetary policy for barring the way to trade revival.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Force will be given to the arguments of the American delegation at Geneva by the passage of the Hale bill to build the United States Navy up to London and Washington treaty strength, Chairman Hale of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee declared in opening the debate on the measure this afternoon.
HONOLULU, May 4. -- Hawaii's most famous criminal case came swiftly to an end today -- so swiftly that few knew what had happened until it was all over.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A feeling of elation swept through Washington this afternoon when the commutation of sentence in the Hawaiian manslaughter case was announced. This satisfaction was immediately tempered by a wide demand that the "stigma" of even one hour's imprisonment must be removed by a full pardon for Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, Mrs. Granville Fortescue and the two sailors, E.J. Lord and Albert O. Jones.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Holding companies, especially those controlling public utilities and investment trusts, "have been frightfully misused as part and parcel of the great boom which induced the present depression," Professor W.Z. Ripley of Harvard says in an article in the current American Federationist, official organ of the American Federation of Labor.

Pompeius, 3-year-old son of Pompey and Elvina, carried the colors of W.R. Coe to a rather easy victory yesterday in the Spring Handicap, which featured the program at the Jamaica track, and thereby delighted a considerable number that fancied his chances over the Mereworth Stud's Waylayer, the generally favored entry in a field of six 3-year-olds.

The list of 117 applicants for admission to the bar, who have been instructed to appear before the committee on character and fitness for examination, was made public, yesterday. Six of the group are women. A second group whose clerkships expire before the Summer will be subjected to examination later in the month.

It has once more been discovered that the average grown-up American has the mind of a 13-year-old child. Might there not be a kindlier way of saying the same thing? Why not state that in the United States the average individual attains intellectual maturity at 13?

WASHINGTON, May, 4. -- The easy non-partisan harmony that has enabled the Senate Finance Committee to make swift progress in rewriting the billion-dollar tax bill was dashed to pieces late this afternoon on the rocks of protective tariff.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 4 -- Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas, in an address this evening before more than 5,000 delegates and visitors at the thirty-first general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in session in the Municipal Auditorium here, asserted that the Bishops' episcopal address demanding more vigorous prohibition enforcement had made a profound impression in Washington.

LONDON, May 4 (Canadian Press). -- Lord Baden-Powell, Chief Scout, who is a painter himself, was caustic today concerning this year's exhibition of the Royal Academy which opened Monday. "I was told there was a notable picture by a girl guide, aged 15, but I thought a large number of the pictures must have been by girls of 5," he said.

"Sports and Pastimes" is the title of a print exhibition current at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It remains through the month and contains a variety of pertinent themes, delightfully illustrated.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Judge Walter C. Lindley entered an order late today in the United States District Court restraining four banks at New York City from disposing of or selling collateral they hold against loans made to Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company.

VIENNA, May 4. -- Seeing without eyes is claimed to have been brought within the range of possibility by an apparatus invented by a Vienna architect, Joseph Gartloruber, and demonstrated yesterday to newspaper men and doctors.

SAN FRANCISCO. May 4. -- California Democracy swept Speaker John N. Garner of the House of Representatives from the gallery of favorite sons in yesterday's Presidential primary, giving him a smashing victory over Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith in the contest for the State's forty-four votes at the national convention.

While the testimony of A.H. Woods, theatrical producer, and that of a mother of a burlesque chorus girl supported the applications of the Republic and Eltinga Theatres for renewal of their licenses yesterday, Commissioner James F.Geraghty placed in the record two letters from church representatives protesting against the burlesque performances.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 4 The Rev. Charles W. Hinton, who served for thirteen years as rector of the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, of which J.P, Morgan is senior warden, has become a successful life insurance salesman since his resignation from the church about a year ago, it became known here today with the announcement that he would leave on Friday for Washington, D.C., to continue his business career in that city.

Phil Kennedy's thirty-five-foot shot that went through the net for a goal after three minutes of play in the ten-minute overtime session enabled the Stevens Tech lacrosse team to break a tie and subdue City College, 5-4, yesterday at the Castle Point Field in Hoboken.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 4 (AP). -- A band of seven Maryland-bred platers met at a mile and seventy yards in the featured Neighbors Purse today at Pimlico and the race provided a stirring finish when the favorite, dancing Mack, lasted to get a head decision over Bokie B. Lillybet was third, a half length further back and a scant nose in advance of Tulach Ard.

That the National Horse Show Association will carry on and will endeavor to eclipse all previous efforts with this year's exhibition was made evident at the annual meeting and election of officers held yesterday. J. Spencer Weed was elected to head the organization, with Adrian Van Sinderen as first vice president and Luther L. Blake as second vice president.

Continued weakness in sugar featured trading in commodity markets yesterday. Refined sold down to 3.77 1/2 cents, and futures, May contract, touched 0.52 cent, with a closing bid of 0.51, new all-time low levels in both instances. Grains rallied moderately, but cotton closed lower. Coffee and silk also reacted. There was a sharp advance in rubber and a slightly better range for cocoa.
Registering its seventh victory in eight starts, the Fordham University baseball team scored a 13-to-5 triumph over Duke University at Fordham Field yesterday.

The flight of foreign funds from this market, set in motion by the action of the House of Representatives on Monday in passing the Golds-borough bill to reduce the purchasing power of the dollar, gathered momentum in the foreign exchange market yesterday.

As the feature of the tenth annual observance of Boys' Day by the New York Stock Exchange, six youthful employes will direct the administration of that institution today. Fred H. Van Ness, 852 Sanford Avenue, Irvington, N.J., will temporarily supersede Richard Whitney as president.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there appeared a report of a lecture delivered by Dr. Millikan which you introduced to readers with the provocative headline, "Mad Hatter Mad? Millikan Doubts It."
PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- With flashy support, Lonnie Warneke held the Pittsburgh Pirates to six scattered hits today, enabling the Chicago Cubs to win, 4 to 1.

The Public Service Commission adopted yesterday, by a vote of 3 to 2, an order for a public hearing on June 13 on the complaint of the City Affairs Committee that the monthly charge of 25 cents imposed by the New York Telephone Company for manual or "French" telephones is excessive.

James A. Beha was re-elected yesterday general manager and counsel of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters at the annual meeting. William Leslie and A. W. Whitney were re-elected assistant general managers. E.E. Robinson, Charles J. Haugh and R.J. Rountree were formally chosen secretary, actuary and controller, respectively, which offices they have been filling for several months.

The Abbey Restaurant and Grill, 25 West Thirtieth Street, and a restaurant at 35 East Forty-third Street, both elaborately furnished and well patronized, were among thirty-two places visited yesterday by agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator.

In England during the last thirty years there has been a marked decline in the influence of book reviews, largely due to too short reviews of too many books, Arthur Waugh, an important figure in English literary circles for two generations and the father of Alec and Evelyn "Waugh, novelists, says in "One Man's Road," published today by Farrar Rinehart.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 4. -- Everett Colby of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., came today with his son, and this evening they were the guests of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. for dinner in the Homestead.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 4. -- The ponderous gates of Atlanta penitentiary closed behind Al Capone tonight as the notorious underworld leader ended his twenty-three-hour journey from Chicago prepared to be a model prisoner during the service of an eleven-year sentence for income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The United States has evolved a new foreign policy based on non-recognition of territorial gains made by any nation breaking the terms of the Kellogg pact. William R. Castle Jr., Acting Secretary of State, declared in an address before the American Conference on International Justice here tonight.

BERLIN, May 4. -- Although church and State are rigorously kept separate in Germany, the government took forcible measures today to protect religion from Bolshevist atheist propaganda. It issued an emergency decree summarily suppressing all Communist freethinkers' associations and their publications, authorizing the confiscation of their means of propaganda and threatening imprisonment for violation of the proscription.

Health administration in the State of New York by means of 1,200 local health boards instead of county board, as has long been recommended, was criticized as "antiquated, inefficient and extravagant" yesterday by Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., State Health Commissioner, at the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the State and local committees on tuberculosis and public health of the State Charities Aid Association.

In general, there was again no change on yesterday's financial markets. With stocks at their present all but nominal prices, variations of a day excite little interest, beyond perhaps showing that superficial speculation persists even in an hour of financial apathy.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, May 4 -- No ship's arrival here for many years has created such a sensation as the return today of the Leviathan for the first time since the World War to the country whose flag she flew when she was the Vaterland, the Hamburg-American Line's crack liner and Germany's pride of the sea.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 4. -- North Carolina woke up to the fact that the tax yield from generations yet unborn had been pledged to pay "local" bonded indebtedness aggregating about $375,000,000, and decided to do something about it.

BERKELEY, Cal., May 4 (AP). -- Wells Drury, pioneer newspaper editor of the Pacific Coast, and friend of the late Mark Twain, died today at his home here after an illness of several years. He was 81 years old.

Anciently, names of chiefs, kings, gods were unutterable. If a magician got hold of them, he would have power over those human and divine personalities. A Roman who blabbed the name of the tutelar divinity of the city of Rome was properly done to death.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 4 (AP) -- Chinese irregulars and Japanese troops clashed in heavy fighting today along the Hulan-Hailun Railway due north of Harbin. The rebel Chinese were using hide-and-seek tactics to great advantage against the Japanese heavier war machinery, and were reported to be holding off three Japanese brigades under General Hirose.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- While wheat dipped early today to a new low level on the current downturn on the Board of Trade, with July at the inside nearly 10 cents under the recent high mark, the market's undertone was firmer.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney characterized baseball as a factor in solving the juvenile crime problem at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night under the auspices of the metropolitan group of Boys' Clubs of America.

The ban on "Merry-Go-Round," the melodrama dealing with political corruption, or rather the closing of the Avon Theatre where it was scheduled for performance Tuesday evening, aroused several city departments yesterday when attorneys for the producers hinted at "political censorship" in their demands for "immediate action" to assure the opening of the play uptown.

With a long-drawn-out program the Amateur Athletic Union's national championship boxing tournament, serving as a qualifying test for the final Olympic tryouts which are to be held in San Francisco the week of July 10, got under way last night in Madison Square Garden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just been looking at THE TIMES rotogravure picture of those good and lovable but misguided women standing "on the steps of the Capitol after having presented resolutions demanding the continuance of prohibition."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- Hits by Goodpasture and Borger in the eighth inning gave the Princeton varsity baseball team a 6-to-5 victory over Villanova today. It was the fifth straight victory for the Tigers.

Little stirred in the day's money market to lift it from the dull and listless state in which it has rested for some time. Only a very small percentage of the money offered upon Stock Exchange call loans was taken at 2 1/2 per cent, which was the official rate, while 2, was paid in the counter trading.

Announcement of the appointment of a committee of British holders of securities of the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, the $375,000,000 Chilean nitrate monopoly, known as Cosach, and its associated nitrate companies, was made here last night at the offices of Cosach.

While no acceptable reasons were assigned for the weakness in the first three or four hours yesterday on the Stock Exchange, it was the prevailing opinion that the recovery late in the day was inspired by reports that the sales tax plan was to be revived in some form.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 4. -- A thrse-run rally, in which the winningrun was scored on a bunt by McEachern, enabled the Naval Academy baseball team to defeat Georgetown today, 6 to 5.

BERLIN, May 4. -- The Boerse continued firm today despite all kinds of disquieting events, like the suicide of Karl Blum, a banker, who was wanted by the police for alleged violation of the law for control of foreign exchange, and a bear raid on Burbach Potash, which led to a net decline of 2 per cent after an initial grain of 3 per cent.
A continued heavy turnover of housing properties featured the market in the New Jersey metropolitan area yesterday.
Not Public Endorsement. As CAPONE emerged from the jail at Chicago on his way to begin an eleven-year sentence at Atlanta, he did not confront an entirely hostile audience.
EXETER, N.H., May 4. -- In an eight-inning contest today Exeter defeated the Holy Cross freshmen, 11 to 10, the game being called owing lo school regulations at 5:30 P.M.

MEMEL, Thursday, May 5 (AP) -- German parties were running far ahead of the Lithuanians in returns early today in the election of a new Diet for Memel, the former German territory that Lithuania has sought strenuously to control.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Returns from the Democratic Presidential primary in California when received in Washington today did more to upset the confidence of the supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Capitol than any previous result in the pre-convention campaign.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 4. -- Scoring three runs in the ninth frame, the Lafayette baseball team defeated Rutgers, 12 to 10, at Neilson Field today.

HONOLULU, May 4 (AP) -- Business and industrial leaders of the Occident and the Orient met at a conference table at this Pacific half-way station today for a three-day discussion of mutual problems and of a program to stimulate trade in the Pacific area.

Neither the German Kaiser nor the official heads of his government wanted war in 1914, but they were drawn into it by their "stupidity and blindness," the late Prince Bernhard von Buelow, one time German Chancellor, wrote in the long-awaited posthumous third volume of his memoirs, to be published tomorrow by Little, Brown Co.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 4. -- A large variety of Spring blooms were exhibited in about fifty classes at the early May Flower Show held today under the auspices of the Plainfield Garden Club at the Y.W.C.A. Keen competition was apparent among the amateur growers who alone were allowed to exhibit.

Members of the advisory committee of the Department of City Planning held their first meeting yesterday with John F. Sullivan, City Planning Commissioner, and expressed the belief that the prospects were better than ever for systematic planning of the future growth of the city.

In a long speech in the House of Commons, the Home Secretary, Sir H. SAMUEL, discussed the public impression that there has been a great increase in certain classes of crime in Great Britain. Criminal statistics in England are wonderfully full, but they are not infallible.

A wide variety of improved real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx was offered at auctioneers' stands yesterday. Plaintiffs attending the sales protected their liens by bidding in the properties. The sale comprised holdings ranging from small taxpayers to a row of five-story apartment houses on Morrison Avenue, in the Bronx.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 4 -- Cornell won its first Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today, defeating Columbia, 4 to 3, despite a fine pitching performance by Ray White, Lion hurler, who allowed only four safeties.

THE team that is variously known as the Robins, the Dodgers and Carey's Canaries hoisted itself out of a hole before leaving for the West, thus relieving some of the thick gloom that had settled over the entire region of Flatbush. It cheered up Manager Maximilian Canarius, too. As Max himself said of the National League cellar: "It's no place for a minister's son."

The Museum of Modern Art, which has just opened to the public its permanent home in West Fifty-third Street, thus passes out of its experimental phase. In its temporary quarters it had handsomely proved that much can be done despite space limitations.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Plans of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to issue $55,813,000 of bonds, to be pledged and repledged from time to time as collateral security for notes it may issue and in substitution for existing collateral for loans, were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 4 (AP) -- Jersey City scored a second straight victory over the Rochester Red Wings today, beating the league champions, 11 to 9. Jersey City scored in every inning except the first and pounded out fifteen hits off the slants of Tony Kaufmann, Jim Winford, Buck Foreman and Clarence Heise.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- The Senate Finance Committee's votes on the tariffs written into the tax bill today were as follows:

A total of $871,065 had been contributed to the 1932 Catholic Charities drive when the fund-collecting efforts officially ceased at 10 A.M. yesterday, it was reported to Cardinal Hayes and the district managers at a meeting at the headquarters of the Catholic Charities Organization, 447 Madison Avenue, by the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, Bishop Auxiliary of the Archdiocese of New York and director of the appeal.

A campaign designed to "preserve the dignity and high character" of the Fifth Avenue midtown shopping district by the elimination of shoddy displays and undesirable advertising practices was started yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association.

TOKYO, May 4 -- The report of the New York correspondent of the Asahi newspaper that the United States was preparing to transfer its entire fleet to the Pacific is said by officials of the Naval and Foreign Offices to give Japan no cause for uneasiness and to be unlikely to disturb public opinion here.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 4 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles routed the Bisons from second place and took over the runner-up position in the International race by defeating Ray Schalk's team, 10 to 6 in the second skirmish of the series today.

The alleged hesitation of banks to extend credit and the tendency of the steel industry to leave untouched the huge piles of scrap iron and steel on which bank loans once were made to members of the association have brought the scrap-metal industry to the lowest point in its existence, it was charged last night in the Hotel Astor by Benjamin Schwartz at the annual meeting of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 4 -- Baroness Giacomo Levi of New York reached the final round of the women's Westchester County tennis championship today on the clay courts of Briarcliff Lodge.

A proposed plan to resume operations of the Albany night boats submitted yesterday to Federal Judge John C. Knox for approval went aground at a hearing in his chambers when creditor interests began wrangling over which should be the first to get paid from revenues.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The remnants of the omnibus economy bill, with its estimated savings of $38,124,500 dwindling to a bare $30,000,000, were sent to the Senate today as House leaders abandoned all hope of finding a way to replace some of the major items stricken from the bill.

An increase of one percentage point in operations in the steel industry, or from 23 to 24 per cent of ingot capacity, is indicated in The Iron Age's estimate of business in the industry at large this week. The publication notes, however, that conditions are still irregular, "in that gains at Cleveland.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Low Fierrepont and Miss Ruth S. Dunning are sailing for France next week on the De Grasse.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 (AP) -- Thomas M. Cassidy's Universe, winner of the Wood Memorial Stakes at Jamaica, was slightly lame tonight, but a veterinarian said there was a "good possibility" he would be able to start in the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday.

MOSCOW, May 4. -- The May Day celebrations throughout the Soviet Union reflected the growing irritation which marks the Soviet attitude toward what is happening in Manchuria and emphasized the line the Kremlin has taken recently.

The roof garden of the St. Regis was opened last night for the season with a special dinner and entertainment. Several hundred attended the event and a portion of the receipts was given to the Actors' Dinner Club, an organization for the relief of needy players.
Small houses in three boroughs figured prominently in realty transactions announced in this city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Hopeful of early action by Congress to permit the entry into the United States of imports on bond pending adjudication of the tariff liability Secretary Mills today postponed for another week the enforcement of a court decision abolishing a practice of the Treasury in effect for many years.

The world is so full of a number of things. I'm sure we should all be as happy as -- Well, not kings exactly, though even that would be playing safe, since they are not much happier than the rest of us these days.

Under the direction of its conductor, Channing Lefebvre, the Downtown Glee Club with Nora Fauchald, soprano, as soloist, presented various choral works last night in Carnegie Hall. The program opened with Bach's drinking song from the "Peasant Cantata," followed by two Holst hymns from the Rig Veda, with solos by Joseph Mezo and Walter Schiller.

The minutes of the Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, do not contain specific authorization permitting the organization committee to have spent sums said to aggregate $500,000 for legal fees between 1926 and 1932, it was admitted yesterday by Frank Wilson, union president, at a hearing before Referee Robert McC. Marsh at the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- More than five hours of debate today on a bill providing for government operation of Muscle Shoals was insufficient for the House to reach a vote.

BERLIN, May 4. -- Former Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm appealed to the American people today to "understand what is at stake in a Germany driven to despair by economic distress and the humiliating limitations on her sovereign rights."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 4. -- One of the most exciting of the school election contests in West-chester County yesterday was in the First District of East Chester, where there were nine candidates for three positions on the school board. Alfred Rado, president of the East Chester Board, was defeated with his running-mates, Walter D. Burke and Arthur L. Page.
A formidable array of American women golfers sailed last night aboard the Berengaria for a twofold golf invasion of Britain.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 4 (AP). -- The American Ambassador and Mrs. William S. Culbertson presented their youngest daughter, Jane, to society at a ball at the embassy tonight which opened the capital social season.

PARIS, May 4 -- Through a microphone from the house in which he was born Premier Andre Tandieu delivered to the French electors tonight one of the greatest fighting speeches of his career. He spoke with the clearly apparent consciousness of the fact that he was beaten in last Sunday's first electoral contest and that he was likely to be beaten again next Sunday.

The sensational run made by Speaker John N. Garner at Tuesday's preferential primary election in California gave the Roosevelt Presidential boom a setback even more serious than the sweeping victory won by ex-Governor Smith against Governor Roosevelt in the Massachusetts primaries.

The first showing of John Barrymore in the R.K.O. Radio picture "State's Attorney" will be held tonight at the Mayfair Theatre. The production is under the auspices of Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt and other women interested in raising funds to continue during the Summer the work of the Adopt-a-Family committee of the unemployed emergency relief.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- The world champion St. Louis Cardinals climbed back into the first division of the National League today when Flint Rhem shut out Cincinnati, 7 to 0. and forced the Reds into the second division.

This phrase appears in the annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute. It might be repeated by thousands of givers -- money lost not through the depreciation of stocks or bonds or real estate, but in helping others, or even in saving their lives.

LONDON, May 4. -- The stock markets were more cheerful today, and British funds continued to be the outstanding section for strength. The war loan remained dull, due probably to the prospect of the loan being repaid or converted at an early date.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Republican party in New York State is getting stronger every day, President Hoover was told today by Charles W. Hilles, Republican National Committeeman, and W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee.

A verdict of guilty of second-degree grand larceny was returned yesterday by a jury in Judge Freschi's part of General Sessions against Dr. Samuel Buchler, lawyer, former Jewish chaplain, in Sing Sing Prison and former city official, in the theft of $200 from a man in an immigration case.

MONTREAL, Que., May 4 (Canadian Press) -- With reduced earnings from steamship and railway services, rigid economy must be enforced to preserve the financial condition of the company, E.W. Beatty. president and chairman of the board, told shareholders at the annual general meeting of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company here today.

Early reports for the fifth week of the Block-Aid campaign show that the sale of stamps for the unemployed has reached a total of $650,000, it was announced yesterday. Cash returns for the fifth week alone are expected to reach $100,000.

BUDAPEST, May 4 -- The act of Count Bethlen, the former Premier, in mounting the Speaker's tribune in Parliament today for the first time since his resignation loosed an unprecedented storm of indignation among the Socialist and aristocratic opposition.

The chief significance of the vote in the Democratic primary of California is not that Speaker GARNER won, but that Governor ROOSEVELT lost. Again it seems to have been a case of bad management or foolish publicity on the part of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S political agents.

The annual exhibition of small paintings by members opened yesterday at the National Arts Club and will continue until Oct. 1. Among the artists represented are Eugene Higgins, Edmund Greacen, Arthur Woelfle, Adrian Land, Keith Shaw Williams, Alaetha H. Platt, Ernest D. Roth, Paul King, George Nelson, Arthur Crisp and Louis Berneker.

A plan to print and sell $6,000,000 worth of counterfeit certificates for common stock in E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was frustrated yesterday with the arrest of four men and the seizure of the printing plant in a loft at 503 West Forty-third Street.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 4. -- A schoolboy was shot dead today while he was waiting for a school bus with a group of school children at the corner of Clinton Avenue and Sage Street in South Plainfield. A man who lived across the street was arrested after the school children had told the police that they had seen the man with a gun in his hand shortly before the shooting occurred.

HONOLULU, May 4 (AP). -- With completion of the case for which he came out of retirement to wage battle, Clarence Darrow said today he was planning to leave for the mainland Sunday on the S.S. Malolo.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 4 -- Army's nine won a ten-inning game from New York University today, 5 to 4. Bob McNamara pitched excellently for the Violet, but his defenses fell apart in the ninth and tenth innings, when Army, trailing 4 to 1, rallied and tied the count in the ninth and went on to triumph.

With the declaration yesterday of a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on its common stock, the directors of the General Motors Corporation reduced the annual rate on the shares from $2 to $1. It was the second cut this year, the annual basis having been reduced from $3 to $2 on Feb. 3.

CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- Three home rung by Detroit today brought an 8-to-7 victory over Chicago in the fYnal game of the series. The Tigers were outhit, but managed to make the most of their blows off Thomas. The Tigers' victory enabled them to tie Cleveland for second place, though the Indians also won.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4. -- In a tour of Philadelphia speakeasies last Saturday night, James K. Shields, superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New Jersey, had found no merry clinking of glasses, no laughter, no songs, no crowds, no champagne and no evidence of the corruption of boys and girls, but only one dull, drab hide-out after another, he announced today.

A program of public works by the Federal Government and by the States with Federal assistance, as a means of stimulating a moderate inflation and reviving industrial activity, was urged yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in an address before the Advertising Club of New York.

A fifteen-cent admission fee for symphonic music, unprecedented -- except for free concerts -- here and probably elsewhere throughout the country, will be charged when the New York Orchestra, Inc., with Modest Altschuler, former conductor of the Russian Symphony Orchestra, conducting its ninety-two players, starts a series of Summer evening concerts on July 5 at the George Washington High School Stadium, 191st Street and Audubon Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Julius Hopp, a director.

ROME, May 4. -- Speaking in the Chamber of Deputies in the discussion of the budget for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Dino Grandi pleaded the delicacy of the present international situation as preventing his dealing in detail with the major problems now under discussion, promising to do so soon, in either the Chamber or the Senate.

PARIS, May 4 (AP) -- In his last appeal before Sunday's final balloting, Premier Andre Tardieu tonight warned that if the Radical Socialists (Liberals) and Socialists combined successfully against republicanism "France's future for four years would be in the hands of internationals."

Pig iron production, as computed by The Iron Age, touched a new low point in April, the daily rate of 28,430 gross tons having come within striking distance of the minimum output of 1921, which was 27,889 tons a day in July. The April total was 852,897 tons, compared with 967,235 tons in the preceding month and 2,019,529 tons in April last year.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- An agreement providing for through shipments of merchandise from the west coast of Central America to Atlantic ports of the United States, affecting the operations of steamships owned by the Osaka Shosen Kaisha and the Pacific Steam Navigation Company, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

Three secret match monopolies valued at nearly $70,000,000, which had been regarded as of such international consequence that they could be referred to only as "agreements with countries X, Y and Z," were described yesterday as inquiry into the tangled financial affairs of the late Ivar Kreuger.

GENEVA, May 4. -- Naval experts from whom the disarmament conference asked advice as to which of their ships to abolish as offensive weapons continued to disagree violently in the naval commission today. Aircraft carriers and submarines were the subjects of contention.

The Port of New York Authority endorsed two projects for the Improvement of water transportation in Westchester at hearings yesterday by Colonel G.R. Lukesh, First District Army Engineer, at Mamaroneck and New Rochelle. In each instance, the Port Authority said, shippers would obtain improved service and the volumes of cargo shipped over the routes would be increased if the improvements were made.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- British and American Judicial procedure was contrasted to the disadvantage of the latter by Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, at the annual meeting today of the American Judicature Society, of which he is president.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I recently received a letter from the American Ambassador in Paris stating that there are twenty-eight war-wounded Russian officers, without country, friends, family or relatives, now living in the direst poverty at 14 Rue des Trois Champtiers.

LOS ANGELES, May 4. -- John Clinton Porter, as stanch a dry as the day he declined a wine toast to the French Republic at Havre, marshaled nearly 200,000 votes around his prohibition and other precepts today and was victorious in a recall election by a majority of more than 50,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 4. -- Still counting on victory despite the defeat in California, Governor Roosevelt received news of the results of the Golden State primary with equanimity today, although his aides were frankly disappointed.

The Thomas Homes Company, headed by Thomas Moffa, builder of Yonkers, has bought the 3 1/2-acre Augustus Thomas estate in Clinton Avenue, between Crosby Place and Coligni Avenue, New Rochelle, for improvement with brick dwellings from plans by Henri Vallet, architect.

The Board of Taxicab Control indicated yesterday at a public hearing in the Board of Estimate chamber its intention to scrutinize carefully the financial practices of all applicants for the transfer or initial issue of certificates of conveniance and necessity to operate taxicabs.

TOKYO, May 5. -- The keynote of official comment on the armistice at Shanghai is the hope that, now the security of Japanese nationals is assured, the way may be open for gradual improvement in Sino-Japanese relations.

The New York Stock Exchange has received an application from the Tri-Continental Corporation for the listing of 509,844 additional shares of common stock. The additional shares have been issued in connection with the acquisition of certain assets of Investors Equity, Inc.

Running the five furlongs in the fastest time that has been hung up in the event, Little Lad won the featured Montauk Claiming Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday, scoring an easy victory over five other juveniles and negotiating the distance in 0:59 3-5.

Three new plays and a return engagement comprise the schedule for next week in the New York theatres. The return engagement, at popular prices, of "Mourning Becomes Electra," Eugene O'Neill's trilogy, will begin on Monday afternoon at the Alvin, Judith Anderson, Florence Reed, Walter Abel, Crane Wilbur, Thurston Hall and others who have been appearing in the Mid-Western road company, will be in the cast, which will play here for two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The War Department appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1933 was reported to the House today with a reduction of $24,380,310 under the budget estimate, and $58,789,703 less than the appropriation for the current year. The sum recommended by the appropriations subcommittee for military and non-military activities is $386,983,452.

LONDON, May 5 (Canadian Press). -- Economic groupings that have been effected among foreign nations would have compelled the British Commonwealth to consider a broad empire policy even if the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa had not been arranged, declared the Federation of British Industries in a report regarding the conference presented to the government and made public tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- More than 3,000 persons, including high officials of church and State, attended the Ascension Day service, held this morning for the first time in the new choir and sanctuary of the Washington Cathedral on Mount St. Albans.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- Denouncing unlimited competition in the garment industry, George W. Alger of New York, Governor Roosevelt's appointee as chairman of the New York Cloak and Suit Commission and impartial chairman of the industry, declared here today he could see no reason "why the lives of 27,000 workers in the cloak and suit industry should be thrown in to make a bargain hunter's holiday."

A Democratic Senator, Mr. HARRISON, calls upon the President to bring order out of chaos. The budget is not balanced. Tax plans have gone astray. "If ever there was a time," he says, "when the President "ought to speak out to his leaders "in Congress it is now."

Musty legal documents passed through the trembling fingers of an old man yesterday as Charles G. Koss, who for decades helped to handle the legal affairs of the Wendels, continued his testimony, which was interrupted by his collapse on the stand from a heart attack Thursday.

Mayor Walker, whom the backers of the Equitable Coach Company called "the boy friend," once contemplated asking public financing for the company, Charles E. Mitchell of the National City Bank disclosed yesterday in testimony before the Hofstadter committee.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- An expression of President Hoover's views on prohibition was demanded in the Senate today by Senator Tydings of Maryland, who said the President lacked the courage to give them.

The annual Spring show by members of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors will be on view at the Argent Gallery until May 31. As is usual in exhibitions of this sort, some pieces of undoubted merit are among a hundred others, "like the pearl in the haystack," as Corey Ford would have it.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns went on a rampage in the sixth and seventh innings today and won the series opener with the Red Sox, 11 to 3. Six runs in the seventh clinched the game. Bump Hadley let the Red Sox down with six hits, while the Browns collected fourteen off four Boston twirlers.

Truck competition adversely affected the traffic of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Lines (the Katy) in 1931, although the railroad started offsetsing trucking service late in the year, M.H. Cahill, president, said in his annual report. The use of gas as a substitute for coal and the growth of pipe lines also hurt the railroad's business.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company and three wholesale shippers who are alleged to have received preferential concessions from the railroad were named yesterday in six indictments handed up to Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson charging violation of the Elkins act.
Charles E. Mitchell Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank testified as follows at yesterday's hearing of the Bofstadter committee:

A "back-to-the-land" movement as a form of unemployment relief was launched yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration with the announcement of a plan whereby unemployed families will be helped to help themselves through garden planting.
PARIS, May 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Socialist party's reply to the last campaign appeal of Premier Andre Tardieu is a renewed cry of "Defeat the candidates of reaction."

PINEVILLE, Ky., May 5 (AP). -- Conditions in the Southeastern Kontucky coal fields, from which New York and Arkansas students recently were ejected on attempted investigations, were quietly viewed and studied today by four New York clergymen.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Fluctuations were erratic in the wheat market today on the Board of Trade. Early breaks carried prices about 1 3/4 cents a bushel under yesterday's finish to a new low mark for the current movement. The July was off 10 1/4 cents from the high on April 14 and back to the figures of late March.

The Clyde-Mallory Line, which investigated the possibility of a daily passenger service between New York and Albany with an experimental trip of the liner Iroquois on Wednesday and yesterday has decided that the Hudson River is not a suitable place for the operation of the 394-foot liner.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Success today crowned the efforts of the Robins in the initial engagement of their Western invasion. With 16,000 North Side fans looking on, Carey's men defeated the Cubs, 2 to 1, with Watson Clark the winning pitcher and Charley Root an unlucky loser.

The dangers to the community if "ill-timed spasms of economy" are allowed to interfere with public health work were emphasized yesterday in speeches and resolutions at the closing sessions of the annual conference of the State and local committees on tuberculosis and public health of the State Charities Aid Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Middlesex County, Mass. Award was made yesterday of a new issue of $1,706,000 Middlesex County (Mass.) 4 1/4 per cent tuberculosis hospital bonds, dated April 1, 1932, and due serially from 1933 to 1947, at a price of 101,139. The bonds went to a syndicate comprising R.L. Dav Co., the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and the First National OJrt Colony Corporation.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 5. -- The University of Missouri medals of honor for distinguished service in journalism were presented today by President Walter Williams, who founded its School of Journalism in 1908, to one German and three Americans.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5. -- The third concert of the Eastman School of Music festival was given tonight in the Eastman Theatre by the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, Dr. Howard Hanson conducting. The program comprised five American works for orchestra, three of them first performances.

An inquiry into abuses in Chancery receiverships has been long overdue in New Jersey. Excessive charges were made and approved in many cases. It was suspected that fees were divided. It was singular that a man who seemed without qualifications to act in the interest of creditors was often appointed by a Vice Chancellor.

Steve Kaslov, 43 years old, who gave the address 209 East Fourth Street and described himself as the "king and judge of all the gypsy tribes in America," was sentenced by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday to a term of from fifteen to twenty-one years in Sing Sing.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Applications for three-year loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Norfolk Southern Railroad for $325,000 and by the Cairo, Truman Southern for $75,000.

LONDON, May 5. -- A startling story of what was described as a plot to blow up the apartment occupied by the Prince of Wales at the Waldorf-Astoria during his visit to New York in 1919 is now related by Lieut. Col. Norman G. Thwaites, who was then acting as the Prince's bodyguard.

Three inspections of the Avon Theatre by the Fire, Police and Building Departments were made yesterday, but the license necessary to operate the theatre had not been granted last night. Accordingly, "Merry-Go-Round," the melodrama dealing with civic corruption in an unnamed city, which had been scheduled to open at the Avon on Tuesday night, still found itself without a Broadway playhouse.

Settlements at the first of the month, as usual, made the total of bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday substantially greater than that for the preceding week, but the total was still far below that of a year ago, according to reports received from leading cities by R.G. Dun Co.

The Duchess of Arcos (Mrs. Virginia Woodbury Lowery Brunetti) has sold a plot on the west side of Thirty-eighth Street (Ninth Avenue), north of Thirty-sixth (Washington) Avenue, Long Island City, to an investor who intends to hold the parcel for future improvement.
"Bulls, Bears and Asses." Milton Herbert Gropper's play about Wall Street, will have its postponed opening at the Playhouse tonight. The curtain is announced for 8:30 P.M.

Adverse criticism by Jane Cowl of conditions in front of the Eltinge Theatre, in which the actress pointedly disagreed with A.H. Woods's statement that none of the visitors to his office in the same building had been annoyed by the burlesque, was followed yesterday at the hearing on applications for renewals of the licenses of the Eltinge and Republic by testimony favorable to the theatres.

Unusually keen competition featured the sale yesterday by the city of Albany, N.Y., of $1,940,000 of various improvement bonds, dated May 1, 1932, and due on May 1, 1933 to 1972. The difference between the first and second bids was 32 cents a bond, and between the second and third bids 2 cents a bond.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The community should be grateful to THE NEW YORK TIMES for devoting a half column of editorial space to the subject of "April Fires." The article emphasizes most graphically the unnecessary waste of forest property annually caused by forms of carelessness of individuals that may be controlled through publicity, but can much more positively be handled if punitive measures were possible by adequate legislation.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., May 5. -- Robert Wright of 22 Altamont Avenue, this village, revealed tonight the coincidence that led him a few weeks ago to find his youngest brother. Alexander G. Wright, whom he had not seen or heard from in more than twenty-five years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5. -- Mrs. L.G. Kaufman's Tick On, one of several New York representatives eligible for the fifty-eighth running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday, loomed as a more confirmed favorite than ever today.

TORONTO, May 5. -- The economic position of the Dominion of Canada is far less seriously affected than that of the United States after two years of world-wide business recession, the Toronto Industrial Commission states in a comparison made public here today.

HONOLULU, May 5 (AP). -- Victim of Hawaii's most famous episode of crime, Mrs. Massie prepared today to leave the islands forever, together with her mother, Mrs. Fortescue, Lieutenant Massie, Lord and Jones.

ST. LOUIS, May 5. -- Two streaks, moving in opposite directions, collided with such force today as to snap both at the hilt. The Giants, engaging in their first passage at arms with the Cardinals this year, thumped their way to a 10-6 triumph over the world's champions, ending a run of four straight defeats for the McGrawmen.

William Curley, 20 years old, and his brother, Matthew, 22, who for the last week had been on trial in General Sessions with William Turner, 21, on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of John McGowan last Jan. 7 in holding up McGowan's speakeasy in West Fifty-seventh Street, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder yesterday afternoon and were remanded to the Tombs by Judge Collins for sentence on May 19.

GENEVA, May 5. -- Admirals, Captains and Commanders or various nations of the world today concluded their discussion of what naval craft should be sunk as offensive weapons if the World Disarmament Conference should decide that nations hereafter should be armed only for defense.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The world's peace, it is universally known, depends upon disarmament. When and how this disarmament will be effected is the basic problem which confronts us, and it is reasonable to surmise that until its solution there will be no real guarantee of peace anywhere in the world.

Fred Feary, a cool, rangy heavy-weight from Stockton, Cal., established himself as a strong candidate for the amateur heavy-weight championship of the United States at Madison Square Garden last night.

Miss Berenice West, a lineal descendant of Benjamin West, the Colonial painter, is having an exhibition of her sculpture at the Midtown Gallery until May 17. Miss West studied with Archipenko, and, after an interlude at the Theatre Guild School, made her professional debut as a plastic artist in 1927.

CAIRO, May 5. -- The British, French and Italian Governments have replied in similar terms refusing the Egyptian Government's request for negotiations concerning the basis of payment on coupons of Egyptian debt bonds.

HONOLULU, May 5. -- The freedom of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, Mrs. Granville Fortescue and the two navy enlisted men, Edward J. Lord and Albert O. Jones, being assured through the commutation of their ten-year sentences for the slaying of Joseph Kahahawai, renewed efforts are being made to obtain for them a complete pardon, which would restore their civil rights and make easier the young naval officer's retention in the service.

The pamphlet report of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana for 1931 shows consolidated net income of $17,596,396 after all charges and reserves and minority interest, equivalent to $1.04 a share on 16,908,543 capital shares outstanding at the close of the year.

Joe Sullivan. St. John's High School star, turned in the best mark ever attained by a high school shot-putter in the East in furnishing one of the eight record-breaking performances of the sixth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championship meet at Ohio Field yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds today defeated the league-leading Boston Braves, 9 to 6, aided by the triple and homer with which Catcher Ernest Lombardi celebrated his return to the line-up.
Leases of space in business buildings in midtown and downtown Manhattan were reported in large numbers yesterday. Some of the contracts are for large floor areas and call for June 1 occupancy.

Reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City increased their loans and investments $202,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the combined statement of their condition published yesterday in conjunction, with the weekly Federal Reserve reports.

The high maternity mortality rate in the United States is showing a tendency to decline, Louis I. Dublin, vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, declared in an address at a Mother's Day luncheon held by the Maternity Centre Association at the home of Mrs. E. Marshall Field, 4 East Seventieth Street, yesterday.

LONDON, May 5. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, was asked in the question hour in the House of Commons today when the next payment of interest was due on the war debt to the United States and whether the sanction of Parliament would be requested before any further payment were made.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP). -- The Athletics' heavy hitters got into action today and ruined what might have been a duel between Lefty Grove and Cleveland's ace, Wesley Ferrell, to give the Mackmen a 15-to-3 victory.
LONDON, May 5 (AP). -- Prime Minister MacDonald was removed from international and domestic politics for six weeks by his operation today.

SHANGHAI, May 5. -- "Tell your people I dearly wish that we shall be at peace," said Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japan's Minister to China, just before noon in addressing Samuel Chang, the Chinese delegate who had gone to Fu-ming Hospital to witness the signature of the armistice on behalf of the Chinese Government.

The Young Plan for reparation payments remains theoretically intact, "but privately expressed opinion in nearly every country regards reparations in the form in which we have known them in the past as practically a dead question," declares Sir Josiah Stamp in his book, "The Financial Aftermath of the War," published today by Charles Scribner's Sons.

As a result of the defeat of the Roosevelt forces in the California preferential primary election on Tuesday, from which Speaker John N. Garner of the House of Representatives emerged a victor, there was heard yesterday for the first time in the Roosevelt camp a threat of deadlock in the Democratic National Convention.

Cash contributions for the fifth week of the Block-Aid campaign amounted to $96,251.04, it was announced last night. There was an increase of 459 in the number of blocks submitting subscription reports. The new total was 4,133 blocks, an increase of 13 per cent in the number of those which reported last week.
Manhattan defeated City College, 10-5, at Jasper Field yesterday to score its first victory of the season over a Metropolitan nine.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker, wife of the second secretary of the American Legation at Stockholm, is arriving today on the Kungsholm. Mrs. Crocker, who is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Marston Seabury, will be with her sister, Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr., at 226 East Sixty-first Street, before going to Bayberry Rocks, Kittery Point, Me.

Condemning Acting Secretary of State Castle's declaration on Tuesday against official boycotts of aggressor nations as "a body blow at the disarmament conference," Dr. Raymond Leslie Buell, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, urged yesterday that the United States take the lead in solving the disarmament deadlock.

LONDON, May 5. -- The stock markets generally were firmer today with a slight improvement in business, although most of the increases in prices were due to bear covering. British funds dull with the exception of some profit-taking that was done following the announcement that the bank rate was unchanged.
LONDON, May 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

By deciding to abrogate, the verbal agreement made with the Elevator Constructors Union, the Elevator Manufacturers Association paved the way yesterday for an early resumption of work by approximately 35,000 building trades mechanics and helpers and an end of the strike which has virtually paralyzed New York's building program since last Monday.

Opposition to the use of fingerprinting as a means of identifying the new-born infant in hospitals was voiced yesterday at the opening session of the annual conference of the Hospital Association of the State of New York in the Hotel New Yorker. The business of the conference will be concluded today, and out-of-town delegates will visit the hospitals of the city as a part of the program tomorrow.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 5. -- As far as the world outside the thirty-acre confines of the Federal prison here is concerned, Al Capone might as well be on another planet.

James Brown, senior member of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., was elected yesterday president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at the 164th annual meeting of the organization, held in the chamber's building, 65 Liberty Street.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 5. -- Governor Roosevelt forgot about primary elections today and devoted himself to local affairs, entertaining 200 neighbors at a house-warming and aiding five youths in distress.

Col. C.F.H. Johnson, president of the Botany Worsted Mills, was named permanent chairman of the recently created advisory board of the wool industry yesterday at a meeting of delegates from various branches of the trade at the Hotel Commodore.

ATLANTA, May 5 (AP). -- The Atlanta Constitution says Senator Long of Louisiana declared today that his State's delegation to the National Democratic Convention would support Governor Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination.

Fluctuations on the Stock Exchange yesterday were held within a narrow range, indicative of a stalemate between opposing market forces. Trading again was reduced and the market had little significance to Wall Street, except that the liquidating movement appeared to be losing force.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Elser grave a luncheon today at the Cascades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Farrell, Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. McLennan, Mrs. John E. Schroeder and Mrs. Carl W. Eberbach.

GENEVA, May 5. -- The League of Nations gave out correspondence showing that the inquiry commission in Manchuria, of which the Earl of Lytton is chairman, a fortnight ago asked Moscow to authorize its officials in Manchuria to give information to the commission, but Soviet Russia, unlike the United States and other powers represented on the commission, refused to accede to the request.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES Adolph Lewisohn makes a plea for a tariff on copper, not so much for economic reasons but because of the suffering among the copper miners in the Southwest. The suffering among the copper miners cannot be denied, but it is extremely doubtful whether a duty on copper would help them.
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The text of President Hoover's message to Congress stressing the necessity far drastic economies was as follows:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5 (AP). -- With Buzz Arlett continuing his devastating batting, the Orioles inflicted a third straight defeat on the Bisons today, 11 to 5. Arlett hit a homer, triple, double and single in six times up.

Chief Justice HUGHES has not forgotten his old "swingeing blow." In his address yesterday before the American Law Institute at Washington he declared that the "paramount" question before this country today is how society is to "protect "itself against the corrupting influences which tend to render it impotent to perform its primary obligations."

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The President's message, sternly calling the attention of Congress to the consequences of its present demoralization and demanding that the budget be equitably and courageously balanced at once, and asking "the country" to "reflect its will," is the most effective move he has made in his dealings with the parliamentary bodies of the nation.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange continued nervous and irregular yesterday in an unusually wide range and prices ended at gains of 3 to 5 points.

THE baseball magnates have adopted so many odd rules and regulations of late that they may be ready for a few more suggestions. In the booklet entitled "American League Regulations, Season 1932," for instance, there is General Rule No. 6:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5 (AP). -- Rochester won its first home victory of the season today by defeating Jersey City, 7 to 4. The Red Wings bunched six hits in the second inning for four runs and came back with three more in the seventh.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 5. -- Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers gained the final round of the Westchester County tennis championship singles today when he defeated Arthur S. Fowler of Pleasantville on the clay courts of Briarcliff Lodge.

The prosecution concluded its case yesterday in the trial of Joseph A. Broderick. State Superintendent of Banks, after nearly five weeks of testimony. This morning the defense will open, with Mr. Broderick on the witness stand in his own behalf.

The Johannes de Wint home at Tappan, N.Y., where Washington made his headquarters about the time of the trial of Major Andre, was turned over to the Grand Lodge, F. and A.M., of New York State yesterday morning at the closing session of the 151st annual assembly of delegates from 1,026 lodges who met in the Masonic Hall at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

The first presentation of John Barrymore in "State's Attorney" at the Mayfair Theatre last night attracted a large assembly of society. The benefit was given under the auspices of Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt and other women interested in raising funds to continue during the Summer the work of the adopt-a-family committee of the unemployed emergency relief.
Higher Rates and Lower Revenue. The protest lodged with the Senate Finance Committee against the proposed increase in second-class postal rates was based upon experience.
Brokers yesterday announced leases of private homes in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Pushing their holdings of government securities up to $1,287,000,000, the Federal Reserve Banks in the week ended on Wednesday increased their purchases of these obligations by $96,000,000 the Reserve Board announced today. In four weeks the banks have bought $402,000,000 of government securities.

After two days of discussion of the Wickersham reports by more than 100 Protestant, Catholic and Jewish educators, specially convened for the purpose at Columbia University by the Religious Education Association, it was agreed yesterday that the problem of delinquency and crime had been located in the maladjustment of the individual to his social environment.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 4, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,842,000,000, an increase of $83,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $870,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

A shipment of $1,600,600 gold to Holland was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. No other withdrawals of gold took place during the day, because of lack of suitable sailings, and there were no imports or changes in earmarked gold reported.

The second jury in Federal Court which has heard evidence presented by the government to show that Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and stock promoter, and Frederick C. Russell, his business associate in Metal and Mining Shares, Inc., defrauded the investing public of $6,000,000 in 1928 and 1929, tried last night without success to arrive at a verdict.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Reports from Tokyo that Ambassador Dehuchi would be relieved from his post here in June were received with considerable surprise in informed circles. It had been understood that Mr. Debuchi would remain here for an indefinite period.

Bernard M. Culver has been elected president of the eight fire insurance companies in the America Fore group -- the Fidelity and Casualty, Continental Insurance, Fidelity-Phenix Fire, Niagara Fire Insurance, American Eagle Fire Insurance, First American Fire Insurance, Niagara Fire Insurance and Maryland Insurance -- to succeed Paul L. Haid, who has resigned to become president of the Insurance Executives' Association.

Mayor Walker appeared before the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday to argue for legalization by court permission for another sixty days of the emergency bus operation in Manhattan. From his statements to the court, there seemed to be little doubt in the Mayor's mind that another sixty days would see the granting of a franchise to the New York City Omnibus Company, subsidiary of the New York Railways Company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- Eight crews, four from Yale and the same number wearing the red and blue of Pennsylvania, tried the new Flat Rock Dam course on the Upper Schuylkill River for the first time today. The annual Blackwell Cup regatta among Yale, Columbia and Penn will be rowed over the new stretch on Saturday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 5. -- Resumption of football relations between the Army and the Navy is a subject that will have to be taken up by the War Department, in the opinion of Major Gen. William D. Connor, the new superintendent of the United States Military Academy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- Lou Little, former star tackle at Penn and now head football coach at Columbia, was the principal speaker tonight at the Penn varsity smoker in Houston Hall when varsity awards voted this year and last were presented to 281 athletes.

YORKTON, Sask., May 5 (Canadian Press). -- Chieftain of Canada's 15,000 Doukhobors, Peter Verigin tonight awaited sentence on a conviction today of perjury. More than 1,000 of his drably dressed followers will hear Mr. Justice D. Maclean pronounce sentence tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Now that California has spoken to settle in Speaker Garner's favor the last major pre-convention contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, party leaders are confronted with an effort by an unidentified "distinguished Democrat" to frame a 100-word plank on prohibition.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Restoration of silver to its 1925 level was called for, with the reduction of armaments and the settlement of reparations, in a three-point program for economic recovery laid down today by Senator Borah in a speech which held the attention of the Senate for an hour.

Prices as a rule were steadier on yesterday's financial markets. In stocks the day's gain, though for the most part only fractional, was of a general nature, and there were numerous recoveries in both home and foreign bonds. This occurred with the usual irregularity, however; the bond market, in a way perhaps not witnessed in our time, continues to supplant the stock market as a picture of rapid and impulsive changes.

Ivar Kreuger at the time of his suicide in Paris was reaching out to establish one of his match monopolies in the United States, notwithstanding this country's anti-trust laws, it was indicated yesterday by official figures gathered in the International Match Corporation bankruptcy proceedings.

United States Government bonds and many domestic corporation issues recouped yesterday a substantial percentage of the previous day's heavy losses, but the trading on the Stock Exchange was somewhat less active. Foreign loans, as a group, however, finished irregularly lower.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve at the New York Bank to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Gaston B. Means, once an agent of the Department of Justice, a former convict and author of "The Strange Death of President Harding," was arrested today on a charge of defrauding Mrs. Edward B. McLean in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The campaign of the National Economy Committee to eliminate $450,000,000 of the $1,000,000,000 now spent annually for the relief of war veterans was carried to President Hoover today. Archibald B. Roosevelt, secretary of the committee, told the President that the time for action has come and, in the name of the committee, asked him to take steps to place the issue before the nation.

It is strengthening, if saddening, to see a great man struggling in the storms of fate. Senator BROOKHART, he of the far-smelling olfactories for rum, and the far-darting and loop-the-loop statistics, is fence-viewer in the home State this week. He will be a candidate for re-election in the Republican primaries.

Open-market discounts on bankers' acceptances were advanced yesterday one-fourth of 1 per cent, making the ninety-day bill rate 1 1/4 per cent bid, 1 1/8 per cent asked. The rise, which was the first since last November, resulted from special conditions within the bill market rather than from any tightening of the general money market.

AMHERST, Mass., May 5. -- Bunching hits in the third and fourth innings, Williams shelled Jack Thompson off the mound and went on to score a 7-to-1 victory over Amherst today in the opening Little Three game of the season.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 5. -- The Westchester County Clearing House Association was formed this afternoon when representatives of eighteen Westchester banks approved a constitution and by-laws at a meeting of the organization committee in the City Club here.

China and Japan have at last signed the armistice at Shanghai, and within a month, it is understood, the Japanese forces are to be withdrawn from the military lines they now occupy. Many painful weeks have been expended on the refinements of "face-saving," with no visible gain for either side, at least to Western eyes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Augur reputedly is one of the journalists best informed of the currents within the British Foreign Office. But Augur also is the declared protagonist of an -- fortunately small -- indiscriminately pro-French and anti-German group in England.

China and Japan have at last signed the armistice at Shanghai, and within a month, it is understood, the Japanese forces are to be withdrawn from the military lines they now occupy. Many painful weeks have been expended on the refinements of "face-saving," with no visible gain for either side, at least to Western eyes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Augur reputedly is one of the journalists best informed of the currents within the British Foreign Office. But Augur also is the declared protagonist of an -- fortunately small -- indiscriminately pro-French and anti-German group in England.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in his annual address to the employes of the Exchange on the occasion of "Boys' Day," said yesterday that President Hoover had come into office at a time of world crisis which made the demands on him infinitely greater than on almost any other President.
