WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Senator Norris spoke after being told that Senator Long had quoted him as advising the Democrats to nominate Mr. Roosevelt, and urging that the Louisiana delegation to the Chicago convention cast its votes for the leading Democratic candidate.
MICHAEL I. PUPIN once disclaimed prophetic powers, using the words of AMOS:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The historic pageant portraying the inauguration of Washington as the first President of the Republic was happily conceived and carried out to the satisfaction and enjoyment of multitudes of spectators. It was well worth standing a half hour or longer to see the procession, but at Twenty-third Street the pleasure was unfortunately marred by the conduct of people who deserve to be called morons.

Statements at the annual meetings of the Standard Oil companies of California and Indiana yesterday indicated that a broad realignment of Standard Oil interests is under way, involving already the three largest units of the Rockefeller group.

When Judge SEABURY first proposed to delve into the Equitable bus franchise, doubts were expressed of the wisdom of digging up that old scandal at this late date. But it has proved eminently worth while. The circumstances surrounding the grant of the franchise make a lurid story, strangely compounded of innocence and intrigue, and full of incidents so bizarre and inferences so sinister that the reader can hardly wait for the next chapter.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- A levy of still another $100,000,000 upon individual income tax payers was voted by the Senate Finance Committee late today as it practically finished rewriting the billion-dollar revenue bill.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Muscle Shoals bill, providing for a board of three members to lease the huge Alabama property to any organization other than power or distributing companies for a term of fifty years, was passed by the House today, 183 to 132.

Auditor's reports showing an extraordinary increase of expense in the conduct of Local 3 of the Electrical "Workers Union following 1926 when H.H. Broach, then international vice president, assumed charge of the local union, were placed in the record yesterday before Referee Robert McC. Marsh at 14 Vesey Street in the examination before trial of Frank Wilson, president of the local.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Chief Justice Hughes told members of the American Law Institute today that their first and most imperative duty was the freeing of the courts and judicial processes from the blight of corruption.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company at the annual meeting yesterday approved a reduction in the capital of the company by reducing the stated value of its common stock to $10 a share from $15.68. Resolutions were also adopted adding to capital surplus the sum of $34,069,543, which was created by the reduction in the stated value.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 5 (AP). -- C.V. Whitney's Blot, chestnut son of Peter Pan and Stigma, accounted for the feature race today at Churchill Downs. At the finish of the mile and an eighth, Blot enjoyed a two-length margin over Mrs. E.L. Swikerd's Sunfire.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Congressional plans to obtain a pardon for Lieutenant Massie, Mrs. Fortescue and the two naval enlisted men who were convicted in the Kahahawai manslaughter case halted today as the proponents waited to ascertain the facts.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was re-elected president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at the annual meeting of the trustees of that organization yesterday morning at the offices of the Carnegie Corporation, 522 Fifth Avenue.

The most interesting development of the day in the money market came late in the afternoon when bill dealers raised the yield on acceptances 1/4 on all dates. This was the first upward revision since last November, since which time there had been a series of cuts culminating with the one on April 21, as the final.

Section 3,453 of the Internal Revenue act, which permits prohibition agents to seize fixtures in places where liquor is sold, contains no provision for a situation, unique in the annals of enforcement, which yesterday confronted agents of Andrew McCampbell, administrator of this district.

The War Department was urged by civic and transportation interests to clear the way for deepening the Hudson River to thirty feet between Weehawken and Edgewater without burdening ship lines or New Jersey communities along the route with the expense of terminal developments at a hearing yesterday morning before Colonel G.R. Lukesh at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

Two nose finishes enlivened the meeting at Jamaica yesterday, one of these coming in the featured Montana Handicap, a dash of five and a halt furlongs for 3-year-olds, in which the Wheatley's Stable's Dark Secret scored over the Greentree Stable's Bird Nest.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, sponsor of a soldiers' bonus bill, has made public a message he sent to economists and bankers in which he outlined a compromise plan to meet objections raised to the measure.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- The Public Ledger quotes Fitz Eugena Dixon, well-known sportsman, as saying today that he plans to retire as captain of the United States Davis Cup tennis team at the conclusion of the North American zone finals to be played at the Philadelphia Country Club May 27-30.

The Manufacturers Trust Company, as agent in the liquidation for the International Madison Bank, has sold the six-story hotel and one-story building at 114-118 Park Row. The property fronts fifty feet on Park Row and extends through to City Hall Place.

Like a good many other people, Milton Herbert Gropper has decided that a play about the stock market might be a profitable speculation just now, and he has assembled a three-act sequence entitled "Bulls, Bears and Asses," which was acted at the Playhouse last evening.

The unwarranted building of public hospitals under prevailing economic conditions was decried yesterday by Dr. Christopher G. Parnall, medical director of the Rochester General Hospital, who addressed the delegates of the Hospital Association of the State attending their eighth annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker.

PARIS, May 6 -- The mystery of the telephone calls by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to France this week was solved today when it was learned that they had chiefly concerned exchange operations.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Representative Celler of New York called upon the Federal Radio Commission today to summon the owners of the broadcasting station WOR, Newark, to answer charges in connection with the alleged censoring of a speech he made Monday.

Producing a yellowish, acid smoke which temporarily blinded the firemen compelled to face it, a five-alarm fire raged all day yesterday in the principal New York pier of the Cunard lines, at Thirteenth Street and Eleventh Avenue, doing damage of $2,000,000.
After holding a slight advance for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward almost $1 a bale and closed near the top with gains of 16 to 17 points.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, May 6 -- Henry Pu Yi, Regent of the new State of Manchoukuo, in an interview today likened Manchoukuo to the United States in its infancy. The former boy Emperor, the last of the famous Manchus who so long bent China and Manchuria to their will, spent an hour with the correspondent today detailing the hopes, aims, anticipations and accomplishments of Manchoukuo.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 6 (AP) -- Complete and official returns today from Tuesday's Democratic primary gave Senator Hugo Black a total of 92,840 votes out of the 188,140 cast, lacking 2,461 of a majority necessary for nomination.

BERLIN, May 6 -- The Boerse took up again today the upward movement as a result of the election in Mcmel and relatively favorable reports from Western industries. Large buying orders from, the Rhineland, especially for chemical, electrical and mining shares, and extraordinary strength in the bond market produced an optimism that counteracted realizing sales.

The finals group or eight high school orators was completed last night when the last three contestants were selected to compete at Town Hall next Friday evening for the regional championship of the National Oratorical Contest which is conducted under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A. Schwarz of Philadelphia won the amateur championship of America at double targets over the traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. To win the title, which featured the preliminary events of the singles championship that is to be decided today, Schwarz had to break 175 out of a possible 200 targets.

4Fire destroyed the Gloucester fishing schooner Herbert Parker about fifty-five miles southeast of the Ambrose Lightship early yesterday morning. Her captain and crew of thirteen men were rescued by a Coast Guard cutter after they had vainly battled the flames for several hours, and the blazing hulk was sent to the bottom by gunfire from another cutter lest it become a menace to navigation.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- For the first time since 1884 college crews will row over the Flat Rock Dam course on the Upper Schuylkill River tomorrow in the Blackwell Cup Regatta.

Possibly in sympathy with the sharp advance in security prices yesterday, there was a similarly brisk forward movement in commodities. Grains, cotton, coffee, sugar, cocoa, rubber and hides in the contract markets all registered good-size gains, and the strength in futures carried over in the spot trading.

The wages and salaries of more than 200,000 employes of the United States Steel Corporation will be reduced by approximately 15 per cent on May 16, it was announced yesterday. It was the second cut announced in less than a year, a 10 per cent reduction in wages having been placed in effect last Oct. 1, while the pay of salaried workers had been decreased the same amount on Aug. 1.

PARIS, May 6 -- When an assassin fired on President Paul Doumer today, a police guard was present only because Director of Police Paul Guichard had insisted on accompanying the President with a sizable strong-arm squad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the letter of Adolph Lewisohn advocating an import duty on copper to meet an "emergency." Although I am a stockholder in some of the Arizona copper companies, I believe Mr. Lewisohn's arguments for a duty are unsound, and I offer the following comments:

Almost half of the amount of the new municipal bonds that are to come up for award next week will consist of the single issue of $12,002,000 of Westchester County various improvement bonds, which are to be sold on Wednesday. The total scheduled is $25,282,661, which compares with this week's revised total of $24,292,428 and with the weekly average for the year of $20,574,305.

VIENNA, May 6 -- The minority government headed by Chancellor Karl Buresch resigned today, and unless another bourgeois coalition can be formed to succeed it, new general elections will be held in June.

LONDON, May 6 -- The reduction of the treasury bill rate helped British funds to make further substantial advances today, but otherwise business in the stock markets was quiet; some sections were dull. Receipt of the news from Paris of the shooting of President Doumer of France caused a sharp reaction in shares that are dealt in in both London and Paris and a decline in French bonds.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Encountering Western opposition for the first time this year, the league leading Washington Senators lost, 5 to 3, to the Chicago White Sox today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 6 -- Miss Catherine R. Bauer of Princeton, N.J., won the fellowship fund, the final award, at the closing session here today of the annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs. The fund, established three years ago, is open to any American girl college graduate in the United States, and Miss Bauer is the first New Jersey girl to receive the honor.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The currency-inflation soldiers' bonus bill, for which a Presidential veto was expected, faced defeat today instead in an unprecedented parliamentary situation in the House.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 8 -- With a revamped line-up, the Women's National Golf Club team, the defending champion, moved into second place of the Class A group in the Long Island Women's interclub golf tourney today by vanquishing the Nassau Country Club aggregation, 3 1/2 to 1 1/2.

PARIS, May 6 -- The Ralph Strassburger prize of $1,000 for articles in the French press which contributed most to Franco - American understanding in 1931 has been awarded to Philippe Soupault. M. Soupault's articles were published in various periodicals, including Europe Nouvelle, Vu, Revue des Vivants and Bravo.

Newspapers of the country, irrespective of party, heartily approve the President's message of Thursday rebuking Congress for its delay in passing needed legislation. Here are comments gathered by THE TIMES:

Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, made public yesterday a letter he had sent on Wednesday to the Public Education Association, setting forth reasons for the discontinuance by the Board of Superintendents of the experimental work in progressive education at Public School 41, known as the "Little Red School House."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 6 -- The rolling green campus of Bryn Mawr College, dotted with graystone, ivycovered, dotted, with graystone, ivychitecture, was the setting today for pageantry and folk dancing handed down from the taverns and forests of "Merrie England," as more than 500 students and alumnae of the college gave their eighth, quadrennial presentation of an Elizabethan May Day celebration.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Democratic Senate leaders will confer soon upon a proposal to float a large Federal loan for the unemployed and semi-public works. Leaders in industry have represented to the party leaders that conditions in the country this Winter call for the creation of a fund to be used by the Federal Government, if necessary, to care for the unemployed who cannot be looked after by the cities and States.

Edward H. Blanc, 63 years old, of 18 East Sixty-second Street, for more than twenty years a senior partner in the law firm of Taylor, Blanc, Capron Marsh, 22 Exchange Place, was killed yesterday when he was hit by a southbound Third Avenue elevated train in the Franklin Square station.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Revocation of appointments of special deputy superintendents of banks named to assist in liquidating the affairs of closed institutions were announced today in the weekly bulletin of the department. The revocations include those of:

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 6 -- The favorable declarations of Senator Norris, Progressive Republican, of Nebraska, and Senator Long, Democrat, of Louisiana, were received with satisfaction today by members of Governor Roosevelt's party and were taken as an indication of a prospective growth of similar sentiment in the coming weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Senate's two-year investigation of postoffice leases culminated today with the presentation of evidence that the government is occupying fifty-one buildings at annual rentals that amount to 12.5 per cent of the value of the properties.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 6 -- Charley Erdmann allowed City College of New York only two hits until the twelfth inning today, but he became wild and received poor support in this session, Springfield losing, 8 to 2.

In a raid on an expensively furnished twenty-one-room duplex apartment and penthouse on the northeast corner of Fifty-third Street and Park Avenue shortly before 1 o'clock this morning, two plain-clothes policemen seized $10,000 worth of gambling equipment, arrested three men and dispersed a gathering of about fifty men and women, all in evening dress, who had evidently been playing for high stakes.

LIMA, Peru, May 6 -- Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, leader of the Apra (Radical) party, was arrested today and street demonstrations in protest developed so quickly and in such strength that a heavy cordon of police had to be thrown around the Presidential palace to hold back the crowd.

Arrangement to terminate the strike of most of the 35,000 building trades workers is expected to be made on Monday at a meeting between John Halkett, president of the Building Trades Council, and C. G. Norman, chairman of the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association.

More than 50,000 public school children, and parents are expected to crowd the area about the bandstand on The Mall in Central Park tomorrow afternoon for the annual celebration of Parents' Day, under the sponsorship of Uncle Robert.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, it was indicated yesterday, hopes to show, before calling Mayor Walker as a witness, that the Equitable Coach Company would have been of small use to the riding public even if it had obtained the necessary financing.

COOFERSTOWN, N.Y., May 6 -- Thomas J. Mangan, Sigmund A. Friedlander and Elmer D. Churchill, constituting the examining committee of the board of directors of the defunct State Bank of Binghamton, were all found guilty today of having made false statements regarding the condition of the bank to the State Superintendent of Banking.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The Robins went down to defeat before the Cubs, 3 to 1, today in the presence of a ladies' day throng of 30,000, two-thirds of which were women. The triumph sent Hornsby's men into first place. The defeat cost the Robins sole possession of sixth place, for which they are now tied with the Giants.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 6 -- Seven new appointments to the Connecticut College faculty and administration staff have been made by the board of trustees.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 6 -- "Connecticut jails are now out of date and cannot adequately fulfill present needs," according to the report of the survey commission created by the Legislature last year.
The union of the Spence School and the Chandor School, under the leadership of Valentine L. Chandor, who will become headmistress of the Spence School on June 1, was announced yesterday.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 3 1/4 per cent for the best names.

American Car and Foundry Motors Company -- For 1931: Consolidated net loss after all charges and amortization $1,936,500r compared with $327,025 in 1930. Company has outstanding 43,517 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 287,713 common shares.
New Yorkers sailing today for Liverpool via Queenstown on the White Star motorship Britannic include:

The cut in bill rates on Thursday failed to develop increased business, offerings continuing upon a small scale, for which demand has likewise dried up, particularly that for foreign account. Interest in other sections of the market was also at a low ebb, quotations for all classes remaining unchanged.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Hoover's message of yesterday to Congress resulted today in bitter partisan debate in the House and Senate, with the House devoting the entire session to discussion of the merits of his call for action on taxation and economy.

Cash contributions and weekly pledges to the Block-Aid campaign for the unemployed have reached a total of $1,151,510, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, who said this sum was not enough, as the committee had definite commitments of $1,500,000 to keep at work the 5,000 men who have received jobs through the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau on the strength of promised success of Block-Aid.

PRAGUE, May 6 -- Paul Gorguloff, President Doumer's attacker, gained his doctorate at Prague University in 1928. He is an Armenian from the Caucasus who came to Prague in 1923 and tried to associate himself with Russian monarchist organizations.

Tomorrow will be celebrated in churches of all denominations as Mothers' Day. It will mark the second annual "Better Observance of Mothers' Day" fostered by the Golden Rule Foundation in behalf of dependent aged persons and neglected children.

NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C., May 6 (Canadian Press) -- The internment prison camp of the World War may reappear in this Province to provide for incarceration of eighty-four Doukhobors sentenced to three years' imprisonment here.

On the ground that the wages of photo-engravers, electrotypers and stereotypers in took and job printing shops still are at the boom-period level, three national publishers' associations have addressed a letter to two associations of employers with a request that steps be taken to reduce costs in these branches of the industry.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Eight alleged Communists were wounded by machine-gun fire in a battle with the police this afternoon in the village of Melrose Park, a suburb. More than 1,000 radicals and their sympathizers, ordered to end an unauthorized mass meeting, attacked a detail of less than a dozen policemen with knives and clubs.

ALBANY, May 6 -- Up-State counties have received about $1,275,000 and New York City has received $319,000 of motor fuel tax money, it was announced today by Thomas M. Lynch, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. The total represents the counties' and New York City's share of money derived from that source during the first three months of this year.
The proposed auctions of collateral securing loans to Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago were postponed again yesterday to next Friday.

Walled in by a rigid censorship the population of Soviet Russia is permitted to read nothing but writings approved by the State, and the government is making full use of songs for Soviet propaganda, Thelma Nurenberg writes in "This New Red Freedom," published by Wadsworth Press.

LONDON, May 6 -- Captain William T. Turner, commander of the Lusitania when she was torpedoed May 7, 1915, is marking the sorrowful seventeenth anniversary of that war tragedy in his neat little cottage near Liverpool, close to the sea.

To the first shock of the news of the dastardly attempt at Paris, succeeded the fervent hope that the stricken President of the Republic might frustrate the designs of his would-be assassin. For this there was promise in the early reports from the doctors and in the spirit of fortitude and the sturdy constitution which had carried M. DOUMER through the labors of a long career of public usefulness and through heavy private sorrows.

Simultaneously with the announcement that it would pay its regular quarterly dividend on its common stock, the Chrysler Corporation issued yesterday its statement of operating results for the quarter ended on March 31, showing a net loss, after expenses, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, of $2,066,485.

LONDON, May 6 (Canadian Press) -- Huntly House, in the Cannongate, Edinburgh, was opened to the public today as a museum for the city. It contains valuable records of Mary Queen of Scots, of Sir Walter Scott and Robert Burns, and of the municipal, military and civil life of Edinburgh for several centuries.

Municipal financing monopolized the new offerings of bonds this week with ten issues aggregating $16,409,000 and ranging in size from 55,000,000 to $100,000. Not previously, since the week ended on April 15, had the new financing been entirely municipal.

Despite the 10 per cent wage cut on Feb. 1 and the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 4, the net operating income of 167 Class 1 railroads decreased 39.2 per cent in the first three months of this year, compared with the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics.

DERBY DAY at Churchill Downs! The blue bloods of the turf will be running in the Blue Grass region this afternoon. Racing is for the regulars and the railbirds most of the time, but the general public has what might be called a claiming interest in the Kentucky Derby. It has flavor, color and tradition. It's more than a race. It's an event in the sports calendar, and a picturesque one, too.

LONDON, May 6 -- As he put it himself at a luncheon given in his honor by the Lord Mayor of London in Mansion House today, Ambassador Mellon was able to shed his unaccustomed role of diplomat and revert to type as a banker and business man.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in April totaled $22,861,717,985, a decline of 6.7 per cent from the turnover in March, and of 42.6 per cent compared with April of last year. Last month's total offset the improvement in March and placed the aggregate for the country slightly above that for February.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 6 (AP) -- A 22-year-old hospital dietitian was found hacked and strangled to death today in a recurrence of a series of slayings attributed by police to a demented person.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 6 (AP) -- Buck Crouse parked a home run over the right-field wall with no one out in the ninth to break a deadlock and give the Bisons their first victory over the Baltimore Orioles in the four-game series terminating today.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 6 (AP) -- Sergt. Donaldson changed his style of running today to win the six-furlong feature at Pimlico. Usually a front runner, the 4-year-old son of Whiskbroom II from M.F. Dollard Jr.'s Stable, came from behind to grab the decision from Mrs. Katharine E. Hitt's Anubis in the final strides.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 -- At the close of the first day's matches today the Episcopal High School of Alexandria, Va., and the Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., were leading in the interscholastic tennis tournament being held at Princeton.

The trouble in Washington is that many leaders are still thinking in terms of 1929 standards, and such standards are no longer the yardstick with which to measure 1932 ability to pay, Governor O. Max Gardner of North Carolina declared in an address yesterday before the Municipal Bond Club of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Joseph Paul-Boncour, in his article on the Danube plan in THE TIMES, says that the "shifting of certain frontiers was done in conformity with the right of peoples to dispose of themselves -- a right which America inscribed above the peace treaties."

Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor whose connection with the Metropolitan Opera has been severed because of a dispute over his salary, issued a statement last night denying that he was the only member of the Metropolitan who did not accept a 10 per cent cut in salary last November, charging that General Manager Gatti-Casazza had a "grudge" against him, and answering the censure leveled at him in a statement signed by thirty-two members of the company.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The attempt upon the life of President Doumer of France today came as a shock to official and unofficial Washington and occasioned expressions of deepest concern.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- Five runs scored in sixth and seventh inning uprisings gave the Philadelphia Athletics their second straight victory over Cleveland today and their fourth in a row. The score was 5 to 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with rumors emanating from certain European agencies and reported in the American press as to Poland's alleged intention to accomplish a forcible change in the existing status of the free city of Danzig, the Polish Embassy states that such rumors are devoid of any justification in fact.

A comprehensive program for the rehabilitation of the lower east side was presented last night by Harland Bartholomew, planning expert of the Lower East Side Planning Association, at a dinner of the organization at the University Club. The plan was said by Mr. Bartholomew to be unique in that no large public expenditures are contemplated under it.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Approval of a three-year loan of $10,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was sought by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company in an application filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- Fred Schulte's home run and Chad Klmsey's ninth inning relief pitching enabled the St. Louis Browns to defeat the Red Sox, 6 to 5, today to make it two in a row. Marty McManus had an exceptional day at bat with a single and four walks in five trips to the plate.

Ambassador MELLON'S speech at the Lord Mayor's dinner in London, touching as it did on the economic depression and the despondency created by it, may fairly be described as a gust of fresh air in a stifling atmosphere. Few men now living have a better right to speak of the present hard times in the light of similar episodes in the past.

Allah Din and Gagha Singh played checkers yesterday in a three-room flat on the ground floor at 634 Stone Avenue, and both lost. When Nigam Din, who owns the flat, came back from the grocery store at 1:30 P.M., Din had four bullets in his body, Singh had six.
CINCINNATI, May 6 (AP) -- Working in fine trim at bat, afield, and in the box, the Cincinnati Reds today trounced the Boston Braves, 14 to 1, for the second victory of the series.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 6 -- The Penn State lacrosse team, led by Cramer and Smith, handed the Colgate team its third defeat of the season today, winning by 6 -- 3.
Numerous residential parcels in the Long Island and Westchester suburban areas were reported purchased or rented yesterday.
Regulation of motor vehicles is advocated by R.B. White, president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, in his report for 1931. He also asks for relief in railroad taxes.

HANOVER, N.H., May 6 -- Hank Barber, injured first baseman of the Dartmouth nine, limped to the plate as a pinch-hitter in the seventh inning today and batted in the winning run against John Paul Powhida, Pennsylvania's sensational pitcher, and the Indians won, 3 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

POTSDAM, Germany, May 6 -- Former Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm celebrated his fiftieth birthday today by entertaining leaders and comrades of the old imperial army at his beautiful castle, Cecilienhof.

The $10,000,000 shore development at the eastern tip of Long Island fostered by Carl G. Fisher and his associates went into receivership yesterday when Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn appointed William H. Robbins of Bay Shore and Otis S. Carroll of Brooklyn as receivers in equity of the Montauk Beach Development Corporation.

By a vote of 15 to 10 the Ways and Means Committee of the House rejected the plan for payment of the so-called "soldiers' bonus." Doubtless an effort will still be made by its advocates to bring it before the House. But the action of the committee is certain to carry weight and to stiffen still further the opposition which has steadily been gaining strength.

The involved and doubtful financial status of the Bank of United States was only one of many problems that faced him during the year prior to the closing of the institution in December, 1930, Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, testified yesterday in his own behalf at his trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Guests at a luncheon of bankers and business men where United States Ambassador Mellon spoke today observed that the Ambassador drank whisky and soda during the meal.

Of $21,656,000 par value of common and $12,520,000 of preferred stock of the Norfolk Western Railway owned by the Pennsylvania Railroad, $15,000,000 of the former and $10,000,000 of the latter were pledged for loans in 1931, the report of the Pennsylvania Railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission shows.

Sale of the foreign properties of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company to the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has been virtually concluded, according to an announcement yesterday by Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, which owns more than 96 per cent of the capital stock of Pan-American.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A decline of $10,000,000 in exports to Great Britain in March has brought home to government foreign trade experts the effectiveness of recent British tariff measures and the "Buy British" movement in restricting manufactured imports.
MONTREAL, May 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals swept the series with Reading before 2,000 fans by capturing the final today, 3-2.

HONOLULU, May 6 (AP) -- Reviewing the recent trade history of the Pacific area, James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council, today saw "elements of distinct encouragement." In an address prepared for the National and Pacific Foreign Trade Council conventions, he said that "trade across the Pacific has disclosed a greater resistance to depressing influences than that of other parts of the world."

PARIS, Saturday, May 7 -- Paul Doumer, President of the French Republic, died at 4:37 o'clock this morning (11:37 P.M. Friday, New York daylight time). He was shot down by a crazed assassin. He was 75 years old.

HONOLULU, May 6 -- Although Mrs. Thalia Massie had planned to sail Sunday for San Francisco with her husband and mother, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and Mrs. Granville Fortescue, there are indications pressure is being brought for the retrial of four men accused of an assault on Mrs. Massie.

A decrease of 171,019 tons in the production of steel ingots in April is shown, in the monthly compilation of the American Iron and Steel Institute, issued yesterday. These figures are the lowest on record.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 6 -- The Westchester Country Club Class A team slightly narrowed the lead of Apawamis in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub tournament on the Century Country Club course today by rolling up 9 points to 8 1/2 for the leaders.

SHANGHAI, May 6 -- Quo Tai-chi, who in a hospital here signed the Sino-Japanese armistice agreement yesterday, telegraphed to the Nanking Government today his resignation as Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs. This action is no surprise, in view of the nation-wide storm of denunciation against the peace pact.

George Pipgras shut out Detroit with five hits yesterday, and the Yankees began a nineteen-day stay at their stadium by vaulting from fourth place to second on the impetus of their 1-to-0 victory over the first Western major league club to invade the metropolis this year.

PARIS, May 6 -- The attack on President Doumer was not known when the Bourse was in session today, but it was an agitated market nevertheless. French shares showed serious weakness at the outstart, while international issues advanced. Later the domestic stocks rallied, but toward the closing they slumped again, while the internationals closed steady.

LONDON, May 6 -- A charge that liquor is being distilled illicitly on a large scale in India was made tonight in the report of the Federal Finance Committee, headed by Lord Eustace Perry, the first of the three round table conference committees to complete its work.

MEXICO CITY, May 6 -- Immediately upon receipt of news of the shooting of President Doumer of France, President Ortiz Rubio sent a cable expressing intense regret, hope that the outrage would have no serious consequences and wishes for a speedy recovery.

WANTAGH, L.I., May 6 -- An Army Reserve officer and a sergeant attached to the Air Corps at Mitchel Field were near death tonight from injuries received when their plane dived into a field near here from a height of 1,000 feet. Many motorists on the Southern State Parkway saw the crash and helped to extricate the men from the wreckage of the plane.
PITTSBURGH, May 6 (AP) -- With Big Jim Elliott in rare form on the mound and at the bat, the Phils downed the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first game of the series today, 4 to 2.

An appeal for "sympathy" toward the State Parole Board from a public that "does not understand" it, coupled with the assertion that the board is actually "doing a marvelous job" among the criminals with whom it deals, was delivered yesterday by Bernard J. Fagan, Parole Commissioner, at the eighty-eighth convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 -- The world today is troubled with too much spiritual dyspepsia and not enough abiding faith the Rev. Justin N. Nixon of Rochester told 1,200 delegates at the national convention of the Young Women's Christian Association here today.
Two mortgage certificates with a par value of $6,000 changed hands yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.
Sales of apartment houses featured the realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

Muscle Shoals is again in the news. The House of Representatives on Thursday passed the 1932 edition of the bill "to provide for " the leasing and other utilization " of the Muscle Shoals properties in " the interest of national defense " and of agriculture, and for other " purposes."

To the Editor of The New York Times: One phase of the Kreuger financial scandal has brought home to financiers the necessity of safeguarding bond issues secured by deposit of negotiable collateral. In the Kreuger case, poor securities were substituted for the good government securities originally deposited.

Three national amateur boxing championships, more than the city has boasted in five years, came to New York last night in the finals of the Amateur Athletic Union's annual title tournament at Madison Square Garden, which served also as the semi-final Olympic trials.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 6 (AP) -- Rochester evened the series with Jersey City today at two games each by beating the visitors, 5 to 2, behind the excellent pitching of Al Eckert, who allowed but one hit after the third inning. One of the runs off his delivery was a homer by "Bud" Clancy.

A handsomely photographed and ably directed picture known as "The World and the Flesh" is now at the Paramount. In this story of the attempted escape from Russia of a band of aristocrats in 1917 the featured players are Miriam Hopkins, George Bancroft and Alan Mowbray.

Sobbing and gesticulating with dramatic force at the hearing yesterday on the applications of the Republic and Eltinge burlesque theatres for renewal of their licenses, Joseph Weinstock, director and part owner of the Republic, charged Arch Selwyn, theatrical producer, and the Erlanger interests with conspiracy to ruin his business through Edward W. Forrest, secretary of the Forty-second Street Property Owners' and Merchants' Association.
PARIS, May 6 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The case of Gaston B. Means, former agent of the Department of Justice, charged with defrauding Mrs. Edward B. McLean of $100,000 as the ransom needed to rescue the Lindbergh baby, went to the grand jury today.

It is always painful to have to find fault with a judge acting within the law according to his discretion and sense of duty, but there are instances where sorrow rather than indignation must prompt rebuke. On one day this week two cases of injustice to the regular and the auxiliary enforcers of the prohibition law were spread upon the record.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 -- Twenty thoroughbreds have been named for the fifty-eighth running of the $50,000 added Kentucky Derby, to be run at Churchill Downs tomorrow, and thousands in this city tonight, drawn from all walks of life and many parts of the country, are at a loss as to which horse will be the winner.

Charges of overwillingnesa to aid the Hofstadter legislative committee in assaults upon, city officials and of conspiring with "enemies of the public" to discredit the present administration to advance his own political fortunes were hurled at Controller Charles W. Berry by Mayor Walker yesterday at a public hearing of the Board of Estimate on bus franchise awards in Queens.

President Hoover's address to Congress on tax legislation, the adoption of a compromise revenue measure by the Senate Finance Committee and the announcement of a proposed reduction in wages and salaries by the United States Steel Corporation were among the developments which contributed, in varying degrees, to yesterday's brisk rally on the Stock Exchange.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange rallied yesterday in heavy trading. United States Government bonds accounted for $4,860,000 of the total turnover of $13,350,000, making dealings in government issues the largest since April 21. Final quotations on this group showed recoveries of 2-32 to 20-32 point for the day, with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2s, which held unchanged.

All of the markets advanced yesterday, apparently in response to President Hoover's sharp reminder to Congress that "the imperative need of the nation today is a definite and conclusive program for balancing the budget." The salutary effect of the Executive's message was demonstrated by an advance of 1 to 6 points in leading stocks, a vigorous advance in domestic corporation bonds, moderately higher prices for United States Government issues and uniformly strong commodity markets.
Although Paul Doumer attained the hjghest honor that France can pay tier sons, his life was one of constant hard work and in many respects was tragic.

James N. Rosenberg of the law firm of Rosenberg, Goldmark Colin has sent a letter to the heads of large civic organizations in this city proposing immediate amendment to the Federal bankruptcy statute to provide for moratoriums and reorganization in the cases of bankrupt institutions.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker and the members of their family have returned from Palm Beach to 33 East Sixty-ninth street.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Senate Finance Committee within three hours today practically rewrote its already much-remodeled tax bill and emerged with a measure estimated to produce $1,010,000,000 in additional revenue toward balancing the budget in the fiscal year 1933.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 6 -- For the final session in its four-day festival of American music, the Eastman School of Music tonight turned its entire program over to the dance and presented under the choreographic direction of Thelma Biracree a joint bill consisting of "Skyscrapers" and "The Happy Hypocrite."

For the fourth time in the sixteen years of Hunter College "sing" history, a junior class won the first place at the annual song festival at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday. The class of '33, portraying a "Modern Mother Goose" pageant, triumphed by less than one-half a point over the senior "Arabian Nights."

Heavy slashes in the army appropriation bill were proposed in the report by the House committee on Thursday. If adopted they would mean drastic reductions of personnel and of military activities in one form or another. For example, it is proposed to retire, or place on inactive duty, no less than 2,000 officers, thus effecting a saving estimated at nearly $4,000,000.

The President's special message, or rebuke, to Congress, caused a sensation in Washington. People with short or imperfect memories hastened to say that such an arraignment of Congress by the Chief Executive was without precedent.

Apropos of the discussion concerning the best method to finance a program to restore the nesting and feeding areas for wild ducks, the American Game Association bulletin states that the Senate Committee on the Conservation of Wild-Life Resources probably will present a bill regarding a policy of financing the work.

Concentrated attacks enabled Columbia to defeat the Navy baseball team, 7 -- 2, yesterday at Baker Field. While Bill Wilkens was holding the midshipmen to five scattered hits, the Blue and White got to Lefty Coombs for nine, some of them coming when they meant runs.

Vacant city lots are not all to be given over to parking and deserted miniature golf courses this year. Private owners will be asked to lease their plots to the community at a low figure, and available public land will be turned over for gardens to unemployed families.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- An all-day deluge of telegrams and telephone messages to the President from every section of the United States and from persons of all types and political beliefs sustains the belief that the people who have been looking for a leader in Washington consider that they have found one in Herbert Hoover.

Thirty delegates, representing the twenty-one clubs in the organization, attended last night's meeting of the New York Rowing Association at the New York Athletic Club, discussed plans for the coming season and announced the list of events for the annual regatta on the Harlem River, which will be held this year, as in the past, on Memorial Day, May 30.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $4,191,737,649 during April, or to $20,319,088,631 on. May 1, the smallest amount since the Exchange began to compile these figures on Jan. 1, 1925. On April 1 the market value was $24,501,826,280, and on March 1 it was $27,585,989,257.
BERLIN, May 6 (AP) -- The dollar remained firm on the Boerse today.

Fifth Avenue Standards. The Fifth Avenue Association was founded twenty-five years ago to preserve the high standards of the shopping district. Its sanctions were never more needed than today, when adversity breeds lower standards and deflation sometimes extends even to matters of taste and decorum.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- Wheat executed a right-about-face today on the Board of Trade, opening easy and closing strong and at the best figures of the day, with net gains of 1 to 1 1/2 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the Appropriations Committee on the military budget bids fair to pretty nearly ruin our pitifully small army. They propose to remove 2,000 regular officers from the list, to suspend all reserve officers' training pay, to dispense with the training of R.O.T.C. candidates and close the C.M.T.C.

The possibility that some French Government offices, as well as a number of art and commercial concerns of that country, may be housed eventually in La Maison Francaise, one of the units in the midtown development here known as Rockefeller Centre, was seen in a report yesterday that plans of the building project are being studied by French officials.

Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman announced yesterday the names of ten firemen to whom medals of valor were awarded for deeds of exceptional heroism during 1931. The selections by the Fire Department Board of Merit have been approved by the commissioner.

Dr. Inazo Nitobe, member of the Japanese House of Peers and formerly of the International Secretariat of the League of Nations, who vowed eight years ago he would never come to the United States because of his resentment over the Japanese exclusion laws, arrived in New York yesterday on a six-month trip to this country "to study American opinion, particularly in regard to Japan."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 6 -- An appeal for lasting peace in the world was voiced here tonight by Acting Secretary of State William R. Castle Jr. in an address before the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A petition asking that the railroads be required to suspend all Sunday operation, except for emergency or charitable purposes, was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Noah W. Cooper of Nashville, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The treaty between Canada and the United States for the construction of the St. Lawrence seaway along the international boundary is expected to be ready shortly for submission to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A joint proposal introduced in the Senate and House authorizing the President to accept from foreign nations in payment on their indebtedness to this country until July 1, 1936, silver at the rate of one and one-half fine ounces for each dollar they are obligated to remit has given added impetus to the discussion of the silver problem by Congress.

A seasonal improvement in retail trade is indicated by reports to Bradstreet's from fifty-five leading cities in the United States. This improvement has been small and is attributed mainly to favorable weather conditions. There is no evidence of increased purchasing power on the part of the public, according to this mercantile agency.

SO wrote Thomas Haynes Bayly, and thus this charming little book of fairy lore appears appropriately enough in the Spring. In it we find the fairy folk of Europe brownie, elf, gnorne, kobold, goblin, lepracaun and many more briefly described.

TOKYO, April 23. -- Seven Japanese officials in key positions constitute the "steel frame" of the new Man- churian Government, gliding its policy, controlling its expenditure and ensuring at least a relative absence of graft and maladministration.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 7. -- Upward of 1,200,000 Ohioans, Democrats and Republicans, are to participate in the primary election next Tuesday at which delegates to the national conventions are to be elected, full slates of State, county and district candidates are to be nominated and controlling agents for the parties selected.

The attention of the insurance world was focused last week on the increasing movement among fire insurance companies to reduce their capital and, by the same step, to increase their surpluses. Several major companies announced plans to make such changes and other companies are considering doing likewise.

Movement of bond market prices yesterday was more worthy of notice than the movement of stocks. The stock market merely indicated the ending of its brief and superficial recovery of the day before; in bonds, however, Friday's irregular recovery continued.

THE author of this novel of New York sometimes seems to be building up a philosophy around the business of driving a taxicab, at other times to be constructing a story suitable for the movies, and at his best, to be analyzing, with considerable seriousness and some insight, the emotions of his characters as they come together.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 7. -- Glen Eagle, the well-known chestnut gelding owned by Dr. Walter H. Brun dage of Pelham, won the saddle horse championship at the second annual Harrison Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Kentucky Riding Academy today.

MOSCOW, May 5. -- One of the most striking differences between the New Russia and Czarist Russia is the intense preparation for defense, apparent everywhere over the Soviet Union, for the Soviet Government believes war is inevitable and that Russia either will be drawn into a conflict or that the Soviet Union will be attacked.

IF Washington Irving were to revisit his old haunts at Westminster and were to stroll out of the Abbey which he knew so well into the Rouse of Commons near by, he would ask. "Who are these members, crowding the floor and gallery and raising the roof with their cheers?

THE most far-reaching amendment to the air commerce regillations since the passage of the original act six years ago became effective on May 5. A "scheduled air transport rating" is established under which all pilots flying interstate on scheduled lines are placed on a higher professional status than ever before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of your editorial comments, particularly of late, have had so much of a demo-publican tinge that it has been a little bit difficult to follow you. What toppled me off my chair, because I am a social worker, was the editorial "The Plight of the Cities."
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess Koudacheff have left the Waldorf-Astoria for their country place in Greenwich.
The assassination of President Paul Doumer of France must be classed as one of history's most stupid crimes. It is of a kind with the shooting of our own President McKinley.

Maintenance or trade contacts through constant calls on prospective buyerd offers sure depression remedy for manufacturers in any line of trade, Frank Geraghty, general manager of the American Enamaled Brick Corporation, said here yesterday.

Ten choice parcels of real estate in the business section of New Rochelle acquired under condemnation proceedings for the widening and extending of North Avenue, one of the main thoroughfares, will be sold at auction by the City Council of New Rochelle early in June.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Major Gen. Enoch H. Crowder, U.S.A. retired, former Ambassador to Cuba and originator and administrator of the selective service act under which 4,000,000 men were drafted during the World War, died at Walter Reed General Hospital here early today of the effects of a general physical breakdown.

TROY, N.Y., May 7. -- Nott Terrace High School of Schenertady rolled up 285-6 points to win the eleventh annual Eastern interscho- lastic track meet at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today. Evander Childs High of New York City was runnel up with 17 tallies, while Erasmus of Brooklyn was next with 11.

WITHIN the year, tire experts predict, thousands of motorists will be riding on the new extreme low-preseure automobile tires. Vehicles of all weights will be carried on tires requiring air pressures from ten to twenty pounds and providing the maximum of cushioning comfort.

MR. GRIGGS wishes to stress the adjective "modern" in his subtitle, because in making the selections for his anthology he aimed to choose such as would interpret contemporary Paris, the city which exercises its fascinations upon those who stream thither to see it and dwell in it for longer or shorter periods.

AS the days get longer and the peeping of the hylas in the country becomes a daily chorus, the "ornithological golfers" sharpen their eyes, polish their glasses and lay their plans for the long course, the big day in May when they may observe their largest list of bird species.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 7. -- Debonis kept Syracuse's nine hits well scattered today and Penn State defeated the Orange, 5 to 3. The Nittany pitcher hurled his first complete game of the season and held the visitors to not more than one hit in an inning except the eighth.

MONTREAL, May 7 (AP). -- The Royals won their eighth straight victory today and climbed into a tie for third position with Buffalo by capturing the opener of a four-game series with Jersey City, 7 -- 3, before a crowd of 4,500.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 7. -- Gallant Knight, the Audley Farm's sturdy 5-year-old son of Bright Knight and Ethel Gray, turned in a record-breaking performance to win the featured $15,000 added Dixie. Handicap and turn the 4-year-old debut of Albert C. Bostwick's Mate into a debacle today at Pimlico before a crowd of 20,000.

PANAMA, R.P., May 2. -- Al- though women cannot vote in Pan- ama, they are taking an active in- terest in the present Presidential campaign, in fact so active in the case of Senora Carmen Berrocal, a husky, six-foot Amazon of Calidonia. a suburb of this city, that Major Alfredo Aleman, militant leader of the combined Liberal Reform and Chiarista parties, has appealed to the Mayor for protection.

THE lowest air passenger fares in history have been placed on the tariff tables of Ludington Lines, between New York and Washington, with the creation of the new "student" or excursion classes, $5 between the capital and New York. These student-rate tickets, J.V. Sheehan, general traffic manager, explained last week, can be used only on certain planes on a space-available basis.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 7. -- Long Island Sound had a beer parade this afternoon, a week ahead of the one Mayor Walker is arranging for New York City. It was held by the members of the Frostbite Yacht Club, an organization of Winter sailors, in connection with its final regatta of the cold water season.

Women show a tendency to be hap- pier than men, Dr. Rowina Ripin, in- structor in psychology at Long Is- land University, asserted yesterday afternoon in making public the re- suits of a five-week survey before more than 150 practicing psychologists from universities and industrial organizations throughout the Eastern States at the second annual meet- ing of the Association of Consulting Psychologists, held at Columbia Uni- versity.

Other morning of May 2 an Associated Press dispatch informed the readers of THE TIMES that "the long-standing feud" between composers and critics ''flared into the open at a conference in Yaddo, the Spencer Trask mansion."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 7. -- The junior music festival to be presented at the County Centre in this city on Thursday and Friday, an outgrowth of the Westchester County Music Festivals, this year will feature the works of American composers in an effort to develop American music-consciousness in both the audiences and the 3,875 child participants.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Bulls in the wheat pit were not so enthusiastic on the buying side today as they were yesterday, and despite a good rally at one time the undertone on the Board of Trade was generally heavy. All upturns ran into scattered selling and the close was at net losses of 1/2 to 5/8 cent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Silhouetted against the sunset on the upper Schuylkill course late this afternoon, another fine Yale varsity crew brought to a finish the Blackwell Cup Regatta with a polished, smooths-rowed victory over Columbia and Pennsylvania in that order.

THE chief source of Hebrew printing in the sixteenth century was Venice, and the early books published there were among the finest specimens of their kind. Christian printers and publishers took an especial pride in the making of beautiful Hebrew books, and some of them spent their fortunes in these enterprises.

WARRENTON, Va., May 7. -- Melita, bay son of Melager and Dusky Girl, wearing the colors of the Flying Horse Farm, Boston, and with Jack Skinner of Middleburg up, today won the Virginia Gold Cup Steeplechase.

MANILA, April 4. -- Fresh discus- sions of the social problems involved in the segregation of persons suffer- ing from leprosy has been aroused by recent events at Culion Leper Col- ony, which is the largest, and believed by many to be the best, segregation station in the world.

One of the most important meetings in its promise of future results was that held last week by the delegates to the American Kennel Club. Of greatest significance was the appointment of a committee to examine into the constitution and bylaws of the governing organization with instructions to file in writing any proposed changes before the September meeting.

The six leading symphonic orchestras of Paris which have just concluded the 1931-32 season (National Conservatory Orchestra, Colonne Concerts, Lamoureux Orchestra, Pasdeloup Orchestra, Poulet Orchestra and Siohan Orchestra, whose, respective conductors are Philippe Gaubert, Gabriel Pierne, Albert Wolff, Rhene Baton, Gaston Poulet and M. Siohan) have been badly hit by the crisis prevailing in musical circles.

LIMA, Peru, May 7. -- A number of persons were injured in a clash between mounted policemen and 1,000 students and other adherents of Victor Raul Haza de la Torre tonight when the police broke up a demonstration which was attempting to reach the Presidential Palace by side streets from the square where the University of San Marcos is located.

W. Beaver of Berwyn, Pa., annexed the twenty-seventh annual amateur championship of America at clay targets over the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the title by breaking 194 out of a possible 200 targets.

TORONTO, Ont., May 7. -- The Ontario Department of Mines has issued a detailed report for the first three months of this year in a sup- plementary statement. This shows that gold bullion to the value of $11,167,541 was produced in the prov- ince in that time.

PRAGUE, May 7. -- Further details relating to Dr. Paul Gorguloff show he is the son of an officer who became property owner in Labinskaya, Kuban. Gorguloff was wounded in the World War by a shell splinter, receiving head injuries from which he never completely recovered.

MADRID. MADRID is going motion picture mad. Another new picture palace has been opened this week. Unlike the showy theatres of America, it is decorated like most of the others, being built or remodeled in the modernistic style so popular in Germany.

PEIPING, April 2. -- Shensi and Kansu, the two provinces of China which have suffered most from the ravages of famine, are more prosperous now than they have been for many years. In many districts the position of the people is precarious, but for the most part the scars of the 1929 famine days are healing.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 7. -- Customers of the Hartford Electric Light Company who are unable to pay their monthly bills were told in a letter sent to all consumers today that credit would be extended for the three Summer months, beginning June 1.

A further recovery in prices marked trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, but the best quotations were made at the opening of the market and the list closed unchanged to a point higher than on Friday.

Members of the Community Councils of the city and other civic leaders participated in memorial exercises yesterday in memory of Lionel Sutro, a former treasurer of the organization, who died last July on a visit to California.

Butter. Receipts 6,588 packages. The shortage of fine butter noticeable Friday was still in evidence early Saturday. Most of the stock due Saturday suffered more or loss delays in delivery and not getting on the market until late in the morning and during the afternoon.

Announcement of the purchase by Salisbury Apartments, Inc., Martin M. Wohl, president, of 215 lets in Williston Park, near East Williston, for a new one-family home development, featured the reports of realty dealings on Long Island yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 7. -- Army defeated Union at lacrosse to- day in a one-sided game by a score of 15 to 3. The cadets dominated the play all the way and scored eleven times in the second half.

Quiet conditions again prevailed in the metropolitan realty field last week. The leasing situation seemed to possess more stability than property transactions, although both commercial and apartment renting were moderate in character.

NEXT Saturday's Beer Parade will mark the revival of a custom which in New York has fallen into comparative desuetude -- the staging of a mass demonstration to further a "cause." Having outgrown the small-town, small-boy type of parade and having encountered opposition to the crowding of its fine avenues, the city finds it more difficult every year to arouse its multitudes to do more than view its marchers from the sidewalks.

With the firing of a starting gun at 8 A.M. next Sunday morning off the Albany Yacht Club a large fleet of motor boats will set out on the annual race down the Hudson River. With good weather the first of them should reach the finish line off the Colonial Yacht Club, at the foot of West 152d Street, before noon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Supposing that the Metropolitan Opera is going to be housed elsewhere in the not too distant future, a question of interest is this: Howcan they possibly move the veteran scenery without having it fall to pieces?

The widespread demand in political and economic circles for measures to arrest the fall in prices by reducing the purchasing power of the dollar, which found its most striking expression last week in the passage by the House of Representatives of the Goldsborough bill, has directed the attention of the financial community toward the experience of Great Britain since the suspension of the gold standard last September.
To the Editor of The Few York Times: Some correspondent has sent me the following which I pass along to you:

BOSTON, May 6. HOW pleasant is Saturday night when you have tried all the week to be good. As the signs go, the final Saturday nights of the season are closing in upon the Boston playhouses. Taking them by and large, they have done as well as possible by a faithful public through a difficult time.

THERE was a day in radio when program sponsors had an overflowing reservoir of new talent from which to draw. They were anxious to sponsor artists of distinction of whom they could boast "they have never been heard on the air."

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., thirteenth in the national ranking, advanced two rounds in the North Side championship yesterday as the tournament got under way at the University Heights Tennis Club with its finest entry in years.

MADRID, May 6. -- Leading politicians, after conferences and discussions, have more or less agreed about settlement of Catalan autonomy, but there are distinct and clearly expressed opinions against national dismemberment on the part of the national elements in the press and in public on the eve of its discussion by the Cortes.

Eleven scholarship and fellowship awards for next year in the Graduate School of New York University were announced yesterday by Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown. Four of the scholarships were established by a bequest of Frederic Courtland Penfield to afford stipend for study and research in the fields of diplomacy, international affairs and belles-lettres.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A tragic story of starvation among Eskimos in Southwestern Alaska, with death facing whole villages as a result of early Spring floods, was unfolded here by Mgr. William Hughes, director of the Bureau of Catholic Missions.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A loan of $271,221 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the receivers of the Georgia and Florida Railroad was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The application was for $1,000,000. Of the amount granted $12,500 is for payment of interest on equipment trust obligations, $172,052 for accrued taxes for 1928 through 1931, and $96,669 for payment of audited vouchers for materials and supplies and for operating expense.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7. -- Har- vard's varsity lacrosse team main- tained its undefeated home record by blanking Williams, 15 -- 0, today.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- With leaders in Congress demanding a 23 percent reduction in the annual appropriation under which it now operates, with a resulting drastic curtailment in its activities, numerous offers of cooperation are reported by the Department of Commerce from business men and trade association executives asking in what way they may help the department in its difficulties.

The swimming teams of George Washington and Fenimore Cooper were the winners of the respective Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. senior and junior high school championships at the concluding series of titular dual meets in the 75-foot pool yesterday.

The sale of the four Gulf services of the United States Shipping Board to private interests revived discussion in shipping circles last week as to the future powers of the board. The government now has only six lines controlled by the board, and its functions under the original plan have been greatly reduced in importance.

ROME, May 6. -- Ever since General Italo Balbao has been head of Italian aviation he has specialized in what are variously called group formation flights. Such flights consist in cov- ering great distances in many successive hops with a large number of machines flying in correct military formation.
The Metropolitan Golf Association has compiled a list of tournaments and special events which will be staged in this area during the season.

Eighteen and nineteenth century English furniture and silver, pewter, porcelain and textiles owned by H. Douglas Curry Co., Inc., will be sold Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., where the items may now be seen.

Awaiting the time when a national program of waterfowl restoration can be financed, Paul G. Redington, Chief of the Biological Survey, has issued an appeal to those individuals or groups who might be interested in establishing refuges on a small scale.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- American participation in the World Court must depend upon an agreement that the court will administer its laws without regard to sex, representatives of the National Woman's party asserted when they appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

The wide range of school perform- ances which we observe in the United States is not the result of a confused professional mind, as some critics superficially assume: it is a clear indication that America is a huge social laboratory in which thou- sands of sincere, if not always well-advised and well-controlled, experiments are being conducted.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- The 120th commencement of Princeton Theological Seminary would be held from May 15 through May 17, it was announced this week. The complete commencement program was made public today. Conferring of degrees will take place on Tuesday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Purchase of the holding of the Fire Association of Philadelphia in the Constitution Indemnity Company of Philadelphia has been effected by a group acting through the Insurance Equities Corporation and Lloyds Casualty Company of New York, it was announced today.
LOS ANGELES, May 7. -- Final preparations are being made by the Junior League of Los Angeles to entertain 350 visiting delegates to the National Junior League convention here May 24-27.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 7. -- The Lehigh track team took the lead in the middle three series by defeating Rutgers, 71 to 55, at Neilson Field today.

ALTHOUGH traffic congestion on the main roads leading out of New York makes it a little difficult to search out places of historic interest, especially on a week-end, yet there are so many of these that it is well worth the effort involved.
PEEKSKILL, N.T., May 7. -- Clancy pitched the Peekskill M.A. nine to another victory today, turning back Manual Training High of Brooklyn, 6-3. He also drove in two runs with a single in the sixth.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Hoover and Acting Secretary of State Castle sent messages of condolence today to Premier Tardieu of France on the death of President Doumer.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Bank debits outside New York City showed a further slight decline during the week ended April 30 and were less than in the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The return of old Dick Glendon to Columbia rowing as a volunteer assistant to his son during the illness of Hubert, his other boy, brings back to intercollegiate rowing the man who is second only to Syracuse's amazing veteran, the 80-yearold Jim Ten Eyck, in length of service to the professoin of coaching rowing.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The thoroughly remodeled billion-dollar tax bill was taken over by drafting clerks and the Public Printer today and reprinting of the provisions began in preparation for submission to the Senate early next week. The hard-pressed Financial Committee took a day off.

LEWES, Del., May 7. -- Two grandstands seating nearly 1,000 men and women collapsed this afternoon during a tercentenary celebration held in honor of twenty-eight Dutch colonists who settled here 300 years ago.

THE University of Michigan has received a unique gift in the form of an astronomical laboratory, which is said to be the most modernly equipped of its kind in the world. The donors are Francis C. McMath, engineer and financier: his son, Robert McMath, and Henry S. Hulbert, senior judge of probate, all of Detroit.

BOSTON, May 5. -- A milk pact has just been consummated, on the successful operation of which the prosperity and permanence of the New England dairy industry may well depend. Nearly all the dairies in New England, 80,000 in number, outside of Connecticut, are directly interested.

HERE is a practical newspaper man's history of the world since the World War. Mr. Powers is the foreign editor of The Boston Globe. As such be knows news. What is more, he understands the significance and importance of events and developments.

THIS week the attention of society here turns to the royal courts in Buckingham Palace, London, the first two of which will be held on Wednesday and Thursday. These traditional state functions mark the festive season in London which, unlike that of New York, begins in the Spring and continues through July.

VIENNA, May 7. -- Because the First Machine-Gun Company of the Fourth Infantry Regiment of Vienna busied itself with National Socialist propaganda during the provincial elections a fortnight ago, instead of attending to military duties, it was dissolved today.

WHEN a "five-year plan" was proposed as the one sure means of coping with our industrial depression and unemployment, the reference to Russia was unmistakable and indeed sensational. The Bolshevist experiment was then at the height of its reputation; and, as it seemed, we were asked to believe that the thing in which our capitalist order had failed so tragically had been triumphantly achieved by communism.

IN this his latest and most lively book, Professor Pitkin has written the Saga of Homo Saphead, the Odyssey of the Average Man pursuing his futile and pathetic way up and down the world under the vigilant and malicious eye of the Tenth Muse: Moros Moha, Jahil, Stupor -- Stupid- ity.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 7. -- For the second time in as many years the Syracuse University crews scored a triple victory over the Naval Acad- emy oarsmen on the Severn River, the varsity, junior varsity and freshman shells representing the Orange giving the midshipmen their first defeats of the season today.

Jack Saltzgaver's triple with the bases filled and the score tied in the seventh inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium set up the margin by which the Yanks registered their second straight victory over the Detroit Tigers, the score being 4 to 1.

Scoring all its points in three of the twelve events contested, De Witt Clinton High School won the team honors in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high schools novice track and field meet yesterday at the General George W. Wingate Memorial Field in Brooklyn.

In the environs of certain European cities one sees thousands of garden plots, often with shacks scattered among them -- little patches of soil in which city workingmen and their families still keep in touch with the mother earth. The motive that first led the temporary tenants of these tracts out from the cities after hours or on holidays was not an economic one.

AURORA, Ill., May 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Emil Denemark's stable scored its third feature victory of the Exposition Park meeting today when Blackstrap, a 3-year-old son of Tryster-Pongee, defeated Capacity, the favorite, in the top race of the program.

The sole common denominator of the several artists who exhibit as "An American Group" at the Barbizon-Plaza is a certain air of seriousness. From Stuart C. Edie, who goes in for abstractions, to Chuzo Tamotzu, one of the best of the Japanese-Americans, and such orthodox Woodstock colonists as Warren Wheelock and Frederick Knight, these painters give the impression of practicing their craft without any thought to "epater les bourgeois."

In a statement charging that business rivals had set out "to get" him, and to deprive him of his liberty, Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and stock promoter, said yesterday, after the failure of a second jury to agree on a verdict in his trial with Frederick C. Russell for mail fraud, that he would demand a Congressional investigation of the case.

The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America will assemble on next Saturday at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., for its annual Spring meeting, according to an announcement by Colonel Allan M. Pope, executive vice president of the First National Old Colony Corporation, who is president of the association.

The more volatile commodities responded sharply on Friday to the general rally in prices, and most of them carried their gains through yesterday, with the result that more groups showed gains on the week than showed losses.

CHICAGO. IT cost Uncle Sam between $130,000 and $150,000 to put Al Capone, notorious Chicago gangster, where he is today -- Atlanta prison -- and where he will remain for at least the next six and one-half years, counting good behavior.

PRINKIPO. THREE years have passed since Stalin and Molotov announced that "Trotskyism" was dead and buried, and now a new campaign -- a fifth or sixth campaign against this same "Trotskyism" has sprung up in the pages of the Soviet press.

BUENOS AIRES, April 21. -- Although it is generally agreed that Argentina has made a gallant attempt to maintain its standing in world financial centres, discussion that has accompanied the 1932 budget estimates has made it abundantly clear that the strain is beginning to tell, and that after fifteen years of somewhat extravagant handling the national finances must be drastically revised if the year is to end with an actual surplus.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 7. -- The undefeated stride of the Lafayette baseball nine was continued today at the expense of Lehigh, the Maroon winning its eighth straight game. The score was 7-3.

Ambrose N. Diehl, a vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, will become president of the Columbia Steel Company on June 1, succeeding A.T. de Forest, who will retire under the corporation's pension plan. Columbia is a subsidiary of the Steel Corporation, operating in the Pacific Coast territory.

SHANGHAI, April 2. -- The Kuo- mintang party -- that is, the real Kuo- mintang as distinct from the Nanking Government -- remains the political hope of China, and Japanese aggressions against China will rally the Chinese people around the party in the belief of Eugene Chen, who has been Minister for Foreign Affairs three times in China since the Spring of 1926.

Open warfare between Mayor Walker and Controller Charles W. Berry flared yesterday when the Controller issued a statement saying that honest Democrats in this city did not believe that "graft and corruption" were assets to their party. So strongly was the statement phrased that it was construed politically anot only as a definite break with the Mayor but with the Mayor's supporters in the city organization as well.

HIGH C," a play by Gladys Unger, over the destinies of which Brock Pemberton for some months had control, has been completely rewritten, and will, in all likelihood, emerge sooner or later under another title and with Lenore Ulric as the star.

NEW ORLEANS, May 5 -- Bedeviled as few other States are by floating deficits, vanishing revenues, poor credit and extravagent traditions, Mississippi finds some reason to hope for better days in the firmness of Governor Mike Sennett Conner.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., May 5. -- Glamorous springtime and the onrush of a new crop season finds among Arkansas' preponderantly rural population a new spirit of independence and of agricultural pride. May launches a new era of high hope with promise of bountiful crops.

LONDON, April 21. IN my liking for "Napoleon: The Hundred Days," written by Benito Mussolini and Giovacchino Forzano and adapted for the English stage by John Drinkwater, I find myself opposed by those critics to whom theatricalism is the essence of drama.
EXETER. N.H., May 7. -- Exeter won a close track meet from the University of New Hampshire freshmen, 65 1/2 to 60 1/2 today.

Keeping up with one's class -- that major effort of generations of dutiful school children in America -- would suddenly lose its urgency if a pro- posal noted in the recent annual report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching should be put into general effect.
