JACKSON, Miss., May 7. -- Mississippi, the first State to adopt a general retail sales tax as a major method of raising revenue, has had the new measure in operation for a week, and thus far the predicted revolution has not taken place.

SMALL-SCALE models of furniture and decorative interiors have long been not only a delight to children but a real aid in furniture design and interior decoration. When important projects are under consideration, such models are painstakingly made for careful study.

ANDOVER, Mas., May 7. -- With Keith Brown, former Andover star, winning the pole vault with a splendid leap of 13 feet 6 inches, the Yale freshmen conquered Andover, 74 to 43, in a dual track and field meet today. Brown tied with Badman of Andover for first place in the high jump at 6 feet 1/2 inch. Ceilings. Andover, and Hirsch of Yale tied at 6 feet.

BALTIMORE, May 5. -- This city with its 900,000 population will on Sunday for the first time in 200 years throw into the discard in a practical manner its ancient blue laws. Preparations have been made for a big time.

ALTHOUGH the lengthening of life is largely due to lowered mortality in the first year of life (since 15 per cent of all deaths each year are of persons within the first year of life), nevertheless there is some progress being made in later years.

In 1926 the Supreme Court held invalid a Texas statute excluding Negroes from participation in Democratic primary elections. The statute was void as a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, which forbids a State to "make or en"force any law which shall abridge the "privileges or immunities of citizens of "the United States."

ANNOUNCEMENT has been made by Harper Brothers of the sixth Harper Prize novel competition, ending on Feb. 1, 1933. Sinclair Lewis, Dorothy Canfield and Harry Hansen will be the judges. Any author who is an American citizen and who has not published a novel in book form prior to Jan. 1, 1921, is eligible.

FOUR thousand boys and girls from elementary, junior and senior high schools of thirty communities will be represented in the two-day Westchester County Junior Music Festival to be given next Thursday evening and Friday afternoon at the County Centre, White Plains.

A number of American sports chaimpions have left these shores to seek honors anew in foreign competitions during the next two months. This is not only true of tennis and golf, but another American challenger, Miss Loretta Turnbull, departed during the past week.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y. May 7. -- Manhattan won all fourteen first places to defeat the Union College track team today by the score of 106 to 20.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., has been elected a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. class of '39. to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Henry Walters.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- At midnight in their guarded tents the Democrats lay dreaming of the 1932 elections, when, like a modern Marco Bozzaris, President Hoover struck.

WITH all the various activities going forward on the home front, and during the past month certain studios have been working overtime on surprisingly interesting material, it remained for what to us is a pioneer recording enterprise to occupy our interest for the week.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Conditions in basic industries in American markets abroad were almost unchanged during the latter part of April and such improvement as existed was confined to a brightening of sentiment in business circles, according to the current weekly survey of conditions abroad of the Department of Commerce.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 22. -- The $500,000 voted April 19 for organization expenses of electoral tribunals throughout the country was an unexpected blow to opponents of President Vargas who have been demanding a constitutional assembly. An open fight has been raging between the political parties of the State of Rio Grande do Sul and President Vargas for several months and, for a time, it appeared that the rift might result in serious consequences.

MONTE CARLO, May 7. -- Mme. Paul Gorguloff, wife of President Doumer's assassin, was aroused early this morning from a hard cot at the police station here, where she had passed the night, and was taken to her small apartment to look on while the police conducted a thorough search of the place.

Five now ships built by the United Fruit Company for service to ports in South and Central America have been named for mountain ranges, cities or provinces in the tropics. Three of the ships, the Antigua, Chiriqui and Talamanca have entered the service between San Francisco, Balboa and Puerto Armuelles, and the Quirigua and the Veragua are almost ready to start operation between New York, the West Indies and Central America.

RADIO has generously sprinkled a trail of stardust along Broadway. It has often been argued that the microphone is luring stars of the theatre by emptying the ethereal horn of plenty at the feet of those who have attained the topmost rung in the ladder leading to theatrical and cinematic fame.

An improvement in buying activity and an increase in the number of buyers arriving in the market were encouraging features during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Small lots of municipal and foreign bonds were added last week to the list of new redemptions for May. The total for the month of bonds called for redemption before maturity dates is now $9,308,000, compared with $13,529,000 in April, and $96,507,000 in May, 1931, at corresponding dates.

PARIS, April 25. -- May Day in Paris will once again be moving day and, for the first time in nearly ten years, there are apartments for rent here. The old rental signs so com- mon before the war have reappeared, not only on business premises and vast new apartment buildings but on the doorways of many houses.

CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP). -- With two out and two on in the twelfth. Ernest Lombardi slammed his third double of today's game against the Boston Braves and the Cincinnati Reds won, 9 to 8. It took a four-run rally in that frame for the Reds to win.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Alice the brown mare owned by George H. Elliott, climaxed a career of thirty years in brilliant fashion on the final day of the Philadelphia indoor horse show at the polo field of the Philadelphia Country Club today.
I CONFESS that I have never been able to fathom -- and I do not think many of the witnesses have really fathomed -- the secrets of the subconscious mind.

TRADE activity continued at its recent level during the week. It has been running somewhat over the decline which would be represented by the drop in prices over the year. This means that unit transactions as well as dollar volume are below the figures for a year ago.

PORTLAND, ME. MAINE is worried over the failure of its lobster industry. Imports of smaller lobsters which have been entering the United States for the last two or three years in ever increasing volume are competition that Maine cannot face under existing regulations.

An eleventh hour compromise proposal made by employers in the cleaning and dyeing industry to avert a strike set for tomorrow will be placed before the union members at a meeting at Webster Hall at 1 P.M. today.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP). -- Painfully bruised, suffering from shock and a dislocated arm, Harry L. Hall, an Associated Press photographer, arrived in Chicago at 7:47 o'clock tonight with the first consignment of news pictures of the Kentucky Derby for telephoto distribution over the country, after narrowly escaping death in an accident which proved fatal for a companion, John Irvin Lautz of Louisville.

SEVERAL hundred reservations already have been made for a dinner dance to be given tomorrow night at the Cafe de la Paix, 280 Park Avenue, as an aid to the hospital fund of the Soldiers and Sailors Club. Unusual entertainment features have been planned for it by Miss Harriet Camac, chairman of the entertainment committee.

ALL through George Washington's personal correspondence, as General and as President, there runs the strain of what in a more sentimental man might have been called homesickness. That he valued his honors and his fame cannot be doubted.

THE third volume in English of this absorbing and intriguing human document is now before us. The wrath which its original created in Germany and Austria in the Autumn of 1930 has not yet subsided. In a review of the first volume in these columns, June 14, 1931, we briefly outlined the contents of the succeeding three with initial attention to the wrath-provoking third, but without any attempt to appraise its value as history.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with the greatest interest that I began to listen to the broadcast of five successful works by American composers through the N.B.C. network this evening. As the program went on I was becoming, more and more amazed, and as the program came to the end I was simply astounded at the utter mediocrity and worthlessness of the compositions presented.

INSTEAD of letting us view the dead body and inviting us to guess the rest, the author of this story permits us to see the murder committed and to watch the murderer's efforts to eliminate all traces of his presence at the scene and to establish an alibi.
Among the many important developments in the field of international education the opening of the Institute of International Education this Spring at Mainz, Germany, is of particular significance.

LONDON, May 7 (AP). --The 1931-32 league soccer season ended today with the main interest centred in the promotion and demotion of teams in the various divisions. Everton had already won the championship in the first division and Wolverhampton Wanderers in the second.

DESPITE the intervening wall of language, a Frenchman like M. Maurois can make himself intelligible to Amer- icans more easily than most Eng- lishmen Perhaps this is because, unlike an Englishman, he is not dealing with ideas or objects which are confusingly alike in name and unlike in significance.

BRONISLAW HUBERMAN, the distinguished Polish violinist, recently addressed a brilliant audience in Vienna on the subject of "Pan-Europe." The lecture was attended by the French, Polish and Bulgarian Ambassadors and others prominent in Austrian politics, as well as a large number of young men and women.

Standardization of terms in comparative price advertising and the establishment of accurate merchandise definitions in store publicity are outstanding features of the standards of advertising practice adopted during the week by the members of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Associaition.

RADIO CITY -- or Rockefeller Centre, to give it the official name -- is no longer a dream. either blessed vision or horrendous nightmare. It is far along in the process of becoming a solid and stupendous reality. Moreover, there is no reasonable room for doubt on a point about which have clustered conflicting hopes and fears.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the convention of the Ladies' Garment Workers of America here today that the finding of jobs for the unemployed and not the balancing of the national budget was the foremost problem faced by Congress and the Federal Government.

ROME, May 7. -- Giuseppe Leonida Capobianca, "discoverer" of a letter alleged to have been written by Abraham Lincoln in 1853 to Macedonio Melloni, Italian Scientist, has been arrested on charges of forging several medieval documents, and his arrest has caused grave doubts concerning the authenticity of the letter.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 7. -- Three sons, four grandchildren and several great-grandchildren attended a family party Thursday given on the ninety-fifth birthday of Rear Admiral Edwin Stewart, retired, who was Paymaster General of the United States Navy during the Spanish-American War.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Following is the text of the address of Samuel Seabury before the American Law Institute tonight:

Disdainful, C.V. Whitney's two-year-old filly by John P. Grier out of Panders, with A. Robertson in the saddle, won the twentieth running of the Youthful Stakes at five furlongs at the Jamaica track yesterday, being the best in a field of nine juveniles.

In just three hours the Senate Finance Committee on Friday wrote a virtually new tax bill providing more than a billion dollars in revenue and balancing the budget. Moral: Try that Hoover Brimstone Tonic for your own Spring maladjustments.

The rally in United States Government bonds and domestic corporation issues was extended yesterday on the Stock Exchange in response to more favorable news from Washington. All the government issues moved up 2-32 to 18-32 point for the day, except the Treasury 4s, which declined 1-32 point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, as a student of history and one deeply concerned for the relations between France and all branches of the English-speaking race, put in a word for an institution about which, I suspect, homestaying Americans know little or nothing -- the American Library in Paris, at 10 Rue de l'Elysee.
IT was an announcer who boasted "fifteen words -- no more, no less." Lawmakers in Washington caught an idea from that expression.

THERE will be a rush of weddings in the coming week, many of them taking place out of town in little country Churches, to be followed by receptions at the large estates of the parents of the prospective bridos, which are at their best at this season of the year when the Spring flowers are in full blossom.

In an article in The South Atlantic Quarterly on "County Consolidation as a Means of Tax Reduction," Professor MANNING of the University of Kentucky calls attention to two actual cases of such consolidation in the South. They are the only two on record, but that need surprise no student of these ancient citadels of political conservatism.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- The "locust swarm of lobbyists" on Capitol Hill, so-called yesterday by President Hoover, is actually one of the largest in recent history.
SHANGHAI, May 7. -- The Chinese Government has definitely abandoned its five-year-old policy of trying to effect unification of China by coercion through punitive military campaigns.

IN a report which is of deep interest for aviation from the viewpoint of both wider utility and greater safety of the airplane, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, from whose researches at Langley Field has come so much of value to flying, gives the result of an investigation of certain modifications in conventional airplanes to give non-stalling and short-landing characteristics.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Hoover's message demanding prompt Congressional action to balance the budget was again under fire of the Democrats and Progressives in the House today, while regular Republicans stanchly defended the President.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 7. -- Coast Guards sank a rum-runner in flames this morning before daylight, rescuing two of her crew and saving as evidence two cases of whisky that came to the surface.

WHEN some wise historian of the remote future undertakes to interpret our time he will dwell less on our wars and our political upheavals than on our scientific achievements. And the early decades of the twentieth century will call for special comment, because it was then that physicists began an attack on the atom which resulted in discoveries that changed the whole character of chemistry and engineering.

Permanent establishment of a Social Science Laboratory, through which students in the Department of Government and Sociology at City College may study at close range problems discussed from the academic viewpoint in the classrooms, was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college.

R. Fulton Cutting, president of the trustees of Cooper Union, announced yesterday a new policy of art educa- tion involving sweeping changes in the curriculum and the imposition of entrance examinations. Mr. Cutting said that the salaries of nearly 60 per cent of the art faculties would be raised, the number of instructors substantially increased, the curriculum radically revised and broadened and the standards advanced.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 5. -- That growing group of Hoosiers who hoped to see the Eighteenth Amendment repealed and the Volstead act amended with the help of Indiana votes is not so enthusiastic now that it has had time to analize the results of last Tuesday's Congressional primaries.

THE growing movement to put prohibition to the test of a direct vote turns attention to one of the associations which has played a considerable part in changing public sentiment. Three years ago seventeen women founded the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 7 (AP). -- Masons from all over the United States tomorrow will begin the celebration of George Washington Bicentennial Week, set aside by the United States Bicentennial Commission.

PARIS, May 7 (AP). -- Alexandre Millerand, former President of France, and Pierre Jullien, head of the secret police, declared today that Dr. Paul Gorguloff, who killed President Paul Doumer, was a Bolshevist. M. Millerand asserted he had personal information which "permits me to say in the most categoric way that the assassin belonged to the regular Bolshevist forces."

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics raised their 1931 American League championship flag today and then took a beating from the Cleveland Indians, 10 to 7, before a crowd of 10,000.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 7. -- Theta Zeta fraternity at Rutgrers University became the Beta Delta Chapter of Theta Chi, national fraternity, tonight as a two-day initiation ceremony came to a close.

LONDON, May 7. -- The death of President Doumer of France was mourned throughout Britain today. The news was telephoned to Buckingham Palace from the British Embassy in Paris and King George and Queen Mary were informed at an early hour.

World Good-Will. Today we sorely need to consider live issues. The return of prosperity is what the whole world is longing for, looking for, and groping to find some way to achieve. One step in that direction is suggested by the very name of a newly appointed day.

MOTHER'S DAY brings special programs to the radio. John Charles Thomas, concert baritone, who always says "Good night, mother" at the end of his broadcast recitals, will sing today at 7 P.M., over WEAF and affiliated stations.

THE two-thirds rule of Democratic National Conventions is again the target of criticism within the party, this time from the adherents of Franklin D. Roosevelt. For an even century the rule has been attacked. In any convention it can be rejected by majority vote.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7. -- Judge and Mrs. William Clark of Princeton, N.J., will arrive over the weekend to open Reveille for the season.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- Lawrenceville was defeated by the Princeton freshmen in a dual track meet by a score of 51 2-3 to 74 1-3. Captain Le Van of Lawrenceville was high scorer for the losers with 15 points. Wollock of the freshmen also tallied 15 points.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 7. -- Baroness Giacomo Levi of Italy, who is now residing in New York City, annexed the women's Westchester County tennis championship today, when she triumphed over Miss Norma Taubele of the Bronx in the final of the singles at Briarcliff Lodge.

Four members of the staff at Ellis Island, including the head of the Deportation Bureau, have been suspended as the result of the escape on Thursday of Harry F. Gerguson. better known in the city as Michael Romanoff, who says he is distantly related to the Russian imperial family.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A compact and portable device, with which any one using ordinary electric lighting current may study the atom, has been perfected at the Bureau of Standards, according to an article in the current number of the bureau's Journal of Research.

AMHERST, Mass., May 7. -- Amherst College acted as host this eve- ning to the Intercollegiate Poetry Society of America. Representatives of a majority of New England colleges delivered selected poems before the convention sponsored by the Amherst Dramatic Society.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 6. -- One side of the much-discussed question of whether fraternities are a menace or an asset in college life has just had a careful restatement at the hands of a faculty committee of Rol- lins College, a committee that believes they are an evil influence and should be abolished.

A decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, made public yesterday, granted a motion of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for a temporary injunction restraining Paul Plunkett Co., 60 East Forty-second Street, financial counsel; Paul Plunkett, individually, and Leslie G. Weldon of Scarsdale, a former business associate of Plunkett, from the sale of stocks and bonds unless they disclose the nature and extent of their interest in such securities.

THE sailor, who once lived perpetually in a world of magic and mystery, does so no longer. Today almost -- but not quite -- everything that happens in his natural environment is explained, after a fashion, in the textbooks.

CLEVELAND, May 5. -- The Cleveland Bar Association is preparing to participate in Cuyahoga County's election of common pleas and appeals court judges this year in accordance with a campaign program unlike that of any other American city.

LONDON, May 6. -- Just how far the present vogue for economy has permeated English life was seen in the new London season which opened this week and will be in full swing with the first two Royal Courts next Wednesday and Thursday.

MACBETH GALLERIES -- Paintings by "a group of younger artists" -- Gerald Foster, A. Henry Nordhausen, C.G. Nelson and Paul Starrett Sample. The lastnamed carries off first honors with his distinctive and decorative canvases thronged with activity.

THE materials that are swept down into the ocean by wind and rain, volcanic upheavals and slowly moving glaciers are subjected to a vast milling of chemical changes. Reacting, dissolving, pre- cipitating, redissolving, these materials are taken up by living plants and animal, go through the life cycle and are then set free again.

Edward L. Bernays, chairman of the Spring membership campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Charities, announced yesterday the names of six vice-chairmen who will assist him in the drive, and thirty members of a committee which will ultimately number fifty group leaders, each of whom will supervise a team of ten volunteer solicitors.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5. -- Just a week after the California Vineyardists' Association worked itself into such a ferment as to blow the prohibition cork out of its official attitude toward the Volstead act it saw the primary election make William Gibbs McAdoo the dominant figure in the Democratic party of the State.

PARIS, May 6. -- Last Sunday's election in France and the probable sequence this coming Sunday seem to prove very fairly what is often contended by those who know France best; first, that the Paris newspapers must never be taken as an indication of what the French people think, and, second, that the French electors prefer peace and fair dealing both at home and abroad.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Pat Malone, speed-ball artist of Rogers Hornsby's staff, shut out the Robins, 3 to 0, today to give the Cubs a 2-to-1 edge an the series and strengthen their hold on first place. A gathering of 10,000 was on hand, many being kept away by the threatening and chilly weather.
Bunching hits with pitching wildness in two innings, the Manhattan College baseball nine defeated the New York A.C. team yesterday at Manhattan Field, 6 to 3.

The discrepancy between the book values of railroad stocks and their prices has been increased by recent declines in prices on the Stock Exchange. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of twenty-five railroad stocks was at $16.85 when the market closed on Friday, compared with an average book value for the issues of $154.79 as disclosed in current figures.

ONE touch of magic makes the whole world kin, thinks Mr. Mulholland. Being one of the master magicians of the world, he has traveled far over its surface and entertained with his art all manner of people, and his observation has taught him that European king or Asiatic coolie, lady of fashion or washerwoman, child of 10 or ancient of 90, all are equally delighted by the tricks and the mystifications of the conjurer.

SEVERAL peculiar pictorial stories reached the Broadway screens last week and one of them, "Letty Lynton," is being held over at the Capitol. In this film a stunning but tarnished girl is responsible for her objectionable former lover drinking poison.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP). -- William R. Martin, alleged to have escaped from Rockview Penitentiary and to have attempted to kidnap and attack Myra Atkins, 12 years old, daughter of socially prominent par- ents, was under arrest here today as the result of the pluck of the girl's mother.

ARETIRING diplomat in Washington recently remarked that the two things he most regretted not having seen while in America were the Grand Canyon and a national party convention. He was right, for he had named two things that, being uniquely American, are to be seen nowhere else in the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am very sorry that my remarks over the radio during the Music Appreciation Hour on April 22 should have been so misunderstood and misconstrued. This is evidenced by the letter of Mr. Harold Butler of Syracuse.

Spurred by a sharp increase in shipments of semi-finished steel products to this country, steel manufacturers in the United States, led by the American Iron and Steel Institute, have started a drive for the exclusion of foreign steel.

BERLIN. THE Goethe festivals are past, having rought edification and delight to many, while to others they provided occa- sion for mordant or cynical criti- cism. That is how public celebrations usually end.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- The University of Pennsylvania defeated Yale, 70 points to 65, in the annual track and field meet today on Franklin Field. It was the fourth straight year that Penn has defeated the New Haven squad.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7 (AP). -- Choate School won team honors in the annual Princeton interscholastic tennis tourney, concluded today, with a total of nine points. Episcopal High was second with seven.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Hoover and Secretary Mills at a special conference with Republican Senatorial leaders tonight discussed further "methods of cooperation to bring about prompt enactment of the revenue bill and economy legislation."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Threats were made today by proponents of bonus legislation to delay the adjournment of Congress until a bonus vote was obtained. Almost at the same time the majority of the House Ways and Means Committee was delivering a scathing rebuke to the advocates of currency expansion in an adverse report on the Patman bill.

BERLIN, April 10, 1932. THE current Haydn bicentennial festivities have served in Central Europe to remind a few people besides musicologists and bookworms that Haydn wrote at least two dozen operas. To say this is not to intimate that the repertories of German and Austrian theatres are suddenly undergoing a substantial classical enrichment.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 7. -- The forty-six delegates from Texas to the Democratic National Convention will cast their vote solid for John N. Garner for President and "the exclusion of any and all other candidates" if the will of the Presidential precinct primary conventions, held today in the 254 counties of the State, is carried out.

Lieutenant Colonel Ralph A. Kluge, whose death was caused by the fire that destroyed Pier 54 at Thirteenth Street and the North River, was the designer of the steel work of the structure, it became known yesterday.

Credit men and trade association directors yesterday called upon the business and industrial executives of the country to lend strong support to the revised bankruptcy act, hearings upon which were held before joint Congressional committees during the week and which will be resumed on Tuesday.

In routine fashion, the Jamaica High School rifle team added another cup to its collection by winning the Wingate Memorial Trophy at the 102d Engineers Armory range yesterday. The P.S.A.L. championship combination amassed 991 points to top the field of fourteen in the meet, which concluded the regular interscholastic rifle season.

ATHENS, Ga., May 6. -- There is a sign of the educational times here in the passing of the Lucy Cobb Institute, which, after nearly three-quarters of a century as a fashionable finishing school for young women, enrolling since ante-bellum days some of the cream of Georgia and Southern womanhood and graduating women who have become nationally known, has at last closed its doors as an educational institution.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Enactment of the Rayburn bill providing for retroactive repeal of the recapture provisions of the interstate commerce act, the placing of railroad holding companies under the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and the substitution of a more flexible rule of railroad ratemaking, was recommended in a report today by the House Interstate Commerce Committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- Six new dual meet records were established and another was tied as the Princeton track team defeated Harvard in Palmer Stadium today, 75 1/2 to 59 1/2, in the first track and field meet between the two universities since their break in athletic relations six years ago.

THE motion picture rights to "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" have gone to Joseph M. Schenck and his Art Cinema Corporation after what was characterized as spirited bidding. Katharine Cornell, who has appeared in Rudelf Besiar's play nearly 500 times on and off Broadway, will be headed with her company next week for engagements in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

RICHMOND, May 5. -- This city and State are recovering gradually from the almost unprecedented festivities of last week, when the Governors' Conference brought President Hoover and three leading candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination to Richmond, and the State choral festival and garden week attracted thousands of visitors from points far and near.

MADRID, May 6. -- Premier and Minister of War Manuel Azana, in promising the press complete liberty in Spain, remarked that the press has the duty of finding the truth, not merely political statements, but underlying factors in any nation.

THE general progrram for the ten weeks of concerts to be given this season by the Goldman Band. Edwin Franko Goldman conductor, has been announced and is printed below. This will be the fifteenth season by the band, running from June 13 to Aug. 18, on the Mall in Central Park and on the campus of New York University.

President HOOVER'S forthright appeal to Congress, with its implied condemnation of what had been done thus far with bills for new taxes and heavier retrenchment, laid a sure finger upon the cause of the mischief that has been wrought. Sectional and group interests had been allowed to prevail over the national interest.

Glulio Gatti-Casazza, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, replied yesterday to statements made by Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor, characterizing them as "a web of inventions" and advising Signor Gigli to "go on singing" but to "stop issuing statements which make every one laugh behind your back."

PROVIDENCE, May 7. -- Scoring in every event except the half mile, Dartmouth's well-balanced track team piled up 68 points to capture top honors in a triangular meet with Columbia and Brown today. The Lions finished second with 48 points while Brown was third with 21.

AS thirty years is a long time to be a polar settler -- most of us would consider thirty days too long -- it may be forgiven Jan Welzl if now and again he mingles what is undoubtedly the truth with flights of imagination that would do credit to the late Baron Munchausen.

A four-run rally in the eighth enabled the Columbia freshmen to defeat Roxbury School, 10 to 8 yesterday at Baker Field. Ed Brominski husky catcher, was Columbia's main offensive cog. getting two doubles at oportune moments.

BUSINESS activity has been dedining in the United States for almost three years, the slump having begun in the early Summer of 1929, before the stock market crash. There have been longer periods of depression in the United States, but none in which an almost precipitous down trend, broken by few and feeble recoveries, has lasted so long.

THE golden age of bel canto has been variously placed," wrote H.E. Wortham in The London Daily Telegraph recently, "but if there is good reason for putting this in the last quarter of the eighteenth century, a legal document now lying on the table before me suggests that the golden age for the prima donna, in no mere figure of speech, was the '80s of the last century.

OXFORD, Eng., May 7. -- Professor Gustav Cassel, the prominent Swedish economist, began his Rhodes Memorial Lectures on "The Crisis in the World Monetary System" at Rhodes House today. His subject was "Changes in the Nature of the Gold Standard."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The Third Division, the first of the Japanese troops to be withdrawn from Shanghai after the signing of the armistice agreement by China and Japan, is being sent to Manchuria, where the Japanese have encountered resistance from insurgent forces.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 7. -- City College of New York fell before the stellar hurling of Eddie Quinton, Providence College pitching star, today, Quinton gaining his eighteenth victory in twenty-two starts by a score of 9 -- 3.

The Beauharnois Power Corporation, whose plant on the St. Lawrence River is now being built and which faces a critical financial problem, is expected to go under the control of the Montreal Light, Heat Power Consolidated, according to predictions in Montreal.

PARIS, May 5. -- The second week of the Paris midseason showings confirms the return to the natural waist division, though Schiaparelli continues the very high Empire waists and Augustabernard shows some belts dropped to hipbone level.

GRADUATION and class days are looming on the horizon of the college girl. Mingled with thoughts of such gala occasions are those of proms and dances, and the long Summer days that lie ahead when vacation comes. Once in a while as she broods over forthcoming "exams" her thoughts are sure to play truant and to roam in fashion's realm.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- Mrs. Dora Boice, horsewoman, was wounded seriously by three bullets fired by her Japanese butler, who had suddenly become insane, at her home about three miles from here early this morning. Running through the house and screaming that he was "going crazy," the butler fatally wounded another servant and then killed himself as the police entered the house.

The international oil conference which will be held here this week will consider chiefly the general demoralization of the markets outside of the United States with a view to determining whether some understanding may be reached toward correcting it, according to C.E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in a recent radio broadcast, said: "One of the striking features of this troubled business period has been the emergence of small business as an increasingly important element in our economic structure."

BERLIN, May 7. -- The Boerse continued firm today on public buying and there were gains as high as 3 per cent. Business in the stock market, was light, but bonds advanced in brisk trading. The strength of the market was more remarkable in view of the announcement by the government of a comprehensive plan for reform of unemployment insurance and relief which may involve new taxes and increased contributions by employers.

OTTAWA, May 5. -- The most exhaustive and authoritative survey of Canadian ocean ports ever made has been completed by Sir Alexander Gibb, British expert, who has reported his findings and recommendations to Parliament in a document of 150,000 words.

PARIS, April 23. -- While not contending that American civilization is superior in all ways to that of Europe, M. Marcel Braunschvig, in his monumental book. "American Life and Its Lessons," makes an urgent appeal to Europeans to study American customs and standards for the benefit that European civilization could draw from them.

SEATTLE, May 7. -- Washington State Republicans, in convention here, adopted a dry plank tonight by a vote of 499 to 421. Meanwhile, Representative Ralph A. Horr, on whom the wets had depended to swing the tide in their favor, was stormbound in the Middle West where his airplane had been forced down on a flight from Washington, D.C.

Music, dancing, flowers and the colors of Springtime marked the twenty-ninth annual white breakfast of the Rubinstein Club at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Well-known artists took part in the musical program, that was followed by dancing. Almost 1,000 women, members of the club, attended, wearing white or pastel shades.

IT is not often that the old-time dramatic unities are so strictly observed as they are in this first novel by an author whose name -- real or assumed -- is so unusual that it will not easily be forgotten. The entire story takes place in the kitchen of a Clapham flat where Deborah Claw toils as cook and general houseworker for the Thornton family.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Hoover, in his newly assumed position as leader of that great mass of American citizens which wants Congress to pass an equitable tax law, a sincere Federal economy measure and adjourn in June, is obviously enjoying the sensation.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- Paul Elmer More, author and lecturer in the Department of Classics at Princeton University, is now compiling, in collaboration with F. Leslie Cross of Oxford University, an anthology of Anglo-ecclesiastical literature, which probably will be completed next year, the centennial commemoration of the Oxford movement, it was announced today.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 7. -- Eight students from New York and New Jersey were among the 253 to receive scholastic honors at the Pennsylvania State College in the annual scholarship day exercises, observed here today in conjunction with Mother's Day.

HANOVER, N.H., May 7. -- Dartmouth and Yale split a double-header in Eastern Intercollegiate League games today, Johnny Broaca pitching the Blue to a 7-to-4 victory in the first game and Dartmouth coming back to score a 9-to-7 victory in the second game.

The final action by the Board of Estimate on pending applications for bus franchises in Manhattan and Queens became more uncertain than ever yesterday as the open antagonism between Mayor Walker and Controller Berry added another complicating factor.

PARIS, May 7. -- With the body of President Paul Doumer still lying in state at the Elysee Palace, France will elect a successor Tuesday, for the Constitution demands that a new President be elected with the least possible delay.

The motor-boat flotilla that will take to the water soon in New York and vicinity will be as large as in past years and possibly even larger, according to the estimates of those observing activity along the waterfront and in boat yards.

DR. ARNOLD FANCK and the Universal expedition which is to make "Iceberg" in Greenland this Summer are on the high seas bound for Germany. In Hamburg the company will be joined by Leni Riefenstahl of the German screen, who will be the heroine of "Iceberg."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Privileges under State laws which permit public officials to refuse to testify on the ground of possible self-incrimination and to exploit the attorney-client relation, concealing bribery and balking investigation of private life, were denounced by Samuel Seabury, director of the inquiry into Mayor James J. Walker's Administration of New York City, in an address here tonight before the American Law Institute.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP). -- Resolutions suggesting that Congress postpone the discussion of bonus payments to World War veterans and advocating adequate appropriations for national defense were endorsed today by the Military Order of Foreign Wars.

Frenchmen are today going about the business of voting for a new Chamber of Deputies under the shadow cast by the death of the President of the Republic at the hands of a demented foreigner. Yet the cloud upon the spirits of the nation would be heavier if there were anything in the circumstances of the crime to suggest that it might be traced, even in the remotest degree, to conditions within France.
PITTSBURGH, May 7 (AP). -- A walk, a wild pitch, a triple and double and three Pirate errors in the first inning gave Philadelphia a clean sweep of the two-game series with Pittsburgh, 5 to 3, today.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Christian Gross of Chicago, second secretary of the legation at Ottawa, has been "separated" from the Foreign Service, the State Department announced today.

TODAY. 10:30 A.M. -- WABC -- The Grenadier Guards Band, music unit of one of England's crack historic regiments, plays a program from the London studios in memory of the American "March King," the late John Philip Sousa.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The estimated cost of all building construction in 311 principal cities through the United States declined $478,681,914, or 27 per cent, during 1931, un- der the preceding year, and reduced activities in Manhattan, New York, accounted for $61,000,000 of the de- dine, according to a report made public today by the Labor Department.

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Opening of its new home at 11 West Fifty-third Street and exhibition of murals by American painters and photographers, which remains for several weeks. Reviewed May 3 and on this page.

THE President has been determined ever since he took office really to base American policy on the Pact of Paris. HP believes in all measures honestly to avoid war, but is determined that these measures should not themselves envisage war.

Several athletes who formerly attended New York City public scools are named as prospects for places on this year's American Olympic team, on a list prepared by the American Olympic Committee and issued by Gustavus T. Kirby, chairman of the New York Committee of that body, who is also president of the P. S. A. L.

The difficulties of dressing and undressing in upper Pullman berths have been banished at last by the creation of a new berth which permits the removal and donning of clothing while the passenger stands erect, according to the May issue of The Pullman News, which reveals that the new berths went into experimental service on the "Motor City Special" of the Michigan Central Railroad between Chicago and Detroit April 10.

The amounts of the loans made by New York banks to the two Insull finance companies, Insull Utility Investments. Inc., and Corporation Securities Company, are as follows, according to advices from Chicago yesterday:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- The Yale and Williams golf teams each won two Intercollegiate League golf matches today over the Springdale links. The Yale golfers defeated Pennsylvania and Georgetown, while Williams won from Princeton and Georgetown.

SOUTHAMPTON. GREAT BRITAIN'S Royal Air Force has stolen a march on the Admiralty by ordering eighteen high-speed motor boats so revolutionary in design that not even the navy's experts had dreamed of them.

MOSCOW, May 7 (AP). -- A new economic alliance between Soviet Russia and Turkey, under which this country is extending an $8,000,000 longterm credit, was announced tonight by Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdi Bey of Turkey.

Roger Wolfe Kahn, son of Otto H. Kahn, and his wife, the former Hannah Williams of the musical comedy stage, separated ten days ago, it was disclosed yesterday by Max D. Steuer, attorney for the young orchestra leader. Mr. Steuer inserted in newspapers on behalf of Mr. Kahn the following notice:

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 7. -- Meher Baba, the Eastern mystic, will arrive here about May 15 to begin his redemption of America, according to Jean and Malcolm Schloss, who maintain his retreat here in a house belonging to Miss Margaret Mayo, playwright.

"Bulls, Bears and Asses," the Milton Herbert Gropper play about Wall Street, which opened at the Playhouse on Friday night, was withdrawn after its second performance yesterday afternoon. The cast, which had assembled for last evening's performance, was notified shortly before curtain time that there would be no show and the box office was instructed not to sell tickets.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The majority report of the House Ways and Means Committee on the bonus question is as follows:
RENO, Nev., May 7 (AP). -- Ann Harding, star of the films, today freed Harry Bannister from his marriage to her so that he might seek a new career for himself.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7. -- Yale overwhelmed Dartmouth's la- crosse team 8 to 2 today, Captain Harry Beggs leading the attack on the Indians with three goals.

Pastors in the city's churches will preach today on Mother's Day, and there will be special floral decorations and exercises by the children in many edifices in tribute to mothers. The annual parade and service of several military and Knights Templar organizations will take place this afternoon.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 7. -- Army carried off a victory in a dual track meet with Holy Cross today, the final score being 84 1/2 to 41 1/2. The Cadets took first places in eight of the fourteen events contested.

The development of new products and an improvement in the quality if products or services are the major aims of current research programs of 161 leading industrial companies, according to the preliminary findings of a survey of research activities of 1,600 laboratories by the National Research Council, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Authorizations for new Federal public buildings in New York State, including projects completed or planned, total $61,161,000, according to figures available at the Treasury today. Authorizations for new buildings throughout the country amount to $496,424,692.

POOR Mathllde came from Iowa, and wanted to write -- not because she had anything to say which impressed even herself as being important, but because it was the smart thing to do and it might, with luck, raise her and her husband and child from the miserable rut of poverty into which they had fallen.

AT the Zeiss works in Jena, Germany, Dr. Cohn has collected the rays of the sun in a mirror and focused them on some zirconium oxide, which melted at 5.432 decrees Fahrenheit. Encouraged by this success, Dr. Anderson of Mount Wilson Observatory is now constructing a gigantic solar furnace composed of nineteen burning-glasses.

MOSCOW, May 7 (AP). -- The Communist International, representing the Communist parties of all nations, protested in a statement tonight against what it called the identification by a French communique of President Doumer's assassin as a Communist agent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Walter Damrosch announces over a national radio network that he can recommend only two schools of music for Summer study. He then recommends a school in New York City of which his brother, Dr. Frank Damrosch, is director, and a school in France of which he himself is a sponsor.

THOSE who know something about the Berry Schools, at Mount Berry, Ga., marvel at their unique achievement. This simply and modestly told story of the life of the woman whose dream and achievement they are is evidence that she herself is quite as marvelous as what she has done.

Can Germany pay the reparations? We are going right here to say she can. Germany can pay the reparations fixed in the Young Plan; she could pay even more, provided, however -- and this is the most important point -- her creditors are willing to accept them. Here one may ask why shouldn't they? Let us see.

With Democratic members of the Hofstadter Committee quietly preparing to place new legal obstacles in the way of its investigation, George Trosk, who is associated with Samuel Seabury, the committee's counsel, announced yesterday that another important witness was missing.

"Hunger knows no holiday" is the slogan that has been adopted for the Salvation Army's united appeal campaign for $1,090,000 with which to continue its emergency relief and institutional aid activities in Greater New York.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7. -- For the first time in the history of the Kentucky Derby, which was inaugurated in 1875, it has been won three times by the same man.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- Six extra base blows, including a homer by Carl Reynolds and triples by Manush and Myer, gave Washington a 7-to-2 victory over Chicago today and Alvin Crowder his fifth winning start of the year.

Physicists have been battering the atom with results told elsewhere in today's NEW YORK TIMES. With the transmutation of the elements and the release of nuclear energy accomplished facts, although on an infinitesimal scale, the imagination soars to Utopia. A new chemistry suggests itself with a dominion over matter that makes our conversion of a noisome gas-house tar into a myriad rainbow tints and seductive scents seem like a child's playing in the sand.

THE delusion that the world is getting smaller and that all nations are arriving at a better understanding of their neighbors persists stoutly in this extraordinary world of ours, though sustained at the present time by little else than the unquenchable will to believe what nourishes our intellectual vanity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7. -- By taking first, second and third in the half-mile run Boston College was able to win the third annual Greater Boston intercollegiate track and fieid meet in the Harvard Stadium today by a margin of 5 1/2 points.
VIENNA, May 6. -- This year's conference of the Little Entente has been tentatively arranged for next week in Belgrade.

BROADCASTERS are continually delving in radio history to determine who first projected the human voice into space on the wings of electromagnetic waves. They find that KDKA, Pittsburgh, claims distinction as "the pioneer broadcasting station," because it went on the air with the Harding-Cox election returns, Nov. 2, 1920.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Gustav Miller, 22 years old, son of Max Miller, a wholesale grocer of Joliet, was returned to his home early today unharmed after a week in the hands of two abductors who had demanded $50,000 ransom. Investigators of the Secret Six asserted that four members of the kidnapping gang might have been captured had members of the family kept their promise to aid the authorities.

Professional Wall Street offered a familiar explanation to account for yesterday's moderate weakness after Friday's swift recovery. The "technical position" of the market had been misjudged; the short interest was not as large as it was thought to have been.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 7. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club la- crosse team scored its fourth straight victory of the season today, defeat- ing the Montclair A.C., 2 -- 1, in a hard-fought game.

IT was announced last Tuesday night at the final concert of the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra that the orchestra will give two series of ten concerts each next season. One will start Nov. 1, the other Nov. 8. They will take place on alternate Tuesdays at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Calling for a motion to adjourn, following charges of discourtesy against several members and guests of the Teachers Union, Dr. Henry R. Linville, its president, brought to a close yesterday the annual luncheon meeting of that organization and the Teachers Union Auxiliary, held in the Park Central Hotel, Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue.

The receiver for the International Match Corporation and counsel are deliberating on measures to prevent the sale by four banks of the controlling interest in the Diamond Match Company, which is held as collateral for a note of $3,800,000 owed by the International Match.

KING LEOPOLD conceived the modernized Congo. Jean Jadot was its builder. Jadot came of a family of engineers. Six of his uncles are engineers, so are his three brothers and so are to be his two sons and almost all his nephews. After constructing railways in Belgium, he was chosen to push the Egyptian line from Cairo to the Pyramids.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Navy's lacrosse team defeated Pennsylvania today 9 to 2. Navy registered four goals in the first half and five in the srcond. Penn's two goals came in the last half.
The winners of seven William Bayard Cutting Fellowships, with a stipend of $2,000 each, were announced yesterday at Columbia University by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. The appointees are:
PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- The Princeton University polo team and the Army quartet played a 6-6 deadlock, today on Devereaux Field. A second Princeton four overcame the Ohio State team, 8 -- 7.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 7. -- "Watch the Professor," by Sherman Rhodes, was presented tonight by the drama section of the Manor Club, under the direction of Sigourney Thayer.

FAR outshining in importance the exhibition that serves as an opening gesture is the Museum of Modern Art's embarkation upon its second "phase." Now comfortably installed in a home that provides so many facilities lacking before, the museum is in a position much mere satisfactorily to dramatize the platform upon which, three years ago, it based its bid for public attention and encouragement.
COMING here [to America] is an adventure overseas instead of underground. America and New York City are such exciting places that to visit them takes me back to Wonderland.

AS long ago as 1917 Doris Kenyon, who supports Spencer Tracy in "Young America," was making films as a star for the old Pathe company. Beginning as an ingenue. Miss Kenyon went by easy stages to the top of the heap in both the stage and screen, and now she appears every once and again in roles that are becoming appropriately more mature.

THIS month witnesses the prison entrance and exit respectively of leading characters in two of the most notorious events of American history of the last decade -- the rise of racketeering and the oil scandals. Last week the doors of the Federal Penitentiary at Atlanta closed upon Alphonse Capone.

In reply to a protective committee of Class A and common stockholders which had protested against a plan for the distribution of certain assets to preferred stockholders, the Union Tobacco Company has sent a letter to its stockholders asserting that the preferred stockholders cannot be compelled to surrender any of their rights.

Health education teachers, school physicians and nurses, students of otology and social workers will attend the first institute on conservation of hearing ever held in this country at the Grand Central Palace next Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on May 2 was 2,758,161 shares, a decrease of 521,237 shares from the total of 3,279,398 on April 1, it was announced yesterday. Most of the reduction occurred at the beginning of April, when the market declined for eight consecutive days.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The elusive trail of the $100,000 paid Gaston B. Means to bring about the return of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby today led Department of Justice agents to safety deposit boxes in the nation's capital as a part of a far-flung investigation.

A spectacular rally in the last half of the ninth inning saw the Poly Prep baseball team push three runs across the plate and come from behind to triumph over the Lawrence- vil's School nine, 5 to 3, on the victor's diamond in Brooklyn yesterday. It marked the sixth victory in eight series for the winners, while it was the fourth setback in eight games for the visitors.

MOSCOW, May 7. -- A stimulus to agriculture, more bread for individuals and a spur to petty trade generally are foreseen as a result of a decree just signed jointly by Joseph Stalin, Communist party chief, and Premier Molotoff.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 7. -- Emphasizing its stand for racial equality, the thirty-first general quadrennial conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church voted here today that it would never meet again in a city where the color line was drawn in hotels, restaurants and other public places.

OTTAWA, May 5. -- Parliament's present contribution to the good of the nation largely has been made, and while business of importance remains there is nothing which promises to delay prorogation more than two or three weeks. The House of Commons has achieved the calm, mellow and reasonable tone which ordinarily indicates the approaching finish, and business is going through at a great rate.

ADVENTURE lifts ambitious eyes again to the highest point of North America, the snowy summit of Mount McKinley in Alaska. Nineteen years have passed since Archdeacon Hudson Stuck and his three gasping, half-frozen companions stood on that exalted height and sang a Te Deum in thankfulness for the privilege.

Arrangements have been completed for the introduction of box lacrosse to this city, and on Tuesday night New York will have the opportunity to witness the modified form of the ancient Indian game for the first time.

TOKYO. TO answer the question: What do the Japanese think of America? one must begin by saying: Which America? Broadly speaking, those United States are personally known to Japan in two major incarnations -- missionary and business America.

Now faced with a serious decline in the number of transactions, as well as in dollar volume, retailers see a rise in the size of the average sale as a step that must be achieved if weakening of the structure of department store retailing is to be avoided.

HERE is a javelin hurled at the intellectuals by one of them. Max Nomad holds the intellectuals of the rev- olutionary camp responsible for the alleged impasse "at which the work- ing class has arrived after a hundred years of revolutionary propaganda and activity."

THE rapid growth in the number of folk-dance events in the concert calendar has taken on all the characteristics of a "trend," and like most trends it gives rise to certain misgivings as well as satisfaction. How, for example, is folk dancing to be presented in concert form when its value lies not in seeing it done but in doing it?

With the renomination of President Hoover on their national ticket a foregone conclusion, the Republican leaders in New York State are concentrating on a program for their State convention this Autumn and have worked out a tentative formula for their general campaign strategy.

IN 1913, that year when so much was begun and so much more was ended, there was a great showing in the shop windows throughout Germany of the Viennese "black and white," which by that time had stormed the citadel of the decorators, presided over the palette of the ceramist, ruled the dressmakers and lent to the general effect of everything an air of gayety, of adventure, a brilliant colorless vivacity.

DETROIT. MOTOR company executives are giving more than casual consideration to the question of whether they are offering too much variety to the buying public. Dealers have protested they find it impossible to finance the purchase of a complete line of chassis models and body types and that they lack the space in which to display them properly.
The Fordham University baseball team shut out Seton Hall College, 4 to 0, at Fordham Field yesterday in a pitchers' battle before 2,000 spectators.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7. -- Five Princeton crews triumphed today in the first regatta of the season over the Lake Carnegie course. The Tiger varsity, junior varsity, lightweight and freshman eights all defeated the M.I.T. crews and the freshman lightweight eight won from Hun School.

IN view of recent events, this book is especially timely. As in the author's earlier volumes on Spain and Germany, it is intended to further the reader's acquaintance with the inhabitants of the country as they are at home, in order that they may be better understood abroad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That "certain condescension in foreigners" which James Russell Lowell noted and America resented has become an American trait. Our country looks down upon, with pity and condescension, all foreigners and all of her own citizens who make their homes in foreign lands.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Hubar, bay gelding of Howard Bruce, Baltimore, owner of the famous Billy Barton, won the Harston Plate, feature steeplechase event of the Whitemarsh Valley Hunt Club, today.

THE suggestion by the Senate Finance Committee to increase the levy on brewers' wort in the pending tax bill directs attention to a comparatively new development in the liquor business and related lines. Although wort-pronounced "wurt" -- is unfamiliar to the layman, it has already caused a number of contro- versies among prohibition officials and in State Legislatures, whose members see in it a valuable source of revenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 22. -- As one of the many reforms promised by the present Brazilian Government, the customs laws are about to be revised after remaining unchanged for the last thirty-two years. It is expected that the changes will be highly beneficial to American merchants shipping goods here.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 7. -- Racing and pleasure craft of the Frostbite Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America sailed into Echo Bay today for the final regatta of the season for the Frostbite fleet. The Cruising Club, represented by fifty yachts in early commission, was host to the dinghy skippers.

DETROIT, May 7. -- Henry Ford, who told President Hoover recently of his plan for an employment liaison between industry and agriculture, is using the national organization of the Ford Motor Company to spread his doctrine that the best employment insurance is Mother Earth.

COPENHAGEN. AS she would come sailing rather than walking down the street, the villagers would speak of her as the Bark Juliane. She suggested not so much a living human being as a house, a race, a succession of generations.

LONDON, April 26. -- It would be contrary to my intention and wearisome to the readers of these articles if they degenerated into barren controversy between Dr. Julius Curtius and me. That can be neither his wish nor mine, but I feel bound to comment on his recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES in the hope of reaching a practical basis for present cooperation and future progress.

Cardinal Hayes has suggested that Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York remember in their wills St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y. The suggestion is made in a letter to his pastors which will be read today at all masses.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 7. -- A pow- erful Yale freshman lacrosse team outplayed Andover Academy and won handily, 6 to 0, today.

MANAGUA, April 29. -- Donald Leroy Trucsdale of Lugoff, S.C., 29 years old, a corporal of the United States Marine Corps, is being recommended to the Secretary of the Navy for the Congressional Medal of Honor for exceptional heroism above and beyond the call of duty performed at the risk of his life while serving as a Lieutenant in the National Guard of Nicaragua.

The Goldsborough bill, instructing the Federal Reserve to put up prices to a level 49 per cent above the present aver age, has fallen flat notwithstanding the House vote of 289 to 60 in its favor. This was certainly not because the people at large did not wish for recovery it staple prices; it was because of immediate recognition that the objective stated in the bill was wholly unattainable through the means prescribed.

Although able to take only three first places on the fifteen-event program, representatives of Douglas Junior High captured the city P.S. A.L. junior high schools outdoor track and field championship at the General George W. Wingate Memorial Field in Brooklyn yesterday morning in the annual meet, in which six records were created and three equaled.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Capturing first place in thirteen of the fourteen events and making a clean sweep in two, Temple's track and field team routed City College, 97 5-6 to 28 1-6, in the first dual meet of the season for both teams today at the Temple Stadium.

A new era, in which profit margins for exporters here will be larger than they ever were in the past, has opened in trade with South America, according to George K. Campbell, export trade counselor of the Ernst B. Filsinger Company, who returned last week from a four months' tour of Latin America.

HONOLULU, May 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Thalia Massie, who is reported suffering from a nervous breakdown, was sought unsuccessfully today by police, who held a subpoena demand ing her presence May 25 at the retrial of four Hawaiians charged with assaulting her.

TOKYO, April 23. -- Criticisms that he American Asiatic Fleet is of low fighting value, and that Admiral Taylor's chief anxiety during the Shanghai affair must have been to avoid collision with the Japanese are made in reviews of the situation by Commander Shinsaku Hirata a popular writer on naval subjects who is sometimes called the Japanese By-waters.

TOKYO, April 23. -- Criticisms that he American Asiatic Fleet is of low fighting value, and that Admiral Taylor's chief anxiety during the Shanghai affair must have been to avoid collision with the Japanese are made in reviews of the situation by Commander Shinsaku Hirata a popular writer on naval subjects who is sometimes called the Japanese By-waters.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 7. -- Assurances that he would receive the twenty-four delegates from Tennessee were conveyed to Governor Roosevelt today by a group of supporters from Knoxville, who motored here to visit him.

IN the short novel "Miner," drama and general literary worth are combined to a marked degree . Mr. Boden, who is the author of two collections of poems based on the life of the English coal miner, knows whereof he writes. At the age of 13, one year below the age at which he allows Danny, the central figure of his novel, to enter the mines.

ALTHOUGH the better part of two centuries has elapsed since Horatio Nelson was born at Burnnam Thorpe in Norfolk and more than a century has passed since Admiral Lord Nelson died on the Victory in the Battle of Trafalgar, a host of biographers is still inspired by his character and his achievements to attempt the solution of one of the most interesting biographical puzzles of our day.

GENEVA. JUDGING from the quotations one hears and sees of it, the thing for which Aristide Briand may be most remembered will be not Locarno or the Pact that bears his name, or the European Union he fathered, but the oath he gave the world, in taking it first of all himself:

That can be neither his wish nor mine, but I feel bound to comment on his recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES in the hope of reaching a practical basis for present cooperation and future progress.

Cardinal Hayes has suggested that Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York remember in their wills St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y. The suggestion is made in a letter to his pastors which will be read today at all masses.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 7. -- A pow- erful Yale freshman lacrosse team outplayed Andover Academy and won handily, 6 to 0, today.

The observance of Mothers' Day yesterday furnished a topic for sermons in many churches, the pastors being almost unanimous in finding motherhood and the influence of the home the ideal foundation of the social order. Some warned that changing this ideal or slipping away from it would bring disaster.

Seeking a means of preventing a rapid drop in average unit sales, retailers in the markets here last week turned their attention to better merchandise. Many stores are planning promotions on more expensive items because of the steady declines in retail volume in the last few weeks.

TOKYO, Monday, May 9. -- Reassuring reports and recommendations regarding Russo-Japanese relations have been brought back from Manchuria by Tokichi Tanaka, former Ambassador to Moscow, who has just returned from a mission of investigation on behalf of Foreign Minister Yoshizawa, to whom he will report probably today.

MONTREAL, May 8 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals ran their winning streak to nine straight and moved into a tie for second place today when they beat Jersey City, 6-5, before 11,000 fans. The Royals wiped out an early Jersey City lead of four runs to win.

Although the lengthened period of instruction in the teacher-training colleges will provide a broader preparation for teachers in the city's schools, the formulation of the best course of study will be a difficult task because of the wide difference of opinion among educators on the question, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, says in his annual report, another part of which is made public today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 8. -- Shipments of all grains last week were well above the totals in 1931. Quotations were weak. Russian inquiry for an Argentine wheat shipment to the Baltic was unconfirmed but probable.

Harry F. Gerguson, who calls himself Michael Romanoff, the stowaway who escaped from Ellis Island last Thursday night while under sentence to be deported to France tomorrow in the De Grasse, was captured at 11 o'clock last night at Second Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street by Erwin F. Brown, chief of the Division of Investigation of the United States Department of Labor, assisted by Frank Angel, an agent of the department, and Inspector George A. Dole.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 8. -- An old violin, believed to be a Stradivarius, is locked in the City Hall vault of the Perth Amboy Water Department pending a court action to decide its ownership.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- In a tense, fourteen-inning struggle Washington won the rubber game of the series from the White Sox today, 6 to 5. Each team previously had won one game.
CLEVELAND, May 8 (AP). -- Philadelphia's Athletics went down to defeat before the Cleveland Indians, 8 to 5, while a near-record crowd of 21,000 at League Park looked on today.

It is a false accusation to say that the church is "meddling" with affairs beyond its province when it passes judgment on the theatre and current plays, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared in a sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
DUBLIN, May 8. -- Higher taxes and wholesale reductions in official salaries are expected in the de Valera Government's first budget, which will be introduced in the Dail Eireann on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- In the face of resubmission declarations by some Republican State conventions, the Anti-Saloon League, through F. Scott McBride, general superintendent, issued today a statement attacking the resubmission plan.

Popular notions about a sharp increase in crime among the young in recent years were sharply challenged by Dr. CARLETON SIMON, former Special Deputy Commissioner of New York City, in an address before the New Jersey Police Chiefs in Newark on Thursday.

BERLIN, May 1 (Science Service). -- Reinmuth's "comet," discovered Dec. 31, 1931, by Dr. K. Reinmuth of the Badische Landes-Sternwarte at Heidelberg, has proved to be a new minor planet, according to calculations announced here by the Astronomisches Recheninstitut, which keeps track of discoveries of these tiny planets, or asteroids.

George and Martha Washington, in the persons of prominent Brooklyn citizens, sat on the lawn yesterday afternoon in front of the reproduction of Mount Vernon in Prospect Park, on the very ground upon which the Father of His Country masterfully marshalled his outnumbered troops in the Battle of Long Island, and heard Mayor Walker and other speakers point the lessons in patriotism and fortitude which the life of the Revolutionary leader teaches.

PARIS, May 6. -- The confusing impressions of the French elections were reflected in this week's Bourse, which declined sharply in the early part of the week on the news of Sunday's voting, then reversed its attitude on Thursday, when prices distinctly improved, only to fall into renewed weakness on Friday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 8. -- Corny Shields today wound up the all-Winter racing of the Frostbite Yacht Club with a total of twenty-six victories and thereby led all the other dinghy skippers in the number of victories scored. He added two triumphs in the final contests, which were the end of the two-day regatta arranged by the Cruising Club of America off the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

Blaming Congress for its recent delays in enacting tax legislation and attacking the backers of bonuses for war veterans, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, minister of All Souls Unitarian Church, meeting at 166 East Seventy-third Street, declared in his sermon yesterday that the time has come for more intolerance in politics.

Three dance performances, all with considerably more than a casual bow to music, were to be found in yesterday's program of concerts, when Anita Zahn and a group of Elizabeth Duncan Dancers appeared at a matinee in the Guild Theatre, and the Ukrainian Bicentennial Committee gave both matinee and evening showings of its "Tribute to Washington" at Carnegie Hall.

Floyd Gibbons, who reported for the Hearst papers in a fashion that certainly was his own the horrible details of the recent unofficial war between the Chinese and the Japanese, bobs up in the middle of what is the last of the so-called "two-a-day" programs at the Palace for the present to relate his experiences to vaudevillegoers.

The City Affairs Committee called upon Surrogate John Hetherington of Queens yesterday to reconsider his action in dismissing charges against John Theofel, Democratic leader of Queens and chief clerk of his court.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- White House conferences on taxation and the administration's economy program were continued tonight, with another group of prominent Republican Senators discussing the situation with the President.

IF Buzz Arlett keeps up his bombardment, the fans in the International League will soon be seeing the games free of charge. Buzz has been knocking down all the fences in the circuit. An odd case, Arlett. The big fellow was a star on the Coast for years, but the majors passed him up because he played a stationary defense in the field. Finally the Phillies took a chance on him.

GENEVA, May 8. -- The beginning of the Japanese evacuation of Shanghai marks what is perhaps the League's most substantial achievement in the struggle with the Japanese military. Yet the news of the evacuation is received here as passively as was the signature of the armistice.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Charges that American sugar refiners are seeking a new "super-tariff" with which to put makers of white sugar in Cuba out of business and then ruin the beet-sugar industry in the United States, are contained in a brief to be filed tomorrow with the Tariff Commission by Daniel C. Roper of Washington and Frank Roberson of New York, counsel for opponents of the proposed increase.

Persons close to Mayor Walker indicated yesterday their belief that the breach between the Mayor and Controller Berry has been widened by recent events beyond conciliation. While all through the first and second Walker administrations the two have differed on matters of policy, the feeling now runs much deeper, it was said.

The gray-clad men and officers of the 107th Infantry and a detachment of the veterans of the old Seventh Regiment in civilian clothes marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to the Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the annual services were held for those who died during the last year.

The World War, because it was the chief contributing cause of the current economic depression, constitutes the best insurance against another war Arnold Zweig, author, declared in a radio broadcast from Berlin yesterday, which was re-broadcast in the United States by WABC and a national network.

A reorganization plan for the Ground Gripper Shoe Company, now in bankruptcy, has been formulated by a committee representing holders of its convertible debentures and the general unsecured creditors of the company in cooperation with creditors having secured claims.
BOSTON, May 8 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox broke their eight-game losing streak today by defeating the St. Louis Browns, 7 to 5, in the final game of their series.
Scoring six runs in the first inning to clinch the victory, the New York A.C. baseball team turned back the Saranac Field Club, 10 -- 4, in a seven-inning contest at Travers Island yesterday.

New York's re-creation of events connected with Washington's first inauguration is presented in detail on the screen of the Trans-Lux news-reel house this week. Among the other twenty-eight subjects are scenes of the society charity ball in Madison Square Garden, the departure of Al Capone for Atlanta Penitentiary, the May Day celebration at Wellesley College, British aviators in blind flying manoeuvres, track and swimming meets and the Akron launching two planes in midair.

BASLE. May 8. -- When the governors of the Central banks of Europe met here today, preliminary to the annual meeting this week of the stockholders of the Bank for International Settlements, their discussions were again dominated by an unexpected event of world importance occurring on the eve of their meeting.
EASTON, Pa., May 8. -- A two weeks celebration, marking the centennial of the founding of Lafayette College opens here tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 8. -- Methods of combating an increase of incendiary fires throughout the country, reported during the first four months of this year and believed due to the business depression, will be the principal topic of discussion at the annual meeting of the National Fire Protection Association, which opens here tomorrow.

The new Matson liner Monterey will dock this morning at Pier 58. North River, en route from the Bethlehem shipyard at Quincy, Mass., to San Francisco, where she will be operated in the South Seas-New Zealand-Australian service. She is the sister ship of the Mariposa, which sailed last January on her maiden trip and of the Liurline.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The time has come when some attention should be given to the attacks being made upon the work of the Block-Aid Workers, the City Work Commission and the Home Relief Bureau by agitators, Communists and other malcontents.

The late General ENOCH H. CROWDER was a many-sided and very human kind of man. The impression that he had an arid legal mind, worked like a machine making so many revolutions a minute and took no pleasure in anything but precedents and the statute and military law was not just to him.

Fifteen revolver shots echoed in Sheridan Square at 2:20 A.M. yesterday when two gunmen tried to shoot their way out of the Four Trees, a Greenwich Village night club, after holding up 100 patrons of the place. After a patron and a waiter had been wounded the robbers were captured.

The number of students needing help from scholarship funds has doubled during the last year. Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College said yesterday in issuing an appeal for financial aid to relieve this condition at Barnard.
