The statement by the Welfare Council that the expenditures for unemployment relief by public and private agencies in the month of March alone were $6,700,000, suggests the immensity of the undertaking, as well as the generous disposition of the community.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. had Everett Colby and Everett Colby Jr. as their luncheon guests at the Casino.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Donald M. Ryerson, chairman of the board of Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc., steel manufacturers, shot himself through the heart this morning on the beach adjoining his home at 261 North Mayflower Road, Lake Forest. He was 47 years old.

By administering a sound beating to Paul De Bruyn, winner of the recent Boston marathon. 20-year-old William Steiner of the 258th Field Artillery gained serious consideration for a berth on the American Olympic team yesterday in capturing the Metropolitan A.A.U. marathon championship, staged over Brooklyn streets by the Major James A. McKenna Jr. Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

PARIS, Monday, May 9. -- Premier Andre Tardieu's majority in the Chamber of Deputies, which was shaken last Sunday on the first ballot, went down in crashing defeat yesterday when the combined Left vote in more than 200 of the remaining 359 constituencies won seat after seat.

Competition for places on the team which will represent the United States in the Olympic modern pentathlon championship at Los Angeles this Summer will get under way today and be concluded on Saturday. The pentathlon represents tests in fencing, riding, shooting swimming and running.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., May 8. -- Clifford E. Grover's Spray scored a brilliant victory today in the opening contest of the Olympic elimination series as international star class sloops of the Barnegat Bay and Ocean City fleets opened the 1932 yachting season on Jersey waters.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 8. -- In his first public appearance since he announced his decision to become a "business man golfer," Jerome D. Travers, winner of four national amateur golf championships, and his partner, William Reekie, former metropolitan amateur champion, triumphed in an exhibition match at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

A plea for the United States and Great Britain to join in a study of the money problem to bring an end to "these absurd nightmare years" of depression was made last night by Winston Churchill, a member of the British Parliament and former Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Why in 1929, they recommended the sale of stock of the Electric Bond and Share Company to officers and employes and, in 1931, advised cancellation of the plan, is told in detail in a memorandum mailed yesterday to stockholders ot the company by the six directors who were responsible for the moves.
BANNER ELK, N.C., May 8. -- Banner Elk residents may have read about the business slump in their newspapers, but they have not felt it.

AKRON, Ohio, May 7 (AP). -- William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, disclosed today that his company had initiated an offer to take over the holdings of the Fisk Tire Company. Mr. O'Neil said negotiations were not now under way, because of the inability of the companies to agree on a price.

LYONS, France, May 8. -- Twenty-seven persons are known to have perished in a landslide that destroyed two apartment houses on the outskirts of the city this morning, burying most of their inhabitants.

In a letter addressed to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, made public yesterday, Howard W. Nudd, director of the Public Education Association, challenges the accuracy of Dr. O'Shea's assertion that "the appraisal of the experimental program so far conducted in the Little Red School-house -- Public School 41, Manhattan -- justified its discontinuance."

PARIS, May 8. -- On the invitation of many friends in both houses of Parliament and with the support of the Paris press, Albert Lebrun, President of the Senate, decided this afternoon to be a candidate for the Presidency of the Republic to succeed the assassinated Paul Doumer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your financial section today there appeared the following paragraph:
NEW YORK. Captain Count Gustaf-Fredrik von Rosen, military attache of the Swedish Legation, is at the St. Regis.

Mayor WALKER made a thinly veiled attack upon Controller BERRY when the new bus franchise was before the Board of Estimate last week. Evidently referring to the Controller's testimony regarding the Equitable scandal, he denounced any man who would defame the city in that way as a "public enemy."

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- As a result of two years of study with the Wickersham Commission and, subsequently, sixteen months of personal observation, George W. Wickersham feels "more strongly than ever" that a national referendum on prohibition is needed.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- A charge that President Hoover had "yielded to the common temptation to play politics at a time when no one, be he Democrat or Republican, should seek personal political advantage," was made today by Representative McDuffie of Alabama, House Democratic whip.

Leasing of retail store locations featured renting announced over the week-end by brokers and managing agents of Manhattan buildings. Several office leases also were reported. Negotiations said to have been carried on over a period of two years resulted in the leasing of the store and basement at 40 Wall Street to Roger Kent, Inc., men's clothiers.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 8. -- With a week of rest and recreation behind him, Governor Roosevelt faces more political activity this week at his Pine Mountain cottage.

Senator BORAH is admittedly one of the most interesting men now in our public life. He is not only a ready debater and moving orator but a student. He seldom makes a full-dress speech in the Senate, but when he does all ears are stretched to hear him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The radio, pulpit, press and almost every other medium of public expression are united in a chorus crying for leadership-national leaders of the Washington, Lincoln and Roosevelt stripe. Those men who happen to be holding the reins of government at present are being accused of grossly lacking the necessary qualities of leadership.
NEW ORLEANS, May 8 (AP). -- "Floating" to health and underwater massage for recovery from physical injuries will be demonstrated to the American Medical Association here tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, May 8. -- The Giants und Cardinals, striving desperately to extricate themselves from the second division, fought to a standstill today in a long double-header on a sweltering afternoon.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP). -- Ambitious gang leaders today looked across a field studded with forbidding obstacles toward the throne deserted by Scarface Al Capone.

WHITE PLAINS, N.T., May 8. -- According to the report of tax collectors in the different cities, towns and villages of Westchester County, there has been no falling off in the payment of taxes of land owners, which is very pleasing to officials and shows that despite the past days of depression Westchester folk believe in paying their taxes.

Edouard Herriot, leader of the French Radical Socialist party, is not likely to introduce extremist policies if he again becomes Premier following his party's victory in yesterday's election for the Chamber of Deputies. The policies of M. Herriot, as indicated in his recent speeches, would be classed here as nothing more than "liberal."

PARIS, May 6. -- Disclosures of the Kreuger embezzlements, and of the fact that they ran back through several years of the later history of his enterprises, have caused veritable stupefaction in financial Paris. It was recalled this week how all of our financial people had entertained the greatest confidence in Kreuger's personal integrity and in the correctness of his business methods.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The votes in the Senate and House by members of the delegations from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island on important roll-calls last week, are given in the tabulation below. This record does not include all important votes in either branch of Congress, as measures are frequently adopted or rejected without a roll-call being taken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Can my wife and I qualify in the field -- bigger and better families for intellectuals? We are both college graduates or more; my wife has professsional training in art, and I in education. We have five children, all girls at that.

The common inquiry, when two people conversant with financial affairs match opinion nowadays, is "Do you see any light?" The usual answer is, "Not yet." There has in fact been little in the recent financial picture on which the imagination could fasten as indicating, even remotely, a distinct turn for the better.

CAIRO, April 10 (By Mail). -- The fly season has begun and visitors from the United States and Europe who have been to Upper Egypt are returning and leaving for home via Italy and the South of France.

Referring to the coal miners of the Harlan strike district of Kentucky as "starving, destitute, hungry, miserable people," the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, who returned several days ago from a visit there, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, that religion has paradoxically lessened sympathy for the strikers.
OAKLAND, Cal., May 8 (AP). -- Jimmy Sharp of Los Angeles died tonight from injuries received in the 100-mile motor car race at the Oakland Speedway today.

Vehicular traffic on privately owned and operated ferry lines and through the Holland Tunnel were the only forms of transportation into and out of the city which made better showings in 1931 than in 1930, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

More than 100,000 persons fare expected to take part in the "Beer for Taxation." parade sponsored by Mayor Walker this coming Saturday, the committee in charge of arrangements announced yesterday. Nearly 60,000 already are listed as participants as the result of questionnaires returned to the committee, but that figure does not include some of the largest labor organizations and a number of fraternal and business organizations that will take part, the committee said.

With their candidate's boom checked by his defeat by Speaker John N. Garner in California and the loss of that State's forty-four votes in the Democratic National Convention, supporters of Franklin D. Roosevelt still believe that he will have more than a majority of the delegates and that his nomination, may be brought about by arrangements with delegations from States not originally supporting him.

Many having the strongest sympathy with the purpose of the Noise Abatement Commission have criticized it for what has appeared to be the futility of its efforts. They may not have realized that it has no power to enforce existing ordinances against noise, nor to see that its further suggestions are obeyed.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP). -- After knocking the Boston Braves from their perch at the top of the National League in their first Western invasion, the Cincinnati Reds made a clean sweep of the four-game series today by winning, 6 to 5.

MEXICO CITY, May 8. -- Extreme indignation evidence from Congressional circles down at the exhibition in a leading downtown theatre of a motion picture film "La Paloma -- Girl of the Rio" in which Dolores Del Rio and Leo Carrillo, both Mexicans, lend themselves to a production regarded as "highly insulting" to their country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 8. -- American law enforcement agencies must devote more time to curbing the criminal tendencies of the juvenile if they are to check the increase in crime that has swept the country in recent years, Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney of New York told members of the Buffalo Police Department today at their annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Statler.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 (AP). -- There was jubilation in the blue grass region of Kentucky today, as friends from far and near gathered at Colonel E.R. Bradley's Idle Hour Farm near Lexington to felicitate him on being the only turfman to win three Kentucky Derbies.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 8. -- Following the lead of the United States Steel Corporation, independent steel makers here will reduce wages 15 per cent, effective on May 15. Most of the fabricating interests allied with the steel trade will make similar reductions.

LIMA, Peru, May 8. -- By jumping overboard from the cruiser Almirante Grau and swimming through the black waters of Callao Harbor to a submarine, a loyal Peruvian sailor last night warned the government of a naval coup in time to block the movement before it got well under way and to prevent what appears to have been planned as a serious revolt against the Sanchez Cerro Government.

Wives who eat their breakfasts in bed and give their husband delicatessen suppers were taken to task by the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin in his sermon yesterday morning in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, where he is completing twenty-seven years as pastor.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Cereal interests absorbed more than 3,000,000 bushels of oats on May deliveries early last week and shipped out a good part of them to Eastern plants. They are consuming about an average quantity of this grain and are buying liberally of heavy oats in central Illinois for shipment to their plants in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

PARIS, May 8 (AP). -- Hushed in mourning for the late President Paul Doumer, victim of an assassin's bullets, France voted apathetically. The assassination, which was expected in some quarters to halt the swing toward the Left displayed in the first election last Sunday, apparently had no political effect on the voting.

A trip to Europe this Summer has been awarded to Robert Spencer Whitlow, 17-year-old high school student of Tulsa, Okla., who was declared winner yesterday of the sixth national competitive examination for high schools on the League of Nations.

Art, music and dramatic critics with little knowledge of the subjects they criticize and who attempt to cover up their ignorance by unwarranted attacks on these subjects themselves were criticized last night by Charles Rann Kennedy, play-wright and actor.

Eugene O'Neill's trilogy, "Mourning Becomes Electra," will begin a return engagement of two weeks, at popular prices, this afternoon at the Alvin Theatre. In the cast will be Judith Anderson, Florence Reed, Crane Wilbur, Thurston Hall, Walter Abel and other members of the road company which has recently played the larger mid-Western cities.
The interest of the shipping companies in this port is concentrated upon what is going to happen tomorrow at the big meeting of the North Atlantic Conference Lines in London.

HAVANA, May 7. -- An attempt to relieve in some measure the desperate situation faced by Cuba's sugar industry by the utilization of surplus cane for the manufacture of alcohol is now being studied by Congress and is said to have the support of the administration.

LAKEHUKST, N.J., May 8. -- The silver shape of the United States Navy's biggest dirigible passed through a disarray of dark clouds and sunlight today as she started from the naval air station here on her long air voyage to the shores of the Pacific.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 8 (AP). -- Albert B. Fall, having served the required part of his prison sentence for acceptance of a bribe, today awaited the arrival of amended commitment papers which will set him free.

BERLIN, May 8 (AP). -- Chancellor Heinrich Bruening emphatically served notice again today that Germany "cannot pay reparations." He predicted the European financial conference at Lausanne a month hence would lead the way either to world recovery or world collapse.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- China has temporarily discontinued sending students from the National Tsing Hua University at Peiping to the United States for education under the Boxer Indemnity Fund. This action is due to the need of funds for developing a graduate school, and the sending of students will be resumed in 1933 or 1934, Dr. Y.R. Chao, Director of the Chinese Educational Mission, said today.

GARDEN, CITY, L.I., May 8. -- Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island revealed himself here today as the "good friend" of all parishes who has relieved the parishioners of their duty to contribute to the Bishop's salary.

The quality of fiction offered magazines today is slumping to a new low after twenty years of slow advance, William C. Lengel, associate editor of Cosmopolitan, which spends more than $500,000 yearly for short stories, novels and articles, said in an interview yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 8. -- Steel ingot production rose about one point last week from the rate of the three weeks preceding. Producers remained in doubt as to whether a definite upturn of consequence had begun, but felt that there was a trend in that direction.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Farm Board has protested to Congress against the drastic reduction in its appropriation proposed for the coming fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- Awidening search for $100,000 turned over to Gaston B. Means to return the kidnapped Lindbergh baby today took government detectives to the records of Means's past.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- High oficials of the government and of the army and navy today joined in paying tribute to the mothers of America.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, is seeking to connect State Senator John A. Hastings, the "political contact man" for the Equitable Coach Company, with a franchise application now pending before the Board of Estimate.

Readjusted wage scales in the building trades have brought out for bidding many small construction projects that were held in abeyance because of uncertainty as to the amount of the wage cut and the prospect of a general strike. Alien E. Beals of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports attaches some significance to these projects because of the fact that they have survived the strike crises in the construction, industry.
PEORIA, Ill., May 8 -- Ten men and two women charged with kidnapping Dr. James W. Parker for ransom will go on trial tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Combined activities of the Federal Reserve Banks and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since early in February have placed at the disposal of banks, railroads and others approximately a billion dollars in the powerful drive to check deflation and depression.

HANOI, French Indo-China, May 8. -- Five hundred persons, including several Europeans, were killed by a hurricane that swept in from the China Sea across the southern tip of the State of Annam last Wednesday, it was learned today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 8. -- Miss Maxine Clarke, 22 years old, a Smith College junior, whose home is at 25 Garden Place, Brooklyn, N.Y., was killed last night and Miss Cornelia Williamson, a sophomore of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was seriously injured, as were James Kennedy and Leonard Wordsworth of Holyoke, Mass., when the car in which they were riding crashed into a fence in Hadley, Mass.

Only three matches were played in the North Side tennis championship tournament at the University Heights Tennis Club yesterday, but one of them provided a surprise for the small gallery in attendance.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 8. -- Election of seventy-two members and associate members of the Cornell chapter of Sigma Xi, national honorary society for which those who have been outstanding in scientific research are eligible, is announced here by Howard B. Adelmann, secretary of the chapter.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 8 (AP). -- Eusebio Ayala, candidate of the dominant Liberal party, is expected to be Paraguay's next President as a result of an election today. Raoul Casal Ribeiro, a Liberal nominee for Vice President, seemed equally sure of winning.

Drug, Inc. -- Earning for the quarter ended March 31, 1932, $4,561,573, equivalent to $1.30 a share on the 3,501,499 shares outstanding, compared with $5,384,146 for the first quarter of 1531, equivalent to $1.54 a share on the same number of shares outstanding.

A forum originally arranged to discuss "the theatre and civic politics," held last night at the Union Methodist Church, 227 West Forty-eighth Street, soon resolved itself into a spirited discussion of the action of License Commissioner James F. Geraghty in withholding a license from the theatre in which "Merry-Go-Round," a melodrama of municipal corruption, was scheduled to open last Tuesday.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. was the principal guest and speaker yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Church of Christ the King, Grand Concourse and Marcy Place, the Bronx. Members of the society attended mass and received communion at the church and the breakfast was held at the Hotel Concourse Plaza.

ELKTON, Ky., May 8 (AP). -- Sheriff Robert T. Kirkman of Todd County was seriously wounded early this morning when he attempted to arrest two men on warrants charging assault and battery. The men were placed under arrest, and while other officers were taking them to jail, their automobile crashed into a tree and one of the prisoners was killed, the other escaping.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 8. -- The cotton market reached new low levels for the season In the early part of last week, when on Monday July dropped to 5.45 and October to 5.66, or forty points below the closing-figures the previous Friday. These levels were the lowest reached by cotton contracts since the Fall of 1898, when contracts dropped to 4.75, the lowest point since the beginning of future trading.

AMSTERDAM, May 6. -- The Kreuger affair is regarded in this market as an absolutely unique scandal in economic history; no precedent is found for it. The combination of genuine industrial achievement and fraudulent behavior which has marked the personal career of Kreuger with his companies is characterized as a wholly extraordinary incident in the world's financial history.

The protective committee for holders of Coral Gables (Fla.) bonds which are in default announced yesterday that the voters of the city had approved by a favorable majority the plan for refunding the indebtedness. The committee said there had been deposited or pledged with it approximately $6,000,000 of the $8,000,000 bonds outstanding, and virtually the entire floating debt of the city amounting to $500,000.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the bridge tournament in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York to be held this afternoon in the ballroom of the Plaza. A committee headed by Miss Ethel Boyd Bowers has made the plans.

"Within the view of scores of Sunday motorists on Queens Boulevard, Joseph Trapasso, 10 years old, of 84-46 127th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, was drowned yesterday with his chum, Morrio Guribba, 13, of 84-13 127th Street, Richmond Hill, in a pond beside the boulevard at Eighty-second Road, when he made a futile attempt to rescue the older boy.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 8. -- Support for a national forty-eight-hour general strike will be asked at the State Federation of Labor convention in Reading on Tuesday by representatives of textile unions which have had the plan under consideration.

The popular notion of a librarian as a mouselike person of uncertain years, with an insatiable appetite for dry literature, is belied the the exhibition of work by staff members, current in the picture collection of the New York Public Library. The work is, almost without exception, original and contagiously alive.

LIMA, Peru, May 8 (AP). -- Sailor Communists staged a spectacular revolt with the only two cruisers In the Peruvian Navy today, but four shots from a submarine were all that was necessary to bring down the red flag and run up the white.

BOSTON, May 8. -- Clasped in the arms of his wife, Mary Alice Lewis, 63, whom he had apparently killed with a hammer, William H. Lewis, 63, was found dead today by police who forced their way into his gasfilled home at 520 Brook Road, Milton.

The latest word from Peconic Bay is that fishermen expect to be catching weakfish by tomorrow or Wednesday on the surface of the water. In the last few days, squid has been the bait as most of the fish caught have been on the bottom, and the best luck appears, to have been toward late afternoon or after sun-down, from five to nine o'clock.

Forty sons of Erin resident here, hardy Gaelic football players all of them, struggled through a practice game yesterday at Innisfail Field in a bid for selection on the All-New York squad, which will face the visiting world's champion. Mayo team of Ireland next Sunday at the Polo Grounds in the interests of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman.

BASLE. May 8 (AP). -- The directors of the Bank for International Settlements will divide 24,600 shares of stock, which still is unallocated, among the original shareholders at their monthly meeting tomorrow. They also will elect a successor to Sir Charles Addis, British vice chairman, who is retiring.

LYONS, May 8 (AP). -- The two apartment houses destroyed by landslides here today were located in the middle-class Caliure district on the outskirts of the city, near Fourviere Hill, where a similar disaster occurred in November, 1930.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 8. -- Built with fortress-like strength, with vaulted underground chambers and looms paneled in hardwoods, a strange structure, believed to be the temple of one of the many mystery religions which flourished when Rome ruled the known world, has been excavated from the ruins of Dime, an ancient town in the Egyptian Fayoum, during the first season of work on the site by the archaeologists of the University of Michigan.

Speaking on the growing divergence in definitions of religion, the Rev. Dr. Goodrich Gates preached his farewell sermon yesterday in the Presbyterian Church of the Puritans, 15 West 130th Street. He is to become pastor of the First Presbyterian Church at Kingston, N.Y., next Sunday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 8. -- The 15 per cent pay cut by the United States Steel Corporation and the satisfaction with which it was greeted by investors were cited to the thirty-first quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this city today as indicative of "the kind of pagan world we live in."
BALTIMORE, May 8. -- With some restraints in its 200-year-old blue laws removed, Baltimore today, for the first time in its history, celebrated a liberal Sunday.

Four Per Cent of Happiness. It may be true that a happy nation has no annals, but the rule does not apply to college students. Happy or not, they have to record their emotions in little books if they happen to sign up for certain psychology courses.

CINCINNATI, May 8. -- H.J. (Dick) Thompson, trainer of E.R. Bradley's Kentucky Derby winner. Burgoo King, said today aboard the Cincinnati Limited, en route to New York, that he hoped to start the Bubbling Over colt in the Preakness at Pimlico on Saturday, but would reserve the final decision until after he had seen how his charge stood the train trip East in the hot weather.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company moved into its new skyscraper home at 30 Broad Street over the week-end and will open for business there this morning. The bank's headquarters, formerly across the street at 25 Broad Street, and its branch office at 26 Broadway are being combined in the new quarters.

HONOLULU, May 8. -- Lieutenant and Mrs. Thomas H. Massie and their party sailed aboard the S.S. Malolo for San Francisco at noon today after a naval officer prevented service of a subpoena upon Mrs. Massie as she boarded the craft through a cargo port.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- The Robins for the third straight day failed to atop Roger Hornsby's energetic Chicago Cubs, and lost the final game of the series, 12 to 5, today before 30,000 fans. The Cubs took the four-game engagement, three to one.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- As she forged ahead tonight on her course, the giant dirigible Akron, which left Lakehurst, N.J., about 8:30 o'clock (Eastern Standard Time) this morning to join the Pacific Fleet manoeuvres, was in constant touch by radio with the Navy Department.

Five composers, four men and one woman, received checks totaling $10,000 last night, having been chosen out of 573 contestants for the National Broadcasting Company's awards for original symphonic works by American musicians.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Economic conditions in the West, resulting in the sale of a large number of farms for taxes and to meet mortgage obligations, have produced a situation unfavorable to the Republican party, according to information reaching the leaders of the party.

SAN JOSE, C.R., May 5. -- The inauguration of Senor Jimenez brings to the Presidency of Costa Rica one of its most distinguished statesmen and beloved citizens, the first in the history of the republic to occupy that post three times by the choice of the people in free election.

PARIS, May 8. -- Two articles on the dollar, evidently inspired by officials of the French Treasury and the Bank of France, to which great importance is attached in Paris, appeared in today's Temps and Journal des Debats. Both expressed faith In the stability of the dollar, mingled with criticisms of the Federal Reserve System's policy as tending to inflation.
There seemed to be some doubt yesterday as to just what day was being celebrated here, but there was no doubt about the celebrations.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP). -- The body of Donald Mitchell Ryerson, who committed suicide today, was found by his wife after she discovered a note in nis room in which he indicated he was going to take his life. The pistol he used lay near his body.

The Real Estate Board of New York, in an open letter sent to Mayor Walker by Anton L. Trunk, its president, has threatened to organize property owners in a drive against realty overassessments unless the Mayor drops his stand against the opening of the $631,000,000 budget for 1932 so that drastic reductions may be made in the city's expenses this year.

PARIS, May 8 (AP). -- The sympathy of the Russian Government for France as a result of the assassination of President Doumer was extended today to Premier Andre Tardieu through the Russian Ambassador, Valerian Dovgolevsky. A letter forwarded to M. Tardieu said the Soviet Union had been "deeply affected by the abominable outrage" and also conveyed the personal condolences of the Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Showing an increase in eight out of the last twelve months, money in circulation April 30 amounted to $5,461,093,541, the Treasury announced today.

ADELAIDE, Australia, May 9. -- The Finnish bark Hougomont arrived off here last night under makeshift sails after drifting, dismasted, in the Great Australian Bight. She is so badly battered that it is doubtful if she ever will return to sea. The crew of twenty, mostly in training, probably will be repatriated.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- More than 700 persons, including an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and other high officials, dined together tonight and heard speakers challenge opponents of the prohibition amendment to submit a substitute.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on May 4 shows increases for the week of $244,000,000 in loans and investments, $308,000,000 in government deposits and $20,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $62,000,000 in net demand deposits and $20,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Pitcher Jack Jarrett held Temple to three scattered hits today and Washington and Lee defeated the Owls, 4 to 1. The Southerner struck out eleven batters. Spalding yielded fourteen hits, Fitzgerald and Burrows of the Generals each getting three safeties.

After several postponements the Hotel Carlyle, a forty-story apartment hotel structure on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, was sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings yesterday. The property was bought in by the plaintiff.
NEW YORK. Countess Pierre de Viel Castel is expected to arrive on the Paris, and will join her mother, Mrs. Charles R. Scott.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 9 (AP). -- The entire police force of Harbin appeared tonight to guard the League of Nations investigating commission. The members of the commission were met at the station by the Chinese Mayor, Pao, and delegations of Chinese, Japanese, American and other officials.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 9. -- Albert B. Fall, who was convicted of accepting a bribe from Edward L. Doneny, oil magnate, while Secretary of the Interior, was freed today from the New Mexico State penitentiary after serving nine months and nineteen days of a year and a day sentence.

Charles G. Koss, 79-year-old attorney and an executor of the will of Ella V. von E. Wendell, who collapsed while on the witness stand before Surrogate James A. Foley last Thursday, completed his testimony yesterday in the Judge's chambers. At the noon recess Mr. Koss had to be helped back to his chair by his daughter, Mrs. Isabel Murray, and his physician.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Senate tax bill, designed to raise $1,030,000,000 toward balancing the budget for the fiscal year 1933, was reported unanimously today by the Finance Committee, which had remodeled the measure passed by the House April 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A short time ago American Jewry lost one of its great leaders, and, although many eulogies were inspired by his passing, it seems to me that one of his greatest acts has not yet been referred to.

Trial of the suit brought by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the Sonora Products Corporation of America, to collect double damages of $3,000.000 from Anthony. J. Drexell Biddle Jr. and seven co-defendants, most of them directors of the Sonora corporation, was begun yesterday before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey without a jury.

No changes were visible in condi-, tlons or quotations for money at the resumption of business in the new week. Stock Exchange call funds were in good supply at 2 1/2 per cent, the official rate, but Street trades went on at 2 and Federal funds loaned at 1/3 Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and steady.

NEW ORLEANS, May 9. -- A proposal to make a one-year investigation Into the entire subject of birth control with reference to legal medical practice was presented today at the opening session of the eighty-third annual meeting of the American Medical Association here.

Alfred Graham Miles, 57 years old, who described himself as a statistician and former captain in the Sixty-first Cavalry, had two encounters with the law yesterday, his third and fourth within two weeks. Last night he was back in a cell in the West Side Prison, convicted of disorderly conduct and held without ball for investigation and sentence tomorrow.

Traffic snarls incidental to Mayor Walker's beer for taxation parade on Saturday will be prevented or unravelled through the cooperation of the blimp "Resolute" and Police Headquarters, with a radio announcer from the blimp informing headquarters of anticipated tangles by shortwave radio.

The break down of prohibition, more than any other single cause, has inculcated among the people of the United States a growing tendency toward a revolutionary frame of mind, Colonel Henry W. Anderson said in a speech before the Ohio Society at the Hotel Pensylvania last night.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Unlted States automobile production amounted in 1931 to 2,389,738 passenger cars, trucks and buses, a decline of 23.8 per cent under that of 1930. It was 77 per cent of the total world output and coupled with, that of Canada comprised 81 per cent of the total, according to figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

Financial markets were again extremely dull yesterday with prices working lower and the volume of business small. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was the slowest since Sept. 1, 1931, the turnover of 638.207 shares falling below the total of Saturday's short session and nearly 1,000,000 shares under Friday's business.

Favored by ideal weather and with all of the ranking contenders gathered for action for the first time in three the North Side championship at the University Heights Tennis Club advanced to the round of sixteen yesterday without a single major reversal marking the long afternoon of play.

The competition of motor vehicles adversely affected the traffic in animals and products, products of mines and merchandise on the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway in 1931. C.T. Jaffray, president, said in his annual report.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9. -- Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist, appearing in Greenwich for the first time, gave one of the closing recitals of his present American tour tonight before a brilliant audience of 2,000 persons who filled the Pickwick Theatre.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9. -- Eradication of the ecclesiastical Mason and Dixon line, elimination of denominationalism in education and the adoption of a common hymnal by Methodists and Presbyterians were forecast or advocated by speakers at the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here today.

Orders Reflect Consumer Buying. With consumer interest in seasonal merchandise quite active, reorders for apparel reaching this market yesterday were quite good, reports indicated. The mail volume reaching the resident offices was described as about as heavy as a week ago, with indications that the number of buyers personally in the market would be about on a par with last week.

Small-home plans for a construction forum under the auspices of the American Institute of Steel Construction on May 24 and 25 should be submitted to the institute at 200 Madison Avenue not later than next Monday, it was announced yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 9 (AP). -- A ninthinning rally gave the Cincinnati Reds a 4-to-3 victory today in their first tussle of the season with the Phillies. It was Cincinnati's fifth straight victory. Making it notable again was Catcher Ernest Lombardi, who hit a triple and a home run.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The question of who was the first President of the United States of America, George Washington, John Hanson or Thomas McKean, has been answered by the State Department in favor of George Washington.

CHURCHILL, DOWNS, Ky., May 9 (AP).-- C.C. Van Meter's Red Whisk a chestnut colt by Whiskalong out of Spider, established himself as one of the most promising juveniles in the West when he defeated a fast band of 2-year-olds in the Lebanon Junction Purse, feature today at Churchill Downs.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- The stock market was blamed tonight by Senator Norbeck for a major share of responsibility for present economic conditions.

Various merger proposals, one of which reached the stage of the drafting of a formal agreement, by which the Bank of United States was to be absorbed by a stronger financial institution or banking group, were described yesterday by Joseph A. Broderick.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Senata leaders of both parties agreed today to the formation of an "economy committee," whose object would be to restore to the economy bill many of the savings discarded by the House, and add such further provisions as may be devised in the Senate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9. -- More than 50 per cent of the fire losses thus far this year were due to incendiarism, Horatio Bond, engineer of the National Fire Protection Association, declared at the annual convention of the organization, which opened here today.

Religion and the Stock Market. Everybody sets up to be a political economist or a financial expert these days, so that it is no wonder that here and there a clergyman does. One minister in his Sunday sermon referred to the fact that the United States Steel Corporation had cut wages, whereupon its stock, with that of some other companies, rose a few points on Wall Street.

THE gentle pastime of box lacrosse will be put on view at the Garden this evening with Newsy Lalonde's professional champions, the Canadians of Montreal, competing against the Maple Leafs of Toronto, and two local charities, the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled and the Cardiac Clinic of New York University, sharing in the proceeds.

Three men bending over a safe in a Brooklyn confectionery store just before dawn yesterday were not counting on the sudden arrival of Patrolman Joseph Kruse. When the three failed to throw up their hands at the patrolman's command he fired five times.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The naval airship Akron left Galveston at 3 o'clock this afternoon for Houston and San Antonio, en route to the Pacific Coast, Lieut. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commanding officer, reported to the Navy Department this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Hoover was urged today by Representative Somers of New York, chairman of the House Coinage Committee, to call an international conference to discuss stabilization of silver. Mr. Somers was accompanied by Representative Perkins of New Jersey, ranking Republican member of the committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- John W. Pierce of Topsfield, Mass., today replaced William Bacon as the No. 6 man in the Harvard varsity crew, marking the first time in three seasons that there has been any change in the stern quartet of Cassedy, Saltonstall, Bacon and Bancroft.

HONOLULU, May 9 (AP). -- Although the complaining witness sailed yesterday for the mainland, John C. Kelley, Honolulu's public prosecutor, announced today that the trial of four youths charged with assaulting Mrs. Thalia Massie would start as scheduled on May 25.

An entertainment was given last night at the Cafe de la Paix, 280 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the hospital fund of the Soldiers and Sailors Club. Many younger members of society attended the fete, which began with a dinner dance and continued through the evening with cabaret features, supper and special diversions.

The committee to open recreation centres of the Community Councils of the city plans to ask the Board of Estimate for $296,779.50 to carry on the work of the vacation playgrounds this year. Police Commissioner Mulrooney, who was elected chairman of the committee at a meeting held yesterday at Police Headquarters, said he would bring the matter up at the next meeting of the Estimate Board.

WARSAW, May 9. -- Poland is profoundly impressed by the results of the French election. The Left's vic-, tory is regretted by all parties except the Socialists. The government bloc regards the French Radical Socialists as the Pilsudski regime's bitter foes, who cannot forgive the dictator for the Brest-Litovsk affair and the imprisonment of Polish Left leaders.

Thomas W. Lamont, a partner in J.P. Morgan Co., will return today from England on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Also on board are Dr. T. Riedmann, Lord Vernon, Baron von Hanstein, Miss Diana Guest and Carl Loeb, banker.

Raymond (Sonny) Workman. Cor- nelius Vanderbilt Whitncy's No. 1 contract rider, who recently has been ill had his first mounts of the met- ropolitan season at Jamaica yesterday and scored two winners and a second out of three chances.

LONDON, May 9 (AP). -- The builder of Miss England III today turned the speedboat over to Lord Wakefield, her owner, and she was shipped to Italy to be prepared by Kaye Don, her driver, for the coming regatta on Lake Garda.

TOKYO, May 9. -- The Privy Council has requested Premier Inukai and the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, War and Navy to attend a meeting of the Council on Wednesday to explain the Shanghai armistice agreement.

The Avon Theatre, which was closed last Tuesday evening by the police just before "Merry-Go-Round," a melodrama of political corruption, was scheduled to open there, received a renewal of its license yesterday, which will permit the opening of the melodrama tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Superintendent O'Shea's criticism of the experimental work of the Little Red Schoolhouse on the ground that its students are backward in certain standard performances is misleading because it ignores completely the nature of the experiment.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- A fantastic tale of an attempt to buy a North Carolina baby resembling the Lindbergh child was investigated today by officials preparing for a prompt trial of Gaston B. Means if he is indicted for embezzling $100,000 given him to effect the return of the kidnapped baby.

The two veteran excursion steamboats, Albertina and Sea Bird, which have been for more than forty-five years in the service between Manhattan and Atlantic Highlands, N.J., were severely damaged by fire early yesterday morning at the Charles E. Gates Lumber Company's pier at 152d Street in the East River.

LONDON, May 9. -- Sir James Jeans advanced a new theory tonight when, delivering a Mond lecture at Manchester University, he described the universe as a stick standing on its point and steadily falling over at a constantly increasing speed. The infinitesimal amount of the fall, how- ever, would require an eternity of time.

ROCHESTER, May 9. -- The tendency of business to seek public funds when conditions are pressing was attacked here today by Ellwood M. Rabenold, former State Senator, in an address at the opening session of the thirty-seventh convention of the New York State Association of Manufacturing Retail Bakers.

MADRID, May 9. -- Minister of Labor Largo Caballero tonight marred the hopes of a tranquil settlement of the Catalan autonomy demands in the Cortes by stating, as spokesman of the Socialist party, the largest in Parliament, that "Catalonia cannot have the statute she has presented or even the more moderate settlement advocated by the parliamentary commission."

Sales of cars by branches of the General Motors Corporation to consumers in April showed a pain of 32.856 units, compared with March, but a decrease of 54.090. compared with April, 1931. The totals for the periods were 81,573, 48.717 and 135 663 respectively.

SAN ANGELO, Texas, Tuesday, May 10. -- The naval dirigible Akron at 11:20 o'clock (Central Standard Time) last night signaled to land at the San Angelo airport and called for a landing crew of 500 men.

Subsidies or long-term loans for socially desirable projects as a means of stimulating revival of industry are essential in the present situation. Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday in making public the regular monthly report of the State Labor Department on employment conditions.

LIMA, May 9. -- Investigation of Saturday night's mutiny on the cruisers Almirante Grau and Coronel Bolognesi in Callao harbor has established definite connection with the Soviet committee at Montevideo, according to an official statement given to your correspondent this afternoon.

AURORA, Ill., May 9 (AP). -- In a spectacular head finish with Gold Step, Scimitar 8-year-old son of Hourless -- La Bayonette, and ridden by Jockey C. King, won the featured Wheaton Handicap at six furlongs today before more than 5,000 fans. Nyack finished third.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I greatly appreciate the problem confronting the Finance Committee of the Senate and the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives in Washington in their efforts to balance the national budget.

The testimony of defense alienists in the Massie case was mildly criticized last night at a discussion of "Medical Expert Testimony and the Massie Case" before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at the New York Academy of Medicine.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP). -- Charles R. Flint spent last night in an inexpensive hotel room here.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., May 9 (AP). -- Marlene Dietrich and Josef von Sternberg are back at work on their old jobs.

Inventions large and small, serious and frivolous, workable and nonworkable, 5,000 in all, will be on public display from 10 o'clock this morning until 10 P.M. of May 28 at the Fourth International Patent Exposition, held for the first time in this city, at Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- President Hoover today vetoed another pension bill, this time a proposition which would give to a certain class of civilians the same status as soldiers and sailors in the matter of hospitalization and the privileges of soldiers' homes.

In The Atlantic Monthly Mr. ERNEST WEEKLEY, whose long explorations of etymology ought to have made him immune, seems to get nervous about the future of the English language. If anything can take care of itself it is that rollicking and reckless leviathan, which a thousand volunteer puritan guardians are always harpooning with bent pins and trying to pull up on the beach of respectability with paper ropes.

TRENTON, N.J., May 9. -- After an illness of less than one week, Sedley H. Phlnney, executive secretary of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, died in Mercer Hospital here early today of pneumonia. He was 42 years old. Funeral services will be held at his home in Princeton at a time to be announced.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP). -- Two runners crossed the plate when Fritz Knothe whacked a long single in the twelfth inning today and the Boston Braves took the first game of the series from the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 to 5.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9. -- In the team matches of the women's Westchester interclub golf tournament, played over the course of the Greenwich Country Club today. Westchester Country Club had high score in Class A with 12 points.

BASLE, May 9. -- The uncertain position of the gold standard the world over has prevented the Bank for International Settlements from expanding to include many nations outside Europe which are expected eventually to become stockholders.

Dr. Albert Einstein has written to Isaac Don Levine that Levine's book, "Stalin," is "undoubtedly the best concerning this great and most profound drama that has yet fallen into my hands." "The whole book," he writes, "seems to me a tune to the theme that might begets might; that freedom is the prerequisite of everything of real value.

GENEVA, May 9. -- The Council of the League of Nations opened its sixty-seventh regular session in the Crystal Chamber of the League Palace today. Dr. Jose Matos of Guatemala, who became president through alphabetical rotation, pronounced eulogies of President Doumer of France and Albert Thomas, head of the International Labor Office.

LONDON, May 9. -- Although business remained on a small scale, there were several bright features in today's stock markets. Following week-end improvement in Wall Street, international stocks advanced sharply. Market opinion is that the difficulties which America, in common with other countries, is facing are unduly magnified.

The week began with no incident of special interest, except a further strengthening of foreign exchange rates. There was the usual disposition in Wall Street to ascribe this movement solely to the vagaries of Congress. That explanation possibly lost some force from the fact, which other markets than foreign exchange have appeared to reflect, that the Congressional situation has in the past few days taken a distinct turn for the better.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Lloyd Brown held the Cleveland Indians to four hits today while his team mates pounded out six off Wesley Ferrell to give the Washington Senators a 3-to-0 victory over the Indians in their first encounter of the season.

BERLIN May 9. -- The Reichstag today opened a four-day session to consider several bills proposed by the Ministry of Finance. Three facts dominating the discussion are the deficit of the Reich at the end of March of 1.295,000,000 marks about 5408.000,000, the floating debt of 1.718,000,000 marks and the unem ployment expenditure by April 30.
TOKYO, May 9. -- Japan's action at the Geneva disarmament conference, in opposing airplane carriers as weapons of offense was explained by naval officers here today.
Mayor Walker will be asked Thursday to sponsor an ordinance prepared by the Department of Health Noise Abatement Commission to curtail noise, according to an announcement yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 9. -- Jimmy Collins, who has displaced Sunny Jim Bottomley as the Cardinals' first baseman, came to bat in the ninth inning today with the bases filled, swung viciously at old Jack Quinn's first pitch -- and the Robins dropped deeper into the depression.
A home run in the eighth inning by Xavier Rescigno enabled the Manhattan freshmen to defeat James Monroe, 5 -- 3, at Jasper Field yesterday. The contest had been scheduled for seven innings.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of a new sports enterprise tonight when the game of box lacrosse will be introduced. Two of the strongest teams in Canada, the Montreal Canadiens and the Maple Leafs of Toronto, will clash in the battle which will be staged for the benefit of two New York charities -- the Cardiac Clinic of New York University and the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.

MONTREAL, May 9 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals won their tenth straight victory and the third in a row over Jersey City when they triumphed today, 7 to 6. A five-run splurge in the third gave Brown his third victory of the season.

The pamphlet report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for 1931 shows net income of the parent company amounting to $21,857,968 equal, after $8,995,416 preferred dividends to 38.2 cents a share on 33.673.328 common shares. The company received $24,845,154 income from subsidiary companies and $832,763 from outside sources Expenses and taxes were $530,004 and interest was $3,289,946.

The city-manager plan is beginning to get attention here in New York. Judge SEABURY once hinted that it might have a place in his final report. Dr. SCHIEFFELIN of the Citizens Union debated the issue with JOSEPH C. BALDWIN, the lonely Republican Alderman.

BALTIMORE. Md., May 9 (AP). -- Walter M. Jeffords today gave his Preaknes eligible, Slave Ship, a final test for the impending renewal of the classic at the Pimlico course and the son of Black Toney -- Lightship took the measure of five other Preakness aspirants in the featured Woodberry Purse, a gallop over the mile and a sixteenth route.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A confused, distracted Congress and country, largely harassed on the one side by lobbyists and partisanship, on the other by irate taxpayers and warning's from President Hoover, are confronted with the most preposterous naval bill ever presented to a people facing a colossal deficit.

The periodic publication of corporate. State and municipal financial statements to instill public confidence, and a new plan of taxation designed to penalize hoarding and reward those willing to invest surplus income in productive enterprises, were recommended in addresses last night at the thirty-fifth annual meeting of The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Crop and war reports fell flat today as market influences on wheat on the Board of Trade here, there being comparatively little buying on news indicating a more serious situation in the East between Russia and Japan. Prices held within a range of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel and averaged higher largely because of sympathy with Liverpool.

PARIS, May 9. The success of the Left parties at the polls yesterday resulted today in a feeling of uncertainty but no nervousness on the Bourse here, and the market's trend was irregularly higher. Bank stocks were steady to higher. Suez Canal, Rio Tinto Copper, Royal Dutch Oil and Credit Lyonnais made gains, while electrical issues and some leading industrials were low.

LONDON, May 9. -- Perplexity rather than hopeful expectation characterizes the British Government's speculation on what will be the sequel to the French elections, so far as international policies are concerned.

The first report from Little Peconic Bay that weakfish were being caught on the surface of the water was received yesterday from New Suffolk. Captain Nathan Warner and a party of five, fishing off the Black Buoy in the Annie Florence, caught forty-eight weakfish that averaged from two and one-half to three and one-half pounds.

Ever since the original company departed on tour three weeks ago this great city has been "Mourning Becomes Electraless." That defect was remedied at the Alvin last evening by the first New York appearance of the second company, which is ably led by Judith Anderson as Lavinia and Florence Reed as Christine.

Konstantin Riabovol, chairman of the Soviet Oil Export Syndicate, who with other Russian officials is here attending conferences on petroleum stabilization with representatives of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, said yesterday that Russian oil exports were only about 10 per cent of the world's total and that, therefore, the Soviets were not responsible for demoralization of the oil markets.

OTTAWA, May 9. -- The United States Government is willing to facilitate the establishment of a nationally owned radio system In Canada, Premier Bennett announced in the House of Commons today. In exchange of notes, the Washington Government expressed its willingness to make sufficient redistribution of radio channels to make the Dominion scheme feasible he said:

Though cash and pledges totaling more than $1,000,000 appear assured that is still $500,000 less than the minimum necessary to give 5,000 men work for twenty weeks, according to Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization, who said last night that 72,000 Block-Aiders were at work at the opening of the seventh week of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Mrs. Hattie Caraway of Arkansas, first woman to be elected to the Senate, tonight filed notice of her candidacy for renomination in the State Democratic primary of Aug. 9. Her decision was made after long consideration.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 9. -- Although weakened by the absence of some of its stars, notably Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake, the women's Southern champion, and Mrs. Leo G. Federman, former Long Island champion, the Trillora team managed to hold its lead in the Long Island Division matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub tournament at the Engineers' Country Club today.

Edward W. Forrest, executive secretary of the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants' Association, told License Commissioner James F. Geraghty yesterday that his organization had directed active opposition to the burlesque shows in the Republic and Eltinge Theatres, although other establishments in West Forty-second Street were also considered objectionable.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Shortstop Joe Boley, who fielded and batted his way from the sandlots of the anthracite regions to a post with the Philadelphia Athletics, today was unconditionally released in a surprise move by Manager Connie Mack.

Reports that the Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning a program of sympathetic cooperation with the Museum of Modern Art were confirmed yesterday afternoon by William Sloane Coffin, president of the Metropolitan, in a broadcast over WJZ.

Columbia's squad resumed practice on the Hudson River yesterday, in preparation for the Childs Cup Regatta here on May 28 among the Lions. Pennsylvania and Princeton. The Morningside varsity eipht, however, is taking seriously the meeting with the New York Athletic Club on the Harlem River Saturday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 9. -- Frank G. Mayne, a prominent retired member of the theatrical profession, died at his Oakwood Avenue home here today. He had been in failing health for some time and about two weeks ago suffered a stroke.

Buttressed by the economic equivalent to political police power, a national board should be established to war against poverty, unemployment and insecurity and to bring about an expansion of the standard of living, George Soule, an editor of The New Republic, and author of "The Useful Art of Economics," writes in "A Planned Society," published today by Macmillan.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read your editorial "Mental Ages." It seems to me that the problem may be studied from another point of view.

G. Hall Roosevelt, Controller of the city of Detroit, conferred with bankers here yesterday regarding renewal of a short-term loan of $4.169,000 which will mature tomorrow. The spokesman for the banking group, which is headed by the Bankers Trust Company, the National City Bank, the Chase National Bank and the Guaranty Trust Company, said no arrangements had yet been made but that a proposition would have to come from Detroit officials today.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Charges that an opinion by former Solicitor General Frederick W. Lehmann declaring that banking affiliates were absolutely illegal was suppressed by the Attorney General of the Taft Administration and by a later Democratic Attorney General, who was "elevated to a place of even higher distinction," were made by Senator Glass in a Senate speech this afternoon.

BOMBAY, May 9. -- The German-American Himalayan expedition, first of the great Himalayan climbing parties to include Americans, is now in India on its way to attack a mountain higher than any yet conquered.

The United Hospital Fund could aid private hospitals by representing its fifty-five associated institutions in the adjustment of common problems such as ambulance service and payment for workmen's compensation cases, Alfred E. Smith suggested yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- A warning of possible revolt unless the Federal Government moves to prevent unemployment distress came from organized labor today as a new drive was launched for Federal jobless relief.

In this country after a political overturn we mark time between the first week in November and the following March 4. After June 1 France will be ruled by a Cabinet in which the dominant factor will be the Radical-Socialist party -- an organization which is neither radical nor socialist but moderately liberal.

The exhibition of costumes or the century between 1750 and 1850 opens to the public today at the Metropolitan. There was a private showing yesterday, and if the enthusiasm displayed by visitors then may be accepted in the light of prophecy, the present exhibition promises to be one of the most popular ever held at the Metropolitan.

Two sisters of Russell T. Sherwood, missing business agent of Mayor Walker, were questioned secretly at the headquarters of the Hofstadter legislative committee late yesterday afternoon, In preparation for their probable appearance as witnesses at a public hearing next week.

With 313 of the delegates already elected to the Democratic National Convention, either pledged to or claimed for Franklin D. Roosevelt, the managers at the Governor's preconvention headquarters yesterday voiced their belief that he would enter the convention with more than a majority of the 1,154 votes.

LONDON, May 9. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said in the House of Commons to- night that it was impossible for the British Government to engage in an international currency conference at present because it already had many conferences on hand.

Tanned after a vacation of ten days at French Lick Springs, Ind., and obviously in excellent condition, Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, came back to New York yesterday for a brief visit before he starts training in Kingston, N.Y., for the defense of his title against Jack Sharkey in Madison Square Garden's Long Island City bowl on June 21.

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute at Troy, N.Y., eventually will receive the greater part of the estate of James C. McGuire, appraised yesterday for transfer tax purposes at $1,493,603 gross and $1,352,072 net. Mr. McGuire, who died on Dec. 7, 1930, was president of the Knickerbocker Hospital and of the engineering and contracting concern of James C. McGuire Co., Inc.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 9 (AP). -- Two long home-run drives by George Detore and Bucky Crouse furnished the margin of victory for the Bisons as they toppled the Newark Bears in the first meeting of their series today. The score was 3 to 1.

Resignation of Professor James C. Egbert ns dean of the School of Business of Columbia University was an- nounced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the uni- versity. Dr. Roswell Cheney McCrea, Hopburn Professor of Economics and a member of the faculty of the business school, has been appointed to succeed him.

CLEVELAND, May 9. -- Holders of the first mortgage leasehold 7 per cent sinking fund gold bonds of the Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation will receive at the rate of $450 per $1,000 bond, according to recommendations embodied in a letter now being fowarded jointly by the management and the bondholders' protective committee, of which J.G. Gosling of Otis Co. is chairman.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9 (AP). -- Ohio Republicans win tell the nation how they stand on prohibition at tomorrow's primaries in the Anti-Saloon League's home State.

The Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company has proposed to reduce its capital and increase its surplus. It is the fifth company in that line of business to make such a proposal to its stockholders in less than a week. Its plan, which has been approved by George S. Van Schaick.
Following a recovery of nearly a half cent last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined about $1 a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 17 to 20 points.

Improved facilities for the increasing population of the city in the matter of public comfort stations were recommended by civic leaders yesterday at a meeting of the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, called for the purpose of discussing a survey made in this field by a special committee of that organization.

Many readers of the news may have connected last week's gold export of $37,000,000 with chaotic conditions in Congress. It would be nothing new for foreign exchanges, under such circumstances, to "move against the United States." The simple-minded foreigner could not be expected to know that the "bonus inflation bill" and the Goldsborough bill were political gestures, and that enactment was not seriously expected.

Friends of Owen D. Young are prepared to present him to the Democratic National Convention as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President if, as they expect, Governor Roosevelt fails, to obtain the two-thirds vote needed and the convention reaches the stage of a deadlock.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Edwin S. Cunningham, the United States Consul General at Shanghai, has been designated chairman of the joint commission of the powers appointed to assist in arrangements for the evacuation of Japanese troops from the Shanghai area.

Legislation in the House and Senate, which would give broad powers to the Shipping Board in regulating foreign-flag ship lines entering American ports, was attacked yesterday us "destructive and discriminatory" and a threat to American business in a statement issued by the National Wholesale Food Distributers' Association.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 10. -- Japanese troops have routed Chinese forces from the city of Fancheng, on the Sungari River about 150 miles northeast of Harbin, but conditions in North Manchuria continue more disturbed than at any time since the Japanese started their operations in Manchuria last September.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff of the army, protested today against the proposed elimination of 2,000 officers, which is one of the major items to be taken up tomorrow by the House in the War Department appropriation bill.

Following closely the Real Estate Board's demand for a conference on methods of reducing city taxes with Mayor Walker, the First Avenue Association took the lead in the movement yesterday by advising its members to bring proceedings before the Supreme Court for review of their property assessments in cases where the assessments were deemed excessive.

A city-born, city-bred, city-minded man, WILLIAM BARCLAY PARSONS may be said to have been a "militant genius" of the city age. He had his training as a civil engineer in Columbia University. His first important engineering work was in the service of the city of New York.

Richard Whitney was re-elected yesterday president of the New York Stock Exchange at the annual election. He will begin serving his third term today. At an organization meeting which the governing committee will hold today or tomorrow, it is expected that Alien L. Llndley, vice president for the last two years, will be re-elected.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., May 9 (AP). -- Upon petition of the Consolidated Oil Corporation of New York, Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy appointed L.R. Crawford and P.C. Spencer of Independence. Kan., receivers for the Producers and Refiners Corporation here today.
CLEVELAND, May 9. -- Professor Alvin C. Brightman of Western Reserve University Law School died late today of a heart attack. His age was 53.

Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers now has less than $50,000 in its treasury compared to $250,000 in 1926, according to citations made from the union's books yesterday by John Holley Clark Jr., at an examination before trial of Frank Wilson, president of the local, before Referee Robert McC. Marsh at 14 Vesey Street.

ELIZABETH, N.J, May 9 (AP). -- The will of Michael Francis Quinn of Rahway, who died on April 23, probated today, provides bequests for a score of religious institutions and leaves the residuary estate in trust for the use of the widow, Mrs. Elizabeth A. Quinn of Rahway.
One bond and two mortgage certificates with a par value of $5,000 changed hands yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 (AP). -- The Chronicle, in a story vouched for by Rear Admiral William C. Cole, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, says Horace Ida confessed to a group of nine men who kidnapped him last Dec. 12 he was one of five natives who attacked Mrs. Thalia Massie in Honolulu.

Slightly easier prices for domestic corporation bonds and United States Government issues and rallying tendencies in foreign loans characterized dealings yesterday on the bond market on the Stock Exchange. The unusually heavy turnover of United States Government bonds accounted for more than half transactions totaling about $14.500.000.

Mr. WICKERSHAM is still unable to understand why the report of his commission on prohibition stirred general interest -- and disappointment -- while the rest of its labors were comparatively neglected. But the popular instinct was justified. Prohibition was the overshadowing question.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak, Mich., whose radio broadcasts on social questions drew the severe criticism of Cardinal O'Connell of Boston, arrived from a vacation in California on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania yesterday.

Dr. Thomas L. Bennett, who is said to have administered anesthetic to more persons of prominence and wealth than any doctor of his generation, died suddenly yesterday at the Doctors' Hospital. He was 63 years old. His career as an anethetist here lasted for more than thirty years.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Charles R. Flint, venerable financier, was back at his Shoreham Hotel apartment tonight after a mysterious disappearance of more than twenty-four hours.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9. -- The leading pairs in the second annual Westchester County Contract Bridge Tournament were hard pressed to maintain their advantage tonight in the nine centres in the county where preliminary qualifying rounds were held.

Lew Kirsch, east side lightweight engaged on a ring come-back after an absence of two years, scored a hollow victory over Johnny McSweeney of Harlem last night in the scheduled five-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

If members of Congress have been seeking a place for repentance, it is now under their eyes. They have heard the wondering reproaches which their conduct has evoked in other countries. Still more to the point, they have heard appeals, indignant, or anxious, coming up to them from their fellow-citizens.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- As the titular head of the House of Repre- sentatives, Speaker John N. Garner has received the full force of the President's recent attacks on the attitude and record of the House during its consideration of the tax and economy measures designed to balance the government's budget.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Moves were made today in the House and Senate to bring about Federal regulation of railroad holding companies.

William S. Dowdell of Well Brothers Co. has been named by the nominating committee for president of the New York Cotton Exchange, to succeed Philip Weld, who will become a member of the board of managers.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Crude petroleum production in March amounted to 67,189,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,167,000, or 12,000 more than the preceding month, the Bureau of Mines announced today. Output declined in virtually all major fields except East Texas, which increased its average daily yield from 312,000 barrels in February to 340,000 in March.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 9. -- Beaten, shot, robbed and tied hand and foot, Melvin R. Marquand, former tax collector of Stamford, was left to his fate in a house on Wire Mill Road in rural Stamford early this afternoon by two men who posed as prospective purchasers of a chicken farm.

More than 2,000 members of the Cleaning and Dye House Drivers' Union, employed in sixty wholesale dry-cleaning and dyeing establishments throughout the city, went on strike yesterday. The strikers devoted the day to picketing and generally combating efforts to break the strike, while the employers reported that for every man who had quit work seven others were available.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Final "taps" for Major Gen. Enoch H. Crowder, noted soldier and diplomat, were sounded in Arlington National Cemetery today, where he was buried after services at Walter Reed Memorial Hospital.

WARM SPRINGS. Ga., May 8. -- Existence of strong reserve sentiment for Governor Roosevelt in the powerful Illinois delegation to the national convention was avowed here today by Thomas F. Donovan, Democratic State chairman of Illinois and candidate for Lieutenant Governor.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 9. -- The 15-year-old son of Austin C. Cheshire, controller of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, jumped to his death here this afternoon from the roof of the Professional Building, a seven-story structure on Fulton Street. Before jumping the boy had made a notation with a heavy black pencil on a stone parapet on the roof of the building as follows:

LOS ANGELES, May 9. -- Defending President Hoover's plan for the staggered employment of Federal employes, in preference to an arbitrary salary cut. The Los Angeles Times of which Harry Chandler is the proprietor, in an editorial printed yesterday asserted that the stagger plan "has been successfully applied in both industry and government from coast to coast."

Lieutenant Thomas F. Sands, former intercollegiate fencing champion while at West Point, and Lieutenant Richard W. Mayo were tied for the lead last night at the end of the first two sections of the three-part fencing competition among candidates for the United States Olympic modern pentathlon team.

PARIS, May 9. -- Former Premier Paul Painleve withdrew late tonight as a candidate for President of the French Republic to succeed Paul Doumer, who was assassinated last Friday, and thus assured the election at Versailles tomorrow of Albert Lebrun, President of the Senate.

Butter. Receipts, 8,820 packages. The break which has lately been anticipated materialized today, values on all grades falling 3/4@1c. Receipts over the week-end were much more liberal, with a good deal of delayed stock and quite a little butter diverted from Chicago coming forward, and there was general anxiety to get prices down to a safe basis.
Several apartment houses, in addition to a taxpayer and small dwellings, were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Harry F. Gerguson, who is known on the Atlantic and in the better speakeasies of New York as Michael Romanoff, languished on Ellis Island yesterday, again a captive after several days of freedom in New York.

The opening of "Lenin's Dowry" at the Chanin Auditorium on the fiftieth floor of the Chanin Building has been postponed from tomorrow until Thursday night. David Vardi, the author of the play, will appear in it with his wife, Eva Yoalit.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- The compromise tax measure reported to the Senate today boosts the income tax rates to 3 per cent on the first $4,000 taxable income; 6 per cent on the next $4,000, and 9 per cent on all above $8,000.

Mrs. Ella A. Boole, president of the National W.C.T.U., and the Rev. Dr. J. Lane Miller, pastor of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, declared yesterday before the annual convention of the Kings County W.C.T.U. at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church in Brooklyn that Mayor Walker's proposed beer parade would not have for its chief purpose the advocacy of a "tax to balance the Federal budget."

BERLIN, May 10. -- The Boerse displayed today its usual strength, due again to a certain amount of buying orders from the public. Stock jobbers, however, still were reserved, and business therefore stayed within narrow limits. Bonds were irregular. Their recent upward movement seems to have come to a standstill for the time being.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Democratic leaders here read with interest of the movement to promote Owen D. Young as a compromise candidate for President as described in THE NEW YORK TIMES today. They said his recent statements on public questions convinced them that Mr. Young was being prepared to take advantage of any situation that might develop in the Chicago convention.

It was declared unequivocally by friends of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday that if opponents of the Governor's nomination for President carry the "Stop Roosevelt" movement into the Democratic National Convention and attempt to use the veto power on nominations, the forces behind the Governor's candidacy would not hesitate to seek abrogation of the century-old rule under which nominations at national conventions of the party have been made by a two-thirds vote.

M. LEBRUN'S promotion from the Presidency of the Senate to that of the Republic conforms to a practice that may yet harden, into a precedent. His two immediate predecessors proceeded along the same line. From the turn of the century almost to the eve of the World War the custom was exemplified in the persons of EMILE LOUBET and ARMAND FALLIERES.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- Another wealthy and socially prominent woman was listed tonight as a possible victim, to the extent of $100,000 or more, of the representations of Gaston B. Means.
Housing properties, including several apartment structures, comprised the bulk of realty trading in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

The political dark horse, like the poet, is born, not made. This is the reason why sudden efforts of politicians to hit upon the most promising candidate for the Presidency, who can be kept behind the screen until the time comes to "spring" him upon a deadlocked national convention, are often so futile and even ludicrous.
