ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10. -- A protest against the wooden platforms in the Times Square and Grand Central subway stations in New York City as potential fire hazards was contained in a report submitted here today at sessions of the National Fire Prevention Association.

New York received its first glimpse of the sport known as box lacrosse last night at Madison Square Garden, where two Canadian teams in the International Professional Lacrosse League met in a game for the benefit of the Cardiac Clinic of New York University and the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.

An appropriation of $700,000 to meet the cost of starting municipal operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway by the Board of Transportation was approved yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate. The committee approved also the authorization or an issue of that amount of special revenue bonds to provide the necessary funds.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 10. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks won the low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.

One of the ambitions of moving pictures -- the hope of opening new paths to the enrichment of life and the education of children -- is being discussed lately with more indication of eventual success than formerly. Perhaps the economic crisis in the movies has had something to do with the change.

CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP). -- Ray Benge muffled the big guns of the Cincinnati Reds today, scoring a 4-to-0 shutout for the Phillies and snapping a growing Cincinnati winning streak at five games. The winners replaced the losers in third position in the standings.
The School Nature League a eighty-third semi-annual exhibit opened yesterday at Public School 21, at 222 Mott Street. The New York Botanical Garden is contributing to the show.

A trend toward economic isolation is to be found not only in the policy of nations which are rapidly fencing off their own preserves with tariff walls: various States in this country are also drawing into their own shells. They are forbidden by the Constitution to curtail interstate commerce by enacting tariff laws, but there are other ways of skinning the cat.

The pamphlet report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for 1931 shows current assets of $79,412,236 at the end of 1931, against $77,998,042 the year before, and current liabilities of $21,958,331, against $22,590,997, a $2,046,860 increase in net working assets.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 10. -- More than eighty members of the New York Athletic Club journeyed out to the Winged Foot Golf Club today to take part in the opening one-day tournament of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A Winter wheat crop of 441,000,000 bushels, which is 347,000,000 bushels under that for 1931 and 108,000.000 bushels less than the average Winter crop for 1924-28, was indicated in the crop report issued by the Department of Agriculture today based on May 1 conditions.

The proposed discontinuance of operation of government-owned ship lines as an economy measure was assailed yesterday for its potential effect on the upbuilding of an American merchant marine and on American business. The government was urged to maintain the ship lines in a letter forwarded by the South Jersey Port Commission to the New Jersey members of Congress.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Wheat traders on the Board of Trade here spent part of today in evening up for the government report, due after the close of the market, but interest was lacking and prices held within a narrow range, the extreme fluctuation being 5/8 cent.

SHANGHAI, May 10. -- Cablegrams from Manchuria report that Harbin is bristling with bayonets and that intrigue is rife. The Harbin authorities, fearing for the safety of the inquiry commission of the League of Nations, line the streets with soldiers and policemen whenever the commissioners leave their hotel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For fourteen years I lived in the suburbs of New York and traveled to the city for business. At first, coming from a foreign land, I was impressed by many peculiarities in the habits of the New Yorkers, but after a while I took these things for granted.

The Provincetown Playhouse, after a brief interval of theatrical respectability, during which it housed the embattled "Merry-Go-Round," lapsed once more into its old habits last night when something called "The Lady Remembers" had its first performance there.

After producing runs steadily, though on a small scale, for four successive innings the Yankees tallied six times in the seventh at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and won their first game of the year with the St. Louis Browns, 10 to 3.

Mayor Walker announced at City Hall last night that he would seek to arrange a meeting soon with representative real estate organizations in the city that have demanded a private conference to discuss methods of reducing the tax burden on real estate and to talk over new sources of city revenue.

Retail failures dropped sharply during to Bradstreet's. They numbered ing to Bradstreet's. They nmbered 388, against 441 in the preceding week. The commercial service group was the only one to register an increase.

Margin requirements on trades in futures contracts on the Rubber Exchange of New York will be increased at the opening of trading today from 1300 to 5400 a contract of 22,400 pounds, the unit of trading. This move is in anticipation of higher prices if the proposed import tariff of 5 cents a pound on crude rubber goes into effect.

LONDON, May 10. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned at the annual dinner of the Bankers' Association tonight that further economies might be forced on the government by circumstances over which it had no control, "economies which would be so drastic that they would involve a change in government policy beyond anything yet contemplated."

F. Scott Fitzgerald, who fifteen years ago was introducing "flappers" into fiction and writing tales of the "Jazz Age," is now in Baltimore, where his wife is a patient in the Johns Hopkins Hospital. Mrs. Fitzgerald, who was Miss Zelda Sayre of Montgomery, Ala., has been a semi-invalid for two years and has been under treatment at Johns Hopkins for the last six weeks.

Reductions in outgo rather than increased rates are the solutions of the railroads' problems, L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the company's stockholders. He made no definite comment on future dividends of the company, although he said income from operations had practically ceased and that consequently disbursements were being made from surplus.

Novels of the West, tales of fast shooting and love in the open spaces, are steadily growing in popularity after a peroid during which, their sales fell away. According to Frederic Melcher, an editor of The Publishers' Weekly, this new popularity trend probaby is due to the work of a group of young writers who learned their trade writing for the "pulp paper" magazines and "know how to tell stories filled wtih swift action."

In a radio address over the Columbia system last night Mayor Walker appealed for support of the beer parade to be staged on Saturday in a demand for legalization of the manufacture and sale of beer by means of modification of the Volstead act.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A nickel in the slot, a half hour's ride in the subway -- then Spring at its maximum loveliness. What a delightfully suitable and economical excursion in time of a depr --, no, I will not use that word amid memories of such beauty.

Miss Harriet Halverstadt, a missionary of the Methodist Episcopal Church, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, and told of being captured by Chinese bandits near Foochow on Christmas Eve, 1931, and confined with thirteen Chinese in one room of a small farmhouse for ten days.

Differences are being cleared between New York Stock Exchange firms and investigators appointed by the Committee on Banking and Currency of the United States Senate to scrutinize short selling, bull pools and other activities on the Exchange, it was announced yesterday by William Gray, counsel for the committee.
After a slight decline in early trading yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and moved within a narrow range, ending 2 to 3 points lower than on Monday.

The Tatler, the society gossip publication, which was enjoined from further stock sales last January in action taken by the Attorney General's office, is again being published, John C. Schemm, its president and columnist, testified yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 10 (AP). -- Garden Message, lightly regarded half of the T.H. Somerville-Foxcatcher Farm entry, upheld the confidence of the patrons who supported the chances of the combination in the running of the Pimlico Nursery today when the son of Messenger-Garden Rose was up in the final strides to take the verdict by a head from William Ziegler's Cattail.

LONDON, May 10. -- British funds again monopolized attention in the stock markets today. Business was on a fairly large scale and further home and foreign buying caused sharp rises. Foreign bonds also were strong, but elsewhere there were few features.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney signed an order yesterday promoting Arthur C. Johnson, to the detective division, third grade, for rounding up the "Spanish gang" that is suspected of the murder of Patrolman James Goodwin, the murder of Joseph Hartol, a building superintendent, and at least twenty hold-ups in upper Manhattan.

PARIS, May 10. -- In even greater numbers than yesterday the French people today went to Elysee Palace to pay tribute to assassinated President Doumer by taking a last look at his face as he lies in state in the darkened salon which has been transformed into a mortuary chapel.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 10. -- Mrs. Harriet Chamberlin of Toledo, Ohio, is slated to become president of the Young Women's Christian Association for the next two years at the election to be held by national convention delegates here tomorrow, no other candidate having been nominated.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP). -- Receivership proceedings were instituted late today in United States District Court against the Federal Public Service Corporation of Delaware on behalf of Luke L. Stager, a bondholder.

Harry Gerguson, who prefers to call himself Michael Romanoff because it is more in keeping with his polished air, stood on the brig at the very stern of the French liner De Grasse at noon yesterday and gazed sadly back at New York from an iron-barred porthole as the ship steamed down the harbor and out to sea.

Colonel Frederick Pope consulting engineer and investment banker, who for four years has been advising the Soviet chemical trust in the construction of huge potash plants, returned from Russia yesterday, on the White Star liner Majestic and said he had a plan which he believed would help to bring about the wish of Russians for recognition in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Farm products made a fairly firm showing the first part of May, the Department of Agriculture said today in its survey of the markets during the past week. Declines in the opening days of the month were followed, it said, by a trend toward recovery in cotton, grain, eggs and some fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Misfortune continues to dog every step taken by the Roosevelt forces to organize the national convention. Now their choice for temporary chairman, Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, is at the stake for heresy, and the Calvin who arraigns him is the leading Roosevelt champion in the Senate -- Cordell Hull of Tennessee.

In a day of idly drifting prices, fractional advances predominated on the stock market. Bonds moved irregularly; there was seemingly less selling of domestic issues, and advances were nearly as numerous as declines. Foreign bonds, however, were lower after Monday's firmness, though the day's changes were narrow.

A twelve-week season of grand opera in English, with one night a week devoted to a performance of an opera in its original language, will be presented by Milton Aborn in the Fall in a centrally located, theatre, provided sufficient interest is manifested by the public to justify such an enterprise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a very able letter to THE TIMES, Edward F. Chandler makes several interesting diagnoses of our present straitened conditions. In pointing out that the country needs small business in addition to having big business, he shows that the great corporations possess highest efficiency for production, but unfortunately are not competent to create a healthy demand.

Greenwich "Village organisations completed plans yesterday to hold "open house" during the week beginning on Saturday, May 21, in order to display to visitors in holiday mood the picturesque attractions of the neighborhood.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation declined 145,487 tons to 2,326,926 tons in April, it was announced yesterday. The reduction, the thirteenth consecutive decrease, brought the corporation's bookings to a new low record. They have fallen into new low ground each month this year.

BASLE, May 10. -- Control of exchange and tariff barriers provide no solution for the fundamental problems of the world's economic situation and only aggravate them in the long run, Gates W. McGarrah, president of the Bank for International Settlements, asserted in his second annual report, which was approved here today by representatives of twenty-one banks of issue and banking groups, comprising the stockholders of the World Bank.

An investigation of the Suicide of Ivar Kreuger in Paris to determine whether news of the Swedish industrialist's death was withheld from the general public to permit informed "insiders" to dump large holdings of Kreuger securities on the market is to be made a part of the International Match Corporation bankruptcy proceedings, it was learned yesterday.

A moderately better tone prevailed in yesterday's security and commodity markets, although, business continued small. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 738,000 shares. After an irregular opening, stocks rallied slightly and then eased to close the day with fractional gains.

Warning the 227 seniors who were attending their last student assembly that they are about to go forth into a period "clouded with darkness," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College advised them last night not to attach too much importance to making money.

The possibility that the Connecticut State Agricultural College at Storrs will include a course in game breeding and management seems quite likely, now that Oliver Could Jennings of Fairfield has offered to supply the equipment, the chief item in the cost of organizing the work.

A plan for refunding indebtedness, increasing working capital and readjusting the capital structure of the Agfa Ansco Corporation, rated as the second largest manufacturer of cameras and photographic supplies in this country, was submitted yesterday to holders of common and preferred stocks by a special committee appointed by the directors.

The collapse of Mayor "Walker's program for bus operation in Manhattan and Queens under "comprehensive" franchises and the substitution of a policy of short-term awards to existing "independent" operators was forecast at City Hall yesterday, following the announcement by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee on Monday of his intention not to back the Mayor's program in Queens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- Albie Booth, brilliant three-sport athlete, counted out of further athletic competition at Yale no less than a fortnight ago, today came back to baseball, playing against the Rikkio University nine of Tokyo.

Before a capacity crowd of more than 8,000, including Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney, who threw out the first ball, the opening game of the Junior Police Athletic League, organized by the Crime Prevention Bureau of the Police Department, was played yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.

PARIS, May 10. -- Texas Guinan, whose theatrical troupe was once barred from France, arrived here today as tourist and announced she would buy many costumes for her forthcoming stage production before returning to New York in about ten days.

Effective on Friday, interest rates paid by Clearing House banks to their depositors will be reduced by 1/2 of 1 per cent, in accordance with a ruling adopted yesterday by the New York Clearing House Committee.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr. arrived on the Majestic and are at the Pierre.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 10 (AP). -- A receivership for the Federal Public Service Corporation, which provides 311 communities in seventeen Middle Western and Southern States with electric, gas, water and telephone service, was asked today by Luke L. Stager of Kearny, N.J.

The New York Little Symphony, Hans Bruno Meyer conductor, appeared in concert last night at the Town Hall in a program of music for chamber orchestra, with Katherine Bacon, pianist, assisting as soloist. This ensemble of sixteen men made itself known toward the end of last season in three concerts at Roerich Hall.

A resolution strongly condemning any obstructionist moves by lawyers aimed at the city investigation being conducted by the Hofstadter legislative committee, and endorsing the work of the committee, was adopted last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 10. -- Further gains in Western States cheered members of Governor Roosevelt's party today as his total of instructed delegates continued to mount.

ORANGE, N.J., May 10. -- The Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Washburn, rector of Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, Boston, was elected Bishop Coadjutor to aid Bishop Wilson R. Stearly in the work of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Newark at the fifty-eighth annual diocesan, convention held at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church here today.

A verdict of guilty of first-degree murder was returned by a General Sessions jury after two hours' deliberation yesterday in the trial of William J. Turner, 23 years old, for the shooting of John McGowan Jan. 7 in the hold-up of McGovern's speak-easy at 407 West Fifty-seventh Street.

GDYNIA, Poland, May 10. -- After sailing all around Europe in an effort to land fifteen deportees from Argentina, the "mystery ship" Chaco, in reality a government transport, was permitted to land nine of them here today when their Polish citizenship was established.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- It you are living in the right places these days, you can buy foor for about what your great-grandparents used to pay.
NEW ORLEANS, May 10 (AP). -- As many children recovered from infantile paralysis without serum as with it in the first big test of this remedy, the American Medical Association was informed.

TOKYO, May 10. -- The War Office announced today that the Fourteenth Division, which was withdrawn from Shanghai, had arrived at Dairen and was en route to one of the scenes of operations, in Manchuria.

Tax collections are the corner-stone of a city's credit. Early this year, when the funk was at Its bluest, dire predictions were made. It was said that real estate had been hit so hard by the depression that thousands of property owners would be unable to meet the city's bills promptly, if they were able to meet them at all.

A week after it had been announced to open on Broadway, the melodrama of political corruption entitled "Merry-Go-Round" emerged placidly from a heavily publicized controversy and had a quiet uptown premiere last night at the Avon Theatre.

After a heated debate, the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York adopted a resolution at its 149th annual convention yesterday in Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, expressing approval of the recent "economy message" of President Hoover to Congress.

Ernie Vavra yielded eight safeties, but kept them fairly well scattered, to give New York University's baseball team a 5-to-1 victory over Washington and Lee at Ohio Field yesterday, the triumph being the eighth in eleven games this season for the Violet nine.

State Senator John A. Hastings found Samuel Seabury's evidence linking him with bus deals since the Equitable Coach fiasco a little funnier than any one else at yesterday's public hearing of the Hofstadter committee, and persisted in laughing above the crowd.

A sudden collapse of earth along the wall of a water main trench at the top of which several small boys were at play in Riverdale Avenue, between Stone Avenue and Watkins Street, in the Brownsville section of Brookiyn, late yesterday afternoon hurled the boys into the ditch and buried two so deeply under an avalanche of falling earth that one later died of suffocation and the second was severely injured.
Block-Aid funds are now providing emergency wages for 4,903 heads of needy families, it was announced last night by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization.

PARIS, May 10. -- The quiet, uncontested election of a new French President today had a steadying influence on the Bourse. The market's trend was generally higher except in some leading international issues like Suez Canal, Rio Tinto Copper, Royal Dutch Oil, Gold Fields and other mining stocks.

CLEVELAND, May 10. -- Wet candidates on the Republican ticket took an early lead in the returns from the State-wide primary today and kept increasing their margin over their dry opponents as the vote piled up.

Two men walked into Marion Roman's restaurant on the second floor of 204 West Sixty-fourth Street early yesterday morning and announced that they were going to "clean out the place." Less than an hour later one of them lay dead in Roosevelt Hospital and his companion, beaten beyond recognition, was reported dying.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent Fabian Franklin does President Hoover great injustice in his charge that when the depression began, and since, he "tried to dispel gloom by expressing a rose-colored view of the facts and doing nothing whatever about them."

MONTREAL, May 10 (Canadian Press). -- The Montreal Royals registered their eleventh straight victory when they swept the four-game series with Jersey City by winning today, 3-1. McAfee went the route and allowed two hits, chalking up Ms fourth triumph of the season.

Municipal employes living outside of New York City would have one year to move into the city or forfeit j their positions, under the terms of an amended revision of the Code of Ordinances introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen by Vice Chairman Dennis J. Mahon.

Lady Chetwode, one of the leading social figures of England and the wife of the Commander-in-Chief of the British forces in India, arrived in New York yesterday in a tourist third cabin of the Majestic. She is here to see her son, Roger Charles George Chetwode, who is studying for a financial career in the banking house of J.P. Morgan Co.

Percy L. Deutsch, former president of the Acoustic Products Company, which became the Sonora Products Corporation of America, spent yesterday on the witness stand explaining to Judge John M. Woolsey in the United States District Court his unsuccessful negotiations the early part of 1928 to raise money to buy De Forest Radio Company stock for the Acoustic Products Company.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Continuing their research work into the upper strata of the National League, the Giants came to grips today with the burning question, "what's come over the Cubs?" and they found an an-answer that was not at all to their liking.

Henri Chardon, president of the French State Railways and president of the section of Legislation, Justice and Foreign Affairs of the Council of State, arrived here late yesterday on the French liner Paris on his first visit to the United States. He was accompanied by his son, F.H. Chardon, an auditor of the Council, who acts as his interpreter.

PARIS, May 10. -- President Albert Lebrun, who was born on Aug. 29, 1871, is, like so many other past Presidents of France, a man who has risen from humble beginnings through hard work and perseverance. His father was a farmer near the little village of Mercy-le-Haut.

DETROIT, May 10. -- Funds for municipal operations and salaries to June 30, the end of the fiscal year were assured today by the City Controller, G. Hall Roosevelt, who announced to the city council that financing operations had been agreed upon in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A determined Senatorial effort to create a balanced budget got under way today with the appointment of a strictly bipartisan Economy Committee of six members, who will meet tomorrow for the first time. In the meantime the Appropriations Committee will defer consideration of all pending supply bills.

George Stanley Shirk, temporary administrator of the estate of Ella V. Von E. Wendel, which had been estimated at $100,000,000, testified before Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday that her realty holdings amounted to $29,988,025, of which $29,356,000 represented the 1930 assessed value of 143 parcels of real estate in Manhattan.

Edward C. Anness, wealthy broker and oldest member of the New York Stock Exchange, and his two infant grandchildren, heirs to his fortune, who live with him at 1,155 Park Avenue, have been guarded for several days by police and private detectives, it was disclosed yesterday.

AURORA, Ill., May 10 (AP). -- Supreme Sweet, a 5-year-old daughter of High Time -- Miss Jazbo, just lasted today to win the Momence Purse at Exposition Park from Portmanteau in a thrilling five-and-one-half-furlong battle.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10. -- Mrs. Henry Ford, president of the National Farm and Garden Association, asked members of the council of the organization at its Spring conference at New Jersey College for Women today to stress the interdependence of women in cities and women on farms.
GLASGOW, May 10. -- The premiere of "Dangerous Corners," J.B. Priestley's first piece originally written for the theatre, excited critics here. It will open in London on May 17.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 10 (AP). -- Trickling returns from the West Virginia primary tonight gave Governor Roosevelt of New York a commanding lead over Governor Murray of Oklahoma in the Democratic Presidential preference contest.

Directors of the Firehiens Insurance Company of Newark voted yesterday to ask the stockholders of the company for authority to reduce the par value of its capital stock from $10 to $5 a share and to add the difference to its surplus.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 10. -- Mrs. Kenneth Lord and Mrs. Herbert C. Bothwell were tied for first honors this afternoon at the annual Spring bulb show of the garden department of the Garden City-Hempstead Community Club in the Casino here.

Lieutenant Thomas F. Sands, former holder of the intercollegiate fencing title while at West Point, led the twelve candidates for the three berths on the United States Olympic modern pentathlon team at the conclusion of the fencing division of the final tryouts last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10. -- Revision of the marriage, burial and communion services of the Methodist Episcopal Church was recommended today in a report submitted to the thirty-first general conference of the denomination. The report, made by the commission on revision of the ritual and referred to the committee on state of the church, proposed the elimination from a bridegroom's marriage vows of the words, "With all my worldly goods I thee endow."

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Further delay in the proposed auction of shares of Insull companies held as collateral by banks in New York City appeared today to be probable following a conference here between Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley and attorneys representing the Eastern banks.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP). -- Vic Sorrell pitched a two-hit game for the Detroit Tigers today while his mates were making fourteen hits off three Red Sox hurlers to annex the series opener, 11 to 0.

Parking and Backsliding. The Sun has a dispatch from Chicago which will be read with interest by many who do business on and near Fifth Avenue in this city. It reports that after four years of experience with "no parking" in the Loop district in the daytime, Chicago is considering the repeal of its famous ordinance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- Peekskill Military Academy handed the Yale freshmen a 3-to-1 defeat in a close battle between Pitchers Clancy of the academy and Harrington of the freshmen today. The visitors bunched their hits to score three runs in the fourth.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday and comparatively quiet. United States Government issues, as a group, advanced moderately, with five of the eleven active issues moving up 1-32 to 12-32 point, three losing 1-32 to 10-32 point and the three others holding unchanged.
LONDON, May 10. -- Amy Johnson and James Allan Mollison, the aviators whose engagement was announced last night, may attempt to fly the Atlantic together.

PARIS, May 10. -- Albert F. Lebrun was elected President of the French Republic today by the two houses of Parliament. He received 633 votes to 114 given to the Socialist candidate, Paul Faure, merely as a party gesture.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Government control of liquor sales on lines similar to the Swedish Bratt system formed the basis of a proposed constitutional amendment presented to a Senate Manufactures subcommittee today by John M. Morehead, Minister to Sweden.

Renewed demand on President Hoover to use his influence with Congress to effect a $450,000,000 reduction in the amount annually spent on veterans not suffering from war disabilities was embodied in a telegram sent to the White House yesterday on behalf of the National Economy Committee.

Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, the tenth ranking player of the country and the top favorite in the North Side championship, was carried to three sets by I. Biltchik yesterday at the University Heights Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- E.N. Baty, executive secretary of the Chicago and Cook County Bankers Association from 1922 to 1931, denied tonight that any bribes had been passed in opposing the McFadden bill, or that he was employed at a special salary to lobby against it.

Prizes in the fortieth, annual exhibition at the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue, were announced yesterday at the opening of the exhibition. Awards were made as follows:

Dr. George J. Ryan, following his re-election unanimously yesterday at the annual meeting of the Board of Education to serve his eleventh term as president of the board, devoted most of his address to a tribute to the teachers and others in the school system who have contributed $1,700,000 since the school relief fund was started for needy children.

LONDON, May 10 (AP). -- The first royal court of the season will take place tomorrow at Buckingham Palace, with the second occurring on Thursday. A number of American women will be presented at one or the other of the courts.

There are so many Democratic candidates for President that one hardly has time to be sure about the circumstances of their early lives; but at least two are able to qualify according to the conventional standard. Mr. MELVIN A. TRAYLOR and Speaker GARNER were not only born on a farm, as most Congressmen arrange to be, but in a log cabin.

The National Council on Freedom from Censorship urged License Commissioner Geraghty in a letter made public yesterday to drop his hearings renewing the licenses for two burlesque shows on West Forty-second Street and to let the courts judge the propriety of the performances.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -- After an unsteady start, Ray White of Columbia held the Princeton varsity nine to one run in the last eight innings, while Columbia hit hard and took advantage of Princeton misplays to score an 8-to-5 victory in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today.

Organization of an insurance holding company, the principal subsidiaries of which will be a large casualty company and two Stock Exchange investment trusts, Is being effected by a group headed by Julius H. Barnes, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Record votes, reflecting spirited and bitter campaigns in which economy was the outstanding issue, marked the local elections yesterday in eleven New Jersey municipalities under the commission form of government.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP). -- Rapid fire changes in a real life domestic drama won Helene Costello, screen actress, a divorce today from Lowell Sherman, director-actor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP). -- With Lefty Grove pitching in his old-time form, the Athletics won the series opener from the Chicago White Sox today, 9 to 0. Grove allowed only six hits, struck out five men and did not give a walk, to win his fourth game of the season.
BERLIN, May 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of May 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

New York broadcasters were divided in opinion yesterday regarding Canada's proposed plan of nationalizing radio broadcasting. The stipulation limiting advertising to 5 per cent of the program period was called a direct blow at advertising on the air and was seen as "killing the goose that lays the golden egg" by Frank Mason, vice president of the National Broadcasting Company.

ROCHESTER. N.Y., May 10 (AP). -- Officials of the New York State Bowling Association were busy today winding up the details of the ninth annual tourney, which closed last night. Prize lists in the five-man event were completed and ninety teams shared in the money award, with 2,701 totals finally edging into the pay-off.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -- The Princeton freshman baseball team scored a 14-to-0 victory over the Riverdale School in a seven-inning game today. The Tiger cubs scored three in the first and seven in the second.

Nicholas C. Fartos, 52 years old, pharmacist who at one time was reported to have amassed millions in real estate ventures and a patented medicine, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions for from five to ten years.

For the first time since the Bank of United States closed its doors in the faces of its 400,000 depositors on the morning of Dec. 11, 1930, the story of the efforts made to save the institution in the last two and onehalf months of its existence was told yesterday by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- The condition and indicated production of Winter wheat in important producing States were announced as follows:

C.R. Coe's Pompeius, winner of the Excelsior Handicap last Saturday by eight lengths, scored again at Jamaica yesterday when he captured the Southampton Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth with five lengths to spare. The 3-year-old son of Pompey and Elvina now has won three in a row, since he also has the Spring Handicap to his credit.

Of no one more fittingly than of HASTINGS H. HART could this have been said. For years his life was devoted to visiting those in prison, to studying the causes and prevention of crime, and how society can best deal with those who are a menace to the general welfare.

Efforts to prevent demoralization of the retail gasoline markets, especially on the Atlantic Coast, are being made by the large refining and marketing organizations. It is understood that arrangements have been made for the purchase for surplus gasoline seeking a market at concessions, especially that coming from the Pacific Coast.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Senator Hayden of Arizona discussed with President Hoover today the Senator's joint resolution which, would permit foreign nations to pay their debts to the United States in silver until July 1, 1936.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Wax Department appropriation bill, which proposes to eliminate 2,000 army officers and suspend the citizens' and Reserve Officers' Training Corps camps for one year, was taken up in the House today, with every indication that it would share the fate of the economy bill.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The naval airship Akron in flight from Lakehurst to the Pacific Coast is weathhurst to the Pacific Coast has weathered in fine fashion the storms of West Texas.

Serious consideration is being given by the postal authorities to a protest against the proposed use of the mails to circulate "Swat the Dry" stamps, it was revealed yesterday afternoon at the annual convention of the Kings County W.C.T.U., which opened a two-day session at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

A young man who has been working in Poughkeepsie for the State of New York will transfer his activities to the American Academy in Rome as a result of winning, yesterday, the Prix de Rome in landscape architecture.

The estate of Isobel Cooper has sold to George B. de Gersdorff a residence and about four acres of land, with garage and outbuildings, at Bedford, Westchester County, adjoining the land of Harold Whitman and the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club.

Although there is no provision in the by-laws of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, permitting the diversion of the defense committee's funds -- held for use in case of strikes or lockouts -- more than $50,000 of a $63,000 defense fund was diverted to the organization committee, whose alleged practices are under fire, according to testimony yesterday by William Beck, treasurer of the union.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Tariffs written into the tax bill during the two weeks of trading in the Senate Finance Committee promised today to furnish the greatest battle ground for conflicting views on the measure.

It is a very interesting little group of paintings by Americans that constitutes the current attraction at the Marie Sterner Gallery, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street. Nearly all of the artists included are represented by early work, or by work not of conspicuously recent coinage.
The Evander Childs High School baseball team tallied its fifth triumph in as many Upper Manhattan-Bronx division P.S.A.L. games by defeating Morris, 6 to 1, yesterday at Sterling Oval.

PARIS, May 10. -- The appointment of Emil Lederer, New York director of the Hamburg-American Line, as executive chairman with "broad dictatorial powers" was "virtually agreed upon" at today's session here of the North Atlantic shipping conference.

ABSECON, N.J., May 10. -- Miss Agnes Christy of the home links carried off the qualifying medal in the annual women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament which started today at the Seaview Golf Club.

BERLIN, May 10 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler's National Socialists ended their policy of aloof tolerance today by launching a furious attack against the Bruening Government in a stormy session of the Reichstag.

Buyers' Registrations Off. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week but remained slightly above the total reached for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Only 624 law students out of a class of 1,932 passed the March Bar examination, it was announced here today by John Kirkland Clark of New York; Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany. This is the smallest number of successful applicants of any examination in recent months.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,251,900 barrels, compared with 2,177,500 in the preceding week, an increase of 74,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,732,300 barrels daily, against 1,659,900, an increase of 72,400.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- Over the objection, of several New York delegates, the convention of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union today adopted a strongly worded criticism of the Soviet Government for its alleged repression of civil liberties and the jailing or exiling of political opponents.

GENEVA, May 10. -- Leaders of the disarmament conference have tacitly agreed to put off its important political work until early in June, meanwhile contiuing its technical work. This agreement was diplomatically hidden in a decision today of the general commissions to create two more technical committees, accompanied by the casual announcement that it could not itself meet again until these or those already working on qualitative disarmament were ready to report to it.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The labor policies of the administration were attacked and the lie was passed between Secretary Doak and members of a group of textile workers and others, from New York and Boston, who called on him today to demand the release of Edith Berkman, a textile union organizer now being held in Boston for deportation to Poland.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Arguing in the Senate today for retention of the branch-banking provision in his banking bill, Senator Glass denounced "propaganda" against this section and charged that "some Congressmen" had been "hired by the Loop banks of Chicago" to vote against the McFadden bill containing similar provisions several years ago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10. -- Ohio voters, despite drizzling rains in several cities and scarcity of outstanding issues, turned out in comparatively large numbers today to nominate Republican and Democratic slates.

Teams in the National Hockey League will have to curb expenses next season. At the regular semi-annual meeting of the league, held in this city yesterday, it was voted to hold each of the eight clubs in the group to a maximum expenditure of $70,000 for the campaign.

John McCambridge's Flaming, the 6-year-old son of Wrack from Flambette, scored his fourth consecutive victory and kept his 1932 record clear when he won easily in the Garden City Claiming Stakes, feature of the closing-day program, at Jamaica yesterday.

Gifts to Columbia University aggregating $52,915.02 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. The largest was a donation of $32,300 from the Commonwealth Fund "for research into the causes of dental decay."

To the editor of The New York Times: Any one who contemplates a trip to our national parks or to other sections of the West finds very attractive fares offered, but what about those of us who are going to Maine or other parts of New England for our two weeks' vacation?

DETROIT, May 11. -- Lawrence P. Fisher, president of the Cadillac Motor Car Company and vice president of General Motors Corporation, was sued today by attorneys representing the Howard Young Galleries, Inc., of New York, for $1,000,000, alleged as past due for paintings purchased n the last three years.

Police of the Old Slip station were called yesterday to the offices of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation, at 120-Broadway, when a group of stockholders opposed to the present management tried unsuccessfully to obtain possession, of the offices, books, records and cash of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Dr. Robert N. Keely, 73 years old, surgeon, explorer and author, who accompanied Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary's first expedition in search of the North Pole, ended his life by drinking poison in his apartment at the St. James Annex, the coroner's office announced today.

Stimulation of the railroads by "giving them competitors worthy of their steel" in the form of a national system of "fourfold super-automobile highways" to supplement them was proposed yesterday as a step toward "a true and lasting remedy for our present dangerous depression" by Edward A. Filene.

LONDON, May 11. -- If the Irish Free State enacts as law the pending bill abolishing the oath to the King, Great Britain will retaliate by cutting off without negotiation, the tariff advantages now enjoyed by the Free State in the British market.
HAVANA, Cuba, May 11 (AP). -- Jack Crawford, No. 1 player of the Australian Davis Cup team, was drawn against Ricardo Morales for the first match of the Australian-Cuba tie starting here Friday.

One never so fully appreciates the value of "the printed page" and the desirability of leisure as when up to his neck in Government documents. Till the arrival of the forty-eight-hour day, one can but take the briefest snack at this immense and unfailing banquet.

In his first public criticism of Samuel Seabury's investigation into the Magistrates' Courts, Mayor Walker charged yesterday that the investigation had so shattered the morale of the Police Department that no policeman would make a vice arrest for fear of being accused of "framing" innocent women.
WASHINGTON, D.C., May 11. -- Tentative agreement on several suggestions for reducing governmental expenditures was reached late today by the new Senate economy committee.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 11. -- The establishment of a fund to be known as the Lou Henry Hoover Scholarship for Girl Scouts was announced today by Mrs. Henry Ford, president of the National Farm and Garden Association, which is holding its annual Spring council meeting at New Jersey College for Women.

CAMP KEARNEY, Cal., May 11. -- A tragic drama of the skies was written in an unsuccessful attempt of the world's largest airship, the Akron, to land here today. Two men of the mooring crew were dashed to death, and a third, Bud Cowart, was carried aloft for two hours, dangling at the end of a 300-foot rope.

NICE, France, May 11. -- A police raiding party numbering forty plain-clothes and motorcycle officers combed the foreign quarter of Nice this morning and made many arrests. The authorities are observing the strictest silence regarding the operations.

Robert Russell Bennett, American composer, winner of two of the five composition prizes in the RCA-Victor $25,000 contest last year, sailed for Europe last night on the New York to complete a grand opera on an American subject. The libretto for the work has been written by Robert A. Simon, music editor of The New Yorker and author of several books.

Mayor Walker, speaking last night over station WEAF of the National Broadcasting Company, challenged opponents of his "Beer for Taxation" plan to produce any other form of taxation that would be "less of a burden upon people already overburdened with taxation."

A biography of Owen D. Young by Ida Tarbell is announced for publication on June 7 by Macmillan. The book will be called "Owen D. Young: A New Type of Industrial Leader." Miss Tarbell, whose two-volume history of the Standard Oil Company is considered a classic in its kind, has been at work on the biography for several years and has packed into the book the results of more than 100 interviews.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11. -- Army won from Washington and Lee on the baseball diamond today, 5 to 4.

BERLIN, May 11. -- Political debts, disarmament and the world economic depression constitute indissoluble and interlocking problems and unless the statesmen of all nations concerned abandon the aimlessness with which they are being approached the near future may see the word "chaos" written squarely across the world's political and economic physiognomy, Chancellor Bruening told the Reichstag today.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The text of the President's message vetoing the Democratic tariff bin is as follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- Yale, helped by the wildness of Pitchers Lyman and Wadlow, today defeated the Colgate nine, 9 to 5. Ned Wheeler, who pitched for the Elis, was steady throughout, and though Colgate touched him for ten hits, he kept them well scattered and was in trouble only in the fourth inning, when Colgate scored four runs on two errors by Albie Booth. three hits and a pass.

A Social Charmer. Mr. DAHL of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company testified yesterday that he had met Senator HASTINGS thirty or forty times, but that they had never conferred, except possibly once or twice, about buses.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Swedish Bratt system of liquor control is being considered by some administration leaders as a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment in wet States, according to strong indications today.

Johnny Allen, North Carolinan and International League graduate, pitched his first complete major league game yesterday and shut out the St. Louis Browns with five hits, the Yankees winning, 3 to 0, for their fourth straight victory and a clean sweep of two games to which their St. Louis series was reduced by Monday's postponement.

Estimated gross revenues of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in April were $6,600,000, against $9,474,705 in April, 1931, and there was a net operating deficit of about $300,000 contrasted with net operating incomes of $309,761 in March and $124,954 in April, 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Representative Woodrum of Virginia caused the House to laugh loudly today when he displayed photostatic copies of pages from the Congressional Record containing excerpts of almost identical speeches credited to Representative La Guardia of New York and Representative Buchanan of Texas.

Moe Kronenfeld's double scoring Leo Schoppmeyer, who had singled, in the twelfth inning gave George Washington High School's baseball team a 5-to-4 victory over James Monroe High yesterday. By winning, George Washington moved into undisputed possession of second place in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division P.S.A.L. race.

City bonds valued at $50,000, which were provided for the bail of George M. McManus after his arrest for the murder of Arnold Bothstein, had been part of a purchase of $100,000 made for that purpose by William McLaughlin, a retired police Inspector and former deputy police chief, Mr. McLaughlin revealed yesterday at a lession of Yorkville Court held in the bedroom of his home at 60 East Cighty-third Street.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.

LONDON, Thursday, May 12. -- The first court of the season, held to-night by the King and Queen, was attended by the diplomatic corps in full force and offered a brilliant spectacle, despite the court's week of mourning for president Doumer of France.

Tuesday's primary in Ohio was virtually a referendum vote on prohibition. This aspect of the contest overshadowed everything else. The result was emphatic and offers a clear indication that both political parties will at Chicago stand for some form of modification or repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11. -- The twelve aspirants for berths on the United States Olympic modern pentathlon team competed in the riding events at the Military Academy today over a heavy course.

DUBLIN, May 11. -- The budget with which Finance Minister Sean McEntee opened the Dail Eireann this afternoon in some respects constitutes a social and economic revolution for the Free State. The measure provides for expenditures of L26,247,365, with revenue of L26,260,250, leaving a surplus of L12,855. [The pound is quoted at about $3.67 at present.]

Albert Tag, former chairman of the board of the Continental Bank of New York, who died on Feb. 14 1931, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,940,518 gross and $1,786,796 net, of which $75,000 will go to four charitable organizations after the death of the widow, Mrs. Anna Tag.

VIENNA, May 11 (AP). -- Sensational reports which circulated in Vienna last night to the effect that King Alexander of Yugoslavia had fled the country in the midst of a military revolt apparently were based on the arrest of sixteen, officers of the army for Insubordination, it developed today.

LONDON, May 11. -- As the British Foreign Office has received informal intimations from all the governments concerned that June 16 is acceptable to them for the opening of the Lausanne conference, the British Government, acting under a mandate, will forthwith issue formal invitations for the meeting to convene on that date.

A closing rally enabled the Seton Hall College nine to down Manhattan, 12 -- 7, at Jasper Field yesterday. Trailing, 6 -- 3, at the start of the eighth, the New Jersey Collegians produced nine runs in the course of the two final innings.

Rapid transit unification, on the basis of the $474,500,000 price which the Transit Commission tentatively recommended last December as a fair value for the B.M.T. and Interborough subway and elevated lines, has been made virtually impossible because of recent disclosures before the Hofstadter legislative commmittee, it was admitted yesterday in official circles.
The entrance of new interests into the control of the St. Louis South-western Railway and the Kansas City Southern Railroad were reflected in changes in their directorates, made known yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 (Canadian Press). -- David Lloyd George, who was then Minister of Munitions, had actually arranged to go with Earl Kitchener to Russia in 1916 on the cruiser Hampshire, which was sunk by a mine.

A dinner dance in behalf of the charitable activities of the Flower Hospital Auxiliary will be given tonight on board the Majestic at Pier 59, foot of West Eighteenth Street. After dinner, which will be served in the main dining salon, there will be a musical program by Paquale Amato, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera; Mme. Gina Pinnera, soprano, and Miss Muriel Pollack and Miss Vee Lawnhurst, pianists.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The Glass banking bill will be put to a crucial test tomorrow when the Senate will decide whether it shall be pushed to a conclusion or be displaced by the $1,000,000,000 tax bill.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11 (AP). -- The Sage Stable's Microphone, a Preakness eligible, displayed a pronounced liking for sloppy going to win the featured Pimlico Graded Handicap, Class A, today at Pimlico. A length in the wake of the winner trudged Happy Scot and an additional three lengths back Portden, another Preakness eligible, shoved his head across the line in advance of Tred Avon.

A conference of physicians, including Health Commissioner Wynne, Dr. Charles Norris, chief medical examiner, and radium experts, agreed yesterday that radium water and radium salt emanations such as caused the death six weeks ago of Eben M. Byers, millionaire sportsman, are "decidedly harmful."

Opposition to the proposed amendment to the code of ordinances requiring residence within the city for city employes was expressed yesterday by the New York League of Women Voters and the Public Education Association in letters sent to the Board of Aldermen demanding a public hearing on the measure so that opposition may be heard.

In recognition of his public service in formulating the Swope plan for stabilizing work with guarantee of employment, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company arid author of the plan, will receive tonight the Gold Medal Award of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the annual dinner of the organization at the Waldorf-Astoria.

EASTON, Fa., May 11. --Princeton's nine snapped Lafayette's winning streak today with a 12-6 victory in a contest played during a driving rain. The Tigers used four pitchers, who held the Maroon to seven safeties, while the Princeton batsmen collected eleven hits off two Lafayette hurlers, Glenn and M. Socolow.

Barney H. Cohen, 45 years old, Manhattan poultry dealer and a brother of Joseph Cohen, the figure in the poultry war of 1914, who was shot and killed a month ago, was killed last night and Daniel Belbiso, 45, of 108-11 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens, an employe, was injured at 159th and South Streets, a busy corner in Jamaica, by a fusillade fired from an automobile.

The steel industry remains irregular, with moderate improvement in some lines offset by recessions in others, according to The Iron Age, which, finds that the industry generally was just able last week to maintain production at an average rate of 24 per cent of capacity.

The eagerness of the general public, that the Metropolitan Opera continue and the heightened interest in the coming season were evidenced yesterday at the Opera House when more than 1,000 old and new subscribers waited in long lines during the opening day for personal interviews regarding subscriptions and change of seats.

PARIS, May 11. -- All day today France's new President, Albert Lebrun, received congratulations. But seldom has any President of the Republic come into office under such difficult circumstances. While the world is waiting for France to help solve the great problem of disarmament and financial reconstruction there already has begun here a political fight that seems likely to clog the wheels of progress many weeks.

A syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York obtained yesterday the award of an issue of $12,002,000 Westchester County (N.Y.) improvement bonds, due variously on June 1, 1933 to 1981, at a price of 100.0171 for a combination of 4 1/4s and 4 1/2s, which represented an interest cost to the county of 4.3793 per cent.

Intimate recollections of old Washington Square and the immediate neighborhood were recited by descendants of socially prominent families who settled in the district more than a century ago, at an "evening of reminiscences" given by the Washington Square Association in the Hotel Brevoort last night.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Reservations were added to the World Court Protocol today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and tomorrow its future course will be determined.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- A new agreement of the Pacific Coast European conference, restricted to rates, tariffs and brokerage matters, was today approved by the Shipping Board.

ABSECON, N.J., May 11. -- Mrs. Irving Brown of Knickerbocker and Mrs. F.B. Ryan of Baltusrol will meet in the final of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament at the Seaview Golf Club tomorrow.

TOKYO, May 11. -- By unconditionally withdrawing all Japanese troops from the Shanghai area within a month, the government intends to show the world that the Shanghai affair was not a premeditated act of national policy, but was an unfortunate adventure thrust upon the Japanese Army by the events of Jan. 28.

The Art Workshop, directed by Erika G. Klien at the New School for Social Research, is having an exhibition in the third floor gallery until May 17. The impress of Miss Klien's personality is everywhere apparent, in the determined "modernism" high color and unity of subject matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having been for two years at the head of a large committee conducting relief of unemployment in the township of Oyster Bay, utilizing the seven Legion posts as auxiliaries and in cooperation with all welfare organizations there, both county and State, I have acquired an intimate knowledge of the unemployment situation in that section.

LONDON, May 11 (AP). -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in April are as follows: Exports of British products, u34,780,000; re-exports, foreign goods, u4,640,000; total exports, u39,420,000; imports, u53,220,000; excess of imports, u13,800,000.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11. -- Army won a one-sided lacrosse game from N.Y.U. today by a score of 14 to 3. Darcy was high scorer for the cadets with seven goals.

In the absence of other market influences, the announcement yesterday of the definite omission of the common dividend of the New York Central, after a probation period of over four months in which the decision was held in abeyance, turned stock prices lower.
BALTIMORE, May 11. -- Homewood House, situated on the grounds of Johns Hopkins University, was officially opened here today by Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University.

A program of public works construction by the Federal Government and States, counties and municipalities as the most effective means for relieving the depression and stimulating a revival of Industry was urged yesterday by the American Society of Civil Engineers.

Weather developments and sympathy with wheat helped improve prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the close being at gains of 3 to 5 points. The resistance that developed on Tuesday's decline stimulated covering and held fluctuations within limits of about 10 points.

The Little Red School House in Greenwich Village has been saved. Abandonment of the project in progressive education which seemed inevitable last week in the face of an unsympathetic Board of Education has been turned aside by a plan of subsistence and the school will carry on next September.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The effect on the railroad industry of placing its employes on a six-hour day will be to increase its annual labor bill by $600,000,000 on the basis of 1930 employment, according to representatives of the industry testifying today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The death of Walter S. Klee, former vice president and director of S. W. Straus Co., which was announced late Tuesday night, was caused by poison tablets swallowed with suicidal intent, the Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

After seven years of vain effort to place franchised buses upon the streets of Queens the Board of Estimate, by unanimous vote of an executive meeting of the Committee of the Whole, decided yesterday to make a fresh start by throwing the entire field open to the highest bidder or bidders on one or more of the twenty-eight routes approved to date.

Gold to the amount of $18,481,300 was exported to Europe yesterday, representing partly transfers of earmarked gold and partly exchange shipments made profitable by the premium at which the gold standard currencies of France, Switzerland, Holland and Belgium are quoted in dollar terms.

ORANGE, N.J., May 11. -- Police reserves were called upon tonight to preserve order among the crowd seeking admission to the Orange National Guard Armory to hear Ignace Paderewski pianist, in his last concert in the United States for 1932.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- A comparison of specific taxes payable by individuals under the present law, the revenue bill as passed by the House and the measure as rewritten by the Senate Finance Committee is shown in the following tables:

John J. O'Brien, president of the Deep Rock Oil Corporation, formerly the Shaffer Oil and Refining Company, has sent notices to the holders of its 6 per cent convertible gold notes due on March 1, 1933, which are outstanding in the amount of $10,000,000, that the company has not sufficient cash resources to provide for this maturity, nor can its operations over the next ten months he expected to produce the sum required.

The engagement of $18,000,000 gold for export, offset by reduction of $4,250,000 in "earmarkings," was the main incident of yesterday's markets. This large consignment, which was not unexpected, went to the four European countries -- France, Switzerland, Holland and Belgium -- whose central banks have been pursuing the concerted policy of converting their "foreign exchange reserves" into gold in their own vaults.
TOKYO, May 11 (AP). -- About 15,000 Japanese troops still are in Shanghai. These are chiefly men of the Ninth Division from Kanazawa.
The membership of Henry R. Ickelheimer in the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange has been bought by George H. Logan of Lamborn, Hutchings Co. for $3.250.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest of the efforts of the press to impress upon the people of the city of New York the importance of an aroused public opinion for a reduced city budget. I fear that these efforts are all in vain.

GENEVA, May 11. -- Five civilians and sixteen Generals and Colonels debated today in the land disarmament commission of the disarmament conference whether a mobile cannon becomes an offensive weapon when its mouth measures three, four, six or more inches across.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Prices of hogs were generally steady today, although, taking the extremes as compared with yesterday some sales showed declines of 10 cents a hundred weight, while others were 10 cents higher. The top, however, was lowered 10 cents to $3.60, a new low since December, 1898, but the day's average was unchanged from yesterday at $3.30.

BERLIN, May 11 (AP). -- Bernhard Grund, president of the German Federation of Industry and Commerce, declared today at the opening of that organization's convention that settlement of the reparation problem was Germany's paramount consideration. She cannot pay reparations and a postponement will do no good either to Germany or her creditors, he said.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Jim Anderson, Penn's veteran stroke oar, was back at his customary seat when the Red and Blue worked out in the rain tonight in preparation for the quadrangular regatta with Harvard, Navy and Massachusetts Tech at Annapolis on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- With daily government expenditures far exceeding the receipts, the Treasury's deficit already has passed the $2,500,000,000 mark.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

FRANKFORT - ON - MAIN, Germany, May 11. -- A basis for the revival of world trade and world credit will not be found without an early and definite solution of the reparations and debt problems, Robert Bosch, chairman of the Board of the I.G. Farben Industrie, told the company's stockholders yesterday.
ROME, May 2 (By Mail). -- The inhabitants of Sodom and Gomorrah reached a high state of culture "before they were destroyed by "brimstone and fire from the Lord out of Heaven."
PARIS, May 11. -- Opposition to the appointment of Emil Lederer as shipping dictator developed unexpectedly in today's Atlantic conference meeting here.

Briggs Manufacturing Company -- uarter ended March 31: Net loss after depreciation, taxes and other charges, $953,993, contrasted with net profit of $43,731, equal to 2 cents a share on 2,003,225 no par shares last year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cry of unemployment has touched the hearts of the world, and the greatest credit is due to the generous souls who have successfully organized to combat it. Alas! few appreciate the true meaning of unemployment for the blind.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation was authorized yesterday by the governing committee of the Stock Exchange to list 1,339,516 additional shares to he used in acquiring the remaining shares of the Nevada Consolidated Copper Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The budget must be balanced, but so must business be revived in order that the balancing will be accomplished through the actual collection of the revenue anticipated. Balancing the budget without retarding business seems to me to be a comparatively simple matter.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 11. -- A saving of $10,000,000 in the running expenses of the State of New York for the current fiscal year will be achieved by June 30, Governor Roosevelt announced here today.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 11. -- Lawrenceville overcame the St. Paul's nine of Garden City 10 -- 3, today. Flash limited St. Paul's to six scattered hits.

More than 3,000 volunteer workers and friends of the Salvation Army filled the Metropolitan Opera House, last night at a meeting which marked the official opening of the Army's "United Appeal" campaign to raise $1,090,000 for the organization's emergency relief and institutional aid in the city.

Further improvement in prices in the bond market as a whole was noted yesterday on the Stock Exchange, although trading dwindled to $8,478,700, of which the turnover in United States Government bonds amounted to $2,160,700. As a rule, fluctuations in prices in all groups were considerably narrower than they had been recently, except in the cases of a few infrequently traded issues.
"Lenin's Dowry," a play of Russian life by David Vardi, with Mr. Vardi and Eva Yoalit as the entire cast, will open tonight at the Chanin Auditorium on the fiftieth floor of the Chanin Building.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity shows a further slight gain, actual operations having held steady In spite of the normal seasonal tendency to decline. For the week ended May 7 it stands at 25.9, as against 25.4 for the preceding week and 54.0 for the corresponding week last year.

One acquainted with the beneficent and far-reaching work of the State Charities Aid Association sees in it the lengthened shadow of LOUISA LEE SCHUYLER. She was a descendant both of General PHILIP SCHUYLER and of ALEXANDER HAMILTON.

The new draft of the anti-alien ordinance now before the Board of Aldermen appears to be an improvement over the original proposal vetoed by the Mayor. It specifically exempts laboratory and hospital workers and a few other similar groups.

COLUMBUS, May 11 (AP). -- Ohio, birthplace of the Anti-Saloon League, gave its support to foes of prohibition in yesterday's primary election on the face of returns nearly complete tonight. Gilbert Bettman, Attorney General, easily won the Republican nomination for Senator on an anti-prohibition platform, leading Louis J. Taber, dry, master of the National Grange, by about 60,000 votes.

The twenty-five-day Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont will begin this afternoon, with Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's colt Equipoise, one of the stars entered in the Toboggan Handicap, the day's feature.

George F. Ewald, former magisrate, and his wife, Bertha, were the principal State "witnesses yesterday in Judge Fresehi's part of General Sessions at the trial of Frank L O'Neill, a suspended attendant in the same court, on Mrs. Ewald's charge he defrauded, her of $3,000.

NEW YORK. Mrs. J. West Roosevelt will sail Saturday on the Paris to visit her son, Nicholas Roosevelt, American Minister to Budapest. She will go to Salzburg in August for the music festival, and will return to Oyster Bay in September.

EXETER, N.H., May 11. -- The Exeter baseball team lost to St. Anselm's by 8 to 5 today. The visitors took the lead in the first inning, but in the sixth Exeter scored three runs to overcome a 3-1 deficit.

When I had climbed upon the half-hidden boulder, I cocked my gun and laid it on my shoulder, Waiting in silent ambush there until My quarry came. Then I would shoot to kill. The boughs above me quivered with emerald things:

It is evident from Premier BENNETT'S announcement that Canada intends to solve her radio problems by combining American and British principles. License fees are to be collected from owners of receiving sets as in the past -- British practice. Radio as a whole is to become a public utility under government control -- British also.

C.M. Loeb, Back From Europe, Says Foreign Trade Is Being Stified. The greater reduced volume of foreign trade is being still further strangled by rising tariff barriers and the fixing of import quotas, Carl M. Loeb, senior member of the New York Stock Exchange firm bearing his name, said yesterday on his return from Europe.
GARDEN CITY, L,I., May 11. -- Miss Rosina Jones, budding golf star, was the winner of the one-day tournament held by the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Cherry Valley Club today.

Leo Arico, 21 years old, only child of Louis Arico, the barber who went abroad to cut William F. Kenny's hair in 1929, disappeared from the Arico home, 2,219 East Fourth Street, early on Monday and detectives are still searching for him, the family disclosed yesterday.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday a resolution praising the action of Richard Whitney, president, for his activities in behalf of the New York Stock Exchange during the "unprecedented economic catastrophe in which the world has been involved for the past two years."

MONTREAL, May 11 (AP). -- The Royals won their twelfth straight game today In the opener of a four-game series with Baltimore, beating the Orioles, 9 to 5. Claset, starting pitcher, became wild in the sixth arid was relieved by Fisher, who finished strongly.

The need for continuing private initiative in charity during the current period of stress was emphasized by five university heads and the president of the Board of Education in telegrams to Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the Federation of Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

Almost $730,000 in cash has been collected in the Block-Aid campaign and the sixth week is expected to result in a sale of $80,000 in stamps, it was announced yesterday by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization. The money raised by Block-Aid is being expended as wages for emergency work for the unemployed.

Alfred E. Smith voiced hearty approval yesterday of the proposal made in the Senate by Senator Robinson, Mr. Smith's running mate on the Democratic national ticket four years ago, for a $2,000,000,000 Federal public works program and a $300,000,000 appropriation for loans to States and municipalities for unemployment relief.

J. Gilbert Hall Of South Orange, N.J., and David N. Jones of Columbia University reached the semi-final round of the North Side champion-ship yesterday on the clay courts of the University Heights Tennis Club on Harlem River Terrace.

The smallest crop of Winter wheat with one exception since the war is forecast in the May report of the Department of Agriculture. The estimate is 441,000,000 bushels, compared with 787,000,000 last year. This is a reduction of 44 per cent in the bumper crop dumped into the market in 1931, to the consternation of the Farm Board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP). -- Young Steve Hamas whipped Tommy Loughran again tonight, this time by an unpopular ten-round decision, but the Philadelphia heavyweight fought a smart and courageous battle.

LONDON, May 11 (AP). -- Twelve American women, who crossed the Atlantic to be introduced to Britain's King and Queen, participated in a free show outside Buckingham Palace tonight for which much of London was the audience.

A recorded total of 4,179,324 persons visited the central building of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street during 1931, an increase of more than 3 1/2 per cent over 1930, according to the annual report of the library issued yesterday.

VIENNA, May 11. -- Britain wishes the Danubian States to meet their desperate financial situation by going off the gold standard -- even at the cost of lowering the par value of their currencies and seeking reductions of their foreign debts -- but not by repudiating any part of their foreign debts, while France wants them to stay on the gold standard, according to an article in the Reichspost, government organ.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Gaston B. Means, under indictments charging embezzlement of $104,000 from Mrs. Edward B. McLean and under suspicion in connection with allegations that he mulcted as much from another Society woman by promising anti-Communist protection, was free tonight on $50,000 bail.

ST. LOUIS, May 11. -- in the twelfth inning of the final game of the series between the Robins and Cardinals today Lefty Hallahan gave a graphic demonstration of why he is called Wild Bill, and the Flatbush team won the game, 6 to 3.

PARIS, May 11. -- With the elections over and a new President chosen, France seems today to have cast aside every thought but to prepare with heart and soul fittingly to honor in death the man who less than, a week ago was her President, Paul Doumer.

Members of the St. Paul's (Rikkio) University baseball squad of Tokyo, Japan, now visiting this country, were guests of honor last night at a dinner given by the Sportsmanship Brotherhood at the Town Hall Club. Among the 150 present were several prominent figures of the sport world.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 11. -- Fourteen players went to bat in the fourth today as Andover scored 10 runs against the Kirkland House team of Harvard. The academy nine owon the game by 23 to 4.

Open-market discounts on bankers' bills were reduced one-quarter of 1 per cent yesterday, restoring rates to the levels prevailing prior to last Thursday's advance. The cut was accompanied by other evidence of increasing ease in the short-term money market.

After listening to testimony for two and one half weeks on the renewal of the licenses of the burlesque shows at the Eltinge and Republic Theatres on "West Forty-second Street, James F. Geraghty, License Commissioner, closed the public hearings yesterday when counsel for the theatres and for the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association both rested their cases.

LIMA, Peru, May 11. -- Peru will begin diplomatic conversations with other South American Republics with-in the next few days in an effort to arrange a conference of South American Governments to study the best means for united action against Communists and the expulsion of professional agitators from the entire continent.

BASLE, May 11. -- Summarizing the findings of the stockholders of the Bank for International Settlements in their annual meeting just closed, Grates W. McGarrah, president of the bank, in a radio address broad-cast from his office here tonight, urged the American public to recognize the international character of the world depression.

CINCINNATI, May 11 (AP). -- Lombardi, Herman and Hafey of the Reds starred on the attack again today, aiding Red Lucas, who allowed only five hits, in scoring a 4-to-1 victory over the Phillies. The victors supplanted the losers in third place.

LONDON, May 11. -- The speech made last night to the Bankers' Association by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, had a favorable effect on the Stock Exchange today, particularly on British funds, which soared further on transactions that were on a scale even larger than that of yesterday.
ROME, May 11. -- Giuseppe De Luca, baritone at the Metropolitan Opera House, interviewed aboard the Saturnia, bound for Trieste, concerning opera prospects in New York, said:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 11. -- Pounding the ball to all corners of the field for many extra-base blows, the Lehigh nine defeated the University of Delaware today, 15 to 3. A light rain began to fall in the third inning and continued throughout the game.

TULSA, Okla., May 11 (AP). -- Oil companies operating in the Midcontinent area are making a profit, some of them for the first time in a year, reports to The Associated Press showed today Only major companies that have no headquarters here or whose spokesmen could not be reached are missing from the list of those that once more are making money, according to the survey.

Samuel Seabury attempted yesterday to delve into the manner in which Gerhard M. Dahl won the friendship of the City Administration for the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company but was blocked by a ruling of Senator Samuel Hofstadter, chairman of the legislative investigating committee.

The New York Central Railroad ended a record maintained since 1870 by omitting yesterday the dividend on its stock due at this time. This action was foreshadowed in December when the management deferred action on the dividend in order to determine whether it would be justified by economic events.
A RECENT article in The London Sunday Observer on Olympic track and field prospects might easily serve, in some respects, as a partial answer to the prayer of Bobby Burns:

READING, Pa., May 11 (AP), -- Governor Pinchot today urged organized labor to speak and act for itself and not look to the "benevolence of industrial leaders for whatever benefits it hopes to achieve."

The control that Ivar Kreuger exercised over his network of international corporations was never scrutinized, according to his American bankers, who added this admission yesterday to their previous testimony that they had never checked up his assets.
