Up to ten hours before the Bank of United States was closed on the morning of Dec. 10, 1930, Joseph A. Broderiek," State Superintendent of Banks, had every reason to believe that the large banks of the city would come to the rescue of the institution, stitution, he testified yesterday at his trial before Judge George L. Donnelian and a jury in General Sessions.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The Boerse again demonstrated extraordinary strength today in the face of bear raids and the nervousness of professional speculation. Prices, which at first were pressed down about 2 per cent by the bears and realizing sales, recovered rapidly within the first hour.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11. -- A revision of the church discipline which would permit ministers to remarry the innocent party in a divorce granted on grounds of "adultery or other conditions which through mental torture or physical peril invalidated the marriage vow" was recommended to the thirty-first quadrennial-General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here today.

Ken Auer, Fordham's speedball expert, was in excellent form yesterday at Baker Field, and the Maroon subdued Columbia, 3 to 1. It was the second victory of the season over the Blue and White for Fordham, the Maroon having downed the Morningside nine in an early season encounter.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- With a proposal to the Senate that the government issue bonds amounting to $2,300,000,000 to finance a two-fold plan for aiding States and municipalities in coping with the problem of unemployment, Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, today unreservedly entered the fight for Federal unemployment relief.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Wheat traders were surprised again today by the government estimate on Winter wheat. It was construed as bullish, but the market made a relatively poor response. While as much as 1 8/4 cents higher at one time, prices finished at net gains of 5/8 to 7/8 cent.

A large and impressive exhibition of paintings by Power O'Malley has opened at the Montrose Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue, where it will remain until May 21. The forty canvases fill three rooms and there are etchings in the entrance corridor. Seldom is an artist's work presented on a scale so generous.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- President Hoover returned the Democratic tariff bill to Congress today with a veto message citing four major objections.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 11 (Canadian Press). -- Of the 518,400 acres sown to Fall wheat in Canada last November, 4 per cent, or 21,900 acres, was Winter killed, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- A general strike of 30,000 New York cloakmakers on the expiration of existing agreements on June 1 was voted here today by the convention of the International Ladies' Garment Association. Endorsement was given also to strikes in the Cleveland cloak and dress industry and the Philadelphia waist and dress industry and to a strike of alteration tailors in Fifth Avenue shops in New York.

With the renomination of President Hoover, a dry, regarded as certain, the New York County Republican organization at the meeting of its county committee this evening will join in the widespread demand of Republican organizations, in the East for the inclusion of a wet plank in the Republican national platform.

NEW ORLEANS, May 11 (AP). -- New vaccines for possible protection against chronic rheumatism and yellow fever, and a seeming complete cure for hemophilia, sometimes called the "curse of royalty," were reported to the American Medical Association today.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Tentative arrangements were completed late today for starting debate in the Senate tomorrow on the billion-dollar tax bill when Senator Smoot, chairman, filed the Finance Committee's formal report on the bill, recommending its revenue proposals as the most equitable and practical solution of the Treasury's financial problem.

LONDON, Ky., May 12. -- Federal Judge A.M.J. Cochran, before whom delegates of the American Civil Liberties Union argued today for an injunction safeguarding their entry into Harlan and Bell Counties, announced tonight that he would go with them into the mine zone.

Not for the world would we have the carping disposition of Repretative WOODRUM of Virginia. He took the trouble to have photostatic copies made of two speeches supposed to have been uttered in the House on April 8 by our own Mr. LA GUARDIA and Mr. BUCHANAN of Texas and in "extended" form printed in the Congressional Record of May 4 and May 5.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 12. -- Professor Leroy Waterman, director of University of Michigan-Cleveland Museum archaeological excavations in Mesopotamia, announced today discovery of what is believed to be the ziggurat or "Tower of Babel" in the ancient city of Akshak.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., May 12 (AP). -- The police reported today that they had discovered evidence of an elaborate anti-government plot in a series of raids on headquarters of the "New Guard," a Fascist organization formed more than a year ago which now claims 100,000 members.
J.A. Sisto, a partner in J.A. Sisto Co., a Stock Exchange firm of 68 Wall Street, refused to waive immunity, but testified as follows yesterday before the Hofstadter committee:

In the terse official phraseology of the Police Department, the police heroes of 1931 received their accolades of honor yesterday when Commissioner Mulrooney made public the names of twenty men, nine of whom are dead, who were singled out by the Honor Board for conspicuous acts of bravery.

TORONTO, May 12 (AP). -- Playing their first baseball in a week owing to rain and cold weather, the Toronto Leafs split today's doubleheader with Jersey City. They lost the first game, 7 -- 3, and won the second, a seven-inning affair, 4 -- 1.

That the usual mid-May renting of houses for Summer occupancy in the outlying sections of the metropolitan area remains undiminished this year is indicated by announcements made by brokers yesterday. Many Long Island and Westchester dwellings have been taken.
Numerous dwelling deals were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 12. -- Washington and Lee University's baseball team defeated Cornell, 7 to 3, today. The Generals scored four runs in the first inning and were never headed, with Jarrett pitching in good form.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 12. -- Gathered at the north end of the old Yale campus today, sixty members of the Yale junior class were honored with election to four senior societies, regarded as the highest social recognition obtainable at Yale. Many of those selected were athletes, while others had earned recognition as scholars in the college.

TOKYO, May 12 (AP). -- Japanese military officials reported today that 250 Chinese irregulars were killed in two battles between the Chinese forces and the Japanese Chientao expedition near Yenki yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Farmers in the South and Northwest have received the bulk of the 1932 crop production loans made by the Department of Agriculture. The total for all States on May 7 was $61,579,621. Of this amount $29,794,556 went to ten Southern States and $25,089,970 to ten in the Northwest.

BELGRADE, May 12. -- Mischa Milosevitch, editor of the official news agency, Avala, which circulates official versions of events in Yugoslavia was arrested tonight at his office. His arrest apparently is connected with that of Dr. Dragojub Jovanovitch, Belgrade professor, which was not known until today because of the censorship although it occurred a week ago.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12. -- Many luncheon parties were given in the colony today.

By unanimous vote the Republican County Committee at its bimonthly meeting held last night at Palm Garden, Fifty-second Street near Eighth Avenue, adopted a resolution calling upon the Republican National Convention to include a plank pledging repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment in its platform.

MAX SCHMELING and Jack Sharkey have gone into training. Ernie Schaaf has moved into town to do a little fighting. The only important discussion going on about this Schaaf-Gross bout at the Garden this evening is whether or not Schaaf will wear his white sailor hat into the ring with him.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Senator Glass in the Senate this afternoon denounced Senator Kean for saying yesterday that Dr. H. Parker Willis, Glass banking bill technician, had used confidential Treasury information in dispatche to Paris newspapers which had resulted in heavy gold withdrawals from the United States.

The belief of engineering experts that the city's new Eighth Avenue subway cannot be counted on to earn operating expenses until the Brooklyn and Queens branches of the line are opened was expressed yesterday at the first hearing before the Board of Transportation on the revised form of contract for operation of the line.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 12 (AP). -- Rochester shut out the Newark Bears, 4 to 0, today behind the effective pitching of Del Wetherell, young righthander. Wetherell allowed only five hits. Jim Weaver and Milburn Shaffner granted Rochester only six between them.

Miss Muriel Guggoiz of the Salle d'Armes Vince advanced a step closer to a place on the United States women's Olympic fencing team by capturing first place in the second trial round, held at the Fencers Club last night.

Gold amounting to $9,002,700 was skipped yesterday to Europe, $6,000,000 going to Switzerland and $3,002,700 to Holland. A has been the case with most recent exports, part of the gold came out of earmarking and so represented no new loss to the gold stocks of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12. -- In the Lindbergh kidnapping and its tragic conclusion the nation stands face to face, with the most terrific challenge that ever confronted a civilized country, speakers before the opening session of the National Probation Association in the Bellevue-Stratford here tonight agreed.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12. -- Lou T. Reichers of Arlington, N.J., 31-year-old speed flier, took off at 11:05 tonight from the municipal airport here on a two-stop solo flight to Paris, hoping to cover the 3,500 miles in seventeen hours, thus cutting by half the time taken by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh for the same distance in 1927.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Governor Roosevelt of New York was reported at the Capitol today to have written a letter to Representative Collins of Mississippi, chairman of the subcommittee which drafted the War Department appropriation bill, expressing his appreciation of the fact that the committee, in proposing the elimination of 2,000 officers and the suspension of citizens' military training camps and Reserve Officers' camps, did not reduce National Guard activities.

Liquidation of the property at 871-9 West End Avenue, a fifteen-story apartment house at the southwest corner of 103d Street, yesterday resulted in the sale of the property at auction to the 103d and West End Avenue, Inc., representing the bondholders.

PRAGUE, May 12. -- An implied reproach that a typical Central European government would rather let its citizens starve than be fed from the bounty of a hostile neighboring country is contained in a protest addressed yesterday by the Hungarian Legation to the Foreign Office here against the holding up by frontier officials of a shipment of potatoes sent by the Greek Catholic Bishop of Miskolcz, Hungary, to feed starving Ruthenians.

Dr. J.F. Condon, the Bronx lecturer who acted as intermediary in the futile payment by Colonel Lindbergh of $50,000 ransom for his son, and John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boat builder, who also has been conducting negotiations, arrived at Hopewell for questioning by the police early this morning.

United States Government bonds broke sharply on the Stock Exchange yesterday on the announcement on the financial tickers that President Hoover was in favor of the Senate plan for relief loans to States and municipalities and for a bond issue to stimulate employment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12. -- A petition to devote a section of the Methodist hymnal to prohibition, including such songs as "Rescue the Perishing," for use at prohibition meetings, is before the commission on revision of the hymnal, according to an announcement made here today by Dr. Clarence True Wilson at the Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The drive to get before the Senate the Goldsborough bill, directing the Federal Reserve Board to use its control over credit and currency to bring commodity prices back to the 1926 level, was started today at hearings before the Bank and Currency Committee.

In a letter to Representative Rainey, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, F.J. Lieman calls attention to a clause in the debt-funding agreement between the United States and France under which our government reserved the right to call upon France to provide, in exchange for the bonds of the French Government now held by the United States Treasury, other bonds of a character suitable for sale to the public.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 12 (AP). -- William Penn Cresson, diplomat, architect, college lecturer and author, died today at Chesterwood, his home here, after a prolonged illness.

The importance of self-regulation in the processes of mutual life insurance was stressed yesterday by Henry H. Jackson, actuary of the National Life Insurance Company of Montpelier, Vt., at the annual meeting of the Actuarial Society of America held in the Waldorf-Astoria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tax bill as elaborated by the Senate Finance Committee represents a praiseworthy endeavor to deal with an admittedly difficult subject. There is, however, one item which was at the last moment slipped into the bill and which I feel convinced does not represent the well-considered judgment of the committee.

Dr. Thomas Darlington, scion of an old American family and a descendant of the English Earls of Darlington, was installed last night as Grand Sachem of the Tammany Society at a meeting in Tammany Hall.

BOSTON, May 12. -- When the new William Beebe oceanographic expedition sets sail for Bermuda at the end of this month, two of its members doubtless will feel as much triumph in its departure as Wellington must have felt after Waterloo.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A government loan to the Pennsylvania Railroad with which to go forward with its program for electrification of its New York-Washington lines was virtually assured today with the filing of an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission, in which the road reduced by half the $55,000,000 loan it had originally requested.

Report Market Conditions Soft. The wind-up of the Spring season in the wholesale markets leaves little basis for firming up in prices for the Fall period, buying executives here said yesterday. One of them said he found wholesale market conditions the "softest" in his career as head of a large buying organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 12. -- Elmer Lindquist, rangy Georgetown lefthander, pitched an excellent game today to hand Harvard its first defeat of the season on the home field, the score being 8 to 2. Limiting the Crimson batsmen to seven hits and registering eleven strike-outs, he held the upper hand throughout.

NEW ORLEANS, May 12. -- The United States will begin play tomorrow in the second round of the North American Davis Cup tennis zone with Wilmer Allison meeting Ricardo Tapia, Mexico's No. 1 star, in the first of the singles matches.

Hundred of thousands of men and women milled about on west side and east side subway platforms from 4:50 to 6:40 P.M. yesterday after a twelve-inch water main burst in Varick Street near the southern end of the Houston Street station of the Seventh Avenue line and flooded all northbound and southbound tracks with six inches of water.

The Union Pacific Railroad, which had maintained dividends at the rate of S10 annually so far in the depression, reduced the rate yesterday to a nominal basis of $6 by declaring a payment of S1.50. However, yesterday's distribution was not designated as a quarterly dividend.

The use of experienced employes of the Park Department as special policemen will be tried out in Central Park this Summer in an effort to prevent vandalism and enforce observance of park rules, Walter R. Herrick, Park Commissioner of Manhattan, told members of the new advisory board of the Park Association of New York City at its first meeting yesterday, at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

The annual garden party of the International Garden Club took place yesterday afternoon at the estate of the Bartow Mansion, Pelham Bay Park. It had been arranged to hold the party in the gardens, but because of the weather, most of the entertainment was transferred to the clubhouse.

LONDON, May 12. -- The Bank of England gave further proof of its cheap-money policy today by reducing the Bank rate from 3 to 2 1/2 per cent. This was the fifth reduction in three months until now the rate is as low as at any time since the World War.

Preliminary steps in the formation of a more extensive city economy program were taken by Mayor Walker yesterday when he conferred with representatives of real estate organizations and at the same time called a general meeting of city department heads for next Wednesday to discuss retrenchments and possible new sources of city revenue.

The traditional questionnaire of the senior class at Columbia College reveals that the 450 who are to be graduated this year will advance upon the world in an average height of 5 feet 10 1/2 inches, weight 154 pounds, and age 21 years 4 months, with an average expectation of salary after five years of $11,352.
CINCINNATl, May l2. -- The Robins beat the Reds, 5 to 2, today and displaced the idle Giants in sixth place in the standings.

CAMP KEARNEY, Cal., May 12 (AP). -- Hampered by the loss of helium gas, the navy dirigible Akron sailed northward along the California coast tonight on the last stage of an interrupted flight to her base at Sunnyvale, Cal., near San Francisco.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 12 Returning from a wide tour of ten farm States in the mid-West and South, Henry Morgenthau Jr., New York Conservation Commissioner, told Governor Roosevelt today that his swing had revealed a strong feeling of revolt against the leadership of President Hoover.

Slockholders of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company will vote on May 23 on a reduction of the par value of its common and Class B common shares from $50 to $5. They will be asked also to approve the distribution among themselves, upon authorization by the directors, of the shares of the Pan-American Foreign Corporation, recently formed in Delaware to acquire all foreign properties of Fan-American Petroleum and Transport.
The Metropolitan Opera Association will present next season a new American opera, "Emperor Jones," based on Eugene O'Neill's play, by the American composer Louis Grueuberg, it became known yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 12 (AP). -- Joseph A. McGinnies, Speaker of the Assembly, veteran legislator and candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, tonight picked up and tossed in the direction of Governor Roosevelt the words of criticism recently used against him by his opponent for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Alfred E. Smith.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Department store sales showed a considerably larger increase in April than usual, the Federal Reserve Board announces.

Dictatora Under the Skin. There seems to be no doubt that the assassin of President DOUMER was a "White" Russian -- that is to say, an anti-Communist. This is not inconsistent with his having been earlier, as investigation tends to show, tied up with his countrymen of the Red and the Green faith, the latter movement having for its aim the establishment of a Peasant International.

The Cunard Line reached an agreement yesterday with the United States Shipping Board and the city of Hoboken whereby its liners Berengaria and Aquitania will be berthed at Pier 4, Hoboken, until a new pier is built to replace Pier 54, North River, which was destroyed by fire last Friday.

The total of bank clearings reported from leading centres throughout the country continues to compare unfavorably with last year. The total for the week ended on Wednesday night amounts to $4,552,857,000. a drop of 42.5 per cent from last year.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 12. -- Holy Cross defeated the Colgate baseball team today, 5 to 3. Howard LaFlamme, pitching for Colgate, gave only four scattered hits, but his mates' misplays were costly.

Two additional damage suits were added yesterday to the legal battle involving the Pepsi-Cola Company and the Coca Cola Company, manufacturers of competing soft drinks. Yesterday The Mirror, owner of candy stores, filed two suits against the Coca Cola Company asking $1,250,000 damages and charging interference with The Mirror's contract to sell Pepsi-Cola exclusively.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 13. -- Japan's army is progressing down the Sungari River with every available craft, from modern gunboats to ancient sailing junks, according to dispatches received from Harbin. They tell of feverish military activity. The bulk of the Fourteenth Division, which was sent from Shanghai to the Manchurian front last week, arrived at Harbin yesterday [Thursday], and more troops are expected.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Documents representing that former Postmaster General New in 1926 aided in rescuing from financial difficulties an unsuccessful bidder for a postal lease, who later withdrew charges that the contract was illegally awarded, were presented today to a Senate committee.
JAMESTOWN ISLAND, Va., May 12 (AP). -- Virginia will observe the 325th anniversary of the landing of the Cavaliers on this island tomorrow.

There is something absolutely new in sculpture at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue, where "Mobiles," by Alexander Calder, were placed on view yesterday. They will remain there until June 11.

PITTSBURGH, May 12. -- James J. McKee, prominent in local, State and national labor movements, and secretary-treasurer of the journeymen plumbers' local union of Pittsburgh, died yesterday at his home in Ingram.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The minority report of Senators Harrison, George, Walsh of Massachusetts, Costigan and Hull, dissenting from the inclusion of tariff duties in the revenue bill, was as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Present difficult conditions have fallen not least harshly upon those members of our business community who deal in works of art.

A public auction that sounded like the stage representation of a frameup was held yesterday afternoon at the United States Barge Office at South Ferry when Deputy Surveyor John H. McGill of the Customs Enforcement Bureau auctioned off 30,000 pounds of fresh fish to the Ship-news Reporters Association of New York.

Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist; Paul Kochensky, American violinist; Mme. Paul Claudel, wife of the French Ambassador to the United States, and Edward Filene, Boston merchant, will be among the passengers sailing tonight on the French liner Paris, for Plymouth and Havre. Others to sail include:

Members of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration, formed by a consolidation of the Home Relief Bureau and the Emergency Work Commission, who will assume their tasks on June 1, were notified of their appointments yesterday by Mayor Walker.

Mayor Walker's "Beer for Taxation" parade will start promptly at 11 A.M. tomorrow from Seventyninth Street and Fifth Avenue and will be led by the Mayor and his citizens' committee south to Fiftyninth Street, west to Central Park West and north, to Seventy-fifth Street and Central Park West, where it will disband.
Stunned, the people of New York received the tragic news of the finding of the body of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. as it was flashed throughout the world early last evening.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals, pounding four Philadelphia pitchers for a total of ten hits, scored in all except two innings today to take the series opener from the Phillies, 8 to 2.

BERLIN, May 12, -- General Wilhelm Groener, who with President von Hindenburg and Chancellor Bruening has composed the triumvirate that for the past year has been conducting German affairs of state, chiefly with the aid of emergency decrees, resigned today from his post as Minister of Defense, which he had held since January, 1928.

On the fiftieth story of the Chanin Building a miniature theatre is tucked away. In the miniature theatre a miniature play, "Lenin's Dowry," was tucked away last evening. David Vardi wrote it; David Vardi staged it; David Vardi and his wife, Eva Yoalit, acted the only two parts the play contains.

The great New York City banks, almost without exception, have continued to make good commercial loans as a matter of course, and they took care of customers for all kinds of credit requirements in an adequate way throughout the stringency of last Fall and Winter, according to Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The presence of the Secretary of the Treasury before committees of Congress has the effect of inviting attention to the fundamental law organizing his office, which contemplates his appearance on the floor before the full membership.

The international oil conference will begin formal discussions next week, probably on Monday, according to C.E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, chief sponsor of the meeting. After the arrival of the Soviet representatives, more than a week ago, preliminary sessions were carried on with them.

DAIREN, Manchuria, April 16. -- Manchuria, or Manchoukuo, as it is now called with studious care by most of the Japanese residing here, is facing a period of intensive railway development by the South Manchuria Railway Company. Before snow flies again across the limitless Manchurian plains work will be going forward on important branches and extensions involving a total of 635 miles of new construction work.

LONDON, May 12. -- The season's second court tonight was marked by the presentation of nine Americans, seven of whom were introduced by the acting doyenne of the diplomatic corps, Senhora de Oliveira, wife of the Brazilian Ambassador. There were three New Yorkers.

The combined Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships and preliminary Olympic tryouts will be held at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday, June 11, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Sy Hedberg following a meeting of the local track and field committee.

Everybody knew that the President would refuse to sign the halting and makeshift Democratic tariff bill. Its very authors expected, and perhaps desired, the veto which they got. But in addition they got what in effect, will undoubtedly be the Republican platform on the tariff, along with a virtual appeal to the country in advance by the President.

Brokers' loans as compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declined $61,000,000, or more than 12 per cent, in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $438,000,000, according to the weekly report issued yesterday. At this figure the loans reached a low record since compilation of the data began in 1917.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 12. -- Lieutenant Brookner W. Brady moved into first place today in the competition for places on the United States Olympic modern pentathlon team. Lieutenant Brady forged ahead of Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands, who was leading after the fencing and riding tests, by scoring 192 for second place on the Military Academy pistol range this morning.
The baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh was found dead yesterday afternoon. The child had been murdered.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 12 (AP). -- The success of the stable of Edward Haughton, which has been one of the features of the current Kentucky season, was continued today when Brass Monkey accounted for the Shawnee Park Purse, a mile and a sixteenth claiming event which featured the program at Churchill Downs.

The broad panorama of American business is unrolled by sixteen economists who have collaborated in writing a two-volume work, "The Economic Foundation of Business," published today by Ray Long and Richard R. Smith.

The day is past, said Owen D. Young last night, in presenting the gold medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences to Gerard Swope, when the head of a large corporation is solely concerned in making as much money as possible for the stockholders at the expense of the workers and the public.

When the Legislature met last January it was clear to everybody that it would have to retrench. Dwindling revenues made economy mandatory; the only question was how deep the cuts should be. Governor ROOSEVELT recommended a budget of $37,000,000 under the previous year's total.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Senator Reed of Pennsylvania, mentioned as President Hoover's choice for chairman of the resolutions committee at the Republican National Convention, came out today in favor of the licensed sale of liquor "in government-owned or government-controlled dispensaries" as a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Advocates of a bill amending the railway labor act to provide for the settlement of disputes between aviators and airline operators by the Railway Board of Mediation, testified today before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Five Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee opened a fight on the tariff features of the billion-dollar tax bill today in a minority report demanding elimination of the duties on coal, oil, copper and lumber and condemning the "log-rolling" by which, they said, the items were inserted.

Mount Rose, near which the body of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's son was found, is a hamlet of about a dozen houses and a general store on the road connecting Princeton with Hopewell and about a mile and a half from the latter. During part of the time that his Sourland Mountain home was under construction Colonel Lindbergh lived in a house in the hamlet.

Hundreds of persons, mostly children, have been the victims of kidnapper-murderers in this country and elsewhere in the last few years. In many cases they have been spirited away, never to be heard from again, like Charlie Ross, who was kidnapped in 1874; Raimonde von Maluski, abducted in 1925, and Grace Budd, who trustingly went to a "birthday party" on June 3, 1928.

NEW ORLEANS, May 12. -- Dr. Morris Fishbein of Chicago asserted today at a joint meeting of the section on the practice of medicine and the section on preventive medicine and public health of the American Medical Association that "the general practitioner must become increasingly a practitioner of preventive medicine, and people must learn that preventive medicine is, like curative medicine, to be paid for, particularly because it is always worth more than it costs."
Medals and cups to the winners of the twentieth annual Wanamaker Drawing Competition for school children of Greater New York will be awarded tomorrow morning in the Wanamaker Auditorium.

After a heated discussion last night a resolution putting, the Rabbinical Assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America on record as condemning "misfeasance in government" and urging the delegates to join forces in fighting graft in civic life was withdrawn.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP). -- Earl Webb's temporary loss of vision on Dick Porter's drive to right field with two out in the ninth inning today gave the Cleveland Indians a 5-to-4 victory over the Red Sox.

AURORA, Ill., May 12 (AP). -- Dollar Princess, chestnut filly owned by Miss L. Hoffman of New Orleans, came within a second of the Exposition Park track record for six furlongs today in winning the feature event of the program.

DUBLIN, May 12. -- The first budget of Eamon de Valera's Government has caused something akin to consternation in Free State business circles. Throughout the election campaign three months ago the Fianna Fail spokesmen promised, if returned to power, to reduce taxation immediately, whereas taxation of every kind, direct and indirect, is increased enormously.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The George Washington Masonic Memorial Temple on Shooter's Hill, Alexandria, overlooking the Potomac, was dedicated with imposing ceremonie's this afternoon. The auditorium was crowded to capacity, the audience including President and Mrs. Hoover, members of the Cabinet and of Congress and prominent Masons from all parts of the United States and foreign countries.

Governor Moore of New jersey yesterday issued an order to H.J. Burlington, president of the State's Board of Fish and Game Commissioners, following a conference, to continue stocking the State streams.

Widespread sympathy for the bereaved parents and relatives of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. and the American people was expressed in messages that poured into the Lindbergh home at Hopewell, N.J., last night from various parts of the world.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Stanley of Alderley have gone to Montreal after a stay at the Barclay.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Gaston B. Means was arrested again today, this time charged with drunkenness and disorderly conduct following an altercation with a newspaper man in a drug store.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week end May 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,895,000,000, an increase of $53,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $962,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- President Hoover today asked Senators Robinson of Arkansas and Watson, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate, to propose to their colleagues a three-point Federal relief program to stimulate private business in reproductive enterprises, to advance money for self-liquidating projects in States and municipalities, to ameliorate agricultural distress and to loan to States -- but not municipalities -- money for the relief of unemployed citizens.
NORFOLK, Va., May 12. -- Captain F.H. Lackmann, skipper of the Consolvo yatch Marcon, said tonight he was deeply shocked at the news that the Lindbergh baby had been found dead near Hopewell, N.J.
LONDON, May 6 (A.P. by Mail). -- Fresh fear is felt that St. Paul's Cathedral, designed by Christopher Wren in the seventeenth century to last forever, may tumble down some day.

Chancellor BRUENING'S statement about reparations is of a kind to bring comfort to the Nationalist elements in France. Among them it is the standing contention that between democratic and conciliatory Germany and aggressive and defiant Hitlerite Germany there is really very little to choose.

Mrs. May Klinge of 714 West 181st Street, widow of a clerk in District Attorney Crain's office, was called as a corroborating witness yesterday by Robert V. Santangelo, Assistant District Attorney, in the General Sessions trial of Frank I. O'Neill, suspended attendant in the same court, on a charge O'Neill defrauded Mrs. Bertha Ewald, wife of former Magistrate George F. Ewald, of $3,000 in June, 1930.

Application was made yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange for the listing of certificates of deposit issued by the Chase National Bank of the City of New York for 1,350,000 shares of participating preference stock of the International Match Corporation.

MONTREAL, May 12 (AP). -- The Royals extended their winning streak to thirteen straight when they took the second game of the series from Baltimore today, 6 -- 2. A crowd of 5,000 roared its approval as Royals rallied for six runs in the eighth after trailing the Orioles from the second.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP). -- Dutch Brandt baffled the Chicago Cubs today, allowing only five hits, and the Boston Braves won the opening game of the series, 8 to 3.

Net incomes of railroads after taxes and charges for March or the March quarter or both showed general declines in statements issued yesterday. The Lackawanna, Milwaukee and some New York Central subsidiaries were among those to report. The statements follow:

His long story of his efforts to save the Bank of United States completed, the cross-examination of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, was begun yesterday by Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, in General Sessions where Mr. Broderick is on trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company End subsidiairies report for the three months ended on March 31 a net profit of $527,602 after interest, taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization, minority interests and other charges, equal to 72 cents a share on 732,724,000 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The authority granted by the Glass-Steagall bill for the use of government securities as a backing for Federal Reserve notes in the place of "eligible paper" was employed for the first time by the Reserve Banks in the week ended yesterday, May 11, when $97,300,000 in United States obligations was so pledged with the Reserve agents.

LIMA, May 12. -- The leading republics of Latin America have begun diplomatic negotiations looking toward the formation of a Latin-American customs union for united defense and concerted reprisals against the United States tariff policy, according to Foreign Minister Alberto Freundt Resell today.
HOPEWELL, N.J., May 12 (AP). -- William Allen, 46-year-old Negro, gave the following account tonight of how he discovered the body of the Lindbergh child:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 12. -- More than 1,000 women, representing twelve New Jersey women's clubs, met at Princeton University here today for their fourth annual conference on the causes and cure of war. The delegates adopted a resolution protesting the action of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday in deferring until today a vote to report a bill for ratification of the World Court protocol for consideration next session.

Money market was listless. Business was small and quotations unchanged for all classes of accommodation. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, street trades went at 1 1/2, and Federals were done at 1/8. Time money was 1 1/2 per cent for all dates.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Removal of the Federal restrictions on dissemination of birth control information was urged today before a Senate judiciary subcommittee by Senator Hatfield and a group headed by Margaret Sanger and including leaders in religion, sociology, surgery and medicine.

Protests against excessive realty assessments should be made now to deputy tax commissioners preparing valuations for next year, Paul H. Fairchild, president of the Twenty-third Street Association, advises. Sales and transfer tax valuations show that property is about 30 per cent overassessed, he declares.

Ernie Schaaf, once of Elizabeth, N.J., but now of Boston, will oppose Jack Gross, Philadelphia southpaw, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Schaaf has gained a high, place in the heavyweight division during the past two years, having lost only to Tommy Loughran in his last twenty-five bouts.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Legislation to place a strict curb on the operations of stock exchanges was introduced today as the Senate Banking Committee prepared to go ahead with its investigation of the New York market.

Equipoise, the famous son of Pennant and Swinging, yesterday continued his come-back to racing by a decisive victory in the $5,000 added Toboggan Handicap, the old sprinting test of six furlongs, which featured the opening-day program, at Belmont Park.

BERLIN, May 12 (AP). -- General Groener, who resigned from the post of Minister of Defense today, has been a marked man, as far as the Nazis were concerned, ever since he dissolved Adolf Hitler's storm troops.

With daily expenditures far exceeding receipts, the Federal deficit has passed the $2,500,000,000 mark. It will be somewhere between this figure and $3,000,000,000 when the current fiscal year ends on June 30 the largest peace-time deficit in the country's history.

The listed bond markets weakened perceptibly yesterday in the final hour of trading. United States Government bonds off sharply, a long list of domestic corporation bonds down a point or more, and foreign loans irregularly lower. Railroad bonds, in sympathy with carrier stocks, were weaker, and industrial and public utility bonds were easier, as groups, in the order named.

Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr. was born on June 22, 1930, his mother's twenty-fourth birthday, at the home of his grandfather, the late Senator Dwight W. Morrow, in Englewood, N.J. From the moment of his birth the world was intensely interested in his career.

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- Governor Albert C. Ritchie was Offered to the Democratic party as the most available candidate for the Presidency at the State convention of the party here today. He was portrayed by Richard F. Cleveland, son of President Grover Cleveland, as "the leader needed to guide the nation out of the morass of Republican maladministration," and convention delegrates at the Maryland Theatre roared applause.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 12. -- Mrs. L.C. Dubois of Wee Burn led the field in the one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Woodway Country Club today, turning in the low gross of 85 to win the first prize.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Foreign powers must accept the original Fifth Reservation of the United States if this country joins the World Court, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today by a vote of 11 to 9, at the same time ordering the resolution of adherence reported to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Senator Huey Long of Louisiana was called to order and forced to take his seat in the Senate this afternoon after he had violently assailed Senator Robinsin, the Democratic leader.

NORFOLK, Va., May 12 (AP). -- With their associate, John Hughes Curtis, absent, the two other Norfolk intermediaries refrained from comment on news that the child's body had been found near the Lindbergh home in New Jersey.

Four high school girls and four high school boys will compete at Town Hall tonight for the 1932 regional championship of the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution. The winner will receive $1,000 and a trip to Europe this Summer, awarded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, which has been conducting the contest since Feb. 1, for the seventh year in New York City, Long Island, Westchester and Putnam Counties and in Northern New Jersey.
LONDON, May 12 (Canadian Press). -- The touring All-India team defeated Blackheath in a cricket fixture today by 61 runs. All-India scored 149 and Blackheath 88 (Nisar, six wickets for 11 runs).
LONDON, May 12 (Canadian Press). -- The touring All-India team defeated Blackheath in a cricket fixture today by 61 runs. All-India scored 149 and Blackheath 88 (Nisar, six wickets for 11 runs).

Tuesday night, March 1, between 11 o'clock and midnight, a nation preparing for slumber heard to its consternation that the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh and Anne Morrow Lindbergh had been kidnapped.

Under the auspices of the Committee of Art in Service of Universal Understanding, the first presentation of G. Aldo Randegger's "Via Pacis," a peace music-drama, with libretto by Henrietta B. Randegger, was given last night in the Town Hall. It was performed in concert and reading form, the composer playing a piano transcription of the orchestral score.

LONDON, May 12. -- The stock market anticipated today's reduction in the rate of the Bank of England to 2 per cent. Prices were easier on profit-taking, but the reduction sent quotation higher again. The markets generally were firmer in the afternoon being pleased with the returns for April, particularly the increase in exports.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Cottonseed, crushed in the nine-month period Aug. 1 to April 30, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 4,926,878 tons, compared with 4,564,322 tons for the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills April 30 was 522,795 tons, compared with 97,374 tons a year ago.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 12 (AP). -- Mrs. T.H. Somerville's Tereus was an easy winner of the Billy Barton Steeplechase, three-mile gallop for hunters ridden by gentlemen riders that featured the Pimlico program today. August F. Goodwin's Bandit was second and Mrs. Frank M. Gold's Kirn was third.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- William A. Gray, counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, informed Chairman Norbeck today that he would be ready to resume public hearings next Thursday in the committee's stock market investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Russia is working witht "feverish acitvity" to condition the Transsiberian railroad as support for troop reinforcements she is sending to the Siberian-Manchurian border, according to authentic advices received here.

PARIS, May 13 -- A defense of the capitalistic system and pleas for reduction of tariffs and governmental expenses and settlement of international debts were made today by Clarence Dillon of Dillon, Read Co., New York bankers, in an address before the American Club here.

In accordance with a recent invitation by the management, officials and bondholders of the New Orleans Great Northern Railroad are conferring on a plan for reducing fixed charges. The road, which is controlled by the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad, showed a loss of about $20,000 after charges in April, making its loss for the first four months of the year about $110,000, against $55,000 in the same period last year.

The second allow at the recently opened Eighth Street Gallery bears a marked family resemblance to the first. The general air of experimentation, combined with rather more "fauvisme," both in color and drawing, than is usual in New York galleries these days, gives the paintings on view at 61 West Eighth Street a stimulating, if not precisely an inspiriting, tone.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 13. -- Officials of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association tonight arranged final details of the Albany-New York motorboat race on Sunday

Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, will return tonight on the Italian motorship Vulcanla from the disarmament conference in Geneva, accompanied by Mrs. Stimson and his staff from the State Department.
CAMBRIDGE, England, May 13 -- Vitamins A,B, C and D may be produced on an industrial basis if the discoveries of two young Cambridge scientists fulfill initial expectations.
ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored an 8-to-7 victory over the Philadelphia Nationals in a ten-inning game today to go back into the first division.
BUENOS AIRES, May 13 -- Spain is pressing the Argentine Government to hasten an understanding for the barter of Argentine wheat for Spanish steel and iron manufactures.

HOPEWELL, N.J., May 13. -- This village, around which the Lindbergh case rrevolved from its beginning to its end, was sobered and dazed today with an undercurrent of anger that amounted almost to the lynching spirit.
A theatre and two factory structures were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday. Numerous residential properties also figured in the turnover.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., May 13 -- Cyril J.H. Tolley, former amateur champion of Great Britain, was carried nineteen holes to win his first-round match in the Morris County Golf Club's annual "weekend of golf" invitation tournament today.

The annual report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, issued yesterday, shows consolidated assets of $615,190,021 at the end of 1931, including $420,818,574 plant, property, patents and licenses, and $83,037,593 investments and advances in and to associated and affiliated companies.

Reasonable Driving of Cars If all motor-vehicle commissioners were as fertile in advice to Motorists as Mr. STOECKEL of Connecticut there would be fewer accidents. His contribution for May is entitled "The Cardinal Rules for Good Driving."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent decision of the Spanish Government to abandon the traditional policy of granting generous -- perhaps extravagant would be a better word -- subsidies to the erstwhile Spanish Royal Mail Line seems to be wanting a few pertinent remarks.

CINCINNATI, May 13 -- In a game featured by the first major league triple play of the season the Robins today won their second straight game of the current series, beating the Reds, 5 to 3, to strengthen their grip on sixth place, while the Giants spent another idle day at Pittsburgh.
Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in April amounted to 25,953 long tons, compared with 27,828 in March, the Rubber Manufacturers' Association announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Wheat traders were more impressed today by the action of the stock market than by anything else, but even this influence had little effect. Trade was light, and, with a strong technical position, a little buying toward the last caused a rally after a break of 3/8 cent.

A crowd of about 5,000 saw Ernie Schaaf, Boston heavyweight, who heretofore had been regarded as a title threat, carry away a decision from Jack Gross. Philadelphia's southpaw heavyweight, in a tenround bout last night in Madison Square Garden.

Governor A. Harry Moore vigorously defended yesterday the conduct of the investigation of the Lindbergh kidnapping as carried on by the New Jersey State Police head, Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf. He pronounced proposals from various county police authorities that Colonel Schwarzkopf be removed from office for incompetence as both "silly and ridiculous."

Details of a large housing operation on Murray Hill were announced yesterday by Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers, who recently sold the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street for the Bowery Savings Bank. The property consists of ten four and five-story dwellings on a plot fronting 123 feet on Park Avenue and 155 feet on the street.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, passed through his second day ot cross-examination yesterday at the hands of Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, at the superintendent's trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.

Cash contributions and estimated unpaid pledges to the block-aid campaign have reached a total of $1,301,622, it was announced last night by Wilton Lloyd-Smith, chairman of the Block Community Organization.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- Rochester won before more than 7,000 fans today, beating Newark for a second straight victory, 3 to 2. The Red Wings defeated Bots Nekola to spoil his mark of four victories and no defeats. Bud Teachout won his first start of the year, holding the Bears to six hits.

Captain Hubert Loveland of Saybrook, Conn., has had some exceptionally fine catches of pollack during the last few days off Montauk Point, L.I. On one particularly good day he took fifty-two fish that weighed between twenty and twenty-five pounds each, the largest in his recollection caught in those waters in some time.

The committee of twenty-one clergymen, headed by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, that has memoralized the United States Senate urging passage of the Costigan-Cuttingr resolution calling for an investigation of conditions in the coal fields of Harlan and Bell Counties, Kentucky, met yesterday at Town Hall, and, after hearing a report from a delegation of its members sent to Kentucky to view the situation, adopted a resolution reiterating its demand for an inquiry.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Disregarding the fact that the Federal Government, under existing law, has no jurisdiction in the kipnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby, President Hoover today ordered all Secret Service agencies of the United States "to make the kipnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby a live and never-to-be-forgotten case until the criminals are implacably brought to justice."

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- President and Mrs. Hoover attended the requiem high mass celebrated at noon today in St. Matthew's Church in memory of President Boumer of France, at which were present also Vice President Curtis and his sister. Mrs. Edward E. Gann. members of the Cabinet and of the diplomatic corps and other high officials.
Police Commissioner Mulrooney repledged the full strength of the New York Police Department yesterday in the hunt for the murderers of the Lindbergh baby.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 13. -- The biggest regatta so far this season will be held tomorrow on the upper course of the Severn, with fourteen crews from four colleges racing. This afternoon the float of Navy's big boat house was taxed as the visiting eights joined those of Navy in final workouts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We hear a great deal today about the importance of balancing budgets, but very little about the much more important question of balancing our minds. The events of the last eighteen years have upset the emotional and mental balance of the civilized world.

The price trend in commodities yesterday was irregular. The grains closed fractionally higher after early weakness, but cotton finished to 3 points off. Coffee, cocoa, rubber and hides in the contract market were heavy, but sugar was firm. In the spot trading, lard, zinc and rubber reached new lows for the year.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Five licensed transport pilots have reported to the Department of Commerce that they have flown more than 10,000 hours each. They are E. Hamilton Lee of Omaha, James H. Knight of Chicago, Clyde Pangborn of Wenatchee, Wash.; Ralph F. Thomas of Akron and Edwin K. Jaquith of New York.

Three weeks before Ivar Kreuger went to Paris and killed himself, he was confronted in New York by the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a private session, with the first challenge to his honesty.

Tributes to the memories of Thomas A. Edison and George Eastman were paid last evening by several hundred inventors gathered here from many parts of the world at the International Patent Exposition at the Grand Central Palace, which opened here Monday and is to continue until May 28.

The Cunarder Aquitania arrived last night from Southampton via Cherbourg with 418 passengers and docked for the first time in her history at the White Star Pier 59, foot j of West Seventeenth Street. Captain Harry McConkey, marine superintendent of the Cunard Line and his staff were on the pier in charge of the docking arrangements.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Establishment of medical schools in connection with Jewish hospitals, to accomomdate Jewish students of outstanding ability who may find themselves barred from other medical schools of limited enrolment, was urged by Dr. Israel Strauss, New York neurologist, in an address here today before a section of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13. -- The United States Davis Cup tennis tear won the first two singles matches from the Mexicans today at the New Orleans Country Club to take the lead in the semi-final series of the North American zone.
LONDON, May 13 -- The colossal task of cataloguing double stars in the northern sky has been completed by Dr. Robert Aitken, director of the Lick Observatory in California.

John Sloan, 24 years old, of 83 Underbill Avenue, Brooklyn, was held for further hearing by Magistrate McGee in Yorkville Court yesterday on a charge of being one of two burglars who were routed from St. Gabriel's Parish House, 308 West Thirty-seventh Street, by the Rev. J. Leonard Boyle after they had extracted $600 in cash, drivers licenses and personal effects from the clothing of eight sleeping priests in the early morning.

DARIEN, Conn., May 13 -- The Class A golf team of Apawamis Country Club won the interclub tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield County Women's Golf Association at Wee Burn today by gaining five additional points for a total of 38.

Frank I. O'Neill, a suspended General Sessions court attendant, testified in his defense yesterday at his trial in Judge Freschi's part of the same court on a charge of having defrauded Mrs. Bertha Ewald, wife of the former magistrate, of $3,000 in June, 1930.

Mayor WALKER refuses to comment on the evidence against him thus far brought out before the Hofstadter committee. He merely remarks that it is Judge SEABUBY'S " prior right " to make the charges. The implication is, of course, that the Mayor is prepared in due time to exercise his posterior right to dispel every possible impeachment of his official integrity.

Almost overnight Japan pulls an army of nearly 25,000 men out of Shanghai. The reasons are twofold. Specifically, Japan needs the troops in Manchuria. She also has come to recognize that the sooner she winds up the Shanghai business, the better for her true interests in Asia.

A deficit of $7,110 in the estate of Harry Houdini, magician, was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission. Mr. Houdini, who died on Oct. 31, 1926, left assets appraised at $69,955, but these were insufficient to meet the debts and expenses totaling $77,065, Debts amounted to $46,367.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13 -- Families with relatively lower incomes still receive inadequate medical care, according to a new study of the cost of medical care presented by Dr. Donald B. Armstrong of New York today at the concluding session of the section on preventive medicine and public health of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

A nation-wide strike of 16,000 elevator constructors employed by 600 manufacturing companies, including the Otis Elevator Company and the Westinghouse Electric Elevator Construction Company, as well as maintenance men in charge of elevator service in New York City's leading skyscrapers, was threatened yesterday as the result of an impasse in the strike of 35,000 building trade workers.

Morris Rosner, stock salesman and former Federal investigator, who was retained two days after the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby because of his supposed knowledge of underworld conditions to aid in the hunt, went to Hopewell yesterday to be questioned by the police.

A long controversy between New York State and New York City was won by the city yesterday when the Court of Appeals rendered a decision affirming title to the city of all lands now and formerly under the waters of Gravesend Bay, extending from the westerly end of Coney Island to Anthony Jansen's Old Bowerye, approximately at the foot of West Twenty-fourth Street, Coney Island.

The member lines of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference which selected Emil Lederer, resident director of the Hamburg-American Line, as executive director of transatlantic passenger business at their meeting in Paris on Thursday, will hold a series of meetings during the Summer to continue their adjustment of affairs.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 3 per cent for the best names.

HARBOR GRACE, N.F., May 13. -- After a record flight from Newark of 6 hours 19 minutes, refueling and an emergency repair of a small rent in his stabilizer. Louis T. Reichers, speed flier, lifted his airplane, Liberty, into a brilliant sun and headed for Baldonnel Field, Ireland, on the second leg of his flight to Paris at 8:29 Newfoundland Time (6:59 New York Daylight Saving Time) this morning.
BUENOS AIRES, May 13. -- The patriotic loan of 500,000,000 pesos ($125,000,000) was approved by the Senate last night and promulgated today.

Total admitted assets of the Aetna Life Insurance Company increased from $424,776,176 at the end of 1930 to $437,949,074 at the end of 1931, according to the annual report made public yesterday. This was a gain of $13,172,898 for the year.

During the past few days events in Washington have moved swiftly in the direction of Federal aid. Though the Costigan-La Follette bill for direct relief was defeated earlier in the session, the demand for action of some kind persisted. Senator WAGNER was in the field with his $750,000,000 program, which recently received the guarded endorsement of Professor SELIGMAN of Columbia.

Weakness in securities and drier weather in the Southwest caused a slight decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but resistance Developed as July contracts approached 5 1/2 cents a pound and the list ended 1 to 3 points lower than on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Charles Evans Hughes Jr. of New York, president of the National Probation Association, declared here tonight at the association's annual conference that the economic depression was adding heavily to the burdens of the probation services throughout the country and warned that retrenchment in this work by States or municipalities would not be justified even under the most severe conditions.

PARIS, May 13. -- As a consequence of President Paul Doumer's assassination by an alien, leaders of the French police, secret service and Foreign Office services met today with Premier Tardieu to lay down a program of stringent measures for the supervision of foreigners in France.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 13. -- Upsala defeated Muhlenberg in a free-scoring contest today, 11 to 8.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Gaston B. Means, arraigned today on charges of embezzling $104,000 from Mrs. Edward B. McLean, was called almost simultaneously to testify for Mr. McLean in a suit to oust him as co-trustee of his father's estate.

HAVANA, May 13. -- Former members of the board of directors of the Band of Mercy, Cuba's only humane society, have filed a protest with the United States Consul General here, F. F. Dumont, against what they describe as a campaign of vilification in the Cuban press.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The joint resolution introduced by Representative Somers of New York, requesting President Hoover to call an international monetary conference which would consider the re-evaluation of silver wherever it is used as money and as monetary reserves, was reported favorably today by the House Committee on Coinage, of which Mr. Somers is chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A drive to force the war-time income tax rates into the tax bill as substitutes for the manufacturers' excises recommended by the Finance Committee was started by Senator Couzens today soon after the billion-dollar measure was formally presented to the Senate.

Clarence Whitehill, veteran American singer, took a stormy departure from grand opera yesterday. In announcing to reporters that he was leaving the Metropolitan Opera Company, with which he had been associated since 1915, he charged its general manager, Giulio Gatti-Casazza, with wasting the organization's funds and with entertaining a bias against American artists.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- A field of twelve colts, including the Kentucky Derby winner, Burgoo King, has been named for the running of the $50,000 added Preakness, which will be contested at the old Pimlico course tomorrow. Geldings are not eligible for this traditional test, which first was won by Survivor in 1873, and no filly has been entered to contest the issue.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP). -- Mrs. Jessie Woodrow Sayre, daughter of Woodrow Wilson, today sent to the Governors of the forty-eight States a group of questions, the answers to which, would be for the guidance of the electorate in forming policies relative to national problems.

Urging the formation of a general protective committee for holders of Hungarian Government external bonds, or a unified bankers' consortium, the Institute of International Finance, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association of America in cooperation with New York University, issued yesterday a formal statement and bulletin outlining Hungary's financial condition.

Forty-four States returned a ratio of ballots in the Literary Digest poll on prohibition within 1 per cent of their official 1928 voting strength in those States, the magazine points out in today's issue, in refutation of contentions that more ballots were sent to the wet sections of the country than to the dry.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The appeal of the railway brotherhoods to President Hoover is as follows:
TORONTO, May 13 (AP) -- Toronto made it two out of three in its home series with Jersey City by winning today's game, 3-2.

Many parents must be wishing that their children understood the value of money nowadays. Allowances have been cut or eliminated altogether, and children accustomed to pocket money of their own do not always see why. Vacation plans nave to be changed when the family income drops.
Purchases and leases of residential properties in various parts of Westchester County furnished the bulk of the deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Cancellation of war debts and reparations, recognition of Russia, lowering of tariff duties and membership in the World Court are suggested as essential to disarmament in a plank proposed today by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom for the platforms of the two major parties.

Control of a large assemblage by means of radio will be tried by the Police Department for the first time today when the movement of Mayor Walker's "beer for taxation" parade will be directed by radio at strategic points, Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced yesterday in making public his traffic regulations for the day.

A parcel of Whitestone, L.I., real estate, sold during the 1925 boom twice on the same day, with an increase in price of $100,000 on the second transaction, was made the basis of a suit brought in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday against Clarence F. Corner, Brooklyn lawyer and official of the Robinwood Realty Corporation.

Arthur Hammerstein's resumption of activity as a theatrical producer has been checked by the United Scenic Artists Union, Local 829, because of the producer's alleged debt of $9,700 to Cirker Robbins, builders and designers of theatrical settings, Mr. Hammerstein said yesterday.

The action of Borough President Sarvey of Queens in submitting to the Board of Estimate comprehensive plans for the proposed extension of Grand Central Parkway and Laurelton Parkway in advance of a specific agreement between the city and the State as to the part each shall play in the construction of the roads was assailed as "premature" yesterday by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

VATICAN CITY, May 13. -- Osservatore Romano, the Vatican City newspaper, in an article certainly reflects the outraged sentiments of the Pope and the entire Holy See, expressed horror at the tragic ending of the Lindbergh baby. Such a "monstrous offense" against all the finer feelings of modern civilization, says Osservatore, calls for immediate exemplary justice.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 13. -- Maurice O'Brien pitched his third no-hit, no-run game of the season and his second in four days in hurling the Barnard School for Boys baseball team to a 1-to-0 triumph over Scarsdale High today. On Tuesday O'Brien held Hackley School of Tarrytown hitless and runless as Barnard won, 2 to 0.

BELGRADE, May 13 -- With declarations from participating Foreign Ministers that Danubian cooperation was the most important question for discussion, this year's conference of the Little Entente opened today at Belgrade. Whether the Rumanian, Yugoslav and Czech representatives will be able to reach a common ground on the subject is not yet clear.

During a period of six years the museum-like home of E. Francis Hyde, 90-year-old retired banker and philanthropist, at 36 West Fiftyeighth Street, was stripped of $100,000 worth of its antiques, silver, furniture, tapestries and rugs, with the owner wholly unaware of his loss.

HIGH up in the White Sox hostelry, Samuel Pond Jones, the squire of Woodsfield, O., was peering out the window with disapproval. He didn't like the weather. Minter Hayes; the second baseman who went to the White Sox with Jones and Bump Hadley when Carl Reynolds shifted to the Senators, was lying on a couch reading a newspaper. Carey Selph, the third baseman, was seated at a desk, writing letters.

A mock battle between a platoon of men and three airplanes, directed by a ground radio-telephone set, was staged yesterday at Ohio Field, University Heights, as part of the fourteenth annual military field day of the New York University Reserve Officers' Training Corps.

S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, May 13. -- Lou Reichers, the transoceanic flier, was rescued from the turbulent Atlantic off the southern tip of Ireland tonight by a lifeboat crew from the President Roosevelt.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 13 -- Lieutenant Brookner W. Brady, by gaining second place in today's 300 meter swim test, strengthened his grasp on first place among the twelve aspirants for places on the United States Olympic modern pentathlon team.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 -- Harvard, Princeton and Georgetown were the winners in Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association matches at the Belmont Spring C.C. today.

HOPEWELL, N.J., May 13. -- Spurred by the statement of President Hoover that the search for the murderers of the Lindbergh baby must never be relaxed, police and law enforcement officials from all over New Jersey sped in and out of Hopewell today on what is rapidly developing into the greatest manhunt in history.

A six-run rally in the seventh inning gave Manhattan College a 10-to-6 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute at Jasper Field yesterday. A home run with two on bases by Elmore of R.P.I. in the fifth had given the visitors an early lead but another homer by Thomas of Manhattan in the seventh counteracted this.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- The Athletics, and Jimmy Foxx in particular, fattened their batting averages at the expense of two St. Louis pitchers today as they pounded out a 9-to-4 victory over the Browns.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production, reflects the resumption of operations on a moderate scale following numerous shut-downs and other forms of curtailment. The index for the week ended May 7 stands at 79.8, as against 57.5 for the preceding week and 93.9 for the corresponding week last year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 13 -- Eugene G. O'Neill Jr., son of the playwright, was one of nine to whom were awarded prizes today at Yale University. Mr. O'Neill received the Noyes Cutter prize awarded an undergraduate for the highest degree of excellency in "interpreting the Greek of the New Testament into modern English."
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Commerce Department's automotive division reports "a very considerable increase" in the number of letters containing inquiries on comparative motoring expenses.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 13 -- A campaign to increase the membership of the local post of the Grand Army of the Republic, which has dwindled to one member, resulted today in the applications for reinstatement of two Civil War veterans who had resigned from the post many years ago.

Some slight seasonal improvement in retail business and a generally better tone generally are reported by the weekly reviews of trade and industry, which assert, however, that the improvement is being retarded by the uncertainties of Federal taxation.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 13. -- Led by Governor Russell of Georgia, visitors thronged to the Pine Mountain cottage of Governor Roosevelt today for short conferences.

BOSTON, May 13 -- Recent increase in the number of museums in the United States has been "amazing," Laurence Vail Coleman, director of the American Association of Museums, said today in an address before the annual meeting of the association at the Museum, of Fine Arts.

The claims of the players in "Alice Sit-by-the-Fire" and "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals" for a percentage of what would have been a week's gross receipts if the engagement of the Barrie revivals had not been canceled suddenly by William A. Brady have been denied by an arbitration board, it was announced yesterday.

SUNNYVALE, Cal., May 13 (AP). -- The navy dirigible Akron was moored at the West Coast naval base here at 6:55 P.M. (10:55 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time) tonight, completing its transcontinental journey begun from Lakehurst, N.J., last Sunday.

Prices on the Stock Exchange sank into new low ground in another period of dull trading yesterday. More than 100 Issues sold at low records for the bear market or longer, and the composite price of fifty representative railroad and indusrial issues fell $2.02.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The 1930 cost of municipal government in the 310 American cities having populations of 30,000 and over was $3,810,681,763, or 66.4 per cent greater than corresponding payments by governments of the forty-eight States and 2.3 per cent more than those of the Federal Government, according to a study made public today by the Census Bureau.

New bond financing this week was slightly larger than it was last week, totaling 517,502,000. Of this amount $16,502,000 consisted of municipal issues and $1,000,000 of public-utility bonds. Last week's total was $16,409,000, made up entirely of State and municipal issues, and that of the previous week, $7,743,000.

Miss Muriel Herzstein, 16 years old, of Washington Irving High School, Manhattan, won the regional championship last night in the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution, sponsored in this district by THE NEW YORK TIMES. She was one of the eight finalists -- chosen from 100,000 pupils of more than 300 high schools -- who made prepared and extemporaneous speeches in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Guy Bush produced one of his few hits in a ninth-inning rally today to give the Cubs a 3-to-2 victory over the Braves and to increase their lead over Boston to three games in the National League pennant race before a ladies' day crowd of 30,000.

Members of the Thomas Jefferson Democratic Club of Forest Hills and Kew Gardens, Queens, expressed gratification yesterday at the adoption of a resolution endorsing former Governor Smith for the Democratic nomination for President. The resolution had been adopted at the preceding meeting by a vote of 134 to 62, which later was made unanimous.

VIKNNA, May 13. -- The government published tonight the text of a note addressed to the League of Nations warning the world that Austria must declare a transfer moratorium unless the League had an alternative solution to offer, and announcing her intention of negotiating with Germany and other countries those preferential agreements whose conclusion was delayed to permit discussion of the Tardieu plan of Danubian union.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Appropriation of money by Congress as a contribution to the World Court, except on conditions that will prevent its use to enforce a code of law containing inequalities based on sex, was opposed today by members of the National Woman's Party before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Messages of condolence and expressions of sympathy continued to stream through the little telegraph office in Hopewell, N.J., to the home of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 13. -- With Way Thompson pitching in good form the Dartmouth baseball team had little trouble with Princeton today in an Eastern Intercolleciate League game, the Green winning handily, 10-3. The victory put Dartmouth in a tie with Columbia for second place.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13. -- A probably brilliant, diseased mentality, against which society can be protected, summarizes a diagnosis of the Lindbergh kidnapping made today by two leading authorities attending the American Medical Association convention.

TIENTSIN, China, May 13 (AP) -- Activities of Japanese troops near Shanhaikwan on the border between Manchuria and China proper do not justify alarming predictions of possible trouble there, an independent source, usually reliable, said today.

Seven 3-year-old colts and fillies which had never before started in a race met in the fifth running of the featured $2,500 added Debut Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday and the blue silks of George D. Widener were first past the winning post, carried to victory by the chestnut filly Sheltered, well ridden by Albert Robinson.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- Announcement of the engagement of Miss Agnes Newhall, niece of Miss Laura E. Newhall of Boston, Mass., to Professor Richard Stillwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Buckley Stillwell of Princeton, was announced at a recent garden party at the American School in Athens, Greece, it was learned here today.

Benjamin De Casseres, who has published nine hooks and has thirteen "ready for publication," announces a magazine which is to be called De Casseres' Magazine and will be written entirely by himself. It will be a magazine of aggressive individualism, he declares, because the individual is the unit of all values, and he defines an individual as "a person who has no program for any one else."

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week will amount to $46,402,746, the heaviest in several weeks, representing the requirements of forty-seven communities throughout the country. The revised total for this week was $25,732,661, and the weekly average for the year to date is put at $20,845,793.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 13 (AP) -- Validity of the election of eight directors and three officers of Consolidated Coppermines Corporation of New York was questioned in a suit filed in Chancery Court today by Paul A. Gow of Butte, Mont., owner of 3,000 shares of the corporation's stock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Like your correspondent Mrs. Lucia Ames Mead, I have been a convinced pacifist for years, and although I lost two sons in the World War I did not wholly accept the political philosophy and teachings that inspired Canada and the United States, my native and adopted countries, to take part in the conflict.

The Board of Estimate threw yesterday into the field of competitive bidding the problem of bus franchises in Queens by announcing that sealed proposals would be opened at its meeting next Friday and grants made eventually to applicants offering the best terms to the city.

State of New Jersey. The State of New Jersey Sinking Fund Commission will meet on Tuesday to set a date for the sale of $21,000,000 of new bonds and arrange finally the terms of sale. The projected financing will be done early in June.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Since the smooth operation of government in this country under the Constitution depends on party control, and there is none in Washington at the moment, the acute issue of unemployment relief is threatened by difference of opinion, as the economy and taxation programs have been.

Spurred by the world-wide grief and indignation over the murder of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's son, and stung by accusations that the case had been bungled, New Jersey State police joined yesterday with Federal Secret Service men and other agencies in the greatest man-hunt in history.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 13. -- Williams defeated Middlebury, 6 to 3, today. Sheehan hit a homer with two on base in the first for the visitors.
CHICAGO, May 13. -- The nationwide campaign against high taxes gained impetus today when the Chicago City Council petitioned Congress to reduce Federal taxes a minimum of 20 per cent.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 13 -- The bridle trails were the popular choice of many of the colonists today. Mrs. William B. Duryea, Samuel Lindsey Nicholson, Mrs. William Wallace Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Love, Mrs. F. W. Magin and James Magin, Miss Carolyn Weber, David Sarnoff, Miss Mary D. Brooks, T.N. McGowen and Ernest A. Thomson were among those who left The Homestead this afternoon' for long rides.
