BALTIMORE, Md., May 13 (AP). -- Sun Meadow, the four-year-old colt which races for Mrs. K. E. Hitt of Virginia, annexed the Pimlico Spring Handicap today, the victory netting his fair owner $2,910.

The highest recognition that Columbia College can give for nonathletic activities, the gold King's Crown, has been awarded to ten students, it was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator. Silver awards have been made to forty other students.

Leaders of Tammany Hall, gravely concerned already over recent disclosures before the Hofstadter committee affecting Mayor Walker, were wondering yesterday what further bombshells may come from Samuel Seabury's briefcase in the next two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House voted today, 141 to 135, to drop 2,000 officers from the army after Representative Wood of Indiana had told the members that he had just come from the White House and that President Hoover "expected and hoped and desired" that the War Department appropriation bill, reduced $24,380,310 under the budget estimates, would be passed by Congress.

The swimming teams of Erasmus Hall and Henry P.O'Nell won the Greater New York senior and junior high school championships of the Public Schools Athletic League in the seventy-five-foot pool of Seward Park High School last night.

MONTREAL, May 13 (AP) -- The Royals' winning streak of thirteen straight games came to an end today when Ken Holloway turned them back in the third contest of the series with the Baltimore Orioles, 3-2. A crowd of 5,500 saw the game.

The downward course of stock prices was unrelieved yesterday. If anything, the decline was accelerated in scope, although not in the volume of business transacted. Railroad shares were uniformly lacking in support and the utility issues appeared to be under special pressure.

NORFOLK, Va., May 13 -- Death has given back to its parents the little lost baby, and in death, perhaps, the tiny son of Colonel Lindbergh has given to the American people, who poured out the sympathy of their heart of hearts to the bereaved parents, a gift even more priceless than the pride they feel in its father.

An amazing chapter of Dr. John F. Condon's efforts to recover the Lindbergh baby was revealed yesterday, when it was no longer to be feared that further harm might befall the child. The story was told in a copyrighted article published by The Bronx Home News, a representative of which had won the confidence of the elderly school teacher, who called himself Jafsie in communicating with the asserted kidnappers through cryptic advertisements in that newspaper.

Stephanie Reynolds, whose first exhibition is now on at the Delphic Studios, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, began painting when she was 55 years old. It is reported she has had no instruction whatever. The results of her late-blooming aspiration, covering a period of two years, are now presented to the public.

We greet with a glad heart still another revival and reappearance of the McGinnies boom. How often, oh, how often, has " JOE'S " bright banner been unfurled, only to be coiled up and laid away till the next time! Wherever there is a dinner of up-State Republicans, a meeting of a Republican up-State committee, he is sure to be nominated for Governor.

The seventh annual interdenominational Bible conference under the auspices of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago will be held in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, beginning tomorrow and continuing eight days. Dr. James M. Gray, president of the institute, will preach the opening sermon at 11 A.M. Services will be held at 3 and 7:30 P.M. tomorrow and at noon, 3 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. every day during the week except Saturday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 13. -- The intended child victim of a $30,000 kidnapping plot was safe today because one of the conspirators lost his nerve as he read in a newspaper that the Lindbergh baby had been slain.

SYDNEY, May 13 -- J.T. Lang, extremist Laborite Premier of New South Wales, was dismissed from office today by Sir Philip Game, British Governor of the State. B.S.B. Stevens, leader of the Opposition and member of the United Australia party, was commissioned to form a government.

NORFOLK, Va., May 13. -- Norfolk police and Federal authorities today began an investigation of the activities of John H. Curtis, Rear Admiral Guy H. Burrage and the Rev. H. Dobson Peacock, who for two months have been conducting negotiations 'for the return of the Lindbergh baby.

KAMPALA, Uganda, British East Africa, May 13 -- The correspondent of The Uganda Herald in the Toro district has reported the ascent of Welssman Peak in the Ruwenzori Mountains by Captain G.N. Humphreys and George Oliver.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- The Soviet Government is launching a big campaign to improve the transportation system, a vital part of the Five-Year Plan, in an effort to make a smashing success of the Autumn harvest.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- The City Council today moved to review the agreement between New Jersey and Pennsylvania, establishing the Delaware River joint commission as a "port authority" controlling bridges and tunnels crossing the Delaware.

The first clear prophecy of the alphabet known as the " Morse code " and of the instrument for its use is to be found in a statement which SAMUEL F.B. MORSE made aboard the packet ship Sully on his way home from Europe in 1832:

Fantastic suggestions for obtaining the return of the Lindbergh baby poured into the offices of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the seventy-two days that passed during the search for the child. Tney came in thousands of letters, through personal interviews, telephone calls, the telegraph and even by cable.

The five dissenting Democrats who signed a minority report argue persuasively against the duties on coal and coke, oil, copper and lumber proposed in the new tax bill. Their first point is that a bill designed to revise domestic tax laws should not be made a vehicle for tariff legislation.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Small Moore Jr. have joined the Hon. and Mrs. Oliver Wallop at the Madison.

BERLIN, May 13. -- Three of the four National Socialist Deputies accused of having beaten a journalist in the Reichstag building yesterday for an alleged slander against one of the leaders of their party were found guilty tonight and sentenced to three months in jail for assault and slander.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The "locust swarm of lobbyists," denounced by President Hoover, is more of a nuisance than a menace, in the opinion of members of Congress who have been exposed to the locusts this session. With bills for the reduction of appropriations and the increase of taxes before Congress, lobbyists of all kinds have been extraordinarily active.

TRENTON, N.J., May 13. -- The body of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was carried from here to Linden, N.J., this afternoon in a simple procession of a hearse and one following automobile, in which rode his father, and there reduced to dust in the Rose Hill Crematory.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Belief that the Pennroad Corporation and the Van Sweringens had tried to consolidate railroad holdings "in absolute violation of the spirit of the law" was expressed today before the House Rules Committee by Chairman Rayburn of the Interstate Commerce Committee.

PARIS, May 15. -- The market, was generally weak today, with trading on the eve of the three-day closing only scattering. Exceptions were some classes of rentes, which were firm, but gold mining and almost the entire list of domestic and international issues sustained losses.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13. -- "Looking ahead, not behind," was the attitude of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and his wife, Mrs. Thalia Massie, as the liner Malolo slowly steamed to dock here today, bringing them from the scene of the recent "honor slaying" trial in Honolulu.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Armand ToKatyan, American tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, appeared tonight in the Staatsopera, Berlin, as Don Jose in "Carmen." After an ovation received in the second act he was engaged by General Intendent Tietjien for an appearance May 18 in "Rigoletto."

Despite a rallying tendency in United States Government bonds and in some sections of the foreign loan list, domestic corporation issues as a group were weaker yesterday on the Stock Exchange. A long list of railroad bonds lost 1 to 9 points for the day.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 14 -- An important move toward permanent settlement by international agreement of the status of Shanghai was made last night when the Foreign Minister, Kenkichi Yoshizawa, summoned the United States Charge d'Affaires, Edwin L. Neville, and the British, French and Italian Ambassadors into a conference on the matter.

HAVANA, May 13. -- Jack Crawford, first-ranking Australian tennis player, defeated Ricardo Morales, Cuban star, by 6-3, 6-1, 7-5, in the opening Davis Cup match between Australia and Cuba today on the courts of the Club Ferroviario.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Senator Hewitt and Assemblyman Porter, chairmen of the fiscal committees of the Legislature, issued a statement tonight suggesting that the $10,000,000 which it was announced Governor Roosevelt would save on the budget would be due to market conditions.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Alvin Crowder pitched a sterling two-hit game today to enable the Washington Senators to turn back the Detroit Tigers, 7 to 0.

Money market pursued much the same course that it has followed for weeks -- extremely light turnover at quotations which showed no variance from preceding sessions. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, street trades at 1 1/2. All maturity money was nominally quoted at 1 1/2, while commercial paper and acceptances were done at prevailing discounts.

Reversing the result of their meeting in last year's final, Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, tenth in the national ranking, yesterday defeated Jerry Lang, former Columbia University captain, to gain the semi-final round of the North Side championship at the University Heights Tennis Club.

LONDON, Ky., May 13 -- Informing representatives of the American Civil Liberties Union that in his opinion they were violating the rights of others by insisting upon their own, Federal Judge A.M.J. Cochran tonight refused to grant the injunction sought by Arthur Garfield Hays and Dudley Field Malone against officials of Bell and Harlan Counties.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Following the announcement of a further delay in the proposed auction of securities of Insull companies held as collateral for loans, four banks in New York filed today a petition in the Federal District Court here asking dissolution of the temporary injunction issued last week restraining the sale of the securities.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Adoption of the Goldsborough bill, which directs the Federal Reserve Board to restore commodity prices by its control over credit and currency, was urged today by Professor Irving Fisher of Yale before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 13 -- With the usual crowd of devotees to the art of the composer, John Sebastian Bach, thronging the city, the Twenty-sixth Bach Festival opened today. The ivy-clad Packer Memorial Church on the campus of Lehigh University was filled close to capacity when, at the late afternoon session, Dr. J. Fred Wolle ascended the conductor's platform and signaled his singers for the entrance chord to the first cantata.
BERLIN, May 13. -- Germany's social structure is in the crucible, and what comes out depends largely on what becomes of its former backbone -- the middle class.

MEMBERS of the Artists and Teachers Benevolent Society will give their annual card party in aid of the pension fund of the organization on Wednesday afternoon in the Louis XV ballroom of the Ambassador. This fund provides for the care and maintenance of invalid artists, teachers in the various professions and musicians.

ALTHOUGH "Another Language" is the first play by Rose Franken to reach Broadway, it is a singularly complete revelation of character and a remarkably workmanlike achievement. Here is one play that belongs to the theatre. It is written for actors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the anniversary of the creation of Lewis Carroll's immortal Alice just a few weeks off, many of us -- adults (with adult I.Q.'s) and school children, (with school children's I.Q.'s) -- will recover and uncover those nonsensical yet fascinating characters that trip through several hundred pages of print.

The rearranged material in Egyptian Hall at the Brooklyn Museum will be placed on public view today. Professor Jean Capart of Brussels has been at work at the museum for several months, reassembling the Wilbour collections and installing in special cases some of the particularly interesting objects.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- In honor of President John Grier Hibben the alumni of Princeton University had established a loan fund for undergraduates, it was announced here today by Walter L. Johnson, '97, of New York, chairman of the graduate council, at the "Hibben Day" luncheon, which was attended by more than 300 alumni who had returned to the campus to pay tribute to the retiring president.

WASHINGTON. THE tourist who visits Washington these fine Spring days has now an impressive item to add to the long list of historical spots and imposing structures which, if he is conscientious, he will visit.

IS membership in the Institute of Mining Engineers becoming a requisite for the Presidency? The heads of the world's two most powerful republics are men who have studied the science of burrowing under ground. At Washington Herbert Hoover, M.E., occupies the White House and is about to negotiate for another four-year lease with his 120,000,000 landlords.

THE second annual Festival of American Music, presented by the Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester in the beautiful Eastman Theatre in that city, acknowledged the existence of the American composer of ballets by devoting its final session on May 6 to the performance of two dance works with music by native composers.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana ad- dressed an appeal to the Democrats of his State to instruct their dele- gates to the national convention to vote for Governor Roosevelt of New York, in a letter to W.W. McDowell, chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, made public here today.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- A field goal by Watt. Harvard fullback, from the 25-yard line gave the Crimson rugby team a 4 -- 0 victory over the Princeton fifteen today.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 14. -- More than 500 students, alumnae and friends of Marymount College assem- bled in the college stadium today to witness the annual sports day program.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico. IF an unrecognized, tall, rather serious, oldish-young man called at the White House offices recently and asked to see the President, probably it was Governor James R. Beverley of Porto Rico.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 14. -- Martin B. Hoyt, treasurer of the Case-Hoyt Corporation, printing and advertising concern and United States food administrator for Western New York during the World War, died at his home here last night, after an illness of six months.

This Spring five outstanding men in the community were asked to state what they expected the elementary school to do for their children or what they expected of elementary education. It is interesting to note that the statements of each were practically identical.

The business cycle has been regarded by students and bankers primarily as art economic phenomenon. Yet to some extent the psychological aspects of economics were indicated by the subjective and psychological school of Nassau W. Senior in England (1790-1864), who developed his theory of abstinence and psychio costs.

In the interesting conversation with Speaker GARNER which our Washington correspondent reported last week the presiding officer of the House of Representatives defended his course, and that of his party, during the present session of Congress. Mr. GARNER frankly admitted that the small and precarious majority at his command would disable any Speaker from asserting the kind of control which used to be associated with his office.

LOS ANGELES, May 12. -- With legal difficulties overcome, all that remains to make sure of an early start on the construction of the Los Angeles aqueduct is a trifling formality involving the sale of $220,000,000 of bonds.

OF two things I am convinced. The first is that there is no country in the world where men and women of all classes are so much a piece as they are here, where apparent social distinctions mean so little. That is why in no other country in the world are there so many people fitted if they are called on to assume great responsibilities.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 14. -- The University of Virginia baseball team defeated the Naval Academy today, 16 to 2. The offerings of three Navy pitchers were pounded, although only two extra base hits were made.

CONSIDERING the number of things that were not planned that have happened since the days of the big bull market it is only natural, even without the example set by Russia, that our economists should weigh the question of what might happen if we did plan a few things.

PANAMA, R.P., May 10. -- The Supreme Court has cleared the record of the charges of alleged peculations against former Presidents Rodolfo Chiari and Florencio H. Arosemena, presented by Attorney General Aristides Arjona in connection with the contracting and construction of the Puerto Armuelles Railroad, which the prosecuting officer asserted cost $818,938 less than the government paid for the work.

GEORGE M. COHAN is going into the pictures that talk. Mr. Cohan will put his Broadway affairs in order and soon leave for Hollywood to begin working out a contract with Paramount. First of all he will assist in writing "The Phantom President," a musical comedy romance, in which he will also play the lead.

Commodities on local exchanges, with the exception of coffee and silver, closed lower as a result of last week's trading. Declines were recorded in sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and wool tops. Silver was unchanged, while coffee continued to advance.

BALTIMORE, May 14. -- E.R. Bradley's Kentucky Derby winner. Burgoo King, strengthened his claim to 3-year-old championship honors by a smashing triumph in the $50,000 added Preakness, which was run at Pimlico today before one of the most distinguished gatherings ever to see a horse race.

THE youthful art of broadcasting is looking forward to the day when it will be aged and seasoned sufficiently for some philanthropist to establish prize awards for achievements at the microphone as the Pulitzer awards recognize letters, journalism and scholarship.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A tribute to Richard Victor Oulahan, late Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, is contained in the 1932 Year Book issued today by the National Press Club, of which he was a member.

WARSAW, May 14. -- Two men will be put to death here as Soviet spies early tomorrow morning. They are Wladyslaw Borakowski, a civilian clerk attached to the Polish general staff, and Jan Bakowski, an engineer.

In an effort to reduce the number of mishaps on motor boats due to fire, the marine committee of the National Fire Protection Association has launched a campaign among operators of pleasure craft and filling stations.

PROFESSOR BABBITT'S book is a collection of essays loosely united at bottom by his critical credo, which he calls humanism, and bridged over at the top by a sentence from Aristotle which he literally translates: "The first is not the seed but the perfect," that is, more freely, "the seed is to be found not in the origins but in the completed thing."

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Impending expansion of currency in Japan is causing government officials to consider control over exchange with a view to preventing possible flight of capital from the country, the Commerce Department was advised today in a cable from Commercial Attache Halleck A. Butts at Tokyo.

BERLIN, May 14. -- Professor Wilhelm Kahl, veteran parliamentarian and Nestor of German jurists, died today at the age of 83. He served as lieutenant in the Franco-Prussian War and was present with Paul von Hindenburg at the proclamation ceremonies of the German Empire in the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles in 1871.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 14. -- The Holy Cross nine defeated Georgetown by 9 -- 3 today. The victors collected twelve hits and were aided by the wildness of three Georgetown twirlers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 14. -- With excellent sailing weather prevailing most of the afternoon, during which a light southwest breeze was evident, six races for dinghies were held today on Manhasset Bay in the first of a weekly series of meetings to be held this Summer under the auspices of the North American Dinghy Association.

Holding the same relative position among the outdoor exhibitions as does the Westminster Club's show in the indoor list, the Morris and Essex Kennel Club's annual event is far more than a display of thoroughbred dogs on the bench and in the com- petitive ring.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14 (AP). -- Robert W. Harden of Westfield, retiring president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, in his annual address to the association today in the Hotel Chelsea, called upon the bankers to continue their efforts to reduce government budgets until there were slashes in every one, from the smallest hamlet to that of the Federal Government.

FOR those who "practice sunbathing as a sort of secret vice," this first history of the struggles of Nacktkultur to gain a foothold on American soil will come as a Bill of Rights. Mr. and Mrs. Merrill, the Jettersons of the Nudist movement, commenced their propaganda last year with a description of life among the Nackt reservations of Germany, which they published in a book called "Among the Nudists."
PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The Penn A.C. defeated the University of Pennsylvania nine on Franklin Field today, 5 to 3.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- Princeton Theological Seminary will open its one hundred and twentieth commencement tomorrow morning, when the annual baccalaureate service will be held in Miller Chapel. The Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, president of the seminary, will preach and the holy communion will follow.
Displaying its best form in several years, the Columbia track team concluded its season of dual meets yesterday by defeating Syracuse, 87 1/2 to 47 1/2, at Baker Field.

ROME, May 13. -- If there is any truth in the saying that the way to a man's heart is through his stomach, it is easy to predict success for a gastronomical guide to Italy just published by the Italian State Tourist Agency.

AS far as physical equipment goes, the Eighth Avenue Subway -- its official name is the Washington Heights, Eighth Avenue, and Church Street Line -- could be put into operation tomorrow. It has 300 cars ready for use, and 500 more have been ordered.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 14. -- The eighth annual Westchester County Music Festival, featured by a musical tribute to Haydn, whose 200th birthday anniversary is being celebrated this year, and by the playing, by Percy Grainger, of his own new composition, written for the occasion, will be heard Friday and Saturday nights at the Westchester County Centre here.

Comparison of retail sales figures during the week centred attention on the fact that while the chain store organizations have been affected by business conditions, their sales volume has tended to be maintained better than the dollar volume of other forms of distribution.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The statement by Representative Rainey endorsing the position of the rail- road unions on unemployment relief reads in full:

MADRID, May 13. -- Spain's tale of two cities at last is reaching a dramatic climax. After a year of discussion, threats and promises, the Catalan statute is coming up for what is optimistically called a settlement.

A year ago last Wednesday the collapse of the Austrian Creditanstalt, which was to pile a disastrous international financial crisis on top of the world-wide business depression, became known. The anniversary of this event, although not formally observed, served to direct the attention of the banking community once more to the long delay on the part of the governments of the nations involved in coming to grips with the problem of international debts.

The story which has had its tragic and heart-breaking ending during the last week in the finding of the dead child has revealed the worst in human nature, if indeed those who committed the most merciless, perfidious and despicable of deeds deserve to be called "human."

The decline in the stock market continued throughout yesterday's short trading period, unrelieved save for a fractional recovery from the day's lows in the last few minutes of business. The general list of bonds was irregular, but declines predominated.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. IN Hollywood it has been a crime for any one to have a mind of his own. Brains haven't had a chance. Executives have protected their thrones by beheading any one who got near enough to jeopardize them.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- Excessive mother love was classed among the chief causes of child delinquency by Dr. David M. Levy of the Institute of Child Guidance, New York, in an address before the annual convention of the National Probation Association here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14. -- A schooner of the Gloucester fishing type, captained by a South Jersey man, is being sought along the New Jersey coast as the boat used by the Lindbergh kidnappers in their last attempt to make contact with the Colonel.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 14. -- The ousting of Berne A. Pyrke, the Commissioner of Agriculture, by the State Council of Farms and Markets was condemned here today by Gov- ernor Roosevelt as an "outrage."

From Miscellaneous Mail. THOSE who stop to think about it realize that automobile drivers do not dash through traffic, race at top speed on highways and otherwise add to the danger of driving because they are in an important hurry to get anywhere.

The Scarborough Players, a new Summer theatre organization, will open an eight weeks' season June 20 at the Beechwood Playhouse under the management of John Shepphard Jr. and Frank Buchanan, formerly head of the Philadelphia Little Theatre.

THE airship Akron, the world's largest dirigible and the navy's first airship of war, reached San Diego last Wednesday after a voyage from Lakehurst that had lasted a little more than seventytwo hours. During this trip the huge rigid airship demonstrated its ability to fight winds of gale force, to climb across high ridges amid treacherous vertical currents and to make this 4,000-mile journey with a ship's company of eighty comfortably, ever luxuriously, cared for.

PARIS, May 14. -- An injury to France's leading junior star, Marcel Bernard, enabled the United States to break even with France today in the opening play of the special fivematch Franco-American competition starting the tennis season at the Roland Carros Stadium.
RYE, N.Y., May 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Carroll of Hilltop Place. Rye, gave a large dinner tonight at their home.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 14. -- Four dual meet records were broken as Pennsylvania's track team defeated Cornell. 81 to 54, in their annual meet on Schoellkopf Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Recommendations made by the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures that President Hoover call, not later than July 1, an international monetary conference, as requested in a joint resolution introduced by Representative Somers of New York, were made public today, together with a preliminary report on the resolution by a subcommittee of which Mr. Somers is chairman.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 14. -- Breaking 49 out of 50 targets, Paul Edward Gardner won the high scratch cup in the weekly shoot over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. There was a tie for the high handicap cup between H. Frankling and F.E. Rasbach.

THESE are difficult days for art galleries and museums; and for several the prolonged period of financial stress has proved too much; on the other hand, art, while very hard hit, has thus far revealed surprisingly few casualtics.
NEW ORLEANS, May 14. -- The United States Davis Cup tennis team entered the finals of the North American zone today by winning its third straight match from Mexico.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 14. -- Led by Maynard McNally, Long Island 100-yard and 220-yard titleholder, who won both the sprints, Hempstead High School's track team with twenty-two points today won the annual St. Paul's School interscholastic invitation track and field meet, in which five meet records were shattered.

DAIREN, Manchuria, April 17. -- Like all other forms of Japanese business in Manchuria, the whaling industry around the Eliot Islands, near here, is undergoing great expansion this year. New ships are being built and the whale reduction plants are being enlarged.

Directors of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) will meet tomorrow to consider the procedure which the company will follow as a consequence of the deposit of its consolidated bonds under an offer to meet their maturity on June 1, one-half with cash and one-half with general refunding bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A truck driver and his helper saw a baby's foot sticking out of a pile of brush near Mount Rose, N.J., Thursday afternoon. They reported it to the police at Hopewell, and within a few minutes the entire nation was mourning over the identification of a tiny corpse as that of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

IN the great colonnaded Hall of Congress at Versailles, France last week elected through her chosen Senators and Deputies, sitting together as a National Assembly, the fourteenth President of the Third Republic. In front of the great tapestry after Raphael, flanked by the symbolic statues of Concord and Security, Albert Lebrun presided over the cession.

Last year saw the beginning of a "back to the land" movement, W.P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern Railway, said, in his report for 1931. This was the first annual report signed by Mr. Kenney who was formerly the company's vice president and director of traffic, and who succeeded Ralph Budd as president on Jan. 1, when Mr. Budd became president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad.

ALTHOUGH Paramount has made an interesting and handsome picture of "The World and the Flesh," the subject-matter -- that of the attempted escape from Russia of a group of aristocrats -- deserved something more real in treatment.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 14 (AP). -- By piling up 59 1/4 points in the first ten events, Manhattan College, favored in advance predictions, today won the annual Middle Atlantic States conference track and field championship meet.

The centennial of the opening of Lafayette College at Easton, Pa., will be celebrated this week with a program starting on Tuesday. Be- ginning in May, 1832, with three teachers and forty-three students, it now has a faculty of ninety-five and a student body of 1,000, the maximum limit set by the board of trustees.

Domestic corporation bonds were depressed on the Stock Exchange yesterday, many issues touching new lows. Foreign loans were irregularly lower, while United States Government long-term bonds made small gains on the average. Trading was active for a Saturday, amounting to $6,091,600 in the two-hour trading period, compared with the previous Saturday's dealings of $5.600,000.

CHURCHILL, DOWNS, Ky., May 14. -- A mild surprise was sprung in the thirty-first running of the Bash- ford Manor Stakes, feature of an ex- cellent card today at Churchill Downs, when In High, racing for the Dixiana Stud of Charles Fischer, scored in a driving finish over C.C. Van Meter's Red Whisk.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Tapping an ancient gold-studded telegraph key at the White Rouse today, President Hoover sent forth a message marking the formal opening of a world-wide celebration of the in- vention of the telegraph by Samuel F.B. Morse 100 years ago.

THE story of how "Maggie: A Girl of the Streets" went begging for publication in 1892 has been made known by Thomas Beer in his brilliant biographical study of Stephen Crane, Henry Hazlitt, in his introduction, retells it here, devoting most of his space to a consideration of the position of "Maggie" in the history of American realism.

WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE, editor of The Emporia Gazette, was in town the other day, and in a clubhouse filled with gilt-framed paintings, he posed for a drawing. The dark wood trimmings, the carved mantels, the chandeliers originally intended for gas but now holding electric lights, the pictures -- all of these things recalled the period in which the house was built.

CONVENT STATION. N.J., May 14. -- Sayre MacLeod Jr., the club champion, won the Morris County Golf Club invitation tournament today by defeating Cyril Tolley, former British champion, 5 and 3, in the semi-finals this morning, and then beating Gene Homans, 2 and 1, in the final.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 14. -- Provisional President Getulio Vargas today ended the tension over a new Constitution for Brazil by issuing a decree calling for the election of a constitutional Assembly on May 3, 1933.

During the recent days of rain and unpleasant weather the Peconic Bay fishermen have been more or less marking time, waiting for the clouds to disappear. But a check of various boat captains indicated that today should be a banner one.

A home run by Jim Maloney in the eighth inning gave the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club baseball team a victory over the New York A.C. yesterday by 5 to 4 in a game that dedicated the Ditmars Memorial Field at the New Moon club's Huntingdon (L. I.) grounds.

FRANCO-GERMAN relations are the storm centre of European politics, and the attention of the world is anxiously fixed on the falling and the rising of the barometer in Paris and Berlin. Certainly, there is a certain amount of tension in the atmosphere, but still, if we look at the question from a very broad point of view, we must be convinced that for the time being there seems little immediate danger of an outburst.

Deposits in mutual saving's banks of New York State were reduced $31,828,369 in April, according to the monthly report of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. The decline, which was the largest of any month since November, 1929, was explained as bring due to the needs of depositors to draw upon their savings to meet living expenses.

GENEVA, May 13. -- Valuable as was Secretary of State Stimson's visit to Geneva, in the estimate of experienced observers here his return to the United States can be even more valuable. Here he gave to others a better understanding of the bedrock American view and therefore of what concessions they have to make if the arms conference is not to fail.

Five men charged with being members of a counterfeiting ring here were arraigned in Brooklyn yes- terday after having been arrested on Friday night by Alan G. Straight, Secret Service operative of the Treas- ury Department, who closed in on the suspects after trailing and watching them for nearly three months.

THE spectacle of a President and a Congress at odds and the sound of "words" sizzling between the White House and Capitol Hill are as much the rule as the exception when American political history is examined for parallels of the present dispute between President Hoover and Congress.

WE still speak of "the Ice Age" as if it belonged to the remote geological past. Geologists have reached the conclusion that there were several ice ages. What is more, the last Ice Age, known as the Quaternary, is only about half over, despite our blistering Summers.

THE tidal wave of uncertainty and fear, which endangered several national currencies and some banking institutions, originated in Austria, swept quickly through Hungary and Germany, and after devastating these areas flowed onward to Britain and the Scandinavian countries, backwashing into the United States, and carried unusual demands on the American gold supply and credit system.

Perhaps the most favorable thing that can be said about retail volume at the present time is that the percentage of volume drop shows a tendency to decrease, according to the market report prepared especially for THE Trams by Kirby, Block Fischer.

When, however, it comes to discussing what these things mean and how to attain them the new school must claim a philosophy and technique of its own.

LIMA, May 14. -- The Central Reserve Bank of Peru today gave up its thirteen-month struggle to keep Peru on a gold basis, and the directorate suspended the sale of sterling and dollar drafts. Sterling, which was selling at 13.30 soles on Friday, went to 18 this morning and the dollar was quoted at 6 soles today, compared with 3.60 on Friday.

As one looks about on all sides one sees men and women with great potential strength, men and women with both ideas and vision, who are totally incapable of concentrating their strength in any particular way toward solving the difficulties confronting us as a na- tion.

HAVANA, May 10. -- There will be no increase in the membership of the House of Representatives at the November elections and the bill pending in Congress for creation of thirteen additional seats, one for each 25,000 increase in population as shown by the recent census, automatically became a dead issue when the electoral period opened.
GEORGE ARLISS brought six manuscripts with him from Hollywood and he has taken them with him to Europe to read and mull over during his Summer vacation.

THERE is hardly anything as tonishing in the fact that until now Louis Adolphe Thiers had not attracted the attention of biographers in English-speaking countries. His prosaic, "bourgeois" personality cannot arouse the interest of those who want history to supply them with striking, adventurous and dramatic men and careers.

PARIS, May 8. -- All Paris, in the very mundane or Tout-Paris sense of the term, turned out for the marriage May 5 of Mile. Diane de Rothschild, daughter of Baron and Baronne Robert de Rothschild, and M. Anatole Muhlstein, Minister Plenipotentiary and Chancellor of the Polish Embassy here.

EXCEPT for the indirect manner of its telling, and the grim, matter-of-fact quality of Burke MacArthur's prose. "Rivers Into Wilderness" might have seemed an almost wantonly cruel story. The descriptions of life on a barren homestead in central Washington are incredibly harsh, but they are set down without bitterness, as they present themselves to the eyes of a healthy and incurious small boy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read Dean Harold Butler's letter concerning Mr. Damrosch's public recommendation of two Summer schools, and I have read Mr. Damrosch's reply. The reply indicates that Dean Butler was right when he said that it is possible Mr. Damrosch "knows nothing of what is going on in the rest of the country."

Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., tenth and thirteenth, respectively, in the national ranking, reached the final round of the North Side championship yesterday at the University Heights Tennis Club on Harlem River Terrace north of Fordham Road.

New York went on record yesterday as being in favor of additional taxation. It said so on banners and streamers, on signs painted along the sides of trucks, on small buttons that superseded gardenias in frockcoat lapels. This taxation would balance the budget, put men to work, start moving the rusted wheels of industry and remove the rackets from the social side of life.

Karl Freund's collection of art for gardens and interiors is to go on sale Saturday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. Annually Mr. Freund produces a rare combination of art suitable for outdoor decoration and also for interior use.

Steady improvements in merchandising methods accompanied the 27 per cent growth in the number of voluntary grocery chains last year, according to executives of the American Institute of Food Distribution, who completed their third annual survey of voluntary chain distribution last week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published recently a letter written by "Winter Southerner" in which an attempt is made to describe Southern shortenin' bread.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP). -- The Athletics won their third straight victory and Lefty Grove his second successive shut-out today when they blanked the St. Louis Browns. 3 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When political schemes are in discordance with the conditions of geographic environment, troubles of many sorts are pretty certain to follow. The case of the Danube States is an example.

PARIS. EVERY one knows what an important part Henrl Bergson has played in the development of philosophic thought during the past forty years. He has been the centre of a vigorous reaction against an excessive intellectualism; he has shown that life ran hardly be explained in terms of mechanism; he has discovered the "immediate data of consciousness."

WAKEFIELD, Va., May 14 (AP). -- The lands and buildings of Wake- field, birthplace of George Washing- ton, were given into the custody of the Federal Government today by the Wakefield National Memorial As- sociation.

PHILIP DORMER STANHOPE. 4th Earl of Chesterfield. 1694-1773, wrote in the course of his long life several thousand letters. Now 2,600 letters are printed, of which some 1,400 have not had previous publication; many hitherto printed were expurgated, and here, for the first time, are given as written.

The dredging of Coney Island Creek to a depth of twelve feet, with a bottom width of 125 feet would result in a saving of $30,000 annually and add more than 100,000 tons annually to the commerce moving along its course, according to the Port Authority.

THERE was a day when New York was depended upon to supply the bulk of the ethereal entertainment. It was radio's reservoir. But not so today. No longer does the show centre entirely around Manhattan Island. The performers may wander all over the country on vaudeville tours and broadcast on their usual schedules with no evidence to the listener that they have strayed away from the New York studio.

CHICAGO, May 13. TO the theatre that he used to own and operate -- the Grand Opera House, then the Four Cohans -- came George M. Cohan this week in the latest product of his industrious pen, a comedy called "Confidential Service."

Top Flight, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitncy's 3-year-old filly by Dis Donc -- Flyatit, captured the second running of the Acorn Stakes at Bel- mont Park yesterday and was acclaimed by an enthusiastic gathering of 15,000, the greatest crowd of the local racing season.

VIENNA, May 13. -- Admission that Austria, if she obtains a new foreign loan, must immediately declare a transfer moratorium; imposition of import embargos by Hungary after the example already set by Greece, Bulgaria and Austria, and an intimation that Rumania is considering a disguised form of inflation are among the developments of the week in Central Europe's steadily worsening financial and economic situation.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 12. -- After four hectic days on Daylight Saving Time this city is again observing Eastern Standard Time and is likely to continue to do so during this and many other Summers.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 14. -- Packer Memorial Church on the campus of Lehigh University was filled for the concluding session of the twenty-sixth Bach festival this afternoon when the mass in B minor was presented for the twenty-fifth time under the direction of Dr. J. Fred Wolle.
LONDON, May 13. -- With the American debt payment looming in the background, the British Government is preparing for further economies which may make the past year's savings appear insignificant.

BOSTON, May 12. -- Lieut. Gov. William S. Youngman did an unprecedented thing a fortnight ago. In the absence of Governor Ely from the State at the Governors' Conference he sent a special message to the Legislature. The Governor is going to be the Democratic candidate for a second term.

When the Cornell varsity eight rows in its first regatta of the season Saturday at Ithaca, meeting Yale and Princeton for the Carnegie Cup, it will be riding in a new Pocock shell, christened "Uncle Pete." This is in honor of Albert W. Smith, Cornell '78, Emeritus Professor and former dean of the Sibley College of Engineering.

RUTH CHATTERTON, making a mid-May appearance on Broadway as the star of "The Rich Are Always With Us," was born in New York and spent her childhood in Fordham Heights as the young mistress of a large estate with acres of gardens and forest lands for her playground.
With the Reparation Conference of Lausanne one month off, indications are multiplying that its effects for good or bad will be enormous.

RADIO broadcasting in Canada is to be entirely reorganized if a plan proposed by a special committee of the Canadian House of Commons is adopted by Parliament. Broadcasting will be conducted by the government. There will be no haphazard growth of radio north of the Great Lakes.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- A big eighth-inning rally gave the Washington Senators a 6-to-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers today and a clean sweep of the series.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, was expected yesterday to try next week to show a connection between Mayor Walker and the $1,000,000 stock transactions of his missing business agent, Russell T. Sherwood.

LONDON. IS the opening of the new Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon a matter of literary or of dramatic news? The occasion is being celebrated, of course, by a series of performances on the stage of the building now completed, but the speeches at the actual opening honored the poet who is read no less than the playwright who is acted.

LONDON, May 7. -- Rejecting the classic theory of the gold standard." under which the supply of money automatically adjusted itself to the international exchange of commodities, as having ceased to exist under modern conditions. Professor Gustav Cassel, delivering today the first of the three Rhodes lectures for this year at Oxford, said the gold standard of the future would always be a "controlled" or "managed" standard, a standard subject to deliberate influence.

THE recent mention here or two Mozart Masses and Haydn's "Seven Last Words" was made without any particular reference to the season. It was merely a coincidence that they appeared when they did, during a month in which, as reference to back files proves, we regularly receive a number of enquiries as to music of this variety.

THE most disgraceful page in American history is the one written after the Civil War. It was then that the conquerors misruled the conquered and that the effects of their misrule extended far beyond government into every phase of life.

By the midsummer of 1933 it was obvious that we were riding a new wave of prosperity. The change did not come about of itself. It was the result of a single line of policy boldly conceived and sternly executed.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP). -- Bill Urbanski's home run with one man on base in the ninth inning today gave the Boston Braves a 7-to-6 victory over the Cubs and a 2-1 edge in the series.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 14 (Canadian Press). -- Total trade of Canada in April was $28,613,779 less than in the same month of 1931, the Department of National Revenue reported today. A year ago the trade had a value of $85,863,487 for the month, against $57249,708 for last month.

ATHENS, May 14. -- The British Minister to Greece sent a note today to Foreign Minister Michalakopulos requesting the resumption of service on Greece's foreign debt. The impression in official circles is that the protest will have no effect, since Greece actually does not possess enough foreign exchange to continue the payments.

MILAN, April 24, 1932. THE revival at La Scala, twenty-three years after the local premiere, of "Elektra" was chiefly notable for the engrossing portrayal of the title role by Giulia Tess, despite vocal indisposition. Her voice is not above average, but her histrionism is unusual, and she achieves a high-keyed projection of every part she essays.

MANILA, April 13. -- The proposal that in the interests of economy the cost of maintaining the Philippine Scouts be transferred to the Philippine Government evoked an interesting response in Manila. For the first three days after the news was received it was impossible to get any responsible comment.

COLLECTORS of illuminated manuscripts today owe a debt first of all to the scribes and illuminators who labored with such patient skill to produce those inimitable examples of medieval art and secondly to those members of royalty and nobility who showed the good taste to acquire them and preserve them from destruction.

Practical workers in the field of child delinquency would agree that this section of the Children's Charter, in less than fifty words, states their ideal objectives. It is not a descrip- tion of what they have achieved, but what they ought to achieve. Scien- tists and teachers dealing with handicapped children would claim this goal worthy of their best efforts.

MR. DESMOND MacCARTHY, well known in England as a gracious commentator on books and men, has reached a point of time. It is that pinnacle from which the veteran critic of life and letters looks back over the long road of his past and observes what he has left behind him in the way of humble mile-posts and greater mile-stones.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A vote in the House on the O'Connor-Hull "beer bills" was assured today when the required 145 signatures were obtained to a petition to discharge the Ways and Means Committee from further consideration. The vote will be taken May 23.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14. -- Princeton today made its first appearance on the Soldiers Field diamond since 1926 and lost to the Harvard nine, 8 to 1. Charley Devens fanned fifteen Tigers, to run his total of strike-outs to seventy-two in his last six games.

Mrs. Reginald C. Hargreaves, the original "Alice in Wonderland," sailed for England yesterday in the Cunarder Aquitania accompanied by her younger sister, Miss Rhoda Liddell. Her son, Captain Caryl Hargreaves, who came over with his mother, remained here. He went to the pier to see her away.

Forgery of an entry in the minute books of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, was charged yesterday by John Hol- ley Clark Jr. at an examination be- fore trial in the case of fifteen union members who are seeking an ac- counting of $7,500,000 of the local's funds.

THE coal-diggers of the Appalachian mine fields are mountaineers by birth and miners by accident. They still remember the proper place to stick a hog and how to scald his bristles. The women sometimes go to the hills for a handful of herbs to brew tea for their sick.

TORONTO, Ont., May 14. -- In its annual report, covering operations in 1931, Pioneer Gold Mines of British Columbia shows bullion production of $725,000, compared with $350,000 for the year immediately preceding. Profit for the year, before providing for depletion and taxes, was $409,976.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 14. -- Motors with exhausts wide open popped today on the placid water of the Hudson River in preparation for the fifth annual motor-boat race tomorrow from here to New York.
PARIS, May 13. -- Three times within the past two weeks the French people have shown in a remarkable manner their common sense, calm and independent judgment.

With the slogan "Hunger Knows No Holiday." 3,500 industrial leaders, business and professional men, oreanized as the trade and industry division, will begin work tomorrow on the Salvation Army United Appeal for $1,090,000.

This week will brine primaries and conventions at which 142 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be elected. The lion's share of the large group to be chosen, the managers of Governor Roosevelt's pre-convention campaign managers believe, will be pledged or instructed for, or friendly to, Mr. Roosevelt's candidacy.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 14. -- The story of a baby ape which outstripped in ability to learn a human child of the same age was told here today by Dr. W.N. Kellogg, Professor of Experimental Psychology at Indiana University, before the annual meeting of the Mid-Western Psychological Association.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 14. -- A woman who had become convinced that she was near death from a lingering illness was carried into the Supreme Court here today for the fulfillment of her desire to die as an American citizen. Against the wishes of her husband she had insisted upon rising from bed to attend the Naturalization Court.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Spurred by the order of President Hoover to press unremittingly the hunt for the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby until the criminals are brought to justice, and by the knowledge that Colonel Lindbergh's original solicitude for square dealing with the kidnappers no longer is a deterrent, the agencies of the Federal Government today proceeded vigorously with their efforts to find the guilty persons.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 14. -- Army won from West Virginia on the track today by 89 1/2 to 37 1/2. Epler, basketball star, was a double winner for the cadets, taking both the low and high hurdles in fast time. The spun's went to Fraser of the Mountaineers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- An appeal for a "more effective" system of Jewish education, if the Jewish population of the country "is to form a community and not a herd," was made by Albert P. Schoolman, director of the Central Jewish Institute, New York, in an address here tonight at the opening of the convention of the National Council of Jewish Education, of which he is president.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 14 (AP). -- The Newark Bears tightened their grip on first place in the International League race by taking both games of a double-header from Rochester today. The Bears annexed the decision in the opener by 8 to 2 and came back to blank the Red Wings, 4 to 0, in the nightcap.

Many important interscholastic track and field meets, in all sections of the metropolitan district, are scheduled to be held on Saturday and when the entry lists are filled, the total number of entries is expected to be well abovet the 4,000 mark.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14. -- Johnny Broaca, Yale's sophomore pitching ace, let Cornell down with three hits today as the Elis triumphed, 4 to 1. By the victory Yale strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League.

PIER fires, such as the one which recently destroyed the Cunard Line pier at the foot of Thirteenth Street, offer New York's firemen some of their worst problems. Fires in sub-basements, lumber yards, ships' holds and warehouses all mean innumerable difficulties, but a bad pier fire -- and the Cunard blaze was one of the worst New York has seen -- ranks with any of them.

A UNIQUE Summer camp for boys who desire to combine aviation with supervised recreation was announced last week by C.S. (Casey) Jones, who will be in charge of the camp, which is to be located at the Curtiss-Wright Airport at Valley Stream.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Bearish sentiment was pronounced again in the wheat market today. There was illdisguised uneasiness on the Board of Trade over the government's financial policy and skepticism as to the sincerity of the politicians. About all the grain trade can see in the proposal to change business conditions is a new lot of taxes.

More than 600 persons, including many diplomatic representatives and military, civic and social leaders, attended a high mass of requiem yesterday for President Doumer of France at the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, in West Twenty-third Street.

LOS ANGELES, May 13. THE local season has reached what you might call its lowest ebb. At the moment exactly one of the seven more or less legitimate playhouses of the town boasts an attraction. That playhouse is Henry Duffy's El Capitan, which continues to flourish at a dollar and a half top, and the attraction is "The Alarm Clock," one of the late Avery Hopwood's less brilliant farces.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during April was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 367,280 bales of lint and 50,935 bales of linters, compared with 488,655 and 54,229 in March this year and 508,691 and 67,415 in April last year.

The need for experimentation in education was never so great in this country as at the present time. The primary concern of such experimentation should be, first of all, that of defining more clearly the social function of education in contemporary life, and, second, the development of materials of instruction and procedures that will make education and the school a more vital force in the life of the individual and in society.

The Association Against the Prohibition Amendment and its wet allies have a lively expectation of being able to add five legislators to the wet roster of the House of Representatives from this State in the Congressional elections this Autumn, including the two to be elected at large.

THE Spring opening of the garden is usually a garish affair. Fiery colors predominate. The daffodils blaze in their warm fashion, the forsythias carry on the sulphury motif and the tulips intensify the pyrotechnical gayety of the picture.

George H. Townsend, president of the American Power Boat Association, has appointed nine new members to the executive council, which has empowered the racing commission to suspend or place on probation speedboat drivers found guilty of unethical tactics in sanctioned races.
MOSCOW, May 13. -- The Soviets are beset by vexing external questions, but their own internal problems are more important and are the target of the full driving force of the Communist machine.

Organist and choirmaster at St. Agnes's Chapel, Trinity Parish, since the day it was opened at 121 West Ninety-first Street, Dr. G. Edward Stubbs celebrates today his fortieth anniversary in the post along with the fortieth anniversary of the church.

THE formal opening for the Summer season of the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria, on June 14, will be marked by an event known as the Starlight supper dance, to be given in aid of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. The dance takes its name from the outdoor effect made possible when the roof of the room is rolled back to reveal the sky.

THE formation a week ago at Chicago of the Air Reserve Association of the United States occasioned little comment. Yet the delegates to the organization convention came from every corner of the United States. Two representatives were sent from each one of the nine corps areas of the country and these representatives left their home districts after an intensive study of the program proposed for incorporation in the permanent constitution.

LIMA, Peru, May 2. -- The Peruvian Congress is now considering a measure which provides for the taxation of foreign colonies consisting of more than 7,000 persons, which may cause many Japanese and Chinese, who comprise the largest foreign groups here, to leave the country.

VOGUES in well papers follow closely the present fashions in furnishings. Recently decorated interiors suggesting the days of the early Republic or the Federal period-from the Revolution to about 1825 -- have brought into use new papers which form admirable backgrounds for Sheraton and Directoire furniture.

HAVANA, May 14. -- The law enact- ed by Congress Feb. 16 placing civil- ians charged with violations of the explosive law, such as bombings, illegal possession of explosives and other terroristic activities in the hands of military tribunals was de- clared unconstitutional this after- noon by the Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- De- spite a bad spill at a post and rail jump, Randy Duffy of Middleburg, Va., remounted Fugitive, owned by T.W. Durant of the Smithtown Hunt Club, L.I., and rode to victory to- day in the Foxhall Farms $5,000 challenge trophy.

DETROIT. MOTOR car manufacturers now are certain the seasonal pickup in business has arrived, and there is definitely a more cheerful tone. While May production and sales figures are not likely to resemble those of other years, they are at least going to represent a considerable improvement upon the depressing tabulations of the past four months.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- There was little improvement in business in most foreign markets covered in the weekly survey of conditions abroad made public today by the Commerce Department.

PARIS. DURING a busy session of the Chamber of Deputies some three years ago a distin- guished looking man quietly took his seat in the second row on the extreme Left. Premier Poin- care, who was making a speech at the time, stopped short, and, turn- ing to the newcomer, said: "You are very welcome here, Monsieur.
LONDON, May 14. -- Professor Gustav Cassel, the Swedish economist, delivered at Oxford today the second of this year's Rhodes memorial lectures on "The Crisis in the World's Monetary System."

OPPORTUNITY for estimating the curve toward modernism described by American art seldom arrives in a form sufficiently varied to call for anything like serious consideration. It is here now, however, in the person of the Whitney Museum's current exhibition, which, in the words of the catalogue preface, "epitomizes adequately the preceding exhibitions and reflects the character and scope of the permanent collection as a whole."

BUTLER, Pa., May 14 (AP). -- Mayor Charles H. Kline of Pittsburgh and his former Director of Supplies, Bertram L. Succop, were found guilty of malfeasance in office by a Butler County jury today, the Mayor on one count and the ousted supplies director on twenty-nine.
BOMBAY, May 14 (AP). -- Three persons were killed and seventy injured in Hindu-Moslem clashes which followed the beating of two Moslem boys by Hindus today.

IN the suffering and hardships of the years to come minds will turn from making money to the service of the State as a citizen. Remember that the main end of life is to develop into rich personality, lead a happy and interesting life -- and if you cannot lead a happy life, you can lead an interesting one and serve the State.

Mr. OWEN YOUNG seldom speaks without having something to say. In presenting last Thursday the gold medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences to Mr. GERARD SWOPE in recognition, among other things, of his "or"ganizing and safeguarding the social "welfare of thousands of employes," Mr. YOUNG dwelt upon the new conception of the duty of the managers of great industries.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 14. -- By a score of 10 -- 4, the Hill School base- ball team defeated the Lawrenceville School today. It being alumni day there was a large crowd on hand to witness the Blue and Gray athletes down their ancient rivals.

OMAHA, May 12. -- Recent events have set Nebraskans wondering what kind of cockeyed politics they are committed to, anyway. As matters now stand, the Republican party officially endorses the record of President Hoover and approves of Senator Norris, who does not approve of either President Hoover or his record.

The first formal meeting of the American bondholders who put $100,000,000 into Ivar Kreuger's International Match Corporation was held yesterday under the direction of Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, and a first tentative report of the developments of the bankruptcy which followed Kreuger's suicide was submitted by the Irving Trust Company as receiver.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 14. -- Mrs. Mary C. Holmes Royal, widow of Forrest Betton Royal, died here today at her home, 930 Madison Avenue, at the age of 71. A former resident of New York, during the World War she was president of the American Chocolate Fund, 4 West Fifty-seventh Street, which supplied gifts of chocolate to soldiers and sailors.

Fifteen homeless girl, penniless and desperate because the economy program of the Emergency Work Bureau had deprived them of their jobs, have applied in the last week or so to the Travelers Aid Society for help, according to Miss Virginia Murray, director.

Last week Mr. THOMAS, Secretary of State for the Dominions, gave notice that if the bill pending in Dail Eireann to remove the oath of allegiance becomes law, Great Britain will without negotiation deprive the Free State of its tariff preferences in the British market. It would be useless to negotiate agreements with those who repudiate agreements.

Asserting that the banking fraternity is in the most powerful position in its history to assist industry, Sidney H. Scheuer of Scheuer Co., cloth brokers and textile consultants, yesterday advocated the organization of clearing houses or Exchanges for various trades, which would "restrict price movements to the real facts of economic sanity."

Prodigious feats of memory are accomplished by the blind girls who play bridge regularly at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, who must feel their cards. The girls are banded together into a club of thirteen, the thirteenth to substitute in case another member is absent, and meet Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14. -- Expressing apprehension over the possibility of war involving one-third of the population of the world, as a result of overlapping claims of Japan and Russia in Manchuria, Senator Joseph T. Robinson urged here today the entry of the United States into the World Court, not only to safeguard its own interests but also to strengthen the cause of world peace.

HAVANA, May 14. -- Jack Crawford and Harry Hopman, Australia's first and second ranking tennis players, overwhelmed the Cuban combination of Gustavo Vollmer, national champion, and Ricardo Morales, the runner-up, in four hard-fought sets today, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, giving the Australian Davis Cup team a clean sweep in the three matches required in the Australia-Cuba Davis Cup eliminations.
WOOSTER, Ohio, May 14. -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover today donned a black academic robe and a gold-tasseled mortar board to receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters of Humanity.

LONDON, May 4. -- An attack on the Prince of Wales for encouraging a British trade exhibition in Copenhagen is the latest twist in Lord Beaverbrook's newspaper "crusade" for a British Empire tariff wall.

SHANGHAI, April 13. -- New attempts to attract large investments of foreign capital to China are to be made by the Central Government under a detailed plan worked out by the Ministry of Industry and just submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval.

THIS imaginative account of a European war which is supposed to break out in August, 1934, is strikingly different from anything of the sort which had been published. In the first place, he has demonstrated with of European politics and of human political nature.

Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, was assailed yesterday by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens for taking "an alarmist view" of the program of State parkway construction within the city limits on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Out of the tangled situation over Federal unemployment relief rose today a new House coalition, declared to have sufficient support to hold Congress in session until a non-partisan program, capable of correcting conditions, had been evolved.

JACQUES CARTIER was a hardy old sea-dog who sailed his top-heavy little galleon into some of the most inaccessible corners of the world. He could stand anything. Appalling hardship, mutiny among his crews, scurvy and Indian trouble only added zest to his five-year voyages.

PARIS. THE midseason collections manifest a tendency on the part of the Paris couturiers to create fashions that are wearable rather than those that are sartorial sensations. Each time the smaller collections are shown one is struck anew by the fact that they reflect, to a great extent, the taste of the couturiers' smart private clients.

ST. LOUIS, May 12. -- Spring is just around the corner and the Missouri Ozark region, which prides itself on being called the "land of a million smiles," is preparing to entertain the greatest number of tourists in its history. Paradoxically, it expects times to be better this season because of the depression.

IN a foreword to "Soviet River," Maxim Gorky places its author, Leonid Leonov, in the forefront of those who are continuing the task of Russian classical literature. Although it is too soon, he says, to grant Leonov fraternal kinship with Turgenev, Tolstoy or Dostoyevsky, yet the talent he has shown in the growth from his two preceding novels, "The Badgers" and "The Thief," to this one, indicates for him a brilliant future.

KENOSHA, Wis., May 14 (AP). -- Four men, armed with sub-machine guns, terrorized the village of Trevor, west of Kenosha, after cutting communication early this morning. They held up the Zmrzlys Hotel, herded guests into the lobby and tossed teargas bombs into the rooms before escaping with $400.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Not only are the Democrats shying from that part of the President's unemploy- ment relief program which would au- thorize the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make loans to private business; there is opposition to it among the Republicans, and among the directors of the corporation it- self.

KATE VIRGINIA COX was a young woman of 20, when in the Autumn of 1860 she went from her Virginia home to Georgia to visit relatives and plunged into the flaming spirit of the deep South where the desire to secede was rampant.

ATLANTA, May 12. -- A political drama is now unfolding in Georgia in connection with the selection of a successor to the late Senator William J. Harris, and unless some deus ex machina appears before the Democratic State primary on Sept. 14, on that day will be recorded the promotion of Representative Charles R. Crisp to the United States Senate.

LOW realty values and widespread unemployment make feasible the programming of considerable work over a long period to improve the aviation facilities of Greater New York and other large cities throughout the country.

THE Berkshires and the Litchfield Hills have been famous for years because of their scenic beauty, but there are many people who know little or nothing about their historic importance. No matter which route is selected for driving into these regions, the tourist who keeps his eyes alert will find many monuments, old houses and other reminders of stirring events of former years.

THE response of the public when the box windows of the Metropolitan Opera Company were opened for subscriptions for the season of 1932-33 must have been heartening to the leaders of that institution. There was a greater response than there has been for years on this annual occasion.
ALBANY, May 14. -- Wearing his famous brown derby and with a cigar tilted at a rakish angle, former Governor Smith visited the Capitol today and received an ovation.

THE large garden party in behalf of the Travelers Aid Society to be held on Friday afternoon at Planting Fields, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe in Oyster Bay, L.I., is attracting wideSpread attention. On that afternoon the entire grounds of the country place, comprising about 420 acres, will be open to visitors.
NEW YORK. The Albanian Minister, Faik Konitza, will give a dinner tonight at the Ritz-Carlton for Herman Bernstein, the American Minister to Albania.

DR. HOWARD W. HAGGARD, in his latest work on the history of modern medicine, has achieved a distinct advance over his fellows. The Yale physiologist, while recording the landmarks included in the books of contemporary writers on this fascinating subject, has digressed to a degree that should make his effort a more or less permanent memorial to the great international figures whom he delights to honor.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Joseph C. Grew, new Ambassador to Japan, has concluded a month of conferences on his duties and left tonight for San Francisco. He will sail on the liner President Coolidge Friday and is due at Yokohama on June 6. A veteran career diplomat, he was Ambassador to Turkey when appointed to succeed W. Cameron Forbes, who has resigned as Ambassador to Japan.

Since Great Britain's new and complicated protective tariff went into effect in March, subsequent British foreign trade returns have been studied in England with anxious interest. It became at once apparent, as was indeed inevitable, that imports from other countries had been cut down drastically.

ALTHOUGH slender in quality is the volume by Gertrude Bartlett which takes its title from her poem "The White Bird," this is more than compensated for by the extreme lyric quality which is everywhere present. Not only is Miss Bartlett sensitive in a marked degree to every lyric nuance, but these lights and shades are transferred to her printed page with a pastel delicacy.

THE boys' clubs of New York City, with, an enrolment of 50,000 and many prospective members, are aiming to keep up their activities, despite financial difficulties resulting from the depression. The problems of these clubs, as they affect the problems of society, were discussed at a dinner given recently under the auspices of the Metropolitan Group of Boys' Clubs of America.

The programs of the Goldman Band this Summer will include many special features as well as many works that have never been played by the band, Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor, announced yesterday. Many compositions have been composed or arranged specially for these concerts.

HANOVER, N.H., May 14. -- With four meet records being broken and one equaled, the Harvard track team won its eighth consecutive annual outdoor meeting with Dartmouth on Memorial Field today by 71 to 64. The meet was not decided until the final event, the pole vault, when Oscar Sutermeister, the Harvard star, placed first to establish his team's victory.

PINEVILLE, Ky., May 14. -- Met at the Bell County line by a delegation who informed them that their entrance into Pineville might result in bloodshed, representatives of the American Civil Liberties Union, which had sought to hold a public meeting here, were turned back today and returned to London, Ky.

The assertion made last week by Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, that New York City's great banks, almost without exception, took care of the credit requirements of their customers in an adequate way throughout the stringency of last Fall and Winter, was not allowed to pass unchallenged.

The reorganization plan of the Empire Public Service Corporation and sudsidiary and affiliated companies, prepared by a reorganization committee headed by Edward C. Delafield, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, provides for the elimination of several underlying holding companies.

Dr. John F. Condon, the Bronx lecturer who turned the $50,000 over to the band of extortioners in the Bronx on April 2 in Colonel Lindbergh's desperate and futile effort to regain his kidnapped child, declared flatly last night that he knew the name and appearance of the man with whom he dealt and "could pick him out of a thousand."
LONDON, May 14. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today for the Whitsuntide holiday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 14. -- Any Missouri postmaster who does not wish to "get out on the firing line" in support of President Hoover was invited today by W. Irving Glover, Second Assistant Postmaster General, to resign.

FEODOR IVANOVITCH CHALIAPIN doesn't attach much importance to recent discussions in music circles about the merits of the "rediscovered" original version of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," judging from what the great Russian basso said to a reporter of the Prager Presse "while in the Czechoslovak Capital recently for a concert.

GENES are to living cells what atoms are to ordinary matter. Both genes and atoms are so small that no microscope can ever be invented to magnify them to visibility, for the reason that ordinary light is too coarse. X-rays are much finer.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 14. -- By the length of a man's arm, Pennsylva- nia's varsity crew came back to the ranks of winners tonight, victor over Harvard in one of the greatest boat races ever rowed.

The Board of Estimate will be called upon this week to determine officially the status of Charles S. Hand, who resigned more than two months ago as a commissioner in the Sanitary Commission, but whose resignation is still unaccepted by Mayor Walker.

The probability that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will face the necessity of deciding before the Democratic National Convention whether he will remove Mayor Walker has become an important factor in the contest for the Democratic nomination for President, as recent developments in the Hofstadter Committee investigation have made it virtually certain that Samuel Seabury, its counsel, will prefer charges against the Mayor within the next three weeks.

PARIS, May 13. -- The French will have a new governmental policy as soon as the new Premier of the re- public considers it possible to invest his new Cabinet with authority. At home and abroad the question is being asked: What will be the character of this new regime and what effect will the change have upon foreign policy at a moment when France is playing such an important part in world affairs?
NEXT season will bring no changes to the personnel of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, according to Arthur Judson, manager. Autumn will find all the men in their accustomed places.

CAPE TOWN, April 8. -- Two budgets have been submitted to the South African Parliament, one on general finances and the other on railways. The first attracted the most attention from the public, yet from the viewpoint of typical African news, and therefore of most interest to the outside world, the second was the more significant.

THE well-known enthusiasm of Milton Aborn for Gilbert and Sullivan (at popular prices) is about to take a new direction, involved as he is in plans for the immediate presentation, of a play with music entitled "The Savoyards" -- score by Sir Arthur, lyrics by Mr. Gilbert and book by Willson Whitman, a woman whose writings have not previously heeded the stage.

IT is smart to be economical these days. The fashion market seems to be responding to the demands of those who have worked out a modest budget and who propose to stay within its limits. There are any number of desirable frocks, in good taste and of excellent materials, which come in the "good value" class.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, May 11.- Another attempt is to be made to give Porto Rico a new election law before next November, according to announcement that comes from Washington which quotes Governor James R. Beverley as saying he would veto the law passed by the recent Legislature and call a special session on his return to the island.

The statistical position of the oil industry improved moderately in March, according to an analysis prepared by William J. Kemnitzer from data supplied by the United States Bureau of Mines. Additions were made to crude oil stocks, but "not to an alarming degree," he says, while additions to gasoline stocks were the smallest for this month in more than ten years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In tracing the etymology of the Sinaitic goddess Serabit, Professor E. P. Horrowitz assures us that "Moses in his occasional relapses from monotheism was a devotee of the heathen woman Serabit."
