This statement, as far as I am aware, is unsupported by any biblical passage or anything deduced from the Bible.
TORONTO, May 14 (AP). -- Toronto and Jersey City broke even in a double-header today, the visitors taking the first game, 5 to 4, and the Maple Leafs the second, 2 to 0.

TOKYO, May 14. -- Japan is increasingly doubtful whether the policy of the powers in standing aside to give the Chinese Government full freedom to consolidate its position and create stable conditions, as called for in the Nine-Power treaty, can survive in the face of what is described as growing anarchy in China.

LONDON, April 29. -- St. Marylebone in London is one of the few remaining "pocket boroughs" of the Conservative party. The constituency has never varied in its allegiance, and it always sent to Parliament the candidate designated by the central authority -- that is, some deserving politician or expert whom the bigwigs of the party desired to see in the House of Commons.

FOR American readers the story of La Salle should have peculiar interest, because his explorations and discoveries have been of the highest consequence to them and because the tale is one of twenty years of almost incessant adventures, the greatest daring, indomitable spirit, adversities innumerable, perils and risks, resourcefulness, courage and fortitude.

TODAY. 10:00 A.M. -- WEAF -- Two hundred and fifty pupils of New York's schools who are members of the Inter-High School German Glee Club offer a program of German folksongs for listeners in this country and Germany.

GLENWAY WESCOTT has written a book of essays in the tradition of Montaigne; its epigraph might well have been "Que scais-je?" As a modern commentary, born of the uncertainty of the post-Versailles world, it bears a close relationship to Kenneth Burke's "Counter-Statement," for it is tentative, corrosive, skeptical of the "seasoned stocks and bonds of set beliefs" -- in brief, a "humanization" of Mr. Wescott "in the state of doubt."
LONDON. ANDREW W. MELLON'S com- ing from the Treasury in Washington to be Ambas- sador to the Court of St. James's has stirred something very like hope in the heart of the British taxpayer.

NEW YORK, with most of its trolley and elevated lines losing money, its operating sub- ways crowded and its newest one lying idle, is struggling to solve another of its transportation problems -- the bus situation. In the past week the Board of Estimate has been concerned with two matters in the tangled affair.

Over the course of the Century Country Club at Purchase, N.Y., on Thursday, one of the interesting golf tourneys of the early season will be held as a preliminary to the women's metropolitan championship.

PARIS, April 25. OF ALL the theatres of Paris, except the Comedie-Francaise, the Varietes has perhaps the most firmly established tradition. That tradition, in its present form, is not so very old, although the house was built a century and a quarter ago and has been almost continuously successful ever since.

The "most-favored-nation" treatment on which this country's tariff relations with other nations is based has proved a decided failure, George F. Bauer, chairman of the World Trade League, said here yesterday. In a statement issued from the league's headquarters Mr. Bauer took issue with the sentiments expressed by President Hoover in the latter's message vetoing the Democratic tariff measure, which provided for negotiation of reciprocal tariff treaties with other countries.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The possibility of stabilizing large ships by means of a new type thyratron control equipment, utilizing vacuum tubes and a small gyroscope, was demonstrated here tonight by Dr. E. F.W. Alexanderson, consulting engineer of the General Electric Company, at a dinner of the American Society of Naval Engineers.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 14. -- Chapeau, owned by Captain A.M. Marshall of Goldens Bridge, NY., won the hunter championship at the second annual Lawridge horse show at the Lawridge estate today. The proceeds of the event went to the Greenwich Hospital and the United Hospital in Port Chester.

MEXICO CITY, May 14. -- The Mexican Government severed diplomatic relations with Peru today following a request by the Peruvian Government for the withdrawal of the Mexican Minister and his staff. The Lima Government asserted the Mexican diplomatic officials had intervened in the internal politics of Peru by supporting plans of communistic elements to disturb public order.

NEWARK, N.J., May 14. -- On a visit to the busiest air depot in the world, the Newark Metropolitan Airport, more than 500 members of the New York Electrical Society had an opportunity today to inspect the facilities of a modern air transport system, carrying passengers, mail and express from coast to coast on twenty-four and thirty-six hour schedules.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent Sunday's TIMES was an account of Mr. Gigli's severance of his contract with the Metropolitan Opera. The important fact of that announcement to the music-loving public, it seems to me, was not whether Mr. Gigli acted from sincerity or pique in refusing a cut in salary, which after all is his own business, but that his annual salary was revealed at $100,000 a year.

The proposal of the Bar Association that a judicial council be formed was endorsed yesterday by Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch of the Appellate Division. Justice Finch spoke at the luncheon and reception at the association building in West Forty-fourth Street, at which he, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals Cuthbert W. Pound and Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals Leonard C. Crouch were the guests of honor.

With Ken Auer, Fordham's bril- liant sophomore twirler, capably handling the pitching burden, his teammates slammed out twelve hits to record a 10 to 2 victory over New York University at Ohio Field yes- terday. Captain Bob McNamara was the Violet hurler.

Not alone in the Soviet and Fascist States is youth allowed the thrill of cooperating in government enterprises. Here at home in these more conservative United States high school boys and girls, as well as art school students, have recently been invited to lend their talents in beautifying official publications.

GENE TUNNEY is writing his autobiography, and we do not mean that he is having it written for him. His publishers, Houghton Mifflin Company, assure us that there will not be a line of ghost-writing in it. In Mr. Tunney's own words: "When my story is told, I will tell it myself.

LONG GEORGE KELLY is one of the real traveling men of the National League. He has been with the Giants, Reds, Pirates, Cubs and Robins. But Burleiegh Grimes tops him as a National League tourist. The Lord of Burlsigh has worn the uniform of the Giants, Pirates, Robins, Cardinals, Braves and Cubs. If he goes all the way round the loop they should give him the brass ring and the next ride free.

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute won second and third places in the javelin throw, the final event on the program, to defeat City College in a dual track meet at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The score was 64 2-3 to 61 1-3. Irving Weber of the Lavender won the javelin event with a mark of 146 feet 4 inches, but Sidney Unger and Fred Rhodes took the next two places to give their team a close victory.

THE eight convertible types of the Nash line are now on special presentation in dealers' showrooms in this city and throughout the country, it is announced. These convertibles include among their features flat folding tops and folding windshields, easily adjustable but permanently weather-tight when raised; door windows set in heavyduty chromium frames, and upholstery of hand-finished leather.

The New York Stock Exchange has been informed of a change made more than two years ago in the collateral securing the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation's twenty-five-year collateral trust 5 per cent gold bonds, due in 1953, it is set forth in the weekly bulletin of the Exchange issued yesterday.

PILOTS who fly the lighted airways sometimes say you can "feel the beam of a beacon before you can see it." This is explained by the fact that the outer portion of the pupil of the eye, next the retina, is more sensitive than that part of the pupil which transmits images to the optic nerve.

WITH the arrival of warm weather and Spring flowers, hundreds of persons are availing themselves of the opportunity for motor drives into the country to view some of the notable country estates which are being exhibited in the interests of philanthropy.

Although most factors were against the cotton market yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange held within an unusually narrow range and after touching low levels of the week, ended unchanged to a point lower than on Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- The Hill School track team scored 39 points to win the Princeton Univer- sity interscholastic field and track meet in Palmer Stadium today, beat- ing the Mercersburg Academy team by a scant half point.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The Senate moved slowly today toward the first major test on the $1,000,000,000 tax bill.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 14. -- Princeton's track team, which a week ago showed superiority over Harvard in the renewal of their rela- tions, came to New Haven today and defeated Yale even more decisively, 80 to 55. The victory of the Tigers was the first registered against the Elis since 1925.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP). -- Ten young men and two girls were arrested today when mounted police waged a brief battle with a group of about sixty marchers who attempted to parade in protest of the treatment of miners in Kentucky.

ALTHOUGH various promotions have stirred up more business here and there in retail trade, the net result, according to reports, has not changed the volume level much. The public is shopping very carefully and comparing values to a greater extent. Women's apparel and accessories continued during the week to attract the best demand.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently the Japanese assertion that Manchuria was essential to Japan as a source not only of raw materials but also of food has been challenged in the American press. In part this confusion comes from saying that Manchuria is necessary only for coal, iron and bean cakes, since these three commodities swell the volume of Manchurian exports to Japan.

A FAITHFUL, reproduction in miniature of a beautiful bit of the land of Nippon is to be found in the Japanese Garden of the Brooklyn Botanical Garden. In May the garden is at its best. Myriads of cherry blossoms, flowering crabapples, azaleas and magnolias in shades from white to deepest rose, fragile against the bare rocks and the deep green of the hillsides, mirror their reflections in the lake.
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM -- Exhibition of costumes (1750-1850) in" Room D6. Opened May 9, continuing through June 19. Reviewed May 10. See further reference on this page.

To the Dramatic Editor: I was amazed when I read Anita Grannis's article in your paper of March 27. There is a decided "theatre crisis" in Prague. There is no "indefinable air of prosperous activity hovering about Prague's playhouses, and especially about the State subsidized ones."

Secretary of State Henry L. Stim- son returned last night from Europe aboard the Cosulich liner Vulcania, and though admitting that he was not "optimistic" over the outcome of the Disarmament Conference, said that he was "hopeful."
IN the third year of a depression which no nation in the world has managed to escape we are witnessing in this country a fresh effort to break the vicious circle of declining prices.

Several clergymen will discuss today Mayor Walker's "beer-parade" of yesterday. Today is "Peace Sunday" and this is Peace Week. This will be a day of special collections. In Protestant Episcopal churches there will be read the pastoral letter recently issued by the House of Bishops in session at Garden City, and an offering will be taken to make up the $400,000 deficit for the year of the National Council of that communion.

THE following communication has just been received from the Museum of Modern Art: "A number of painters and photographers not represented in the current mural show were invited to exhibit but were unable to accept the museum's invitation.

LONDON, May 14 (Canadian Press). -- British weekly reviews today were inclined to deprecate the attitude of J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, in which he warned the Irish Free State that passage of the Republican Government's bill to abolish the oath of allegiance to the British crown would mean Great Britain could no longer enter agreements with the Free State.

AN unusual outdoor festival will be held throughout the day of June 17 at the Lido Country Club in the interests of the Social Service Bureau of Bellevue Hospital. Features of the entertainment will be a sports gymkhana and a water carnival.

LEOPOLDSHALL, Saxony, May 2. -- Working unobstrusively, the research laboratory of the Vereinigte Chemische Fabriken, the consolidated chemical works, owned by the State of Prussia, has discovered a process of extracting gallium so revolutionary that it may reduce the selling price from 175 to 10 marks a gram.

THE French electorate has spoken. The sovereign voters in the third of Europe's great democracies have voiced their decision on the personnel of their new Parliament. Even though the shift from Right to Left was marked, their verdict is ncne too clear.

STERLING BROWN, whose poems in "Southern Road" are chiefly portrayals of Negro characters, belongs in what James Weldon Johnson of Fiske University terms the "younger group" of Negro poets. Of this group in general Mr. Johnson goes on to say.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Follow- ing is the partial report submitted to the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures by its sub- committee:

IT is a strangely assorted pair who stand side by aide in the frontispiece of this book. They are physically incongruous in height and build, their countenances reveal mentalities and temperaments so unlike that one wonders how any sympathetic understanding could ever have existed between them, and the story the book unfolds shows them to have been as unlike as they look.

The week ended yesterday with no change in the markets from their trend of preceding days. Stocks drifted fractionally lower. Bonds as a rule lost ground irregularly, though with a few advances. Foreign exchange rates held firm, and some belated gold consignments went out to Holland and Switzerland.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 14. -- Pushing in a run after two were out in the ninth. Seton Hall defeated C.C.N.Y. today, 2 -- 1. Nippy Joyce Seton Hall's star pitcher, who had played left field until the ninth, singled, stole second and came home on Keller's scratch infield hit.

Columbia's varsity crew came back from two previous defeats yesterday to topple the New York Athletic Club oarsmen by six lengths on the Harlem River. Going over the one and one-half-mile course the Blue and White aggregation took the lead after the first 100 yards and sped down the river in 7:28, while the Winged Foot crew was timed at 7:33.

FOUR years ago Mr. Beals accomplished an exploit in journalism that for sheer daring, dogged courage and willing submission to protracted danger and hardship has had no parallel since a venturesome correspondent risked his neck to interview Abd-el-Krim in the Riff.

DODGE CITY, Kan., May 12. -- Public interest in prohibition in Kansas has taken a referendum turn since William Allen White's proposed method for a vote on prohibition has been sympathetically received by conservative drys as well as wets.

PLANS for the Inaugural Ball to be given on May 24 by the New York City George Washington Bicentennial Commission have assumed a more formal aspect since it was decided recently that the event should be held in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria instead of in Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, May 12. -- The last midseason collections confirm the trends already signaled. Vionnet's mode remains unchanged save for reduced coat fullness. Her rust wool sports coat with a while knitted yoke that ends in a tie scarf it a knockout.

AN ambitious and nationally comprehensive program of highway construction is embodied in a bill introduced into Congress last month by Representative W.L. Tierney of Connecticut. It calls for the building of 14,300 miles of "wide, smooth and level trunk-line highways" graded to a width of 500 feet "with ample space at all points for the "landing of aircraft" and in the centre a concrete roadway 200 feet wide with ten traffic lanes in each direction.

MEXICO CITY, May 14 (AP). -- Rafael Iturriaga, former Secretary of the Interior and Navy in Cuba, testified on a witness stand here last night that President Gerardo Ma- chado of Cuba had sent gunmen to Mexico to slay Julio Antonio Mella in 1929.

WHEN such a book is published as "Arabia Felix," by the English explorer, Bertram Thomas, or, as now, "Across the Gobi Desert," by the Swedish explorer, Sven Hedin, the feeling of a reader surely is akin to that of one who heard Marco Polo, returned from his travels, or Francis Drake, ashore from the deck of the Golden Hind.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 14 (AP). -- The United Australian party, headed by Sir Stanley Argyle, appeared tonight to have defeated the Labor Government of Premier E.J. Hogan in Victoria as returns from sixty-five constituencies voting in today's general election became known.

TOKYO, May 14. -- Charlie Chaplin landed in Japan this morning and was received at Kobe and twelve hours later at Tokyo in a welcome greater than any potentate could expect. But if dictators, presidents and kings envy the sincerity and dimensions of his welcome they can appreciate its personal cost.
THE price of milk is down. Not for a decade has it been possible to buy in New York a bottle of what has been described as the perfect food for so small an outlay.
RADIO manufacturers are busy preparing for their eighth annual trade show and convention at Chicago. The date is May 23-26, which is about two weeks earlier than usual.

Vocational guidance is one of the latest additions to the routine of public schools. It grew out of the increasingly evident need of children for an expert assistance in the planning of and preparation for their vocations.

AT West Burlington, N.J., rises a curious structure which, has long puzzled the countryside and which may prove to be as historically important as the first steam-driven central electric station built by Edison just fifty years ago in Pearl Street, New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The problem of reparations has been "settled" repeatedly since the close of the World War. With each "settlement" the nations concerned have breathed a sigh of relief comparable only to that expressed by the same nations, and many more, on each occasion that they have outlawed war.

SHANGHAI, April 13. -- There has been a complete breakdown of governmental authority along the water ways in the vicinity of Shanghai since the fighting between the Japaness and Chinese armies ended in the first week in March. Along Soo chow Creek, within a few miles of the International Settlement and out side of the Japanese zone of occupa tion, there has been an unparalleled series of hold-ups and piracies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 14. -- With a rearranged team, several performers participating in new events, the Naval Academy track team defeated the University of Maryland today 89 2-3 to 361-3. Hardman of Navy, running in the two-mile race, lowered the Academy record by nearly twenty seconds.

BY special permission of the copyright owner" is a phrase long familiar to radio listeners. An increasing tendency has been noticed on the part of announcers and masters-of-ceremonies to trifle with the exact wording of the oft-repeated expression, to facetiously twist the phraseology or otherwise humorously comment on the announcement.

The Textile High School fencing team registered a 5-to-1 victory over the Boys High foilsmen in the Wash- ington Irving High School gymna- sium yesterday and strengthened its lead in the second annual city P.S. A.L. championship tournament as Abraham Lincoln High, previously undisputed holder of second place, was beaten in another of the eight tourney matches contested.

ALMOST ten years ago occurred the first event in a succession of happenings of which the publication of this "charter" is the latest, but not the last. An exploratory survey made in 1923-4 of the teaching of the social sciences reported it to be "in a state of chaos."

EVEN before he was officially called into the case Superintendent Wilson remarked that the man whose death was being investigated had too many names. Ronald Bittamore, who found the body, identified it as that of his uncle.

BUFFALO, May 12. -- A decision by Justice Thomas H. Noonan of the Supreme Court in an action here upsets the general practice throughout the State in the distribution of tax money between counties and towns. Direct taxes for towns, counties and State are collected in one bill.

The Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform will observe National Repeal Week this week in forty-one States and the District of Columbia by a vigorous campaign for members and money to fight for prohibition repeal during the Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended May 7 were above those of the preceding week but continued considerably below those of the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Guest conductors who will lead the Philadelphia Orchestra during its contemplated eight-week series of outdoor concerts in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, were announced today. Alexander Smallens, for the third season, has been named music director of the Summer concerts, which, under present plans, will open on June 28.

HANOVER, N.H., May 14. -- Columbia's baseball team enjoyed two big innings today which were enough to give the Lions a 12-4 victory over Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. In the third inning Columbia staged a four-3 hit rally off Arthur Boisseau, which included a home run with two on by McLoughlin, and tallied four runs.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals made it three straight from the Phillies by winning today's game, 7 to 6, in the final game of the series. Chuck Klein hit a home run for the Phillies' first score.

WASHINGTON. AN officer of the National Government's new credit agency, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was traveling in the Middle West when he met a friend from his home town. After some conversation the man asked, "Are you going to put through that loan for the bank at X?"

PARIS, May 15 -- Alongside Secretary Stimson's statement that he believed his visit to Geneva would aid him greatly in the effort to lead the United States to contribute effectively toward a happy result for the disarmament conference, Paris newspapers this evening print a speech made today at Dijon by Joseph Paul-Boncour which seems to indicate the new government may offer at least a change in the French disarmament policy.

Nine German youths, ranging in age from 18 to 26 years, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Berlin. They are members of the society known as "Wandervogel," or "wandering birds." Wilhelm Schmidt, in charge of the group, is 35 years old.

The Paris-Lyons-Mediterranean Railroad Company (Compagnie des Chemins de Fer de Paris a Lyon et a la Mediterranee), through its fiscal agents, Kuhn, Loeb Co., announced yesterday its decision to redeem on Aug. 15 all of its 6 per cent external sinking-fund bonds, due on Aug. 15, 1958, offered here in 1922 in an amount of $40,000,000, of which $38,390,000 are now outstanding.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- A barrage of extra base hits in the closing innings gave Philadelphia an 8-to-6 victory over the Cubs in the series opener today, and accounted for Lon Warneke's first defeat of the season. Klein, Hurst and Virgil Davis hit homers for the Phils, and Moore for the Cubs.

"We are unable to manage crime, and the recent sentencing of "our most prominent criminal on charges of income tax evasions, rather than on some more serious charges, should convince us of this astounding fact," the Rev. Francis Connor told more than 800 members and guests of the Vera Cruz Council, Knights of Columbus, assembled yesterday for their annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 15 -- Charges that intolerant racial discriminations were combining to drive the American Jew out of commerce and industry and to leave him facing a future of great uncertainty were made by Dr. I.M. Rubinow, international secretary of B'nai B'rith, before the annual convention of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service here today.
CHICAGO, May 15-- Talking motion, pictures are at the door of the college classroom.

NEW YORK. The Albanian Minister, Faik Konitza, gave a dinner last night at the Ritz-Carlton for Herman Bernstein, the American Minister to Albania. His other guests were the Director of the Near East Foundation and Mrs. Harold C. Jaquith, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Farwell, Dr. and Mrs. John H. Finley, Mrs. William Bourke Cockran and the Albanian Consul-General in Boston, George Prifti.

The Art of Delay. DICKENS'S Circumlocution Office was a miracle of speed compared with the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate when dealing with the World Court. Year after year, session of Congress after session of Congress, it goes on weaving a tangled web about the whole subject.

In the Children's Aid Society report on Negro children of New York the point is made that because the Negro must struggle upward against almost insurmountable handicaps it is our social duty to make some compensation to his children. It is "not a matter of likes or dislikes."

The economic depression is not the product of disordered government, stock depreciation or economic readjustment, but the result of a wrong mind-set which puts higher evaluations on the intrinsic than "Christ-consciousness," the Rev. Dr. William H. Woodfin, president of the College of Divine Metaphysics of Indianapolis, declared, in his sermon yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Apathy of trade leaders and the public toward grains and securities has brought about a condition that is new to most operators of the present day. Buying power seems to be small, although occasionally a large operator on the Board of Trade here will enter the wheat market and take 500,000 bushels or more, boosting prices sharply, and within a few days will close his trade.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 15. -- W.A. Clark 3d, 36 years old, and his pilot, Jack Lynch, 42, who taught Colonel Lindbergh to fly, met instant death north of here this afternoon when one of Mr. Clark's planes crashed in the foothills near Clemenceau.

Increased church attendance during the depression may be explained by the adage "The devil got sick, the devil a saint would be; the devil got well, the devil a saint was he," according to the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, who preached yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

The Lindbergh baby case, from its beginning to its tragic finale, is presented as the principal subject at the Broadway Trans-Lux Newsreel Theatre this week. Among the other twenty-seven items are scenes of the Blackwell Cup regatta, Olympic equestrians in practice.
PANAMA CITY, May 15 -- Two men were killed and nine were wounded in political clashes last night.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns, ancient jinx of Washington, opened a series today with a 1-to-0 victory, breaking a five-game winning streak for the enators.

Work for 100,000 men, of whom 75,000 already have been placed, will be the contribution of the railroads to the American Legion's campaign to restore 1,000,000 men to jobs, it was announced yesterday by Mark T. McKee, executive director of the Legion's National Employment Commission.

The Hofstadter legislative committee's investigation of the City Administration, conducted by Samuel Seabury, its counsel, will approach a climax this week by the presentation of testimony relating to financial transactions connected with Mayor Walker.

The opening of the eighth week of the campaign of the Block Community Organization this morning will find 72,000 block-aiders at work raising money to aid the unemployed. Returns from last week's sales of relief stamps are expected to show a new total of almost $1,500,000 in cash and pledges when reports are compiled on Thursday, it was said yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, 29 Broadway.

LONDON, May 13 -- Thursday's reduction in the London bank rate to the level which ruled a year ago has created a degree of excitement decidedly out of proportion to its importance. The movement had been fully expected and is regarded in the City merely as a step toward a still lower rate, which will give the country the fullest possible advantage of cheap money.

ALBANY, May 15 -- A reduced mortality rate among children under 10 years of age may result from the use of a taxoid that is "an effective agent in the control of diphtheria," Dr. Thomas Farran Jr., State Commissioner of Health, announced tonight.

The suffering of Jews in Poland was described last night by Dr. Aaron Singalowsky, of Berlin, vice president of the World Ort Verband, an organization formed for the economic advancement of Jews in Eastern Europe, speaking at a dinner in his honor given by the Peoples Ort Federation of America at the Hotel Commodore.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 15 -- Makers of semi-finished steel last week announced an advance of $2 a ton on sheet bars, making the price $28. The announcement, considerably in advance of the time when the increase is to take place, is interpreted as notice to non-integrated sheet mills which must purchase semi-finished requirements, to mark up their sheet prices accordingly.

NOW is the time to go down to the sea in ships. A life on the ocean wave, a home on the rolling deep; that's the ticket. Rumor has it that, due to the depression, they are practically giving away catboats, sloops, yawls, ketches and schooners at the shipyards. As soon as an unwary stranger approaches a shipyard they shove him aboard a boat, cast off and shout: "It's yours! Take it away, Barnacle Bill!"

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A demand that Attorney General Mitchell present to a grand jury "evidence herewith enclosed of perjury" by Deets Pickett of the Methodist Board of Temperance was made in a statement today by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts.

The closing rush of the Mayo Provincials fell short of its mark yesterday, and the All-New York defense team conquered the world's champions, 13 to 12, in a thrilling and hard-fought Gaelic football game at the Polo Grounds.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Business throughout the Middle West gives more evidence of slowly returning confidence by liberal sales of seasonal merchandise. Employment conditions are said to be slightly better. Building operations in Chicago continue restricted by union movements.

Preparations for special Decoration Day promotional events during the next two weeks created considerable activity in the wholesale markets here last week. Many orders for inexpensive dresses were reported, with cotton styles outstanding in the business placed.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 18 -- "Thus far Russia has not attempted to upset conditions within Manchuria, nor to foment disturbances here. We shall take no steps antagonistic toward the Soviet unless Russian agents meddle with internal affairs in Manchuria.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Bedell H. Harned entertained with a dinner in honor of Vincent G. Byers of Richmond, Va., editor of The Richmond Times-Dispatch, who is their guest. Mr. and Mrs. John Wheeler had Mr. and Mrs. Harned and Mr. Byers as their guests for luncheon.
BALTIMORE, May 15 -- Burgoo King, the great chestnut son of Bubbling Over, today reigned as 3-year-old king of the 1932 American racing season.

BUENOS AIRES, May 15 -- The total week's shipments of all grains was less than in the corresponding week in 1931, but the price of wheat was higher and firm. Flaxseed was in poor demand. Dealers in cereals say the official figures of the Ministry of Agriculture on the exportable surplus of corn are much below the actual supply of corn.

Samuel H. Hofstadter, Republican, chairman of the legislative investigating committee, and William Lathrop Love, Democrat, are the only New York City members of the State Senate who received the unqualified approval of the Committee on Legislation of the Citizens Union in its twenty-eighth annual report on the records of individual Senators, made public yesterday.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., May 15 -- The Spring air meet of the Long Island Aviation Country Club was held here today and was attended by about 500 persons. Among the notables present were Hugh Herndon Jr. and Clyde Pangborn, round-the-world fliers. Only one accident occurred and that was not serious.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- The White Sox pounded Wilcy Moore for nine hits and eight runs in the first two innings today and won the opening game of their four-game series with the Red Sox, 9 to 2. Bob Fothergull led the attack with three hits in four times at bat, one of them a homer with a team-mate on base.

Cass Canfield, president of the National Association of Book Publishers and of Harper Bros., writes in The Publishers' Weekly issued today, that both publishers and booksellers should keep in mind that "times will turn." "That is a very simple fact," he writes, "but as the depression has deepened most of us have tended to forget it.

MEXICO CITY, May 15 (AP) -- American and British investments totaling several hundred millions of dollars are jeopardized by the new "public utility law" of the State of Hidalgo, Jose Cruz y Celis, president of the National Mexican Chamber of Commerce, declared today.
NEW ORLEANS, May 15 -- Trading in the cotton contract market here last week was quieter than for several weeks. Traders showed more disposition to wait for definite action by Congress on the budget.

In an editorial in the May American Federationist attention is called to the fine spirit of wage earners during the depression. They certainly deserve applause for facing the most disturbing conditions with a firm resolution to meet their obligations and to help their fellows.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Only two important roll-calls were taken last week in the House and none in the Senate, all other legislative action having been by viva voce or rising vote.

TOKYO, Monday, May 16 (AP). -- The Premier of Japan, Ki Inukai, fell mortally wounded at dusk yesterday before the revolver fire of military terrorists. Simultaneously five buildings in Tokyo were bombed.

The initial step in an effort to obtain a full and public explanation of bonuses, said to aggregate more than $250,000, voted to Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of directors of the B.M.T. in 1928, 1929 and 1930 by his associates as compensation for time and services expended in promoting better relations between the company and the city administration in transit matters, was taken yesterday by the City Affairs Committee.
BOSTON, May 15 -- Preliminary steps have been taken to organize the "Free Church of America" by a commission appointed by the Unitarian and Universalist Fellowships, the commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Charges that a threatened boycott of "the American petroleum industry" and a prospect of the replacement of American production by foreign oil were involved in a meeting of some American and foreign oil companies scheduled to be held in New York this week were made today by Wirt Franklin, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America.

Franco-American fellowships, American Field Service fellowships -- both for study in France -- and appointments as assistant teachers in France for 1932-33 were announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education at 2 West Forty-fifth Street.

The United States liner Manhattan, largest commercial vessel ever built in an American shipyard, will sail from New York on Aug. 10 on her maiden voyage to Cobb, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg. Announcement of this second change of sailing date, originally set for June and then for October, was made yesterday by P. A.S. Franklin, chairman of the board of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operators of the line.

BELGRADE, May 15 -- The Paramount and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer offices here yesterday dismissed all employes in Yugoslavia, preparatory to closing down. It has been found impossible to comply with the conditions of the latest Yugoslav film law, the officials declared.

Those strange caricatures known as the "stage Frenchman," the "stage Englishman" and the "stage American" do a great deal of harm and actually keep nations from making an honest and serious effort to know and understand each other, in the opinion of Andre Maurois, noted French writer, who spoke yesterday from Paris over a National Broadcasting Company network under the auspices of the International Radio Forum.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- American foreign trade fell to the lowest level in two decades in the first quarter of this year, according to figures of the Department of Commerce.

Determination to fight any moves to cut the salaries of postal employes and resentment over appeals to their "patriotism" in the present economic crisis were expressed yesterday by speakers at the opening session of the thirteenth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Post Office Clerks, at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee probably will decide some time this week whether to report the Goldsborough bill to the Senate for a test vote. The measure, which directs the Federal Reserve Board to use its control over credit and currency to restore commodity prices to something like the 1926 level, was passed recently in the House under suspension of rules, by a vote of 289 to 60.

In getting and song the stage of the Chanin Theatre, where the Spring Folk Festival was presented yesterday afternoon and last night, rolled the centuries hack to the first articulate expressions of the race while a cast of 400 interpreted the folklore of ten nations with spontaneous gayety, grace and charm.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Factors underlying the Federal Reserve Board's action in authorizing the use of government securities to replace eligible commercial paper as collateral behind reserve note circulation, obtained today, showed that in every Federal Reserve district except Minneapolis, there was a material drop of commercial bills pledged with the reserve agents between April 13 and May 11.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- All indications are that the Winter wheat crop in the United States will be the smallest in fifteen years despite recent rains. Winter wheat is heading in a large part of the Southwest. The condition in Kansas is 75, the lowest that the trade has known in about twenty-five years.

The League of Nations Association is obtaining the views of dominant figures in American life on the role that can be played by international cooperation in terminating the world-wide economic depression and maintaining peace, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Democrats, to date, have named 806 of their 1,154 delegates to the Chicago national convention. The Republicans, having the same convention total this year, have selected 944.

One of the contributions of the women's division of the architects' emergency committee toward the relief of unemployed architects and draftsmen will be the garden party the afternoon of June 11 at the estate of Samuel Untermyer overlooking the Hudson River at Yonkers.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The United States needs more convalescent homes and an intelligent policy regarding them, Dr. E.H. Lewinski Corwin, executive secretary of the Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine, says in a report to the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, of which Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior, is chairman.

LONDON, May 13 -- Financial London feels that only very general conclusions can toe drawn from this week's statement of Great Britain's foreign trade in April. The decrease in the surplus of imports over exports from L30,750,000 in the same month of last year to approximately L13,750,000 this April was in itself undoubtedly encouraging.

As the Seabury investigation approaches a dramatic climax it can no longer be-said that the public is indifferent. During the last few days both curiosity and apprehension have been intensified. Everybody is eager to follow the disclosures day by day, and to discover how close home to the official head of the City Administration Judge SEABURY is able to bring the inquiry.

That certain air of aristocracy which hovered for so long around the Palace Theatre and made it a vaudeville actor's idea of a personal paradise was mildly jolted on Saturday when the last straight variety house in the country made its bow to one thing and another and joined the ranks of the four-a-day.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals suffered an 8-to-3 defeat at the hands of the Boston Braves today on the day when the pennant emblematic of St. Louis' victory over the Philadelphia Athletics last year was raised over Sportsman's Park.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (AP) -- Kazuo Edina, editor-in-chief of Hokubei Asahi, the Japanese Daily News, said today the assassins of Premier Inukai are young Fascists in the Japanese Army and Navy.

A report by the F.W. Dodge Corporation covering thirteen districts comprising the thirty-seven States east of the Rockies states that all but three showed higher construction contract totals in April than in March. The April contracts for the entire eastern area showed an 8 per cent gain over March in contrast with a loss of 9 per cent between the two corresponding months of 1931.

For the first time in many months there is a sign of improvement in North Atlantic steamship travel, according to David Lindsay, assistant passenger agent of the Roosevelt and I.M.M. lines, who has had nearly forty years' experience in shipping in this city.

Sunshine, warm weather and the lure of a day in May conspired with the calendar yesterday to draw thousands of New Yorkers to near-by beaches and open country for their Sabbath holiday. Straw hats appeared in large numbers. Hundreds of persons went in bathing at the Long Island and New Jersey shore resorts.

Resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment through constitutional conventions in the States is advocated in a "platform of American industry" for 1932, drawn by industrialists from all parts of the United States under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers and made public yesterday by John B. Edgerton, chairman of the board of the association and also chairman of the general platform committee.

Five men and a woman were responsible for the kidnapping of the baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh on the night of March 1 and his murder soon afterward, according to information believed to be in the hands of the New Jersey State Police.

Dr. Felix Adler, 80-year-old founder and senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street, declared yesterday morning that faulty moral ideas and not defective economic theories are primarily responsible for the ills besetting mankind.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 -- Election of officers of the eighteen upper-class eating clubs of Princeton University was completed here today and the results were announced by James G. Shennan of Hazelton, Pa., chairman of the interclub committee.

Water-colors, drawings and miscellanies by a group of five modern Europeans have just been put on exhibition in Marie Sterner's International Gallery, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street. This work, from the collection of Helena Rubinstein, will remain on view through May.

PARIS, May 15 -- Despite the decision to keep its star, Marcel Bernard, out of the play on account of the injury he suffered yesterday, the French junior team practically clinched the Franco-American tennis tournament in Roland Garros Stadium today.

William H. Todd, intimate friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith and president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, was fatally injured when he fell downstairs yesterday afternoon in the home of his son, J. Herbert Todd, at 109 Maple Street, Brooklyn, and died within a few minutes.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the Holy Child Convent have arranged a bridge party for next Saturday afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza in behalf of their scholarship fund. The proceeds will be used to aid young women to complete their education at Rosemont College, Rosemont, Pa., which is maintained by nuns of the Order of the Holy Child.

CINCINNATI, May 15 -- Greeted by a midsummer afternoon and a capacity crowd of 25,000, the Giants, after four days of idleness, unveiled all their latent power today to overthrow the Reds in the opening clash of a four-game series, 9 to 1. The result enabled the McGrawmen to supplant the Robins in sixth place, but the crowd derived no pleasure at all from the outcome.

Within a few feet of a crowd of several hundred persons, largely women and children, Motorcycle Patrolman George Neary dragged down a runaway horse shortly after noon yesterday, in front of the Park Avenue Baptist Church, Bennett Street, Port Richmond, S.I.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Proceedings to remove Edward B. McLean, publisher of The Washington Post, as co-trustee of his father's estate will go to trial here tomorrow in the District of Columbia Supreme Court, with Gaston B. Means, former government agent accused of embezzling $104,000 from Mrs. McLean, called as a defense witness.

WEST POINT, May 15 -- The United States Military Academy graduating class of 265 will be graduated June 10, it was announced today by Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent. The graduation exercises will be conducted at the Battle Monument, on Trophy Point.

BUFFALO, May 15 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons won the first game of the series with Jersey City today, 4 -- 0, Fred Fussell outpitching Morrell and Pipgras. Fussell held the visitors to seven scattered hits and did not give a base on balls. Carnegie and Werber hit homs runs for the winners and Werber played well on the defense.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for the first quarter of 1932, giving for the first time in a quarterly statement the balance sheet at the end of the period, shows that bank loans were re- duced from $43,600,000 to $37,100,000 in the first three months of the year, and again to $33,000,000 by May 12, 1932, without financing by the company.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Whitney and Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred L. Wright of Garden City, L.I., were the guests in honor of whom Mr. and Mrs. William B. Nisbet, whom they are visiting at Midmeadows, Great Barrington, gave a dinner tonight.

The New York A.C. baseball team scored a 5-to-1 triumph over Manhattan College at Travers Island yesterday, thereby avenging the 6-to-3 defeat by the collegians early in the season. Joe Sisko's home run in the second inning saved Manhattan from a shutout.

Eighteen paintings by contemporary American artists have been purchased by the National Academy of Design since January, 1931, through the Henry W. Ranger Fund, it was announced yesterday by Charles C. Curran, corresponding secretary of the academy.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A response to recently expressed opposition to the cash bonus for veterans by Archibald Roosevelt came today from Representative Patman of Texas in the charge that a shipping company with which Mr. Roosevelt was associated had, since 1930, "received a gift from the government amounting to $779,004."

PARIS, May 13 -- The monthly index number of Bourse prices shows the index for April to have been 250, compared with 274 in March and 346 in April, 1931. The averages for the whole market and for separate groups of securities compare as follows:

LONDON, May 13 -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades met a quiet trade at steady rates. Smoked sheet spot, May and June, sold 1 15-16d a pound buyers' July-September at second value, October-December at 2 1-16d buyers, January-March at 2 1/8d buyers, and April-June at 2 1/4d value.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- A five-run rally in the fifth inning, climaxed by Charlie Gehringer's seventh home run of the season, figured prominently in a 7-to-2 victory by the Tigers over the Athletics today.
ANGELS CAMP, Cal., May 15 (AP) -- Budweiser, sturdy Californian-bred frog, blinked both eyes today and proved that championship stuff will tell.

The Robins dropped in on 25,000 of the home folks at Ebbets Field yesterday long enough to be shut out by Steve Swetonic with two hits, while the Pirates collected six safeties off Joe Shaute, to triumph, 2 to 0.

PARIS, May 13 -- The index of wholesale prices in France at the end of April, as compiled by the Statistique Generate, stands at 424. This compares with 427 in March and with 494 in April, 1931. The retail price index is reckoned at 555, as against 558 in the preceding months and 628 a year ago.

BERLIN, May 13 -- The comment of the German financial press on the American outlook is unfavorable, but they apparently exaggerate greatly the importance of the Goldsborough and other inflationist schemes, which well-informed Berlin banking circles believe bave no chance of enactment.

About 12,000 boys between the ages of 10 and 20, shoulders squared, and, soldierlike, trying to suppress happy smiles at the sight of friends and relatives among the 50,000 persons who watched them march, paraded yesterday afternoon in Fifth Avenue in honor of the bicentennial of George Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Throughout the nation the people are in rebellion against tax burdens and unnecessary governmental expenditures. In towns, cities and States they are clamoring for economy in administration of public affairs.

Without discussing the merits of prohibition, John Haynes Holmes in his sermon yesterday before the Community Church congregation, meeting at Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, denounced Saturday's beer parade led by Mayor Walker as a "trick for diverting public attention from the waste and debauchery, the incompetence and corruption of our City Administraton."
LONDON, Monday, May 16 -- The assassination of the white-haired Premier of Japan, a small, kindly man, was particularly brutal, according to the Tokyo correspondent of The Daily Express.

Some "military reinforcement" of law may be required to rout the underworld that threatens to become the "overworld" of New York City, the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, of which he is the senior co-pastor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- A town nearly 6,000 years old, antedating even the royal tombs at Ur of the Chaldees, has been uncovered in northern Mesopotamia by a joint archaeological expedition from the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the American Schools of Oriental Research.

The murder of the Lindbergh baby by its kidnappers was regarded yesterday in many pulpits throughout the city as another evidence that present-day civilization is far from a success and as showing the need for a return to the church.
The Fulton Trust Co., as trustee of the will of William A. Belden, has extended to May 1, 1937, at 6 per cent, a mortgage for $25,000 held from Irma Lucchesi on 859 Levington Av.

LONDON, May 15 -- The Lausanne Conference, at which fourteen European nations have agreed to discuss reparations, war debts and "other economic and financial difficulties which are responsible for and may prolong the present world crisis," will open barely a month hence, yet what it will or can accomplish is more doubtful than it was when the meeting was first planned.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 15 (AP) -- As delegates assembled tonight for the State Democratic Convention here tomorrow, supporters of Governor Roosevelt, led by Governor Harry Woodning and Guy T. Helvering, State chairman, claimed sufficient strength to control the twenty votes of the State in the national convention.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 -- A barge of the Interstate Oil Company, carrying a cargo of 300,000 gallons of gasoline, which went aground on Absecon Bar a mile from this city, at 7 o'clock last night, was floated early today, little the worse for the mishap. During the night 150,000 gallons of the gasoline were pumped into the ocean.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Moses of New Hampshire, President pro tem of the Senate and one of President Hoover's advisers, tonight issued a sharp reply to Speaker Garner's criticism of the President.
The colorful ritual of a pontifical mass was celebrated by Cardinal Hayes in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in observation of pentecost Sunday.

The report of a survey of security distribution prepared by the research department of R.G. Dun Co., based upon information on stockholders' lists and bond holdings contributed by more than 400 corporations, the securities of which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange, says that although the period of widespread inflation ended in 1929, the common stock was as much the "king of securities" after the break as before.

The Goldaborough bill, which was recently passed in the House of Representatives, was condemned as a measure "so unsound as to be absurd, if it were not potentially so dangerous," in a report authorized yesterday by the executive committee of the Merchants' Association, of which Thomas J. Watson, president of the association, is chairman.
Premier Inukai was born in 1855 at Okayama, about eighty miles from Kobe. He was interested in politics from his early youth, starting in journalism.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- The public's interest in corn on the Board of Trade here is small and sales of cash grain by country holders last week were the lightest in nearly a month. Professional speculators, however, inclined to the buying side on all breaks, believing that corn at 30 cents a bushel or under in Chicago was low enough.

Two nation-wide campaigns for membership and funds for organizations opposed to prohibition open today. One is the National Reform Week drive of the Women's Organization for Prohibition Reform, which is seeking funds to oppose dry candidates at the November election and at the same time is attempting to raise its membership to 1,000,000.

The metropolitan outdoor polo season got under way yesterday when a crowd of 3,000 saw the First Division quartet of Fort Hamilton triumph over the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club team, 6 -- 2, at Fort Hamilton.

The city's streets are not clean, despite the expenditure -- $38,000,000 in 1931 -- for that purpose, the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness declared yesterday in an open letter to the City Administration.

Dr. KIMBALL of the meteorological service does not view the Atlantic flying season with equanimity. Ever since 1927, the year when so many brilliant flights to Europe were made to the glory and advantage of aviation, every pilot meditating another crossing consults him about the vagaries of the weather.

One veteran weakfisherman makes a few suggestions apropos of the season that is now under way at Peconic Bay. He recommends to those who may be venturing down Long Island for their only salt-water expedition this year to remember to play the rod against the fish.

Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, has purchased a Northrop all-metal, lowwinged monoplane capable of a speed of 230 miles an hour for his expedition of discovery in the Antarctic next year. The plane, which is an improvement on other Northrop types both as to speed and load-carrying ability, will be ready for its first flying tests next August.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The fatal attack on Premier Inukai of Japan was reported to the State Department today by Edwin L. Neville, the American Charge d'Affaires in Tokyo, who said the assailants had described themselves as members of the Young Officers' Association, which is opposed to weakness and corruption in government and to capitalism.
Popping under every ounce of energy in them, two motor boats swept across the finish, line only one second apart in yesterday's race down the Hudson from Albany.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 15 -- Thirty-three juniors at Colgate University were "tapped" by the senior societies Scull and Scroll and Gorgon's Head at the annual junior prom here Tuesday night.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Thursday's reduction in the Bank of England rate is not likely to affect the Reichsbank's discount policy. Under the bank law of 1924 the present 5 per cent rate is the lowest permissible to the Reichsbank so long as the gold, and exchange reserve stands below 40 per cent.

From the bewildering perplexity which, in the ordinary citizen's mind, surrounds the whole financial picture, the one simple and almost commonplace fact emerges -- that the pressing difficulties of the hour arise from the shrinkage in business earnings.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 15 -- Governor Roosevelt was informed today that a whispering campaign about his physical condition was being spread throughout the Middle West in an effort to head off his nomination by the Democrats of Chicago.

BOMBAY, May 15 -- The death toll mounted to thirty today and the casualty list to more than 370 as Hindus and Moslems met in sanguinary clashes throughout this city. The trouble started yesterday with the beating of two Moslem boys who had become embroiled with a Hindu shopkeeper.

TOKYO, Monday, May 16 -- Shortly before 5 o'clock this morning two gendarmerie corporals, two naval officers and a sergeant arrived by automobile at Nagatacho, the official residence of Premier Ki Inukai, opposite the newly constructed Diet building.

A plan of reorganization for Witherbee, Sherman Co., operators of iron mines and furnaces, providing for a reduction of the corporation's capital structure and indebtedness, was announced yesterday by a reorganization committee, headed by D. C. Borden.

An English residence of eight rooms in the Beechmont Woods section of New Rochelle has been bought by W. Scott Patjens from Helen M. Slick. The property was held at $30,000, according to Raymond D. Porter, broker in the deal, who also reported the sale of an eight-room house on Forest Avenue to Robert J. Rader for the Gripeca Realty Corporation.

TOKYO, Monday, May 16 -- Premier Ki Inukai, the 77-year-old head of the Seiyukai government in Japan, was shot by militaristic terrorists yesterday afternoon and died at 12:04 A.M. today. The assassination was the culmination of an amazing series of terroristic acts, including bombing of government buildings.

BELGRADE, May 15 -- When the Little Entente conference was concluded today a communique was issued which was whole-hearted in its condemnation of the tendency of the present-day economic system. No remedy was suggested, however.

Unanimous disapproval of the suggestion of Governor Roosevelt's Committee to Review Medical and Hospital Problems, appointed March 1. 1931, for the establishment of clinics under the direction of the State, is expressed in the annual report of the committee on medical economics of the Medical Society of the State of New York, published in the New York State Journal of Medicine, official organ of the State society.

The Parents' Day ceremonies, postponed last Sunday because of inclement weather, were celebrated yesterday in the Central Park Mall. About 10,000 persons, mostly children, joined in the festivities. Mayor Walker and others prominent in municipal and State affairs were gathered as attractions by Uncle Robert, the genial philanthropist.
S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AT SEA, May 15 -- The flight from Newark to Newfoundland was uneventful except for some poor visibility and rain.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15 -- Warning that "right now there is the greatest danger, far greater than we know, of the political debacle of the temperance movement," the men's council of the thirty-first quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church urged, in a statement adopted today, a crusade to hold the thirtten States needed to block repeal until the tide of public opinion can be turned against the opponents of prohibition.
Control of the Alvin Theatre in West Fifty-second Street has reverted from Alex. A. Aarons and Vinton Freedley to L. and A. Pincus and M.L. Goldstone, it was announced yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 15 -- Chapel services were interrupted at Georgian Court College here this morning when fire of uncertain origin broke out in Raymond Hall, a dormitory, and destroyed the building at an estimated loss of $100,000, including valuable chimes imported from England by the late George J. Gould, on whose former estate the college was established eight years ago.

Our Canadian friends are so much like ourselves in most respects, and in things political most of all, that it's a wonder we don't quarrel. As it is, even the tariff walls of protection which they were forced to build against us provoked no resentment against them and plenty against the fanatics of "the American system " at Washington.

Solicitation of funds in the Salvation Army's United Appeal for $1,090,000 to finance the organization's emergency relief and institutional activities will begin this morning, with more than 3,500 volunteers participating, backed by the Salvation Army's organization and supported by business, industrial, social, financial and civic leaders.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- On State and Federal court dockets throughout the country 24,642 prohibition cases were pending on April 30, as compared with 21,407 June 30, 1931, according to figures for the first ten months of the current fiscal year made public today by the Prohibition Bureau.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 15 -- Robert B. Meyer's Bobkat II was the winner of the second of a series of races among six-meter yachts held today by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. The race, in which six craft took part, was sailed over a windward and leeward course from Parsonage Point to Prospect Point buoy and return, a distance of about eight miles.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Hoover conferred tonight with Secretary Mills, Colonel J. Clawson Roop, Director of the Budget, and two other men whose identity was not divulged. The conference, which was presumably on the taxation and economy measures before Congress, lasted nearly two hours.

PARIS, May 13 -- The Bourse continues very weak, with business inactive. Apparently the result of the French elections has increased the uncertainty of a number of investors. The market expects the political situation to remain obscure until the opening of the new chamber, but financial Paris does not yet reject the supposition that a government may be formed without the participation of the Socialists.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent speech before the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, Colonel A.H. Carter suggested that Stock Exchanges require an independent audit of company affairs before admitting a stock to trading.

What chiefly strikes one in exGovernor SMITH'S address last evening is its appalling candor. Most men mentioned for the Presidency at once suffer a kind of mental paralysis. They cannot make a bold and unequivocal utterance. Everything they say has to be qualified, hedged about with weasel words and designed to be all things to all men.

Charles C. McCarthy, formerly the managing editor of the Brooklyn section of the old New York World, died yesterday at his home, 134-03 Ninety-fifth Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, in his sixty-ninth year.

BOSTON, May 16 -- "For the first time since the war the cotton industry is not suffering from over-expansion," Ralph E. Loper, textile accountant, states in a report made to a committee of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers. "According to Department of Commerce figures," he adds, "the industry has been able to operate at about 90 per cent of single-shift capacity while other major industries are operating at between 20 and 60 per cent.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, April 19 -- "Though I have been a citizen of China all my life, I have never agreed with the foreign policies pursued by the Nanking Government, and the new State of Manchoukuo will not adopt a foreign policy at all similar," was the opening declaration made this afternoon in an interview given by Hsieh Chieh-shih, Minister for Foreign Affairs of the new government at Changchun.

There are fewer speakeasies in Greater New York than there were licensed saloons in the days before prohibition, Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director, said yesterday in Pennsylvania Station before boarding a train for Chicago, where he is to begin a series of surveys of enforcement costs with a view toward bringing about economies in his department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of "M.M." in THE TIMES, objecting to Park Commissioner Benmnger's proposal to put a golf course in Riis Park, on the ground that golf is a "fad" and may fade away after a few years, makes one pause and think quite seriously.

A reply to the attack of the committee on medical economics of the Medical Society of the State of New York on the proposal for the establishment of clinics under the direction and supervision of the State for the treatment of workmen's compensation cases was made yesterday by Howard S. Cullman.

BOSTON, May 16 -- The White Sox defeated the Red Sox, 4 to 3, in ten innings today when Luke Appling and Charlie Berry drove out doubles to break a 3-to-3 tie. The winning run was scored off Jack Bussell, who went to the mound in place of Ed Durham in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The suggestion has come from New York City to the cloakrooms of Congress, and perhaps to the White House itself, that the industrial emergency calls for the re-establishment by the the President of the Council of National Defense.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary Stimson reported on his Geneva visit to President Hoover today at luncheon at the White House.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 16 -- The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association has returned to its port-to-port race week program, and will open the week at Freeport on July 30. Last year race week was held off Bay Shore.

" Personally, and speaking: broadly," said Secretary WILBUR at the Conference of Social Work in Philadelphia last night, " I think that un"less we descend to a level far be"yond anything that we at present "have known, our children are apt "to profit rather than suffer from "what is going on."

In the upflare of terrorism at Tokyo, the native press and the for- eign correspondents see a demon- stration by fanatical young patriots against the politicians. But the sins of Japanese politicians include one never charged against their kind in the Occident.

CLOVIS, N.M., May 16 (AP) -- The Democratic State Convention was recessed after a brief opening session today to permit the central committee to consider credentials of three contesting delegations from counties divided over the national committeeman issue.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday through the committee on business conduct that its attention had been called to the practice of some members in suggesting to customers the purchase of units consisting of one share each of several prominent stocks.

WASHINGTON May 16 (AP). -- Sen- ate Democratic leaders now in the midst of the tax fight noted with interest, but for the most part in silence, the advocacy of the sales tax tonight by Alfred E. Smith. The private opinion was expressed by party leaders in the revenue contest that it was too late to revive the sales tax now, in view of its decisive defeat by the House.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- Riggs Stephenson's single with the bases filled in the ninth today gave the Cubs an 11-to-10 victory over Philadelphia, and raised their league lead margin over the idle Boston Braves to a game and a half.

A Congressional investigation "to disclose and correct the errors in operation of the numerous laws concerning veterans which have been enacted since the World War" is urged in a report of the committee on public health relations, of the New York Academy of Medicine, released for publication today.

Predictions of a Fascist coup d'etat in Japan, with the military clique sweeping aside the Parliamentary system and setting up a dictatorship, are heard with growing frequency, but are subject to strong reservations.

While the New Jersey State police intensified the secrecy around their investigation of the kidnapping and murder of the baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, New York City officials yesterday prosecuted their inquiry into the payment of $50,000 ransom in the Bronx on April 2.
PARIS, May 16 -- France, again without using Marcel Bernard, today won the Franco-American special tennis tournament, three matches to two, in Roland Garros Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- The support of President Hoover for legislation to compensate through tariff adjustments for depreciation in foreign currency was sought today by Senator Schall and Representative Knutson, both Minnesota Republicans.

Members of the Riverside committee of the New York City visiting committee of the State Charities Aid Association will hold a card party this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Ray P. Stevens, 834 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the Riverside Hospital.

Fifty-two of the welfare agencies that depend largely upon the Clothing Relief Division of the Gibson Committee to obtain garments for thousands of needy, expressed satisfaction yesterday that the division would continue its activities for an extended period.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 16 -- Leading surgeons from the United States and Canada and some from Great Britain gathered here today for the three-day convention of the American Surgical Association that opened in the Sterling Hall of Medicine this morning.

Pointing out that the average annual salary of postal clerks is now $1,440 and "not commensurate with the American standard of living," the New York State Federation of Postoffice Clerks adopted a resolution at its convention at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn yesterday opposing any reduction in pay and demanding a five-day week in place of the present five-and-a-half-day week.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 16 -- In one of the stormiest political conventions Kansas has seen since the old Populist days, the Democratic party today instructed its twenty-four delegates, with twenty votes, for Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York, reaffirmed its former stand for strict enforcement of the prohibition laws and split the party into two hostile camps.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16 (AP) -- Leslie E. Keiffer's Daisaburo, which finished seventh in the Preakness last Saturday, came back to account for the mile-and-seventy-yard Snow Hill Purse, feature of the charity day program today at Pimlico.

The trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions was enlivened yesterday by a series of clashes between Mr. Broderick and Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, who has been cross-examining the defendant for three days.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- American foreign trade in April fell to the lowest point in recent years. Exports valued at $136,000,000 were the smallest since August, 1914, when they totaled $110,400,000, and imports worth $127,000,000 were the lowest since February, 1915, when they reached $125,100,000, according to Commerce Department figures issued today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Hoover submitted to the House today a supplemental estimate for veterans' administration amounting to $17,106,760, to take care of deficits for 1931 and 1932. He also asked for an additional $200,000 for the Bureau of Immigration, to be used to carry on deportation and removal of aliens.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ended May 7 stands at 65.1, as compared with 65.5 for the week ended April 30.

An instrument which measures quantitatively an individual's sensitivity to pain, developed as a possible aid to physicians in diagnosing certain symptoms, was demonstrated last night at a meeting of the Yorkville Medical Association at 125 East Eighty-fifth Street by its inventor, Dr. Lorand J.B. Gluzek of 1,022 Park Avenue.

Attention was directed yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, to "the grave crisis" confronting private charity and welfare organizations as the result of an erroneous belief that because aid is being received by those in distress from State and municipal agencies, there is little need left for private organizations.
Resales of two housing structures were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Kid Chocolate, Cuban lightweight, signalized his return to local boxing after an absence of six months at the St. Nicholas Arena last night with a hollow victory over Mike Sarko of Boston in the feature bout of ten rounds.

To set at rest rumors of an im- pending merger of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company with some other bank, which have been current in Wall Street for a month, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Manhattan Company, which controls the bank, issued yes- terday an unequivocal denial that any negotiations for a merger had been under way or were in contemplation.
The Spring inspection of the New York Botanical Garden was largely attended yesterday by members of the board of managers and advisory council of the garden, as well as by the general public.

Processional Sizes and Speeds. Estimates of the number of people who marched in Saturday's beer parade differ so widely as to prove once more that round figures are at their roundest when it comes to appraising the size of crowds.

The city of Winston-Salem. N.C., faced with bond maturities aggregating $900,000 between May 1 and July 1, and finding it impossible to borrow money in the open markets, has obtained assistance from local taxpayers, according to a letter received yesterday from Mayor George W. Coan Jr. by the bankers here who have marketed the city's bonds in the past.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Peruvian Government, in a statement issued through the Peruvian Embassy here today, disclaimed any responsibility for the severance of relations with Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Captain John C. Greenslade, a member of the Navy General Board, was designated today as the next commander of the submarine force of the fleet. He will succeed Rear Admiral Arthur L. Hepburn, now in Geneva as technical adviser to the American delegation to the Disarmament Conference.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 16 -- John T. Scott of Cleveland, special referee representing the District Court of Appeals in the fight against the now-abandoned Youngstown Sheet and Tube-Bethlehem Steel merger, ruled today that there was no cause of action and that the Sheet and Tube Company need not pay the attorney fees incurred by the opponents of the merger.

The membership of the Fifth Avenue Association is almost unanimously in favor of a change in the prohibition law, it was indicated yesterday when William J. Pedrick, president of the association, made public the final results of a poll of the members.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 16 -- Condemning the capital gains tax feature of the revenue bill now under consideration in the Senate as uneconomic and inflationary, the committee on Federal taxation of the Investment Bankers' Association, in its report at the Spring meeting of the board of governors of the association here today, characterized the tax as the least productive when most needed.

Frederick Jagel, tenor, and Gladys Swarthout, mezzo-soprano, American members of the Metropolitan Opera, joined yesterday in denouncing as unfounded the charge made by Clarence Whitehill last week that Giulio Gatti-Casazza, general manager of the opera, was prejudiced against Americans.

Shakespeare s "Hamlet" was designed as an everlasting memorial to the Earl of Essex, the "darling of England" and of Elizabeth and great patron of the Elizabethan arts, John Dover Wilson, Professor of Education in the University of London and oae of the greatest living authorities on Shakespeare, writes in "The Essential Shakespeare," published by Macmillan today.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Selena Royle of New York, leading woman in George M. Cohan's play, "Confidential Service," at the Grand Opera House here, today confirmed New York reports of her engagement to Earle Larimore, a leading member of the "Mourning Becomes Electra" company now appearing in Philadelphia.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 16 -- The Protogueroffist faction of the Macedonian revolutionary committee, which for long has been on the defensive against a campaign of its merciless opponent, the terrorist Ivan Michailoff, took its first offensive action for many months tonight when members of their faction shot dead Professor Demeter Michailoff president of the legal Macedonian National Committee, as he was entering his house.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A plan of Senator Wagner to combine his public works program with the self-liquidating construction proposal advocated by President Hoover and Senator Robinson, Democratic floor leader, in a $2,400,000,000 bill was debated by a Democratic steering committee subcommittee this afternoon without a conclusion being reached.

HARTFORD, May 16 -- A bold stand on the prohibition question was urged upon the Democratic party tonight by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Executive Committee of the party, in a speech opening the State Democratic Convention.
BOMBAY, Tuesday, May 17 (AP). -- Troops and armored cars were rushed today from Poona to break up bitter fighting between Hindus and Moslems raging unabated here after three days.

Ahto Walter, 19-year-old Estonian youth, who sailed across the Atlantic to New York last year in a 27-foot boat and later raced back to Plymouth in the transatlantic yacht races, returned yesterday in a similar craft, having crossed the Atlantic to Miami in sixty-seven sailing days from his home town of Tallinn, Estonia.

PARIS, May 16 -- The $4,000,000 French liner Georges Philippar which was abandoned afire this morning five miles off Cape Guardafui, Italian Somaliland, was returning from her maiden trip to the Orient. She was on her way from Colombo, Ceylon, to Djibouti, French Somaliland, when the fire broke out.

Richard Shikat, 218, Philadelphia, former world's champion, scored a triumph over Earl McCready, 227. Oklahoma, in the feature finish bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. Shikat pinned McCready in 21 minutes 16 seconds with a combination body hold and head scissors while 5,000 persons looked on.

New York got a premature taste of Summer yesterday when the temperature soared to 83 and exceeded by two degrees a Weather Bureau record for May 16 that had stood since 1906. The warm spell was general throughout most of the country, but New England bore the brunt of it.
