Stray bullets slightly wounded two passers-by and whistled over the heads of a large number of children playing on the west side of Forsythe Street, between Rivington and Stanton Streets, yesterday afternoon, when a gunman darted out of the hallway of a tenement at 186 Forsythe Street and fatally wounded James F. Alascia, 31 years old, of 335 East Twentieth Street, described by the police as a petty racketeer.

Steps were taken yesterday to adjust conditions in the French and Italian trade routes while shipping men awaited the arrival of W.A. Roper, secretary of the European offices of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, who is scheduled to arrive Friday to confer with Emil Lederer, recently selected as executive chairman of the conference with broad powers in the regulation of transatlantic shipping.

Deposits of more than the required 75 per cent of the Atlantic Securities Corporation's preferred and common stocks have been received by the Atlas Utilities Corporation under its plan for acquiring control of the former company. The offer will expire on Friday, having been extended from April 30.

JERUSALEM, May 16 -- Parts of five skeletons of the Neanderthal type have been discovered recently in the Cave of the Kids, a small rock shelter ten miles south of Haifa, and the excavators hope to find other evidence of a connection between the prehistoric inhabitants of Palestine and the Mousterians of Europe.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16 -- Recognition of the Russian Soviet Union and repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment were advocated here today by Representative Percy H. Stewart as means "to create an economic condition that will increase the buying power of the public and restore the people's confidence."

LONDON, May 16 -- Leysmith William Fember Reeves, originator of many far-reaching social experiments in New Zealand, where he was distinguished as an editor and a statesman, died in London today at the age of 75. His industrial arbitration act of 1894, which compelled State intervention in quarrels between capital and labor, provoked world-wide controversy.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- The death of Eben M. Byers from radium poisoning has caused "unwarranted condemnation of radium by apparent authorities," Dr. Jacob Gutman, director of the Brooklyn Diagnostic Institute, declared in an address read before the American Therapeutic Society at the opening session of its two-day convention here today.

Japan faces more trouble before the conditions that underlay the assassination of Premier Ki Inukai are straightened out, Dr. Inazo Nitobe, crown member of the House of Peers and a former delegate to the League of Nations, said yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: William Allen White, famous editor of The Emporia Gazette, in a recent issue of THE TIMES warns the country of impending rebellion. Among many other interesting things he states: "The bitterness of the wets in the East threatens orderly government.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 16 -- Edward P. Beckwith of the Carpe Mount McKinley Expedition, ill and emaciated, was taken off the Muldrow Glacier and brought back here today by Jerry Jones, an Alaskan Airways aviator, in one of the most remarkable flights in the history of flying in the North Country.

Bonds of the Japanese group were under severe pressure on the Stock Exchange here yesterday. Of the fifteen active issues, thirteen broke 1 1/8 to 4 1/2 points, with six of these touching the lowest prices since issuance. Japanese Government 6 l/2 s lost 3 1/4 points for the day and the 5 1/2 s lost 2 points.
An eight-oared crew of freshmen won the intramural rowing championship of Manhattan Collate in the feature event of the first annual interclass regatta on the Harlem River yesterday.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 17 -- The army swung its mailed fist upon Japanese politics today and dictated that a national, non-partisan Cabinet must be named to succeed that of the slain Premier Inukai.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Dr. B.J. Cigrand of Batavia, Ill., founder and president of the National Flag Day Association, collapsed today in a Loop restaurant and died a short time later of heart disease. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Extra policemen watched the doors of the Supreme Court today after reports that Communists planned a demonstration, but the justices took their places with nothing to interrupt the calmness of the judicial atmosphere.

Public and charitable bequests totaling $205,000 are provided from the estate of Mrs. Frances R. Biggs, widow of Hermann M. Biggs, former State Health Commissioner, which was valued at $594,565 gross and $547,847 net in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission.
Following is the text of the address of former Governor Alfred E. Smith last night over the National Broadcasting Company net work:
MONTREAL, May 16 (Canadian Press) -- J.P. Anglin, head of the firm of Anglin-Norcross, Ltd., died last night at a fishing camp near L'Annunciation, Que., it was learned here today.

MARSEILLES, May 16 (AP) -- Pierre Pasquier, Governor General of French Indo-China, was to have boarded at Saigon the motorship Georges Pasquier, which was destroyed by fire this morning off Cape Guardaful at the entrance to the Gulf of Aden.

The time for deposit of the St. Louis Southwestern, or Cotton Belt, Railroad's consolidated 4 per cent bonds, under a plan to meet their maturity on June 1, one-half in cash and one-half with general and refunding 5 per cent bonds, has been extended to May 25, it was announced yesterday by Daniel Upthegrove, president.

The Class A golf team of the Westchester Country Club clinched second place in the interclub tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield County Women's Golf Association at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The principle of political economy back of the taxation program suggested by Mr. Wehringer, in a letter to THE TIMES, is a sound one.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that as of May 1 the directors had temporarily suspended the corporation's savings and investment plan for minor employes, which was established in 1919. Since then eight annual classes of the plan have matured through which employes have received $56,189,195, including 1,597,844 shares of General Motors stock.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Tuesday, May 17 -- The field of 368 contestants which began competition two weeks ago for the J. Noel Macy trophy emblematic of the contract bridge pair championship of Westchester County was narrowed down to 44 as the third and last round of the sectional elimination contests ended early this morning.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 16 -- Although his entry was misplaced and he had to start a round behind the rest of the field and unseeded, William Horton 3d of Williams, defending champion in the New England intercollegiate tennis tourney, advanced into the quarter-final round at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tour editorial "Coining at Last" hits the nail squarely on the head. It is high time to "let the people of the several States, in convention, decide whether they want the Eighteenth Amendment to stay or to be torn out."

Virtually all groups of bonds listed on the Stock Exchange were weak yesterday, although the turnover was less than $8,000,000, or $2,000,000 below what is considered an average day's business. Japanese bonds led the decline in the foreign loans, and rails, in the domestic corporation group.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 16 (AP) -- Princes Camelia, acquired by Mrs. John Marsch out of the Leiter dispersal for $7,200, qualified handsomely for her engagement in the Kentucky Oaks when she defeated a smart band of fillies, including two other candidates for the classic, in the Petunia Purse, mile feature at Churchill Downs today.
After an early slight decline, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply a 1/4 cent yesterday and ended with gains of 19 to 21 points.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- After spotting Jersey City four runs in the first inning the Bisons came back vigorously to defeat the invaders again today. The score was 9 to 5. The victory made it three straight and sent the Bisons into second place.

The phenomenal pitching performance of the Yankee staff against Western invaders reached the zone of all-time baseball records yesterday when Vernon Gomez held Cleveland to five hits and no runs in the second game of the series, the Yankees winning, 8 to 0.
COLLEGE PARK Md., May 16 -- Closing its home season today, the University of Maryland's baseball squad turned in a 9-5 victory over the University of Virginia.

CLEARWATER, Alaska, May 15 (By Telephone to Fairbanks via. Mount McKinley Park) -- We have succeeded in reaching both peaks of Mount McKinley, the first time any expedition has done this feat, but our pleasure in the achievement was tempered by the discovery on our descent of the body of Theodore Koven and of every evidence of the death of Alien Carpe, who, with Koven, headed the cosmic ray expedition.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for Lady Macneal. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Cram, Mrs. William A. Hamilton, Miss Marjorie Drexel, Miss Carrie Cortis, Colonel G. Creighton Webb, T. Chesley Richardson and Anthony J. Drexel 3d.

Athletics were hailed by United States Attorney George Z. Medalie yesterday as the "greatest force for international good will and more effective in promoting inter-racial understanding than all other economic and political methods that have thus far been tried."

"There's Always Juliet," John Van Druten's successful comedy starring Herbert Marshall and his wife, Edna Best, will end its Broadway engagement at Henry Miller's Theatre after tomorrow night's performance. Accompanied by Miss Best, Mr. Marshall will leave soon for Hollywood, where he will spend fifteen weeks under contract to Paramount.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Arguing that the Jewish school was placing too much, emphasis upon moral knowledge rather than upon the practice of desirable behavior, Dr. Julius B. Maller of Teachers College, Columbia University, told the National Council for Jewish Education here today that "it seems we are often trying to impart knowledge to a child who already knows how to be much better than he is."

"Humiliating subservience" to their political bosses is a general charge brought against the Democratic Assemblymen in a report of the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union, covering the members from Manhattan and the Bronx, which was made public yesterday.

In a radio address last night, former Governor Alfred E. Smith presented a program of action by the Federal Government for coping with the crisis now confronting the nation. He called upon every member of Congress to cooperate loyally in an earnest effort to lead the country out of the depression.

BOMBAY, Tuesday, May 17. -- Thirty-two persons were killed and 286 injured yesterday in fighting between Hindus and Moslems. Nearly 100 have been killed and about 600 have been injured since the rioting started Saturday.

In the presence of German and American World War veterans a German flag was placed in the World War Shrine in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church in Hoboken last night. The emblem will rest beside the flags of the Allies and other war mementoes in the sanctuary.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Washington Senators drooped out of the league leadership today under the burden of their second consecutive shutout from the St. Louis Browns, Sammy Gray winning a 2-to-0 verdict.

The consolidated report of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., for 1931, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $881,028 after depreciation, subsidiary dividends, interest, amortization and other charges. It does not include an estimated loss of $1,098,280, from trading in Class A stock of Fox Film Corporation, which was controlled by General Theatres, and the failure of a brokerage firm.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Fed- eral Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on May 11 shows decreases for the week of $137,000,000 in loans and investments, $116,000,000 in government deposits and $30,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks, and increases of $64,000,000 in net demand deposits and $4,000,000 in time deposits.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior, startled several thousand delegates to the national conference of social work by declaring here tonight that the economic depression was likely to he beneficial rather than unduly harmful to the American child.

The news of the deaths of Alien Carpe and Theodore Koven was received by telegraph at the Koven Summer home in Denville, N.J., yesterday and transmitted by telephone to Mrs. Carpe at the home of Mr. Carpe's aunt, Mrs. W.H. Kenyon, 40 East Sixty-second Street, New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- After reading a telegram from Henry Ford endorsing prohibition, Dr. Clarence True Wilson told the conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here this evening that the Methodists were "going to select a President and a Vice President for a Christian Republic and for a prohibition nation."

Testimony to support his previously expressed charge that Mayor Walker kept Russell T. Sherwood, the Mayor's personal accountant, out of the State, will be offered by Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, at this week's series of three hearings, which will begin tomorrow.

New York City's infant mortality rate is lower than that of any other city in the nation whose population exceeds 1,000,000, according to the Weekly Bulletin of the Health Department. For 1931, the bulletin shows, the infant death rate here was 55.59 per 1,000 births, against 56.40 in Chicago, 64.13 in Philadelphia, 56.92 in Detroit and 58.33 in Los Angeles.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church. Boston, speaking last night at a dinner of the Alumni Association of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, before a group of 225 pastors of many denominations, declared that it was time the churches got together to do something definite for the religious guidance of college students.

LONDON, May 16 (Canadian Press) -- Rain throughout England today interfered with several scheduled first-class cricket matches in which play began on Saturday. Three matches had to be suspended and play was stopped in two more.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 16 -- The refusal of Owen D. Young to allow himself to be considered as a Democratic Presidential candidate brought smiles to the faces of members of Governor Roosevelt's party here today, although the stand of Mr. Young was not unanticipated.

Voicing resentment at the innuendo that it had countenanced improper influence of public funds, the board of directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation made public yesterday the minutes of meetings of its executive and finance committees at which bonuses aggregating $275,000 were voted to Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board, for extra services performed from 1928 to 1931, inclusive.

The price trend in commodities yesterday was forward, reversing the movement of most of last week. Grains, cotton, rubber, hides and cocoa showed advances, while coffee and silk were steady. Silk was slightly lower. In the spot trading, butter and zinc reached new lows, but other articles followed the trend in futures.

The names of the three books by American authors that are to be recommended as candidates for the French award of the Prix Femina Americain will be announced by the American committee today. The French, committee for the prize will pass on these three nominations and the selected book will be translated into French.
This is the height of the juvenile art season. It is known as "the children's hour."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Monetary stabilization is as urgent a necessity during the present session of Congress as balancing the budget and granting relief to the unemployed, Senator Borah said in a Senate speech today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 16 -- Mrs. Henry H. Bradley, Mrs. F.L. Meeske, Gerard Swope, A.H. Robertson, Samuel Lindsey Nicholson, Mrs. L.T. McCloskey and F.C. Jones made up a riding party for a long horseback excursion into the mountains today, returning late in the afternoon for tea on the Casino lawn.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 17 -- Admiral Mineo Osuml, Minister to the Navy, issued instructions yesterday to all fleet commanders to suppress agitation aboard their ships following the assassination Sunday of Premier Inukai and the attacks upon five buildings here.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The reported demand by W. Irving Glover, Second Assistant Postmaster General, that postmasters "get out on the firing line for Hoover or resign" occupied the attention of politicians today. It drew fire in the Senate from Senators Norris and Joseph T. Robinson, and was the subject of heated discussion in the House.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Republican Presidential campaign expenditures this year may have to be limited to $1,000,000, J.R. Nutt, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, said today after a conference of six party leaders with President Hoover at the White House.

Supreme Court Justice Schmuck dismissed yesterday the $3,500,000 damage suit brought by the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers against the Structural Steel Board of Trade and ended for the time being any possibility of an attempt to end the twenty-seven-year feud in the iron-erecting industry between the union and the employing erectors.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House passed a bill today introduced by Representative Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the Naval Committee, reducing the number of enlisted pilots of the navy from 30 to 20 per cent. The bill now goes to the Senate, and if approved there virtually will empower the Secretary of the Navy to "wipe out" the enlisted flyer.

George Walcott, 61 years old, vice president and chairman of the board of the Hunter Manufacturing and Commission Company, cotton brokers of 58 Worth Street, killed himself yesterday in his apartment at 885 Park Avenue by firing a bullet through his right temple.

While there has been a certain dissatisfaction with the New Jersey State Police, criticism has not taken the form of doubting its usefulness for the duties it was created to perform. It is a countryside force, affording protection to the most isolated farm.

A little over a year ago First Assistant Postmaster General COLEMAN, discussing the qualifications of first, second and third-class postmasters with members of the House Committee on Postoffices, remarked that it is "not enough" to find men who are "competent administrators."

SAN RAFAEL, Cal., May 16 (AP) -- Captain Dollar had been, ill for two weeks. He caught a severe cold after a visit to a near-by town where he had addressed a meeting of young people in his characteristic manner, advising them that hard work, and plenty of it, was the secret of success.

Counsel for the receiver of the International Match Corporation will try to find how much stock of the Diamond Match Company was owned by International or its affiliates beyond the 350,000 shares pledged to secure a $3,800,000 bank loan of the company, when the bankruptcy hearings are resumed tomorrow before Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16 -- Revival of industrial markets to put men back to work and bring about the return of normal conditions was the goal of the National Industrial Advertisers Association, opening its tenth annual convention here today.

Weakness in bonds was the outstanding movement on yesterday's financial markets. It was irregularly distributed, but some of the declines were considerable, and in many cases it was impossible to regard them as having any meaning except selling by hard-pressed or frightened investors, in a market whose resisting power is slight.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The embargo Owen D. Young has placed on the activities of those promoting him as a candidate for the Presidential nomination was accepted by impartial Democratic politicians here as removing one of the outstanding barriers to Governor Roosevelt's nomination.

Chesapeake Ohio. The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported a net income of $6,164,749 in the four months ended on April 30, or 80 cents a share on its $25 par common stock, against $6,527,361, or 85 cents a share, in the same period last year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 16 -- By winning from Salisbury, 3 to 2, in the final match at the North Hempstead Country Club today, the Trillora team, captained by Mrs. J.L. Andersen, finished first in the Long Island division of the interclub team matches and will represent that section against the New Jersey and Westchester winners in the final matches to be played in the Fall.

The first and only other successful attempt to reach the icy pinnacle of South Peak, the higher and more formidable of the two white ramparts of Mount McKinley, was made nineteen years ago. The Very Rev. Hudson Stuck, Episcopal Archdeacon of the Yukon, and his party reached the top of the North American Continent in June, 1913.

Production of new life insurance in April was 19.7 per cent lower than in the same month last year, while for the first four months of this year it was 9.4 per cent under that in the corresponding period in 1931, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents has reported to the United States Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- News of the deaths of Alien Carpe and Theodore Koven, members of the expedition climbing Mount McKinley in Alaska, came as a shock today to associates of Dr. Arthur H. Compton, scientist of the University of Chicago, with whom the Carpe party was cooperating in cosmic ray determination.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- A barrage of Brooklyn hits that echoed throughout Forbes Field today gave the Robins an 11-to-1 victory over the Pirates and turned Max Carey's first homecoming as a major league pilot into something of a personal triumph.

Retail Trade Shows Pick Up. The best retail business of the half-month was done on Saturday, reports of retail executives here yesterday agreed. The weather proved a strong aid in swelling consumer attendance in the stores, with seasonal wearing apparel and accessories meeting ready sale.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Representative La Guardia, Republican, of New York, told the House today that Federal jurists were indulging in an orgy of "judicial joyriding," at the expense of the country when they should be contributing to sound economic government.

A production schedule of forty-eight pictures for the 1932-33 season was announced for the Fox Film Corporation at the opening session of the company's annual sales convention yesterday. Noel Coward, British actor and playwright, contributes a total of four films to the schedule, the chief among them being a screen version of his recent London success, "Cavalcade."
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Senate rejected today by 49 votes to 31 the Couzens proposal for wartime income tax rates.

Only a few days ago a 16-pound weakfish was caught by a party that left Southold, L.I. Within a short time his record specimen will be mounted and placed in one of the hotels of the town as another testimony to the lure of the sport in Peconic Bay.
AURORA, Ill., May 16 (AP) -- Pre- meditate, owned by Harry Heren- deen and piloted by T.P. Martin, cheered the long-shot players by beating Essential by a neck in the feature event at Aurora today.

Mr. OWEN YOUNG knows now to express his thought and determination, so that when he writes "definitely and finally" that he cannot accept a nomination, for the Presidency, even "if made," there is an end of his candidacy, at least for this year.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- The 11,000 employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company have accepted a wage reduction amounting to slightly less than 9 per cent, effective June 1, it was announced today.

LONDON, May 16 -- The smallest American professional golf delegation in years, numbering only three top-flight players and minus Walter Hagen, four times winner of the title, has been entered for the forthcoming British open at Sandwich.

Friends of Owen D. Young, according to The Associated Press, voiced the belief yesterday that consideration for his wife, who is ill with a heart ailment, was responsible for his refusal to enter the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 16 (Canadian Press) -- For nearly three years the Earl of Egmont, the "loneliest peer in England," as he was often described, lived in historic Avon Castle, Hampshire, with his only son, Viscount Perceval, for company.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 16 -- For the second time within twenty-four hours, Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, met with defeat today in the final round of a championship tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Bullish enthusiasm for wheat was more apparent today on the Board of Trade than it had been in some time. Reports from the Southwest saying that the crop was deteriorating more than offset the effect of easiness in stocks early.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Speaker John N. Garner replied today to Senator Moses's criticism of the Speaker's remarks against President Hoover by saying:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a three-year loan of $25,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad as a result of a recent compromise by which the road reduced from $55,000,000 to $32,500,000 the amount sought.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 16 -- Speaking at a mass meting held here tonight to protest against the proposed increase of 2 cents in the gasoline tax in New Jersey to provide funds for unemployment relief, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of the State, assured about 4,000 workers in oil refineries that the proposed tax would not be passed by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The authority of the Oklahoma Corporation Commission to exercise its judgment in curtailing the production of oil was unanimously sustained by the Supreme Court today in an opinion handed down by Justice Butler. The case involved what is known as the "proration law."
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors appropriated $195,000 this afternoon to provide work on the parkways during the Summer for the county's unemployed.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16 -- The one hundred and twentieth annual commencement of Princeton Theological Seminary, the oldest Presbyterian divinity school in the New World, will be held tomorrow morning at the First Presbyterian Church when thirty candidates will receive the degree of Master of Theology and forty-one candidates the degree of Bachelor of Theology.

Funeral services for William H. Todd, civic worker and philanthropist and president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, who died on Sunday afternoon a few minutes after falling down a fourteen-foot flight of stairs, will be held at 2:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street, between Franklin and Bedford Avenues, Brooklyn.

About this time, as the almanacs say, look for a period of stupidity. It came last evening according to schedule with the appearance of "There You Are" at the George M. Cohan Theatre. If the authors, joiners, singers, composers and players had conspired to fill an evening with hackneyed dullnes they could hardly have succeeded more conspicuously.

After sinking to new low prices for the bear market, stocks rallied 1 to 4 points yesterday to close with moderate net gains. The volume of trading on the "Big Board" increased to 1,304,000 shares, compared with 866,745 shares last Friday. The early weakness carried 168 issues, including United States Steel common, to the lowest prices yet reached on, the decline.

Twenty-four firemen were overcome, one fatally, by smoke and illuminating gas last night while fighting a fire in the basement of a six-story loft building at 457-459 Broome Street, near Mercer Street, and had to be assisted or carried to the street by fellow-firemen.

A gift of $250,000 to establish and endow a training school for Boy Scout leaders has been made by Mrs. Jacob H. Schiff as a memorial to her son, Mortimer L. Schiff, it was announced last night by Walter W. Head, president of the National Council of Boy Scouts of America, at a dinner of that organization at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers staged a fiverun rally in the fourth inning today to take the opener of the series with the Athletics, 6 to 4. Rogell's home run off Walberg in the seventh provided the extra counter.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Governors of the Federal Reserve Banks gathered here today for a called meeting to open tomorrow for the discussion of the many complicated problems of credit and finance now facing the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- William G. McAdoo, leader of California's dry Democrats, is expected to change his attitude on prohibition before he enters the race for Senator from this State, according to word brought to San Francisco by co-workers on the Hearst-McAdoo-Garner delegation to the Chicago convention.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 17 (AP) -- Fascism in Japan apparently suffered a setback as a result of Premier Inukai's assassination when the Military Council decided today to replace General Sadao Araki. leading nationalist, as Minister of War.

With airplanes bearing tidings up the Hudson and fourteen automobiles and trucks carrying women speakers to strategic parts of the city for a series of street meetings opening the local campaign. New York's share of the National Repeal Week drive of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform got under way yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House today passed by a viva voce vote the Steiwer bill, amending the Federal farm loan act to widen the scope of the Federal intermediate credit banks.

Dark Secret, the roan son of Flying Ebony which races for the Wheatley Stable, was a decisive winner of the Islip Purse, featured event yesterday at Belmont Park. Stepping the seven furlongs in 1:25 3-5 over a fast track, Dark Secre won by four lengths in the easiest sort of fashion from James Butler's Forewarned, a Spur colt and the outsider in the betting, at 60 to 1.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Recent reports that Federal agents plan to clamp the lid on Chicago speakeasies and bootleggers during the Republican and Democratic conventions next month were denied today in an unofficial announcement prefaced with "no names to be mentioned."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Railway Brotherhoods and affiliated labor organizations have split into camps over the recent action of seven brotherhoods in urging President Hoover to support a twenty-five-year foreign debt moratorium in the interest of employment and relief.

One of the most powerful agents in imposing national prohibition and in sustaining it for more than ten years is the Methodist Episcopal Church. The moral, religious and political influence exerted by that great denomination and certain others has been what may fairly be called the chief propulsive force of the whole movement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP). -- Nathan Gerson, a laundry owner, reported to police tonight that his 19-year-old daughter, Dora, was kidnapped by four Negroes last Saturday, held prisoner for thirty-five hours and released today after payment of a $300 ransom.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., May 16 -- Owen D. Young has definitely and finally declared that ha cannot accept the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.
Upsets resulting from the efforts of leaders of both parties to repeal the Hobart State enforcement act marked yesterday's primaries in New Jersey, according to late returns last night.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Continuation of open market operations by the purchase of government securities was agreed upon today by the governors of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks and the Federal Reserve Board.

Money market continued quiet and featureless. Virtually little new money was taken despite the liberal offerings and the Stock Exchange call loan rate held at the "pegged" figure of 2 1/2 per cent. Street trading and Federal funds were 1 1/2 and 1/8 respectively.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17. -- Another new golfer of considerable promise loomed on the metropolitan horizon today in the person of Miss Grace Amory, who registers from the Engineers Club in Roslyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The women of the world, as well as the men, have been shocked beyond expression by the unparalleled crime committed not only against an innocent child, not only against his brave and beloved parents, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, but against every basic principle of liberty, law and the right of every person to freedom and happiness under the Constitution of the United States of America.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17. -- Connecticut's sixteen votes in the Democratic National Convention were pledged for Alfred E. Smith today in one of the longest and tensest gatherings in the history of the party in the State. Thirty-four delegates will cast their votes for Mr. Smith until he himself orders otherwise.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Senate suddenly tore loose today from the barrier which had held It on the first page of the tax bill since Friday and adopted within two and onehalf hours seventy-two amendments proposed by the Finance Committee to the measure as passed by the House.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Walter Johnson's Senators lost their third straight game to the St. Louis Browns today, bowing, 11 to 2.

Few will deny that the recent proceedings in Congress have menaced the financial situation. This is not because dangerous laws have been actually enacted; it is because of loose and reckless talk, on the floor of the House particularly, which has created uneasiness in the mind of the general public.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17. -- J.P. Morgan, exhibiting tulips grown Matinecock Point, his estate on East Island, won first honors this afternoon in the opening day's judging of the annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society being held at the Pratt Oval on the Pratt estate.

Recapitalization of the Tubize Chatillon Corporation was approved yesterday by stockholders at a special meeting and an initial dividend of 1 3/4 per cent on the 7 per cent preferred stock was declared. J.E. Bassill was elected president to succeed B.G. Slaughter.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover took six little boys and girls to a circus today and provided them with many delights of the sawdust kingdom -- even live chameleons to take home.

DANZIG, May 17. -- The strained relations between the Free City of Danzig and Poland were further aggravated today by a protest to the City Senate by the Polish General Commissioner against the ordinance regulating the rights of foreign warships in Danzig Harbor.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- An assertion that Alfred E. Smith in his radio speech last night virtually approved the President's legislative program was made today by Senator Moses in a formal statement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To finance "reproductive enterprises" should be the chief function of government, as it must be the chief concern of business. We have thought of business as a lifeless, souless thing, and of government as a thing still more sterile.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Negroes were urged tonight by Senator Capper of Kansas to work without regard to party alignment for complete emancipation, and for racial advancement rather than personal preferment.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 17. -- Johnny Hines of Old Westbury was the low scorer in the opening one-day tournament of the season for members of the Long Island Golf Association held at the Brookville Country Club today.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17 (AP). -- A prolonged cheer drowned out scattering shouts of disapproval today as the Democratic State Convention pledged Connecticut's sixteen votes to the Presidential candidacy of Alfred E. Smith as long as his name is before the national meeting.

Rudyard Kipling, bolder of honorary doctorates in eight universities in England, Scotland, Canada, France and Greece, has been elected to an honorary fellowship in Magdalene College, Cambridge. "Magdalene," says The London Times in commenting on the appointment, "is the college of Samuel Pepys, who entered it as a sizar in 1651.

The adoption of a ten-year program, through which trained leadership will be extended in the ranks of boyhood, brought to a close yesterday the twenty-second annual meeting of the National Council of Boy Scouts of America, which opened on Monday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

"National Buyers' Week," from June 27 to July 2, designed to stimulate a general revival of industry and business, will be sponsored by the American Legion's National Employment Commission, it was announced yesterday by Mark T. McKee, executive director.

MOSCOW, May 17 (AP). -- First reports from the provinces, received today, indicated the recent decrees permitting the sale of a greater proportion of grain and meat by farmers were being received with widespread enthusiasm on the collective farms throughout the Soviet Union.

Economy, Federal, State and city, is widely accepted as necessary to the return of prosperity. But none of the roads to it are popular with the politicians. One of them, although traveled by such pioneers as CLEVELAND and ROOSEVELT, has been almost wholly neglected.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Mrs. Rockefeller McCormick, a director and guarantor of the Chicago Civic Opera Company, today demanded a reduction in rent on the opera auditorium to permit the continuation of grand opera in Chicago.

A gang of armed bandits attempted to hold up the Bronx County Trust Company's office at 4,201 White Plains Road, the Bronx, yesterday morning, but was routed after an exchange of shots with Joseph Ebbers, 60-year-old retired policeman, who was employed as a special officer by the bank.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reports for the three months ended on March 31, a consolidated net income of $536,071 after charges and provision for depreciation, depletion and other reserves. This is equivalent, after dividends on its 7 per cent preferred stock, to about three-tenths of a cent a share on the 14,584,025 common shares outstanding.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Wednesday, May 18. -- The Rengo News Agency today reported that the forces of the Chinese irregular General Li Tu had massacred thirty-five Japanese and fired the town of Ilan (Sanshin) yesterday in the face of an advance by Japanese troops.

Two hold-up men were caught last evening by the police after they had unsuccessfully attempted to rob Ozias Alteres, proprietor of a jewelry store at 228 Third Avenue, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets. Alteres was shot and slightly wounded in the shoulder by one of the pair, Carlo Rinzuello, 25 years old, of 702 Seventh Street, Union City, N. J., according to the police.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley today urged four banks in New York not to "rock the financial boat" by pressing for immediate sale the securities that they hold as collateral for a $10,000,000 loan to Insull Utilities Iivestments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, Insull holding companies, now in receivership.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Senator Ashurst of Arizona interrupted Senate proceedings today to make a plea for the Democratic convention to abandon the rule that a two-thirds vote is necessary to nominate.

Frank I. O'Neill, 39 years old, suspended attendant of the Court of General Sessions, was acquitted in Judge Freschi's part of General Sessions yesterday of the theft of $3,000 from Mrs. Bertha Ewald, wife of the former Magistrate George F. Ewald. The jurors deliberated fifty minutes.

PARIS, Wednesday, May 18. -- One hundred and fourteen of the 815 persons aboard the French motorship Georges Philippar when she was abandoned in flames yesterday in the Gulf of Aden are still unaccounted for, according to a wireless message from Captain Vicq, the ship's commander.
Knockouts-featured an amateur boxing tournament held by New York Lodge No. 1, B.P.O. Elks, under the auspices of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union at the clubhouse last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17. -- When the men's council of the Methodist Episcopal Church unanimously adopted on Sunday a statement saying, "We confess the tragic blunder of temperance thought and strategy since 1917," it did not represent the views of every section of the church, it was disclosed today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17. -- George A. Latimer of Cortland, N.Y., was selected today as the most popular man in the senior class at Rutgers University, in the annual ballot conducted by The Targum, student newspaper. Latimer is president of the senior class, a member of the student council and Cap and Skull, the senior honorary society, and an all-American Lacrosse player.

Our old and vicissitudinous friend The Saturday Review is now "open under new management," as the cafes used to say in the days of darkness. In its last phase but one there were manifestations of the splenetic cocksureness that was one of its most amusing characteristics, perpetuated from prime to falloff.

PINE AIRE, L.I., May 17. -- Three men and a boy were killed instantly today at the Grant Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad when a westbound train struck a light truck in which they were crossing the tracks. The closed cabin of the truck, it was believed, had prevented the driver from seeing the train as it approached on a stretch of tracks easily visible from both side's of the crossing.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States for the week ended on last Saturday was 2,237,400 barrels, compared with 2,251,900 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 14,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

COBLENZ, Germany, May 17 (AP). Cloudburst floods, which, added six known dead to the twenty-five killed in various disasters throughout Germany other Whitsuntide, apparently had done tremendous damage throughout the whole Moselle Valley, according to meager reports received today.

With virtually every municipal bond house in Wall Street a member of one of the six syndicates that submitted sealed bids yesterday for the new issue of $5,000,000 State of Missouri 4 1/2 per cent road bonds, the sale was closely contested. The bonds, due $500,000 on April 1, 1950; $1000,000 annually from 1951 to 1954, inclusive, and $500,000 in 1955, brought a price of 103.1977, equivalent to about 4.26 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17. -- The Christian Church needs to recover the "old thrill" of religion, not in an emotional sense but as an overwhelming experience transforming life, the members of the graduating class of Princeton Theological Seminary were told this morning by the Rev. Dr. W. Taliaferro Thompson, Professor of Christian Education at Union Seminary, Virginia.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Congress cannot complete its essential legislative program, including taxation and economy and relief measures, and adjourn finally by June 11, SenatorsWatson and Moses, Republican leaders, today informed Speaker Garner and Representative Snell of New York, Republican leader in the House.

On Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays Congress is going to get through its necessary work and adjourn before the national conventions in June. But on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays the thing becomes flatly impossible. There are too many tills to be passed.

An agreement to make an intensive effort to raise $250,000 for the Democratic Victory Campaign was made last night at a conference of leading Democrats at the Metropolitan Club, after a dinner given by Owen D. Young, John W. Davis, chairman of the Victory Campaign Committee, and Alfred E. Smith, nominee for President in 1928.

ADEN, Arabia, May 17. -- The full horror of the Georges Philippar disaster was not realized here until nerve-racked, semi-clothed survivors from the burned French liner came ashore tonight from the rescue ships Contractor and Mahsud.

The ascent of both the south and the north peaks of Mount McKinley by LINDLEY'S party may be described as a complete conquest of one of the most difficult mountains in the world to climb. This is not only because the approach to the Muldrow Glacier is a tremendous test of stamina, but because hidden crevasses are a constant menace to even experienced alpinists.

A chastened America is emerging from the depression with none of its usual indifference to criminal license and civic corruption, Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, declared yesterday in an address before the Motion Picture Club Forum at the club's headquarters, 1,560 Broadway.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre for her daughter, Mrs. Austen Townsend Gray, who sailed with Mr. Gray last night on the Leviathan for their wedding trip in Europe.
MOSCOW, May 17. -- The Nijni-Novgorod Ford plant, Autostroy, again has drawn the fire of the Soviet authorities for failure to produce a tangible result in actual automobiles.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Shipping Board today authorized the Merchant Fleet Corporation to accept the offer of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company of Baltimore to purchase the steamship Lake Glasco for $30,000 cash for operation in the company's coastwise service.

HELENA, Mont., May 17 (AP). -- Montana Democrats today instructed delegates to their national convention to work for a prohibition repeal plank, while Republicans, also in State meeting, advocated a national referendum on the liquor question.

The stock market turned irresolute again yesterday and was unable to follow up its sharp recovery of the previous afternoon. Opening prices were off from a fraction to a point and the trend was irregularly lower until noon, when a rally set in that restored all the earlier losses and lifted some issues above their previous closing quotations.

Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, radio preacher, told a meeting of 2,000 Army members at the Salvation Army Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, yesterday that if he had his way he would commit all the disbursement of charitable funds in New York City to the Salvation Army.

Joseph A. Broderick's story of how he worked night and day to save the Bank of United States in the two and a half months before he closed the institution will go uncontroverted to the jury which for seven weeks has been hearing evidence in General Sessions at the trial of the Superintendent of Banks on a charge of neglect of duty.

Deflation of government costs is the most acute problem facing American business today, John Lowry, vice president of the Merchants' Association of New York, said yesterday at the casual meeting of the organization in the Woolworth Building.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- A major Y in preference to Sigma Xi honors was today given as the "honor most desired" by the members of the senior class of Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University in the announcement of the results of the annual class vote on a list of forty-two questions.
MONTREAL, May 17 (Canadian Press). -- The Newark Bears won the third game of the series with the Royals today, 5 to 4.

ELIZABETH. N.J., May 17. -- With the exception of Linden, where a record vote seemed likely with ballots dropping at the rate of one a minute, voting was comparatively light in today's primary election in Union County. Seventy-two candidates for various municipal offices brought an unprecedented number of voters to the polls in Linden.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 17 (AP). -- Joe Brown, a native of Buffalo, went on a batting spree today that enabled Jersey City to beat the Bisons, 9 to 4, and give the visitors their first victory of the series. He got a homer, a double, two singles and a pass.

Comprehensive economies in the administration of the three city colleges through restrictions in the number of entering students and inireases in the system of undergradlate fees, were approved by the Board of Higher Education at its anlual meeting last night at Board of Education Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Open hearing's in the stock market investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will be resumed Thursday morning. Chairman Norbeck informed the members of the committee today.

CINCINNATI, May 17. -- Memphis Bill Terry's eighth home run of the current championship campaign kept the Giants in the running for all of two hours today, but in the last of the tenth the Reds won their second successive victory over the forces of John McGraw, 2 to 1.

Commissions totaling $61,000 were paid by the N.L. Nelson Ironworks, Inc., of Clifton, N.J., to Daniel McKettrick, former fight promoter, on the sale of snow plows to the New York City Department of Sanitation, it was disclosed yesterday at the hearing of a suit brought by a stockholder of the company in the Jersey City Chancery Court.

TOKYO, May 17 (AP). -- The Seiyukai members hoped that Prince Saionji, last of the elder statesmen and adviser to Emperor Hirohito, would induce the Emperor to give Mr. Suzuki a mandate to form a Ministry.

LONDON, May 17. -- British Government funds rose again at the opening of the Stock Exchange after the holiday. Industrials were quiet, although firmer. Dunlop was better and Imperial Chemical steady. Swedish Match B rose from 5s 9d to 9s 3d, but Kreuger Toll was unchanged.

The twenty-fifth annual park fete of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League, with several thousand girls from the public schools of Manhattan participating, transformed the sheep meadow in Central Park into a forest of gayly decorated Maypoles yesterday afternoon.

Okapi from the Brookmeade Stable, ridden by the apprentice jockey, Silvio Coucci, who has been doing well of late, was a decisive winner of the Bouquet Claiming Stakes, feature at Belmont Park yesterday. Surging ahead strongly in the last furlong, Okapi took the lead and won by a length and a half from the Foxcatcher Farms' Golden Fate, which led the Dorwood Stable's Bronx Park by a head.
LIMA, Peru, May 17 (AP). -- Peru's temporary abandonment of the gold standard has been approved by Congress.

Copper prices established yesterday a new low record in the domestic market, metal being sold at 5 3/8 cents a pound delivered in the Connecticut Valley. Demand was small, and the two or three sellers at the reduced price were unable to dispose of much copper.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 17. -- Albert Horton 3d of Williams, the unseeded defending champion, gained the final round of the New England intercollegiate title tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today along with John Richardson of Dartmouth, the top seeded player, who won the title in 1930.

LONDON, May 17. -- The United States team of women golfers has only to retain its present promising form, particularly on the greens, to meet Miss Joyce Wethered's British team on even terms in the international test at Wentworth Park Saturday.

GRAVESEND, England, May 17. -- The Swedish bark Abraham Rydberg, first home out of a score of sailing ships carrying South Australian grain to Europe, anchored off Gravesend tonight, having made the 11,000-mile journey by way of Cape Town in 124 days.

The State Transit Commission, by a 2-to-1 vote, approved yesterday the application of the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation, a B.M. T. subsidiary, to increase the fare from 2 to 3 cents for the local service on Williamsburg Bridge. The new fare becomes effective tomorrow at 12:01 A.M.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Disagreement over the form of a Federal unemployment relief bill was evident tonight following the second day's session of a committee appointed by the Democratic Steering Committee of the Senate to draft such legislation.

NORTH BRUNSWICK TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 17. -- Mrs. Sophie Furrer, 48 years old, of 12 Maple Avenue, who was elected a member of the Middlesex Democratic County Committee today, her husband, Philip, 57, and their friend, Mrs. Mamie Corrigan, 43, of 5 Chestnut Street, were instantly killed at 11:15 o'clock tonight in an accident at the Adams Station crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Explanation, of the entry in the minute books of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, alleged to have been a forgery, was made yesterday before Referee Robert McC. Marsh at 20 Exchange Place by Eleanor Olsen, stenographer employed in the office of C.W. Whitford, the union's recording secretary.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 18. -- Solution of the problem of forming a new administration for Japan is in suspense because the Emperor's chief adviser, Prince Saionji, last surviving Genro (Elder Statesman), has decided to postpone coming to Tokyo until the situation clears.

Gas Tax Rises. This is a time when the most painless forms of taxation are sought. Under the circumstances, it is rather remarkable that the gasoline tax, now in vogue in all the States, has been kept within comparatively reasonable bounds.

Considerable thought, as a rule, goes into the arranging of a Summer exhibition. Pictures that are to occupy a gallery's walls for a long period should be -- with the visiting public in mind -- sufficiently representative of the artists themselves and the gallery that shows them.

The first pilgrimage this year of Gold Star mothers and widows to visit the graves of their soldier dead in France sailed last night on the Leviathan of the United States Lines. Seventy-eight women from all parts of the United States made up the party.

Small Drop in Buyers Here. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a slight decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week but remained practically the same as for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reports for 1931 a consolidated net loss of $4,510,465 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization, canceled and surrendered leases, minority interest and a loss of $1,787,500 on investment an the stock of the Marida Oil Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, May 18. -- Shantung will again acknowledge the control of the central government in taxation as a result of conferences between General Chiang Poh-cheng, a representative of Chiang Kai-shek, leader of the Nanking regime, and Governor General Han Fu-chu of that province.

BERLIN, May 17. -- A full list of Polish intelligence officers and agents in Russia is said to have been delivered to the Soviet Government by two spies, Wladyslaw Borakowski and Jan Bakowski, who were executed at the Warsaw citadel on Sunday, according to news received here from reliable sources in Warsaw.

LONDON, May 17. -- The first eyewitness account to reach London of the burning of the French motorship Georges Philippar and the rescue of many of her passengers and crew came from Captain Owen, commanding the British rescue steamer Contractor, in a radiogram xo The Evening Standard.

EASTON, Pa., May 17. -- Lafayette College, in the celebration, of its one hundredth anniversary recalled today in a convocation, attended by representatives of 150 American colleges and universities, the enthusiasm of a century ago for France and for the name of the Marquis de Lafayette, who had just revisited the nation which he helped to independence.

PITTSBURGH, May 17. -- Those Brooklyn bats that resounded so loudly were silenced today by Bill Harris, a young right-handed pitcher from Texas, who held the Robins to six hits and was deprived of a shutout only by Floyd Vaughan's wild throw in the eighth.

BOMBAY, May 17. -- Murderous Hindu-Moslem combats kept this city seething today, with arson, looting and savage attacks on innocent passers-by adding to the people's terror. Before a curfew was clamped down at 8 o'clock tonight 11 more persons had been killed and 100 wounded, bringing the total since the riots began, according to revised figures, to 72 killed and nearly 900 injured.

A bronze plaque in recognition of "meritorious service in the war against depression" was presented last night to Colonel Mathew J. Farrell by Tiger Post No. 23 of the American Legion held at a meeting in the Army and Navy Club, 30 West Forty-fourth Street.
Instead of moving from the Shubert Theatre to the Morosco next Monday evening, as had been reported. "Springtime for Henry" is now scheduled to end its Broadway engagement on Saturday night.

The Fordham baseball team registered its tenth, triumph, in eleven starts this season when a long single to centre field by Joe Zapustas sent Jerry Pepper home from third with the winning run in the eleventh inning to beat Colgate at Fordham Field yesterday.

LONDON, May 17 (Canadian Press). -- Lancashire today increased its lead in the county cricket standing by an overwhelming victory over Yorkshire at Bradford, winning the match by an innings and 50 runs.
There was little activity in Manhattan real estate yesterday. Except for the leasing of a house in the Lenox Hill section, few changes of control were reported.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Captain L.C. Covell, Acting Commandant of the Coast Guard, revealed today that from the first the Coast Guard had believed that no such ship as that described by John H. Curtis, self-styled intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, existed.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 17. -- Alien Carpe and Theodore Koven met their deaths probably on May 10 by falling into a crevasse slightly above their camp, pitched at an altitude of 11,000 feet. There is no evidence that they were using a rope and the tragedy may be attributed to Carpe's custom of climbing unroped.

Prices of bonds were weaker again yesterday on the Stock Exchange in all principal classifications. In the United States Government list the Liberty loans moved up 1-32 to 3-32 point, but all Treasury issues were off 1-32 to 12-32 points, the major loss being in the Treasury 3s.

Frank Parzych, 30 years old, of 102 Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, "confessed" to the police yesterday that he was one of a band of seven men that kidnapped the Lindbergh baby. He said the child died because the man carrying it down the ladder let it fall on its head by accident.

The backbone of the building trades strike, which affected directly 30,000 mechanics and helpers, was broken yesterday when a collective agreement on the employers' terms -- wage reductions of 20 to 30 per cent -- was signed for nearly all the unions in the Building Trades Council with the Building Trades Employers' Association.

Jesse L. Lasky, pioneer motion picture producer, has retired as first vice president of the Paramount Publix Corporation, it was announced yesterday by the directors. It was stated recently that Mr. Lasky, who was in charge of the company's production department, would take a three-month leave of absence.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- The Appellate Court today upset a Superior Court ruling in which it said that Captain Christian C. Gross of the diplomatic service was the father of a 4-yearold daughter, Ann, born to his wife after their separation, in 1928. The higher court held that Judge Joseph B. David in Superior Court had no jurisdiction in the matter, and the reversal was made without reference to the evidence.
PARIS. May 17. -- Francois Pietri, French Minister of National Defense, was rescued at sea when a seaplane in which he had been flying to Corsica was forced down in the Mediterranean today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Farm products were showing hardly as many gains as losses in price on May 15 and were "no more than holding their own" as a group, the Department of Agriculture said today in its weekly survey of the markets.

The Julian Goldman Stores, Inc., one of the leading concerns engaged in the sale of men's and women's clothing on the instalment plan, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday listing liabilities of $1,112,865 and assets of $890,220. The petitioner operated forty-two stores in eleven States and had been in business for twenty years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- The Yale freshman nine won its eighth victory of the season today, defeating Milford School, 15 to 3. Harrington, who has pitched all except three innings of the ten games played, fanned thirteen, raising his strike-out total to eighty-seven men in eighty-two innings.

Argument on the taxpayers' action brought by Paul Blanshard of the City Affairs Committee to annul the franchise granted last year to the Brooklyn Bus Corporation, B.M.T. subsidiary, took place yesterday before the Appellate Division.

BUFFALO, May 17. -- A contention that American education has failed dismally in its effort to train its students for good citizenship was made by Dr. A. Caswell Ellis, director of Cleveland College, Western Reserve University, at the round-table discussion on education for citizenship in connection with the annual conference of the American Association for Adult Education today.
Apartment houses in several communities of the New Jersey metropolitan area were included in the realty turnover reported yesterday.

Margin requirements on short sales have been increased in the last week by several members of the New York Stock Exchange to a minimum of 10 points. The minimum has been 5 points for stocks selling at 10 to 20 and 50 per cent for those selling below 10.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 17. -- A permanent writ of prohibition preventing Circuit Judge Hall of St. Louis from taking further action in temporary receivership for the Missouri State Life Insurance Company was issued today by the Missouri Supreme Court en bane.

Celebration of Greenwich Village Week will begin on Saturday with a children's carnival, and during next week the village will be on exhibition. Greenwich House and other community settlements of the section will have charge of the fete, which will be the first of its kind since 1913.

Earl Averill's home run in the first inning yesterday at the Yankee Stadium ended, for the time being at least, the drive of Manager McCarthy's pitching staff toward a new shut-out record, but the Yanks, though held to four hits by Mel Harder, Cleveland right-hander, kept their winning streak in operation, recording their eighth straight victory.

TACOMA, Wash., May 17 (AP). -- Sunny Mary Sundstrom, 4 years old, daughter of William J. Sundstrom, an executive of the General Motor Corporation living in New York City, was drowned in Steilacoom Lake near here today.

Less rain in the Southwest and predictions of favorable weather for the cotton crop both east and west of the Mississippi River caused a setback yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange. Trading was steady for several hours in sympathy with improvements in stocks and wheat, but selling by spot interests depressed prices in the last hour and closed the list at the bottom, 18 to 20 points lower than on Monday.

PARIS, May 17. -- The Bourse resumed operations today after the three-day closing with conditions unfavorable. The weakness was accentuated throughout the session. With the exception of Royal Dutch Oil, gold mining stocks, and some of the French rentes, the entire list suf- fered losses.

BERLIN, May 17. -- Business on the Boerse was extremely quiet on the first day after the holidays. Uncertainties of the political situation in Prussia, and reports that several big banks in the United States would be merged were regarded as the cause of failure of the market to improve.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 17 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings defeated the Reading Keys, 10 to 2 and 11 to 3, in a double-header today. Puccinelli of the victors drove out his eleventh and twelfth home runs of the season.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals combined two singles and a double off Ed Brandt in the third inning today to score all the runs which gave them a 4 to 3 victory over Boston in the second game of the series.

A card party under the auspices of the Artists and Teachers Benevolent Society will be held this afternoon in the Louis XV ballroom of the Ambassador. The proceeds will be devoted to the society's pension fund, which provides for necessities and cares for needy and ill artists, musicians and teachers in various professions.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17 (AP). -- Twenty women sought positions on the tickets of the two major parties in today's primary election, and the majority of them were successful in their efforts. One, Representative Mary T. Norton, was renominated on the Democratic slate for the House of Representatives, and the others were named to Assembly tickets in seven counties.

Three Roosevelts -- Archibald B., George E. and Philip J. -- were among those who sent telegrams commending former Governor Alfred E. Smith on his radio speech Monday night, in which he urged that partisanship be sunk in the enactment of a plan to lift the country out of the present economic depression.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17. -- Opposition to proposed endorsement of the principle of compulsory unemployment reserves was recorded this afternoon by a vote of 151 to 124 at the annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 17 (AP). -- A belief that Theodore Koven received injuries from which he died in a futile attempt to save Allen Carpe was expressed by A.D. Lindley, Minneapolis mountaineer, in a telephone conversation from Mount McKinley Park today.

Decreased income on its investments has forced a cut of $117,000 in the budget of the Union Theological Seminary for the next academic year, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the institution, told its Associated Alumni at their annual meeting there yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17 (AP). -- A dispatch to the newspaper La Nacion from Salta, Argentina, said today there were persistent rumors there that Bolivian troops had begun an offensive against Paraguay in the Gran Chaco region, long a hot-bed of dispute.

Declaring that the Municipal Civil Service Commission had "plainly permitted the political organization to build up its patronage machine" in this city, the annual report of the Civil Service Reform Association's executive committee charged yesterday that ninety Democratic district leaders and their relatives, together with, sixteen Republican district leaders, drew combined salaries of more than $715,000 a year from the city without having taken civil service examinations for their positions.

A new landscape plan for Bryant Park and the reproduction of Federal Hall which has been erected there in connection with the Washington Bicentennial celebration is being made by Joseph H. Freedlander, architect of the reproduction and chairman of the plan and scope committee of the city bicentennial committee.
AURORA, Ill., May 17 (AP). -- Tannery, E.F. Pritchard's 5-year-old campaigner, today won the top race at Exposition Park, making a great stretch run to defeat Portmanteau.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP). -- The Cubs batted Ed Holley, a former teammate, from the box during an eight-run uprising in the seventh inning today to defeat Philadelphia, 9 to 4.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- The national council of the United States Chamber of Commerce adopted a resolution today calling for a referendum on the prohibition laws among the members of the national chamber.

State Senator John A. Hastings, who is to testify before the Hofstadter committee tomorrow, visited the committee's headquarters yesterday and revealed that he received a $10,000 a year salary from Barren Collier, Inc., an advertising company specializing in outdoor, bus and street car displays.

As was expected from the recent course of foreign exchange rates, gold exports were resumed yesterday. Of the $10,600,000 taken for shipment only $2,000,000 went to France, but Switzerland drew $6,000,000 and Holland and Belgium, between them, $2,500,000.

CHURCHILL, DOWNS, Ky., May 17 (AP). -- Herbert M. Woolf's Lady Broadcast flashed her old-time form today to stop the winning streak of Mrs. M.B. Price's Silverdale in the Western Parkway Purse, feature at Churchill Downs.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- A further improvement in sentiment was apparent today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and local bulls had some assistance from commission houses in an effort to advance prices. Quotations moved up 1 1/4 cents a bushel on the active futures after an early dip, July at the top showing 3 cents above yesterday's low.

Scoring its runs in pairs, New York University's baseball team downed City College by 12 to 4 at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Violet nine's final home appearance of the season, and Ernie Vavra, who pitched for N.Y.U., recorded his fifth victory in six starts.

ALBANY, May 17. -- One of the greatest dangers that faces the NewYork Penitentiary on Welfare Island is a possible breakdown of its electric plant, which would plunge the place in darkness, "especially dangerous for a penal institution," according to a report just approved by the Commissioner of Correction.

John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boatbuilder and intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping, confessed yesterday that his negotiations with the kidnappers were false from beginning to end. He gave as his excuse that he had hoped to sell his story for publication and to the motion pictures.

BUFFALO, May 17. -- Felix M. "Warburg, New York banker, told Jewish leaders of Buffalo at a luncheon today that the investments made by American Jews in Central and Eastern Europe for the Jews of those countries were at stake, in the economic crisis.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 17. -- Content with the delegate-gathering process in behalf of Governor Roosevelt during the current period, members of his party expressed the opinion today that the intensive drive to solidify support for him would be reserved for the homestretch of the pre-convention campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The House of Representatives today eliminated three economies amounting to about $5,794,165 from the reduced War Department appropriation bill during a day of debate in which two prominent Republicans, Representatives Wood of Indiana and Beedy of Maine, charged each other with "misrepresenting" the President.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Congress has a way, especially in Presidential years, of untangling itself suddenly and adjourning. Not since 1916 has there been a Summer session in the quadrennial election year.

NORFOLK, Va., May 17. -- The admission by John H. Curtis that he had concocted his story of negotiations with the Lindbergh baby's kidnappers out of whole cloth was received with incredulity by the Rev. H. Dobson Peacock, who, with Rear Admiral Guy H. Burrage, retired, enabled Curtis to get in touch with Colonel Lindbergh.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox today dropped their third game in a row to the Chicago White Sox, 7 -- 3. Milton Gaston was touched for ten hits, but he started four of Chicago's five double plays.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- A new civilization, in which a "free, secure and creative social life" must supersede wealth, size, speed and invention as the essential values, was pictured here tonight by Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of The Temple, Cleveland, as necessary to the nation's successful weathering of the economic depression.

The most encouraging report that has emanated from New Suffolk, L.I., this season, concerning weakfish was received yesterday. Peconic Bay captains were able to dock with the satisfaction that the fish seemed "at last to be here."

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- "Prohibition generally" was discussed by W. Kingsland Macy with President Hoover today in a conference which also was attended by Harry J. Bareham of Rochester, Republican leader of Monroe County, and Clarence R. King of Syracuse, the leader in Onondaga County.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Strong disapproval of the Goldsborough bill, which aims to restore the dollar's purchasing power to a 1926 level, was expressed by Secretary Mills in a letter to Senator Norbeck, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, made public today.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 31, at 11:30 A.M., for independent operation of the new city subway system under the revised form of contract prepared after a previous one had failed to elicit bids.

NEWARK, N.J., May 17. -- A twelve-mile pursuit of three suspects in an automobile by a lone patrolman in a police car ended here today when the automobile containing the escaping men overturned at South and Pulaski Streets and burst into flames.

Salary reductions for elected and appointed city officials and Supreme Court justices are under consideration by the ways and means committee of the Board of Estimate, Mayor Walker announced at a meeting of the board yesterday following a request for such reductions made by the New York League of Women Voters.

Iona School's baseball team registered its ninth triumph in as many Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. games by defeating Fordham Prep, 7 to 4, at Fordham Field yesterday. Fee, the victors' pitcher, fanned fifteen batsmen.

Mayor Walker praised members of the Police Department for their devotion to the protection of the "common people" during the exercises at City Hall yesterday in which he bestowed medals of honor in recognition of the heroism of twenty policemen, nine of whom were killed last year in performing their duty.

The directors of the Foundation Company (foreign) were authorized at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday to purchase the company's stock with surplus funds. The directorate was reduced from seven to these five members, who were re-elected: J.J. Brown, Morgan Cowperthwaite, Charles A. Dana, John W. Doty and Harold C. Richard.

LONDON, May 17. -- The present riots in Bombay show the futility of trying to impose any Hindu-Moslem setttlement from London, in the opinion of Mrs. Patricia Kendall, an American writer, who has just returned from watching the working of the government's repressive ordinances in India.

Mrs. Granville Forteseue, who, with Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, was convicted of manslaughter, and served a sentence of one hour in Honolulu in connection with the death of Joseph Kahahawai, one of five men accused of attacking Mrs. Massie, will demand a full pardon, she declared yesterday following her arrival in New York.
EDDIE MORGAN of the Cleveland Indians didn't want to talk about hitting or about pitchers.

A plea to theatrical stars now engaged in other work to support the legitimate stage, "the mother of the theatrical arts," by returning to it at intervals is contained in an editorial in the current issue of Equity, the official publication of the Actors' Equity Association.

The Longwood Bowl invitation tournament, one of the oldest and most important events on the tennis calendar and the fixture in which Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena started his remarkable string of victories leading to the national championship last year, will open on July 11.

The directors of the Foundation Company (foreign) were authorized at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday to purchase the company's stock with surplus funds. The directorate was reduced from seven to these five members, who were re-elected: J.J. Brown, Morgan Cowperthwaite, Charles A. Dana, John W. Doty and Harold C. Richard.

LONDON, May 17. -- The present riots in Bombay show the futility of trying to impose any Hindu-Moslem setttlement from London, in the opinion of Mrs. Patricia Kendall, an American writer, who has just returned from watching the working of the government's repressive ordinances in India.

Gordon S. Rentschler and S. Sloan Colt, presidents respectively of the National City Bank and the Bankers Trust Company, were examined yesterday in the International Match bankruptcy proceedings, in connection with the receiver's contemplated action to recover assets valued at $4,500,000.

Cooperative action by the mutual savings banks of the country to promote sound administration of cities and of the nation's railways was urged yesterday by speakers at the opening of the twelfth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Representative Maas of Minnesota introduced a bill today to abolish the office of postmaster in all first-class postoffices, and in second-class offices having receipts of more than $18,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 18 -- Governor Roosevelt re-avowed tonight his demand for consideration of the "forgotten man" and assailed "privilege in the saddle" in an address to a gathering of Georgia Kiwanis Clubs here.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Self-identification of children with animals, a widespread form of behavior, is being investigated by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka curator of physical anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution.

VATICAN CITY, May 18 -- "No leader in public economy, no power of organization will ever be able to bring social conditions to a peaceful solution unless first in the very field of economics there triumphs moral law based on God and conscience," says Pope Pius XI in an encyclical letter addressed today to all Bishops of the world, in which he examines the causes and suggests remedies for the present economic crisis.

The Southern Pacific Company formally passed the dividend's on its capital stock yesterday, making the first omission since 1905. The action was forecast in February, when the directors failed to take action on the quarterly dividend usually payable on April 1.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Florence Barnard plan for teaching economics in the graded and high schools of the country was suggested to President Hoover today by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts as one of the ways to educate the Americans of the future in the value of budgeting in governmental as well as private affairs.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were notified by telephone yesterday by officials of the Exchange that margin requirements on short sales of customers should be increased to a minimum of ten points. Previously the minimum requirements of many brokerage firms had been five points on stocks selling between 10 and 20, and 50 per cent for those selling below 10.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- The thirty-first quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was asked today formally to disclaim responsibility for the views of the Men's Council of the Methodist Church, which on Sunday adopted a resolution warning that "right now there is the greatest danger, far greater than known, of the political debacle of the temperance movement."
BERLIN, May 18 (AP) -- The Reichsbank statement as of May 14 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Authority to completely unify the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company with its eleven subsidiary lines, to provide a consolidated system of 7,833 miles valued at $512,939,972, was sought today in an application by the roads involved, filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Democratic House, which bolted its leaders on both tax and economy bills, today voted the Bankhead bill, carrying a $4,000,000 authorization for vocational rehabilitation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 18 (AP) -- President Juan E. Montero promulgated a law today authorizing a State gasoline monopoly, but it was understood in official and business circles that the government would hold the monopoly in abeyance until a more propitious time for setting it up.
