MOUNT McKINLEY PARK, Alaska, May 18 -- It is with the deepest regret that I describe our discovery of the death of Alien Carpe and Theodore Koven in the course of our descent of Mount McKinley. I had met Mr. Carpe in New York in February and had received much valuable advice from him regarding the plans and equipment for our expedition.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 18 -- Manhattan College routed the naval training station nine by 19 to 5 today. Led by Hassett, who crashed out five hits in as many trips to the plate, Manhattan collected twenty-one hits and scored in every inning.

One cannot regret the public display of exacerbation by those eminent Republican statesmen, Mr. BEEDY and Mr. WOOD, as to the accuracy of their ears and their memories. It has drawn from Speaker GARNER another instalment of his serial anti-Hooveriad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that many Democrats like myself, convinced that our present tariff and the mounting tariff rates of nearly all the rest of the world constitute a frightful obstacle to the return of this country's prosperity, must have read with bitter disappointment the veto message disapproving H.R. 6662, entitled "An act to amend the tariff act of 1930 and for other purposes."

PARIS, May 18 -- The next French Government will support a policy of international bimetallic standard of currency, Raymond Patenotre, Deputy and one of the wealthiest men in the country, said in an interview with your correspondent today.

LONDON, May 18 -- A suggestion is made in the current Westminster Bank Review that sooner or later Great Britain will return to the gold standard, "but only upon conditions which will insure, as far as human foresight can govern unknown future contingencies, that the gold standard shall not again be called upon to function under impracticable conditions."

What Secretary STIMSON told the reporters when he landed in New York he seems to have told Mr. HOOVER when he rendered an account of his visit to Geneva. He is not optimistic about the disarmament conference but is hopeful. He thinks there is good ground for expecting a substantial gain.

Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in excerpts from his annual report, made public yesterday, hailed the establishment of the Bureau of Child Guidance as "one of the most progressive steps in the development of our school system."

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- Fifteen men of science, five of whom have pursued their researches in foreign countries, were honored for their achievements at the medal day exercises of the Franklin Institute today.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Senate today voted overwhelmingly against the proposal to legalize 2.75 per cent beer as a basis for new taxes. It then faced about and by a still more decisive ballot approved a levy on ingredients for home brew and home-made wine, calculated to yield $97,000,000 in new revenue for the 1933 budget.

Greenwich Village Week will be observed from next Saturday to the following Friday. Several concerts have been arranged to increase interest in the musical opportunities of the Village. The Greenwich House Music School, the People's Chorus, the churches and the public schools are planning programs.

Giving away handicaps that will force them to come close to their own world's record performances to win, Gene Venzke, George Spits, and Leo Sexton, three record-smashers of the recent indoor season, will head a field of 500 athletes in the twilight track and field meet of the New York. Curb Exchange at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight.

Clarence M. Lowes, a leading resident of Flushing and vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburg in Brooklyn, was arrested last night on a charge of grand larceny in connection with an alleged transaction involving $42,500.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18 -- A proposal to empower the ecclesiastical court of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island to issue decisions on problems connected with the annulment of marriages was held over until next year at the closing session of the annual diocesan convention here today in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley made no ruling today on the motion to dissolve the injunction restraining banks in New York from auctioning securities pledged with them by Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation securities Company, for loans amounting to $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An additional loan of $1,576,200 to the receivers of the Wabash Railway Company from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LONDON, May 18 -- News of further rioting in Bombay, with eleven persons killed and seventy injured, bringing the total of casualties in five days of intercommunal disturbances in India to more than a hundred dead and well over a thousand injured, has failed to arouse British public opinion to the extent that casual mention of these figures might lead Americans to expect.

Mayor Walker delivered an ultimatum to his department heads and subordinates at City Hall last night, warning them that they faced the loss of their positions unless they effected "substantial reduction" in the budget for next year and established enough new sources of revenue to lighten the tax burden upon real estate in the city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 -- Harvard's baseball team easily defeated Bates, 12 to 1, at Soldiers Field today, with Harold Taylor holding the Lewiston team to three scattered hits in his second start of this season.

The League of Nations has grown steadily in effectiveness and usefulness during the last ten years, in the opinion of Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson Administration, as expressed in a reply to five questions submitted to him on behalf of the League of Nations Association.
The text of Mayor Walker's address on economy to his departmen heads and subordinates at City Hall yesterday follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18 -- Business men and bankers, not legislators, must accomplish the return of prosperity, Senator Robert Buckley of Ohio said today to the Maryland Bankers' Association, which is holding its thirty-seventh annual convention here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 18 -- Ned Wheeler turned back the hitherto undefeated Providence College nine today with six scattered hits and Yale won, 3 to 1. The Friars failed to score until the seventh, when Perrin led with a triple and scored on Roberge's single.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Hoover today sent a personal greeting and an official welcome to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which opened its annual conference Here yesterday.

Two blocks of Carrara marble, which were to have been auctioned today by customs agents, were found yesterday to contain more than $1,500 worth of Scotch whisky and brandy. The two blocks had been lying on the Fabre Line pier at the foot of Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn, since Jan. 3, 1930.

What has happened to the great Tammany jurists who a little while ago were about to rush to the courts to defend and vindicate those constitutional rights upon which Judge SEABURY was trampling like a tyrant? Has their zeal cooled off? Whatever the explanation, they have been leading a sweet submissive life since the legislative investigation began to close in upon the Mayor.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 18 -- The State Democratic convention here today elected delegates to the Democratic convention favorable to the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt and went on record for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead act.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, world famous pianist and former Prime Minister of Poland, made an address here last night in which he declared that any policy tending to isolate Poland from her allies was a dangerous policy that might well lead to another world war.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 19 -- The crisis in Japan is moving toward a solution. Kisaburo Suzuki, president of the Seiyukai, the dominant party, will form a Cabinet of an essentially party government, which, however, will not be confined to members of the Seiyukai.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The Council of the League of Nations, which reumed its sixty-seventh session today, will be urgently asked before the week is out to send a representative to the Kru coast of Liberia "to assist in the pacification of the country and return the tribes to their villages under conditions' of security."

EASTON, Pa., May 18 -- As part of its centennial celebration Lafayette College today undertook a revaluation of the enthusiasm for the French which caused the citizens of Easton a century ago to name their new college for Lafayette, who had just revisited the United States.

More than $541,000 goes to twenty-one charitable and public organizations from the $679,720 net estate of Henry F. Homes, lawyer, who died on Sept. 15, 1929, according to the valuations given in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday at the State Tax Commission.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, supports General Manager Giulio Gatti Casazza's policies in facing the financial crisis that beset the company this season. Mr. Gatti-Casazza received yesterday a letter to this effect from Paul D. Cravath. chairman of the board and president of the association.

The Boca Grande Tarpon Tournament Club is sponsoring the first of what is to be an annual tarpon tourlament, and, judging from the results af those who fished the first time an Monday, some interesting fishing awaits those who, between now and July 15, decide to go to this locale an Florida's west coast for game fish.

Driving her way before a quartering wind, the large schooner yacht Vema, formerly Edward F. Hutton's Hussar, made a record passage of the Atlantic for a sailing vessel, according to cable advices received yesterday from England.

Because of decreased volume of business and uncertain conditions, the directors of the American Sugar Refining Company voted yesterday, to reduce the quarterly dividend on the common stock from $1 to 50 cents. The regular quarterly payment of $1.75 on the preferred stock was voted.
LONDON, May 18 -- The speech of Premier Bennett to the Canadian Parliament revived British interest in financial affairs in the United States and "disquieting" reports coming across the Atlantic.
HANOVER, N.H., May 18 -- Dartmouth won from Vermont today, 11 to 10. The visitors were charged with nine errors, while the Green committed three.
MONTREAL, Thursday, May 19 -- The Gazette today publishes the following:

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- An appeal for a "straightforward" Democratic platform that would evade no important issues was made by former Governor Harry Byrd of Virginia in an address today before the Democratic Women's Luncheon Club.

The market in money was a counterpart of previous sessions, business being on a small scale at quotations which developed no variation. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent, the counter trading at 1 1/2 and Federal funds at 1/3. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all dull.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a native-born Negro resident, citizen and voter of New York, whose foreparents for three generations back also dwelt in the State of New York, may I tender my sincere thanks and appreciation for your editorial "The Negro Is Here," appearing in today's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES?

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States will not go off the gold standard, Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, confidently predicted when he appeared before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today to oppose the Goldsborough and Fletcher dollar stabilization bills.

Count Rene d'Harnoncourt was born in Vienna in 1901 -- though this is much too prosaic for any review of so romantic and versatile an artist's exhibition. Some of d'Harnoncourt's more recent drawings, many of them in color, are being shown at the Weyhe Gallery, where they will remain through the month.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Senators dropped their fourth straight game to the Browns today. St. Louis winning 11 to 7. Leading the league when the Browns arrived, the Senators finished the series well behind the Yankees.
Realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday were confined almost exclusively to housing properties.

The success of the Republican faction headed by former State Senator Ralph W. Chandless in Bergen County and the defeat by a narrow margin of State Senator Arthur N. Pierson, Republican, for renomination in Union County following his transfer from a dry to a wet platform, which was interpreted as having lost one following for him without gaining another, were the outstanding upsets revealed in the tabulations of primary results in New Jersey yesterday.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 18 -- No word has been received from Spadavecchia, now missing for seven days with only a limited food supply. [Nicholas W. Spadavecchia was with the expedition of which Carpe and Koven were members. When Beckwith fell ill he started to find a telephone and summon aid.]

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Average wholesale prices throughout the United States declined during April to the lowest point on record. The index number of wholesale prices for that month was placed by the Labor Department today at 65.5, compared with 66 for March and based on average wholesale prices for 1926 equaling 100.

Warden Lewis E. Lawes, whose book "20,000 Years in Sing Sing" is among the non-fiction leaders, will be guest of honor and speaker at a literary reception to be given in the auditorium of Wanamaker's tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. Grover A. Whalen, general manager of the store and former Police Commissioner, will introduce Mr. Lawes, who will autograph copies of his book after his address.

DUBLIN, May 18 -- Despite the controversy with Great Britain over the oath of allegiance, it was officially announced today that President Eamon de Valera intended to lead the Irish Free State's delegation to the Ottawa imperial conference in July.

The great problem of the world today is not that of providing a substitute for the gold standard, but that of making the gold standard a better standard, according to Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, research professor of international finance at Princeton University.

Two former Governors of New York, Alfred E. Smith and Charles S. Whitman; Herbert H. Lehman, the present Lieutenant Governor, and fully a dozen of the city's leading bankers appeared yesterday as character witnesses in behalf of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, at Mr. Broderick's trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.

Charging misappropriation of more than $1,250,000 of the assets of the company and loss of $538,000 to stockholders through a scheme to dissolve the firm and transfer its assets to a new company, Ruth Goldman filed yesterday a stockholder's suit in the Supreme Court against William P. Goldman Brothers, Inc., manufacturers of GGG clothes, and William P. Goldman and Morris Goldman as directors in control of the company and majority stockholders.

NEW York University's track team defeated Rutgers, 86 1/2 to 39 1/2, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the winners' only campus appearance this season and their second and final dual engagement of the current campaign.

THE Cleveland Indians have departed, but they left several stories behind them. One of the tales has to do with the late Alexander Julius Heinemann, who owned the New Orleans Pelicans of the Southern Association for many years and was one of the quaint figures in baseball.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Senate investigation of the stock market will be resumed tomorrow morning with the hearing of more than a dozen witnesses whose names are a closely guarded secret, but private conversations in Senatorial circles today revealed a far different attitude toward the inquiry than the approving one that marked its opening.

The Roxy Theatres Corporation, owner of the Rcxy Theatre, the $10,000,000 dream of Samuel L. (Roxy) Rothafel, passed yesterday into equity receivership, following its default last April on a mortgage payment of $200,000.

The Public Service Commission closed yesterday its year-old investigation of fees and charges paid by the twelve operating companies of the Associated Gas and Electric system to the so-called service companies that are affiliated with the system.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee today voted to report next Tuesday the Cochran bill making it a capital offense to transport a kidnapped person, across a State line. This is the first action by a Congressional body since the child of Colonel Lindbergh was found dead and is expected to be the forerunner of several equally drastic measures.

TEMUCO, Cautin Province, Chile, May 18 -- Fifty laborers were buried alive today behind a curtain of mud at the entrance of Las Raices Tunnel near Longquinay on the route of the new Southern Railroad through the Andes.

PITTSBURGH, May 18. -- It required only an hour and twenty-nine minutes for the Robins to take the third game of the current series from the Pirates today and very little of that time was occupied by the Pirates at bat. They got four hits and two of the quartet were very scratchy.

SCHENECTADY, May 18 -- More important than winning new ground in the battle with vulgarity and ignorance is the consolidating and holding of the territory already won, declared Dr. Harold A. Larrabee today in his Phi Beta Kappa address before the faculty and students of Union College at the annual Prize Day exercises. Dr. Larrabee made a strong plea for having the courage of our "intellections," a word he coined.
VATICAN CITY, May 18 -- Following is the full text of the encyclical of Pope Plus XI calling upon the world to unite in prayer for divine assistance in overcoming the prevailing universal distress:
A 53,000 mortgage certificate was sold yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

BERLIN, May 18 -- Trading at today's session of the Boerse was again extremely quiet. Politically and economically there were no stimulants, and investments by the public which supported the market in recent weeks seem to have come to a standstill for the time being.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 18 -- In team matches among clubs of the Westchester and Fairfield Counties' Women's Golf Association at the Woodway Country Club today, the Greenwich Country Club scored 5 1/2 points, Woodway 3 1/2 points, and the Century Country Club 6 points in Class A.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, May 18 -- Two-year-old Eugene Swearingen was stolen from his crib last night by extortionists, who apparently lost their nerve and tossed him behind a fence, county authorities said today.

LONDON, May 18 -- Following the recent rises. British Government funds weakened today. Industrial stocks were quiet, with Dunlop and Imperial Chemical improving. Swedish Match B fell after an early advance.

WEST CHESTER. Pa., May 18 (AP) -- Judith Vosselli Lloyd, stage and screen actress whom John Eshelman Lloyd, wealthy Philadelphia lumberman, divorced in Reno Jess than a month ago, today began a trespass suit against Mr. Lloyd's present wife, the former Mrs. Mary Penrose Gilford, of New York and West Chester.

BERLIN, May 18 -- The trend of Germany's foreign trade in April again increased the difficulties Germany faces in transferring the full amount of her obligations abroad, Imports rose and exports declined sharply, the export surplus falling from 152,000,000 marks [$36,176,000] in March to 45,000,000 marks [$11,710,000] in April, which is the lowest since July, 1930.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 18 -- Cornell lost its sixth Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today, bowing to Pennsylvania, 4 -- 1. The Ithacans were unable to bunch their six hits off Johnny Jackson and left eleven men on bases.

Although public offering will not be made until today of the new issue of $3,986,000 city of Newark (N.J.) 5 3/4 per cent bonds, which was awarded formally yesterday morning by the city commission to the single banking group that submitted a tender on Tuesday, the bankers reported yesterday that advance orders had been received for virtually the entire amount.

The Case of City Budgets. At least as late as 1930 the cost of municipal government in the United States was still increasing, despite the fact that the dollar had a larger purchasing power than in any year since the war.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- All records for counterfeiting were broken in the past year, bootleggers are joining in the fraudulent-money game and there is now more counterfeit money in circulation than at any time within his memory, William H. Moran, chief of the Secret Service, said today.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox today scored their first victory of the season on their home diamond by topping the White Sox, 13 -- 10. in the final game of the series. Five rival pitchers were pounded hard as the Red Sox broke a six-game losing streak.

Swimmers of Henry P. O'Neil School captured the honors with 44 points in the individual P. S. A. L. junior high school championships in the Seward Park pool last night. Prospect and Fenimore Cooper scored 16 and 15 points, respectively.

CINCINNATI, May 18. -- The Giants appeared to be riding to another fall today, when with an effort born of dispair they crushed the Reds with a seven-run rally in the seventh in which the final thrust was provided by Memphis Bill Terry's ninth home run of the current campaign.

Housing properties on the west side figured prominently in Manhattan real estate activity yesterday. New contracts were reported on properties on Washington Heights, in Harlem and West Fifty-sixth Street.

NEW YORK. The Counselor of the American Legation at Copenhagen and Mrs. North Winship, who have been at the Plaza, will sail tomorrow on the Bremen and will be in Paris for a brief stay before going to Copenhagen. Major Gen. Blanton Winship, U.S.A., of Washington, has been visiting them here.

Inflation, properly conceived and applied, is the only measure that will pull the country out of the depression, according to W.E. Woodward, former banker, who has spent the last few years writing biographies and novels. His book, "Money for Tomorrow," in which he develops this contention, is published today by Liveright, Inc.

Excessive construction of new ships at the close of the World War and an unwise tariff policy in recent years were blamed for much of the difficulty which American ship lines now face, in a statement issued yesterday by Roger D. Lapham, president of the American Hawaiian Steamship Line.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP). -- The Athletics captured the series from Detroit, two games to one, by winning the final contest today, 8 to 2.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 18 -- Mrs. Bedell H. Harned was hostess at one of the many luncheon entertainments in the Homestead colony today. Guests in her party included Mrs. George A. Ellis, Mrs. Daniel Karsner, Miss Mary D. Brooks, Mrs. James B. Weir, Miss Carolyn U. Weber and Miss Clara Murdock.

Babe Ruth's home run, his first since April 30, gave a spectacular finishing touch yesterday at Yankee Stadium to the clean sweep the Yankees successfully completed of their May schedule with the four Western American League clubs. Nine consecutive victories were recorded, the Indians yielding four of them.

The program for the weekly concert to be held at the Lyceum Theatre on Sunday night in aid of the Actors' Dinner Club is announced to include Beatrice Lillie, Albert Carroll, Hal LeRoy, Helen Broderick, Edmund Lowe, Leon Rothier, Smith and Dale, Olive Borden, Frank Morgan, Victor McLaglen, Medrano and Donna, Bubbles and Lawler, and James Stanley.

BUCHAREST, May 18 -- Marine Craconescu, chief of the Bucharest secret police, was arrested yesterday, according to the newspaper Cuvantul, charged with being the accomplice of bandits whom he was supposed to repress.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday, and despite weakness in securities closed at gains of 8 to 9 points.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was again extremely dull yesterday, and after a ragged show of resistance prices turned downward once more in the afternoon to close between 1 and 2 points lower on the average. The volume of shares dealt in, about 684,000, was the smallest in a week, as was the number of different issues which changed hands.

Arthur Hammerstein has obtained a settlement whereby the United Scenic Artists Union, Local 829, will permit the completion, of the settings for "The Man Who Reclaimed His Head," a play by Jean Bart, which Mr. Hammerstein will try out next month in association with L. Lawrence Weber.

With April imports at the lowest point for any corresponding month since 1911, the Ways and Means Committee of the House is holding hearings on a bill which would still further curtail exchange of foreign goods. This measure is sponsored by Representative HAWLEY of Oregon, co-author with Senator SMOOT of the present tariff law.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.
The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding declined $32,251,844 in April, reducing the total to $879,038,870 on April 30. compared with $1,422,021,675 on the same date last year.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 18 (AP) -- A fierce battle between Chinese insurgents and Japanese, in which both sides lost heavily, raged today along the north bank of the Sungari River, just north of this city. It began yesterday evening.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- A continuation of unfavorable weather and crop reports from the West and South-west and a fair run of local professional buying advanced the prices of wheat on the Board of Trade early today about 3/4 cent over yesterday's finish, but the market became overbought and when weakness in stocks developed there was little support.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 18 (AP) -- Long-shot players came in for a big innings today at Churchill Downs. The outstanding surprise came in the feature when Hildur Rock, racing for Hamed Brothers, defeated Justice Logan in a driving finish. Hildur Rock rewarded his backers at $26.58 for $2.

One fireman was killed and two others of a crew of seven were injured yesterday when a part of the steering-gear of Hook and Ladder Truck 32 broke, causing the truck to crash into an electric-light pole at Boston Road and De Reimer Avenue, the Bronx.

The directors of the Seaboard Oil Company declared yeseterday a quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share on the capital stock. Previously, the stockholders at their annual meeting had approved a reduction in the stated value of the capital stock from $7 to $4 a share.

One of Park Avenue's finest private residences, the Redmond house on the northwest corner of Sixtyninth Street, is being torn down to make way for the new home of the Union Club now located on the northeast corner of Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Chambers gave a dinner last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for Miss Elizabeth Van Rensselaer Voislawsky, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Antonie P. Voislawsky, and Joseph van Beuren Wittmann, whose marriage will take place May 26.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Parliamentary rules were devised to expedite the business of law-making bodies and to permit clear-cut votes, on points of political principle as well as on specific items of legislation. How these rules may achieve results exactly contrary to their purpose was illustrated during the Senate debate on the tax-tariff bill today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18 -- Dunlap Campbell of Dunwoodie romped off with all the awards in the opening one-day tournament of the season for the Westchester County Golf Association at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today, but the association's rules permitted him to take only one.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Republican Congressional leaders have decided that there will be no adjournment or recess of Congress until the appropriation tax and economy bills and probably the relief legislation are enacted.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The League of Nations Council today formally approved rules for League supervision of the armies and navies of disputants when war threatens. These rules were drawn up to implement the "convention to improve the means of preventing war."

MELBOURNE, May 18 -- With the dismissal of J.T. Lang as Premier of New South Wales and the triumph of the United Australia party at the State election in Victoria, all six States of the Australian Commonwealth are now governed by ministries pledged to enforce internal economies and pay external debts.

The Municipal Art Society has rendered a public service by calling attention to the official functions of the Art Commission. The charter provides that no work of art shall become the property of the city or be contracted for or erected unless the design, or the work itself, has been submitted to the commission and has been approved by it, together with the proposed location.

Check books, stubs, canceled vouchers and memoranda covering approximately $1,500,000 spent by the organizing committee of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, have been destroyed and no record exists showing the specific and itemized purposes for which the money was used, Jacob S. Solomon, secretary of the committee, testified yesterday at an examination before trial in a suit brought by fifteen members for an accounting of $7,500,000 of the local's funds.

Mrs. Isabel Sloan's Flag Pole, bearing her Brookmeade Stable silks, was the surprise winner in the thirty-second running of the featured Swift Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The victor paid 8, to 1 and won by two lengths from another 8 to 1 shot, the Anall Stable's Larranaga.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The market for hogs showed a heavy undertone today, being easy at the beginning of trading and generally declining to show a loss of 10 to 15 cents at the close, while some sales of packing sows showed 25 cents lower. Shipping demand was again inactive, while packers were slow in taking hold.

Few members of the Assembly from Kings, Queens and Richmond receive commendation for effective service in a report of the Citizens Union Committee on Legislation which was made public yesterday. Most of those included in the report are credited with "average" records or records below average.

A series of coincidences and remarkable explanations came to light at yesterday's public hearing of the Hofstadter committee when Samuel Seabury, chief counsel, tried to link Mayor Walker with the transactions of the missing Russell T. Sherwood.

LONDON, May 18 -- The members of the United States women's golf team today visited the Royal Ashdown Forest course and played a number of social matches as the guests of Angus V. Hambro, chairman of the British rules committee.

The breakdown of religious influences in American secular colleges and universities was decried yesterday afternoon by Dr. Herman Harrell Horne, Professor of the History of Philosophy at New York University, speaking at the commencement exercises of the Gramercy School for Training Christian Leaders, held at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 18 -- Led by Miss Eleanor Goss, ten players, including seven in the first ten of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, began competition on the turf courts of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today in quest of places on the team that will represent the association in the annual intersectional matches for the Sears Cup to be held at the Germantown Cricket Club, Philadelphia, June 3 and 4.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 18 -- Mrs. Robert G. Lake, Long Island and Southern champion, and Mrs. Leo G. Federman, erstwhile Long Island titleholder, were deadlocked with scores of 84 for the low gross honors today in the third of a series of oneday tournaments of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the North Shore Country-Club.

WASHINGTON, May 18 --The five Democratic Senators delegated to frame an unemployment relief bill expect to have at least the substance of the measure decided upon by Friday, Senator Robinson, the Democratic floor leader, said today.

A group of French poets gave themselves a banquet not long ago, and feasted their minds after dinner by reading to each other some of their own compositions. There is nothing new or startling in that in Paris or anywhere else. Poets must find a sympathetic audience once in a while, and if the public fails them they turn naturally to each other.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 18 -- Army defeated Lafayette at baseball today, 9 to 3. It was the tenth victory for the Cadets in eleven games played this season.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18 -- Although a last-inning rally netted six runs, the Princeton baseball nine was unable to overcome the New York University lead and the visitors won, 13 -- 11, on University Field today.

The second formal meeting of the international oil conference was held yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria, with Charles E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, as chairman. Representatives of the Soviet oil industry were present and received preliminary details of a plan through which it is hoped to stabilize the export oil market.

Nearly forty organizations will join in an Anti-War Parade on Fifth Avenue next Saturday, according to an announcement yesterday. The parade is scheduled to start at Washington Square at 1:30 P.M., march up the avenue to Twenty-third Street, turn east to Madison Avenue, up that thoroughfare to Fifty-fifth Street, march west to Broadway and thence to Columbus Circle where there will be speeches.

A plan to establish, in the Bronx six private medical clinics to furnish complete diagnostic, therapeutic and laboratory service at reasonable cost was placed before the Bronx County Medical Society at its monthly meeting at Eismere Hall, 170th Street at College Avenue, last night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Strong objections to any economy move which would result in the transfer of the health functions of the Federal Children's Bureau to the Public Health Service were voiced by speakers tonight before the National Conference of Social Work, which celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the bureau's establishment.
ST. LOUIS, May 18 (AP) -- The Craves pounded the Cards' pitchers for twelve hits today to take the final game of the series, 5 to 3, with Tom Zachavy limiting St. Louis to five safeties.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate conferred yesterday, in executive session, with officials of Bus Transfer, Inc., on that concern's pending application for a franchise to operate a comprehensive bus system in Manhattan, including the motorizing of the surface car lines on Madison and Fourth Avenues.

De Witt Clinton High upset Evander Childs, 3 to 2, at Dyckman Oval yesterday in an Upper ManhattanBronx division P.S.A.L. baseball game. It was the first defeat in seven league contests for the divisional leaders. Clifford Harden's single scored Frank Marianne with the winning run in the sixth.

MONTREAL, May 18 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals gained an even break in the four-game series with Newark by winning the final contest today, 6 -- 2. Brown pitched his fifth victory of the season, allowing only five hits.

PARIS, May 18 -- The offices of the Compagnie des Messageries Maritimes announced here late tonight that ninety-one of the 767 persons aboard the Georges Philippar when she burned off Italian Somaliland Monday were still unaccounted for.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) . -- Pitching by Guy Bush and batting by the veteran Charley Grimm gave the Cubs a 6-to-4 victory over the Phillies today and three games out of four in the series.

Judge SEABURY is not the only one who is exposing the methods of the City Administration. Now and then a bit of evidence turns up in the most unexpected quarter, sometimes within the charmed circle, sometimes without. The latest revelation has to do with the workings of the Department of Sanitation, long under fire by the Academy of Medicine.

With 30,000 families under their Care during March and 9,800 new applications in that month, thirteen family service agencies reported yesterday that for the first time in their history their March expenditures were more than $500,000, it was announced yesterday by the Research Bureau of the Welfare Council.

Crowds in front of Grand Central Terminal and the Commodore Hotel scattered for cover yesterday afternoon when two hold-up men, each waving an automatic, burst from the Pershing Square Building, pursued by elevator men, starters and mechanics. They had taken $200 from a tenant in the building.

Sixty-two feature pictures will be produced by R.K. O -- Radio Pictures during the 1932-33 season with a company of stars headed by Ann Harding, Constance Bennett, John Barrymore, Richard Dix and Leslie Howard. Among the outstanding productions on the program will be screen versions of "The Animal Kingdom," the Philip Barry play; Somerset Maughan's "The Moon and Sixpence" and Ernest Hemingway's "The Sun Also Rises."
The total received yesterday at the first session of the sale of the Cecil Partridge collection at the National Art Galleries, Inc., was $7,241.50.

The American Steel Warehouse Association, which concluded its twenty-third annual convention in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, adopted a resolution placing itself on record as favoring the bill introduced in the House by Representative W. C. Hawley of Oregon in January to equalize tariff rates by compensating for the fluctuations in foreign exchange.

Stimulated principally by increased orders from the automobile industry, the average rate of steel ingot production increased in the last week 1 per cent over that of the preceding two weeks to 25 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age, which says in part:

NEW BRUNSWICK. N. J., May 18.-When he received his wrrstling award at the annual Spring dinner of the Rutgers Varsity Club in VVinant's Hall tonight Jerry G. Cronin of New York City became the first five-letter man In the history of Rutgers University.

Irregularity marked the price trend in commodities yesterday, the grains losing ground, while cotton turned up. Rubber and coffee also improved, but silk, hides and sugar were steady. Other staples remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The State Department has received summaries of two reports on Liberia made public today in Geneva by the Liberian commission of the League of Nations, but in the absence of the texts said that it was not in a position to comment on them.

BERLIN, May 18. -- For the impending Russian Army manoeuvres, Klementy Voroshiloff, the Soviet Commissar for War has called to the colors the reserves made up of the young men born in 1909, 1910, 1911 and all those who were born in 1912 but have been exempt from army service on account of the urgent need for labor in industry, the Berlin Socialist newspaper Vorwarts learned today from Moscow.

Prominent members of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, supported by several other speakers, joined, last night in a general denunciation of prohibition at a dinner given by the Business and Professional Women's Committee of the New York State Division at the Hotel Commodore.

About $5,000,000 gold was taken for export yesterday, most of it consigned to Holland and Belgium. Shipment of $750,000 gold to Germany was not without its interest. In all, we have sent about $2,500,000 to that country since the beginning of the year, and it has certainly been helpful in sustaining the Reichsbank's position.

John H. Curtis, Norfolk boatbuilder, who befogged the search for the baby of Col. Charles A. Lindbergh for two months by means of the elaborate deception to which he confessed Tuesday morning, was locked in the Hunterdon County jail at Flemington, N.J., last evening on charges of giving false information for the purpose of hindering the hunt for the kidnappers.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 -- The case for the railroads was put before the convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States here tonight by Alfred Hurrell, vice president and general counsel of the Prudential Insurance Company; Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago North Western Railroad, and others.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's modified request for a three-year loan of $27,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, with which to go forward with the electrification of its New York-to-Washington lines, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The House pasesd today the War Department appropriation bill by a vote of 201 to 182 after restoring all training camp activities, which had been eliminated in committee.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx's eleventh home run of the season came with the bases filled in the first inning today to give the Athletics a 4-to-2 victory over the Red Sox.

DUBLIN, May 19 (AP). -- Final removal of the oath of allegiance has yet another formidable hurdle ahead of it. The Irish Senate, where President de Valera's plans have already been assailed, must pass on the Dail's action and the Opposition was already massing tonight for the attack.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Airmail service on the route from New York to Miami and to West Indian, Central and South American cities will be speeded up through a change of schedules to be made effective by the Postoffice Department June 1. Under the new schedule an airmail letter leaving New York at 5 P.M., daylight saving time, will reach Miami the next morning at 5:50 o'clock.

TOKYO, Friday, May 20. -- Negotiations between General Sadao Araki, representing the Japanese military, and Kisaburo Suzuki, president of the Seiyukai, or government party, are not running as smoothly as both had anticipated after their conversations of Wednesday, when they seemed on the point of agreement on a coalition ministry which would take in strong national leaders free of party ties.

Heavy selling weakened prices of bonds yesterday in virtually all sections of the list on the Stock Exchange. United States Government issues were sharply lower, and severe losses occurred in the domestic corporation group, particularly in railroad obligations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- Heated attacks on President Hoover by speakers at an unscheduled meeting held in Convention Hall and attended by several thousand delegates to the National Conference of Social Work threw the session into disorder and threatened to disrupt the whole meeting today.

Among the passengers who will sail tonight for England, France and Germany on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are Tommy Armour British open golf champion, who will defend his title at Sandwich; Fred Astaire, dancer and musical comedy star; Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain; Mrs. William Howard Taft, and Gene Sarazen, American golfer, who will also compete in the British open.

BOSTON, May 19. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will be his own pilot on his next flight to the South Pole, it was learned here today. His newest exploration plane will be a four-motored affair, twenty miles an hour faster than the tri-motored plane which carried him over the South Pole on Nov. 29, 1929.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 19 (AP). -- Buffalo advanced to second place, half a game behind the Newark Bears, with an 11-to-2 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today. The Bisons shelled Del Wetherell for five hits and Jim Winford for two more in the first two innings to score eight times.

PORT WASHINGTON. L.I., May 19. -- With 7,800-horsepower engines sending her fifty tons over the still waters of Long Island Sound and then lifting her easily into a rosy East, the huge Dornier flying boat. DO-X, took off just after daybreak today from a point midway between Sands Point and New Rochelle for Newfoundland on the first leg of her homeward passage to Lake Constance, Switzerland, by way of the Maritime Provinces and the Azores.

TRENTON, N.J., May 19. -- As a gift from Charles Lathrop Pack of Washington and Lakewood, president of the American Tree Association, and his son, Arthur Newton Pack of Princeton, N.J., received today an arboretum of 1,000 trees and 1,500 shrubs native to the State.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Professor John Dewey of Columbia told the annual conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today that the only important issues of the present time are economic. He urged that Negroes refuse to be beguiled by the "bunk" and "bait" of the old political parties, which, he declared, are "trying to get by with as little attention to economic issues as possible."
The text of Dr. Butler's address last night before the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria follows:
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The extent to which the depression has made Inroads on tobacco smoking was reflected in internal revenue figures for April made public today by the Treasury Department.

The world's output of zinc in April was 75,827 short tons, compared with 80,203 tons in March and 102,889 tons in April, 1931, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The daily average output in April was 2,528 tons, compared with 2,587 tons in March and 3,430 tons in April, 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Democratic special Senate committee which has been considering an unemployment relief program virtually reached an agreement tonight, the details of which probably will be announced tomorrow. It is understood that the agreement provides:
GREENWICH, Conn., May 19. -- The flower show of the Greenwich Garden Club opened this afternoon in the ballroom of the Greenwich Country Club.

For the concluding exhibition of the season at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, Alfred Stieglitz has selected paintings by five of the artists whose work we associate, first of all, with this gallery: John Marin, Georgia O'Keefe, Arthur Dove, Charles Demuth and Marsden Hartley.

BALTIMORE, May 19. -- Governor Ritchie in an address tonight criticized those Democrats in Congress who are supporting a program for tariff. Mr. Ritchie spoke over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company.

STAMFORD, Conn, May 19. -- Samuel Beresford Childs Jr., 22-year-old son of Dr. Samuel Beresford Childs, X-ray specialist of Denver, and a member of the Yale varsity crew last year, broke his neck about 3 o'clock this morning while wading into a shallow section of Rippowam River in the Turh-of-River district of Stamford.

PARIS, May 19 (AP). -- Edouard Herriot, who is likely to control France's foreign relations in the next government, declared himself today for the established French policies on war debts, reparations and disarmament.

Miss Jeannette M. Genius gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Katherine Shankland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Shankland of this city, and Walter K. Woolman of Philadelphia, who will be married tonight in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Mayor WALKER has long been generous with pledges of retrenchment. About this time last year he sent to all heads of departments a circular letter calling their attention to the sorry state of affairs in the business world and solemnly warning them that it would not be possible to include in the budget for 1932 "any but items of genuine necessity."

BALTIMORE, May 19 (AP). -- Charles Perkins was too good for the Orioles tonight and Jersey City walked away with the opening game of the series, 4 to 2. In addition to holding Baltimore to six hits, Perkins hit a home run in the third with Jordan on base.

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. yesterday completed final plans for its first competitive invasion of California, where the fifty-sixth annual track and field championships of the association and semi-final Olympic tryouts will be staged on July 1 and 2 at Berkeley.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

HARBIN, May 19. -- The proximity of war was brought forcibly to the Attention of members of the League of Nations investigating commission last night when blazing buildings on the battlefront a few miles north of this city lit up the sky. A number of members of the League party joined thousands of Harbin residents lining the south bank of the Sungari watching the spectacle.

It is not strange that in our present discontents many should long for what is not. They are dissatisfied not only with our present political leaders but with our existing political machinery. Some talk lightly of the prospect, or even the desirability, of a "revolution" in this country.

Money market continued quiet. Quotations in all sections remained unchanged on the minimum of business reported. Day loans on the Stock Exchange were done at 2 1/2 per cent, and in the Street at 1 1/2. Time money was quoted 1 1/2 per cent for all maturities, but the turnover was small.

Henry W. Taft, retiring as president of the New York County Lawyers Association, stressed last night the necessity for changing laws and judicial procedure to bring the courts abreast of changing conditions and to strive to eliminate the causes for complaint which have been increasingly directed at lawyers and courts alike.

GENEVA, May 19. -- The League of Nations Council today approved the terms of the draft declaration that Iraq will have to make in order, as Rapporteur Potitch of Yugoslavia said, "to join the League and become independent."

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., May 19. -- Darkness and a dwindling fuel supply combined tonight to halt the homeward flight from New York to Europe of the giant German airliner Do-X at Dildo in Trinity Bay, forty-miles from Holyrood, her preliminary goal.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Birth control advocates urged removal of Federal restrictions at a House hearing today, while opponents denounced restriction of population at another hearing in the Senate.

Results from the examination of thousands of students in forty-nine colleges in Pennsylvania by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, since 1928, a full report of which has just been completed, indicate that "at least one-third of the students had learned nothing at all and about one-half had learned very little," Dr. Albert Edward Wiggam, author and lecturer, said last night in a radio discussion of "American Colleges" over WOR.

MOSCOW, May 19. -- The Soviet Government officially and flatly denied today that it was mobilizing any reserves. The Soviet press is devoting little space to affairs in Manchuria at present, and it Is impossible to get official comment of any sort on the problem beyond guarded statements and denials by Tass, the Soviet news agency.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article in THE TIMES recently stating that the drys of Belgium "defeated amendments to the present 'strict' laws which would make purchase and consumption of liquor easier" is a little misleading.
Entries for the 1932 United States open golf championship total 1,010, only 131 fewer than last year, it was announced through The Associated Press yesterday.

Means have been taken to meet interest charges on all railroad obligations due until July 1, E.G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, said yesterday after the monthly meeting of the organization. Mr. Buckland, who is chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, added, however, that the corporation's receipts were falling below and its expenditures were running above the original expectations.

Despite beneficial rains in dry sections east at the Mississippi River, prices on the Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and after a alight early loss recovered 10 points and closed 3 to 7 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,944,000,000, an increase of $49,000,000 compared with the precedng week and of $1,027,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Sigrid Undset will be 50 years old today and the anniversary will be elaborately celebrated in Norway. The author of huge historical novels which have received high critical praise in fourteen countries and have sold more than 1,000,000 copies, Miss Undset was a Nobel Prize winner in literature in 1928 and is generally recognized, as one of the world's greatest living novelists.
DUBLIN, May 19. -- President Eamon de Valera's bill to remove the oath of allegiance from the Free State Constitution passed the Dail Eireann tonight by a majority of 8 votes.

TOKYO, May 19. -- Premier Ki Inukai, who was assassinated last Sunday by young military officers, was buried today with the dignified ceremony due to his rank, but without any manifestations of feeling by the general public.

Another hearing which representatives of the New York State Conservation Department will attend has been called for today at Nyack, N.Y. Sportsmen of the section favor a change in the open season for cotton-tail rabbits from Nov. 1 to Dec. 31 instead of the existing regulations covering the period of Oct. 25 to Jan. 31.

Pour partners of Lee, Higginson Co., American bankers for the late Ivar Kreuger, have resigned front protective committees in the International Match bankruptcy case, it became known yesterday, as public hearings continued before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, 280 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- International gold movements between March 18 and April 22 were featured chiefly by an increase of $38,000,000 in the holdings of the Bank of France, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, which six months ago reduced its annual dividend rate from $7 to $4, omitted yesterday the semiannual dividend due now. At the same time, the Louisville Nashville, a controlled line, also omitted its semi-annual dividend.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 19. -- Colgate crushed Clarkson Tech today, 14 to 4. The Maroon tallied nine runs with the aid of only three hits in the seventh.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The President is expected to present tomorrow some figures on government construction work which will demonstrate that less than $100,000,000 need be appropriated by Congress as part of any unemployment relief plan to carry out public projects already authorized.

PROBABLY because he had just compiled an atrocious score with considerable exertion over the North Hempstead links, William B. Johnstone, the artist, sat on a bench in front of his locker and began wondering who had started this thing called golf. It annoyed him so much that he finally began wondering out loud.

PARIS, May 19. -- The recent downward tendency on the Bourse was reversed today and in a spirit of greater optimism the majority of the list made substantial recovery. The Bank of France shares rose 675 francs, Suez Canal, 425 and Credit Foncier, 165, while most of the electricals gained more than 100.

Washington advices speak of "feverish activity" on the Transsiberian Railroad to expedite the movement of Soviet troops and war materials to the Far East. In that region the Soviet Government now is supposed to have close to 100,000 men, or more than double the size of its forces last Autumn when Japan swung into action in Manchuria.

Citing the vote in Congress against the beer tax proposal, John Sullivan, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, told a gathering of women at the Commodore yesterday that "our Representatives are Wind and stupid; they are not going to listen to common sense and reason, and the women of America will be the ones responsible for leading us out of prohibition."

SHANGHAI, May 19 (AP). -- Chinese Communist hordes, ravaging wide areas in Central China, endangered the safety of Americans today and threatened the Nanking Government with civil war. Apprehension was acute among sixty Americans, most of them missfonaries, at Pengpu, in Northern Anhwei Province, where 20,000 Communists had surrounded a force of 7,000 Nanking troops.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 19. -- Georg Vetlesen's three-masted auxiliary schooner Vema made a stately entrance into Southampton Harbor today, after having achieved what is believed to be a record in transatlantic travel for craft of its kind.

A decline of $24,000,000 in brokers' loans in the week ended on Wednesday was shown in the weekly report published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop carried the total of loans to brokers down to $414,000,000, which was the lowest ever reported since compilation of the figures wag begun, in 1917.
BERLIN, May 19 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler told National Socialist members of the new Prussian Diet today that his party would not participate in the formation of a new government.

HELSINGFORS, May 19. -- There is much indignation in Masonic circles over a decision of the Finnish Officers' Union to ask the Commanderin-Chief of the army to forbid officers joining Masonic organizations. The decision was reached at the annual meeting of the Officers' Union after the reading of the findings of a special delegation appointed last Fall to investigate the suitability of officers being Masons.
CINCINNATI, May 19 (AP). -- Stephenson's single in the twelfth, scoring Richbourg, gave the leagueleading Cubs a 4-to-3 victory today in the opening game of a series with the Reds.

ST. JOHN, N.B., May 19. -- Amelia Earhart Putnam, landing at the St. John Airport at 5:46 P.M., three hours and three-quarters after leaving Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., completed the first lap of her projected transatlantic flight. Tomorrow she plans to go on to Harbor Grace, Nfld., whence with the first favorable weather she will take off alone across the ocean.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh took a personal hand in the effort to trace the kidnappers and murderers of his son yesterday afternoon and directed a group of his close associates and detectives in a re-enactment of the kidnapping.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., May 19. -- Leading a starting field of fifty-nine players in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Association's one-day golf tournament over the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course today, Mrs. Harold Johnson of the Siwanoy Country Club posted a score of 95 -- 14 -- 81 to carry off the low gross honors.

After deferring any decision as to its annual cruise for two months, the New York Yacht Club held a meeting in its Forty-fourth Street clubhouse last night and a cruise was decided upon, for August that will take the fleet as far east as Hattapoisett, on Buzzards Bay.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 19. -- A feeling of increasing confidence that Governor Roosevelt will be nominated by the Democratic National Convention was evident here today among members of the Executive's party as a result of the latest election of delegates.

LONDON, May 19. -- The principal editorial in tomorrow's London Times will be devoted to "American perplexities." There is still no rift in the clouds that for months have cast their deeping shadows over the people of the United States, it says, and "hopes that the President and Congress would be able to concert measures for restoring public confidence and industry grow steadily fainter."

Governor ROOSEVELT'S speech before the Georgia Kiwanians is interesting on account of its cautious and prudent spirit and its preference of the general to the concrete. The Government has been "extravagant" and must curtail expenditures "somewhat."

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Bulls in wheat were able today to advance prices fractionally on the Board of Trade here, virtually all of the news being in their favor. The rise, though, was not maintained, as profit-taking appeared at the last. The finish was unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday, the July showing the most strength.

The twelve-story banking building at 70 Wall Street has been purchased by the 1932 Holding Corporation, it was snnounced yesterday. The structure occupies a lot 26 by 100 feet adjoining the Seaman's Bank for Savings and the propprty of the Bank of Montreal.

The nation-wide Democratic Party of Jefferson is dead and so is the nation-wide Republican Party of Lincoln, and if the thoughtful people of the country had a real leader to follow they would "sweep the whole discredited fabric of our present-day national political machinery into the dust-bin," Dr. Nicholas Murray Sutler declared last night in a speech at the annual dinner of the National Industrial Conference Board in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
PITTSBURGH, May 19. -- The Robins dropped a close game to the Pirates today, 3 to 2, and fell from sixth to seventh place, changing positions with the idle Giants.

MEXICO CITY, May 19. -- Drastic changes in Mexico's monetary legislation, were announced this evening in a Presidential decree under which all branches of foreign banks must in the future work in association with the Bank of Mexico, the nation's sole bank of issue, in strict accordance with the decree of April 12, which converted it into a central banking institution similar to the Federal Reserve Bank.

SHOW BOAT, a musical comedy in two acts and seventeen scenes, adapted from the novel of the same name by Edna Ferber. Music by Jerome Kern and book and lyrics by Oscar Hammentein 2d. Settings by Joseph Urban; costumes designed by John Harkrider; revived by Florenz Ziegfeld. At the Casino Theatre, formerly the Earl Carroll.

Dean Sage, president of the board of managers of Presbyterian Hospital, addressing a class of eighty young women graduates of the School of Nursing of the hospital and more than 1,000 guests yesterday afternoon at the thirty-eighth commencement, held in the garden of the Medical Centre, announced that plans were maturing for an affiliation of the School of Nursing with Columbia University.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The motto of THE NEW YORK TIMES is a pledge to its readers that your paper can be relied upon to print all the important news. THE TIMES is a great paper. I read it daily to obtain a comprehensive view of current events.
Following in full is the address delivered yesterday by Charles M. Schwab at the general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19. -- Nine graduates of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary received diplomas at the annual commencement exercises held today in Kirkpatrick Chapel on the Rutgers University campus. Dr. William H. S. Demarest, president of the seminary, presented the diplomas.

A collection of graphic hors d'oeuvre to whet your Spring appetite will be on view at Ferargil's for the next eight days. These parodies of places, persons and painters by Zdzislaw Czermanski, a young Polish artist, are well seasoned with wit and malice, but suave enough to appease the sensitive.

PARIS, May 19. -- Though governmental business is practically at a standstill, the administration of Premier Tardieu showed today that it could still take vigorous action in so far as trade is concerned through decreeing additional import quotas.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 19. -- Manhattan's infield failed Bill Blake in the eighth inning today, enabling Providence College to bunch four of its five hits to score three runs and blank the New Yorkers, 3 to 0.

Formation of a committee of the protection of the interests of creditors and security holders of the Compania de Salitre de Chile, known as Cosach; the Lautaro Nitrate Company, Ltd., and the Compania Salitrera Anglo-Chilean was announced yesterday by Medley G.B. Whelpley, president of the three companies.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 19. -- The Westchester team won the women's annual Spring intersectional team golf match for the Golf Illustrated Trophy held today on the course of the Century Country Club under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.
EGHAM, Surrey, England, May 19. -- On the eve of the international team match for women golfers we Americans feel confident that we have a very good chance of walking off with victory.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Contributions by railroads and telephone companies to unemployment relief funds may properly be charged to "operating expenses," representatives of the Bell System telephone companies and several railroads contended today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
NEW YORK. Marcel Bourguin, newly appointed French Consul to New York, arrived on the Lafayette and is at the Delmonico.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Information reaching the capital of the organization of a committee of leading industrialists to put to work the hundreds of millions of dollars in credit, released by the Reserve Banks in the last six weeks, explained to observers here the sudden visit to New York yesterday and today of Secretary Mills and Eugene Meyer, governor of the Reserve Board.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was again extremely dull yesterday, but after early weakness a somewhat better tone appeared and leading issues ended the day with moderate net gains. The movement of prices was irregularly downward throughout the forenoon, but at midday a rally set in which wiped out all the early losses.

The family welfare societies of New York, for the first time in their history -- some were formed fifty years ago and one has been in existence more than eighty years -- announced yesterday that they could no longer provide for more than the cases now on their lists and must turn away destitute families coming for help.

BERLIN, May 19. -- The Boerse continued weak today. A sharp decline in the export surplus in April, pessimistic forecasts on the trend of business by the Bureau of Statistics, M. Herriot's statements on reparations and uncertainties of the domestic political situation combined to cause a general downward movement in prices.

Members of the Flatbush W.C. T.U. were amused at their annual meeting yesterday in the Flatbush Congregational Church, East Eighteenth Street and Dorchester Road, Brooklyn, by the reading of a letter received by two of their officers from agents of a brewery inviting them to become customers.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Two of four men on trial for the kidnapping of Dr. Max Gecht and his wife, Georgia, whose "flirtation" with one of her captors was taken seriously and eventually led to the gang's arrest, pleaded guilty today in the Criminal Court her ore Judge Philip L. Sullivan.
The National League rule against baseball players conversing with spectators, which caused Rabbit Maranville to inquire, "What is baseball coming to?" was rescinded yesterday.

A sentence of from two and one-half to five years imprisonment was imposed by Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday upon Dr. Samuel Buchler, 48 years old, automatically disbarred lawyer, former Jewish chaplain, in Sing Sing prison and former city and State official, on his conviction by a jury May 4 of defrauding a client of $200 in an immigration case.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When something on which we are depending does not function properly our first inclination is to examine it and see where the trouble lies and when that is found discard what is wrong and salvage the good.

State Senator John A. Hastings began his effort to set himself right with the Hofstadter committee yesterday after Fred C. Harris, secretary of the Manhattan Company, contributed a new chapter to the Odyssey of Russell T. Sherwood, Mayor Walker's missing business agent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an economic crisis which has shaken every pier and footing of our social structure it is almost fool-hardy to single out any group or class and say: "Here stand the real victims of the depression." And If we were to concern ourselves solely with today's misery and suffering it would be foolhardy.

A Happy Solution. The father of EDWARD D. DUFFIELD, who has been appointed acting president of Princeton University, was accustomed to refer to a happening that seemed especially arranged by Omniscience as "almost providential."

NORFOLK, Va., May 19 (AP). -- Robert M. Hughes Jr., registrar of Christ Episcopal Church, of which the Rev. H. Dobson Peacock, Norfolk Lindbergh "intermediary," is rector, issued a written statement today defending his minister's action in refusing to go to New Jersey for questioning on the Lindbergh case.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- The Rev. Dr. Ralph S. Cushman, pastor of the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, Rochester, N.Y., and the Rev. Dr. Junius Ralph Magee of Seattle, Wash., district superintendent of Methodist Northwest Conference, were elevated to the posts of Bishops today by the thirty-first quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in session in the municipal auditorium.

Steel producers throughout the country are considering an advance of $2 a ton on steel slabs and billets to be delivered after July 1. The increase would bring the price to $28 a ton, compared with the present quotation of $26 a ton. Sheet bars were advanced a similar amount a week ago.

CLEVELAND, May 19. -- The Alleghany Corporation reported today for the three months ended with March a net income of $264,099, exclusive of $11,941,105 loss on securities sold which was charged against paid-in surplus. Dividend and interest accruals totaled $1,322,739, against $2,349,153 in the quarter a year before.

Yesterday's statement or the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings, total bills discounted and the ratio of reserve to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.
NEWARK, N.J., May 19 (AP). -- Legett's homer over the left field bleachers with two on and two out decided a ten-inning game in Reading's favor, 8 to 5, over the Newark Bears today.

As city department heads began yesterday to consider means of effecting the economy program ordered by Mayor Walker on Wednesday, the City Affairs Committee attacked his retrenchment speech to his subordinates as "cheap theatricals," while the Committee of 10,000 Citizens hailed it as a token of victory for the real estate owners, who have been demanding reduced taxes for months.

Improved prices were recorded in two of the major groups of commodities yesterday, the grains and cotton, higher levels also being recorded in coffee, cocoa and silk, while sugar was generally steady throughout the day. Rubber was lower and hides were irregular.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Banking difficulties in the United States during April were principally concentrated in Boston, the Pacific Northwest, Illinois and Michigan, and resulted in halting the return flow of currency from circulation which had been noted since the early weeks in February, according to Federal Reserve Board statistics made public today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- Describing the present Congress as "one of the greatest of absurdities known in our history," Dr. Douglas S. Freeman of Richmond, editor, today told the Maryland Bankers' Association's convention that the present crisis in government was "too big a job for it."

Although general business activity in April declined below the March level by a greater than seasonal amount, sizeable upturns were registered in automobile output and in public works construction, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 19 (AP). -- Knebelkamp and Morris's Abode Post, a big disappointment in the Kentucky Derby, showed a return to his best form today when he easily defeated a small band of 3-year-olds in the featured Castlewobd Purse, a dash of seven furlongs.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Senator Reed told President hoover today that the legislative jam in Congress had reached a point where the interests of the nation demanded that Congress remain in continuous session until the budget was balanced and the economy and appropriation bills disposed of.

BERLIN, May 19. -- Germany's depression over the rejection of her disarmament proposals was increased today by the news that the aviation committee of the Geneva conference had rejected the German proposal to prohibit all military aircraft.
TORONTO, May 19 (AP). -- Toronto opened a series with Montreal today by winning, 4 -- 3, with Truett Sewell getting credit for the victory, though Guy Cantrell had to go to his rescue in the ninth.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices fell again to a new low of 88.7 on Tuesday, compared with 89.1 (revised) on the preceding Tuesday, and 102.5 a year ago.

Shri Meher Baba, the Indian mystic who has not spoken for seven years, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to break his lenghty silence in a message to America. This message will be given to a group of disciples at Harmon, N.Y., where the mystic visited last October.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 19. -- At the end of the second day of trials at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, six players and an alternate were named tentatively today to represent the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association in singles in the Sears Cup matches with the New England, Middle States and Middle Atlantic Associations at the Germantown Cricket Club, Philadelphia, June 3 and 4.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Meat packers to whom the Supreme Court recently refused the right to deal in groceries and other non-meat products filed with the court today a petition asking for a rehearing and a reversal.

PARIS, May 19. -- America's decision to form her own separate autonomous army in the World War was based on an understanding with Marshal Joffre during his mission to the United States after America's entry. General Maxime Weygand recounted today when received into the French Academy to occupy the seat left vacant by Marshal Joffre's death.

Sammy Fuller, diminutive Boston lightweight, and Jack (Kid) Berg. the English whirlwind, will clash in a twelve-round bout tonight at Madison Square Garden. The pair met six weeks ago in a ten-round contest, and honors were declared even after a bitter and exciting struggle.

Painting a gloomy picture of the present state of the steel industry and sounding a warning to government that industry cannot continue to carry the heavy burden of taxation placed upon it, Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, called yesterday "for the readjustment of Federal, State and local expenditures to our present lean purses" as the first step toward the revival of industry.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- If the people of the United States want Congress to complete its emergency labors and adjourn by the end of the fiscal year, they should make it Known immediately. In the opinion of hte most experienced judges of the ways of Congress, the President and the bipartisan leaders who are urging this program can be assured of success if the country will endorse their appeal.

Although it was not the richest race of the card, great interest at Belmont Park yesterday centred in the Ben Brush Handicap, which saw Joseph E. Widener's Mr. Sponge score in what was his trial for the famous Metropolitan Handicap, to be run tomorrow.

Whether or not of the faith that prompted and pervades the Pope's encyclical, one is moved by its concern for all mankind. It is as universal in its appeal as is distress. It is filled with the compassion of Him who, seeing the hungry multitude in a desert place, asked: "Whence are we to buy bread that these may eat?"

The trend of yesterday's markets was unchanged from that of preceding days this week. Stocks, on a total business which again ranged around 700,000 shares, drifted idly up or down, with most of the net changes only fractional. The bond market was weaker, the larger declines this time affecting industrial securities.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Crosser airship bill, designed to encourage the development of lighter-than-air craft through airmail contracts between the United States and Europe, was attacked today as a Federal subsidy, by Representatives Bulwinkle, Huddleston and Shallenberger of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee in a minority report.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19. -- A wide program aimed to revive business activity, including a strong and unified bank system for the country, was suggested by Henry I. Harriman, chairman of the New England Power Association, in an address tonight before the convention of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, May 19. -- About 689 persons were rescued from the burning liner Georges Philippar, according to a telegram from the vessel's commander, Captain Vicq, received tonight from Aden by the head offices of Messageries Maritimes Company.

In these troubled and difficult times not only leadership but a willingness to follow is needed to help us solve the nation's problem, and under the constitutional processes of this country we have a leader who is our leader as long as he is there, Newton D. Baker told 750 lawyers and their guests yesterday at a luncheon of the Columbia University Law School Alumni Association.

A school teacher who was arrested last Monday on a charge of grand larceny provided a flurry of excitement in the District Attorney's office in Brooklyn yesterday when she was linked with a mysterious telephone conversation with Dr. John F. Condon, the "Jafsie" in the Lindbergh kidnapping negotiations.

The Colorado Southern Railway, controlled by the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, has reported for 1931 a net income of $522,354 after taxes and charges, equal, after dividends on the 4 per cent non-cumulative first preferred stock, to $2.14 a share on 4 per cent second preferred non-cumulative stock.
SCHENECTADY, May 19. -- The dirigible Los Angeles, observing eye of the navy, "whispered" down a beam of light to the ground as she cruised over this city tonight.

Anton, L., Trunk, president, of the Real Estate Board of New York. Inc., commenting on Mayor Walker's instructions to city department heads to "slash city costs or quit" expressed his entire confidence in the Mayor's sincerity in the following statement:
EASTON, Pa., May 19. -- More than 1,000 of the 6,000 living alumni of Lafayette College are due here tomorrow to attend the centennial celebration of the founding of their college.

Holding that the city is not entitled to collect "gratuities, tips, gifts and voluntary contributions made to city officers" which are not a part of the legal "perquisites" of their office, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler granted yesterday a motion to vacate a $135,000 attachment on bank accounts of Deputy City Clerk James J. McCormick.

LONDON, May 19. -- The stock markets were quiet today and the bank rate was unchanged. British Government funds went lower, then recovered but closed below yesterday's levels. Foreign bonds were steadier.

After a prologue after the manner of Gilbert and Sullivan the Town Hall Club got down to business last night and at its fourth annual "town meeting" voted to Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, the club's medal of honor awarded annually to the member who has achieved "an accomplishment of lasting merit."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19. -- Adhering to his usual custom of qualifying early in the day, Eddie Driggs of Cherry Valley today won the medal in the annual Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament, one of the oldest events in the metropolitan district.
