TRENTON, N.J., May 19. -- At the suggestion of former Governor Edward C. Stokes, chairman of the board of the First-Mechanics National Bank of Trenton, a general sales tax, instead of an additional levy on gasoline, for unemployment relief was endorsed today by Governor Moore, legislative leaders, bankers and industrialists.

The Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, reported a loss of $11,941,000 from the sale of securities in the quarter ended on March 31. This resulted from the sale of railroad stocks to the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The revenue features of the billion-dollar tax bill were pushed aside in the Senate today as Republicans and Democrats indulged in a battle-royal on the tariff.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Amid a few audible chuckles in the House, Representative Fuller of Arkansas offered a resolution today to compel every civil service employe to prove his ability to sing, recite or write from memory the words of "The Star-Spangled Banner."

HUDSON, N.Y., May 19. -- The annual Blossom Festival by which the residents of the Hudson Valley each year pay a tribute to Spring opened here today. It will last until the end of the week and is expected to draw 75,000 persons to the city. Towns up and down the river, from Yonkers to Saratoga Springs, are taking part in the various events.

The Yankees' pitching, impregnable against Western attacks, crumbled yesterday at the Stadium as Washington broke the nine-game winning streak of the McCarthymen. The Senators took the first game of the double-header, 8 to 6, in ten innings, then went on to capture the second.

The Citizens Union, in a letter to members of the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday, laid the "confusion'' surrounding the awarding of bus franchises in Queens to the failure of the board to adopt, "in advance of franchise negotiations, basic principles and a definite plan of procedure."

GENEVA, May 18. -- The United States brought strong pressure here today to hasten the rehabilitation of Liberia. In a memorandum privately circulated to the Liberian Committee of the Council of the League of Nations by Samuel Reber Jr., the American member of the committee, the United States declares that conditions in Liberia are so chaotic that it is doubtful that effective government still exists.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 19. -- Promotion of four associate professors to full professorships at Yale University was announced today by President James R. Angell. He also announced the appointment of William O. Douglass to be Professor of Law, and of Charles Edwin Weaver as research associate in paleontology, with the rank of professor.

Bank clearings continued to recede in the week ended on Wednesday, according to reports received from leading cities by R.J. Dun Co., which show that the aggregate for the week was $4,451,305,000, or 48.4 per cent below the total in the corresponding week last year.

The Inner workings of the organisation committee of Local 3 of the Electrical Workers' Union and of the methods used when the union was Deset by dissident groups and antagonistic employers were revealed yesterday by John Holley Clark Jr. before Referee John McM.

Four women and 125 men, applicants for admission to the bar, have been instructed to appear before the committee on character and fitness for examination, it was announced yesterday. The examination will take place at the Appellate Division courthouse, Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue.

The Chase National Bank and the National City Bank decided shortly before noon yesterday to submit a joint bid for New York City's issue of $5,000,000 of home and work relief 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due on April 30, 1934 to 1937, and the bonds went to Wall Street instead of to the city sinking fund.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Rear Admiral William T. Tarrant, Chief of Staff of the Commander-in-Chief, United States Fleet, has been assigned to command Cruiser Division 4 of the Scouting Force, relieving Rear Admiral Wat T. Cluverius, about Aug. 15.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lyle G. Hall gave a dinner for ten persons this evening. Mr. and Mrs. Timothy S. Goodman, Mr. and Mrs. C.G. Medley, A.W. Beresford, Mr. and Mrs. J.E. Martin, Mr. and Mrs. R.C. Ross, with Mrs. Charles Stewart Smith, were others having guests this evening in the Homestead.

ADEN, Arabia, May 19 (AP). -- The steamer Andre Lebon arrived here shortly after midnight this morning from Djibouti, French Somaliland, where she had landed most of the survivors picked up from the Georges Philippar.

The most powerful coalition of financial leadership since the days of the Liberty Loan Committee was called into being yesterday with the formation, under the chairmanship of Owen D. Young, of a committee of twelve bankers and industrialists to aid in putting to work the hundreds of millions of dollars being poured into the market by the Federal Reserve System in its credit expansion program.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Profits of almost $5,000,000 realized from a pool in Radio common stock which operated for one week in March of 1929, with an original investment of $12,683,000, were described today as the stock market investigation was resumed by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 19. -- The fifty-eighth commencement of Bloomfield College and seminary was held tonight in the old First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Morgan Phelps Noyes of Montclair delivered the address. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Hunter, president of the seminary, gave the charge to the graduates.

Except for the brief testimony of one witness, the defense of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, on trial for seven weeks before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions charged with failure to close the Bank of United States promptly was concluded yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities declined 1 1-3 per cent during the month ended April 15 and on that date were 16 per cent under those of the same date last year, the Labor Department announced today. The department's weighted index numbers, with average prices in 1913 as 100, were 124 for April 15, 1931; 105 for March 15, 1932, and 103.7 for April 15, 1932.

Federal Judge Caffey of the Southern of New York confirmed yesterday the appointment of Samuel Insull, E. N. Hurley and C.A. Mculloch as ancillary receivers for the Middle West Utilities Company at the conclusion of a meeting of stockholders and creditors.

HAVANA, May 19. -- More persons were arrested today on charges of plotting a revolutionary uprising which the secret police believe was scheduled for tomorrow. Sixty prisoners had been locked in Principe Castle by afternoon.

Gene Venzke's famous closing sprint that carried him to a 4:10 mile indoors and to a season of unbroken triumphs on the boards failed him last night as America's 1,500-meter Olympic hope was defeated by Otto Rosner, and even beaten by George Bullwinkle for second place.

As the Goldsborough bill has been taken up toy the Senate committee, attention has been directed more closely to the methods, very like parliamentary sharp practice, by which the large vote for it in the House was obtained. The trick of inviting testimony almost exclusively from witnesses favoring the measure will not be repeated by the Senate.

Fashionable New Yorkers will, as usual, leave the city this Summer, partly because of unbreakable habit, partly because it may be cheaper to go away than to stay at home. Passionate week-enders will still rush out to the suburbs, and the small group that loves New York in the hot quiet of the Saturday-to-Monday pause will find the town happily deserted.

AURORA, Ill., May 19 (AP). -- War Glow, speedy member of the O.L. Foster stable, made a show of his field at Aurora today to win the featured Thompson purse over six furlongs. Rated cleverly by Jockey D. Cox, War Glow stepped to the front at once and breezed home the winner by three and one-half lengths over Mrs. Emil Denemark's Blackstrap.

Richard Bonelli, American baritone, who has sung leading roles with the Chicago Civic Opera Company for the past five years, has been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Company for next season, it was learned yesterday from the singer's concert management, the Columbia Concerts Corporation.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Price reductions ranging from 5 to 50 per cent under the levels of 1931 are announced in the mid-Summer catalogues of Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co. mailed to customers today.

Gold amounting to $37,829,000 was withdrawn from the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday for shipment to Europe, $17,019,900 of the metal being earmarked stocks held here by foreign central banks and now being repatriated. The large amount of earmarked gold released, combined with imports of $1,015,900 gold at New York and $3,519,000 at San Francisco, reduced the day's net loss to $16,274,200.

A little book about Oxford published twenty-five years ago suggested that there was at the Bodleian Library "a wonderful opening "for the modern millionaire, who "for L50,000 could connect his "name forever with the greatest "of England's learned foundations."

A total of $9,324,749 of new municipal loans will come up for award next week, representing the requirements of thirty-eight communities throughout the country. This week's revised total was $57,225,746. The weekly average for the year to date is $22,664,795, so that next week will allow the market something of a breathing spell.
VIENNA, May 20 -- After a fortnight's endeavors Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss, former Minister of Agriculture, formed a Right coalition Cabinet today to succeed the Buresch Government.

Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The London Daily and Sunday Express and several other newspapers and periodicals in England, arrived last night on the Cunarder Berengaria, accompanied by his son, the Hon. Max Aitken, Viscount Castlerosse, who writes a column for The Express, and his secretary.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Final approval by the War Department of the application of the North River Bridge Company to build a bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, to New Jersey is awaiting adjustment of the plans to local requirements, Secretary Hurley informed Representative Lehlbach of New Jersey today.

The largest number of young men be set apart as Lutheran clergymen at a single time in the 200-year history of that denomination in this city will be ordained on Wednesday eveing in St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, in connection with the fourth annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

LONDON, May 20. -- Dominions Secretary J.H. Thomas tonight appealed to the people of the Irish Free State to uphold treaties and not to undo all the good work of the past decade. Speaking at Brighton, he repeated his recent warnings in Parliament, but his tone was friendlier and his words were in the nature of an olive branch to the Irish electorate.

Confirmation that Libby Holman, Broadway musical 'show star, and Smith Reynolds, second son of the late R.J. Reynolds, tobacco financier, are married was given yesterday afternoon at the Ambassador Hotel, where they are staying.

CHURCHILL DOWNS, Ky., May 20 (AP) -- Bay Angon, racing for E. A. Igleheart, Evansville, Ind., and ridden by the apprentice, G. South, gave a sparkling display of speed to win the National Retail Coal Merchants' Purse, today's feature at Churchill Downs.

MEXICO CITY, May 20 -- Optimism and satisfaction have replaced a first reaction of gloom in foreign banking circles over the Presidential decree issued yesterday requiring foreign banks in Mexico to affiliate with the Bank of Mexico.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would have been more aboveboard in Governor Roosevelt to have given some indication of what Thomas Jefferson was talking about when he said "the mass of mankind was not born with saddles on their backs nor were a favored few born booted and spurred, ready to ride mankind legitimately, by the grace of God."
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- A House vote on beer-for-revenue legislation next Monday was assured today when anti-prohibitionists insisted on a Saturday session to meet parliamentary requirements.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Detroit defeated Vic Frasier in the eleventh inning of a pitchers' battle today by combining two singles with Jonathan Stone's home run for three runs to down the White Sox. 8 to 5, in the opener of their series.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 21 -- The government crisis in Japan remains unsettled and the outcome is still uncertain. The chances that Baron Hiranuma would become Premier, which were put at 3 to 1 yesterday, slumped somewhat in the evening, when Kisaburo Suzuki, leader of the Seiyukai, the dominant party, intimated he would oppose any super-party or coalition government.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- Billy Petrolle defeated Bat Battalino in their ten-round battle tonight by outscoring him in a savage body attack.

Heavy trading in United States Government issues, all of which closed lower, featured yesterday's bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic bonds sold off late in the session and ended irregularly lower after having registered early gains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let the Government of the United States say to its European debtors: "Without further ado about debt commissions or international conferences, we leave to you the settlement of your obligations held by us. You will make such payments and at such times as you may determine.

An arbitration, award of $1.65 an hour, or $13.20 a day, 15 per cent below the previous wage of $15.40 a day, was fixed yesterday by Professor Joseph P. Chamberlain of Columbia University, Milton Mayer, lawyer, and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise in the dispute between the bricklayers and an independent organization of employers, the Associated Brick Masons Contractors, Inc.

CLEVELAND, May 20 -- Orders for parts for 100,000 Ford cars put Cleveland concerns making automotive parts on a full-time operating basis today, and in some cases day and night shifts have been started. The orders are for parts for both the four-cylinder and the eight-cylinder models, which now are being produced in mass quantities.

Unwary criminals will be beguiled into the hands of justice by a corps of young, good-looking and well-dressed policewomen, under the terms of a local bill discussed by the Board of Estimate yesterday, which changes the age limit of policewomen from 40 to 29 years.

The first American presentation of "Love Time," described as an intimate Viennese operetta, will take place at the Geary Theatre, San Francisco, next Monday night. Under the title of "Die Schoenen Rivallnnen" the piece was produced in Berlin in 1923. Hans Siegfricd Linne wrote the score, while the book and lyrics have been adapted by W.H. Clifford.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Princetonians, past and present, took full charge of affairs in the Carder City Golf Club's annual Invitation tournament today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The scouting fleet will remain in the Pacific with the battle fleet until Oct. 1, under orders announced today by Admiral Pratt, the Chief of Naval Operations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- More than 3,000 persons came to the County Centre here tonight to hear the eighth annual Westchester County music festival, the greatest community musical aachievement of the Westchester County Recreation Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The extent of government assistance to rail- roads to help them weather the current crisis was disclosed in statistics made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, showing approval of loans to thirty-six separate roads from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounting to $164,608,513.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Lack of pressure, with moderate commission-house and local buying, advanced wheat prices rather sharply today on the Board of Trade here, the July advancing 1 3/4 cents to the best figure since late in April.

The problem of expressing movement in the plastic arts is an old and hard one. There are three solutions: actually to make the image move, to catch the subject at the precise moment when the entire action, previous and subsequent, is implied in the pose, and to abjure motion altogether as something incongruous with the serene and eternal character of the fine arts.

LONDON, May 20 -- A detailed story of the Rev. H. Dobson Peacock's alleged contact with the New York underworld in connection with the Lindbergh case appears in The Daily Express, which publishes what purports to be a letter he wrote to his mother in England.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 20 -- With his stay in the South nearing conclusion, Governor Roosevelt began whipping into shape today the address he will deliver at the commencement exercises of Oglethorpe University at Atlanta on Sunday.
NEWARK, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Don Brennan's six-hit pitching and the Bears' heavy hitting beat Reading today, 5 to 1, to even the series, one all. George Selkirk drove a homer for the batting feature.

No change in conditions or quotations was apparent in the day's trading in money, and except for the routine requirements engaged in new business was at a minimum. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent, with the usual concessions in the counter market, and for Federal funds.

Among the sixty-five productions on the 1932-33 schedule of the Paramount Publix Corporation will be screen versions of Ernest Hemingway's "A Farewell to Arms," H.G. Wells's "The Island of Dr. Moreau," Sudermann's "The Song of Songs," Karel Kapek's "R.U.R." and "Lives of a Bengal Lancer."

On Wednesday of last week Senator ROBINSON proposed that Congress authorize "the issuance of, say, $2,000,000,000 of tax-exempt bonds, to be spent upon self-liquidating or profit-making enterprises, such as tunnels, bridges, and the destruction of slum districts in the great industrial centres."

HOLYROOD, Nfld., May 20 (AP) -- The German flying boat Do-X, en route to Europe, landed at Holyrood at 9:20 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, after flying from Dildo, where it was forced to land yesterday. Weather conditions were perfect on the twenty-five-mile flight.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 20 -- Under a cloudless sky, the crews of three colleges went out on Lake Cayuga today to put the finishing touches on training leading up to tomorrow's three-cornered regatta among the varsity, junior varsity and freshman crews of Yale, Princeton and Cornell.

Taking the trade completely by surprise, the Standard Oil Company of New York announced late yesterday a reduction of 4 cents a gallon in the service station price of gasoline in the metropolitan district, effective today. The new price in this city will be 9 1/2 cents a gallon, exclusive of the 3-cent State tax.

Short selling may or may not be justifiable, but "rigging the market" on an extended scale, and with the use of vast sums of money, will find few defenders. This is particularly true in the case of that "pool" for dealing in Radio stock of which the operations were uncovered in Washington on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House adopted today, without a dissenting vote, the Warren resolution opening the House of Representatives payrolls to the public. South Trimble, Clerk of the House, almost immediately made public the April payroll, the last one prepared by his office, revealing that 100 members employed office help with the same names as theirs.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Although Selnick hit a home run with two on, C.C.N.Y. was beaten today by Temple University, 8 to 3. Selnick's drive came in the seventh in- ning with Levy and Spanier aboard as the result of errors.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 18;

The Foxcatcher Farms White Clover II, which finished second to Mate in the Thanksgiving Day Handicap at Bowie last Fall, yesterday made his first start since that race and won the Peter Pan Purse, feature offering at Belmont Park. Backed from 11 to 5 to 8 to 5 at closing, White Clover II made short work of Mountain Elk, which opened a strong choice and closed at 3 to 2.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- Wesley Ferrell won his sixth victory of the season today as the Indians defeated St. Louis, 11 to 7, in a game marked by fifteen bases on balls, seven off the Browns' pitchers and eight off Indian hurlers.

NASHVILLE, May 20 -- Tennessee's Democrats in convention today gave the State's twenty-four votes in the national convention to Governor Roosevelt of New York. But under the wide open resolution which so instructed the delegates, in the event the Roosevelt cause for the Presidential nomination appears hopeless, the delegates are left fancy-free as a unit to throw their support wherever a majority may dictate.

One fireman was killed, another critically injured, and ten others hurt shortly before 7 o'clock, last night, when an engine and a fire truck side- wiped at Boerum and Leonard Streets, Brooklyn, while answering a false alarm turned in by a 5-year-old boy.

Copper Exporters, Inc., yesterday reduced the price of copper 1/8 cent a pound to 5 1/2 cents on special offering's, c.i.f. base European ports. In the domestic market copper was available at 5 1/4 cents a pound for near-by deliveries, also a reduction of 1/8 cent a pound.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 20. -- Yale maintained its lead in the Intercollegiate Golf League by defeating Dartmouth, 8 to 1, on the Taconic course today. Williams defeated Holy Cross, 7 1/2 to 1 1/2. Parker of Yale and Smith of Williams turned in the best individual scores, each getting a 74.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A legal campaign planned by Nathan R. Margold of New York to defend Negroes against every form of discrimination was adopted here today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The representatives of the oil companies at the international oil conference here are in accord on plans looking toward the stabilization of oil prices outside of the United States, according to Charles E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, and James A. Moffett Jr., vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, spokesmen for the conference.

Repairs to nine school buildings, estimated to cost about $600,000, were not voted by the Board of Estimate yesterday following Mayor Walker's statement that it was against the board's present policy to pay for such improvements by new appropriations if they could possibly be financed through savings in the budget of the Department of Education.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Resolutions condemning excessive taxes and insisting that all governments -- Federal, State and local -- retrench drastically were adopted today at the closing session of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

The swimmers of Manual Training, Brooklyn, garnered top honors at the individual senior high school championships of the Public School Athletic League in the seventy-five-foot pool of Columbia University last night. They totaled 20 points, while the boys of Evander Childs and Jamaica, next in line, earned 18 and 12 points.

Giuilo Gatti-Casazza, before sailing yesterday on the Conte Grande for his Summer vacation, announced the novelties end revivals for the coming Metropolitan Opera season and sweeping changes in personnel. Eight new singers have been engaged, and twenty-eight who were on last year's roster have not been re-engaged.

The thirty-second annual commencement activities of The Biblical Seminary in New York started last night with a reception by the undergraduate body for the thirty-four members of the graduating class at the seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., May 20 -- Amelia Earhart Putnam took off here at 7:20 o'clock tonight (5:50 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time) alone for Paris, the first woman to attempt to conquer the Atlantic. Smiling and confident the blond-haired slim young woman climbed into the enclosed cockpit of her red and gold monoplane and, after a quick handclasp with Bernt Balchen and Eddie Gorski, her mechanic, she waved to the small crowd and opened the throttle.

CINCINNATI, May 20 (AP) -- With two men on bases and two out, Andy High slammed a triple in the eleventh inning today to give the Reds two runs and a 3-to-2 decision over the Cubs in their second extra-inning contest in as many days.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics made it four, victories in a row today by taking their second straight from the Boston Red Sox, 6 to 1.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 20 -- After scoring an excellent 41 for the east course, Mrs. Walter MacGowan of Essex Fells faltered to the extent of taking 50 to come home over the south nine, but her total of 91 proved to be the best gross score by two strokes in the women's New Jersey Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.
In sympathy with improvement in the stock and grain markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday and ended 4 to 5 points higher than on Thursday.

The protective committee for holders of bonds of the city of Sanford, Fla., made public yesterday a summary of a decision just handed down by the Supreme Court of Florida. The summary was prepared by the committee's counsel, Thomson, Wood Hoffman.

The purpose of the committee of twelve eminent bankers and industrialists, named by the governor of the New York Reserve Bank, obviously is to bring into more effective and cooperative working all the banks of this district. While it is true that applications for credit by borrowers of unquestionable standing are small as compared with normal times, the contention has been widely made that agreements between deserving borrowers and banks have not been sufficiently promoted.

A committee of shipping men representing the important North Atlantic ports has been summoned by William H. Chandler, manager of the traffic bureau of the Merchants' As- sociation of New York, to a meeting next Thursday, at which steps will be taken to protect the Northern ports from any diversion of Central Freight Association freight to Southern ports.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 20 (AP). -- A Swedish investigating committee today reported that fictitious assets for large sums were created on the Kreuger Toll books since 1924.

LONDON, May 20 -- The stock market was generally firm today. British Government funds received renewed support, dealers reporting foreign buying. Industrial stocks were quiet, with few price changes. Dunlop Rubber made a slight gain, while Imperial Chemical was lower and Swedish Match B was dull.

Dr. John F. Condon told the Bronx County grand jury for two hours yesterday of the negotiations which resulted in his paying $50,000 of Colonel Lindbergh's money to a Scandinavian named "John" in a Bronx cemetery for the return of his stolen baby, which later was found murdered.
NEW YORK. Count Alberto Marchetti di Muriaglio, counselor of the Italian Embassy, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

HUDSON, N.Y., May 20 -- "Alfalfa Bill" Murray came out of the West today, to bring his "Crusade" -- for the return of the government to the people -- before the effete East. For "Crusade" is the word the Governor of Oklahoma uses in place of Presidential aspiration, and of the latter he conceded he had little, indeed.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The creation in New York yesterday of a committee of bankers and industrialists to aid in stabilizing economic conditions and to make more effective the credit expansion policies of the Federal Reserve Board has the wholehearted approval of President Hoover.

Winning ten of the fourteen events on the program, Manhattan College's well-balanced track and field team gained a decisive victory over City College yesterday in their annual dual meet at the Lewisohn Stadium. The score was 80 -- 46.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 20 -- Almost 3,000 persons were present yesterday afternoon at a garden tea given by Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe at Planting Fields, their Oyster Bay estate, for the benefit of the Travelers' Aid Society. Flower lovers from Westchester, New Jersey, Long Island and New York City were among those who viewed the collection of blooms from other countries.

A legal opinion that grounds existed for a charge of conspiracy against the Laundry Board of Trade of Greater New York, Inc., because of the activities of certain members of the Brooklyn Division, was contained in typewritten minutes of a meeting of the directors of the Laundry Board last December, which were introduced as evidence yesterday at the inquiry of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into the laundry industry in Greater New York.

Samuel Seabury's recommendation that city magistrates be appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court instead by the Mayor, to take their selection out of politics, has been, disapproved by the New York County Lawyers Association through action by its board of directors on the ground that the change would have the contrary effect.
LONDON, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Lancashire today increased its lead in the county cricket championship standing by defeating Kent on the first innings at Manchester.

The overnight announcement of the formation of a committee of distinguished bankers and industrialists to aid in making effective the credit expansion program of the Federal Reserve System gave pronounced buoyancy to the early trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 20 -- N. W. Spadavecchia, missing member of the Carpe expedition to Mount McKinley; Percy T. Olton Jr., another member of the expedition who has been marooned on Muldrow Glacier, and S.E. Robbins, Alaskan Airways pilot, who took off from here yesterday to rescue Olton and search for Spadavecchia and had been unreported since, are all safe on the glacier, according to word reaching here tonight.

CARL REYNOLDS, heavy hitter and fleet outfielder of the Washington Senators, was called to the stand. Against the advice of his counsel, Moe Berg, he waived immunity. Being duly sworn, he said that he was born in Larue, Texas, Feb. 1, 1904, attended Southwestern University, was graduated in 1926, won his letter in four sports, was 6 feet tall, weighed 184 pounds, was right-handed all the way and was brought up on curve-ball pitching.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 20. -- Introduced in Maryland today, a figure eight course for jumpers, including a triple in-and-out and a series of pocket jumps, proved baffling for some of the best hunters in the State participating in the first day's program of the Green Spring Valley Hounds' horse show at the Worthington Valley grounds.

In accordance with the request of Senator THOMAS of Oklahoma, a radio address by Mr. JOHN A. SIMPSON, president of the National Farmers' Union, on "Farm Life and Conditions in Denmark," fattens the Congressional Record and has thence been reprinted, "not at Government expense."

All city employes are being asked by their superiors to contribute $1 each to the "Patriots' Roll-Call," the proceeds of which will go to pay the bills of the New York City George Washington Bicentennial Commission. In the Police Department the request was in the form of an order from Commissioner Mulrooney asking for 100 per cent enrolment in the fund-raising campaign.

DUBLIN, May 20 -- One day after the Dail Eireann voted to abolish the oath of allegiance to the British Crown, the de Valera government tonight announced its acceptance of the invitation to the Ottawa imperial economic conference still held good. The government says it will be willing to begin discussion with other governments "when its preparations for the conference are sufficiently advanced."

To Stop Rayon Output During June. In an effort to bring production into line with demand, the rayon yarn industry will be completely shut down during the month of June, with quotations remaining unchanged at their present level, according to authoritative reports in the market yesterday.

Convention Delegates in Fractions. Offhand one would say that a delegate at large should rate higher than a district delegate, but by this time the assiduous reader must be aware that it is the other way about.
BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Braves defeated the Phillies, 10 to 0, today as Huek Betts turned back his former team-mates with five hits, three of them by George Davis.

PARIS, May 20 -- The Council of the League of Nations today approved the draft plan for the rehabilitation of Liberia drawn up by the committee headed by Viscount Cecil of Chelwood to serve as the basis for negotiations which the Council desires to begin in August with the Liberian Government, the American Finance Corporation and the Firestone Plantations Company.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Democratic special Senate Committee made public today in detail a $2,300,000,000 program for the relief of unemployment and the stimulation of business.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 20 -- Ohio State took a long stride toward its first Western Conference track and field championship today by qualifying for sixteen places in the title finals, which will be held tomorrow in Dyche Stadium at Northwestern University.
ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- Larry French, Pittsburgh southpaw, allowed only two hits today in the Pirates' 5-to-0 shut-out victory over the Cardinals.

LONDON, May 20 -- Bankruptcy proceedings for Kreuger Toll, holding company for the vast Kreuger interests, were recommended by the Swedish investigation committee in a report issued here tonight by the British protective committee.

More than one-third of the sales of Block-Aid stamps have been made in blocks in which the subscribers have relatively small incomes, according to Wilton Lloyd-Smith, director of the Block Community Organization, who reviewed the efforts during seven weeks of the campaign last night.

Both sides rested yesterday afternoon in the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, which has been in progress for seven weeks before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.

Vernon Gomez, whom the Senators batted from the box the only other time this year he started a game against them, turned back Washington in the pinches at Yankee Stadium yesterday, the Yankees winning handily by the score of 6 to 3.

Permission for an open-air art exhibition in the streets around Washington Square for the benefit of hundreds of needy artists of Greenwich Village and other parts of the city has been granted by Police Commissioner Mulrooney with the approval of Mayor Walker.

PARIS, May 20 -- Measures to strengthen the enforcement of regulations governing the entry and sojourn of foreigners in France were decided on today by the Council of Ministers, presided over by President Lebrun, in its first held since the assassination of President Doumer.

The conviction of Bernard K. Marcus, president of the Bank of United States; Saul Singer, executive vice president, and the latter's son, Herbert Singer, found guilty last June of willful misapplication of the funds of a subsidiary of the defunct bank, was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision.

In a twenty-page statement read to the Hofstadter legislative committee yesterday. State Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn replied to all the charges concerning him developed in evidence presented by Samuel Seabury, counsel.

Competitors for bus franchises in Queens dumped thirty-six petitions into the lap of the Board of Estimate yesterday, ranging from applications for a single route to petitions covering the entire twenty-six routes which formed the basis for the open bidding invited by the board on May 13.

Percy Kynaston and Melvin Partridge, the only players seeded in the Amackassin Club's invitation tennis tournament, had little difficulty surviving the first round on the club's courts in Yonkers yesterday. Kynaston defeated Stanley R. Nobel, 6 -- 0, 7 -- 5, while Partridge eliminated Jess Baker, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every schoolboy who knows anything at all about the English language knows that the word for "center" used by the English is middle, Anglo-Saxon middel, and center was introduced into the language by Norman-French influence.

The committee of bankers and industrialists, under the chairmanship of Owen D. Young, formed to aid in making effective the credit expansion program of the Federal Reserve System held no formal meeting yesterday, but a number of its members conferred at the Federal Reserve Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Wide usage of the power of taxation in the prevention of future periods of unemployment was recommended tonight by C.A. Dykstra, City Manager of Cincinnati, in addressing 3,500 delegates to the National Conference of Social Work.

One fact about Owen D. Young which Ida M. Tarbell recounts in her forthcoming biography, "Owen D. Young: A New Type of Industrial Leader," is that the "D'" in his name stands for nothing at all. A friend of the family suggested the name Owen but at the time of the christening no one had given any thought to a middle name.

Samuel Untermyer, counsel for the independent protective committee for holders of debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, of which committee Bainbridge Colby is chairman, has requested the New York Stock Exchange to compel the furnishing to the committee of the list of debenture holders to whom the committee headed by Grayson M.P. Murphy mailed requests for the deposit of debentures.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 20 (AP) -- Judge John P. Nields in United States District Court today appointed Perry O. Crawford of Chicago and Clarence A. Southerland of Wilmingtcn as receivers of the Federal Public Service Corporation.

VIRGINIA WATER, Surrey, England, May 20 (AP) -- When Miss Joyce Wethered, England's greatest woman player and a match for most men, and Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, five times American champion, meet in the singles tomorrow they will resume an old rivalry, which so far has been all in the English girl's favor.

Irregularity marks trade and industry throughout the country, some lines still showing seasonal improvement and others, having passed their peak, declining, according to the weekly reviews by the mercantile agencies. Generally, most of the improvement has been in retail lines.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A threat to take George White New York theatrical producer, "for a ride" when he comes to Chicago to stage his "Scandals" at the Chicago Civic Opera House next Sunday was the subject of a conference today between Mayor Cermak, Police Commissioner Allman and Ben F. Holzman, Mr. White's representative.

Lou Reichers, who was forced down at sea in his flight to Ireland and rescued by the United States liner President Roosevelt late at night on Friday, May 13, returned on the liner that saved him yesterday, declaring he intended to try it again as soon as possible.

EASTON, Pa., May 20 -- Alumni in an unbroken succession, from the oldest living class of 1872 down to date, assembled here today at Lafayette College for a two-day celebration of the first class assembled and the first lessons taught in their alma mater a hundred years ago.

BUFFALO, May 20 -- Describing prohibition as an issue in which there was no hope in compromise, Senator Wagner asked unqualified repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment in an address over a National Broadcasting Company network tonight. Ho spoke at an anti-prohibition rally here and repeated his speech over Station WBEN and affiliated stations.

In Japan, reports our Tokyo correspondent, the quarrel between the military caste and the "politicians" does not concern foreign policy but economic and social problems at home. The reason why there is no difference of opinion about foreign affairs is presumably to be found in the fact that here the military have had it all their own way.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- An investigation into the "locust swarm of lobbyists" which has been steadily buzzing through the halls of Congress this year was demanded today in a resolution introduced by Senator Wheeler.

BUFFALO, May 20 -- Harvey Ogden, chief test pilot for the Curtiss Airplane and Motor Corporation, was killed this afternoon at Bowmansville, eight miles east of Buffalo, when he fell nearly two miles as the experimental army observation plane ho was testing crumpled.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Industrial employment throughout the United States showed another drop of 2.7 per cent in April below the preceding month, while earnings of those having jobs were 5.1 per cent less than in March, the Labor Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Duties on oil and coal, hitherto denied in tariff revision even as general as the Hawley-Smoot act, were written into the tax bill in the Senate today, while the essential revenue features of the bill were shunted aside.

Having wiped the slate clean -- or as clean as it could, considering the past -- the Board of Estimate yesterday took up again the question of buses for Queens. Bids were received from twenty-one companies. Some of them were said to offer better terms to the city than in their previous proposals.

The Giants invaded Ebbets Field yesterday, and before 14,000 spectators overcame the Robins with a high-powered offensive. McGraw's men assailed the eminent Arthur C. Vance for nine hits that included a home run, two triples and a pair of doubles, to win the series opener, 9 to 4, and climb 21 points above the Phillies into fifth place.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For many weeks past it has seemed evident to me that the attitude of commercial banks in this and other cities toward the extension of credit for the purchase of securities has been a major factor in retarding the return of confidence on the part of the public.
WENTWORTH, Surrey, England, May 20 -- The order of play in tomorrow's women's international golf team matches between Great Britain and the United States was announced tonight as follows:

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the issue of $700,000 of revenue bills or certificates of indebtedness to provide funds needed by the Board of Transportation to begin municipal operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway line. The city's transportation agency is planning direct operation if no bids are received of May 31 on the revised contract for private operation under lease.

These are days of continued joy for Peconic Bay weakfishermen. The stories of the last few days are replete with tales of good fishing, sunny weather and ideal conditions. Not the least encouraging is the fact that the average weakfish has been from five to seven pounds.

A $10,000 letter of credit, which a promoter of the Equitable Coach Company bought for cash, paid for Mayor Walker's tour of Europe in the Summer of 1927, according to evidence presented to the Hofstadter committee yesterday by Samuel Seabury.

An exhibition that deals with the landscape painting of four centuries has opened at the Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue, where it will remain until June 10. These historical surveys have a way of sounding a little more formidable than inspection proves them to be.

Experiments indicating the presence in some normal tissues of a substance that inhibits the growth of certain types of cancer in mice are described in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, by Dr. James B. Murphy and Dr. Ernest Sturm of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

LYNBROOK, L.I., May 20 -- A parade of 100 automobiles across Long Island in the "Repeal Week" campaign of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform was met here today by a delegation of several hundred drys, organized by the Rev. George W. Roesch, pastor of St. James Methodist Episcopal Church.

The sale of a Washington Heights apartment house and several changes of control of business and residential plots in the Bronx comprised the outstanding feature of real estate activity in this city yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 20 -- Nearly 3,000 persons attended the annual military field day of the Rutgers University unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps at Neilson Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A complicated transaction involving the purchase for $23,500,000 of a company with assets of $1,750,000 and patents on a food-freezing process figured today in the stock market inquiry by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

Jack (Kid) Berg, English lightweight, fought one of his most spectacular ring battles in vain last night at Madison Square Garden. For twelve rounds he battled Sammy Fuller of Boston in a sizzling encounter before 7,000 fight fans and then had the decision go against him.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- The wave of economy which has swept over the thirty-first quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, wiping out seven Bishop areas, shortening the conference itself, retiring future Bishops on the pension allowances of ministers and closing the offices of the commission on world peace, lapped today at the doors of the board of Bishops.

The steady growth of savings deposits during the last three years seemingly indicates that the United States, during the depression, is moving toward the ideal distribution of wealth discussed by economists, Wilson G. Wing, newly elected president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, said yesterday during the final session of that organization's convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 20 -- Iona School's baseball team scored four runs in the seventh and last inning to defeat Manhattan Prep, 7 to 6, today for its tenth triumph in as many Manhattan division Catholic High School's Athletic Association games.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The downward movement on the Boerse came to a standstill today after early losses of 2 to 4 per cent. Foreign offers, which had been pressing heavily upon the market, decreased gradually. As the public continued to hold back orders, these offers could be executed only at declining prices.

Stocks opened from a fraction to more than a point higher on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as a result of overnight news. Although prices continued to move fractionally higher until around noon, the rally failed to hold and values eased off, erasing the greater part of the early gains.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Real cooperation has come at last in Washington. The announcement by the committee of Senate Democrats today of the details of their bill to relieve unemployment revealed an honest harmonizing of the plans of private citizens, members of Congress on both sides and the President.

The Schulte Real Estate Company, Inc., has sold to the Bridgehead Realty Corporation, represented by Walter Ryan, a two-story business building at 37-52 to 37-58 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, on a plot 80 by 100 feet. The realty was held at $250,000, Gerson Sweedler, the brokers, report.

"In these trying times it is an undoubted temptation for church councils to divert funds in their care to other purposes than those for which they were given," says the report of the committee on moral and social welfare of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, which will be presented to the synod at its annual convention at St. John's Church, 81 Christopher Street.

A TORNADO of Hindu-Moslem rioting has swept over the city of Bombay. For several days bazaars were wrecked and looted, streets were destroyed by incendiaries, and individuals were violently assaulted.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Leaders of the radio industry, representing an investment of $1,000,000,000, will go into conference here Monday, in the eighth annual convention and trade show of the Radio Manufacturers' Association, for a discussion of the many problems facing the industry, including ways and means of stimulating business.

NOT often does an autobiography tell its story so entertainingly as does this book through the greater part of its pages. And equally unusual is it to find one that reveals simply and sincerely a spiritual evolution so significant, a spiritual training leading surely to achievement so momentous.

IN his account of the disaster that befell Theodore Koven and Allen Carpe in ascending Mount McKinley, Albert Lindley states that he found thermometers which had been left by the Stuck-Karstens expedition at 15,000 feet. The arrowmarkers pointed to temperatures below minus 95 degrees Fahrenheit.

LONDON, May 5 AS I watched H.F. Maltby's play. "Ring on Her Fingers," and observed how a lady who lived by her wits prepared to discard her profitable lovers and turn to a young man whose face was his only fortune.

AN Italian geologist was quoted the other day in press dispatches as predicting that an island of continental proportions would eventually make its appearance in the present oceanic area between South America and Africa. How many newspaper readers were reminded by this announcement of Atlantis?
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 21 -- Army won its third successive track victory by defeating Penn State in a dual meet today by a score of 87 to 39.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 21 -- The Yale golf team won the championship of the intercollegiate association by defeating Harvard, 8 to 1, in the final match on the Taconic Club course today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 21 -- A ninth-inning rally with the tying run on the bases failed to bring victory today to the Temple University baseball team, the Naval Academy winning through an early-game advantage, 4 to 3.

S. Tilden Stern is having his first one-man show at the Midtown Gallery. Stern was an artistic prodigy in "his student days at Erasmus Hall High School and has earned an impressive roster of scholarships and medals.

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., May 21 (AP) -- There was no Lindbergh celebration in Little Falls today. The day had been set aside for dedication of Lindbergh State Park in honor of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, a native Minnesotan, but elaborate ceremonies were cancelled because of the kidnapping and death of the Lindbergh baby.

LESLIE HOWARD of London New York and occasionally points West is to be seen and heard at the Paramount this week in "Reserved for Ladies." Being one of those perennial English young men, he has served longer, in the drama than seems quite possible.

New York anglers have been anticipating what may well be one of the best week-ends of the season for fishing. Some headed for trout streams yesterday and others for Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut to feel a salt water breeze whip their faces.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 21 -- Nicholas W. Spadavecchia of the Carpe-Koven cosmic-ray expedition to Mount McKinley, whose safety was established yesterday when one of the planes searching for him found him with Percy T. Olton Jr. in the expedition's camp on Muldrow Glacier, was never lost.
THE television station atop the Empire State Building is in operation. Unseen images are leaping into space from the lofty pinnacle 1,276 feet above the sidewalks of New York.

The Hakoah All-Stars and the German All-Stars will clash in a goodwill soccer game at the Polo Grounds today. The contest is sponsored by leading Jewish and German citizens as a means of promoting interracial understanding. Mayor Walker, honorary chairman of the sponsoring committee, will kick off the ball at the start of play.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- Wands and Irwin led the Pennsylvania, varsity lacrosse team to a 6-to-3 victory over the Princeton twelve today in the final game of the season for the Tigers.

HARBIN, Manchuria, April 21 -- Japan's aggressive policies in Manchuria are not confined to military and political expression, but are also evidenced by manoeuvres designed to shake Russian control of the Chinese Eastern Railway, the 1,000-mile system which crosses North Manchuria and shortens by more than 500 miles the route from Vladivostok to Moscow.

The collection of Robert Cluett Jr., consisting of fine old English furniture of the Queen Anne, early Georgian and Chippendale periods, with nine valuable painting's by Gainsborough, Lawrence, Raeburn, Romney end Downman, will be sold Thursday at the American Art Association-Andersen Galleries, Inc., where it is now being shown.

LOS ANGELES, May 21 -- New Democratic party control was established in California today when delegates to the national convention meeting here elected William Gibbs McAdoo, Garner supporter, as their chairman. John B. Elliott, also a Garner man, was named National Committeeman, to succeed Isadore Dockweiler, a Roosevelt backer, and leader of the State party since 1916.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a superstition among sailors that the rats leave a ship when danger is imminent. Who cares what happens to the rats? Real trouble comes when the crew, unnerved, perhaps, by days of storm, and fearing some invisible peril, want to follow the example of the rats and trade the comparative security of the ship for certain death at the mercy of the waves.

BERKELEY, Cal., May 21 -- Bullet Bob Kiesel, University of California sophomore sprint sensation, gained a measure of revenge today for an earlier beating from his keenest rival when he defeated Frank Wykoff of Southern California in the 100-yard dash of the annual California intercollegiates.

A proposal that the people of the United States erect a colossal statue of George Washington on the reservation at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., where it would be visible to all travelers entering or leaving New York Harbor, was made by Vernon B. Hampton, director of the Richmond County George Washington bicentennial celebration, in a speech yesterday at ceremonies opening the county's celebration.

ROSA DARTLE owes her fame -- a fame that has reached the dictionaries -- chiefly to her reiterated requests for information. This characteristic, so unusual in a young English woman of the middle nineteenth century, was hardly one to win the irresponsible Steerforth, upon whom her affections were fixed, but it would have made her an almost unbelievably perfect representative of the American public of today.

SHEILA KAYE-SMITH'S latest book seems to mark a completely new departure from her previous work. In "Summer Holiday" she has produced something of a kind she has never before attempted, which very few writers have ever tackled successfully a story of children.

FLORENCE IN the most beautiful of Italian novels. Manzoni reminds us that the 22-year-old Prince of Conde slept very soundly on the night preceding the battle of Rocroy, which was to make him the most famous French General of his day.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee is now providing emergency work for 16,384 men and women, according to a statement last night by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman, in a summary of the committee's activities.

Two men, who, the police said, attempted to extort $1,000 from Generoso Pope, Italian newspaper publisher, by posing as racketeers, were arrested yesterday by a detective hidden in Mr. Pope's office on the thirty-first floor of 551 Fifth Avenue.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 16. -- Arizona with its three staples -- corn, cattle and copper -- at the lowest prices in decades is yielding again to the witchery of the age-old lure of gold. It was the hope of gold which led the Spanish conquistadores in the sixteenth century up from Mexico in search of the fabled Seven Cities of Cibola.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Seemingly deaf to pleas of leaders for swift action on the billion-dollar tax bill, the Senate continued today in a jam over the remaining tariff items in the measure.

The recently approved curriculum of Brooklyn College, established two years ago as New York's third public institution of higher learning, gives an indication of the new types of courses winning their way into higher education. Firmly resting on the traditional disciplines and equipments, the curriculum yet bears the stamp of contemporary interests and sympathies.

PUBLIC interest in antiques as well as in American history has had much to do with the salvaging of old structures and their restoration to their original condition. In this work the antiquarian's knowledge of furniture has been, of great help.

Led by Giles Verstraten, who on Wednesday won the Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis singles championship for the second successive year, the McBurney School tennis team has high hopes of finishing the season undefeated. To date the McBurney netmen have won all their nine matches and have only three more scheduled with Brooklyn Friends, Stony Brook and Kew Forest on successive days this week, beginning Tuesday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., May 19 -- Exact in detail even to the manuscript of music to be played by the band, George Washington's visit to the town of Salem in May, 1791, will be reproduced here on May 28.

With 412 delegates already pledged to or instructed for Governor Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President, campaign managers of the Governor expect that they will be able to have a majority before the end of this week.

REPORTS from State and city chairmen of the Atwater Kent national radio auditions indicate a record-breaking number of entries. Local auditions have been held in each of the five national districts. The winners in these auditions have been certified to their respective State auditions, to be held later.

ALTHOUGH about 90 per cent of naval planes today operate from fields, carrier decks or other surface vessels, and, consequently, are land planes, the real background of present-day naval aviation is the flying boat, says a bulletin from the Bureau of Aeronautics.

Advocating control of production of crude oil by interstate compact "to prevent waste and to protect the natural resources from premature exhaustion," C.B. Ames, vice president of the Texas Company and a former judge of the Supreme Court of Oklahoma, said in a recent speech that overproduction of oil now was contributing a three-fold element to the national depression.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A campaign to prevent postmasters From engaging in political activities and to cut off the pay of W. Irving Glover, Second Assistant Postmaster General, was opened in the Senate today by-Senator King, Democrat, of Utah.

Approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a $27,500,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to the Pennsylvania Railroad, railroad men said yesterday, had aroused wider popular interest than any similar action taken in Washington.
NEW YORK Prince Max Hohenlohe is arriving on the Morro Castle from Mexico City and will be at the Ritz-Carlton until he sails on the Olympic Friday.
THE New York Opera Reoertoire Company plans twelve operas for next season, to be given for one week each in a Broadway theatre. Henri Elkan will conduct. Stefanie Gloeckner will be managing director.

WENTWORTH, Surrey, England, May 21 -- Cool heads and steady nerves in crisis after crisis gave the United States women's golf team victory, by 5 1/2 points to 3 1/2, today over its British opponents in the first official women's international match played between the two countries.

THE rise of Japan as a great power in the modern world is one of the most significant developments of our time. The fact that an Asiatic nation could make itself over into a modern State inside a period of thirty-seven years constitutes the greatest single political event of the nineteenth century.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended May 14 declined below those of the preceding week, when there had been a gain due to month-end influences, and continued under a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

HAVANA, May 17 -- Five associations of feminists have protested to President Machado and Congress against a bill now pending which would permit women to be elected on the City Council of Havana, the re-establishment of which is embodied in the measure.

LONDON DRAMATIC festivals are as old as the drama itself, although there are people who think the idea was started in Salzburg. There were festivals of plays in Europe before there were any theatres, and Stratford-on-Avon and Malvern follow in a grand English tradition.

Professional baseball's greatest crowd of the year anywhere, about 60,000, saw the triumphal finish of the Yankees' five-game, first-place series with Washington yesterday at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees won both contests of the double-header, 14 to 2 and 8 to 0, and gained a lead of two and a half games over the Senators.

THIS new biography dealing with the reign of that brilliant prince of the Renaissance, Francis I of France, is dedicated to the proposition that history ought to be made entertaining. This is a laudable as well as a profitable intention since it is generously subscribed to by those persons who do not like their history straight.
PORTLAND, Me. MOTORISTS who tour next Summer over the Atlantic Highway into Kastern Maine and Canada will have two interesting side trips available.

BOSTON, May 19 -- What may prove to be a document of much historic importance has just been given to the public by a joint commission representing the Unitarian and the Universalist Churches, both of which have their denominational headquarters here.

Store executives are now beginning to give increasing attention to figures on gross margin, inasmuch as fixed charges in the expense category differ widely and are not directly controllable, whereas the gross return figure is readily comparable as between stores.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, said to include 181 organizations in New York, with a membership of more than 100,000 women, yesterday went on record as favoring prohibition reform as a means of increasing revenue and aiding employment.

GREENWICH HOUSE will celebrate its thirtieth birthday on next Thursday with an open house for all its friends. Thus a new generation will be reminded that on May 26, 1902. Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch, a young settlement worker, and her husband, an instructor at Columbia, rented an old dwelling in Jones Street, convinced that the best way to serve the poor was to work with them rather than for them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- The eighth annual Westchester Music Festival was concluded at the County Centre tonight with the presentation of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, one of the most difficult undertakings of the festival chorus of 1,500 voices.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 19 -- Vermont impressed itself upon the national consciousness this week through action taken at its two State conventions. The Democrats elected delegates favorable to the candidacy of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, although they were not instructed to support him.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21 (AP) -- Suntica, owned by Dr. Willis Sharpe Kilmer of Binghamton, N.Y., won the fifty-eighth running of the Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs today.

A sports field for children in the Yorkville section was opened yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Thrift House Settlement. The field, which borders the East River, runs between Eighty-ninth Street and Ninetieth Street. When completed it will include a baseball field, tennis courts, swings, slides, seesaws and a wading pool.

BOGOTA, May 17 -- Although the present high tariff is said to have increased smuggling, Argemiro Martinez, correspondent of El Espectador at the Atlantic port of Santa Marta, has discovered to his sorrow that he may expect no gratitude on the part of either the State or municipal governments for reporting the introduction of contraband.

THOSE who motor to the Civil War battlefield of Gettysburg for Memorial Day this year will, perhaps, be even more interested than usual in adjacent Revolutionary landmarks, because of the nation-wide observance of the George Washington bicentennial.

BOSTON, May 20 THE remnants of the season will be pulled off the counter at the end of the week and the theatre-shops closed until August or September -- except, possibly, for tryouts as occasional bargain days.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21. -- Davis Harrington pitched the Yale freshman nine to an 11-1 victory over the Harvard freshman team today. He fanned eight, bringing his strikeout record for the season to 95.

JUST two centuries ago this month, Maryland and Pennsylvania made the settlement over their boundary which later formed the basis of the Mason and Dixon Line. From a petty squabble between jealous Colonies arose the famous dividing line which Mason and Dixon drew in indelible ink on the pages of American history.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 22 -- It is now agreed that a national coalition Cabinet shall be formed, but the opponents of Baron Ki-ichiro Hiranuma, vice president of the Privy Council, have proved strong enough to cause serious doubts as to whether he will become Premier.

SOME twenty-five years ago boys and girls were able to read in "What Mr. Darwin Saw in His Voyage Round the World in the Ship Beagle," an account of Darwin's five-year scientific expedition, but for many years the book has been out of print.

FAVORABLE weather brought about quite a fair increase in retail trade during the week and volume gained also as a result at various promotions. From all reports, national cotton week drew an excellent response. There was increased activity on Summer lines, and attention was called to brisk sales on games and sporting goods.
HANOVER, N.H., May 21 -- The Dartmouth freshman track team defeated Andover, 67 -- 51, today in a meet which was held in alternate sunshine and showers.

WHEN the Dutch settlers had pushed their new town of New Amsterdam some five minutes' walk inland from their sandy landing place they gazed apprehensively into the underbrush beyond and then built a wall or stockade to keep out the Indians.

DETROIT. ONE hears remarkably little about midsummer new models in Detroit these days in comparison with the past. And the little one hears indicates quite definitely that there are going to be few, if any, such offerings.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 21 -- Briggs S. Cunningham sailed his 6 meter racing yacht Lucie to a forty-six-second victory today over the new craft Nancy, syndicate-owned, which had Olin J. Stephens, her designer, at her tiller. J.S. Johnson's Jill, handled by C. Sherman Hoyt, was fifteen seconds astern of Nancy.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 19 -- When Dr. Edwin A. Alderman, first and only president of the University of Virginia, died April 30, 1931, speculation as to his successor was immediate and insistent. Hardly had they buried the late executive before the university was feverishly seeking a man worthy to take his place.

Finding fault with Congress is no new thing in this country, but is as old as Congress itself, it seems from a letter of Revolutionary times which has been acquired in New York recently. As long ago as 1780 one of the members of the Continental Congress came to the conclusion that his colleagues in Congress were "governed by principles unworthy of the meanest of God's creatures."

MEDFORD, Mass., May 21 -- While Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam streaked through, the skies across the Atlantic toward Paris alone in an airplane, her mother occupied herself here with two small grandchildren at her home at 118 Traincroft Road.

As a result of the financial difficulties of the Globe Theatre, operated by Charles Dillingham, "The Cat and the Fiddle." the Jerome Kern-Otto Harbach operetta, was withdrawn last night from that playhouse, where it opened on Oct. 15. According to Ben Boyar, representing Max Gordon, producer of the operetta, the show will resume its Broadway engagement at the George M. Cohan Theatre on Tuesday night.
ALBANY, May 21 -- Four Bronx men were sentenced in Federal court this afternoon for alleged income tax evasion after pleading guilty.

BROADCASTING stations in seventy-three countries are pumping spoken words and music into the emptiness of space. It did not take long to discover, after the pioneers rushed into the gold fields of broadcasting, that the microphone is the gateway to expensive enterprise.

The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was crowded with children yesterday afternoon at the annual presentation of the Lenten missionary offering from each parish Sunday school in the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York.
BOSTON, May 21 -- Boston College won its second game in three days and its ninth in eleven this season, by defeating Manhattan College of New York, 11 to 3, on University Heights today.

Allotment of places for qualifying trials for the national open golf championship was announced yesterday through The Associated Press, with New York drawing the largest number. 24 of the 116 places for which 978 entrants will contest. Thirty-four players are exempt from qualifying.

ROME, May 20 -- Nobody interested in international affairs could come to Rome without wishing to meet the men responsible for Italy's foreign policy now that their country definitely has taken the lead among the nations that believe that something must be done speedily to get the world out of its present sorry plight.

RUMBLINGS of discontent are heard among the radio audience by Lyman Bryson, director of the California Adult Education Association. He reported to the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education at the second annual assembly held during the past week in Buffalo that "the crowns of the monarchs of the radio industry rest uneasy on their heads" because there are signs of revolt among the millions of listeners.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, May 21 -- Just five years after Charles A. Lindbergh's historic flight to Paris, Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam landed today in a lonely pasture at Culmore, near Londonderry, 14 hours and 56 minutes after leaving Harbor Grace, Nfld.

Plans for a junior science club federation sponsored by the American Institute of the City of New York, an organization of scientists which has been functioning for more than 100 years, were discussed at a meeting of school science teachers and representatives of principals called by the institute at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The use of fuel oil in small high-speed internal-combustion marine engines will be the subject of the evening at the first formal meeting of the recently organized marine division of the Metropolitan Section of the Society of Automotive Engineers, which is to be held Tuesday at the Park Central Hotel.

GRENOBLE, May 20 -- The efforts of munition makers to prevent a successful outcome of the disarmament conference at Geneva were denounced by delegates to the Seventh Congress of the World's International League for Peace and Freedom, which Jane Addams founded during the World War.

EXETER, N.H., May 21 -- The Tufts freshmen defeated Exeter, 11 to 10, today in a game marked by hard hitting on both sides. Tyrance and Woodworth knocked home runs for Tufts and Tyrance also made a three-bagger. Exeter used three pitchers and Tufts two.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- An earthquake which shook Central America this morning, frightening inhabitants of Managua and other places in Northern Nicaragua, was recorded on the seismograph of Georgetown University at 5:10 A.M., Eastern Standard Time.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Protests have been received by the State Department from Chile and Peru against the proposed import taxes on petroleum and copper.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 19 -- Growing out of the pressing financial problems of the past two years, the farm country is acquiring a new state of mind which has to do more with the underlying causes of today's conditions than with the surface effects in price levels and markets. The vastly expanded discussion of the latter has left little to add to the sum of information.

THIS book by the German entomologist Friedrich Schnack is, as the author says, "not a textbook." It is rather a poetic appreciation of the butterflies and moths that have most appealed to him throughout his years of study.

Women have been active in aviation almost from its beginning and while in the earlier stages of its development their participation in hazardous flights was usually as passengers, in the last three years they have vied with one another in setting record after record for speed, altitude and distance, and in piloting tiny planes to remote and dangerous corners of the world.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 21 -- The People's Savings and Trust Company of Duryea was closed by the State Banking Department this morning and a warrant was issued this afternoon for the arrest of W.S. Barren, former treasurer, charging him with embezzlement.

RUSH-HOUR trains on the Yokohama line became so crowded that foreign suburbanites (British and American) entered official complaints. As a result an extra car was added to each train and conditions were a little bit-better.

Advising his hearers to remember that "there are still more frames than there are pictures," Mayor Walker made known yesterday that he is prepared to face "any man" on the charges developed before the Hofstadter committee.
Following is a list of successful airplane flights across the North Atlantic from west to east.
METRO-GOLDWYN - MAYER has acquired motion picture rights to "The Education of a Princess," the autobiography of the tempestuous life of Marie, Grand Duchess of Russia.

New York's latest marathon craze will be one of diet and food values, it was indicated last night at the Grand Central Palace, where twenty-four contestants entered upon "a vitality demonstration" fostered by the Bernarr Macfadden Foundation.

WENTWORTH, Surrey, England, May 21 (AP) -- The Americans' sweep of the Scotch foursomes, in which each pair played alternate shots, came as a distinct surprise today. It is the traditional British game and critics had expected the native stars to excel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Mr. J. Smith Jr., in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, on the subject of "High Opera Salaries" is extremely interesting and illuminating, because every word he says is perfectly true.

WITHIN a short time Paris will have talking clocks. Parisians have long had the habit of telephoning the Observatory to ask the time, but these calls are increasing to such an extent that it is difficult to answer them all. To solve the problem the director of the Observatory, M. Esclangnon, has made an ingenious use of the talking movie idea.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- The election of officers for the Princeton Theological Seminary eating and social clubs for next year was announced today. There are four clubs, among which the student body is divided nearly equally. The clubs and their officers are as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- Having paused only to get their breath after the Presidential primaries and incidentally to count the casualties, California political pundits now turn gleefully to the business of forming new lines and making combinations for the Senatorial preliminaries.

PARIS. PARIS fashions are returning to the expression of easy nonchalance that characterized them before the great feminine revival influenced everybody to "dress up." Women nowadays have too many serious preoccupations to make clothes the paramount purpose in life; and they do not want to be bothered with "playing up" to super-luxurious modes.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 21 -- S. E. Robbins, the Alaskan Airways pilot, returned early this morning from Muldrow Glacier on Mount McKinley after repairing the broken axle of his plane with parts dropped from another ship. Robbins reports N.W. Spadavecchia returned to the Muldrow camp on May 20, having been gone ten days.

The foundation has been laid for rehabilitation of the National Electric Power System and the paying off of bank loans of the parent company and its subsidiaries as a result of negotiations conducted for ten days by executives of the company, bankers in this city and the receivers of the Middle West Utilities Company, which controls the National Electric Power Company, a $600,000,000 corporation.

Austin Hewson, president of the New York Typographical Union 6, the "Big Six," in a letter to the American Federation of Labor and to the New York delegation in Congress, protested yesterday against the proposed increase in second class postal rates on the ground that it would add to unemployment, increase illiteracy and diminish the demand for advertised goods and thus hamper business.

CAMBRIDGE. ONCE upon a time a distinguished stranger dined at Trinity College in Cambridge. Seated at the high table which is sacred to dons, fellows and distinguished strangers, he fell into conversation with his table companions.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21 -- Penn State defeated Syracuse, 12 -- 7, in a Triangular Association baseball game at Hendricks Field today.

FAYETTEVILLE. Ark., May 19 -- Arkansas is swinging into the long pull of a new political campaign, the dominant interest of the day. The State's crop of candidates, always abundant, this season is superabundant. Bright young men, whitehaired patriarchs, prohibitionists and intelligent citizens, farmers, preachers, lawyers, doctors, veterinarians, truck drivers, distillers and college professors are placing themselves in the ranks of the self-proffered saviors of government.

WENTWORTH, Surrey, England, May 21 -- The United States won all three of the foursomes in the international team match for women golfers against England today owing to the definitely superior play of the American girls.

Two of the most enthusiastic persons to learn yesterday of Mrs. Amelia Earhart Futnam's Atlantic flight were Miss Ruth Nichols and Miss Elinor Smith, women fliers, who plan to hop off themselves on the great adventure this year. From her home on Grace Church Street, Rye, N.Y., Miss Nichols, holder of the women's speed, distance and altitude records, sent this cable to Mrs. Putnam:

BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) -- Four home runs in the seventh and eighth innings enabled the Orioles to come from behind to defeat Jersey City, 9 to 6, today and even the series at one game each. Jordan, Packard and Linton hit the four-baggers, the latter having two of them.

PARIS, May 20 -- Sitting in Paris the other day a distinguished-looking woman of 80 spoke over the radio to America. Her act was in many ways the completion of what her father did 100 years ago, for she is Mrs. Morse Rummel, daughter of Samuel Morse.

ST. JOHN, N.B., May 21 (AP) -- A cablegram bearing the congratulations of the city of St. John was sent today by K.D. Spear, the commissioner through whose department the local airport is administered, to Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam on her transatlantic flight.

FOR God or against God, this once more is the alternative that shall decide the destinies of all mankind. In politics, in finance, in morals, in the science and arts, in the State, in civil and domestic society, in the East and in the West, everywhere this question confronts us as the deciding factor because of the consequences that flow from it.

In view of the controversy in Washington over "money" and "prices," the Bureau of Labor Statistics has published its latest compilation of commodity averages at an interesting time. The report shows that the average for all commodities now stands at 65.5, compared with 74.8 a year ago and with 100 in 1926.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- Wes Schulmerich banged the centre field fence with a double today to break up a fourteen-inning game and give the Boston Braves a 6-5 victory over Philadelphia. This timely hit enabled the tribe to gain valuable ground on the league-leading Chicago Cubs.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 -- Harvard's junior varsity nine defeated the Yale Jayvees today, 17 to 4, Lockwood leading the attack with a home run.
