WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The $2,300,000,000 Democratic relief program was discussed at a conference between President Hoover and Secretary Mills just before the President left Washington this afternoon, for his camp in Virginia.

ALBANY, May 19 -- The city of New York need not look to Long Island for an additional supply of water, for there are millions of gallons going to waste every day over the Sacandaga dam which could be piped into the Ashokan reservoir and then sent to New York, according to General Amasa J. Parker, veteran legislator.

BIRMINGHAM, May 19 -- Alabama is sharing with Mississippi, Florida and other Southern States a difficult problem raised by the inability of thousands of property-holders to pay the heavy ad valorem taxes due this Spring. Reports from Mississippi that about 25 per cent of the privately owned property in that State is under sale for delinquent taxes are matched with statistics of similar trouble in Alabama.

ALTHOUGH not a voluminous poet, the late Elinor Wylie was one of the most gifted lyrists of the first quarter of this century, a period during which a rage for experimentation interfered only too often with genius.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I express approval of a recent editorial in THE TIMES in which attention was directed to the most unfortunate ignorance of practically all nations of the earth in respect to the inhabitants of neighboring countries?

HORACE GREELEY once wrote an editorial appeal which he entitled "The Prayer of Thirty Millions." Today four times as many Americans are waiting with impatience for Congress to do its duty. If they could, they would sign a monster petition praying the Representatives and Senators to leave off wrangling about personal and local interests while the great concern and anxiety of the nation are ignored.

THE struggle in Japan betweer tha politicians and the militarists -- a political, economic and at times even a social conflict -- reached a climax when a group of military cadets on last Sunday entered the official residence of Ki Inukai, Premier of Japan, and killed him.

The law which Russell T. Sherwood, missing fiscal agent of Mayor Walker, defied was invoked successfully by the Hofstader committee, it became known yesterday, to bring back from Europe the Equitable Coach Company employe who bought the Mayor a $10,000 letter of credit and later made good his $3,000 overdraft.

The Merchants Association made public yesterday a review of its activities for the year, pointing out that it had advanced suggestions, which, if adopted, would have resulted in yearly savings to the public of New York city of $125,000,000. The association celebrates its thirty-fifth anniversary on June 21 according to the pamphlet sent yesterday to members; the last year was said to have been the most active in the history of the association.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 21 (AP) -- Oregon's ten votes will be cast for Governor Roosevelt at the Democratic National Convention and Joseph I. France of Maryland will have the State's thirteen Republican votes at Chicago.

LONDON, May 12 -- As the days pass, and May is running out, with the conference at Lausanne on German reparations less than a month away, the problem before the Cabinet is seen to be that of the debt of the United States. This is the question which today is uppermost in the minds of the principal Ministers and of Treasury experts.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21 -- Five new meet records were established and two tied today in the twenty-seventh annual track and field games of the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association, which were won by New Rochelle High after a duel with Gorton of Yonkers, victor five times in six previous meets.

Abraham Kaplan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, issued a statement yesterday denying the recent allegations of the Civil Service Reform Association that political patronage systems were being built up in this city through the use of positions exempted from civil service.

FOR a little more than two years Los Angeles has been watching the operation of its Institute of Family Relations, whose task is to advise and guide those involved in domestic difficulties. The experiment has created such interest that at least thirty American cities have indicated that they are anxious to launch similar institutes.

What are the cosmic rays? Photons or bullets of light, MILLIKAN holds in an article which appears in the current issue of The Physical Review. Electrons swifter than any we can produce in the laboratory, KOLHOERSTER argues. Neutrons, reason a few ultra-modernists. The reason for the international organization that Professor A.H. COMPTON created for the world-wide study of the rays is obvious in the face of this conflict of opinion.

Greenwich Village blossomed yesterday in holiday attire for the inauguration of "open house" week. Many visitors viewed the picturesque attractions of the neighborhood, with its lanes and alleys, remnants of a countryside of long ago. This was the gala day of the week, and each day through to May 27 will include a program of various activities and displays.

One of the strongest fields in recent years will tee off tomorrow morning at the Century Country Club, Purchase, N.Y., for the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship. A total of 111 entries has been received for the test, with the list likely to be swelled over the 130-mark by the addition of post entries at the tee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 21 (AP) -- Eleven base hits, eight of them for extra bases, delivered nine runs for the Red Wings and victory over the Buffalo Bisons today, 9 to 7. The Wings, after holding a lead of 4 to 0, were forced to come from behind to hang up the verdict in the third game of the series.

Led by Sam Aronowsky, brilliant in-home. New York University's lacrosse team blanked Lehigh, 7 to 0, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Violet twelve's final game of the season and its fourth victory in ten starts.

THE United States lost its last frontier when Oklahoma was opened to settlement forty years ago, but Canada, as Grey Owl testifies in a book full of love for the wilderness and intimate acquaintance with it, still has one. Grey Owl is the son of a Scotch father and an Apache mother.

To the Dramatic Editor: Through the groans of the dying theatrical year are heard once again the Spring announcements of productions to come for the "bigger and better" 1932-33 season. In this depression period the theatre has not suffered more than any other business.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- A warning that political and industrial leaders might force the country into revolution if they persisted in "clinging to certain extraneous phases of our present social and economic system" was voiced by Owen R. Lovejoy, secretary of the New York Children's Aid Society, at the closing meeting of the National Conference of Social Work today.
"Three Roosevelts Laud Smith Speech." -- NEW YORK TIMES.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 21 -- Michigan's plucky track team, scoring in thirteen of the sixteen events, carried off the Western Conference outdoor track and field championship today to the accompaniment of recrd-breaking performances.

The oppression in shipping has definitely eliminated the college student as a candidate for membership in the crews of oceangoing liners, shipping men report. Emergency help in manning ships on the early Summer trips was once welcomed by the lines, but hundreds of experienced seamen are seeking work now.

The Commerce Department's classified statement on origin and destination of gold imported and exported in April shows that most of the $49,509,170 total exports of the month went to France and Holland, to which we shipped respectively 524,526,766 and $18,706,863.

ABOUT ten years ago a middle-aged man stepped, ashore at Manhattan. It was his third trip to the United States, and he was heralded as a great Swedish industrialist. His name was Ivar Kreuger. He was relatively unknown in the United States at this time and one would not be far wrong in stating that he was barely known to the American financial world.

Foreign Deposits. The solution of the maintenance of the gold standard lies in the recognition that foreign deposits are external debts, even when in the currency of the home bank. This economic law must be made to apply to all post-war changes in currency values.

THE Modern Thinker has added a new department which is to be a permanent feature of the magazine. It is called "Authors' Review," and its purpose is to permit authors to review their own books, to reply to their critics and to explain, if they so desire, how they came to write the books under discussion.

There was little activity In the wholesale markets throughout the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Encouraging reports, however, were received from retailers, and dress buyers fro mleading stores are expected in town tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The insistence of the United States Government upon the delegating of adequate authority to a single official of an international agency to assist Liberia in remedying slavery and sanitary conditions and in instituting budgetary and other governmental reforms was set forth by Samuel Reber Jr., the United States representative on the Liberian committee of the League of Nations.

A brisk recovery in United States Government bonds, which erased the Josses of the previous day, featured an otherwise weaker market for bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Irregularly lower prices for domestic corporation issues and foreign loans resulted in THE NEW YORK TIMES averages for both foreign and domestic bonds touching new low marks for the year.

Move than 250 bills of particulars were filed yesterday with John Killoran, chief of the probate division of the Surrogate's Court, by claimants to the large fortune left by Ella V. Von E. Wendel, aged spinster and last member of the Wendel family.

The New York State Society of Professional Engineers, at its annual convention at the Hotel Commodore yesterday adopted a resolution urging a nation-wide public works program as "the only definite means of combating the economic crisis" and endorsing a recent proposal along the same lines by the board of directors of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 21 -- The Arnold Pavilion far Children at St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital was dedicated this afternoon with services conducted by Bishop Manning of New York, who also delivered an address. Dr. George F. Clover, superintendent of St. Luke's Hospital, New York, presided.

WILLIAM HARLAN HALE. who in his first book comes forth at 21 to hurl a "challenge to defeat" at the Goliath of pessimism, Oswald Spengler, will be an interesting figure to watch. A year ago, as editor of a lively undergraduate publication, The Harkness Hoot, he upset the proponents of Yale's "Gothic Revival" by applying the genetic method of criticism to a growing passion among the university architects for "telephone booths designed as fourteenth-century confessionals."
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 21 -- A home run by Shetelick with two out in the ninth broke up the game between the New York Athletic Club nine and East Orange today, the latter winning, 7 -- 6.

OPERA faces a period of crisis. The signs of the times are encountered at the Metropolitan Opera House and in most if not all of the important lyric theatres of the world. Local indications are the curtailment of the length of the next opera season, reductions in prices of seats and drastic cuts in the salaries of highly paid singers.
The Giants and Robins broke even in a double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday before a crowd of 40,000, the McGrawmen winning the first game, 12 to 5, but losing the nightcap. 7 to 2.

A STATEMENT from the American Library of Musicology announces that the library has been founded for the purpose of publishing in English or translation into English valuable contributions to the science and critique of music that would not otherwise be presented through the ordinary channels of the book trade.

Sugar, coffee, rubber and silk made gains last week in futures trading on local commodity exchanges, while the other staples, including cocoa, hides, silver and wool tops, closed lower after irregular movements.

THE simplicity of Dorothy Wordsworth's life should not blind the student to its profundity. If ever the sister of a famous man deserved to live in her own right it is this brave, intelligent, dreaming woman who so unmistakably sacrificed herself that her brother might the better live.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 21 -- Behind Johnny Broaca's steady hurling, Yale defeated Cornell, 2 -- 0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game before 4,000 persons on Hoy Field today. The game was a feature of Cornell's annual Spring day.

Most parents are not equipped emotionally to be of much help to their children, and few of them have sufficient specific knowledge in regard to the developmental needs of children to be of help. In the "good days" we rather considered it a blessing when the mother found an occupation that took her outside the home.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns put on a four-run rally in the ninth inning today to beat the Indians, 8 to 7.

LONDON, May 20 -- Parliament, having finished its Whitsun holiday, will settle down on Tuesday for the last lap prior to its long Summer vacation with all the major work of the first session virtually accomplished.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- An assertion that "no greater disaster could befall any part of our country" than enactment of three measures designed to strengthen Federal control over Hawaii, was contained in a report by Governor Lawrence Judd of Hawaii, made public today by the Senate Territories Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. USING for the first time their recently formulated "pre-production" cutting system by which film is cut and assembled each day during the shooting, regarded as an impossibility heretofore, RKO-Radio this week completed the Norman Taurog absurdity, "Hold 'Em Jail," with Wheeler and Woolsey, and is now awaiting the opinion of the preview audience to see whether it will be possible thus to save weeks of time and several thousand dollars on each picture.
ANNANDALE, N.Y., May 21 -- The Upsala baseball team defeated the St. Stephen's nine, 6 -- 2, today.

THE school of political pamphleteers writing anonymously or under a convenient sobriquet has recently been joined by an irreverent, quick-witted, occasionally shrewd, and frequently amusing observer of affairs in Washington who uses the name Jay Franklin.

HUDSON, N.Y., May 21 -- The three-day blossom festival for the residents of the Hudson Valley came to an end today. It finished with a parade of floats through the flag-decked streets of Hudson and a beauty show in a lot on the outskirts of town where the festivities have been held.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21 -- Colgate's track team took all three places in the javelin throw, the final event of a dual meet with Syracuse today and defeated the Orange squad, 65 -- 61.

Control over $18,000,000,000 of banking and industrial resources, enough to pay off the entire public debt of the United States Government, is vested in the hands of the twelve men who were called in last Friday by Governor George L. Harrison of the Federal Reserve Bank to form a committee to help make effective the credit expansion program of the Reserve System.

HORTA, Azores, May 21 -- The flying boat Do-X arrived off this harbor at 10:55 P.M. tonight [8:55 P. M. New York Daylight Time] after having been forced to land on the sea six and two-thirds miles out because of a shortage of fuel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: IT seems to me that your music editor is rendering a decided disservice to the musical people of this city by his efforts to whitewash the management of the Metropoiltan Opera Company. It is this attitude of mutual admiration society which has brought the Metropolitan to its present precipitous condition.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- City College of New York, gaining an early lead, defeated Drexel Institute today, 7 to 6.

AFTER the many gangster pictures and those lachrymose effusions in which either a mother is deprived of her child for two decades or a youngster with a leg in a steel brace awaits the operation by a famous foreign surgeon, it is a joyous relief to witness the German-made English version of "Congress Dances," which is now sojourning at the Rivoli.

The nation's bankers are more hysterical over the depression than the unemployed themselves, Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, told members of the Women's Trade Union League yesterday at a conference of the league at 247 Lexington Avenue.

WHAT should creep up now in the pre-1932-33 season schedules but a project to present Irene Bordoni and Leon Errol in a musical version of "The Command to Love." The notion is the property of Dwight Deere Wiman and John Tuerk, both of whom were associated with William A. Brady Jr. in presenting the Lothar-Gottwald play five years or so ago.

ABOVE the mammoth Fairfield Air Depot near Dayton, Ohio, says the Air Corps news letter, one day last month, the air was rough and treacherous. The air was biting cold, and raw ether straight from the frozen wastes of the North stabbed down over the Miami River.

Cardinal Hayes ordained nineteen young men as priests yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony began at 8 o'clock and continued almost three hours. The cathedral was filled with relatives and friends of the candidates, all of whom have just finished the course in St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y.

BERLIN THE Ralph Beaver Strassburger Foundation has this year awarded to Walther Reinhardt, German Consul at Seattle, its prize for the book best calculated to further friendly relations between America and Germany.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., May 21 -- The Rev. D. Wesley Soper, 21 years old, pastor of the Elmsford Dutch Reformed Church, resigned today and left town for an unannounced destination, leaving with a newspaper a prepared statement giving as the reason for his action that he wished to be free.

ONE of a series of out-of-door entertainments planned for the late Spring and early Summer in behalf of the New York Women's League for Animals will be the garden party on Thursday afternoon at Three Oaks, the home of Mrs. H. Van Rensselaer Kennedy in Hempstead, L.I.

Six senior records were broken as Poly Prep of Brooklyn annexed the team trophy for the fourteenth time at the fifteenth annual track and field games of the Private Schools A. A. at Baker Field yesterday. The winners recorded a total of 35 points. St John's High was second with 29 points and Horace Mann third with 17 points.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 21 -- Governor Roosevelt is watching with close interest, it was learned today, the developments in the Hofstadter committee revelations concerning Mayor Walker.

Mayor Walker has, it is announced, accepted an invitation to serve at the head of an imposing staff of auctioneers for the sale of contemporary American paintings and prints, which will be staged as the finale of the popular "Theatre in Art" exhibition at the Sidney Ross Gallery, 22 East Fifty-fifth Street.

MEDIA, Pa., May 21 -- Sid Hirst rode his own horse, Jack Point, to victory in the Gloucestor Fox Hunters Plate, at the final day of the Spring meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt Club, held over its course, near here, today. The race, a steeplechase, was at three and a half miles over hunting country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a citizen of this glorious country, where the gangster and the political grafter reign supreme, I wish to exercise my right of free speech and self-expression, about which we hear so much today, to present a college woman's reaction to what she sees daily.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 21 -- Fordham broke Army's winning streak in a well-played game of baseball today, defeating the cadets by a score of 4 to 2. Five thousand spectators crowded the stands and stretched along the foul lines to witness the game.

LOS ANGELES, May 21 -- A moving image was flashed by television upon a screen in an airplane in flight today when a Western Air Express transport plane, 3,000 feet above United Airport, received a motion picture transmitted from the Columbia-Don Lee radio station KHJ onto an eight-inch screen before experimenting engineers and other observers.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, with prices slightly lower than on Friday under a little Southern seling and liquidation promoted by favorable weather in the South and the usual week-end considerations. Offerings were absorbed by trade buying and covering, and after showing net losses of 7 to 8 points on the more active positions, prices rallied slightly in sympathy with the steadier tone of the late stock market.

PANAMA, R.P., May 18 -- The cardinal point in the platform of Dr. Harmodio Arias, Doctrinal Liberal candidate for the Presidency of Panama, is to take away from the Chief Executive the autocratic power that has resulted in the country being ruled by a small clique of politicians, he explained in an interview in which he also emphasized the need for fiscal reform and for maintaining the service on the foreign debt.

BERLIN, May 7, 1932 THE Berlin Philharmonic closed with a resounding birthday party. Fifty years have rolled by (not such an impressive span when one thinks, for instance, of the New York Philharmonic) since the orchestra grew out of the fifty-man aggregation fathered by Benjaman Bilse, and the fact was celebrated with music and more or less appropriate talk.

BERLIN, May 20 -- The outlook for the Lausanne conference on reparations, as it is now shaping up, provokes only a modest measure of optimism in German official, political and financial quarters, despite the critical importance attached to that meeting by Chancellor Bruening in his recent impassioned plea before the Reichstag.

LIVERPOOL, May 10 -- Preparatory work on Liverpool's new Catholic cathedral is being pushed so rapidly that within a year it should be possible to lay the cornerstone of what will be the second largest church building in the world.

The week or two stretching just ahead of the teams of the colleges will see the gradual ending of another year of college sport. The climax of the baseball season is looming ahead and the other sports are tapering off.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. J. Smith Jr., in his letter concerning operatic salaries, has issued many statements which invite response. Although Mr. Smith "does not inveigh against Mr. Gigli personally," he has somehow managed to leave the impression that that excellent tenor is the answer to what is wrong with the Metropolitan Opera Company.

PASTEURIZATION of milk and the increasing knowledge of parents about such things as sun baths, raw vegetables, cod liver oil and vitamins are cited by health authorities as contributing factors to the impressive drop in infant mortality in New York City.

In considering the possible evils of child labor it is important to remember that the children who leave school for the factory at 14 or 15 years, if the law allows, are in the great majority the children of poor families, and that means that they have more than their share of physical handicaps.

Critics who have listened with cynical ears to California's claims of bigger, better and more enlightened school system must bow their humbled heads. Rated on five factors related to efficiency by the National Education Association, California alone of all the States in the Union ranks on every count consistently in the upper sixth.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -- Authorities moved today to correct a typographical error which caused George Maas, alias Jacob Cedar, to be sent to prison for life in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The Athletics ran their winning streak to six straight and swept the four-game series with the Boston Red Sox by taking both ends of today's doubleheader. The Mackmen won the first game, 18 to 6, and the second, 6 to 3. Jimmy Foxx hit his twelfth and thirteenth homers.

A nation-wide survey, which, took one of its representatives into nearly all the large cities of the United States, was recently completed by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of -- America. The purpose was to discuss directly with editors and publishers the newspaper treatment of aviation accidents.

Senior Week at Barnard College will open next Friday with the traditional step-singing of the four classes on the quadrangle before Milbank Hall, followed by the annual Senior Show, an 1850 comedy entitled, ''Fashion, or Life in New York," in the Brinckerhoff Theatre, Broadway and 120th Street, at 8:30 P.M.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 -- Adoption of Governor Meier's five-point program for further reduction in governmental costs and redistribution of the tax burden by the Oregon Taxpayers' Equalization and Conservation League, and the reopening of the Hibernia Bank as result, of cooperation of the depositors were two events that have taken centre stage in interest in the State in spite of the primary election campaigns.

OMAHA, May 21 -- The "Smith-or-Hoover" Democratic Club, formed in Omaha several weeks ago with the object of bringing together Democrats who if they are not given a chance to vote for former Governor Smith, intend to support President Hoover in the election this Fall, is attracting attention all over the country.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 21 -- The Bronxville Riding Club held a horse show today for the benefit of Lawrence Hospital. The show was followed by a dinner and hunt ball at the Siwanoy Country Club here. The reception committee for the show included Frederick A. Schaff, Theodore Kiendl, Ernest Quantrell and Robcliff V. Jones.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- Harvard's track team downed Yale by 89 1/4 to 45 3/4 in the annual dual meet today. It was the worst defeat the Elis ever have suffered on the track at the hands of the Crimson.

Sonny, a new schooner built for Albert D. Phelps of Riverdale, slid down the ways at Robert Jacob's shipyard on City Island yesterday, thereby putting afloat another entrant in the ocean race to Bermuda, which will start off Montauk Point on June 25.

ISTANBUL, May 19 -- At the second Balkan conference held in the Yildiz Kiosk last October it was decided to hold a conference of the three tobacco-producing countries -- Bulgaria, Turkey and Greece. The conference began its meeting here on Tuesday, attended by delegates representing producers, traders, cigarette manufacturers, chambers of commerce, marketing organizations, such as the Turkish Tobacco Regie.

The pendulum of interest in women's golf will swing back to this country this week. Yesterday the international matches focused attention on England and in another week the same situation will prevail as the American stars will be competing in the women's British championship.

ALTHOUGH vitamins are not the discovery of any one man, there can be no doubt that it was Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins of Cambridge, England, president of the Royal Society and Nobel prize winner, who drove home to physicians the importance of the few that were known twenty year ago and stimulated research in a branch of chemistry which is revealing more and more about the nature of life.

SEVERAL novel features have been worked into the plans for the Starlight Supper Dance which will take place on June 14 to mark the formal opening for the Summer season of the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The net proceeds of the event will aid the work of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, which for seventy-eight years has served the congested area of the city in the lower east side.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- A goal by Captain Nelson Cochrane, with only two minutes to play remaining in the overtime period, gave Harvard a 5-to-4 lacrosse victory over Yale on the Harvard Business School Field today. Although Yale's passing attack was superior to Harvard's, the Crimson's defense was much stronger.

Clergymen of different communions will today comment in their sermons on the Encyclical of Pope Pius XI setting apart an octave of prayer beginning with the Feast of the Sacred Heart, June 3, to petition for the passing of the period of world depression.

THIS volume with the double title from the pen of the late Arnold Bennett consists of a story of about novelette length and a novel, about half completed, on which the author was engaged at the time of his death. Both pieces centre about the theatre Bennett enjoyed so much, the world of which he knew so well.
LONDON SIXTEEN years ago, when Theodore Dreiser wrote "A Hoosier Holiday," he was so little known in England that no London publisher thought it worth while to secure it for his own catalogue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- Yale's lightweight varsity crew clinched the collegiate rowing championship for 150-pounders on the Charles River today, defeating both Princeton and Harvard in the annual Goldthwaite Cup regatta, rowed on the Charles for the fist time in seven years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The capitalistic world is blindly groping for increased buying power to lift it out of this depression. Each country, not finding it at home, looks for it abroad. Much time and effort are wasted in this vain search, in putting up and in attempting to pull down the tariff barriers that each nation may reserve its own market but open up all others.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21 -- The Rutgers lacrosse team scored its sixth victory in eight starts and closed its season by defeating Union, 9 to 1, at Neilson Field today.

IN spite of financial retrenchment on all sides, the dance season which is now closing shows a substantial increase in activity over all previous seasons. As is the annual custom in these columns, there follow lists of performances in various categories, and from them many useful deductions may be drawn.
BARD, Cal., May 21 -- Government entomologists have high hopes of producing rubber in appreciable quantities from the milkweed that grows wild in the desert wastes of Southern California and Arizona.
Secretary of State Stimson, returning from his trip to Geneva, has it announced that he did not discuss war debts find reparations with the Old World statesmen.

LONDON WHENEVER triplets are born in any part of Great Britain -- thus entitling the mother to the "royal bounty" of $25 -- and whenever a great disaster occurs in this country or abroad, King George's message of congratulation or condolence is drafted by Colonel Sir Clive Wigram.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Colonel Thomas E. Murphy of this city, retired lawyer, capitalist and part owner of the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club, died of heart disease today at Isleridge, his Florida estate near West Palm Beach. He was in his seventy-fifth year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following is a proposed substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment:
ANDOVER, Mass., May 21 -- Andover's baseball team scored five runs in the fifth and defeated the Governor Dummer Academy nine, 6 to 1, today. Reiter allowed only five hits.

IN vain does M. de Comminges: provide his Laura not only with a garden and a diary about it but also with a husband and children to call her "mamma" and servants to address her as "Madame" and much feminine paraphernalia of clothes and thoughts and emotions!

BUENAVENTURA, May 13 -- Communism with all its ugly features has invaded the lovely Cauca Valley of Colombia, the beauties of which have been immortalized in thirty-one languages through translations of Jorge Isaacs's "Maria," which year after year continues to run second only to "Don Quixote" as the best seller in the Spanish language.
BALTIMORE, May 21 -- Launching a fast attack in the first half. Johns Hopkins defeated Maryland at lacrosse, 7 to 3, at the Stadium before a crowd of 8,000 today.

Alfalfa Bill Murray, Governor of Oklahoma, having surveyed in the last few months political and economic conditions outside of his native State, arrived in the city last night in a doleful mood. Things are going to get worse before they get better, he declared, and nearly everybody except himself has a chance for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

DURING the past fortnight the second company of "Mourning Becomes Electra" has been visible at the Alvin Theatre. Those of us "who had been introduced to Mr. O'Neill's long, mordant drama by the inspired first company had thus an opportunity to contemplate it through the medium of a relatively pedestrian troupe.

LONDON, May 21 -- The stock market was quiet today, with little business. British Government funds were lower because of profit-taking. Among the industrials, Swedish Match B and Kreuger Toll were down following the latest company announcement.

THE panoramic backgrounds devised for the csreen adaptation of "Strange Interlude" offer a striking contrast to the more restricted settings designed for the original stage presentation of Eugene O'Neill's nine-act play. "Whereas the six different sets in the Theatre Guild production of the play with two exceptions represented livingroom or library interiors, a substantial amount of the action of the screen, play takes place outdoors.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 21 (AP). -- An application for the appointment of a receiver for the Republic Gas Corporation of Chicago was filed in Chancery Court today by Doris L. Charing of New York, a bondholder.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Crop reports from the Winter wheat belt are becoming more bullish daily, and while dealers on the Board of Trade were disposed to go slowly today, outside support and professional buying developed sufficiently to carry prices up more than a cent from yesterday's finish.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps the most impressive political cartoon ever published was that which appeared in Punch, with the title "Dropping the Pilot," when the Kaiser dismissed his great Chancellor, Bismarck. It was indeed a tragic error.

IN the lower east side of New York we encounter in its most acute form a problem which is the inevitable result of modern city growth as found in American municipalities -- social and economic instability and obsolescence on such a large scale as to threaten the soundness and stability of the whole municipal structure.

ST. PAUL, May 19 -- Much sentiment has been expended on the little red schoolhouse from time to time, but it is being subordinated in these tax-oppressed times, so far as Minnesota is concerned, to stern realism. About twelve years ago, thanks to a combination of agricultural depression and high local taxation, the idea began to assert itself that the little red schoolhouse was not an inevitable institution.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- By buying and selling the stock of their own company, Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., in 1930, the three Warner brothers realized a profit of $9,251,454.50, according to testimony presented today before the Senate Banking Committee in its investigation of transactions on the New York Stock Exchange.

MR. HUME'S love of nature seems to have been carefully lifted to an imaginative plane; he writes like one who, having seen and loved the woods, feels himself obliged irrationally to rationalize his love into a worship of Pan and of all the strange flitting creatures who from time immemorial have inhabited the wild places.
CULMORE, Northern Ireland, May 21 (AP) -- Amelia Earhart Putnam described her husband, George Palmer Putnam, New York publisher, as a "good sport" today for having let her fly the Atlantic alone.

COREY FORD'S latest book is not appreciably different, in spirit or in effect, from his others. It invades the literary scene at several weakly guarded points and has a merry go, with firecrackers, popguns and slingshots, at the people present.
Police Commissioner Mulrooney, who took office on May 21, 1930, celebrated his second anniversary as commissioner yesterday with but few flowers and without fanfare or formality.

ROME, May 20 -- The assassination of President Doumer of France again has focused the attention of Italian public opinion on the treatment that the neighboring republic metes out to political refugees. This subject is of great interest in Italy because rightly or wrongly Paris is considered to have headed the anti-Fascist intrigue conducted mostly by Italians but financed by sources which hitherto have remained somewhat mysterious.

THE Summer season on Long Island this year will be augmented by many festivities now being planned by exclusive beach clubs which have in recent seasons added to the recreation of North and South Shore colonists. The coming season at these clubs promises to be unusually busy.

STOCKHOLM. AFTER a lifetime of interest in clockmaking as a hobby, a Swedish engineer in the village of Bofors has completed what looks like an ordinary grandfather clock, but in reality is an extremely versatile grandfather capable of telling a variety of times and performing automatically a variety of tasks.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 -- Andy Cohen's daring base running and a thrilling slide in scoring from second on a scratch hit by George Selkirk gave the Bears a 2-to-1 victory over the Keys in an exciting eleven-inning game today.
CINCINNATI, May 21 (AP) -- Mrs. John Endres, embraced her youngest son and wept when told today of the death of her eldest boy, Captain George Endres.

THIS is more than a book about Adolf Hitler and present-day Germany. It is an illuminating exposition of a cross section of our unbalanced contemporary civilization as it appears in a country suffering perhaps more than any other from the dislocations of the post-war era.

NORWICH, England. TWELVE homing pigeons were taken the other day in a basket from Norwich to a large field seventy miles away. At the same time Squadron Leader Rea, chief test pilot of a Norwich firm of aircraft constructors, was driven in a car with the blinds drawn to the field, where his "Avian" light airplane awaited him.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 -- Winning decisively, Delhanover, 3-year-old Sandy Flash colt owned by Wilbur D. Blood of Rutherford and driven by Walter Garrison of Bridgetown, romped off with the outstanding event of the opening matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey today.

When Robinson Crusoe was cast upon a desert isle he began seriously to consider his condition. This led him to draw up the state of his affairs in writing, "not so much to leave them to any that "may come after me as to deliver my "thoughts from daily poring over them "and afflicting my mind."

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Faced with the possibility that the "stop Roosevelt" movement may deadlock the Democratic National Convention, party leaders in the Middle West are turning their attention to second choice Presidential candidates and the field of dark horses.

Representatives of more than thirty peace organizations and societies numbering about 3,000 men, women and children joined yesterday afternoon in an anti-war demonstration, with a parade from Washington Square through midtown streets to Columbus Circle, where a mass meeting was held and speakers urged concerted effort to establish world peace.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Equipoise captured the thirty-ninth running of the famous Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday before a crowd estimated at 20,000 and established himself as just about the best horse in the handicap division.

Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL'S speech, in the House of Commons the other day, jeering the Liberal members of the Government, the "four satellites of Jupiter" whose simultaneous disappearance the House would be sorry to see, and more particularly devoted to Sir HERBERT SAMUEL, was excellent fooling.

PARIS. PARIS insists upon our being chic even in those hours of relaxation which enable the busy butterfly to get through the social season and still retain a minimum of poise and good looks. But whether one lounges in pajamas or a gown is a matter of preference.

JOHN M. MOREHEAD, United States Minister to Sweden, testified recently before the Senate Committee on Manufacturers regarding the Bratt system of liquor control, in operation in the country to which he is assigned. He prefaced his statement before the Blaine committee with a general review of the prohibition situation in this country as he sees it.

GENEVA, May 21 -- With one small indication of progress, the Council of the League of Nations once more postponed today action on the urgent recommendation of the financial committee for a stop-gap loan to Austria, despite the fact that it was backed by a warning from the Austrian Government that bankruptcy was imminent unless it was obtained.

MOSCOW A BOUT half of the pictures being shown in Moscow at the moment are old products of the American and German studios. The most important of the native Russian product is a talking picture of Dostoievski's early novel, "The House of the Dead," which had a recent Moscow premiere and is enjoying a popular success.

BERLIN, May 21 -- The Boerse today was irregular and generally weaker and nervous under rumors of unfavorable international developments. Since the Boerse is the only principal stock exchange on the Continent transacting business on Saturdays, leaders in financial circles advocate following the example of the others and thus prevent possible scares.

Municipal and foreign bond calls predominated in a small list of new redemptions announced last week for May and future months. They increased the total for this month to $15,904,00, which compared with $15,427,250 in April and $102,739,000 in May, 1931, for corresponding weeks.
LONDON, May 21 -- All England thrilled today at the news of Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam s solitary flight.

IF the romance in this tale of politics and intrigue, of the love of a powerful dictator for a modern young Princess, seems rather thin stuff beside "The Prisoner of Zenda," or even "Graustark," that is only to say that this story belongs to our times, when romance itself, of the old order, seems a bit thin and when the gloss has been pretty well rubbed off the trappings of royalty.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Wet leaders who had looked upon Senator James J. Davis's overwhelming victory over Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler in the Pennsylvania Republican Senatorial primary as a mandate for prohibition repeal are perturbed by what they term the "pussyfooting" tactics of the party heads as demonstrated at last Saturday's caucus of the Pennsylvania delegation to the national convention.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 -- An all-day police search today failed to yield any clues to two armed men who beat Dr. Royal Phinney, wealthy retired New Haven physician, into unconsciousness on the Derby Turnpike in Orange late last night, robbed him and then drove away in his automobile with his companion, a girl about 22 years old, whom he described as Miss Agnes O'Neil.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- Harvard's varsity tennis team after dropping the first trio of singles' matches showed surprising strength in the remaining seven singles to rout Yale, 11-4, today for the seventh victory in eight matches this season, and their fifth successive triumph over Yale.

THE late May weddings, while not so numerous as those earlier in the month, are notable ones, uniting members of old families that have figured prominently in the history of this country. The marriage of Miss Corinne Roosevelt Alsop to Percy Chubb 2d, which takes place on Saturday afternoon, is of more than usual interest.

The search for Information about the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby is now centring in Maryland, where the day before the baby was found dead a New Jersey bootlegger gave a circumstantial account of how the baby had been taken, said that it had been killed and decared that its body was within five miles of the Lindbergh home.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Sonny Martens's two-bagger, which drove in Captain Bill Graupner with none out in the eleventh gave Penn a 9-to-8 victory over Princeton on Franklin Field today in the straw hat and alumni game.

DETROIT HENRY FORD sat talking in the last of a row of glasswalled rooms in the long low building in West Dearborn which houses his engineering laboratories. He sits little in offices and when he does it is likely to be in any one's but his own.
LONG BEACH, L.I., May 21 -- Vincent Richards, former American Davis Cup ace, went down in defeat at the hands of Karel Kozeluh of Czechoslovakia today on the courts of the Lido Country Club.

PARIS, May 20 -- Blase Parisians are welcoming with genuine enthusiasm something quite new in the way of entertainment, now being offered to them by a hustling young American promoter of sporting events. It is billed as "The Great Indoor African Lion Hunt," and 100 real lions are star performers in its highly original plot.

Improvement in industry and the restoration of profits to manufacturing companies hinge on the deflation of fixed overhead charges to a point where products can be sold on a profitable basis at the present sharply reduced volume of sales, according to opinions expressed here yesterday in industrial and accounting circles.

The United Stores Realty Corporation, one of the three principal subsidiaries of the United Cigar Stores Company of America, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court, listing assets of $1,543,625 and liabilities of $8,116,589. Of the latter sum $7,900,000, according to the petition, is owed to the parent company for advances made from time to time.

THE following article by K. Korchmarev appeared in V.O. K.S., the magazine published by the society of the Soviet Union for cultural relations with foreign countries, and bearing consequently the official fiat of the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 21 -- Taking two places in the broad jump, the deciding event on the card, Lehigh vanquished Lafayette, 64 -- 62, today to keep its season's record for dual meets unmarred.

GARDEN visits at some of the most beautiful country estates in the vicinity of the metropolis are continuing as popular diversions and as a means of raising funds for philanthropic purposes. Hundreds of persons are visiting the various estates on Long Island and in Westchester that are being opened to the public.

Miss Alice C. Smith, probation officer in charge of probation work in the Manhattan Women's Court, will be guest of honor Tuesday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock at a reception which Mrs. Mortimer M. Menken, prominent welfare worker, will give in her home, 253 West Seventy-second Street, in celebration of Miss Smith's thirty years as a probation officer in the magistrates' courts.

AT the moment when the story opens a jury of seven men and five women is endeavoring to decide on a verdict in the case of a woman accused of murdering her bootlegger lover. Ten members of the jury are for conviction, two for acquittal.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell to the lowest ebb since Aug. 8, last year. With the exception of that day, the 302,470 shares dealt in yesterday were the fewest of any day since Sept. 13, 1924. Despite the small volume of trading, prices were moderately firm and closing quotations were, on the average, fractionally better than on Friday.

KEARNY, N.J., May 21 -- Barringer High School of Newark and Westfield High School set new records in the annual championship relay meet of the New Jersey State Interscholastic A.A., held in the Kearny High School stadium today.

An official American league of Mayors and local authorities to cooperate with and form part of the organization already established known as the International Union of Local Authorities would do much to improve municipal government, would educate the citizens to avoid war, and would advance the progress of civilization, Dr. P.A. Wickmann of Berlin, representative of the International Union said yesterday.

TEN years ago today this radio page appeared for the first time. Since May, 1922, many watts have gone over the ether. Millions of spoken words and musical notes have been electrified and radioed through space. Today there are about 16,000,000 receiving sets in the United States, compared with approximately 100,000 in 1922.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Open market operations of the Federal Reserve Banks, which between April 6 and May 18 increased their holdings of government securities from $885,014,000 to $1,466,403,000, an increase of $581,389,000, have been carried on chiefly in the New York Federal Reserve district.

BERLIN, May 21 -- The denial by Tass, official Soviet news agency, of the report that four classes of reserves had been called by the Soviet Government to take part in the forthcoming Red Army manoeuvres was countered by the Berlin Socialist newspaper Vowarts with a circumstantial reiteration based on the assertion that its radio specialist had listened in on a Moscow broadcast.
EASTON, Pa., May 21 -- A Lafayette College centennial celebration crowd of 7,000 saw the maroon baseball team swamp Rutgers, 22 -- 10, today.

To the Dramatic Editor: I wish to offer two concrete suggestions which, if adopted, would, I think, improve the financial situation of the New York theatres. I am one of those play-lovers who are pleased with even a moderately good play, especially when it is well acted, and I can't say there is a dearth of good material.

HARPER'S FERRY, W. Va., May 21 -- The ideals of John Brown are being carried forward by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared Dr. J. Max Barber of Philadelphia, head of the John Brown Memorial Association, in an address today dedicating a memorial bronze tablet to John Brown's memory on the campus of Storer College.

Charging a conspiracy to strip the Fox Theatres Corporation of its assets, for the benefit chiefly of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., Jacob L. Rubenstein has brought suit in Supreme Court against the two companies, asking for a determination of the losses to the Fox Theatres Corporation and the appointment of a receiver for that company, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- T. Bedell Jr. won a registered shoot of the American Trapshooting Association over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He triumphed by breaking 96 out of a possible 100 targets. The High Handicap Cup was annexed by J.D. Prince in a shoot-off against seven other gunners.

A DRAMATIZED version of Mendelssohn's oratorio "Elijah" was performed in Southampton, England, several weeks ago. T.C. Fairbairn, who had done the same thing for "Hiawatha." made this attempt, and the reports in the London press indicate that the transformation was successful.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I disagree with THE TIMES editorial, "Shadow and Substance." It treats of the proposed removal by the Dail Eireann of the oath of allegiance. An editorial on this subject would be, I think, more appropriately headed "Soul and Substance," although in this material age, I know, many believe that a nation does not need a soul.

A five-hour schedule, including stops, is to be established between New York and Chicago, as a part of a new coast-to-coast under twenty-four-hour service, this Fall. The first three planes for this new schedule on United Air Lines are approaching completion at the plant of the Boeing Airplane Company at Seattle, P.G. Johnson, president of the airplane company and the air transport system, announced yesterday.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 21 -- Lawrenceville's track team defeated the Hill School today, 70 -- 56. Levan of Lawrenceville was high scorer with nineteen points, while Connell of the losers was second, with fourteen.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21 -- Kenneth Kreusser, 20 years old, Pelham Manor High School student and athlete, died in the hospital here today from injuries received in two automobile accidents early this morning. He was the son of Walter J. Kreusser, an official of the American Specialty Supply Company of New York City, who lives at 1,305 Bolton Road, Pelham Manor.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, chairman of the fund-raising unit of the American Joint Distribution Committee, which is seeking to raise $2,500,000 to aid starving Jews in Eastern Europe and to preserve the agencies of relief and self-help established in former years, said yesterday on his return from some of the larger cities where campaigns are under way, that the Jews of the United States and Canada were responding generously to the appeal.

BERLIN, May 6 FOR years the Rotter brothers, the Shuberts of Berlin, have been bathing us in operetta tears. Since the enormous success of Lehar's "Friederike" they have set their managerial chips on lingering sadness.

BERLIN THE first film operettas were greeted by this writer with considerable enthusiasm. But it is hard to keep up that first fresh fervor when you are being positively bombarded with "Tonfilm" operettas.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 21 -- The administration of President Hoover was condemned as "a pitiable fiasco" and both the Republican and Democratic parties were characterized as having "failed lamentably" in the crisis now confronting the people of the United States in the keynote address delivered by Morris Hillquit of New York City, national chairman, at the opening of the national convention of the Socialist party here today.

George Palmer Putnam summarized his wife's preparations for the Atlantic flight and the transatlantic telephone conversation which he had with her at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in a broadcast delivered over the Columbia Broadcasting Company's WABC network at 4:45.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- Two new dual meet records were established today as the Princeton varsity track team maintained its undefeated dual meet record by downing Cornell in Palmer Stadium, 84 1/2 to 50 1/2.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Business activity remained for the most part unchanged in a majority of American markets abroad, according to the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.
SIX vitamins have been discovered and labeled. Probably there are at least three more. A list of the known vitamins, with their properties, follows:

In the City's Traffic. THE battle cry with which New York City greets visiting motorists remains: "They shall not pass." The driver who attempts to find his way through Brooklyn or the Bronx must still depend upon obscured street signs, vague directions from uncertain natives and the law of averages, according to which he should reach the open country at least once out of every ten or twenty tries.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 21 -- An undefeated Yale varsity crew heads for its traditional meeting with Harvard. The end came to its preliminary season early this evening with a victory over Cornell and Princeton in the Carnegie Cup regatta on Lake Cayuga.

MICHAIL Pavlovitch Miloff looks across the barracks full of sleeping comrades. Ivan, on the next bunk, is nothing but a mound under the clothes. Mischa in another bunk looks a good deal like a Pekingese one might see waddling down Fifth Avenue on the end of a leash, but Miloff has never seen a Pekingese, nor has he seen Fifth Avenue.
QUINCY, Mass., May 21 -- The new 10,000-ton cruiser Portland was launched at the Fore River Yards of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation here today.

LONDON, May 21 -- There has been a material slowing down in the movement of American industrial concerns to establish themselves behind the British tariff walls since this country's new customs laws went into effect.

PARIS, May 21 -- The possibility of a criminal act as the cause of the burning of the French motor ship Georges Philippar in the Arabian Sea was discussed in the Paris press tonight with the receipt by the Ministry of Merchant Marine of details of a report made by Captain Vicq, the lost vessel's commander.

The importance of child health to the future welfare of the nation, a subject emphasized by conditions growing out of the economic stress in the country, was brought to the attention of more than 1,900 school principals, teachers and representatives of welfare organizations yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria at a luncheon and conference planned as a follow-up of the White House conference on child health and protection.

Leading marketers in the metropolitan area of New York yesterday met the cut of 4 cents a gallon in the service station prices of gasoline that had been announced late on Friday by the Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc., a subsidiary of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation.

EXCEPT for the plight of the Athletics, the current campaign in the American League is running fairly true to advance notice. But the order of precedence in the National League is still badly scrambled.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 21 -- Boston College's track team today came through with flying colors to capture the New England intercollegiate championship in the forty-sixth annual two-day meeting which concluded at Brown Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Congress at this session has not paid much attention to what its elected leaders and the President have requested, demanded or pleaded for. But this week the leaders and the President effectively served notice that Congress should not recess to the national conventions, as had been proposed in the Senate, without completing its budget-balancin; program and passing unemployment relief before the beginning of the next fiscal year,which is July 1.
EASTON, Pa., May 21 -- The centennial celebration of Lafayette College ended today with alumni reunions of sixty classes in unbroken succession from the oldest living class of 1872.
ATHENS, May 21 (AP). -- Premier Eleutherios Venizelos resigned today because of difficulty in getting Parliment to pass legislation he sponsored.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, Howard C. Miller declares that "it is a grievous wrong to compel the debtor class to discharge debts with dollars worth 150 cents each when the contract called for dollars worth 100 cents."

MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- As a further spur to the workers on the collective and private farms to engage in private trade and thus increase food supplies in the city and stimulate farm production, the Soviet Government decreed today the abolition of all State and local taxes which heretofore have been assessed against these groups if they sold their produce outside of State contracts.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21 -- Tommy Tailer, Princeton sophomore, today joined the illustrious group of men who have their names inscribed on the roll of winners of the famous Garden City Golf Club Cup when he defeated Jimmy Robbins, Merion Cricket Club star, 1 up, in the final round of the club's twenty-sixth invitation tournament.

LONDON, May 14 -- Responsibility for the extraordinary fall in prices in the last two and a half years and for the present crisis produced by that fall was placed squarely upon the central banks of the world by Professor Gurtav Cassel in the second Rhodes lecture delivered by him today at Oxford.

The radio-active clock has superseded today the older methods of measuring the earth's age by land erosion, the study of fossilized remains and the process of measurement by star orbit changes. Although these older formulas still contribute valuable aids to the new science, it is now seen that they are seriously defective for use for anything more than general approximations of the truth.

Three records were broken, two defending individual champions retained their titles and New Utrecht, perennial team champion, captured the laurels for the ninth straight year in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school track and field championships, held before a capacity crowd of more than 4,000 at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

Columbia University disbursed $487,000 to students in loans, fellowships and scholarships during the academic year 1931-32, according to figures made public yesterday. The sum was the largest ever expended by the university for these purposes. Loans totaled $140,000.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- William Guggenheim, New York capitalist, addressing fellow-members of the University of Pennsylvania's class of 1889 at a reunion today, called upon American political factions to compose their differences and cooperate toward re-establishing political security abroad and meeting responsibilities at home, to the end that liquid capital may be put back to work and "thrift and industry may again abound."

Representatives of Public School 34 of the Bronx and Public School 89 of Manhattan captured team championships in the annual city P. S.A.L. elementary school outdoor track and field title meet yesterday morning at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

REVISITING the opening exhibition in the new home of the Museum of Modern Art, one discovers that the murals have been to some extent rearranged, greatly to their advantage. At first there was a disconcerting melee of photo-murals and painted panels in the galleries on the ground floor.

Swooping suddenly out of the northwest just after 6 o'clock last night, a freak thunderstorm lashed parts of the city with the fury of a cloudburst, barely touched others, indirectly caused two deaths and three injuries in a Bronx automobile accident, flooded a myriad of cellars and streets and tied up traffic in all parts of the city.

REVISITING the opening exhibition in the new home of the Museum of Modern Art, one discovers that the murals have been to some extent rearranged, greatly to their advantage. At first there was a disconcerting melee of photo-murals and painted panels in the galleries on the ground floor.

Swooping suddenly out of the northwest just after 6 o'clock last night, a freak thunderstorm lashed parts of the city with the fury of a cloudburst, barely touched others, indirectly caused two deaths and three injuries in a Bronx automobile accident, flooded a myriad of cellars and streets and tied up traffic in all parts of the city.

WHEN the new French Parliament meets next week its dominant political party will be composed of Socialist-Radicals, a group, it has been said, that is neither Socialist nor radical, but liberal. Similarly, it might be said that the Popular Democrats are neither popular nor democrats, but rather more unpopular than they were in the previous elections and certainly more republican then democratic.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Londonderry, where Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam landed today, has long been immortalized by a song, the "Londonderry Air," and by centuries of Irish lore and legend, according to the National Geographic Society.

BERLIN, May 12 -- Finland took third place among all the nations competing at the last Olympic Games at Amsterdam in 1928, carrying home eight gold, eight silver and eight bronze medals. In the track and field events Finland finished second behind the United States despite the fact that its relatively small team was unable to participate in all of the events.

HEREIN, the jacket promises, a "famous sculptor interprets his great controversial works and discusses art and artists." Do not, however, open this book with oversanguine hope that the Epstein riddle is about to be solved.

CONFRONTED by this department's bureau on Other People's Business, Frank C. Dae, the police commissioner among the turbulent events of "Merry-Go-Roudn," consented the other day to sit down and talk off a page from the life of an actor.

IT is just five years yesterday since a silver-winged monoplane, its pilot thrusting his head through one of the side ports of the blindest cockpit ever built, settled down for a night landing at Le Bourget. In that thirty-two-hour flight from New York Charles A. Lindbergh established a new distance record for airplanes and a solo distance record which has never been approached.

There may be a change from Montauk, L.I., as the place for holding the Gold Cup motorboat race, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles F. Chapman, secretary of the racing commission of the American Power Boat Association. Philadelphia may get the event on Aug. 13 for the Delaware River.

SEEKING to attack the accident problem as a whole, rather than to scatter safety efforts in separate drives, the National Safety Council of Chicago has made an analysis of motor vehicle casualties and on the basis of this analysis, has prepared what it terms "a balanced program for reduction of traffic accidents."

THESE further essays in Catholic journalism may be rejected by traditionalists as "modern," "liberal" and heretical. They are all that, but being also realistic and intelligent they have a right to be read by believers and unbelievers alike.

The pledging of eighty-one students by seventeen City College fraternities was announced yesterday, following the expiration of the semiannual non-pledge period, during which by agreement all Greek letter societies refrain from extending invitations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- Before the march of economy and retrenchment that has marked the thirty-first quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this city, four of the eight regional editions of The Christian Advocate, the national weekly circulated as the official organ of the church, went down to defeat today after a bitter fight.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 21 -- Coming from behind in the ninth frame to score three runs, Holy Cross defeated Harvard today in an exciting baseball game, 5 to 4.

ROME, MAY 21 -- A fatal accident in which two Hungarian aviators, one of whom had made flying history were killed, marred at the outset the convention of transoceanic fliers which is scheduled to be opened here tomorrow by Premier Mussolini.

Canvas-spreading on the large Summer scale will be started this afternoon by the Larchmont Yacht Club with the first of its special races. Then on Saturday the championship series of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound will begin with the opening regatta of the American Yacht Club of Rye.

MEXICO CITY. MEXICO'S literature has changed radically in the last decade and its evolution from a revolutionary futurism to an evenly balanced conservatism, if not classicism, presents an interesting spectacle.

THE victor of the recent parliamentary contest in France is Edpuard Herriot. His Radical Socialist party is not only the largest in the Chamber of Deputies, with more than 160 members at his command, but also it has shown the largest increase.

The Port of New York Authority expresses the opinion in its current bulletin that the Federal Government invested wisely during the last thirty years when it spent $1,048,693 in improving Newtown Creek. The tidal arm of the East River opposite Thirty-fourth Street, which serves as a dividing line between Brooklyn and Queens, carried 5,581,615 tons of freight during 1930.

The first preliminary report of the committee on community dental service of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association was made public yesterday. The report reviews the committee's activities during the last year, the first of its existence, in which it began a campaign in preventive dentistry among children of the city.

LONDON, May 21 -- The best thing for the world at this juncture, in the opinion of J.L. Garvin, writing for tomorrow's Sunday Observer, would be for President Hoover to "summon a compact conference of the larger powers for a preliminary discussion of war debts, armaments, gold and silver."

To the Editor of The New York Times: An ancient remedy is hereby suggested which inevitably will cure the ills of the country. Let the various governmental bodies of the United States appropriate such sums as are necessary to finance a "return to the land" movement.

THERE have been a number of suggestions of late to cut down the postoffice deficit. Of interest in connection with the air mail is one made by A.L. Rushton of Omaha in a letter to Aviation printed and favorably commented on in the current issue of that publication.

BERLIN, May 21 -- With the elections for the German Presidency and the Parliaments of Prussia, Bavaria and Wuerttemberg ended and a period of two and a half years filled with plebiscites and elections, beginning with the vote on the Young Plan, closed, the way is free for a new order of things in the German Commonwealth if no unforeseen catastrophes occur.
TORONTO, May 21 (AP) -- After Art Smith pitched the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-0 victory over the Royals in the first game of today's doubleheader the Montreal team came back to win the second, 3-2.

Personally, I see no substitute for a good home with healthy family bonds. Every child has a right to belong to a small human group with different age levels represented, bound together with bonds of affection. This the family provides to an extent which no school can rival.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Miss Lucylle Goldsmith of Los Angeles, a 16-year-old high school girl, won the Ninth National Oratorical Contest tonight and thus became entitled to represent the United States in the Seventh International Contest to be held here in the Autumn.

The Salvation Army's funds now available for its emergency relief work will be exhausted on June 11, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and executive chairman of the United Appeal, who described the urgent situation that he felt required an immediate response in the campaign for $1,090,000 to continue Army activities in New York.

THE American Art Anderson Galleries have shut their doors for the season on what, it is to be hoped, was the Dark Age of bookselling. But for one notable and shining exception they have groped their way uncertainly through these sunless eight months and it must be with more than the ordinary sigh of relief that they welcome the Summer interlude.

Charges that government officials are carrying on a campaign for high protective tariffs and using confidential customs information, denied to others, to bolster their arguments were made here yesterday by Peter Fletcher, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders. Inc.

TORONTO, Ont., May 21 -- Production of gold in Ontario amounted to $3,813,989 in April, an increase of $274,426 over the corresponding month last year, but a decline of $33,646 from March, according to figures issued by the Ontario Department of Mines.

When four years ago Amelia Earhart sat huddled in the drafty cabin of an airplane behind a huge gas tank, flying to England as a passenger, she made a resolution. She decided then that some day when the weather was right, when she possessed the right kind of airplane and when she received a great deal more training, she would fly the ocean again and this time she would be skipper of the plane.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Miss Lucylle Goldsmith of Los Angeles, a 16-year-old high school girl, won the Ninth National Oratorical Contest tonight and thus became entitled to represent the United States in the Seventh International Contest to be held here in the Autumn.

The Salvation Army's funds now available for its emergency relief work will be exhausted on June 11, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and executive chairman of the United Appeal, who described the urgent situation that he felt required an immediate response in the campaign for $1,090,000 to continue Army activities in New York.

THE American Art Anderson Galleries have shut their doors for the season on what, it is to be hoped, was the Dark Age of bookselling. But for one notable and shining exception they have groped their way uncertainly through these sunless eight months and it must be with more than the ordinary sigh of relief that they welcome the Summer interlude.

ZAGREB, May 20 -- Although recent reports of a wide-spread revolutionary movement in Slovenia have proved exaggerated and that of an attack on King Alexander was absolutely unfounded, scarcely a week passes now without bringing trustworthy news of minor events that indicate that Premier Marinkovitch's Government and perhaps even the Karageorgevitch dynasty are riding for a fall in Yugoslavia.

EDUCATORS to be successful at the microphone must disregard many pedagogical practices which have been developed for decades, according to Levering Tyson, director of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education. Transferring a classroom lecture to the air has been found the least effective and most unsatisfactory procedure in educational broadcasting.

ITHACA, May 21 -- The senior class at Cornell University completed a successful class memorial campaign today, with 673 members of the class pledging annual gifts to the alumni funds equivalent to an endowment fund of $65,650. More than 80 per cent of the senior class subscribed.

With more than two thousand dogs on the benches, the sixth annual bench show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, to be held next Saturday at Madison, N.J., will break all records in the matter of entries for a one-day exhibition. Last year, when Harkness Edwards's great Dane Fionne v. Loheland was declared the best of 1,923 dogs shown, it was felt that the limit had been reached for an event of this kind.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 21 -- Miss Edith Gould Anderson, popular young equestrienne from Brooklyn, was the dominant figure in the third annual Bronxville Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Bronxville Riding Club today.

A COMPLAINT frequently voiced is to the effect that in the voluminous record lists one finds a plethora of overworked standard items and a formidable range of comparatively out-of-the-way compositions by minor musicians, whereas the rich and substantial field between the two remains, to all intents, untouched.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am wondering whether any of THE NEW YORK TIMES readers can help me to track down the orchestral score of the symphony, "A Night in the Tropics," written by Louis Moreau Gottschalk about the middle of the past century.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is something wrong in the system which, in the wanton destruction of the value of property, ruins the owner, who otherwise is efficient and industrious, and ruins not only his human happiness and that of his dependents, but his usefulness as a producing factor in society.

An 18-year-old youth and his 16-year-old companion were surprised last night by two plains-clothes men in the act Of holding up the drug store of Abraham Lesser at 987 Rutland Road, in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The older boy, who had a pistol in his hand, was knocked down by a blow from a pistol butt of one of the policemen.

Attempts to compare the gravity of the current depression with earlier crises usually take arithmetical form. The relative duration of the periods of decline and recovery; the fall in prices as measured in range and speed; the number of receiverships and bankruptcies; the extent of unemployment -- by such indexes we try to find out whether things today are worse or better than they were in 1893, in 1873, in 1857, in 1837.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 21 -- Erastus F. Post of Quogue has been elected president of the Riverhead Savings Bank to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Usher B. Howell of Riverhead. He has been a vice president of the bank since 1918 and a trustee since 1906, and has been acting as president since Mr. Howell died late in February.

Charges that government officials are carrying on a campaign for high protective tariffs and using confidential customs information, denied to others, to bolster their arguments were made here yesterday by Peter Fletcher, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders. Inc.

TORONTO, Ont., May 21 -- Production of gold in Ontario amounted to $3,813,989 in April, an increase of $274,426 over the corresponding month last year, but a decline of $33,646 from March, according to figures issued by the Ontario Department of Mines.

When four years ago Amelia Earhart sat huddled in the drafty cabin of an airplane behind a huge gas tank, flying to England as a passenger, she made a resolution. She decided then that some day when the weather was right, when she possessed the right kind of airplane and when she received a great deal more training, she would fly the ocean again and this time she would be skipper of the plane.

Thrown from a runaway horse, which had been frightened by a squirrel on a bridle path in the woods near Jamaica yesterday, Vicki Baum, author of "Grand Hotel," was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital suffering from possible concussion of the brain, a lacerated head and fractures of at least two ribs.

LONDONDERRY Northern Ireland, May 22 -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam looked fresh and rosy cheeked when she opened the door of Robert Gallagher's little farm house at 8 o'clock this morning and walked out into a sunlit morning.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 22 -- Following their bitterly fought match at Montclair, N.J., yesterday, William Tilden, world's professional tennis champion, scored the most decisive victory of his many meetings with Hans Nusslein of Germany today at the Lido Country Club.

The Philadelphia Athletics, apparently in championship form again after their mysterious Spring slump, brought their current winning streak to Yankee Stadium yesterday and by firing three homers registered their seventh straight victory, the score being 4 to 2.

An attempt will be made by the United Lutheran Synod of New York this week to prohibit the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America from ever issuing again a pronouncement, or what has come to be called "a Protestant Encyclical," without first submitting it to each of the twenty-eight church bodies that compose the council and then attaching to it a list of those church bodies that fail to approve.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Although the foreign trade returns for April show a heavily diminished export surplus, the immediate outlook for the reichsmark's stability seems to have improved. At Berlin dollar exchange continues, as it has done ever since the July crisis, to be officially quoted at 4.13, but most exchange rates of gold-paying countries on Berlin have sunk, and in foreign gold-currency countries as a whole the mark quotes above par.

More than 1,000 children in Colonial costumes, representing Polish parochial schools in this city, marched yesterday afternoon from St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church, 101 East Seventh Street, to City Hall Park, where they participated in Washington Bicentennial exercises.
MONTREAL, May 22 (AP) -- The Royals took both ends of a double-header from the Toronto Maple Leafs today before 11,000 fans, winning 3 -- 1 and 6 -- 5.

ROCHESTER, May 22 (AP) -- Rochester today took two games from the Buffalo Bisons, 6 to 5, in eleven innings and 7 to 4 in a seven-inning game, which did not end until 7:30 P.M., to give 16,000 fans plenty of thrills. The two victories gave Rochester second place in the standing.

William Z. Foster, Communist leader, tells what will happen in this country if communism wins to power through revolution in "Toward Soviet America," published today by Coward-McCann. Taking full advantage of the fact that there is more work to do in Soviet Russia than is likely to be done for some time, he pictures that country as the present hope of the world and paints the depression here in darkest hues.
