To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days when many citizens point to the creakings of our antiquated legal machinery and despair of the corrective power of our criminal courts, it may be allowable for one who has practiced many years in various jurisdictions to offer a helpful suggestion.

Former Governor Smith and Governor Ritchie of Maryland, candidates for the Democratic nomination for President, have joined with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and others to urge the Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress to lay aside partisanship and unite to adopt a balanced Federal budget and an economically sound plan of taxation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. May 22 -- The Rev. Dr. Ralph S. Cushman of Rochester, N.Y., and the Rev. Dr. Junius Ralph Magee of Seattle, Wash., were consecrated as bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church this afternoon in the presence of delegates to the thirty-first quadrennial general conference and visitors all numbering more than 5,000.

TOKYO, Monday, May 23 (AP) -- The prospect of a strong national emergency Cabinet headed by Admiral Viscount Hakoto Saito, former Governor of Korea, emerged yesterday from the welter of anxiety and bewilderment into which terrorism and the assassination of Premier Ki Inukai plunged Japan a week ago.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The announcement of the naming of a committee headed by Owen D. Young, to find ways to use Federal Reserve credit, holds forth the hope of basic, constructive action. If this committee proposes an enlightened course of procedure in accordance with the most authoritative opinion, business revival will be realized.

Whatever may be thought of Atlantic flying as a sport, a woman's solo flight from Harbor Grace to Londonderry is a famous achievement. It will always have its niche in the annals of aeronautics, Mrs. PUTNAM was not a stranger to the Atlantic, having previously flown to Wales with STULTZ and GORDON.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Soviet Government today relaxed its unrelenting attitude toward the survivors of the old Czarist regime -- the disfranchised or "declassed" elements of the population.

AMSTERDAM, May 19 -- The persistence of dollar exchange at a point favoring gold imports to this market from America and the resultant large shipments from New York to Amsterdam during recent weeks -- about $50,000,00 since the beginning of April -- are ascribed by the market to the misgiving which seems to prevail in this country regarding the attitude of the United States toward the gold standard.

A letter has been addressed to holders of 5 per cent secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company by the committee headed by Bainbridge Colby, attacking the committee headed by Grayson M.P. Murphy as representing bankers, through who the securities were sold, despite the resignation of partners in Lee, Higginson Co. from the Murphy committee, and requesting deposits of the debentures with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York.

DERBY, Derbyshire, May 22 (Canadian Press) -- Hope that 1932 would prove historic in drawing together all citizens or the British Empire was expressed today by J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, in an Empire Day address.

Christians can unite for common action only around the figure of Jesus Christ, and because of this fact the work of the various denominations for social reform is less effective than it might be, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

BERLIN, May 22 -- Manfred von Brauchitsch of Germany, driving a Mercedes-Benz, won the feature race today of the international automobile and motorcycle carnival conducted by the Allgemeiner Deutscher Automobile Club.

A reception in behalf of Greenwich House will be held at 27 Barrow Street on Thursday afternoon, when all the departments of the settlement will be open to visitors. The occasion will mark the thirtieth anniversary of its founding, on May 26, 1902. Later in the afternoon there will be a musical program by students of the Greenwich Music School at its headquarters, 46 Barrow Street.

Wholesale hitting featured the overwhelming victory of the New York Athletic Club over the Fort Slocum nine at Travers Island yesterday. The Winged Foot team pounded out eighteen hits to win, 17 to 4, taking the lead in the second inning, scoring five runs in the third and from then on crossing the plate at will.

PARIS, May 20 -- After being for some days in very bad shape, the Bourse recovered fairly rapidly on Thursday, owing to a better impression concerning the new government; but it weakened again on Friday. Political uncertainty is still too great for any upward tendency to become clearly established.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Senators pounded out a 7 to 1 victory off four Boston Red Sox pitchers today to advance to within a game and a half of the first place New York Yankees.

The Board of Taxicab Control, in a unanimous decision made public yesterday, laid down the rule that all applicants for licenses must undergo a searching investigation of their business record and operations.

Lord BYRON, at the dedication of whose shrine in Newstead Abbey Premier VENIZELOS less than a year ago expressed the deep homage and remembrance of his nation for the poet " who gave his life in defense of its liberties," would have another tear for Greece.

NEW HAVEN, May 21 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 61.1, which compares with 61.4 a week ago, 61.6 two weeks ago. 61.8 three weeks ago and 61.8 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; this week's average is the lowest.
William Henry Murray, Governor of Oklahoma, chatted with reporters for an hour or more in his suite at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

The new 54,000-ton, liner Rex will sail from Genoa for New York on Sept. 27 and the 48,000-ton vessel Conte di Savoia will follow on Nov. 8 on their maiden trips, the Italian Line announced yesterday. With the addition of these two ships, to the fleet already in operation, between New York and the Mediterranean a five-day service to Spain and Northern Africa and a six-day service to the Riviera will be possbile.

Preceded by a parade in which nearly all the uniformed Negro organizations in Harlem participated, the cornerstone of the new $1,000,000 home of the West 135th Street Y. M.C.A. at 180 West 135th Street, was laid yesterday afternoon.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 22 -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's speech made here tonight.

A call to educators to prepare the children of the next generation for reconstruction of the economic and social order of today was issued in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, yesterday by Dr. William P. Ladd, dean of the Berkeley Divinity School of New Haven, Conn.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Warm weather increased sales of seasonal goods by wholesalers and retailers last week, making average distribution close to that of a year ago. A feature of the merchandise situation described by the head of a leading State Street store is that prices have been on the down grade for two years and are regarded now as having about reached bottom.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Riding in an airplane in brilliant sunshine 3,000 feet above the Municipal Airport late this afternoon, a young passenger waved a farewell to earth and shot himself through the head.

The mantle of the late Senator CARAWAY appears to have descended on Senator WHEELER. Recalling the recent Reed-Hoover reference to the " locust swarm " of lobbyists about the Capitol, he has introduced a resolution directing the Judiciary Committee of the Senate to investigate lobbying and decide whether it should be " prohibited."

A comparison of the annual directory, Club Members of New York, for 1932-1933, issued today, with earlier editions, shows substantial changes in club membership during the last year. More than 32,000 members of forty-nine selected clubs within a fifty-mile radius of the city are listed in the volume.
CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, April 21 -- "If Japan wants it, let her have it!"

LONDON, May 22 -- Throughout England there is being celebrated this year the centenary of the temperance movement, which originated in, Lancashire in 1832 and spread throughout the world with the most pregnant social and political consequences, nowhere greater than in the United States.

Elderly men in the dark institutional uniforms of the City Home for the Aged and Infirm and women dressed in white veils and frocks knelt before the chancel steps of the little Chapel of the Good Shepherd on Welfare Island yesterday to receive confirmation from Bishop Manning.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y. May 22 -- The annual fine and applied arts exhibit of Marymount College students opened here today and will be on view until May 31. The exhibit includes oils, water-colors and pastels, drawings in charcoal and pen and ink, photographic enlargements, interior designing layouts, leather and metal work.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., May 22 -- The Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad Company won a victory in Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Christopher J. Heffernan when it obtained the right to use $640,000 of its money which for several years has been tied up in the vaults of the New York Trust Company.

The total Investment of national advertisers in newspaper space dropped $25,000,000 last year in comparison with the preceding year, according to a report made public yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Intemperate thought and action constitute a menace to real estate mortgage bond investments, according to recommendations contained in a survey of the subject just completed by Dwight L. Hoopingarner for the American Construction Council.

Total returns of $139,122 from 1,396 gifts and pledges had resulted during the first week of active solicitation for the Salvation Army'a United Appeal for $1,090,000 to continue relief and welfare activities in New York City, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the campaign.

The City Affairs Committee issued a statement yesterday renewing its demand that Sheriff John E. Sheehy remove from office two deputies who were unable to explain their bank deposits when called upon to do so by the Hofstadter committee.
Buyers of sites on Long Island and Staten Island have plans for erecting new houses, according to announcements made over the weekend.

When Greenwich Village was a charming suburb lying north of the city no one thought of holding a combined " open house." Individual parties under the trees and in the gardens were the custom, and the scattered householders had little of the community feeling that now characterizes the neighborhood.

With the investigation of the kidnapping and murder of Colonel Lindbergh's baby devoid of progress yesterday as far as official reports disclosed, interest in the case swung again to John H. Curtis, Norfolk boatbuilder and bogus negotiator, who is in the Hunterdon County jail at Flemington, N.J., on charges of giving false information and hindering the hunt for the criminals.

LONDON, May 19 -- The Bank of England's official and unexpected purchases of about u3,000,000 gold from the open market continue to arouse discussion. There is no question that these operations were directly connected with the establishment by the government of an "exchange equilibrium account," for which u150,000,000 is to be assigned and which is intended to provide funds, not only for purchase of sterling exchange when necessary, but also for purchase of gold.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 22 -- Even in an off year of international golf, eleven Americans will be among the 235 starters at the Honorable Company of Edinburgh Golfers' Old Homestead course near the Gullane Hills for the 1932 British amateur championship, opening tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Speaker Garner would make no statement today on the letter other than that he was "perplexed" as to its implications.

CINCINNATI, May 22 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs were almost toppled from their perch at the top of the National League today as the Cincinnati Reds won, 4 to 3, their third straight in the four-game series. Kolp won a hurling duel with Root.

ROME, May 22 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini opened the first international congress of transatlantic fliers today with a prediction of regular commercial service across the world's oceans within a short time.

The efficiency of the public schools of Kew York City is threatened by the economy program now being "grappied with" by the Board of Education, it is declared in the last issue for the school year of The Public and the Schools, organ of the Public Education Association at 8 West Fortieth Street.

THE Columbia crews had come in off the river. It was getting on toward twilight. The shells had been swung to their racks. The oarsmen had taken their showers and were strolling up the hill toward the dinner table. One of the tall boys was asked the whereabouts of those Cape Cod folk.

The government of the Republic of Colombia, in a statement transmitted yesterday to its bankers here, explained its reasons for having abandoned its plan to issue scrip in lieu of the unpaid coupons on the dollar obligations of its political subdivisions. Some of the departmental assemblies and municipal councils failed to ratify the scrip agreement, it said.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- James C. Stone, chairman of the Federal Farm Board, replied today to the suggestion of Peter B. Carey, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, that the Farm Board be abolished so that the stabilization wheat could be sold by private dealers at higher prices.
HYANNIS, Mass., May 22 (AP) -- Tom Skeyhill, author and lecturer, of West Dennis, died today from injuries received in the forced landing of an airplane last night.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Hoover's letter to President Parker of the American Society of Civil Engineers read as follows:

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- Corn shipments set a record last week, but the totals for all grains were less than a year ago. Export surpluses at date are: Wheat, 53,469,954 bushels; corn, 160,154,538 bushels; flaxseed, 45,116,040 bushels.

FALSE PASS, Alaska, May 22 (AP) -- A party of two students and myself have successfully made the first ascent of Mount Shishaldin, a volcano of Unimak Island, which was in extremely active eruption two months ago. We reached the summit of the 9,400 foot cone, which was still emitting ashes and flowing lava, six days ago.

The sidelights on the general situation to which probably the most attention was given last week were the absence of recovery in volume of business or distribution of goods, the export of $63,000,000 more gold from America to Europe, and the comtinued abnormal weakness of investment markets.
NEWARK, N.J., May 22 -- Newark defeated the Reading Keys in both games of a double-header before 15,000 today to give the Bears a stronger hold on first place.

After a first-hand study of conditions in the twenty-seven municipal hospitals, a joint committee representing civic and medical associations reported to Mayor Walker and the Board of Estimate yesterday that additional facilities were needed for the care of tuberculosis patients and suggested establishment of "recovery homes" where convalescent patients could recuperate without using hospital bed space.

An "unworthy conspiracy," entered into by those opposing the nomination of Governor Roosevelt for President, is on foot to throw the Democratic National Convention next month into a prolonged deadlock, with consequent confusion to the Democratic party and disastrous results to its candidate, according to Homer S. Cummings, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and one of the chief lieutenants of Mr. Roosevelt in his quest for the Presidential nomination.

With the investigation into Mayor Walker's conduct in office-scheduled to reach a climax Wednesday with the Mayor on the witness stand, yesterday was marked by unusual activity on the part of Samuel Seabury and his assistants.

NAPO, Oriente, Ecuador, April 22 (by mail via Guayaquil) -- We have just finished the hardest task of our entire trip, the traversing on foot of the fifty-five miles of forest trail that connect the village of Mera with that of Napo. Before us stretches some 800 miles of the Napo River and 2,000 of the Amazon -- all down hill, and all navigable by canoe, motor boat and steamer.

The Medical Information Bureau, which was established three years ago by the New York Academy of Medicine and the County Medical Society as a clearing house for all medical information of interest to the general public, will sponsor health talks by eminent members of the medical profession to be broadcast from Station WABC for fifteen minutes every Monday, beginning at 11:30 A.M., it was announced yesterday by Dr. John A, Hartwell, president of the academy.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Miss Drew Steele, 16-year-old student of Peabody High School, Pittsburgh was announced tonight as the winner of a national essay contest conducted by the National Student Forum on the Paris Pact, on the subject, "What is the Bearing of the Paris Peace Pact on the Question of World Disarmament?"

Goals by Captain Guy Thompson and Captain William McCreight in the fifth period enabled the First Division polo team of Fort Hamilton to defeat the Brooklyn Freebooters, 5 to 4, before 2,000 yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn.

A general committee to protect the interests of holders of defaulted real estate bonds has been formed by a group of bankers, acting in cooperation with three large real estate concerns. Edward C. Delafield, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, is chairman of the organization.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Hoover and officials of his administration were criticized by Senator La Follette today for their attitude toward the unemployed.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Federal prisoners now number 49,700, the Justice Department disclosed today in a review of the penal situation.
NEW YORK. The Countess of Suffolk, now at the Madison, is sailing Wednesday on the Berengaria.

Leading throughout, the Great Island four defeated Governors Island, 8 to 5, in the opening game of the polo season at Governors Island yesterday before a crowd of 3.500. The visitors received one goal by handicap, but did not need the allowance.
Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, after having flown yesterday from Londonderry, Ireland, to London, spoke over the radio on an international hook-up with the Columbia Broadcasting Company's chain here.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Live-stock raisers have had a bad year, prices declining irregrularly to the lowest levels in many years and hog's selling at the lowest since 1898. The decline in prices has checked marketing of cattle and hogs to a moderate extent, while the run of sheep and lambs continues large.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 22 -- A program of singing and dancing by several hundred children in the orphans' home of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society was presented here today in connection with the biennial meeting of the board of directors of the society.

SEASIDE, PARK, N.J., May 22 -- W.H. James of Philadelphia piloted his Scarab to an unusual victory today in the third test of the Olympic trial series for international Star Class sloops along the Jersey coast.

PARIS, May 22 -- The British International Club gained revenge for its defeat on the covered courts last Winter when it defeated France in the annual team tennis match which ended in Roland Garros Stadium today. The score was 11 to 8. France led on the day's play, taking five out of nine matches, but Great Britain's big lead gained on the opening day assured it an easy victory.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Two ninth-inning rallies today gave the White Sox a double victory over the Tigers, 3 to 2 and 8 to 7, enabling Chicago to even the four-game series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sir Wilfred Grenfell returns the latter part of May for his forty-first year of work among the fishermen of Labrador and North Newfoundland. Weatherbeaten, wiry, alert, his face crinkling with humor and sweetness, Sir Wilfred possesses the enthusiasm, if not the inexhaustible strength, of the seventy-five young college men and women who will go north with him.

The sportsmen of Rockland County have gone on record as favoring a change in the open season for cotton-tail rabbits, and have filed a petition with the Conservation Department of the State asking for a shortened season which would be from Nov. 15 to Jan. 15.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- Tight pitching by Steve Swetonic gave the Pirates the first game of a twin bill with the Cardinals today, 5 to 1, and Wild Bill Hallahan pitched the Cardinals to victory in the second, 5 to 3.

Victor Barry of De Witt Clinton High School, wearing the colors of the West Side Y.M.C.A., and Miss Evelyn Fogler of the Women's Swimming Association gained close victories in 100-yard free-style handicaps for men and women at the initial water carnival of the Metropolitan A.A.U. outdoor season in the 100-foot pool of the Washington Baths, Coney Island, yesterday.

ROME, May 22 -- Despite the gloom cast over the proceedings by the tragic death yesterday of the Hungarians, Captain George Endres and Captain Julius Pittay, Rome today accorded a rousing reception to more than fifty transocean fliers assembled here for a congress convoked by the Italian Aero Club.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- Making her first start in American waters, Horace Havemeyer's Mouette, champion English twelve-meter yacht, was beaten today by W.A. W. Stewart's Iris. They covered an eighteen-mile triangle on Long Island Sound and Iris, sailed by Charles F. (Bubbles) Havemeyer, finished 1 minute and 12 seconds ahead.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 -- The awarding of fifty-one fellowships and scholarships to undergraduates and graduate students of Princeton University was announced here today by Dr. Augustus Trowbridge, dean of the Graduate School.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation. The symbol Y stands for yea, N for nay, NVP for not voting but paired, and NV for not voting and not paired. The subjects of the roll-calls, designated A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I,J and K, were as follows:

BAYONNE, N.J., May 22 -- Denied his 10-months-old son. Robert Jr., Robert Knault, 26, wounded his estranged wife, Stella, 20, and shot and fatally wounded the infant and himself in her parents' home at 468 Boulevard here tonight. In a letter found in his pocket Knault recited his troubles and added, "Above all that, my wife walks out on me, taking all I have in this terrible world, my sonny boy."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent London dispatch to THE TIMES gives the views of a building engineer on the structural insecurity of St. Paul's Cathedral. This great architectural monument stands on the site of a medieval Gothic cathedral of the same name which never collapsed from settlement but was ruined by the great London fire in 1666.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP) -- Jersey City closed its four-game series today by dividing a double-header with Baltimore, winning the opened, 9 to 7, by staging a three-run rally in the ninth, and dropping the second game, 4 to 3. This evened the series.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- The largest crowd that ever assembled for a major league game in Boston today saw the Braves split a double-header with the Phillies. The official count was 51,331.

The membership of Christian churches in the United States increased from 49,318,787 in 1930 to 49,752,443 in 1931, a gain of 433,656, according to The Christian Herald's annual report of church statistics, prepared by Dr. G.L. Kieffer and published in the June issue of the magazine.

Keaffirmation of loyalty to Christ as a way out of the cloud of darkness that hangs over this country was urged by Professor Arthur L. Swift Jr. of the Union Theological Seminary in a sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church at Eighty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Hoover today reiterated with vigor his opposition to a Federal bond issue for non-productive public works as an unemployment relief measure and urged the adoption of a 12-point relief credit program for the nation.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A resubmission plank, suggesting a remedy for the alleged evils of national prohibition, rather than a "straddle" on that subject in the party platform, is being worked out among dry Republicans formerly associated with the Progressive group.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 -- Passage of another week without marked change in the steel situation encouraged the trade in two respects. There was none of the seasonal decrease in demand that usually comes at this time of year, but there was another week of sustained prices and it increased confidence in the stabilization movement.

The National Economy Committee, whose petition for the repeal of the laws authorizing $450,000,000 payment annually to veterans who suffered no war disability was presented to President Hoover early this month, has decided to effect a permanent organization, it was announced yesterday by Archibald B. Roosevelt, its secretary.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., May 22 (AP) -- More than 300 World War veterans, on their way from Portland, Ore., to Washington to urge passage of a bonus bill by Congress, remained "camped" in the Baltimore Ohio railroad yards here tonight, blocked by refusal of the railroad to move the freight train, which they had boarded today for the rest of their journey.

From the Institute of Law of the Johns Hopkins University comes another fruitful study of justice as it is administered in one of those minor courts which are most immediate to " the average citizen." " The " Justice of the Peace Courts of " Hamilton County, Ohio," is a collection of first-class information.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Government statistics of the last three decades show that years of short crops have been followed by seasons of greatly increased production, and that periods of excessive crops, with few exceptions, have been followed by short yields.

Mayor WALKER'S attitude of proud defiance is what one would expect of him. He professes entire willingness, even the utmost eagerness, to meet his enemies in the gate this week. For the sake of his own reputation, and for the good name of the city, it is strongly to be hoped that he will be able to break the force of the charges brought against him.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 22 -- Bold experimentation to achieve redistribution of the national income was demanded here tonight by Governor Roosevelt to prevent a collapse of the current economic order.

Owen D. Young, who declined recently to be even a receptive candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, explained yesterday that his desire to prevent any breakup of the existing political order in this country had led him to participate in the drive to raise $250,000 in New York City for the Democratic National Committee during the next few weeks.

More than 250 members of the theatrical profession participated yesterday in the first High Mass to be celebrated by the Rev. Thomas McGlynn, son of Frank McGlynn, the actor, who was ordained as a Roman Catholic priest of the Dominican Order last Friday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 (AP) -- The existence of white Indians with blond hair, who live like animals in the grand desert of Northeastern Paraguay, was confirmed by Dr. Donald S. Wees, Harvard Museum explorer, on his arrival here today.

No departure from the standard lesion-sermon, read in all Christian Science churches yesterday, was made at the services opening the new $275,000 edifice of the Fourth Church of Christ, Scientist, 185th Street and Fort Washington Avenue. The structure is of modernistic design and is believed to be the first such church of its denomination in America.

The "wet society women" who collected "nickels and hand-outs on the street last week to wage a propaganda for the repeal of prohibition" were described yesterday by Dr. D. Leigh Colvin as "Bacchantian maidens parching for wine -- wet women who like the drunkards whom their program will produce, would take pennies off the eyes of the dead for the sake of legalizing booze."

Favorable weather during the week combined with cotton promotions to create a fair amount of business for retail stores, with the result that they placed a considerable number of reorders, each for only moderate quantities, however. All types of cotton goods, particularly dresses, were active, resulting from the emphasis on them during the week.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 22. -- Norman Thomas of New York was named candidate for President of the United States by the national convention of the Socialist party here today. As his running mate the convention named James H. Maurer of Pennsylvania, a former president of the Federation of Labor of his State.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Determined to complete before June 10, if possible, its investigation of stock market manipulation, the Senate Banking Committee has sent its corps of investigators back to Wall Street for further data.

LONDON, May 22 -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam is sleeping at the United States Embassy here tonight as the guest of Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon just as Charles A. Lindbergh was Ambassador Herrick's guest after his Paris flight five years ago.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- The radio industry is so confident that good times will soon return that it is risking $200,000,000 on its chances in 1933 according to J. Clarke Coit, president of the Radio Manufacturers' Association, which will open its eighth annual convention, and trade ihow here tomorrow.

HAVANA, May 22 -- An attempt on the life of Captain Samaniego, military supervisor of Camaguey Province, was frustrated today as a result of orders issued last night by Secretary of the Interior Zubizarretta forbidding the delivery of packages to army officers, according to a report received here.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Grimly determined, Senate leaders met threat with threat today as they gathered forces to push through the billion-dollar tax bill.

TOKYO, Monday, May 23 -- Admiral Viscount Makoto Saito, liberal-minded former Governor of Korea and a delegate to the Geneva naval conference in 1927, yesterday was chosen non-party Premier of Japan. He is 73 years old and succeeds the 77-year-old Ki Inukai, who was assassinated last week.

A weekly passenger service between Baltimore and Bermuda will be established by the Clyde-Mallory Line with the sailing of the Shawnee from Baltimore on June 25, J.E. Craig, vice president, announced yesterday. The Shawnee will leave Baltimore every Saturday at 5 P. M., arrive at Bermuda the following Tuesday at 8 A.M., and sail nine hours later, returning to Baltimore on Friday.

Her escape cut off by a fire in the five-story studio apartment building at 145 East Thirty-fourth Street yesterday morning, Miss Pauline Newman, 24 years old, of 530 West 114th Street, was being pulled up to the fifth story by a policeman from a window in a fourth floor apartment when she lost her grip on his hands and fell to the areaway below.

NEW ORLEANS, May 22 -- While trading in the cotton market here was rather restricted last week, owing largely to unwillingness of traders to do more than engage in scalping operations until Congress has disposed of the measures designed to balance the budget, the market was well supported and prices developed a slight upward trend.

An analysis of the building outlook as it appears immediately following the new wage scale adjustment is presented by Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The building trades are watching three factors in the present situations, according to Mr. Beals, who describes these elements as prospective new and alteration work, the building code and the availability of investment building money.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Credit for the allowance and allotments system embodied in the war risk insurance act of Oct. 6, 1917, was attributed to the late Julia C. Lathrop, pioneer in the juvenile court movement and first chief of the National Children's Bureau, in an address here today by Justice Julian W. Mack of New York.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Efforts are being made by speculative interests in Chicago, the East and other sections to advance wheat prices 10 to 15 cents a bushel or more. Leaders in the trade believe that should wheat prices hold the appreciation, it will do more than any other factor toward starting a prosperity boom that eventually would restore confidence.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in a letter yesterday to Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association, endorsed the proposal to have Fort Schuyler, at Throgs Neck in the Bronx, turned over to the city for park purposes.

State of Minnesota. Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $10,000,000 State of Minnesota highway bonds, consisting of $3,000,000 4s, due on June 1, 1934 to 1936, priced to yield 3.50 to 4 per cent, and $7,000,000 4 1/4s, due on June 1, 1937 to 1947, and priced to yield 4 to 4.10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The American Palestine Committee, a non-Jewish body formed to aid the Zionist movement to restore Palestine as the national homeland of the Jewish people, was organized here tonight at a reception to Dr. Nahum Sokolow of London, president of the World Zionist Organization.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., May 22 -- A safari composed of Chief of Police George Scheussler, the day and night shifts of the local police force. Lieutenant Louis Meyers of the Glen Cove motorcycle squad, hordes of citizens and helpful motorists hunted through the woods here today in futile effort to capture a little black and white monkey.

LONDON, May 20 -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were quiet and barely steady. Smoked sheet spot sold at 1 7/8d a pound sellers. May at 1 7/8d sellers, June at 1 7/8d sellers, July-September at 1 15-16d sellers, October at 2d sellers, January-March at 2 1-16d sellers, April-June at 2 3-16d to 2 1/3d sellers, crepe spot at 2 1/2d sellers.

PARIS, May 22 -- More than any ether issue, the policy to be adopted by France on disarmament and the attitude which is taken at the Geneva disarmament conference will determine the constitution of the new French Government and the majority behind it.

Telegraphic invitations were dispatched yesterday to eight teams which have been officially selected to participate in the final play-off series for the honor of representing the United States in the Olympic lacrosse competition. Announcement was made by Charles L. Ornstein, chairman of the American Olympic Lacrosse Committee, following a committee session at the Hotel Paramount.

Soldiers and Farm Relief. Japan's military leaders in the some what unfamiliar role of spokesmen for the oppressed farmer have an interesting parallel in recent Soviet history. It was in March, 1930, that STALIN issued his famous order to slow up the farm-collectivization campaign which had been proceeding, incidentally, under his own urging, at a furious speed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES one reads that the Senate voted overwhelmingly against the proposal to legalize 2.75 per cent beer as a basis for new taxes. It then faced about and by a still more decisive ballot approved a levy on ingredients for home brew and home-made wine calculated to yield $97,000,000 in new revenue for the 1933 budget.

A cure for economic distress and a way to accord among nations through adherence to a spirit of truth, in the scientific, objective sense, was offered yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale, pastor of the St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 126th Street.

Mrs. John D. Hertz's Stimulus filly Risque, winner of the famous Alabama Stakes last year, was placed first in the Milkmaid Handicap, feature at Belmont Park yesterday, but the decision of the judges was criticized by many. Finishing on the rail, Mrs. Hertz's colorbearer appeared beaten by the Greentree Stable's Parry, which crossed the line out in the middle of the track.
ALBANY, May 23 -- Attorney General Bennett ruled in a formal opinion today that disabled war veterans "must be the last to be separated from the State service."

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Important developments toward a governmental policy on relief and unemployment measures today followed President Hoover's forcible expression of opposition to a bond issue for public works. While officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation discussed the program to enlarge the resources of that corporation by $1,000,000,000, two new relief plans, both sponsored by Republicans, appeared in the Senate.

An informal "election," demonstrating the uses of the Hare system of proportional representation, resulted in the choice of President Hoover, Walter Lippmann, Norman Thomas and Nicholas Murray Butler as members of the Board of Aldermen from ten candidates voted on.

An omnibus book of Aldous Huxley's earlier writings is being prepared for publication in England by Chatto and Windus. It is to be called "Rotunda" and will contain 1,088 pages in which will be included a full-length novel, "These Barren Leaves"; a long short story, "Uncle Spencer"; five short stories, twelve poems, twelve essays and "The World of Light," a play.
Several deals by New Yorkers were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 23 -- Walter F. Manning, for several years head of the firm of L.L. Manning Son, monument works, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital In his fifty-sixth year.

Most financial markets were colorless yesterday. Stocks hardly moved, and the transactions of approximately 600,000 shares were nearly or quite the smallest full-day business of the year. It is about the five-hour average of this time in 1921, since which period some fairly spectacular changes in activity of the sort have been presented to the eye of an admiring public.

Formation of a committee to protect holders of Consolidated Machine Tool Corporation of America first mortgage 7 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1942, was announced yesterday, following a statement by the president of the corporation that the interest amounting to $78,113 due on the bonds of June 1, this year, could not be paid.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- A five-run rally in the seventh inning at the expense of Elon Hogsett gave the Browns a 7-to-6 victory over Detroit in the series opener today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The draw to determine the order of play in the first day's Davis Cup matches Friday between the Australian and the United States tennis teams will take place Thursday noon in the Racquet Club, it was announced today by Fitz-Eugene Dixon, American captain.

To cope with the growing burden of unemployment relief, Germany is to have a new emergency decree establishing additional taxes on the one hand and slicing allowances on the other. The official estimate of the average number of idle workers for the current year is 5,900,000.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 23. -- Fire, early tonight, destroyed Mondanne, a residence of James A. Stillman, banker, on a 440-acre estate adjoining that of John D. Rockefeller Jr., in the Pocantico Hills. The house, a two and a half story H-shaped building containing thirty-five rooms and built to resemble a Swiss chalet, burned to the ground with nearly all its contents, including many fine paintings, a choice library, and valuable antiques, tapestries and other furnishings.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Jacob Nachman, convicted in New York City of using the mails to defraud and under a penitentiary sentence, failed in a plea for a review by the Supreme Court today.

PARIS, May 23. -- In one of the few interviews he has given since the victory of the Radical-Socialist party in the recent elections, Edouard Herriot told a correspondent of the Paris-Midi today that in his foreign policy, if he took office as Premier, he would observe the greatest prudence and practice what he described as an "inch by inch" policy.

Asserting that 74 per cent of the students now attending the evening session of City College would be forced to discontinue their educations if the increased fees recently voted by the board of higher education were actually imposed when the new term opens in September, college liberal organizations began a fight against the fees last night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The Giants bombarded a trio of Burt Shotton's pitchers for a total of nineteen hits today and contrived to bring down the Phillies by a score of 9 to 7. The diminutive Hughie Critz and the ponderous Frank Hogan, with four hits apiece, contributed the bulk of the thumping.

The story of why Peter the Great savagely tortured Russia from a condition of semi-Asiatic degeneration toward "Europeanization" is told by Alexei Tolstoy in "Peter the Great," published today in translation by Covici, Friede.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Without comment the Supreme Court today refused to grant a rehearing in the packers' consent decree case, which means that the court's recent decision will stand holding the packers to the terms of the 1920 decree forbidding them to trade in other than meat products.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Admiral William S. Benson, who died suddenly on Saturday, was buried in Arlington National Cemetery today with military honors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- When Pennsylvania's crews started practice today for the Childs Cup regatta with Columbia and Princeton on Saturday, Head Coach Rusty Callow announced several important changes.

The Inaugural Ball, an event expected to be one of the most brilliant of the ceremonies marking the Washington bicentennial, will be given in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tonight by the New York City Bicentennial Commission. Arrangements have been in preparation for weeks.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., May 23 -- Six persons were rescued by Coast Guards and life-savers late yesterday when the twenty-eight-foot cabin boat Elaine, owned and piloted by Harry Gordon of Central Avenue, Lawrence, struck a submerged wreck at the ocean front of Beach Twenty-ninth Street, Far Rockaway, and started to sink.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names.

The plea of the Academy of Medicine and its associates for improved hospital facilities, especially for the tuberculous, is sure to receive public and official support, even in these difficult times. The pressure on the city hospitals was never greater than today.

DANZIG, May 23. -- German leaders here assert they have evidence of designs in Poland to seize Danzig at the first favorable chance and that all essential preparations have been made. Sections of the Polish press have been urging Marshal Pilsudski, the dictator, to defy the world and make an end to an impossible situation by annexing Danzig and East Prussia.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The House today refused by 228 votes to 169 to discharge the Ways and Means Committee from further consideration of the O'Connor-Hull bill, which would have legalized 2.75 per cent beer under a tax of 3 cents a pint.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 10 (AP) (by mail) -- To take possession of a fortune of $120,000,000, a white-haired Armenian woman. Marianne DJanikian, 80, has gone to India with her two sons.

To the Editor of The New York Timss: The Mayor's tardy acceptance of the principles of economy and retrenchment in the city's expenditures must make the demand almost unanimous. Every one else has been insisting on it for months back.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Carrying the equivalent of the remarkably low rate of .29 per cent on an annual basis, $60,050,000 in Treasury bills will be issued on Wednesday, Secretary Mills announced today.

United States Government obligations led a mild rally in active trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Of the twelve Liberty loans and Treasury issues that figured in the transactions, ten advanced 3-32 to 28-32 point, Liberty 3 1/2s held unchanged, and the first Liberty 4s, which are not traded every day, lost 31-32 point from the last previous sale.

About the head of Dr. D. Leigh Colvin, chairman of the Prohibition National Committee, who, on Sunday, described women wets as "Bacchantian maidens parching for wine," there swirled yesterday storm of criticism.

Professional women church workers are suffering from "inadequate salaries and unregulated conditions of work, inadequate standards of training, and the need for a central bureau to act as a clearing house for positions," according to a statement issued yesterday by a committee of women of the Episcopal Church which was appointed by Presiding Bishop James De. Wolf Perry to study the problem of opportunities for women's work in the church.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Prominent Republicans who are endeavoring to shape a moist plank which would conserve the party's dry support have so far run up against opposition from dry organization leaders who have been consulted.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Milton Gaston blanked the Indians with two singles and batted in the run necessary for victory, as the White Sox won the opening game of the series, 4 to 0, today. Cleveland sent three pitchers to the mound.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks', is being "pilloried as an official who has given unselfish and unstinting service to the State," Martin Conboy, defense attorney declared yesterday in his closing address in defense of Mr. Broderick at the Superintendent's trial before Judge George L. Donnellan and a jury in General Sessions.

The indictment charging Francis X. Mancuso, former General Sessions Judge, with a misdemeanor as a participant in the fraudulent insolvency of the defunct City Trust Company was dismissed yesterday by Justice William F.Bleakley in the Supreme Court, who directed the jury hearing the case to give a verdict of acquittal.

The price trend in commodities soared yesterday. In the grains the advance ranged from a good size fraction to 1 5/8 cents, while cotton rose 7 to 8 points, reaching the best figures in two weeks. Coffee improved 8 to 12 points, with sugar and cocoa firm. Slight losses were recorded in silk, rubber and hides.

Surviving enforced readers of Senator BROOKHART'S innumerable speeches on economic and financial subjects are only too often put in mind of Speaker REED'S vinegary epigram on Representative WILLIAM M. SPRINGER of Illinois:

Lee Shubert, theatrical producer and co-receiver with the Irving Trust Company for the Shubert Theatre Corporation, made a bitter and unexpected attack yesterday against the council of the Actors' Equity Association for its refusal last December to sanction Sunday night performances in legitimate theatres.
LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- The real reason Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam flew the Atlantic alone was to stop all those nasty things men say about women airplane pilots and women automobile drivers.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Gainfully employed workers 10 years old and over throughout New York State numbered 5,523,337 in 1930, or 43.9 per cent of the population compared with 4,503,204, or 43.4 per cent of the population, in 1920, the Census Bureau announced today.

The galleries are now opening their Summer shows right and left. Several that usually remain closed during the warm months have decided to continue activities this year without a break. In certain cases, again, the Summer program is being divided into instalments (or as Sidney Ross would call them, "editions").

An Error Admitted. THE TIMES has been asked by the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals to acknowledge and correct a mistake made in a recent editorial, "A Confession of Defeat."

Renewing its appeal for a public works construction program, backed by the guarantee of Federal credit, as a stimulus to business recovery, a committee of the American Society of Civil Engineers issued a statement yesterday pointing out that President Hoover, in his letter to the society made public Sunday, attributed several statements to the society which it had not made.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 23 -- Satisfied with the launching of his homestretch drive for the Presidential nomination with his "bold experimentation" speech at Oglethorpe University, Governor Roosevelt was back at his cottage today to enjoy two final days of recreation before starting north.

GENEVA, May 23 -- Dr. Albert Einstein, author of the theory of relativity, urged absolute disarmament or nothing in receiving the press here today. He held that it was better for the disarmament conference to fail outright than to end with an agreement to humanize war by abolishing certain weapons or any other half-way measure.

New Orleans, La. Award of a new issue of $750,000 city of New Orleans (La.) 5 per cent bonds, dated June 1, 1932, and due from 1933 to 1937, was made yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including the National City Company and the Hibernia Securities Company, Inc. The price paid was 99.

Those who were governing the city "only for their own interests" were condemned by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, in a sermon last evening in St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, at the opening session of the fourth annual convention of the synod.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- In a wild-hitting game, featured by Arlett's and Packard's home runs, the Baltimore Orioles turned back the Newark Bears today, 17-9. The Bears staged a rally in the ninth to score five runs.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Patrons of speakeasies are immune from arrest, search, and unlawful interference unless raiders are armed with a warrant for their arrest, according to a ruling by a Federal judge here today.

Those who in the past have enjoyed surf fishing from piers or so-called stands at the end of Long Island are requesting the Long Island State Park Commission to consider the erection, of such structures over the rocky portions along the coast now under the supervision of Montauk State Park, where it is impossible to fish from the shore.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 23. -- Three hundred National Guardsmen were ordered tonight to East St. Louis, Ill., to preserve order among more than 300 World War veterans stranded there en route to Washington, D.C., to demand immediate cash bonus payments.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- Carl Laemmle, 65, president of the Universal Pictures Corporation, underwent an operation today at Johns Hopkins Hospital. It was performed by Dr. Hugh. S. Young, urologist-in-chief of the hospital, who issued this statement:

A total of 557,520 shares was dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, which was the smallest volume of business since Sept. 1 and the second smallest day in seven and a half years. The movement of prices was again purposeless. During most of the day quotations were fractionally above Saturday's closing levels but the final hour of trading was marked by a general sagging trend.

LARKSPUR, Col., May 22. -- A rapid expansion of the live-stock industry is one of the major projects of the current Soviet program. Every one in the government, from Stalin down, appears vitally interested in the plan, which contemplates an increase in meat production to a point which will provide for an annual per capita consumption of 100 pounds.

The winners of 161 prizes, medals and honorable mentions for excellent in the various departments of the Woman's Art School and the Night School of Art at Cooper Union were announced last night by R. Fultoe Cutting, president of the board of trustees, at the opening of the union's seventy-third annual exhibition of student art.

RYE, N.Y., Tuesday, May 24 -- A ''dark-horse" pair forged to the front at the midway mark of the final round of the annual competition for the J. Noel Macy Trophy, emblematic of the Westchester County contract-bridge championship, when play halted early this morning at the Westchester Country Club here.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, May 23 -- The German-American Himalayan Expedition, which aspires to climb to the summit of the 26,630-foot Nanga Parbat, an achievement which would break all records, has just come through a week of great suspense. For a time all our hopes seemed doomed.

LONDON, May 23 -- The discovery of two meteorite craters on the site of the legendary city of Ubar in the wastes of Southern Arabia was announced tonight by H. St. John Philby, British Arabic scholar and explorer.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Granville Fortescue is expected to tell the House Territories Committee tomorrow whether she thinks the Hawaiian Islands should be placed under military control.

William Hogan, financial secretary of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and treasurer of the international union, testified yesterday in an examination before trial that dozens of union members had sought to name him beneficiary or part beneficiary in their life insurance policies and that he has agreed in the cases of four of these men.

The Right Rev. Dr. Henry Knox Sherrill, Bishop of Massachusetts, delivered the baccalaureate sermon before this year's graduating class of the General Theological Seminary last night in the seminary chapel, Ninth Avenue near Twentieth Street.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Washington Park's thirty-day meeting opened today with a surprise victory for Gold Step in the featured $5,000 added Washington Park handicap as 15,000 looked on.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23 -- Sharing interest at the State House here tonight with a decision by Republican wet leaders in the Legislature to take their fight for repeal of the Hobart prohibition enforcement act to the State convention tomorrow was the speculation caused by announcement that Representative Mary T. Norton of Jersey City, instead of Governor A. Harry Moore, would be the keynote speaker for the Democratic platform builders.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on May 18 shows decreases for the week of $103,000,000 in loans and investments, $12,000,000 in net demand deposits, $35,000,000 in time deposits and $49,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $36,000,000 in reserves with Federal Reserve Banks and of $5,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 -- Revision of Article 231 of the treaty of Versailles so that it will no longer hold the German nation solely responible for the World War was demanded by the quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

MONTREAL, May 23 (AP) -- Rochester captured the opener of a four-game series today, 5-4, before a small crowd of 800. Starr saved the game by his fine relief hurling in the ninth, retiring two Royals with the tying run on third base.

The task of obtaining a jury for the perjury trial of Isidor J. Kresel, general counsel for the defunct Bank of United States, proceeded with unexpected speed in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday. Six jurors from the special panel of talesmen had been selected before the trial was adjourned by Justice Samuel J. Harris of Buffalo until this morning.

On one page of yesterday's TIMES were printed statistics showing an increase in church, membership during the year 1931, and "confirming "the general belief that interest in "religion increases in times of depression." With good times and bad alike the curve has gone upward decade by decade from 6.5 per cent of the population in 1800 to 40.1 per cent.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., May 23 -- The Rev. Mother Mary Louis Grummey, superior general of the Sisters of St. Joseph, died yesterday, after a month's illness, at the mother house of St. Joseph's Convent here. The Right Rev. Thomas E. Molloy. Bishop of the Brooklyn Diocese, will be the celebrant of a requiem mass on Wednesday morning at 10:30 o'clock in the convent chapel.

A receivership for the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway is "imminent," Daniel Upthegrove, president, asserted yesterday in a letter sent to holders of the company's consolidated bonds which remain undeposited under the refinancing offer announced on May 16.

An accounting of sales totaling between six and seven hundred thousand dollars in a real estate project that was to have brought $5,000,000 is sought by the J.A. Wigmore Land Corporation, James A. Wigmore, president, of Queens. The Wigmore corporation went before Justice Burt J. Humphrey in a special term of the Supreme Court in Queens yesterday seeking leave to serve a supplementary summons and complaint in an action for foreclosure.

Roy O. Emery, 35-year-old former service man, threw his 2-year-old daughter, Jean, from Manhattan Bridge yesterday afternoon and then jumped after her. Their bodies were found a few feet apart on South Street, near Peck Slip, about 200 feet below the bridge parapet.

In the last seven months, more than 1,400 homeless women have come to the attention of social agencies, according to the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee on Unemployment, which said yesterday that this new type of homeless woman was young, intelligent, often cultured, well trained and eager to work.

NEW YORK. Miss Janet Hayward gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Beatrice Carroll, who will be married tomorrow to Melville E. Ingalls 3d. Among the other guests were Mrs. Waldron K. Post Jr., Mrs. R. de la Vassalais, Mrs. C. Vanderveer Lovett and the Misses Katherine Young, Laura Niles, Sally Phillips, Doris Crandall, Jane Maroney, Jessamine Goddard and Jeanne Froment.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- In an effort to conquer the drought that periodically ravages the Lower Volga grain region, Joseph Stalin, secretary general of the Communist party, and Premier Viacheslaf Molotoff issued a decree today ordering the immediate construction of a hydroelectric station of 2,000,000 kilowatts' capacity for the irrigation of 10,000,000 acres of the land.

Six New York institutions receive contingent bequests amounting to $400,000 under the will of Edward B. Sexton, who died at his home, 20 Fifth Avenue, on May 11, under his will filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The legacies are payable on the death of his widow, Ella Marion Sexton, who receives a life estate in $400,000, a cash bequest of $20,000 and the residue outright.

Legal action to block appointment of the Irving Trust Company as sole trustee in the International Match bankruptcy has been decided upon by the group of independent security holders' committees for which Samuel Untermyer is senior counsel, it became known yesterday.

A total of $53,000 out of the $250,000 "special gifts quota" for New York City has been raised within the last four days for the Democratic Victory Campaign. This was reported yesterday by members of the group of forty New York Democrats at a luncheon at the Bankers Club given by former Supreme Court Justice Morgan J. O'Brien, who presided.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23 -- With an entry list of thirty-six players, the women's annual Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament got under way today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club. Miss Charlotte Miller, Columbia University ace who won the title last year, is not defending her crown because of studies.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23 -- Professor Arthur Leslie Wheeler, one of the leading classical scholars of the country and chairman of the department of classics of Princeton University since 1926, died at his home here late last night of a stroke. He was 60 years old.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 -- Harvard University authorities discounted today stories of white Indians in Paraguay given out by Donald S. Wees in Buenos Aires, describing Mr. Wees as an "obviously inexperienced amateur," and saying that Mr. Wees had revived a "hoax."

Among the twenty-nine students who will be graduated from the National Bible Institute and Union Missionary Training Institute, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street, at exercises to be held this evening at 8 o'clock, will be Charles Buermann, 75-year-old real estate dearer of 28 Throop Avenue, Brooklyn.

Negotiations between the Publishers Association of New York and Typographical Union 6, which on Sunday ratified a membership referendurr calling for higher wages and shorter working hours, were foreshadowed yesterday by a meeting of the publishers' group at 63 Park Row.

Abolition of military training in college and university curricula and establishment of "peace departments" or "courses on peace and war" as two means by which colleges can promote world peace were suggested last night in papers read by the principal prize winners in a college essay contest conducted by the New History Society.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 23 (AP) -- A recount of ballots cast in Oregon's Presidential primary today gave James W. Mott, State Corporation Commissioner, an apparent victory by 86 votes over the veteran Representative Willis C. Hawley in a neck-and-neck contest for the Republican nomination from the First Oregon District.

Being exclusively concerned with the more spiritual aspects of life, the drama investigated the habits of vicesquad detectives and stool-pigeons last evening. "On the Make" was the label under which this first epistle to the yokels appeared; it was presented with a good deal of athletic acting at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

IT was the late Colonel Bozeman Bulger, whose sudden and unexpected death has grieved the sports world, who first broken out with the story of Josh Devore and the ambidextrous player. One of the Giant officials, with Josh Devore standing by him, was watching a player in practice.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- A Federal dole was pronounced preferable to payment of the veterans' bonus in a "five-year plan" for the revival of business drawn by members of the department of economics at the University of Chicago and made public today.

Another suspended vice squad plain clothes patrolman, John J. Stiglin, was found guilty by a jury in General Sessions at 6:30 o'clock last evening of giving perjured testimony at the arraignment of two women in the Women's Court in March, 1929. Stiglin was one of the first of the abolished vice squad patrolmen to be accused of having sworn falsely against prisoners in the Women's Court after raids.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 23 (AP) -- The German flying boat Do-X narrowly escaped disaster on arriving here at 7:15 this evening (2:15 P.M. New York Daylight Saving Time) after a flight of 630 miles from Vigo, Spain.

A large, expensive, discouraging British book will soon arrive in this country through an American publisher, or in some less usual way. Perhaps it has already reached these shores, for some of the book-reviewers may have had their European holiday already, and they are the ones to find "Fiction and the Reading Public" and bring it back.

Direct, negotiations between the city and the B.M.T, and Interborough for unification of rapid transit lines should be started immediately, Mayor Walker was advised yesterday in a letter delivered at his office on behalf of the City Club, the Merchants Association, the State Chamber of Commerce and the Real Estate Board of New York. Inc.

There was no change in the money market at the opening of business in the new week. Stock Exchange call loan rate continued at 2 1/2 per cent, while in the unofficial market there were the usual concessions. Time money market was quiet, all maturities being quoted nominally at 1 1/2 per cent.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 23 -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol, who took up the game of golf only three years ago, earned a half-interest in the qualifying medal for the 1932 Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today with a highly commendable score of 84 over the rugged Century Country Club course.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Plans for a campaign to stimulate business throughout the nation during National Clearance Week, beginning June 27, were announced today by the Merchandise Mart Chamber of Commerce. A concerted buying drive is the nucleus of the plan.

E.G. McKeever was elected yesterday a director and subsequently president of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company to succeed R.G. Stewart, who resigned as president to head the Pan American Foreign Corporation. Other officers to resign from Pan American Petroleum included Harold Walker, William Green and T.S. Cooke, all vice presidents and dirertors.

Forty-eight feature pictures will be produced during the 1932-33 season by the Columbia Pictures Corporation, according to the schedule announced yesterday. Joseph Hergesheimer's novel, "Tampico," will be produced as "The Dictator." Two plays of the current season, S.N. Behrman's "Brief Moment" and Preston Sturges's "Child of Manhattan," also will be converted into films.

Billy Hogan of the Holy Name Club knocked out Buster Hardy, Newark welterweight, in the third round of their special 148-pound class bout, which was one of the features of the final indoor amateur boxing tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night.

The authorities investigating the kidnapping and murder of the baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh were admittedly no nearer a solution last night than when the child's body was found twelve days ago, and their only hope appeared to rest in the reward of $25,000 which the State of New Jersey is expected to post today.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Rabbit Maranville got four hits today, and the last one, a single off Hollis Thurston in the tenth, defeated the Robins, 5 to 4, and put the Braves in first place. This marks the first time in years that the Boston National League entry has occupied that proud position this late in the race.

The Van Sweringen Corporation, which controls the Cleveland Terminals Building Company, the Medical Arts Building, the Midland Bank Building and other properties in Cleveland, Ohio, lost $1,591,117 net in 1931, according to its annual report.

The criminal alien squad arrested as a fugitive from justice yesterday a man whom they described as Frederick Joubert Duquesne, 52 years old, a critic, living at 44 West Seventy-fifth Street. They held him all day at Police Headquarters, booked him at Elizabeth Street station at 9 o'clock and announced that the British authorities would call for him today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The House listened and frequently applauded for thirteen minutes this afternoon as Representative Mary Norton of New Jersey, chairman of the District of Columbia Committee, "spoke her mind" about the filibustering tactics of Representative Blanton of Texas, whom she charged with attempting to block the passage of bills designed to improve the capital.

Milton Krompier, undefeated Bronx lightweight, extended his string of victories last night at the closing boxing show of the season at the St. Nicholas Arena when he fought his way to the decision over Johnny Fitzpatrick of the west side in the feature bout of six rounds.

BERLIN, May 23 -- The Boerse began the week with sharp declines. I.G. Farben lost 5 per cent, and losses by the potashes, electricals and mining's averaged 2 per cent. Bonds were extremely weak, business was quiet and the weakness was due to realizations following last week's decline. Reports of an impending Austrian moratorium accentuated the market's nervousness.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Adoption of a platform by the Democratic National Convention "short enough to be memorized by a man with a poor memory" was urged tonight by Newton D. Baker before the Democratic County Central Committee.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 23 -- Dr. Gordon F. Willey, 47 years old, new superintendent of the Westfield State Farm, also known as the Bedford Reformatory for Women, shot and killed himself at about 7 o'clock this morning in the basement of his home on the grounds of the institution. His body was found by his wife.

Construction work has been completed on the new $3,500,000 United States Assay Office on the north side of Old Slip between South and Front Streets. Niles R. Becker, superintendent, announced yesterday. The last of the interior equipment, consisting of shelving for the vaults, is being set in place and the movement of the $2,000,000,000 store, of gold from its present stronghold in the old quarters at 32 Wall Street will start about July 1.

The seven-game winning streak of the Philadelphia Athletics was snapped yesterday when the Yankees made the most of their half-dozen hits at the Yankee Stadium and took the second game of the series, 6 to 5.
In sympathy with a strong wheat market, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday to the best figures of the last two weeks and closed at the top, 7 to 8 points higher than on Saturday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23 -- Yale's track team tonight elected Joseph Patrick Crowley of Milwaukee, shot-put and discus star for the past two seasons, captain for 1933. He succeeds Harold L. Fates of Orange, N.J. Samuels Caldwell of Omaha was named manager to succeed Emmert W. Bates of Detroit.

AUTEUIL, France, May 23 -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, making her first appearance on French courts in two years, showed the gallery in Roland Garros Stadium today that she had lost none of her court wizardry as she paired with Miss Elizabeth Ryan and reached the quarter-finals of women's doubles in the French tennis championships.

BUFFALO, May 23 -- A resolution condemning the efforts of anti-vivisectionists against animal experimentation as "a menace to public safety and an attempt to strike at the well-being of the community in general" was adopted unanimously here today at a meeting of the house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York on the opening day of the 126th annual meeting of the society.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Although personally favoring continuance of American sovereignty in the Philippines pines, W. Cameron Forbes, former Governor General, in a letter made public today, endorsed the Hawes-Cutting Senate bill providing conditional freedom for the islands in between fifteen and nineteen years.

Circumstances may compel the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to bid for an oil monopoly in Chile, it was said yesterday in oil circles here, although the company is opposed to the principle of oil monopolies. The President of Chile last week promulgated a law authorizing the creation of an oil monopoly in that country.

LONDON, May 23 -- With the Anglo-American team matches at Wentworth out of the way, American women golfers headed today for Saunton in North Devonshire for the strongest attack ever made on the one British golfing title that has eluded American hands.

LONDON, May 23 -- The stork markets were dull today, with little business, and prices generally were down. Underwriting arrangements were completed for the E1.500.000 British Columbia loan. With further profit-taking. British Government funds declined.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Lewis, Democrat, of Illinois, today offered a new plan for economic recovery, proposing revision of war debts on the basis of present-day prices and payment of the inter-governmental obligations in commodities.

To the Editor of The New York Times : It is not difficult to believe that government in the United States has become the victim of a badly controlled hysteria. Time was when the public temper was both registered and directed in no small degree by rational discussion and the logic of sound conviction.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Bourse opened today with nearly the whole list considerably lower than Friday's closing prices. Uncertainty over the French internal political situation retarded trading. A good many shares, however, strengthened during the day. although the majority still showed losses at the closing.
At a meeting of the New York Rowing Association held at the New York Athletic Club last night, entries and plans for the annual Memorial Day regatta on the Harlem River were announced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every thoughtful person will be moved to applaud THE TIMES editorial "Responsibilities of Wealth." Fortunately, as one glances down that list of names involved in the transaction so typical of those mad, greedy days of 1928-9, the Radio Pool, one notes that nearly all of them represent what we used to call the nouveau riche.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Senator Borah has broken with a group of administration advisers who sought the weight of his influence in framing a prohibition resubmission plank for the Republican national platform.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The last-place Boston Red Sox turned into a hard-hitting team today behind effective pitching of their left-hander, Bob Weiland, to down the Senators, 6 to 2.

Rudolph Kohlhaas, 48 years old, a machinist, planned to sail tomorrow for his home in Germany with his wife and their adopted daughter, Dorothy, 12 years old, with $6,600 the couple had saved since they came to the United States nine years ago. They had paid $400 for their passage on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg and promised to give away their furniture to neighbors and to the Salvation Army.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Congress and the Supreme Court convened today under police guard to prevent demonstrations by bonus advocates and by Communists.

RENO, Nev., May 23 -- Suits for divorce were filed here today by Mrs. Maya de Chrapovitsky Auchincloss, who charged mental cruelty in her action against Hugh Dudley Auchincloss, investment banker, and by Mrs. Katharine C. Montgomery Firey, who alleged cruelty in her suit against Lewis Milton Firey.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 23 -- Officials of the Consolidated Oil Corporation agreed today at a conference with Governor Harry H. Woodring to take all the output of 6,500 stripper oil wells in Southeastern Kansas, estimated at between 5,000 and 6,000 barrels daily.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Deductions from the vote in the House of Representatives today to legalize and tax 2.75 per cent beer will be laid before the party conventions and the voters in the election. Both the anti-prohibitionists and their opponents will contend that the vote demonstrates entirely different things.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- Rabbi M. N. Weisblatt, who would have been 57 today, died suddenly last night of heart disease at his home here while his family was preparing for his birthday celebration. Rabbi Weisblatt came to this country from Russia, with his wife, Anna Weisblatt, twenty-three years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The claim that he had 231 delegates to the Republican National Convention pledged to him was made tonight by Senator France of Maryland in an open letter addressed to President Hoover.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- A two-day deadlock on tariff schedules in the billion dollar tax bill was broken tonight, when the Senate voted for import duties on lumber and copper.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 23 -- Leonard Martin of the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., and holder of the metropolitan amateur golf championship, eliminated Eric Martin Smith, holder of the British open amateur championship, in the first round of that contest today.

PRETORIA, Transvaal, May 23 -- Professor H.P. Lamont of the University of Pretoria, author of the book "War, Wine and Women," was tarred and feathered today by four men as a protest against anti-Afrikanders sentiments which he was said to have expressed in the book.
TOKYO, May 23 -- Several days are likely to elapse before the new Cabinet can be completed by Admiral Viscount Makoto Saito.

By a coincidence not too fortunate for Governor ROOSEVELT, his speech at Atlanta was printed yesterday in the same newspapers which carried President HOOVER'S long letter to the President of the American Society of Civil Engineers, outlining his plans for legislation and for economic recovery.

PARIS, May 23 -- Relatives of Georges Clemenceau, war-time Premier, declined to be present today at the unveiling of the bronze statue of "The Tiger" in the Champs-Elysees. The statue is at a corner of the Petit Palais and was erected by the municipality of Paris.

HAVANA, May 23 -- Former President Menocal and Colonels Carlos Mendieta and Roberto Mendez Penate, leaders of the unsuccessful revolt last August, were arrested today and held in Fort Cabanas on suspicion of being involved in the revolutionary plot alleged to have been uncovered by the police here last Thursday.

Without disturbing the early forenoon audience of about 100 persons, two young men held up the cashier of the Academy of Music motion picture theatre at 126 East Fourteenth Street yesterday, bound and gagged him and escaped with $4,700.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Dyckman Street ferry carried us gently across the Hudson in the sunlight of a perfect May day. That ferryboat moved as rhythmically, so it seemed to us, as an Italian gondola. A tall, good-looking man played melodies on his violin, and a curly-haired, slightly lame young man sang -- probably unemployed musicians, reduced to ferryboat earnings.

Without disturbing the early forenoon audience of about 100 persons, two young men held up the cashier of the Academy of Music motion picture theatre at 126 East Fourteenth Street yesterday, bound and gagged him and escaped with $4,700.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Dyckman Street ferry carried us gently across the Hudson in the sunlight of a perfect May day. That ferryboat moved as rhythmically, so it seemed to us, as an Italian gondola. A tall, good-looking man played melodies on his violin, and a curly-haired, slightly lame young man sang -- probably unemployed musicians, reduced to ferryboat earnings.
MEXICO CITY, May 23 -- The discovery of a tomb believed to be that of the ancient Mayan Kings at Chichen Itza, in the State of Yucatan, was eported today in a dispatch from Merida.
ROME May 23 (AP) -- A project for weekly air service between Rome and Buenos Aires was presented to the Congress of Transoceanic Fliers today by General Italo Balbo.
LONDON, May 23 -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam. with her modesty and simple, unaffected demeanor, took London by storm today during a crowded first day here.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- In a speech bordering on anger, Senator Watson today replied to an appeal by prominent Democrats and Republicans who asked Congress to forsake partisanship and balance the budget by telling members of the group, in effect, that they are incapable of judging the acts of Congress and incompetent to advise the Senate.

Federal authorities are investigating Mayor Walker's status as an income-tax payer, it became known yesterday as Samuel Seabury presented a mass of new evidence for the Mayor to explain when he makes his first appearance tomorrow as a witness before the Hofstadter committee.

Edward S. Steinam, 67 years old, who, in a confidential executive capacity, held power of attorney for the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. until his retirement four years ago, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the chest as he lay in a bathtub in his suite on the eighth floor of the Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue.

Several luncheons were given yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. N. Baxter Jackson gave one there for Mrs. John K. Roosevelt, Mrs. John M.P. Thatcher, Mrs. Spencer Turner, Mrs. Stone Bouvier, Mrs. Don Morrison Kelley, Mrs. Grover O'Neill and Mrs. Paul Yaccacci.
