The coffee shops which Alice Foote MacDougall built up more than ten years ago with a capital of $38 from a little stand in Grand Central Terminal into a chain of nine large restaurants, doing a business of more than $1,000,000 in 1929, have been hit by the depression.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 24 -- State-created misery stalks New Zealand today as never before, and throughout the land a revolt has arisen against the government. The revolt is none the less dangerous because it is wordless and almost leaderless and because the recent public safety act denies it the means of expression through public demonstration.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A "fundamental readjustment" of the international commercial policy of the United States is necessary "if the foreign loans now outstanding are to be collected," according to a report on American commercial policy and the world crisis issued by the Foreign Policy Association today.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., May 24 -- (AP) -- Dr. Edwin Brant Frost, blind astronomer of Yerkes Observatory near here, said tonight that the discovery of a new planetoid that can attain a proximity of about 4,350,000 miles to the earth was "exceedingly important."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The six-hour day for railroad workers was urged today by A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, in testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission, as a step toward economic recovery.

CLEVELAND, May 24 -- Perry Williams Harvey, 63 years old, Cleveland philanthropist, industrialist and sportsman, died at his Thomasville (Ga.) residence today. Burial will be in the hillside graveyard of his Southern estate at Pebble Hill on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate returned to consideration of the revenue features of the billion-dollar tax bill tonight after a six-day excursion into tariffs, farm relief and general discussions on the economic plight of the country.

Two more fashionable midtown resorts were raided at dinner-time last night and stripped of their furnishings by Federal agents on the staff of Prohibition Administrator Andrew MacCampbell. They were the Chateau Bruno, at 6 West Fifty-third Street, and the Surf Club, at 42 East Fifty-second Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Leopold Stokowski, director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, will conduct more than half of the concerts next season, and four other conductors will divide the remaining time, it was announced after the annual meeting of the board of directors today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- House leaders are planning to begin a series of three-day recesses next month to continue through the national political conventions at Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Seaton Pippin, noted bay mare representing the Seaton Hackney Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore of Moorestown, N.J., kept her undefeated record clear by capturing two events today as the annual Devon Horse Show opened.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Representative Cochran of Missouri told the House today that "hoarded and idle" money of the old, large-size issue amounted to $538,496,159 on April 30. He also put into the record a letter from A.A. Ballantine, Undersecretary of the Treasury, showing the series of the outstanding notes, as well as a list of matured debts on which interest has ceased, amount, amounting to $39,993,670.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial, "More Money and Prices," criticizing the Goldsborough bill, THE TIMES refers to the actual stock of money in 1931 as consisting of gold, silver, minor coin and currency.

TRENTON, N.J., May 24 -- The endorsement of former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York for President by the New Jersey delegates to the Democratic National Convention and a slashing attack on the national Republican Administration by Representative Mary T. Norton of Jersey City, featured the opening session of the Democratic State Convention here today.

Mrs. Eleanor Post Hutton Sturges filed suit for annulment of her marriage to Preston Sturges, playwright, on May 12, in Supreme Court here, it was disclosed yesterday. The suit charges the playwright was not legaily divorced from his first wife, the former Estelle Mudge, when he eloped with the former Miss Hutton in 1930.

The United Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, made public yesterday its pamphlet report for 1931 with a consolidated statement of its income and that of its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, showing a deficit of $466,403 after first and second preferred dividends.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your nobly restrained editorial of this morning on "Uncle Sam's Farm School," in which the Western larch, ripened beef, vigorous eggs and whipped cream were discussed as examples of the Department of Agriculture's published piffle, deserves further comment.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Additional income taxes of $732,008 for 1923 to 1926 must be paid by Albert R. Erskine of South Bend, president of the Studebaker Corporation, the Board of Tax Appeals ruled today.
LONDON, May 24 -- Prime Minister MacDonald delivered a pointed hint to Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, as to the best way of altering an objectionable treaty.

Demanding that the Board of Education "immediately revoke its policy of false economy and retrenchment in education," the Teachers Union, at a special meeting yesterday in Public School 27, East Forty-second Street, voted to send a delegation to a meeting of the board today to protest against consolidation of classes and to urge the reduction of "oversized" classes and the employment of licensed teachers awaiting appointment.

Buyers' Registrations Ahead. An increase in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the same period last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The total for the week was 666, which compared with 613 listed in the previous week and 653 reported for the corresponding week a year ago.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, noted pianist and former Premier of Poland, was the city's guest of honor yesterday at a public reception by Mayor Walker at City Hall, attended by a large group who came to bid the venerable artist farewell on the eve of his departure for Europe.

Federal backing for proposed self-supporting public works and a wider interest on the part of State and local authorities in large-scale model housing were suggested as the "most promising means of aiding in a business revival and relieving unemployment" at a meeting of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
NEW VORK. Viscount and Viscountess Lee of Fareham, now at Mayfair House, will sail Friday on the Europa.

The outflow of gold from this market, which has been Tunning toward countries already surfeited with gold, turned yesterday toward England and Germany, the two nations which suffered most severely last year from a shortage of metallic reserves. A total of $5,219,200 gold was withdrawn from the Federal Reserve Bank for shipment to the two countries, $3,919,200 being consigned to England and $1,300,000 to Germany.

Columbia's varsity 150-pound crew will leave for Poughkeepsie next week as part of the Blue and White fleet that will train there for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, regatta on June 20. The Lion 150-pounders will seek to qualify for an opportunity to represent the Morningside Heights institution in the Junior varsity race, it was announced yesterday by Manager Edward Haines.

LONDON, May 24 -- The British and United States Governments, acting through, normal diplomatic channels and without any conference and trumpet blowing, have nearly completed an arrangement by which the Hoover moratorium arrears due to the United States from Britain for the year ending next month will be paid if and when payments of wardebt annuities are resumed.

ROME, May 24 -- The International Congress of Transoceanic Fliers took a step toward definite conclusions today. After Harold Gatty of the United States had remarked that the speeches delivered so far did not appear to be leading anywhere, General Italo Balbo suggested and the Congress approved the formation of two committees to study problems pertaining particularly to air routes across the northern and southern Atlantic, respectively.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 24 -- The results of the annual vote of the members of the senior class at Princeton University, which were announced by Algernon Roberts, permanent secretary of the class, at the class dinner here tonight, revealed that the majority of the class preferred a Phi Beta Kappa key to a varsity athletic letter and that a large percentage of the class will take up graduate work next year.

Satire -- precisely why, it might be difficult to determine -- seems inherently cool. Perhaps this is so chiefly because satire reports not directly, but in a spirit of sly indirection, of subtly calculating innuendo, with ever a proneness to overstatment or understatement that confesses the literary approach.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In the tabulation of the House vote on the 2.75 per cent beer proposal, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, Representative Whitley of New York appeared as voting both for and against the motion to discharge the committee and thus permit a vote for beer.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- National governmental extravagance, the status of television and broadcasters' problems were some of the subjects touched upon today at the annual convention of the Radio Manufacturers' Association. Following a brief talk by J. Clark Coit, president, Mayor Cermak welcomed the radio men to the city and invited them to come back for the World's Fair next year.

A condensed annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for 1931 was issued yesterday, showing total asests of $941,238,518, against $922,008,793 at the end of 1930, and plant of $832,280,912, against $753,895,079. Investments, including advances to subsidiary and affiliated companies not consolidated, were $78,269,461, against $123,567,554.
After an early improvement, prices on the Cotton Exqhange declined sharply a dollar a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 15 to 16 points.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Local and Eastern operators who recently were active on the buying side of wheat were credited with having been the best sellers of that grain today on the Board of Trade here. Rains in Central Kansas and Nebraska, with some precipitation in parts of Oklahoma and Texas, dampened the ardor or the bulls, who displayed as much anxiety in getting out of their lines as they had done in accumulating them.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 24 -- Playing true to form, the six seeded players in the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship advanced to the quarter final round of play in the annual tournament today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

Preference Both Ways. Attorney General BENNETT'S latest ruling calls attention again to the nature of the special privilege which the voters of this State saw fit to accord to veterans when they approved the preference amendment inserted in the civil service clause of the Constitution in 1929.

All important financial markets declined yesterday. Stock Exchange prices, having lately shown encouraging signs of stability, broke emphatically, to the accompaniment of an increase in the volume of trading. Under the depressing example of United States Government securities, domestic and foreign bonds reacted, many of them to new lows.

BERLIN, May 24 -- After nineteen months of globe-trotting, the flying boat Do-X returned to Germany today in an eight-hour flight from Southampton, England, landing on Mueggel Lake, near Berlin, late in the afternoon. A huge, cheering crowd lined the lake.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Hancock bill to legalize the distribution of birth control information was defeated today by the House Ways and Means Committee in a 20 to 4 vote.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Wes Ferrell was knocked from the mound, and his relief hurler, Sarge Connally, was batted hard as the White Box won their fourth straight game today, defeating Cleveland, 11 to 7. After Vic Frasier faltered in the fourth inning, Tommy Thomas came in and received credit for the victory.

The New Jersey State Police engaged in the hunt for the kidnappers and murderers of the Lindbergh baby spent yesterday rechecking stories told by local residents soon after the kidnapping. Farmers and others dwelling near the Lindbergh home at Hopewell were interviewed again.

Walter L. Clark, president of the Grand Central Art Galleries, has been decorated by the Italian Government for his services in promoting art in this country and Italy, the galleries announced yesterday. The Grand Central Art Galleries built and own the gallery in Venice, Italy, in which American art is shown at the Venice international expositions.

The first eleven railroads to report for April showed net operating incomes of $5,704,000, against $6,692,000 in April, 1931, a decline of 18 per cent, and against $8,854,000 in April, 1930, a drop of 35.5 per cent. Their net operating income in March was $6,848,000, against $7,565,000 in March, 1931, a decline of 9.4 per cent.

CINCINNATI, May 24 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Pirates pounced on Benny Frey in the twelfth inning today, Pie Traynor walloping a triple after the Waner brothers had singled, to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 5 to 3.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 24 -- United States golfers struck a hard blow in the second day's play in the British open amateur championship today, when they gained victories over three of Great Britain's foremost players.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- As the debate continues on the so-called tax bill. Senate Democrats have realized that one of the hardest battles at their Chicago convention will come on tha party's tariff position.
A glance over the report of the Fort Myers Boat and Fishing Club is almost enough to make any one with a desire to go tarpon fishing pack and dash off to Florida in a hurry.

NEWARK, N.J., May 24 (AP) -- Don Brennan pitched a good game for the Bears today, but his defense cracked and Baltimore won, 5 to 2. It was the first time this season any team has taken two straight from the Bears.

DOVER, Del., May 24 -- Delaware Democrats in State convention this afternoon elected six delegates to the national convention pledged to Governor Roosevelt and adopted a platform from which the prohibition question was eliminated.
Criticism of Dr. D. Leigh Colvin's radio talk on Sunday, in which the dry leader characterized women wets as "Bacchantian maidens, parching; for wine" was agran voiced yesterday by wet spokesmen.

TORONTO, May 24 -- S.W. Labrot's consistent 3-year-old, Springsteel, captured the forty-sixth running of the $2,000 added Woodstock Plate, feature at the Woodbine track today, when he scored with comparative ease over the Greentree Stable's Delicacy.

LONDON, May 24 -- Sir Henry Alfred McCardie, justice of the Court of King's Bench, today administered what he characterized as a "public rebuke" to Sir Thomas Edward Scrutton, president of the appeal court which reversed Justice McCardie's decision in the recent "Helen of Troy" case.

At his own suggestion, the salary of the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, was cut from $6,000 to $5,400, and his allowance for rent was cut from $1,500 to $1,350 yesterday at the fourth annual convention of the synod in St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street.

It is sad to think that a Republican National Convention can be held without the presence of the intellectual and moral quorum composed of the senior Senator from Idaho. This was the case in 1924. It is to be the case this year. Mr. BORAH'S enthusiasms and disappointments from 1928 till now, when he is almost at the end of his quadrennial revolution, are known to all.

United States Senator Dwight W. Morrow of New Jersey, who died on Oct. 5, 1931, left a New York estate formally valued at "over $10,000," it was learned yesterday when his widow, Mrs. Elizabeth C. Morrow of Englewood, N.J., and the Bankers Trust Company applied to Surrogate James A. Foley for the appointment of the trust company as ancillary executor of the estate.

Reports that Charles A. Stoneham, owner of the New York Giants, and Lester W. Patterson, Bronx Counts Clerk, bad obtained a pass to visit the mysterious "Miss Helen Smith" in the Women's House of Detention on Monday afternoon were denied yesterday by Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction.

More than 2,000 Girl Scouts, representing 100 troops of the Manhattan Council of the organization, passed in review with the massed colors of their troops before Mrs. Frederick Edey, national president, on the east meadow of Central Park last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Within the next three weeks the Treasury Department expects that foreign governments will have signed agreements with the United States providing for the payment of the arrears of $252,000,000 of war debts on which the one-year Hoover moratorium was granted.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Melvin Ott drove two homers over the right-field wall of Baker Bowl today and Acting Manager Dave Bancroft sent five pitchers to the firing line, but there were not enough home runs or pitchers, and the Giants lost to the Phillies by 11 to 8, twenty-one hits being collected by the-Phils and fourteen by the Giants.

HAVANA, May 24 -- Despite reports of the arrest yesterday afternoon of former Presideat Mario G. Menocal, one of the leaders of the revolt last August, on a charge of being involved in the new revolutionary plot that secret operatives claim to have discovered and that has led to hundreds of arrests during the last few days, it was definitely learned today that General Menocal was now at the Brazilian Legation.

A 49-year-old man who wanted to "live high" was arraigned in Tombs Court yesterday afternoon charged with stealing $65.000 by falsifying the accounts of George H. Burr Co. of 57 William Street, the brokerage firm by which he had been employed for nine years.

Complete quotas for the thirty-six Eastern colleges which are members of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. were announced yesterday following a meeting of the executive and advisory committees of the I.C.A.A.A.A. The total is 209 athletes. The party will leave New York on June 19 for the fifth-sixth annual association championships at Berkeley, Cal., on July 1 and 2.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., May 27 (AP) -- Trinchera, 3-year-old son of Eternal, racing in the colors of the Three D's Stable, made it five in a row today, winning the feature race at Washington Park by a head over Supreme Sweet, with Flag Bearer third.

If the city should decide to resume unification negotiations with the B.M.T. and Interborough "at this most inopportune time" it should at once undertake an independent study of recapture as a method of effecting transit unity and should also take an active part in any public hearings before the Transit Commission, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the commission, declared yesterday in a letter to Mayor Walker.
AUTEUIL, France, May 24 -- Americans swept the boards today in their play in men's and mixed doubles in the French tennis championships.

"So, the first thing I knew, I had written a play myself." In that way the "little grandmother of the Irish theatre" answered questions when American, reporters wanted to know what the Abbey Players were going to do next and why they were so successful and what connection Lady GREGORY had with their good fortune.

A suggestion that the President issue an immediate call for a world economic conference was made yesterday by Otto H. Kahn, partner in Kubn, Loeb Co., and also by John Henry Hammond, partner in Brown Brothers Co., both bankers replying independently to a questionnaire sent out recently by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler as chairman of the Advisory Council of the League of Nations Association, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street.

ISLIP, L.I., May 24 -- Cyril Tolley, former British amateur golf champion who is now located in America, won the low gross prize today at the Timber Point Golf Club, where the members of the New Jersey, Westchester and Long Island teams gathered in anticipation of the annual triangular team matches tomorrow.

LONDON, May 24 -- It was officially announced today that the Stock Exchange would be closed on Saturday. It is the intention of the committee to make weekly decisions for the time being. The announcement caused no surprise among brokers. Business last Saturday was especially poor.

In the tremendous pressure for admission to the examination of Mayor WALKER today by Judge SEABURY is shown the intense public interest in this climax of the legislative investigation. Much more than local concern is involved. The whole nation is watching the inquiry and waiting for its issue.

Commodities were heavy yesterday, the grains and cotton losing the best part of the gain picked up on Monday, with rubber, silk and hides continuing lower. Coffee was up, while sugar was irregular and cocoa heavy. In the spot trading rubber reached a new low for the year at 2.87 cents.
GEORGE EARNSHAW suggested that it was time to go out to the apple orchard.

Although the Provincetown Playhouse can scarcely be said to specialize in providing innocent merriment, it demonstrated last flight that when it chooses it can reach as high a mark in that category as it has attained less often of late in its customary soul-shaking offerings.

WASHINGTON, May 24 --Temporary currency inflation based on United States Government bonds was tentatively suggested today by Senator Glass as a substitute for the Goldsborough bill to stabilize the dollar on a 1926 purchasing level.

After a considerable absence from this neighborhood Jane Cowl has returned in a tenderly romantic play entitled "A Thousand Summers," which was put on at the Selwyn last evening. It is the work of Merrill Rogers, who once wrote a bit of balderdash labeled "Her First Affaire."

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 24 (AP) -- A former California champion was among the Americans who lost in the British amateur golf championship today. He is Douglas Grant and he was the victim of E.R. Tipple in a second-round match by 2 and 1.
LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- Los Angeles welcomed the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America here today with sunshine and high temperature.

Bond prices were irregularly lower in practically all sections of the list yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. As a rule the losses were much smaller than had been the case on many days recently. United States Government bonds were only moderately active, with three of the eleven active issues moving up 2-32 to 6-32 point, while seven lost 3-32 to 17-32 point.

What architects do when not designing buildings is illustrated in the Architects' Hobby Show, which was exhibited privately yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will be opened to the public today under the auspices of the Women's Division, Architects' Emergency Committee.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Hack Wilson hit his fourth homer of the season with two men on in the opening inning of today's game, and the drive helped the Robins even the series with the Braves by a count of 6 to 3.

ALLAHABAD, May 24 -- The close of "Congress week" here was marked today by a revival of All-India National Congress activities, which had seemed to be dropping off recently under pressure of the government's ordinances.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 24 (AP) -- After agreeing that Speaker Garner should have the State's forty-six votes at the national convention, Texas Democrats tonight, after barely averting a riot, adopted a resolution proposing resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment to the States.

Much of the expected opposition to proposed legislative action to ban the sale of loose milk in New York City turned out to be ephemeral yesterday when the matter came up at the Board of Health's regular weekly meeting. Out of 425 wholesale loose milk dealers in the city, all of whom had been invited to attend the meeting, only forty-three were present.

LAKELAND, Fla., May 24 -- The honorary deerree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon John Ringling, circus owner and art connoisseur, at the commencement of Southern College today. He received the degree in absentia.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Federal prohibition enforcement during the present fiscal year will cost $11,069,500. Of this, $1,610,419 was spent in New York, or almost twice as much as in any other State.

On the arrival of the two twenty-eight-knot liners Rex and Conte di Savoia, in October and November respectively, they will be berthed at Pier 86 North River, recently vacated by the Leviathan. The present Italian Line piers, 95 and 97, are not long enough to accommodate them, according to Colonel M. Serrati, one of the three directors of the newly formed merger of the Lloyd Sabaudo, Navigazione Italiana and Cosulich eteamship lines.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 24 -- With few exceptions, only three of special consequence, the sixteen matches played in the opening round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association title tournament today at the Century Country Club produced the results that were anticipated.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- No comment was forthcoming from the Bureatu of Internal Revenue today on reports from New York that the Federal Government was investigating the income tax returns of Mayor Walker of New York.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday May 25 -- While the 3,000 outdoor workers of the Shanghai Postoffice refused mediation today in their strike against alleged use of postal funds by Nanking for non-postal activities and the strike spread to Peiping and Tientsin, Wang Ching-wei, president of the Executive Council, announced that the government was prepared to adopt drastic measures to safeguard communications and maintain peace and security.

TORONTO, May 24 (Canadian Press) -- Buffalo took two games from Toronto today before a holiday crowd of 6,000. The Bisons won the first game, 2 -- 1, scoring the winning run in the ninth on a walk, a sacrifice and a single by Crouse. Then they captured the second, 4 -- 0.

LONDON, May 24 -- Frederick Wellington Ayer, American actor and playwright, married Miss Enid Margaret Cooper, British actress, at the Register's office here today. They met when both were appearing in "Late Night Final," the Louis Weitzenkorn play known on Broadway under the title of "Fine Star Final."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Despite President Hoover's opposition to expanding public works at this time. Senate Democrats today decided to insist on $500,000,000 for this purpose in their unemployment relief bill scheduled to be introduced tomorrow by Senator Wagner.

Representatives of women's organizations and poetry societies in New York City gathered yesterday afternoon at the Hall of Fame on the campus of New York University, University Heights to pay tribute to eight American poets and George Washington, "patron of arts," in a ceremony arranged by Miss Anita Browne as part of the observance of Poetry Week.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 24 -- The Yale golf team won permanent possession of the cup offered by the Eastern Intercollegiate Association by winning the league title this year for the third time, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, secretary of the league.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was requested yesterday to broaden the scope of its investigation into warehousing and storage charges and practices in the New York port district to include all ports of the North Atlantic or to begin contemporaneous independent investigations of conditions at the other ports.

The Congress of Transoceanic Fliers at Borne should be able to solve the problem of regular services between Europe and tlie Americas, if anybody can. Among the delegates are aviators who have flown the Atlantic by way of the Faroes and Iceland, the Grand Circle, and from Africa to Brazil.

The man arrested here on Monday as Captain Frederick Joubert Duquesne, "cleverest and most dangerous" agent of the Central Powers in the World War, was placed in the Federal House of Detention yesterday to be held on a thirteen-year-old warrant until word comes from London as to whether he is wanted by Great Britain for trial on a charge of murder on the high, seas.
HARBIN, Manchuria, May 24 (AP) -- Japanese troops routed 4,000 Chinese irregulars today in a sweeping drive that took the Japanese into Hulan, four miles north of Harbin.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) -- Jimmy Collins, Cardinal first baseman, hit two homers and a single today, giving the Cardinals an 8-to-6 victory over the Cubs, and by increasing his home runs to eleven for the season, took the National League leadership.
Student opposition to the increased fees recently voted by the Board of Higher Education continued at Hunter and City Colleges yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 24 -- J.P. Morgan, financier, appears as plaintiff and defendant in the same action, the papers for which were filed in the County Clerk's office here today. He is suing as trustee of the trust fund created by the late J.P. Morgan, his father, for the benefit of Juliet P. Hamilton and Louisa P. Morgan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen B. Stetson was the only loser among the veterans as the first round was played today in the tournament for the women's golf championship of Philadelphia. She bowed before Miss Jane McCullough of Philadelphia, 2 up.

MONTREAL, May 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Royals sent Rochester from second place to fifth and moved to within a game of Newark when they won both ends of a doubleheader from Rochester today before 17,500 persons. The scores were 11-6 and 5-2.

Reopening of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, which was closed last October because of the non-liquidity and depreciation of its assets, was advanced materially yesterday with the submission to Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, of the proposed board of directors of the reorganized institution.

In order to obtain timing of awards of new issues of State and municipal bonds so as to synchronize better with market conditions, a movement is on foot in municipal banking circles, which if successful, will greatly facilitate the distribution of new bonds, it is believed.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,225,350 barrels, compared with 3,237,400 in the preceding week, a decrease of 12,050 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Production east of California averaged 1,721,850 barrels daily, against 1,717,900 in the preceding week.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 23 -- For the present at least, Japan's plans for the colonization of Manchuria by means of a vast State-sponsored program of migration are in abeyance. Growing Manchurian opposition to the scheme, coupled with a rising realization of the difficulties involved, may force abandonment of this dream of empire-building.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Although he wabbled precariously in the eighth inning and had to be relieved, Izzy Goldstein, recruit pitcher for the Tigers got credit for a 6-to-5 victory over the Browns today.

The two recent votes on prohibition in the House of Representatives offer an interesting comparison. On March 14 the question was whether to take up for discussion the Beck-Linthicum resolution resubmitting the Eighteenth Amendment to the States.

MILWAUKEE, May 24 -- After fiery debates, the national convention of the Socialist party today adopted a plank calling for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and voted for loyal cooperation with the American Federation of Labor as against any policy implying hostility to the accepted labor movement of the United States.

Money market was lifeless, with virtually no business of size being reported in any section, while the quotations for all classes remained unchanged. Stock Exchange day loans were 2 1/2 per cent, street trades, 1 1/4, and Federal funds 1/8. Time money was nominally quoted at 1 1/2, for all dates.

After a run of nearly twelve weeks, Florenz Ziegfeld's musical show, "Hot-Cha!" featuring Bert Lahr, Lupe Velez and Buddy Rogers, will be withdrawn from the Ziegfeld Theatre on Saturday night. It is possible that "Hot-Cha!" will be transferred on Monday to another Broadway theatre, probably the Globe.

RYE, N.Y., Wednesday, May 25 -- Walter T. Leon and Fred Heyman of New Rochelle won the Westchester County contract bridge pair championship and the custody of the J. Noel Macy Trophy when play in the final round of the annual tournament, which started three weeks ago with 368 entrants, wound up at the Westchester Country Club here early this morning.

The balance sheet of the Van Sweringen Corporation, a real estate holding company, for Dec. 31 shows that $15,000,000 segregated assets were eliminated in 1931 and that notes payable were reduced from $10,087,000 to $2,595,399. This reflected the return to O.P. and M.J. Van Sweringen of United States Government obligations against which the notes had been issued.

The fifth victory in six 1932 starts was scored yesterday by Ha Ha, now bearing the silks of the Latin Stable. The chestnut son of Polymelian, which won the first race of the metropolitan season for W.R. Coe, was a driving winner in the thirty-third running of the featured Harlem Claiming Stakes at Belmont Park.

A pictorial primer of some of the causes behind the depression is offered, in "A Picture of America," prepared by Charles Gross and published by Simon Schuster. In headlines and snapshots it shows that, while America's payroll for productive work done in a year amounts to about $25,000,000,000, the goods produced on this payroll cost the consumer $70,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Plans of the three large Insull operating companies for meeting their mid-year debt maturities took definite form today, when they applied to the Illinois Commerce Commission for permission to sell an aggregate of $70,000,000 of bonds.

Preparation of a plan to revise the capitalization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway in conformity with a recent order of the Interstate Commerce Commission is proceeding and may result in an announcement next week, it was said yesterday in financial circles.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Super-Intendent of Banks, had some "motive" for acting as he did toward the Bank of United States, "suppressing reports of his examiners" and "lying" in his annual report to Governor Roosevelt in 1929, Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, charged yesterday in summing up at Mr. Broderick's trial.

Stocks closed nearly at their low points for the day on the Stock Exchange yesterday in trading almost as heavy as on Monday. The turnover exceeded 900,000 shares. The market opened irregular and turned reactionary early. Particular weakness was noted in public utility and tobacco issues and in some railroad stocks.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., May 24 -- Invigorated by his twenty-five-day stay here, Governor Roosevelt will start back North tomorrow prepared to plunge into the final drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

DUBLIN, May 24 (AP) -- President de Valera tonight was preparing to dispatch within a few days his answer to Great Britain's note regarding the payment of about $11,000,000 in land annuities to the British Treasury. The question of annuities arose when the Republican administration of the Free State decided it would try to put through legislation withholding payment.

PARIS, May 24 -- In the presence of President Albert F. Lebrun, Edouard Herriot, Radical Socialist leader, listened today for two hours while first Premier Andre Tardieu, then Finance Minister P.E. Flandin set forth for his guidance the situation in which they are relinquishing the country's affairs into his hands.
LONDON, May 24 -- Two famous fliers met for the first time today and "talked shop." One was the Prince of Wales, the other Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam.

The Treasury Department's monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of May 1 shows the following principal changes during April. Gold earmarked for foreign hanks is deducted, sold released from earmark is added:

UNION CITY, N.J., May 24 -- James Markstein, 44 years old, proprietor of a restaurant on Twenty-seventh Street, near the Public Service Transportation Company's car barns in this city, shot and killed one of three hold-up men who made a futile attempt to rob him today of $5,000 he had just drawn from the bank.

The personal quarrels which broke out in the Socialist National Convention at Milwaukee, after the unanimous nomination of Mr. NORMAN THOMAS for the Presidency, will probably not disrupt the party. It has long been made up of members who do not see eye to eye in everything.

The thirty-three competitive applications for bus franchises in Queens, submitted to the Board of Estimate on May 20, were referred to the Division of Franchises yesterday by the committee of the whole, with instructions to investigate the financial responsibility of the applicants, their proposals as to service, type of buses, transfer facilities and other factors, and to report back to the committee not later than June 7.

The American Red Cross was praised as a distinctive and characteristic contribution of the United States to the welfare of humanity by Dr. John H. Finley, speaking yesterday afternoon at an informal reception for college women at the Red Cross Building, 315 Lexington Avenue. The reception was under the auspices of the committee on clubs and colleges of the New York Red Cross chapter.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Columbia University will row in the first heat of the varsity 150-pound crew race which opens the American Henley Saturday.

BERLIN, May 24 -- After a hesitant opening, with selling orders diminished, the Boerse became steadier today, the improvement continuing after the close on the Curb Market. The money market was unchanged. Bonds were weak, losing 1 to 2 per cent.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The foreign affairs committee of the Reichstag today adopted a resolution requesting the government to notify Poland that any attempt by Polish raiders to interfere with the sovereignty of the Free City of Danzig would be considered an affront to Germany.

John Fatseas led New York University's freshman track team to a 72 1/2 to-44 1/2 dual meet victory over the Rutgrers freshmen at Ohio Field yesterday, winning three events, placing second in a fourth and third in a fifth. Fatseas won the 120-yard high hurdles, the 220-yard low hurdles and the discus throw, accounting in all for twenty points.

BOSTON, Wednesday, May 25 -- The Lee, Higginson Trust Company announced early this morning that it would discontinue operation as soon as depositors could be paid off and arrangements made for turning over the assets of trusts in its charge.

The Actors' Equity Association will make no formal reply to the statement issued on Monday by Lee Shubert attacking the Equity council for its refusal last December to sanction Sunday night performances in the legitimate theatres.

Mayor Walker and Commlssioner Mulrooney will address 268 probationary patrolmen who have completed a six months' course in the Police Academy Recruits' Training School tonight at their graduation exercises in Madison Square Garden. The guests of honor will be a group of foreign Consuls General in New York.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 24 -- A truck owned by the Dittmar Powder Company, Inc., of 201 Franklin Avenue, Mount Vernon, was blown to bits at Crugers, four miles south of here, today when its contents, 100 sticks of dynamite and 200 percussion caps, consigned to the Rockefeller estate, exploded when the truck caught fire.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 24 -- The Cascades Club was a popular rendezvous for the Homestead colonists today. Mr. and Mrs. Charles U. Caesar, Mr. and Mrs. B.W, Edwards and Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dillon were among those Who entertained there for luncheon and golf.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- Grounds for divorce recognized by the Methodist Episcopal Church were greatly broadened tonight when the thirty-first quadrennial General Conference of Methodism, in session in the Municipal Auditorium, adopted the report of its committee on state of the church.

Dick Shikat, 218, of Philadelphia, former world's champion, won from Sam Stein, 200, of Newark, in 28:33 in the feature finish wrestling bout before a crowd of 7,000 at the New York Coliseum last night.

A reckless youngster of perhaps 13 years gave several hundred passengers on the New Haven Railroad's crack Puritan Express and a hundred or more passersby on upper Park Avenue a horror-stricken few minutes early last evening when he seemed to have trapped himself hopelessly in the path of the speeding train.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The eagerly awaited convocation of the new Prussian Diet with its 162 National Socialist (Nazi) Deputies failed today to produce a sensation and, so far as curiosity went, finished a poor second to the arrival of the flying boat Do-X as a popular attraction.

aMayor James J. Walker will face Samuel Seabury from the witness stand today at a public hearing of the Hofstadter Committee. He will be called upon to render an accounting of his conduct in the office he has held since January, 1926.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Under the sales tax proposed today in the Senate by Senator Walsh of Massachusetts levies excluded from the tax bill would be automobiles, trucks, accessories, tires and tubes, chewing gum, radios, real estate conveyances, oil transportation by pipe line and lubricatting oil.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- More than 75,000 persons marched through Red Square today before Joseph Stalin, War Commissar Voroshiloff and other government officials, tying up traffic for three hours in Soviet Russia's annual physical culture parade.

BUFFALO, May 24 -- "Vigorous, unanimous disapproval" of the proposal by Governor Roosevelt's Committee to Review Medical and Hospital Problems, favoring the establishment of clinics under the direction of the State for the treatment of work-men's compensation cases, was voted today by the Medical Society of the State of New York in its annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Hoover has taken a hand in the preparation of a prohibition plank for the Republican platform with the hope of placating the wets and of averting the third party threat which some party observers have read into Senator Borah's decision to stay aloof from the national convention.

Iona School captured the Manhattan division baseball championship for the first time by defeating All Hallows Institute, 6 to 2, yesterday at Mosholu Field for its eleventh triumph in as many Manhattan C.H. S.A.A. contests.

With two rival protective committees seeking deposits from holders of Republic of El Salvador bonds, Series A, B and C, because of the government's insistence on taking over the customs receipts from the fiscal representative of the bankers, the Manufacturers Trust Gompany, fiscal agent, announced yesterday that funds had been received sufficient to pay the interest due on July 1 on the Series A bonds.

The statement three years ago by Dr. SIMON FLEXNER that "much of "our present-day knowledge of "medical science is due to experiments upon dogs" is testimony from the highest authority. It puts dogs among the great benefactors of the human race.

The jury was completed in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court yesterday on the second day of the trial of Isidor J. Kresel, general counsel of the defunct Bank of United States, on a perjury indictment growing out of his testimony nearly a year ago at the trial which resulted in the conviction of Bernard J. Marcus, Saul Singer and Herbert Singer, officials of the bank, for misapplication of $8,000,000 of its funds.

Fire losses in New York City last year totaled $15,363,020, a decrease of $2,753,285 from the figure for 1930, Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman said in his annual report, submitted yesterday to Mayor Walker. Malicious false alarms of fire in 1931 increased at the approximate rate of six a day, or a total increase of 2,131 over the previous year.

Led by its captain, Joe McCluskey, national and intercollegiate two-mile champion, Fordham had little difficulty in conquering City College in their annual track and field meet yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium. The Rams captured eleven first places of the fourteen at stake and won by a 78-48 score.

The stock market, after a lower opening, continued to drift steadily downward to new low levels for the bear market in the morning session yesterday. Early in the afternoon prices were slightly steadier, but they sagged in the final hour and were near the lowest levels of the day at the close.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which has been in existence forty-one years, was assured another year today by the signing of an agreement between Henry E. Goegell, manager and treasurer of the Chicago Orchestral Association, and James C. Petrillo, president of the Chicago Federation of Musicians, who have been in a friendly controversy for the last three months.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Restoration of a group of special excise taxes voted by the House but stricken from the revenue bill in the Senate Finance Committee's compromise with the Treasury appeared inevitable tonight after the Senate had whittled $14,000,000 from the measure and apparently had its knives whetted for more.

Mayor Walker lashed back at his "critics" last night before an audience of 18,000 men and women assembled in Madison Square Garden to watch the graduation exercises of the Class of May, 1932, of the Police College. He proudly maintained, "I am still Mayor of New York," and said bitter things about "criticism predicated on individual ambition; criticism arising out of political jealousy; criticism sometimes emanating from vindictiveness."
President Hoover joined with men prominent in banking and public utilities yesterday in honoring George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York.
The Hunterdon County grand jury will take up the case against John H. Curtis, accused of obstructing justice through his hoaxing of Colonel Lindbergh, at Flemington, N.J., this morning.

Fighting desperately for his political life, Mayor James J. Walker matched wits yesterday with Samuel Seabury at a Hofstadter committee hearing. His Honor was heartened somewhat by the vociferous support of the many Tammany braves present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am quite as desirous as any one to see a stability in the purchasing power of the monetary standard, but I do not believe this can be effected by changing the gold standard or by having a managed standard based on the price level of many other commodities.

The commencement exercises of the Class of 1932 of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking will be held tonight at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, with 215 graduates receiving certificates. The address will be delivered by Dr. J. Duncan Spaeth, Professor of English at Princeton University.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 25 (Canadian Press) -- Tariff bulletins have gone forward to customs appraisers effective today on the importations of tomatoes and strawberries. In the case of tomatoes when entered from the United States or other countries outside the empire, the duty value shall be 3 cents a pound above the invoice price in Canadian funds.

LONDON, May 25 -- W.M.G. Singer's Orwell, winner of the Two Thousand Guineas, and four other American-owned thoroughbreds remained in the English Derby field of twenty-three horses when the final acceptances were posted today for the one and one-half mile classic at Epsom Downs June 1.

As Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan was broadcasting a patriotic address in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, a man who later described himself as Paul Chepoloff, of 243 Henry Street, ran onto the speakers' dais, pushed the Borough President to one side and shouted in the microphone:

Payment of part of the past due interest on three Peruvian loans will be made beginning today from funds which were on deposit with the fiscal agents prior to the issuance on May 29, 1931, of a decree by the Peruvian Government suspending temporarily the payment of service charges on the entire public debt of the republic.

Marguerite Sylva's oft-postponed production, of 'Carmen" took place last night in the Chanin Theatre before a well-filled house at prices scaled from a 510 orchestra down. The opera was given in English, in an arrangement including spoken dialogue, apparently without cuts, and entirely without scenery.

A code of unfair advertising practices has been approved by the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies, it is announced by the latter organization. A review committee is planned to consider cases which the National Better Business Bureau is unable to decide to the satisfaction of the parties concerned.

More than 400 unappointed school teachers and sympathizers filled the hall of the Board of Education to overflowing yesterday at a meeting of the board to protest against the retrenchment program in the education system which will prevent their employment.

Find Past Due Accounts Gaining. Past due accounts were reviewed by dress credit managers at a meeting held at the Garment Credit. Conference Club under the auspices of the bureau of trade relations of the Credit Clearing House. It was found that a number of retail accounts indicated previously as likely to be slow have now definitely entered that classification.
NEWARK, N.J., May 25 (AP) -- Baltimore beat Newark, 7 to 6, to win their third successive victory over the Bears. The victory enabled the Orioles to tie Newark for first place.

SEATTLE, May 25 (AP) -- Earl Campbell, graduate manager of the University of Washington, announced today that only the Husky varsity crew will compete in the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., next month.

LONDON, May 25. -- A move to permit the Treasury to purchase silver as well as gold to protect sterling was made today in the House of Commons. Although it was defeated, it was championed by two strong leaders of the Conservative party.

The home board of Congregational and Christian Churches, which maintains missions in sixteen foreign lands, went on record yesterday as strongly opposed to the granting of a Congressional pardon to Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, E.J. Lord and Albert O. Jones, the three male defendants in the Hawaii murder case.

After an early decline yesterday that carried quotations more than a quarter cent below the high levels of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered the loss and ended unchanged to a point higher than on Tuesday. Weakness in securities and new low record for rubber had a depressing influence for a time but short covering brought best figures of the day in the closing dealings.

In a double-header marked by four home runs, all in the first game, Jersey City broke even with Reading at Jersey City yesterday, the home club winning the first game, 5 to 4, and losing the second, a seven-inning contest, 4 to 3. Horn, Legett and Barton connected for the circuit for the Keys, while Jackie Warner poled a four-base drive for Jersey City.

MONTREAL, May 25 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals won the series from Rochester, three games to one, when they took the final contest today, 7-6 Montreal scored two runs in the ninth to win following Puccinelli's fourteenth homer in the first half with two on base.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- Asserting that "the present industrial order is un-Christian, unethical and anti-social, because it is largely based on the profit-motive, which is a direct appeal to selfishness," the quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at its closing session appealed today to "the conscience of mankind to create a social way of life in which all men have opportunity to develop their capacities to the fullest possible extent."

CHICAGO, May 25. -- The Illinois Commerce Commission today authorized the Commonwealth Edison Company, the People's Gas, Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois to issue a total of $70,000,000 of mortgage bonds, in accordance with applications received yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Federal civil income tax liabilities of Henry M. Blackmer, Denver oil man who is self-exiled in France, have been compromised for $3,669,784.47, according to a Treasury announcement.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 25. -- It is reliably reported in government circles that Bolivia will formally offer her good offices to Peru and Mexico this week in an effort to settle the diplomatic rupture that grew out of Peru's declaration that the Mexican Minister and other members of the legation in Lima were persona non grata.

PARIS, May 25 -- Prices on the Bourse fell again today, with almost the whole list showing serious losses. The international stocks, more affected than French domestics, weakened under the influence of a sharp decline in Canadian Pacific, which dropped 20 per cent in value in the day.

MEXICO CITY, May 25 -- Governor Lugo of Hidalgo today ordered the seizure of the French-owned Cruz Azul Portland cement factory in Tula and turned it over to the workers. The seizure was the first under the State expropriation law, promulgated April 25.

Through an exchange of stock the New Amsterdam Casualty Company proposes to acquire control of the United States Casualty Company, and has called a meeting of stockholders to he held on June 14. The plan provides for the exchange of one share of New Amsterdam for two shares of United States Casualty, of which there are 60,000 shares outstanding.

It is nearly fifty years since the appearance of the first volume of A History of the People of the United States, From the Revolution to the Civil War. Palpably modeled after MACAULAY, and in its manner re-echoing- some of his pompous redundancies, it revealed to many that American history could be made interesting:

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Business, industrial and financial leaders of the Middle West today joined the movement begun by the Federal Reserve Board a week ago to study ways to expand credit for commercial purposes and thus stimulate business and relieve unemployment.

It is a friend of the President who describes the probable prohibition plank of the coming Republican platform as " tepid resubmission." All the reports have for some time been to the effect that Mr. HOOVER will approve some declaration of that kind.

Plans for the construction of a museum of shipbuilding and other arts of the sea at a cost of about $10,000,000 were announced here yesterday by Homer L. Ferguson, president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 25 (AP) -- President Hoover, turning to the press of the nation, tonight discussed means of aiding the nation's economic situation, and rallying public opinion in local communities behind a breaking of the legislative jam in Congress.
CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) -- Advancing again under a first-inning barrage, Pittsburgh today took a second game from the Cincinnati Reds, 9 to 4. The victory gave the Pirates sixth place.

BOSTON, May 25 -- The Ford Motor Company shows a loss of $53,586,000 for 1931, according to its balance sheet filed with the State Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation yesterday, the only statement which becomes public of the company's financial operations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25 -- The Yale University Athletic Association board of control today announced approval of seventy-seven sports awards to members of the Tale University track and tennis teams and the freshman baseball, track and polo teams, as well as to the winners in the varsity and freshman tennis tournament.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 25 -- Although outhit, eight to four, Harvard beat the Brown nine by 5 to 2 on Soldiers Field today in the opening game of the series. Scoring all of its runs in the first four innings. Harvard then settled down to play a steady defensive game.

To the Editor at The New York Times: I has been my custom for many years to call attention to May 30 as the Memorial Day of the Grand Army of the Republic. This day has been adopted by all veterans of the different wars in which this country has been engaged.
An Emergency Order. Closing of all the publie forests of this State is by order of Acting Governor LEHMAN. For almost two weeks what the foresters call "fire weather" has prevailed.

A letter from Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, submitting fifteen recommendations for the examination and consideration of the advisory board of the school for the Pulitzer Prize for reporting for 1931 was made public yesterday by the dean.
NAPO RIVER, Oriente, Ecuador, April 26 (By mail via Guayaquil) -- We are approaching the Peruvian frontier, and this story will be mailed at the last Ecuadorean outpost, Rocafuerte.

PROBABLY Mickey Walker and Paulino would have done well in the old days when fighters were "gentlemen of the fancy" and anything less than fifty rounds was just a pugilistic sprint. Certainly Paulino is a throw-back to the earlier era when hardy heroes pounded one another for hours with bare knuckles. Padded gloves cramp his style. Short bouts baffle him.

ROME, Thursday, May 26 -- The International Congress of Transoceanic Fliers closed, after a night session lasting into the early hours of this morning, in an atmosphere of fierce debate, occasioned by a motion proposed by General Italo Balbo Italian Air Minister, in favor of freedom of the air.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Two officials of the Updike Grain Company, a subsidiary of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, were suspended tonight from membership in the Chicago Board of Trade and the grain company itself was ordered deprived of corporate privileges in the Exchange's clearing house.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., May 25. -- Thirty-eight men who asserted that they had been "called by God," to advertise radio sermons and solicit subscriptions for a ten-volume edition of the collected sermons, were in the county jail tonight for violations of a borough ordinance.

There was a brief recess during the afternoon testimony of Mayor Walker yesterday. The members of the investigating committee spent five or six minutes in the ante-chamber for a breathing spell and then filed back to the platform.
"The Man Who Changed His Name," the Edgar Wallace play starring Fay Bainter, will continue its engagement at the Broadhurst Theatre, instead of closing on Saturday night, as previously reported.

LONDON, May 25 -- With the exception of British Government funds, the stock markets today had a depressing appearance following disappointing foreign news. A better showing in revenue returns was responsible for recovery in the government list after considerable fluctuating.
MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 25 -- Dave Martin, America's chief remaining hope, was eliminated from the British amateur golf championship today.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Relief from "oppressive terms" of copyright laws and liberalization of the anti-trust laws were among the points touched upon by John W. Van Allen, general manager of the Radio Manufacturers' Association, in a talk before the radio convention here today.

Collateral held by William Fox against a note for $2,300,000 of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., was sold at auction for $450,000 yesterday by Adrian Muller Son, auctioneers, at 18 Vesey Street. The note was part of the consideration paid to Mr. Fox in April, 1930, for his controlling interest in the Fox Film Corporation, represented by 151,000 shares of Fox Class B stock.

Comet or asteroid ? Astronomers have been asking that question about two small bodies which are not more than a mile or two in diameter and which, if pulverized, would provide barely enough dust to cover Manhattan Island lightly. One was discovered by the Belgian astronomer DELPORTE last March and the other by the German REINMUTH in April.

Shipments of gold to England and Germany continued yesterday, but on a smaller scale than on the preceding day. As a result of yesterday's shipment of $1,188,600 to England and $500,000 to Germany, the two-day movement to these countries amounts to $5,007,800 for the former and $1,800,000 for the latter.

PRINCTON, N.J., May 25 -- Coach Keene Fitzpatrick has selected thirteen members of the undefeated Princeton varsity track team to participate in the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. meet to be held at Berkeley, Cal., July 1 and 2.

Except for momentary steadiness early in the afternoon, stocks continued their downward trend persistently throughout yesterday's trading session on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading volume continued to increase, with a total turnover for the day of 1,308,302 shares.

Without authority from any of the union's officers and without advising them of his action, Jacob S. Solomon, secretary of the organising committee of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, secretly destroyed vouchers and records of the expenditures of close to $1,500,000 between 1926 and 1930 because he feared "spies" would gain access to the records.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25. -- The Summer flower show at the Newport Casino on July 6 and 7 is assured. This was decided at a joint meeting of the Newport Garden Association and the Newport Horticultural Society this afternoon at Penn Craig, the home of Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster, president of the former organization.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Many and varied were the trials and trlbulations which beset Freddy Fitesimmons at Baker Bowl today, but he struggled on to a 12-to-8 victory over the Phillies, while his fellow-Giants pounded three pitchers for seventeer hits, among them Bill Terry's tentt home run.

Max D. Steuer, special prosecutor, continued yesterday at the trial of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, the summing up he had begun on Tuesday morning, reiterating many times his admittedly unconfirmed "suspicion" that Mr. Broderick had had a "motive" for acting as he did toward the Bank of United States.
PARIS, May 25 -- Ambassador Walter E. Edge laid the cornerstone today for the new United States Government Building here, where it is intended to house the embassy and consulate.
At its annual meeting last night at the Art Centre, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street, the American Institute of Graphic Arts elected the followingofficers :

SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 25 -- The Brazilian Provisional Government found a solution for the serious situation in this city by appointing Paulistan elements to fill the vacancies in the Sao Paulo Cabinet. Quiet prevails once more after yesterday's street fighting, which resulted in several casualties and the wrecking of tyro newspaper plants.

The application of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company to list its new $5 par value shares on the New York Stock Exchange reveals that the Standard Oil Company of Indiana on May 2 held 971,897 shares of Pan American common stock and 2,301,398 shares of the Class B common stock.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25 -- Reduction of the proposed $21,000,000 bond issue for road and institutional construction to $18,000,000 was voted today by Governor Moore, Treasurer Middleton and Controller McCutcheon, who constitute the State issuing authorities.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 26. -- Admiral Viscount Makoto Saito completed his new Cabinet yesterday and it will be inducted into office today.

ST. LOUIS. May 25 (AP) -- After receiving a ring today for his part in helping the St. Louis Cardinals win the world's championship last year Burleigh Grimes today pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 3-to-0 victory over his former team-mates. He allowed seven hits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to see the specific directions of the Volstead law regarding alcoholic content, and similar regulations, repealed and such matters left to the States, as the Eighteenth Amendment provides.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- In surprising upsets, last year's winner and runner-up were defeated today in the quarter-final round of the women's Philadelphia golf championship tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The first eighteen railroads to report for April showed net operating incomes of $6,936,000, against $8,924,000 in April, 1931, a drop of 22.2 percent, and against $11,801,000 in April, 1930, a fall of 41.2 percent. Their net operating income in March was $8,578,000 against $9,670,000 in March, 1931, a decline of 11.2 per cent.
The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Harvey D. Gibson is chairman, voted $1,461,225 yesterday for expenditures in June. The sum was part of the $18,000,000 collected last Winter.

DUBLIN, May 25 (Canadian Press). -- The Seanad Eireann (Irish Senate) tonight voted 35 to 21 to adjourn until June 6. Te decision came after submission by President Eamonn de Valera of his bill abolishing the Parliamentary oath to the British Crown and a short exchange between Senator Joseph Connolly and Oliver St. J. Grogarty.

Jewelry valued at $15,000 was stolen from Mrs. Frederic Pruyn in the apartment she shares with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Fellowes Morgan, at 510 Park Avenue on the afternoon of May 18, it was made known yesterday by the police of the East Sixty-seventh Street station.

HARBIN, Manchuria, April 25. -- Irregular Chinese soldiers and bandits are harrying the countryside in North Manchuria to such an extent that the peasant farmers dare not leave their crenelated walled villages to go to their fields to plow. Even around the larger towns and cities the prevalence of raiders is such that few dare leave the narrow zone where the police still maintain some authority.

LONDON, May 25. -- News of negotiations now proceeding in Washington to arrange bookkeeping details for the payment of the British arrears on war-debt annuities suspended during the Hoover moratorium aroused considerable misunderstanding in Parliament today.

Manual Training High School captured the Colonel Robert M. Thompson Trophy, emblematic of the city P.S.A.L. lacrosse championship, for the nineteenth time since 1910 by defeating Erasmus Hall, defending titleholder, 4 to 2, at Erasmus Field yesterday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 25 -- Colgate made a clean sweep of its annual baseball series with Syracuse by blanking the Orange, 4 to 0, at Hendricks Field today.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Walters has come from Wilmington, N.C., to the Pierre, where she will remain until joining Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope in Newport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter signed "G.W.D." published in THE TIMES hits an immensely important banking matter so squarely that I am moved to suggest it deserves the thoughtful consideration of every bank executive and director.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- (AP) -- The $10,000,000 liner, Manhattan, newly completed at Camden, broke away from her moorings at the Philadelphia Navy Yard in a swift tide today, but quick work by the crew saved her from damage.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 25 -- Major J. Divine, Negro religious leader who had conducted what was known as "Heaven" at Sayville, L.I., was convicted by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Lewis J. Smith here today on an indictment charging that he had maintained a public nuisance at 72 Macon Street, Sayville, where he had conducted a religious centre.

The St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) stood last night apparently on the verge of receivership, an insufficient number of bonds having been received at the close of business to make operative a refinancing plan on which continuance of the road in its present status depends.

Until Typographical Union No. 6 agrees to discuss the proposal of a wage reduction the Printers' League (Closed Shop Section) of the New York Employing Printers' Association will refuse to take up the matter of a new agreement to replace the one expiring on Oct. 1, the employers announced yesterday.

The comment of Senator GLASS on the Goldsborough bill was to have been expected from a public man of his sense and knowledge. He said in the Senate that ordering' the Federal Reserve to put prices back to the level of four or five years ago was asking flat impossibilitieis.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 25 -- Army resumed its winning stride in baseball today by defeating Union, 7 to 3, in a fast game. The up-Staters started well, nicking Coughlin, Army's big southpaw, for three hits in the opener, one of them a slashing triple by Ackley, to score two runs.

The International Hydro-Electric System reported yesterday for 1931 a consolidated net income of $3,217,867, equal after preferred dividends to $3.20 a share on 858,197 shares of Class A stock, compared with $3,790,694, or $4.30 a share, earned in 1930.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 -- The second day's sessions of the annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America took social welfare as their major theme, with Mrs. De Forest Van Slyck of New York, executive director of the association and secretary of the welfare committee, in charge.

Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland, contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, in a radio speech last night, rejected as "folly" proposals looking to unemployment relief and general economic revival which would have the country "rush headlong and unseeing into some of the radical, if not socialistic, panaceas which are being proposed with all earnestness in high places."

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 25 -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks, comedalist in the "Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tournament, defeated Miss Katharine Bragaw of Essex County after a hard struggle to survive the second round of the competition at the Century Country Club today.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Railroad Credit Corporation, created to administer revenues from the recently increased freight rates, cannot meet the requests for loans to pay fixed charges unless additional funds are forthcoming, R.G. Buckland, head of the corporation, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., May 25 (AP) -- Adobe Post, ridden by Jockey Charley Landolt, and shortest-priced horse to score thus far at the Washington Park meeting, easily triumphed in the top race at seven furlongs today. Struggling five lengths back of the victor campe Brave and Bold and Blackstrap.

CRANFORD, N.J., May 25 -- The Cranford Township committee today set June 14 for the sale of $116,000 assessment bonds and $58,000 Improvement bonds of 1932. Ordinances authorizing the issues had been adopted. The bonds are to supplant temporary notes issued in connection with a program of permanent financing.

GROTON, Mass., May 25 -- The favorite was on the short end of the score after the forty-fifth annual Groton-St. Mark's School baseball game before 2,000 spectators on the Groton campus today. Groton came from behind to defeat its ancient foe. 11 to 7.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Negotiations between the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a government loan with which to go forward with electrification of its New York-Washington lines entered a new phase today when the road filed a second amended application with the Interstate Commerce Commission, objecting to some conditions imposed by the latter in approving a three-year loan of $27,500,000.

PARIS, May 25. -- The Japanese Government, according to reports here, is seeking to purchase titular ownership in the Chinese Eastern Railway and negotiations toward that end are being conducted in Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The House today began consideration of one of the last major legislative items planned for this session when the Steagall bank guarantee bill was introduced under a special rule. Speaker Garner and other leaders said they hoped to pass the bill by Friday night and adjourn over Decoration Day, next Monday.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Arrivals of hogs here today were well in excess of expectations and the largest for a Wednesday since Feb. 3. Demand, however, was good and prices were, steady to 10 cents lower than yesterday, the greater part of the offerings going at 5 to 10 cents decline.

Degrrees in pharmacy will be presented to 142 candidates tonight at 8 P.M. at the 102d annual commencement exercises of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University at the McMillin Academic Theatre on the campus. W. Bruce Philip, general representative of the National Association of Retail Druggists and president-elect of the American Pharmaceutical Association, will deliver the address to the graduates.

Arrangements have been made, as the first step in the plans of the Young Committee for making effective the credit-expansion program of the Federal Reserve System, to place funds in the hands of the savings and loan associations of this State which will enable them to refinance the maturing mortgages of the small home owners of the State.

Operations of the International Mercantile Marine Company and its domestic subsidiaries for the year ended Dec. 31 resulted in a net loss of $1,278,001 after depreciation, interest and other charges. This contrasts with a net profit of $1,252,285, equivalent to $2.09 a share on 600,000 capital shares in the preceding year.

New York's Fire Department carties a heavy responsibility. The safety of a man's property and even of his life may depend on the efficiency of the fire fighters, as it often depends on the alertness of the police. It is of the first importance that the department shall be well equipped, manned by an experienced force with good morale, and headed by an expert chief and a capable Commissioner.

The first annual tournament of the recently organized Metropolitan Contract Bridge League opened last night at the Hotel Roosevelt with sixteen teams of four competing for a trophy donated by Commander Winfield Liggett Jr., president of the new organization.

Another attempt has been made to satirize the radio in "Heigh-ho, Everybody," which was acted at the Fulton last evening. Herbert Polesie and Jack McGowan, authors, have assembled the right material and assumed the proper contemptuous air. But, like "Wild Waves," "Heigh-ho, Everybody" only goes to show that the bleaters and crooners of the microphone will never go down under the satirists' scalpel, until George S. Kaufman wields it.

Moscow's sports carnival, which opened on Tuesday with a parade of 75,000 boys and girls, is among the cheerier pictures to be found in the news from Soviet Russia. In too many instances the story of " reconstruction " under way in that country brings with it the tale of destruction.

The League of New York Theatres will revive its campaign for Sunday-night performances in the legitimate theatres at a special meeting of the board of governors at the league offices tomorrow afternoon. Steps to obtain the cooperation of the Actors' Equity Association, which has twice rejected a proposal for Sunday-night shows in the last three years, will be discussed.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 25. -- Scoring the first major upset of the event, Miss Grace Surber, youthful Jackson Heights Tennis Olub star, conquered Miss Carolyn Roberts of the New Rochelle Tennis Club in straight sets in the quarter-final round of the Women's Eastern Clay Court title tennis tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club.
GREAT RIVER, L.I., May 25. -- New Jersey's golfers appear to be invincible in team-match competitions against Long Island and Westchester.

Grain and cotton prices rallied yesterday, following Tuesday's decline, the improvement in the foodstuffs ranging from a small fraction to close to a full cent, and that in cotton about one point. Losses were found in coffee, rubber, hides and silk. In the spot trading beef and rubber reached new lows, while zinc featured by a jump of 30 points to 2 7/8 cents.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 25 -- Praising the care given by the Jews to their afflicted needy as surpassing that of Protestants and Catholics, Cardinal Hayes blessed this afternoon the new $500,000 Irvington House, home for cardiac children, in the name "of the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob -- the one God."

Increases in the output of steel in some parts of the country have not been sufficient to offset slackness in other sections, with the result that the average rate of ingot production dropped from 25 to 24 percent of theoretical capacity the last week, according to The Iron Age.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, May 25 (AP). -- Dr. Karl Reinmuth, whose discovery of a new planetoid was announced by the Heidelberg Observatory last night, said today that the object was a minor planet of the twelfth degree of clearness.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 25 -- A wild throw in the last inning, with the score tied and the winning run on third, gave the Naval Academy a 5-to-4 victory over Mount St. Mary's College today.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 25 -- Gettysburg College will celebrate the centennial of its founding with, a program beginning tomorrow and culminating Monday with commencement exercises at which Dr. John H. Finley of New York will be the speaker.

PATERSON, N.J., May 25. -- Application to amend the provisions of an agreement under which two trust funds of between $8,000,000 and $9,000,000 each were established in 1917 by Murry Guggenheim for his son and daughter, was made here today before Vice Chancellor Vivian W. Lewis in Chancery Court.
BUENOS AIRES, May 25 (AP) -- The Colon Theatre here began its Winter opera season tonight with Giacomo Lauri Volpi and a new Italian soprano, Gina Cigna, singing "Aida."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25 Williams College defeated the Yale nine, 8-4 today. The winners hit Wheeler, George Parker and Fitz hard and timely to pile up a lead which the losers could not break down. Mark Filley twirled for Williams, and with the exception of two innings kept the Blue hits scattered.

Details of a nervous breakdown suffered by Ivar Kreuger in his apartment in Park Avenue last February, just before he left New York on the journey which ended with his suicide in Paris, were made known yesterday as hearings were resumed in the International Match Corporation bankruptcy.
DUBLIN, May 25. -- President Eamon de Valera introduced his oath of allegiance bill into the Senate today, insisting as he did in the Dail last month that it did not violate the Anglo-Irish treaty.

Plans for circulating a petition among west side business men, property owners and residents asking the Board of Estimate for immediate operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway line were laid yesterday at a meeting in the Holland Hotel, 351 West Forty-second Street.

ROME, May 25 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini and Premier Ismet Pasha of Turkey signed today a five-year renewal of the Turko-Italian treaty of friendship which a few years ago settled existing differences between the two nations.

"Save Me the Waltz" is the title of Zelda Fitzgerald's first novel, which Charles Scribner's Sons will bring out in the Fall. The wife of F. Scott Fitzgerald, who became one of this country's better-known authors when he published "This Side of Paradise" in 1920, at the age of 24, Mrs. Fitzgerald has been a semi-invalid for the last three years.

DEVON, Pa., May 25 -- Grey Ace, owned by the Foxcatcher Farms of Wilmington, scored an impressive victory in the class for ladies' hunters shown under side-saddle at the Devon Horse Show today before another big gathering.
