WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Senator Borah should be, if he isn't, the most puzzled man in Washington when he reads militant interpretations of his decision not to attend the Republican National Convention at Chicago. Particularly, the Senator must marvel at the reasoning processes of those who see a third party threat in his plan to stay away from the convention.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 25 (AP) -- Another American quest for the British amateur golf championship failed today as the three survivors of an original delegation of eleven went down to defeat in the third round.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- Patrick J. Hurley of Oklahoma, the Secretary of War, is receiving such prominent support for chairman of the Republican National Committee that some party chiefs believe his selection probable. It is expected in these quarters that he will accept if the chairmanship is offered, and will resign at the same time from the Cabinet.

One Long Islander, who has acquired the habit of spending some time each year fishing in Maine, writes from Rock-wood describing conditions in that part of the Pine Tree State. Harry Schoen of Forest Hills, L.I., says in part:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 (AP). -- Harry Cox of Indianapolis, mechanic, riding with Benny Benefield of Indianapolis, was killed late today when the car in which they were practicing for the 500-mile race here Monday, lost a wheel in the first turn, plunged over the outer wall and struck a tree.

BOSTON, May 25. -- Four hours after the second of several SOS messages, supposed to have been sent from the mail plane of the liner Europa, had been received here, and while three Coast Guard destroyers aided the liner in a search, the plane arrived intact at the Boston Airport, leaving the messages unexplained.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The output of the automobile industry increased from the low level of March by more than the usual seasonal percentage during April, and in the steel industry, where activity had declined from early February to the middle of April, production increased somewhat up to the third week of May, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly business review.
LONDON, May 25 -- Sir Ronald Ross, the conqueror of malaria, is lying seriously ill tonight in the Ross Institute and Hospital for Tropical Diseases, which he founded. He is 75 years old.
The complete official record of the fifty-ninth hearing of the joint legislative committee, devoted to the examination of Mayor James J. Walker, follows: ...

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Wheat traders were inclined to be bearish early today and caused a decline of 3/4 cent a bushel from Tuesday's finish on the Board of Trade here. The selling, though, exhausted itself and a rally displaced the loss with a gain, the finish being 5/8 to 3/4 cent higher and at the best figures of the day.

A political campaign of complete silence was suggested by Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, who told an audience of sixty-five women savings bankers of the metropolitan area at a dinner last night that he got the idea a few days ago from a conversation with Justice Brandeis of the United States Supreme Court.

Park Avenue and the Bowery went home last night with a new respect for each other's elbows. They had met where the race was to the swift and the strong, in the narrow doorway to a room in the County Court House.

The stories behind some of the books catalogued as "Eccentric Literature" in the New York Public Library are told by Walter Hart Blumenthal in an article, "An Alcove for Alienists," to be published today in Part X of The Colophon, a book collecters' quarterly.

BUFFALO, May 25 -- A new technique for resuscitating persons in a state of extreme asphyxia, which, it is claimed, has saved many lives of still-born children as well as of adults that could not have been saved by any other method, was described here today by Dr. P.J. Flagg of New York during the final sessions of the meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

LONDON, May 25. -- David Lloyd George took a gloomy view of the world in general and of the British Government in particular this afternoon at a Liberal party conference in Wales. He said the government had taken advantage of the great patriotic impulse of sacrifice on the part of the British people to put the manacles of a tariff on the country and that nothing helpful could be expected from the present Ministry.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, May 26 (AP). -- Baron General Yoshinori Shirakawa, commander-in-chief of the Japanese forces here, who was wounded by a bomb on April 29, died today, Japanese military headquarters announced. The end came at 7:30 A.M.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 26 (AP). -- Premier Saito will hold the portfolio of Foreign Affairs for the time being, with no change in the foreign or military policies of the last eight months in prospect.

PARIS, May 25. -- At a moment when, in France, the hope was encouraged that the debtor nations of Europe might be organized on a common front at Lausanne against their American creditor, the action of the British Government in concluding an arrangement with Washington for repayment over ten years at 4 per cent interest of the suspended annuities has caused in many quarters disagreeable surprise.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 25. -- The Greenwich Committee for Maternal Health opened its campaign tonight with a public meeting in the High School Auditorium, at which Dr. William Darrach of Greenwich presided and Dr. Frederick Holden, director of the department of gynecology at Bellevue Hospital, New York, was the principal speaker, his subject being "Why I Believe in Birth Control."
LOS ANGELES, May 25 (AP) -- A slip of a blonde girl may become the fourth wife of John Gilbert, screen star, when his divorce from Ina Claire, film and stage actress, is made final Aug. 15.

BERLIN, May 25. -- A violent pitched battle between Nazis and Communists today left the Prussian Diet hall littered with the debris of improvised weapons and resulted in injuries to a half-dozen Deputies, including neutrals, which required medical treatment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- Raymond Pitcairn, vice chairman of the Republican Citizens' Committee Against National Prohibition, telegraphed to Postmaster General Brown today protesting against any "tepid resubmission plank" and declaring that "the Republican electorate -- three to one for repealcounts much on your efforts to save the party from pussyfooting that will bring inevitable defeat."

WASHINGTON, Ind., May 25. -- Transportation across the State was arranged tonight for the "bonus expedition" of Western World War veterans who reached here this morning from East St. Louis on their way to Washington, D.C.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 25 -- Declaring it did not consider it wise or proper to indict the owners and operators of several Plainfield theatres against whom complaints had been made for permitting Sunday movies, the Union County grand jury, in a presentment handed to Judge Lloyd Thompson in Quarter Sessions Court here today, recommended a State-wide referendum on the question.

Addressing the graduates of the General Theological Seminary at the 114th commencement of that institution yesterday, Dr. Chauncey Brewster Tinker, Professor of English Literature at Yale University, urged the young clergymen to hold to their ideals of Christian teaching in the face of widespread criticisms of the present day.

Street preaching by Lutheran "friars" will soon be begun here and in other large cities of this State and New England, it was indicated yesterday at the fourth annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, held at St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street.

ABOARD GOVERNOR ROOSEVELT'S TRAIN, Charlottesville, Va., May 25. -- Dixie paid a warm pre-convention farewell to Governor Roosevelt today as he headed toward New York to spend the final weeks before the nomination fight in his home State.

To the Editor of The New Tork Times : THE NEW YORK TIMES stated that "according to advices received in credit circles [in New York] from Washington * * * an agreement has been reached by both committees not to report the bankruptcy bill out until the next session of Congress, which starts in December, it was said."

A total of twenty-one crews will form the flotilla in this year's regatta of the Intercollegiate Bowing Association at Poughkeepsie on June 20, according to the draw made yesterday at the offices of Maxwell Stevenson, chairman of the board of stewards.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- Meeting for the first time since they had opposed each other in the campaign for Goveronr last year, Governor A. Harry Moore clashed with former United States Senator David Baird Jr., defeated Republican nominee in a discussion here today of the agreement made between New Jersey and Pennsylvania for the sale of the Delaware River Bridge to the Interstate Bridge Commission.

BERLIN, May 25 (AP). -- Smoldering political passions in the new Prussian Diet broke out in hand-to-hand fighting between National Socialists and Communists today with a violence unprecedented in the parliamentary history of Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Senator Wagner, chairman of a special Democratic committee of the Senate, today introduced the party's relief bill providing $2,300,000,000 for immediate State loans for unemployment, Federal works and loans for self-liquidating enterprises.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 25. -- Tufts freshmen lost, 7 -- 1, to Andover Academy at lacrosse today. Thompson scored three goals.

Fifty games are slated for each, of the six teams in the newly organized American Box Lacrosse League, according to the 150-game league schedule for the coming season announced yesterday. The campaign will open a week from, tonight and close on Sept. 24.

The Museum of Irish Art, in this Hotel Barbizon, opened yesterday an exhibition of paintings by six contemporary Irish painters, which will continue for a fortnight. Most vehement in its challenge, though not the most startling, is the work of John Keating.

Four members of the Doris Humphrey-Charles Weidman concert group of dancers made their official debut last night at the Provincetown Playhouse under the name of the Little Group. Its personnel consists of Ernestine Henoch, Letitia Ide, Eleanor King and Jose Limon who have been appearing in less formal programs of their own creation for more than a year in and around New York.

Silvio Coucci, apprentice jockey from the Bronx, who went to Agua Caliente last Winter and gained a reputation as a star rider, yesterday scored a triple at Belmont Park, including the featured Spindrift Handicap in his sweep.

AUTEUIL, France, May 25. -- Play in the French tennis championships today advanced to the semi-final round of women's doubles and the quarter-finals of men's and mixed doubles, with Americans still prominent in all three divisions.

President Hoover sent a mesage to the small-house forum at the Engineering Societies Building yesterday, praising it as an effort to solve the problem of better housing and to increase employment. His communication was read at the final sessions of the two-day meeting called under the auspices of the American Institute of Steel Construction for exchanges of views on the mechanical construction of small houses at moderate cost utilizing various modern materials.

Heated criticism of a proposal to charge a fee of $2.50 for each credit for students attending the evening sessions of Brooklyn College was voiced last night at a students' protest meeting at Borough Hall Plaza, at Court and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn.

Summer weather, prevalent through most of the country yesterday, brought to New York City the warmest day so far this year. The mercury rose to 84 at 4:15 P.M., 1 degree higher than the maximum for May 16, the warmest day of 1932 theretofore.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Statemerits that President Hoover was helping to draft a plank for the Republican platform which would indicate a leaning toward re-submission of the Eighteenth Amendment to the States has brought down upon the capital a tremendous number of inquiries and the foreshadowing of protests.

BOSTON, May 25 -- Bob Brown held the Robins to four hits today while the Braves collected seven off Dazzy Vance to win the final game of the series, 4 to 2, but three Boston tallies were unearned. A crowd of 8,000 was on hand to cheer the Braves.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The House of Representatives paused today to honor the members of Congress who have died since the election in 1930.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Walcott-Kahn bill to authorize President Hoover to present the Distinguished Flying Cross to Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, in recognition of her transatlantic flight, probably will be reported favorably to the House on Friday.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George B. Saint George, Miss Priscilla Saint George and Mrs. Price Collier of Tuxedo Park will sail tonight on the Europa. They will attend the marriage of Mr. Saint George's sister, Miss Vivien Saint George, to Alexander F. Stanley-Clarke, which will take place in London, June 7.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A resolution authorizing a special subcommittee of the Judiciary Committee to investigate the official conduct of Federal Judge Harold Louderback of the Northern California District was introduced today by Representative La Guardia of New York, with the intimation that "a scandal involving Washington" would be revealed.

In the opinion of members of Tammany and friends of the City Administration, Mayor Walker had rather the better of it in his tilt with Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, which ended yesterday afternoon after the Mayor had been under examination for two days.

BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP). -- The Republican State Convention today formally gave Maryland's nineteen votes in the national convention to President Hoover and refused to go on record as favoring a national referendum on the prohibition question.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- Wheat bulls are having a hard time in advancing prices on the Chicago Board of Trade. The weather map showed heavy rains in the American Northwest and showers in the Prairie Provinces of Canada the day after reports of extreme oryness were received by the trade.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 26 (AP). -- George Grosz, artist, who caused a sensation four years ago by showing a picture of Christ on the Cross wearing a gas mask and a pair of Wellington boots, sailed on the liner New York today to teach art in Nev York City.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The text of Secretary Mills's statement on a public works program was as follows:

Fluctuations in the market values of securities are a matter of indifference to the life insurance business, Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday in a statement issued to explain the "oft-repeated assurance that the institution of life insurance remains sound and unshaken in the face of so much distress among some other types of moneyed corporation."

TIVOLI, Italy, May 18 (By mail). Horace's Sabine villa, where the famed singer of ancient Rome composed his odes, has come to light through the efforts of a 30-year-old American, Thomas D. Price of Boston, graduate of the Harvard University School of Landscape Architecture and of Ohio State University, now a fellow of the American Academy in Rome.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 26 -- Play for the second Gillespie Trophy got under way in the annual invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today without the attendance of the former national champion, John Doeg, who lifted the first Gillespie Trophy last year. Doeg was forced to default because of pressure of business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A goodly number of New York motorists will be coming through or into New Jersey during the coming week-end-in many cases for the first time this year. This letter is a request to those New York drivers to pay some attention to two New Jersey usages which differ from those of New York City and adjacent places in New York State.

The New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform voted yesterday to stay non-committal on Presidential candidates until after the nominations are made at the national party conventions. A resolution adopted at the annual meeting at the Plaza Hotel read:

The pamphlet report of the Royal Dutch Company for 1931 shows net profit of 27,916,648 florins, which was equal, after the payment of 4 per cent on the preference shares, to slightly more than 6 per cent on the 503,624,000 florins ordinary share capital.

"The Journal of Arnold Bennett, 1896-1910" is almost entirely a record of work and success. There were few mornings when the novelist did not get up from breakfast to the certainty that on that day he would write the number of words he expected of himself, that he would sell these words at the price he expected -- or rather more -- and would invest the money wisely.

Several of the many magazines devoted to homemaking, housekeeping and women's interests in general are bringing out in their June issues optimistic urgings for marriage. The month of June is traditionally one for weddings, so that it is nothing new to find discussion of ivory satins and orange blossoms in all the periodicals at the end of Spring.

The election of John D. Reilly as president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, succeeding the late William H. Todd, was announced yesterday afternoon at the close of a meeting of the directors. Mr. Reilly was associated with Mr. Todd in business for about twenty-five years and for many years had been executive vice president of the company.

Firms dealing in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a sweeping reduction in differentials demanded on transactions in less than 100-share lots. The change was explained in a statement issued by V. C. Brown Co.; Carlisle, Mellick Co.; De Coppet Doremus, Jacquelin De Coppet and Tefft Co.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 27. -- Startling Communist victories, involving the loss of two government divisions, are imperiling the Nanking Government's hold on Anhwei Province, which lies just west of the city of Nanking.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 26 -- Greenburgh High captured the four-cornered track and field meet of the Greenburgh Scholastic League today, edging out Irvington by a fraction of a point. The winning total was 385-6, while Irvington had 387-12. Dobba Ferry was third with, 221-3 and Ardsley fourth with 17 1/4.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 26. -- A growing interest in the arts and culture of modern civilization as one of the finer results of the present economic depression was cited here today by Mrs. John De Witt Peltz of New York City during the third day's program of the National Conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The District of Columbia Court of Appeals denied today a petition of the Radio Commission to reopen the reallocation of forty domestic short-wave channels which the commission recaptured from the bankrupt Universal Wireless Communications Company. The forty channels when allocated were estimated to be worth $1,000,000 each.

Robert Frost will be Phi Beta Kappa poet and Walter Lippmann Phi Beta Kappa orator at the annual public exercises of the Phi Beta Kappa chapter of Columbia University on Tuesday evening in the McMillin Theatre, 116th Street and Broadway.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- The battle between the Federal Farm Board and the Chicago Board of Trade, which reached a climax last night when the exchange deprived the Farm Board agencies of trading privileges, continued unabated today.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The acquisition of government securities by the Federal Reserve System varied according to the district last week, with a sharp reduction of holdings shown for the New York bank and increases at all other banks excepting those at Dallas and San Francisco, which showed no change.
BERLIN, May 26. -- Rioting by the unemployed kept the police busy in two German cities today, while partisan strife continued here between Communists and the followers of Adolf Hitler.

Largely as a result of heavy declines in the larger cities, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday night continued to show a sharp drop from last year. The total reported from twenty-two leading cities to R.G. Dun Co. was $4,017,416,000, or 48 per cent below that of the corresponding period in 1931.

Negotiations in progress between the Treasury Department and various European Governments on the subject of the war debts are described as merely a matter of international "bookkeeping." Under the terms of last Summer's moratorium, approved by Congress in December, the United States agreed to waive payment of principal and interest during the year 1931-32.

Exorbitant taxes and bureaucracy prevent a return of stable conditions and employment, C. Weston Bailey, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, told the annual meeting of that organization in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. This conclusion was reached by Mr. Bailey in his annual report to the representatives of the 225 member companies attending the conference.

Indications are multiplying at Washington that the best way out of the taxation muddle will be found to be to go back to the general sales tax. The original arguments for it have only been strengthened by what has taken place since its defeat by a sort of hysterical uprising in the House.

MR. BERNON S. PRENTICE, whose duty it is to chaperon our Davis Cup forces in battle, is now viewing with alarm the Australian peril in the immediate offing. Mr. Prentice professes to be "all of a tremble," which is somewhat extraordinary because he is, as a usual thing, quite self-possessed and a Harvard man into the bargain. The history of Harvard men in tight spots is that they remained calm and collected.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 26. -- A 36-foot sloop tacked bravely out of the harbor yesterday and headed across the Atlantic for Europe. Aboard are only two persons, a young Harvard graduate and his South American bride.

Alexander Munro, British Army Captain in the World War, ex-convict on parole and, according to police, an expert "penman" whose specialty is raising checks from insignificant to substantial sums, forging some one else's name on them and then collecting cash for them, was arrested yesterday at the Yorkvine branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, Third Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to comment upon your eading editorial of today, comparng President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 26 -- Baroness Giacomo Levi, Italian star, and Miss Norma Taubele, metropolitan indoor titleholder, gained the final round of the women's annual Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament today, posting decisive victories in semi-final matches.

A suit to recover $5,000,000 in assets and profits of the Equitable Casualty and Surety Company from fifty-one former directors was begun yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, who charged in the summons and complaint filed in Supreme Court that they had permitted dishonest persons to remain, as officers and employes of the company and had allowed its property and assets to be wasted, spent, stolen and dissipated.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26. -- Addressing a luncheon of Democratic nominees for Congress and county leaders here today, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State leader, forecast the election of Democratic Representatives to Congress from the fourteen districts in the State.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- President Hoover was told today by John Barton Payne, chairman of the Red Cross, that 40,000,000 more bushels of wheat would be necessary to feet the needy next Winter.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 26. -- With the tolling of 101 strokes on a bell used to assemble the first classes in 1832, Gettysburgh College opened today its five-day centennial and commencement program. Attired in academic robes, Dr. Frank H. Kramer, Professor of Education, rang the old bell, one additional tap symbolizing the beginning of the college's second century.
SAUNTON, Devon, England, May 26. -- One of the competitors in the women's British open golf championship, arriving at the first tee here today, asked, surprisedly: "Well, where's the course?"

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a result of ruinously low commodity prices many foreign countries are finding it increasingly difficult not only to pay interest on external debts but to make purchases from industrial countries.

PARIS, May 26 -- The Bourse was irregular today, with trading scarce. There was transitory improvement at mid-session, but profit-taking followed, leaving the list closing near or even slightly below yesterday's weakened levels. Some of the heaviest losers vesterday, including Canadian Pacific, rallied somewhat today.

In another of the outbreaks that have marked recent meetings of "Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, whose affairs are now the subject of a $7,500,000 accounting suit, 200 of the 2,500 members attending a meeting last night in the Central Opera House on East Sixty-seventh Street near Third Avenue battled with chairs and fists, injuring twelve men, before they were quieted by a squad of twenty-three policemen.

A cablegram announcing that Sweden has evolved a plan for reorganization of the Swedish Match Company under a moratorium and with American representation on the reorganization committee was received here yesterday in connection with the bankruptcy proceedings against the International Match Corporation.

BERLIN, May 26. -- A regular transatlantic airplane service will be started by the Deutsche Lufthansa at the end of this year across the South Atlantic between British Gambia, Africa, and Natal, Brazil. A 6,000-ton steamship will be stationed in mid-Atlantic this Fall to serve as a refueling station.

The United States cannot continue indefinitely with democratic political institutions and autocratic industrial institutions, Norman Hapgood, author and economist, declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore which closed the first annual conference of the Industrial Experimenters, an organization to further methods of employer-employe ownership, control and management in industry.

SHANGHAI, May 26. -- Dispatches received here from Harbin indicate that a dramatic climax is approaching in Northern Manchuria. The most serious warfare since last September has resulted from the arrival at Harbin of General Shigeru Honjo, the Commander-in-Chief of the Japanese forces in Manchuria, and an advance on the city from three directions by the forces of General Ma Chen-shan, leader of the Manchurian insurgents against the Manchukuo Government.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Following a "camp meeting" of House Democrats late this afternoon, Speaker Garner made public his proposed $2,100,000,000 unemployment relief bill, which he expects to introduce in the House tomorrow.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP). -- The Athletics, with homers by Bishop and Foxx starting the assault, pounded two of the three pitchers used by the Red Sox today to win the opener of their four-game series, 7 to 1. Rain ended the contest at the end of the sixth.

LONDON, May 26 (Canadian Press). -- Yorkshire today won its county championship cricket match from Somerset at Bath by nine wickets, while Sussex defeated Leicestershire at Hastings by an innings and 92.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The text of a petition urging further economy in government, which was signed by twenty-five civic organizations in New York City and up-State and mailed on Wednesday to President Hoover and members of the Senate and the House, was made public yesterday by James Brown, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Returns by railroads issued yesterday continued to show a downward trend in gross revenue and net operating income. The New York Central reported net operating income of $363,974 in April, the smallest total for a corresponding period in many years and a drop of $2,437,000 from April, 1931.

The New York Stock Exchange has sought to obtain early publication of annual reports of companies whose shares are listed on the Exchange by getting definite agreements, when applications are made for listing additional securities, that reports will be published not later than specified dates.

With a larger business done than in other recent markets, stocks declined yesterday, in some cases rather sharply; but the movement was reversed in the afternoon and most of the early losses were recovered. The bond market was again, however, the focus of interest, and prices again gave way.

Governor Roosevelt returned to his home State yesterday to find his pre-convention campaign managers brimming with confidence that he would go into the Democratic convention at Chicago with enough votes to insure a swing that would win him the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 25, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,005,000,000, an increase of $61,000,000 compared with the preceding week and $1,115,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Thousands of New Yorkers will leave the city today and tomorrow by rail, sea, road and air for the Memorial Day week-end. The exodus, which is expected to reach its peaks tonight and tomorrow afternoon, started yesterday evening.

Louis Benson, stenographer last June to the county grand jury which investigated the Bank of United States failure, testifying yesterday as the first State witness in the perjury trial of Isidor J. Kresel, general counsel to the bank, admitted to Justice Harris and the jury in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court that he had made many changes in his original stenographic notes.

The State closed its case yesterday in the General Sessions trial of John C. Western, former Acting Assistant District Attorney in the Women's Court, on a perjury indictment growing out of big testimony before Samuel Seabury as referee in the Appellate Division investigation of the magistrates' courts, and Judge Collins adjourned the proceeding until today.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 26. -- The British amateur golf championship field, without any foreign competition, moved into the quarter-final stage over sodden greens and through windy, rainy weather today with hardly a golfer left who is known outside his own club.

While the New Jersey State police plodded away yesterday on various unpromising leads, the Hunterdon County grand jury heard evidence against John H. Curtis, accused of obstructing justice through the fictitious negotiations with mythical kidnappers by which he hoaxed Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

BERLIN, May 26 -- Business on the Boerse was extremely quiet today because of the Catholic holiday. Prices were steady at the opening, but moved downward later. The losses, however, were small. The bond market continued quiet and weak.

In a final effort to avert a receivership for the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway, the management announced yesterday that an offer for deposit of 4 per cent first consolidated mortgage bonds under a refinancing plan to meet their maturity on Wednesday would be extended to the succeeding Tuesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Carbon monoxide is one of the most insidious gases in industry. It has no small; it has no taste; it is colorless and widely diffused. Every automobile engine that belches forth exhaust gas contains carbon monoxide, and as it is combined with disagreeable smells, the danger is not considerable unless breathed in enclosed spaces.

Above the loud arguments of lawyers and the admonitions of an angered magistrate, a small black and yellow canary sang within its cage yesterday afternoon in the bedroom of former Police Inspector William W. McLaughlin, once known as "the millionaire cop," at 60 "West Eighty-third Street.

GENEVA, May 26. -- The draft report of the naval commission, which was the first to answer the disarmament conference's question regarding what weapons ought to be abolished under qualitative disarmament, was released today. It shows there still is the widest disagreement on every naval weapon it examined in seeking to decide which one in the hands of an aggressor is most specifically offensive, most efficacious against national defense and most threatening to civilians.

Mayor Walker, in a statement to the Hofstadter legislative committee at the conclusion of his examination yesterday, and after he had been excused from further testimony, expressed hope that that body would give its attention to the reconstruction of the city charter, which he described as "archaic, worn out, overlapping and out of date."

Twenty sport committees of the American Olympic Committee were notified yesterday by Avery Brundage, the president of the committee, that teams which will represent this country at the Olympic Games ia Los Angeles will have to be reduced.

Sinclair Lewis, novelist, returned from a short trip to Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, accompanied toy Mrs. Lewis, and announced that he had completed a new novel of 170,000 words, finishing the last chapter at sea on Wednesday.

City College's baseball team brought its 1932 season to a close yesterday, scoring its most important victory of the entire campaign by slugging its way to a 19-11 victory over Manhattan College at Lewisohn Stadium in the second game of the series with the Jaspers.

SEYMOUR, Ind., May 26 (AP). -- The Oregon "bonus brigade," slowly proceeding across Indiana in National Guard trucks, reached this city late today and the veterans spent their third night in the State encamped in the city park. The "marchers," in twenty-seven motor trucks, left Washington, Ind., shortly after 8 o'clock this morning.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 26 (AP). -- Prizes totaling $13,000 were awarded today to fourteen University of Michigan students who submitted manuscripts for the annual Hopwood literary contest.

Responses from savings and loan associations throughout New York State received yesterday at the offices of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations indicate that a substantial amount of the credit being placed at the disposal of the associations through the arrangements made by the Young Committee can be employed immediately, according to George L. Bliss, president of the league.

LONDON, May 26 -- The stock markets were steadier today, with renewed buying of British Government funds, and price rises were general. The markets were helped by Mr. Baldwin's reassuring statement in Parliament last night.
The steamers City of Chattanooga of the Savannah Line and the Grecian of the Merchants and Miners Line crashed in a pea-soup fog off Block Island at 2:50 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The recently organized Alton Railroad Company received the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval today for a three-year loan of $2,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The loan, if granted by the corporation, is to be used for payment of $1,500,000 of receivers' certificates, $800,000 of matured and maturing equipment obligations and $200,000 of Illinois taxes.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., May 26. -- Mrs. Willard S. Perrigo of Antwerp was elected president of the Northern Federation of Women's Clubs at the twenty-fifth annual convention today. She succeeds Mrs. Udelle Bartlett of Oswego.
AUTEUIL, France, May 26 -- Rain today caused the postponement of nearly all matches in the French tennis championships, blocking the leading American entrants entirely.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP). -- A rally in the eighth inning in which five runs were scored enabled the Phillies to defeat the Boston Braves, 17 to 13, today.

The increasing practice of "scrapping" employes in early middle life was condemned by the United Lutheran Synod of New York at its annual convention yesterday in St. John's Lutheran Church. The convention, which has been in session since Monday evening, closed yesterday.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP). -- Louis Schneider, the former Indianapolis policeman who won the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway last year, qualified for this year's race today.

George V. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company and vice chairman of the advisory committee of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told an audience of 400 dinner guests of the National Institute of Credit here last night that business had made no use of the credit provided by "three months of courageous and aggressive effort."
Cash and pledges to the block-aid campaign now amount to $1,476,780, it was announced last night by Barklie McKee Henry, vice chairman, who said that the cash gifts total $874,760.29.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (AP). -- With a three-run lead to protect, Pittsburgh pitchers broke up rallies in the seventh and eighth innings by the Cincinnati Reds, and won today, 3 to 2, making a clean sweep of the three-grame series.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Scarface Al Capone, the Chicago gangster, now serving ten years in the Atlanta. Penitentiary for evading Federal income taxes, today asked the Supreme Court to reconsider its refusal of May 2 to review his case.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- The demand for hogs was less aggressive today, weather conditions being a factor, and prices were generally 5 to 10 cents lower. The top was off 5 cents to $3.40, which equalled the lowest figure since the Summer of 1896. The day's average was 5 cents lower at $3.20, a price which has been witnessed several times in the last two weeks.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 26. -- A renaissance for advertising was advocated today by B.H. Namm, president of the Namm Store in Brooklyn, in an address here before the Retail Merchants' Board of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Lou Gehrig's homer with the bases filled in the sixth and five-hit shut-out pitching by Charlie Ruffing today, launched the Yanks upon a four-game series with a 5-to-0 victory. It was the McCarthymen's first triumph of the season, incidentally, in a local setting, having lost three straight here the first three days of May.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26. -- June week, the period of graduation for the midshipmen of the Naval Academy, officially began today with the presentation this afternoon of athletic awards in Thompson Stadium.

Speakers at a mass meeting at the Town Hall last night held under the auspices of the National Economy Committee prophesied dire consequences to the United States Government if the present veterans' relief scheme under which disability payments will reach close to a $1,000,000,000 this year is allowed to continue.

Excessive taxation and unemployment have forced into foreclosure many real estate bond issues that normally would have weathered the storm, according to a report of the real estate securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association, made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- James M. Cox, Democratic candidate for President in 1920, is figuring in the gossip on possibilities for the party's nominee for Vice President.

The "Four Horsemen" were drawing away from the field when the second day's play of the Metropolitan Contract Bridge League's threeday tournament ended early this morning at the Hotel Roosevelt. They had increased the lead of one match point which they held after the first day to six full points.

Mickey Walker strengthened his claim to consideration as a heavyweight title threat last night in Madison Square Garden where, before a crowd of about 7,000 fans, who paid gross receipts estimated at $20,000, he hammered his way to the decision over Paulino Uzcudun, the rugged Basque, in a bruising ten-round struggle.

April Retail Collections Better. April retail collections were 1.52 per cent behind the same month of last year, according to the 20-store index announced yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The highest percentage reported was 57.3 and the lowest 27.53, as compared with 61.80 and 30.96 in 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Senator Wheeler of Montana served notice on the Senate today that he would demand a vote before Congress adjourns on his bill for the free coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1 with gold.
The complete official record of the Second Public Hearing of the Joint Legislative Comntittee to be devoted to the examination of Mayor James J. Walker follows:

Mayor WALKER complained loudly yesterday that enemies are seeking to take his political life. The investigation here, he protested, is only preliminary to his real trial, which will occur when proceedings are taken to have him removed from office by Governor ROOSEVELT.

Objections from the minority members of the legislative committee during the examination of Mr. Walker were many and lengthy. A sample of the fighting tactics of the protestants, displayed when Sherwood's brokerage accounts were introduced, was as follows:
Mr. Montross opened yesterday in his gallery at 785 Fifth Avenue another exceptionally good group exhibition of work by contemporary American artists. This will remain on view through June.

In the Senate on Tuesday Mr. SMITH of South Carolina made the sufficiently commonplace remark that "the farmer is ruined." "Is not everybody ruined?" asked Mr. KING. "Yes," answered Mr. SMITH. Something is always going to be done for the farmer.

Financing just completed by two of its English subsidiaries improved the consolidated current position of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation by u3,960,000, which the corporation calculates at $19,272,340 on the basis of the gold parity, according to an announcement made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Agreements of the New York and Porto Rico Steamship Company with the Hamburg-American Line and with the North German Lloyd for through shipments of all traffic between Hamburg, Bremen and Puerto Rico, with trans-shipment at New York, were modified by the Shipping Board today.

Aside from rallies in United States Government bonds and a sharp rise in United Kingdom 5 1/2s to a new peak, the bond market on the Stock Exchange made a poor showing yesterday. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of ten foreign and forty domestic corporation bonds touched the lowest levels since the compilations were begun in 1913.

LONDON, May 26. -- Leaders of political thought in Great Britain more and more are turning their attention toward the problem of world currencies as a source of the world's economic stress and particularly of the ills besetting Britain herself. The tariff has been tried and it has helped -- that is to say it has had the desired effect of restricting imports and thereby somewhat improving the country's trade balance.

"Ford Earnings" in 1931. The loss of $53,586,000 on its business for 1931, shown by the Ford Motor Company in its report to the Massachusetts authorities, cannot be taken as measuring precisely the scope of the industrial reaction.

A committee representing holders of Fisk Rubber Company first-mortgage twenty-year 8 per cent sinking-fund gold bonds and five-year 5 1/2 per cent sinking-fund gold notes has been formed, with a program calling for an immediate partial payment of at least 20 per cent in cash on these securities, of which $15,800,000 are outstanding.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 26. -- Samuel Untermyer will open, his estate, Greystone, in Yonkers on Saturday afternoon for a concert to aid the scholarship fund of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society, which provides free tuition to talented music students in public schools.

ROME, May 26 (AP). -- A keen contest between the French and Italians to be the first to establish a successful commercial airline from Europe to South America was revealed in the first convention of transoceanic fliers that ended today.

TOKYO, May 26 (AP). -- The reten- tion in the Cabinet of General Araki, militarist director of the Manchurian operations, insures relentless prosecution of the "pacification" campaign against the Chinese in Manchuria who are opposed to the Japanese-supported regime of Henry Pu Yi.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- An agreement to vote on farm relief before the session ends was sought today by leaders of the Senate, while its Agriculture Committee declared that the marketing act now in force had failed to accomplish desired aims.

LONDON, May 26. -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam met Britain's leading airwoman, Miss Amy Johnson, today, giving her advice and suggestions on her contemplated transatlantic flight in company with her fiance, J.A. Mollison.
"Pray for rain" was the admonition from the New York State Conservation Department yesterday following the proclamation that closed forests and woodlands in the State to the public.

Keep on watch that the great and honored profession of medicine be not permitted to become a "third-rate business enterprise," Miss Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, urged the members of the New York Claim Association at a dinner last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are still a few beautiful wooded sections within the greater city of New York which ought to be saved. The Hemlock Forest and Jungle Walk in Bronx Park are properly kept in their wild state, but there are other areas on Staten Island and in Queens which should likewise be preserved as natural parks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 26 -- The report of the committee which made a survey of Yale athletics also recommended today that the division of the undergraduate body into college groups be completed early in the Spring of 1933 in order that each college may have an opportunity to consider its athletic organization for the following year.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26. -- Newport will be the Summer headquarters of the Netherlands Legation for the first time this year. J.H. van Royen, Netherlands Minister to the United States, and Mme. van Royen, were visitors in Newport last weekend and have leased an estate, it is understood, though the official announcement has not been made.
George Palmer Putnam, publisher, will sali tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to join his wife, Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, who flew the Atlantic last week. Others booked include:

PARIS, May 26. -- An attack on prohibition and "a lot of cheap politicians," who, he said, were now governing the United States, was made here today by General John J. Pershing in a speech at a luncheon of the American Club. The blame "for what is being visited upon us today" was laid by General Pershing to the American public, "which is too indifferent to perform its duty at the polls."

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Pilgrims who come to Washington from the neighborhood of Broad and Wall Streets, and others who (with the aid of the telephone) send their voices only on the pilgrimage to the capital city, are asking every day now:

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Another test on the manufacturers' sales tax as a means of raising the bulk of new revenue needed to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933 is near in the Senate, following the restoration today of a long list of unpopular excises to the billion-dollar tax bill.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- Drastic curtailments in Yale's intercollegiate athletic program, with shifting of primary emphasis to intramural sports for "fun and informality," were outlined today by President James Rowland Angell in announcing acceptance of a survey committee's recommendations.

BALTIMORE, May 26. -- Inland waterway projects of the Federal Government were denounced as unwarranted burdens on the taxpayers for the benefit of a few selfish industrialists by Samuel S. Wyer of the Fuel-Power Transportation Educational Foundation in an address at the annual meeting of the American Forestry Association here today.

Increased use of silver coin as a means of relieving the depression in international trade was urged by three speakers representing the United States, China and Mexico last night in a discussion of "Silver and the Depression," broadcast by WOR's Radio Forum.

Summer weather lingered in the metropolitan area yesterday. New Yorkers appeared publicly in short-sleeves and swarmed to the outdoors at the end of the business day when the mercury climbed steadily from 66 degrees at 7 o'clock in the morning to 84, Wednesday's high mark, at 3 o'clock, and continued on to 85 degrees, the warmest temperature of the year, throughout the late afternoon rush hour.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 26 (AP). -- The Bisons enjoyed a triumphant return to home territory today as they defeated the Rochester Red Wings with a homer barrage for their fourth consecutive victory, 5 to 1. Ollie Carnegie, Billy Werber and Pitcher Fussell hit homers.

YEAH-MAN, a negro revue in two acts and twenty-three scenes. Dialogue by Leigh Whipper and Billy Mills; lyrics and music by Al Wilson, Charles Weinberg and Ken Macomber. Dances arranged by Marcus Slayter; staged by Walter Campbell: produced by Mr. Campbell and Jesse Wank. At the Park Lane Theatre, formerly Daly's 63d Street.

VIENNA, May 26. -- The ceremony of renaming one of the great workers' apartment houses built by the Socialist municipality of Vienna the George Washington Building today was marred by Communist protests against the sentencing to death of the Scottsboro, Ala., Negro youths convicted of having attacked two white girls.

Mayor Walker tried to laugh Samuel Seabury out of court yesterday at the conclusion of his examination before the Hofstadter committee when the chief counsel sought to show that the missing Russell T. Sherwood was his dummy in extensive Wall Street operations.

Happy Gal, bearing the Belair Stud silks of William Woodward, was a driving winner of the featured $4,000 added Juvenile Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. It is the richest 2-year-old stake run so far this season. The daughter of Sir Gallahad III and My Reverie earned $12,800 by a speedy dash down the Widener chute, setting a record for the stake, which was inaugurated in 1874.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- The Garner bill's proposal to expend $22,985,000 for public works in New York State, includes the following allocations for postoffices hitherto unauthorized:

DETROIT, May 26 (AP). -- The Tigers won the first half of a double-header from the White Sox, 11 to 2, today and were tied in the nightcap, 1 to 1, when a downpour stopped the contest in Detroit's half of the fifth with one out and one on base. The game was ruled official.

Prices reacted in the commodity markets yesterday. Grains lost from a fraction to more than 1 cent, while cotton sagged 4 to 7 points. Coffee, cocoa, rubber and hides declined, but silk was slightly higher. In the spot section silk and rubber reached new lows for the year.

Japan's new Cabinet, bipartisan and with an exceptional infusion of the military element, will naturally favor a strong policy in Manchuria. Compensation for wounded pride at Shanghai would be indicated in Manchuria even if from the beginning it had not been made manifest that Japan is there engaged upon an enterprise of the first magnitude.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP). -- Appointment of the outstanding American candidates for the Olympic Games instead of sending them to national tryouts was advocated today by Leslie A. Henry, president of the Pacific Southwest A.A.U., as a, means of meeting the financial crisis confronting the American Olympic Committee.

Colonel Frederick Pope, president of the Nitrogen Engineering Corporation, 535 Fifth Avenue, urged yesterday that the United States send an unofficial observer or commissioner as a preliminary step to possible resumption of normal diplomatic relations between Washington and Moscow.

If the Democrats elect a President and win control of Congress this year, they should introduce the executive budget system in the Federal Administration, as insurance against recurrence of billion dollar deficits, Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland, contender for the Democratic nomination for President, declared in an interview yesterday.
DENVER, May 26. -- The Rev. Dr. C.W. Kerr of Tulsa, Okla., was elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America at the opening session of the annual Assembly here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published a letter recommending that the government borrow several billion dollars to buy farms for those who are unable to make a living in the cities, and to transplant their families to those farms.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 26. -- Despite the fact that Miss Maureen Orcutt, New Jersey's perennial winner of the women's metropolitan golf title, is in England in search of larger honors, the State still has a worthy representative left among the quartet still in the running for the district laurels at the Century Golf Club.

Suspension of a prominent cotton brokerage company in Liverpool caused active liquidation in the early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. The heaviest pressure was at the start, when it was estimated that between 20,000 and 25,000 bales were sold, mainly for foreign account.

GARDONE RIVIERA, Italy, May 26 (AP). -- Kaye Don, British speedboat driver, failed by almost twenty miles an hour today in an assault on the world's speedboat record with his new boat Miss England III.

Workmen last night cleaned the haggard face of the new County Court House. With brooms and hose they washed down the steps, and with mops attacked the hallways. They cleaned up old papers, icecream boxes, cigar stubs and trampled roses.

Except for the broadened sale of choice name commercial paper at 2 3/4 per cent, enough, in fact, to make that the going rate, and a reduction of 1/4 from the previous figure, there was little else of interest in the day's money market. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

Summing up was completed early yesterday afternoon, at the trial of Joseph A. Broderlck, State Superintendent of Banks, and Judge George L. Donnellan adjourned court until 11 o'clock this morning, when he will deliver his charge to the jury, which for seven weeks has been hearing testimony in the case in General Sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The most important Davis Cup match to be held in this country since the trophy was lost to France in 1927 will start at the Philadelphia Country Club tomorrow when Australia and the United States meet for the first time since the challenge round of 1924.

For the first time since 1929 the New York Stock Exchange took disciplinary measures yesterday against a member for bear-raiding tactics when it announced the suspension for one year of Daniel Manning McKeon, an independent floor broker, with offices at 71 Broadway.

ALBANY, May 26 (AP). -- For the thousands of New York State citizens who deluged the Conservation Department with telephone calls today to find out whether they could go ahead with their plans for the Memorial Day holiday, there appeared to be some hope tonight that the ban on pleasure-seekers in the State's fire-ravaged woodlands might be lifted Saturday.

BALTIMORE, May 26. -- Dr. Naseed Masood, 35 years old, disabled World War veteran, and his nurse and secretary, Miss Dorothy A. Cassell, both of Altoona, Pa., late today plunged from a train of the Pennsylvania Railroad, traveling at high speed, near Glencoe.

The Theatre Guild, the Shuberts and the Erlanger Amusement Enterprises have completed a radical booking arrangement whereby the out-oftown subscription groups of the Shuberts and the Guild will be combined, beginning next season. Although official announcement of such a step was made only yesterday by the Guild, it was reported in THE TIMES on March 16 that representatives of the Guild and the Shuberts had been working on details of the plan for several months.
Housing deals constituted the bulk of realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

TORONTO, Ont., May 26. -- A group of Toronto medical research workers hope to announce within a few weeks not only the apparent cause of diabetes but also the development in the Connaught Laboratories of a toxin or toxoid and the results of the use of an antitoxin upon a group of patients for more than two months with at least temporary relief.

TOKYO, May 26. -- The new Cabinet of Premier Makoto Saito was installed today, the only surprise occasioned in its final composition being the retention of the post of Minister of War by General Sadao Araki.

State Senator John A. Hastings took time off yesterday morning from the Hofstadter hearings to make an appearance in Brooklyn where two court orders and a tax lien summons confronted him. He appeared personally on the tax charge in the Federal Building, his lawyer answered another in the Supreme Court, and neither of them responded to a third in the City Court at the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

The four-story dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 38 West Eighty-seventh Street, adjoining Central Park West, has been sold by L.M. Perkins to the 38 West Eighty-seventh Street Corporation. Hattie M. Melhuish and Irene M. Miller were the brokers.
DEVON, Pa., May 26. -- In a spectacular jump-off, Olive, owned by Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery of Villanova, won the Gray Parson Trophy, today's feature at the Devon horse show.

TRENTON, N.J., May 26. -- Governor Moore and Senator Emerson L. Richards, leader of the Republican majority in the upper house of the Legislature, agreed today upon a $20,000,000 bond issue as a supplement to the proposed general sales tax to provide funds for emergency relief.

Texas Guinan returned on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday after a sojourn of ten days in France, undertaken to prove to the world that the country that rejected her coldly last year was waiting to receive her with open arms.

ROME, May 27 -- General Italo Balbo and his air force put on a gigantic aerial show today at Littorio Field to demonstrate to transoceanic fliers of eleven nations the great development of Italian aviation in recent years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 27 -- One of the liveliest half-hours ever experienced on the San Francisco Curb Exchange took place on receipt of news from New York that the Cities Service Company had announced the omission of dividends on common and preferred stocks of the parent company and its two large subsidiaries, the Cities Service Power and Light Company and the Empire Gas and Fuel Company.

This week's new financing consisted entirely of State and municipal bond and note issues. Ten new issues were marketed, aggregating $18,226,950, compared with, nine last week totaling $20,890,000. A year ago the weekly total was $96,354,000, of which public utility financing accounted for $82,500,000, State and municipal $10,854,000, and a Canadian provincial issue for $3,000,000.
The first fifty-two railroads to report for April showed a net operating income of $17,310,000 against $31,054,000 in April, 1931, a drop of 44.2 per cent. Their net in March was $26,239,000.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senator Walsh of Massachusetts explained his sales tax amendment today as follows:

Refusing to uphold an earlier ruling by the referee, Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey decided yesterday, following argument before him on Thursday, that James H. Perkins, president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, need not answer a subpoena calling for his appearance for questioning in the bankruptcy proceedings against the International Match Company.

WASHINGTON, Hay 27 -- Automobile production of the United States during April increased nearly 30,000 cars over the preceding month to a total of 148,013, compared with 118,959 in March, the Commerce Depart- ment said today.

Local salt water fishermen are anxious to take advantage of every opportunity a holiday week-end offers. And boatmen's associations are meeting the demands by running on special schedule. The Long Island Sound Boatmen's Association will run eight boats leaving from the foot of Soundview Avenue and Clason Point at 8 o'clock tomorrow and Monday to accommodate the fishermen.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The text of President Hoover's statement today on Speaker Garner's relief program was as follows:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 27 (AP) -- Relief Pitcher Bill Gould of Buffalo won his own game with a single after two were out and the count on him was three and two in the ninth inning, the Bisons repelling the Rochester Red Wings, 5 to 4, today for their fifth straight triumph.

The strength imparted to the market in Thursday's late dealings by the reports from Washington of improved prospects for the enactment of a sales tax was insufficient to withstand the depressing influence of the announcement early yesterday afternoon of the reduction in the quarterly dividend of the General Electric Company from 25 cents to 10 cents.

GENEVA, May 27 -- Ambassador Hugh S. Glbson, head of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference, today formally notified Arthur Henderson, its president, that the United States desired the conference to remain in session without adjournment until it accomplished something.
Mayor Walker. Q. -- Mr. Mayor, in September, 1926, did Senator Herrick advise you that he would like some stock of the Interstate Trust Company that was formed at that time? A. -- He did not.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Agreement was said today at the State Department to have been reached among the United States, Great Britain, France and Italy not to attend the conference of powers on China, as suggested by Japan, unless China was invited.

SCHENECTADY, May 27 -- In commenting the retiring Terrace Council, senior honorary society, and the Student Council, the governing body, at the mnving-up-day exercises of Union College this morning, President Day declarel that most of the twenty-two fraternities had taken steps to change from ordinary "clubhouses" to "homes for cultivated college men," a fact he found encouraging to the college authorities.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Representative Rainey, the Democratic leader, seems to think that the chances of enacting President Hoover's home-loan bank bill this session are slim.

PASADENA, Cal., May 27 -- While a fellow scientist adjusted a kodak to photograph him on the brink of a cliff near the summit of Mount Wilson today, Dr. Leonard Thompson Troland, aged 43, lecturer on psychology at Harvard University, suffered a fainting spell and plunged to his death in a rocky canyon 250 feet below.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 27 (AP) -- A plea for support of the navy by the American public wag made today by Admiral William V. Pratt, chief of naval operations, at the annual commencement exercises of the Naval War College.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- In reply to ouster threats by Secretary Fitzgerald of Michigan the Standard Oil Company of Indiana in a statement today said that it will submit the question at issue to the Michigan courts.

SAUNTON, England, May 27 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of the United States, with a superb round of 73, placed herself two strokes ahead of all competitors in the first qualifying round of the women's British open golf championship today. Three other United States players.

Prospects of fair weather with continued coolness during the Memorial Day week-end were indicated last night on the instruments at the Weather Bureau after a heavy thunderstorm, which resulted in one death by drowning, had set in shortly before 6 o'clock, breaking the waning heat wave.

VIENNA, May 27 -- A sharp encounter between members of the Heimwehr and Hitlerites on one side and Socialists on the other in the Tyrolean town of Hoetting, near Innsbruck, tonight resulted in more than 100 being wounded.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A statement by Judge Charles L. Estep of Logan, W. Va., that the United Mine Workers of America caused the 1921 disorders in his State was challenged before a Senate committee today by Philip Murray, vice president of the labor organization.

Barely recovered from the strain of two days' testimony before the Hodstadter committee, Mayor Walker plunged into another clash with Controller Charles W. Berry at a meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday in which the Mayor linked the Controller to the same sort of innuendoes that he said had emanated from the Hofstadter committee to the city's detriment.

Expressing the belief that democracy was moving slowly toward the "educational State" as described by Plato, Dr. L.P. Jacks, publisher of Hibbert's Journal and formerly principal of Manchester College at Oxford University, asserted last night that the recreation movement in America will make an important contribution in this democratic evolution.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- Cleveland widened its fifth-place margin over the Browns today as Clint Brown allowed only five safeties in the Indians' 6-to-3 victory over St. Louis. Goose Goslin's homer, his first this year, produced two of the Browns' runs.

BERLIN, May 27 (AP) -- The riots that have harassed the police in many German cities for three days continued throughout last night and part of today in a number of places. The casualties included one dead and more than a score injured. There were many arrests.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Authority to issue $75,000,000 of refunding and improvement 5 per cent mortgage bonds, Series C, was sought today by the New York Central Railroad in an application filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The issue would be dated Oct. 1, 1921, and mature Oct. 1, 2013.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- The Pirates continued their climb up the National League ladder today, advancing to fourth place with an 8-to-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The losers dropped from fourth to fifth.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- Continuing their slugging tactics, the Phillies pounded out an 8-to-5 triumph over the Boston Braves today for their second straight victory over McKechnie's men. The Phils advanced from eighth to seventh place as a result.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 27 -- Ten Spot, the sprightly chestnut mare owned Toy George W. Oliver Son of Closter, N.J., won the polo pony championship at the fourth annual Horse Show of the Boulder Brook Club, held on the club grounds today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The pages of our newspapers are full of figures, charts and quotations showing new laws, loss of traffic, less power used, Everybody is sick and tired of reading them. It is hard to discover some really hopeful news tucked away in some outof-the-way corner.

In the path of an oncoming train, Mary and Anna Skrzypek, sisters, of 147-16 Brinkerhoff Avenue, South Jamaica, Queens, slipped and fell while crossing the Long Island Railroad tracks at 159th Street and 110th Avenue, South Jamaica, during the rainstorm at 6:40 o'clock last night. Mary, 19 years old, struck the third rail and was fatally injured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the Winter several articles were published decrying the fact that child labor, being cheap, had increased appallingly. It is evident to every thinking person that the evils inherent in such a condition will be felt long after the depression is forgotten.

The Mercantile Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis has averted receivership for the St. Louis Southwestern, or Cotton Belt, Railway by depositing 700 consolidated 4 per cent bonds of the road, which it held under a refinancing plan, according to reports from St. Louis yesterday.

The "good old days" in old New York would be considered barren of amusement by the week-end holidaymakers now hurrying away from the city by train, automobile, steamer and even by airplane. The tempo of life was slower forty or fifty years ago, and the entertainment provided was meager.
The case against Mayor Walker was outlined, in part, to the Hofstadter legislative committee yesterday by Samuel Seabury.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The National Broadcasting Company was ordered to cease synchronization tests between stations WEAF, in New York, and WTIC, at Hartford, and between WJZ, in New York, and WBAL, in Baltimore, by the Radio Commission today.
NEW YORK. Mrs. M. Orme Wilson is at the Pierre. Later she will go to the country.

MORRIS, Okla., May 27 (AP) -- A bank robber was slain and Miss Claire Aggas, young bookkeeper, was wounded in a gun fight following the robbery of the First State Bank of Morris by three men here today.

GARDONE, RIVIERA, Italy, May 27 (AP) -- Kaye Don, British speed-boat driver, decided today to abandon his attempt to set a new world's record on Lake Garda with his Miss England III. Don said he would return to England to discuss possible modifications in the boat with her owner, Lord Wakefield.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Both sides of the Scottsboro (Ala.) case were presented today to members of the Supreme Court in petitions circulated among the justices, urging with equal fervor that the court grant and refuse a review of the death sentence of seven Negroes for assaulting two white girls.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 27 -- Starting of a new form of unemployment relief to put workers on farms was announced by Governor Roosevelt today in an address to Westchester Democrats at Tuckahoe, where he balted on his trip here from New York City.

Pete Donohue, former major league pitcher, made his debut yesterday with Jersey City in the International League and pitched his new club to a 9-to-5 victory over Baltimore at Jersey City. Donohue held the Orioles to five hits, but two of them were homers by McGowan and Heffner.

With the University of Pennsylvania ruling as the slight favorite for the first time in recent years, Columbia, Princeton and Penn will race over the mile and three-quarter course on the Harlem today in the Childs Cup regatta, New York's only taste of intercollegiate rowing this season.

Suze, a sophisticated chimpanzee, arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Mauretania after having shared a first-class cabin from Cherbourg with its owners, Wood Kahler, the American novelist, and his wife. The couple were married on May 3 last. Mrs. Kahler has had the chimpanzee for two years, having obtained the pet in Algiers from the leader of a caravan.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) - The Senate spent twenty minutes today telling the country how hard it works and explaining why none of its members was on hand yesterday when Vice President Curtis rapped the gavel at 10 A.M.

A referendum vote by the membership of the Actors' Equity Association is being sought by the League of New York Theatres in its persistent campaign to obtain Equity's approval for Sunday night performances in the legitimate playhouses of New York.

United States Government bonds and foreign loans were fairly steady yesterday in the face of a weak market for domestic corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover amounted to $14,005,000, of which government issues accounted for $5,907,000, compared with the trading total of $14,133,000 on Thursday, in which Federal loans aggregated only $3,471,500.

The split in the ranks of the building trades unions over acceptance of the reduced wage contract signed by the executive committee of the Building Trades Council two weeks ago was widened yesterday when the spokesmen for the twenty building crafts opposing the new agreement issued a statement declaring that the Building Trades Council had had no authority to sign the contract.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 -- The Mex- ican Foreign Office was officially in- formed today by Ambassador Puig Casauranc that the United States Senate had approved import taxes on petroleum, copper and lumber which are said to have the effect of prohibiting entry of those products from Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Without a record vote, the House passed today the Steagall bill creating a guarantee fund of $400,000,000 to protect depositors and distressed financial institutions. The bill also authorizes a Federal Bank Liquidating Board, established to manage the financial activities under the measure, to borrow an additional $500,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation prior to Jan. 22, 1934, and gives the board power to assess member banks an additional $100,000,000 a year.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- A lesson for present day pessimists who see no hope for recovery from the depression is contained in the decaying papyrus of ancient Egypt, according to an article carried in The Corn Belt Farm Dailies.

LOS ANGELES, May 27 (AP) -- A suit for $10,000 to collect fees for legal work was filed today against Betty Compson, film star, by Edward Brand, Hollywood attorney. Mr. Brand said he had filed attachments on the actress's property and her bank accounts.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 27 -- Baroness Giacomo Levi, Italian star, and Mrs. Philip Hawk of New York today gained the final round in the doubles of the women's annual eastern clay court tennis championship tournament at the Montclair Athletic Club.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 27 -- Egremont Inn at South Egremont, an old tavern recently restored by its present owners, Major Hugh Smiley and Mrs. Smiley, was opened for the season tonigrht. The tap room, in early American pine and hand-hewn beams, is unchanged.
Samuel Seabury started yesterday to chop at tie props of Mayor James J. Walker's defense against possible removal in his appearance as a witness before the Hofstadter committee.
The principal parts of the testimony of Walter R. Herrick and Paul Block before the Hofstadter committee yesterday follow:

Spiced by such anecdotes as that which tells how race-night prohibition came to the Nelson House bar at Poughkeepsie long before the rest of New York State considered prohibition even a possibility, and telling again the stories of the "eel-grass" crew of Yale and the "berry-crate" crew of Wisconsin, the first history of American rowing has just been published.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 (AP) -- Dr. Pedro Jose Zepeda, foreign representative of General Augusto Sandino, Nicaraguan insurgent leader, today asked Secretary of State Stimson to explain his reported statement of yesterday.
BREST, France, May 27 (AP) -- The Italian ship Artiglio II today resumed its attempt to salvage five tons of gold and forty-five tons of silver from the sunken liner Egypt.

At the meeting of the Adult Education Association a year ago in New York the President, Mr. NEWTON BAKER, alluded to the peril of informing a hundred million people simultaneously of some incident that might stir to action without reflection.

Acting under an old statute, the town officials of Weymouth, Mass., have removed a family of six to its "legal settlement" in Fall River, much to the indignation of the latter. Some time ago the rulers of Weymouth announced that they would send "back home" all families that had received town aid but had not lived there for the five years necessary to give them a "legal settlement."

BERLIN, May 27 -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler, the conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, in an exclusive statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES, denied yesterday that he had intended anything in the least derogatory to American orchestras in likening them to "pet dogs" in a recent speech on the semi-centennial of the Berlin orchestra.

Colleges themselves are largely responsible for the attitude of many students who try primarily for degrees rather than for the education these degrees represent, according to Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, who was the principal speaker at the 299th commencement of the Collegiate Institute last night at the school's auditorium, 241 West Seventy-seventh Street.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 27 (AP) -- Chancellor J. O. Wolcott, in Chancery Court, approved today reorganization plans for the Midland Natural Gas Company and the Twin States Natural Gas Company, sub- mitted by receivers of both companies.

SAUNTON, England, May 27 (AP) -- After Miss Maureen Orcutt, Englewood, N.J., had scored a brilliant 73 in the women's British golf championship today, the wind came up and rain swept the bleak stretch, sending the scores of the remainder of the American contingent, as well as the British entrants, soaring.

Attempts to bring before the Board of Estimate a protest against the imposition of academic fees in the city colleges were rebuffed yesterday when the board declined to grant a hearing to a committee of forty-five students from Brooklyn, Hunter and City Colleges.

BERLIN, May 27 (AP) -- Dr. Adam Stegerwald, Federal Labor Minister, told the German Economic Society tonight that 50 per cent of German workshops were idle and more than half of her 44,000,000 electors were dependent to some degree upon the State for a living.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 27 -- The Republican party of Illinois went wet at today's State convention. A plank was included in the State platform calling for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, for a beer and light wine amendment to the Volstead act and repeal of the State search and seizure act.

A contest of the will of Sultan Abmed Kadjar, deposed Shah of persin, who died in exile in Paris Feb. 27, 1930, will soon be started in Surrogates' Court here, it was disclosed yesterday, when an accounting in the estate of the Shah was filed by the Guaranty Trust Company, executor of the estate, so that two of his widows who had been overlooked might be made parties.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Senator Reed charged in a statement today that Speaker Garner's relief proposal "springs from a political motive" and that "in endeavoring to promote his personal prospects he would destroy the credit of the Federal Government."
A mortgage for $7,026 held by Louis Katz from David Block on 182 2d Av. has been extended to Dee. 3, 1934, at 6 per cent.

John W. Davis, chief defense counsel in the perjury trial of Isidor J. Kresel, former general counsel for the defunct Bank of United States, continuing yesterday his cross-examination of Louis Benson, former grand jury stenographer, got the witness to make further admissions regarding Benson's faulty shorthand reporting.

After meeting for three hours yesterday in the Federal Reserve Bank, the Young committee of bankers and industrialists, formed to make effective the credit-expansion program of the Reserve System, adjourned with the meager verbal announcement that it had "discussed questions of fiscal legislation and their bearing upon the things that the committee itself might recommend."

UTICA, N.Y., May 27 -- Compensation and relief for veterans have been "terribly abused," Colonel M. C. Baines of the Veterans' Bureau told the annual convention of Disabled American Veterans of the World War today. Colonel Baines has just been appointed director of the new government hospital at Canandaigua.

The price trend in commodities was lower yesterday. Wheat and rye in the foodstuffs group were heavy, but corn and oats were steady. Cotton, dropped 7 to 10 points, with losses in coffee, cocoa, rubber and silk. Hides were irregular. Spot rubber touched a new low at 2.71 cents.

Professor Osten Unden, former Swedish Minister for Foreign Affairs, will sail today for Gothenburg on the motorship Gripshoim of the Swedish-American Line. Other passengers will include Gustaf Weidel, counselor of the Swedish Legation in Washington; Victor Mutt. Estonian Consul General in New York; Professor and Mrs. J.H. White, Dr. C. H. Fornell, Miss P. Shaffer. Mr. and Mrs. H.D. Ides and Mrs. E. Triest.
