PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- What the world needs, Joseph Hergesheimer believes, is "more politeness and less love."

Thirty-six oils and water-colors and a group of prints comprise the Summer exhibition at the Babcock Galleries, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street. The roster contains many distinguished names, painters who have contributed richly to American art. We encounter Ralph Blakelock, represented, on this occasion, by a very curious "Indian War Dance."

The Cunarder Franconia arrived here yesterday at 9 A.M. with 251 passengers from a 134 days' tour around the world, having visited Egypt, India, China, Japan and the East Indies. The vessel left again at 5 P.M. for London via Plymouth and Havre with 450 passengers.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation reports for the year ended March 31 net income amounting to $9,265,737, equal after preferred dividends to $1.43 a share earned on the average number of common shares outstanding during the period and to $1.02 a share on 3,317,201 common shares outstanding at March 31.

Intimations from well-informed sources that John H. Curtis, accused of obstructing justice through his hoax in the Lindbergh case, would avoid an open trial, were current in Flemington, N.J., last night, on the eve of his expected indictment by the Hunterdon County grand jury.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 27 -- The bayonets of Bolivian outposts in the Chaco district are likely to be the next serious trouble confronting 370 Mennonites of German origin who fled from Russia. After their lands were confiscated by the Soviet Union they wandered through Russia for five years trying to escape Soviet rule.

Mayor WALKER left the witness stand trailing clouds, not of glory, but of mystery after him. Never were there so many explanations which themselves demand explaining, never so many stories or implications quite incredible as they stood, never so many direct invitations to flat contradiction by subsequent witnesses.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Provisions estimated to yield $270,000,000 in new funds were written into the revenue bill in the Senate today as a second and inevitable showdown on the manufacturers' sales tax drew nearer.

The splendor and magnificence that was to have been revealed by the Giants many weeks ago was still conspicuous by its absence yesterday, when the McGrawmen dropped their second straight engagement to the Robins at the Polo Grounds.

The holiday festivities on the north and south shores of Long Island and in the Sound district of Westchester will be marked by the formal opening for the Summer season of several beach clubs that have been popular resorts among members of society for several years.

PARIS, May 27 -- America's chances of success in the doubles of the French tennis championships narrowed today to the prospects of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and her partners through elimination of Sidney B. Wood and Gregory Mangin in the men's quarter-finals by the young French combination of Christian Boussus and Marcel Bernard in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, at the Roland Garros Stadium.

Stocks opened yesterday slightly below the previous close on the Stock Exchange and continued on an irregularly lower trend until about 1:30 P.M., when news of General Electric's reduction of its common dividend caused a more preciptant decline for the rest of the session.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Seaton Pippin, the undefeated brown mare of the Seaton Hackney Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore, Morristown, N.J., won her fifty-third championship today at the Devon horse show, being adjudged the best hackney mare shown in hand.

The "Four Horsemen," captained by P. Hal Sims, maintained the early lead they established in the Metropolitan Contract Bridge League's tournament in the final round of play last night at the Hotel Roosevelt and rode to victory by a lead of seven match points.

Elmer A. Sperry, inventor of the gyroscope, left a gross estate of 53,142,329 and a net estate of $2,853,656 when he died in Brooklyn on June 16, 1930, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a transfer tax report on his estate in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

MADRID, May 27 -- Perhaps the oldest minority problem in Europe, dating from the days of Ferdinand and Isabella, was virtually settled tonight except for formal ratification when Premier Manuel Azana, with a large majority of the Cortes vote pledged to him, stood responsible for granting ample autonomy to Catalonia without endangering Spanish unity.

Barnard College opened its senior week last evening with the traditional step-singing by the student body in the quadrangle of Milbank Hall, followed by the senior show, an 1850 comedy entitled "Fashion, or Life in New York," in the Brinckerhoff Theatre, Broadway and 120th Street.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 27 -- Golf's uncertainties were never more clearly shown than they were today at the Century Country Club, when the two outstanding favorites, Miss Charlotte Glutting and Mrs. Leo G. Federman were swept out of the women's Metropolitan championship in one of the most upsetting semi-final rounds in the history of the event.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- An agreement under which Edward B. McLean would relinquish all power over the affairs of The Washington Post while still serving as co-trustee of the remainder of his father's estate, was filed today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

Busines activity generally is continuing on a hand-to-mouth basis. The weekly reviews of conditions in trade and industry, however, note several indications of improvement in some lines. The oil industry is found to have steadied substantially as a result of the recent Supreme Court ruling in favor of State proration, and some of the lighter industries appear to have succeeded in their efforts to adjust themselves to current conditions.
LONDON, May 27 -- The two biggest railroad companies in Great Britain announced tonight they had agreed to pool receipts "wherever there is competition or contact between them."

PATERSON, N.J., May 27 -- A controversy between two Democratic candidates for the nomination as State Senator to fill the unexpired term of Senator Roy T. Yates, who resigned several months ago, was disclosed here today. Charges of illegal expenditures and improper filing of campaign statements against Assemblyman Thomas E. Manly, the successful candidate in the primaries two weeks ago, were made by Dr. Frank J. Van Noort, who was defeated for the nomination.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The story of an "extraordinary achievement" in line of duty was made public by the Navy Department today with the announcement that the Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Marine Corporal Hilmer N. Torner for an act of "self-sacrificing heroism."

The first dead heat of the year was run yesterday at Belmont Park in the Larkfield Purse, sixth on the card, when Indiantown and Algeria rushed past the judges on such even terms that they could not be separated. Algeria bore the colors of Joseph E. Widener while Indiantown sported the silks of a newcomer to racing, Lew Brown, well known in theatrical circles.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, was found not guilty of neglect of duty for not closing the Bank of United States before he did at 3:40 o'clock this morning by a General Sessions jury which deliberated more than twelve hours before reaching a verdict.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- An effort is being made by prominent Republicans and Democrats to take the prohibition issue out of the coming campaign by having both parties adopt at their national conventions identical planks on the issue.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- A bit more fortunate in bunching their hits at the right time, the Tigers defeated the White Sox again today, 7 to 5. The White Sox used three pitchers, Lyons and Faber yielding nine hits. Vic Sorrell, who started for the Tigers, was removed in the ninth when Chicago started a rally with one out.

White Vogue Gains Headway. The vogue for white apparel and accessories has steadily gained ground and merchandise of this nature represents a large percentage of the goods being reordered at this time, it was reported here yesterday.

The validity of the agreement entered into last July by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and the New York Clothing Manufacturers' Exchange was upheld yesterday in a decision, of Referee John J. O'Connell, to be filed today or Tuesday in the Supreme Court.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27 -- The varsity crews of Cornell, Syracuse and Harvard, which will meet in a triangular race over the mile and three-quarter course on the Charles River tomorrow, put in their final practice spins today.

LOS ANGELES, May 27 -- Mrs. John G. Fratt of New Orleans, Tulane graduate and director of Region 4, was nominated today as president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, at the annual meeting here, to succeed Mrs. Roger S. Speery of Waterbury, Conn.

With $32,800,741 of new State and municipal bonds listed for award next week, $20,000,000 will comprise a single issue, that of the city of Philadelphia 5 per cent long-term bonds, scheduled for Friday. This week's revised total amounted to $11,084,749, and the weekly average for the year to date is $22,113,364.

LONDON, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- "We are likely to have a complete economic collapse in Europe within the next few months," said L.S. Amery, member of the House of Commons and former Secretary of State for Dominions, in addressing the Conservative Association of Oxford University tonight.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had urged the deepening of the Hudson River to at least 40 feet as far north as West Fifty-ninth Street, Manhattan, in a statement filed with the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.

RIDGE WOOD, N.J., May 27 -- With lightning flashing and thunder rolling over the New Jersey hills, little Birkie Donald of Cherry Top calmly posed on the judging block beside a huge Great Dane and nonchalantly accepted the rosette and massive silver cup which went with the title of best dog in the first annual dog show of the Ridgewood Kennel Club, held today on the grounds of the Elks Club.

The stockholders of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, ratified the selection of a board of fifteen directors for the reorganized bank when it reopens some time in June. Eight of the directors represent capital and seven labor.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- In the view of political Washington, Mayor James J. Walker of New York City has become a national problem, just like prohibition, taxation, economy and unemployment relief.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Hoover today recommended an appropriation of $7,000,000 to carry on construction work on Hoover Dam on the Colorado River.

Three men are dead and a fourth, reported missing all day yesterday, is believed to have drowned in the crash of the Merchants and Miners Line freighter Grecian with the Savannah liner City of Chattanooge early yesterday morning off Block Island.

Virtually little new business was turned in any section of the money market with the result that quotations for every class of accommodation carried over without change. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, street trades went at 1 1/4 and Federals sold at 1/8.

ALBANY, May 27 -- After being closed for a day and a half, forests in New York State were reopened to the public today, thus assuring use of the State's forest preserves for the many who have planned outings for this Memorial Day week-end.
Other witnesses besides Park Commissioner Walter R. Herrick have given testimony in direct conflict with that given by Mayor Walker.

THE new plan for athletics at Yale is open for inspection. The line forms on the right. Do not push or crowd. There's plenty of time. It doesn't go into effect until 1933, and even then there will be holdover obligations such as the scheduled intersectional football game with the University of Georgia.

The increase in public expenditures of Federal, State and municipal governments, which presents "a staggering situation," similar to conditions when this country entered the World War, was attacked yesterday by Leroy A. Lincoln, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in an address to the members of the American Legion posts of that organization and of the New York Life Insurance Company, at their annual memorial luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin.

BERLIN, May 20 ((AP) by Mail) -- Various proposals emanating from European capitals in the shape of trial balloons proposing that the United States accept bonds of the German railways system in lieu of war debt payments from the former Allies, find American business men here skeptical in view of the present condition of the German railways.

ALFRED, Me., May 27 (AP) -- Lawrence Noll, a New York youth whose career of crime started with larceny and ended on the same day with murder, tonight sat in solitary confinement, awaiting commitment to the State prison at Thomaston to begin serving a life sentence.

Sales of department stores, chain stores and wholesalers in the New York area continued to decline in April, the monthly review of credit and business condition of the Federel Reserve Agent in New York will say on June 1. The report follows in part:

For years Tammany orators cried aloud for home rule. Finally the Legislature and the people of the State gave it to them, generously in the constitutional amendment of 1923, somewhat more guardedly in the home rule act of 1924. That charter of municipal liberties accords the local legislative body broad powers to adopt and amend local laws in relation to the "property, affairs or government" of the city.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 27 -- While three navy fliers dropped a tribute of roses, Gettysburg College conferred the degree of Doctor of Laws upon President Hoover in absentia at the centennial exercises here today. The crowd of several thousand persons rose and cheered when Dr. Henry W.A. Hanson, president of the college, announced the degree for Mr. Hoover, who was unable to come here to receive it.

Forty thousand men are expected to march in the golden jubilee parade of the Holy Name Society to be held Sunday afternoon, June 12, at 2 o'clock. The rally following the parade will be held in The Green in Central Park. The parade will start from Thirty-fourth Street and proceed up Fifth Avenue past St. Patrick's Cathedral to The Green, which is on the west side of the park, just north of Sixty-sixth Street.

The fifty-seventh running of the Withers, one of the most famous stakes renewed by the Westchester Racing Association, will be the feature at Belmont Park today and will see E.R. Bradley's Burgoo King, winner of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, in action against six formidable 3-year-old rivals.

Isadora Newman, who has written children's books illustrated by Willy Pogany, is having an exhibition of "imagics" and "spirituals in color" at the Ainslie Gallery in the Waldorf-Astoria. It remains until June 10.

Henry L. Doherty, president, and W.A. Jones, first vice president of the Cities Service Company, announced yesterday that five companies of the Cities Service group had omitted or would omit today all dividends on their preferred and common stocks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The special Washington dispatch in THE TIMES today from Arthur Krock shows clearly the situation that will confront the Chicago Democratic convention on the tariff issue. This issue must be met squarely and boldly by the party if it hopes to win the election.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Approval of a further Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan of $2,775,000 to the Erie Railroad by the Interstate Commerce Commission today was criticized by Commissioner Eastman, who assailed the policy of bankers in demanding payment of railroad obligations when due.
After displaying resistance for several hours, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined sharply yesterday as securities weakened. The close was at losses of 7 to 10 points.

Women and Showmanship. Women have long had an important part in the theatre as actresses, as playwrights and as producers. Now, according to Variety, they are turning to theatre management, and with striking success.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The Boerse opened today with an upward movement in prices, caused by Swiss buying orders and increased activity among public investors, but an attack on General Electric of Germany interrupted the advance, which was followed by realizations on all sides. Practically all the gains were lost.

LONDON, May 27 -- The tendency of the stock market was somewhat better today. Liquidation was on a smaller scale and showed signs of ceasing in some departments of the Exchange. The recovery in Wall Street yesterday strengthened the tone in the industrials, as did news of firmness in Paris.

PARIS, May 27 -- The Bourse was irregular again today. With the exception of rentes and some of the international stocks, most of the list showed losses. A sharp decline in Union Parisienne owing to rumors concerning that institution, which were officially discounted, affected all French bank shares.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Hoover in the strongest language he has used since becoming Chief Executive denounced the Garner unemployment relief bill today as "the most gigantic pork barrel ever proposed to the American Congress" and "an unexampled raid on the public treasury."

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, May 27 -- The contemplated tax of 4 cents a pound on copper imported into the United States is raising a question of grave importance here, where the total production of copper ore is second only to that in the United States.

A new process for hand-reproduction in water-color, which, it is said, can be applied equally well to auditorium walls and women's pyjamas, is being shown at the Art Centre by David Darling, a native New Yorker, well known as a book illustrator. For several years he has been engaged in perfecting this "water-graph" process.

The sale by a bank of a large upper west side apartment house was the outstanding transaction in Manhattan yesterday. Conveyance of a large site in the Pennsylvania Station zone to the Hotels Statler Company was shown in papers recorded, but the deal has no significance because of the fact that the Statler interests had controlled the properties for many years through "dummy" corporations, C.B. Stoner, secretary and treasurer of the company, explained.

The Board of Transportation served notice yesterday on 297 employes that their services would not be required after June 30. The reason given for the laying off of the men was "no work," It was announced that the payroll reduction would result in a saving of $761,889 a year.

Declaring that the "zero hour" in New York's war against want was at hand for thousands of men, women and children dependent upon the community for aid, Dr. S. Parkes Cadman broadcast a plea last night from Station WABC for the support of the Salvation Army's united appeal.
Housing properties continued to provide the bulk of realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan, area reported yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York rimes: The creation, under the chairmanship of Owen D. Young, of a committee of bankers and industrialists to help stabilize economic conditions and make effective the credit expansion policies of the Federal Reserve Board is another proof of the inadequacy of our rugged individualism to cope with the present crisis.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- A six-run blast against Ray Kolp in the third inning today gave the Cubs a 6-to-4 victory over Cincinnati and increased their margin over the Braves for the National League lead to one and one-half games as Boston lost.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Farm aid spokesmen voiced confidence tonight a vote would be had in the Senate on agricultural relief measures before Congress adjourns.

"A Princess in Exile," the further memoirs of Marie, Grand Duchess of Russia, whose earlier book, "The Education of a Princess," was the best-selling non-fiction book of 1931, will be brought out by the Viking Press on Aug. 26. This new volume begins where the first book left off, starts with the escape of the Grand Duchess from Russia to the court of Queen Marie of Rumania, and carries her through Europe to America.

ANNAPOLIS, May 27 -- Twenty-six midshipmen out of the graduating class attained a star, or distinctive ranking, in the final averages for the four-year term, it was announced today at the Naval Academy.

DENVER, Col., May 27 -- A Fundamentalist group was defeated in the Presbyterian General Assembly in an effort to exclude from the $10,000,000 budget, adopted today, an item of $14,500 for participation in the affairs of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Large numbers of Chinese and Russian refugees are streaming into Harbin, Manchuria, from the cities to the eastward down the Sungari River, where severe fighting between large Japanese forces and Chinese irregulars has been taking place, according to a report received by the State Department today from George C. Hanson, the Consul General at Harbin.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Saracens, an organization of young prohibitionists, was started in Chicago today. It is planned to make the society national in scope.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The possibility of the United States being eliminated from the competition for the Davis Cup without reaching tha European front became an improbability today when the American team established a commanding lead over Australia in their final round tie at the Philadelphia Country Club.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28. -- A week's bitter struggle for the forty places in Monday's 500-mile automobile race here ended late today with the completion of the fastest field in the history of the event.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- A new "mystery squad," hand-picked, by Kern Dodge, Director of Public Safety, today raided four alleged liquor-selling establishments, three of which were in the crowded central city district. Director Dodge went personally to one address to watch the work of demolishing a bar with hatchets, axes and crowbars.

WHAT planks shall go into the Democratic platform? The question was put to seven outstanding Democrats at Washington. Their answers, given below, coincide in many respects, though there are some notable differences.

Charges that the treasury of the Federal Water Service Corporation, 27 William Street, was "stripped of many millions of dollars" through the purchase of worthless securities from and loans to "insolvent and financially irresponsible corporations" controlled by the same group that dominated the Federal have been made in a stockholder's suit brought in Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday.

THE first volume of Sir William Rothenstein's "Men and Memories" was one of the most delightful books of 1931. The work of a distinguished artist whose talent for portraiture finds equally felicitous expression in the printed word, Sir William's recollections of the "'80s and '90s" at once assumed a place among those personal records which truly reanimate the past.

About 1,000 degrees will be conferred at the eighty-seventh commencement of Fordham University, which will begin next Saturday and continue through the following week, it was announced yesterday. The College of Arts and Sciences will give 280 degrees; Law, 275; Pharmacy, 165, and the Manhattan divisions, which include the Graduate School, Teachers College, Downtown College, Sociology and Business Administration, 400.

RICHMOND, May 26. -- The controversy over the propriety of staging at the Confederate reunion here next month a pageant depicting Virginia's withdrawal from the Union doubtless will not attract the international notice which was accorded the discussion last year of the advisability of showing the surrender of Cornwallis at the Yorktown Sesquicentennial, but it is getting pretty lively, and is highly significant in its implications.

OUT in the Bay of Fundy, at White Head, Grand Manan, Island, the sea-farmers or dulse pickers are preparing for the season which begins in May and extends until September. The island itself is twenty-one miles long with many harbors and fishing villages.

The current month proved featureless so far as trade activity was concerned, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents points out in its current report. The only gain noted was in the Western States, where a seasonal improvement of small proportions was observed.

LONDON. NEXT Wednesday is Derby Day, the one day of the year on which Englishmen away from home tend to become absent-minded and to cast an occasional eye at the clock -- the day on which the annual murmur, "They're off at Epsom," rustles from Englishman to Englishman, around the world and back again, as soon as the local timepieces indicate that it is 3 o'clock in the afternoon at home.

C.G. Allers led a field of fourteen gunners at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. He had a card of 95-6-100, the best scratch and the best handicap score of the day. As he could not take both cups, R. Jones, C. Schad and G.C. Schwalb, who each had 100 full targets, shot for the handicap trophy.

Several changes in the collateral behind the Solvay American Investment Corporation's fifteen-year 5 per cent secured notes due in 1942 were announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The indenture provides that the notes must have a 200 per cent coverage.

YOU have three Important factors in a country like this. You have your economic situation, you have your social situation and you have your political situation. Disintegration in any one of them merely encourages disintegration in the others, and I am convinced that our situation in the United States today is such that we have to be most careful to keep Integration in all three.

JUNE will usher in many weddings and there is scarcely day during the entire month without at least one of note, several on some days, especially Saturdays. One of the outstanding marriages will be that of Miss Vivien Antonia Bligh Saint George to Alexander Frank Stanley-Clarke.

THE Federal Radio Commission is not playing ostrich with its head in the sand in regard to television, according to Commissioner Harold Lafount, who reported to the Radio Manufacturers' Association that "we are not yet convinced television has emerged from the laboratory and is ready to matriculate into the more severe course of adult entertainment and education."

Furniture, tapestries. Oriental rugs, paintings, silver and textiles will be offered at auction on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. An entire session will be devoted to the sale of Chinese semi-precious minerals, porcelains, pottery, lamps, furniture and rugs sold by various owners, including Armand Tokatyan of New York.

SAUNTON, England, May 28. -- The heroine of Devonshire tonight is Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., who, adding only 78 shots today to her 73 of yesterday, headed the qualifying list for Monday's match play in the women's British open golf championship with a total of 151.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28. -- Manowarson, a 5-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Doris Boice, and Happy, a brown gelding owned by Mrs. Helen Benson, but entered by W.J. Stratton, shared the major honors at the second annual Stony Brook Hunt horse show today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial "Archaeology and the Bible" in THE NEW YORK TIMES is an example of the danger of drawing hasty conclusions. However comforting may be the statement that "fresh testimony comes out of the earth in support of the scriptural narrative," it is unfair to archaeologists and to serious Bible students.

OXFORD, England, May 28. -- The best thing the gold standard countries could do for rapid economic recovery would be immediately to start inflation of their currencies, declared Professor Gustaf Cassel, Swedish economist, in the last of his three Rhodes lectures on the crisis in the world's monetary system.

DEVON, Pa., May 28. -- Squire of the United States Army horse-show team from Fort Myer, Va., slipped on the treacherous outside course during the five-foot jumping class and fell, rolling over several times, today at the Devon horse show. Lieutenant Bennett, who was riding the horse, barely escaped injury.

Manual Training High School's 4-to-2 lacrosse victory over Erasmus Hall on Wednesday that gave Manual the laurels for the nineteenth time since 1910 accounted for the second city P.S.A.L. championship won by the school within six days. In both instances the title-winning teams, the only two at Manual during the current school year, were coached by Joe Harrigan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Rowing a superb forty-stroke in the last quarter mile, Columbia University's varsity 150-pound crew scored a spectacular victory in the feature event of the twenty-eighth annual American Henley on the wind-swept Sehuylkill today.

UNEMPLOYED architects and draftsmen will be the beneficiaries of the garden party which will be held on the afternoon of June 11 at Greystone, the country place of Samuel Untermeyer, overlooking the Hudson River at Yonkers. The event is one of a series that has been arranged by the Women's Division of the Architects' Emergency Committee in their efforts to raise a relief fund of $100,000 for destitute architects and draftsmen, and their needy families.

ONE might have expected the custodians of auction sales records to curtain with silence the evidence in their possession for the years immediately following the fateful 1929. But no, to prove that life must and does go on, they have Just issued the thirty-seventh volume in that annual register of names and figures known as "American Book-Prices Current."

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The nation stretched its ears to hear what replies Mayor James J. Walker made to Samuel Seabury before the Hofstadter Committee's investigation in New York City this week. It heard confessions, evasions, contradictions of other witnesses, jests, threats, and, at the end, a lecture to the committee from His Honor.

NEW HAVEN, May 28. -- Plans for the 231st commencement at Yale University were announced today. Members of the graduating class of Yale College and Sheffield Scientific School will receive their degrees on the morning of June 21, and graduate, professional and honorary degrees will be conferred on the following morning.

ST. LOUIS. LAMBERT-ST. LOUIS MUNICIPAL AIRPORT here is becoming recognized as a "Union Air Depot," with whirring propeller supplanting the hiss and clangor of the steam railroad, according to the annual report of O.R. Parks, field manager.

VIENNA, May 26. -- The formation after a fortnight of party bargaining of a Christian Social-Farmers-Heimwehr coalition represents a decided swing to the right in Austrian politics. It was scarcely an outcome expected by the Socialists when they forced the resignation of the Buresch Cabinet and demanded new elections.

A decrease of more than $2,600,000 in the value of the estate of Robert W. de Forest, former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, since his death on May 6, 1931, was shown yesterday in an intermediate accounting filed in Surrogate's Court by his sons, Johnston de Forest of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Henry L. de Forest of Plainfield, N.J., as executors.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- An analysis of the reports of leading political writers in all parts of the country indicates:

IN the yellowed, century-old registers of a Niagara Falls hotel are the names of celebrities, including that of Abraham Lincoln, who journeyed to the Falls before the modern age of transportation in family coaches and on horseback. The hotel is the Cataract House, which, renovated and enlarged, carries on the tradition of the Eagle Tavern, erected in 1814.

WASHINGTON. A GREAT cry has gone up in Washington from President Hoover and his supporters against what the President rails "a locust swarm of lobbyists who haunt the halls of Congress." Strange as it may seem, no administration voice was lifted against the lobbyists when the Capital was overrun with those who were supporting the measures favored by the administration.
WITH the approach of Summer the operating schedule of WGY's short-wave stations is altered to give maximum service over a maximum area.

SIX years ago this week the civilized world was anxiously wondering what had become of six men who set out from Spitsbergen on May 25 in two planes to fly over the North Pole. For twenty-four days a waiting world held its breath and scanned the northern horizon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 28. -- Brig. Gen. John Ross Delafield, commander-in-chief of the Military Order of the World War, will be the principal speaker at the Memorial Day celebration to be held at Playland, in Rye, Monday afternoon. He will be introduced by John Motley Morehead, United States Minister to Sweden.

THE site of one of the fiercest hand-to-hand conflicts of the Civil War was recently deeded to the United States. It is the four-acre plot in the Spottsylvania Court House Battlefield, known as the "Bloody Angle."

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the Week ended May 21 were above those of the preceding week, but continued considerably below those of a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

THE brook - trouting season comes once more. Its high harbingers, the President the ex-President, reappear in printed word and picture, inspiring a million hearts with hope. If the Rapidan is kind to Mr. Hoover and the Simsbury stream to Mr. Coolidge, so shall other little rivers be good to all brothers of the angle and yield treasure and pleasure in the happy days at hand.

LONDON, May 27. -- Lord Ronald Gorell's committee, appointed on the eve of the depression by the late president of the Board of Trade, William Graham, to investigate the relationship of art and industry, issued a report this week in which it says that the present hard times are better than any other for making its outlined campaign for raising the standards of public taste.

MOSCOW, May 27. -- There is a growing conviction among responsible Americans here who have a finger on the pulse of international affairs that recognition between the United States and the Soviet Union is not far off. They feel that affairs have reached a state where these two countries are bound to recognize each other for the interests of both.

MUSEUM OF IRISH ART -- An attractive group exhibition containing the work of six contemporary Irish painters -- George Russell (AE), Paul Henry, John Keating, Jack Yeats, Miceal McGonigail and Power O'Malley. The last-named has just concluded his successful one-man showing at the Montross and Mr. Yeats exhibited recently, also on a large scale, at Ferargil's.
BERLIN, May 27. -- The ascendency of the militarists in Japan, well-informed opinion here holds, contains a formidable and multiple danger for Germany.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- The national convention of the Communist party of America tonight nominated William Z. Foster of New York for President and James W. Ford, a Negro, for Vice President, amid scenes of shouting and singing in the red-draped Coliseum.

The smaller business and industrial concerns of the country have made more drastic reductions in salaries and wage scales during the current depression period than have the larger organizations, a survey of 1,718 companies, employing 3,258,666 persons in 1929, by the National Industrial Conference Board revealed yesterday.

Behind the effective pitching of Walter Signer and Don Shearer, who combined their efforts in holding the New York Athletic Club nine to four hits and striking out nine between them, New York University triumphed by 9 to 6 yesterday at the Winged Foot diamond in Travers Island.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Japan is finding the cost of her Manchurian adventure more than she reckoned, according to informed Opinion here. She is about to vote $61,000,000 more for her operations there and this is regarded as only a start.

At the Imperial College of Science a Huxley Memorial Lecture is given every year. By happy choice the lecturer for 1932 was THOMAS HENRY HUXLEY'S grandson, ALDOUS. Thus to an eminent man of letters fell the pious task of honoring a still more eminent man of letters.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 28. -- Orange County's part in the Revolution was celebrated today in the second of the New York State observances of the Washington Bicentenary.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 28. -- Prince Charming, a bay gelding owned by the Warfield Farms, captured the hunter championship as the fourth annual horse show of the Boulder Brook. Club came to a close today on the club grounds.

THE problem or unemployment has at least one good feature about it: it apparently keeps many persons employed at the task of writing about unemployment. Many and varied are the points of view presented by the unusually large number of books that now appear on the subject.

CHICAGO. WHEN the Republican and Democratic National Conventions come to Chicago in June, this city will be returning to a familiar role -- one in which she may be said to have gained pre-eminence among American cities since the middle of the last century.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most barren and one of the most dangerous experiences in life is to have one's heart wrung with emotion; to feel one's nerves pulled until they are ready to snap; to fly into a terrible rage and cry out that "something must be done," and then end up by doing nothing-at all.

WHEN Robert Louis Stevenson wrote his "Modern Arabian Nights," he probably never thought that the imaginative story of the Suicide Club would flower into reality. But the idea of a suicide bureau, even as the slightly different story itself, has traveled across Europe, and now, after a slow career, has developed and been modernized into the present Beratungstelle Fuer Lebensmuede (Advisory Centre for Those Weary of Life) in Vienna.

TRENTON, N.J., May 28 (AP). -- Outscoring a closely bunched field of eighteen rivals by nine points, the New York City police today captured first place in the eighth annual inter-State pistol shoot at the Wilburtha Station of the New Jersey State Police.

SAUNTON, England, May 28 (AP). -- Remaining in the field of the women's British golf championship, tucked neatly away under the qualifying limit of 180 strokes, are all the members of the American team that defeated a British team recently at Wentworth, with the sole exception of the non-playing captain, Miss Marion Hollins of Santa Barbara.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- Faced by a threatened occupation of the capital by hundreds of war veterans, Pelham D. Glassford, Chief of Metropolitan Police, appealed today to the Governors of Virginia and Maryland not to transport veterans to the District of Columbia unless they agreed not to stay longer than forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- A summary of the revised Garner relief bill shows an increase in the total sum from $2,146,874,468 to $2,309,084,337. As it goes to the Ways and Means Committee, the bill provides a total of $1,209,084,337 for public works construction, including Federal buildings, highway and waterway Improvements; a $1,000,000,000 increase in the funds of the Reconstruction Corporation for loans to States, political subdivisions and private industry, and $100,000,000 for direct relief.

Art left the rarefied atmosphere of velvet draperies yesterday and descended to the sidewalk. It was a move which gave a festive color to the south and west sides of Washington Square, where needy artists showed their paintings in one of New York's rare outdoor art exhibitions.

Just around the corner, we are constantly being told, is an era when all of us, grown-ups as well as children, will be going to school. Millions of adults in the past few years, particularly in the university towns and metropolitan centres, have been turning toward lighted classrooms at night.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Edward F. Swift, chairman of the board of Swift Co. and an outstanding figure in the business and social life of Chicago, was killed this morning by a fall from his eighth-floor apartment at 1,550 North State Parkway. He was 68 years old.

LONDON, May 28. -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, Amy Johnson and J.A. Mollison flew to the Brooklands civil air display today. The American airwoman was pilote by Gordon Seldridge Jr. in his Puss Moth machine and received a great ovation. The Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators organized a display and conferred an honorary membership on Mrs. Putnam.

THE second of George Bernard Shaw's plays is to reach the screen, via a British producing company. Two years ago an amateurish film of Shaw's one-act comedy "How He Lied to Her Husband" emerged out of Elstree. Cecil Lewis, who was responsible for that piece, is now preparing to make a film of "Arms and the Man" at the British International Pictures Studio in Elstree.

FINDING present methods of paying for motor injuries inadequate to meet an increasingly serious situation, the Committee to Study Compensation for Automobile Accidents, in its report recently issued, recommends a plan analogous to that of the workmen's compensation laws, "with limited liability and without regard to fault."

DENVER, Col., May 28. -- Women of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America have won admission to the general council, highest administrative body in the church. An overture to admit one woman to the council, submitted to the Presbyteries last year, has been approved by a vote of 146 to 91, with fifty-four Presbyteries not voting, it was announced at the general assembly here today.
LONDON, May 28. -- Ord Hamilton, an American composer, and Miss Constance Carpenter, actress, were married at the Register Office today.

OUTLIVING all his eminent contemporaries, and rounding out ninety years before death took him in 1928, Sir George Otto Trevelyan was one of a group typical of English public life in the reign of Queen Victoria -- the type of literary man who was also a statesman, the statesman and literary man who was also a historian.

Sofina, or Societe Financiers de Transports et d'Entreprises Industrielles of Brussels, one of the leading international utility holding companies, had no funded debt and no bank loans at the close of 1931, according to its pamphlet report, received here last week.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., May 28 (AP). -- Colorado's sixteen delegates to the Democratic National Convention will cast their twelve votes for Governor Roosevelt for President.

BESIDES her old stand-by, Lord Peter Wimsey, Dorothy Sayers presents in this story Harriet Vane, the writer of detective stories who owes Lord Peter a deep debt of gratitude for having once cleared her of a charge of murder.

WESTERN AIR EXPRESS, the first air line in the country of those now in operation to carry passengers on regular schedule, celebrated its sixth anniversary last week. The company offers this record for inspection: ...

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Speaker Garner replied today to President Hoover's characterization of his Federal relief bill as a gigantic "pork-barrel" measure, charging the President with inconsistency, and declaring that Democrats in Congress did not expect to get "real cooperation" from the White House in relief steps.

Butter. Receipts, 12,253 packages. The market closed in unsettled position. Supplies are not cleared in first hands, and with heavy offerings available Tuesday the immediate outlook is uncertain and probably sliglitly easier.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- Detroit and Chicago split a double header today, the Tigers taking the opener, 4 to 1, and the White Sox winning the nightcap, 7 to 5 in 10 innings.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 28. -- Cardinal Hayes will preside at the twenty-fifth annual commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle on Monday, June 6. Degrees will be awarded to 161 young women. The commencement speaker will be the Rev. Dr. John S. Middleton of Dunwoodie Seminary.

ON the brow of the Arlington hills, encased in marble, lie the symbol of America's sacrifices to the god of war and of America's attitude toward war. Other times and other nations have thought of war in terms of triumphal arches and statues of conquerors on horseback.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 28 (AP). -- Thomas J. Mangan, convicted May 6 of falsifying a return of the looted State Bank of Binghamton, was sentenced this morning to from one to three years at hard labor in Auburn prison by Justice F. Walter Bliss of the Supreme Court.

FOR those who, on the eve of the Ottawa conference, wish to be up to date this is the book to be read. Graduated a Oxford, Professor Brady has not ceased to be a Canadian, and his work is a labor of love. From coast to coast he has surveyed the familiar landscape of his country, nor does the merit of the picture consist only in perspective.

Virtually all the pastors in the city will preach a Memorial Day sermon today. Some of the ministers will refer to the legislative investigation of the Walker Administration. Because of the national holiday tomorrow many patriotic and Masonic organizations will have their annual church service this afternoon or evening.

THE League of Nations Council has finally approved a draft Plan for the rehabilitation of the Negro Republic of Liberia, a country dominated by a small group of American Liberians, and having an area about as large as Pennsylvania.

The Spring membership campaign of the Federation, for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies will open Tuesday and continue for two weeks. It was announced yesterday that every effort will be made to enroll 5,000 new subscribers by June 15.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 28. -- Miss Norma Taubele of New York won the women's Eastarn clay-court tennis championship for the second time today when she defeated Baroness Giacomo Levi. Italian star, in the final match at the Montclair Athletic Club.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A.M.M. Carette writes to THE TIMES that he was amazed to see some flags hang in Fifth Avenue overnight, pointing to it as a breach of flag etiquette.

ANGORA. MODERN Turkey has had no "Five-Year Plan" like Soviet Russia's and very little publicity has attended the efforts of Mustapha Kemal Pasha to "Europeanize" his people. Yet, if the two revolutions are compared, the achievements of the Turkish dictator are more striking than what has been accomplished by Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin.

MADRID, May 27. -- A national terrorist plot, designed to destroy and overthrow the Spanish Government, was blocked during the past week by the Department of the Interior. Police, acting on information supplied by the secret service, raided syndicalist headquarters in all parts of Spain, finding thousands of bombs.

A MILWAUKEE engineer, John P. Ferris, recently told a joint meeting of the Engineers' Society of Milwaukee and the faculty of the College of Engineering of the University of Wisconsin what is wrong with this machine world of ours, now that it has fallen upon lean days.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- More than 10,000,000 persons are receiving flour from the Red Cross out of the 40,000,000 bushels of Farm Board wheat voted to it by Congress for distribution among those in need, the Red Cross announced today.

All the banks, as well as the financial and commodity markets, except the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, will be closed tomorrow in observance of Memorial Day. Business will be entirely suspended in Wall Street.

WALT WHITMAN'S line, "I think I could turn and live with animals, they are so placid and selfcontain'd," comes naturally to mind as one reads these two books, the one by a professional dealer in wild animals, the other an amateur who is never so happy as when he is in a circus menagerie or a zoo.

June will be a busy month for dog exhibitors in the metropolitan district. On returning from the compact Pennsylvania circuit their first event will be the ever attractive exhibition of North Westchester Kennel Club on Saturday, June 11, which is to be held as usual at Lawrence Farms in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

MOSCOW, May 28 (AP). -- Signal honor was paid to an American engineering company today by the Soviet Government, which conveyed formal appreciation to Stuart, James Cooke, Inc., of New York for its six years of technical assistance in the development of Soviet industry.

EDMUND BURKE (1729-1797) is one of the greatest names in the history of political literature. His commanding position was achieved without his once holding an important post in any English ministry. No other statesman has employed general philosophic ideas more successfully to illuminate the specific problems of law-making and administration than Burke.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- The "yellow-dog contract," which Congress recently declared contrary to public policy, was defended before a Senate Mining sub committee today by E.L. Greever of Tazewell, Va., counsel for the National Coal Association.

READING, Pa., May 28. -- The tailend Reading Keys throw a jolt into the Newark Bears today, winning the first game of the series in ten inning, 6 to 5, and plunging the visitors into their fifth straight loss.

On to Washington! ln conversation, with, several leading men here, the thought was advanced It might be a good idea if some of the representative men of our large cities would plan for a drive entitled "On to Washington." It seems to me high time that some members of Congress realized they have been sent to Washington to perform a service that would be in the best interests of our country.

WITH this week's announcement by the Victor Company that the Beethoven Sonata Society, sponsored by the Gramophone Company, Ltd., of England, is to be conducted on more general lines than those under which the Hugo Wolf subscription set was launched, one breathes a sigh of relief.

The common stocks of two companies, General Theatres Equipment, Inc., and Cuban Cane Products Company, Inc., which have been, active trading mediums on the New York Stock Exchange, may be stricken from the list on Tuesday at a meeting of the committee on stock list of the Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

WHILE most of us are familiar with such controversies as the Shakespeare - Bacon, many may not know of the counter claims of Coster vs. Gutenberg. Ever since the appearance of the Cologne Chronicle in 1499 with the longest and most important fifteenth century description of the beginning of printing, with its reference to Gutenberg as having "improved but not invented the art," there has been much controversy as to who did the inventing.

FUNDAMENTALLY, the condition of unemployment, which is sapping our national morale, is due to the prostration of American business. Unemployment will not be relieved until business revives and business will not revive until confidence in the future has been restored.

To the Editor of New York Times: IN the Sunday TIMES of May 15 I find a reprinted interview with Mr. Feodor Chaliapin in regard to the "rediscovered" original version of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff." Mr. Chaliapin states that, "as a whole, this original version is not adapted for the stage.

JUST fifty years ago the State of New York embarked upon a program of "farm relief" that was looked upon at the time by many persons as an exceedingly doubtful undertaking. The proposal was to put science to work for the New York farmer by setting up an agricultural experiment station to which he could take the problems that he could not solve for himself.
CINCINNATI, May 28. -- The ordination of eighteen young men as rabbis marked the graduation exercises of the Hebrew Union College today.
PARIS, May 28. -- Senator Henry Berenger, former French Ambassador to the United States, today urged a one-third reduction in reparations payments because business has diminished 30 per cent.

THE holiday festivities which began yesterday and will continue through tomorrow night are serving to inaugurate the Summer season at notable beach clubs on the North and South shores of Long Island and in the Sound districts of Westchester.

On complaint of Thomas E. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney, United States Commissioner Francis A. O'Neill issued a warrant yesterday for the arrest of Larry Fay, Broadway character, for his alleged failure to pay to the government its share of cover and food charges in the Club Rendezvous, which he operated in the Winter Garden Building in 1929.

THE United States Army Air Corps has a fighting plane with a 600-horsepower engine which has attained a high speed of 218 miles an hour at 22,000 feet. This same machine at sea level has a speed without ground boosting of 176 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON. FEDERAL relief for unemployment now looms as a certainty. Administration and legislative groups which have been disputing this proposal in the past now agree that it is a necessity. The official viewpoint which held only a few months ago that such relief is the sole province of States and their subdivisions has now veered sharply to acknowledgment that the Federal Government must cooperate.

RADIO research experts are moving close to the realm of light to work new wonders. They are experimenting with waves so short that they act in general like rays of light. The tiny waves are carrying television faces flashed daily from atop the Empire State Building.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 27. -- Out of the restless cerebellum of Governor Alfalfa Bill Murray has come another initiative petition to harry the hard-pressed business men of Oklahoma.

KEEPING records of "visibility" -- that is, the transparency of the atmosphere as defined by the greatest distances at which conspicuous objects, such as trees and buildings, can be seen and identified from a specified point of observation -- has lately become one of the big routine tasks of the weather man, mainly because of the need of such information in connection with aviation.

THE week in aviation was marked by the annual conference of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at Langley Field, Va. As usual the committee had something very much worth while to show the leaders in the field of civil and military aviation who were assembled to see, at first hand, the results of its past year of effort.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 28. -- Ken Mackenzie, the New Haven (Conn.) schoolboy who enlivened the finish of the Albany-New York race two weeks ago, turned in another thrilling performance on Lake Quinsigamond today to win the feature of the opening outboard program of the Worcester County Motor Boat Club's annual three-day regatta.

When President HOOVER last December called the leaders of the building trades together to discuss the dwelling of Everyman, whose income is less than $1,400 a year, he could hardly have foreseen the outcome. What he had in mind was the revival of an important industry.

Great Britain is believed about to give to the world additional and grandiose evidence of her financial recovery and economic good health. It is understood that the London government will in the near future undertake the refunding of the 1917 5 per cent war loan of u2,500,000,000 by converting it into 3 per cent, 3 1/2 per cent, or 4 per cent bonds and by cash redemption.

Declines prevailed in all the local commodity markets last week. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk, silver and wool tops closed with losses. All the Exchanges except silk were closed yesterday.

Columbia University's 178th commencement opens today with the baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel at 4 P.M., and will close Wednesday evening with a great outdoor ceremony before the library, at which Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will confer about 5,200 bachelor, graduate and honorary degrees in addition to about 700 certificates and diplomas.

A "TWO-EYED" motion picture camera which has been perfected after five years of will be officially tested for the first time in timing the intercollegiate and Olympic races in California this Summer. The camera is designed to give an absolutely fool-proof record of speed to the 1-100th of a second and to eliminate any possibility of inaccurate placing of contestants as they cross the finish line.

With the recent testimony before the Hofstadter legislative committee virtually certain to form the basis of charges against Mayor Walker looking to his removal by Governor Roosevelt, the real points at issue were largely obscured in the two-day examination of the Mayor by Samuel Seabury, counsel of the committee.

Keen interest was evidenced in retail and manufacturing circles during the week in the tested goods campaign launched by R.H. Macy Co., Inc. The promotion, representing one of the most extensive endeavors of its kind, will continue through the coming month.
Entries for the Bermuda race starting from Montauk Point on June 25 had totaled eighteen yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The unusual mission of three little children who came here from Detroit to appeal to President Hoover for his help in obtaining the release of their father, under arrest in Detroit charged with the unlawful possession of an automobile, so impressed the President today that he gave them half an hour of his busy time and promised to use his "good offices" in their behalf.

WARSAW, May 25. -- As they have for the last three months, Polish officials deny there is any plan for Poland to occupy Danzig. They say they would not risk an adventure affecting the free city because the entire problem of the Polish corridor would be raised again and the status of Gdynia, the Polish free port, would be imperiled.

AMHERST, Mass., May 28. -- Scoring five runs in the first two innings. Amherst won a 5-4 victory from Wesleyan in a spectacular Little Three contest today. It marked the Jeffs' second triumph of the season over Wesleyan.

DEARBORN. Mich. BETTER than many books. Dearborn expresses the life and works of Henry Ford. Here he was born, son of an Irish father and a Pennsylvania Dutch mother. Hence he escaped from his father's farm at 17, and here he returned to marry and settle on a farm of his own after his first adventures in the machine shops of the city.

HAMILTON, Mass., May 28. -- Yale's crack polo team, although a 13-3 victor over the Harvard varsity in the annual game at the Myopia Club today, had to play at its best in order to down its Crimson rival. In actual play, the Elis completely outclassed their Cambridge rivals, but Harvard put up a plucky fight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28. -- Charley Devens of Harvard turned back the Columbia nine, 8 to 3, today to make amends, for his 4-to-3 defeat by the Blue and White earlier in the year.

AN army of city employes" is a phrase that is frequently used, but few people realize that the number of persons on New York's municipal payroll is actually greater than the number in the active military service of the United States.

THE urge to stroll through the countryside among Spring flowers is drawing many from the city to the handsome Long Island and Westchester estates that are now being opened to the public in the interests of charity. These garden visits have grown in favor each year and on the days of exhibition cars from many parts of the East may be noticed bringing visitors.

India's hopes of becoming a selfcontained independent nation are tempered by acceptance of the fact that for some years to come she must import products which require a high degree of technical skill in manufacture, M.A.J. Noble, widely known business man of Bombay and sales representative there for many American exporters, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The fundamental concept upon which must rest a political party as distinguished from a bloc or other group representing only a passing phase is that it shall be an aggregation of individuals drawn together by a common purpose to serve the State through the advocacy of certain principles and policies.

The Goddess of Liberty, our "Lady of the Lamp," is having her second bath in forty-seven years. Under the guidance of army engineers sent to Bedloe's Island for the purpose, a crew of workmen is busy blasting the grime from her granite pedestal, cleaning and mending her copper shell and installing new windows in her coronet.

OMAHA, May 26. -- The Corn Belt has been vastly entertained by the furious Senatorial primary campaign being waged in Iowa. The outcome will determine on June 6 whether Smith W. Brookhart still has the love and affection of at least 35 per cent of the Republican electorate of his State or if it has been transferred to one of his numerous political opponents.

RADIO broadcasters in the United States must renew their licenses every six months. To be granted new permits to continue operating proof must be furnished the Federal Radio Commission that the stations are serving public interest.

LONDON, May 21. -- With the industrialists of the country bringing strong pressure to bear upon the government in favor of inflation and with the Bank of England, as well as all sane financiers, lined up in opposition to such a course, financial circles are awaiting with tense expectancy the development of the monetary policy in the next few months.

BOSTON, May 26. -- Throughout the session of the General Court now nearing its end financial matters have had a major share of attention, not so much the routine money bills which must be dealt with year by year as the problems of taxation and administration which abnormal times have produced.

The opening contests of the newly formed American Box Lacrosse League's 150-game schedule are listed for Thursday night at the Yankee Stadium and in Boston. The Toronto Lacrosse Club is to face the Yankees here and the New York Giants are to play the Boston team at Fenway Park.
LAWHENCEVILLE, N.J., May 28. -- In the annual New Jersey State track meet today Lawrenceville easily won the Class A prep school championship with 49 1/2 points. Peddie was second with 28 1/2.

Add to the good-sized weakfish that have been caught in the waters of Peconic Bay this year one of fourteen pounds and two ounces taken in the North Race off New Suffolk, L.I., the past week by Adolph Berliner.

DALLAS, May 26. -- If Speaker John N. Garner receives the Democratic nomination for President nowhere will the surprise be greater than in Texas. Back of all the hullabaloo for him there is little real feeling that he will be the convention's choice.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Armed with heretofore confidential figures showing that five government departments maintain expensive individual staffs in foreign capitals, even the minor ones. Senator Vandenberg is laying plans to push his fight to authorize the President to consolidate government agencies in the interest of economy.

PARIS, May 28. -- By this time next week Edouard Herriot is expected once more to be Premier of France and to have formed his Cabinet. But even he does not yet know just quite the kind of a Cabinet he is going to have.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 28. -- Commencement exercises for the National Guard and Reserve officers class at the Army Signal School were held in the War Department Theatre here today.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Withdrawing conditions previously imposed, the Interstate Commerce Commission today acceded to demands of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and gave final approval to a three-year loan of $27,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, with which the road is to proceed with work on the electrification of its New York-Washington lines.

This year's freshman class at the University of Chicago has furnished the "guinea, pigs" for an educational experiment that has proved extremely exhilarating to those conducting it and to the "guinea pigs" as well. indeed the "guinea pigs" have so thrived under the experiment that our original faith in the soundness of the basic principles of the new plan has been converted into a conviction that we are on the right track.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. GENEVA, May 27. -- There are three great international discussions, one of which, the reparations conference, has yet to begin; three conferences in which the future of our old Europe is the stake. Of these three, one, the Danubian, is in a state of stalemate, one has fallen asleep, the third is in danger.
There has not been quite so much discussion this year as in the past two or three of the diminishing interest in college baseball. The game has been through one of its most interesting seasons.

BY the wireless from England comes the bulletin that Emil Jannings will appear on the London stage on June 7 in "Hocus-Pocus," a comedy derived by Justin Page from a novel by Susan Ertz. A Broadway future is already awarded to it in the event of success by the Thames.

THROUGHOUT the world locusts and man battle desperately to the death, both struggling for the food on which their lives depend. In Cape Town, in Manila, in Buenos Aires, troops were lately mobilized, planes equipped, insect poisons prepared, wire barriers erected -- every device man can conceive of was called to the incessant struggle.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Mrs. O. H.P. Belmont, president of the National Woman's party, is offering a first prize of $500 and a second prize of $200 for the best essay by a college girl on the proposed equal rights amendment sponsored by the party.

A PRIZE of $2,500 is offered by the Limited Editions Club for the best set of book illustrations submitted before Jan. 15, 1933. The competition is open to all artists, anywhere. For the guidance of competitors the club has issued a list of thirty titles, any of which may be chosen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The TIMES editorial "Some Justice of the Peace" was not only informative but a deliciously humorous breakfast tidbit. In Memphia, Tenn., several years ago, I heard from various members of the bar, at different times, what seemed to be a favorite story about justices of the peace.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Development of a successful treatment for hay and grass fever, consisting of application for three to fifteen consecutive days of a vapor inhalant, was announced today by Dr. Arnold H. Zifferblatt, director of the Wynne A. and Robert W. Murphy Memorial Laboratory for Hay Fever Research.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Use of silver bullion as security for Federal Reserve note issues in some cases is proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator King of Utah.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. UNDAUNTED by rumors of a depression, the major studios this week announced their product for the coming year. All promised as many pictures as were made in the period now ending; all promised better pictures; all renounced and denounced cycles.

Favorites swept aside all opposition as the opening round of the fifteenth annual Brooklyn men's singles tennis championship got under way yesterday on the Terrace Club courts. Percy Kynaston, Edward Burns Jr., Edward Jenkins Jr. and William Einsman, seeded No. 2, 3, 4 and 7, respectively, easily outplayed their opponents.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 22. -- President Ricardo Jimenez has picked a Cabinet of able and experienced men to assist him in his third term as Chief Executive of Costa Rica. A Cabinet that is strong and comparatively permanent will be necessary to meet the present difficult problems that face the new administration.

LONDON. REBECCA WEST, writing in The Daily Telegraph, makes a wholesome protest against the too frequent disparagement of the popular taste in literature. The offender in the present instance is Mrs. Q.D. Leavis, in her recent book on "Fiction and the Reading Public."

THE wet society women who this week have been collecting nickels and hand-outs on the street to wage a propaganda for the repeal of prohibition know not what they do. Among other things they have been depriving the poor and unemployed of money which should have gone to them.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index has registered a new low. The preliminary figure for the week ended May 21 is 55.7, as against 56.1 for the preceding week and 76.4 for the corresponding week last year.

CAMBRIDGE, May 28. -- The principal innovation in the coming commencement week at Harvard will be the shift of scene from the yard to the new houses on class day. The bands, the singing, the Japanese lanterns will leave the yard and the triangle between Eliot and Lowell houses will become the scene of the evening celebration.

Of paramount Importance to the financial community is the amount of new Treasury financing that will have to be done next month, not alone of the maturities to be met, which total $527,000,000, but the extra demands in line with the unbalanced budget and additional requirements for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and for relief money to be expended by the States.

JAMES BRYCE, commenting more than forty years ago upon the neglect from which the history of the American States had suffered, remarked that "he who would understand the changes that have passed on the American democracy will find far more instruction in a study of the State governments than of the Federal Constitution."

A survey of passenger tariffs recently published shows that the railways are providing for this Summer concessions in passenger rates that are the largest made in years. At the same time, notably in respect to air-cooling, facilities have been improved to levels not previously equaled.

AS one of the greatest leaders of his time in the work with which be deals in this book. Dr. Mott speaks with the voice of authority. For forty years and in all the five continents he has been devoting his energies to the task of making the lay forces of Christianity more forceful and more fruitful.

BERLIN. HERMANN STEGEMANN is not a professional historian, nor does he lecture on history at any university. He is more than a mere scholar. Possessed of a profound and lucid view of the development of historic events among the nations, he penetrates to a recognition of the needs that determine those events.

ELLERY WALTER went to Russia last Spring as a Communist sympathizer, a journalist and free-lance writer who was eager to see for himself and tell the world "about the success of the Russian experiment and the life of the young Russians."

ADDIS ABEBA, Abyssinia, May 28 (AP). -- Ras Hailou, Governor of the Abyssinian Province of Gojam, and his son were arrested tonight, while reports of all sorts of political disturbances and plots were current.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- After eighteen years of search and examination of prospects, the Geological Survey has reached the conclusion that the United States might as well give up the idea of producing commercial nitrate from deposits found within its borders and resign itself to dependence on by-products or synthetic sources of nitrogen or upon nitrate imported from Chile.

MANAGUA, May 25. -- The recent Conflicts in the densely wooded and mountainous northern part of Nicaragua, in which units of the National Guard have repeatedly routed bands of rebels who frequently outnumbered them has brought into prominence again the fighting qualities of the individual Nicaraguan as well as the efficiency of the National Guard's organization.

IN at least one respect Robert E. Sherwood, author of "Reunion in Vienna," is a Shavian disciple: his prefaces are independent pieces of writing. Most of them discuss current topics, and discuss them vigorously, without close relation to the play.

SO much has been, and is being, written, learnedly and otherwise, on esthetics in general, and on the plastic arts in particular, that the layman who earnestly tries to form for himself an intelligent independent opinion as to what "art" is, is often left bewildered by the controversial character of the writings, if not positively swamped by the overwhelming number of books on the subject issued yearly from the presses.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 28. -- John P. Leonard, 55 years old, of 1,043 Dewey Place, a foreman in the Bayway Refineries of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was found dead hanging from a fence along the embankment of the Pennsylvania Railroad here today.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A detailed summary of the report of the drafting committee adopted by the naval commission of the general disarmament conference at Geneva yesterday was received by the State Department today from Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson, chairman of the United States delegation.

IN the third year of a prolonged depression, with confidence chilled and discouragement widespread, it is useful, first, to note that certain recent gains have been achieved, and second, to remember that a large amount of work is being done in the United States.

IN behalf of the Nerve Clinic of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital a dinner dance has been arranged by members of its auxiliary committee for Thursday night on board the Ile de France. Various divertissements will follow dinner, including an entertainment by well-known artists, and there will be an opportunity to play bridge or backgammon.
To the Dramatic Editor: To your correspondent who recently complained of not being able to get good seats when applying at the box office, let me offer this tip:

MONTREAL, Quo., May 28 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian Pacific Railway reports for April gross earnings of $9,511,106, a reduction of $2,742,974 from April last year. Net earnings decreased $428,558 to $918,483. For the four months ended April 30 gross earnings were $38,031,142, or $9,251,029 lower than the first quarter of 1931, while net profits were reduced from $3,812,286 to $2,935,898

Although earnings of most of the "depression-proof" industrial issues which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange have declined during the last two years, an analysis shows that this group, consisting of grocery products, tobacco, drug and chemical companies, has generally earned the designation by resisting the trend toward smaller profits.

PARIS. TWO major Intersets are gripping the imagination of Paris at this time -- the midseason fashions and the races. While new styles are being launched, favorite horses are being picked. All Paris from the banker to the loafer,is chatting in the vernacular of the race tracks.

All European exchanges soared in terms of the dollar yesterday. Sterling, despite official dislike of a higher quotation, rose 3 3/8 cents to S3.72 3/4, the highest price since April 23, and closed at $3.72, a net gain of 2 5/8 cents. The franc rallied to 3.95 3/8 cents, the best price since Oct. 10 last, and closed at 3.95 1/8 cents, up 3/4 point.

IF costume has counted less than usual in art during the past decade, it may be because there has been less of costume to count. At the costume exhibition of the Metropolitan Museum this Spring it has been necessary for the visitor to create in imagination suitable occupants for these overpowering structures of silk and lace and ribbon and feathers, so much vaster, so much weightier than any we now know.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I add my comment to those who have voiced their sentiments in THE TIMES of May 22 regarding the exodus of some of our greatest singers, who unfortunately will no longer be heard at the Metropolitan?

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 28. -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange seeded first in the annual invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club was eliminated by Samuel Gilpin of Philadelphia in the quarter-final round today, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Business conditions in some foreign countries have recently improved slightly, but without any marked change in basic industries, according to the current weekly survey by the Department of Commerce.

DETROIT, May 27. -- When the motor car industry more than two years ago started out to scrap obsolete automobiles, it did something more than merely to remove a large number of traffic menaces from the highways. It took "out of circulation," so to speak, a great many vehicles that by the very fact they still could be operated were retarding the distribution of new cars.

After six years of waiting, the Childs Cup, oldest sprint race trophy of college rowing, went back to its home yesterday afternoon when Pennsylvania's varsity crew, taking command early, rowed steadily and well to finish a length ahead of Columbia and Princeton in that order on the Harlem River course of a mile and three quarters.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 28. -- Penn State won the Triangular Association baseball championship today by defeating Colgate, 6 -- 4.

MANY phases of American pioneer history have recently been incorporated into serious works of fiction -- so many, indeed, that one is safe in assuming that there has been a new outcropping of national self-consciousness on the part of American writers, and that they are turning at last to the home-grown material that so many of their critics, since the days of Lowell and Griswold, have urged upon them.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 28. -- Four bases on balls in the ninth inning gave Providence College a tie with Brown today after Brown had taken the lead in the same inning with a four-hit rally that yielded three scores. Two more passes in the tenth, followed by Reilly's single to left, scored the winning run, giving Providence a 5-to-4 decision in the second game of the annual city series.

THE American writers on shooting, after a generation in which little that was excellent was produced, now are furnishing a number of books admirable in every way. For some reason the accepted style in writing of sports, and gunning especially, was for decades curiously stilted and awkward, often an imitation of an archaic manner of writing.

It is always interesting from the spectator's viewpoint to watch an athlete take part in a sport that is usually considered outside his sphere. When a competitor is classed as a tennis player or a hockey star, one is generally anxious to know how he would fare should he decide to go into other competitions, swimming, high jumping, golf or football, for example.

DAIREN, Manchuria, May 28 (AP). -- Nearly a ton of statistics and documents confronted the League of Nations commission which is investigating the Sino-Japanese situation in Manchuria as it arrived today.

IN the age of the Mussolinis, Stalins and Hitlers popular attention naturally turns to the first modern dictator. Frederick the Great. His bold on the imagination is enhanced by his Cinderella story, which combines all the ingredients of a first-class romance.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 28 (AP). -- The man who as Princeton's head football coach soon will watch Yale athletics closely doesn't agree entirely with the Blue's new program.

GUAYAQUIL, May 22. -- Regulations for the enforcement of the latest decree which prohibits all traffic in foreign exchange except through the Banco Central have just been published, and are practically identical with those which governed Ecuador's former attempt to control the value of the sucre through an embargo of drafts.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28. -- The Naval Academy baseball team concluded its season today by defeating Maryland University, 11 to 4.

Coney Island's 1932 season got under way yesterday with the opening of Luna and Steeplechase Parks and other amusement centres. A crowd estimated at 250,000 promenaded the Boardwalk and bathed in the sun on the beach, a scattering of hardy souls venturing into the surf.
