Again there was no evidence of progress yesterday in the hunt for the kidnappers and murderers of the son of Charles A. Lindbergh.

Stanislaus Felix Hausner, 31-year-old Polish-American aviator, took off on an attempted transatlantic flight at 4:07 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but six hours later he set his flame-colored monoplane back on the same runway trom which he had taken off at Floyd Bennett Airport.

PARIS. THE Bibliotheque Nationale organized this Spring an exhibition of drawings, medals and paintings (two paintings) by Pisanello. Some one has observed that Pisanello was above all things a draftsman and beyond all men a medalist -- though Vasari gives Vittore Pisano very grouching praise until he hears, apparently from an outsider, that Pisanello is a good man (we have not been furnished with those details respecting this excellent master).

Warned by the Supreme War Council of the Salvation Army that the united appeal for $1,090,000 now being carried on in New York is of vital importance to the entire nation, workers in the Army's campaign are prepared for increased activities during the forthcoming week, it was announced yesterday.

A national conflict in the building trades is threatened if the New York building trades employers seek to engage non-union, workmen in this city, it was asserted in a letter sent by twenty-one building unions yesterday to Governor Roosevelt, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Senators Royal S. Copeland and Robert F. Wagner, Mayor James J. Walker and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

"Only in name is this year's Presidential campaign going to be a political one," writes William B. Munro, former president of the American Political Science Association, in Current History for June; "there are no longer any political issues in the old sense."

The will of Miss Laura Shannon, daughter of the late Georgiana Hegeman and Thomas Waldron Shannon, who died at her home, 3 East Ninety-second Street, on May 13, provided for gifts to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine totaling $937,500, but a codicil drawn three years later and offered for probate with the will in Surrogate's Court yesterday disclosed that the money now will go instead to St. Luke's Hospital.

DETROIT. RACING SEEMS to be arousing the interest of passenger car manufacturers to an unparalleled degree. Rumor now has it that it is a member of the industry who will provide the financial backing for the attempt which Barney Oldfield will make to bring the land speed record back to the United States.

MOHAMMEDANISM, which, it is reported, will seek converts in this country with the aid of a tunic said to have been worn by the prophet about 1,300 years ago, has already made some strides in England. At Woking, in Surrey, there is a mosque which is the headquarters of the Moslem Society of Great Britain.

EVERYTHING that photography and photo-engraving combined now do toward supplying the great public with a pictorial record of what is going on around us from day to day -- with reminiscent pictures from the record of the past as current events suggest that past -- all this the lithographer did in the period between, roughly, 1820 and 1885.

LANGHORNE, Pa., May 28 (AP). -- Al Thiesen of Dayton, Ohio, at the wheel of a Vance special, won the twenty-five-mile feature sweepstakes auto race at the Langhorne spedway today in the fast time of 17 minutes 2-5 seconds.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 26. -- Within a few weeks the North Carolina political battle which will be determined, in part at least, in the Democratic primary on June 4 has changed from one of the most apathetic campaigns the State ever witnessed to one that is intensely bitter.

MADISON, N.J., May 28. -- Champion Lone Eagle of Earlsmoor, wire-haired fox terrier owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City, received tonight the sterling silver trophy offered by P.A. Rockefeller for the best dog in the sixth annual dog show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club held at Giralda Farms, the country estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge.

Bonds and stocks of companies in the Cities Service group declined sharply yesterday following the announcement late on Friday that all dividends on both the common and preferred shares would be discontinued by the several companies. Declines in the stocks ranged from 1/2 to 16 1/2 points, while the bonds lost from 1 1/2 to 11 1/8 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Here, in Cuba again after an absence of three years, I find things very much in the same situation as at home, but conditions here are in part the result of our tariff ideas.

NOW that spaghetti, pigeons and stuffed polecats are being brought forth as exhibition material, it is probably time to decide that the season proper in town is about finished and to cast, as Walt Whitman would say, a "backward glance oer travel'd roads."

The near future in China is more cheerfully appraised in British business circles than in this country. This would appear from a NEW YORK TIMES dispatch reporting the formation by some of Great Britain's leading engineering firms of a joint enterprise for the promotion of Chinese industrial development.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 26. -- Appeals for national party support for a new political status for Puerto Rico ranging from independence to Statehood are to be made at the national conventions in Chicago next month. Delegates to the Republican convention will seek to have a Statehood plank included in the platform.

AN additional group of Essex cars at new low prices has been announced by the Hudson Motor Car Company and will be known as the Essex "Standard" series. The cars supplement, and do not replace, the present Essex Pacemaker series.
RYE, N.Y., May 28. -- Many dinner dances were held tonight in Westcheater County in celebration, of the holiday week-end.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Temple closed its baseball season today by easily defeating Villanova. 15 to 4. It was also the final game of the year for Villanova, which bowed twice to temple.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I understand from a newspaper article that a Congressman from this section is to introduce another bill in Congress to have the government take over Mount Vernon because he thinks "it could be run for profit." Commercialize the tomb!

An increase in the last month of 200,000 in its membership bringing the total up to 900,000, representing every Commonwealth, and with branch organizations in forty-two States, was announced yesterday by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform on its third anniversary.

Prevention and Prohibition. IT has been discovered, even by some liquor abolitionists, that prohibition does not always prevent the sale and consumption of alcohol. Likewise, the fact that prohibition does not necessarily mean prevention is recognized by those who are working intelligently, rather than emotionally, for the promotion of street and highway safety.

WILLEM VAN HOOGSTRATEN will present a Beethoven cycle during the four weeks that he will conduct the Stadium concerts this Summer, it has been announced. All the nine symphonies will be given, as well as the "Egmont," "Coriolanus" and "Leonore" No. 3 overtures.

LONDON, May 13. MR. VAN DRUTEN'S new piece, "Somebody Knows," is outwardly the story of an undetected crime, but only a minor part of its interest depends upon our attempts to identify the murderer of Lily Coles.

The Hofstadter Committee, it became known yesterday, has been unable to locate Mayor Walker's brother, Dr. William H. Walker, since testimony was given linking him with commissions paid on the sale of equipment to the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection, with the latest shocking news from Japan, newspapers are again printing the statement that three Japanese "friends of America" have recently been killed -- Hamaguchi, Inoue and Dan.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 28. -- Many dinner parties were given tonight at the entertainment marking the opening for the season of the Sands Point Bath Club. The majority of the guests arrived from near-by country places, while others motored out from the city.

ROME, May 27. -- Immediate establishment of a regular air route between Rome and Buenos Aires across the South Atlantic was suggested by the Italian delegation to the international congress of transoceanic fliers sitting in Rome this week.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP). -- Aided by four hits from the bat of Dave Barbee, Pacific Coast importation, the Pittsburgh Pirates today annexed their fifth consecutive game by defeating the St. Louis Cards, 8 to 6. It was the eighth victory for the Pirates out of their last nine combats.

Walter M. Jeffords's Man o' War colt, Boatswain, beaten only a head and a nose in the Preakness, thrilled a crowd of 15,000 persons at Belmont Park yesterday when he captured the fifty-seventh running of the historic Withers, which found E.R. Bradley's Burgoo King sixth in a field of seven.

PARIS, May 27. -- Those who like uncertainty are having plenty of it just now in Paris. It is almost a month since the people of France voted for a new Parliament and returned a new majority. But it will be another week or more before they can learn how the majority is going to line up and what the program of the leaders will be.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28. -- Captain Shorty Bowman won his first game of the season for Princeton today, defeating Pennsylvania, 3 -- 1, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League battle before 2,000 persons at University Field.

RYE, N.Y., May 28. -- At the opening of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's championship Summer season today, the English designed and built 12-meter yacht Mouette distanced the Iris by 6 minutes and 24 seconds over a 19-mile course.

BUDAPEST, May 10, 1932. THE Royal Opera of Budapest presented as a last novelty of the season an opera composed by that genius of modern Hungarian music, Mr. Zoltan Kodaly. The opera, "Szekely Spinnery," is based entirely upon popular songs of the Szekely people in Transylvania.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28. -- Johnny Broaca, Yale's star sophomore twirler, today turned back the strong Holy Cross nine, 6 -- 4, before 6,000, the largest crowd to witness a college game here this season.

WITH the same sympathy and poetic understanding with which, in "Bambi" and other tales, he wrote of wild creatures in the forest, Felix Salten now tells in this new book of the tragedy of animals imprisoned in a city zoo.

HE is an old-time booking manager who could route your show to the Coast and back in five minutes -- on paper -- without missing a one-night stand or looking at a map, and he was measuring his words as he said that, mark his word for it, the legitimate theatre would be back in the fold by 1934.

The Fordham University basebal team scored twice in the ninth inning to gain a 5-to-4 triumph over Boston College at Kordham Field yesterday, thereby recording its eleventh consecutive conquest and its thirteenth in fourteen starts this season.

A TEN weeks' season of grand opera will be given this Summer in Cincinnati, thanks to a reversal of its previous decision on the part of the board of directors of the Cincinnati Zoological Garden. The board was induced through a committee headed by Mrs. John J. Emery and Mrs. Horace Schmidlapp to reconsider its plan to give up opera this Summer, as the committee promised to underwrite the season, which will begin July 12.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A performance of Verdi's "Aida," reminiscent of its original performance for the Khedive of Egypt, is contemplated for June 5 at Griffith Stadium. A cast of 1,000 persons, including Metropolitan Opera stars, the complete chorus of the Metropolitan and the Chicago operas, and 500 supers recruited from the local unemployed; horses from Fort Myer and elephants and camels from the National Zoological Park are promised by the management.

PARIS, May 19. -- Henri Cochet, number one man of amateur tennis, writing in the Paris Intransigeant, gives some of the reasons he thinks account for the failure of the United States to recapture the Davis Cup.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 28. -- Cornell closed its home season and Eastern Intercollegiate League drive by defeating Dartmouth 3 -- 2, on Hoy Field today. Eddie Smith's run in the fourth inning, resulting from his single and another by Kappler, along with a force play, broke a 2-2 deadlock established in the first frame.

AN unusual event in behalf of the Boys Club of New York and the Girls Service League has been planned for the night of June 24, when an out-of-doors performance of "Aida" will be held at the Polo Grounds. In the cast will be Miss Helen Gahagan, Miss Carmela Ponselle, Giuseppe Martino-Rossi and Lladislav Soucek.

SALISBURY. Md., May 28. -- A German today added his name to the list of the United States Olympic team as Hans Oldag, from the Oriole Club of Buffalo, N.Y., who withstood the terrific pace during the first half of the distance, to win the Cambridge-Salisbury marathon.

SYRACUSE, May 28. -- Hundreds of Syracuse University graduates, members of seventeen classes having reunions and representatives of other classes, will assemble here for ceremonies to precede the commencement exercises Monday, June 6.

A distinctly unpleasant week on the financial markets ended yesterday without great change in character. The stock market drifted idly downward, with most of its changes fractional, then regained the losses. Some stocks reached a "new low level" for the season in the early weakness and, it should be needless to say, touched prices highly indicative of the community's mental state.

LOS ANGELES, May 28. -- Plain Joe Scott, the 64-year-old political stump veteran who will place the name of Herbert Hoover before the Republican National Convention for the Presidential nomination, calls himself "just a doughboy, one of the 120,000,000 in America."

WORLD WARS may come and go, boom times flourish and disappear and vast depressions submerge the reading world, but still with measured step and undisturbed serenity the Home University Library continues on its beneficent way, never failing when the due time arrives to add another small volume to its already long and varied list.
ROME. TO few men has it befallen to be obscure and without administrative authority at 61 and at 75 to have a post of world-wide power and prestige and a record of brilliant executive achievement.

ELKINS, W.Va., May 26. -- West Virginia has just emerged from a primary election which for multiplicity of candidates, a cumbersomeness of ballot, the difficulty of speedy tabulation and costliness stands in a class myself and has led to renewed agitation for material changes in the primary system.

BENEATH the streets of New York lies a vast gridiron of mains through which pours an average of 1,000,000,000 gallons of water a day, the amount used by the 6,930,446 people of the greater city. Four thousand miles of mains distribute this generous stream through the five boroughs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time of the year I find myself thinking of my friend Henry F. Gilbert, the American composer. He was the most original and distinctively American of any composer we have had since Stephen Collins Foster.

THE astronomical world has again been startled by new discoveries, not only of the usual crop of comets but of two strange and interesting bodies, the "Delporte-object" and the "Reinmuth-object." The former, discovered by Professor Delporte at Brussels, immediately threatened to take from Eros its distinction, undisputed for thirty-four years, of coming closer to the earth than any astronomical body except the moon.

TODAY. 12:30 P.M. -- WABC -- A talk by E. Kupers, president of the Dutch League of Trade Unions, opens a typical Dutch radio program coming by short wave from Hilbersum, Holland, during this international broadcast period.

MONEY IN FLIGHT HOW much money do transatlantic aviators carry with them? If they come down on dry land, they need a little loose change for incidentals until checks for motion picture and syndicate rights catch up with them; on the other hand, there is constant risk while they are in flight of sudden liquidation of their currency.

Are the foundations of the great deep about to be broken up in the United States? One might think so from reading the alarmed and unsettling statements which fall so thick in current discussions. Some of these utterances are made by men who ordinarily feel themselves under an obligation to be calm and restrained in what they say in public.

More than 30,000 mothers and children attended the nineteenth annual May party of the Thomas M. Farley Association, Tammany organization of the Fourteenth Assembly District, on the east green of Central Park yesterday. The young guests of the former Sheriff, most of them in fancy costumes, and their mothers assembled in the streets off First Avenue from Fifty-ninth to Eighty-fourth Street at 11 o'clock and marched to the park.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Though Babe Ruth found the range of the Griffith Stadium right-field fence for homers in each game of today's double-header, his twelfth and thirteenth of the season, the Yankees were otherwise in an extreme eclipse, dropping the two games to the Senators by the decisive scores of 5 to 1 and 13 to 5.

WASHINGTON. SEVERAL times when I have gone in to see Herbert Hoover his political fortunes have been at low ebb. As I have walked toward him some new jest at the expense of his administration has darted across my mind, and I have wondered if he realized that people sit around ridiculing the occupant of his great office whenever their affairs are not marching.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Asserting that young graduates of the Naval Academy should not be "bothered with brides and babies," the Navy plans to bar the marriage of Ensigns within two years after leaving Annapolis.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 25 (AP). -- With a eulogy from President Hoover for her long career in behalf of human betterment by means of the home, the funeral of Miss Martha Van Rensselaer, late co-director of the College of Home Economics of Cornell University, was held here today in Sage Chapel.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 28. -- Although the club has not as yet gone into commission for the Summer, there were races off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. The regatta was made up of two divisions, the first away being the sixmeter yachts.

ALREADY this season there have been two interesting transatlantic crossings to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the Lindbergh hop to Paris and the other great flights of 1927. Amelia Earhart Putnam, flying her fast Lockheed with the supercharged Waspengine, crossed the North Atlantic to Ireland in less than fourteen hours establishing a new speed record for the great circle course.

EDWARD G. ROBINSON, now represented in the cinematic marts with "Two Seconds," has had the sort of cosmopolitan career, both in and out of his profession, that one might expect from the variegated roles his employers give him. He was born in Bucharest, Rumania, in 1893, attended the New York public schools, took a Master of Arts degree at Columbia and is said to be on quite intimate terms with Spanish, Italian, French.

MANY who drive northward from New York along the Hudson River and into the Catskill Mountains become so engrossed in the scenery that they lose sight of the fact that this region abounds also in places of historic interest.
BOSTON, May 28 (AP). -- The Athletics combined seven hits with three Boston errors to defeat the Red Box, 8 to 2, today. It was the Mackmen's eighth victory in nine starts against the Sox.

SPECTATORITIS is the deadliest of all the "itis," or any other diseases, its menace the widest, its trail of destruction the surest -- that is the conviction which Mr. Nash, Professor of Education in New York University, holds concerning the ailment he describes and discusses in this stimulating book.

THE present unusual period of dry weather, which last week forced Acting Governor Lehman to order all forests and woodlands in New York State closed to the public because of danger of fires, has already been a contributory cause of many brush and forest fires in recent weeks.

PITTSBURGH, May 28. -- An almost noiseless subway or elevated system with seats for nearly every passenger and possibly operated free to all is credited to Norman Wilson Storer, consulting railway engineer for Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company by other engineers of the concern.

A FAIRLY good pre-holiday business was done by retail stores last week, though volume in the aggregate did not go much beyond recent levels, according to reports. Sports and beach wear received promotion emphasis and drew about the best response.

GENEVA, May 27. -- A newly published report of experts of the League of Nations shows at a glance that the recent memorandum of the United States was not overstating when it termed conditions in Liberia "so chaotic" as to threaten disintegration.

After declining to the lowest levels of the week and to within 3 points of the season's low record, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday under week-end covering and closed at a loss of 1 point on the day. For what was said to be the first time on record, each active month showed the same change from the previous closing figure.

BERLIN, May 28 (AP). --Whether the Bruening Ministry stands or falls will be decided in the next few days. President Paul von Hindenburg will return tomorrow from Neudeck, where he has been on vacation since May 13. Back in the Presidential Palace, his first task will be to solve the Cabinet problem.

HERE is a scholarly and pains-taking attempt to rescue from oblivion the personality and achievements of an obscure naval officer of the Revolution. From the Historical point of view Mr. Clark presents a convincing case of neglect.

BOSTON, May 28. -- After discharging her eighty-five passengers and twenty-nine members of the crew of the steamer Grecian, which she rammed and sank with a loss of four lives off fog-bound Block Island early yesterday, the Savannah liner City of Chattanooga sailed from here late today for New York and Savannah.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- When the dust from the latest drive of the dry raiders to mop up Chicago had settled today, a survey showed that thirty three places, ranging from a Loop saloon to a small neighborhood beer flat, had been raided and forty-four defendants, two of whom were women, had been arraigned as violators of the prohibition laws.

PARIS, May 15,1932. NEVER has the music season of Paris been so brief. Ten concerts or so in April and May; two performances of Russian ballet to be given in June by the troupes each of which claims the apostolic succession to Diaghileff, and everything will be over.

AMSTERDAM, May 28. -- The Zuider Zee, a familiar landmark on all maps of Europe for centuries, became a thing of the past today. Amid the screeching of sirens on hundreds of excursion steamers and tugboats the last gap was closed in the eighteen-mile dike connecting Wieringen with Friesland.

Confident of an ample majority in the Democratic National Convention on the first ballot, leaders in the movement to nominate Governor Roosevelt for President are preparing to take the offensive in the convention from the moment the opening gavel falls.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28. -- Following a week-end devoted to annual meetings, exercises of the senior class, and alumni reunions, the 185th commencement of Princeton University will be held on Tuesday, June 21, according to the program announced here today by Dr. Wilson Farrand of South Orange, clerk of the board of trustees and chairman of the commencement committee.

NEW ORLEANS, May 26. -- The Legislature of Mississippi has adjourned after one of the longest and most momentous sessions since reconstruction days. It seems to have made some substantial advances. Beginning amid such harmony that Mississippians half expected to awake some day to discover the streets paved with gold and hear a heavenly choir chanting in the Capitol, the Legislature wound up its business amid the familiar sulphurous odors of factionalism.

TORONTO, Ont., May 28. -- Ontario's mineral output in the first quarter of 1932 was valued at $15,694,581, compared with $18,453,508 in the first quarter of 1931. The Ontario Department of Mines reported the decline was 14.9 per cent, which, according to the report, "was a creditable record compared with many other industries." Production of both gold and silver was increased.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28. -- Presentation of a new main gate to the Naval Academy by the class of 1907 marked the day's exercises there today. The presentation was made by Captain Russell Crenshaw of the navy mine department. It was accepted by Rear Admiral Thomas C. Hart, superintendent.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 28. -- Miss Martha Parker of Westchester Hills regained the women's metropolitan golf championship today by defeating Miss Bea Gottlieb of Lakeville, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final which culminated the week's play at the Century Country Club.
From Judge Seabury's cross-examinations we carry away the distinct impression, that there are more forgotten men in Tammany Hall than in all the rest of the United States.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 28. -- Two hundred and fifty couples took part here tonight in the Junior Promenade of Union College. Thirteen of the twenty-two fraternities on the campus are holding house parties and had booths at the dance. There was also a booth for the faculty.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- There seems to be a rift in the lute that has played for harmony, efficiency and civic progress since Mayor Cermak was inaugurated. Discordant sounds are heard and citizens are wondering whether the marred melody portends a worse cacophany in municipal affairs.

ALEXANDER KORDA, the Hungarian director, who made several films in the three years he was in Hollywood, including the highly amusing "Helen of Troy," is responsible for the Paramount-British production, "Reserved for Ladies," which held the screen of the Paramount Theatre last week.

LISBON, Portugal, May 28 (AP). -- A proposed new Constitution for Portugal, under which the President would be elected by the people instead of by parliament was published today for consideration by the public preliminary to its submission in a popular referendum.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Reports that President Hoover would send to Congress early next week special message on the revenue bill, possibly recommending the sales tax specifically, threw the Senate into a snarl today over the Walsh amendment proposing a 1.75 per cent general manufacturers' levy.

De Witt Clinton High School captured the senior trophy in the first annual Manhattan and Bronx P.S. A.L. championship track and field meet at Ohio Field yesterday. The winners amassed 61 points. Evander Childs was second with 45 markers and James Monroe placed third with 17.

TULSA, Okla., May 27. -- One Industry that has looked into its own future and drawn educational specifications for the young men it expects to need, and cooperated even in this none too rosy year in finding part-time jobs for students bent in its direction, is the petroleum industry of the Southwest.

WHITE as a Summer favorite is having its innings again this season, particularly where hats are concerned. Hearing the sages of fashion prophesying it some weeks ago, we set forth to verify their prognostications, for seeing is believing.

A general consumption tax would be preferable to a manufacturers' sales tax, according to an interim report of the committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday. Copies of the report have been sent to President Hoover and to members of Congress.

THE new radio sets of 1932-33 design were exhibited during the past week at the eighth annual radio trade show under the auspices of the Radio Manufacturers' Association. Five radically new radio tubes are the basis of improvements in tone, sensitivity, sharpness of tuning and general fidelity in reception.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Marston have come to the Pierre from Los Angeles.

LOS ANGELES, May 26. -- Oil, fire and water. Poor mixers, but elements important to Southern California at the moment. Oil, basis of livelihood of a large percentage of our workers, shows signs of rallying from the coma in which it has slumbered for months.

STUDENTS at the language, the literature and art and the life of the ancient Greeks have never concerned themselves much with the status and environment of Grecian children; so little has been written about them for general reading that this book by the Professor of Greek and Latin in Perm College, Oskaloosa, Iowa, deserves a double welcome.

Gasoline taxes paid by motorists last year to the various States reached the record high total of $536,397,458, or $42,532,341 more than the $493,863,117 paid in 1930, according to reports of the United States Bureau of Public Roads compiled by the American Petroleum Institute.
McKINNEY, Texas, May 28 (AP). -- Art Goebel, widely known aviator, was injured and his mechanic, R.L. Riss, was killed when their plane struck a tree as they took off from an airport here today.

LONDON. PERPETUAL pensions, which have cost the British nation a prodigious sum, have recently been under fire both in and outside the House of Commons. There are not many of these pensions payable in perpetuity in existence now and the facts about them are striking.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission approving the substitution of trucking for switching in the handling of freight in the Chicago district was viewed yesterday by the Port of New York Authority as applicable to the transportation plans to be effected here this Fall at the union inland freight terminal under construction at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Discouraged longs were on the selling side of wheat today on the Board of Trade, and while fairly good buying was credited to seaboard exporters early, at no time did the active futures sell above the finish of the previous day. Prices held within a range of about 3/4 cent and closed 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel lower, except on the May, which ended 1/4 cent higher.

ANNAPOLIS. Md., May 28. -- By showing superiority in the track events Ohio State defeated the Naval Academy in a dual meet today, 63 1/2 to 62 1/2. The victory was dependent on the last two field events, the javelin throw and broad Jump, with Ohip State leading Navy by only a few points throughout the meet.

LOS ANGELES, May 27. MET by good-will so palpable that you could almost see it, Romney Brent's new comedy, "The Mad Hopes." revealed itself to a local audience at the Belasco Theatre last Monday night. Billie Burke, supported by a cast which included names recognizable in the Times Square sector, plays one of those vague, charming and irresponsible mothers who have come to be familiar through such plays as "Hay Fever" and "The Vinegar Tree."

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Thirty-four Kurds have been sentenced recently to be hanged for the rebellion they waged about Mount Ararat two years ago, and 500 more are to be tried by President Mustapha Kemal's courts for participating in the insurrection that spread through the valley of Araxas, where, tradition says, Eve tasted the forbidden fruit.

PARIS. A FILM dedicated to the history and glory of the French Legion of Honor was shown for the first time recently to the pensioners of that organization who are installed in their new home in the Chateau du Val, in the forest of St. Germain.

More than 100 marine engineers, yachtsmen and others interested in motor boating attended last Tuesday night at the Park Central Hotel the first open meeting of the newly organized marine division of the metropolitan section of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

THIS collection of William Faulkner's early sketches, articles and poems, culled with one exception from The Double Dealer of New Orleans, have a pronounced curiosity value. The section on New Orleans types -- ranging from the longshoreman to the magdalen -- wallows in color; the same color, restrained, chastened and made incidental to story demands, may be found in "Sanctuary."

TORONTO, May 28 (Canadian Press). -- Tred Avon, 4-year-old filly of the S.W. Labrot stable, won the fortieth running of the Toronto Cup, feature stake event at Woodbine today. She led R.H. New's Frumper to the wire by a head, with the Seagram Stable's Khorasan third.

SANFORD BATES, Superintendent of Federal Prisons, is one of those who believe in making a virtue of necessity. Finding the prisons under his charge when he took over the work in 1929 grossly overcrowded, and threatened with still worse overcrowding, he evolved a plan to extend the long arm of the law outside prison walls by probation, parole and prison camps.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- The most formidable obstacle to confront a United States Davis Cup team on this side of the Atlantic since 1927 was successfully hurdled today when Australia was defeated in the North American zone final at the Philadelphia Country Club.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 28. -- Governor A. Harry Moore will preside at the inauguration of Dr. Robert C. Clothier as fourteenth president of Rutgers University on Commencement Day, Saturday morning, June 11. Complete plans for the ceremony were announced today by Dr. Carl R. Woodward, chairman of the inauguration committee.

BAYSIDE, L.I., May 28. -- Yacht racing on Little Neck Bay started today under the auspices of the Bayside Yacht Club. The feature was the first appearance of seven crafts in the Snipe Class, a new division of small yachts that will make its headquarters at the Bayside Club.

The Textile High School baseball team, which clinched the Lower Manhattan-Richmond Division P.S. A.L. title last week, brought its regular league schedule to a close by halting the Curtis High School nine of Staten Island. 17 to 11, at the George Washington High School Stadium yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 27. MET by good-will so palpable that you could almost see it, Romney Brent's new comedy, "The Mad Hopes." revealed itself to a local audience at the Belasco Theatre last Monday night. Billie Burke, supported by a cast which included names recognizable in the Times Square sector, plays one of those vague, charming and irresponsible mothers who have come to be familiar through such plays as "Hay Fever" and "The Vinegar Tree."

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Thirty-four Kurds have been sentenced recently to be hanged for the rebellion they waged about Mount Ararat two years ago, and 500 more are to be tried by President Mustapha Kemal's courts for participating in the insurrection that spread through the valley of Araxas, where, tradition says, Eve tasted the forbidden fruit.

PARIS. A FILM dedicated to the history and glory of the French Legion of Honor was shown for the first time recently to the pensioners of that organization who are installed in their new home in the Chateau du Val, in the forest of St. Germain.

BUCHAREST, May 28. -- The British, Dutch and Swiss Ministers to Bucharest today followed the example set by the French Minister a few days ago in protesting to the Rumanian Government against the plan for conversion of agrarian debts on the ground that it endangers the leu, to whose stabilization the four countries have contributed financially.

Ending a silence of two days, Daniel Upthegrove, president of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway announced late yesterday that deposits of its 4 per cent consolidated bonds under a refinancing plan to meet their maturity on Wednesday amounted to 88 per cent of the amount outstanding.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 28. -- While his supporters in mountain and Western States were adding today to his delegate total, Governor Roosevelt rested in preparation for an intensive week on his return to his desk at Albany on Tuesday.
Small homes comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 28. -- Five meet records were shattered in the New York State Public High School Athletic Association sectional track and field championships for district I, held at the White Plains High School Stadium today, as Gorton High of Yonkers retained its sectional title for a third straight year.

THERE are almost as many conceptions of beauty as there are variations of human taste. Esthetics, a realm of thought which, for want of scientific measurement, definitions can scarcely be fixed quantities, has charmed the philosophic mind from Aristotle down to Croce.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28. -- The plan restricting Yale's varsity football program to five games and confining practice to the normal season was assailed today by Albie Booth, Edward Rotan and John S. Wilbur, members of the 1931 eleven, in a statement published in The Yale Daily News, undergraduate publication.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- From far-away California came Sidney Grant, a 5-year-old, to electrify a crowd of 18,000 today in winning the $5.000 Robert M. Sweitzer Handicap, beating Spanish Play by a neck in the last strides. A field of nine started.

The eighty-fifth anniversary of the Hamburg-American Steamship Line was observed on Friday with the docking of two incoming ships and the usual activity at its piers, where others were taking on freight or being prepared for passengers out-bound.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP). -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley refused today to vacate the injunction he had issued restraining banks in New York from selling stocks of Insull utility companies held as collateral for loans to Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company.

JUNE brings radio to the season's crossroads. By that time many of the star performers, especially those affiliated with the opera, have forsaken the microphones for vacationland. In the month of roses, graduates and brides, the broadcasters turn to what they call music of a lighter vein.

UNLESS you have been warned in time and have arranged for a quick getaway, some actor is always telling you how he made his very first stage appearance in "Uncle Tom's Cabin," back in the days when the theatre was the theatre and only brave men wandered west of Scranton.

THE annual migration to Summer homes often creates new problems in achieving decorative effects with the primitive background furnished by barn studios, log cabins, week-end lodges with unplastered walls, and country cottages whose rooms have the bare simplicity of early days.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 28 (AP). -- Utah's eight Democratic National Convention votes were pledged to Governor Roosevelt today and Governor George Dern of Utah was endorsed for the Vice Presidential nomination.

THE Metropolitan Opera served notice several months ago that it will figrht to live. In his annual announcement on the day of his sailing some days ago, Giulio Gatti-Casazza adduced further evidence of the mood of the management.

PARIS, May 28. -- The United States won the first of the French tennis championships today when Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Elizabeth Ryan swept the former titleholders, Mrs. Eileen Bennett Whittingstall and Miss Betty Nuthall, to a quick defeat in the women's doubles final, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.
THERE is a growing suspicion that the National League has no cellar at all. It's just a basement revolving door.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Plans are under way for the publication of an "Encyclopedia of the Negro," designed to be as of high character and scholarship as similar publications in other fields, according to an announcement today, authorized by Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes, president of the Phelps Stokes Fund and Canon of "Washington Cathedral.

THIS critic of American education has not much to say that has not already been said more effectively. But his critictism is interesting because of its basic comprehensiveness. Mr. Nock aims his blows primarily at its fundamental ideas and purposes.

Bonds and warrants of three municipalities were added last week to the list of securities called for payment this month before their maturity dates. The total for May is now $15,904,000, compared with $15,427,000 in April, and $102,790,000 in May, 1931, at corresponding dates.

Memorial services will be held here today as a prelude to the annual Memorial Day observances tomorrow, when the forty-two remaining Civil War veterans in New York City -- all that are left of the once mighty Grand Army of the Republic -- will join with veterans of the Spanish and World Wars in honoring the soldier dead.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 28. -- There were a number of dinner parties this evening and entertaining at the Crystal Room assembly in honor of newly arrived visitors. Mr. and Mrs. Charles U. Caesar entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Tevis Huhn of Washiagton and Baron Leopold Buffin of New York, who came today to be their week-end guests.

EXETER, N.H., May 28. -- The Dartmouth freshmen defeated Exeter in track today by a score of 72 to 54. The Collegians made clean sweeps in the high jump, broad jump, 880-yard run and the one-mile run.

BERLIN, May 28. -- Land settlements, voluntary labor service and a lottery loan to finance public works were catchwords in an outline of the government's plans for a solution of unemployment which Chancellor Bruening gave tonight at the annual banquet of the Foreign Press Association.

Domestic corporation bonds lost further ground, United States Government issues were generally easier and foreign loans showed considerable irregularity in quiet trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Transactions amounted to $5.578,000. compared with $6.382,500 a week before, largely because only $660,000 of Federal bonds changed hands, the smallest total for a Saturday since April 2. and compared with $2,730,500 on the preceding Saturday.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 28. -- Declaring the present economic situation was "not so dark as some would have us believe," Charles F. Kettering, vice president and research director of the General Motors Corporation, appealed here today for "constructive and progressive energy" in the solution of the problem of technological employment.

The recent announcement of five Stock Exchange firms which deal in odd lots of stock, for the convenience of all other brokerage firms, that they would reduce the differential demanded on odd-lot buying orders to an eighth of a point has been praised by the financial community as a measure which should help to revive trading activity.

In a House of Commons Speech. I REMEMBER that on June 18, 1815. on the field of Waterloo, the Duke of Wellington said to a staff officer: "It is going to be a damned close thing." It is going to be a very close thing between the survival of civilization as we know it and its decline.

MADISON, N.J., May 28. -- Seventy-one degrees will be awarded by Drew University on Tuesday at its sixty-fifth commencement exercises. Two undergraduate schools will present candidates for degrees for the first time. Twelve Brothers College graduates will receive Bachelor of Arts degrees and eight College of Religious Education and Missions graduates will receive the same degree.

In the midst of the discussions of roads to economic recovery many prominent Dersons have paused in the last few weeks to ask how the children are faring in the depression. For New York City the reply, based on observations obtained from persons actively dealing with children in large numbers, and especially, with public school children, is that the picture, on the surface at least, is still fairly bright.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 28. -- Led by Alex Wilson, Canadian Olympic flash, the Notre Dame track team upset Army today, winning the first meet ever held between the two schools, 68 1-3 to 57 2-3.

MUNICH, May 16. -- The attitude of the National-Socialists toward women in politics and business was one of the favorite arguments against the Nazis during the recent election campaign. It has been charged that as soon as it comes into office the party would drive all women out of politics and business and relegate them once more to the narrow limits of the home.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- I am a Democrat because government was made for man. I am not a Republican because, consciously or unconsciously, the Republican party believes man was made for government.

C.S. (CASEY) JONES is wondering if he has begun to slip. Casey for years has well sustained his reputation of being a money flier; of never flying a race -- closed course or cross-country-without finishing somewhere in the money.

Moscow. THERE is no land of make-believe for children in Soviet Russia. From infancy, little citizens must feel that they are part of a living world. Why should they learn about flying horses, when real wild horses are being bred in the high pastures of the Pamirs?

WATERWAYS, Alberta. WITH the sun beginning to warm the frozen reached of Northwestern Canada, many grizzled prospectors and mining engineers at this northern outpost of civilisation await the day when they can safely fly toward Great Bear Lake -- the land of the new Eldorado.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 28. -- Declaring the present economic situation was "not so dark as some would have us believe," Charles F. Kettering, vice president and research director of the General Motors Corporation, appealed here today for "constructive and progressive energy" in the solution of the problem of technological employment.

The recent announcement of five Stock Exchange firms which deal in odd lots of stock, for the convenience of all other brokerage firms, that they would reduce the differential demanded on odd-lot buying orders to an eighth of a point has been praised by the financial community as a measure which should help to revive trading activity.

MADISON, N.J., May 28. -- Seventy-one degrees will be awarded by Drew University on Tuesday at its sixty-fifth commencement exercises. Two undergraduate schools will present candidates for degrees for the first time. Twelve Brothers College graduates will receive Bachelor of Arts degrees and eight College of Religious Education and Missions graduates will receive the same degree.

In the midst of the discussions of roads to economic recovery many prominent Dersons have paused in the last few weeks to ask how the children are faring in the depression. For New York City the reply, based on observations obtained from persons actively dealing with children in large numbers, and especially, with public school children, is that the picture, on the surface at least, is still fairly bright.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 28. -- Led by Alex Wilson, Canadian Olympic flash, the Notre Dame track team upset Army today, winning the first meet ever held between the two schools, 68 1-3 to 57 2-3.

MUNICH, May 16. -- The attitude of the National-Socialists toward women in politics and business was one of the favorite arguments against the Nazis during the recent election campaign. It has been charged that as soon as it comes into office the party would drive all women out of politics and business and relegate them once more to the narrow limits of the home.

MANILA, April 26. -- The anticipated roar of the radicals in the newly constituted opposition party in the Philippines has died down to a harmless echo of previous party sentiments The new group, which has chosen the name of Confederate Democratic party, has suggested in its tentative platform many changes in the present governmental organization, but has shown few radical tendencies.

PITTSBURGH, May 26. -- The public school teachers of this city have made a voluntary decision that seems destined to have a far-reaching effect upon the economy movement in the State. They have elected almost unanimously to turn back 10 per cent of their salaries to the school district, the aggregate saving to the taxpayers being $850,000 a year.

TOKYO. WAR films are booming in Japan, not the familiar march of the Hollywood doughboys through the villages of France, but sulphureous transcripts, mostly made without the aid of female beauty, of the fighting in Shanghai and Manchuria.

At the conclusion of New York University's centennial commencement on Wednesday, June 8, about 48,500 students will have received degrees in the century of the university's existence, Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar, said yesterday.

EAST LONDON, South Africa, April 12. -- In addition to econmic crisis and racial imbroglio, the Union of South Africa is threatened with secession. From the viewpoint of internal politics, the outlook rarely has been worse. What America went through in 1859-1860, South Africans going through today.

BOONTON, N. J., May 29. -- William Henry Meadowcroft, who had been employed by the late Thomas A. Edison for more than fifty years and had served as confidential secretary to the inventor for more than twenty years, celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday at his home here today with an automobile ride, a family dinner and recollections of his long association as "prime minister" of the inventor.

LONDON, May 27 -- Financial markets here, in the language of the critics, are again suffering a "calamity complex," of the kind which has afflicted them with unpleasant frequency. On this occasion several considerations appear to have come suddenly into view, whose combined influence was to dispel the more hopeful feeling which had recently begun to assert itself.

Five major steps should be taken at once by Mayor Walker and the Board of Estimate in the interest of drastic municipal economy, according to a report made public yesterday by the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

DETROIT, May 29. -- Henry Ford, refusing a $75,000 loan, sought by a committee to enable the Baraga County National Bank of L'Anse, Mich., to reopen, asserted that a study by the Ford interests of several communities showed that "they do very well without banks as at present managed."

OAKLAND, Cal., May 29 (AP). -- Alfred C. Read Jr., a broker, declared today that letters from Claire Windsor, Hollywood actress -- ''simply letters with nothing in them" were the cause of the marital misunderstanding which has led to his arrest on a charge of kidnapping his own wife.

SAUNTON, England, May 29 (AP). -- A steady downpour and continued cold and dreary weather kept the seven Americans who qualified for the match play rounds of the women's British golf championship off the tricky Saunton course today.

The pastoral letter written by Cardinal Hayes in compliance with the recent encyclical of the Pope, in which the Cardinal ordered that the archdiocese observe an octave of prayer and penance beginning on June 3 in supplication for the relief of world distress, was read at the 11 o'clock mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. John M. Quinn yesterday.

MADRID, May 29. -- The "One Big Union" of the Communist and Anarchist allies failed today to produce mass demonstrations as planned against "government severity" at Seville. With meetings forbidden, with police patrols on the streets and heavy guards at banks and public buildings, the disturbances were limited to sporadic clashes in Madrid, Barcelona, Bunol and Valencia, in which six persons were killed, including two Civli Guards, and a number were wounded.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Agreements for funding the war-debt payments due to the United States in the 1932-33 fiscal year, but suspended under the Hoover moratorium, are expected by Treasury Department officials to be signed by most of the debtors in the next ten days.

PARIS, May 29. -- The national congress of the French Socialist party debated all today the vital question of whether it should participate with the Radical Socialists in, the government of the country. Between the participationists and non-particlpationists the battle of words at times became hot and furious.

Nominating Without Rhetoric. The Californian who has been chosen to place President HOOVER in nomination at Chicago announces that he will do it without any frills. He is known as "plain JOE SCOTT," and proposes to offer nothing but "common sense" to "plain American people."

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 29 (AP). -- The Bisons extended their winning streak to six straight by humbling the Red Wings, 6 to 2, in the opener of a double encounter today, but lost the second game, 8 to 7. Approximately 15,000 persons saw the Bisons split and continue in a tie for first place.

Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, expects to complete his investigation of Mayor Walker within the next two days, with the possibility that interruptions by Democratic members of the committee and testimony by witnesses friendly to the Mayor might take two more days.
SEATTLE, May 29 (AP). -- In telling the story of his take-off today to The Associated Press, Nathan C. Browne said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES this morning are two articles -- "Foster Predicts a Soviet America" and "Fhelps Asks Dry Repeal." William Z. Foster, Communist leader, predicts that the change will develop more swiftly than in Russia.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Lack of general outside interest in the wheat market is making it difficult for the few speculative leaders who have taken hold of late to maintain bulges. They are buying on breaks and taking profits on part of their holdings on sharp bulges, keeping long fairsized lines.
PITTSBURGH. Pa., May 29. -- The American flag was unfurled today over "Coxtown," giving assurance to scores of destitute families they soon will have permanent homes they can call their own.

DUBLIN, May 29. -- Not content with refusing to pay the next instalment of the land annuities, the de Valera government is preparing to demand the return from Britain of the $150,000,000 in annuities paid in the last decade.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- The arrival here this morning from Warsaw of the 25-year-old Prince Feisal, second son of King Ibn Saud of Hedjaz, gave the Soviet Government another welcome opportunity to demonstrate its friendship for independent Eastern nations.

BERLIN, May 29. -- Immediately on the return today of President von Hindenburg from his vacation at Neudeck, Chancellor Heinrich Bruening submitted a report on the political situation, the two remaining closeted for 4 hours and 45 minutes. An official communique said the conference would be resumed tomorrow.

Memorial Day always has its pathetic or regretful side for some people. Not only do they speak of the "thinning line of veterans " and lament the lack of solemn commemorative ceremonies, but think it a reproach that the day has become so largely one for merriment and recreation and the holiday spirit.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator Borah today held informal conferences with several dry leaders who have come here to attend the meeting of the Prohibition Board of Strategy next Tuesday, at which its fight to prevent the Republican and Democratic parties from adopting wet planks will be mapped.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 29. -- The Outing Club at Mount Holyoke College, which began a new chapter in its history four years ago with the opening of the Jog cabin half way up Mount Holyoke and has since been growing in popularity and membership, is embarking on a new phase in its development, emphasizing the first part of its title rather than the second.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, a leading member of Tammany, has been suggested as an appropriate person to make the speech to place Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in nomination for President before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 29 (AP). -- Miss Jane L. Jones, dean of women at St. Lawrence University, was elected president of the New York Division of American University Women yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting.

If all goes well today should close one of the busiest sessions for Peconic Bay weakfishermen. By a preholiday "roll-call," boatmen's associations that have been catering to salt water anglers all season stated that their bookings were far in excess of available accommodations.

PARIS, May 29 (AP). -- The newspaper Le Temps in a leading article today declared it was impossible to solve such problems as disarmament, reparations, debts and "the new economic order" without the help of the United States. The article drew a conclusion, of hope that the troubles the United States was undergoing "will recall its rulers to present realities."

ALBANY, May 29 (AP). -- An allotment of $156,500 for the Conservation Department announced today by the Temporary Emergency Relief Commission will be expended largely for labor on State parks. Eight park districts will supervise the expenditure of $120,000 and the divisions of fish and game and lands and forests receive $22,000 and $14,500, respectively.

Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, speaking to the United States in her second transatlantic broadcast since her flight to Ireland, expressed astonishment yesterday at the development of private flying in the British Isles, and paid tribute to the warmth of the reception accorded her by the British.

The Sabine farm, which comes into the news of the day through the enterprise of a young Harvard scholar in further unearthing HORACE'S villa, was given by MAECENAS to his friend in the year 33 B.C. Professor RAND of Harvard has led many a reader up to the site of that famed farm.

PARIS, May 27. -- The Bank of France return of Thursday, covering the position of May 20, shows decrease for the week of 502,000,000 franca in circulation and increase of 518,000,000 in private deposits. Bankers accept this as proving that the circulation is completely saturated and that the French people are returning bank-notes in large quantities to the banks.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Prospects of better credit conditions in Chicago and the West were made possible last week by the conference of government and bank officials here. Shortage of credit is said to have kept back business when they believed there were indications of betterment.
ALTON, N. H., May 29 (AP). -- A suicide pact between a man and a woman was believed to have been revealed today with the finding of the bodies in a Summer camp at Place's Pond, near here.

SAUNTON, England, May 29. -- The American players' path, to victory in the women's British open golf championship seems to have been made somewhat easier by the unfortunate disqualification today of Miss Dorothy Pearson, a strong English match player, whose partner credited her in the qualifying round with a 4 where a 5 should have gone down.

The Christian, or righteous man, is like a palm tree, flourishing in dry, barren soil, getting its nourishment from a tap root going far beneath the surface to hidden streams, of the world and yet above it, the Rev. Will H. Houghton, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- After firing two shots over the lofty local right-Held fence in, a lost cause yesterday Babe Ruth made his third homer in three successive games in today's seventh inning, the drive clearing the same fence. Coming with the bases empty, it played only a minor part in the 11-to-8 victory of the Yankees over the Senators before a crowd of about 15,000.

Striving desperately to extricate themselves from the National League's cellar, the Giants, with a heroic effort that stirred the 20,000 onlookers at the Polo Grounds, overcame a seven-run deficit to wrench the opening clash of the double-header from the Phillies, 10 to 8, and forthwith lost all the ground gained by losing the second engagement, 4 to 2.

Memorial Day exercises will be held at widely divergent points in the city today in honor of the war dead. Chief among them will be those at Grant's Tomb at 2:30 P.M. under the auspices of U.S. Grant Post, Grand Army of the Republic, and Lafayette Camp, Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29 (AP). -- The semi-official newspaper Vreme undertook today to arouse the nation against Communist agitation, which it said had spread even to younger officers in the army. It also attacked the foreign press for the publication of what it called "false news" about conditions in Yugoslavia.

A terse warning that the nation expected ex-service men to forego any demand for immediate payment of their compensation certificates was voiced yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, during the annual memorial service of the American Legion of New York County which was held there.

As a reaction to disclosures made last week in the Seabury investigation, many clergymen of New York City joined yesterday in a concentrated attack upon Tammany Hall, Mayor Walker and civic corruption, and voiced an appeal for a political house-cleaning.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP). -- The Athletics and Red Sox split a double-header today, Boston winning the opener, 6 to 4, behind the fine pitching of Bob Weiland, and Walberg hurling shut-out ball as the visitors took the nightcap, 3 to 0.

The second annual entertainment and garden fete by the women's auxiliary of the Society of St. Johnland, to be known as "A Summer Day," will be held on June 29 at the Community of St. Johnland in Kings Park, L. I. The entire community will be open to visitors.

The Carsteel Football Club of Montreal, winner last season of the Canadian eastern soccer championship, here to play two matches at Starlight Park, bowed in the initial encounter with the New York Americans yesterday. The American Leaguers, holding a two-point lead at half time, won handily by 5 to 0.

The headquarters of the search for the kidnappers and murderers of Colonel Lindbergh's baby, which have been in the garage of the Lindbergh home near Hopewell, N.J., since March 2, the day after the kidnapping, was moved yesterday to the New Jersey State Police Training School at Wilburtha, on the River Road about five miles from Trenton.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Hoover out short his Memorial Day week-end at Rapidan Camp tonight, unexpectedly returning to the White House to which he summoned Republican Senate leaders for a conference on the legislative situation, particularly the tax bill.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 29 (AP). -- A passenger in a biplane was burned to death and its pilot critically injured today when it crashed from an altitude of 400 feet and took fire at Bennett Airport.
In a quaint bit of verse of the early seventeenth century it is written:

PARIS, May 29. -- Paul Painleve, former French Premier, who will undoubtedly hold an important ministry in the new government, declared today at Rouen that the best solution for the whole debts and reparations problem would be to wipe the slate clean.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., May 29. -- With national politics forgotten for the week-end, Governor Roosevelt attended Memorial Day services today at St. James's Episcopal Church in company with members of the Montgomery Post of the American Legion, in which he is enrolled.

A Sunday crowd of 30,000 that invaded Ebbets Field yesterday was rewarded by seeing the Robins pull the second game out of the fire in the ninth inning after having dropped the first one to the Braves and seemingly having lost the nightcap, too. The scores were 10 to 6 and 3 to 2.

The inferior ability of an easy-money policy to bring credit into use when confidence is lacking was demonstrated by the outcome of the 1931 credit program of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to the annual report of that institution, made public today.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Memorial Day messages were exchanged today between President Hoover and King Albert of the Belgians. The monarch's message read as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Ten honorary degrees will be conferred by the University of Pennsylvania at its commencement June 22.

TORONTO, Ont., May 29 (Canadian Press). -- Thousands of United States tourists are in Toronto tonight for the Memorial Day week-end. Railway, steamship and highway officials all report the tourist traffic was the heaviest of the season so far and estimate that more than 2,000 Americans will spend the United States national holiday in Southern Ontario.

NEW ORLEANS, May 29. -- Trading in cotton here last week was moderate, with occasional spurts of activity. The price trend was slowly downward, although the selling pressure was limited, traders feeling that the price level now is too low to justify any activity on the short side of the market.
Transactions announced over the week-end by real estate brokers indicate a continued demand for small residential properties in the metropolitan area.

Mayor Walker regards the evidence adduced against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, as having fallen far short of warranting serious consideration by the Governor of charges looking to his removal from office, it became known yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That Governor Roosevelt realizes that the suffering in the country today is due to economic inequality was indicated very plainly by his Atlanta address. In his eagerness to be frank, however, he fell into serious economic error.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- With the graves of thousands of war dead strewn with flowers, the nation's capital this afternoon united in a formal observance of Memorial Day with a massing of colors at Sylvan Theatre, near the Washington Monument. A crowd of 25,000 persons witnessed the ceremony, arranged by the Military Order of the World War and the District of Columbia Bicentennial Commission, with 250 organizations joining in the spectacle.

NEW HAVEN, May 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 60.2, which compares with 61.1 a week ago, 61.4 two weeks ago, 61.6 three weeks weeks before and 62.6 four weeks present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; this week's average is the lowest.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 29. -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel of New York, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, told the 114 members of the graduating class of Gettysburg College in a baccalaureate address today that their aim should be "not to get ahead of others but to get ahead of self."

The Hofstadter legislative committee's investigation of the New York City administration, with the inquiry by Samuel Seabury, its counsel, into the financial affairs of Mayor Walker, was characterized yesterday by Senator John J. Dunnigan, member of the committee and Democratic Senate leader, as part of a Republican scheme to re-elect President Hoover and elect a Republican Governor this Fall.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Glenn Spencer and the Pirates shut out the league-leading Cubs, 2 to 0, in the second game of today's double-header, after the Cubs had blasted out a 7-to-8 victory in the opener, in which Rogers Hornsby made his first appearance as an outfielder.

Henry Ford expresses disapproval of routine charity and asserts that the only true charity is a cooperative spirit between employer and employed, in the first of two statements on unemployment which appears as an advertisement today.

DENVER, May 29 (AP). -- Colonel Amos W. W. Woodcock, Prohibition Administrator, told the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today that millions who wish to see the traffic in intoxicating liquor abolished hope there will be "sufficient courage to sustain this great adventure in nation self-denial."
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- A thirdparty movement, directed by one of the State's best-known lawyers, is under way in Illinois.

To the Editor of The New York Times. A letter to THE TIMES from S.G. Rich needs some comment. Mr. Rich is under the impression that the New York law differs from the New Jersey law regarding automobile driving. However, it will be found in the New York law that Mr. Rich has given some sound advice to New York motorists to observe in their own State.

MOSCOW, May 29 (AP) -- Troops of Soviet Russia drew up to rigid salute to a royal visitor today, the second such personage to pay a state visit to the stronghold of communism since the Czar was overthrown fifteen years ago. The visitor was the Prince Feisal, Vice Emir of Hedjaz.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 29 -- Continuing a series of raids started yesterday in the central city section by special plain-clothes policemen selected by Kern Dodge, Director of Public Safety, district police in the uptown section today smashed through the barred doors of two speakeasies, seized a still in operation, confiscated eight half-barrels of beer and liquor and arrested seventeen men and women patrons.

Those who plan to add art to their Decoration Day program of activities will perhaps find the following information helpful. More than forty of the galleries in the city will be closed today, though enough are on the "receiving" list, with attractions that for the most part have ere this received critical notice in the art columns to Keep even the most strenuous visitor fully occupied.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29. -- In the third of the Olympic elimination trials for the star class yachts of Western Long Island Sound George W. Elder's Iscyra III led twelve others of the jib and mainsail craft around a nine-mile triangle today. Iscyra III defeated H. McMichael's Grey Fox by 1 minute 18 seconds.

PITTSBURGH, May 29. -- The steel trade is encouraged by demand continuing to hold at a time of year that usually shows marked decrease. Steel ingot production was off slightly last week in some districts, notably Birmingham, but the loss was only fractional from the 23 per cent estimated for the preceding week.

Acquittal of Superintendent BRODERICK on the charge of criminal neglect of duty, in not closing the Bank of United States at once when he found what its condition was, is in our judgment the proper ending of the case. The problem confronting him in the last months of 1930, after the bank's impairment of capital had been discovered, was extremely difficult.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Prices of meat continue low, with supplies liberal, a good average consumption and nothing in sight to cause an immediate lowering of values. Choice to fancy steers sold last week at $7.50 to $7.85 a hundredweight, with most steers at $5.25 to $6.75 and the poorest as low as $4.85. Consumers are getting a good grade of beef.

Morristown, N.J., of Revolutionary memories, will dedicate today Jockey Hollow Cemetery, a tract of land near the city and a part of the encampment where 12,000 officers and men spent the bitter Winter of 1779-80. Hundreds of soldiers were buried there in graves which as time went on could not be identified.

Cool breezes and an overcast sky kept the crowds at the shore resorts in the metropolitan area far below expectations yesterday, but the Weather Bureau predicted last night that today would be fair and warmer, with moderate northwest winds. The temperature here yesterday ranged from 51 to 63 degrees.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- With American flags flying before them, sixteen truckloads of war veterans came to the end of a transcontinental hitch-hike today with the avowed purpose of remaining in Washington until Congress pays their bonus in full.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. May, who have been at the Pierre for several months, will sail Friday for Europe. They will go to Geneva, Switzerland, where Mr. May is attached to the League of Nations.

The observance of Memorial Day, the anniversary dedicated to the memory of the past, began yesterday throughout the city, State and nation with solemn, services in honor to the dead. Today the graves of the heroes of another day will be piled with flowers, and the flash of uniforms and the rattle of side-arms will do homage to the men who fought their country's wars.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Lowering of Winter wheat crop estimates last week in the Southwest and Middle West was more pronounced than in previous weeks. Rains in Kansas, Oklahoma and the Southwest generally did some good, but in the main were too late to revive wheat that has deteriorated in the last few weeks.

ANNAPOLIS, May 29. -- The sword was pictured today to the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy as the symbol of peace and justice. Chaplain Frank H. Lash, delivering the baccalaureate sermon, emphasized that it was given as a legacy from the past.

BERLIN, May 29 (AP) -- The two men upon, whom the present fate of Germany rests -- Chancellor Bruening and President von Hindenburg -- held a private conference today, but declined to comment on their "discussions" beyond saying they would be continued.

The new Frencn cabin liner Champlain, scheduled, to dock in New York on her maiden trip on June 27, will carry no deck ventilators, and her decks will be covered with slipproof rubber tiling, according to H. Alnsley Highman, passenger manager of the French Line.

BALTIMORE, May 29 -- Three young men lost their lives in Chesapeake Bay early today in a storm after their canoe capsized. The fourth of the party, unconscious from cold and exposure, was rescued by a lifeboat crew of the steamer W.S. Miller, an oil tanker of the Standard Oil Company of California.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The votes in the Senate and Houss by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Advocating the adoption of the sales tax as an emergency measure, former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, in an interview here today, said that he was opposed to Speaker Garner's relief measure as a means of stimulating prosperity.

The dreams of 264 young women undergraduates at Barnard College centre on marriage, reading and men, in the order named, according to the answers to a questionnaire sent out by the Associate Alumnae, the results of which were made public yesterday by Miss Helen Erskine, the president.

WARSAW, May 29. -- Public opinion in Poland has been genuinely alarmed by the resolution of the German Reichstag's foreign affairs committee proclaiming the readiness of the Reich to defend Danzig in case of Polish aggression as well as by evidences of growing anti-Polish feeling in Germany.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 29. -- Two world's motor boat records were established on Lake Quinslgamond today in the second day's program of the annual regatta of the Worcester County Motor Boat Club.

LAWRENCE, Mass., May 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Samuel T. Luscomb told the police tonight she was convinced the body of a girl found in a Summer camp at Alton, N. H., was that of her daughter, Helen. She said her daughter had been friendly with William Foster of Andover Foster, she said, was married and the father of three children.

The significance of Memorial Day was the main subject in many pulpits of New York houses of worship yesterday, and in many sermons an appeal for peace and social orderliness was emphasized in the name of those who have fallen in battle since the national holiday came into existence.

J.A. SISTO, Wall Street operator and taxicab financier, testified before the Hofstadter committee that he had offered to carry Mayor WALKER in a Cosden Oil stock pool. JOHN T. McKEON, another Wall Street man, testified that he had delivered to the Mayor, while riding in a taxicab uptown with him from City Hall, bonds to the value of $26,000, representing his share in the profits of that pool.

ALLAHABAD, May 29. -- The "Buy British" campaign sweeping England is being imitated in India to the embarrassment of British business. Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, the veteran all-India National Congress leader, today issued a long manifesto urging concentration on the "Buy Indian" movement as a means of easing India's economic suffering and reducing the poverty of the masses.

England, because of the stronger character of her people, is recovering from economic adversity while the United States continues in depression, declared the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Boston, in a sermon on "Moral Causes and Economic Consequences" at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday morning.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The reichsmark's value on the international market weakened somewhat during the present week. Until the last few days, the Reichsbank had supported the mark by refusing to buy foreign exchange except at one-half of 1 per cent below the German official rates; thus compelling foreigners who needed marks to buy them on foreign markets, where, owing to the German prohibition against export of home currency, a shortage of marks continues.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 29 -- The English-designed and built twelvemeter yacht Mouette, owned by Horace Havemeyer, showed the way to W.A.W. Stewart's Iris by 1 minute 43 seconds today in the twelve-meter class race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club over a course of thirteen and one-half miles on the Sound.

Some intimate letters in which George Washington told of the difficulties in being called upon too often to play the part of host, were reproduced by the late Thomas Nelson Page in his "History and Preservation of Mount Vernon," a revised edition of which has just been printed for the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union by the Knicker-bocker Press.
LANCASTER, Pa., May 29 (AP). -- The four occupants of one automobile were killed and six in another were injured seriously in a collision on the Lincoln Highway tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29. -- Thomas E. Armstrong, captain of the Harvard varsity crew, was arrested early today by Cambridge police after a clash between students and a group of Cambridge youths known as the Kerry Corner Boys.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP). -- The Tigers made it four out of five against the White Sox today, winning the final game of a series, 4 to 3.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- E. Bogardus Shaw, retired broker and brother of Walden W. Shaw, one of the founders of the Yellow Cab Company, was killed this afternoon in a fall from the fire escape landing of his thirteenth-floor apartment at 1,120 Lake Shore Drive.

WITH the heavy firing on Decoration Day, the ball clubs will be pulling past what might be called the "three-quarter pole" in the pennant race, to borrow a phrase from the turf, which has its peculiarities such as naming the distance markers backward from the finish toward the start. The "eighth pole," for instance, on the turf is the marker a furlong from the finish.

Washington Square's outdoor art exhibition, which opened last Saturday and will continue throughout the week, earned $380 for needy artists yesterday and got two of them permanent jobs. In all, fifty-one paintings were sold and the receipts exceeded by $20 those of the opening day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES'S report of the action of the Medical Society of the State of New York at Buffalo on antivivisectionists, there is a long list of assertions of the benefits of vivisection, without a vestige of proof being given.

SEATTLE, May 29. -- Nathan C. Browne brought his big monoplane, the Lone Star, back to Boeing Field today seven hours and twenty minutes after he had made a perilous take-off on a projected non-stop flight to Tokyo.

BERLIN, May 27. -- There has been no improvement in the German home steel market, except in the wire branch. Export steel is weaker, probably because England is buying chiefly from Belgium, at prices averaging 25 cents per ton below April. The German Stahlwerksverband is unwilling to export except at prices averaging 10 marks per ton above the Belgian prices.
