LONDON, May 27. -- Only the determination of the British authorities to obstruct an undesired rise in sterling has prevented a considerable advance in sterling this week and a proportionate decline in dollar exchange. It is unfortunately true that the manner in which the American Congress continues to fumble with the national finances has weakened confidence abroad, and that this is the main cause for the weakness of dollar exchange.

CALCUTTA, May 29. -- The Bengal ordinance which was clamped down on the terrorists last December will be superseded on its expiry at midnight tonight by a new ordinance promulgated at Simla last night.

VIENNA, May 29 (AP) -- A mysterious parable writer who signs himself " " and is believed by many to be a leader of the Rumanian People's party, caused excitement in Bucharest today with veiled warnings of death for King Carol of Rumania and his friend, Mme. Helene Lupescu.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Speaker John N. Garner of the House, and Majority Leader Henry T. Rainey retorted individually today to President Hoover's criticism of the Garner $2,100,000,000 unemployment relief bill, contending that what the President now terms "pork, barrel" legislation once was advocated by him.

A detailed report on municipal operation of the new city subway system, beginning with the Eighth Avenue line, has been virtually completed by the Board of Transportation. It is based on a five-cent fare and includes a detailed estimate of operating costs and revenues, as required by the State law authorizing municipal operation.

PARIS, May 29. -- Henri Cochet and Jacques Brugnon, France's Davis Cup doubles team, maintained their supremacy at Roland Garros Stadium today by winning the French men's doubles championship, defeating the French junior combination of Christian Boussus and Marcel Bernard, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP). -- The Indians split a double-header with the Browns today, and ended a four-game series with three victories. The Browns took the opener, 12 to 3, and dropped the second game, 2 to 1.
NEWSREELS, a compilation of Movietone and Met rot one newsreels, shown continuously at the Embassy Theatre.

By those who have opportunity to observe financial sentiment in other localities than their own it is commonly remarked that the depth of gloom, the despairing attitude toward occurrences of the present day, are more strikingly apparent in America than in Europe, and in New York than in any other part of America.

Two upsets were recorded last week as the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race entered its final stages. Princeton's 3-1 victory over a favored Pennsylvania team on Saturday at Princeton forced last year's champions into third place, while Cornell's 3-2 triumph over Dartmouth at Ithaca eliminated the Green from all chance of finishing in first place.

ABOARD STEAMSHIP ARTIGLIO, Off Brest, France, May 29 -- The first contents of the sunken liner Egypt's bullion room have been brought to the surface by divers of the Italian salvage ship Artiglio, who recently resumed their efforts to recover the liner's $5,000,000 treasure.
READING, Pa., May 29 (AP). -- Reading split a double-header with Newark today, taking the series from the Bears, two to one.

Lieutenant Gustave Heiss of the Fencers Club won the national outdoor epee championship at the NewYork A. C. grounds at Travers Island yesterday. There were thirty-six contestants in the title competition, that lasted almost nine hours.

LONDON, May 29. -- Prime Minister MacDonald announced today he was going to Lausanne with the intention of broadening the scope of the conference to include not only reparations and war debts but also the creeping paralysis that is overtaking international trade.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- Historians differ as to the exact age of Independence Hall, most famous of the nation's shrines, but, according to some of of them, its 200th birthday party should be held this year.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 29. -- Twenty-two of the gardens of Summer estates will be opened to the public on Tuesday afternoons, beginning on June 14, under the auspices of the Newport Garden Association for the benefit of the Newport Civic League.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 29. -- The Yale Gallery of Fine Arts has come into possession of the last of four Chinoiserie tapestries woven about 1700 for Elihu Yale, for whom Yale University was named. The tapestry, known as "The Palanquin," is a gift to the university from Edward S. Harkness of New York, who donated the others in 1926.
CINCINNATI, May 29 (AP). -- The Reds and Cardinals split a double header today, the Cards winning the first, 5 to 0, and the Reds the second, 3 to 2, in the eleventh inning.

RICHMOND, May 29. -- In line with the nation-wide effort backed by President Hoover to stimulate credit by loosening vast bank credits. Governor George J. Seay of the Fifth District Federal Reserve Bank yesterday announced the appointment of ten of the twelve members of a district committee.

Leading for most of the contest, the All-New York team defeated the Mayo Provincials, world's Gaelic football champions, 10 to 7, before 15,000 at the Tankee Stadium yesterday for its second victory in the three-game series between the teams.

The Pulitzer Prize in reporting has been, awarded to W.C. Richards, D.D. Martin, J.S. Pooler, F.D. Webb and J.N.W. Sloan of The Detroit Free Press for their "coordinated spot news story, written against press time, of the parade of the American Legion during the 1931 convention in Detroit," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

The Fox Film Corporation and wholly owned subsidiary, controlled and affiliated companies report for the thirteen weeks ended on March 26 a net loss of $1,922,628 after all charges, taxes, depreciation and settlement of contracts or previous years, contrasting with a net profit of $974,704 in the thirteen weeks ended on March 28, 1931.

Engineers of the Department of Docks are studying several proposals for the further fireproofing of piers which the city plans to build in the next few years, Dock Commissioner John McKenzie said yesterday. The recent destruction by fire of Pier 54, North River, he said, revealed weaknesses both in its physical make-up and in the opportunities afforded the apparatus of the Fire Department to reach vital parts of the structure.

The birth of 15,202 babies was recorded in New York City's municipal hospitals last year -- the largest number in the history of the city-owned institutions -- according to a report sent yesterday to Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, by Dr. Caroline R. Martin, head of the Division of Medical Records and Statistics.

Herbert D. Fuchs, the 15-year-old Brooklyn boy. whose fight against infantile paralysis attracted nationwide attention during the 270 successive days he spent in an airtight steel respirator at the Kingston Avenue Hospital, returned yesterday to his home at 1,314 Eastern Parkway.

Competitive examinations in literature for men in public life would scarcely be welcomed by them. The statesman who refused to answer questions would excuse himself on the ground of being too busy with important affairs to waste time on schoolboy nonsense.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- With the Republican National Convention just two weeks off next Tuesday, Congress is still so deeply enmeshed in a tangle of sizable tasks that some leaders expect the convention to be run off with alternates in most of the principal roles.

Pointing out objections to the tax on capital gains on general and special counts, the Committee on Taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has issued a report recommending to the President of the United States and to Congress that no change be made in the existing law unless this tax be eliminated from the income tax system.
HOMEWOOD, Ill., May 30 (AP). -- The Audley Farm stable's Hilena, making her second start, won the $5,000 added Debutante Stakes, today's feature of the Washington Park program.

Although storm signals had been flying above the German Government for a few days past, the sudden resignation of Chancellor BRUENING, along with his entire Cabinet, came as a disagreeable surprise. Its causes are still rather obscure.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30. -- Visitors at the Newport Country Club today were Cyril Tolley, former British champion, who will compete in the annual invitation tournament in July, and Kenneth MacColl of Providence, winner of the tournament last Summer, who will defend his title.

Lewis Gawtry, president of the Bank for Savings in the City of New York, has become chairman of a consulting committee formed to assist the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with reference to real estate and mortgages in the Second Federal Reserve District.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30. -- Seton Hall College closed its baseball season today with its second victory over Manhattan College, winning 9 to 3. The home team hit the offerings of Blake, who went three innings, and Pendergast, who finished the game, freely, every player getting at least one hit. Reiss made four in as many times at the bat, including two doubles.

Cannon thundered salutes at noon yesterday and bugles sounded "Taps" as residents of the five boroughs assembled at soldiers' graves and military monuments to honor the nation's war dead at Memorial Day services.

Business will be resumed as usual in Wall Street today, after having been suspended yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. All the financial and commodity markets, as well as banks, were closed yesterday. Outside of New York, the New Orleans Cotton Exchange was open.

THERE was some comment here recently on a British review of Olympic prospects in which California was classified as "this remote corner of the earth," Big Ben Eastman and Gene Venzke were not even mentioned by name and most of our stars were blandly ignored. A glance at a recent issue of La Domenica Sportiva (Milano) shows that they order these things better in Italy.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30. -- David N. Jones of Columbia University, seeded fifth in the draw, came from behind to defeat Berkeley Bell of New York in the final round of the annual invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Difficulties that will be met by the GermanAmerican expedition that has set out to climb Nanga Parbat, lone peak in Kashmir, are described in a bulletin issued by the National Geographic Society.

ROME, May 30 (AP). -- The body of Anita Garibaldi, whom her husband, the red-shirted liberator General Giuseppe Garibaldi, called "the most perfect human creature known to mankind," will be brought here from Genoa Thursday for burial under her statue on Janiculum Hill, overlooking the Vatican, near the spot where her famous husband directed the battle with French and papal troops.
The list of graduates and postgraduates who will receive diplomas at the commencement of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilllard School of Music today was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Henry W. Peabbdy, chairman of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement, conferred with Senator Borah today. She said she wanted to tell him about her plans for the coming campaign and learn the attitude of Congress.

NEW ORLEANS, May 30. -- The police tonight notified William W. Parish of 241 Central Park West, New York City, that the description of a man who killed himself in a hotel here last Tuesday fallied with that of his son, William W. Farish Jr., who had been hunted since his disappearance May 17 in Juarez, Mexico.

VATICAN CITY, May 30 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI will be 75 years old tomorrow. He will celebrate the day with a special mass of thanksgiving in his private chapel. His sister, Donna Camilla Ratti; his niece and nephew by marriage, the Marquise and Marquis Persichetti-Ugolini, and a few prelates of the papal household will attend the service.
BRUNSWICK, Me., May 30. -- In a Memorial Day address Kenneth C.M. Sills, president of Bowdoin College, advocated a national referendum on prohibition.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 30. -- Holy Cross defeated Boston College, 10 to 2, in their annual baseball classic today before a holiday crowd of 7,500.

The five-point program advocated toy the executive committee of the State Chamber of Commerce has much to commend it to those seeking to bring about the "drastic municipal economy" so necessary at this time. "Immediate unification" of transit facilities seems like a rather large order, though no one can contemplate with equanimity the present drift toward municipal operation.

The New York Law School made public yesterday the list of graduates on whom the degree of Bachelor of Laws will be conferred at commencement exercises in Town Hall on Thursday evening. Professor Robert D. Petty, dean of the Law School, also announced that the address to the graduating class would be delivered by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Del Hanover, fast trotting colt owned by Wilbur D. Blood of Rutherford and driven by Walter Garrison of Bridgeton, romped off with the 3-year-old trot which featured the Memorial Day matine today as more than 25,000 persons looked on.

In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in this country were closed yesterday. In Europe, the day's movement was irregular, prices for home securities generally holding steady on the various markets but foreign securities showing weakness.

MUNICH, May 30. -- The call for a dictatorship in Germany does not imply a charge against democracy, but is addressed to a courageous leader who will not leave responsibility to the masses and will be willing to renounce immediate advantage for the benefit of future generations, Professor Harwood L. Childs of Princeton University declared here yesterday.

Columbia remained in the race for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship yesterday by defeating Pennsylvania twice in a double-header at Baker Field. The Morningside nine blasted its way to an 8-to-3 triumph in the opening combat, but barely managed to emerge with an 8-to-7 conquest in the second encounter.

Russia and Islam. Soviet Russia's cultivation of friendship with the peoPles of the Near East has brought to Moscow a royal visit from the kingdom of Hedjaz, close on the heels of the Turkish Premier and Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- On the wooded slopes of Arlington and in every cemetery in and near Washington where rests a soldier of the Republic the nation today honored its dead. There were flowers on every grave, and memorial tributes were paid at many services, chief of which was the observance in the amphitheatre at Arlington, where the principal address was delivered by former Senator Reed of Missouri.

Long Island paid tribute to its war dead yesterday when veterans of three wars made pilgrimages to the various cemeteries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and laid wreaths on the graves of heroes or placed flowers at the memorials dedicated to the memory of those buried in other lands.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 30. -- Sensational golf on the part of Paul Runyan, former New Jersey and Metropolitan P.G.A. champion, spelled defeat for Billy Burke, national open champion, and Johnny Farrell, former holder of the title, in an eighteen-hole exhibition match played over the new Munsey Park Golf Club course today.

The Board of Taxicab Control hopes to have its tentative code of regulations ready for distribution to representatives of the taxicab industry at a public hearing in City Hall tomorrow afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Maurice Hotchner.

Joe Hoctor captured two first places and Jack Shevlin one to feature the team triumph of Iona School of New Rochelle in the senior division of the first Manhattan division C.H.S. A.A. outdoor track and field championship meet contested yesterday at Manhattan College.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- With all revenue-raising provisions of the tax bill tentatively adopted, the measure tonight contained a total of $963,500,000, or $46,000,000 less than the revenue estimated by the Finance Committee for the bill as it was reported to the Senate.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Frank Nordell, brilliant New York University runner, won the James B. Sheehan Memorial Mile in the sixty-sixth annual Hibernian games at Cahill Field today.

SEATTLE, May 30 (AP). -- Unless Harold Bromley, former Tacoma flier en route here for his fourth attempt to span the North Pacific by air, starts tonight he has no chance to win a $25,000 cash award raised five years ago, W.W. Conner, secretary of the fund, said tonight.
CHICAGO, May 30. -- The following statement, signed by Charles H. Swift, vice president, was issued today to its shareholders by the Compania Swift International:

Preparations for June sales events nad purchases of Summer apparel provided activity for the wholesale markets here last week. Orders for sales goods favored inexpensive dresses, silks and handbags. In most instances, retailers were hesitant about making commitments for any large quantity of merchandise, due to uncertainty over price stability and future business.

The new United Fruit liner Quirigua, under construction at the Fore River yards of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, will sail from New York on Thursday, June 9, on her maiden trip to Port Everglades, Fla., and Havana, Kingston, Cristobal and Port Limon, according to announcement yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., May 30. -- Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the United States Supreme Court "should be drafted to serve as President" declared Hugh A. Carney, lawyer of Boston, in an address at the Memorial Day services of the Charitable Irish Society of Boston at Granary Burying Ground today.

MANILA, May 30. -- A storm of Filipino opposition was expressed today against the amendments suggested to the United States Senate by W. Cameron Forbes, former Governor General of the islands, to the Hawes-Cutting bill for Philippine independence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 30. -- In a Memorial Day address before 2,000 persons at Playland in Rye, Brig. Gen. John Ross Delafield, commander-in-chief of the Military Order of the World War, urged Congress and the citizenry of the nation today to fight efforts to reduce the strength of the nation's military armament.

Fordham's string of eleven consecutive baseball victories this season was broken yesterday when the Maroon met its second defeat at the hands of the New York University nine, 7 to 5, at Fordham Field.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 31. -- Some London newspapers today express fears that the fall of the Bruening Cabinet in Germany yesterday will result in increased power for the militarists which will add to Europe's troubles.

LONDON, May 30. -- The stock markets were irregular today and business was still slack. British Government funds started dull, then rallied and became strong. Industrials were quiet and prices generally lower in the absence of support.

Four golf suits full of four of the keenest of Commissioner Mulrooney's pickpocket squad burst out in the crowded districts of Harlem yesterday with a splash of color that looked like an explosion of a dye works. Even the best friends of Detectives Barry, Sheehan, Buckley and Hollingsworth would have taken them for real duffers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 30. -- Buenos Aires rather than Washington is to be the scene of any further quarreling growing out of the Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay if the contestants sign the non-aggression pact drawn up by a commission of neutrals in Washington after several months of arguing.
BERLIN, May 30 (AP). -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening and his Cabinet stepped aside today and the Nazis of Adolf Hitler hailed the resignation with the triumphant slogan: "Our Hour Has Come!"

OMAHA, May 30 (AP). -- Blown northwestward by a strong wind that delayed their take-off almost two hours, six hydrogen-filled balloons late today started from the municipal airport in the National Balloon race, final event of the second annual Omaha air races.

SAUNTON, England, May 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare and Miss Virginia Van Wie won their matches today in most decisive fashion. Playing at the top of her game, Miss Van Wie crushed Miss Jean McCulloch, Scottish champion, 8 and 6. Mrs. Vare, five times United States champion, overwhelmed Mrs. George Coats of Troon, 7 and 6.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Friends of Kern Dodge, Director of Public Safety, revealed today that racketeers had offered him a $50,000 bribe to be permitted to open, lavishly furnished gambling and liquor establishments.

BUFFALO, May 30 (AP). -- Largely through the lavish use of their homerun punch, the Bisons staged two Memorial Day parades against the Maple Leafs today on winning both halves of a double encounter before 16,000 and taking the undisputed league leadership after having been tied with Baltimore.

SAUNTON, England, May 30. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, the medalist and well-backed popular favorite, and Miss Helen Hicks, the American champion, are out of the women's British open golf championship. They joined the gallery of amazed spectators today with Mrs. Harley Higbie, Mrs. Opal S. Hill and all five French entrants.

At the free placement bureau of the Vocational Service for Juniors requests for boys and girls from employers have dropped from over 5,000 in 1927 to 2,000 in 1931. Dr. MARY HAYES, the director, has just published a report on its activities for the past five years.

In the shadows of the converging Chatham Square elevated structures, memorial exercises were held yesterday afternoon at the graves of fourteen Jewish patriots of the Revolutionary War. The fourteen are buried in the oldest Jewish cemetery in New York, on the east side of the New Bowery, between Oliver and James Streets.

Republican Spain, having provided herself with, a Constitution of her own, is now engaged upon the next biggest single problem, that confronts her -- the drafting of a statute for Catalonia. Here again, according to the week-end's news from Madrid, the good fortune that has smiled upon the infant republic continues to manifest itself.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP). -- A fist fight between George Moriarty, American League umpire, and four members of the Chicago team followed Cleveland's victory in both games of a double-header over the White Sox today. Moriarty broke his hand in the fracas.

HARLAN, Ky., May 30 (AP). -- F.M. Bratcher, 45-year-old coal miner, was called to trial here today as the first of the remaining twenty-seven defendants to face murder charges before a jury as a result of the "battle of Evarts" last May 5 which cost four lives during the coal-fields strike.

The soldier dead of four wars were honored throughout New Jersey yesterday with parades of patriotic, civic, military and veterans' organizations to Memorial Day services, held in historic shrines and public parks. Preparations for national defense in times of emergency was the principal subject of the addresses, and the kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh was cited as the challenge of a rising tide of lawlessness.

Getting away to a good start, Horace Havemeyer's 12-meter Engish-built sloop Mouette made a runaway race yesterday of her class competition in the second championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- In drab, abandoned buildings, the "bonus expeditionary force" bathed and shaved today and then moved to consolidate their scattered groups under one leader-Walter W. Waters of Oregon.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30. -- With death-defying speed, Freddy Frame of Los Angeles roared to victory in the twentieth international 500-mile automobile race over the Indianapolis Speedway today, leaving a string of broken records in the wake of his tiny gray-painted eight-cylinder racer.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- Rochester obtained an even break today in the holiday double-header with Montreal, winning, 6 to 5, after losing the first game, 4 to 2, before a crowd of 10,000.
MONTREAL, May 30. -- The Canadian sales tax has provided considerable revenue during the last ten years, the high mark being reached in 1924, when the income from this source reached $100,950,678.

ALBANY, May 30. -- The leadership displayed by George Washington in time of national stress was put forward by Governor Roosevelt as an example for current times in an address delivered today at Kingston.

Paced by Frank Bowden and Percy L. Kynaston, the two top seeded contenders, each of whom played two rounds, five players gained the quarter-finals of the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday on the clay courts of the Terrace Club of Flat-bush.

Josiah P. Marvel, for the last two years assistant director of the Brooklyn Museum, has been appointed director of the new art museum now under construction in Springfield, Mass. This announcement ,has just been issued by Nathan D. Bill, president, and the board of trustees of the City Library Association in Springfield, together with the following report:

OSSINING, May 30. -- John Finnegan, 28 years old, serving his second term in Sing Sing for robbery in Manhattan, was shot in the left arm this afternoon in an attempt to escape while, the prison baseball nine was playing a team from Jersey City. One bullet from a watch-tower machine gun caught him as he went over the wall and he dropped fifteen feet to the railroad tracks, where he was captured.

A pageant of American shipping in the days of the clipper ship will be presented on June 11 at the Federal Shipbuilding Company's yard at Kearny, N.J., in connection with the launching of the new Grace liner Santa Paula, second of four ships being built by the company for its intercoastal service.

READING, Pa., May 30 (AP). -- Baltimore and Reading split two games today, the Orioles taking the first, 13 to 4, and the Keys coming back in the final, 6 to 4. Eight homers were driven, Packard making two.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- Secretary Hurley in aligning himself alongside the President in a slashing denunciation of Speaker Garner's public works bill as a "wasteful extravagance" prepared his statement late in the day after a conference with Major Gen. Lytle Brown, chief of engineers, and Brig. Gen. George E. Fillsbury, assistant to General Brown.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- While the nation was celebrating Memorial Day, 525 veterans of the World War, 300 from the Pacific Coast and 225 from scattering States, camped here today after arriving yesterday in trucks, prepared, their leader said, to stay here until Congress accedes to their demand for immediate cash payment of their bonus certificates.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 30. -- Cadet Rush B. Lincoln Jr., son of Lieut. Col. Rush B. Lincoln, who is on duty at the Boston Army Base, will be graduated at the head of his class of 262 at the Military Academy.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30. -- Speaking on "The Education of Abraham Lincoln," Dr. John H. Finley of New York at commencement exercises of Gettysburg College today declared that unless the present educational system was fostering in the student a "zeal for knowledge" such as Lincoln had it was missing its chief purpose.
The First Division polo team defeated the Princeton Officers in the second game of the Memorial Day Cup series at Fort Hamilton yesterday, 9 to 7. The game was witnessed by a crowd of 3,000 persons.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30. -- Terming the "economy bill" sent by the House to the Senate a few weeks ago a "joke," Henry P. Fletcher, former Ambassador to Italy, asserted in a Memorial Day address in the National Cemetery here today that the country was "suffering from governmental incompetence and extravagance."

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 (AP).-- Efforts to avert a threatened suspension of motion picture imports after June 1, which would close Chile's 350 movie houses within a few months, will be made tomorrow at a mass meeting of distributers, theatre owners and their employes.

SEATTLE, May 30. -- Nathan C. Browne's second attempt to span the Pacific by air ended today when his big monoplane Lone Star collapsed during refueling operations and plunged into Puget Sound. The New York pilot and his assistant, Frank Brooks, saved themselves by leaping with parachutes.

For his design of a $7,000,000 Columbia University skyscraper of thirty stories equal in capacity to all the space now occupied for educational activities on the Morning-side Heights campus, Howard E. Bahr of Sayville, L.I., has received the Charles Follen Mckim fellowship of the Columbia School of Architecture, it was announced yesterday by Dean William A. Boring.

MOSCOW, May 30 (AP). -- The government organ Izvestia today charged certain Japanese elements with seeking an invasion of Eastern Siberia to "facilitate Japan's preparations for war against the United States by making available for the Japanese military machine the rich natural resources of Asiatic Russia."

With 32,000 holiday fans going into a frenzy of excitement and showering torn papers onto the field, the Robins yesterday staged an eighthinning rally to defeat the Phillies in the second game, 5 to 3, after having annexed the opener, 13 to 4, and for the first time this season gained a precarious perch in the first division.

Reports that some of the leaders at the national conventions purpose taking "an equivocal position" on prohibition, "so that parties and candidates shall be committed to delay rather than action," are being called to the attention of President Hoover and aspirants for the Democratic nomination by the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, which has protested against such tactics in a resolution.

On Friday morning Mr. FESS rose in the Senate with something of the sadness which his rising communicates to his colleagues. Some "bright newspaper boys" had sent dispatches, published that morning, reporting correctly that "a Senate consisting entirely of empty seats" was called to order by the Vice President the day before, Mr. FESS began a lament of some length.

The tap of canes and the gentle creak of crutches kept pathetic time to the blare of marching tunes and the clank of arms yesterday as the old and the disabled, veterans of Gettysburg and Belleau Wood, joined with the soldiers and the sailors of today in the city's annual observance of Memorial Day.
While Manhattan real estate trading was practically at a standstill over the week-end, considerable activity was noted at the lake and shore resorts in the metropolitan area.

Clinching the game in the fourth period, when it registered three goals, the Great Island polo team triumphed over the Governors Island quartet in the third and deciding match of their series yesterday before 2,500 persons at Governors Island. The score was 5 to 3.

The misery of Russia cries aloud art every Russian street, but foreign newspaper correspondents can tell only "fractions of the truth" about it, Paul Scheffer, for seven years the Russian correspondent for The Berliner Tageblatt, writes in "Seven Years in Soviet Russia," published by Macmillan.

A fist fight in the gallery of the Harlem Opera House, a motion picture and vaudeville theatre at 211 West 125th Street, near the busy intersection of Seventh Avenue, threw the audience of 1,600 persons into a panic yesterday afternoon, resulting in minor injuries to twenty-four persons and the arrest of two alleged trouble-makers.
BELGRADE, May 30. -- The palace of King Alexander and five other strategic spots in the capital were bombed today.

BOSTON, May 30. -- The Giants today served notice on the world in general and Boston in particular that they were dissatisfied with their lowly surroundings. They commenced major pennant operations in earnest by overthrowing the aspiring Braves in both encounters of the holiday double-header to emerge from the cellar and advance to seventh place.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Scores of high officials and representatives of foreign governments joined today with more than 60,000 men and women in honoring the memory of George Washington at a military field mass celebrated at the Catholic University by Archbishop Michael J. Curley of Baltimore.

SEVILLE, May 30. -- A serious attempt to restore Alfonso XIII to the Spanish throne, financed by the contributions of feudal landowners, collapsed today at Seville when 600 extra police cowed bombers and terrorists during a general strike. The movement was general in Southern Spain.

ANDOVER, Mass., May 30. -- Bill Sline Jr., son of the old-time New England League pitcher, exhibited a fine brand of southpaw twirling in the holiday game this morning and the Holy Cross freshman team defeated Phillips Andover by 11 to 2.

WHITE HAVEN, Pa., May 30. -- When a friend tells you about his favorite trout stream you can usually expect a good story. There is always a certain pool where in the twilight, he hooked a big one last year and the year before that. But if you are the least bit skeptical the surest way to satisfy yourself is to accept his invitation.
Five G.A.R. veterans peered down into the shadowy recess of Grant's Tomb yesterday and tossed the white flowers they had worn in their lapels upon the crypt of their former commanding General.

Alexander Leftwich, musical director, has abandoned his project to present musical comedy revivals at the Westchester "County Centre, White Plains, he announced last flight in a statement in which he charged that the Actors' Equity Association, by invoking its Sunday night performance rule and its minimum wage scale for chorus members, had caused the loss of ten weeks' work and "about $150,000 in expected salaries" to 145 persons.

PARIS, May 30. -- President Hoover's strong support of the efforts for adoption of a sales tax are being watched with Interest in France, where the sales tax was undoubtedly one of the most important measures by which the country, righted itself financially after the World War.

MADISON, N.J., May 30. -- A pageant, "Of Such Is the Kingdom," was the principal feature of Alumni Day at Drew University today. The pageant was written and directed by Elizabeth Edland of New York and depicted the history of the Sunday school from the time of its founding in 1781 to the present day.

Featured by victories of the veteran scullers, Kenneth Myers and W.E. Garrett-Gilmore of the Bachelors Barge Club of Philadelphia, and by the graduate crew of Columbia University, which is training for the Olympics, the annual regatta of the New York Rowing Association was held yesterday afternoon over a mile and a quarter course on the Harlem River.

As long ago as 1667 there were proposals to reclaim the Zuider Zee, but not until our own time were any advanced which could be seriously entertained. Now the old dream of the Netherlands is partly realized; another twenty years must elapse before the far-reaching plans laid down in eight reports published between 1887 and 1891 can be carried out.
LONDON, May 30. -- Larry Gains of Toronto. holder of the British Empire heavyweight championship, outpointed Primo Camera, Italian giant, in ten rounds at the White City Stadium tonight.
MONTREAL, Que., May 30. -- W.E. J. Luther, former chairman of the Montreal Stock Exchange, was found dead in his garage at Hudson Heights, Que., this morning.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 30. -- A Memorial Day crowd of 25,000 lined the shady banks of Lake Quinsigamond today as Worcester's annual three-day motor boat regatta came to an end.

PARIS, May 30. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Sidney B. Wood Jr. of the United States today defeated Mlle. Josane Sigart of Belgium and Jean Borotra of France, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, to gain the final round of the mixed doubles of the French tennis championships at the Roland Garros Stadium.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30. -- Harvard was defeated by Brown today, 4 -- 3, in the annual Memorial Day baseball game, the Bears breaking even in the yearly series.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Here is a suggested outline of a two-year plan for national and State legislation:

NEW HAVEN, May 30. -- No disillusionment about the aims of the World War, its diplomacy or its results should not render the nation insensitive to the heroism of those who gave their lives, Professor Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School said at the Yale Memorial Day services.

An attempt to show a close financial connection between Mayor Walker and Russell T. Sherwood, his missing accountant, through payments from the accounts of each to a mysterious person whose identity has not been disclosed, will be made by Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, when the public hearings are resumed this morning.

HAVANA, May 30. -- Whispers that armed expeditions are now approaching Cuba from other countries are beard on all sides and sharper watchfulness in military and naval quarters here is evident. An order requiring military passes for entry into and departure from Havana is being enforced.

Newark and Jersey City divided morning and afternoon games in Jersey City yesterday, Jersey City capturing the second contest, 7 to 3, after losing the morning encounter, 9 to 4. A crowd of 5,000 saw the first game, while 10,000 attended the second.
A hard-hitting New York Athletic Club team capitalized on thirteen safe drives to defeat the Brooklyn College nine, 10 to 4, on the victor's field at Travers Island yesterday.

At this time of year this sort of thing in books used to be known as "hammock fiction." It is light and silly and frequently funny, and at the Cort last evening it was entitled "Bridal Wise." Although a mischievous printer left their names off the program, Albert Hackett and Frances Goodrich, quondam authors of "Up Pops the Devil," are also the authors of this Summer antic.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 30. -- With an almost direct reference to Mayor Walker, Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, declared today that the time had come to do away with tin boxes and safes bulging with money in the homes of politicians living in luxury, while the depression worked hardships upon the plain citizen.

DEVON, Pa., May 30. -- More than 10,000 persons attended the final session of the Devon Horse Show today, at which Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery's Olive was judged the champion hunter. The Edward F. Beale Challenge Trophy went to the Villanova (Pa.) entry, while Mrs. William du Pont Jr.'s Quarryman took the reserve ribbon.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The con troversy between Democrats and the Administration over the form which unemployment relief shall take, extended today to the independent Re publican ranks, when Senator Cutting attacked the President for his opposition to public works.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont are expected today at the Ritz-Carlton.

Women who served abroad during the World War took part yesterday in the Memorial Day services of the Overseas Service League, held near the entrance to Central Park at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street. In the smooth green plot set aside for the organization by the Park Department two trees were added to the twenty-four already planted by the league, each of which is a tribute to the memory of a dead member.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Cincinnati Reds split two holiday games today, Pittsburgh winning the afternoon game, 5 to 2, after dropping the morning encounter, 4 to 2.

One sentence in Controller BERRY'S address before the savings bank officials deserves to be "read, marked, learned and inwardly digested" by all concerned about the budget and the credit of this city: "There "should be some limit placed on that "part of the tax-rate which is for "debt service."

Fred S. Burroughs, director of the company and executive vice president of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, has been elected a vice president of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, it was announced yesterday. This election sets at rest rumors of a misunderstanding between the Associated system and its principal bankers.
DENVER, Cal., May 30. -- "Christ-less" leaders of a "godless" civilization were denounced before the Presbyterian General Assembly here today as responsible for the present condition of the world.

Rose Walsh, 9 years old, of 209-40 112th Avenue, Bellaire, Queens, was killed and two small companions were injured yesterday afternoon when they were struck by an automobile at Springfield Boulevard near 112th Avenue, Bellaire. The three children were crossing the street when they were hit by a car driven by William Southall of East Avenue Valley Stream, L.I.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With much of the criticism of the Congress, especially the Senate, I am in hearty accord; but in order to keep the records straight I set forth the actual record so that my constituents may properly appraise the situation.

PARIS, May 30. -- For the fourth time in less than four months financial experts of the League of Nations and representatives of European government treasuries have met in an effort to help the Danubian States, especially Austria. And once again the atmosphere is one of defeatism and virtual hopelessness of any tangible accomplishments.

A fight on every Congressional candidate opposed to the legalization of beer will be made throughout the country in the Fall election by the newly organized Beer for Prosperity Campaign, Inc., with headquarters at 150 Broadway.
SEATTLE, May 30 (AP). -- Frank Brooks, assistant to Nathan C. Browne, describing their parachute leap from Browne's plane, Lone Star, here today, said:

Surviving members of the class of '82 of Columbia College met last evening to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their graduation at the home of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, himself a member of the class, at 60 Morningside Drive. When graduated the class had fifty-three members, of whom twenty-three are living.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- A practical agreement between President Hoover and Democratic leaders of the Senate to work out the fiscal problems of the nation without, at this time, a general manufacturers' sales tax was understood to have been reached at a White House conference tonight.

SAUNTON, England, May 30. -- The first match play round of the women's British golf championship today resulted in a number of seemingly amazing upsets as far as the American contingent was concerned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Encountering unexpected opposition on the last day of the series, the United States Davis Cup tennis team today made a clean sweep of its North American zone final with Australia by winning the last two singles matches at the Philadelphia Country Club.

HARBIN, Manchuria, May 30. -- Japanese forces struck out north and south of Harbin today to break the encircling movement of irregulars, and bombs dropped by their planes were reported to have set fire to Hailun, 150 miles north of here. [Hailun, a city of 50,000 inhabitants, is the terminus of a railway from Harbin and lies in a narrow valley at the foot of the Little Khingan Mountains.]

Memorial Day brought to the openair art exhibit in Washington Square a throng of visitors large enough to excite the envy of museum statisticians. The combination of a holiday, ideal weather, novelty and the possibility of finding bargains crowded the sidewalks south and west of Washington Square, where hundreds of paintings, drawings and prints were hung by artists hoping to attract buyers.
MEXICO CITY, May 30. -- Two nuns were burned to death in Santa Maria Church in the city of Guadalajara yesterday when the building caught fire from a box of linen.

TARRYTOWN, May 30. -- Cardinal Hayes will preside at the commencement exercises at Marymount College tomorrow at 11 A.M. The address to the graduates will be delivered by former Justice of the Court of General Sessions Alfred J. Talley.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP). -- In a home-run mood, the Philadelphia Athletics scored two victories over the Washington Senators in the holiday bill today.

Mayor Walker, his head high, his smile as cordial as ever, paraded in Yankee Stadium yesterday before a crowd of about 45,000. The concourse of fans at first mingled boos with their cheers, but finally applauded almost unanimously when the Mayor took his turn at the microphone as the climax feature of the ceremonies dedicating a memorial tablet to the late Miller Huggins, manager of all the Yankee teams that ever won championships.
BERLIN, May 30. -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening, who resigned today as Chancellor, leaves a deeper mark on German politics than any of his postwar predecessors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- An attack upon the theory that epilepsy is hereditary was made by Dr. Calvert Stein of Palmer, Mass., in a paper read today before the section of convulsive disorders of the American Psychiatric Association's annual meeting.

With only today remaining in which holders of bonds of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, or Cotton Belt, may deposit their securities in sufficient amount to make the road's refinancing plan operative, there is still lacking nearly 2 per cent of the 90 per cent of bonds required, Walter E. Meyer, a minority director, said last night.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby's bat led the Cubs to a 6-to-2 victory over the Cardinals in the second game of today's doubleheader after the world champions had mistreated their old mate, Burleigh Grimes, to win the opener, 6 to 4.

BUDAPEST, May 30. -- The reduction in the interest rate on her foreign obligations which Hungary is trying to obtain from American an other creditors was one of the topics discussed by Premier Count Julius Karolyi in a talk with Louis Wiley of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- The first farm relief bill ever to be offered frankly by its proponents as a direct subsidy for agriculture is be tag written as rapidly as a subcommittee of the House Agriculture Committee can do it.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The suggestion of Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain, through an interview in The London Daily Mail, for converting the Lausanne conference into one on world trade was complicated today by the fall of the Bruening Cabinet in Germany.

Ideal weather, with balmy temperatures and soft winds, lured hundreds of thousands to the beaches and other resorts in the metropolitan area for the holiday yesterday. When night fell the highways, railways and airways leading to the city were throbbing with life as the vast army of holiday-makers returned home to begin their workaday week today.

A number of special Memorial Day services, including one from Rome, were heard over nation-wide networks yesterday. Tolled in memory of the World War dead, the great bell of the Castle of Rovereto, which was cast from the metal of cannons of nations that engaged in the World War, was heard in this country from coast to coast.

REGINA, Sask., May 30. -- Investigatlon into the possibilities of a stabilized empire currency is the first recommendation in several presented to the Saskatchewan Government by representatives of about a score of organizations who have met from time to time to frame an outline of a Saskatchewan brief for presentation to the Imperial Conference in Ottawa in July.

Relying exclusively on freshman athletes, Manhattan College annexed the team trophy at Ulmer Park yesterday in the seventh annual track and field games of the United Scottish Clans as Coach Pete Water's yearling group compiled seventeen points to gain a leg on the perpetual trophy.

Viewing as a "false evaluation of life" the outlook which identifies success with wealth, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in his thirty-third annual report, made public today in its entirety, stresses character development and citizenship training as "the great, if not the sole aim of the school."

LONDON, May 30. -- In accordance with tradition, owners, trainers and jockeys concerned in the English Derby gave their tips at the Press Club's Derby luncheon today. Lord Riddle, as chairman, replaced the late Edgar Wallace. Opinion was virtually unanimous that the favorite, Orwell, would win at Epsom Wednesday, with Miracle second choice.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- President Hoover, who, according to some Republican leaders, is supervising the writing of points for a Republican platform in the hope of obtaining a compromise prohibition plank satisfactory to moderate drys, today renewed his conference with Senator Borah on this question.

Total contributions of $186,132.55 to the Salvation Army United Appeal were announced yesterday by James C. Blaine, executive chairman, as the campaign entered its third week. More than 3,500 active workers are seeking funds for the Army's emergency relief and institutional welfare work in this city.
BERLIN, May 30. -- Disregarding Parliamentary prerogatives and precedents, President Paul von Hindenburg forced the resignation today of the government of Dr. Heinrich Bruening.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP). -- The Tigers went into second place in the American League by defeating the Browns in both games of a double-header today, taking the first game, 17 to 9, and the second, 4 to 0. The Washington Senators dropped into third place in the league as a result of Detroit's victories.

MONTAUK, L.I., May 30. -- After nearly four hours of racing, tacking and trying to dodge Coast Guard machine-gun fire, the 75-foot speed boat Margaret, powered with three 250-horsepower engines, was beached about 5 o'clock this morning twelve miles west of Montauk on the beach of the State park at Hither Hills.
CRANFORD, N.J., May 31 -- James E. Malone, hull foreman for many years at the old Nixon Shipyard in Elizabeth, died this morning at his home, here.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,169,400 barrels, compared with 2,225,350 in the preceding week, a decrease of 55,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,679,700 barrels daily, against 1,721,850, a decrease of 42,150.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- A controversy more than 100 years old was settled when the Supreme Court decided today that the President can sign bills after Congress has finally adjourned.

Miss Eleanor May Caminade of Highland Falls, N.Y., one of fortyfive nurses who were graduated from the Jersey City Hospital Training School last night at exercises in Lincoln High School, received a scholarship which, provides $700 to be applied in post-graduate training in nursing education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review the sentence of the seven Negroes convicted of attacking two white girls near Scottsboro, Ala. The men were to be executed June 24, but through the consent of the court to hear the case Nov. 10, the execution will now be stayed.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Folllowing is the text of the address made by President Hoover in the Senate today:

A majority of the 600 members of the Actors' Equity Association who attended the nineteenth annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor sustained Frank Gillmore, president, in his refusal to bring before the membership the request of the League of New York Theatres for a referendum vote by Equity on the question of Sunday night performances in Broadway's legitimate playhouses.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Final preparations for the Chicago conventions of both parties next month were definitely in the making here today through the medium of a series of conferences among leaders of each.

LONDON, May 31 -- With his words broadcast to the United States for the first time since his appointment to the Court of St. James's, Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon delivered an address tonight at a dinner given in his honor by the English-Speaking Union.

Generally favorable weather in the cotton belt during the holidays and extreme weakness in security markets depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Buying power was lacking and increased selling pressure caused losses which were 27 to 29 points at the close.

The entrance of the Federal Government into the grain business through the formation of the Federal Farm Board was attacked yesterday by Herbert L. Bodman, president of the New York Produce Exchange, speaking at the Annual meeting of its members.

THE is Derby Day in jolly old England, all the way from Land's End to John o' Groat's. It isn't the oldest horse race in the world, but it has become the most famous. The Derby was first run in 1780. The St. Leger began four years before that. But somehow the St. Leger, the Oaks, the Two Thousand Guineas and other such races are merely brilliant British turf fixtures.

Although the collective agreement between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., which expired yesterday was not renewed, negotiations to avert a strike of 27,000 workers are being continued, it was announced by Samuel Klein, executive director of the council.

PARIS, May 31 -- The British mixed doubles team of Miss Betty Nuthall and Fred Perry won the French championship by crushing the American team of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Sidney B. Wood Jr. in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the final at the Roland Garros Stadium today.
Changes in the layout of buildings on the Fifth Avenue side of Rockefeller Centre, to give an "international character" to this entire frontage, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 1. -- The Senate at 12:25 o'clock this morning passed the $1,115,000,000 tax bill for balancing the Federal budget, by a vote of 72 to 11, thus ending two months of Congressional confusion since the passage of the House revenue measure on April 1.

CLEVELAND, May 31 -- The Memorial Day "battle of the runway" cost four of Chicago's pugnacious White Sox a total of $1,350 in fines, a 10-day suspension for one, and a severe reprimand for George Moriarty, veteran umpire who offered "to fight the whole White Sox team."

Of the two Moscow newspapers familiar to American readers as the organs of the Soviet Government, the stronger words are to be found in the Pravda. This is because it is only the mouthpiece of the Russian Communist party, whereas its sister publication, Izvestia, is that of the Soviet Government.

Larry Fay, former night club operator, who once was widely interested in the city's distribution of loose milk, walked into the Federal Building yesterday, unaccompanied by a lawyer, to surrender under an indictment for his alleged failure to pay entertainment taxes to the government in 1929.

Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, chosen as German Chancellor by President von Hindenburg, was German military attache in the United States during the World War and was expelled from this country on orders of President Wilson, together with the late Captain Karl Boy-Ed, naval attache, for improper activities in military and naval matters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the fading away of the [sic] Noise Abatement Committee, I have no one to whom to tell my decibellic troubles except THE NEW YORK TIMES. But truly, my suffering should melt even an editor's heart; and as I have many companions in my misery, perhaps the editor will be interested.

BUFFALO, May 31 (AP) -- Rallying briskly in the sixth to overcome a deficit of four runs, the Bisons protected their league leadership today with their third straight triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The score was 10 to 8.

One of the largest deals in recent months in the Sixth Avenue section below Twenty-third Street was reported yesterday by Spear Co., brokers, who negotiated the sale of the property at 108-14 West Twenty-second Street, through to 113-15 West Twenty-first Street, for Duparquet, Huot Moneuse, manufacturers of hotel and restaurant fixtures, to the Hershey Chocolate Company.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The appointment of Franz von Papen, former German naval attache here, as Chancellor of Germany was learned in official circles today with even more surprise than was the resignation of Chancellor Bruening yesterday.

PARIS, May 31 (AP) -- The defeat in the mixed doubles final of the French tennis championships today cost Mrs. Helen Wills Moody an opportunity to make a sweep of the three divisions in which she is entered.

Not since October, 1931, had withdrawals of gold been so large for a month as they were in May. Exports through the Port of New York amounted to $215,035,000, against imports totaling $7,490,800, making an export excess of $207,544,200. The movement compared with $10,142,300 received here and $49,489,400 shipped out in April, and with imports of $60,953,000 and only $10,000 exported in May, 1931.

New securities publicly offered here in May consisted entirely of bonds, Canadian, State and municipal loans accounting for the bulk of the month's flotations. The total was $79,028,000, the second smallest sum for a month this year. It compared with $130,299,000 in April, when bonds aggregating $129,549,000 and stocks $750,000 were marketed, and with $382.120.000 for May, 1931, $335,145,000 of which was in bonds and $56.975,000 in stocks.

What is hailed as a rift of most cheering augury in the clouds of foreclosures and receiverships that for so long have darkened with ever-deepening gloom the real estate situation in this city appeared yesterday.

Fifteen European steel mill operators and managers arrived yesterday on the French, liner Ile de France to study American steel production methods. A.T. Kathner, consulting engineer, of Paris, headed the visitors who will inspect industrial plants in Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Youngstown.

The hope of music today lies in the successful teaching of it to children in kindergarten, primary and secondary schools throughout the country, Dr. John Erskine, head of the Juilliard Foundation of Music, asserted yesterday afternoon in an address before more than 1,000 members of the Barnard College Alumnae Association at its annual commencement reunion in the Brinckerhoff Theatre, Broadway and 120th Street.

Dyed Gasoline for Finical Drivers. To read Drs. TRUESDELL, EGLOFF and MORELL, research chemists, in World Petroleum, is to confirm the conclusion that man is beyond understanding -- particularly if he drives a car.

With the order to close forested areas in New York rescinded over the week-end; thousands of fresh water anglers enjoyed the holidays in their own particular style and came home with partially filled creels. There was much satisfaction in being out in the streams again, even though baskets might not have held the limit.

Sharp declined yesterday in most of the active bond issues on the Stock Exchange forced a long list to the lowest levels since issuance. As trading was nearly $2,000,000 under Friday's total, it Was not dumping of securities for what they would bring, but lack of bids that caused many issues to fall a point or more between sales.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The text of the Connally income tax amendment to the revenue bill, which was adopted by the Senate today, 86 to 3, and which, by increasing the rates previously voted by the Senate, is expected to raise $70,000,000 of the additional revenue needed, follows:

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- When Mrs Marie Ahnighito Peary Stafford, the "Snow Baby" daughter of the late Admiral Robert E. Peary, sails next month for the Arctic Circle, where her explorer parents sought for the North Pole and where she herself was born, she will take with her for the ceremony at the monument to be erected to her father by the Peary Memorial Expedition the flag of the Society of Women Geographers.

The principal obstacle in the way of putting to work the funds made available by the credit expansion program of the Federal Reserve Banks is fear, says the current bulletin of the National City Bank. To a large extent, the bank continues, this fear is the outcome of delay in this country and in others in dealing with problems which have passed beyond the control of business men and have become governmental problems.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- Heinie Manush's bat broke up a long ball game today and grave Washington a 5-to-4 decision over the Athletics after twelve innings of exciting baseball.

Almost every week some malicious rumor attributing instability within the Lone Star State itself with reference to Speaker GARNER'S boom has to be denied, although it needs no denial. The Democratic loyalty of Texas to this illustrious citizen rests, as The Texas Weekly says, upon his demonstrated "ability to "lead in the interest of his party "and his country."

A telephone company employe who rescued a deep-sea diver from drowning is one of the two silver medal winners of the Vail awards, which are given each year to members of the Bell company's roster for acts of public service. The other was given to an employe who prevented a hold-up and aided in the capture of the robber, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a $3,805,222 loan to the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation brought from Commissioner Mahaffie today the first through-going dissent from a decision of that body.

Greatly encouraged by the action of the Senate Finance Committee yesterday in approving additional taxes sufficient to balance the budget, the Young committee of bankers and industrialists resumed its consideration of financial measures to help to make effective the credit-expansion program of the Federal Reserve.

BERLIN, May 31. -- President Paul von Hindenburg tonight commissioned Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, former military attache at Washington and an influential member of the conservative wing of the Centrist party, to form a "national concentration" Cabinet.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 31. -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club went into commission yesterday at noon. The fleet assembled about the harbor and on signal of one gun from the clubhouse grounds dressed ship and the flag on the clubhouse was mastheaded.

James Simpson, chairman of the boaid of Marshall Field Co. of Chicago, returned yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic from a three-months hunting trip during which he visited Egypt, East Africa and India.

Eighty-six athletic insignia will be awarded to Columbia students for participation in varsity and freshman athletics this past year and to managers and managerial candidates, it was announced yesterday by Athletics Manager Reynolds Benson.

Not by any means are bargains in art restricted, at the moment, to the sidewalks of Washington Square, where the open-air market permits New Yorkers a vicarious stroll along the Rive Gauche boulevards of Paris. There are some notable bargains as well in two of the galleries, the Macbeth and the Downtown, where groups of paintings carry the uniform price of $100..

Retirement of bonds in May before their maturity dates continued at about the same level of activity as in April, both months showing sharp declines from a year ago. The total was $15,904,000 in May, compared with 515.427,000 in April and $102,790,000 in May, 1931.

No changes occurred last month in the interest rates for call loans on either of the two local stock exchanges, 2 1/2 per cent for funds on the New York Stock Exchange and 3 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange prevailing throughout May. These rates have not changed since Jan. 7.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Lonnie Warneke and the Cubs subdued the Cardinals and Jess Haines, 3 to 1, today, to take the edge in the series and retain their two-and-one-half-game margin over the Boston Braves for first place in the National League.

In that little possession of France known as St. Pierre et Miquelon, whence untold quantities of wines and liquor have been transported for illegal consumption, the inhabitants are so poor that they drink tea instead of wine, according to Henri Camille Sautot, Acting Governor of the islands in the North Atlantic.

SHANGHAI, May 31 -- More than 2,000 Communists were slain in the vicinity of Tsaoshih, sixty miles northwest of Hankow, in a battle on Friday and Saturday in which the Nanking Government's Forty-eighth Division won an important victory, capturing Tsaoshih, Tienmen and Hanchwan.

The Brazilian Davis Cup team, composed of six players headed by Ricardo Pernambuco, is scheduled to reach New York today. The team will meet the United States in the North American-South American interzone match.

Corporations whose accounting methods are not under State or Federal supervision and whose securities are traded by the public should amend their by-laws to permit their stockholders to select independent certified public accountants, according to a report to be made at the regular monthly meeting tomorrow of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

SAUNTON, England, May 31 -- If only this weather we are having over here will take a turn for the better, America will still have a good chance of coming through to victory in the women's British golf championship.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31. -- A bill urging a block-aid campaign throughout New Jersey to provide funds for unemployment relief was Introduced in the Senate tonight by Senator Dryden Kuser Republican, of Somerset County. Urging the formation of a block community organization on a plan similar to the block-aid campaign of New York City, the bill pointed out that the proposal had demonstrated its worth in actual operation.

Sharp price declines were recorded in commodity markets yesterday. Grains dropped a fraction to 2 cents, and cotton on an average $1.40 per bale. Losses were also reported in sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk. Coffee moved against the trend and was higher. In the spot marekts, rye, butter and cotton reached new lows for the year.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 31.-- Any rights of citizenship Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie may have lost in his native State of Kentucky by his conviction in the Honolulu honor slaying were restored in an executive order from Governor Ruby Laffoon today.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- An international conference in London to consider stabilizing world commodity prices appeared assured today when Secretary of State Stimson, after a conference with President Hoover, announced the United States had replied favorably to an inquiry from the British Government as to its attitude toward such a project.
SAUNTON, England, May 31 -- Mrs. Leona Cheney of California alone among the United States challengers survived today's battles to enter the last eight in the women's British open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 1. -- An omnibus economy bill, calculated to save more than $238,605,000, was reported favorably to the Senate by the Appropriations Committee at midnight and will be brought up for consideration today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 31. -- Two men, described by the police as aides to a beer runner, were riddled with bullets fired from a passing car as they were about to drive into the entrance to a home at 1 Hudson Park Road at about 3 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, May 31 -- Despite the German Governmental upset, French reluctance and the British Prime Minister's desire for some different sort of gathering, there is every indication tonight that the Lausanne conference of European nations to deal with debts and reparations will be held as scheduled on June 16.

OMAHA, May 31 (AP) -- Unofficial estimates by race officials of the distances traveled by the balloon Goodyear VII was set at approximately 750 air miles from Omaha. This is the longest flight yet reported by any of the race contestants.

BELMAR, N.J., May 31. -- Returning from a visit to the seashore, four young persons were killed and two were seriously injured early today when a southbound Central Railroad of New Jersey train struck their automobile at the Sixteenth Avenue grade crossing here.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The President's sudden decision to address the Senate this noon on "the emergency that has developed in the last few days" was dramatic. So was the moment of his appearance in the chamber. But the period of the address was not dramatic at all.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse, the former as president of the Old State House Commission, who superintended the restoration of the historic building, entertained at luncheon today at Stone Villa, in honor of Governor Norman S. Case and Judge Ira Lloyd Letts of the United States Court who were speakers at the subsequent exercises of the reopening of the old building.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., May 31 (AP) -- Hillsborough, owned by A. Bartelstein of Chicago, won the feature race today and established a new Washington Park track record, running the seven furlongs in 1:24, which lowers the former time by one-fifth of a second.

Controversy over Speaker GARNER'S bill for a vast program of public works, described by its author as essential to recovery and by the President as a "gigantic pork barrel," has led to talk in Congress of a compromise on the alternative plan proposed by Senator WAGNER.

The business men of Union Square were urged yesterday to assist in the beautifying of their park by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of the city, who addressed the members of the Union Square committee of the Broadway Association at a luncheon in the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

The dollar recovered strongly yesterday from its extreme weakness at the close of last week, hut the continued tendency of funds to escape from this market was indicated by a spread of 4 1/2 cents between spot rates on sterling exchange and the price of three-months sterling futures.

Adverse actions on dividends predominated throughout May, reductions and omissions of payments to shareholders showing no sign of decreasing. In some instances where payments had been deferred from previous months in the hope that business conditions would warrant the making of them last month, company directors voted to omit them entirely.

A few minutes after the Roosevelt freighter Unicoi tied up at her West Sixteenth Street pier early yesterday morning the ordinarily prosaic and business-like pier began to ring with a bedlam of jungle sounds.

The true value of a college education cannot be measured by examinations or certificates, but must be judged by the actions of the student in after life, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon in an address to 322 members of the senior class of Columbia College in the annual Class Day exercises, held in the Van Amringe Quadrangle.

ALBANY, May 31. -- Assured of control of the machinery of the Democratic National Convention, Governor Roosevelt discussed the organization of the convention today with Archibald McNeil, national committeeman from Connecticut.

The Marquis and Marquise de Chambrun will sail today for France on the Cunarder Mauretania. They have been visiting relatives of the Marquise, who is an American. Others sailing on the ship for Cherbourg and Southampton are Sir Edward Denham, Beniamino Gigli, operatic tenor; Mme. D. Giannini, soprano concert singer; Captain and Mrs. D.C. Hanrahan, Colonel Francis L. Roberts, Cornelia Otis Skinner, actress, and Nigel Bruce, actor.

Holiday Cut Buyers' Total. Due to the holiday during the past week the number of buyers registered in the market showed a large decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total was also well behind the number listed for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP). -- Reorganization plans have been effected for twenty-four bond issues underwritten by S.W. Straus Co., amounting originally to $32,045,000, it was announced today. S.J.T. Straus, chairman, of the board, said reorganization schemes for at least ten more issues for $16,175,000 would be submitted to bondholders within two months.
DUBLIN, May 31 (Canadian Press). -- The Dail Eireann is speeding up business to permit the Free State delegation to go to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa.
LONDON, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Hampshire defeated Northamptonshire by 15 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluding today.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 31 (AP) -- The sun set in a blaze of many hued colors over the fast drying Epsom Downs tonight, where tomorrow twenty-one crack English 3-year-olds will attempt to check the championship bid of the favorite, W.M.G. Singer's Orwell, in the 153d running of the English Derby.

Vincent Albano's home-made burglar alarm had its first work-out yesterday, with, good results. At 5:50 A.M. Albano was waiting on six customers in his restaurant at 115 Thompson Street, on the edge of Greenwich Village, when three men walked in, covered Albano and the patrons with revolvers and took $20 from the cash register.

It is Hawthorne Hurst's whim to conceive of Columbus as a professional palace philanderer in "Christopher Comes Across," which was acted at the Royale last evening. Brock Pemberton has given his author tie encouragement of a mettlesome troupe of actors, brilliant costumes and medieval settings of solid charm by Dale Stetson.

BUENOS AIRES, May 31. -- Speaking today at the luncheon of the British Chamber of Commerce the Duke of Atholl and others criticized the control of foreign exchange by the government as excessive. The Duke said foreign concerns here were unable to send interest or earnings abroad at need and therefore it was illogical to expect that new money would come here while the regulations were enforced.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 31. -- Arthur Garfield Hays, national director of the American Civil Liberties Union, told the Highland Manor School and junior parish graduates tonight that his generation had "made a mess of things politically, economically and socially" and yet presumed to advise and counsel the young.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 31. - -W.M.G. Singer's big bay colt Orwell is an overwhelming favorite to win the Derby which will be run at Epsom Downs tomorrow before the King and Queen and other members of the royal family and a million British subjects.

Records that Patrick McGovern, building contractor, had removed to Massachusetts to defeat Samuel Seabury in his investigation of large payments made to him by Patrick McGovern, Inc., and charged to cash, are in the possession of the Federal Government, which is conducting a John Doe investigation under the income tax law, Federal Attorney George Z. Medalie said yesterday.

LONDON, May 31. -- Mayfair society was stirred today by the fatal shooting of Michael Scott Stephen, son of a London banker, after a gay cocktail party in the apartment of Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, beautiful golden-haired divorcee and daughter of a knight, whose former husband is John Sterling Barney, an American singer.

Jules Sauerwein, former foreign editor of Le Matin in Paris and now of the Paris-Soir, arrived, on the French liner Ile de France yesterday to study conditions in the United States, where, he said, immediate developments, politically and economically, are of "tremendous importance to the future of the world."

REGINA, Sask., May 31 (AP) -- Strong prairie winds swept the balloons of the United States National Air Race into Saskatchewan today, one landing at Tyvan and another carrying on communication with farmers near Woodrow and Gull Lake.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- With whistles screaming, bells ringing and children's voices raised in song, Chicago will send forth its pledge tomorrow that the Century of Progress Exposition will open June 1. 1933.

BERLIN, May 31. -- Fear of inflation characterized today's session of the Boerse, as indicated by a typical rise in stocks and weakness in bonds. The broad advances in stocks of 4 to 6 per cent were reminiscent of the best pre-depreasion days. Foreign orders as well as the reappearance of the public in the market precipitated the sharp rise.
CHICAGO, May 31. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here were on the downgrade from the opening today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 31 -- The New York Yankees came to West Point today for their annual baseball game with the Army nine. The big leaguers won, 9 to 3.

HAVANA, May 31. -- Bombs exploded this afternoon almost simultaneously in three of Havana's most prominent schools. Some property damage was reported, but no personal injuries, although the schools were crowded with children.

PARIS, May 31. -- The trend of prices was higher on the Bourse today. The month-end liquidations were carried out under favorable conditions and were followed by a buying movement. Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch and several electrical stocks were the only exceptions to the general upward movement in quotations.

DENVER, Col., May 31 -- Proposals for reorganization of the general council of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America were decisively defeated at the general assembly of the denomination here today, and a counter-attack ended in a vote of confidence and appreciation for the general council.

Occasionally the atmosphere of the laboratory becomes so rarefied in the pursuit of the abstract that it loses much of its relation to reality. Not so with the work of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, conducted at Langley Field, Virginia, which has become the world's leading testing-ground for aircraft.

BUCHAREST, May 31. -- The entire Rumanian Cabinet, headed by Dr. Nicholas Jorga, resigned tonight on the heels of yesterday's denial that Finance Minister Argetoianu would withdraw. An urgent message was sent to Dr. Nicholas Titulescue, Ambassador at London, to return from Geneva.
Jersey City turned back the invasion of the Newark Bears yesterday at West Side Park, winning by 3 to 1 and moving from seventh into sixth place as a result of the triumph.

When bids were opened yesterday for operation of the new city subway under Eighth Avenue, Chairman DELANEY of the Board of Transportation found more prizes than he had expected in the box. It contained four offers, variously de- scribed as "formal bids," "informal bids" and "informal proposals."

An average of $709 a. lot was Realized at the sale of Long Beach properties conducted last Saturday and Monday by Joseph P. Day. Altogether 194 lots were sold for a total of $137,589, Mr. Day reported. The auction, to liquidate the holdings of Long Beach on the Ocean, Inc., will be continued next Saturday.

Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of City Court, who was cleared recently of charges brought by Samuel Sea bury, who demanded his removal by the court's board of justices, was made a defendant yesterday in a bankruptcy action filed by Max Rockmore, as attorney for three creditors.

Marshall Field's colors were borne to victory in the Colin Purse, feature at Belmont Park yesterday, when his Villon, a son of Stimulus and Heloise, led from start to finish of the mile and a furlong test to score by a length and a half. The veteran Pony McAtee was in the saddle and he did an excellent job in getting the colt home in front at 6 to 5.

LONDON, May 31. -- The stock markets were irregular today. British Government funds continued to receive support, with more foreign buying in progress, but the general tendency was dull. Industrials again were subjected to forced liquidation. One of the few bright spots were German issues, which recovered sharply.
