Complete fields in all events were announced yesterday by Paul Pilgrim for the 128th track and field games of the New York A.C., to be staged at Travers Island on Saturday. Four world's record-holders -- Gene Venzke, Leo Sexton, George Spitz and Percy Beard -- head the list of entrants.

Columbia's rowing squad will leave this morning for its headquarters on Krum Elbow, two miles above Poughkeepsie, to start intensive preparations for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Regatta on the upper Hudson on June 20.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 31 (AP). -- Rochester won the third game of the series from Montreal today, 9 to 3, driving out sixteen hits off the slants of four Royal hurlers. Charley Wilson got four safe drives, a homer, a double and two singles.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The State Department today denied a report from La Paz that the negotiations for a pact of non-aggression in the Chaco would be moved from here to Buenos Aires.

PARIS, May 31 (AP) -- Edouard Herriot, the probable Premier-designate of France, declared tonight the dominant program for him was one that permitted "political relaxation and economic understanding abroad."

President Hoover alone kept the United States from abandoning: the gold standard when Great Britain took that drastic method of meeting the depression early this year, according to Herbert Corey in his book, "The Truth About Hoover." The book, published by the Houghton Mifflin Company, will be out today.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31. -- For the first time since the passage of the prohibition laws the New Jersey Republican party adopted a plank advocating repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the repeal of the State prohibition enforcement act at final sessions of the State convention held here today.

After five weeks in Paris inspecting construction work on the new American Embassy, of which his firm is the general contractor, John W. Harris of the Hegeman-Harris Company returned to New York yesterday on the Ile de France. While abroad Mr. Harris also attended a general conference of builders representing European countries.

Apparently unruffled by his experience as a witness before the Hofstadter legislative committee investigating city affairs, Mayor Walker left New York from Grand Central Terminal for Detroit at 7:30 P.M. yesterday to attend a conference of Mayors on unemployment relief.

Ernest Gutman, 28-year-old sculptor, received ten days' grace to pay the rent on his studio at 101 West Third Street when, he was haled into the First District Municipal Court, 146 Grand Street, yesterday by his landlord, Albert Strunsky.

Courtland H. Young, head of the C.H. Young Publishing Company, who died on Dec. 3, 1930, from suffocation in a fire in his apartment at 110 West Fifty-fifth Street, left an estate of $1,338,713 gross, reduced by debts and expenses to $681,390 net, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

A stock market which seemed to Wall Street to be wholly under the influence of reactionary forces continued yesterday its search for an absolute low-price level. Almost all groups on the Stock Exchange were under severe pressure at various times.

Dick Shikat, 217, of Philadelphia, former world's champion, threw Fritz Kley, 212, of Germany with a crotch and arm hold in 30:47 of the interesting feature finish wrestling match at the Coliseum last night before a crowd of 4,000.

Financial circles here expect prompt payment of interest due today on the German Government international loan 5 1/2 per cent bonds of 1930, due on June 1, 1965, and on the score of other German corporation, bank and municipal loans, either today or on June 15, although most of them are quoted at "default prices" on the New York Stock Exchange.

Curtailment of ferry service between Whitehall Street, Manhattan, vand St. George, S.I., which, was to have taken effect tonight, has been postponed indefinitely at the request of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce and other Richmond civic organizations.

The transient democracy of today, "with no authority above it, without religious, political or moral convictions to control its opinions, without coherence and purpose," cannot last long and must inevitably give way to "some more settled social order," Walter Lippmann, editor and author, said yesterday in the annual Phi Beta Kappa oration in the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University.

The Wiener Bank-Verein of Vienna has canceled 550,000 shares of its capital stock, which it held, and has made arrangements for the sale of 23,000,000 schillings par value of new shares to its large stockholders, according to a cable dispatch yesterday to Rudolf Hahn, its representative here.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Persistent "runs" on the American dollar, quoted at a discount in foreign markets despite the enormous wealth of the United States, should be checked by enactment of tax legislation balancing the budget, in the view of Treasury officials.

S.R. Guggenheim resigned yesterday as treasurer of the Public Schools Athletic League and William W. Cohen was elected as his successor at a meeting of the league's board of directors held in the chambers of Surrogate George A. Wingate in the Brooklyn Hall of Records.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- The Murphy Oil Company of New York won a review today by the Supreme Court of the decision of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals sustaining the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in proposing a deficiency in income and excess profits taxes of the company of $394,400 for 1919 and 1920.

Averting a receivership by a margin of six hours, the management of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway announced yesterday that sufficient consolidated 4 per cent bonds had been received to make operative a plan for their refinancing.
The person who wrote the ransom note which Colonel Lindbergh found in the nursery of his baby on the night of the kidnapping three months ago used a disguised handwriting, the police believe.

LONDON, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- With government, coal owners and coal miners' representatives making last-minute endeavors to obtain some measure of agreement on the questions of wages and working hours, the executive of the Miners Federation will meet tomorrow to discuss whether to accept the government's coal mines bill or to call for a national stoppage of mining.

Abandoning after twelve years its private efforts to provide retirement annuities and death benefits for employes, the Vacuum Oil Company has placed the whole program in the hands of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, completing the outstanding group annuity retirement transaction of the year so far.

WASHINGTON, Pa., May 31 (AP). -- The tSate Theatre, a motion-picture house, was destroyed by fire of unknown origin early today. The damage was estimated by M. M. Wear, the manager, at $200,000. The flames were discovered when they broke through the roof at 1 A. M. and firemen of Washington and Connellsville, in a fight of several hours, failed to save the building.

BOSTON, May 31 -- The long-awaited uplift movement of the Giants, which appeared to have received such excellent impetus with yesterday's double victory, came to a full stop today, when the McGrawmen became impaled upon the stout left arm of Dutch Brandt.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the smallest of any month since October, 1924. Sales for May, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 23,151,047 shares, compared with 31,402,988 shares in April, and 46,663,292 shares in May a year ago.

The Superintendent of Schools did welt to give out his report this year piecemeal. This has made it possible for the press and the public to fix separate attention upon each of the outstanding features of the year's work, and to become better acquainted with the educational methods and objectives of the system.

Emergency relief funds of the Salvation Army are so low that the family welfare department, for the first time in its history, is unable to respond immediately to new applications for assistance, according to Brigadier Thomas Seaver, head of the welfare department.

In the address which the President made in person to the Senate yesterday there was undeniably a note of serious warning, yet the effect of the whole was not alarmist. Mr. HOOVER was but doing his duty in laying the entire case before Congress and the country.

COLUMBUS, May 31 (AP) -- John C. Cromwell, 65 years old, former president of the Cromwell Steel Company of Lorain, Ohio, died today at the home of his nephew, Cromwell Denton, at Alton, near here. Death was due to cancer.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31. -- The overwhelming anti-prohibition sentiment of ten representative Eastern colleges and universities was revealed today with the announcement of the results of a poll conducted by The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper of Princeton University.
CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP) -- Peace reigned over the Cleveland ball park today, in contrast to the Memorial Day hostility, as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Indians, 6 to 5.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Four New York banks will take further steps to obtain legal sanction for the sale of collateral they hold for loans to the two Insull investment trusts, according to indications today, after the Federal court's refusal to dissolve the injunction holding up the sale.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Somehow one cannot but feel that, if readers could only come with visitors from our social agencies and see the pasty, listless faces of the children in homes of men long out of work, the problem of finding a way to send them to the country for a fresh-air outing would be solved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE TIMES a correspondent, referring to the back-to-the-land suggestions made by Henry Ford, commented unfavorably on the scheme. It appears to me that quite a few people view this program from a wrong angle.

A new issue of $30,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks will be placed on the market today by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent. It will represent the first financing by the system since the Federal Reserve Bank act was amended to make the debentures eligible collateral for fifteen-day loans by member banks at the Federal Reserve Bank.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 31 -- Cardinal Hayes presided at the Marymount College commencement exercises here today, at which Alfred J. Talley, former justice of the Court of General Sessions, was the speaker.

MADISON, N.J., May 31. -- Marked by the conferring: of the first degrees to graduates of Brothers College and the College of Religious Education, the annual commencement of Drew University was held on the campus in the rear of Mead Hall this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- Clinical studies made on living sufferers from dementia praecox, showing that in every case examined the patient's brain structure had undergone atrophy to a greater or lesser degree, were reported today to the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

Samuel Seabury made a new effort yesterday to demonstrate to the Hofstadter committee that the missing Russell T. Sherwood, whose financial transactions amounted to $961,225.52 in five and a half years, was Mayor Walker's proxy in Wall Street.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 31 -- Three of the four seeded players advanced to the semi-final round of the junior girls' annual New Jersey district tennis championship tournament on the opening day of play today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Terms of the contract under which Emil Lederer, resident director of the Hamburg-American Line, will assume the duties of a virtual dictator of transatlantic travel have been forwarded to the offices of the ship lines that will come under his direction and have been accepted by most of them.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- Picked leaders of the "bonus expeditionary force" began a lobbying drive in Congress today, while their 600 or more roughly clad comrades entrenched themselves to await the arrival of more former soldiers demanding immediate cash payment of the bonus.

United States Attorney George Z. Medalie, addressing a group of motion-picture executives at the Motion Picture Club Forum, 1,560 Broadway, yesterday, said the facts about crime and criminals were too humdrum for popular consumption and would make dull copy for the reading and film-going public.

Henry Ford is urging branch managers and Ford dealers everywhere to study his suggestion of self-help by way of farming, he announces in the second of a series of paid advertisements, published today.

Henry Ford is urging branch managers and Ford dealers everywhere to study his suggestion of self-help by way of farming, he announces in the second of a series of paid advertisements, published today.

Fred S. Burroughs, new vice president of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, will be principally occupied, in company with H.C. Hopson, vice president and treasurer, and William Buchsbaum, vice president, in the financial department of the company.

Four proposals for private operation of the new city subway system under a contract and lease were received yesterday by the Board of Transportation. Only one of them was a formal bid under the contract draft prepared by the board. It was indicated that none of the proposals were considered satisfactory, and that the Board of Estimate would be so informed in a report to be placed in its hands on Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The tax bill, whose revenue features were completed in the Senate tonight, carried as its main structure a substantial increase in income taxes and in postage rates, supplemented by a group of miscellaneous taxes and special excises and administrative changes intended largely to plug up possible leaks in the present taxing system.

Department stores having annual sales of $10,000,000 or more made the best showing during 1931, according to the report on operating results of department stores and specialty shops in 1931, published yesterday by the bureau of business research of Harvard University.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- A. Melville Dollar, eldest son of the late Captain Robert Dollar, shipping magnate, was found dead of a heart attack today in a garage at his home in Vancouver, B.C.

The haste of Ivar Kreuger in floating a new issue of 30,000,000 kronor of Kreuger Toll securities in Holland in 1929 aroused the suspicions of Mahler's Bank in Amsterdam and resulted in the severance of relations between the Swedish match king and the banking firm, according to an article printed in Nya Dagligt Allehanda of Stockholm on May 7.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 31 -- Bolivia will not sign in its present form the Chaco non-aggression pact drafted by the commission of neutrals in Washington, in the opinion of leading members of the government, through whose hands it must pass before ratification.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 31 -- Bryn Mawr College will hold its commencement tomorrow morning in Goodhart Hall when Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, will deliver the address. President Park will confer the degree of Bachelor of Arts upon ninety-four candidates, the Master of Arts upon twenty-one and the Doctor of Philosophy upon nine.

Broadway and the theatrical profession paid tribute to Selena Boyle with loud applause and not a few tears last night when her "brain child," the Actors' Dinner Club, reopened in new and larger quarters under Loew's State Theatre at 165 West Forty-fifth Street.

At a meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers yesterday William F. Parish, former chief of the lubricating department of the Army Air Service, and Leon Cammen, consulting' engineer, described discoveries which they have made in lubrication and which promise to have revolutionary effects on the design of machines.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The terms of the quota arrangement reached by Ambassador Edge with the French Government were a source of gratification here today, as it was felt the agreement not only improved the situation but laid the basis for a later and more permanent settlement, possibly to be incorporated in a commercial treaty, negotiations for which have been conducted intermittently for years.

Stocks of gasoline at refineries representing 95.1 per cent of the total refining capacity of the country amounted to 44,337,000 barrels on May 28, compared with 44,703,000 on May 21, a decrease of 366,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

What is the Republican National Convention going to say about prohibition? Divers Senators have contributed their sketches of the proper "plank " on the subject to Mr. JAMES R. GARFIELD, that distinguished Ohio early Progressive, who is or was a Dry, but may have been chastened by the suspension of Republican dividends in votes in his State.

LONDON, Thursday, June 2 (AP). -- The final volume of Queen Victoria's letters, covering the last five years of her life, was published here today, disclosing that she once wrote "it wouldn't do" to give former Kaiser Wilhelm "a good snub."

DUBLIN, June 1 (Canadian Press). -- Division on adjournment of debate until tomorrow on President Eamon de Valera's bill abolishing the Parliamentary oath of allegiance to the British Crown tonight showed the j Opposition in the Senate nine votes stronger than supporters of the government.
"Blue Monday," a play by Benson Inge, will open tonight at the Provincetown Theatre in Macdougal Street.

A $2 annual basis for capital stock of the Chase National Bank was established yesterday, when the directors voted to pay a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share. For the first quarter of the year the bank paid 75 cents a share. Before that the stock had been on a $4 annual basis.

All former records for tax collections in a single day were broken on Tuesday when $74,381,144,04 was paid into the city treasury, Controller Charles W. Berry disclosed yesterday. The previous high mark, established on May 31, 1931, was $74,023,384,77.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The tax bill which the Senate passed early this morning in a burst of speed was sent to conference at noon today.

Selling pressure on the Stock Exchange in May, embracing all classes of issues, and uninterrupted except for a slight upturn In the first week, sent shares to new low levels for the bear market. Trading activity increased at the month-end, when the lows were made, although transactions in May were smaller than in April.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Going into the last month of the 1932 fiscal year today, the government showed an excess of expenditures over receipts amounting to about $2,690,000,000.

In accordance with arrangements announced at the annual meeting of the Bank for International Settlements on May 10, the unissued part of that institution's capital stock, amounting to 26,400 shares, was taken up on Tuesday by the seven banking institutions or groups that founded the world bank.

Brains, vision and service, the three essential gifts of a liberal arts college, are needed today if the country is to be lifted from the "slough of depression in which it now lies," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College asserted yesterday afternoon in an address to the 220 members of Barnard's graduating class at the annual class day exercises, held in the college gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- It is now reasonably clear that when President Hoover suddenly went gunning in the Senate chamber yesterday either he shot at a bird which he knew was already dead or he brought down a bird at which he did not aim.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- H.O. Hamilton, a New York architect, accepted the invitation of the government today to remain here after revising his design for the projected Palace of the Soviets to draft preliminary plans for a series of large hotels in the principal cities of Russia.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a speech broadcast recently a prominent politician made use of the expression "Mugwump tactics."

St. Luke's Hospital has extended is real estate holdings on Morningside Heights by the purchase of two apartment houses in the block to the north of its main buildings, it was announced yesterday by L.J. Philips Co., brokers, who handled the deal.

PARIS, June 1. -- The trend of prices was higher on the Bourse today. Confident belief that both the French and German internal political situations were being settled to the satisfaction of the electorate, as well as steps taken by the United States Congress to balance the budget, contributed strongly to the feeling of optimism here.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 1. -- A home course representative, Miss Josephine Merrill, gained a two-stroke lead for the first eighteen holes of the women's New Jersey Golf Association championship, which started today at the Montclair Golf Club.

DENVER, June 1 (AP). -- The harmony of the closing session of the 144th general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America was momentarily disturbed today when the Rev. Irving W. Underhill, a Negro missionary who has been serving in West Africa, Objected to Fort Worth, Texas, as the 1933 meeting place.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Prohibition was the subject of three important White House conferences today, and tonight there Is reason for the statement that a tentative agreement has been reached as to the form the prohibition plank will take in the Republican platform to be adopted at the Chicago convention.

Steady Call for Sales Goods. Steady absorption of special lots of merchandise for retail sales events this month was reported yesterday in the wholesale markets here. Ready-to-wear, silks and other yard goods, shoes, gloves, luggage, handbags and underwear were said to be outstanding in the goods sought.

BALTIMORE, June 1. -- Four Negro athletes have been debarred, through a standing rule of Johns Hopkins University, from competition in the Olympic track and field trials of the South Atlantic Association at Homewood Saturday.
LONDON, June 1. -- A crowd of 4,000 sat enthralled in the darkness of a London movie theatre today watching the Derby by television.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once upon a time there was a man named Johnnie Hunt. He lived in Rapid City, S.D., and was himself rapid. His skill as a bronco buster was built up step by step until his reputation became far-flung. He figured in the leading Western rodeos and tamed many a bucking bronco.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 1. -- Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, in addressing today the largest class ever to be graduated from Bryn Mawr College, advocated a program of relief construction with a thirty-hour week, the financing of industrial projects by the Federal Government "if necessary" and the adoption of unemployment benefits by industry generally.

DETROIT, June 1. -- Viewing the national depression as a "war situation" demanding immediate marshaling of the nation's resources against poverty and hunger, twenty-eight American Mayors of American cities passed resolutions here today calling upon Congress for a $5,000,000,000 loan to build public works, mobilization of a "work army" and authorization for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to advance credits to cities during the distress.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- American adherence to the World Court, but with a qualification that in effect reiterates the original Fifth Reservation, was recommended to the Senate today in a report from the Foreign Relations Committee, written by Senators Walsh of Montana and Fess.

MANILA, June 1. -- A sharp attack on some features of the Hawes-Cutting bill for Philippine independence, culminating in a protest to President Hoover and a prediction of revolution in the islands because of the "insincerity" of some Filipino leaders on the question, was made at a meeting today of the Independent Citizens' Federation.

When news came of the fall of the Bruening Government an anxious world asked first of all whether it meant the triumph of HITLER and a crisis of the first magnitude in Europe. Cooler judgment argued that this was not necessarily the case.

MEXICO CITY, June 1. -- A general strike that would paralyze railroad traffic along the entire west coast of Mexico is contemplated in the near future by employes of the Southern Pacific. The situation is regarded as so grave that Primo Villa Michel, Under-Secretary of the Industry and Commerce Department, said today he would intervene in an effort to avert such action.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Strong support for the Wagner unemployment relief bill was shown before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today after Senator Wagner had spent two hours explaining his $2,300,000 measure.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- An income and profits tax credit of $2,421,873 in favor of the United States Rubber Company for the years 1919 and 1920 was announced today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.
To the Editor of The New York Times : May I answer the letter of Raymond V. McNally, in which he takes Governor Roosevelt to task for committing an "economic error" in his Georgia speech? I quote:
LONDON, June 1. -- Waterloo Bridge, whose graceful arches have spanned the Thames for a century, was saved from destruction tonight after a dramatic non-party debate in the House of Commons.

Since the Autumn of 1929 the volume of foreign short-term funds in the New York money market has been reduced by about two-thirds, says the current monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in discussing the outflow of gold.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1 (AP). -- Ohio will give no more transportation to bonus marchers, as it did in conveying some 300 across the State after they had entered Ohio from Indiana.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- An agreement among the Cosulich, Fabre and Greek Lines for the purpose of coordinating intineraries, fares and commissions and apportionment of passenger traffic between Greece and North Atlantic ports was approved today by the Shipping Board.

The ninth annual Founders' Exhibition opened yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries for the Summer. Forty-seven paintings are listed in the illustrated catalogue and these have been hung in two of the large rooms. On Oct. 20 the annual drawing will take place, at which time each contributing lay member of the galleries will receive one painting provided by an artist member.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 1. -- The Springfield College nine defeated Wesleyan today, 14 to 2. Wesleyan went to pieces in the fourth inning and three pitchers were sent in to stem the tide, but all were wild and were hit freely.

Action that is likely to precipitate a crisis in the building trades in a few days was taken yesterday by the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association, which authorized builders to resume operations in defiance of a group of unions which have refused to abide by the collective agreement signed May 17 by spokesmen of the Building Trades Council, the employes' association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Associated Press item which you published about the conflicting dates ascribed to the construction of Independence Hall, with its reference to the hanging of the Liberty Bell in the tower upon its completion, is calculated to envelop the history of the bell in needless confusion.

Polo on Long Island swings into full stride this week-end with games at Meadow Brook Saturday, the first contest of the season at the Sands Point Club in Port Washington Sunday and the announcement from Meadow Brook of the make-up of the teams for the annual Spring tournaments for the Meadow Brook Cup, the Third Westbury Challenge Cup and the Hempstead Cups, play for which starts about June 11.

One of the biggest upsets of the season in the 2-year-old division occurred yesterday at Belmont Park in the thirty-fourth running of The Fashion Stakes. $2,500 added, when Mrs. William Ziegler Jr.'s Glorify, a 12-to-1 shot, came home first.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- Speaking at a celebration here today of the fiftieth aniversary of the founding of the United Gas Improvement Company, John E. Zimmermann, the president, called for "honest and fearless leadership in high places" as a means of directing the world out of the economic depression.

All records were broken on the Cotton Exchange yesterday when June, the spot month, closed at 4.92 cents a pound, compared with a previous low mark of 4.98 cents for a spot month, made in 1898. July went below the 5-cent level, the first time in the half century history of the Excriange that a future contract had touched that figure.

The 132-36 Thirty-ninth Street Corporation, August Schindler, president, conveyed to the Claremont Building and Loan Association of Jersey City the four-story, sixteen-family apartment house on a plot 37 by 100 feet at 136 Thirty-ninth Street, near Hudson Avenue, Union City, assessed at $39,700.

LONDON, June 1 (AP). -- A polite and unofficial difference of opinion appeared to have developed today between Great Britain and the United States concerning the disclosure of plans for an international conference to attempt to revive business.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- That great intellectual development is associated not with the number of brain cells or the weight of the brain but rather with the number of blood vessels and the chemical composition of the blood itself was a proposition presented to the American Psychiatrio Association tonight by Dr. Henry H. Donaldson of the Wistar Institute, University of Pennsylvania.

Excluding domestic and Canadian municipal bond issues, new public financing in the United States for the first five months of this year aggregated $229,078,000, according to Otto P. Schwarzchild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 1. -- The first circus of the season yesterday was an attraction for many early arrivals in the Summer colony. Among those who attended in the afternoon were Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse and Miss Adelaide Whitehouse, Mrs. Reginald Norman, Mrs. Giraud F. Elliott and Miss Katherine Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The readiness of the United States to attend an international conference in London on commodity prices and other economic questions short of war debts and reparations threatened to develop into a controversial political question today when it became known that Great Britain yet hoped to work out the projected meeting through the attendance of the United States at the Lausanne conference.

PARIS, June 1. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody advanced to the semi-finals of the women's singles in the French tennis championships at the Roland Garros Stadium today by defeating Mile. Lolette Payot of Switzerland, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Hopes that the Senate would pass an economy bill within one or two days faded today when it recessed early "to go to bed" after several members had given notice that they expected to exercise their right of unlimited debate.

On the theory that Europeans know more about Josephine Baker than about Jane Addams, more about Babe Ruth than about John Dewey, and are less familiar with the Rocky Mountains than with the slums of New York, Fred J. Ringel, literary correspondent here for Berlin newspapers, decided to introduce to Europe what Americans themselves consider representative of America.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Further sharp advances in stocks on the Boerse today led to the authorized statement that the Boerse board and the new government are opposed to inflationary measures. As the statement came near the end of trading, it failed to prevent today's extensive "flight into investments," which drove up the average level 3 to 5 per cent, with peak gains of 12 per cent.
Manhattan College will hold its seventy-ninth commencement today, with Cardinal Haves of the class of 1888 presiding. Degrees will be conferred and prizes presented as follows:

The Yankee Lacrosse Club and the strong Toronto team will clash at the Yankee Stadium tonight in the opening box lacrosse game of the newly formed American Lacrosse League. The Giants will play the Shamrocks at Fenway Park in Boston tonight, while Brooklyn will await, its opening tomorrow at Ebbets Field against the Yankees.
NEW YORK. Lady Gweneth Cavendish of London and her son, William Baring, left the Madison yesterday for Quebec, where they will visit the Governor General of Canada and the Countess of Bessborough.

Mrs. Anna Woerishoffer, widow of Charles Woerishoffer, a leading Wall Street operator fifty years ago, left a gross estate of $10,368,770, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., surviving executor. The report covered the period from Mrs. Woerishoffer's death on Aug. 28, 1931, until Jan. 27, when Lewis Cass Ledyard Sr., co-executor, died.

Seventeen Manhattan and Bronx properties offered at auctioneers' stands yesterday were bid in by the plaintiffs in the liquidation actions which brought about the sales. Small dwellings and tenement houses comprised most of the offerings.

In an official report issued yesterday by the Chorus Equity Association, Alexander Leftwich, musical show director, is attacked for revealing only "half a story," when he announced on Monday the abandonment of his project to present a series of musical comedy revivals, beginning June 11, at the County Centre, White Plains.
PARIS, June 1. -- France will be ready to go to Lausanne June 16 if Germany is, Edouard Herriot, who will be Premier by the end of this week, indicated in a conversation today.

LONDON, June 1 (Canadian Press). -- Amazing cricket was seen at Lord's today when the county match between Gloucestershire and Middlesex started. Middlesex lost the last six wickets of its first innings for only 16 runs, within forty minutes, and Gloucestershire collapsed even more badly before the Middlesex bowling, losing its last seven wickets for 13 runs in twenty-five minutes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1. -- The ten-game winning streak of Rhode Island State's undefeated baseball team came to an end at Soldiers' Field today as Charley Devens set down the Kingston team with four scattered singles, while his mates hammered a dozen safeties to register a 7-to-2 victory.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 1 (AP). -- I Say, the 3-year-old pride and joy of Al Sabath's stable, warmed up for the $10,000 added Illinois Oaks to be run Saturday at Washington Park by running away from a small field of fillies in a seven-furlong trial today.
Gumancindo Munoz stared wide-eyed at the doors ill to his father-in-law's second-floor home in the El Coronado Apartments yesterday.

The traditional rush on June 1 to the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building was tempered yesterday by the economic depression. Even the offer of a high silk hat to the first couple to apply for a marriage license, made by a Sixth Avenue hatter, failed to promote anything more than an early morning spurt which soon tapered off.

LONDON, June 1. -- The entire stock market was cheered today by the United States Senate's passage of the revenue bill and the Washington Government's decision to participate in the economic conference. Leading international stocks rallied spectacularly, Hydroelectric rising more than 20 per cent, from 5 1/2 to 6 3/4.

A personal platform containing fourteen points was promulgated by former United States Senator Joseph Irwin Prance of Maryland, Republican candidate for the Presidential nomination, in a radio address, broadcast last night from Station WOR.
LONDON, June 1 (AP). -- Before Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam went to the Derby at Epsom Downs today she said she was going to place a little bet -- but she didn't.

An improved demand for structural steel and tin plate is reported in the midweek review of The Iron Age. The fact that this increase in buying did not lift the rate of operations in the last week is explained, according to this publication, by the curtailment of activity incident to the Memorial Day holiday.

Joseph Stafford, 56 years old, who retired from business a year ago to enjoy the leisure that he had always promised himself, was shot and killed early yesterday morning by a burglar he surprised in his house, a large semi-colonial structure, at the northwest corner of 157th Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
EXETER, N.H., June 1. -- Exeter defeated the Boston College freshmen, 6 to 4, today, making the most at five hits off Duffey.

DETROIT, Mich., June 1. -- Charging Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, with malice and unfairness, Mayor Walker today replied to Mr. Seabury's charge that the Mayor's ownership of bonds in the Reliance Bronze and Steel Company, doing business with the city, constituted grounds for his removal.
MANILA, June 1 (AP). -- Two boxers, a high jumper and two breast-stroke swimmers were named today by the Insular Olympic committee to represent the Philippines in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

LONDON, Thursday, June 2. -- The United States Senate's passage of the tax bill came as a profound relief to Great Britain. Stocks bounded upward in all departments of the London Exchange yesterday, and there was an immediate rise in the dollar rate.

Through Morris L. Strauss, Assistant Corporation Counsel in charge of the City Workmen's Compensation Bureau since 1922, Samuel Seabury showed at yesterday's Hofstadter Committee hearing that several of the physicians alleged to have split fees with Dr. William H. Walker, the Mayor's brother, were apparently vastly overpaid for their services.

The historic gardens of Bolton Priory, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Alien in Pelham Manor, N.Y., will be opened to the public June 10 under the auspices of the Pelham Service League to aid the organization's work among the unemployed in the Pelhams.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP). -- The bark Coriolanus, once "queen of the jute clippers," sailed today for Bath, Me., to be fitted out in the same powerful square rig in which she established a sailing record between London and Calcutta in 1877.

Along with the reports dealing with the taking of large quantities of fish recently, especially of flounders, in the waters of New York and vicinity, have been statements from fishermen that part of their catches were being distributed to the needy.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 1. -- Al Blanche, Providence College hurler, held Holy Cross to four hits today and the Domincans defeated the Crusaders, 7-5, after the visitors had taken a three-run lead in the first.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For three years all the world's wiseacres seem to have been at sea in a rudderless craft, not even knowing what port they were heading for, or even which way to steer.

SAUNTON, England, June 1. -- Mrs. Leona Cheney fell today before the devastating game of Misa Enid Wilson, defending champion, in the women's British open golf tourney. Mrs. Cheney did not fall, however, without putting up a great fight. It was an uphill battle for her all the way, and she faced it worthily, as the representatives of the United States always do on these occasions.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1. -- The New Jersey appropriations bill calling for expenditures of $25,088,292 was passed in the Senate by a unanimous vote tonight after an executive session lasting far into the night in which slashes of $519,000 were made from a bill as submitted about a month ago.

Believing that the plan "might be " of real value in the present depression," the State Department announces the willingness of our Government to enter "an international " conference for the purpose of considering methods to stabilize world "commodity prices."

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- A homer by Max Bishop in the first game and Jimmie Foxx's eighteenth circuit clout of the season in the second, each in its turn, snatched a victory from the Yankees' grasp today. The McCarthymen began a six-game series with a double defeat at the hands of the Athletics, 8 to 7 and 7 to 6.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 1. -- April the Fifth, 100-to-6 outside, owned and trained by an actor, Tom Walls, scored a tremendously popular triumph by winning the Derby today with a spectacular finish, defeating the Aga Khan's Dastur, which was second, and Lord Rosebery's Miracle, third.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, former general staff officer, succeeded today in forming the government of "national concentration" that was envisaged by President Paul von Hindenburg Monday when he abruptly deposed Chancellor Heinrich Bruening in defiance of parliamentary prerogative.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 1. -- Taking advantage of an exceptionally smooth river surface, three boatloads of Columbia oarsmen paddled about the historic Hudson River regatta course today a few hours after the flotilla arrived at its Krum Elbow headquarters to embark on its training grind for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20.

The promptness with which the Senate responded to the President's emphatic speech, and the rapidity with which the Federal tax bill went to conference of the two houses yesterday, had immediate though somewhat chequered influence on financial markets.

The only remaining indictment against former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso in connection with the failure of the City Trust Company was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, on motion of Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 1. -- Fifteen executives of European steel companies are due to arrive here this week from New York to inspect the cold-strip method of steel rolling in local steel plants. Among the plants they are especially interested in inspecting is that of the Cold Metal Process Company.

HAVANA, June 1. -- Cotubanama Enrique Carbajal, son of former President Francisco Enrique Carbajal of Santo Domingo, was arrested in Havana this afternoon, accused of being one of the leaders of ABC, a student revolutionary organization in Cuba.

NORTON, Mass., June 2. -- President J. Edgar Park of Wheaton College presented Miss Barbara Roper of Princeton, N.J., yesterday with the Catherine Filene Dodd $10 prize for being the best student in natural sciences. Miss Virginia Hall of New Haven won the $25 Rosemary Buckingham prize for the most original thesis produced in the history department.

LONDON, June 1. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Minister, in a statement in the House of Commons today virtually invited the United States Government to join the Lausanne conference -- not to participate in the discussion of war debts and reparations, but in that other part of the Lausanne agenda that covers "other economic and financial difficulties which are responsible for and may prolong the world crisis."

Only when personal welfare and satisfaction and the "public weal" are merged into a common and outstanding ideal will the government of man "take on a more satisfying form," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said yesterday afternoon in his address as president at Columbia University's 178th commencement services.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP). -- Effective pitching by Dizzy Dean and a rainstorm today gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 1-to-0 seven-inning victory over the Cubs, but cheated Pepper Martin and Eddie Delker out of home runs.

Not even the inspiring presence of John McGraw proved of sufficient influence to shake the Giants out of the doldrums and prevent them from slipping back into the National League cellar yesterday as they opened a five-game series with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds by losing, 4 to 2.

SAUNTON, England, June 1 (AP). -- Miss Purvis-Russell-Montgomery defeated Mrs. Ina Marshall Clarke of Ireland in the other semi-final today, 3 and 2, and gained the right to meet Miss Wilson for the title.

MEXICO CITY, June 1. -- All Catholic churches in the State of Mexico closed last evening on account of failure of the Catholic authorities to comply with recent legislation requiring the church to name thirty-four priests to officiate la the State, as compared with the present number of 150.

Negotiations with the Turkish Government to recover $14,250,000 for owners of securities of the International Match Corporation, now in bankruptcy, have been virtually completed by agents of the Irving Trust Company at Ankara, Turkey, it was announced yesterday at a creditors' meeting before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, at 280 Broadway.

After according an enthusiastic reception to the news that the Senate had, overnight, adopted a revenue measure calculated to balance the Federal budget, the stock market resumed its decline yesterday without any reason that was visible to Wall Street.

Kid Chocolate, Cuban lightweight, celebrated the opening of the outdoor boxing season at the Queensboro Stadium last night with a hollow victory over stout-hearted little Lew Feldman of Brownsville in the fifteen-round feature bout before 6,000 fans.

BUCHAREST, June 1 (AP). -- The publication today of the full text of the report by Charles Rist, the French financial expert who has been investigating Rumania's economic position, disclosed that the government had not enough money to pay even half its civil service salaries.

Ambassador MELLON showed that his philosophic calm as an old observer of American politics had not been upset when he assured his hearers in London on Wednesday that Congress would soon pass bills to balance the budget and preserve the credit of the Government.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 1. -- Governor Roosevelt requested Sheriff John E. Sheehy of New York County today to investigate further into the financial affairs of Under-Sheriff Peter J. Curran.

SAUNTON, England, June 1. -- "The Last of Mrs. Cheney," to the intense relief of Miss Enid Wilson, defending champion in the women's British open golf tourney, was seen on the sixteenth green in the semifinal round today.

On the very day when the President went to the Capitol to address the Senate in person, the Supreme Court was making it possible for him to cut future visits short, perhaps dispense with some of them altogether. What visitor to Washington has not been shown the "President's Room," across the lobby from the Senate Chamber?

Notes received from the kidnappers and murderers of Charles A. Lindbergb Jr. subsequent to the kidnapping were positively identified as authentic by the twin circle symbol with its red ink stamp, Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the New Jersey State Police, announced yesterday.

PARIS, June 1. -- Another deeply vexing Franco-American problem was settled late last night when Premier Tardieu approved a most-favored nation agreement governing quotas for future American imports into France. A month ago the French agreed to drop double taxation, also an extremely troublesome question between the two countries, and the whole American business world of Paris is hailing these evidences of French friendship with deep gratification.
TOKYO, June 1. -- Police precautions for the protection of Emperor Hirohito when he went to open the Diet today were unusually elaborate, even for Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Federal Farm Loan Board appointed a receiver today to take immediate charge of the St. Louis Joint Stock Land Bank as a result of the latter's failure to pay interest due today. Paul Bestor, Federal Farm Loan Commissioner, announced the action.

READING, Pa., June 1 (AP). -- Buzz Arlett, Baltimore outfielder, equaled the home run record for the International League as well as for the major leagues today when he clouted four home runs in one game as the Orioles defeated Reading, 14 to 13. Arlett fell short, however, of equaling the slugging feats of two other minor leaguers.

ATHENS, June 1. -- General Theodorus Pangalos, former dictator of Greece, and eleven of his principal supporters have been banished for five months to different islands. The government expressed regret at having to take what it described as a preventive measure rendered necessary by Pangalist agitation among the people.

Completion of the refinancing of $20,727,750 of St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway 4 per cent consolidated bonds upon their maturity yesterday was marked by a skyrocketing in their price on the New York Stock Exchange. Opening 5 points higher, the bonds soared a maximum of 25 points, a gain which would have been extraordinary even in the case of a junior issue.
The testimony of Dr. WiKtam H. Walker given yesterday before the Hofstadter Legislative Committee follows:

WILMINGTON, Del., June 1. -- A bill in equity was filed in the Federal District Court today on behalf of Harry Koplar of University City, Missouri, against Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and a group of directors, asking the appointment of receivers to manage the business and to "oust from office such of the individual defendants as shall appear from the evidence to be unfit to continue to discharge their trusts."

THE rush to get hold of Al Schacht's diet schedule ceased when the Senators slipped from the lead in the American League. But Colonel Jacob Ruppert is still interested, and perhaps John J. McGraw might like to try it on J. Francis Hogan and one or two other heavyweights on the Giant squad.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 1. -- Completion of negotiations by which the Owens Illinois Pacific Coast Company, a subsidiary of the Owens Illinois Glass Company, will acquire the Illinois Pacific Coast Company, was announced here today by C.N. Davis, president of the last named concern.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 1. -- Following a final workout on the turf courts of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club the team to represent the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association in the Sears Cup matches at the Germantown Cricket Club, Philadelphia, on Friday and Saturday was picked definitely today by Mrs. Jeanette Chappell Hitchcock, chairman of the selection committee.
EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 1 (AP). -- Ten million dollars -- probably more -- went wrong today.

There wil be nothing left of the "Stop Roosevelt" movement when the Democratic National Convention opens in Chicago on June 27, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee and principal field agent for the Roosevelt forces, asserted yesterday.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Governor Roosevelt stuck closely to State affairs today, presiding at four clemency hearings, conferring on financial affairs and making up a schedule of appointments and reappointments.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- The recent assurances given by Japanese statesmen of their peaceable intentions toward the Soviet Union are taken in official Soviet circles and in public opinion here with a large grain of skepticism. Following the lead of a similar editorial in the newspaper Izvestia of Sunday, the Red Star, organ of the War Commissariat, says today:

Jersey City again defeated Newark yesterday, triumphing, 6 to 3, to capture the series at Jersey City, three games out of four. Jimmy Jordan led the visitors' offensive, connecting for four hits in five times at bat.

The indictment returned on April 17, 1916, against Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, the new German Chancellor, charging mat he conspired with four others to blow up the locks of the Welland Canal in Canada, was nolle pressed March 8, this year, United States Attorney George Z. Medalie revealed yesterday.
Arthur Schulte has leased for the season a 5 1/2-acre estate in King Street, Port Chester, from William Berbusse. Warren L. Marks Co. acted as brokers.

Spokesmen for independent owner-operators of taxicabs and two members of the Board of Aldermen appeared yesterday at a public hearing of the Board of Taxicab Control to oppose an application by the Dodge Motors Company of New York for a ruling under which medallions or "licenses" of repossessed taxicabs would go with the cabs and be issued, on resale, to such purchasers as would meet the board's qualifications as to financial responsibility and general fitness.

The State Charities Aid Association maintained active leadership during the last year in the development throughout the State of machinery to meet the rapidly growing relief needs resulting from unemployment, according to its annual report, made public yesterday by Homer Folks, secretary.

In the annual report of the State Charities Aid Association, published today, is a record of valuable new developments carried forward under the greatest handicaps in many years. The association receives no support from public funds, and is dependent on the gifts and labors of volunteers.
PRINCETON, Ky., June 1 (AP). -- Walter Merrick, 48, white, was taken from the county jail by a mob late last night and his body was found hanging from a tree three miles from here today.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A bill by Senator Glass to make all United States Government bonds available for temporary currency inflation to the extent of $1,108,000,000 was substituted by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today for the Goldsborough bill, which seeks to stabilize the dollar on a 1921-1929 average purchasing level, and was reported to the Senate by an unrecorded but overwhelming vote.
BOSTON, June 1 (AP). --The Washington Senators Hashed a double play to squelch a ninth-inning Boston rally and defeated the Boston Red Sox today, 2 to 1.

Official announcement of an alliance between the Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman, in the promotion of the Max Schmeling-Jack Sharkey world's heavyweight championship ring struggle, to to be held in the Garden's new bowl in Long Island City, was made yesterday by William F. Carey, Garden president.

Dr. William H. Walker, a brother of Mayor Walker, who banked $431,258 in four years, admitted yesterday before the Hofstadter committee that he had split fees with physicians who enjoyed a monopoly on treating the bruised fingers and injured toes of city employes.
Various leasehold deals announced yesterday involved residential and business properties in Manhattan.
GENEVA, June 1. -- Notification that Japan might reopen the question of naval ratios among the great powers was served on the naval commission of the world disarmament conference today.

The Marines in Nicaragua. President MONCADA of Nicaragua is reported to have said that putting down internal disorders is the duty of the National Guard, and that the lives of United States marines should not be sacrificed.

Two raids on Broadway in which twenty-seven persons were arrested, and a third raid on a lower east side printing plant were staged last night by policemen attached to the staff of Chief Inspector John O'Brien in an effort to break up the J. S. Daily Double Two-Horse Parlay, a racing pool said to have attracted a play of $100,000 daily since it was started two weeks ago.

The American Legion's nation-wide drive for jobs will end on July 1, it was announced yesterday by Henry L. Stevens Jr., national commander, who said that up to noon yesterday 850,026 jobs toward the quota of 1,000,000 had been reported.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP). -- Harry Koplar is a pioneer St. Louis movie exhibitor.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Mildred Van Schaick Gwynne, who challenged the validity of an order of Leonard J. Smith which consolidated school districts in Suffolk County, was successful today when the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Appellate Division and affirmed that cf the trial term.

OMAHA, June 1 (AP). -- Lieutenants Paul and Bishop tonight appeared certain winners of the 1932 national balloon championship, being assured possession of the Litchfield Trophy for one year and a place on the United States team in the international race in Switzerland next September.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr., James H. Stillman, Barren G. Collier and other residents of Pocantico Hills and Mount Pleasant appealed to the State troopers for protection today, following the ousting of the new Mount Pleasant police force of twelve men on a court order.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1. -- Henry E. Foster, 66 years old, teacher of mathematics and science in the Hebrew Technical Institute, New York City, and a former police justice of Floral Park, was convicted by jury in the county court here today of accepting a bribe of $1,600 as president of the Sewanhaka High School District School Board at Floral Park in 1930.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP). -- Harry Koplar is a pioneer St. Louis movie exhibitor.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Mildred Van Schaick Gwynne, who challenged the validity of an order of Leonard J. Smith which consolidated school districts in Suffolk County, was successful today when the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Appellate Division and affirmed that cf the trial term.

OMAHA, June 1 (AP). -- Lieutenants Paul and Bishop tonight appeared certain winners of the 1932 national balloon championship, being assured possession of the Litchfield Trophy for one year and a place on the United States team in the international race in Switzerland next September.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr., James H. Stillman, Barren G. Collier and other residents of Pocantico Hills and Mount Pleasant appealed to the State troopers for protection today, following the ousting of the new Mount Pleasant police force of twelve men on a court order.
Bank clearings in the last week were less than half of the total reported for the same period a year ago; according to R. G. Dun Co.

George E. Holmes, 53 years old, income-tax expert and lawyer who recently represented Henry M. Blackmer, self-exiled oil man, in his settlement with the Treasury Department of civil income-tax liabilities, was killed yesterday when he was struck by a southbound B.M.T. local subway train entering the Thirty-fourth Street station.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

DANZIG, June 2. -- Protesting anew against Polish propaganda carried on in the Free City's territory against the seaside resort of Zoppot, the Danzig Senate has sent identical notes to Dr. Papee, Poland's diplomatic representative, and Count Gravina, the League of Nations commissioner, stating that it has found itself regretfully compelled to take police measures against this propaganda.

LONDON, June 2 (AP). -- In the final volume of Queen Victoria's letters, published today, is a reference to her grandson, now King George V, when he was the Duke of York. Four years after he had married the present Queen Mary Queen Victoria wrote in 1897:

PARIS, June 2. -- Mrs. Helen Wins Moody met a severe test and Rene Lacoste tasted defeat in two matches that were filled with unexpected excitement in the French tennis championship play at the Roland Garros Stadium today.
LONDON, June 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

NEWARK, N.J., June 2. -- Bishop Thomas J. Walsh announced today the transfer of eighteen assistant priests in the Newark diocese of the Roman Catholic Church and the assignment of seventeen priests whom he ordained on May 21.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Business, labor, agriculture and financial representatives met here today in a national conference for the reduction, of government expenditures and demanded that the "Roman holiday" of tax-spending agencies give way to the strictest economy.

PITTSBURGH, June 2. -- Howard E. Wandless, now a witness for the State In the Modern Building and Loan Association conspiracy case, was free under $25,000 bond today after an admission that he had embezzled $80,000 or more of the association's funds to pay an alleged extortionist.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- James R. Garfield, selected by President Hoover to be chairman of the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention, resumed his conferences with Republican leaders here today to obtain a consensus of views on the perplexing plank of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- In exhausting its capital stock of $500,000,000 and dipping into its first offering of $250,000,000 of debentures, the first purchases of which have been made by the Treasury, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has extended relief to a diversified list of institutions throughout the country.

The Brookmeade Stable of Mrs. Isabel Sloan scored a double at Belmont Park yesterday, Okapi capturing the Wild Briar Purse and Helianthus scoring in the fifth running of the Maturity, featured offering.

SAUNTON, England, June 2. -- Miss Enid Wilson, 22-year-old English girl, won the women's British open golf championship for the second year in succession today when she beat Miss Clem Purvis-Russell-Montgomery, former Scottish champion, in the final round over thirty-six holes by 7 and 6.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- The government today turned an inquiring eye on Communistic activities as thousands of war veterans marched and rode toward the nation's capital to demand immediate payment of their bonus.

With stocks pointing sharply upward in the late dealings, Wall Street seemed to have succeeded yesterday, in shaking off its fit of despondency. The share market drifted lower in the morning but reversed its course around noon and advanced steadily until the close, with an impressive burst of strength in a few issues just before the bell rang.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A complete agreement on all features of the tax bill was reached by the Conference Committee of the House and Senate at 10:30 o'clock tonight. Official announcement of the conclusions was withheld, pending a formal report tomorrow to the House.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 2 (AP). -- Hoping to find a box car to carry them to Washington, a second Albany contingent of thirty World War veterans marched out of town today bound for the "bonus parade" at the National Capital June 8.

Bonds of the Long Island Railroad Company, which have not been legal for investment by savings banks in New York State because a railroad company must have paid dividends on its capital stock for at least five years equivalent to onefourth of its fixed charges, were added to the State's legal list yesterday by Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Returning to its customary deliberative routine, the Senate debated the economy bill for more than six hours today without reaching the point where a vote could be taken on the proposal to cut Federal salaries 10 per cent, the first item in the bill.

Using a strategy seldom employed, agents of Andrew McCampbell, Prohibition Administrator, raided a deserted night club at noon yesterday and were in full possession of furnishings valued at more than $100,000, when later in the day a sleepyeyed doorman entered the place to begin work.

Vacancies on the directorate of the Associated Gas and Electric Company caused by the resignation of C. W. Beall, W. E. McGregor and George D. Woods of the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation were not filled at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Routine new had little effect today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade. Reports from the American Notthwest on the new Spring crop were gen erally optimistic and more rains were reported in that section and also over a considerable area in the Canadian Northwest.

Thirty-three New York University varsity and freshman athletes were entered yesterday in the fortieth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships to be held at the Yankee Stadium a week from tomorrow. Eighteen of them will represent N.Y.U. and fifteen will wear the colors of the New York A.C.

SEATTLE, June 2. -- Robert S. Monahan of Pawtucket, leader of the advance party of the 1932 expedition to Mount Fairweather, Alaska, left this afternoon on the steamship Admiral Rogers with thirty crates of climbing and camping equipment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 2. -- The right of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California to bring Colorado River water into Southern California with funds of the $220,000,000 bond issue approved by the voters on Sept. 29, 1931, was validated today by the California State Supreme Court.

LONDON, June 2. -- W.F.F. Oppenoorth, Dutch engineer with the Java Geological Survey, is "probably justified" in claiming that the five skulls which he and Mr. Terhaar, also an engineer, discovered at Ngandong, in the Solo River Valley, Java, are representative of a hitherto unknown species of fossil man, according to Professor M. Elliot Smith, British anthropologist.

LONDON, June 2. -- Stanley Baldwin, Acting Premier, told the House of Commons today it was hoped that Parliament would adjourn early in July in order to release the Ministers from their duties in Commons so they could attend the various conferences in which the British Government is interested.

The Painters and Sculptors' Gallery in East Eleventh Street, which opened last November, right in the well-sharpened teeth of the depression, is casting a backward glance at a highly successful first season. The retrospective show of seven months' achievement will continue through June 25.

After having declined a half cent in three days to the lowest quotations ever recorded on the Cotton Exchange, prices of cotton steadied yesterday and recovered more than a quarter cent. The July reached 5.01 cents a pound early, which was within 2 points of the low record of the week, and then advanced to 5.28 cents, but fell back to 5.22.

M. HERRIOT, who is now regarded as the next Premier, asks plaintively why it should always be his fate to come into power when the difficulties are greatest. This makes the picture darker than it really is. The office of head of the Government is nowhere today a bed of roses; but it would be hard to name a country less beset with troubles than France.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Loans to railroads from the Railroad Credit Corporation during May for meeting fixed interest obligations totaled $3,032,992 and brought the amount advanced by the corporation for that purpose to $7,221,574, according to its monthly report filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- In a brief and perfunctory legal proceeding, the final chapter of the celebrated criminal cases growing from the oil scandals of the Harding Administration was written today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

The State of Virginia, which has not increased its bonded debt since 1926, awarded yesterday $3,440,000 of refunding bonds and certificates of indebtedness to a syndicate comprising the First National Old Colony Corporation, the First and Merchants National Bank of Richmond, MasonHagan, Inc., of Richmond, and Scott Stringfellow of Richmond.

The local season of the American Lacrosse League opened at the Yankee Stadium last night, where the New York Yankees engaged the Toronto lacrosse club in a box lacrosse game. A crowd of 4,000 saw the Yankees win, 11 to 9.

William O. Riordan has resigned as Vice president and general manager of Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn, to become president of Stern Brothers, it was announced yesterday by Walter N. Rothschild, general manager of the Brooklyn store. Mr. Riordan will take up his new duties on June 14.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 2. -- Another young member of the Montclair Golf Club, this time Miss Lucille Parsons, arose today to dispute Miss Charlotte Glutting's retention of the women's New Jersey Golf Association championship. Miss Parsons played the No. 3 and No. 4 nines of her home club in 87 with an 8 on the fifteenth, her two-round total of 173 placing her first in the big field.

Oswald Jacoby, one of the members of the "Four Horsemen," the team that has been riding high across the contract bridge firmament for the past year, was dropped from the quartet yesterday by his three former team-mates, P. Hal Sims, Willard S. Karn and David Burnstine.

City Tax Collections Satisfactory. On the whole, this city did pretty well with its tax collections for the first half year. Taxes for that period were due on May 1, but could be paid without penalty up to May 31.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The vigorous and effective double appearance of Ogden L. Mills before Congressional committees today crystallized into comment what has hitherto been only a growing impression. It is that the Secretary of the Treasury is the strongest member of President Hoover's Cabinet, and deals with Congress more successfully than any President or Cabinet Minister has for many years.

Reports to date indicate that Class I railroads earned net operating incomes of $20,400,000 in April, against $39,074,000 in April, 1931, a drop of 47.7 per cent, and against $62,312,000 in April, 1930, a fall of 67.2 per cent. The gross revenues of these roads in April were $268,600,000, against $369,652,000 in April, 1931, a decrease of 27.3 per cent, and $451,233,000 in April, 1930, a decline of 40.4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Miss Jeannette Rankin of Montana, the first woman elected to the House of Representatives, and Miss Emma Wold of Oregon, technical adviser to the American delegation at The Hague Conference on the Codification of International Law two years ago, left Washington at noon today on an automobile speaking tour in the interest of peace.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2. -- Drawing a contrast between the life of a naval officer and "what the world outside offers," Secretary Adams told the graduates of the Naval Academy today that "Victory will go to the combination of men that has developed the greatest unity of action and the best spirit."

Three young thugs with pistols entered the offices of the Ettl Studios, Inc., sculpture dealers, at 227 West Thirteenth Street shortly before noon yesterday and, after tying up Charles H. Ettl, sculptor and vice president, secretary and treasurer of the company, and four employes, escaped with $40,000 in securities which they took from an open safe, $250 in cash and a $75 diamond ring.

DUBLIN, June 2 (Canadian Press). -- The Free State Senate tonight gave second reading to the government's bill abolishing the Parliamentary oath of allegiance to the King, but observers saw possibility of a deadlock between the Dail and the upper house which would, bring a general election in the Fall.

Not until men open their minds and their hearts further to Christ will they find a solution to then present economic, social and political difficulties, Cardinal Hayes declared yesterday afternoon at the seventy-ninth annual commencement of Manhattan College, held in the quadrangle on the college campus at Spuyten Duyvil and 242d Street, Riverdale.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 2 (AP). -- Prediction that Governor Roosevelt of New York would be the second choice of a majority of Illinois' fifty-eight delegates to the Democratlc National Convention was made by down-State party leaders at a meeting here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 2. -- "Our own is perilously like Froude's terrifying picture of the corruption of the Roman noble," said the Rev. Henry A. Riddle Jr. of Lewiston, Pa., tonight in concluding his baccalaureate sermon to the members of the graduating class of Washington and Jefferson College.

Between the tax bill as adopted by the Senate and the estimated current expenditures of the Federal Government next year there is still a gap of about $350,000,000. To bridge it with added economies is now the problem of a balanced budget.

Citing the tendency of agencies outside the medical profession to provide care for the sick, Dr. Walter L. Niles, Professor of Clinical Medicine at Cornell University Medical College and a former dean of the school, urged the graduating class of that institution yesterday to aid in adjusting their profession to a period which finds diagnosis and treatment "far more expensive than heretofore."

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 2 (AP). -- Airplanes from Montreal and Boston converged on Newfoundland tonight to join in a search for Arthur Sullivan, aviator, and Dr. K. Karl A. Kuehnert, Grenfell Mission dentist, who have been missing since they took off on a pleasure flight from St. Anthony Monday.
Hack Wilson hit two home runs yesterday, No. 6 in the first game and No. 7 in the nightcap, pleasing 13,000 fans mightily, but the Robins could only break even with the Braves at Ebbets Field.

Medical practice under the Tammany code of ethics is singularly lucrative, as the bank accounts of Dr. WILLIAM H. WALKER and of his less eminent associates show. The city of New York is the best-paying of patients. Dr. WALKER is a man and a physician of many activities.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 2. -- Senator Huey P. Long's self-styled title "Kingfish of Louisiana" was challenged today in two resolutions introduced in the Legislature, requesting him to return to his Senate seat in Washington and stop "meddling" in Louisiana's affairs of State.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 2 (AP). -- Ten persons were reported killed today in a terrific rainstorm that swept the village of Matchja, in the Dobrudja district. Scores of persons were injured and there was heavy property damage, including a great loss of cattle.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Purchases at government securities by the Federal Reserve Banks increased $50,004,000 in the week ended yesterday, bringing the total holdings to $1,575,000,000, which was $690,000,000 greater than on April 6, when the new open-Market policy was launched, according to Reserve Board figures available today.

BALTIMORE, June 2 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles took the opening game of the series from Reading tonight, 8 to 7, in a clash that was featured by the batting of Eddie Kenna. The catcher clouted a pair of doubles, a home run and a single. It was his single, with the bases loaded, in the ninth that won the game.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- President Hoover sent two of his most outspoken Cabinet members to Congress today to voice his opposition to the Garner relief bill and parts of the Wagner bill. Secretary Mills appeared this morning before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, while Secretary Hurley addressed the Ways and Means Committee for three hours.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 2. -- Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, Yale's head football coach, today attacked five of the major methods by which the university proposes to transfer emphasis from intercollegiate to intramural sports.

BERLIN, June 2. -- The necessity for another general agreement with all Germany's medium and short term creditors for partial prolongations is forecast by the Institut Komjukturforschung because there will not be enough bills of exchange available for the rest of the year's debt service in full, while the extensions in force, including the Bank for International Settlements rediscount, are so closely intermeshed it is impossible to deal with one creditor without dealing with all.

The government closed its case yesterday against five ammunition companies, charged with combining in restraint of trade, at a Federal Trade Commission hearing which was characterized by William A. Tobler, vice president and general manager of the Remington Arms Company, as "an unpatriotic inquisition."

Plans to rescue the book publishing industry from its present disorganization, in which overproduction and price cutting are listed as outstanding evils, are contained in a report of a committee of eight publishers, headed by W.W. Norton, which has been sent to members of the National Association of Book Publishers and others.

Manhattan realty trading picked up briskly yesterday with an announcement involving important properties in the sale and leasing of which the Louis J. Ehret Holding Corporation figured as a principal. Added to these deals were several other transactions in scattered sections of the borough.

News that the Senate had passed the tax bill to balance the budget had a good effect at home but caused an extraordinary sensation abroad. Newspapers in London and Paris began rubbing their eyes to assure themselves that they were awake.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Complete figures on the financial operations of the United States Government during the first eleven months of the fiscal year 1932, issued today by the Treasury, showed that the deficit, on May 31, was $2,684,950,445, as compared with $1,044,910,099 at the same time last year.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 2 (AP). -- Spanish Play captured the featured Del Prado Purse today by two and one-half lengths and covered the mile in 1:38 2-5. Prince Atheling was second and Pittsburgher finished third. Only four horses started.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 2. -- Columbia defeated Williams, 14 to 7, in a game marked by hard hitting today. The Lions found Filley, the Purple's pitching ace, for fifteen hits, including triples by Balquist and Matal.

PARIS, June 2 (AP). -- In other matches in the French tennis championships today Henri Cochet defeated George P. Hughes of Great Britain, 6-4, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, to gain the quarter finals; Roderick Menzel of Czechoslovakia defeated the veteran Jacques Brugnon, 8-6, 6-4, 6-4; George de Stefani of the Italian Davis Cup team beat Baron von Kehrling of Hungary, 6-4, 9-7, 6-4, and Frederick Perry of England defeated Franz Matejka of Austria, 6-2, 6-4, 6-4.
WARSAW, June 2. -- The Poles seem to be quite pleased with the new German Government which, it is argued, at least has the virtue of being openly militaristic and revisionist.

BALTIMORE, June 2. -- Receivers were appointed today for the Consolidation Coal Company by Judge W C. Coleman in the Federal Court and they were directed by the court to continue the business of the corporation.

Judging by the course of yesterday's market for stocks and bonds, another day's reflection on the turn of events at Washington had begun to infuse some cheerfulness into the financial mind. Probably this was in part derived from the quite unmistakable response of European markets to the news of the past few days.

Shaking the dust of city scandals from his feet, Mayor WALKER journeyed to Detroit to give a group of American Mayors assembled there the benefit of his views on unemployment relief and municipal finance. They are such as to make his fellow-citizens groan.

PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, June 2. -- One of the most Important movements since the Union of South Africa was formed reached a new stage today with the opening of a congress attended by delegates favoring secession of Natal from the Union.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2. -- Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club, one-time Westchester-Fairfield women's titleholder, won the one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Knollwood Country Club today, covering the eighteen holes in 82, two above par, to capture the gross honors.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP). -- The Senators took a doubleheader from the Red Sox today by scores of 6 to 4 and 8 to 1.
LONDON, June 2. -- Air Commodore Charles Kingsford-Smith, Australian, who flew the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, received a knighthood in the list of the King's birthday honors issued tonight.

PARIS, June 2. -- At a meeting today the Bank of France decided to join in a renewal of the credit to the Reichsbank "in principle." The questions of reducing the interest rate from 6 to 5 per cent and of a partial reimbursement -- probably of 10 per cent -- were left as subjects for negotiations.

RENO, Nev., June 2. -- Alleging coercion, Mrs. Helen Russell Auchin-closs Rogers filed suit here today to set aside Die divorce she obtained at Yerington, Nev., in June, 1931, from Charles Francis Rogers of New York.
