LONDON, June 2. -- A fivefold increase in the number of eligible voters in India is recommended by the Marquess of Lothian's Indian franchise committee, whose report was issued tonight.

When librarians get together these days one of their most earnest discussions relates to the purchase of new books. All public libraries are laboring under a handicap. Some of them have suffered comparatively small reductions in income, but most have seen the budget dwindle anywhere from a fourth to threefourths of the funds available for 1929.

TOKYO, June 2. -- There is absolutely no danger of war between Japan and Soviet Russia, Admiral Makoto Saito declared today in one of his first statements on foreign policy since he assumed the Premiership last week.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., June 2. -- Society sportswomen and sportsmen turned out today for the opening of the annual two-day horse show of the Allegheny Country Club in the Sewickley Valley. The event is being conducted this year for the benefit of the Allegheny County Emergency Association.

WOBURN, Mass., June 2 (AP). -- Municipal and industrial heads today sought to solve the mystery that lay behind the walls of a seemingly impenetrable, windowless, concrete and steel building, which for several days has defied the efforts of Federal prohibition agents.

A description of the machinery of justice as utterly unfitted to present-day life and a warning that unless bench and bar undertook to improve conditions they might some day find an "outraged public" doing it for them, were the themes of a speech that United States Attorney George Z. Medalie delivered to the graduates of the New York Law School last night.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., June 2 (AP). -- Damages of $250,000 for alleged "unlawful appropriation" of her husband was asked today in a statement of claim filed in court here by Judith Vosselli Lloyd, stage and screen actress, in her suit against Mrs. Mary Penrose Gilford Lloyd of West Chester, second wife of John Eshelman Lloyd.

The depression would be worth the suffering it has caused if it brought men to face facts squarely and read the lesson they teach. Dean John T. Madden of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance said in an address last night before more than 500 seniors of that school at their final meeting of the year at the university's School of Education auditorium, 37-41 West Fourth Street.

Miss Elsie Dixon of 44 East ThirtySecond Street went on the stand before Justice Louis A. Valente in Supreme Court yesterday to tell why she should receive $89,000 from Clarence A. Pitman, 70-year-old nephew of Sir Isaac Pitman, shorthand inventor, under an agreement she says he made in 1920 to pay her $300 a month for life so that she could devote herself to writing motion picture scenarios.

LANSING, Mich., June 2. -- Having been restrained temporarily by the United States District Court in Detroit from revoking the license of the Standard Oil Company, the State turned today to the local courts and filed suit against the firm for $3,000,000.
With the hearings before the Hofstadter committee at an end, future action on Mayor Walker rested yesterday with Governor Roosevelt.

WARSAW, June 2. -- The Polish Government is determined to adhere to the gold standard and maintain the zloty's internal and external value at the present rate of 1.72 zlotys to the gold franc, according to Vice Premier Zawadski, who spoke today at the monthly meeting of the Government party.
Purchases and a sale by New Yorkers were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Secretary Mills spoke twice before Congress today.

MANHATTAN, Kan., June 2. -- Speaking to the graduating class of the Kansas State College here tonight, William J. Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said that industry, "at a most crucial period," had failed to establish a balance between forces which produce and those which consume.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Colleges and universities thus far have weathered the depression, remarkably well. None has closed, although a few consolidations have been made and more may become necessary unless conditions improve.
BERLIN, June 2 (AP). -- The Retchsbank's statement as of May 31 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

Salvatore Spitale, who was named with Irving Bitz by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to negotiate with the kidnappers of Colonel Lindbergh's baby son before the baby's murdered body was found, was picked up in an alleged speakeasy at 44 West Forty-seventh Street early this morning by three detectives, who charged that he had a fully loaded pistol in his possession.

ALBANY, June 2. -- Exemption from taxation of the Corporation of Yaddo, which maintains a large estate at Saratoga Springs as a retreat for creative artists, was upheld by the Court of Appeals today when it affirmed a ruling of the Appellate Division.

TOKYO, June 2. -- A Japanese delicacy called tempura, meaning prawns fried in batter, pleased Charlie Chaplin so much that his last act in Japan was to buy a quantity of live prawns and send them aboard the steamship Hikawa Maru, on which he sailed for Seattle this afternoon.

Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, outlined yesterday his attitude toward prohibition planks in the party platforms, a point of view similar to reported descriptions of the proposed Borah plank. He urged that both parties recognize an honest difference of opinion on the Eighteenth Amendment and that they take the steps of quoting in their platforms the procedure which is embodied in the Constitution to provide for changes in it.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2. -- Westchester's first county-wide dance festival will be held tomorrow night at the Westchester County Centre under the direction of Ruth St. Denis.

ST. ALBANS, L.I., June 2. -- A veteran and a youngster were deadlocked for the medal at the end of the qualifying round of the annual Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship at the St. Albans Golf Club today.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., June 2. -- The Academy of St. Elizabeth will present diplomas to seventeen graduates of the senior school and to seven of the junior school at the seventy-second annual commencement on Friday, June 10. Mgr. John A. Duffy, vicar general of the diocese of Newark, will preside.

The money damage caused by smoke and air-borne dirt in New York City costs the average resident $14 a year and causes an average annual loss of $42,000 each to department stores and speciality shops in the mid-town area, health officials, merchants and experts in smoke abatement were told at a luncheon Wednesday at the Metropolitan Club.

MONTREAL, June 2 (Canadian Press). -- Buffalo won the opener of a three-game series today from Montreal, 4 to 0, before 5,000 fans. A homer by Winsett with two on climaxed a four-run first-inning attack by the Bisons. Gould held the Royals to six scattered hits.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP). -- Bunching their hits off Spencer, the Chicago Cubs took the first of their three-game series with the Pirates today, 9 to 5.

Down at Wildwood Crest, where the sea laps its peaceful monotone against the sands of the Jersey coast, the boys of the army's only railway coast artillery outfit are eating real ham and eggs this morning.

The Money market was featureless. Rates for call and maturity money, and the discounts on acceptances and commercial paper were all unchanged. Business was at a minimum, and represented only the routine requirements of the day.

The bill for the fourth evening of Senor Arias's experimental Spanish theatre at Roerich Hall proved to be his "The Tragedy of a Lighthouse," presented before a small but highly pleased audience. Given a lighthouse with a refugee keeper and his beautiful daughter, together with a couple of castaways, and much may happen before the arrival of a policeman in the last act.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of the troubles of the railroads are probably due to overcaptalization, particularly with regard to junior securities which were issued in the way of liens prior to preferred and common stocks. Of course, for quite a number of years past no such securities were issued without the approval and permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The international oil conference that was in session for three weeks in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria seeking a way to stabilize oil markets outside the United States failed to reach a successful conclusion, according to a joint announcement issued yesterday by C.E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, and Philip Rabinovich, a representative of the Soviet Government.

Until the increased fees recently voted by the Board of Higher Education are rescinded by the City Administration every student of voting age at City College will be asked to promise to vote and campaign against any Democratic nominee for municipal office, according to a motion adopted by more than 300 students at a mass meeting yesterday to protest the new fees.

Mrs. Mary G. Ford, a suspended teacher in Public School 67 In Brooklyn, was held In $3,000 ball for the grand jury on a charge of grand larceny yesterday by Magistrate Liota in the Adams Street Court, Brooklyn.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad declared yesterday a semiannual dividend of $3, thus reducing its annual rate from $10, at which it has stood for many years, to $6. This was the first Burlington dividend cut since 1895.

Strict economy in the government of the nation and of New York City was urged yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a series of resolutions adopted at the organization's monthly meeting in its headquarters, 65 Liberty Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most interesting and distinguished contemporary views of Washington is to be found in the "Eulogy on George Washington, delivered in St. Peter's Church, Baltimore, Feb. 22, 1800, by John Carroll, first Bishop and Archbishop of Baltimore," a famous discourse recently reissued.

Dry Goods Trade Sees Quiet Month With few orders placed in the primary dry goods markets during the week, wholesalers resigned themselves to a very quiet period during the current month. The main drawback at the present time is the declining market, they pointed out yesterday, and neither wholesalers nor small independent retailers are willing to commit themselves for any goods outside of actual needs.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP). -- Receivership for the Mobile Ohio Railroad, which operates between St. Louis and Mobile, Ala., was asked in a suit filed in Federal Court here late today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- Declaring that Professor Freud, the high priest of psychoanalysis, was wrong, Dr. Milton Harrington, psychiatrist at the Great Meadow Prison, Comstock, N.Y., told the convention of the American Psychiatric Association today that human behavior was not necessarily due to suppressed desires and that faulty mechanism of the human body might underlie abnormal actions.

The first concrete step toward employment security taken by an industry as a whole was announced yesterday with the adoption by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association of the unemployment insurance plan proposed by Gerard Swope president of the General Electric Company.
TOKYO, Friday, June 3. -- Viscount Makoto Saito, the new Premier of Japan, outlined the policies of his government in the Diet this morning.

PARIS, June 2. -- It was with a mixture of surprise and skepticism that Paris learned through London today that President Hoover had become as suddenly eager for a world economic conference as just a year ago he was eager for a moratorium. For a long time French political, economic and financial leaders have desired just such a conference.

The soundness of municipal bonds and municipal management depends upon ability to collect taxes and regulate expenditures, according to M. J. Devlet of Gertler, Devlet Co., municipal bond brokers, who has prepared a "yardstick for measuring municipals."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2. -- Miss Marjorie Ortenberg, 18 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Ortenberg of 14 East Seventy-fifth Street, Manhattan, was injured fatally and her parents and a friend were seriously hurt this morning when the automobile in which all were riding left the Bronx River Parkway, crashed through a concrete wall on the Woodland Avenue Bridge here and plunged fifty feet into the Bronx River.

ALBANY, June 2. -- After inspecting newly forested areas in a 150-mile swing today, Governor Roosevelt declared that the State's reforestation program was a modern example in coordinated social planning. Accompanied by a group of conservationists and State officials, the Gov- ernor toured areas in Otsego County planted under the enlarged schedule prepared by the Reforestation Commission and learned that this Spring 23,000,000 trees had been planted and 122,000 acres acquired.

GENEVA, June 2. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's proposed world economic conference gets much more criticism than support in League of Nation circles. It is considered that the time, the place and the agenda all help to doom it to failure.
SAUNTON, England, June 2 (AP). -- Miss Enid Wilson announced today she would go to the United States to play in the American women's championship at Salem, Mass., the week of Sept. 26.

ROME, June 2 (AP). -- The Black Shirts of Fascism saluted the Red Shirts of Garibaldi today on the fiftieth, anniversary of the death of the Italian liberator. Ceremonies were held throughout Italy and 1,000 war cripples left Civitavecchia on a pilgrimage to the island of Caprera, where Garibaldi is buried.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The United States is prepared to adopt the British suggestion and attend a general economic conference in London as the second part of the Lausanne conference to discuss general economic conditions, but will do so only on the express understanding that reparations, tariff rates and governmental debts owed the United States will not be discussed.

Nine football contests have been arranged for Manhattan College next Fall, according to an announcement by Brother Anselm, director of athletics, yesterday. An all-home sched- ule faces the Jaspers in their first season under John F. (Chick) Meehan, former N.Y.U. coach.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Illinois Central Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a three-year loan of $11,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The Western Pacific in another application sought a further loan from the corporation of $759,000.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Scott Rokenbaugh, who were at the Gotham for the Winter and early Spring, have gone to Villa Avalon, their place in Bay Shore, L.I., for the Summer.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, will be among the speakers to address the New York State Bankers Association at its annual convention to be held from June 13 to 15 at the Westchester Country Club, it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, president of the association.

THE forlorn Giants are resting uncomfortably in the National League cellar and some of the players are hoping that Judge Seabury will not haul them downtown for an explanation. They would prefer not to talk about it.

The word "workhouse" will have a definite meaning for Charles Monsolino for the next six months. Instead of playing poker for matchsticks -- a favorite pastime on Welfare Island -- he will work at his trade. Monsolino is 45 years old, an expert woodcarver and cabinetmaker who has been in and out of court for years on his wife's complaints of non-support.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP). -- St. Louis shelled Al Thomas with two doubles, three singles and a base on balls in the third inning today to score all their runs and defeat the White Sox, 4 to 2, in the series opener. Burns, Ferrell and Melillo accounted for the runs.

A resolution urging that organizations and municipal departments whose responsibility it is to protect the health of children "be urged to maintain their present program for health work among children despite the depression" was adopted at a luncheon yesterday afternoon of the Children's Welfare Federation of New York City, held at the Fraternity Clubs Building.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP). -- Helen Hayes, who created the title role in "The Good Fairy" on last season's stage, has played a real life drama in which her husband's first wife alleged she acted a much less generous part.

Having nothing in particular to disclose is a handicap to the author of "Blue Monday," which was acted at the Provincetown last evening. He is Benson Inge, one of the old Henry Street boys. Although his first play arrives at no conclusions and appears to have no artistic reason for being, it reveals a knowledge of people and it is daintily staged and acted.

Education should be a far broader undertaking for vocational or professional life, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said last night at the commencement exercises of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson.

BERLIN, June 2. -- Chancellor Franz von Papen's Cabinet -- Germany's new "government of national concentration," which is chiefly notable for its lack of representation of any of the liberal elements in the Reich -- was sworn in by President von Hindenburg tonight, held its first session and formally took hold.

At the commencement exercises of the Fieldston School, the secondary-school unit of the Ethical Culture Schools, at Fieldston Road and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, diplomas will be presented this morning to ninety graduates, by John L. Elliott, head of the ethics department.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- The slim figure of Vernon Gomez blocked the Athletics' upward drive today, the Yankees rebounding from yesterday's double defeat to take the third game of the series, 5 to 1.

A general strike of 19,000 elevator constructors in the United States and Canada against operations of New York elevator manufacturers was threatened yesterday in an ultimatum addressed to the Elevator Manufacturers Association by the International Union of Elevator Constructors.

SWEETSBURG, Que., June 2 (AP). -- Canadian authorities issued warrants today for the arrest of six Americans charged With crossing the international line illegally last night and abducting Armand Lelanne from his home on the Quebec side of the border.
CHICAGO, June 2. -- California, Maine and Pennsylvania will sit right up front at the Republican National Convention.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 2. -- Five high-rigged Columbia shells were propelled up and down a four-mile stretch of the Hudson today as some fifty Lion sweep-swingers braved the rough water to engage in two workouts in preparation for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20.
STOCKHOLM, Juno 2. -- Assar Gabrielsson, managing director of the Swedish Match Company, told the writer today he believed the company would come through the present difficulties without bankruptcy.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- With his army revolver lying close by, Dr. Orlando H. Petty, former Director of Public Health of Philadelphia and World War hero, was found shot to death late today in a bedroom of his home.

Fishing captains returning to New Suffolk, L.I., last night reported that good quantities of porgies were taken by their parties, who were out chiefly for weakfish. Averaging from one pound and a half to two and one-half pounds, the porgies are now plentiful in Peconic Bay.

Among the passengers arriving today on the United States liner Leviathan, from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, are George Jessel, actor; Maynard Williams, staff correspondent of the National Geographio Magazine; Axtel J. Byles, president of the Tide Water Oil Company, and Mrs. Byles. Others include the following:

The so-called Glass bill, just proposed in the Senate as a substitute for the Goldsborough bill, lately voted by the House, has the somewhat unusual distinction of being described by the Senators who offered it, as both unnecessary and in present circumstances unworkable.

ASTOR, Kashmir, June 2. -- We have reached Astor after having made a successful crossing over the Burzil Pass with our ponies. Ours is the first horse caravan to cross this season, as the pass is not yet regarded as open to any but foot traffic.

PARIS, June 2.-- The trend was Irregularly bigher on the Bourse today. Yesterday's rally was not sustained these being even a slight reaction from the sharp upward movement in prices. Such leaders as Suez Canal. Lyonnaise des Eaux, the electricals, Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch, Kuhlman, Pechiney and Citroen fell below yestrday's quotations.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was 52,081,000,000, an increase of $76,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,157,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 2. -- Ninety-one sports awards today were authorized by the board of control of the Yale University Athletic Association, including seven minor Y's to members of the undefeated varsity golf team and twenty to the members of the lacrosse team.

Continued progress toward the $1,000,000 mark in cash contributions in the block-aid campaign for unemployment relief by the Block Community Organization was indicated yesterday with the announcement of collections of $36,761,49 for the ninth week of the campaigin.

A former airplane factory on the edge of the East River at Thirtyfirst Street took on the aspect of Coney Island in mid-Summer yesterday as the Boys' Fair, under the direction of the Madison Square Boys' Club, got off to a blatant start. The noise will continue for two more days.

LONDON, June 3 (AP). -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, carrying the big silver bowl she won for leading the qualifying field in the women's British golf tournament, will sail for home on the Berengaria tomorrow, with others of the American group which came over to defeat an English side in a team match and play in the championship.

Wall Street celebrated the formation of the $100,000,000 investing corporation by staging, in advance of the announcement, a series of buying demonstrations which lifted prices in the bond market sensationally and produced a sharp advance in all divisions of the stock market.

After a nine-hour discussion, a General Sessions jury which heard a perjury charge against John C. Weston, former Acting Assistant District Attorney in the Women's Court, reported its inability to arrive at a verdict at 4 o'clock yesterday morning and was discharged by Judge Collins.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- Attacking the popular belief that a person who commits suicide must have been "pathologically depressed" before undertaking self-destruction, Dr. Gregory Zilboorg of New York told a joint meeting of the American Psychiatric Association and the American Psychoanalytic Association here today that suicidal trends often took root in early childhood.

Except for the increased activity in bankers' acceptances, with the supply about matching the brisk demand during the forenoon, there was no other development of importance in the money market. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and commercial paper quotations were all unchanged, in quiet trading.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3. -- Dennis Goldstein, guiding his heavy express truck along George's Road on the outskirts of Dayton, near here, just before dawn today, got to thinking it was going to be a warm June 3 -- a record-breaker.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- An offering of $20,000,000 of 5 per cent city bonds, the highest interest rate paid since just after the World War, attracted subscriptions totaling only $107,500 today. Banking syndicates failed to bid, and the issue was immediately placed on sale to the general public "over the counter" in the city treasurer's office.

Formation of a corporation with initial funds of $100,000,000 subscribed by twenty leading New York banking institutions for the purpose of buying bonds and other securities was announced yesterday by Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- House Democrats pledged themselves, in a four-hour caucus late today, to support the Garner $2,321,500,000 relief bill. Now they plan to push the bill through the House Tuesday, under the strictest rules adopted since the Underwood tariff bill was passed in 1916.

PARIS, June 3. -- In the same manner as yesterday the French press continued today to deal skeptically with the proposed world economic conference in London which would ignore as world economic factors tariffs, reparations and intergovernmental debts.
Flying through a twilight of freezing fog mingled with storm clouds and possibly rain, Stanislaus F. Hausner, Polish-American pilot, was on his way over the Atlantic last night bound for Warsaw.

DANVILLE, Ill., June 3. -- Passage of the concurrent bill for the revision of the Federal bankruptcy law to provide an efficient process for corporate reorganization is the only alternative to liquidation at an enormous sacrifice as a remedy for the present condition of industry and commerce, Thomas D. Thacher, Solicitor General of the United States, declared today at the annual dinner here of the Illinois State Bar Association.

The strongest, although not the active, bond market of the year on the Stock Exchange, brought about yesterday recoveries of one to dozen points in domestic corporation issues, notably rails, and gains of 1 to 5 points in many representative foreign loans.

Borrowings by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange were reduced last month by $73,619,440, or from $379,016,662 on April 30 to $300,397,222 on May 31, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange. The decrease, which reflected heavy liquidation of securities last month, brought these loans to the lowest level since the Exchange began to compile the records.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 3. -- Six of the Interclub yachts sailed today in the first of the series of Friday afternoon races of the Larchmont Yacht Club, and A.F. Broderick's Bozo defeated E.H. Marks's Bee over four miles by exactly one minute. E.A. Hodge's Barbara was third, seventeen seconds after Bee.

Although the plans for a strongly equipped investing corporation under banking auspices were not announced until after the close of the markets, this highly important development was foreshadowed yesterday by a rather violent advance in bonds and by an impressive if less enthusiastic rise in share prices on the Stock Exchange.
HOLLYWOOD, June 3 (AP).--A. boy was born today to May McAvoy, former motion picture actress. Her husband Is Maurica Cleary, a broker.

To the Editor of The New york Times: May we reply to the letter signed by J. Rosenthal in behalf of the Rumanian Embassy, to which he is technical counselor, denying the torture of a Zionist leader named Samson Bronstein in the town of Yedinez, as reported by Unser Zeit, released by the Jewish Telegraphic Agency on May 27, and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES the following day?

Vittorio Giannini of Philadelphia has received the Horatio Parker fellowship in musical composition for the American Academy in Borne under the direction of Felix Lamond, according to an announcement by the Academy. The fellowship includes a stipend of $2,000 a year for three years, with residence and studio provided free at the Academy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3. -- Declaring that "the Red Top training exaggerates the importance of crew as a sport and is out of place in a college" the Harvard Crimson, undergraduate daily, today attacked four-mile college crew racing.

The annual commencement of Stevens Institute of Technology will be held this afternoon in the William Hall Walker Gymnasium at Castle Point, Hoboken, Degress of Mechanical Engineer will be awarded to eighty-five members of the graduating class and degrees of Master of Science will be presented to seven graduate students.

Drastic action against despotic control of unions by labor leaders was taken yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer when, in a sweeping decision, he granted lull relief on all complaints of usurpation of membership rights charged by 630 members of Local 125, International Union of Operating Engineers, in a suit against John Possehl, their general president, and officers of the local.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- In an excruciatingly close match that was not decided until the last set of the final doubles contest, the New England Sears Cup team, winner of the trophy each year since it was put up in 1925 by Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston, was eliminated by the representatives of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association today on the turf courts Of the Germantown Cricket Club.

Invitations have been extended to six countries to enter army teams in the forty-seventh annual exhibition of the National Horse Show, to be held in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 9-15 inclusive, according to an announcement made yesterday by Reginald W. Rives, secretary and treasurer of the National Horse Show Association of America.

After a further improvement had carried July contracts to 5.30 cents a pound, or 30 points above the low levels of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back yesterday $1 a bale and closed with losses of 12 to 16 points. Covering in the preceding two days had weakened the technical position of the market, and when wheat dropped a cent a bushel professional reselling disclosed few buying orders.

Three thoroughbred racehorses, as well as other live stock and hundreds of articles of all descriptions, will be sold at the annual fair and tea next Friday afternoon at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney in Manhasset, L.I. The event, now in its fifteenth year, will benefit the Babies' Milk Fund of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Seldom has the grain trade been in such "a pessimistic frame of mind as it was after today's close of the Board of Trade. The action of the stock market was ignored by wheat operators most of the day.

VIENNA, June 3. -- Negotiations of the Austrian Government with the British and American creditors of the Creditanstalt regarding the repayment of 570,000,000 lent to the bank in short-term credits and "frozen" for two years by a later agreement, reached a critical stage today.

Ten steamships of an aggregate total gross tonnage of 206,628 were tied up yesterday at the Chelsea piers of the Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company, setting a new high mark for the accommodations, according to the pier operators. The piers include numbers 58 to 62 and extend along the North River from West Sixteenth Street to Twenty-third Street.

Although the Chorus Equity Association reported a decrease in membership, the financial deficit "was amazingly small in view of the tremendous unemployment as the result of less musical comedy activity," it was announced yesterday afternoon at the twelfth annual meeting of the organization at its headquarters, 110 West Forty-seventh Street.

The sales of Walter B. Pitkin's "A Short Introduction to the History of Human Stupidity" have increased since the book's price was raised from $3.50 to $5, Simon Schuster, its publishers, report. It was this firm that found possibilities in the writings of Will Durant, whose work thay discovered in the little blue books of Haldeman-Julius, retailing at 5 cents each.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 3. -- Following the full-dress military and naval review at the dockyard today in honor of King George's birthday, Governor Cubitt and Lady Cubitt entertained tonight at a banquet at Government House. Graham Kemper, American Consul; the Lord Bishop, the Chief Justice, the heads of civil departments and military officers were among those present.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Officials of leading railroads are drafting a list of reforms which they believe necessary to the restoration of their industry's credit, it was disclosed yesterday. It is planned to use this material in outlining improvements the railroads may effect for themselves and others for which they must depend on the force of public opinion.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- With the "on-to-Washington" parade of war veterans demanding bonus payment gaining recruits from coast to coast, the police of the capital today served notice that their role as hosts was being overplayed and the end was in sight.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Worthington Bull are at the New Weston.

Samuel Seabury promised yesterday to supply Governor Roosevelt with a copy of the official record of the Hofstadter committee proceedings against Mayor Walker, together with "an analysis" of the testimony, "as early next week as is possible."

LONDON, June 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, daughter of a wealthy knight, was arrested tonight and charged with the murder of Michael Scott Stephen, socially prominent young man who was found shot to death early Tuesday in her West End flat.

An issue of refunding and improvement mortgage 6 per cent gold bonds of the Staten Island Edison Corporation, due on June 14, 1933, is to be offered in the amount of $7,424,000 in exchange for a like amount of 3 per cent gold notes of the corporation due on June 15 next, par for par, plue $10 in cash for each $1,000 note exchanged.

GENEVA, June 3. -- Censorship of all kinds was denounced by Senator de Brouckere of Belgium today in the arms conference commission which is considering moral disarmament. He made a strong impression in attacking the Polish proposals, which to him amounted to governmental control of theatres, nooks and radio stations.

The Brunton Piano Company, Andrew Brunton, president, sold to Raymond Van Riper of North Arlington the Booraem Building, a three-story brick store and office structure on a plot 81 by 39 feet at 116-24 Newark Avenue, northeast corner of Grove Street, Jersey City.

With the publication of the report of the Board of Transportation, rejecting the four proposals for private operation of the new subway, straight-out municipal operation, long threatened, moves a step nearer. Chairman DELANEY and his advisers deemed excessive the fee demanded by the one company which had put in a formal bid.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reply to the letter of Bupgoyne Hamilton in your issue of June 2, headed "All or Nothing"? This letter refers to an article in THE TIMES concerning the Beer for Prosperity Campaign, Inc.

The possibility of having "electrical fireworks" for public displays, as a result of the recent development of new sources of light, was predicted yesterday by S.G. Hibben, manager of the commercial engineering department of the Westinghouse Lamp Company at the Summer Lighting Conference of the Electrical Association of New York, held at the head-quarters of that organization in the Grand Central Palace.

Although new State and municipal bonds scheduled for award next week amount to only $12,210,423, compared with $32,800,741 this week, the comparison is tempered by the fact that of this week's total $20,000,000 consisted of obligations of the city of Philadelphia for which bankers here declined to bid and for which they virtually had decided not to bid when the city's financing was first discussed.

When Charlotte L. Schierenbeck and others of her family sold 619 11th St. to Irving Danker the latter gave back a purchase-money mortgage for $3,500, due in five years, at 6 per cent, and subject to a first mortgage for $5,000, due Oct. 14, 1934, at 5 1/2 per cent, held by the Title Guarantee and Trust Co.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3. -- Five boatloads of Columbia oarsmen fought the waters of the Hudson River in another stormy practice session late today and when they returned to their Krum Elbow quarters shortly before twilight there was a conviction in camp that Coach Rich Glendon would send some of the boats over the course against the watch tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- lf any foreign government fails to under-stand that no world accord on an effective program for economic reconstruction can come until after the American general elections in November, the fault lies in the chancelleries. All Ambassadors to Washington thoroughly comprehend the operation of the American political system to that end and have regretfully informed their governments that such is the case.

Fourteen liners will leave for foreign ports today with 8,000 passengers, the banner sailing this year. Of those departing, 75 per cent are bound for Europe. Among those to sail today on the Ile de France of the French Line for Havre via Plymouth are Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Miss Anne Morgan, Mrs. Bourke Cockran, Mr. and Mrs. Eustis Paine.

Pleading ill health, which has prevented him from giving his full time and attention to his team, John J. McGraw, outstanding figure in baseball for twoscore years, yesterday resigned as manager of the New York Giants, a post he had held for thirty years.

If Japanese militarism is really the power behind the new National Cabinet, it has seen fit to select for its spokesman a Premier not in the least addicted to the clipped and biting utterance of the traditional Junker statesman. Admiral SAITO'S statement on foreign policy before the Diet was mildness itself on the subject of war scares in Siberia when compared with the tremendous lambasting in which the official Soviet press has recently indulged.

Lew Brown and Ray Henderson, song writers and musical show authors, have formed an independent producing firm and will offer as their first production a revue to be presented on Broadway in September, in was announced yesterday. Two other shows, both musical comedies, also are on their schedule for next season.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- Henry Louis Gehrig's name today tool rank in baseball's archives along with Bobby Lowe and Ed Delehanty, the only other sluggers who, in more than half a century of recorded diamond battles, ever hit four home runs in one major league game.

The Brooklyn Dodgers made an auspicious start in their American Lacrosse League campaign by defeating the New York Yankees at Ebbets Field last night, 14 to 4. A crowd of 3,000 persons turned out to witness the struggle, which was the first box lacrosse contest ever staged in Brooklyn.

VALETTA, Malta, June 3. -- Religious peace was restored in Malta today after two years' dispute between church and State by the publication of a pastoral letter from the Bishops of Malta and Gozo, revealing the terms of an apology by Lord Strickland, Prime Minister, and its acceptance by Rome.

Industrial research is leading the way to recovery from the depression and to ultimate prosperity, Broderick Haskell Jr. of the Guaranty Company told an audience of scientists last night at a symposium on "The Economics of Research" held under the auspices of the New York section of the American Chemical Society in the McGraw-Hill Auditorium.
Twelve homes were sold last month In the New Park City development at Allwood, N.J., Charles H. Reis, head of Reis Allwood Homes. Inc., reported yesterday.

GUESTROW, Mecklenburg, Germany, June 3 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler is ready to offer a coalition of his National Socialists with the powers behind the new Cabinet, he told a crowd of 25,000 voters here in a campaign speech last night.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- New York City in 1930 had 3,187,459 workers 10 years of age and over employed in what the Census Bureau describes as "gainful occupations." An analysis of New York occupation statistics by the bureau today placed these workers at 46 per cent of the city's 1930 population of 6,930,446 and 54.8 per cent of the population over 10 years old.

CARLISLE, Pa., June 3. -- Dr. Karl Tinsley Waugh was inducted today as the nineteenth president of Dickinson College, and in a speech he defended the position of the cultural college in the field of higher education.
Sales of housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx constituted the outstanding realty activity in the metropolitan area yesterday.

Criticism of the Queens Park Department for procrastination in making immediate arrangements that would be necessary to open the city's new $530,000 bathing pavilion in Jacob Riss Park, Rockaway Beach, on July 4, as scheduled, was expressed by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New Tork City, Inc., in a letter sent yesterday to Albert C. Benninger, Queens Park Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Differences of views developed between Secretary of State Stimson and the House Foreign Affairs Committe today over the advisability of the calling of an international monetary conference by the United States while the London world economic conference is pending because monetary problems presumably will be considered at London.

Responsibility for increasing the costs of the New York City Employes Retirement System by permitting employes to retire upon accident disability claims instead of the ordinary retirement basis was placed upon Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the Mayor, and his associate physicians in a report submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate.

Algebra left young William Beal in the lurch last Winter at the Lincoln School, but art has come to his rescue. It looked a little gloomy for William in January after an unsuccessful combat with mathematics, but everything is smoothed out now and the Lincoln School has a new set of murals which yesterday still smelt of fresh paint.
PARIS, June 3. -- Gregory Mangin took one set from Henri Cochet in their match in the semi-finals of the French tennis championships today, making a hard fight in the face of undoubted superiority.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: In THE TIMES of May 24 was a dispatch from Danzig in which considerable prominence was given to the statements of Acting Pnesident Wiercinski of the Danzig Senate.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., June 3. -- Joan Davisson, daughter of Mrs. Paul Pryible of Locust Valley, won the horsemanship trophy for children under 12 years this afternoon in the first day's event of the fifth annual Glen Head Junior Horse Show being held in the new show ring on the Vincent F. Clark estate here.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 3. -- Trial of a suit for $7,000,000 brought by William C. Durant of Deal and New York City against Benjamin Block Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, was started here today before Circuit Court Judge Rulif V. Lawrence without a jury.

The unanimity of the American and British oil companies at the international oil conference,-which ended on Thursday without reaching an agreement with the Soviet oil industry on ways of stabilizing world oil markets outside the United States, was stressed by Robert I.

BALTIMORE, June 3 (AP). -- Reading unleashed a fifteen-hit barrage to take the second game of the series from Baltimore today, 11 to 4. Buzz Arlett hit his twenty-first home run of the season in the fourth.

The letters written by the international leaders of the World War period in comment and criticism on the ideas which gradually developed into those which stand behind the League of Nations form the bulk of a two-volume work called "Development of the League of Nations Idea," just published by Macmillan.

SIMLA, India, June 3. -- The report of the Marquess of Lothian's franchise committee is being studied with intense interest here. Thus far the Nationalist press has treated it much more kindly that it did the Simon report.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- President Hoover will hold important conferences on the economic situation at his Rapidan camp tomorrow. Those with whom he will confer are the members of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, and Paul Bestor of the Federal Farm Loan Board.

In Les Annales M. PIERRE BOST reports an interview with M. PAUL VALERY, exemplar of pure poetry, critic, mathematician, philosopher. Who would have expected to find that subtle and accomplished Academician discoursing of politics:

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- A second application for a loan of $3,898,629 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was filed by the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad with the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

PARIS, June 3. -- Paris staged a celebration today for Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, and, although it may have failed to equal in size and intense excitement her memorable reception four years ago, there was no less warmth or admiration. The crowds were a bit smaller but just as enthusiastic, and the same police official was handling them.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP). -- The Henry M. Leland collection of Lincolnia was sold at auction here last night al prices regarded by collectors as being "very good, considering the times."

The sixty-fourth running of the rich and historic Belmont Stakes, inaugurated at Jerome Park in 1867, will be the feature at Belmont Park this afternoon. Ten have been entered overnight, and if all go to the post the starting field will be the largest in years, since there has not been so open a race in any of the recent renewals.

To Hold August Fur Sales. Indications are stores which have featured August fur sales in previous years win stage these events this year, although no hopes are entertained that they will be successful in a big way. The View was expressed that a fair percentage of customers will respond to the deferred payment terms on coats to justify stores taking steps to obtain additional volume.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 3. -- With an excellent entry and a fine attendance during the afternoon competitions, the annual Tuxedo Horse Show began its two-day session today in the picturesque show ring under the hills of beautiful Tuxedo Park, just now florally perfect.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP). -- Goose Goslin stepped into the breach with a powerful home run blow into the right-field stands in the tenth inning to give St. Louis a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox today.

Former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, a pillar in the Tammany organization, has been designated "czar" of the cleaning and dyeing industry of New York at a salary of $50,000 a year, it became known yesterday. He will seek to "bring order out of chaos" in what members call "a racketeer-infested industry."

SCIENTISTS are all agog over a discovery made by W.F.F. Oppenoorth, Dutch engineer with the Java Geological Survey. Excavating in the Solo River Valley, near Ngandong, Java, he turned up a cluster of five more or less human skulls, and the report of Professor M. Elliot Smith, British anthropologist, is to the effect that the skulls are "representative of a hitherto unknown species of fossil man."

ST. ALBANS, L.I., June 3. -- Another noted golfer has followed the lead of George Von Elm and Jerry Travers by deserting the amateur ranks. This time it is T. Philip Perkins, former British amateur champion, who hereafter will capitalize his skill in the royal and ancient game.

Dr. JOHN H. MACCRACKEN, announcing for the American Council of Education the results or the survey of the attendance and financial state of our colleges and universities, sounds a hopeful note. The questionnaire included only 250 institutions of the more than 500 that are accredited and tout 168 responded.
The entire eligible personnel of the Dry Dock Savings Institution has subscribed to a cooperative retirement annuity program to be administered by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3. -- Two hundred and thirteen degrees will be conferred by New Jersey College for Women at the annual commencement here tomorrow morning. The degree of Bachelor of Arts will be conferred upon ninety-two undergraduates, that of Bachelor of Letters upon seventy-seven and that of Bachelor of Science upon forty-four.
CHICAGO, June 3 (AP). -- On the basis of the law of averages, the Republican National Convention would be over by the night of June 17 and the Democratic National Convention about noon July 2.

The necessity for convening the Jews of the world to consider the complex problems now facing them was emphasized yesterday at an informal discussion under the direction of several leaders of the American Jewish Congress held in the Town Hall Club.

DETROIT, June 3 (AP). -- Cleveland took both ends of a double-header, from the Detroit Timers today, winning the first, 3 to 1, and then pounding four Detroit hurlers for a 10-to-7 victory in the nightcap.

The exhibition that opened yesterday in the American Room of the Balzac Galleries, 449 Park Avenue, is oddly mixed and possesses, as an exhibition, little character. There are some good things in it, however, especially the etchings by Joseph Margulies.

Another home run by Hack Wilson, his third in two days and his eighth of the season, served only to tie the score once with the Braves yesterday and Max Carey's athletes lost a ninth-inning decision, 6 to 5, with Ben Cantwell, third Braves' hurler of the contest, getting credit for the triumph at Ebbets Field.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP). -- Tony Piet's long home run gave the Pirates a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs in eleven innings today. With none on and none out, Tony cracked Jakie May's first pitch to the flagpole and then jogged home.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 3 (Canadian Press). -- An increase in the rapidity with which money was turned over in Canada in the three months ended with April bespeak an improving business situation and increasing confidence by the public, says the Department of Trade and Commerce in a statistical review issued tonight.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 3. -- The Aga Khan's Udaipur, an outsider, today won the 150th renewal of The Oaks, classic race for 3-year-old fillies, before a great crowd on the Downs which Included King George and other members of the royal family.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Senate leaders, embarrassed by three days of fruitless debate on the economy bill, tonight planned to force a decision tomorrow on one of the three proposals for reducing the Federal payroll-a flat percentage reduction, a sliding scale or the President's furlough plan.

The dollar volume of checks exchanged at the principal clearing houses of the country in May totaled $20,097,852,071. This was a drop of 9.4 per cent from the April turnover and 45.4 per cent below that for May last year. It was likewise the smallest in more than fifteen years.

To the Editor of The New TorK Times: Some of the world's biggest philanthropists and outstanding statesmen have dreamed of instituting back-to-the-land movements. Governor Roosevelt has applied the ideas of regional planning to the problem and really made a beginning with a small group of families under the State relief administration.

Patrick McGovern, building contractor, who has avoided testifying twice as a witness in State investigations, was held in contempt of Federal court yesterday and sentenced to sixty days in the House of Detention as a result of his failure to answer questions unevasively before a Federal grand jury.

TORONTO, June 3 (AP). -- Toronto won two games from Rochester today. It took the first, 3 -- 2, in ten innings, Frank Doljack, former Detroit Tiger, driving the ball over the left field fence with one out to break up a tight pitching contest. It won the second, 5 -- 4, by overcoming a one-run lead in the last inning.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 3. -- Acting immediately upon an application filed by Kenneth M. Keafe. John S. Harris, Henry Hart and Fred P. Hayward, the Florida Supreme Court today granted an order enjoining the city of St. Petersburg from using any of its revenue from 1931 tax collections for any purpose whatsoever except paying interest on bonds of the city.
NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP). -- Jersey City defeated Newark, 4 to 3, today in the opening game of the series. It was the fourth successive victory for Jersey City over the Bears.

Cardinal Hayes will sail for Ireland on Monday, June 13, at noon on the De Grasse of the French Line, which leaves from Pier 57, at the foot of West Fourteenth Street, to attend the International Eucharistic Congress, which will be held in Dublin June 22-26.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- The Republican high command went to work in earnest today on the formulation of the prohibition plank, but the end of a round of conferences brought word that no conclusions had been reached.

While Wall Street was somewhat disappointed over the stock market's failure to respond with the same enthusiasm that the bond market did to yesterday's developments bearing on the securities situation, the day's net results were regarded as distinctly encouraging.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- The last of this session's appropriations bills was used in the House today as a starting point for vigorous partisan political speeches and predictions as to what the party conventions meeting this month will and will not do.

ROME, June 3. -- An impassioned plea for international cooperation to lift the world out of economic depression and assure to the people peace and employment was made to the Senate today by Dino Grandi, the Foreign Minister.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Delegates to the National Conference for the Reduction of Government Expenditures, representing 568 organizations in thirty-nine States, organized a nation-wide movement today to unite local groups of business men and industrialists, farmers, property owners and others in waging war against waste of public funds and high taxes.

MOSCOW, June 3. -- The Soviet Government's earnest determination to revive direct peasant trade in foodstuffs upon the old-fashioned private-profit basis was underlined in a long article published nation-wide today over the signature of the Soviet Union's peasant President, Mikhail I. Kalinin.

CLEVELAND, June 3. -- After waiting in vain several hours for a freight train which they hoped would take them to Pittsburgh, several hundred "bonus marchers" swarmed over the Pennsylvania Railroad yards here tonight vowing they would stop all activity until their demands were met.

BERLIN, June 3. -- President von Hindenburg decided tonight to sign a Presidential decree dissolving the Reichstag, which less than a month ago gave the now vanished Bruening Government a decisive majority.

When the Cunarder Aquitania arrived here yesterday ship's officers told of having encountered seven schools of whales Thursday night about 170 miles east of the Nantucket Lightship. There were eight or nine of the big mammals, ranging from thirty to thirty-five feet in length, in each of the schools which were heading north for cool water.

Commissioner Thomas H. Beck of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game advocates later planting of trout in the streams of his State to insure better fishing. He is also convinced that if the State Legislature were to grant the board power to regulate fishing seasons according to climatic conditions the sportsmen would reap additional benefits.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3. -- The Navy lacrosse team has been withdrawn from the Olympic trials, it was announced today by Lieut. Commander Lynde D. McCormick, aide to the superintendent of the academy.

Summer came with a rush last night to West Forty-fifth Street-came, specifically, to the Bijou Theatre, where there was deposited "Under the title of "Hired Husband" and the name of August L. Stern the first of the warm weather errors. Its further billing, "a sterling comedy in three acts," is said to contain, in addition to a deceptive boast, a hint of the auspices under which "Hired Husband" braved Times Square.

There is a ring of direct courage in the challenge by Governor ROOSEYELT which must hearten his friends. He lets the public know that he is not running away from any issue which may involve his relations with Tammany. He will neither delay nor dodge if the question is squarely put up to him.

Mrs. Catherine P. Johnson, 70 years old, sister of the late Patrick J. Carlin, builder, and who for eight years since the death of her husband has been living in seclusion in her sixteen-room brownstone home at 41 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, was bound and gagged yesterday morning by two men who ransacked the house from cellar to attic.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3. -- After trailing by four strokes with only eight holes left to play, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol, the defending champion, came home in 41 at the Montclair Golf Club today to score an 88 and win the fifty-four-hole closed championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association by three shots.

Engineering contracts awarded during the last week in May, totaling $14,953,000. show a considerable drop from the May weekly average awards of $26,385,000, Engineering News-Record reports. The cumulative value of all heavy construction contracts from the first of the year to date is $469,279,000.

Mrs. John D. Hertz's 4-year-old Daughter of Stimulus, Risque, which won the Alabama last year at Saratoga, gained her second victory of the meeting when she was first in the Minerva Purse at Belmont Park yesterday.

ST. ALBANS, L.I., June 3. -- The hero of the first two rounds of the Long Inland amateur championship at the St. Albans Golf Club today was Fred I. Hamm, a member of the home club, and a man who confines his golf largely to week-end play.
ATHENS, June 3. -- The government of Premier Alexander Papanastasiou, which was formed on May 25, resigned today at its first appearance before Parliament, without asking for a vote of confidence.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 3. -- There is every possibility of a contest during the coming week-end between the Vanitle and the Weetamoe, two of the big sloops that were contenders for the honor of defending America's Cup. The Weetamoe, now owned by Frederick H. Prince, has been at anchor in Brenton's Cove for several days.

The ninth annual commencement of the Dalton Academy was held yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the school at 108 East Eighty-ninth Street. Twenty-one students received diplomas. Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, was the principal speaker and Miss Helen Parkhurst, headmistress of the academy, presented the diplomas.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 3 (AP). -- Evergold, promising member of the Shandon Farm Stable, capped a field day for long shots over the muddy Washington Park track today by defeating a fast field over seven furlongs in the feature event.

John J. McGraw was hailed as s great influence in the development of baseball as tributes were paid yesterday to the veteran manager who resigned his post with the Giants. Eival pilots did not hesitate to characterize him as the game's fore-most manager and all agreed that his passing from active participation would be a blow to the sport.

TOKYO, June 3. -- The plight of the Japanese farmer was brought sharply to the attention of the Diet today with the presentation of a petition signed by 32,000 farmers asking the government to grant 50,000,000 yen ($16,405,000 at yesterday's quotation) to aid in emigration to Manchuria.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The conference committee's formal agreement on taxes was laid before the House at noon today, thus clearing the way for final action by Congress on the revenue bill.

LONDON, June 3. -- The stock markets generally were cheerful today, stimulated by a good deal of bear covering and the improvement in Wall Street yesterday. British Government funds, after an uncertain start, received renewed attention and scored rises.
CHICAGO, June 3. -- A crisis for 600,000 needy in Chicago and Cook County was averted today by prompt action of a "rescue committee" of business leaders.

MONTREAL, Que., June 3. -- Announcement is made here of the formation of the Canadian Foreign Credit Underwriters, Ltd., to aid Canadian exporters by providing a credit factor, including insurance against insolvency of foreign buyers.
PARIS, Saturday, June 4. -- Edouard Harriot succeeded Andre Tardien last night as head of the French Government and at 1:30 this morning he completed the formation o his Cabinet as follows:
Bill Terry in succeeding John McGraw as manager of the Giants replaces the man who brought him back into professional baseball after Terry had definitely quit at the age of 19.

Hope for improvement in general business conditions is seen in the adoption by the Senate of a plan for balancing the budget, but many business men and industrialists assert that, until banks lift their restrictions on credit, business will continue dull, according to the weekly reviews of trade and business.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP). -- A youthful former motion picture studio employe, whose name was "withheld by Buron Fitts, District Attorney, was held today for questioning in connection with the receipt of extortion letters by Marlene Dietrich, film actress, and another woman, threatening the lives of their children.

ST. LOUIS, June 3. -- Ernest E. Norris was appointed receiver for the Mobile Ohio Railroad today by Federal Judge Faris on petition of Gatch, Tennant Co., a St. Louis insurance agency, the railroad joining in the petition.

LONDON, June 3 (Canadian Press). -- Six centuries were recorded in cricket fixtures ending today, the highest total being achieved by Dal Davies of Glamorgan, playing against Essex at Cardiff. Davies had 175, beating his previous best total by four runs.
Honoris Causa in Kansas. What seems at first glance a contribution by Kansas to the Americana in which the sophisticated, delight, takes on with closer study a much more pleasing character.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 3 (AP). -- At least five lives were taken and about 700 homes washed away by a swirling flood that struck the sleeping city with little warning early today as the result of a deluge of six to ten inches of rain.

R. Stanley Dollar of San Francisco was elected president of the United States Lines Company of Nevada at a meeting in San Francisco early last week by representatives of the International Mercantile Marine Company, the Dollar Steamship Company and the Kenneth D. Dawson shipping interests, owners of the company.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Following is a summary of the tax bill in its final form, including the agreements reached in conference:

John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boat-builder who for weeks carried on his own "negotiations" for the return of the Lindbergh baby, is to be arraigned this morning in Flemington, N.J., on an indictment charging him with obstructing justice by giving false and misleading information.

Fourteen years to the day after they had abandoned the torpedoed liner President Lincoln 300 miles off France, two former American officers met on the United States liner Leviathan and recalled events of the day when they rowed together in a pitching lifeboat after watching their ship sink.

LONDON, June 3. -- Beginning next Monday, the experiment of presenting a play twice daily will be tried at the Ambassador Theatre, where "The Price of Wisdom," a comedy by Lionel Brown, will open with Irene Vanbrugh in the leading role. The scale of prices for tickets will he from 50 cents to $2.

A move to demand a cash settlement from American bankers as a prerequisite to any reorganization of the International Match Corporation or of the Kreuger Toll Company became known yesterday through a meeting of the independent protective committee for holders of Kreuger Toll debentures.

If the people of the United States have any passionate interest in the national party conventions of this month, they have no difficulty in hiding it. Bread and butter is a somewhat more absorbing object of reflection than partisan sound and fury.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP). -- Opposition to immediate full payments of veterans' compensation, except to the destitute, was voiced today by the National Executive Committee of the Disabled Veterans of Foreign Wars. A resolution to that effect was adopted by the committee meeting in national headquarters here.

While sitting with her fiance in his automobile parked at Oriental Point, near Manhattan Beach, in Brooklyn, Miss Helen Coop, 19 years old, a stenographer of 277 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, died suddenly last night. Examination by Dr. Rood of Coney Island Hospital later disclosed that her neck had been broken.

Prices receded yesterday, grains losing from a fraction to more than a cent, while cotton, sagged 12 to 16 points. Losses were also reported in coffee and rubber, with silk irregular. Sugar, cocoa and hides were firm. Yesterday's closing wholesale cash prices for commodities in the New York markets, unless otherwise noted, were:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The satisfaction which Controller Berry expressed concerning the way the taxpayers are meeting the 1932 levy does not presumably refer to the receipts of any one day, but rather to the total receipts up to and including May 31, the last day when taxes for the first half year may be paid without penalty.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- The Carley bill to authorize $15,500,000 for the purchase by the government of the Grand Central Station postoffice property at 452 Lexington Avenue, New York, was approved today by the House Buildings Committee.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 3. -- Mrs. Bill Terry was a very, very proud young woman today when she heard of her husband's appointment as manager of the New York Giants.

The George Washington High School will give three benefit performances of "The Chimes of Normandy" next week for the school's student relief fund to aid families of needy pupils in the neighborhood. There will be a matinee Tuesday at 3 P.M., and two evening performances on Wednesday and Thursday at 8:30 o'clock in the school auditorium, 192d Street and Audubon Avenue.

The issue of municipal operation of the new city subway system, beginning with the Eighth Avenue line, was placed squarely before Mayor Walker and the Board of Estimate yesterday in a report submitted by the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Two nationally known figures occupied the centre of the stage in the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's stock market inquiry today. John J. Raskoh, chairman, of the Democratic National Committee, and Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, testified, respectively, concerning transactions in General Motors stock and the flotation of Anaconda Copper stock by the National City Company.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- Federal officials in close touch with the country's finances today expressed "genuine pleasure" over the formation of a gigantic investment corporation in New York. The corporation was described by a high official in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as "a very desirable thing."

The monthly inder number of average prices, compiled by Dun's Review as of June 1, shows decrease during May of 2% per cent. The decline since the beginning of the present year has been 8 3/8 per cent. As compared with a year ago, the reduction is 11 5/8.

MEXICO CITY, June 4 (AP). -- Reports trickling into Mexico City over damaged communication systems said thousands were homeless in remote sections of the back country. Organizations of local relief commissions to speed aid to the victims was ordered by authorities.

Next week will bring the second of the huge one-day dog shows In this section, the event being the third venture of the Greenwich Kennel Club. It will be held on Saturday, June 18, on the field of the Greenwich Polo Club at Greenwich, Conn., with the net proceeds to be donated to the unemployed.

In "Black on White" the young author of "New Russia's Primer" has written a brief history of man's communication from the days of the first oral story tellers to modern paper and print. "What Time Is It?" is a history of man's devices for measuring time, from early sundials and water clocks to modern chronometers.

BOSTON, June 2. -- For more than two years the cotton textile industry, so long of fundamental importance to all New England and during the last decade of almost equal importance to a group of cotton States in the South, has been hard at work upon the problem of self-regulation for the general good.

PRIZES amounting to $25,000 are being offered by the Plymouth Motor Corporation in a contest for the best description in fifty words or less, of "How and why Plymouth patented floating power makes riding smoother." The contest begins today and closes on July 31.

A PLEASANT, very feminine little romance of a highly improbable, old-fashioned kind, A.E.R. Craig's new novel contains more beautiful women than are often found within a single volume. Two are Indian and two Scotch-English, the scenes being laid partly in India and partly in Scotland, with brief visits to England and the south of France.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Senate voted today to reduce all Federal salaries, except those of less than $1.000 a year, by 10 per cent for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The estimated saving will be $117,150,000, or $3,900,000 less than that recommended by the Appropriations Committee, which advocated a 10 per cent cut without exemptions.

THE blonde and radiant Ann Harding, who is the star of this week's "Westward Passage," started out in life as the daughter of an army officer stationed at the time of her birth in Fort Sam Houston, San Antonio, Texas.

A request that the city turn the new Eighth Avenue subway line over to either the B.M.T. or the Interborough for operation, pending the unification of all rapid transit lines, was sent to the Board of Transportation yesterday by William Kennedy Jr., president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

The receivership ordered on Friday for the Mobile Ohio Railroad may mean eventual severance of that line from the control of the Southern Railway, it was said in financial circles here yesterday. The Mobile Ohio came under the control of the Southern in 1901.
One thing Judge Seabury is bound to admit, and that is that Mayor Walker didn't hoard.

ANNAPOLIS. THE recent order that graduates of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis may not marry until two years after commencement will break a tradition of long standing. For years it has been the custom of a number of midshipmen o take wives in June Week, at the same time that they receive their commissions as ensigns.

MR. SHAY was inspired by two motives to write this biography of the man who discovered, ended and became master of the empire of the Incas. The first and perhaps the more potent of the two was the fact that Pizarro was a hero of his boyhood and has been ever since one of his personal enthusiasms.

BERLIN, May 26. -- Before discussing the chances of Eastern Europe in the Olympic Games, there is still one country which deserves to be mentioned and which is likely to figure in the scoring at Los Angeles -- Ireland. Ireland has many capable athletes and is not unlikely to do well with one of its boxing stars at the Olympics.

DURING coming weeks a great many motorists from New York and vicinity will be taking trips to the Pocono Mountains of Eastern Pennsylvania. These constitute one of the most beautiful and popular highland regions in the country, and are readily accessible from the metropolis, as they lie only about 100 miles west and may be reached over several excellent high-ways.

LONDON, June 4 (AP). -- Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, young London society woman, collapsed in Westminster Police Court today when she was formally charged with the slaying last Tuesday of Thomas William Scott Stephen, 26-year-old socially prominent Londoner.

A Thomas Paine Society. White the American people are building reproductions of Mount Vernon and Federal Hall, how many remember the anniversary of Thomas Paine's death? He died June 7, 1809. It was of him John Quincy Adams said, "Paine was the first factor in bringing about the Revolution."

The New York market, although representing only one-fourth of 1 per cent of the area of the United States, does over $6,800,000,000, or 13.6 per cent, of the country's annual retail trade of $50,000,000,000 according to a market study just completed by the promotion and research group of New York City newspapers.

The imponderables of the situation, with a force that is merciless for politicians and their shibboleths, is bringing the world closer to a showdown on war debts. In this development the operation of putting the situation up to the United States begins to appear as approaching with inevitable sureness.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 4. -- Mrs. Anna Johnson Pell-Wheeler of Princeton, mathematician, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Science at the annual commencement exercises of New Jersey College for Women held here today. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, conferred the degree.

The resignation of Chancellor Bruening at the request of President von Hindenburg raises sharply the question of the proper role of a titular Executive in a parliamentary system. However much the fact may seem to he belied by recent events, the President of the German Reich is a titular Executive.

QUEBEC, Que., June 4. -- Outside interests head Price Brothers Co., Ltd., oldest newsprint manufacturers in Canada, for the first time since 1820, when the concern was founded. Today at the annual meeting of shareholders Allan A. Aitken of London, brother of Lord Beaverbrook, British publisher, was chosen president.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4. -- Bunching its seven hits in three innings. Brown University's baseball team defeated Tufts College today, 6 -- 1. Tufts made two of its five hits off Humphries in the opening inning and these, with a base on balls, gave Tufts its only run.

CLEVELAND. IN the event of a deadlock over the Presidential nomination at the Democratic National Convention, the delegates will seek the "available man" from a notable roster. In this list, which includes favorite sons, avowed candidates, and men who have declined to put forward their claims as Presidential possibilities, the name of Newton Diehl Baker stands prominently.

BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP). -- Eight home runs featured the Reading Keys' 12-to-11 victory over the Orioles today. Manager Maisel played the game under protest after Manager Rowland of the Keys had been discovered in the stands following his ejection from the game by the umpire.

SCENES from the changeful, splendid pageant of English history. the thirteen short stories collected in Jeffery Farnol's new book, "Voices Prom the Dust," ere each illustrative of some specially notable period. A reincarnation theme holds them all together, for again and again do the man and maid whose first recounted meeting took place in the days when Britain was a Roman province meet and fall in love.
BUFFALO, June 2. -- The approach of the national campaign has not prevented various features of local politics from claiming their fair share of attention.

TOKYO, June 4. -- There is no friction between the governments of Japan and Russia that is likely to lead to serious consequences, General Sadao Araki, the Minister of War, told a secret session of the Diet today.

AN accelerated demand for copies of Du Maurier's "Trilby" might well accompany (and possibly really does attend) the artists' open-air carnival in Washington Square, closing tonight. The sidewalks are, for New York, unbelievably gay, "Bohemian" -- if the word retains, at this late date, any of its one-time color and piquantly magnetic charm.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The effect on the foreign trade of the United States of reduced purchasing power and increased import restrictions abroad was reflected in smaller April exports to twenty-four of the thirty-nine principal markets.

ONE of those manuscripts which have had their share of straying around from office to office has, they say, now come more or less to rest in the Shubert domain. It is Leo Perntz's "A Trip to Pressburg" (and that's not just another play about the newspaper business, either), which belonged first to the Ray-Miner Corporation and then to Arthur Lubin, who recently assigned his rights to Irving Lande.

AN immense crowd sits calmly in a theatre. Suddenly a maniac or some one who really thinks he smells smoke yells "Fire!" The entire audience rises. Those near the aisles make a dash for the doors. The rest follow, knocking down those in front of them.

LONDON, June 4. -- Prince's, Sandwich, where the British open championship will be played, starting Monday, is from a championship point of view a course without a history. The qualifying rounds were played there when the great event itself took place next door, at the Royal St. George's.

Solution to the problem of misleading comparative price claims in retail advertising lies in the thorough investigation and corrections of abuses on the basis of individual facts, H.J. Kenner, manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York, said here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 2. -- Members of Parliament have gone to their homes in the nine Provinces to report to their sovereign lords, the voters, on the business of the session. Four months have seen the work accomplished, and now the way is cleared for the imperial economic conference, which opens here on July 21.

BALTIMORE, June 4. -- After a free ride across the city with a police escort, the 400 veterans who arrived here last night from Chicago on their way to Washington today struck out on foot toward the capital, forty miles away.

The New York State Economic Council, with headquarters at 40 Wall Street, announces that it will submit a plan for dealing "adequately and effectively" with government obstacles to a revival of prosperity at a State-wide conference of business and professional leaders on June 10 in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

ARTISTICALLY speaking, this is by far the most outstanding and significant novel that has emerged from Soviet Russia in the course of these fourteen post-revolutionary years. True, although the American publishers do not say so, these 387 pages are only the beginning of a work which, apparently, is going to cover a very wide historical canvas depicting all of Peter the Great's life.
Faireno, a son of Chatterton and Minerva, owned by the Belair Stud of William Woodward, yesterday won the sixty-fourth running of the historic Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park.

LONDON, June 4. -- The announcement of the willingness of the United States to participate in the proposed world economic conference in London is discussed widely in newspapers here, The Times calling it "the best piece of news in weeks, more for what it implies than for what it actually says."

At a time when the security markets had just plumbed the lowest depths in a quarter of a century, twenty of New York's largest banks have chipped in $100,000,000 to provide the nucleus for the most ambitious investment pool ever organized.

PERFORMANCES of opera and ballet will be given under the direction of Mary Binney Montgomery in Fairmount Park, Philadelphia, on June 21 and 22 for the benefit of the Philadelphia Orchestra pension fund and Summer concerts fund.

Burmah Oil Company, Ltd. -- Year ended Dec. 31: Net income, after depreciation, income taxes, interest and other charges, u1,869,495, equivalent, after preference dividends, to 23.70 per cent on u6,868,256 ordinary stock, compared with u2.736,013, or 36.20 per cent on ordinary stock, in preceding year.
