MILAN, May, 21, 1932. IN reviewing the Scala Opera season just closed, something more than the usual ritual remarks are in order. It is no secret that the "Holy of Holies" of Italian opera finds itself, like many other operatic enterprises today, in a critical phase of its career.

TO GIVE authentic atmosphere in motion pictures, producers think nothing of sending men to various parts of the world or having the research departments of the studios spend weeks in obtaining what is wanted, whether it be the Chinese lettering on a railway coach, correct jungle modes, the interior of a Parisian cabaret, or the stately grounds and facade of an English mansion and the decorations of the rooms.

THE man whose image of George Washington has been stamped upon the consciousness of his countrymen so indelibly that in vain are all the efforts of the seekers after truth to efface it in favor of what they conceive to be a more exact likeness has at least this to his advantage: In an age of eminent portraitists his reputation for "taking a likeness" was generally acknowledged even by his severest critics.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 4 (AP). -- This flood-swept city laid plans today to erect a canvas camp for its homeless, while Oklahoma counted at least eight dead from high water.

One or the leading New York City scholastic tennis teams this season was the Poly Prep unit of Brooklyn which won all twelve of its matches to stretch the school's string of net victories to twenty-one. Last year the Poly team closed its campaign with a nine-match winning streak.

BROADCASTERS are enlivening their studios. They are ripping away some of the sound-absorbing materials that "deaden" the walls and ceilings. They have discovered that the old idea of heavily draped walls is all wrong. Station WOR is the latest to drop the idea of "dead" studios.
PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- Captain Bill Graupner starred as Pennsylvania wound up its baseball season with an 11-8 victory over Dartmouth at Franklin Field today.

Drastic reduction in present tariff rates was urged here yesterday by Charles T. Riotte. executive secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., as the only ready means of reviving world trade and thereby improving present economic conditions.

QUEBEC, June 4 (Canadian Press). -- Lord Beaverbrook, British publisher, at the annual meeting today of Price Brothers Co., newsprint manufacturers, laid before shareholders a plan of reorganization. Formal approval will be sought later.

IQUITOS, Amazonas, Peru, May 16 (By mail via Guayaquil). -- After having covered the last 300 miles of the Napo River in our outboard motor boat in the record time of fifteen hours, we are back to pavements, motor cars and ice, to say nothing of a famous product of Munich that seems to go very well in combination with the last-named luxury.

WASHINGTON. ON the eve of the convening of the major national party conventions prohibition looms as a paramount issue. Both conventions will go on record in favor of "cut-to-the-bone economy"; both will probably soft-pedal foreign affairs and -- after each has blamed the other -- declare in strong words the necessity for a balanced budget.

THIS is the most delightful collection of true folk tales and legends that the reviewer has seen in some time. Mr. Applegate knew his Mew Mexico intimately. He had, moreover, the story-teller's delight in a good tale, and he went in search of material where material was as rich as the soil itself.

CONSTANCE LINDSAY SKINNER writes of frontier life and characters with a sure knowledge and a fine imaginative understanding. It is easy to choose a period and assemble facts for an historical background; it is another matter altogether to create living human beings to move across this background.

William Humphreys, 50 years old, a coin-matcher and confidence-game artist of such established reputation that it really is not fair to play tricks on him, had the distinction in Jefferson Market Court yesterday of being the latest victim of the pickpocket squad's new disguise, the "plus fours college boy" get-up.

THE broadcasters are preparing to spray a barrage of political oratory into the American air. For the third time the national political conventions will be microphoned. A radio set is a ticket to eavesdrop on the Chicago arena in which the two major parties will nominate candidates for the Presidency this month.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 2. -- Two ominous questions overshadow the political situation in Utah almost to the exclusion of other considerations. They involve United States Senator Reed Smoot and Governor George H. Dern.

ST. LOUIS. June 4 (AP). -- Bill Hallahan won his sixth pitching victory of the season and struck out nine Reds as the Cardinals defeated Cincinnati, 7 to 3, today in the first game of the current series.

TORONTO, June 4 (Canadian Press). -- Toronto made a clean sweep of the series with Rochester by winning both games of today's double-header, 5 -- 2 and 3 -- 2. Liebhardt outpitched Teachout in the second game, which saw the Leafs again come from behind to snatch the verdict.

MAN AND MEDICINE" affords Americans two unusual experiences. First, the book emanates from Europe. For several years we have been deluged with medical bistories, all written in the United States. Second, it was not written for the primary purpose of recording medical history or of putting one's self on record as being the author of a book.

PARIS, May 26, 1932. PARIS, with its generally abominable music, looks better now than at any earlier season that this correspondent remembers, because of the absence of tourists; although the faces of the French are long for lack of Spring trade, the city seems to have regained its rich individuality and the flavor of the past.

VINELAND, N.J., June 4. -- John D. Taminini, 38 years old, a World War veteran, shot and killed his wife, Emily, 28, with a shotgun early this morning after he had attempted to kill her 10-year-old son in their apartment at Chestnut and East Avenues here.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 4. -- Lohr's single in the thirteenth after Zawacki had tripled enabled Penn State to defeat Bucknell today, 13 to 12.

THE pond lies deep in a gorge on a mountain top, a Titan's well in a wilderness of woods and rocks. Pine-fringed cliffs as steep as skyscraper walls guard it on the sides, and dense rhododendron swamps screen it at the ends. Deer come out of the shadowy thickets to dip their noses in the clear, cool water, and in snowtime bobcat tracks are seen here.

GRAND CENTRAL GALLERIES-- Ninth annual Founders Exhibition. It contains forty-seven canvases, contributed by artist members, for which, next October, lay members will draw lots. The work, representative both of the painters and of the gallery, will remain on public exhibition all Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- After an inconclusive talk with Senator Borah today, James R. Garfield, the prospective chairman of the resolutions committee at the Republican National Convention, arranged for a conference tomorrow with Old Guard leaders of the Senate on the difficult task of shaping the party's plank on prohibition.

The whole of the Chelsea pier frontage between Fourteenth and Twenty-second Streets was jammed yesterday morning from 10 o'clock until well after 12 with automobiles and taxicabs which conveyed 4,586 passengers bound for Europe on four steamships.

EVEN If it is true that all roads once led to Rome, the chances are that some of them had a hard time getting there. A really complete highway system of roads that get where they are going without breaks and bottle-necks and detours seems to be reserved for the millennium.

DAYLIGHT dining is a double pleasure these days, for the fair sex. Not only does it offer epicurean thrills: it provides sartorial delights. Time was, when daylight saving was first introduced, that women found it boring to be asked to dine at 7:30.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- Pennsylvania is preparing for its trip to Poughkeepsie with more than ordinary rowing enthusiasm this year. Plans are under way to leave Philadelphia on Sunday, June 12, which will permit of one week's practice on the Hudson.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The political situation in Yugoslavia has, of late, been followed with considerable interest in the American press, though not always with a complete comprehension of the various questions at issue. Many of the domestic questions for which a solution is being sought have been greatly exaggerated and represented as being revolutionary in character.

AS the Paris season advances smart women take more and more interest in afternoon clothes, for the races are generally the culminating point of the fashionable day. Real Summer frocks made their first appearance at Longchamps on Whitsunday.

WITH Summer approaching, the accumulation of vocal records is hardly as formidable as usual, and though there are no new names in the list, there are none the less several items of interest. From the Metropolitan Opera, present, past and future, are Mmes.

The United States Shipping Board announced yesterday the publication of two pamphlets dealing with Chicago and Cleveland as port cities. The pamphlets were prepared jointly by the board's Bureau of Operations and the Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors of the War Department and are designed primarily for individuals and corporations seeking detailed information as to facilities at the ports.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- A new plea to the political parties to give prohibition "the full benefit of the safeguards and limitations which belong to every other provision of the basic law" was issued today by the National Prohibition Board of Strategy.

GENEVA, June 4. -- "An honest difference of views is a good thing for the world," Dr. Mary E. Woolley told the committee on moral disarmament today in an expression of United States opposition to censorship and restrictions of many kinds that some delegations were urging the disarmament conference to accept as a part of the moral means of maintaining peace.

IT argues well for the editors that the tenth number of this nagazine retains all the vigor and freshness that characterized the initial volume. It was not to be expected that Messrs. Adler and Winterich could nourish and maintain their delectable offspring by virtue of their own lively imagination and activity alone.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 4. -- The Penn Athletic Club defeated the Princeton nine, 4 to 2, today, Baily holding the Tigers to four hits. The victors made six safeties.

A STRANGE succession of happenings in London comes to the attention of Richard Sedley, a playwright, who is completely cynical and completely skeptical about everything excepting his own talents. Some of the mysterious acts of which we are told are merely trivial, while others appear to belong in the category of malicious mischief on a grand scale, but all are alike in being irrational and apparently motiveless.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The President's unemployment relief plan was put before the Senate today in a bill introduced by Senator Barbour of New Jersey. It had been previously opposed in the House by Representative Hawley of Oregon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The news item, in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, regarding the primitive gold earrings found by Sir Flinders Petrie on the site of ancient Gaza in Palestine, will prove after careful study to be very important.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic Executive Committee, is going to deliver a "keynote" of his own if he is elected either permanent or temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention. He has told his friends this, and said moreover that he will not submit his speech in advance "to any candidate."

Intercollegiate rowing now heads for the climax events of the regular season -- at Poughkeepsie and New London. The sprint races of the season ended with the past Saturday, when Pennsylvania clung to its place is a returned winner by taking the Childs Cup back home and when Syracuse turned back the highly favored Cornell crew at Boston.

PITTSBURSH, June 4 (AP). -- Heinle Meine started his first game of the season for the Pittsburgh Pirates today, and Pittsburgh celebrated by trouncing the Chicago Cubs. 12 to 4. The erstwhile hold-out hurler held the Cubs in check throughout the game.

EXETER, N.H., June 4. -- Andover won its annual track meet with Exeter today, 81 to 45. Bailey Brown, in winning the low hurdles in 24 3-5 seconds, broke the old dual meet mark made in 1925 by Richard O'Connell, then running for Exeter.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4. -- Providence College defeated Boston College, 6 -- 5, today in a ten-inning game to record its fifteenth baseball victory in sixteen games this season. Dion's two-bagger to centre, with one out in the tenth, gave the Dominicans the game.
SEVILLE, June 3. -- Seville this week has become the centre of the fight against the subversive forces that are attempting to sabotage the moderate republic.

THE proposed plan of street preaching, recently announced by the United Lutheran Synod of New York, recalls the activities of the famous mendicant orders of the Middle Ages, whose friars traveled from town to town extending spiritual aid to the needy.

John H. Curtis, Norfolk boat builder, who conducted the imaginary negotiations for the return of the baby son of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, later found murdered, pleaded not guilty yesterday at Flemington, N.J., to an indictment charging him with obstructing justice through his hoax.

The plight of Baltimore as a seaport as described to the Trunk Line Association at its hearing here Thursday on the proposal of the rail lines to charge $1 a ton for all freight delivered by ship at their piers and transferred to motor trucks for delivery to local consignees, held the attention of shipping circles yesterday.

Health Commissioner Wynne paid tribute yesterday to the Summer camp program of the Salvation Army, which will send several thousand needy mothers and children from New York into the country or to the seashore for a fortnight's vacation.

Judging by the further spirited advance in security prices yesterday and the second-day comment in financial circles, overnight reflection upon the bankers' concerted investment enterprise served to heighten Wall Street's enthusiasm for the project.

ROME. THE legislative measures applied by Italy in favor of World War veterans and their relatives aim especially to enhance their prestige. Measures for moral assistance, therefore, have a preponderating part. Among them, worthy of special notice, are the granting of special emblems to the mutilated, to those decorated for valor, and to the parents and orphans of the fallen, and the concession of precedence at court and at official functions.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., June 4. -- G. Grenville Hunter, 40 years old, socially prominent New York advertising man, killed himself with a shotgun late today at the Summer cottage of Arthur Munn of Bronxville, N.Y., at Harvey Cedars, near here. He had been depressed by financial worries, according to H.J. Anderson Bugbee, county coroner.

THE Province of Quebec; according to a recent statement, has an iron mine that was opened a little more than two centuries ago and continued in operation until well into the present century. This record gives the Canadian mining industry a respectable antiquity, but it does not compare in age with ore-production activities in other parts of the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I CANNOT help wondering how much knowledge of the musical profession your correspondents Leo Armstrong and Alan Johnson have. Or for that matter, of any kind of business. If Mr. Armstrong thinks that Mr. Gatti was so wildly extravagant during those years of plenty -- well, the more credit to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent edict of the Governor pertaining to the fire ban on the State parks brought from J.S. Apperson, widely known conservationist and authority on the Adirondacks, the following reply to an inquiry:
LURAY, Va., June 4 (AP). -- His mind free of tax-bill worries for the moment, President Hoover at his mountain camp today gave another pressing problem, relief, a thorough survey.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The metropolitan police said tonight that they had funds sufficient to feed the bonus marchers now in the district for only forty-eight more hours. They estimated that their supplies would be exhausted by Sunday night if 1,000 more veterans enroute to Washington arrive on schedule.

ST. PAUL, June 2. -- After twelve years of relegation to a minor role in State affairs, the Democratic party in Minnesota is so impregnated with the grossest sort of political opportunism that there is no predicting what use its leadership will make of an apparently fair chance to elect a Democratic Governor this year.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 4. -- Crash Clarence Woodman's Montclair High School track learn captured its fifth straight Class A State crown and its sixth title in the past eight years by winning the fourteenth annual New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association track and field championships today at Essex Field.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 4. -- Beating the wind around a 15 1/2-mile course on Long Island Sound today, Horace Havemeyer's 12-meter English champion, the sloop Mouette, demonstrated that she is a slippery creature.

Moscow. COMING through the Iberian Gate into Red Square in Moscow you can synthesize former and present-day Russia at a glance. The variegated, Asiatic -- the at once fearsome and farcical -- Russia of the autocratic Czars is embodied in the Cathedral of Saint Basil.

The jump in railroad bond prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday pointed the way to the strongest bond market in recent years. Net declines for the day were so few throughout the entire list as to be negligible. In domestic corporation bonds the rise was from 1 to 10 points, with the majority of the active foreign issues up 1 to nearly 5 points, and United States Government issues up 1-32 to 15-32 point.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 4 (AP). -- Dr. Ira Otis Tracy, noted psychiatrist and neurologist, died tonight at the home of his son after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and was born in Lisbon, N.Y.

WESLEYAN COLLEGE, at Middletown, Conn., opened its doors on Sept. 21, 1831, with forty-eight students, a faculty of four and a president, the Rev. Willbur Fisk, whose ideas on education were so much in advance of his time that his inaugural address aroused some apprehension.

DARWIN'S theory that man can adapt himself to almost any new environment is being illustrated, in this day of economic change, by thousands of New Yorkers who have discovered new ways to live and new ways to earn a living since their formerly placid lives were thrown into chaos by unemployment or kindred exigencies.

To the Radio Editor THE NEW YORK TIMES. We have three radio sets at our house, and one at the office. There was a time when a set was always on the go. We are surprised at our-selves nowadays. It is rarely that any machine is going, particularly in the evening.

DODGE CITY, Kan., June 2. -- From the complexities growing out of a political year that is marked by an economic disturbance that has reached every fiber of this agricultural State is evolving a mental attitude, at least on the part of the farmer, that is unique in the Kansas record.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 4. -- Weetamoe, with her owner, Frederick H. Prince, at the helm, beat Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie today by two minutes in an informal yacht race off Newport. Mr. Lambert, Chandler Hovey and Miss Elizabeth Hovey made up the afterguard on the losing boat.

THE Gibbs family always seems to have made a specialty at telling the world, and particularly England, about the trials and problems confronting the youth of the day and about the splendid and courageous spirit with which those problems are met.

LONDON, June 4 (AP). -- Meteorological experts said here tonight that Stanislaus Hausner had probably encountered a thirty-mile an hour head-wind after ha struck Long. 30 degrees W., or for about 1,250 miles of the route to London.

THERE is a fascination about the conquest of seas. It held true la the days of man's early adventuring in crude boats driven by oars and then sails. It holds true now that the realm of the air has been successfully invaded. Witness the continued attempts, some of them successful, to span the great oceans in non-stop flights.

DETROIT. AFTER a week of thinking it over, automotive engineers in the passenger-car industry are more convinced than ever that the showing of semi-stock cars in the Indianapolis race was an extremely creditable one.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4. -- Major George T. Sinks, U.S.A., retired, of 170 Elm Street, this city, died yesterday at his Winter home in Ruskin, Fla. Funeral services will be held Monday morning. Burial will take place in Arlington Cemetery, Washington.

DR. ERNEST WILSON, author of this book, needs no introduction to true lovers of gardens all over the world. Explorer, plant collector, botanist, author and at the time of his tragic death, head of America's greatest garden, his name is associated with the many plants, some bearing his name, which he brought back from distant lands, to enrich the gardens of the New and Old World.

The calm waters and the lack of breeze on the conservatory lake in Central Park yesterday did not discourage more than 150 boys from various parts of the city who took part in the eighth annual competition for model boats, conducted by the Bureau of Recreation of the Department of Parks.

Carlos Davila, leader of the revolution in Chile which came as a climax to that republic's recent economic distress and political confusion, has long been a leader in Chilean affairs. As the popular and active Ambassador to this country from 1927 until last year he is well known in the United States.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4. -- R.H. Helsel did some splendid shooting in the registered shoot of the American Trapshooting Association over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Shooting from the 16-yard mark, he won the High Scratch Cup, breaking 100 straight targets.

BERLIN. VETERANS' pensions are handled in Germany by the Labor Ministry, which has charge of social insurance and other welfare services. This fact emphasizes the character of the German war pension system.
LONDON. IN the past twelve years Great Britain has reduced the financial burden of pensions growing out of the World War by 55 per rent.

MEXICO CITY, June 4. -- Seventeen persons were killed and twenty-five injured in the city of Colima and four killed and forty injured in Guadalajara, according to the latest reports, in the earthquake which rocked nearly all of Mexico early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The conference report on the tax bill was adopted by the House today without a record vote after a stormy session in which Representative Rainey, the Democratic leader, charged Acting Chairman Crisp of the Ways and Means Committee with "surrendering" to the Senate in the final negotiations on the measure.

GENEVA. IN the daytime, no one would dream that these quais are haunted. The avenue, between the lakeside with its double row of clipped sycamores and the tall gray apartment buildings with little shops and big terraced hotels interspersed, is as busy as any street in the fashionable quarter of any city in toe world.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4. -- The Pennsylvania Military College polo team overwhelmed the Princeton four, 13 to 5, today. Hernig and Nicholls starred for the victors, each accounting for four goals, while Bickering tallied three times.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- The Yankees and Athletics completed their Spring dual relations today by breaking even in a double-header, witnessed by Philadelphia's largest baseball crowd so far this year, an overflow gathering estimated at about 35,000.

PARIS, June 4. -- The Cross of the French Legion of Honor was conferred on Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam this afternoon as a climax to a day whose every minute gave evidence no flier since Colonel Lindbergh has so won the hearts of the Parisian populace.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 4. -- Duplicating feats at Philadelphia, Cincinnati, New York and Washington, Nancolleth Markable, the sterling pointer owned by Giralda Farms of Madison, N.J., maintained an undefeated record in this country by winning the award for best in show at the seventeenth annual Ladies' Dog Club event today.

TUXEDO, N.Y., June 4. -- Championship stakes in the several divisions brought to a successful conclusion the annual Tuxedo horse show today on the picturesque show grounds in Tuxedo Park. There was an excellent attendance of enthusiasts attracted by the delightful weather and the prospect of exciting competitions -- and in the latter they were not disappointed.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 4. -- Miss Madeline Taylor, shooting from thirty yards, scored six golds and automatically became a member of the Six Golds Club, the national organization, as the Metropolitan Archery Association Spring championship tournament got under way today at the Scarsdale High School athletic field.

A POSTLES of many faiths, from St. Francis to Mahatma Gandhi, have taught that the flowers of the spiritual life blossom more profusely in the soil of poverty and deprivation than in the rich mulch of prosperity. Luxury, it has usually been held, as in the classic case of the Roman Empire, acts as a too powerful fertilizer that kills the souls of men.

The twenty-two-day meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct will begin on Friday with the assurance from John E. Cowdin, president, that all of the famous old fixtures, many of them steeped in tradition, will he renewed. Included are such well-known stakes as the Dwyer, Brooklyn Handicap, Carter Handicap, Queens County Handicap and Shevlin.

The First Division polo team of Fort Hamilton will meet the All-Army four at the Fort Hamilton army reservation in Brooklyn next Sunday in a match for the benefit of the food relief committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

BAYSIDE, L.I., June 4. -- Misfit, owned by Arthur Knapp, was first home today in the Gull Class of the Bayside Yacht Club regatta, but the victory was protested by E. Culhane, owner of Slopoke, who said that in a luffing match, Misfit luffed too long when Slopoke really was free.

The preferred stocks of utility holding companies were in demand in the last three days as a result of the high yields which became available through the previous continued liquidation. Most of these issues closed at their high prices of the week and with substantial gains above the low points of the year.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- A "bonus march to Washington," starting tomorrow afternoon, in which 200 war veterans are expected to participate, was planned at a meeting in Military Park here this afternoon by the Provisional Bonus March Committee of New Jersey.

EDMUND RUFFIN fired the first shot at Fort Sumter in 1861; he had earned that right by his unwearying leadership of the forces for secession. The Charlestonians courteously gave Ruffln this place of honor, for he was a guest among them, a Virginian who had abandoned his native State in protest against her slowness to withdraw from the Union, and had cast his lot with the South Carollnians.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Duke of Gloucester was almost thrown from his horse today during London's most brilliant military spectacle -- the trooping of the colors-which is held every year to mark the King's birthday.

BERLIN, June 4. -- President von Hindenburg today dissolved the Reichstag on the ground that "according to the Diet elections held in the last few months in the German States it no longer represents the political will of the German people." The decree which makes this statement was signed by the President, Chancellor von Papen and Interior Minister von Gayl.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 4. -- Two fast games of polo featured today's play at the Meadow Brook Club as the teams warmed up for the start of the club's Spring tournaments which open a week from today.

THE discussion in Congress of a huge public works program to aid the unemployed; increased taxation to meet the vital needs of Germany's jobless, and the increase in unemployment in Great Britain, after months of decline -- these factors focus attention on the picture of millions of persons thrown out of work in every industrial country in the world through the deflationary processes of the depression.

PARIS, May 25. -- Well-known Americans are present in only moderate numbers at such social gatherings as precede the big June racing and other events. The weather has not yet been warm enough for Armenonville, Pre Catelan, the Chateau de Madrid and other restaurants in the Bois de Boulogne to become highly patronized rendezvous for fashionable dining and dancing.

PANAMA CITY, June 4. -- Elly Beinhorn, the 24-year-old German aviatrix, faced 600 miles of flying over trackless jungles with no landing fields when she left the National Airport at Punta Paitilla at 7:45 this morning for Cali, Colombia, on the first leg of her lone flight around South America.

BOHEMIANISM never has been much of a favorite among American artists. Not, at least, in its European form. The tendency here has been in the direction of concealing any wayward impulses and revulsions against the existing order under an exemplary and formal aspect of dress and manner.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended May 28 were lower than at any time in recent months, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

BERLIN, June 3. -- The conference at Lausanne involves more than reparations for it vitally affects Germany's business solvency. Germany is eager to pay her business obligations abroad fully, but this becomes more unlikely the longer reparations are allowed to drift.

KARAMAZOV" and "Way of a Lancer" have tooth had their names scratched off the Goldwyn schedule after preliminary work had been done on both stories, and now Ronald Calman, for whom they were intended, is out in the cold without any story at all.

Yesterday was the warmest day so far this year. With the temperature averaging 10 degrees above normal for the date, the mercury climbed 21 degrees in a little more than twelve hours and reached its maximum, 86, at 5:45 P.M. It was not, however, the hottest June 4 on record.
WITH dramatic suddenness, the Bruening Cabinet has resigned. Again the German Republic, with its seventeen political parties, faces one of its perennial political crises.

GENERAL-MUSIKDIREKTOR Professor Bruno Walter, as he is titled in the German press, recently expressed himself in a speech given in Vienna on the possible causes of "opera-weariness" apropos the perennial query as to whether opera is losing ground in the popular taste.

The implication of President BUTLER'S Commencement remarks is that we have such politicians as we deserve. He called attention to the poor repute in which they have been held "from the very beginning." They have been attacked by each generation for their shortcomings and vices, but, as the authority whom he quotes asserts, these are "not native or original but derivative" -- derived from the "weaknesses and foibles of human nature."

IT seems strange to think of the Giants under any other leadership than that of John J. McGraw. In the Thirty Years' War at the Polo Grounds the ownership changed, the players changed, the rules changed and even the scenery changed. But John J. McGraw remained the outstanding and dominant figure through it all.

GARDONE, Riviera. A GREAT many years have passed since Italy's poet last produced a work of general interest. "Notturno," written during the war and published immediately after, although it contained a great many superb passages, was not widely read outside of Italy.
MOST ships, like most people, know when they are licked. But not the 58-year-old cutter Bear, veteran of the Coast Guard and heroine of a hundred polar rescues.

Mr. Dooley once remarked that, while the Constitution follows the flag, the Supreme Court follows the election returns. Whether that toe a libel or no, it is no reflection on the court to say that it is generally alive to the exigencies of the times. Take, for example, the increasing responsibilities of the Presidency.

Thirty-three threesomes will tee off at the Plainfield Country Club on Wednesday in the qualifying round of the annual Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship, all of the ninety-nine golfers in search of the honor won last year at Quaker Ridge by Leonard Martin, young Apawamis star who survived a week of upsets.

JERKILY but consistently the Japanese nation moves forward to a new political and social order. Admiral Viscount Saito, the aged and highly respected administrator who, at the suggestion of the yet more aged Prince Saionji, has formed a compromise Cabinet taking into account the superpatriots and politicians, the financiers and Generals, the rival parties, Seiyukai and Minseito, is described by the Japanese press as "the last bulwark of party government."

IN this graceful little romance of the war generation, Margaret Widdemer evokes a timely mood, a nostalgic longing for the peace and security and idealism of life in the years before the war. Miss Widdemer has few peers in the writing of light and tender romance; but, like most romancers, she requires her readers to take a good deal for granted.

IN these columns last Sunday was discussed that part of the report of the Committee to Study Compensation for Automobile Accidents which dealt with the present systems of paying damages for injuries and death caused by motor vehicles.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 4. -- The Sleepy Hollow Country Club was the scene tonight of a dinner dance. A concert by Reinald Werrenrath and the University Alumni Glee Club was held in the outdoor theatre.

Readers of the prose works of WALT WHITMAN remember the Summer days when he built up the vigor of a body threatened with paralysis by taking the nature cure in the woods of Timber Creek, some sixteen miles out of Camden. On the 113th anniversary of his birthday, on May 31, a number of his admirers gathered on Timber Creek and planted a memorial dogwood tree.

SAM JOHNSON was no respecter of the printed book. When he borrowed one from a hapless neighbor he would return it (if at all) with some unmistakable mark of his appreciation. The volume would be minus a cover, or the hinges would be broken, and the text would be almost certainly defaced, inscribed, we should call it today, with his annotations.

RENEWED FAME. AMERICAN newspaper readers found an old acquaintance in the headlines last week. Until a few days ago the name of Franz von Papen meant Ambassador von Bernstorff's military aide at Washington who was sent home in 1915.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Raymond V. McNally discusses Governor Roosevelt's proposals. Though I must agree in general with his criticism, I must apply to Mr. McNally the statement he applies to the Governor: "Before he can intelligently recommend a remedy to correct the condition, he must first know what the cause is."

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Moving, who have been living for some time at 45 East Eighty-fifth Street, left yesterday for Chicago, where they will make their permanent home. They will pass the Summer in Lake Forest, III.

THE crowd in the lobby of the New Amsterdam Theatre on Tuesday nights would lead a passer-by to think that the curtain was about to go up on the Follies. But no, the attraction is Ed Wynn on the roof, where there are 675 seats for radio enthusiasts anxious to see the comedian in action at the microphone.

Native capacities and academic achievements of students in school, rather than the customary entrance examinations, should be emphasized more strongly as a basis for judging candidates for admission to college, according to a report made public yesterday by the school and college relations committee of the educational records bureau.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., June 4. -- Princess Xenia's chestnut gelding, | Jada, was declared the champion jumper of the Glen Head Junior Horse Show this afternoon while the owner sat at the ringside and Charles Plumb of East Norwich took him over the bars to victory.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A vote in the House on Monday, June 13, on the question of immediate payment of the soldiers, adjusted service certificates was assured just before the House adjourned for the week-end today.

Some of the pastors today will discuss the investigation of the city administration. Other clergymen will deal with the world-wide depression and refer to the coming national Republican and Democratic conventions. In Roman Catholic churches a pastoral letter of Cardinal Hayes will be read.

FORGERY is achieving new importance in crime circles. This is attested by the recent settlement of the so-called Waterlow case, in which an old London corporation was deceived into printing 580,000 unauthorized Portuguese bank-notes, and by the deception practiced by the late Ivar Kreuger.

Led by William Devereaux, who won all three of his matches, the James Madison High School fencing team defeated Textile, 5 to 3, yesterday as the regular schedule In the second annual city P.S.A.L. team championship tournament was concluded in the Washington Irving High School gymnasum.

LONDON, June 3. -- British thrift seems to thrive on British depression. The savings of working people during the hard times of last year have not only held their own, but have increased, for with diminishing wages the percentage of earnings set aside for the traditional rainy day has been greater.
KINGSTON, N.Y., June 4. -- I'm finding good sparring partners very scarce. Joe Jacobs remarked after a workout I had with two new men that they "don't look so good in there."

LONDON, June 4 (Canadian Press). -- The touring cricket team from South America started its first game against Oxford University today and dismissed the Dark Blues for 170, D. Ayling taking four wickets for 38 runs.
True to tradition, Memorial Day this year again proved the signal for the launching of thousands of power craft in waters adjacent to New York City.

New York University's Centennial Commencement opens today at 4 P.M. with the baccalaureate service in the Chapel of Gould Memorial Library at University Heights, and will conclude Wednesday morning with an outdoor ceremony at Ohio Field, at which Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown will confer degrees on about four thousand candidates, the largest class in the history of the university.
WASHINGTON, Pa., June 4 (AP). -- The text of Samuel Seabury's address to the graduating class at Washington and Jefferson College today is as follows:

ST. LOUIS, June 2. -- A new era in State transportation history will be inaugurated late this month when the lower Missouri River, the traditions of which are inseparably linked with the more glamourous Mississippi, will be formally opened for navigation.

With sturdy Frank Crowley unreeling a 4:17.2 mile on the anchor leg, the Manhattan College relay team broke the world's medley relay record at the 128th track and field games of the New York Athletic Club before a crowd of 7,000 in the picturesque Travers Island setting yesterday.

Former State Senator Nathaniel A. Elsberg, who was President of the National Republican Club from 1922 to 1924, died yesterday at his residence, 112 Central Park South, of pneumonia, after a long illness. His age was 60. He is survived by two brothers, Herman A. and Dr. Charles A. Elsberg, and a sister, Mrs. Bertha Oppenheim.

The problems of American industry cannot be solved by centralized control lodged in a government bureau or vested in trade groups, but must be dealt with by the men on the spot, James A. Farrell, retired president of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 4. -- The feeling that the grain situation is hopeless and that lower prices are inevitable was more pronounced today on the Board of Trade here than at any other time recently.

UP to the end of February, 1932, the American Government had spent a total of $5,475,505,520.29 directly for the relief of World War veterans and their dependents. Of this sum, $2,100,888,433.65 was for various forms of disability and death compensation to ex-service men and those dependent upon them; $582,931,845.08 for allotments and allowances; $486,936,049.78 for medical and hospital care; $644,943,719.72 for vocational training; $1,003,406,857.64 for insurance, and $656,398,614.42 for miscellaneous expenditures, including administration.

IN "Love Fetish" Evans Wall continues his study of the mixed-blooded natives of the Louisiana swamp country begun in "The No-Nation Girl." Beneath the garish title may be discovered a simple and effective story notable for its accurate observation of a little-known corner of the world.

The first commencement exercises of Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, will be held from June 15 to June 20 in connection with the national convention of orthodox congregations, according to an announcement yesterday. The program will open with a dinner at the Hotel Astor next Sunday evening.

LONDON, June 3. -- In the international conference on disarmament the representatives of fifty-five nations, great and small, leaguers and non-leaguers, are meeting together, each bringing the special point of view which arises naturally from the traditions, history and present circumstances, geographical and political, of his own country.

With entertainment enterprises on all aides tottering under the bludgeoning of hard times, educational courses for adults are holding their own amazingly in this city. At Columbia University, as at the College of the City of New York, for instance, registration has stood this season near the peak totals of the boom years.

MME. VERA BOREA, Paris couturiere, has come to America to see for herself what the women here are like, so she told the writer in an interview given shortly after her arrival in New York. "When I see them against their own background I will know better how to design for them," she explained.

John McGraw, whose resignation as manager of the Giants confounded the baseball world Friday, found himself yesterday relegated exclusively for the first time in his long and brilliant career to a desk job in the front office.

Current economic conditions demand a new type of executive control in industry, capable of revising the objectives, patterns and functions of business corporations to meet the changed competitive situation that has developed in the last few years, in the opinion of Harry A. Hopf, management engineer and head of the company that bears his name.

A concept of civilization new for the modern world, with emphasis transferred to rural life, may be necessary for the preservation of the race, Dr. Clarence G. Campbell suggested yesterday in his address as president of the Eugenics Research Association, delivered at its joint annual meeting with the American Eugenics Society at the American Museum of Natural History.

SO very new is the institution which this book examines that even its name is unknown to large numbers of intelligent people. Sometimes it advertises itself as a "dancing academy" or a "dancing school." But among its frequenters and those who are familiar with the place in city life it has already made for itself, it is always called simply a "taxi-dance hall," and the young women who provide its attraction are "taxi-dancers."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 4. -- Coach Rich Glendon sent his Columbia varsity crew pounding over three miles of the Hudson River course today in what appeared to observers on the shore to be the anticipated time trial which closed the Lions' first week in training here for the I.R.A. regatta on June 20.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- Accused of implication in a series of New York bond thefts in which bank runners and brokers, messengers have been robbed of more than $500,000 in securities during the last two years, two men were held in $20,000 bail each for court here today by Magistrate Joseph Coward.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Throwing aside the responsibility of enacting legislation to appropriate money for direct relief, the House Democrats and Republicans staged a baseball game at the home of the American League Baseball Club today to raise funds to feed the unemployed of Washington.

THE suburbanite comes into his little kingdom with the advent of late Spring and early Summer. The calendar Spring of mid-March merely makes the suburbanite hope that the warm season is no further round the corner than the business recovery.
Mayor Walker intends to fight any move to place him on trial before Governor Roosevelt until after the Democratic National Convention, which meets June 27 in Chicago, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 4. -- Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee in the legislative inquiry into the government of New York City, declared at Washington and Jefferson College today that the investigation would continue until the city had "ousted those who are degrading its government."

An address by Robert P. Lamont, Secretary of Commerce, will be a feature of the joint conference of the sales promotion and merchandise managers' divisions of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, to be held on June 21 and 22 in the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON. J.C. SQUIRE has just been saying a good word -- a very good word, indeed -- for American novelists to the disparagement of their English contemporaries. We have in England, he admits, young men writing fiction who possess gifts of insight and melody, pathos and humor, and some awareness of history and the beyond.

About the West Point horse snow there is much that is different from the average Summer exhibition, making it one of the most enjoyable events of the season. Environment contributes a lot to the charm of the occasion and the fourteenth annual show which opens tomorrow morning and continues through Tuesday will have its customary delighful setting.

IN Spain, as elsewhere, musical affairs have not been running smoothly. This despite the ambitious program of the State intervention formulated with the advent of the republic. For several months all projects have been hanging fire pending the approval of the budget by the Constituent Assembly.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 4. -- Tip Tobin, star left fielder of the Fordham University baseball team, slammed two homers to help his team register an 8-4 victory over the Rutgers nine at Neilson Field today. Ken Auer, unbeaten this year, pitched his tenth straight triumph for Fordham, fanning thirteen batsmen.

TOKYO, May 11. -- Having become a millionaire (in yen) Sakaji Ito left the Stock Exchange at the age of 35 years and is devoting his fortune to founding a magazine. The publication is called Nippon Kokumin (The Japanese Nation) and is a handsome but not expensive production of 700 pages, which makes it the biggest magazine published in Japan.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4 (AP). -- Whirling along behind another homer outburst, the league-leading Bisons tipped over the Montreal Royals today 9 to 4. for their sixth straight triumph and their twelfth victory in thirteen starts.

PERHAPS 2,000,000 parents and friends will, during this month of June, watch more than 100,000 college seniors file by on commencement platforms and receive from the hands of their president their coveted diplomas. Many people are wondering what this new crop of graduates are like.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Business activity remained, in general, unchanged or slipped to slightly lower levels in American foreign markets covered in the current weekly survey by the Commerce Department.

The annual report of the American Gas and Power Company, signed by A.E. Fitkin, chairman of the hoard, who acquired the entire common stock and a substantial part of the preferred stock from the receivers of American Commonwealths Power Corporation on Jan. 18, subject to a right of the receivers to repurchase these shares within a year, gives details of the cursent position of the company and of the problems which it has to face.

THE charter of the city of New York, criticized by Mayor Walker at the Seabury inquiry as "archaic, worn out, overlapping and out of date," has often been the subject of attack. Granted by the State Legislature in 1897, it has been frequently amended, altered and revised, until its changes are nearly as numerous as its original provisions.

Announcement of the formation of the Campaign Contributors' Associates as the start of a movement to obtain definite declarations on major issues in the platforms of both major political parties was made yesterday by Abram S. Hewitt.
Veterans from the city started to march on Washington yesterday but halted at Elizabeth and Newark after their plea for a free train ride was rejected.

OTTAWA. HOWARD the relief of World War veterans, and to their dependents, the government of Canada is paying today more than $1,000,000 every week and will continue to pay as much, or more, for many years to come.

STOCKHOLM, May 20. -- Preliminary studies of the diet of school children in districts north of the Arctic Circle have been undertaken by a group from the medical faculty of Uppsala University under the guidance of Professor G.F. Gothjin, assisted by Gunnar Falk and K.O. Cedda.

With three former two-time winners of the trophy seeking to score a third victory and retire the prize from competition, among the entrants, play started yesterday in the thirty-sixth annual men's metropolitan clay court tennis singles championship tournament at the New York Tennis Club.

LA PAZ, May 25. -- The ruins of forty-three settlements of the late Inca era have been discovered and examined by the American Museum of Natural History expedition which has just returned to La Paz after a survey trip of several weeks on the high Bolivian plateau in the neighborhood of Lake Titicaca.

An emergency has developed in the last few days which it is my duty to lay before the Senate. The continued downward movement in the economic life of the country has been particularly accelerated during the past few days and it relates in part definitely to the financial program of the government.* * *

SENATOR FORAKER, dubbed "Fire Alarm" Foraker by his contemporaries, as people will recall who are old enough to remember a decade or two back of the turn of the century, was for almost fifty years an eminent and influential figure in the political life of Ohio and the nation.

SINCE tradition declares it one of the more adventurous arts, eager to go anywhere upon due payment of its passage and the posting of a bond to bring it home again, the theatre is said to chafe uneasily the while it seeks new worlds to conquer.
MOBILE, Ala., Juna 4. -- Relatives here were informed by cable today of the death in London of Lady Benn wife of Sir Arthur Shirley Benn. Lady Benn formerly was active in Mobile and New York society.

THE world has a short memory and a callous heart, so there are now probably very few people who remember anything about H.A.W. Tabor. But forty years ago he was a Croesus of Colorado whose lavish expenditure of money in spectacular and foolish ways had brought him nation-wide attention.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox bunched hits to good advantage and defeated the St. Louis Browns, 6 to 5, in a ten-inning game today.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 4. -- Specific losses said to have been suffered by William C. Durant, automobile manufacturer and stock speculator, when Benjamin Block Co., New York brokers, sold out his holdings in 1930, will be contained in calculations filed by both parties at the close of the trial of Durant's suit on June 17.
ST. ALBANS, L.I., June 4. -- Since establishing himself in America, Cyril Tolley, one - time British amateur golf champion, has found the going extremely rough.
In sympathy with the rallies in stocks and bonds, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered more than $1 a bale yesterday and ended 20 to 25 points higher than on Friday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I call to your attention inaccuracies in the editorial, "Bears in Alaska," that appeared in THE TIMES of April 29? "You assert:

Official approval has been granted by the National Outboard Racing Commission to three new outboard motor boat records made in California. A certificate for a five-mile competition mark of 42.384 miles an hour in Class B amateur has been granted to Fred Bastauchury of La Habra, Cal.

Mayor Walker indulged in a few typical witticisms last night and incidentally paid his respects to "some judges" at a dinner in honor of Judge John J. Freschi of the Court of General Sessions at the Hotel Biltmore.

GENEVA, June 3. -- There is more controversy here as to whether the present so-called expertizing stage of the world arms conference is to be very valuable in the cause of disarmament. There is no doubt, however, that it is an excellent school for the warriors of the various nations, with plenty of good business tips thrown in for the munition makers.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Gainfully employed workers in the Borough of Bronx in 1930 numbered 549,896 and represented 43.5 per cent of its population of 1,265,258, but 52.2 per cent of the population of 10 years of age and over, the Census Bureau announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- That the Senate has, as a body, feminine qualities was proved again this week when it suddenly passed the tax bill. Vowing it would ne'er consent, the Senate consented. The act was accompanied by a series of circumstances some comic, some tragic, some merely dull.

WLISTFIELD. N.J., June 4. -- Miss Theodora Meyers of Elisabeth advanced to the semi-final round of the Anne dimming Memorial tennis tournament by defeating Miss Rose Rice of Jersey City. 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

Entries have been made officially by the North American Yacht Racing Union in all the yachting events to be held off Los Angeles as part of the Olympis Games. The craft will be an eight-meter, a six-meter, a Star boat and a monotype. They will be selected through elimination trials, and the winner in each class will represent this country in the international competition.

CLEVELAND, June 4. -- Economic, rangy son of Infinite and Karelia, swept down the last stretch at Bainbridge Park today like a champion to win the eighth annual running of the Ohio State Derby in the record time of 1:51 3-5.

BELGRADE, June 3. -- The revival of political terrorism evidenced by the explosion in a single night this week of three bombs in the centre of Belgrade not only is symptomatic of the disease of the State but is recognition that emigre terrorists are being supported in foreign countries.

IF you have wondered whatever became of the theatrical season that began on the 25th night of last August at the Avon Theatre, when and where Brock Pemberton presented "Three Times the Hour," these columns are prepared this morning to fold their judicial robes about them, arise and present a stately answer.

DETROIT, June 4 (AP). -- After losing three straight to Cleveland in two days, the Tigers jumppd on Hudlin and Hildebrand for ten hits in the second game of today's double-header and defeated the Indians, 10 to 4. Today's first game went to the Indians, 3 to 1.

THE excavation of Jericho is of fundamental interest to students of biblical history. For, as all know, the capture of Jericho by the Israelites is the first episode narrated in the Book of Joshua after the crossing of the Jordan, the first step in their invasion of the Promised Land.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Junn 4. -- Nott Terrace of this city won the annual Eastern New York State high school track championship meet today, scorinng 731-10 points. Mont Pleasant, also of Schenectady, was runner-up with 40 1-10.

Democratic governments having much the same characteristics all over the world, we may well stop occasionally to study in other nations faults which we tend to overlook in ourselves. In the course of the recent general election in France a political writer in Marseilles, M. PAUL BARLATIER, undertook to define the chief vice of French political methods.

AMERICA AS AMERICANS SEE IT" offers pabulum for the ironists. Its editor. Fred J. Ringel, a correspondent for German newspapers, has taken part in many all-night discussions with European friends about a fabulous "American civilization" which threatened, just a few short years ago, to drown the world with a flood of goods and which produced, among other things, the Hollywood cinema, Scariface Al Capone, and a convenient butt for the wit of George Bernard Shaw.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It sometimes happens that good people and also Congressmen are given nicknames which, whether deserved or not, cling to them and cannot be brushed off lightly. They have to be lived up to, and not infrequently they must be lived down; that is, if an individual is in the least interested in his reputation.

THIS is probably the gayest, giddiest, most utterly charming book of travel to be offered this season. Sagacious, energetic and sportive, it moves like a whirlwind. Sketches in praise of practically nothing, as well as appreciations of practically everything that is Spanish -- from Goya through bullrights -- it is a lovely example of the flamboyant style of writing.

Judge Julian W. Mack, chairman of the board of trustees, will preside at the seventh annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion at Carnegie Hall this morning. The degrees will be conferred By the Rev. Stephen S. Wise, president of the institute.

Families in which every effort and sacrifice were made last year to keep their homes intact have now been compelled to turn their children over to child-welfare agencies because all avenues of home relief are closed, according to Franklin Thomas, chairman of the dependent children's section of the Welfare Council, in a letter yesterday to Mayor Walker and the Board of Estimate.

OVER the green Chemung Valley on the hills outside Elmira the silent fliers will gather on July 11 for a two weeks' meet. The silent fliers are those masters and students of air currents who fly the soaring gliders or sailplanes.

LONDON, May 20. THE dramatic version of "The Good Companions" was written by J.B. Priestley in collaboration with Edward Knoblock. Now Mr. Priestley has entered the theatre with a play of his own, "Dangerous Corner," and is said to have another in reserve.

THE story of one of the most dramatic bank failures in New York history reached one of its most dramatic moments a few days ago when Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banking, was acquitted in General Sessions Court of charges of neglect of duty growing out of the collapse of the Bank of United States.
ALBANY, June 4. -- The Port of Albany will be dedicated with a two-day celebration which starts Monday under the auspices of the Albany Port District Commission.

Leaders, public officials and guests of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club mingled with 5,000 children of the district at the annual June outing and athletic carnival held yesterday by that organization on the east green of Central Park, at Seventy-second Street and Fifth Avenue.

NO better tales of adventure in the Worm War have appeared than those that have come to us by way of translation from the German, none of wilder recklessness, more gripping adventure, more thrilling dangers. So fascinating are they in such respects that sometimes one wonders if things really did happen in quite such startling fashion or if perhaps the author has touched up the colors a bit.

Emphasis on better goods and values, the timing of offerings to feature wanted items at close mark-up, aggressive departmental promotions and suggestive and multiple-unit selling efforts feature the plans retailers are developing for the Summer period, a canvass of store executives revealed here yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4. -- Harvard beat Holy Cross today, 5-4, registering its first baseball victory against the Crusaders since 1927 and its fourth in the last twelve seasons. Devens and Mahoney were the opposing pitchers, each allowing eight hits, and each having a streak of wildness.

ATLANTA, June 2. -- Down here in Franklin D. Roosevelt's other State, statistically inclined politicians figure that when the Democratic National Convention is called to order the New York Governor will be within seventy-three votes of the nomination.

BLIND landings, not as stunts performed after long preparation and with the aid of elaborate apparatus, but as something which every Air Corps pilot can do at fields provided with very simple equipment, are just around the corner for the army's fliers.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 4 (AP). -- Robert R. Reynolds, who campaigned on an anti-prohibition platform, and Cameron Morrison, militant dry, polled almost vote for vote in the first 237 ballot boxes counted in today's Democratic primary for the nomination of a United States Senator.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 4 (AP). -- William B. Bryant, owner and publisher of The Teaneck (N.J.) Times-Review, died suddenly tonight after a second stroke at his home here. He was 55 years old.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4. -- Commencement events, which will end Tuesday, began today at the College of New Rochelle with a sodality mass and the awarding of sodality crosses to twenty-four of the 161 young women who will graduate on Monday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4. -- The government of President Juan Esteban Montero has been forced out by combined political and military forces and succeeded by a junta. A Socialist republic in Chile is the aim of the revolutionary forces.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to acquire control, through lease, of the Kansas Southwestern Railway Company. The lease is to take the place of one entered into in 1920 prior to the effective date of the transportation act and recently terminated.

NOBODY has done more than John T. Faris to make his fellow-countrymen aware and appreciative of the enormous and prodigiously varied scenic resources and attractions of the United States. In a long series of books, now numbering almost a score, he has told engagingly of the things to be seen and done and thought about along old roads, up and down famous rivers, in mountains and forests in various sections of the country.

In bringing to an end the movement of prices during a week of extremely varied incidents and influences -- a weak which began with financial despondency probably at its darkest -- yesterday's markets had before them, first, the overnight news of the $100,000,000 banking corporation, to be organized for purchase of outstanding bonds; second, knowledge that the House of Representatives would vote in the afternoon on the Senate's budget-balancing bill, and would presumably accept it.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox today amazed its following by taking a double-header from the Senators. It was the first time this season that the lowly Sox have won two consecutive games. The scores were 4 -- 2 and 9 -- 8.
The June days for which most fishermen have been eagerly waiting are now here and are tempting enough to lure the angler away from tie city for a few days of his favorite sport.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. LIKE all good New Year's resolutions, Hollywood's solemn promise at the opening of the current year that there would be no more cycles went into the discard again this week. RKO-Radio's "Is My Face Red?," the first of the batch of columnist stories reached the screen, beating the several other gossip-writer yarns from other lots by several weeks.

MEXICO CITY, June 4. -- Latest telegrams from Jalapa, the capital of the State of Vera Cruz, announce the approval by Governor Adalberto Tejeda of a measure passed by the Legislature under which any property regarded by the Governor as a public utility may be expropriated with indemnification.

Knotty human problems appeal when 7,000,000 people try to live and work within such a small area as New York City, and a vast network of social service organizations has grown up here to untangle them When some two years ago the writer looked for a means or making the study of sociology "real," he found this field hardly touched by the academic sociologist.

Two former world's heavyweight champion wrestlers, campaigning now for a chance to retrain the mat crown, will come to grips Thursday night at the dedication of Madison Square Garden's Bowl in Long Island City to outdoor sport. Dick Shikat, German grappler, and Ed (Strangler) Lewis, burly Kentuckian, will meet in a finish exhibition in the interests of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman.
AMHERST, Mass., June 4. -- Springfield College got off to a three-run lead in the first inning and gained a 4-2 victory over Amherst today in a close contest.

NEW YORK has just had its first open-air art show, staged in Washington Square by the artists of Greenwich Village. New to us, these outdoor exhibits are familiar sights in several European cities, and in Philadelphia.

The three-day Boys Fair, held at Osborn Field, East Thirty-first Street, under the auspices of the local boys clubs, ended last night with a boxing contest. Prizes and medals were awarded for almost every kind of activity, including even cooking and baking.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4. -- The Harvard varsity, junior varsity, freshman and combination eights, which will assemble tomorrow night for dinner at Red Top, Conn., where on noon Monday they begin preparation for their annual races with Yale, were announced by the Harvard Athletio Association tonight.

THE Hofstadter legislative investigation has made familiar to the public the legal term "waiver of immunity," while at the same time raising a question as to what a waiver of immunity is, Though many have signed waivers before giving testimony to the Hofstadter committee, many others have "respectfully refused."
GENEVA, June 4. -- The League of Nations Economic Committee drafted a gloomy report tonight.

IT is open season on the North-west Frontier of India. With Ramazan, the month of fasting, well behind and Spring in his blood, the Pathan tribesman is ready at a moment's notice to kick over the traces. Across the line all preparations to meet him have been made.

THIS, though in form a biography of Moorfield Storey, is much more. It is the biography of a type. Storey happened to be its most striking and consistent exemplar, but many men of more celebrity were of it. None of them, not Godkin or Schurz or any of its historic representatives, so consistently and temperamentally and permanently, all through their lives, illustrated the type with Storey's perfection.

HYDE PARK, June 4. -- Charging Samuel Seabury with underhand tactics, a close friend of Governor Roosevelt asserted here today that the Executive would deal promptly and without regard to politics with charges against Mayor Walker when they reached his desk.

Except for the grains, which were fractionally lower, the trend of commodity prices was sharply upward yesterday. The recovery from the last week coincided with the improved securities markets. Cotton, hides, silk and rubber of the major staples, all scored good-size gains. Coffee, sugar and cocoa exchanges were closed.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4. -- Major Divine, Negro religious leader who maintained what was known as "heaven" at Sayville, L.I., and who was convicted here recently on a charge of maintaining a public nuisance there, was sentenced by Supreme Court Justice Lewis J. Smith here today to serve one year in the Suffolk County jail at Rlverhead, L.I., and to pay a fine of $500.

AUTEUIL, France, June 4 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody will take he court against Mme. Rene Mathieu. France's leading woman player, tomorrow in the women's singles final of the French tennis championship. The American star is seeking her fourth title and her second championship of the tournament, she having won the women's doubles with Miss Elizabeth Ryan.

PARIS. WHILE the United States is paying this year more than a billion dollars in war veterans' relief, France is paying just over a quarter of that sum, the total appropriation being $286,722,000 This does not mean, however, that France does not also have a war veterans' problem which is becoming a growing embarrassment to each successive government and to the country as a whole.

When Miss Enld Wilson was here last Fall she stated that she would return to compete in the women's national golf championship this year. But her announcement, made again a few days ago, carries much more significance now that she has won the British championship for the second time in succession and helped to stem the strong American invasion.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 2. -- Interest in the impending political battle in Arizona has become intense. It took a sudden flare recently when the Republicans, almost dormant during the Winter, suddenly realized that they have a good chance to carry the State.

There was general activity in the wholesale markets during the week, and although orders were not heavy they reflect consumer response to special price June promotions, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

PROFESSOR ROBINSON is the first scholar in any country to trace the history of the Russian peasant, from the beginning to the Revolution, in the light of materials made available since 1917. No Russian scholar has undertaken the task, for Russian historians are too busy revising history to engage in historical research.

At the seventy-second commencement of the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital, in the Town Hall, Tuesday evening, the degree of doctor of medicine will be conferred on eighty graduates of the college; and nurses' diplomas and pins will be presented to twenty-six graduates of the Nurses Training School.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- A little Kansas school, Arkansas City High, with three good pole vaulters, today won the twenty-eighth renewal of the University of Chicago's national interscholastic track and field championships with 31 2-7 points.

THOUGH compared with a pre-holiday period, the week's results in retail trade were reported ahead of the preceding week. The gain was credited to special promotional efforts, greater emphasis on value and closer attention to consumer demand.

PARIS, May 23. -- The stately horse-drawn landau, one of the last official vehicles of the species which was used for the formal excursions from the institute by members of the French Academy, is no more.

THE FOUNTAIN" is one of the most poetical pieces of prose fiction that has come to light for a long time, Yet, though Mr. Morgan is evidently of both a poetic and scholarly mind -- incidentally he is dramatic critic of The London Times -- he is not out of touch with the realities of daily living.

To a greater extent than ever before it is expected that the comprehensive facilities of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at its great testing laboratories at Langley Field, Va., will be used by the aviation industry at large this year.

A late rally last week failed to lift the prices of commodities on the local exchanges out of the trough of lows into which they had fallen earlier. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides and wood tops all closed lower than at the end of the preceding week.

George Kelly's great stop of Margrave's slashing grounder in the eighth inning of the nightcap saved the day for the Robins at Ebbets Field yesterday, gave them an even break and brought a tremendous burst of cheering from 25,000 fans for Kelly.

Adoption of a policy under which vendors of taxicabs who repossessed them from the operators for failure to meet payments would have the disposition of the operating certificates and licenses, under conditions preventing a monopoly or the elimination of independent owner-operators, was urged on the Board of Taxi-cab Control yesterday by Morris Markin, head of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Company.

THE recent emphasis on settings for fine furniture has encouraged the importation of unusual and highly artistic types of wall ornamentation. Eighteenth-century France supplies many of these unique interiors, for in Paris during that period the harmony between the walls and furnishings of a room reached a high degree of excellence.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4 (AP). -- A revolutionary junta, headed by Carlos Davila, former Ambassador to Washington, overthrew the government of President Juan Esteban Montero tonight and prepared to establish a socialistic State in Chile.

Despite Pittsburgh's forty-one-story skyscraper university, the world's tallest schoolhouse is yet to come. This at least, is the opinion of architects solving the mass movement; in fast elevators, of thousands of students, and space allotments for seats of learning in the modern city.

SINCE the first political convention broadcasts of 1924 radio has weaved its networks across the Mississippi and the Rockies. The microphone has mustered a great array of entertainers, many of whom never dreamed of going on the air until lons after KDKA made history by sending out the Harding-Cox election returns in 1920.

PARIS, May 3. -- Perhaps it is because the sun is shining after a month of storms and rain or perhaps just because the French people cannot remain gloomy very long, but whatever the reason Paris in the past few days has begun to take a more optimistic view than for many months.

The Nye bills, Nos. 2626 and 2628, governing trade practice conferences, will be favorably passed on by the Senate subcommittee, now considering them, within the week, and will also be reported out by the judiciary committee, according to authentic information from Washington received in trade association circles yesterday.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 30. -- Not so very long ago Ecuador produced about 60 per cent of the cacao beans of the world, but in 1922 the trees began to show signs of a strange growth and there followed a decrease in the crop. The mycologists of the newly founded experiment station promptly labeled the strange, exuberant sprouts as the witch-broom, or marasmus perniciosus, that had killed off the cacao orchards of Suriname.
CHICAGO, June 4. -- When they write down the names of America's truly great jockeys, 15,000 Chicago fans will give a lusty shout for Johnny Maiben.

Two of the largest industrial bond redemptions in recent months were announced last week for future months, together with numerous municipal calls for June, and several small lots of foreign and industrial loans for months subsequent to June. The current month's total is now $8,465,000, compared with $9,308,000 in May, and $73,900,000 in June, 1931, for corresponding dates.

BERLIN, June 4 (AP). -- The new German Cabinet, in announcing today its political program, said: "The foundation for any successful representation abroad of our national interests is inner political clarity.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange was reduced 617,601 shares last month to 2,140,560, according to statistics issued by the Exchange after the close of the market yesterday. The total on May 31 was the smallest reported since the Exchange on May 25, 1931, began to make public figures on the size or the short interest.

TOMORROW evening The Players Club will act Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida." Strictly speaking it will be a revival, since "Troilus and Cressida" was once acted at Yale and once acted by professionals in London within the present century, and probably it has been acted here and there by adventuresome organizations.

About 1,500 specimens of merchandise were tested in the initial week of the tested goods campaign being conducted by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., it was reported yesterday by Ephraim Freedman, director of the bureau of standards of the store. This compares with a weekly average of about 400 testa prior to the start of the quality drive.

ROME, June 3. -- Italy probably is among the very few countries whose total volume of exports have been practically unaffected by the worldwide depression. Speaking at the annual meeting of the National Institute of Exportation Deputy Guido Jung, president of the institute, pointed out that the value of Italian exports in 1931 compared to 1930 decreased only 15.8 per cent.

DUBLIN, June 2. -- Following a period of political discussion aroused by President de Valera's proposals to scrap the oath of allegiance, the people of the Free State are settling down to arrange the program of the International Eucharistic Congress of the Catholic Church, which opens here June 20.

MILLIONS of dollars' worth of food marketed annually in this country is perishable, Clarence Birdseye and Gerald A. Fitzgerald inform the American Chemical Society, evaporation, spoilage and the perils of transportation being responsible for great losses.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 4. -- Lower Hudson Valley athletes triumphed in the annual New York State Public High School Athletic Association track championships today, compiling 30 points to give Section 1 first place. Long Islands schools, representing Section 8, trailed by onequarter of a point.

SOME of the more outstanding problems of India, with its numerous, often antagonistic, races and even more numerous and more antagonistic creeds, are clearly and briefly described in this very interesting book. A short outline of India's history, a history which for more than a thousand years has been one of conquering invaders, is combined with a more detailed account of its religions.

CHARLOTTESVILLIE, Va., June 2. -- One of the things accomplished by the last session of the Virginia General Assembly with comparative expedition and resultant general disatisfaction was the redistricting of the State made neccessary after the 1930 census showed a decrease in population.

TORONTO, Ont., June 4. -- In less than forty years, or from 1892 to 1929, Canada increased the value of her mineral products from $17,000,000 to $311,000,000, an eighteen-fold expansion, and in 1931, notwithstanding the depressed condition of markets, the output of metals had a value of $228.000,000.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4. -- Pitcher Bill Ruddy's home run in the tenth with McLaughlin on base gave the New York Athletic Club a 9-to-7 victory over Yale today.

OCEAN voyages are famous for producing friendships, more or less enduring, but few develop so profitably as the encounter of Arturo Toscanini and Yehudi Menubin, the boy violinist, on a liner bringing the conductor from America to Europe.

The New York Giants, performing for the first time in thirty years without the guiding genius of John McGraw directing the moves, yesterday gave their newly appointed pilot, Memphis Bill Terry, the most wholehearted endorsement that was within their power to make.

For several years now young Joe McCluskey has been considered as America's leading and only hope for premier honors in the 3,000-meter steeplechase event at Los Angeles. When the Fordham captain raced over the barriers at the Penn Relays a month ago to set a new American record, his performance moved him up into the same class with the Finns.
