TORONTO, June 4. -- Young Kitty, flying the colors of the Edward F. Seagram Stable, in a driving finish, outlasted the Erindale Stable's Gay Parisian to win the Greyhound Handicap today at Thorncliffe Park.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- A controversy over the headquarters of George Washington here seemed no nearer solution today, after two rival groups had visited the Miller house in North Castle and the Purdy house here as a part of the Washington bicentennial celebration.

More than 4,000 employes of the city Department of Sanitation attended a communion service yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral and afterward marched in a body to the Hotel Astor, where they had breakfast in the grand ballroom.

ST. ALBANS, L.I., June 5 -- Prevented by the three-year rule from defending his title as intercollegiate champion this year, George T. Dunlap Jr., Princeton star, went out today and won another crown which has no strings attached to it.

HE won't be happy until he gets it. The reference is to Gene Sarazen and the British open golf championship. He is after it again, and this time he is staging his attack over the Prince's course at Sandwich, a long, hard test of golf. That should suit Gene. He is a long hitter.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- In a book entitled "Mr. Justice Brandeis," edited by Professor Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School and just published by the Yale University Press, Chief Justice Charles E. Hughes, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, recently retired, and other leaders in the law pay signal honor to the jurist in commemorating his seventy-fifth birthday.

The detrimental influence United States government has had on the Roman Catholic religion in the Philippine Islands was decried last night by the Rev. Charles G. Herzog, S.J., Professor of Theology at Woodstock College, Woodstock, Md., preaching at the farewell ceremony in the Church of St. Ignalius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, for fifteen Jesuit missionaries who are to leave soon to work among the Filipinos.

NEW ORLEANS, La., June 5 -- The week just passed witnessed a drop in cotton prices to the lowest levels in thirty-five years, or since the Fall of 1897, when the price for contracts dropped to 4.73 cents a pound. On Wednesday July contracts traded down to 5 cents and middling spots were quoted at 5.05 cents.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 5 -- The Pequot Yacht Club's Atlantic Class fleet won a victory over the Black Rock Yacht Club boats today, scoring 32 points to Black Rock's 23. Much of the race was a drifting match.

BERLIN, June 3 -- Although Bruening's resignation and von Papen's appointment created a political sensation, the only visible effect on business was the violent advance in stocks and the corresponding decline of fixed interest securities. This reflected the public's precipitant conclusion that the new Cabinet would embark on currency inflation and also perhaps enforce the proposal for reducing interest rates on bonds and mortgages.

Mr. MCGRAW has been often called the Napoleon of the national game. From the bench he directed battles on the diamond in which victories were snatched from the jaws of defeat. His was the mind that planned not only separate games but the strategy of campaigns that lasted from April to October.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Speaker Garner is undoubtedly correct as he is sincere in his statement that his program for unemployment relief by the building of numerous government buildings has no element of the "pork barrel" in it. Nevertheless, there lurks in every appropriation for new postoffice buildings an element of special privilege involving graft which should be guarded against with vigilance.
BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) -- Reading divided a double header with Baltimore today, winning the first game, 6 to 4, and losing the nightcap, 10 to 6.

The City Farm Colony horseshoe pitching team at Four Corners near West New Brighton, S.I., issued a challenge yesterday to any and all horseshoe pitching-teams in or near New York, all games to be played at Four Corners, stakes to be good chewing or smoking tobacco, or both, in any reasonable amount.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The crippled Washington Senators fell further behind the league-leading New York Yankees today by dropping a loosely played, slugging game to Philadelphia, 11 to 7. The Mackmen advanced from fifth to fourth place as a result.

By winning both games of a doubleheader with Pennsylvania last Monday, Columbia remained in the running for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship. The Lions have finished their season and are now in second place with a record of seven games won and three lost.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Hoover's plan to meet the unemployment problem and "to stiffen the whole agricultural situation" was made public in a statement issued by the White House this afternoon. The conclusions set forth in the statement were agreed upon by the President and members of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at conferences held yesterday at the President's Rapidan camp.

Prior to yesterday's game between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, the managers of the two teams completed a trade by which Pitcher Danny MacFayden was acquired by the Yankees in exchange for Pitchers Henry Johnson and Ivy Paul Andrews.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 5 -- Mid-Western iron and steel production schedules for this week show an acceleration by the leading independent interests. The Carnegie Steel Company expects to operate its Ohio works on a part-time basis, following a suspension.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 -- One hundred and sixty-four students will receive the degree of Bachelor of Laws at the twenty-third annual commencement of New Jersey Law School at the Old First Presbyterian Church here Tuesday evening. The Rev. Norman D. Fletcher of Montclair will deliver the commencement address.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., June -- Elected by the trustees as president of the Northfield Schools, Wilfred W. Fry, head of the N.W. Ayer advertising Company of Philadelphia, will receive a diploma dated 1896 from Mount Hermon School tomorrow when his son, Wayland A. Fry, receives one with the class of 1932.

The State's "paternalistic encroachment" upon the field of medicine and the public's failure to pay promptly its medical bills while using free clinics were criticized yesterday by Dr. David J. Kaliski, president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, in a statement advocating the instalment plan of paying the doctor's bills for patients with small incomes.

NEW HAVEN, June 4 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 60.2, which compares with 60.2 a week ago, 61.1 two weeks ago, 61.4 three weeks ago and 61.6 four weeks ago. This is the first week since April in which there has been no declines.

Stopping off at home for a day between their Philadelphia series and their first Western trip, the Yankees spent the afternoon pleasantly at the Stadium yesterday by administering a 12-to-1 beating to the Boston Red Sox.

T.Tong, a member of the royal family of Siam; Lady Muriel Fitzherbert, Lucien Lelong, Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt and Baron and Baroness Rudolph M. de Schanansee are among the passengers leaving tonight for Bremen via Cherbourg and Southampton on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others are:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Summer is now here with all its accompanying dangers at the seashore. It is not of these but of a potential danger that I wish to speak.

Soft shadows blurred the outlines of the sagging shack with the staring panes in the rear yard at 505 West Fifty-first Street at dusk yesterday as neighbors told the story of "Mother Barbara" Strohner.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Georgetown University will hold its 133d annual commencement tomorrow afternoon. The graduates will be addressed by Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

Modern society stands in need in these tragic times of the "cheerful ridicule of a Cervantes, to loosen the knees and lighten the hearts of the dollar worshipers," Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown of New York University told the graduating classes of 1932 yesterday afternoon in his centennial baccalaureate address, delivered in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library, University Heights.

NEWCASTLE, Pa., June 5 (AP) -- Several banknotes that were part of the $50,000 hoax ransom paid by Dr. John F. Condon to the supposed kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby have appeared in Newcastle, the police said today. Efforts to trace the passers of the money have failed.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Bringing total new issues of government securities during the 1932 fiscal year to the total of $9,448,000,000, Secretary Mills announced today that $750,000,000 in notes and certificates would make up the June 15 financing.
PITTSBURGH, June 5. -- Last week's production of steel is estimated to have been well under the 22 to 23 per cent rate in May up to Memorial Day, representing about one point gain from April.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 5 -- L.G. Chapin led fourteen entrants in the men's metropolitan round of the Spring championship tournament of the Metropolitan Archery Association in the second and concluding day at the Scarsdale High School athletic field today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5 -- Chancellor Flint gave Syracuse University's graduating class today a creed to carry with them into the world of affairs -- a world which, he said, was grappling with one of history's most stupendous economic upheavals. A crowd of 2,500 persons thronged Archbold Gymnasium this morning to hear the annual baccalaureate services, first event of the two-day commencement program.

An exhibition of paintings by Alethea Hill Platt, Alice Judson, Antoinette Inglis and Lucia Leffingwell has opened at the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street. It will continue until November. The work is the sort once happily described as "surface painting" -- the mere "look" of objects transcribed neither with distinction nor beauty.
TROY, N.Y., June 5 -- The largest number of graduates in the 108 years of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 269, will receive degrees at the annual commencement next Saturday.

An appeal for cancellation of reparations payments and international war debts, signed by fifty outstanding English churchmen acting under the auspices of the British Council of Ministers, has been sent to the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Luther A. Weigle, chairman of the council's administrative committee.

Signs of improvement in the real estate financing field are seen by the consulting committee formed at the invitation of Charles A. Miller, manager of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, with a view to aiding in the real estate mortgage problems of the Second Federal Reserve District.
PARIS, June 5 -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody won the women's singles championship of France by defeating Mme. Rene Mathieu, French tennis star, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, at Roland Garros Stadium today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5 -- Re-elected national chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition at the closing session of the conference here today, Dr. Daniel A. Poling of New York declared the task at hand is to aid parties and candidates in favor of enforcement and to defeat those for repeal.

The letter of the National Civil Service Reform League to President HOOVER about the postmasters deserves more attention at the hands of the Administration than it is likely to get in the midst of a campaign. The Postoffice Department is supposed to be a business organization, with no other constitutional function than to handle the mails.

Just when the Robins and 15,000 Sunday fans at Ebbets Field yesterday were rejoicing over the fact that the Carey athletes had won another game those irrepressible Phillies staged a ninth-inning assault to come from behind and win, 7 to 6.

Municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway b the Board of Transportation, although "unfortunate and unnecessary," would be far better than turning the line over to the B.M.T. or Interborough, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, declared yesterday in a statement issued from his home in Yonkers.

Reports of real estate brokers over the week-end indicate a good early Summer demand for housing properties in the suburbs. Most of the deals announced were leases in New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester.

PARIS, June 5 -- Two questions dominate all others in France: What attitude will Premier Herriot's new Radical Socialist Government take toward the German Junker Government of Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen and General Kurt von Schleicher and on what majority will M. Herriot depend?

The Chicago Conventions. In speculations about the length of the national conventions in Chicago this month the weather must not be left out of consideration. Nothing wilts a convention like a hot wave.

Two characters of fiction, George F. Babbitt, out of Sinclair Lewis's novel, and Soames Forsyte of the Forsyte Saga of Galsworthy, stand with Jane Addams, Colonel Charles Lindbergh, Einstein, Henry Ford and Freud as among the most colorful figures of our times, in the judgment of the staff of the Newark Public Library.

BERLIN, June 3 -- Mark exchange again weakened temporarily this week in foreign countries, possibly in connection with the inflation talk which accompanied the appointment of the new ministry. The weakening was unimportant, however, because the quantity of mark currency abroad and available for sales is very small, and because the Reichsbank is still in a position to intervene in support.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5 -- Declaring that it takes "a stout heart" to look at the world now and not suffer disillusionment, the Rev. A. E. Kinsolving, chaplain, called on the graduating class of the United States Military Academy today to face modern problems with courage and patience.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- One hundred and ninety-three flying cadets will enter the new "West Point of the Air" at Randolph Field, Texas, on July 1, the War Department announced today. It is one of the smallest classes in several years.

Contributions totaling $226,873 during three weeks of active solicitation in the Salvation Army's United Appeal for funds required for continuation of the Army's emergency relief and institutional activities in New York were announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The ranks at more than 2,000 war veterans demanding bonus payment threatened passive resistance tonight to any efforts to evacuate them from the capital.

When people turn their backs on Jesus they are simply condemning themselves, the Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. MacLeod said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

BOSTON, June 5 -- In sharp contrast to its imposing debut at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the new regime of Memphis Bill Terry as the manager of the Giants encountered no end of disaster today. Terry, himself, was shot down in action in the first inning of the second game, and on top of this mishap the Giants dropped a double-header to the Braves.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, June 5 -- As Iowa's Senatorial primary fight drew to a close the chances of any one polling 35 per cent of Republican votes were regarded as doubtful by seasoned politicians. A 35 per cent vote makes a nomination automatic. If no candidate gets 35 per cent, the choice is made by State convention.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- On the invitation of Exportles, the Soviet timber exporting trust, two Americans visited the Archangel district for a week and observed conditions. They afterward made affidavits that they could find no signs of convict or forced labor in the felling, rafting, sawing and loading of lumber destined for export to the United States and other countries.

Net funds of the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, Ltd., increased in 1931 by L723,052 to L25,415,698, and, after full provision for all outstanding liabilities and reserves for unexpired risks, the underwriting surplus stood at L219,544 at the end of the year as a result of operations in 1931.

MONTREAL, Que., June 5 -- Shareholders of Fraser Companies, Ltd., will receive only one share instead of ten now held under a plan of reorganization which has been adopted by the directors. Postponement of payment of interest for at least two years on the company's bonds and issuance of voting trust certificates representing common shares in lieu of the company's unsecured debentures are other features of the plan.

One hundred and forty-nine years ago this month a handful of Pennsylvania raw recruits, barracked at Philadelphia, their scanty numbers enlarged by a few inexperienced soldiers from Lancaster and a few actual veterans forced to march, tried to bulldoze Congress into giving them more pay.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Winter wheat in the Southwestern States is doing fairly well, with scattered rains in the eastern and part of the western sections and part of Texas. The crop is heading and maturing over a large area, and harvesting is under way in Texas and Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A tentative Republican prohibition plank declaring for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment, and said to be acceptable to the administration, was framed by fifteen Republican leaders at the Congressional Country Club today.
NEW YORK. Lieut. Col. Harold E. Hambro, Mrs. Hambro and their son, Nigel Scott Hambro, will arrive at the Barclay today from Canada, and will depart Wednesday night for their home in London.

"The trouble with our churches today is that they are burdened with a weight of old gospel which they accept as a static thing. The teachings of Jesus were never meant to be taken as adages, for Jesus saw man as a progressive being, a being that could become infinitely better," the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland said yesterday in his sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixtenth Street east of Third Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 5 -- While today was not scheduled to be the official opening date for Bailey's Beach, it nevertheless was so declared. The flags were run up, and by noon there were fully fifty persons in the water taking their first dip of the season.

ROME, June 5 (AP) -- As a result of the discovery yesterday of a plot to kill Premier Mussolini, a bomb search of exceptional thoroughness was conducted overnight to protect King Victor Emmanuel, who this morning reviewed 16,000 troops of the Rome garrison on the anniversary of the Italian Constitution.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Twenty-three Senators have declared in statements made to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom that they favor action by the Geneva Disarmament Conference toward a substantial reduction in world armaments.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation.
ROME, June 5 -- The vigilance of the Italian police yesterday averted another attempt on the life of Premier Benito Mussolini, it was revealed today by the government press bureau.
PANAMA CITY, June 5 -- Panama voted today with no disturbance reported and apparently with free and fair balloting, the polls closing at 4 P.M.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5 -- New apparatus and electrical appliances were shown today at the exhibit of the National Electric Light Association in the auditorium here.

LONDON, June 3 -- The course of British security values, stocks and bonds, since the suspension of the gold standard in September, presents some striking contrasts. The immediate effect of last September's ac- tion was to cause a general relapse, but within a month marked recovery occurred.

The Governors Island four repulsed the First Division A team of Fort Hamilton yesterday in the opening clash of their six-game polo series on the Governors Island field. A crowd of 3,000 saw the home quartet concede a four-goal handicap to the Fort Hamilton combination, and then overwhelm the visitors, 15 to 7.
NEWARK, N.J., June 5 -- Newark and Jersey City, divided a doubleheader today before a crowd of 16,000. The visitors won the first game, 4 to 3, and the home club captured the second, 11 to 2.

A place in the national open championship to be played at the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Flushing, L.I., on June 23, 24 and 25, will be the goal of 978 golfers who today are to play thirty-six holes of medal play on twenty courses throughout the country.

The famous "Spokesman" of President COOLIDGE lived a much ridiculed life and died an inglorious and unlamented death. Now it appears that Governor ROOSEVELT would resuscitate him, or at least create another in his image. On Saturday a long statement came from Hyde Park, given to the press by an anonymous gentleman who described himself as a spokesman for the Governor.

Charges that Mayor Walker, while recognizing conditions of vice exist- ing in the city and "the dastardly conduct of officials and others who, besides accepting graft, also framed women to increase their graft," had done absolutely nothing to remedy the conditions or prevent the graft were made in a statement issued yesterday by the executive committee of the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

DANBURY, Conn., June 5 -- Grappling crews who have dragged Lake Candlewood for the last eighteen hours have failed to find the body of Lawrence Verbank, aged 28, of Bedford Hills, N.Y., who was drowned when he was struck by a motor boat from which he was thrown Saturday night.

Declaring that "the bell has rung for the pussyfooter and the trimmer" and that party honesty is more important than party harmony, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, made public yesterday a prohibition repeal plank which he will offer to the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention.

Surf bathing came into its own again in the metropolitan area yesterday as a scorching sun, burning through a sultry haze, sent the mercury up to 88 degrees, a new high for the year, and started a mass movement to the beaches, parks and mountains.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP) -- Jimmy Reese, the new Cardinal utility infielder, made a brilliant debut today and helped the Cardinals take the first of two victories over Cincinnati, both won by scores of 3 to 2. The victors advanced from sixth to fourth place, while the Reds dropped from fourth to fifth.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 5 -- The Yale and Harvard rowing squads arrived at their training quarters today. Yale's contingent arrived about 2:30 o'clock, coming over from New Haven on Samuel Salvage's Diesel-powered yacht Colleen.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Comments upon Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's demand for a repeal plank, follow:

Twelve operettas will be presented during the Summer at the municipally owned Forest Theatre in St. Louis, beginning tonight with "The New Moon" and concluding with a musical version of "Cyrano de Bergerac" on August 28. Many Broadway actors have been recruited for their original roles in shows which have been seen here.

However the revolutionary government at Santiago may describe itself, it has sought power by unlawful methods. The revolt was successful only because it was backed by the armed forces of Chile disloyal to the duly elected Government.

Declaring that "pugnacity gone wrong is a tremendous evil, but pugnacity put to the service of cleaning up the deplorable mess of our government would do us all honor," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick urged New Yorkers yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Crop news on Winter wheat is bullish and has been for months. Harvesting is on in the Southwest, where the exportable surplus of wheat is raised. All efforts to advance and maintain a higher level of prices have failed, as Spring wheat conditions in the American and Canadian Northwests indicate a large crop.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5 (AP) -- The revolutionary junta moved swiftly today to rebuild the government structure along Socialist lines under Provisional President Carlos Davila.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 5 -- Information that Columbia's graduate crew probably would be the only one to enter the Olympic trials next month reached the Lions' training quarters at Krum Elbow today and proved the only noteworthy incident in an otherwise quiet Sunday's program.

Experienced steamship agents said yesterday that the outlook for Atlantic travel this month was fair. Both tourist and the third class are doing good business, they said, adding that this was likely to last until the middle of July.

The second of the new 30,000-ton liners under construction for the United States Lines at the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., will be named Washington, it was announced yesterday by P.A.S. Franklin, chairman of the board of directors of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operators of the lines.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Consumption of meats last week was at a good average and prices here were the lowest in years, while quality held up well and supplies were ample. Beef steers, cows and heifers advanced and closed 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight higher than the week before, with the top price on choice beef steers $7.75.

The list of 1932 graduates of the Horace Mann School for Boys was made public yesterday. Diplomas will be presented today at commence- ment exercises, at which Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, will preside. The commencement speaker will be James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University.

SANDWICH, England, June 5 -- The aspirants for the British open championship, which no Briton has won in the last nine years, set out for practice over the Royal St. George's course today muffled to the ears like Arctic explorers.

It is no longer in accord with public feeling to put all the blame for a child's delinquency or a man's crimes on the individual. Chemistry, psychology, studies of heredity and environment, and other scientific research have demonstrated the multiplicity of causes for unsocial behavior.
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen docked at Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, at 1:15 yesterday afternoon with 210 first-class passengers from the Channel ports.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senators Hull. Dill and Wheeler, regarded 35 the dominant Senate group supporting Governor Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President, were responsible for advising Governor Roosevelt to oppose Jouett Shouse for permanent chairman of the convention, it was said here tonight.
RYE, N.Y., June 5 -- Eleven inter-club yachts sailed a special race off the American Yacht Club today.

BONN, Germany, June 5 (AP) -- Under the baton of Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor of the Portland (Ore.) Symphony Orchestra, the Beethoven festival week opened here tonight, featuring Beethoven's symphonies. Elly Ney, American pianist, was starred in the performance.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- Bob Carey, Pacific Coast automobile racer, was victor over a field of fourteen, in a dirt track race at the State Fair Grounds today. The race, scheduled for 100 miles, was stopped at the end of the eighty-fourth lap of the one-mile track because of rain.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 5. -- Concentration of greater powers in the hands of the President of the United States, with abandonment in part of the present system of checks and balances, may be necessary to enable the Chief Executive to deal effectively with economic crises, Owen D. Young said here today in a commencement address.

Sophie Tucker's hardy vocalism is the most resounding of this week's items at the Palace, if Miss Tucker's vocalism can be called an item when the fact is, of course, that it is actually an institution. Four shows a day instead of merely two find her declaiming the old innuendoes as stridently as ever in the style to which she and her public are accustomed, which is a very positive style indeed.
A fast-swelling army of veterans marched steadily from all parts of the nation last night to join comrades in Washington demanding payment of the soldiers' bonus, The Associated Press reported.

A ten-week season of grand opera in English, to begin at the Imperial Theatre Sept. 26, is planned by Milton Aborn, director of the Aborn English Grand Opera Company, he announced yesterday in his offices at the Imperial Theatre.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A week, or possibly a fortnight, of bitter controversy faced Congress tonight with the paramount legislative questions of taxes, economy, relief and possibly the bonus to be settled.

Norman Armitage of the Fencers Club, national outdoor saber champion in 1929 and 1930, regained the title in the competition held on the New York A.C. grounds at Travers Island yesterday. Armitage won four matches in the final round to capture the crown.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5 -- A Socialist republic was proclaimed in Chile tonight by the revolutionary junta which seized power yesterday from the government of President Juan Esteban Montero.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 5 (AP) -- Rochester won two extra-inning games from Toronto to break a losing streak of four today. George Puccinelli hit two home runs in the first game, one in the tenth inning for a 5-to-4 triumph.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 5 (AP) -- The Bisons increased their league leadership today by whipping Montreal in both halves of a double encounter, running their latest winning streak to eight straight. The scores were 11 to 6 and 5 to 3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Like many others who enjoy being out in the country over the week-end, I am a pedestrian as well as a motorist, and I can appreciate the viewpoint of each with regard to the "sins" of the highway committed by the other.

PARIS, June 3 -- The comment of this market on the continued movement of exchange at New York and the export of gold is that the great proportion of the sales of dollar exchange have still been coming from the Bank of France and other European central banks, particularly that of Switzerland, which continue to liquidate their foreign balances.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP) -- Detroit scored six runs in the eighth inning today to end a threat of being toppled from third place in the American League. The rally enabled the Tigers to defeat Cleveland, 10 to 9.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Business here is moving along in a quiet way despite the political influences that have tended to hold it back for months. Business men in meetings last week demanded reductions of government expenditures. At the same time they were looking for a slow pick-up in buying.

Women active in the charitable work of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children have arranged a bridge tournament in behalf of that institution to take place on four successive Wednesday afternoons at the home of Mrs. Harold E. Talbott in Old Westbury, L.I.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 5 (AP) -- Robert R. Reynolds, who campaigned on a platform calling for repeal of prohibition, was leading a field of five candidates for the Democratic nomination as Senator when the vote in Saturday's primary from 1,355 of the State's 1,823 precincts had been tabulated.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- Grain shipments last week were under the total a year ago, except flaxseed, the price of which was depressed and farmers are withholding supplies in the hope that small sowings will be followed by a better demand at the end of the year.

The scope of the Bureau of Biological Survey of the Department of Agriculture includes wild life conservation and game protection. This, of course, is a vast difference from the time when the bureau some twenty-five years ago was known as the Division of Entomology.

The new United Fruit liner Quirigua is scheduled to dock this morning at Pier 9, North River, on her first trip to New York." She was reported yesterday en route from the Fore River yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, where she was recently completed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- Charities to be selected by executors for the estate of Henry C. Rowe will participate eventually in probably more than $1,000,000, it was revealed yesterday in the will presented before Probate Judge John L. Gilson here on an application made by Judge Samuel H. Davis of Westerly, R.I., for an order of distribution.

Fordham University held its baccalaureate services in the university chapel yesterday morning. The 280 graduates of Fordham College, in academic robes, attended solemn high mass and heard the baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. John J. Scally of the class of '18.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Fluctuations in the level of monetary gold stocks of the United States between May, 1923, and June, 1932, have been marked by increases of $1,066,000,000 and declines of $988,000,000, due chiefly to importation and exportation, leaving a net gain of $78,000,000 during these years, according to an analysis of Federal Reserve figures today.

BAYSIDE, L.I., June 5 -- Adrian Iselin 2d sailed his Star class yacht Ace to victory over H.B. Atkin's Jubilee in the special contest of the Bayside Yacht Club today, scoring by 3 minutes 25 seconds. J. W. Smith's Sonny was third.

Two 21-year-old youths from opposite sides of the continent, Ernest Crosbie of the Cross-Country Club of Baltimore and Bill Chisholm of the Los Angeles A.C., gained places on the American Olympic team yesterday by finishing one-two in the 50,000-meter final Olympic walking tryout five times around Central Park.

Governor Roosevelt and his anonymous spokesman who attacked Samuel Seabury's motives were accused last night by the City Affairs Committee of drawing a red herring across the issue of "whether or not Mayor Walker is fit to hold office."

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 5 -- Coast Guards in a seaplane and boats, marine police and yachtsmen searched the sea between Marblehead and Gloucester today for the body of Norman L. Skene, noted boat designer and naval architect, believed to have drowned yesterday during a canoe trip.

A current Dow Service release by Allen E. Beals says some real estate owners and architects in this city have about made up their minds to proceed with certain construction projects which they have been postponing from time to time because of uncertainty in the building trades over settlement of the wage dispute.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bulkley Hubbell of New York opened Brookside at Williamstown today and quietly observed their fifty-third wedding anniversary. Mr. Hubbell is a retired lawyer and is a former president of the New York Board of Education and one-time trustee of Williams College.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The text of the White House statement issued today on conclusions reached at the President's conference with members of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Board at his Rapidan camp read:

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The overthrow of the Montero Government in Chile by revolutionists who set up a Socialist republic is viewed with deepest concern in high official circles in Washington. United States investments in Chile are tremendous and while administration circles tonight refused to comment on developments, pending more detailed information concerning the purposes of the new government, there was no attempt to disguise the gravity with which the situation was viewed.

The Christian religion is challenged today not in matters of minor importance, but at the very centre of its being by questions of fundamental belief, the Rev. Dr. Frederick L. Fagley, associate secretary of the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 5 -- In an address this evening at a dinner of the National Association of Jewish Centre Executives, now holding its annual conference here, Harry L. Glucksman, executive director of the National Jewish Welfare Board, took issue with a statement of Secretary of the Interior Wilbur concerning the care of children during the depression.

Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, was praised as a great and faithful leader of Judaism and received a testimonial of appreciation for his thirty years of service to the seminary at the commencement exercises of the institution yesterday afternoon.

Herbert L. Bowman, the defending champion, who is seeded No. 4; Julius Seligson, seeded No. 1, and Edward E. Jenkins Jr., seeded No. 6, gained the quarter-final round yesterday in the men's thirty-sixth annual metropolitan championship clay court tennis tournament at the New York Tennis Club.
The New York State Grand Commandery of the Knights Templar opened its 119th annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The historians of the future will place the responsibility for the present "chaos" in industry and in international relations largely upon Christianity as it is now organized, the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale said yesterday morning in his sermon at St. James Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and 126th Street.

The necessity of replacing the old theological concept of God with a modern substitute was the topic of the sermon delivered before the members of the Community Church, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, by the Rev. Lon Ray Call, associate pastor.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 3 -- In view of statements that 80 per cent of the Texas delegation are favorable to Roosevelt and your editorial comment thereon, I shall appreciate your carrying the following statement:

MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- A split in the political group that rules Mexico was indicated today when El Nacional, organ of the National Revolutionary party founded by General Plutarco Elias Calles, denounced the new Vera Cruz State expropriation law.

Summer lines were active in the wholesale markets here last week, with orders and reorders concentrated on apparel and accessories for current retail promotions. White was emphasized, not only in outer apparel but in accessories and undergarments as well.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 5 -- At the commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle today 161 young women who will receive degrees tomorrow held a reception for relatives and friends in Leland Castle. The reception was preceded by services in the chapel, when Mgr. John P. Chidwick, president of the college, delivered the baccalaureate sermon.

To bring about full recovery of international trade and finance and thus lift the world from the depression, "intergovernmental conferences upon outstanding economic and financial questions" must be called "as soon as possible," Silas H. Strawn, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and chairman of the American Committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, asserted yesterday.

In these weeks of commencement addresses so many words are uttered that confusion seems worse confounded by the multitude and variety of counsels. But in the midst of them is heard a voice that has often spoken in order to lift the views of many into one clear counsel.

BERLIN, June 5 -- Mecklenburg-Schwerin, one of the Federated States in North Germany, held its Diet elections today and the results follow those of the election in the somewhat smaller State of Oldenburg last Sunday in emphasizing two factors -- German discontent with the present order of things and an increasing popular tendency to seek in Adolf Hitler and his Nazi party that which shall provide the remedy.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Borough of Brooklyn in 1930 had 1,109,299 workers regarded by the Census Bureau as gainfully employed in its population over 10 years of age. They constituted 43.3 per cent of the borough's total population of 2,560,401 and were 52.4 per cent of that part past 10 years, according to figures made public by the bureau today.

A bursting front tire on an automobile that was passing east on the Williamsburg Bridge last night caused the car to crash into the sidewalk guard-rail, completely overturn, and resulted in serious injury to two of the occupants and the injury of five others.

Asserting that high officials of the Postoffice Department have maintained in the past year that Presidential postmasterships are still "virtually spoils of the party in power," the National Civil Service Reform League urges President Hoover, in an open letter made public yesterday, to "take such disciplinary action * * * as you deem appropriate."

Supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President will oppose Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, for permanent chairman of the national convention, which will convene at Chicago three weeks, from today, and have picked Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana for the place.

Central Park, noted hitherto for its natural beauties, its trees, shrubs, benches, walks and fishing pools, now boasts a Monte Carlo touch. It has no blue Mediterranean, of course, but northward a stream slips sadly down to Harlem Meer, and that is almost as good.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Senate's stock market investigation was headed today for a quick and sensational wind-up in time for the adjournment of Congress. Investigators were sent back to New York with instructions to finish their most important cases as quickly as possible and make their reports to the committee.

PARIS, June 5 -- Professor Georges Claude, who has conducted experiments at Matanzas, Cuba, in extracting power from the sea by use of the warm water at the top and the cold water 3,000 feet beneath the surface, believes he has found a way to cure one of the chief defects of his system.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 5 -- Following is the text of the address of Owen D. Young today before the Notre Dame graduating class:

Everybody is reading OWEN D. YOUNG'S address to the graduating class of Notre Dame on Sunday. It makes all other commencement speeches seem pale and perfunctory. When you nave begun it, you go on to the end as if drawn by a fascinating tale.
The text of John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s letter to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in which he favors repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, follows:

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- A crowd of about 3,000 men attempting an unemployment demonstration at the gates of the Mack Avenue plant of the Briggs Manufacturing Company were driven back this noontime after a brief struggle with fifty policemen armed with tear gas gombs and riot clubs.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- James Simpson chairman of the board of Marshall Field Co., replaced today Samuel Insull as chairman of the board of the three Insull operating utilities companies and virtually wrote finis to Mr. Insull's career as a public Utility magnate. Mr. Insull retired as chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company, the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6 -- The commencement exercises of the Pennington School for Boys will be held tomorrow morning in the school chapel, with the address to the graduating class by the Rev. Dr. Henry H. Crane of Scranton, Pa, Dr. Francis Harvey Green, headmaster, will present diplomas to thirty-three boys in the senior class.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The thirty-day furlough plan for Federal employes advocated by President Hoover came into direct conflict today with the flat 10 per cent salary reduction voted by the Senate Saturday, when Senator Moses introduced it as a substitute for the adopted measure.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6 -- A broad program for guidance in the future development of Essex County embracing ten major proposals was presented at the court house tonight by Harold M. Lewis, engineer of the Regional Plan Association, Inc. Mr. Lewis offered the Regional Plan program at a meeting of the Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders called for the formal presentation of a set of the Regional Plan volumes and a graphic map.

ATHENS, Ga., June 6 (AP) -- The World War only postponed depression, Frederick B. Robinson, president of the College of the City of New York, said today in the commencement address for the University of Georgia.

LOS ANGELES, June 6. -- Clara Kimball Young, once the reigning beauty of the screen, has been married four years and was seriously injured in an auto accident more than a week ago. This was disclosed today through investigation of an auction sale in which many of her treasured gifts will go under the hammer tomorrow.

For the first time since its formation the International Mercantile Marine Company will operate without the active participation of J.P. Morgan Co. At yesterday's annual meeting J.P. Morgan and Charles Steele, partners in the banking firm, retired from the board of directors, and were succeeded by Howard Bruce of Baltimore and John M. Perry of New York.

The stand of John D. Rockefeller Jr. against the prohibition amendment was greeted with surprise, criticism and some resentment yesterday by dry leaders and Mr. Rockefeller was accused of "wild" statements, impossible of proof.
LEWISBURG, Pa., June 6 -- A class of 199 was graduated from Bucknell University today, President Homer P. Rainey presenting the degrees.
A Red Bank hotel lease and a Jersey City apartment house sale featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

GENE SARAZEN, Macdonald Smith and Tommy Armour should qualify handily today at Sandwich. Their first rounds in the wind and the rain will give them plenty of leeway. Some "uninstructed delegates" from this side of the Atlantic did not do so well, but this was no surprise. They probably went over for the boat ride or a sight of the English landscape where

With the end of the long controversy at last reached by Congress, and the Senate started on a program of retrenchment in expenditures, the question of Federal relief is the great problem still facing Congress. After his conference at Rapidan with representatives of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve, the President again stated the program which he favors.

To "the trade," which likes to see its entertainment traveling under labels, the revue which arrived at the Shubert Theatre last night under the almost excesslvely blithe title of "Hey, Nonny, Nonny!" will be known as "a hot-weather show," which is a description not without its merits.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The House passed today, by 150 votes to 24, a bill introduced by Representative Hill of Alabama to revise the emergency officers' retirement act and to limit the retired pay of officers now holding civilian positions with the government or with corporations whose principal stock is owned by the United States.

A new theatrical producing organization called the Actors' Theatre, in no way connected with the former group of that name, will present "Gas," a play from the German of Georg Kaiser, about June 20, probably at the Chanin Auditorium. According to announcement, the Actors' Theatre is described as a "co-operative organization of professionals," with offices at 110 East Fifty-ninth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Topic of THE TIMES, "Scamped Work Durable," is interesting to lovers of Gothic architecture, as Peterborough Cathedral -- as was cited by a professor of architecture under whom I was studying in the "nineties" of the last century -- is almost the only medieval building known which has given evidence of unfaithful work in construction.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Treasury's deficit passed the $2,700,000,000 mark June 3.

A portrait of Owen D. Young as man, captain of industry, statesman and leader in the intricate task of adjusting social policy to modern industrial trends is presented in a biography of Mr. Young by Ida M. Tarbell, published today by the Macmillan Company.

SYRACUSE, June 6 -- Premier Richard B. Bennett of Canada proclaimed everlasting amity between Canada and the United States in his address today at the sixty-first annual commencement exercises at Syracuse University, in which ten baccalaureate and honorary degrees were conferred and 1,044 students were graduated.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) -- European anxiety over the fate of Stanislaus P. Hausner, Polish-American flier, deepened today as no word of him had been heard since he took off from New York last Friday.

Week-end suburban auctions, mostly involving beach and residential properties, brought but a fair amount of buyers and gave indication of a somewhat wider demand for realty in the outlying sections of the metropolitan area, auctioneers reported yesterday.

Unless an unforeseen change in the economic situation occurs, not less than $50,000,000 of city funds will be needed for the coming year for work and home relief, according to the directors of the Welfare Council, representing 1,200 private family welfare agencies.

WARSAW, June 6 -- G.B. Shaw's play "Too True to Be Good," which was banned by the Governor of Warsaw recently, is still a theatrical sensation here because of the producer's efforts to present it without the omissions demanded by the official censor.

LONDON, June 6 -- On a sudden invitation from Eamon de Valera; President of the Irish Free State Council, J.H. Thomas, British Secretary for Dominions, and Viscount Hailsham, Secretary for War, left, for Dublin tonight to discuss with him the existing deadlock between the British and Free State governments.
To the Editor of The New York Times: We have a real war on our hands, a war against fear, and nothing is being done about it from the psychological angle.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Here are five suggestions for staving off the "irreducible minimum" in the present depression:

LONDON, June 6 -- The sturdy little research ship William Scoresby arrived at London today after nineteen months' exploring in the South Atlantic and South Pacific Oceans and along the fringe of the Antarctic.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 6. -- Bobby Cruickshank, the Scot, led a field of close to 200 golfers in the metropolitan, section qualifying round for the national open championship today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

Considering the violence of the advance in the security markets on Friday and Saturday, the moderate reaction yesterday was accepted as a logical sequel. Obviously, there was considerable profit-taking and speculators who sought last week to anticipate the results of the formation of the bankers' investment pool were possibly a trifle less enthusiastic yesterday.

A battery of real estate lawyers who went to Brooklyn yesterday to do battle with the city of New York over some $700,000 worth of Coney Island beach property unexpectedly found themselves in a kind of lawyer's paradise.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The B.E. F. (Bonus Expeditionary Force), with 4,000 men bivouacked here and with several thousand more on the way, made final plans tonight for a parade tomorrow evening designed to show to Congress and the nation the strength of the movement for the immediate payment of $2,400,000,000 to the war veterans.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Under one of the most rigid rules ever accompanying a major hill in the House, Speaker Garner's $2,290,000,000 relief bill will be presented tomorrow noon and its fate will be known in the next few hours.

More Smiths hold public office in the United States than the possessors of any other name, according to a compilation made by the Biographical Research Bureau, 460 West Thirty-fourth Street, which yesterday released the second edition of its "Who's Who in Government."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 6 -- The eighty-ninth annual commencement exercises of Villanova College will be held on the campus of the Main Line School tomorrow. The Very Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Hickey, assistant general of the Order of St. Augustine, consultor of the Sacred Congregation of the Sacraments at Rome and former president of Villanova College, will preside.

The difficulties which confronted American banks in 1930 and 1931 did not develop because the banking system had become unsound but because abrupt changes in commodity and security prices and in production and trade revealed that the system had failed to adjust itself to changing economic conditions, according to a report which is to be published soon by the National Industrial Conference Board, 247 Park Avenue.

A shrinkage of $4,178,027,551 in the aggregate market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange is disclosed in the compilation for May issued by the Exchange yesterday. The ratio of security loans to market values was 1.86 per cent on June 1. compared with 1.87 per cent on May 1.

ORANGEBURG. N.Y., June 6 -- Jack Sharkey indulged in a lively eight-round workout today in the open, air arena, completely disregarding an injured eye. He boxed four rounds, one with Lou Flowers, two with Tommy De Stefano and one with Charley Anderson.

The pamphlet report of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for 1931 shows current assets of $37,361,669 on Dec. 31, including $10,779,052 cash, and current liabilities of $30,341,912, including $13,228,087 secured notes payable and $5,971,037 unsecured notes.

State of Illinois. The State of Illinois has scheduled an issue of $6,250,000 of 6 per cent revenue notes for award on June 16. The issue will be dated June 20, 1932. and will carry an indicated maturity of "not earlier than Dec. 1, 1932.'' Bids may be made for all or any part of the issue.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., regarded as the most prominent individual In the ranks of prohibition supporters, one of the largest contributors to the Anti-Saloon League, and who together with his father subscribed $350,000 to make possible adoption of prohibition legislation, declared himself yesterday in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
Courses and starting times for the New York Yacht Club's eighty-first annual regatta and special races to be held on June 16 and 17 were announced yesterday.

ROME, June 6 -- Five persons, including Domenieo Bovone, alleged leader of a band of professional bombers, who is said to have confessed he was hired for $50,000 by anti-Fascists to kill Premier Mussolini, were committed today for trial by a special tribunal for the defense of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- Charles E. Ingersoll, lawyer, banker and railroad official, died of a heart attack at his home in Penllyn today after an illness of several months. He was in his seventy-second year.

Mrs. George H. Miles of Rumson, one of the seven delegates at large to the Republican National Convention from New Jersey and president of the Women's State Republican Club, announced yesterday that she would not attend the convention and would not vote for President Hoover for re-election unless he pledged himself for immediate repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

SYDNEY, June 6 -- Sydney, the capital of New South Wales, was a city astonished, in a Labor party demonstration in the city park yesterday, when 200,000 persons paraded and sang in the cause of former Premier J.T. Lang.
EUREKA, Cal., June 6 (AP) -- One woman was killed and three other persons injured in a severe earthquake which shook Northern California and Southern Oregon early today.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday that he would sent this week to all security dealers in the State forms which must be filled out and returned to him by July 1, giving full information as to past and present security sales and complete data as to the personnel of their organizations.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. P.D. Glassford, Superintendent of Police, announced tonight the uncovering of a communistic plot to interfere by force with the veterans parade tomorrow night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6 (AP) -- The staying powers of Chile's three-day-old Socialist Government were tested today by a counter-revolutionary movement in the south and an incipient general strike here in the capital.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A trend away from early marriage in the United States for the first time since the compilation of marital statistics was begun in 1890 is shown by figures for 1930 in a report issued by the Bureau of the Census today. The percentage of divorced rose for both sexes.

When the doctor prescribes a strict diet, the patient at first feels pleasantly important. But all too soon he begins to yearn for the forbidden foods. PAUL REBOUX, who loves to upset established notions and set up new ones, has written a book on diets which presents them in so deliciously appetizing a manner that the healthy reader may well envy invalids.

The identity of the person to whom Mayor Walker and Russell T. Sherwood paid more than 582,000 will not be a mystery to Governor Roosevelt when the case against the Mayor is laid before him by Samuel Seabury, it became known yesterday.

Representatives of American interests which have investments of more than $800,000,000 in Chile, declared yesterday they were not alarmed by the seizure of power by a junta that has been represented as possessing socialistic inclinations. Bankers for American companies doing business in Chile said they knew Provisional President Carlos G. Davila, and were sure that he was "not a Socialist."

The quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which recently was in session for a month in Atlantic City, was criticized severely by all four speakers at a specially called meeting yesterday of the Methodist Ministers' Association of New York and vicinity in the Methodist Book Concern Building, 150 Fifth Avenue, to hear reports from delegates to the conference.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A probable winding up of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's stock market investigation by the end of this week or the first of next was forecast tonight by those in close touch with the inquiry. Members of the committee's steering committee will make a final decision on the question tomorrow or Wednesday, but this evening it appeardd very generally settled that the investigation soon wil be finished.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Gainful workers in Manhattan Borough during 1930 numbered 995,034 and accounted for 53.3 per cent of the total population and 61.2 per cent of that part over 10 years of age, according to a further analysis of New York City occupation statistics made public today by the Census Bureau.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 6 AP) -- About 5,000 members of the Benevolent and Protective order of Elks were present today at their State convention here.

The longevity of the metropolitan clay court challenge bowl, in competition since 1908, became a little more precarious yesterday with the advance of Watson M. Washburn in the annual tournament at the New York Tennis Club.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP). -- Al Mamaux halted a Baltimore rally in the ninth inning by fanning three men to give Newark a 13-to-8 victory in the series opener today.

Even if The Players' production were uniformly excellent Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida," which was acted at Moss's Broadway Theatre last evening, would doubtless seem like an interminable play. Being more speculation than drama it discusses endlessly the springs of action, but with only the scantiest representations of action.

ALBANY, June 6 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt formally put Into effect today his plan to take care of unemployed by transferring them from the cities to farms. In a statement to the public, he appealed to the unemployed to notify the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration if they desired this form of relief.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The new tax bill designed to produce $1,118,300,000 in additional revenue for the fiscal year 1933 became law at 5 P.M. today.

The listed bond market held its heavy gains of Friday and Saturday reasonably well yesterday. Many railroad issues continued their advance, gaining 1 to 10 points. However, relatively small declines in several leading issues caused THE NEW YORK TIMES'S a average of railroad bonds to show a slight decline for the day, with public utility issues, and to some extent industrials, easier j in tone by comparison.

Municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway line, starting July 1, is urged by the City Affairs Committee in a statement issued yesterday voicing unqualified approval of the plan recently submitted to the Board of Estimate by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

Judge Caffey, sitting in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York, confirmed yesterday the appointments of John K. Garrigues, Herbert W. Brings and Herbert L. Nichols as ancillary receivers, and of Albridge C. Smith as their solicitor, for the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, and of Messrs.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 6 -- Edwin Markham, the poet, told the 1932 class of Clark University at the forty-second annual commencement today that "man has as his business the serving of the good."

WILMINGTON, Del., June 6 (AP). -- A new receivership suit against Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., was filed in chancery court late today by Marinus P.V. Newcastle of New York after a receivership suit filed by him in February was dismissed earlier in the day by the same court.

Recent conversations between the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation and bankers have paved the way for the retirement at maturity on Aug. 1 next of $13,500,000 three-year 6 1/2 per cent secured gold notes of the company, it was understood in well-informed Wall Street circles yesterday.

A crowd of nearly 500 cheered from the steps of Borough Hall when fourteen Brooklyn World War veterans, led by Edward J. Hunter of Buffalo, marphed in a small column of twos from Borough Hall Square, Brooklyn, yesterday morning en route to Washington to swell the ranks of the "bonus army."

READING, Pa., June 6 (AP). -- Reading opened its night baseball season tonight by dropping the first game of the series to Jersey City, 9 to 7. Moore and Outen got homers for Jersey City, while Hunnefield, Legett and Van Alstyne connected for the Keystones.

SANLWICH, England, June 6. -- Alfred Robert Bradbeer, young English professional from Somerset, headed the first qualifying round of the British open golf championship today with a 70 over the Royal St. George's course.

The 8,000 Knights Templar attending the 119th annual conclave of the Grand Commandery of the State of New York here, in their colorful uniforms and white plumed hats, marched yesterday afternoon up Riverside Drive from Eighty-sixth Street to Grant's Tomb.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors held its first meeting in the new $2,000,000 County Office Building this afternoon and formally accepted the completed structure from the contractors.

DUBLIN, June 6 -- Everybody in the Free State except the extremists hopes earnestly that the new Anglo-Irish discussions will be successful. In view of the paramount importance of the Ottava conference to the Free State and especially to her farmers, most persons here welcome Great Britain's acceptance of Eamon de Valera's invitation as a sign of British godd-will.

Strong impetus to the movement to bring about the adoption of wet planks by the Republican and Democratic National Conventions has been given by the declaration of John D. Rockefeller Jr. for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, in the opinion of local party leaders.

More than 300 parents and friends of members of the graduating class of the Hebrew Union College School for Teachers, which in the nine years of its existence has graduated 176 students and enrolled more than 2,000 others in its classes, were shocked last night by the announcement by the Rev. Dr. Julian Morgenstern, president of the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, that the school was to be discontinued.

ALBANY, June 6. -- The American Securities investing Corporation, a $100,000,000 concern whose operations are expected to help to stabilize the bond market, received its charter today from Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State. The company, which is the largest formed in this State this year, was organized by J. P. Morgan Co. in conjunction with nineteen other leading financial houses in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In reply to the announcement of James A. Farley yesterday that the Roosevelt leaders will support Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana for Permanent Chairman of the Democratic National Convention. Executive Chairman Jouett Shouse of the party's national committee today made a charge of broken faith agrainst Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt personally.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6 -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., who won the cup in 1930, was among the seeded players to come through the first round of the New England tennis tournament at the Hartford Golf Club today. Hall disposed of W.D. Qualie of Brooklyn. 6-0, 6-1.

PARIS, June 6. -- The Bourse had an extremely agitated session today, closing, however, without any great change being registered. It was hoped that Saturday's improvement in Wall Street would have a stlmuleting effect, and such, was the case at first, but the tendency was reversed on receipt of news of the suspension of payments by the British metal firm of Lewis Lazarus Sons.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6 -- The organization of a counter revolt against the three-day-old Socialist Government of Chile was admitted today, with the intimation that Communists who are dissatisfied with the moderate policy of the new regime are involved.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Silas H. Strawn, past president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged rigid economy and reduction in the cost of government today, coupled with a vigorous attempt to enlarge foreign trade through adjustment of the foreign debt situation, as essential to the return of prosperity.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 6 -- Dr. James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University, in the address at the annual graduation exercises of Upsala College, East Orange, today advised the fifty-six graduates to maintain interest in their government, religion and themselves, for in doing so they would find the steps that lead to success.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 6 -- Colleges and universities of the United States were denounced for robbing man of his soul and for discrediting the existance of God by the Rev. Dr. John S. Middleton, Professor of Philosophy at Dunwoodie Seminary, in the baccalaureate address at the commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle held this afternoon on the campus of the college.

Reports by 167 Class 1 railroad compiled by the Bureau of Railway Economics showed total net opera ting income of 520,621,000 in April against 539,653,000 in April, 1931, drop of 48 per cent. which compared with a fall of 30.5 per cent in March from a year before.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Chicago's recently organized committee of bankers and industrialists, set up to find ways to stimulate business and employment, held a meeting today which was attended by Owen D. Young, chairman of a similar committee now functioning in New York and chairman of the General Electric Company.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 6 (AP) -- Further returns from Saturday's Democratic primary tonight decreased the lead of Robert M. Reynolds of Asheville, a wet, from 12,000, held earlier in the day, to 8,366, in the race for the United States Senate nomination.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 6 -- Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, delivered the address at the annual Swarthmore College commencement exercises in Clothier Memorial this morning.

The first home game of the New York Giant box lacrosse team will be played at the Polo Grounds tonight when Manager Jack Filman's sextet clashes with the Boston Shamrocks in a regular American League contest. The Brooklyn Dodgers also will play tonight, meeting Toronto at Ebbets Field.

SANDWICH, England, June 6 (AP). -- A.R. Bradbeer, who shot a 70 over the St. George's course today to lead an international field of 236 competitors, is the youngest of seven English golfing brothers. The slender Somerset pro finished two under par for a one-stroke lead over all rivals.

Price trend in commodities was Irregular yesterday. Some articles were higher, while still others gave ground. In the first group, sugar and cocoa registered improvement, while the grains, cotton, coffee, hides, rubber and silk were easier. In other sections steadiness prevailed. Yesterday's closing wholesale cash prices for commodities in the New York market, unless otherwise noted, were:

LONDON, June 6 (Canadian Press). -- Nottinghamshire and Kent won their first-class county cricket matches by decisive margins today, while Hampshire defeated Derby by two wickets. Thanks to fine weather, great progress was made in all the scheduled fixtures, most of which will conclude tomorrow.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 6. -- The Summer headquarters of the Netherlands legation will be located at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor, who have leased the estate to J. H. van Royen, the Minister, and Mrs. van Royen.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Buried beneath an evalanche of hits in the first five innings, including Chuck Klein's fourteenth home run of the season, the Robins lost their second straight game to the Phillies today. The score was 15 to 7.

GENEVA, June 6 -- After five weeks of debate over the question of what army weapons should be abolished if the disarmament conference should decide on purely defensive armament for the world, the land commission of the conference today adopted its report and showed an even more thorough disagreement on every weapon than the naval commission did in the report it made last month.

Commuter, owned by Mrs. James Simpson Jr., won the Nassau County Handicap, feature yesterday of a charity program at Belmont Park which attracted a crowd of 12,000. The Westchester Racing Association turned the program over to the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau, with the result that approximately $25,000 was realized for the fund.

The appointment of a receiver for the Majestic Hotel Corporation, which constructed an apartment hotel on the site of the old Hotel Majestic, Central Park "West from Seventy-first to Seventy-second Street, was asked yesterday in a suit filed in Supreme Court by Samuel Brooks and Richard A. Schoeler, holders of mortgage certificates of $10,000. part of a $9,400,000 issue secured by a mortgage on the property.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 6 -- Cliff Sutter of New Orleans moved easily through two matches today to go a round ahead of the field in the first day's play of the national clay-court tennis championship.

Yesterday's markets moved with some irregularity. That they did not reflect with emphasis the action of the House, late Saturday afternoon, in concurring on the Senate's revenue bill, was due partly, in all probability, to the fact that a mood of pessimism does not readily lose its hold on a financial community's minds, but also to the fact that the action of the House had been taken for granted and had already moved prices upward.

HAVERPORD, Pa., June 6. -- Miss Charlotte Miller of Berkeley, Cal., and Miss Alice Francis of Orange, N.J., were among the winners in the opening matches of the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today.

SANDWICH, England, June 6. -- Of the American big three in the British open about whom you will naturally want to hear, Tommy Armour played at St. George's, and Gene Sarazen and Macdonald Smith at Prince's. All three played well enough to avoid, humanly speaking, the slightest danger, and I should rate their achievements as all, more or less, the same.

WASHINGTON, June 6 .-- The declaration of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and adoption of similar planks by both parties to remove the question from partisan politics caused the greatest political sensation in the capital in years.

PARIS, June 6 -- Playing invincible tennis Henri Cochet today for the fifth time became the champion of his native France when he defeated George de Stefani of Italy in the final of the French championships at Roland Garros Stadium, 6-0, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3.

William S. Dowdell of the cotton shipping firm of Well Brothers was elected yesterday president of the New York Cotton Exchange, succeeding Philip B. Weld. William S. McFadden, senior partner in George H. McFadden Brother, was elected vice president.

An easier tone in commercial paper with some names going at 2 1/2 per cent and a better supply of acceptances than previously with the Federal and individual banks buying, stood out as the interesting features of the money market. Both sections enjoyed a sustained activity throughout the day and by comparison with recent trading were active.

Mr. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER JR.'s letter to President BUTLER approving his resolution for submitting to conventions of the people in the several States a proposal for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment has a deep significance and is likely to have a powerful influence.

LONDON, June 6. -- The stocK markets were cheerful today under the stimulus of Wall Street's week end improvement and the latest European political developments, price generally showing a rising tendency. British Government funds again were supported.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lucien H. Tyng are returning on the Paris and will go to the Shallows, their place in Southampton.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- With only a week remaining before the Republican National Convention, Senator Watson of Indiana, the Republican leader, told newspaper men today it would be impossible for the Senate to finish its legislative duties in time for members to attend.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- New low prices for the season for all deliveries of grain except the July wheat future were made today on the Board of Trade here. Liquidation in a semi-demoralized market carried wheat off as much as 3 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 6 -- About 5 o'clock this afternoon a heavy rain storm swept down the Thames River, flattening out the four-mile course and making conditions ideal for the evening drills of the Yale-Harvard crews. The practice sessions today were the first in preparation for the regatta June 24.

Announcement yesterday that the Government's borrowings this month would be $750,000,000, making $9,448,000,000 for the fiscal year which ends June 30, possibly gave an erroneous impression. Out of this month's offering of one and three year loans, only $425,500,000 represented increase in the public debt; the rest merely provided for maturing short-term obligations.
Three deputies from the office of Sheriff McQuade in Brooklyn went to Coney Island yesterday afternoon prepared to remove from under the noses of the guests the furnishings of the Half Moon Hotel.

BERLIN, June 6 -- The forthcoming Reichstag election has been set for Sunday, July 31. It will be the fourth time in four months that the German electorate bas been called to the polls, and the date falls in the midst of the harvest season, which it was desired to avoid, but apparently there is no other choice.

The man who insists he is Frank de Trafford Craven, but who, according to the police of the radical squad, is Fritz Joubert Duquesne, German spy, who escaped from Believue Hospital in 1916 while he was being held for extradition to England on a charge of murder on the high seas, was freed yesterday by Federal Judge Prank J. Coleman.
Repesentative newspaper editorial comment on Mr. Rockefeller's letter folloivs:

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- During the Senate debate today over the 3 per cent tax on electrical energy, Chairman Smoot of the Finance Committee said the language adopted -- placing the tax on the buyer of electricity -- had been submitted by Chairman Crisp of the House conferees.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6 -- A two-mile sprint down the river this morning by the graduate and lightweight boats enlivened the day for the Columbia crews in training on the Hudson for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Here are some don'ts for keeping the Federal Reserve act operative:
The Fordham University College of Pharmacy will hold its graduating exercises this evening in the university gymnasium at 8 P.M.

BUCHAREST, June 6 -- Premier Alexander Valda-Voevod and seven members of the Cabinet he formed to succeed that of Dr. Nicholas Jorga were sworn in by the King today. The other portfolios will be filled when George Bratianu, leader of the Young Liberals, has decided whether he will support the new government.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary Stimson intends to move cautiously before determining upon recognition of the new government in Chile, and now expects that weeks will elapse before a decision is reached, even should the revolution quickly demonstrate its success.

BOSTON, June 6 -- Making good use of a dozen passes. Holy Cross won its annual series with Boston College today, scoring a 6-5 victory over the Eagles at University Heights. A week ago Saturday Holy Cross was a 10-2 victor. The Eagles outhit their Worcester rivals, but Ed Gallagher's wildness prevented them from tying the series.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 7 -- Poverty unparalleled in the history of modern Japan is described in the preliminary reports of four officials of the Department of Agriculture who are now investigating conditions among farmers in Nagano, Iwate, Niigata and Hyogo Prefectures, following an order of the Minister of Agriculture to prepare plans for immediate relief.

ALBANY, June B -- Governor Roosevelt indicated clearly today that he did not intend to enter into a controversy with Jouett Shouse over the decision of the Roosevelt supporters to back Senator Thomas J. Walsh instead of Mr. Shotise for permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. Friday --2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6. -- The new administration in Chile has been credited with a fierceness of purpose and violence of action which are entirely groundless in press information and forecasts, with far-reaching effects.

TOKYO, June 6 (AP) -- Alfred Massenet, director of the Franco-Asiatic Bank, is here as a representative of a group of French financial houses that would participate in the loan of several million francs to Manchukuo.

One estimate from New Suffolk, L.I., yesterday placed the number of boats fishing off Jessups Point and Middle Ground as over 400, and one of the reasons why the weakfish were not caught in any quantities, according to Captain Cornwell is that "they are overfed."

LONDON, June 6 -- The skeleton of Jeremy Bentham, great utilitarian reformer, looked on from a corner at the University of London tonight while some of his modern disciples held a dinner to commemorate his death, on June 6, 1832.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Edward F. Swift left an estate worth about $4,500,000, from which he made large bequests to a number of Chicago charities, it was disclosed today as atttorneys prepared to present his will for probate tomorrow.

Abundance of Keynoters. The less there is to say in partisan speeches this year, the greater the number of orators volunteering to say it. In the Democratic party, the dispute about who shall sound the keynote is, of course, tied up with the question who shall be the temporary chairman and who the permanent.
