TRENTON, N.J., June 6 -- "There will be no sales tax," Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County, Republican leader in the Legislature, declared today before an audience that had thronged the Assembly chambers to protest against the proposed general levy on necessities as well as luxuries.

MEXICO CITY, June 6 (AP) -- Eighty-eight earth shocks were registered on instruments here in the forty-eight hours ending at noon today, leading experts to believe that severe earthquakes might follow.

ALBANY, June 6 -- The Port of Albany was officially linked to the "Seven Seas" today at the opening of two-day dedication ceremonies which included a large aerial display and a parade of more than 5,000 persons.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6 -- More than 200 gypsies from all parts of the country gathered in the foreign tenement section here today to file past the bier of their dead leader, Theodore Mitchell, gypsy "king" of the French tribes in this country, who died in Boston on Memorial Day.

Four more jurors, making ten in all, were selected yesterday in the criminal branch of Supreme Court on the second day of the new trial of Isidor J. Kresel, lawyer, on a perjury indictment growing out of his testimony last February in the grand jury investigation of the failure of the Bank of United States.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 6 -- The annual commencement exercises of the Peddie School were held here this afternoon in the First Baptist Church. Diplomas were presented to sixty-two members of the graduating class by Horace Robinson, president of the Board of Corporators.

Former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley took possession of his new offices yesterday on the ninth floor of 570 Seventh Avenue and behind a large flat mission oak desk carried on his duties as head of the Trade Association Management Company, an unincorporated association affiliated with the Metropolitan Trade Association of Master Cleaners and Dyers.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open privately today its Summer exhibition. The splendid group of paintings, drawings and sculpture, part of which belongs to the museum's permanent collection, will be on public view beginning tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As we approach the two great hurly-burly political conventions, after long controversy in Congress over the most pressing issues of the budget, an anxious public should be as intent upon the platforms as on the nominations.

Delay by operators in installing an up-to-date ventilating system, which would have carried the odor of cooking mash beyond the scent of prohibition agents, resulted yesterday in the seizure at 296 South Street of one of the largest distilling plants ever uncovered in this district and liquor and equipment value in all at $300,000.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 6 (AP) -- Returns from almost a fourth of the State precincts in Iowa's Republican Senatorial primary election tonight gave Henry Field, seed merchant and radio station operator of Shenandoah, a lead over United States Senator Smith W. Brookhart for the Republican nomination.

Sixty feature pictures, ten less than last season, will be produced during the season of 1932-33 by Warner Brothers and the affiliated company, First National Pictures, Major Albert W. Warner, vice president of the two companies, announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 6. -- Unofficial but reliable sources disclosed today that a client's demand for $300,000 resulted in the closing Friday of the First National Bank of Beverly Hills to protect interests of other depositors, including many stars of the film world.

The work and aims of modern European composers and musicians was the topic of an international broadcast yesterday afternoon by Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who spoke before a microphone at Warsaw, Poland. Transoceanic radio conditions were especially kind for the occasion and Mr. Downes's voice was heard here with remarkable clarity.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Charles G. Dawes, president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, created to combat the economic depression, resigned this afternoon.

BERLIN, June 6. -- Trading on the Boerse today hovered between small transactions and complete stagnation, while the absence of all speculation tended to stabilize prices. The uncertainties regarding the plans of the new Cabinet, combined with the hope that it may bring some relief to business, prevented the public from selling, which accounts for advances in some stocks.

An American investigation into the affairs of the late Ivar Kreuger at Stockholm, particularly for the possible discovery of further assets of the International Match Corporation, has been decided upon by the Irving Trust Company as trustee in the International Match bankruptcy.

A notably sharp decline in retail failures featured business defaults for the week ended June 2, according to Bradstreet's. The number dropped to 343, as compared with 406 in the preceding week. The other major classifications also showed declines, with the exception of the banking group, which was unchanged at eighteen, suspensions.

A record entry of 246 individuals was approved yesterday by the championship committee for the fortieth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field title games and qualifying Olympic tryout at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. Since nearly all the athletes will double up in two or more events the aggregate entry reveals a total of more than 500 competitors for the twenty-one-event program.

BERLIN, June 7 -- The installation, of a Federal commissioner to govern in place of the Prussian Ministry was foreshadowed today as a solution of the parliamentary impass in the State when Chancellor von Papen, in negotiations with the Prussian Government, failed to arrive at an understanding on the immediate payment of 100,000,000 marks [$23,700,000] that the Reich owes Prussia and that is necessary to cover the deficit in the Prussian budget.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 7 (AP) -- Bill McAfee, Boston Braves' farmhand, put the silencer on Buffalo's bats for the first time in many a day today, pitching Montreal to a 4-to-2 victory, the Royals' first in five starts gainst the herd.

On loans aggregating $178,650,607 made by Morris Plan banks and companies throughout the country to more than 800,000 persons in 1931, losses as a result of failure to repay amounted to less than one-half of 1 per cent, according to the annual report of the Industrial Finance Corporation, parent company of the Morris Plan Corporation of America.

SHANGHAI, June 7 -- The United States gunboat Oahu, which forms part of the international patrol on the upper Yangtse River, had an engagement with 2,000 Chinese soldiers this morning more than 1,000 miles up that stream from Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate refused today to effect economies at the expense of World War veterans when it followed the example of the House in voting, 63 to 14, to eliminate seven items in the economy bill, which would have reduced veterans expenditures by $48,714,000.

Production of steel ingots last month by companies operating in this country decreased 132,387 tons from the total for the preceding month, according to the monthly compilation of the American Iron and Steel Institute, issued yesterday.

THE stocky gentleman with the spectacles and the turned-down hat brim made no attempt to deny his identity. He admitted that he was J.A. Robert Quinn, president of the Boston Red Sox. In other words: Guilty as charged. He was ready to give evidence and he made no claim of immunity.

Hundreds of messages, of congratulation were received by John D. Rockefeller Jr. yesterday on his advocacy of prohibition repeal as expressed in his letter to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, giving unqualified approval to Dr. Butler's proposal that the question of repeal be submitted by Congress for ratification to conventions of the people of the several States.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7 -- Syracuse University's crews arrived on the Hudson this morning to enter upon their training for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20, but were prevented by high winds and rough water from launching their shells.

All that the Republican opponents of Senator BROOKHART'S renomination had hoped to accomplish in Monday's primary election was to cut down his vote to below 35 per cent of the total. In such a case the primary law directs that the choice be made by the State convention, sure to be controlled by the "reactionaries."

PARIS, June 7 -- Premier Edouard Herriot received an overwhelming vote of confidence today in the French Chamber of Deputies in his first test of strength on the foreign policies of the new Radical Socialist Government. The vote was 390 to 152 in the new Chamber, Which has 612 Deputies.

J.M. Kurn, president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, and other officers of the company conferred yesterday with bankers on a plan to reduce the railroad's interest charges. Until recently there were indications of a deadlock between the management and the bankers, but it was considered certain last night that a compromise plan would be offered today or tomorrow for the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, expressed sharp disagreement yesterday with the statements of a committee of physicians who were seeking the authorization of additional city hospital facilities from the Board of Estimate on the ground that city hospitals could not cope with the large number of cases resulting from the depression.

More than 1,500 persons were present yesterday afternoon for the annual commencement exercises of the College of Mount St. Vincent, held in the auditorium on the college campus at Riverdale. The graduates numbered 138, including one who received a master's degree and another upon whom was conferred an honorary degree of Doctor of Literature.

The application of esthetics in modern plumbing will be the predominating note in the golden anniversary exposition of plumbing and heating products by the National Association of Master Plumbers of the United States, Inc., officials announced yesterday. The show is to be held at Madison Square Garden the week of June 20.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 -- Professor George McLean Harper would retire this month from the faculty of Princeton University after forty-three years of service, it became known today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 7 -- Nearly 200 flowers and plants were entered in the annual Maplewood flower show, which opened today at the Maplewood Women's Club. The garden department of the club is sponsoring the show, which will end tomorrow night.

The city and county of San Francisco, Cal., announced yesterday that bids would be opened on June 20 on $6,836,000 of Hetch-Hetchy water supply project bonds. One lot will consist of $5,477,000, due $169,000 on each June 1 from 1939 to 1970, and $69,000 in 1971, on which the interest rate may be bid up to 6 per cent.

CHESTER, Pa., June 7 -- Secretary Adams, receiving an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to the accompaniment of a salute of nineteen guns, told twenty-four graduates of the Pennsylvania Military College at commencement exercises today to remember that "the world is based on the principle of the survival of the fittest."

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Eleven persons were known dead, twelve were missing and nearly twoscore others were burned or injured in an explosion and fire which raged through the six-story Ellington Apartment building in downtown Cleveland early today.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 7 -- Mrs. Edward F. Low, with 42 points, took the sweepstake prize, a silver cup, at the anual Spring flower show of the Garden Club of Westfield held here today. Mrs. W.H. Wolfs, with 29 points, won the second prize.

Carl Gray, president of the Union Pacific, said yesterday he was hopeful that Fall traffic of the road would make a better comparison with 1931 than had been the case in recent months. He added that general business was running on the same level which prevailed in the last five or six months and that crop conditions in the road's territory were good to excellent.

The price trend in commodities was mixed, but for the most part the changes were unimportant in size. Grains, coffee, silk and hides were lower, with improved levels in cotton and sugar, cocoa ruling steady. Other articles were unchanged.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 7 (AP) -- Lloyd Fisher, member of counsel for John H. Curtis, said today that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh would be summoned as a defense witness in the trial of the Norfolk (Va.) boat builder on June 27 for obstructing the search for the kidnapped Lindbergh baby.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 -- Capturing two championship titles, one sweepstakes competition and two blue ribbons for extra measure, the Oldtown Hill Farm of Mrs. Florence F. Dibble of Newbury, Mass., was the most successful exhibitor today as fourteenth annual West Point Horse Show came to a close.

BERLIN, June 7 -- Because of the complete lack of stimulating news from Germany the Boerse reacted today to the decline in Wall Street yesterday and to the revolution in Chile. Stocks lost around 2 per cent, while bonds held steady. The prospect of a long and rigorous Reichstag election campaign served to increase the pessimism, but the absence of the public, preventing any large transactions, resulted in a comparatively stable market.

Subscribers to the block-aid campaign were urged yesterday to pay the balance of pledges expeditiously to assure emergency employment to 5,000 workers. Barklie McKee Henry, vice chairman of the Block Community Organization, said the campaign's biggest problem at present was to collect outstanding pledges which amount to more than $500,000.

CULVER, Ind., June 7 (AP) -- Culver Military Academy, by action of its owners, will become the trust of a permanent foundation, Bertram B. Culver, president of the board of trustees, announced at commencement today.

The proposed ordinance that would compel city employes to live within the city limits would place school teachers in a class with "the industrial serfs in the mining areas who must patronize the company store," according to a brief prepared by a joint committee of teachers' organizations and sent to members of the Board of Aldermen.
Further newspaper editorial comment on Mr. Rockefeller's stand for repeal follows:

What is needed in the United States is statesmanship to make chauvinism unpopular, John Thomas Smith, general counsel for General Motors, asserted yesterday in his replies to four questions submitted by the League of Nations Association on this country's participation in an international conference to consider economic problems.
CHICAGO, June 7 -- Interest at the Republican National Convention, due to assemble here a week from today, will centre in the controversy over a prohibition plank which now appears inevitable.

MANILA, June 7 -- Emphasizing the necessity for cooperation between Filipino leaders and United States officials in working out a basis for Philippine independence Manuel Quezon, the President of the Senate, deplored today the sharp criticism here of the Filipino independence mission in Washington.

LONDON, June 7 -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor ot the Exchequer, returned to London today after their prolonged absence because of illness, and eleventh-hour Cabinet discussions were immediately begun in anticipation of the opening of the Lausanne conference on reparations next week and the early resumption of the disarmament negotiations at Geneva.
Leaseholds of properties in scattered sections of Manhattan were reported yesterday. Deals were announced for buildings on the upper west side, in the midtown area and in downtown Manhattan.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith has accepted the challenge of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, his rival for the Democratic nomination for President, and will support to the limit Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, for the post of permanent chairman of the Democratic national Convention.

Four out of ten tubercular persons applying to the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association for diagnosis have allowed the disease to progress so far that they cannot be cured. In the association's annual report, just published, this distressing fact is stated.

With the arrival of 38,200 bags of coffee now afloat, the full amount of 1,275,000 bags which was bartered by the Brazilian Government for 25,000,000 bushels of wheat of the Grain Stabilization Corporation will have been delivered in New York, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reported yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Pla., June 7 (AP) -- Mark Wilcox, a West Palm Beach attorney, who campaigned on a platform advocating repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, tonight was leading Representative Ruth Bryan Owen in the Fourth Florida District Congressional race, as returns from today's Democratic primary began to be counted.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 7 (AP) -- Morris B. Levy of Yonkers, N.Y., filed a receivership suit in Chancery Court today against the White Sewing Machine Corporation, which has offices in New York. Insolvency was alleged in the bill.

What appeared to be the most powerful drive against prohibition yet launched developed yesterday with the publication of the letter of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, advocating repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Hoover's program to accelerate economic recovery, as re-announced by him after conferences with administration leaders Sunday, contains four principal recommendations, including an increase in the resources of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to $3,000,000,000, and enactment of legislation for a Federal home loan bank system.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., June 7 -- A baby's fall from her crib, early this morning, started a train of events that led to a collision between a speeding ambulance and an automobile that cost the lives of six persons, and critically injured a seventh. The baby, Emma Bloemaker, 2 years old, of 17 West Summit Avenue, Haddonfield; and her father, Richard J. Bloemker, a 36-year-old printer, were among the casualties.

Walter E. Edge, United States Ambassador to France, arrived yesterday on the Paris of the French Line to attend the Republican National Convention in Chicago as a delegate at large from New Jersey. He was met at Quarantine by political associates from Newark, who will accompany him to Chicago on Sunday.

The sale of Christmas seals by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association has fallen short of that organization's goal of $300,000 by about $100,000, with the result that the association is appealing to its friends for funds to carry on its work uncurtailed.

The strange story of "Sister Carrie," Theodore Dreiser's first novel, the first edition of which was reviewed although not one copy was sold here until seven years later, is told by Mr. Dreiser in a foreword to the newly published Modern Library edition of this book.

Cathedral College, the preparatory department of St. Joseph's Seminary at Dunwoodie, will graduate a class of forty-five young men tonight, to enter the seminary in September to continue their studies for the Roman Catholic priesthood. The twenty-fifth annual commencement will be held in the auditorium of the Cathedral High School at 562 Lexington Avenue, with Cardinal Hayes presiding.

Prices of bonds were steady to firm in comparatively quiet trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Railroad bonds particularly held their recent gains for the most part. Foreign loans and United States Government bonds showed minor irregularity. Trading dropped below $9,000,000, being only slightly more than the total for the two-hour trading period last Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Wormser's letter on the subject of law reform directs attention to a condition with which every layman and every lawyer is thoroughly familiar. That the present system is antiquated and ineffective is also a matter of common knowledge.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 7 -- At the annual commencement of Peekskill Military Academy, held today, fifty-four cadets were graduated. The address to the graduates was delivered by the Right Rev. Bishop David Lincoln Ferris, D.D., of Rochester, N.Y.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Ydnkers, N.Y., reached the fourth round in the Pennsylvania and Middle States tennis championships today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, by taking the measure of A.W. Patterson of Harvard, 6-1, 6-4.
Stocks of slab zinc in the United States on June 1 amounted to 132,580 short tons, compared with 132,025 tons on May 1 and 143,049 tons on June 1, 1931, according to the American Zinc Institute.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., June 7 -- Miss Bea Gottlieb, representing the Glen Oaks Country Club of Great Neck, L.I., registered an 83 to capture the low gross honors at the weekly tourney conducted by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association on the Leewood Golf Club links today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7 (AP) -- The close race between Representative Gilbert N. Haugen, dean of the National House, and C.A. Benson for the Republican, nomination in the Fourth Congressional District apparently was won by the co-author of the McNary-Haugen farm relief bill.
To the Editor of The New York Times: J.G.'s letter to THE TIMES deserves attention. Our enthusiasm for aviation will not survive the selfishness of aviators.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Details of the agreement between France and the United States for a modification of the French quota system as applied to American imports were received by the State Department today from the American Embassy in Paris.

LONDON, June 7 (Canadian Press) -- Surrey and Leicestershire Won their county cricket matches concluding today, while in other matches the touring teams from South America and India scored decisive victories.

How to raise money for relief of the unemployed in New Jersey, who are said to number 800,000, is a question that baffles the State Legislature. A proposal to add 2 cents to the three-cent tax on gasoline was so vigorously opposed that it was abandoned.

NEWARK, N.J., June 7 -- Degrees of Bachelor of Law were awarded to 164 members of the graduating class of the New Jersey Law School tonight at commencement exercises held at the Old First Presbyterian here. Governor A Harry Moore, a graduate of the class of '24, who had expected to present the prizes and honors, was unable to attend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the eight months since my return from a long stay abroad I have traveled considerably about the country and am shocked at our frivolity in connection with the convention of the Democrats.

The Grand Commandery, Knights Templar of the State of New York, ended yesterday its annual three-day conclave with a business session in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in the morning, at which officers were elected for the ensuing year, and a dinner in the evening to Sir Knight Arthur L. Lee, retiring Right Eminent Grand Commander.
NEW YORK. The Ambassador to France and Mrs. Walter E. Edge, who arrived on the Paris, are at the Ambassador.

The memorial exhibition of work by Daniel Chester French, who at his death last October was dean, of American sculptors, opened yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries. More than forty items, including several small preliminary plastic sketches, compose this showing, which will ramain through June 25.

Activity in the acceptance market was again the feature. The supply was much better than the demand which continued to come from the Federal and outside banks. Rates remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call money held at 2 1/2 per cent, but Street trades at 1, a drop of 1/2, reflected offerings from private bankers.
COMMERCIAL, PAPER. Yesterday-2 3/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' Paper.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Cincinnati Union Terminal Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of an $11,400,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for completion of the union station and equipment terminal it is now constructing.

BELGRADE, June 7 -- Dr. Mile Budak, prominent lawyer of Zagreb and a fervent Croatian Nationalist, was wounded so severely by three men armed with clubs and daggers on the main street of the Croatian city today that he was not expected to survive tonight at the hospital where he was taken.

The march on Washington of the "bonus army" of ex-service men was denounced last night by General James G. Harbord as a direct attempt to hold up the government of the United States. General Harbord spoke at a dinner at the National Republican Club in his honor and in honor of Richard W. Lawrence, also an ex-president of the organization.

Fordham University will confer 680 degrees this afternoon at commencement exercises of the College of Arts and Sciences, Graduate School, Teachers College and the Schools of Sociology and Business Administration.
Samuel Seabury expected yesterday to send his analysis of the case against Mayor Walker to Governor Roosevelt by tonight or tomorrow morning.

SEATTLE, June 7 -- John F. Dore, attorney and former police reporter, became Mayor of Seattle yesterday to the accompaniment of city excitement that included an unprecedented midnight inauguration, a drastic reformation of the Police Department, salary cuts for all city officials, including the Mayor, an unemployment demonstration, a mass meeting of 15,000 citizens in City Hall Park to hear the inaugural speech and a warning to the underworld that graft and vice must cease.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Wheat made a feeble effort to rally today on the Board of Trade here, but the buying seemed to exhaust itself after a fractional advance above Monday's finish. Spreading operations between this market and Winnipeg, as well as pressure from local operators, filled buyers up and a decline of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the best figures followed, with scattered liquidation developing on the way down.

An officer, two tellers and a discount clerk in a Brooklyn branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company were arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny for thefts totaling $172,000 from the bank. The loss was said to be covered by surety bonds.

Mayor Walker and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial clashed yesterday on the question of how much money the city has available to finance its extra-budgetary activities for the rest of this year, when the matter came up before the Board of Estimate in connection with a request for $2,000,000 for unemployment relief up to Aug. 1.

PARIS, June 7 -- The trend of prices was irregularly downward on the Bourse today. Uncertainty about the internal and exterior political situations was blamed chiefly for the tendency among professional speculators to realize or mark time. Such leaders as Suez Canal, Pachiney, Air Liquide, Citroen, Rio Tinto and Royal Dutch were from 20 to 205 francs lower.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I quote from Henry Ford's advertisements: "Employed men, in groups of ten, twenty or fifty, could rent farms and operate them with several unemployed families.

A steady decline in the gross sale of all kinds and types of music does not indicate "an incipient musical degeneracy," William Arms Fisher, vice president and publishing manager of Oliver Ditson Co., declared at the annual meeting of the Music Publisners' Association yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 7 -- After a late start, Mrs. Marion Zinderstein Jessup of Wilmington, defending singles champion, reached the quarter-final round of the Women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club today.

Working swiftly and with a minimum of waste motion, three armed youths entered the offices of the Bristol Seamless Ring Company, on the third floor of 123 Liberty Street, just at the closing hour last evening; held up, bound and gagged the owner and ten employes and escaped with uncut diamonds, platinum settings, watches and other jewelry, taken from the safe.
ALBANY, June 7 -- Governor Roosevelt reavowed tonight his stand for prohibition repeal and expressed optimism about an early change in liquor control conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The electorate of Iowa has turned away from Senator Smith Wildman Brookhart, denouncer, of big business and that of North Carolina from Senator Cameron Morrison, an unflinching dry.

The second fastest time for the Speed Handicap was reeled off at Belmont Park yesterday when the Sage Stable's Microphone stepped down the Widener chute in 1:03 4-5 for the five and one-half furlongs. Chestnut Oak, winner in 1929, captured the stake in 1:02 4-5, the track record for the distance.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 7 -- E.W. Edwards, president of the Fifth-Third Union Trust Company, one of the largest banks in the Middle West, followed John D. Rockefeller Jr. today in changing his viewpoint on prohibition. In a prepared statement Mr. Edwards said:

PARIS, June 7 (AP) -- For the first time in two weeks the American dollar showed improvement on the foreign exchange market today. The quotation was 25.3275, as against 25.3250, the level at which it had stood since May 25. The improvement was attributed to the action of the United States Congress in voting the tax bill.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- As this session of Congress nears an end, the Senate finds itself once more hopefully viewed as the nation's bulwark against radical and irresponsible legislation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7 -- Former President Juan Esteban Montero, who was deposed by the new socialistic regime Saturday, has taken refuge in the Argentine Embassy, thus dispelling rumors that he was on the way down the coast to head a counter-revolutionary movement in the south.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The House today passed the Garner relief bill, carrying a total of $2,290,000,000, by a vote of 216 to 182, after four hours of bitter partisan debate which at times found the Republicans so resigned to defeat that several members ridiculed the Democrats with "pork-barrel" poetry.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 8 -- Steps for drafting of emergency measures to aid farmers, many of whom poverty has brought to the dire straits of eating feed intended for animals and selling young daughters, were taken by Premier Makoto Saito today.
Those who have been following the proposal for legislative measures to improve the waterfowl situation are viewing with interest the fate of the proposed Federal dollar stamp plan.

PARIS, June 7 (AP) -- The Chamber of Deputies vote today in support of Edouard Herriot's newly formed Cabinet came from the Left and well over toward the Centre Right, including several members of the former government, despite opposition from, his predecessor in the Premiership, Andre Tardieu.
Annie Bartels has extended to May 1, 1937, at 5 1/2 per cent, the mortgage for $20,000 she holds from the Yorkville Boys Holding Corporation, Jack Rothstein president, on 432 E. 84th St.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have in our country a radical dry group demanding the total elimination of alcohol as a beverage and its strict control by Congress for medicinal use. These people have in the past permitted themselves to become the unquestioning followers of those moral demagogues, those religious profiteers and those political clerics whose emotional excesses harden the heart against temperance and moderation.

HAVANA, June 7 -- A writ of habeas corpus issued by the criminal section of the Audiencia Court of Havana ordering the appearance today of Colonel Roberto Mendez Penate, one of the most important leaders of the revolt of last August, who has been held in the Isle of Pines penitentiary since May 23 on a charge of being implicated in a new revolutionary plot, was ignored by the military authorities.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7 -- The counter-revolutionary movement which started yesterday in the south continued today to smolder, apparently gaining some additional support, although definite news from the affected region wag meager, and it was impossible to say whether the revolt was formidable.

The American Diamond liner Black Eagle, formerly the Tomalva, will sail from New York for Antwerp on July 15, the first of the fleet of six ships to be rebuilt and improved under an agreement with the United States Shipping Board at a cost of about $1,000,000.
READING, Pa., June 7 (AP) -- Six runs in the seventh inning were not enough for Reading to overcome the Jersey City lead here tonight, and Jersey City took the second game in a row, 12 to 7.
The dollar rallied strongly in the foreign exchange market yesterday on the improvement of sentiment abroad produced by the passage of the new tax bill, assuring the balancing of the Federal budget.

Plans for five festival concerts to be held next season in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Aid Fund were announced yesterday by Walter Damrosch at his home, 130 East Eightieth Street. The program, which will start on Nov. 26, will have its culmination on Jan. 25 with a pageant pantomime, the music of which, Mr. Damrosch said, "was written by a great master."

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- The nine-place Qualifying list alloted the Philadelphia district for the national open golf tournament was complete today after William A. Neilan of North Glenside, Pa., was eliminated in a play-off for seventh, eighth and ninth positions.

The Boston Shamrocks scored their second successive victory of the season over the New York Giants box lacrosse team at the Polo Grounds last night, 10 to 9. The game marked the local debut of the Giants and was witnessed by a crowd of 1,000 enthusiastic fans.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Lieutenant Alford J. Williams, former navy speed and stunt flyer, and Captain Ashley McKinley, who was aerial surveyor of the Byrd Antarctic Expedition and made the flight over the South Pole, are planning a flight by airplane over the Himalayas.

SANDWICH, England, June 7 (AP) -- Eric McRuvie and Don Curtis broke the record at Prince's by two strokes when, they blazed away at one of the toughest golfing tests in Britain for 69s today. Their cards were five under par and broke the old record of 71, set by Jock Hutchison.

Wall Street seemed convinced that yesterday's moderate decline on the Stock Exchange was the result of fresh liquidation. However, the selling was slow and of little effect. The total volume in the stock market was 833,649 shares, compared with 962,785 on the day before.

HARTFORD, June 7 -- Fritz Mercur of Bethlehem Pa., the former Lehigh star, required three sets today to eliminate the Hartford veteran, Robert Swain, in the second round of the New England tennis tournament by 6 -- 3, 9 -- 11, 6 - 2. Another Hartford veteran, Joseph W. Thurston, went three sets before John Donley of New York won, 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
Watson Washburn's endeavor to retire the metropolitan clay court challenge bowl, upon which he established legs in 1913 and 1915, came to grief yesterday at the New York Tennis Club.

New York University will celebrate its centennial commencement today. In outdoor ceremonies on Ohio Field, University Heights, at 11 A.M., Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown will confer 3,942 degrees and certificates, the largest number in the history of the university.

DETROIT, June 7 -- Six Detroit errors made the Yankees' first game of the year in the West an easy victory today, the score being 9 to 2. All six misplays figured in the Yankee scoring and all except one of the Yankee runs had one or more errors helping it, so that, although outbatted, nine hits to eight, they had a runaway time of it from the second inning to the finish.

TRENTON, N.J., June 7 -- A bill calling for graded salary reductions from 2 to 10 per cent for all State employes was passed by the Senate today, after the schedules had been approved by the State Civil Service Commission. A companion bill requesting constitutional officers, including Governor Moore and members of the judiciary, whose remuneration is not subject to change by the Legislature during their terms, to accept reductions also was passed.

DUBLIN, June 7 -- J.H. Thomas, Dominions Minister, and Viscount Hailsham, Secretary for War, were homeward-bound tonight after a meeting with President Eamon de Valera of the Irish Free State Council which, from all outward indications, was friendly and fruitful.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The former battleship Utah, now a radio-controlled target ship, will leave the Norfolk Navy Yard Thursday for the Pacific Coast, to be used as a mobile target for vessels of the United States fleet. The Utah was put in commission April 1 under command of Commander Randall Jacobs, in accordance with an order issued by the Navy Department.

Morris J. Levine of Newark sold to Max Henechowitz of the same city the Lincoln motion-picture theatre building at the northeast corner of Kearny and Elizabeth Avenues, Kearny. The two-story brick building covers a plot 100 by 100 feet and includes four stores.

A series of conferences was begun yesterday in what was described as a final attempt to settle amicably the several disputes in the building trades which have prevented approximately 150,000 mechanics and laborers from resuming normal contractual relations with their employers.
The Brooklyn Dodgers box lacrosse team scored a 13-to-5 triumph over the Toronto Club before a crowd of 2,000 at Ebbets Field last night.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June (AP) -- Ed Lejeck of Chicago and Louis Thalheimer of Dallas, two of the eight seeded players, were eliminated from the national clay courts tennis tournament today when they encountered unexpected opposition.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Pounding Roy Hansen for seventeen hits, Pittsburgh opened its Eastern invasion with a 7-to-4 triumph over the Phillies today. The defeat dropped the Phillies from seventh to last place.

"If you wish to rise, make enemies." Such was the advice which an old French public man gave to a political aspirant. Somehow it sounds more Irish than French -- perhaps more Democratic than either. All the signs now point to bitter quarrels in the Democratic National Convention.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7 -- Senator Smith W. Brookhart, running for renominatlon for the Senate in yesterday's Republican primary, appeared tonight to have been decisively defeated by Henry Field, 61-year-old seed merchant of Shenandoah.

A second selection from the private-letter books of Sir Walter Scott, which were preserved at Abbotsford until Hugh Walpole acquired them in 1921, has been announced for publication in England. They consist of letters written by all sorts and conditions of people to Sir Walter Scott and carefully preserved by him.

Dally average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,181,250 barrels, against 2,169,400 in the preceding week, an increase of 11,850 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Production east of California averaged 1,703,250 barrels daily, against 1,679,700.

Mayor Walker attacked reformers who said he had maligned the reputation of the city's uniformed forces yesterday when he addressed the twenty-six members of the Fire Department who received medals from him at City Hall in recognition of heroism and efficiency during the last year.

BUFFALO, June 7 -- Declaring that the financial difficulties which some cities are going through have proved "a blessing in disguise," Mayor John B. Harris of Watertown told the State Conference of Mayors today that "the real fact is our municipalities are now operating on a sounder basis than ever before."

LONDON, June 7 -- The stock exchange was quieter today at the opening, but was better in the afternoon on the reassuring statement by the secretary or the London Metal Exchange that the tin which the pool had taken over in connection with yesterday's failure had been disposed of.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- An agreement has been reached on a reaubmission plank by the Republicans, including a declaration more accptable to the drys than a repeal proposal. Republican leaders said tonight that the party's program would have the support of several prominent churchmen and those, aligned with the dry cause and the 1912 progressive movement.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Wes Ferrell chalked up his tenth pitching victory of the season today when the Indians overcame the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 to 3, after the score had been tied three times.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 7 -- At the graduation exercises of the Scarborough School here today Frank A. Vanderlip, who has been the moving spirit of the school from its beginning, presented to the school and the board of directors a deed to the property and building.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. George Fritz Chandler gave a small dinner at Maplehurst this evening.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Samuel Insull has definitely severed every tie, except those of sentiment, which bound him to the public utility companies of Chicago and the Middle West. He has presented his resignation as an officer or director of fifty-six companies which he founded or managed.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Production of crude petroleum throughout the United States in April amounted to 67,717,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,257,000 barrels, the Commerce Department announced today. This was an increase of 90,000 barrels over the average daily output of the preceding month, but was 7 per cent below that of April, 1931.

The jury was completed yesterday in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court for the new trial of Isidor J. Kresel, the lawyer, on the perjury indictment arising from his testimony about a year ago at the General Sessions trial which resulted in the conviction of Bernard K. Marcus and Saul Singer, officers of the defunct Bank of United States, and the latter's son, Herbert Singer, for misapplication of some of its funds.

DEANS, N.J., June 7 -- Upward of fifty men, women and children suffered bruises or more painful injuries tonight in the wreck near here of a six-car passenger train, bound from Atlantic City to New York. The locomotive of the passenger express plowed into a loaded coal car which was one of twelve that had jumped from the east-bound low-speed freight tracks.

Prizes, awards and fellowship appointments were announced yesterday by Dean Collins P. Bliss and Acting Dean Arthur E. Hill at class day exercises of the New York University College of Engineering and the College of Arts and Pure Science. More than 150 seniors, faculty members and friends attended the exercises in the Gould Memorial Auditorium, University Heights.

ALBANY, June 7 -- In dedicating the 118,000,000 Port of Albany today, Governor Roosevelt warned against careless expenditures of funds for public works, and urged properly planned and definitely useful projects for unemployment relief.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 7 -- Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, ordered a sudden shift in the champion's training routine upon his return from New York today. Jacobs called off the scheduled workout and announced that Max will box tomorrow, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday and every day thereafter until he ends training for the fight with Sharkey in the new Madison Square Garden Bowl at Long Island City June 21.
SANDWICH, England, June 7 -- British, amateurs for the first time in twenty years have thrown out a deft challenge to the world's professionals in the British open golf championship.

LONDON, June 7 -- Rare European manuscripts, some more than 1,000 years old, brought u23,053 [the pound was $3.67 yesterday] in a little more than an hour today at Sotheby's auction of the first part of the famous A. Chester Beatty collection, valued at u200,000.

Patrolman John J. Lowe of the Ryer Avenue station knew just what duty demanded of him fourteen months ago when a murderer shot at him, for he had already survived two shooting affrays. He killed his assailant and for doing so he was commended and promoted.

The full effect of Mr. ROCKEFELLER'S statement regarding the Eighteenth Amendment cannot be inferred from the first comments on it. Naturally, proponents of repeal have found it heartening. To the defenders of the present law it brings disappointment which their reiterations of faith in the cause itself do not conceal.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 7 -- In a day when rowing was seriously interfered with by a high wind which blew down the historic Thames River course, the crews of Yale and Harvard managed to get in double workouts today, with the coaches in both camps experimenting with their boatings.

The American Securities Investing Corporation, the so-called bond pool formed by leading New York banks and banking houses, yesterday made its first purchase of bonds and held its first meeting of directors. The amount of bonds purchased was not stated.

Municipal operation of the city's independent subway system was urged upon the Board of Estimate yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation Sitting in committee of the whole the board heard Mr. Delaney describe as virtually dead the tentative $474,500,000 unification plan published last December by the Transit Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- An army of 7,000 ex-service men paraded up Pennsylvania Avenue tonight in motley uniforms but orderly ranks.

The directors of the Aetna Mills having advised bankers that the company will be unable to pay interest of $14,560 due on July 1 on its $416,000 of first mortgage 7 per cent sinking fund bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1937, a bondholders' committee has been formed, with Benedict J. Baker as chairman.

Decline in the foreign exchanges was the incident that attracted most attention yesterday. Sterling and francs went to the lowest since the middle of May, rates on Switzerland and Holland to the lowest in nearly two weeks. This receding process may have been the response of Europe to the passing of the balanced revenue bill onto the statutes; it may also have been stimulated by the largeness of the recent gold exports from New York.
Prince and Press. A few days ago London Passing Show ran a cartoon showing a line of bank-tellers wearing cutaways above and plus-fours, riding-breeches, shorts and tennis fiannels below.

BOSTON, Mass., June 7 -- With Sir Henry Thornton, president of the Canadian National Railways, as the commencement speaker, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today conferred degrees upon 461 seniors and 236 advanced students at the sixty-fifth graduation exercises.

Master Melvin Ott, the strong, silent little man who patrols right field for the Giants, took matters into his own Hands at the Polo Grounds yesterday and by crashing two baseballs into the upper right-field tier started the new regime of Manager Bill Terry off with a victory in its first home stand of the year against the West.

By paying strict attention to business you can doubtless discover all the plots, subplots and related incidents of "The Boy Friend," which was acted at the Morosco last evening. Most of the early Summer playwrights economize on plot. But John Montague pyramids his plots; he makes a parlay of all the routine plots in existence, and plays them recklessly across the board.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 7 -- The National Association of Jewish Centres, concluding its fourteenth annual convention here today, elected Dr. Charles S. Bernheimer, editor of The Jewish Centre, as president. Dr. Bernheimer has been first vice president of the association.

SANDWICH. England. June 8 (AP). --Gene Sarazen's brilliant 70 in the first round today was four strokes under par for Prince's long and difficult layout. He went out in 35 Etrokes, one under par, and then came back with another 35, three under par.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 (AP). -- Authorities of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology could ascribe no reason for the attempted suicide of John Gibson. He was a member of the class which was graduated yesterday, but had a small amount of work to do before getting his degree.

The Irving Trust Company, trustee for the International Match Corporation, now in bankruptcy, was authorized yesterday to issue $500,000 in trustee certificates, the money to be used for the search for and conservation of the corporation's assets. The company is one of several that were controlled by Ivar Kreuger, who committed suicide in Paris.

LONDON, June 8. -- John R. Mott, president of the International Missionary Council and of the World's Alliance of the Y.M.C.A., disclosed tonight on his arrival here from Scotland that he had come to favor resuhmission of the prohibition question to the people of the United States, if some way could be found to do so that would keep the whole matter clear of partisan politics.

Margaret Hamilton, now making her Broadway debut in "Another Language." will appear at the Booth Theatre this afternoon in a program of songs, burlesques and characterizations. W. Peter Joray and Carroll Hollister will assist her in the recital, which will begin at 3 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate passed the economy bill late this evening after reducing its contemplated total from $238,000,000 to between $134,000,000 and $156,000,000, and grudgingly substituting the President's thirty-day furlough plan for the 10 per cent pay reduction previously voted for Federal employes.

PARIS, June 8. -- Coincident with a slight decline today in sterling, the dollar for the first time in several weeks rose above the point where it is profitable to make gold shipments from the United States to France and closed at 25.34.

Threatened with expulsion from the world's oil markets by a powerful coalition of American and British producers, the Russian petroleum syndicate has agreed to resume the negotiations that were broken off here last week after a disagreement among the conferees over measures for stabilization of the oil industry outside the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent in today's TIMES suggests a three-minute speakers' campaign gainst fear, recalling their accomplishments during the late war. From which one might say "Heaven save us!" were it not that the nation has long since realized that the claims of these spellbinders on the need of making the world safe for democracy proved to be but a hollow sham.

Edgar F. Luckenbach, president of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, appeared yesterday at a monthly meeting of the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York in support of the Copeland bill for regulation of rates among ships engaged in intercoastal trade.

Reports that Thomas M. Farley, former Sheriff, is considering resigning as "czar" of the cleaning and dyeing industry, a post for which he has been designated by the Metropolitan Trade Association of Master Cleaners and Dyers at a salary of $50,000, were current in the industry yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Two hundred and fifty-five awards have been made to Princeton athletes for participation in Spring sports, Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, announced today.

The first of a series of public hearings on a tentative code of uniform, rules for the taxi cab industry was held at City Hall yesterday by the Board of Taxicab Control. Maurice Hotchner, chairman, announced that hearings would continue on Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays until all concerned had had an opportunity to present their views.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, insisted today that Governor Roosevelt had approved his selection as permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention. A statement issued by Mr. Shouse said that Robert Jackson, secretary of the national committee, had given to him a verbatim report of a telephone conversation between Mr. Jackson and the New York Governor, in which the Governor ''commended" Mr. Shouse for that post.

For the second successive day Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok provided a distinct upset, as play In the quarter-final round of the thirty-sixth annual Metropolitan clay courts tennis championship tournament was completed on the New York Tennis Club's courts yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 8. -- W.H. Hubbard won the low gross honors and the Manhattan club championship at the club's third annual golf tournament at the Westchester County Club today. Hubbard played the eighteen holes in 87, to replace Don Parker, titleholder the past two years.

No Trouble About Starting. One day this week in the Senate Mr. MOSES of New Hampshire introduced a bill, as a substitute for a pending measure, which was supposed to reflect the wishes of the Administration.

Jack Quinn waged a gallant pitchers' battle against Charley Root for the last seven innings of the fourteen the Robins and Cubs played at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the younger man won the decision and Carey's men lost, 7 to 5. About 5,000 fans sat through the 3 hours and 40 minutes of the tense contest.

Mutual benefits might result from a working agreement between writers and public men engaged in making or executing the laws, in the opinion of some frivolous Parisians. La Vie asks plaintively if it is Utopian to think that writers might be of service to legislators in bringing national questions to their attention, or that the latter, in their turn, might "ameliorate the intolerable conditions of the life of authors."

A demand for the immediate removal of Dean George R. Hardie of Long Island University, based on charges of administrative mismanagement, misrepresentation of the university's financial condition and toleration of a system of espionage which has caused the university to become known as the "prison college," was sent yesterday to Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, by a committee appointed to represent the faculty.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 8. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., former Princeton star and intercollegiate champion for the past two years, established a new course record in the qualifying round of the metropolitan amateur championship today by negotiating the Plainfield Country Club course in seventy strokes, two under par.

The suicide rate in the United States during 1931 reached the highest figure recorded since 1915 and very nearly approached the highest ever known, according to the results of a statistical study by Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman, consulting statistician, published in the current issue of The Spectator, an insurance periodical.

ALBANY, June 8. -- The Public Service Commission today denied permission to the Staten Island Edison Corporation to issue $8,500,000 principal amount of first and refunding mortgage gold bonds. The company sought to issue the bonds for the purpose of refunding before maturity or for the payment at maturity of $7,500,000 face amount of one-year 3 per cent notes maturing on June 15 of this year.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 8. -- Members of the graduating class and recent alumnae of Smith College who have received fellowships, lectureships and assistantships in this country and abroad were announced today by Dean Marjorie Nicolson.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. - Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, presented tonight two honorary degrees and eighty-five degrees in course at the commencement exercises of the New Jersey College of Pharmacy.

BUFFALO, June 8. -- A comprehensive study of the State Public Service Commission law and all public utility statutes affecting municipalities was authorized today by the New York State conference of mayors and other municipal officials, now holding their annual meeting here.
SHANGHAI, June 8. -- The decision Of the Chinese Government to resume diplomatic relations with Russia probably will be announced officially in a few days.

Accompanied by a suggestion that "the maintenance of decent standards among public officials" requires the removal of Mayor Walker from office, Samuel Seabury's analysis of the Walker testimony before the Hofstadter legislative committee was forwarded to Governor Roosevelt by special messenger last evening.

Samuel Seabury's analysis of the evidence presented before the Joint Legislative Committee appointed to investigate the government of the city of New York, in so far as that evidence relates to the conduct of the Hon. James J. Walker as Mayor of the City of New York, which was sent last night to Governor Roosevelt, follows:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 8. -- At the annual commencement exercises of Seton Hall College and the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception, Bishop Walsh awarded today fifty-four degrees of Bachelor of Arts, eleven of Bachelor of Science and twenty-two of Master of Arts.

GENEVA, June 8. -- The air commission of the world disarmament conference adopted today its report answering the conference's query as to what weapons are most specifically offensive or most dangerous to national defense or most threatening to civilians.
LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP). -- William G. McAdoo declared tonight for a vote of the people in a special national election to settle the question of prohibition.

Growing confidence that there will be no prolonged fight at the Democratic National Convention over a suitable party expression on prohibition was expressed in the Roosevelt camp yesterday. Governor Roosevelt himself, in an interview in Albany, declared that he believed a practical method of repealing the Eighteenth Amendment would be outlined in the platform.

The war of the bridge tables so bitterly fought in the past year by Ely Culbertson with his "approach forcing" system of bidding and the exponents of the "official system" is about to come to an end, it was announced last night. The two factions are holding a series of conferences in the Culbertson apartment in the Hotel Chatham to "get together on a more friendly basis," Mr. Culbertson said.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Mr. Neville and the British, French and Italian Ambassadors to Japan were informed today by Premier Saito that the proposal by Kenkichi Yoshizawa, Foreign Minister in the Inukai Cabinet, for a round-table conference of the interested powers to consider the future status of foreigners and their interests in Shanghai was still open.

Mitchell L. Erlanger, who, five years ago, at the age of 70, was retired automatically from the State Supreme Court bench, on which he had sat for twenty-one years, obtained a license yesterday in the City Clerk's office to wed Janet Norden-shield of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street.

MEXICO CITY, June 8. -- The Vera Cruz expropriation bill, under which virtually every source of income may be taken over by the State at the discretion of Governor Adalberto Tejeda, is raising a storm of opposition in business centres throughout Mexico.

The west side's younger set from Ninth, Tenth and Eleventh Avenues, ranging in age from a few months to the early 'teens, put on its annual Spring frolic yesterday. It was held in Schermerhorn Playground, West Thirty-eighth Street, under the guiding hand of the Children's Aid Society.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested in a letter from F. Bayard Rives which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 19.

LONDON, June 8. -- As a sequel to unofficial intimations that such an invitation would be most welcome, Premier Herriot has invited Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, to Paris for conversations concerning Lausanne prior to the opening of that conference on June 16.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- One of the causes of the difficulty in obtaining action from Congress on pending bills dealing with the depression is the widespread fear among members of reprisals at the polls. In the cloak rooms the general opinion of the national legislators has seemed to be that they were "damned if they did and damned if they didn't."

New York City, in common with many up-State communities and New England, went off the warm weather standard yesterday when a cold wave from Nova Scotia and the St. Lawrence River Valley made millions shiver in record low temperatures for the date, brought snow and ice back to the counties in the northern part of New York and caused thousands of dollars of damage to early crops in Massachusetts, Connecticut and other New England States.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- Reports that were apparently well founded but were unconfirmed by officials today said that army posts in the vicinity of Washington had taken precautionary moves in view of the mounting numbers of veterans in the city.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Between $85,000,000 and $90,000,000 of assets in the three major utility companies of Chicago and suburbs, developed by Samuel Insull, are to be "written off," according to reports in La Salle Street. These are the Commonwealth Edison Company, the People's Gas Light and Coke Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.

Speaker GARNER can scarcely be surprised at the coolness shown in the Senate toward his plan to deal a deadly blow to the depression by building 2,300 postoffices. At no time have the Senate Democrats shown evidence of interest in this bill, with its proposal for a $1,000,000,000 bond issue with which to finance a long list of politically desirable but essentially unnecessary projects.

"Never," said the late Lord BALFOUR, "is a very dangerous word in "public life. It is used only by very "young men." Sometimes, however, it is used by older men, though perhaps experience has taught them that it is wise to leave open a way of retreat, as Benedick explained that he did after vowing that he would "never" get married but die a bachelor.

At the seventy-third commencement of Cooper Union, at 8 o'clock this evening in the large hall of the Union, R. Fulton Cutting, president of the board of trustees, will present post-graduate and Bachelor of Science degrees, diplomas and certificates to 387 graduates of the Institute of Technology, the Woman's Art School, the Night School of Engineering and the Night School of Art, as follows:

BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP). -- Newark closed its series with Baltimore today by dividing a double-header with the Orioles. The Bears lost the first, 6 to 4, and won the second game, 7 to 4, to break even on the four games.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The discovery that carbon dioxide probably is present in large amounts in the atmosphere of the planet Venus was announced today by the Carnegie Institution of Washington.
LONDON, June 8. -- King George today unveiled a memorial to his mother, Queen Alexandra, in the garden wall of Marlborough House, her old home, on the occasion of Alexandra Rose Day.

Copyright. 1932, by NANA, Inc. WASHINGTON, June 8. -- This "bonus army" which is camping at the capital's gate has a strange and striking personnel. It seems to be a fair cross-section of middle-class America. There are truck drivers and blacksmiths, steel workers and coal miners, stenographers and laborers.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Smiling despite the loss of a fortune estimated at about $100,000,000 and his removal as bead of a vast public utility combination. Samuel Insull today wound up his business affairs and received a few friends bringing him good vrishes.

CORTLAND, N.Y., June 8. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, at a Democratic luncheon here today, proposed as a way to restore prosperity that money be lent to farmers and small business men to re-establish their buying power.

With the exception of a few minutes, when an architect-engineer presented a diagram of the grand jury room, Louis Benson, stenographer, occupied the witness stand throughout yesterday's session in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court of the new trial of Isidor J. Kresel, the lawyer, on a perjury indictment.

The authorities, simply had to do something about it. Imprisoned in the bathroom of his parents' apartment at 35-21 Seventy-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, was 3-year-old Donald Eichmeyer, who was finding his predicament a matter of grave concern.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Following a day in which reports were circulated freely among party leaders at the capital that President Hoover had given his approval to a prohibition resubmission plank for the Republican platform, the White House recognized the prevalence of the story with an emphatic denial.

Seven angry witnesses, all business men with convivial inclinations, appeared yesterday in Federal court to testify that they had submitted to indignities similar to those suffered by Henry C. Murphy, Curb Exchange broker, who swore Tuesday that he bad been held a prisoner for two days in an uptown "clip joint" and had not been freed until he had turned over a check for $2,000 to his captors.

In the May number of Journal of the American Judicature Society Mr. FRANK W. GRINNELL described the unification of the inferior courts in Massachusetts and the expansion of their jurisdiction. In the district and lowest trial courts a great part of all civil and criminal cases is disposed of.

BERLIN, June 8 (AP). -- The Prusian Government imposed a levy on Prussian civil servants of 21/2 to 5 per cent of their salaries in the form of a forced loan today in an effort to balance the State's budget.

IF they want a good man to sound the keynote in the coming political conventions, Howling Dan Howley, the Voice of Cincinnati, can be highly recommended. He has an alert mind, a commanding presence and Grade A vocal equipment. He is a sixteen-cylinder, free-wheeling, floating-power orator trained to the minute.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Governor Roosevelt announced today that the goal of $10,000,000 savings for the current fiscal year had been practically achieved and that orders had been issued for another $10,000,000 slash for the new fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Dr. Sylvanus G. Morley, director of the Calakmul expedition of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, has returned to Washington and reported in greater detail on the discovery in April of the great ancient Maya city of Calakmul in Southern Campeche, Mexico.
To the Editor of The New York Times: If there were only six families in New York, and one family should suddenly be cut off from all its resources, what would the other five families do?

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- The attention of rowing enthusiasts shifted today from the Krum Elbow camp of Columbia University to the training quarters of two of the crews that may fight it out in the last mile on boat race day for the I.R.A. championship, Syracuse and California.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP). -- Lefty Grove pitched and batted his way to his eleventh victory of the season and his tenth straight today as the t Athletics defeated the Indians. 3 to 1, and advanced from fifth to third place in the American League. Cleveland dropped from fourth to fifth as the Tigers fell from third to fourth.

After having weakened again early yesterday as a result of the passage of the Garner relief measure by the House of Representatives, the dollar resumed its recovery in the afternoon. At the close of trading the French franc was below the export gold point and only the exchanges of Holland and Switzerland continued to be quoted at prices which made shipments of the metal to those countries profitable.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 8. -- Councils of workers took over the administration of Chilean savings banks as one of many steps today toward the socialization of the country under the new revolutionary regime headed by former Ambassador Carlos Davila.

The net lose of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on Feb. 27 was $2.769.184. after all charges, including interest and depreciation and after allowing for a profit of $2,498,515 arising from the retirement of debentures and subsidiaries' funded indebtedness.

Who would not be encouraged to "agitation" if he could know that he would be banished for it to a Grecian isle -- especially the particular one to which General THEODORUS PANGALOS is to be sent? It is Corfu, where Ulysses was received by Nausicaa and escorted to the town of her father Antinous.
The School Relief Fund made cash disbursements of $1,588,297 from Oct. 1, 1931, to May 27, according to a report issued yesterday by Frederick D. Chambers, treasurer of the fund.

Lawrence Languor's New York Repertory Company will perform three new American plays this Summer at the Country Playhouse, West-port, Conn. They are "Thorough-bred," a comedy by Doty Hobart; "For Husbands Only," also a comedy, by Basil Lawrence, and "Chrysalis," a comedy-melodrama by R.A. Porter.

There does not seem to be any objection to a plan, to conserve the weakfish that make Peconic Bay such fine fishing grounds these days. Repeated statements by fishermen, young and old, are of the opinion "that something should be done about it."

DUBLIN, June 8. -- The whole political situation in the Free State changed suddenly this afternoon when the Senate, in committee of the whole, rejected a vital section in the oath bill. As a result the bill cannot become law for eighteen months unless President de Valera decides to hold an immediate general election.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Owen D. Young's address to the graduating class of Notre Dame University, in so far as it touches upon the agricultural question, is chiefly valuable in that it is an implied recognition that the welfare of the industrial areas is largely dependent upon that of the rural.

One of the largest Fifth Avenue Investment deals in1/2 recent months was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, which acted as broker in the sale of the fourteen-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- The organization of the Westchester Home Finance Committee with an initial fund of $1,0000,000 to lend money for the building of moderate-priced homes was announced here today by Arthur W. Lawrence, banker and president of the Westchester County Park Commission, following a conference with bankers and real estate men.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 8 (AP). -- A direct Federal appropriation of $600,000 for emergency relief was carried today in the District of Columbia supply bill as reported to the Senate with a total of $43,789,728 an increase of $3,875,918 from the total approved by the House.

The adjusted Index of steel-mill activity for the week ended June 4 shows a further drop to 24.4, as compared with 26.1 for the week ended May 28 and 47.7 for the week ended June 6, 1931. In part the current decline represents a readjustment of the weekly estimates on which the index is based to actual production as revealed by the official figures of the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

DURHAM, N.C., June 8. -- Lawrence Clarke Apgar of Philadelphia has been engaged as organist and carillonneur of Duke University. He is a graduate of Yale University and has studied for four years at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.

Shares of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation sagged yesterday to new low records on the Stock Exchange. The day's low of 11 1/8 for the common stock was the smallest price for the shares since the 9 1/4 recorded in 1923, and the low of 31 1/2 for the preferred stock was under the previous low record of 34 1/2 established in 1923.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 8. -- Favorites encountered more opposition than they had bargained for in the national clay courts tennis championships today and Berkeley Bell of New York, seeded No. 3, was twice within a point of being beaten before he eliminated Jiro Yamagishi, Japanese entry from the University of Illinois, 1 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5.
READING, Pa., June 8 (AP). -- Jersey City made it four straight over Reading today, taking both games of a doubleheader, 6 to 5 and 5 to 0.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today rejected by a vote of 9 to 6 the Barbour relief bill backed by President Hoover, and immediately afterward, by a vote of 7 to 4, ordered a favorable report on the Wagner relief program to which Mr. Hoover is opposed.

The new Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City will be dedicated to sport tonight with a wrestling exhibition to a finish in which Dick Shikat, German heavy-weight, and Ed (Strangler) Lewis, Kentuckian, both former world's champions, will be rivals.

Weakness in the stock and grain markets had a depressing influence on prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. After the list had shown considerable resistance the action of securities in the last hour brought contracts from several directions and quotations closed at the bottom, 11 to 13 points lower than on Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- Dr. George Grant MacCurdy of Yale University has been notified by Theodore D. McCown, field representative of the American School, and in charge of the joint excavations with the British School of Archaeology near Haifa, Palestine, of the discovery of four more Neanderthal skeletons in the Cave of Kids, at the western foot of Mount Carmel.
ROSLYN, L.I., June 8. -- The Manufacturers Trust Company won the Bankers Athletic League golf tournament for the third year in a row, over the course of the Engineers Golf Club today.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 8 (AP). -- The tension of campaigning for the October Presidential election has snapped into rebellion in the north, and fifty-one men have been slain in battle.

Charles G. Dawes, who resigned on Monday as president and as a member of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the resignation to take effect on June 15, will be engaged thereafter In working out plans for the rehabilitation of the extensive Insull enterprises, and principally of the Middle West Utilities System, according to information received yesterday in financial circles here.

The retrenchment program of the Board of Education will not affect the operation of Summer schools. At a meeting of the board yesterday approval was given for the Summer sessions, but in the high schools only for pupils wishing to repeat subjects. Those wishing to advance their grades will not be registered in the high schools, although such pupils will be admitted to the elementary schools.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The government's investigation of charges brought by the Farmers' National Grain Corporation against the Chicago Board of Trade reached a deadlock at the first hearing today, when counsel for the board challenged the admissibility of evidence to show the financial solvency of the grain corporation.

VIENNA, June 8. -- In anticipation of the legalization of the Nazi armed forces in Germany by the von Paper Government, the Austrian Hitlerites are trying to strike a bargain with the Heimwehr for absorption of the Heimwehr rank and file and, more important, Heimwehr arms and ammunition.

Prominently placed, boldly lettered affiches in the halls and on the landings of the Art Students League announce the morning class in life drawing and painting, to be conducted through June, July and August by George Grosz. The German artist arrived in this country several days ago, all but unaware, he confessed, of the melodramatic upheaval that had centred in the left wing's insistence upon his being invited to join the faculty.
The text of Samuel Seabury's letter to the Governor accompanying the transcript of Mayor Walker's testimony and an analysis of that testimony, follows:

DEANS, N.J., June 8. -- Officials of the New Jersey State Public Utilities Commission, the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Pennsylvania Railroad began their formal investigations today into the derailment last night of a six-car passenger train near here in which upward of fifty passengers received injuries.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- Mrs. Edward B. McLean, estranged wife of The Washington Post publisher, told a jury today of being swindled by Gaston B. Means of $104,000 she paid him to recover the Lindbergh baby.

For the first time since the interzone match between France and Japan was staged there in 1926, the West Side Tennis Club, at Forest Hills, will be the scene of a Davis Cup tie today when Brazil and the United States begin play in the American, interzone final, the winner to qualify for the meeting with the survivor in the European zone in Paris next month.

The motorship Saturnia of the Italian Line will sail today at 4 P.M. for Dublin, flying the papal flag at her main truck, carrying 1,037 pilgrims to attend the Eucharistic Congress. According to the Catholic Travel League, which has chartered the Saturnia, it is the largest group of pilgrims to leave an American port for any event of that kind.

John S. Coleman of 1,695 Broadway, New York, purchased from the Broadbank Corporation of Newark the five-story, forty-family brick apartment house on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 18 Kensington Avenue, near Bergen Avenue, Jersey City. The property, assessed at $125,000, was taken over by the buyer subject to two mortgages totaling $102,000.

Continued activity in farm properties in various parts of New York State is reported by E.A. Strout, broker. Sales announced yesterday by Mr. Strout included sixty-five acres near Groton, bought by Mrs. E. B. Blacker of Glenbrook. Conn., from Mrs. C.H. Wilbur; 107 acres near Rochester, purchased by William Boyd of College Point from Jesse McDonald, and ninety-one acres near Auburn, bought by Gordon Roberson of Plainfield, N.J., from Joseph Welch.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 9. -- The Manchurian Commission of the League of Nations is now staying in Peiping, where it arrived Sunday, and is expected to move to Tsingtao, where it will write its report.
In the history of the world heavy-weight boxing championship there have been two occasions when "long counts" by referees seemed to many of the spectators to be deciding factors in the outcome.
LONDON, June 8. -- The stock markets were quiet today and in the absence of support prices generally were lower. British Government funds reacted on profit-taking, recording a sharp decline.

There was dancing in the tortured streets of Greenpoint last night, and wassail in her happy homes. Lights winked gleefully across the river, to the brooding, monolithic towers of the west. Children played in the gutters, electing Mayors, Governors and (who knows) even a President some not distant day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 8. -- Be-quests to several New York institutions are contained in the will of Miss Cecils Langton, a former resident of this city, who died in Rome, Italy, on May 24. The will was probated in Surrogate's Court here today. Miss Langton was a niece of the late John McGrath, a wealthy flour and feed merchant here.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange approved for listing yesterday $9,327,500 of St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt) general and refunding 5 per cent gold bonds, Series A, due on July 1, 1990. Consenting holders of the road's first consolidated mortgage 4 per cent bonds that matured on June 1 received payment comprising $500 cash and $500 of the new refunding bonds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- A $2,000,000 foundation to aid investigations on a world-wide basis into causes of and a cure for cancer was launched here today under the presidency of William H. Donner of Villa Nova, a retired steel manufacturer who created the fund.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- An unofficial compilation of the delegations to the Democratic National Convention, made up from all reports at present available in Washington, shows that:
