TRENTON, N.J., June 8. -- By votes of 14 to 4 and 42 to 1, respectively, the Senate and House late today passed a bill for a referendum at the general election in November on repeal of the Hobart State prohibition enforcement act. If ratified, the repeal will be effective Dec. 1.

The National Security League, of Which General Robert L. Bullard is president, yesterday sent a telegram to Pierre S. du Pont, president of the newly formed United Repeal Council, pledging the support of the league in the movement for the repeal of the prohibition amendment.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The agitation for stabilization of silver and an international monetary conference promises to produce one of the sharpest battles in the Republican National Convention, second only to the prohibition question. Today the discussion among Republican Senators, who are delegates to the convention, centered upon the sectional struggle between the West and East over the maintenance of the gold standard and the remonetization of silver.

Preliminary drafts of a statement outlining steps that might be taken within and without the railroad industry to improve its position received consideration yesterday at a meeting of a subcommittee of the Association of Railway Executives here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- The Harvard alumni nine took advantage of Ned Wheeler's wildness, coupled with opportune hits to defeat Yale, 11-7, in a ten-inning game today. Howey Whitmore, who pitched for the victors, though touched for fifteen hits, received fine support.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 8. -- Holy Cross won its eleventh game of the season today, defeating Syracuse. 9 to 1. Joe Mulligan held the visitors to four scattered hits, and Vin Black, the Orange ace. was nicked for eight. Ha also gave six passes.

Upper Park Avenua provided one of the most stimulating realty transactions of the year yesterday and simultaneously with the announcement of the deal came the filing of plans for a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment house to cost $650,000 on the southwest corner of the avenue and Seventy-second Street.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 8 (AP). -- More than 5,000 unemployed men demanded at a mass meeting today that the government turn over to them, the Club de la Union, owned by wealthy and fashionable residents of Santiago.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP). -- An anti-war demonstration and protest against the appearance of General Douglas McArthur as the commencement speaker at the University of Pittsburgh was stopped by police today.

WTLLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 8. -- Malcolm E. Erskine of Stamford, Conn., who in less than ten days would have been graduated from Williams College, committed suicide today. The body was found at noon by Joseph Eaton and Christopher Stanwood in a clump of trees on the Adriance estate about a quarter of a mile southwest of the Delta Psi fraternity house.

A public hearing on the application of the Department of Docks for a realignment of the bulkhead line of the East River, between East Houston Street and Fourteenth Street, was held at the Army Building yesterday by the New York Harbor Line Board.

After several days of activity in acceptances, business in that section relapsed to join the dull state prevailing elsewhere. Business was extremely light and quotations unchanged for Stock Exchange call loans, maturity, and commercial paper.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The powers receiving reparations from Germany have been Informed through diplomatic channels that the United States has no sympathy for any program that envisages the cancellation of those reparations contingent upon annulment of the war-time debts owed to this government.

Pig iron production in the United States during May, as reported by The Iron Age, was 783,554 tons, comparing with 852,897 in April and with 1,994,082 in May of 1931. The Iron Age states that the daily average output of pig iron last month, 25,276 gross tons, is the lowest for any month since August, 1897.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 8. -- Miss Alice Francis today reached the semi-final round of the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club by gaining a three-set victory from Miss Florence Le Boutillier, 10-8, 5-7, 6-4.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP). -- The Phillies won a hard-hitting contest from the Pittsburgh Pirates, 11 to 10. today by making a four-run rally in the eighth inning.

Foreign copper producers will continue to restrict production in accordance with the agreement made last Winter, although under its terms they were at liberty to terminate the compact if either the United States or England levied an import duty on the red metal.

The Board of Estimate will take a formal vote next week to determine whether or not it will commit the city to a policy of municipal operation of its new subway system, it was indicated yesterday at City Hall.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP). -- The Cardinals today came out of their batting slump and captured the series opener by pounding four Boston pitchers for twenty hits and a 15-8 victory in a weird game that lasted double out of six times at bat. almost three hours.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- A request for the voluntary evacuation of Washington tomorrow by the bonus army, now swollen to more than 7,000 and with new detachments coming every hour, was made today by the Washington authorities.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., June 8. -- Mrs. W.W. Kenyon of this village won the sweepstakes prize in the ninth annual flower show of the North Suffolk Garden Club, held this afternoon at the Smithtown Country Club. Upward of 500 persons from various parts of Long Island attended the show, which was declared one of the best and most elaborate ever seen in Smithtown.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the beat names. Tuesday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations aer for three-four months' paper.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Faced with a bitter fight over prohibition, the Republican convention, due to open here next Tuesday, will write its own prohibition plank which in verbiage and purport may or may not hew closely to the line laid down in the tentative plank declaring for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment, which was made public in Washington last Sunday with the report that it was acceptable to the administration.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein Invoked last Thursday the so-called "no work-no eat" law In sentencing Charles Monsolino, an indolent wood carver arraigned before him in Family Court for failure to support his wife and two children. Yesterday Richard C. Patterson Jr., commissioner of corrections, wrote to Magistrate Goldstein: "It is impossible to carry out your order."

The wage-scale conference committee of the Publishers Association of New York will confer with the conference committee of Typographical Union 6 in Room 421, Sun Building, 280 Broadway, at 10:30 tomorrow morning to negotiate a new working agreement to replace the old contract that expired on June 30, 1929, covering employment in newspaper composing rooms.

Further weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was attributed in Wall Street to a variety of developments, but principally those reported from Washington. The turnover again fell short of 1,000,000 shares, and brokers reported that little interest was shown in the market, outside of the ever-present professional group.

DETROIT, June 8. -- After totaling one single each in the three previous meetings this year between the Tigers and the Yankees, the Ruth-Gehrig combination today broke the spell and by their powerful hitting supplied what Vernon Gomez needed to assure him of his seventh straight victory and his tenth of the season.

New York University held its centennial commencement yesterday in the great open-air hall of Ohio Field. Three thousand, nine hundred and forty-two degrees and certificates, the largest number in the history of the institution, were awarded. In addition, sixteen persons received honorary degrees, and fifty-six graduates won alumni medals "for unusual service."

Replying to Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee's statement that conditions in city hospitals were not as bad as they were painted, Howard S. Cullman, president of thte Beekman Street Hospital, informed him yesterday that overcrowding in city hospitals had increased by 42 per cent the number of city patients in Beekman Street, a private institution, in the last year.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Faced with a bitter fight over prohibition, the Republican convention, due to open here next Tuesday, will write its own prohibition plank which in verbiage and purport may or may not hew closely to the line laid down in the tentative plank declaring for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment, which was made public in Washington last Sunday with the report that it was acceptable to the administration.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein Invoked last Thursday the so-called "no work-no eat" law In sentencing Charles Monsolino, an indolent wood carver arraigned before him in Family Court for failure to support his wife and two children. Yesterday Richard C. Patterson Jr., commissioner of corrections, wrote to Magistrate Goldstein: "It is impossible to carry out your order."

The wage-scale conference committee of the Publishers Association of New York will confer with the conference committee of Typographical Union 6 in Room 421, Sun Building, 280 Broadway, at 10:30 tomorrow morning to negotiate a new working agreement to replace the old contract that expired on June 30, 1929, covering employment in newspaper composing rooms.

New York University held its centennial commencement yesterday in the great open-air hall of Ohio Field. Three thousand, nine hundred and forty-two degrees and certificates, the largest number in the history of the institution, were awarded. In addition, sixteen persons received honorary degrees, and fifty-six graduates won alumni medals "for unusual service."

Replying to Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee's statement that conditions in city hospitals were not as bad as they were painted, Howard S. Cullman, president of thte Beekman Street Hospital, informed him yesterday that overcrowding in city hospitals had increased by 42 per cent the number of city patients in Beekman Street, a private institution, in the last year.

New York City will pay off tomorrow the $148,000,000 which it borrowed piecemeal since January under the $151,000,000 revolving credit arranged by a city-wide group of banks. With the slate wiped clean, the city may borrow again according to its needs in the remainder of 1932 up to the full amount of the credit.

The defeat of Mrs. Gwladys Whitney's Beacon Hill in the featured Meadowbrook Steeplechase Handicap and the acquisition of a double by Mrs. Payne Whitney were the outstanding occurrences at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON. June 8. -- Regulations under which the new taxes of the 1932 revenue act will be collected probably will be issued within a short time by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Officials of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway went yesterday to Washington to put before the Inter-state Commerce Commission several alternative methods for reducing the fixed charges of the road. They are taking this action in conformity with a requirement attached to a recent loan to the road from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation calling on the management to devise some such methods by July 1.

Hubert T. Parson, president of the F.W. Woolworth Company for thirteen years, has resigned because he is approaching the company's 60-year age limit, it was announced yesterday. He has been succeeded by Byron D. Miller, formerly vice president and treasurer.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., June 8. -- In her will, probated today, Mrs. Cyrus H.K. Curtis left an estate valued at "$200,000 and upward" to relatives, friends and servants in trust funds and outright gifts.

ALBANY, June 8. -- In its issue of Friday THE NEW YORK TIMES stated that Justice Staley had directed the Burland Printing Company of New York to turn over to the J.B. Lyon Company the contract for election printing which had been awarded to it by the Department of Standards and Purchase.

The ring craft he accumulated prior to his retirement from the sport seven long years ago, pulled Benny Leonard, former world's lightweight champion, through to victory last night in his battle against rugged Andy Saviola, Bay Ridge, in the tenround feature at the opening of the Coney Island Stadium's outdoor boxing season.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 8. Hard work, with the accent on the individuals, featured the day at the rowing camps of both Harvard and Yale today. Both head coaches spent a part of the day tubbing with various members of the varsity squads and there were morning and afternoon rows by the crews.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Princeton routed Rutgers, 21 to 0, today, making seventeen hits, while Gosnell held Rutgers to six. Double plays in the fifth and six helped Gosnell.

LONDON, June 8. -- Following Sir linders Petrie's excavations at Caza, which recently brought to light gold ornaments of Irish manufacture of the time of Queen Hatshepsut, inquiry has now disclosed that in 1914 Professor Archibald Sayce and the late Dr. H.R. Hall of the British Museum identified certain blue glazed beads discovered at Stonehenge and elsewhere in Wiltshire as having been made in Egypt about the time of Hatshepsut, according to Sir Charles Marstot.

The previous day's downward trend continued yesterday in most of the foreign exchanges, although with fractional recovery in the rates on London and Switzerland. As had been expected, more gold was engaged for export; the day's total being $30,000,000, making something over $50,000,000 for the week to date.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- President Angell in his annual report, made public today, said the university would show a deficit of $500,000 in its budget for the year because of reduced income from investments and other items. In his report President Angell reviewed the ten years which he has spent "in the service of Yale," which reflect many noteworthy developments and accomplishments.

PARIS, June 8. -- France's new Radical Socialist government intends to reduce armaments appropriations this year by nearly 10 per cent, the figure currently given being 1,500,000,000 francs, or $60,000,000. The reduction will be distributed among three services-the army, the navy and the air force.

ROME, June 8. -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam flew here today from Milan with her husband in a large tri-motored plane placed at her disposal by the Ministry of Aeronautics. When Mrs. Putnam, smiling: boyishly, jumped lightly to the ground at at Litterio Airport at 3 o'clock this afternoon, she was immediately surrounded by a small crowd of cheering people.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Four billion 3-cent postage stamps are being made at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.

Cardinal Hayes urged Fordham University graduates to combat communism in the United States by being "builders of the home" when he addressed them on the campus at the institution's eighty-seventh annual commencement exercises at which he presided yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 8. -- Candidate advocating repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment or a referendum on the prohibition issue led the field in the four Congressional contests of yesterday's Democratic primary, which gave Governor Roosevelt an overwhelming preferential vote for the Presidential nomination.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg and Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell.
Trust funds established by the late J. Pierpont Morgan for three of his daughters have shown large increases according to accountings filed yesterday by executors of his estate in Surrogates' Court.

Events of the past few days have moved quickly toward a complete emancipation of American public men from the political slavery to which they have long been subjected in the name of prohibition. Every one awake to changes in public opinion must be aware that a great one has been wrought on that subject.

A further decrease in the volume of steel bookings is ascribed, in the mid-week review of The Iron Age, to seasonal influences and to the recent uncertainties surrounding tax legislation in Washington. The average rate of operations is estimated by this publication at about 20 per cent of the country's ingot capacity.

Judge SEABURY'S summary of the evidence against Mayor WALKER did not take the form of "charges " demanding removal from office. But Governor ROOSEVELT declared yesterday that he was not going to quibble over any merely formal question, that the Seabury letter, together with the transcript of the testimony, amounted to charges and that he would immediately devote himself to their careful study.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 9 (AP). -- Former Governor James M. Cox today issued the following statement:

The money market was quiet and uneventful so far as rate changes and business volume were concerned. Quotations for all classes remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent. Street trades went at 1 and Federal funds sold 1/8 @ 1/4.

Net income from the facilities operated by the Port of New York Authority for the first four months of this year totaled $1,349,183,43, according to an announcement yesterday. This income was derived from the Holland Tunnel, the George Washington Bridge and the three bridges connecting Staten Island and New Jersey.

The foreign exchanges again moved favorably to this market yesterday, as they have done each day since the revenue bill was enacted. Most of them went below the normal gold-export point, franc exchange in particular reaching the lowest figure in more than a month, with corresponding reaction in rates on Holland, Switzerland and Belgium.

An automobile in which a patrolman off his post was a passenger, struck and critically injured a 16year-old schoolgirl yesterday morning at West End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street. The car continued on its way until several shots fired by a pursuing policeman forced the driver to stop.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department is awaiting more detailed reports from the United States Embassy in Santiago before determining its attitude toward the Socialist program of the Davila Government in Chile as it affects American interests.

The faculty of the newly formed New York School of Vocal Art, headed by Hugh Ross, director of the Schola Cantorum of this city, was announced yesterday at a tea in Carnegie Hall. The introductions were made by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, who was introduced by Deems Taylor, composer.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9 -- Graduation and prize day exercises were held this afternoon at Rosemary Hall. In accordance with custom, the prize awards were kept secret until the moment they were announced at the exercises. They were as follows:
ROME, June 9 (AP). -- A visit to the famous Orbetello flying school was the principal event in today's program for Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, Atlantic solo flier.

The new liner Acadia steamed through the harbor to her pier yesterday amid the loud greeting of more than a hundred harbor craft, docking at Pier 18, North River. The Acadia came from Newport News, Va., where she was built for the Eastern Steamship Company by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company.

HAVANA, June 9 -- While the national budget for 1932-33, which must go into effect July 1, will not be definitely fixed until June 13, it was learned today after a Cabinet meeting that the total will be about $50,000,000, a reduction of $10,000,000 compared with the 1931-32 budget.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the harassed correspondent of a European economic periodical, I find myself wholly bewildered by two contradictory items in this morning's edition of THE TIMES.

LONDON, Friday, June 10 -- Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, was heavily guarded when he landed on British soil shortly before last midnight for a conference with Prime Minister MacDonald in London.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 -- The Harvard alumni nine, which won a ten-inning game from Yale at New Haven yesterday, was unable to repeat against the Harvard varsity today.

Lone Valley," an unproduced play by Sophie Treadwell, author of "Machinal," will open on June 29 at the Broadway Theatre, Nyack, N.Y., as the third production of the Rockland Producing Company, a new Summer group. Miss Treadwell will direct the play, which A.H. Woods was once reported to have purchased for Jane Cowl.
Announcing that he would name two prominent attorneys to assist him, Governor Roosevelt took his first step yesterday toward determining whether to remove Mayor Walker from office.
CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians toppled the champion Athletics from third place in the American League into the second division today by winning a heavyhitting game, 9 to 8.

Reservoirs Now Full. Last Spring New York City was menaced with a water shortage. Drought had been exceptionally prolonged. Gauges in the reservoirs dropped to the half-way mark; mud-flats were exposed that are ordinarily deep under water at that season.

MADRID, June 9 -- The Catholic Church, through Mgr. Tedeschini, the Papal Nuncia, has filed claims with the Spanish Government for payment for fifty churches and monasteries burned during the nationwide church riots of May 11, 1931.

MANILA, June 9 -- A blow against racial division in the Philippines was struck today by Governor General Theodore Roosevelt when he ordered the Manila Central High School to eliminate the racial qualification for entrance.

A strike order to 19,000 members of the International Union of Elevator Constructors, which was to have been issued last night, was cancelled when Frank Feeney, union president, received what he considered was assurance of a satisfactory settlement of the wage question from the Elevator Manufacturers Association.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 9 -- The 262 members of the graduating class at the Military Academy, who will receive their diplomas tomorrow, bade formal adieu to the Cadet Corps late this afternoon at a colorful review which marked the climax of the "Alumni Day" ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Unless the White House spokesman who denied that any plank on prohibition has been submitted to or approved by the President was uninformed of the facts, his statement to that effect today falls into the category of diplomatic utterances.

The recent sharp declines in prices of Brooklyn Manhattan Transit and Interborough securities and the dilemma facing New York City in the operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway are believed in financial circles here to have enhanced greatly the prospect for an early understanding between the transit companies and the city on the unification of subway and elevated lines of New York.

A plan for united action by business and labor, to take over the leadership in the economic affairs of this country, bring concentrated pressure to bear on government in matters affecting trade and industry, and cooperatively work out solutions for problems of overproduction and other economic questions, was proposed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen at his inauguration as president of the Advertising Club of New York.

Detailed plans for the forum and sunken, plaza which will constitute the central link in the $15,000,000 decorative scheme for Rockefeller Centre were revealed yesterday by the developers in awarding additional contracts for sculptural work in the $250,000,000 midtown business and amusement project.
GENEVA, June 9 -- Encouraging news reached the disarmament conference headquarters today, although on the surface it seemed to continue to be in a moderately bad way.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The government will move to close by injunction all speakeasies and other liquor-selling places in the Borough of Manhattan, New York City.

A scroll expressing gratitude to Mrs. Edward F. Hutton for establishing the Marjorie Post Hutton free food station operated by the Salvation Army at 455 Tenth Avenue, signed by more than 1,000 women and children who have been fed there for the past six months, was presented to Mrs. Hutton last night when she visited the station.

Unemployed musicians will share in the proceeds of a series of three orchestral concerts to be given by the Symphony Ensemble under the direction of Bernhard Levitow on the remaining Fridays in June. The first concert will be held this afternoon at Carrollcliff, the home of Mrs. Howard Carroll in Tarrytown-on-Hudson.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 9 Modern civilization has grown too fast for its soul, Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins, formerly Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, told the graduates of Rutgers University in his baccalaureate sermon this morning.

Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, was re-elected president of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce at its annual presidents' meeting at its headquarters yesterday. Mr. Macauley has been president of the chamber for the last three years.

BERLIN, June 9 -- In a firm but markedly conciliatory speech, Baron Wilhelm von Gayl, Minister of the Interior, gave the Reichsrat (Federal Council) the first comprehensive outline of the new government's program today, pouring oil on the rough waves of political debate provoked by the appointment of a Cabinet labeled reactionary by the liberals and Socialists.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,167,000,000, an increase of $86,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,233,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

One out or every seven residents of New York City is now being cared for by private or public relief agencies at a cost which has totaled $102,209,500 in the last eighteen months, Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, declared in an address last night.

BUFFALO, June 9 -- David Lawrence, editor of The United States Daily, in addressing the dinner which closed the State conference of Mayors tonight advocated a more equitable distribution of the tax burden in the governmental structure.
LONDON, June 9 (Canadian Press) -- Glamorgan defeated Leicestershire by an innings and 86 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluded today at Cowbridge.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Opening a series of radio talks on State finances, Governor Roosevelt declared tonight that large economies in the State could be effected only by elimination or limitation of governmental functions. He called upon the people to make their own choice of the functions they desired to abolish or restrict.

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the promotion of four of his clergy to pastorates, transfer of many assistants from one parish to another and the appointment to parishes as assistants of the young men he ordained in St. Patrick's Cathedral a fortnight ago.

Three men, alleged to have participated in a new racket whereby Chicago merchants were swindled out of $100,000, were arrested here yesterday at the offices of the Standard Adjustment Bureau, which they had recently opened at 570 Seventh Avenue, and are being held as fugitives from justice pending extradition.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The revised resolution by Representative Somers of New York, approving steps which have been begun for an international monetary conference at London, received privileged status today from the House Rules Committee and will probably be placed before the House early next week for action.

Resolutions urging upon Congress additional economy measures, modification of the Volstead act, curtailment of expenditures for the relief of veterans and enlarged powers for the President to effect savings were adopted yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association, meeting in the Empire State Building in its final session before the Summer recess.

Mrs. Frederic M. Paist, president of the national board of the Y.W. C.A., took issue yesterday with John R. Mott, president of the World's Alliance of the Y.M.C.A. and of the International Missionary Council, who, in an interview in London Wednesday, came out for resubmisson of the Eighteenth Amendment to the people.

A friendly receivership for the $1,600,000 home of the Real Estate Board of New York, 12 East Fortyfirst Street, is one of the proposals that will be considered at a special meeting of bondholders of the Real Estate Board of New York Building Company, Inc., at 2 P.M. on June 21.
NEWARK, June 9 (AP) -- The Newark Bears opened a long home stay today by crushing the Rochester Red Wings, 11 to 6, in foe first of their three-game series.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, burly Kentuckian, demonstrated last night the punishing power of his famous headlock when he pinned the shoulders of the powerful Dick Shikat, German heavyweight, to the mat in 1 hour 6 minutes 7 seconds at Madison Square Garden's new sport bowl in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The War Department appropriation bill, carrying a total of $389,578,000 for the activities of that branch of the government for the fiscal year 1933, was passed by the Senate tonight without a record vote.

By far the best showing for many weeks in bank clearances throughout the country was made in the week ended Wednesday, according to reports received by R.G. Dun Co. The totals were reduced from an average of approximately 50 per cent below last year reported for the past several weeks, to only 31.3 per cent below last year.

Erratic price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the prevalent mood of uncertainty in Wall Street. The market was fractionally lower at the opening but rallied before the end of the first half-hour and then held steady, 1 to 3 points above the day's lows, until early afternoon, when reactionary tendencies appeared again.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A continuation of the Federal Reserve Bank's open-market policy of buying government securities in the week ended Wednesday led to an increase of $70,000,000 in holdings, bringing the total to $1,645,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Contrary to the usual seasonal movement, the value of department store sales showed a decline from April to May.

Approximately 55,000 stockholders in twelve general management investment trusts controlled by or affiliated with the Atlas Utilities Corporation are being invited to exchange their shares for those in the parent company in letters mailed yesterday, marking the first step by Atlas to consolidate the interests it has been acquiring in the last two and one-half years.

ADDIS ABEBA, Abyssinia, June 9 (AP) -- Like Napoleon, the former Emperor Yeassu of Abyssinia has escaped captivity and is gathering a large army about him to march on the present ruler, Haile Selassie.
General salary reductions affecting all city employes and members of the Board of Estimate are urged by the City Club in a letter sent yesterday to the Board of Estimate.
PARIS, June 9 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Mrs. Herbert Hoover reviewed nine of twenty-seven divisions in which about 125,000 children and adults of Brooklyn Sunday schools marched yesterday afternoon in the anniversary day parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union. Earlier she was guest of honor at a luncheon given for the reviewing party at the Montauk Club, Eighth Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, by former Senator and Mrs. William M. Calder.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

New York City completed arrangements yesterday for $23,000,000 of short-term borrowing, of which $8,000,000 will be obtained today and $15,000,000 on next Tuesday. Today's financing will consist of tax notes and special revenue bonds to mature on June 10, 1933, on which the interest rate is 5 1/2 per cent, the same as on the $6,000,000 borrowed on April 20 and the $5,000,000 on May 13 under the tentative arrangement for a total of $25,000,000.
Fordham University graduated 261 students of its School of Law with exercises held yesterday on the broad green quadrangle of the campus in front of the new Science Building.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Treasury security issues of the offerings to be dated June 15 were heavily oversubscribed, Secretary Mills announced today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There appeared in THE TIMES recently an interview with Dr. P.A. Wickmann of Berlin, a representative of the International Union of Local Authorities, in which he stated that he was "astounded at the lack et any sort of official municipal organization and clearing house in this country."

However one may disagree with JOHN DELANEY, Chairman of the Board of Transportation, on questions of policy, one cannot but admire the man's audacity. If the club which he has wrought turns to sawdust in his hand, he will still shake it at his foes.

Reiterating his prediction that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt would be nominated for President on the first ballot at the Democratic National Convention, James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman and manager of Governor Roosevelt's campaign, served notice yesterday on Tammany that the Governor would not need New York's electoral vote to be elected.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The stock market investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will be resumed next Thursday, Chairman Norbeck said today after a telephone conversation with William A. Gray, committee counsel.
LONDON, June 9 -- Business again was quiet in the stock markets today under New York influence. British Government funds reacted further, although they partly recovered.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A bill to abolish the Federal Farm Board and turn over its affairs to the Department of Commerce for liquidation was introduced today by Representative Britten. It was the second measure introduced this session with that purpose.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The New York Central Railroad Company today requested the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of a further loan of $13,600,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to pay interest on its funded debt, rent for leased roads and taxes.

NEW YORK. Miss Adelina Moller, who will sail on the Homeric tomorrow to pass the Summer in England, gave a farewell luncheon yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza. Her guests were Mrs. Charles B. Alexander, Mrs. Charles R. Scott, Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren, Mrs. Julian W. Robbins, Mrs. Charles A. Childs, Mrs. George Rose, Mrs. James B. Clews, Mrs. Schuyler N. Warren, Mrs. Arthur Ryle and Mrs. Ansel Phelps.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- A bullish construction was placed by the trade today on the government's estimate of a Winter wheat crop of 411,000,000 bushels. This was 30,000,000 bushels less than was estimated a month ago and 22,000,000 bushels below the average of the June returns of the leading local statisticians.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 9 -- The Republican party went wet today in hitherto nominally dry Indiana, wets defeated drys on the floor of the State convention and by a vote of 823 to 620 put through a plank headed "Temperance" calling for the submission by Congress to the States of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and for repeal of the Wright State dry law.

Patrolman "Sugar" of the Arsenal station strolled along his beat -- the Central Park Mall -- yesterday thinking. The patrolman, as the story goes, has never failed to answer the thousands of questions the children ask him, to settle disputes, nor has he ever lost his temper.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The administration's thirty-day furlough plan today appeared to have slight chance of surviving as the major feature of the economy bill as conferees of the House and Senate prepared to begin consideration of the bill tomorrow.
EASTON, Pa., June 9 -- The two days of festivities incident to the commencement exercises of Lafayette College started today.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 9 -- The Little Man, the bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith of New Canaan, Conn., and shown in the ring by Mrs. Smith, carried off championship honors today in the polo division during the first day of the thirty-ninth annual Westchester County Horse Shaw at the Rye Turf and Polo Club.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Amplifying his comment on the prohibition repeal plea of John D. Rockefeller Jr., Governor Roosevelt today envisaged the possibility of action by the present Congress in its next session to amend current prohibition regulations.

Bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $2,040,002,188 in market value in May, according to the monthly tabulation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The market value of the 1.587 issues on June 1 was $36,856,628,280, against $38,896,630,468 for 1.590 issues on May 1.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The B.E.F. has "dug in" along the Potomac and is prepared to stay in the nation's capital until the bonus payment bill is passed.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The 1932 Winter wheat harvest is likely to be only 410,699,000 bushels, compared with the record crop of 787,465,000 bushels in 1931 and with the preceding five-year average of 548,632,000 bushels, the Department of Agriculture said today, on the basis of crop conditions as of June 1.

SANDWICH, England, June 9 -- Gene Sarazen placed himself three strokes ahead of his nearest competitor in the second round of the British open golf championship today by a spectacular round of 69, which equaled the record for the Prince's course.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.
A factory purchase and several apartment house conveyances were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

PARIS, June 9 -- Scarcely any notice has been taken in Paris of Secretary of State Stimson's reaffirmation, on the eve of the Lausanne reparations conference, of the well known political position of the United States Government: that there will be no "total cancellation of debts" even if there is a total cancellation of reparations.

Liquidation continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices made new low records. June, the spot month, closed at 4.85 cents compared with 4.98 in 1898, while spot quotations of 5 cents compared with 5 3/8 cents, the bottom mark of thirty-four years ago.

When a committee waited upon Governor ELY of Massachusetts Tuesday night to notify him that the Legislature was ready to adjourn, he said: "I appreciate the " things you have done, and the " things that you have not done I " understand."

The Bay Shore captains are preparing for weakfishing parties tomorrow and Sunday, as the first weaks have begun to put in an appearance in Great South Bay. Although blackfish and flounder have predominated thus far, some of the weakfish catches during the past few days have already assured the fishermen that the fish should be running in greater numbers from now on.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 -- The Harvard Athletic Association announced today that 205 awards had been made to Harvard athletes for participation in Spring sports.

BERLIN, June 9 -- Price movements on the Boerse were irregular today, mostly downward, on account of realizations by nervous speculators following weakness in Wall Street and the European markets. News that Prussia had obtained credit from German banks caused a temporary rally, but business remained dull.

DIRECT from Melbourne, Australia, comes word that this country is threatened with an invasion of Australian football teams. In the country called "Down Under" they think they have a game that combines the best features of rugby, intercollegiate football and Canadian football. They aim to sell it on that basis by sending over two Australian football teams to play a series of exhibition games in our large cities.
The five principal legatees under the $30,000,000 will of the late Miss Ella V. von E. Wendel have settled with five of the eight outstanding claimants, it was learned yesterday.

Loans and Investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City were reduced $205,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the statement of condition of these institutions published yesterday showed. This drastic decline in bank credit was described by bankers as due largely to preparations for the forthcoming Treasury offering, to which the banks have subscribed heavily.

Sixty-four scholarships, prizes and medals were awarded last night to members of the graduating classes of Cooper Union during its commencement exercises in the large hall of the Union. R. Fulton Cutting, president of the board of trustees, made the awards and presented diplomas, certificates and degrees to the 387 graduates of the Institute of Technology, the Woman's Art School, the Night School of Engineering and the Night School of Art.

DETROIT, June 9 -- Eleven Detroit bits in six innings, together with lack of offensive cooperation, on the part of his new team-mates, spoiled Danny MacFayden's debut as a Yankee pitcher today, the Tigers winning, 5 to 4, to advance from fourth to third place.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 9 -- Three high-goal polo games were played at Meadow Brook today in preparation for the opening of the Meadow Brook Cup and third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament next week.

The bonus march of the war veterans on Washington was disavowed yesterday by Henry J. Amy. commander of the New York County organization of the American Legion, on behalf of his organization. In doing so, Mr. Amy asserted his belief that, in New York at least, the march had begun as the inspiration of the Workers' Ex-Service Men's League, a Communist organization.

Yesterday was Hack Wilson's day at Ebbets Field, and the stocky outfielder hasn't been so happy since he signed the contract that put him in a position to prove to Rogers Hornsby that the Cubs made an error in disposing of him.

Offering "expert guidance in literary problems for those interested in writing either as a profession or as a means of personal satisfaction and development," the seventh annual session of the Bread Loaf Writers' Conference will be conducted this year by Middlebury College from Aug. 17 to Sept. 1 at Bread Loaf Inn, Vermont.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Reflecting the effect of the depression, American underwriting of foreign securities declined in 1931 to a par value of $285,000,000, or little more than a fourth of those publicly floated in the United States during the preceding year, according to a study by Paul D. Dickens made public today by the finance and investment division of the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- A prediction in the House by Representative Celler that Calvin Coolidge would condemn prohibition in the July issue of The Cosmopolitan -- quickly denied by that magazinetoday brought from the New York Democrat the statement that the former President nevertheless would do just that "in the next issue."
BERLIN, June 9 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 7 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks :

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 9 -- During his long career as an outstanding golfer Cyril Tolley, ex-British amateur champion, may have visited some unusual spots but probably never one such as he found himself in at the Plainfield Country Club today.

Louis Greenstein, who by threats of violence and blackmail held intoxicated persons in his speakeasy at 152 West Seventy-second Street until he had extorted cash and checks from them, was sentenced yesterday to serve three years in Atlanta penitentiary, the maximum punishment for conspiracy and maintaining a nuisance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9 -- The commencement program of Vassar College will open tomorrow with a memorial service in honor of Laura J. Wylie, whose service on the English faculty of Vassar College for more than a quarter of a century is an outstanding memory of Vassar students.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Accurately speaking, it was Iris Day in the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, but we could not resist the ross garden, although Rose Day formalities will not be celebrated by the Botanical Garden until the second week in June.

The American Federation of Arts has announced its schedule of travling exhibitions for the season 1932-33. The federation, since its esablishment almost a quarter of a century ago, has adhered to the polcy of sending art from town to town, thus making it possible for thousands of people, especially those living far from the important cultural centres to see pictures and sculpture about which they could otherwise know little or nothing.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Hogs were in somewhat better demand today and prices were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, with packing sows showing as much as 10 cents higher in some instances. The firmness was in face of reports of a slow demand for fresh pork loins.

Decision on an application for the appointment of a receiver in bankruptcy for the Kreuger Toll Company was postponed yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack to allow Gordon Auchincloss, American representative of administrative trustees in Sweden, to determine the Swedish attitude toward a voluntary petition in bankruptcy and the election of a trustee.

The grandiose plans of Congress for a reduction of expenditures sufficient to compensate the public for the higher taxes it must pay have now simmered down to a modest bill proposing economies which will amount at most to $157,000,000. This measure, adopted by the Senate and now sent to conference, aims to save $88,000,000 by requiring Federal employes to take thirty-day furloughs without pay.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 9 -- Weather which made real rowing out of the question and which made any sort of oarsmanship something of a problem of navigation held the crews of Yale and Harvard ashore for most of the day today.

Yesterday General MATTHEW A. TINLEY of Council Bluffs, Iowa's Democratic Favorite Son for Vice President, left our city, where he had been visiting old army friends after attending the dedication of the Port of Albany. He was a distinguished soldier in the war and first commander of the American Legion in Iowa.

To the Editor of The New York Times, I have changed my mind about the depression, Until recently I have been thinking that it would be a fine thing to jump into good times again. Too much needs to be changed before we go into another period of prosperity.

A plea for an adequate detail of special policemen, under the supervision of the Bronx Department of Parks, to protect city playground property in that borough from vandalism and depredations was made by Park Commissioner Thomas J. Dolen in the course of a tour of the parks yesterday by a group of Bronx officials, realty men and business leaders under the auspices of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.

MADRID, June 9 (AP). - Indalecio Prieto, one of the founders of the Spanish Republic and Minister of Public Works in the present Cabinet, was charged in the Cortes (National Assembly) today with having deprived the government of 200,000 pesetas a year through an illegal tobacco concession.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9 -- Monday evening, July 18, has been selected as the date for an entertainment being arranged as a benefit for the Newport County League for Animals. The location for the entertainment has not been decided. The program will include a series of tableaux of famous paintings.

Harry Fleisher, leader of the "Purple gang" in Detroit, who has been sought by New Jersey police since early in March for questioning about the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., gave himself up yesterday in Detroit.

John J. Raskob, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who has furnished most of the money to keep the party's national organization functioning since 1928, has canceled two promissory notes of the committee for $50,000 each. This forgiveness of a debt of $100,000 was made by Mr. Raskob as a gift to the party's $1,500,000 Victory Fund, to which Mr. Raskob pledged a contribution of that amount on condition that the full amount'was raised.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 9 -- The expropriation of deposits of foreign currency in Chilean banks was decreed today by the government and the Central Bank of Chile was taken over by the government.

Six have been named for the $2,000 added Rockaway Claiming Stakes, feature today at Aqueduct, where the twenty-two-day meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will get under way. The six are Condescend, Commuter, Uncanny, Blind Bowboy, Ha Ha and Caplin, and they should provide the keenest sort of contest over the six-and-one-half-furlong route.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Radio Commission is ready to prepare plans for government ownership and operation of broadcasting stations if desired, the commission notified the Senate today in a 300-page report in connection with the Dill-Couzens resolution passed in January.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 9 -- Cliff Sutter of New Orleans, Tulane's star; Bryan Grant of Atlanta and Berkeley Bell, New York, marched into the semi-finals of the national clay courts tournament today, the two last-named over opponents who stubbornly contested every inch of ground.

Evidence has been uncovered by a group of archaeologists indicating that the biblical mention of the "house of ivory," built by Ahab, King of Samaria In the eighth century before Christ, may have been more than just a poetic description of a white stone house.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Asking that it be allowed "to work out its own salvation," the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to give it until March, 1933, to comply with conditions imposed by the commission in authorizing the Rio Grande's control of the Denver Salt Lake.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Edward B. McLean identified today in the trial of Gaston B. Means her signature to a memorandum authorizing Means, employed by her to negotiate for the return of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, to turn over $100,000 ransom money to a mysterious man called "The Fox" and named in the memorandum as "Williams."

RICHMOND, June 9 -- Virginia Democracy tonight endorsed former Governor Harry F. Byrd for the Presidency on a platform stating that the prohibition issue must be squarely faced. A prompt referendum to provide a direct vote of the people on the question was urged.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Warned by health authorities that the growing army of veterans huddled in shacks and on the open ground on the edge of the capital constituted the gravest health menace in the history of the city, the District of Columbia commissioners appealed today to the Governors of all States to turn back the tide of bonus-seeking ex-service men at its source.

The State Department of Education, which received a demand Wednesday for the immediate removal of Dean George R. Hardie of Long Island University from a committee representing the faculty, would not act on the charges on the grounds that Long Island University was a private institution and did not come under the jurisdiction of the State department, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, June 9 (Canadian Press) -- The government desires to make public the agenda of the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa before June 16, but is still awaiting replies from the dominions.

For a short spell in the inaugural match there was a legitimate prospect of an even division of the opening's day's spoils yesterday as Brazil and the United States met in the American interzone Davis Cup final at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

PARIS, June 9 -- Prices fluctuated little during a dull session of the Bourse today. Closing quotations generally were a trifle higher than at the opening. A conservative attitude was maintained while traders waited for further details of the new French Government's financial policy.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 9 -- Following a meeting of the executive committee of South Orange Post 220, American Legion, this afternoon, Commander Joseph C. Paul of the post sent to President Hoover a telegram that said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Tuberculosis Work," if I interpret it correctly, shows that you in common with many other public-spirited members of the community, are in error about the role that the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association plays.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Relief legislation was temporarily sidetracked while the Senate worked today and into this evening on the army appropriation bill, but proponents of the various proposals made plans to take them up tomorrow, if possible, and push them steadily to a conclusion.

PETROVSK, Russia, June 9 -- Another catastrophic wreck on a Soviet railroad in which an undetermined number of persons were reported killed on May 15 was revealed publicly for the first time today, when sixteen railroad employes went on trial, charged with responsibility for the accident.

Three American women golfers who have been playing in England will return today on the Cunard liner Berengaria. They are Glenna Collett Vare, Maureen Orcutt and Helen Hicks. Others on the Berengaria include:

An application for listing 1,177,641 shares of Class A stock and 8,994,937 shares of common stock, both of $1 par value, of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation has been made to the New York Stock Exchange. The new shares will be exchanged for the same number of no-par shares.

Defending the war debt settlements concluded under his administration between the United States and our former associates in the war as just and fair and expressing himself as opposed to any cancellation, former President Coolidge, writing in the July issue of The Cosmopolitan, rejects also the proposal to remit the debts on condition that the debtor nations agree to increase their trade with this country.

The Bayonne Bridge over the Kill Van Kull between Bayonne, N.J., and Staten Island, the longest arch bridge in the world, has won the 1932 Class A prize of the American Institute of Steel Construction as "the most beautiful bridge of steel erected last year," for structures costing in excess of $1,000,000.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP). -- The roar of tractor engines and the crunching of their treads upon hardened snow will mingle with the barking of sled dogs and the whir of airplane motors when Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's second polar expedition heads into the Antarctic wastes next Winter.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 9 -- In an "excursion into ethics, morals and points of view on public questions," Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the boards of Consolidated Gas Company of New York and the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, said tonight to the National Electric Light Association at their annual convention here that he believed that any company violating the highest standards of the industry should not be permitted to remain within the association.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Washington took advantage of some loose defensive play by the White Sox in the early innings today to win the third game of the series, 6 to 5, and gain a full game on the New York Yankees, who lost to Detroit.

MONTREAL, Que., June 8 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Government's assistance would be essential to reorganization of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Arthur F. White, vice president, said today at the annual meeting of shareholders here.

Tentative proposals for the acquisition of the Richfield Oil Company of California, now in receivership, have been made to the three committees representing the Richfield bondholders, the Pan-American Petroleum Company of California bondholders and the general creditors.

Louis Benson, stenographer in the grand jury investigation, in February, 1931, which led to indictments in the Bank of United States failure, continued his testimony yesterday under cross-examination of John W. Davis, chief defense lawyer, in the new trial of Isidor J. Kresel, formerly general counsel for the defunct bank on a perjury charge.

ALBANY, June 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Grace Levine of Brooklyn was elected today State president of the Woman's Relief Corps at the convention in conjunction with the encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 9 -- The American women tennis stars are confident tonight that they have more than an even chance of winning the Wightman Cup series, which begins on Wimbledon's historic courts tomorrow.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 9 -- Chief Justice Hughes of the Supreme Court declared today that the judiciary should interpret the Federal Constitution in the light of new conditions.

Under the leadership of Mr. WICKERSHAM and the auspices of the New York State Economic Council, a group of business and professional men are meeting in this city today to formulate plans for retrenchment in Federal, State and local government.

SEATTLE, June 9 -- The national convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs opened tonight with a program with an early Colonial motif. Mrs. John F. Sippel of Baltimore presided over the 3,000 delegates, representing 5,000,000 American clubwomen.

Reports containing an outline of the regulations covering the 10 per cent excise levy on furs and on "merchandise in which fur is the chief component part" were made yesterday to members of the Industrial Council of Cloak. Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and the Merchants' Ladies' Garment Association, following a conference on Wednesday of a delegation of executives of the associations with officials of the Treasury Department in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Early passage of the Crosser bill to estabish regular transatlantic air-mail service with airships through longterm air-mail contracts was predicted late today, after adoption by the House of a special rule to bring the bill up for immediate consideration.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- As Republicans who will pilot next week's national convention begin to appear on the scene, a desire of many party leaders, perhaps a majority of those gathered here, to have Vice President Curtis supplanted by some other man for second place on the ticket is becoming apparent.

Feeling the urge to put on another one-man show, Master Melvin Ott hit two more home runs at the Polo Grounds yesterday, thereby repeating his performance of Tuesday and again sinking the Reds practically single-handed.

MUNICH, June 9 -- Adolf Hitler, on the stand today in his suit for libel and perjury against Werner Abel, a journalist, declared that his National Socialist party had never received and would not accept subsidies from Italy or other foreign countries or their nationals.
SYDNEY, June 9 (Canadian Press). -- Few political contests in Australia's history have aroused such intense interest as the State elections that will take place in New South Wales on Saturday.

MEXICO CITY, June 9 -- Despite opposition from the Mexican Government and business interests throughout the country Governor Adalberto Tejeda of the State of Vera Cruz has put into effect the new expropriation law under which virtually every business and income can be taken over by the State.
EASTBOURNE, England, June 9 -- The United States and Great Britain broke even today as the team matches between the two countries opened on the eve of the Wimbledon championships.

TRENTON, N.J., June 9 -- While State Senator Richards of Atlantic County, leader of the Republican majority in the upper legislative house, was assuring an audience at a luncheon in Elizabeth today that the Senate would not pass a bill, already approved by the Assembly, to abolish the Elizabeth Water Board, the Senators were enacting the repealer by a vote of 12 to 1.

That Max D. Steuer has resigned or is about to resign as Special Assistant District Attorney in the prosecution of the remaining indictments growing out of the grand jury investigation of the defunct Bank of United States was indicated yesterday in Judge Rosalsky's part of General Sessions.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Top Flight, champion 2-year-old of 1931, again proved herself best of her sex and age when she won the sixteenth running of the Coaching Club American Oaks, closing-day feature yesterday at Belmont Park. The margin was half a length.

At the Booth Theatre, where the bickering House of Hallam assembles nightly in "Another Language," Margaret Hamilton, the acidulous Helen of that clan, made her first New York recital appearance yesterday afternoon.

Domestic corporation bonds moved lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and the losses, together with those of Wednesday, wiped out most of the sensational gains made last Saturday. Foreign loans were irregularly lower, but United States Government bonds showed good strength, reflecting the premiums of 7-32 and 5-32 bid, respectively, for the new treasury one-year 1 1/2 per cent certificates and three-year 3 per cent notes, traded over the counter.

GENEVA, June 9 -- A return to the gold standard as the world's "best available monetary mechanism" was strongly recommended by the League of Nations gold delegation today in its final report, the full text of which will be given out tomorrow or Saturday.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 9 -- Two youths were held today on a charge of attempting to extort $5,000 from George W. Norris, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Shorty after his arrest one of the prisoners attempted to commit suicide in his cell by slashing his wrists with a razor blade.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production is 69.9 for the week ended June 4, as against 64.3 for the preceding week and 94.7 for the corresponding week last year. There was further heavy curtailment in some kinds of cloth, but this was more than offset by increased output in other descriptions.
Gene Sarazen is the first graduate of Westchester County caddie ranks to scale the heights of winning the British open championship.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

MONTREAL, Que., June 10 -- A definite plan of reorganization of the financial structure of the Beauharnois Power Corporation and its subsidiaries, involving the disappearance of the corporation entirely and the issuance to bondholders of a controlling amount of the shares of the reorganized operating company, has been evolved for submission to a special committee that was appointed here today by a general meeting of bondholders.

Deposits in the 146 mutual savings banks in New York State amounted to $5,215,532,463 at the end of May, a decrease of $21,079,487 during the month, according to Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

The Scripps-Howard chain of twenty-five newspapers, represented in New York by The World-Telegram, announced yesterday its support of Alfred E. Smith for the Presidency. A front-page editorial, published in all of the papers of the chain, declared that Governor Roosevelt is "another Hoover" and that the election of either President Hoover or Governor Roosevelt in November "would be a blow from which this nation would not recover in a generation."

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 149,764 tons in May to a total of 2,177,162 tons, it was announced yesterday. It was the fourteenth consecutive decrease and it brought the corporation's bookings to a new low record. In each month this year the backlog has dropped into new low ground, and not since March, 1931, has there been an upturn in any month.

DETROIT, June 10 -- Combs's double over third base and Sewell's single to centre, coming with two out in the eleventh inning, gave the Yankees an 8-to-7 victory over the Tigers today, making it three out of four for the series and twelve in thirteen games with, the Western clubs so far this year.

HARTFOHD, Conn., June 10 -- Five hard sets were required for Dave Jones of New York to defeat Holbrook Hyde of Hartford in the semi-finals of the New England tennis tournament today. Tomorrow Jones will meet J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., who won in four sets from Jerry Lang of New York City.

As one of his first moves to combat the removal charges prepared by Samuel Seabury, Mayor Walker plans to seek postponement of action by Governor Roosevelt until after the November elections, it became known yesterday.

The Greer Club, 46 West Ninety-sixth Street, a memorial to Bishop David H. Greer, has been turned over by the Greer Club Association to the emergency relief committee of the Church-woman's League for Patriotic Service. The collaboration will continue until Oct. 1, when the lease expires on the club quarters.

The total assets of the Kreuger Toll Company in the United States known to Alexis Aminoff, official "observer" in this country for the bankrupt Swedish concern, amount to only $62,100.94 in cash, $79,000 of the company's 5 per cent secured debentures and 113,246 American certificates representing Kreuger Toll participating debentures.

Violet Sharps, described by the police as "the only servant in the Lindbergh-Morrow homes who could not furnish a suitable alibi" after the kidnapping of Colonel Lindbergh's baby on March 1, committed suicide by drinking poison before noon yesterday in the Morrow home in Englewood, where she had been employed as a waitress.

Commodity prices soared yesterday, coincident with the rise in security values. In the grains, the advance ranged from 1/2 cent to 1 1/2 cents and cotton rose 10 to 12 points. Sharp gains were also reported in coffee, sugar, cocoa, hides and silk, while rubber was steady. Spot markets maintained the advance in their trading.

Central Park for healthful recreation for elderly people was extolled yesterday by Louis C. Luhrs, retired real estate man, 71 years old, who goes to the park almost daily, Winter and Summer, to enjoy its seasonal advantages.
EASTBOURNE, England, June 10 (AP) -- The United States took a lead of two matches to one today in the informal tennis series with a British team.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- The Newark College of Engineering conferred the degree of Bachelor of Science upon a graduating class of eighty this evening, together with eight post-graduate degrees in engineering.
The Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game has been investigating the destruction of small trout in streams of the State.

The third "nothing over $100" exhibition this Spring has opened, at the Midtown Galleries, 559 Fifth Avenue. Eighteen canvases by American artists of some standing are for sale at prices within the scope of diminished budgets.

Before Benjamin Gordon, under sentence to die in the electric chair for shooting a man in a Bronx garage hold-up, resumed testimony yesterday in General Sessions at the first-degree murder trial of Jack Zaroff, accused of shooting Patrolman Maurice O'Brien in Harlem on Jan. 30, 1930, Judge Corrigan ordered all visitors to the trial be searched at the entrance.

William H. Todd, who rose from newsboy to the presidency of the largest shipyard corporation in the country, left the bulk of his fortune to his three children, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of his will in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Funds for operation of the Farm Board during the year beginning July 1 were cut upward of 50 per cent today by the Senate Appropriations Committee in reporting the billion-dollar independent offices supply bill to the Senate.
Municipal operation of the new city subways by the Board of Transpotation will be authorized at a special meeting of the Board of Estimate next week, it was indicated yesterday at City Hall.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The bullish government report on Winter wheat almost fell flat today as a market influence on the Board of Trade here, but toward the close there was renewed short covering on the strength in stocks and on rumors that Congress might adjourn soon.

A violent advance in the shares of the Auburn Automobile Company and the J.I. Case Company, in both of which there appeared to be danger of a technical corner, imparted strength to the general list on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The slightly brisker realty activity of the last few days was continued yesterday, when brokers reported new deals in scattered sections of Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- Because New Jersey State police and Federal officials want to question Harry Fleisher concerning the Lindbergh baby kidnapping, the gangster, who surrendered yesterday here, will not be arraigned until Monday on a year-old murder charge.

A campaign by the Department of Health to insure clean food and drinks, properly handled and sanitarily served, at refreshment stands and food shops at the shore and in river resorts and city parks, was announced yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health.
SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, June 11 (Canadian Press) -- The voters of the States of New South Wales and Queensland went to the polls today to record their decision on the Labor bid for power.

CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- The Athletics bounded back into third place today as they scored four runs in the tenth inning to defeat Cleveland, 10 to 7. They lost the services, however, of Ed Colemand, right fielder, who broke a bone in his ankle sliding into the plate in the second inning.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Dry leaders of America held the opening rally of a three-day "loyalty" convention tonight in the Third Presbyterian Church under the auspices of the Anti-Saloon League of America and the Illinois Conference of Associations Supporting the Eighteenth Amendment.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 10 -- One high school boy was killed and four others were injured seriously in an automobile collision, this afternoon at the intersection, of Oxford Boulevard and Warwick Road, in the undeveloped section of Great Neck Gardens.

Since the appointment of the gold delegation of the League of Nations in the Summer of 1929 to "examine into and report upon the causes of fluctuation in the purchasing power of gold and their effect upon the ecconomic life of the nations" the sweeping effects of the world-wide economic depression have made themselves felt, driving many countries off the gold standard and forcing others to institute rigid methods of exchange restriction and control.

Another effort to have the Chrysler Building, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street, declared permanently exempt from taxation was made yesterday, when Cooper Union, owner of the land on which the building was erected, applied to the Supreme Court for cancellation of the $12,000,000 assessment put on the building for 1932 by the Board of Taxes and Assessments.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The answer of the bonus expeditionary force today to the warnings of disease and to the efforts of the District of Columbia to choke off the stream of incoming veterans was to adopt such measures as it could to forestall an epidemic, and to send recruiting squads throughout the country to rally 50,000 reinforcements to the army now here demanding immediate payment of the $2,400,000,000 bonus certificates.

Because the depression has reduced the membership of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, thus decreasing the funds for operating expenses, William Sloane Coffin, president, has issued an appeal to "citizens of New York to maintain at least the level of last year in membership dues."

Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts, one of the leading supporters of Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency, implied in a statement yesterday that Governor Roosevelt, if nominated, would have difficulty in carrying the strong Smith States in the November election.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The part of the report by the League of Nations gold delegation that recommends a return to the gold standard by the nations of the world was generally received with approval today by members of Congress and administration officials.

More than 3,000 persons are sailing for Europ today. Leaving on the White Star liner Homeric are Sir Charles Ballance, consulting surgeon to the British Army; Mrs. Chauncey M. Depew, C.E. Barlow, Captain F. B. Howarth, Dr. K.B. Hubbell, F. W. Calder, United States Vice Consul at Southampton, and Mrs. Calder; Amos Tuck French, the Right Rev. P.J. de Strycker, Miss M.F. Ogden, Miss J.A. Thomson and Miss A. Smith.

The Board of Estimate, holding its last regular meeting yesterday before Summer recess, voted $862,460 for school equipment, authorized sufficient funds to keep the Municipal Lodging House open for the remainder of the year and revised its policy of continuing the services of city employes more than 70 years old by voting to grant extensions of only one year instead of two.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Walter E. Edge and her children, who have been at the Ambassador since their arrival from Paris, will leave today for their country home in Ventnor, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Hoover was asked today to revive the Council of National Defense as an agency "operating in a national emergency of the first magnitude," to end the depression, but lost no time disapproving the suggestion.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Representative McFadden of Pennsylvania made a vitriolic attack on the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Reserve Banks and President Hoover today on the floor of the House, calling them "thieves" and among "the most corrupt institutions the world has ever known."

Control of the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., a general management investment trust, and the management contract for the Broad Street Investing Company have been acquired by the Tri-Continental Corporation through purchase of control of the Broad Street Management Corporation.

The Board of Estimate adjourned yesterday until Sept. 30 with the question of bus franchises in Manhattan and Queens still unsettled. If any awards are to be made before next Fall they must be made at special meetings during the Summer.

Playing some of their best baseball of the season to defeat the Cubs, 4 to 3, in the final game of the series, before 12,000 fans, at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Robins added to the thrills and excitement for the spectators by staging a free-for-all fist-fight with their opponents in the first inning.

Scholarships for study in Austria, Hungary, Italy and Switzerland during the coming year have been awarded to nineteen American students in recognition of the opportunities offered to foreign students in this country, the Institute of International Education announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 10 -- The finance bill was passed on third reading in the House of Commons today by a majority of 375 in favor of the government, after a debate in which Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sprang several surprises.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10 -- The wooded crags of Crow's Nest beetled down upon tradition this morning as West Point sent another class out into life.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A $300,000,000 unemployment relief bill written by Democrats but satisfactory in its basic purposes to the administration was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 72 to 8.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Perpetual memorial to the friendship existing between Canada and the United States, the Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park will he dedicated at Glacier Park, Mont., on June 18.

The joint legislative committee on banks announced after its meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that it would consider a plan for forming central banks that might be either State-wide or established in judicial districts.

Five minutes before the arrival of an armored car at the Bay Ridge branch business office of the New York Telephone Company at 5,202 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, for the day's receipts of about $2,000 or more, three armed men held up eight employes and two women subscribers in the office at 3:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon and escaped with the money.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Little concern was shown in government circles today over the reported adoption by the Mexican State of Vera Cruz of an expropriation law under which practically every business and income may be placed under State control.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10 -- Leaders of the Senate and Assembly were attempting to bring the Legislature to adjournment for this year tonight, after Governor A. Harry Moore had signed a bill submitting the question of repeal of the State prohibition enforcement act to the voters at the election this Fall, and another bill providing a reduction of salaries of State employes on a graded scale from 1 to 10 per cent.

Carrying cardboard banners demanding "We Want Coach Gottschallk," more than 300 students of the Woodrow Wilson High School in Weehawken marched in a parade through the township last night to protest the action of the board of education in removing Harold Gottschallk as football coach and instructor of history.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 10 -- Negotiable bonds with a face value of $200,000 were stolen from the Girard Trust Company today when, a clerk who was checking them over rushed into another department of the bank in response to a mysterious telephone call.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10 -- Harvard's varsity crew went back to its original boating today, with Gerry Cassedy again at stroke and Edward Yeomans Jr. at No. 2, and there was every indication that this would be the line-up for the race with Yale two weeks from today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Charges that the collapse of Radio-Keith-Orpheum stock last Fall and Winter was accompanied by illegal acts by the directors of the amusements company and "bear raids" on the company's stock that enabled the Radio Corporation of America to obtain control of RKO at a fraction of its value, entered into the Senate stock market inquiry today.

Commuter, gelded son of Transmute, which sprang a surprise at Belmont Park by winning the Nassau Handicap, was responsible for another yesterday as the twenty-two-day meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club opened at Aqueduct. Running in the silks of Ella De T. Simpson, Commuter captured the Rockaway Claiming Stakes by three lengths, returning 16 to 5.
LONDON, June 10 -- The negotiations between Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, and leaders of the British Cabinet ended in a complete breakdown late this afternoon.

Mild rallying tendencies in domestic corporation issues, irregularly lower prices in foreign loans and United States Government bonds and the slowest trading since April 25 characterized dealings yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange.

Of $37,665,012 of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week almost 50 per cent will be accounted for by the $18,000,000 issue of bonds of the State of New Jersey. The revised total for this week is $15,910,423. New issues up for award thus far in 1932 have averaged $22,308,340 weekly.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The visit to Geneva next week of Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, is expected here to bring some action at the General Disarmament Conference.
