It was admitted by officials today that for weeks the conference had been idling as the technical experts disputed over offensive and defensive weapons.

PARIS, June 10 -- Putting his faith in the good-will on both sides, Premier Edouard Herriot hopes during the conversations in the next two days with Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain and Sir John Simon, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to reach some compromise between the British and French viewpoints as to what should be done at the Lausanne conference starting next Thursday.

From Chicago come reports that the Republican managers are fearful lest their tentative plank for a referendum on prohibition be brushed aside for one pledging the party to direct repeal. The forces favoring this action were reported earlier in the week to be making rapid gains.
Speculative operations in a handful of stocks with which a stubborn bear party may have toyed too long gave color and excitement to yesterday's dealings on the Stock Exchange.

TOKYO, June 10 (AP) -- Major Gen. Hideo Hiramatsu, with his twentyseventh brigade of the Fourteenth Japanese Army Division, claimed today to have smashed the Chinese insurgent forces under General Ma Chen-shan in Northern Manchuria, according to a dispatch to the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency from Hailun.

The State of Sao Paulo. Brazil, normally notified its bankers here yesterday of the inability to meet the service on part of its foreign debt under a decree dated April 28. In March the Brazilian Government Suspended payment of principal and interest on the major part of its external debt.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney and Chief Inspector John O'Brien will be in line with 3,000 members of the Police Department Branch of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the National Holy Name Society when the parade in celebration of the golden jubilee of the local union will march up Fifth Avenue at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.
Changes in the entrance requirements of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy were announced yesterday, the date on which entrance examinations have been held each year for prospective cadets.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Immediate solution of the reparations and war debts problems by means of an international conference in which the United States would play a direct part, accompanied by international action looking toward economic stabilization through the adjustment of currency and other factors was declared essential to world economic recovery by Colonel Henry W. Anderson in an address today before the Union League Club of Chicago.

MAYS LANDING, N.J., June 10 -- Herman Meier, 25 years old, was beaten, burned and thrown into the river tonight by six men who invaded the River View Cabin, a dancing and eating place he operates at Betsey's Landing on the Great Egg Harbor River at English Creek, six miles from here.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Confidence that Congress will adjourn before the Democratic convention in Chicago, June 27, was expressed on both sides of the Capitol today, and some of the Senatorial leaders went so far as to say the goal could be achieved by a week from tomorrow.

Steps to provide railroad transportation from the "bonus army" camp at Washington for bona fide residents of New York City who wish to return, home were taken yesterday by Governor Roosevelt, in response to a telegraphic request from the Commissioners of the District of Columbia asking that New York State cooperate with them in assisting stranded New Yorkers to leave Washington.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Experimental proof that the functioning of the brain is accompanied and characterized by electric currents and that these are confined to the so-called architectonic areas of the cerebral cortex is claimed to have been established at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Brain Research by the work of Dr. A.E. Kornmueller.

NEWARK, June 10 (AP) -- The Bears defeated the Red Wings, 6 -- 5, today for the second straight time. A five-run rally in the eighth routed Bis Jim Winford from the Rochester mound and settled the issue.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per rent for the best names. Thursday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Edward Arons of New York conveyed to the Weehawken Trust and Title Company the three-story brick flat, with store, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, at 469 Palisade Avenue, near Ninth Street, West New York. The realty, assessed at $14,000, was taken over by the buyer subject to a mortgage for $15,000.

PITTSFIELD, June 10 -- Ten million volts of electricity, 5,000,000 greater than ever before produced by man in electrical experiments and about one-tenth, the voltage of a flash of lightning, were created here today in the engineering laboratory of the General Electric Company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10 -- Columbia University's light crew convincingly demonstrated its superiority over the junior varsity today and clinched its right to represent the Lions in the jayvee race on June 20.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Broadening of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's ship-to-shore radio telephone service, to include coastwise vessels, fishermen, and even the small yacht, were seen today in the announcement that the New England Telephone Company is to make the first tests of small boat radio telephony off the Massachusetts coast within a few days.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A ruling that the new admissions taxes provided for in the revenue act of 1932 would not be applicable to tickets purchased prior to June 21, even if the performance involved takes place after that date, will be made by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

"Canst thou send forth lightnings "that they may go and say unto thee, "Here we are?" JOB'S question was answered yesterday at Pittsfield, Mass., by Dr. F.W. PEEK Jr., who created a 10,000,000-volt 60-foot flash of lightning, which unmistakably indicated where it went by splitting wooden beams and crashing deafeningly through the air.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- On the heels of reports from Chicago of talk of nominating ex-President Coolidge as Vice President at the Republican convention, a conviction was apparent among leaders in Senate and House that an attempt to induce Mr. Coolidge to accept would amount to little, and that Vice President Curtis will be renominated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ten years ago I opposed vigorously any suggestion of bonus or other form of special consideration for the returned soldier. My opposition was based upon the supposition that an economic order deserving of the name would prevail, giving the veteran a fighting chance in the process of readjustment that lay before him.

BELGRADE, June 10 -- The attack Monday on Dr. Budak, a Croat leader, who was gravely wounded when three men armed with clubs and knives set upon him on the main street of Zagreb, has had a sharp reaction even in Parliament, all of whose members belong to the Government party.
Fred A. Russell, builder, has rented his stone residence at Park Av. and 5th St., Halstead Manor, Mamaroneck, to John J. McDonald. The Houghton Company was the broker.

Appointment of Dr. PAUL, MONROE as president of the two American colleges -- Robert College and the Constantinople Woman's' College -- at Istanbul marks the beginning of a new chapter in the life of those two institutions. They stand but a little way apart looking across the Bosporus from Europe into Asia.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 10 -- An unusual loan exhibition of furniture, paintings and other art objects, all dating back to the days of George Washington, will be opened tomorrow afternoon at the Gushing Memorial Building of the Newport Art Association.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- The front pages of all Soviet newspapers today carry the first public announcement of a decree issued by the Central Executive Committee and Council of Commissiars calling for a new State loan, designated "the State internal loan of the fourth or conclusive year of the Five-Year Plan."

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Receipts of hogs were light today and prices ad- vanced 5 to 10 cents, as the demand was more general than of late. Some increase in shipping orders was in evidence. The top was 5 cents higher than yesterday at $3.60 a hundred-weight, with the day's average also up 5 cents at $3.35.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The prosecution completed its case today in the trial of Gaston B. Means on the charge of embezzling $104,000 from Mrs. Edward B. McLean in an alleged Lindbergh ransom fraud.

Chairman FARLEY has issued many puzzling statements in behalf of Governor ROOSEVELT'S Presidential candidacy, but none so mystifying as his latest. In it he asserts that Mr. ROOSEVELT can be elected without the aid of any majority at all in this city and, indeed, without the electoral vote of this State.

Patrolman Francis X. Tevlin of the West Sixty-eighth Street precinct was suspended yesterday by Commissioner Mulrooney following the death in Reconstruction Hospital of Dorothy Goodman, a high school girl, who was hit by an automobile in which Tevlin was a passenger at 8 o'clock Thursday morning at West End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street.

Led by Auburn, which repeated its recent spectacular performances, the stock market gave a demonstration of strength yesterday that greatly impressed Wall Street. The industrial group on the Stock Exchange made a sharp advance, largely as the result, it appeared, of the exceptional situation in Auburn and a few other stocks in which there is a slender floating supply.

"Reunion in Vienna," in which Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt are appearing, will close its Broadway engagement at the Guild Theatre on July 2. At that time the play, by Robert E. Sherwood, which has been running here since Nov. 16, will have achieved a run of thirty-three weeks.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 10 -- Blue Sky, the little 4-year-old chestnut mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Tobey of Southold, L.I., and cleverly handled by their daughter, Miss Ida Louise Tobey, today was awarded the championship in the saddle pony division during the second day of the thirty-ninth annual Westchester County Horse Show at the Rye Turf and Polo Club.

MANILA, Saturday, June 11 -- A direct appeal to the United States War Department to maintain a school in the Philippines for American children may result from the order of Governor General Theodore Roosevelt yesterday that the Central High School end racial qualifications for admission and reduce its tuition.

The Salvation Army, with its emergency relief funds exhausted and facing an unprecedented demand for aid on the part of homeless workers and destitute families, will cut the pay of all its officers 10 per cent beginning next Friday, and will also close four of its training schools on the same day.

ABOARD THE SALVAGE SHIP ARTIGLIO, off Brest, France, June 10 -- The divers of the Artiglio recovered today the first real sample of the contents of the sunken liner Egypt's bullion room in the shape of bundles of ten-rupee and 100-rupee notes printed in London for the State of Hyderabad, India.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Over the protests of spokesmen for the Hoover Administration, the Republican National Committee this evening voted to seat Joseph W. Tolbert, veteran Republican National Committeeman from South Carolina and the bloc of contested delegates he is bringing to the Republican National Convention.

Continued improvement in the banking situation and steady betterment of credit conditions resulted in a fairly pronounced upturn in retail trade throughout the country in the last week, according to the weekly reviews of trade and industry.

READING, Pa., June 10 (AP) -- With Al Shealy pitching airtight ball in a pitchers' duel with Fred Fussell tonight, Reading ended its losing streak and downed the league-leading Buffalo Bisons, 4 to 1.

Nothing transpired in the money market to set it aside from preceding sessions. Business, as usual, was light and quotations unchanged for all classes of accommodation. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent. Street money loaned at 1 and Federals at 1/8 @ 1/4 Nominal quotation of 1 1/2 covered all maturity loans, while commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

SANDWICH, England, June 10 (AP) -- Gene Sarazen, with his 70, 69, 70, 74 for the seventy-two holes, shattered par on every round hut the last one this afternoon. He finished 13 strokes better than regulation figures for the championship layout, a long, treacherous par 74 course laid out on the edge of the English Channel.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 10 -- Sailing across Long Island Sound and back in a puffy northwester that at times reached 20 knots strength, Eleven Interclub class yachts had a lively tussle today in the second race of their Friday series. Gordon Raymond brought Robert McC. Shields's Canvasback home the winner by 30 seconds over Cornelius Shields in Aileen, with Eric H. Marks's Bee 55 seconds astern of Aileen.
Gen Harbord at West Point. At the Military Academy cadets are taught not only engeering, science, mathematics, drawing, languages and the art of war, but ethics, temperance and self-control.

The attempt of Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, to induce the State Athletic Commission to engage an out-of-town referee for Schmeling's heavyweight championship battle against Jack Sharkey in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on June 21 was rejected by Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan and Commissioner William Muldoon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Gold exports of $385,000,000 from the United States between May 1 and June 8 have exerted an influence toward easing conditions in the international money markets and increasing the volume of loanable funds in foreign countries, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in a review of the financial situation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 (AP) -- Foreign governments protested today against the confiscation of foreign currency deposits, while the Socialist junta proceeded to control prices of grains, sugars and other foods.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 10 -- With a fiercely fought victory over Berkeley Bell of New York, George Lott of Chicago, the favorite, today advanced to the final of the national clay courts tennis tournament, in which he will face Bryan Grant of Atlanta tomorrow.

Jersey City lost to Toronto, 5 to 3, at Jersey City yesterday, the Maple Leafs evening the series at one game each. Frank Barnes held the losers in check and also played a prominent part in his team's attack with three hits.

The announcement of Amos W.W. Woodcock, Prohibition Commissioner, that the government would move to close by injunction all speakeasies and liquor-selling resorts in Manhattan -- 3,844. according to his own estimate -- was received yesterday at the Federal Building with considerable surprise.

The nature and achievements of Soviet planned economy and the alleged futility of the proposals for planning under capitalism are discussed comprehensively in "Socialist Planned Economy in the Soviet Union," published by International Publishers.

Another chapter in the difficulties of the Hotel Pierre was closed yesterday when it was announced that the forty-one-story structure on the south corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street would be sold at auction on July 1. The sale will be held in the Vesey Street Salesroom and Joseph P. Day will be the auctioneer.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 10 -- Governor Roosevelt had no comment to make on the declaration of the Scripps-Howard newspapers for the nomination of former Governor Smith. At the same time it was believed that the action came as no surprise to the Governor and that his managers were of the opinion that it would help rather than hurt the Roosevelt chances at the Chicago convention.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- All members of the Cabinet, except Secretary Adams and Attorney General Mitchell, are either on the way or preparing to leave for Chicago. Walter Newton and Lawrence Richey, of the White House secretarial staff, also are to be in Chicago.

Held in restraint by the crafty pitching of Red Lucas to nothing more than a long fly, Melvin Ott nevertheless made this one shot suffice to win another game for the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the fly scoring Len Koenecke from third in the seventh inning and toppling the Reds, 4 to 3.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 10 -- Two college golfers, Tommy Taller of Princeton and John E. Parker of Yale, will meet in a 36-hole match at the Plainfield Country Club tomorrow to decide the metropolitan amateur championship.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Good progress was made in the committee of thirteen today with some hope of a tentative agreement tomorrow on the principle of giving Austria a long-term loan of 300,000,000 schillings (about $42,000,000 at yesterday's exchange rate) guaranteed by about eight governments.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10 -- Four women were elected to membership in the board of trustees of Rutgers University at the quarterly meeting of the board this afternoon. It is the first time in the history of Rutgers that women have been admitted to the governing body.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Department of Commerce reports show that imports from the United States into the port of Dairen totaled 513,000 yen for the first four months of 1932, as compared with 1,279,000 yen for the same period one year ago.

PARIS, June 10 -- The trend of prices was lower on the Bourse today. Rumors of Parliamentary discord over the new government's financial policies caused a selling movement, which began at the opening and continued throughout the session.

Hugo Castello, George Washington High School junior, successfully defended the city P.S.A.L. individual fencing championship by winning all of his five matches in the final round of the second annual title foils competition last night at the Washington Irving High School.

The prisoner Monsolino, who bids fair to rank with the Count of Monte Cristo and the prisoner of Chillon before the city authorities get through with him, bobbed up again yesterday in a continuation, of the dispute between Magistrate Jonah Goldstein and Correction Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr. over what work the prisoner shall do in prison.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- California's delegation to the Republican National Convention left for Chicago this evening certain of the renomination of President Hoover, confident of his re-election and with an open mind on the prohibition question.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 10 -- Lehigh alumni paid honor to Dr. Charles Russ Richards tonight at a dinner marking his tenth anniversary as president of the university and heard Dr. Neil Carothers, head of the College of Business Administration, declare that universities such as Lehigh represent, in these times, the most stable of institutions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10 -- George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, was elected today president of the National Electric Light Association at its convention here to succeed J.F. Owens, president of the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 10 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs, in convention here today, went on record in favor of a bone-dry plank in both the Republican and Democratic national platforms. Out of 600 delegates voting, only thirteen women opposed the motion to acquaint Simeon D. Fess and John J. Raskob, Republican and Democratic national chairmen, respectively, with the federation's traditional stand.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Uncertainties regarding the reparations question held down business on the Boerse today. Offers and orders were scarce and price movements were irregular in a narrow range. Mr. Coolidge's statement that war debts should be paid caused pessimism which was reflected by weakness in bonds.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 10 -- The United States virtually clinched the Wightman Cup tennis series on the first day of play today by winning all three matches in straight sets against the British team.

In an effort to lead the way to a peaceful settlement of the dispute in the building trades the Mason Builders Association, affiliated with the Building Trades Association, offered yesterday to pay the bricklayers $13.20 a day pending arbitration of the scale that would be in effect until Dec. 31, 1932.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 10 -- Dr. John Leshure, 62 years old, who died by his own hand today, had just opened his Summer home for the eleventh season in Greens Farms and was well known among the residents. His wife, Mrs. Charlotte Schoerner Leshure, heard him cry out in his room this morning and rushed to him.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Hoover, addressing the graduating class of Howard University this afternoon, told them that nothing the government had ever done in the way of meeting an obligation had reflected more credit upon it than the establishment of this Negro university in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A tariff plank upon which most Democrats can stand and which at the same time will offer an "out" to Senators Barkley and Walsh of Montana, if they are chosen as the chairmen of the party's national convention, is being evolved in Senate conferences.

The assertion of Mrs. Frederic M. Paist, president of the national board of the Y.W.C.A., that in her judgment the majority of the leaders of this organization "not only desire law observance and enforcement to include the Eighteenth Amendment but believe this possible of achievement," was disputed yesterday by Mrs. Mabel Jacques Eichel, member of the New York State executive committee of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

PARIS, June 10 -- Premier Edouard Herriot and his Finance Minister, Louis Germain-Martin, are already finding the road to national economy hard. Hardly had they hinted that there must be a 10 per cent cut in armaments appropriations and probably a similar amount in civil servants' pay than protests began to fall on them in torrents.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary Stimson praised the orderly conduct of the Presidential election in Panama in a message today to Senor Dr. Horacio F. Alfaro, the Minister of Panama.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. ASTOR, Kashmir, June 10 (by runner from camp above Doyan) -- As this expedition gets nearer to Nanga Parbat, the 26,630-foot peak we hope to conquer, setting a world record, our many problems of transport and route, difficult to solve at a distance because of the general lack of knowledge about this region, are apparently working themselves out very satisfactorily.

MADRID, June 10 -- Catalonia, the district comprising the four Northeastern provinces of Spain, was created tonight the first autonomous region in what eventually is intended to become a decentralized Spanish republic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of May 22, S.T. Williamson, in his article "In Foch's Shoes," makes reterence to an anecdotal conversation which supposedly occurred between Marshal Pilsudski and General Weygand, and, from the attitude taken at this conversation by Marshal Pilsudski, derives the judgment that the French General was the author of the strategic Plan which gave the victory to the Polish Army over the Bolsheviki in 1920.

SANDWICH, England, June 10 -- Smashing golf championship records with almost every swing of his clubs, Gene Sarazen won the coveted British open crown today, leading by five strokes another American, Macdonald Smith, who had 288.

Reductions in Federal, State and municipal expenditures, retrenchment in various branches of government, and the repeal of laws artificially raising the cost of public works or saddling mandatory expenditures on municipalities were demanded as necessary steps toward a revival of prosperity by business and professional leaders at a meeting held here yesterday under the auspices of the New York State Economic Council.

The last redout along the American front fell before the United States Davis Cup team at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, L.I., yesterday, marking the fifth successive year that this country has qualified to meet the winner of the European zone for the right of throwing down the gauntlet to France in the challenge round.

LONDON, June 10 -- The stock markets ended the week dull, prices falling to new low records, partly because of the weakness in Wall Street, but largely because of a paucity of business. British Government funds continued to droop on lack of support, although the war loan was steadier.

AS SOON as the final scores from Sandwich were in, a volunteer committee went to work on plans for the reception of Gene Sarazen when he lands in New York. Certainly, stocky Gene deserves a royal welcome. He rounded out his collection of golf titles and trophies by taking the British open and added a fine flourish by doing it with a record score. He won breezing.

HAVANA, June 10 -- An attempt to assassinate President Machado was frustrated this morning when a bomb was discovered planted at a street corner past which he was to pass a few minutes later and the police seized three alleged assassins.
After having reached on Thursday the lowest quotations in the history of the Cotton Exchange here, cotton prices readied yesterday and closed 10 to 12 points higher than on Thursday.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 10 -- The annual fair for the Babies' Milk Fund of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County was held at Green-tree, the country home of Mrs. Payne Whitney, at Manhasset this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, June 10 -- Receivership proceedings against Hambleton Co., stock brokers and bankers, and the Hambleton Corporation, an affiliated body, were begun today in Circuit Court by William E. Bauer and other stockholders, who alleged that the first-named concern was hopelessly insolvent.

Two young men, graduates of Jamaica High School, according to the police, were under arrest last night charged with the attempted blackmail of James A. Moffett of the Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue, director and vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, member of a socially prominent family.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- Ohio State's track and field men got the jump on the field in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships today by qualifying for seven places in tomorrow's finals.

William Howard Gardiner, president of the Navy League of the United States since 1928, was re-elected to that office yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at 230 West Forty-first Street.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 10 -- Discussions preparatory to the submission of a definite offer for the Richfield Oil Company have heen started, on behalf of the Standard Oil Company of California, it was reported here today. At authoritative sources in San Frnncisco, where Standard Oil has its headquarters, it was said that company must be reckoned as a positive factor in whatever bidding for Richfield developed.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- The Rev. Albert J.M. Wilson, rector of St. George's-by-the-River, Rumson, N.J., has been called to the rectorship of Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, by the wardens and the vestry. He has formally accepted and will enter upon his duties here the first part of October, filling the vacancy caused by the elevation of the Rev. Dr. Frederick G. Budlong, Bishop Coadjutor of Connecticut.

If Governor ROOSEVELT removes Mayor WALKER, what are the chances of his running; again this Fall, being re-elected, and serving out the balance of his term? Rather slim. Tammany Hall must first make up its mind whether it wants to back a roan whom the Governor has formally declared unfit.

EASTON, Pa., June 10 -- Lafayette College held its annual commencement exercises today in Colton Memorial Chapel, awarding 186 degrees in course, eleven graduate and three honorary degrees. The commencement address was given by Dr. Robert L. Kelley, executive secretary of the Association of American Colleges, who said that "the synthesis of the arts, the humanities and the sciences into a unified life is the ideal of liberal education today."

A further sharp decline in foreign currencies in terms of the dollar featured the foreign exchange markets yesterday. The French franc dropped 9-16 point to 3.93 13-16, or the lowest level since April 29, while the Swiss franc dropped 2 1/2 points to 19.53 1/2, the lowest level in a month.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Fairbanks II, a 9-year-old bay gelding owned by Mrs. G.L. Redmond and ridden by F. Thorndike, was the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap, the featured event on the card of the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association today on the West Hills race course.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S "A Farewell to Arms," which Paramount promises for the new season, is taking definite cinematic shape. Helen Hayes and Gary Cooper will recreate Hemingway's nurse and soldier for the screen.

JOHANNESBURG May 9 -- Each new monthly report issued by the Transvaal Chamber of Mines shows an increase in the value of South Africa's goid production. Thus figures for January, 1932, run into more millions than those for January, 1931, as is also true of figures for February and presumably also for March.

The scientific actuarial basis customary in commercial insurance is lacking in the British system of unemployment insurance, according to expert British testimony reported in the latest monograph of social insurance published by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
LONDON, June 11 -- Emily Sharpe said today that her sister, Violet Sharpe, killed herself because she was being hounded to the point of insanity by the New Jersey police.

A satisfactory rental record for the developments of the City and Suburban Homes Company, despite the present low level of business and realty activity was noted yesterday by Clarence Hoyt Holmes, president, in his annual report to stockholders.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, is making a collection of plaster statuettes modeled by the famous American sculptor John Rogers. The society has now acquired fifty-five of these Rogers groups and lacks only twenty-one to make a complete set.

A study of housing needs, particularly in the low-cost field, and discussions of means of relief for property owners from the tax burden will be features of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards opening in Cincinnati on June 29.

The figurative expression, "money to burn," became a tragic reality for Mrs. Anita Castaldi of 1,484 New Durham Avenue, North Bergen, N.J., yesterday when she mislaid some $3,250 in bills that she had been saving and discovered shortly afterward that the money had found its way into a pile of rubbish and had been dumped on a burning heap across the street.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Mrs. Mabel Walker Willebrandt, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of prohibition prosecutions, will probably oppose the prohibition resubmission plank which administration advisers intend to present to the convention to block a repeal declaration.

PARIS, May 26. NO record of the theatrical movement in Paris can afford to pass in silence the loss this week of both Albert Brasseur and Maurice de Feraudy. Although both of them were over 70, each represented, in his very different way, an epoch in the French theatre, and each was acting until within a few months of his death.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 11 -- Projectile, owned by Walter J. Salmon, captured the featured $5,000 added Thomas Curran Memorial race at Washington Park today with a fine burst of speed in the stretch run.
FRANKFORT, Ky., June 11 -- In the shadow of Kentucky's historic old Capitol Daniel Carter Beard received yesterday a medal emblematical of the highest ideals and achievements of the Boy Scouts.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 11 -- Samuel Knopf of 815 Park Avenue, New York City, treasurer of Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., book publishers, of which his son, Alfred A. Knopf, is president, died here at 7:15 this morning in his room at the Beach Point Club on Oriental Point of a heart attack that came upon him suddenly and unexpectedly as he was about to rise for the day.
YONKERS, N.Y., June 11. -- A garden fete was held this afternoon at Greystone, the estate of Samuel Untermyer here, for the benefit of unemployed architects and draftsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- President Hoover conferred with Cabinet officers today on preliminaries for the Chicago convention and kept in touch with developments at Chicago by telephone and by telegraph. Some callers at the White House said that he had received "cheering news" on major developments, including the progress of drafting the prohibition plank.

The outflow of gold from this country, which since last September has reduced the monetary gold stocks of the United States by more than 20 per cent, is expected to come to an end this week. In banking circles the prediction has been made that before the Fall the movement will have reversed itself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: YOUR recent article on "Music for Children" omitted a record of orchestral music in our Public schools as far back as the early '90s by Dr. Henry T. leck. With characteristic directness he started this fundamental musical activity by interesting John Jasper, City Superintendent of schools, as well as a number of the leading principals, prominent among them Dr. Edward W. Stitt.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11 -- The carrying of the daisy chain, traditional and colorful event that features the annual class day at Vassar College, was conducted today in a perfect Summer setting on the college campus.

WEYHE GALLERY -- Group show by young American artists. The work of these young painters who hail from practically every part of the United States augurs well for American art. Nina Barr Wheeler draws the lone pine trees and grazing ponies of her native West.
BERLIN, June 11 -- The overthrow of the Bruening government came sooner than expected. The upset was accelerated by psychologically clumsy, one-sided and hence unjust measures to throttle Hitlerism.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Ralph Metcalfe, 22-year-old Negro youth from Marquette University, in two amazing races today eclipsed three world's records and tied another as Indiana won the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championship with 56 points.

Many attacks have been made upon Mr. Rockefeller for coming out against prohibition, but, as usual, Bishop Cannon lead all the rest. To him the explanation is simple. Mr. Rockefeller has lived too long in "Satan's seat" -- that is to say. New York City -- and in too intimate contact with Governor Smith and Mayor Walker.

TOMORROW night the ten weeks' series of concerts by the Goldman Band under Edwin Franko Goldman opens in Central Park, the fifteenth season of free outdoor band concerts to be given by this organization.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., June 11 -- In an address here today at the sesquicentennial commencement of Washington College, Dr. Friedrich W. von Prittwitz und Gaffron, the German Ambassador, proposed a return to normal international relations as the first of four remedies for the present economic breakdown of the world.

WHEN the Eighteenth Amendment was passed I earnestly hoped -- with a host of advocates of temperance -- that it would be generally supported by public opinion and thus the day he hastened when the value to society of men with minds and bodies free from the undermining effects of alcohol would be generally realized.

CHATTANOOGA, June 9 -- Aroused by the discovery that purchases by the Department of Education for which bills have not been presented will cause the city government to fail in its record of always staying within its budget, Mayor Ed Bass is sponsoring an ordinance for the emloyment of a city purchasing agent through whom every purchase of more than $50 must be made.

To Professor SHAPLEY it is "a minor crustal phenomenon" and to JEANS "a mere accidental and possibly quite unimportant byproduct of natural processes wvhich have other and more stupendous ends in view."

MEDFORD, Mass., June 11 -- Harvard beat Tufts, 3 -- 2, in the Jumbos' annual commencement day baseball game today. The victors took a two-run lead in the opening inning and sent over the winning tally in the fifth.

PARIS, June 10 -- Important conversations are being held this weekend in Paris between the Prime Ministers of France and Britain. Next week there is going to be another reparations conference at Lausanne to which will go also Germany's new and untried Chancellor.

IN a world which has already been pretty thoroughly explored and charted, few things remain to us more remote and adventurous than the lives of our neighbors. Hence, a new type of novel has been appearing in some profusion -- a novel whose principal mission is informative and in which the romance, as such, is of secondary interest.

By now, roughly, a fifth of the students perhaps are directly concerned with such projects, while a much larger number, there is reason to believe, are well aware of the work being undertaken.

Hitherto no author has made an attempt to cover the field here traversed by Professor Soltau.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner or Immigration at Ellis Island, said yesterday, in reply to criticism of the bureau resulting from numerous delays in issuing return permits, that the issuing and application force on the island could easily handle all cases, even if the number increased above the present rush season.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Wirt Thompson of Yale University and Dan Dean, University of Pennsylvania star, hung up new district records in the annual Middle Atlantic States A.A.U. championship meet on Franklin Field today.

The passage of the excise taxes on drugs cosmetics and sporting goods during the week spurred leaders in the various-industries to call meetings for next week to consider in what manner the levies will be handled. It is generally expected that manufacturers will agree that the passing on of the tax to retailers will be absolutely necessary to maintain the industries on a sound basis.

SANTIAGO, June 11 (AP). -- A National Socialist Economic Council, with workers among its members, was called by the new Socialist Government today to assist in the formulation of its economic policies.

Cardinal Hayes has accepted an Invitation to be the house guest during the World Eucharistic Congress in Dublin, Ireland, June 22-26, of Frederick A. Sterling, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States to the Irish Free State.

GENEVA, June 10 -- The disarmament conference stands at another and by no means the last of its crossroads. Since April 22 all the commissions have been engaged in answering the question growing out of the general commission's decision to begin disarmament on a qualitative basis by abolishing or internationalizing the weapons that are most specifically offensive, most dangerous to national defense or most threatening to civilians.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- To just what extent his pocketbook will be hit by the new and higher tax rates which Congress has voted is a subject close to the heart of the American citizen, and particularly to the man of relatively small income, who in many instances has been forced to curtail expenses because of salary cuts.

CHICAGO'S tribulations over its school system, of which the attendant wailing and gnashing of teeth have been widely heard, have produced at least one positive result for the rest of the country: the city officials have had a group of experts examine the system's every wheel and joint and draw up a report proposing changes that would make it a model of smooth running and effectiveness.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- The first shipment of Soviet lumber destined for the United States this year left Archangel recently in the Norwegian steamer Fernmoor, bound to Poughkeepsie. Already this year many loads have left Archangel and have been delivered in the British Isles.
THE opportunity for service was never so great as it is now. The reason is that, in the last few years, the world has changed.

Speaking on the necessity for relief from existing real estate tax burdens before the recent taxpayers' convention in New Jersey, Harry A. Taylor, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, called attention to need of greater governmental economy, coordination of various municipal and county systems and general tax equalization.
LONDON, June 3 -- The Times of London says today:

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- President Hoover held an unexpected conference at the White House tonight with Republican members of the conference committee on the economy bills, and is understood to have told them that the budget was not balanced and must be balanced before Congress adjourned.

Except for a further pyrotechnical display in Auburn, there was little in yesterday's trading on the Stock Exchange to hold Wall Street's interest. Auburn at one time was up more than 9 points from the previous close, but it showed no net change when trading ended.

AMHERST, Mass., June 11 -- Collecting four runs in the fifth inning, tha Massachusetts State Varsity baseball team closed its season in ipressive style, today, defeating Amherst, 5 -- 1, before a large commencement crowd.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 11 -- The annual alumni day at Lehigh University brought over 1,200 old graduates to the campus, fewer than last year but not less enthusiastic in their class activities.

BALTIMORE, June 11 -- Johns Hopkins and the University of Maryland today advanced to the semifinals of the pre-Olympic play-off by winning their first-round contests before 6,000 spectators at the Baltimore Stadium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The facts were slightly askew in the story on the motion picture page in your issue of May 22 about Universal's production of George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart's "Once in a Lifetime" for the screen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11 --Colleges need "a faculty of great teachers, who combine with high academic standards that rare ability to bring life and inspiration into the classroom," Dr. Robert C. Clothier said today in his inaugural address as president of Rutgers University.

GENEVA, June 11 -- Barter has already replaced normal trade in certain products among fifteen European countries. Since last July agreements to exchange goods in kind have been concluded between Germany and Hungary, Austria and Rumania, Bulgaria and Greece, Bulgaria and Switzerland, France and Latvia, Norway and Russia, Poland and Austria, Hungary and Bulgaria and Estonia and Yugoslavia.

Former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley resigned yesterday as "czar" of the cleaning and dyeing industry because he objected to the methods used by the Metropolitan Cleaners and Dyers Association in soliciting members, and because he found that "broader activities" were expected of him than he had been led to expect.

Charley Perkins, Jersey City southpaw, held the Maple Leafs to three hits at West Side Park in Jersey City yesterday and Jersey City won, 2 to 1, to capture the deciding contest of the three-game series.

HARBIN, May 9 -- There is an unopened treasure chest in North Manchuria, awaiting only men to unlock it. This, in substance, was the finding of O.L. Cranfelt, mining engineer, on a prospecting expedition into the Great Khingan Mountains, that wild jumble of peaks which forms a natural barrier at Manchuria's northernmost frontier.

BERLIN, June 11 -- In his first speech as Chancellor, Franz von Papen declared today that the formation of his Cabinet had nothing in common with the customary changes In Parlyiamentary Cabinets, but represented a fundamentally new course in the conduct of German government.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A marked increase in the attendance of women at the Republican National Convention was hailed today as indicating a growing interest of women in political affairs by Mrs. Ellis A. Yost, director of the women's division of the Republican National Committee.
After an early improvement of 7 points yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange fell back sharply and closed with losses of 6 to 7 points on the day.

As an aid toward stabilizing real estate values at the present time, a plea is made by I.S. Chanin, head of the Chanin organization, that real estate mortgage holders consent voluntarily to a reduction in interest rates and a suspension of amortization payments during the continuance of the depression period.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prosperity exists when there is a proper balance between production of farms, mines and factories and consumption. When this is maintained, capital and labor are profitably employed and there is steady employment, for the honest and competent.

IN books so diverse as "The Land," "The Edwardians" and "All Passion Spent" Miss Sackville-West has shown in varied forms the same unchanging ability which raises her head and shoulders above the vast majority of her contemporaries. Although her output has not been large, one has learned to expect in her work only the very highest excellence combined with an astonishing versatility -- and one is never disappointed.

LONDON, June 11 -- Something new in tariff-making has been shown to the British public by the non-political committee headed by Sir George May which has been transforming this citadel of free trade into a protectionist stronghold.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 11 -- About 200 members of the Federated Garden Clubs of America arrived here this afternoon from Squantum, Mass. They were received by Miss Amy L. Varnum, chairman of the visiting gardens committee of the Newport Garden Association.

DELAY is as destructive as no action. I do not complain of this situation -- I only call attention to it as the answer to the criticism that somebody should do something promptly. There is no such "somebody."

RALEIGH, N.C., June 9 -- By securing a plurality of more than 10,000 votes over Senator Cameron Morrison in last Saturday's Democratic primary, Robert R. Reynolds has demonstrated beyond question that it no longer means political suicide for a candidate for high office in North Carolina to advocate repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

TEN years ago next Wednesday the World Court opened its first session for the transaction of legal business. The eleven judges and their registrar filed into the small courtroom in the Palace of Peace. The room itself was familiar enough.

Despite the difficulties besetting opera in Germany as elsewhere, new works continue to appear with commendable regularity in the provincial as well as the Berlin houses. Two were given first hearings last month. One was Ignatz Lillian's setting of Bernard Shaw's "Great Katherine," produced at the "Wiesbaden May festival.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11 -- Answering an emergency call received at the New Brungwick station of the Pennsylvania Railroad at about 2 A.M. today, a work train was speeded to the Highland Park side of the Raritan River Bridge, where Michael Haleluk, 17 years old, was found bound to a railroad tie on the main-line passenger track.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- The navies of Yale and Harvard finished their first week of training here today and tomorrow will spend the day cruising the Sound in yachts provided for them by graduates. The opening week, despite examinations, saw considerable accomplished, including the first-time rows of both crews.

Frank W. Demuth, president of the West Side Taxpayers' Association, calls attention to the change made at the last session of the New York Legislature in the law governing dispossess proceedings. This becomes effective on July 1.

KEARNY, N.J., June 11 -- A pageant of clipper-ship days preceded the launching this afternoon of the $5,000,000 Grace liner, Santa Paula, at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here. Thousands saw the big liner slide down the ways into the Hackensack River, where she was taken in tow by several tugs.

LONDON. THE Prince of Wales has been called Britain's best traveling salesman. In the course of a year he makes many speeches, urging better marketing methods; incidentally, he stimulates home trade by his own purchases.

IT would seem that the problem of camera lighting would be nonexistent in an area where the sun shines fervently all the day. But the theory proved just another rumor to the camera men who went to Siam with Frank Buck to take animal pictures for his ''Bring 'Em Back Alive."

TORONTO, Ont., June 11 -- Dome Mines, Ltd., reports for May a bullion output valued at $411,201, a net gain of $56,948 over April, when production was $354,254, and comparing with $300,380 in May, 1931. The value was a record for the new mill and was attributed directly to the finding of a pocket of rich ore which was estimated to have yielded $50,000.
